column2: United States Senator Royal S. Copeland made a plea last night for the election of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, as Joseph P. Ryan, president of the Centra' Trades and Labor Council, announced that he was switching his backing from Mayor La Guardia to Mr. Mahoney.
" Ghettos" for Jewish students in Warsaw colleges have been established by university authorities. Seats in lecture halls and laboratories have been numbered and Jews allotted to a special section.

Mrs. Sara Pelham Speaks, a Negro attorney, was adjudged yesterday the winner of a primary contest for the Republican nomination for the Assembly in the Twentyfirst District by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag following a recount of protested ballots.

A baby boy born to Mrs. Rosa Camerano of 335 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, shortly before daylight yesterday, died in Prospect Heights Hospital at 11 A. M. despite unusual measures taken to save its life.

W. F. Hall Printing Company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that the Chicago Rotoprint Company, a subsidiary, has engaged the president of the parent company, Alfred B. Geiger. to be general manager for three years at a salary of $30,000 a year plus 10 per cent of net profits in excess of $150,000 a year.

A new issue of 200,000 shares of Continental Can Company, Inc., $4.50 cumulative preferred stock will be placed on the market today by an underwriting group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and including twenty-eight other investment firms. The stock will be offered at $100 a share and accrued dividends.

The Fox Theatres Corporation lost $13,249 net in the first six months of this year and a total of $479,146 net from June 22, 1932, to June 30, 1937, the period of its equity receivership, according to a report filed by Milton C. Weisman, receiver, yesterday in Federal court.
Registration at the exhibits at the National Restaurant Association convention in its second day here today reached 7,000. Some 135 exhibits showed foods, recipes and machinery.
Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, lauded President Roosevelt for his presentation of the American stand on peace in a speech here today.

An 11-year-old boy was suffocated by smoke from a fire which broke out at 5:40 A. M. yesterday in the basement of a two-story frame house at 185 Twenty-eighth Street, South Brooklyn. Three other boys, who escaped from the house, were taken to the Norwegian Hospital suffering from smoke inhalation.
Film production plans of Vittorio Mussolini and Hal Roach encountered legal difficulty here today when Dr. Renato Senise of Italy filed suit declaring he originated the idea they are following.

The first report, after summarizing in 3,000 words the history of the present conflict, citing both Japanese and Chinese versions, says: "Since July 7, faced by growing resistance, Japan has not ceased to intensify her action, employing larger and larger forces and more and more powerful armaments.

President Roosevelt made a--personal request today "to every worker," to fill out the unemployment report cards on which will be based the first voluntary census of unemployment ever taken in this country. The cards will be distributed Nov. 16 and 17.

The Republican National Committee was called today by Chairman John D. M. Hamilton to meet in Chicago Nov. 5 to consider a proposal advanced by him and former President Hoover for a national conference in 1938 to draft a declaration of principles.

Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard White Star Line; Lewis W. Douglas, Captain H. Ledyard Towle, Mr. and Mrs. C. F. Crandell, Mr. and Mrs. James R. Angell and Lionel Barrymore are passengers leaving today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

New York State Shoe Retailers Association, concluding their convention today, went on record in favor of a higher tariff on Czechoslovakian shoes and also took a firm stand against proposed reciprocal trade relations with that nation. The resolution, adopted unanimously, said:

Equity Fund, Inc.-Six months to June 30: Net investment loss, $11,357 compared with $1,548 in same period of 1936; net income including $162,757 profit on sale of securities amounted to $151,400, compared with net income of $37,010 on $38,558 securities profit in first half of last year.

While Premier Mitchell Hepburn was addressing an Election Eve meeting this afternoon, ten tiers of back benches gave way under the stamping feet of Automobile Union hecklers and precipitated 300 of them to the floor below.

Several sales of small residential properties were reported yesterday in various sections of Brooklyn. Among the houses changing hands was the two-story four-family dwelling at 19 Bay Fourteenth Street, sold by Antonio Cantone for cash to a client of Samuel Hurwitz.

Mrs. A. Watson Armour 3d of Chicago, defeated Miss Barbara Neilds of Cleveland, 6-3, 6-1, today in the second round of the women's singles in the 25th annual Hot Springs Fall invitation tennis tournament. Mrs. Frederic McBride of Short Hills, N. J., former Wightman Cup player, halted Mrs. Arthur McPherson, 6-1, 6-0.

Several sales of residences in Larchmont, Westchester County, were reported yesterday by Cornelius Van Buren, broker. Among the properties involved was the brick house at 23 Nassau Road, which was purchased by Charles A. McCune from William M. Dowling.

Football's most startling development in this young season is the very general use of a five-man line on defense.... Its chief source of annoyance, it seems, is that the offensive assignments are thrown out of kilter because the defensive players never are polite enough to wait in the proper spots.

A spokesman for the Foreign Office devoted a lengthy press conference today to commenting on President Roosevelt's speech and THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial on the Far Eastern situation published Monday.

The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind will open its twenty-third annual pencil campaign to raise funds today with the presentation to Park Commissioner Robert Moses of the 35,000,000th pencil issued by the guild.

Mr. and Mrs. William Edwin Hall of Greenwich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Beardslee Hall, to Eric F. L. Archdeacon of Berlin, Germany. The announcement was made at a uncheon given here yesterday at Sherry's.

Marshal Pietro Badoglio, Chief of Staff of the Italian Army, left tonight, ending a six-day visit during which he spent most of his time conferring with military authorities or inspecting details of the military organization.

The Metropolitan Opera will present this season a cycle of three Richard Strauss operas--"Rosenkavalier," "Elektra" and "Salome"a revival of Verdi's "Otello" and, as a novelty, the one-act comic opera in English, "Amelia Goes to the Ball," by the 25-year-old ItalianAmerican composer, Gian-Carlo Menotti, graduate of the Curtis Institute of Music.

Police officials investigating the slaying of Lewis Weiss and Frances Hajek appealed yesterday to the public for help. Since the couple were founds dead in Weiss's automobile in a narrow lane in Hollis Woods in Queens last Sunday all leads have failed.

The jinx that has dodged the footsteps of Miss Maureen Orcutt in the women's national golf championship ever since she set out in quest of the crown got in its foul work again today as the sixty-four qualifiers began match play on the Memphis Country Club course.
Mayor La Guardia accused the State Transit Commission yesterday of failing to do its part in connection with the removal of Brooklyn's Fulton Street elevated structure.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, returned from Europe last night on the French liner Ile de France. She visited Italy and Austria and afterward stayed in Paris with her sister, Mrs. Dora Delano Forbes.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ross Browning will celebrate their golden wedding anniversary tomorrow at Overbrook, their Llewellyn Park home, at a reception for several hundred guests and a dinner for fifty.
The British navy's high-speed motor torpedo boats are having their first real test under war conditions in the anti-piracy patrol program in the Mediterranean.

More than one hundred and fifty members of the Sodality of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel at White Plains were guests of the college at a tea here today on the north campus. The tea followed a bicycle treasure hunt.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 14,000, including 4,000 directs. The market was 50-65 lower than Monday's average; top $11.50 sparingly; little above $11.30 now; bulk good and choice 190-230 pounds, $11-$11.30; few 240-280-pound butchers. $10.85-$11.25;

Gross assets, $615,312; net, $447,249 To Mount Sinai Hospital, $50,000 Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases, $25,000; Edith Abrahamson, daughter, personal effects, $10,000 and life estate in residue with power of appointment. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $298,505. Louis Brodio, attorney, 551 5th Ave.

Contending Teams and ManagersYankees, champions of American League; Joseph V. McCarthy, manager. Giants, champions of National League; William H. Terry, manager. How Series Is Decided-Four out of seven games.

The Council of the League of Nations closed its ninety-ninth session near midnight by extending to Spanish merchantmen some of the moral but none of the material protection of the Nyon anti-piracy arrangements.

A second mortgage for $5,000, payable $277.78 monthly at 6 per cent, was given by the 106 Macdougal Street Corp.. George J. DeMartini, president, to L. T. Realty, Inc, and the Nel Holding Co, Inc, on 106 Macdougal St, subject to a first for $9,000. The Franklin Savings Bank extended to Sept. 20, 1940, at 5 per cent, a mortgage for $10.500 on 447 W 51st St, held from John Robert Stroh.

Consummer cooperatives are definitely on the way, F. Raymond Johnson, president of Bonwit Teller, Philadelphia, and vice president of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce, told the Atlantic City Soroptimist Club today.

Not to be overshadowed even by a world series, the Dodgers, who tumbled home in sixth place in the National League pennant race just ended, nevertheless gained the distinction yesterday of engineering the first deal of baseball's onrushing Fall and Winter trading season.
The same betting odds continued to prevail yesterday in Jack Doyle's world series book, with very little wagering being done. "The betting is still light," said Doyle, "and may remain so.

A jury composed of seven women and five men yesterday exonerated Mrs. Gladys Kimball, former WPA actress, of marital misconduct charges brought by her husband, Joseph C. Kimball. Yonkers real estate broker.

Miss Norma Gretchen Karsten, daughter of Mrs. August F. Karsten of 204 West Eighty-second Street and the late Mr. Karsten, was married last night to Earle Trounson MacHardy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer MacHardy of Seymour, Conn., in the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Ninety-third Street and Broadway. The Rev.

The flight is on! Four magio words those, for they bring an immediate response from the pulses of thousands of sportsmen who feel that the shooting season is not really open until they can hunt woodcock.

H. A. Riebe of Kensal, N. D., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Anne Marie Riebe to Seth Haskell Low, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Cutler Low of Quincy, Mass. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents

Members of the Chicago Board of Trade and all registered futures commission merchants today were requested by L. A. Fitz, Chicago administrator for the Commodity Exchange Administration, to submit to his office copies of all "market letters, reports, news flashes, trade gossip or other market news" sent out yesterday.

The Marine Draftsmen's Union, Federal Local 2, of the International Federation of Technicians, Engineers, Architects and Draftsmen's Unions, has transferred from the American Federation of Labor to the C. I. O., it was announced yesterday.

Despite assurances from both the Yankee and Giant officials that plenty of reserved seats are available, speculators in the Times Square district last night were offering large blocks of tickets at $12 for a single opening game pasteboard originally purchased for $5.50.

The Capital season's first production of the Theatre Guild and the American Theatre Society, a dramatization of Flaubert's novel, "Madame Bovary," was presented at the National Theatre here tonight to a capacity audience of unusual distinction.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey will open bids soon on an $800,000 contract for the installation of a steam power plant at Burlington, it was announced yesterday. The business is about the largest now before the combustion trade and Babcock Wilcox Company and the Foster Wheeler - Corporation are among the leading bidders.
As attack on the bill introduced by Senator William G. McAdoo to allow national banks to open branches anywhere within their

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Jimmy Dykes, whose White Sox will open a series with the Cubs for the city title at Comiskey Park tomorrow, will take an active part in the proceedings if needed-but he's hoping he'll be able to do his "masterminding" from the dugout.
The New York Telephone Company was ordered by the Public Service Commission yesterday to discontinue the 10-cent monthly charge on hand-set telephones beginning Jan. 1.

At its meeting last night the Board of Higher Education adopted a report recommending the appointment of one staff physician for each 1,000 students in the four city colleges. The report, presented by a sub-committee, called for the naming of chief physicians at City, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges.

The candidacy of Dr. Charles N. Gelber, president of the Physicians and Allied Professions Nonpartisan League, who is a andidate for Councilman from Manhattan on the Fusion and Progressive parties' tickets, has been endorsed by four medical bodies, it was announced yesterday at a lunch n of the league in the Murray Hill Hotel.

Stanley Quinn Associates. Inc. George C. Smyth and Clarence C. Meleney. additional apace, Emile F. Antonette and Frayser Childrey, additional space, in Graybar Building, 420 Lexington Ave; Eastern Offices, Inc, agent. Knitted Sportswear Co., floor, in 113-15 University Pl: Shepmils Trousers, Inc.

Unrelieved by rallies of any consequence, the stock market traveled yesterday from a lower opening to a weak finish. Leading stocks were down 2 to 8 points on the day, and a few issues lost as much as 9 to 15 points.
Spanish Government troops fought forward tonight in a claw-like formation that threatened to trap several hundred Insurgents entrenched in an advance salient south of Madrid.

A feminine touch bobbed up yesterday in General Sessions when fifteen women talesmen sent three questions in a note to Judge John J. Freschi in his part of the court, which the judge promptly answered from the bench amid guffaws from the men on the panel with them.

About 200 commuters were delayed one-half hour last night when the electric ferryboat Westchester of the Electric Ferries, Inc., which plies between Bayonne, N. J., and Port Richmond, S. I., developed engine trouble in the Kill Van Kull and finally grounded. 25 feet offshore on the New Jersey side, about 600 feet west of the slip.

Almost two years of court action came to an end yesterday when counsel for Torr Co. and others consented to an injunction restraining them from alleged violations of the Securities Act and the Securities Exchange Act.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that it had a net gain of 9,740 telephones in service during September,

Another of Hollywood's second generation will frequent sound stages that both her father and mother knew when Leatrice Joy Gilbert, daughter of John Gilbert and Leatrice Joy, reports on the MetroGoldwyn-Mayer lot soon to appear in "Benefits Forgot."

Mayor Frank Hayes, Democrat. who is also Connecticut's Lieutenant Governor, was re-elected today by a plurality of fifty-five votes over State Senator George T. Culhane, candidate on the Republican and Independent tickets.

Mrs. Helen Hotchkiss Greeff of New York, widow of Gerhard E. Hugh Greeff, New York attorney, was married to Herbert Neal of Westport, Conn., at noon today in the Greenwich Town Hall after the five-day clause in the marriage law had been waived by Probate Judge Harold L. Knapp. Justice of the Peace George H. Duff performed the ceremony.

Estate, less than $10.000. To Dr. George Calder Dunlevy, brother, executor, 319 South East 2d St., Evansville, Ind., household, personal effects and residue. Suzette Dunlevy, niece, same address, executrix.

A suit against Columbia University for the readmission of Robert Burke, dismissed student, has been discontinued because "other matters are more important and the university was through with him anyhow," Arthur Garfield Hays, his attorney, announced yesterday.
Chancellor Hitler's address opening the annual National Socialist -charities campaign today was largely a sermon on the duty of self-sacrifice.

The Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania announced today that rehearsals would be started later this week for its golden jubilee production, a burlesque which has been named "Fiftyfifty."
Michael J. Quinn, who had been on the police force for thirty-two years when he retired on Oct. 24, 1924, died yesterday at his home at 24 Audubon Avenue. He was 71 years old.

Counsel for five concrete pipe companies received permission at a Trace Commission hearing today to file a motion asking dismissal of charges they engaged in practices tending to create monopoly and restrain trade.

195th St, 2,851 E, 50x100; Home Owners Loan Corp. against A. Julius Carlson; due, $10.808: taxes, etc., $1,018; to plaintiff for $3,550. By EDWIN J. McDONALD Astor Ave. s s, whole front between White Plains Rd and Olinville Ave. 200x106.8. irregular; also White Plains Rd, w s,

The appointment of Lewis Douglas as head of McGill University is entirely explicable to those who know the background of his life, the charm of his personality and the practical idealism of his public interests.

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, wrote yesterday to Police Commissioner Valentine and to Dr. Harold -G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, against the holding of an American Labor party rally last night in Public School 65, Cypress Avenue and 141st Street, the Bronx, where six places of registration are situated.

The United States Freight Company reported yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission that the Linden Securities Corporation, a holding company staffed by employes of the Guaranty Trust Company, held 54 per cent of its capital stock.

Mrs. King Smith entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's for Miss Edith May Hartshorn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. Morgan Hartshorn of 830 Park Avenue, whose marriage to Ailing Woodruff, son of Mrs. Heman J. Pettengill of Waban, Mass., and the late Alling Woodruff, will take place on Saturday in the Central Presbyterian Church.

An exhibition of WPA Federal Art Project work, selected from the creative art and service divisions as examples of particular interest to the medical world, will be on view in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania during the American Public Health Association convention, which opened yesterday and will continue through Friday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be the guest of honor and principal speaker at a luncheon and musical of the Women's League for Palestine, to beheld in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor on Oct. 18 at 12:30 P. M., it was announced yesterday.
Major league baseball attendance for the season just closed showed a 10 per cent increase over last year's figures and was within striking distance of all-time records.

The sale of beer served with meals in a restaurant is not subject to New York City's 2 per cent sales tax, the Court of Appeals ruled today in upholding a similar ruling of the Appellate Division. The lower court annulled a determination of City Controller Taylor, who had levied the tax on beer sold with meals in the Luchow Restaurant.

Fast Express, claimed by Mrs. K. N. Gilpin, Virginia sportswoman, out of his previous race, made good at the first asking for his new owner in the fourth event on today's program. Fast Express defeated the Millsdale Stable's Early Times by two and a half lengths with Rough Party third.

Robert M. McBride, publisher, will arrive in New York tomorrow after a six weeks' trip to Poland, France, Denmark and England. Booth Tarkington's new novel, dealing with Rumbin, an art dealer, will be published by Doubleday, Doran on Oct, 29. The title is "Rumbin Galleries."

The Labor party today rejected more emphatically than ever before the idea of forming a united front with Communists. A link with communism was disapproved at the party's annual conference at Bournemouth by the overwhelming card vote of 2,116,000 to 331,000.

In his report before the annual meeting of the National Association of Insurance Agents today, Albert Dodge of Buffalo, chairman of the publicity and education committee, advocated the immediate launching of a nationwide newspaper advertising campaign.

A continued rise in the city's death sate was reported for the week ended last Saturday by Health Commissioner John L. Rice yesterday. After two months of exceptionally low rates, the general death rate rose from 7.8 to 9 for each 1,000 of population in the week ended Sept. 25, and last week it rose to 9.5.

World commerce generally would be greatly benefited by an Anglo-American trade agreement, the Foreign Commerce Committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States said in a statement issued today by James A. Farrell, chairman.

All records for trading volume and deliveries in cocoa on the New York Cocoa Exchange were eclipsed in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, Carlos A. Sholtz, president, said yesterday in his annual report to members of the Exchange.

Offering will be made today by Hartley Rogers Co., Inc., of 40,000 shares of capital stock of the Lane-Wells Company at $15 a share. This is the first public financing for the company, which was organized this year by consolidation of six oil-well equipment and service companies.
The annual Fall conference of the Westchester County Realty Board will be held at the Orienta Beach Club, Mamaroneck, beginning at 2 P. M. today and continuing tomorrow.

One of the tests of the Public Works Administration's constitutional authority to finance publicly owned hldroelectric plants in competition with private enterprise was abandoned when the Supreme Court, on agreement of counsel, today dismissed the suit affecting Iowa City.

Joseph Lewis of New York City won one phase of his fight to bar the reading of the Bible in public schools when the Court of Appeals today denied the motion of the Board of Education to dismiss the appeal, but gave leave to renew it upon the argument.

Nearly 700 students have enrolled in graduate courses for this semester in the Hunter College Evening and Extension Division, it was announced' 'yesterday by Broderick Cohen, the director. ' Although classes began two weeks ago, registration is still being accepted on payment of a nominal late fee in the Lexington Avenue building of the college at Sixty-eighth Street.

In the great court of Les Invalides, within whose walls Napoleon, Marshal Ferdinand Foch and most of the great soldiers of France are buried amid trophies of past wars and souvenirs that go back to the days of Louis XIV, 2,500 members of the American Legion with 500 French comrades, sat down to luncheon today as the guests of Marshal Philippe Petain and Albert Riviere, French Minister of Pensions.

Drug wholesalers have maintained their position despite a tendency on the part of the industry toward controlled distribution and direct selling,, John Albright of the wholesale division of the Bureau of the Census declared at the convention here today of the National Wholesale Druggists Association.

The colors of Mrs. Emil Denemark were prominent at Jamaica yesterday when her 4-year-old colt, Shot Up, got up in a hard drive through the stretch to win the featured Kew Gardens Handicap at 10 to 1, followed by an easy victory for her 3-year-old filly, Dressy, in a six-furlong-test.

The modern English basement residence at 169 East Seventy-ninth Street has been sold by Mrs. Anna Merwin, now a resident of California, through Culver, Hollyday Co. The name of the new owner was not revealed.

A group composed of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago; White-Phillips Corporation, Davenport, and the Iowa-Des Moines National Bank and Trust Company has bought a new issue of $250,000 of primary road bonds of Sac County, Iowa, on a bid of 101.32 for 2 3/4s. The bonds are to be dated Oct. 1, 1937, and mature serially from May 1, 1938 to 1950.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Holmes Edwards of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Esther Edwards, to Dr. Paul Harper, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Harper of Watertown, Conn.

Mayor Robert McIntosh of Bellport, who was nominated by the Democrats last week for Supervisor of Brookhaven Town, filed today a petition as an independent candidate for the same position on the "Anti-Dictator"

Senator James J. Davis said tonight that "there can be no business or labor stability" while the issue of court reorganization remains unsettled. In an address before the York Civic Clubs the Senator asserted: "The court-packing proposal is not yet settled.

J. Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, facing today a cool and partly hostile audience of labor leaders, categorically denied that the board had discriminated against the American Federation of Labor and in favor of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, baseball's high commissioner, yesterday issued a warning to all world series players that any contemplated barnstorming activities must be completed within ten days after the series ends.

Major L. A. Jenny, who during the World War assisted General W. W. Atterbury in laying out the transportation system for the A. E. F. in France, explained at a Rapid Transit conference today his transit plan for North Jersey.

Mayor-La Guardia gained control of the Board of Higher Education yesterday when he swore in three new members for nine-year terms, without salary. They are Ordway Tead, Ernest MacDonald and Dr. Carmyn Lombardo.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 4 unless specified: Shanghai to Manila: Bittern, Heron, Pecos. At Newport: Craven, Oct. 5; Cassin. At Pearl Harbor Yard: Humphreys, King, Lawrence, Sands. San Francisco Bay to San Pedro: Nitrg, Sirium.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a small increase over the preceding week but were practically the same as in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
I am glad to come once again to Chicago and especially to have the opportunity of taking part in the dedication of this important project of civic betterment.

Thomas D. Thacher, former Federal Judge and Solicitor General, appeared yesterday before the United States Circuit Court as attorney for the Electric Bond and Share Company in its appeal from the decision of Judge Julian W. Mack, who had held that two sections of the Public Utility Act of 1935 were constitutional and refused to rule on other sections.

The closing session of the first LatinAmerican congress of university students was held this afternoon, with delegates from ten republics making stirring speeches stressing the continental importance of the meeting.

The threatened strike of 15,000 undergarment workers, members of Local 62 of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, was averted yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at a conference called by him at City Hall, attended by representativeg of the union and three employer associations.
Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edward Hicks of Princeton, N. J., entertained 200 at a cocktail party in the Greenbrier today.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt visited the Mother's Milk Bureau of the Children's Welfare Federation at 435 Ninth Avenue yesterday morning and inspected the bureau's processes in its fight to prevent the deaths of hundreds of premature and sick babies for want of mother's milk.

The Artef Players got off "with the right foot first" at their new quarters on Sixty-third Street, the former Daly's Theatre, where they presented last night "The Outlaw," written by a Soviet poet, M. Kulback and revised by Chaver Paver.

President Roosevelt spoke to an American audience yesterday, but what he said will be read and weighed and studied by an international audience, and searched to the last dreg for its possible implications.

With not more than twenty-five candidates expected to be elected to the City Council under the new city charter, 211 aspirants for these offices had filed nominating petitions with the Board of Elections up to 10 o'clock last night.

Three of Pennsylvania's leading secondstring backs were shifted today in an effort to better balance the team for its game at Yale Saturday. Harry Buxbaum of Lawrence, L I., 195-pound blocking back, was moved to fullback as first substitute to Jim Connell;

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, was a pawn ahead when the first game of his match with Dr. Alexander Alekhine of-Paris, titleholder from 1927 to 1935, was adjourned after forty-one moves had been recorded tonight.
Captain Peter Lagaay, master of the Holland-America liner Volendam, turned over to representatives of the line yesterday a large moth caught on board in mid-Atlantic.

Coach Ducky Pond drove the Yale varsity eleven and reserves through another severe scrimmage today, the regulars opening on the defense. For the final half hour they tested new plays for use against Pennsylvania.

A man about 35 years old, in whose pocket was a pay envelope bearing the name de Lillio, was shot and killed early today in front of 501 West Forty-eighth Street. Detectives declared that they believed the shooting to be an outgrowth of a quarrel over the "loaders racket" on the West Side waterfront.

The possibility of a Federal investigation of the meat industry in the city, particularly that section involving the kosher trade, was foreseen yesterday afternoon when Mayor La Guardia announced that Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace and other Department of Agriculture officials would attend a conference at City Hall Friday morning.

An unofficial and probably incomplete list of candidates for whom independent nominations have been filed with the Board of Elections follows (abbreviation are A. C. for Anti-Communist party, T. U. for Trades Union party, C. F., City Fusion party, and P., Progressive party):

Army coaches devoted half of today's practice to pointing out errors that had shown up in the moving pictures of last Saturday's game. After the dummy scrimmage play speeded up and three teams were put through a scrimmage against the B squad, trying out plays designed for the Columbia game on Saturday.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Whelan of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Frances Whelan, to William F. Watters, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Watters of Belleville.

Sixteen minor-league players were drafted by the major leagues last night as they met with Commissioner Landis in their annual draft session at the Hotel Commodore. The Bees drafted the most, three players. They were all infielders. Bob Kahle from Indianapolis, Joe Walsh from Little Rock and Earl Maggert from Houston.

The atmosphere at the Supreme Court Building was as different today from that of yesterday as is daylight from dawn. Yesterday was all excitement when Justice Black took his seat for the first time in the face of two legal challenges.

Miss Laddie Irwin, 18-year-old Glen Ridge star who reached the semifinals of the recent New Jersey championship, annexed low gross honors in the next to last one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today at the Essex Fells Country Club.

Adhering strictly to the newest trends in transportation, many of the contingent of 150 cowboys and cowgirls competing in the twelfth annual world championship rodeo, which begins in Madison Square Garden tonight, arrived in automobiles yesterday, towing their mounts in specially constructed trailers.

The suggestion that food chains, voluntaries and cooperatives establish graded schedules for point-ofpurchase advertising was advanced yesterday by Gordon C. Corbaley, president of the American Institute of Food Distribution, in discussing legal methods- for proceedings under the Robinson-Patman law.

The ten-story apartment house on a plot 110 by 100.5 feet at 53-55 East Sixty-sixth Street was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. S. Harby Plough, trustee, as plaintiff, bought in the property for $5,000.
City Chamberlain A. A. Berle, according to announcement made yesterday, has accepted the chairmanship of the Non-Partisan Committee for the election of Robert K. Straus to the new City Council.

Television is to be used for the first time tomorrow at 7 P. M. as a means of showing the activities of the State Department of Health to those attending the convention of the American Public Health Association in New York City.

Listing of 21,750 additional shares of Eaton Manufacturing Company common stock has been authorized by the New York Stock Exchange committee on stock list. The shares, to be issued in connection with absorption of the Eaton-Erb Foundry Company, will bring the total outstanding to 717,896.

Harold W. Hastings, Democratic candidate for District Attorney, in the first formal speech of his campaign, told members of the Greater New York Taxpayers Association last night that property owners, taxpayers and tenants in New York County "have been saved millions of dollars" by the investigation into fake accidents which he, as First Assistant District Attorney, and his associate, Assistant District Attorney Bernard Botein, conducted.

The 200-acre farm estate of Jacob Souberman in the Milltown section of Brewster, N. Y., has been sold to William R. Kirkland of New York, who will occupy the place. The Souberman property is one of the best known dairy farms in the Brewster section.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the adoption of a new rule granting certain exemptions under the Holding Company Act to companies subject to the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission. Also announced were amendments to three other rules.

Rumors persist that Premier Mussolini has been forced to postpone the meeting of the Fascist Grand Council scheduled for Thursday on account of a slight touch of grippe. He is now at Rocca delle Caminate, to which he flew Saturday.

Langdon Lea, former Princeton athlete who was named an All-America football tackle for three years, captained the team one year and later coached the Princeton eleven, died last night at his home in Paoli. He was 63 years old.

The registration of voters qualifying for the November elections continued to lag yesterday, as 309,872 more persons brought the total for the two-day period up to 609,700, which compared with 647,094 in 1933 when the last Mayoralty contest was fought.
WHEN LABOR ORGANIZES, by Robert R. R. Brooks (Yale, $3). A study of modern labor in the United States. THE AMERICAN CIVIL WAR, by Carl Rusell Fish (Longmans, Green, $3.50). An analysis.
The famous art collection of Jules S. Bache, which he presented to the State of New York last Spring, probably will be opened to the public about Nov. 1, it was learned yesterday.
The possibility of a citizens' committee calling upon Governor Lehman to undertake "a sweeping reorganization of the State Boxing Commission" loomed, following a meeting of that body yesterday.

Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Brooklyn radio campaign rally of American Labor party. Speakers: Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll, Louis Waldman of the party's executive committee, candidate for Supreme Court Justice, Second District;

The Theatre Guild comes along this evening to make the season official: it will begin its twentieth subscription year with Ben Hecht's "To Quito and Back." Sylvia Sidney and Leslie Banks are in the cast, so, too, are Joseph Buloff, Evelyn Varden, Walter N. Greaza, Francis Compton. Lena Peters, Horace Sinclair, Natalie Danesi and others.

Nobody at the State Department today professed to know what the President meant in his Chicago speech by suggesting an isolation of the world's treaty-breakers by "quarantine," or by his offer to join "positive efforts to preserve peace."

An eighty-four family apartment house is projected for the northwest corner of East Eighteenth Street and Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, involving the expenditure of $250,000, according to plans filed yesterday.

Mrs. Mary S. Holladay, known as the first woman president of a railroad, died here yesterday of pneumonia at the age of 70. She became president of the Williamsville, Greenville St. Louis Railroad after the death of her husband, Hiram Newton Holladay, who had headed the road.

The Whitney Museum of American Art will open on Oct. 13 an exhibition of contemporary American ceramics, consisting of 142 examples of the work of artists, assembled by the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts for exhibition in the Scandinavian countries and England during the last Summer under the auspices of the American Society of Ceramic Art.

Although refusing to incorporate it as a plank in the party's platform, as proposed by George C. Warren Jr. .of Summit, the Republican State Convention adopted today, by a divided voice vote, a resolution censuring President Roosevelt for his Supreme Court reorganization plan and his appointment of Associate Justice Black.

Business agents and organizers of forty locals of the Teamsters and Chauffeurs Union met here today to discuss plans for "highway picketing" to halt non-union drivers and proposed boycotts on plants operating under C. I. 0. contracts.

Ed Selway shut out Little Rock for his second time while pitching Fort Worth's Texas Leaguers to the Dixie series championship in a.9-0 victory tonight. Selway, never in serious trouble, limited the Southern Association champions to seven hits.

Each of the following named reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Capt. Guy H. Madara, Ch.-Res., April 7. Capt. David S. Eisenberg, Med.-Res., April 20.

Grain markets went into nose dive today following the action of securities and other commodities. General liquidation by holders of futures, headed by houses with Eastern connections, was in evidence in both wheat and corn on the Board of Trade here.

The health of 35,000 persons and the fire protection of several hundred homes and stores depend on the completion by the Westchester Joint Waterworks 1 of a new water system, including a ninety-foot water tower in Purchase, witnesses testified today before Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme when trial was resumed of a suit to enjoin construction of the tower.
Eight thousand persons meeting in Albert Hall tonight under the chairmanship of the Archbishop of Canterbury protested against the deaths of civilians in the Sino-Japanese conflict.
President Roosevelt today pledged his Administration to a "concerted effort" with other peace-loving nations to "quarantine" aggressor nations.

At least ninety-three companies have formal plans under which extra compensation is given workers whose services are no longer required, the National Industrial Conference Board found in a survey the results of which were released yesterday.

Responding alike to the renewed fall of the French franc and to reports from Wall Street, the stock market here did badly today in all quarters except gilt-edge issues, which rose with a continued investment demand.

General Public Utilities, Inc., of Newark, a registered holding company, has filed a declaration with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the issuance of 26,909.6 shares of no-par common stock.

Insertions twice a week in key newspapers throughout the country and copy in weekly magazines will be used by Gillette Safety Razor Company to promote a series of six weekly contests for consumers who predict seven winning college football teams and write the best fiftyword letters explaining their reasons for any single selection.
What a magnificent speech that would have been of Justice Black's if the time and place had been a little more happily chosen.

Miss Emily M. Opper, who for thirty-five years was associated with the Hebrew Technical School for Girls before her retirement several years ago, died in her home at 314 West Eighty-third Street on Monday at the age of 78.

Henry Melville Parker of 156 Dwight Place died at his home today of heart disease after a brief illness. He was born in West Newton, Mass., sixty years ago. Mr. Parker was managing director of A. D. Juilliard Co., textile merchants, of 40 West Fortieth Street, New York, with whom he had been associated since 1902.
Carnegie Institute of Technology asked an apology today for the painting of the score of New York University's gridiron victory over Tech on the front of the $6,000,000 Mellon Institute Building.

Mrs. Elizabeth Coombs Strode, wife of Dr. George K. Strode, chairman of the Paris office of the Rockefeller Foundation, died yesterday morning in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness.

Oscar (of the Waldorf) Tschirky and Mrs. Tschirky will receive an illuminated parchment scroll, signed by President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and hundreds of the country's leading men and women, at a dinner in celebration of their golden wedding anniversary in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night, it was announced yesterday.

The romance that was baseball and the glamour of its world series were banished yesterday morning from the life of Anthony Albano when, after a four-day vigil outside the bleacher entrance to the Yankee Stadium, he and his belongings were "farmed out" by an unsympathetic policeman.
Opposing groups of stockholders of Continental Shares, Inc., appeared today at a hearing in the receivership case before Judge Dickerson.

Stocks fell 2 to 8 points and closed nervous; turnover, 1,680,720 shares. United States Government bonds steady; corporate issues lower, with Germarr, Italian and Japanese loans; transactions $9,074,800.
The seven four-family houses on Avenue Y, between East Twentythird and Twenty-fourth Streets, Brooklyn, were purchased by investing clients of Alexander L. Carlin, attorney.

William E. Borah, Republican dean of the United States Senate, said today "every American will support the President" in his peace policy enunciated at Chicago today. Mr. Borah read the text of the address and prepared this statement:

Despite the ending of the socalled apartment renting season on Sept. 30, brokerage offices and rental agents are receiving a steady stream of inquiries, though in somewhat reduced numbers. for suites in the city.

James Alexander Stevenson, the sculptor, died here today at the age of 56. Signing his work "Myrander" to distinguish himself from another sculptor of similar name with which he often was confused, he had exhibited regularly at principal art exhibitions in Eurone since 1906.

Handicapped by the loss of George Savarese, ball-carrying ace of his New York University squad, Coach Mal Stevens has been forced to make important changes in the backfield for the North Carolina game on Saturday.

Five men charged with soliciting funds for a fraudulent charity were held in $5,000 ball each yesterday for further hearings by Magistrate Aurelio in Felony Court. They were Walter Rogers, 35 years old, who said he was publisher of The New York State Police Magazine, which the police say is not an official publocation; Henry Freeman, 36;

Tommy Farr, the Welsh heavyweight who gained fistic fame by going the limit with champion Joe Louis recently, has signed a contract in which Mike Jacobs will have first call on his services for the next five years, it was announced yesterday by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

Steel ingot production declined last week when a seasonal rise was called for and the adjusted index has dropped to 106.8 from 111.3 in the previous week. For the week ended Oct. 3, 1936, the number was 108.7, thus marking the first time this year that the index has fallen under the comparable 1936 figure.

Judge John A. McKenna of Rockland County signed today an order directing State, county and local police to show cause why they should not be restrained from interfering with the operation of the Orangeburg dog racing track.

In a surprise move, Federal counsel in the oil conspiracy and price-fixing case, at the resumption of proceedings here today, demanded that the defense submit proof of governmental approval before they be permitted to make any statement before the jury that the alleged conspiracy to raise and fix gasoline prices was an outgrowth of the invalidated National Industrial Recovery Act.
Two women who were among the eleven who served Monday on a jury in City Court with Harry Meistrich differed sharply yesterday as to the righteousness of his subsequent criticism of their behavior.

Only United States Government obligations and some of the higher grade corporate loans showed any resistance to selling pressure yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The vulnerability of the secondary corporate issues was again clearly demonstrated as most of them relinquished a large part of the recovery from the low levels made in the last week or so.

The Empire Trust Company in its statement of condition as of Sept. 30 reports total assets of $76,612,235 and total deposits of $68,068,053, compared, respectively, with $77,369,853 and $68,852,853 on June 30.

When Greater New York's voters go to the polls next month they will have two jobs to do: first, they must pull the levers of a voting machine in the usual way to elect a Mayor and other city officials; second, they must indicate on a paper ballot, by checking or writing in, their preference for Councilmen from their boroughs.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, with jurisdiction in the city transportation industry, opened its first national convention at the union's headquarters, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street, yesterday, with 400 delegates representing a membership of about 80,000.

Sales of apartment properties in Washington Heights and on the lower East Side and a garage building on the upper East Side, and leasing of a well-known Sutton Place residence were among the Manhattan realty transactions listed yesterday.

Japan's quotas on 300 categories of imports, which will become effective on Sunday, represent a continuation of the six-year-old process of financing war preparations out of the national standard of living.

The two five-story business buildings on a plot 36.8 by 102.2 feet at 57 and 59 East Fifty-ninth Street have been leased for a long term by the Nielmo Realty Corporation, owner of the adjoining Hotel Delmonico.
A warning against adoption by Congress of "sickness taxation misnamed health insurance" was voiced today as the Medical Society of Pennsylvania began its annual convention in this city.

A prediction of a "good business boom before we finally start down in the next fundamental decline" came today from Ralph B. Wilson, vice president of Babson's Reports at the national business conference here.

The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that the daily average production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,647,450 barrels, a decrease of 18,850 barrels from the preceding week. Reductions of 19,250 barrels in Oklahoma production, 8,500 in Kansas and 3,650 in West Texas accounted largely for the decline in output, offsetting increases in other fields.

For a team that had taken the thumping Amherst received from Dartmouth last Saturday, the Lord Jeffs were a poor imitation of a dispirited, disorganized squad this afternoon as they worked out on Pratt Field.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in the Massachusetts General Hospital of Alexander Blair Thaw, second son of the late William Thaw of Pittsburgh by his first wife. Harry K. Thaw is a half-brother.

The need for "material improvement" in the annual reports of many corporations to their stockholders, and the public pitfalls they still contain, were disclosed here yesterday by Carmen C. Blough, chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Although the franc was, again slightly lower today at 30.43 to the dollar, confidence in the future continues tobe felt in French Government circles as a result of Saturday's Cabinet meeting and the declaration of policy then made.
The Morgenthau Corp., M. Morgenthau, president. has arranged a 5-year extension of the first mortgage on the five-story apartment at 741-3 Hunts Point Ave., the Bronx. for the Porson Realty Corp.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that its component units in the deck, engine and stewards' departments had concurred in resolutions endorsing Associate Justice Black on the strength of his "liberal record in the Senate."

Clarence J. Shearn, former Justice of the Appellate Division, called yesterday at the campaign headquarters of Thomas E. Dewey, prosecutor of rackets and candidate for District Attorney jointly on the Republican and American Labor party tickets, and announced that he would accept the chairmanship of a lawyers' committee now being formed to further the candidacy of Mr. Dewey.

With the 1937 polo tournament season on Long Island at an end, several high-goal players who took an active part in this year's competition participated in a members' round-robin today on Belmont Field of the Meadow Brook Club.
Again Mussolini has made a move in defiance of France and Great Britain. This time the master showman's work is so melodramatic as to command nearly universal attention.
A daring Japanese raiding party was overwhelmed by Chinese defenders early today when it tried to break a nine-day deadlock by penetrating the shattered Station area.

If all the base hits, including a considerable number of home runs, that were belted in the Polo Grounds and the Yankee Stadium yesterday were tossed into today's grand opener between baseball's two champions, the Yanks and the Giants, the game probably would have to be called on account of darkness.

John A. Cissel has been elected chairman of the committee on customers' men of the New York Stock Exchange to succeed Henry Rogers Winthrop, who has resigned from the committee. Mr. Cissel, who had been vice chairman, will be succeeded in that post by Robert W. Keelips.

Luxury and individuality were the keynotes of the Winter fashions in millinery exhibited yesterday afternoon in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel by twelve members of the Millinery Creators' Guild, Inc. Sixty hats, worn with costumes furnished by members of the Fashion Originators' Guild of America and leading style furriers, were viewed by 500 millinery buyers and manufacturers and fashion writers.

Ladenburg, Thalman Co., as special agent, today will notify holders of State of Rio Grande do Sul twenty-five-year 8 per cent bonds of 1921 that funds have been deposited with them sufficient to pay 35 per cent of the face amount on the coupons due on Oct. 1, 1937. If accepted by the holders, this payment must be accepted in full payment of such coupons.

ALBERT-Charles S., in his seventy-sixth year, beloved husband of Lena, and father of Leonard S., Mildred M. Schwenk: grandfather of Carl L. Albert. Services at the residence, 532 Minneford Ave., City Island, Wednesday, Oct. 6, at 8 P. M. Funeral at the convenience of family. Please omit flowers.
Mrs. Joseph Jay Manning of New York was the guest at dinner today of Mrs. Henry Graves Jr. A. L. Miller of New York entertained at luncheon in the Colonial Room.

Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director and treasurer of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, died early today at his home here after a six-week illness. Mr. Sweitzer, who had lived here since 1929, before which he had long lived in Brooklyn, was 49 years old.

Penniless but good-humored and without a trace of ill-feeling toward those who had expelled her from her fatherland, where she had worked a lifetime for the benefit of womanhood, Dr. Alice Salomon, internationally known German sociologist, told yesterday the story of her exile.
Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, campaigning for District Attorney on the basis of his war on crime, became a victim of robbers yesterday.

With the chips on the table in a pile that promises to reach a record height and each side preparing to- lead its mightiest ace, New York's second successive world series jackpot will get under way today, when 70,000 are expected to storm the huge Stadium to see the Yankees, still overlords of the American League, and the Giants, once again the National League's standard bearers, meet in the opening clash for baseball's biggest prize.

Public offering of $18,000,000 of Idaho Power Company first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1967, the proceeds of which will be used principally for refunding and new construction, will be made today by an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation and including Coffin Burr, Inc.;

Recovery in Japan continues to be concentrated in the production of goods and services for export and for armament, according to the monthly review of the Bank of Nova Scotia. These industries, it declares, employ but 20 per cent of the working population.

Fascist aviation circles disclosed today that Bruno Mussolini, 20-year-old son of Premier Benito Mussolini, accompanied by the flower of Italy's bombardment aviation, was in active service as a pilot for the Insurgent armies in Spain.

James H. Perkins, chairman of the board of the National City Bank, was elected president, and Herbert P. Howell, president of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, was named chairman of the Clearing House Committee at the annual meeting yesterday of the New York Clearing House Association.
The sixty-ninth meeting of the. American Public Health Association in New York serves to remind us of the enormous strides which have been made in improving the hygienic conditions of the masses.

Without anticipating more weighty pronouncements, perhaps a humble layman may be permitted to point out one or two things which the 150 signatories to the open letter do not seem to have treated with the acumen which might have been expected of them.

Mrs. Agnes P. Roberts Groome, widow of Colonel John C. Groome, who headed the American military police overseas during the World War, was a former warden of Eastern State Penitentiary and one-time head of the Pennsylvania State police, died at the age of 69, of a heart attack today at her Bryn Mawr home.
The engagement of the Marquess of Clydesdale to Lady Elizabeth Percy, sister of the Duke of Northumberland, was announced tonight. Lord Clydesdale is the heir of the Duke of Hamilton.

A verbal battle between sponsors and opponents of the National Administration's agricultural program, the Wages and Hours Bill, the Vandenberg amendments to the Wagner act and the Executive Reorganization Bill stirred The New York is Herald Tribune's seventh annual forum on current problems at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

SUPREME COURT OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, COUNTY OF NEW YORK. In the matter of the Liquidation of Greater New York-Suffolk Title and Guarantee Company.--Notice to trust claimants. To all persons having trust claims against Greater New York-Suffolk Title and Guarantee Company:

Retired Lieutenant Henry Schweikert, formerly a member of H. and L. 108, residing at 74-25 93d Ave., Woodhaven, died Oct. 3. Funeral will taken place from Schnatz Funeral Parlors, 3,478 Fulton St., Brooklyn, at 10 A. M., Wednesday, Oct. 6.

Commodity futures continued downward in active trading on the local exchanges yesterday. Heavy losses were recorded in metal, rubber, hide, silk and cocoa futures. In the cash markets all the grains, tin, flour, cocoa, lard, cotton, silk, wool tops, rubber and hides declined, with half the list at new low levels for the year. No advances were made.

John E. Dalton of this city, an economist and former head of the sugar section of the AAA, will marry Mrs. Martha Downing Eggleston of 160 East Eighty-third Street, daughter of Mrs. Claude E. Downing of Berkeley, Calif., and the late Mr. Downing, on Saturday afternoon in All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., today made public an interpretation by David Saperstein, director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, of two important rules governing trading over the counter.

That dolorous phrase, "leading a dog's life," took on added significance yesterday in the realty world when it was learned that the managers of two major apartment properties had taken drastic steps to solve the canine pet problem.

The larger percentage of the kosher butcher shops were still closed and there were practically no kosher markets yesterday. Trading in steer hinds and ribs was at a standstill and demand for other classes was fair to slow. Veal cuts were steady to weak, cow and bull steady. other classes steady to slow, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
It took an emergency squad of police armed with bayonets, rifles and tear gas to quell a renewal today of a battle between 2,000 native workers deep in a gold mine here.
Harry Offett has resigned as superintendent in charge of operations at Franklin Simon Co., erfective Saturday, and no successor has been chosen. He was not ready to announce future plans. Paul J.

Liberalization of the terms forI Government loans on low-grade cotton attracted sufficient buying to hold prices steady yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here, despite weakness in other commodities and stocks.

Mayor La Guardia was greeted enthusiastically by 2,000 social workers when he appeared yesterday to officiate at the laying of the cornerstone of the city's Welfare Hospital for Chronic Diseases at Welfare Island, the magnificent $7,000,000 institution that will be the largest and most modern hospital in the world devoted exclusively to the scientific care of chronic diseases.

Mrs. Mary Mintz, widow of Wolf Mintz and a former resident of this city, died in Hollywood, Calif., on Monday, according to word received here yesterday by her son, Harry I. Mintz of 1,307 Boscobel Avenue, the Bronx.

The drive to organize the 869.000 employes of the United States Government, begun at the organization less than foulr months ago of the United Federal Workers of America, a CIO affiliate, was stated by its officials today to be in full swing, with every indication of ultimate success.

Mrs. Joseph T. Robinson, widow of the former majority leader in the Senate, gave public endorsement today to the candidacy of Representative John E. Miller, Independent Democrat seeking election to Robinson's unexpired term.

Japan's invasion of China has cost American interests tremendous sums in business as well as actual damage to property, Carl L. Reed, manager of the export department of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company, told the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Support for Thomas E. Dewey as candidate for District Attorney of New York County was urged yesterday by the civic affairs commission of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation in a resolution adopted at a meeting in the Central Y. M. C. A., 55 Hanson Place. The action was made public by the Rev. Ben F. Wyland, chairman of the commission.

Delivery of 2,060 airplanes during the first eight months of the year brought the income of aircraft manufacturers to $71,723,589 and indicated that they would do a total business of $110,000,000 by the end of the year, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America announced yesterday.
Canada leads world in the carriage of freight by air, the Department of Commerce has been informed by the American commercial attach in Ottawa.

Yvon Robert, 225, of Montreal used a pick-up and drop to down Richard Stahl, 220, of Germany in 21:08 of the main wrestling bout at the Royal Windsor Arena last night, according to The Associated Press. Benny (Crusher) Feldman, 280,

The four-story store and apartment property at 580 Bergenline Avenue, corner of Twenty-ninth Street, Union City, N. J., was sold to an investing client of J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker in the deal. George Moser acted as attorney.

Confronted by difficult and controversial problems, the fifty-second triennial general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States will open here tomorrow and remain in session for two weeks, with church dignitaries from all parts of the United States and from mission fields in attendance.

A group of Sweden's leaders in the arts and sciences will visit American universities and colleges in an interchange of knowledge as part of the Swedish tercentenary celebrations, 1937-38, it was-announced yesterday by Dr. Henry Goddard Leach chairman of the AmericanScandinavian Foundation.

Intent on thoroughly familiarizing the Lions with the Army mode of play, Coach Lou Little again sent the Columbia varsity and reserves against the freshmen yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the contest at West Point Saturday.

TO QUITO AND BACK, a play in two acts and six scenes, by Ben Hecht. Staged by Philip Moeller; settings and costumes by Aline Bernstein; produced under the supervision of Theresa Helburn, Lawrence Langner and Mr. Moeller; presented as the first offerings of the Theatre Guild's twentieth subscription season. At the Guild Theatre.

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was guest of honor at the first meeting of the third season of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pierre. Mrs. August Belmont presided.

Army opened its soccer season today with a 4-to-O victory over Lehigh. The Cadets surpassed in team play and scored in each of the four periods. Lough, Army captain, netted the ball twice and the other goals were kicked in by Lehr and Grant.

Following is the text of the letter of former Secretary of State Henry L. Stimson appealing for American cooperation with the League of Nations in the efforts to stop Japan's war in China and favoring an embargo on war commodities to Japan by the United States and Great Britain.
Sir Edgar R. Bowring and his daughter, Mrs. John Shannon Munn, arrived from London and are at the Pierre. They will return to England on Oct. 20.
Two more changes were made in the Dartmouth football line-up as Coach Earl Blaik found a better combination in a long scrimmage today. Bill Hutchinson,

The body of Walter S. Case, president of Case, Pomeroy Co., Inc., a private investing corporation engaged primarily in exploring, developing and operating gold mines, copper mines and oil wells, was found yesterday morning on the roof of the five-story building at 110 Wall Street.

A demand on Sept. 28 by Max D. Steuer that The Nation withdraw published reflections on the motives of Paul Block and others in exposing the Ku Klux Klan relations of Justice Hugo Black is answered in The Nation of Oct. 9.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, gave notice yesterday that he intended to check the spreading by organizations of WPA workers of "false and malicious statements" on matters of WPA policy.

" Shucks, that's only one game!" exploded Colonel Bill Terry when the writer, the first man to approach the Giant manager after his defeated players had trooped glumly into their dressing room, was bold enough to proffer his condolences.

The United States war memorial here was formally dedicated today by Rear Admiral Arthur P. Fairfield, who spoke for General John J. Pershing, chairman of the American Battle Monuments Commission, who was unable to be present.

The performance of the Gilbert Miller production, "French Without Tears," tonight at Henry Miller's Theatre will be for the benefit of the Stepney Fresh Air Camp of the East Side Settlement House. Many women of society have been working toward the success of the benefit.

The machinery for carrying out the reciprocal tax convention between the United States and Canada, ratified on Aug. 13, under which each Government will have access to reports of withholding of income taxes was set in motion today by publication of an executive order by President Roosevelt and the promulgation of regulations by Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury.

The grain markets opened lower today, but the selling quickly ran its course and a strong rally developed when stocks turned upward. Closing trades on the Board of Trade here were within a small fraction of a cent a bushel of the high point with wheat showing net gains of 1 to 1 1/4 cents and corp 1/8 to 5/8 cent.
Mrs. Beula Post Kellogg, artist and wife of Robert Kellogg, concert manager, died today after a long illness at her home in West Hartford. Her age was 51.

In connection with a proposed refinancing by the Northern Boston Lighting Properties, several subsidiary operating companies have filed declarations with the Securities and Exchange Commission under Section 7 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act for the issuance of ten months' notes aggregating $3,309,375.

It looks as if love has found a way once more, this time to solve a postmastership problem which has been a headache to James A. Farley and a heartache to the people of Stevenson for more than three years.

Leaders in the field of retailing and other prominent men will be among the honorary pallbearers for the funeral of Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director and treasurer of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at his home in RidgeI wood, N. J., today at 2:30 P. M. i The Rev. Harry N. Bassler of Haririsburg, Pa., %will officiate. Burial will be tomorrow in Glen Rock, Pa.
Michigan's football team went back to fundamentals today as hard drills ended for Saturday's Western Conference game with Northwestern at Evanston.

The marriage of Miss Eugenia Frances Deacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Newell Deacon of this place, to L. Frederick Caufield Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. L. F. Caufield, also of Maplewood, took place this evening in the home of her parents.

Production of gold in the United States in August reached a high record for recent years at 518,000 ounces, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. This figure compared with 425,000 ounces in July and 388,000 in August, 1936.

The belief that Max Rubin, who gave Grand Jury testimony against Max Silverman, Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro and was shot down in the Bronx last week, might be a valuable witness in a year old Brooklyn murder was advanced yesterday by District Attorney Geoghan of that borough.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today with 1,921 passengers from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg. They include Nelson Doubleday, Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Pannill, Konstantin Fotic, Yugoslav Minister to the United States; Miss Elsa Maxwell,

Thirteen thousand two hundred and twenty-three persons, about evenly divided as to whether they were witnessing a RO-deo or a ro-DAY-o, thronged Madison Square Garden last night for the annual cowboy world series.

President Roosevelt's speech is being hailed in Loyalist Spain as the most resounding pronouncement America has yet made for the principles for which Valencia is fighting. Despite the ordinarily weak foreign news service and the lack of newsprint, every morning and evening newspaper here prints columns of extracts and gives them the most prominent place in today's news.

Too much "sparring and shadow boxing" has occurred in the reorganization proceedings of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, O. John Rogge, special counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission,

Tribute to this country's pioneering stock was paid today by Sir Campbell Stuart, a director of The Times of London and chairman of the Imperial Communications Advisory Committee, in an address after the College of William and Mary had conferred on him the honorary de gree of Doctor of Laws.

Dean Melvin E. Haggerty of the University of Minnesota Education Department, president of the National Association of College Teachers and authority on educational psychology, died today. He was 61 years old.

Secretary Swanson announced today that Rear Admiral Wilson Brown Jr., now commanding the training detachment of the fleet, would relieve Rear Admiral David Foote Sellers as Superintendent of the Naval Academy Feb. 1, one month before Admiral Sellers retires from service after reaching the statutory age of 64 years.

Back from a two-week trip through the Northwest, President Roosevelt gave the strongest kind of indication today that he would call a special session of Congress and ask it to pass most of the New Deal legislation' which the first session of the Seventy-fifth Congress failed to enact.

GIANTS-Gomez sent over the first pitch of the 1937 world series for a called strike which cut the heart of the plate. Moore missed a swing at the next one and then grounded to Gehrig, who raced over to the bag, beating Moore's dash, for the first put-out.

The Treasury, seeking to forestall numerous suits for tax refunds, announced today that it would recommend legislation providing refunds of levies collected under the Tobacco and Potato Control Acts and the Bankhead Cotton Act.

Shouting down an appeal from their president and overriding a written request by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, 4.000 members of the Federation of Kosher Butchers voted last night to continue their stoppage "strike" which has kept 5,000

Miss Dorothy Jane Rose, granddaughter of Stephen Foster, was married today 1 to Ralph L. Melady, Brooklyn realty broker, before the ancient brick fireplace in the home of the composer, now a part of Henry Ford's Greenfield Village.

The doings tonight at the Plymouth Theatre--they go by the name of "Susan and God"-bring together three of the theatre's better known names, those of John Golden, producer; Gertrude Lawrence, star, and Rachel Crothers, playwright.

The Composers' Forum-Laboratory of the Federal Music Project opened its third season last night at the Theatre of Music, presenting orchestra works of Roy Harris, whose honor it was to inaugurate this series.

The Japanese Foreign Office called an emergency conference today following United States action condemning Japan as a treaty violator. Simultaneously, newspaper extras began appearing with the bare text of the pronouncement issued by the State Department in Washington.
Teamwork between the police and prosecutors offers the only real method of checking modern organized crime and its rackets, Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for District Attorney of Manhattan.

Filing slowly across the green of the playing field of the University of Cincinnati's stadium to a stanctuary and'chancel constructed across one end a solemn and impressive procession of ecclesiastics and laymen opened today the general convention of the' Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Chicago speech was printed on the front pages of Moscow newspapers, without comment yet, but it undoubtedly has been received with universal satisfaction.

J. Gilbert Hall of New York, seeded first, won two matches today with the loss of only two games in the Hot Springs Fall invitation tennis tournament. He defeated C. Maury Jones of Seabright, N. J., 6-1, 6--0; then halted Sam Snider of Hartford, 6-0, 6-1. Hall captured tournament honors in 1931, 1932 and 1933. He meets Percy Kynaston, Brooklyn, the defending player. in the next round.

With 318 coeds volunteering their rooms in Balch halls for the accommodation of delegates assembled from every part of the country, all is in readiness for the inauguration of Dr. Edmund Ezra Day as fifth president of Cornell University on Friday.
The Unity Amusement Company, Inc., operators of the Oxford Theatre, 552 State Street, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to a charge of giving an indecent performance.

Electric power production increased last week. However, the gain was smaller than anticipated on the basis of seasonal and longterm trends, and the adjusted index has ease. to 104.4. It was 104.7 for the previous week and 105.5 for the week ended Oct. 3, 1936.

Albie Burke, quarterback, and Johnny Long, left halfback, returned to the Colgate football squad today, after being out with injuries, but Coach Andy Kerr continued to use Bob Johnson as quarter on the first team and Hal Lube at left half.
Edward Baker, sports editor of The Ottawa (Ont.) Citizen, who had come here to cover the world series, died in the Hotel Lincoln of a heart attack yesterday morning. He was 68 years old.

The auction sale of the Hotel Drake, which was to have taken place on Tuesday, has been adjourned to Dec. 7, 1937, and an order is being prepared demanding that cause be shown why the bondholders' plan should not be consummated, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc.

The Commerce Department announced today receipt of a cablegram from Paris announcing the French import quotas for the last quarter of 1937, on industrial products, as announced in the Journal Officiel of Oct. 1.

The Treasury will advocate enactment of legislation in the next session of Congress providing necessary authority and appropriation to-permit about $6,000,000 in refunds of taxes paid under the terms of the KerrSmith Tobacco Control, Bankhead Cotton Control and Warren Potato Control Acts.

Edwin S. Isham, who had sung baritone roles with the Savoy Opera Company in England and The Bostonians in this country, died here this morning at his estate, Lambert Hall, of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 70 years old.
The Nine-Power Conference on the war in China is awaited here as the first example of that "concerted action" of which President Roosevelt spoke in Chicago yesterday.

President Roosevelt's speech in Chicago yesterday has come as a heartening encouragement to the democratic countries of Europe at a moment when they are daily engaged in a tense diplomatic struggle with dictatorships in an effort to avoid war.

A rising spiral of wages and prices is to be avoided at all hazards in seeking to solve economic problems of the future, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.,

Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Isidore Nagler, candidate for Borough President of the Bronx; Grace Gosselin, director of Ethical Culture School, over WNEW (1,250 Kc.), 7:45 to 8.P. M.

Captain Russell Allen, right guard, has won the punting assignment on Harvard's football team. The Crimson pilot, who scrimmaged for the first time yesterday and also punted, was so outstanding that he received a special workout in the Stadium today.

The semi-annual report of the Crown Cork International Corporation and subsidiaries, controlled by the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., showed for the first half of this year a net income of $200,621 after depreciation, interest, income taxes, minority interest and exchange adjustments.

To the Bditor of The New york Times: You say in your editorial "MovingDay Misgivings" that the housing problem can be solved if enough money is spent on it and this is proved by the rr sent opening of two Federal housing projects, one being Williamsburg Houses.

Tourist guides will be mobilized for a rigorous course of training in propaganda. Dr. Joseph Goebbels's Ministry has come to the conclusion that tourists are an important means of disseminating propaganda. Therefore, for the first time guides will be assembled for systematic training now that this season Is over. Rather desultory courses had been offered to guides before.

Charley Caldwell is one of the few football coaches in the East who has remained entrenched at the same post over the span of a decade. Coming to Williams in 1928, when he might easily have been mistake for a member of his team, and after a brilliant playing career

The news that the owners. of two large apartment properties had decided to restrict the keeping of dogs by their tenants unleashed a spirited debate yesterday and inspired many suggestions for handling the canine problem in congested areas.

Operations in the mountainous Asturian front, which is the most difficult terrain in all Spain, have been retarded by a solid week of bad weather. Without the rain and fog, which have eliminated aviation cooperation with ground forces, General Solchaga's army in Eastern Asturias 2nd General Mizuel Aranda's

In opposition to one school of thought which says that the current football season is to see a drift back toward the conservative, Dick Harlow, Harvard's coach, writes in the H. A. A. News, Haryard publication, that he expects to see "a better, more open, more interesting game than we saw in 1936."

The Anchor Post Fence Company is notifying holders of first closed mortgage 6 1/2 per cent bonds dated 1927 that upon surrender of these bonds to Chase National Bank, depository, delivery will be made of new registered first closed mortgage 5 per cent income bonds issuable under the reorganization plan of the company, as confirmed.

Navy officers disclosed today that Federal agencies were investigating possible sabotage of machinery aboard an unnamed warship. A Navy Department spokesman said there had been "derangement of some machinery" on the ship and that "an investigation is under way."

Evergold, 8-year-old campaigner from the Shandon Farm, returned to the scene of the stake triumphs of his youth today and turned in a smashing effort to annex the Grade B Handicap that featured the program.
Is the nation headed in the wrong direction on child labor? It depends on what President Roosevelt means by

Establishment of uniform minimum wage scales on a nation-wide basis was advocated today by Fred W. Steele, legislative chairman of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers, at its annual meeting. He said his proposal, wiping out the regional differential,

The sequel to the Government's "easy-money" policies of August and September has been somewhat mixed. On Aug. 27 the Reserve Board reduced its rediscount rate from 1 1/2 per cent to 1-the lowest ever fixed by any great central banking institution, in this country or abroad.

Most commodity futures opened sharply lower yesterday, but late rallies tended to erase the declines and prices at the close were irregularly under the previous day's closing levels.
