In the cash market wheat, rye and oats advanced, but cocoa, raw sugar, tins, corn, cotton, printcloths, silk, wool tops and rubber declined, the latter six to new low marks for the year.
Bandits who kidnapped the Rev. Gerard A. Donovan from the sacristy of the Roman Catholic church at N6rth Fushun last night, demanded $50,000 ransom today. Japanese authorities were taking action.

Republicans will fight Democratic control of the State Constitutional Convention on three grounds, William S. Murray, Republican State chairman, said here today. Republicans would battle, he said, for retention of the present system

Japan was condemned by the United States for her action in China and accused of having violated the NinePower treaty for safeguarding China and the Kellogg-Briand antiwar pact in a formal statement issued late today by the State Department.

The program for the opening concerts of the ninety-sixth season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society. to take place at Carnegie Hall Thursday evening, Friday and Sunday afternoons, Oct. 21, 22 and 24. is announced as follows:

A demand for pressure on President Roosevelt to invoke neutrality legislation in the China situation, and a call for a world peace conference of theologians and political philosophers that would exclude diplomats, were made yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Brooklyn division of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom at the Hotel Victoria.

With the aid of a well-judged ride by Alfred Robertson, Cleaveland Putnam's Moon Side splashed through the mud at Jamaica yesterday to win the featured Warwick Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth in a photo finish that thrilled the crowd all through the final furlong.

The Works Progress Administration reported tonight, following President Roosevelt's Hyde Park statement concerning relief roll reductions, that more than 1,000,000 persons had been dropped from work relief projects within a year.

Bursting out of the misty haze like an enveloping flame such as a man might encounter on locating that leak in a gas pipe with the aid of a match, the Yankee juggernaut exploded only once at the Stadium yesterday, but that once sufficed to blow the opening clash of the 1937 world series virtually into atoms.

The National League's Cubs fitted a rousing fifteen-hit assault together with Tex Carleton's brilliant pitching in the city series opener today to conquer their American League rivals, the White Sox, 7 to 3.

The men who put the swing into Tin Pan Alley's tunes yesterday proposed organization of an informal "Arrangers Guild," which would demand credit lines from movies, theatres, publishers and radio programs.

The third U. S. Camera Salon, comprising photographs by professional and amateur photographers from many parts of the country, will be opened to the public on Oct 19, following a private view the preceding evening, in the mezzanine galleries of the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue.

Charles H. Coles, octogenarian Chicago business man, who was a witness to the start of the great Chicago fire sixty-six years ago, is willing to rally to the defense of the cow that often has been accusecd of starting the flames by overturning a lamp. Mr. Coles,
Officials cut today from 500 to 300 the number of counties in which Federal farm tenancy loans will be made in this fiscal year.

After ruling today that a formal document, signed by either Secretary Ickes or President Roosevelt, would be the only competent evidence through which counsel for the defense would be permitted to bring out the fact that the defendant oil companies operated under the NRA code with governmental approval, Judge Patrick T. Stone, presiding in the oil conspiracy case here, subsequently modified that decision to the general satisfaction of defense attorneys.

Princeton University's gridiron battalions slipped into high gear this afternoon on University Field, and for some three hours, with the mercury soaring above the 70 mark, the Tiger varsity elevens roared along at their fastest clip of the season.

Miss Grace Washburn Pelzer, daughter of B. Henry Pelzer, was married here tonight at the home of her father to Carr Robinson Purser of New York, sons of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Purser of Charlotte, N. C., by the Rev. John A. MacSporran of the Hillside Presbyterian Cnurch.
Records of the Department of Justice showed tonight that President Roosevelt since taking office has appointed 66, or more than onefourth, of the 241 Feleral judges now sitting in the courts.

There was one error that did not appear in the box score of the world series opener yesterday and it was one that had the gathering of 60,573 completely mystified. Gus Mancuso was the culprit and Gus is supposed to be one of the smartest men in the baseball business.
Tommy Farr, the Welsh heavyweight who surprised the boxing world by going fifteen rounds with Joe Louis, sailed for England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Miss Charlotte Jauss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew C. Jauss of Newark, N. J., was married last night to William L. Halfmann of this city, son of the late Rev. and Mrs. Louis Halfmann, in Immanuel Lutheran Church, Eighty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, of which she bridegroom's father was minister for thirty years.

The smooth-running Our Manager took the brush jumps on Richard K. Mellon's Rolling Rock Farms faultlessly today to win the fourth annual running of the Rolling Rock Hunt Cup before a gay society throng of more than 5,000.
Kenneth Bonham of New York was host at a large supper dance tonight at the Greenbrier Swimming Pool, which was transformed into a tropical garden room for the event.

-Michael F. Dooley, banker in this State and previously a prominent Democrat in Connecticut politics, died here today., He was 84 years old. Some months ago his health was so poor that a conservator for his estate was appointed by the Probate Court.

Ernest H. Sanford, a newspaper man for half a century who had been a copyreader on several New York newspapers, was found dead of heart disease yesterday morning in his room in the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.

Mme. Helene Piper, American onetime circus performer and for a long time a fortune teller wellknown in all Chinese coast cities, who was opening her roadhouse and night club near Ribicon village, a few miles west of the International Settlement, took in several score Chinese wounded yesterday, when the village was bombed and machine-gunned by Japanese planes, and used table linen for dressings for the poor folk.

Headquarters for the "League for the Protection of American Standards," a group sponsored by manufacturers anxious to promote a boycott against Japanese goods, were set up yesterday at 103 Park Avenue. The organization,

George H. Charls, executive officer of the American Iron and Steel Institute and, a prominent stockholder in the defunct Continental Shares, Inc., testifying as the last witness in the legal battle in court here between stockholders of the company seeking either its reorganization or liquidation, declared today that he would "never agree" to liquidation of Continental and held out hopes of reorganization.

Charles Hudd Sr., for a half century an employe of Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company here and father of Policeman Charles Hudd, died yesterday at his home at 148 Orchard Street, He was born in Wales.

Irving Frankenstein, 42 years old, who gave his address as 118 West Seventy-second Street, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Felony Court on a charge he extorted $28 from Dr. Carl L. Levenson of 471 Park Avenue last Tuesday in what the police described as a new racket.
The Treasury's financing plans were discussed today by Secretary Morgenthau with the executive committee of the open market committee of the Federal Reserve Board, but no conclusions were announced.

The 1,385 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $47,283,743,291 par value as of Oct. 1, had a total market value of $43,270,678,790, according to compilation' by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Sept. 1, there were 1,386 issues, aggregating $47,227,272,516 par value, which had a total market value of $43,808,755,638.
Sir James Frazer, who since his debut as an author in 1884 has published books that won him membership in learned societies of many nations, will bring out his 284th work within a fortnight.

The Department of State has been informed by the American Minister to Switzerland of the text of the report adopted by the advisory committee of the League of Nations setting forth the advisory committee's examination of the facts of the present situation in China and the treaty obligations of Japan.

Federal Judge William Clark here today ordered fifty lawyers from all parts of New Jersey to explain within the next few days why they failed to pass counsellors' examinations within the prescribed period of five years after being admitted to practice before the Federal bar.
Lehigh University granted honorary degrees to four men and paid tribute to two former administrative officers at its fifty-ninth Founder's Day exercises this morning.

Albert Winton Brown, attorney and organizer of the Mortgage Holding Corporation of Nassau County, died suddenly last night of a heart attack at his home here. Mr. Brown had been at his office yesterday and appeared to be in good health. He was in- his sixty-fourth year.
Amy Johnson Mollison, British flier, today filed a divorce action against her aviator husband, James A. Mollison, with whom, she holds numerous joint flight records. The action was not defended.

Bronislaw Huberman, Polish violinist, was cut on his arms and hands in a crash of a Royal Dutch airliner near Palembang, Sumatra, today. Of the five other passengers one was killed and the others were slightly injured.

Secretary of Commerce Roper said today that his study of indicators led him to believe that with the exception of normally spasmodic interruptions of minor consequence, business should continue on a satisfactory basis.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Harvey Hudson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fletcher Hudson of Richmond, Va., to Robert Lee Sherrod, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Arnold Sherrod of Thomasville, Ga., took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church, 631 West End Avenue, who performed the ceremony.

The three-story brownstone dwelling at 293 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, was sold to Alfred Drayton for occupancy. George C. and Alva T. Stephen were the sellers and were represented by Gleason, McLenahan, Merritt Ingraham, attorneys. Samuel Weisstein was the attorney for the purchaser. R. M.

Meeker's Main Street was deep in gloom tonight, silent sorrow for the ill luck of this town's No. 1 citizen--Carl Owen Hubbell. Meeker locked up shop in high spirits this afternoon and crowded around radios to listen to G. O.

Marlene Dietrich is denounced in the latest edition of Julius Streicher's Stuermer as a traitor to the Fatherland because she became an American citizen. The Stuermer gives a photograph of the film star preparing to take her citizenship oath before a supposedly Jewish court official.

Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Downs of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Marie Downs, to Cornelius Charles Hayes of Elmhurst, Queens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Hayes of Elkhart, Ind.

As a result of the decline on foreign markets the American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday lowered its domestic copper quotation to 12 cents a pound, against 12 1/2 cents on Tuesday. Primary producers and other custom smelters were said to be holding firmly to a 13-cent price. The decline in London prices brought the electrolytic quotation down from the equivalent of 12.38 cents a pound to 11.94 cents.
The Nazi newspaper Angriff prominently displayed- today an attack on the Vatican for its purported lack of enthusiasm over the recent visit to Germany of Premier Mussolini of Italy.

Reports received from Malta by The Daily Telegraph are said to provide grounds for the belief that the submarine that attacked the British destroyer Basilisk while on anti-piracy patrol off Spain on Monday was sunk by depth charges.

The marriage of Mrs. Mary McNulty Grayson of Chicago, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. McNulty, to William W. Crehore Jr., son of Mrs. William W. Crehore of 131 East Eightieth Street and the late Mr. Crehore, took place here yesterday at the Pierre.

Three blind children presented to Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, yesterday the 35,000,000th pencil issued by the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, thereby starting the guild's twenty-third annual pencil sale campaign.

Major Mariano Vassallo of the army chaplain corps, attached to the Sixtyfifth Infantry, has been named vicar general of the San Juan diocese, succeeding the late Jos Torres, dean of the Catholic clergy In Puerto Rico.

Eye conservation should be made the subject of special study in the field of preventive medicine, Dr. William F. Snow, general director of the American Social Hygiene Association, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Authoritative quarters here received President Roosevelt's Chicago speech as an echo of his address opening the inter-American peace conference at Buenos Aires last year appealing for a united America to maintain peace, but at the same time the clearness of his utterances against dictatorships was regarded as an admonition to the countries of this continent.

The Army football squad put in a long session this afternoon, getting further acquainted with Columbia plays as demonstrated in a light scrimmage by the B squad. Assignments for the backs in breaking up Columbia passes were rehearsed, while the line had a long drill on the peculiar style of play used by the Lions' forwards.

A request that the two special committees investigating the "corner" in September corn on the Chicago Board of Trade keep a complete stenographic record of their proceedings was made today in a letter sent to the Exchange by John H. MacMillan Jr., president of Cargill. Inc.
Charley (Red) Ruffing, who will go to the firing line against the Giants today in the second game of the world series, last night put himself away out on a limb.

Yale University will follow traditional inauguration programs of two centuries in installing Dr. Charles Seymour into office as president Friday afternoon in Battell Chapel. Members of the corporation and faculty will compose most of the congregation.

The Danbury Trojans defeated the Brown Bombers of Harlem, N. Y., Fritz Pollard's all-Negro football team, 12-0, tonight at Lee Stadium. Ike Kern scored for the Trojans in the second quarter after.receiving a lateral pass from Frank Saniuk. Early in the fourth quarter, Coach Jack Thompson took the ball over on a line buck from the 4-yard line.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will attend the anniversary celebration of Saks-Thirty-fourth Street this afternoon and present a check from the store's proceeds during the week to the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, beneficiary of the seven-day fete.
While Shanghai continues to furnish headlines to the world's press as a prize for which ever-growing armies

Revision of the Anti-Trust Laws is essential, Attorney General Cummings said at a press conference today, adding that with the statutes in the present shape he could see no hope for successful criminal prosecution of steel companies on the ground of identical bidding.

When Vernon Gomez wound himself up yesterday afternoon and then unwound himself and sent the first pitched ball of the world series detouring around Joe Moore's bat, everything else ceased to matter for the maddened throng at the Yankee Stadium and for nobody knows how many bootblacks, lawyers, elevator operators, bankers, C. I. 0. organizers, A. F. of L. officials,
Dr. Charles G. Post Jr., Assistant Professor of Political Science at Vassar College, made an address today on the Constitution at chapel assembly to commemorate the anniversary of its signing.

Starting today and continuing for another week, a number of new and enlarged campaigns for liquors will break in local newspapers, emphasizing the sharp competition for volume that has developed this Fall among leading distillers.

It is virtually certain that a new Arab High Committee for Palestine will be formed in Syria and will conduct its political,activity from there, it was learned today. The new group, it is reported, will include members of the outlawed old committee-Izzet Darwaza, Auni Bey Abdulhadi, Alfred Roch and Jamal el Husseini, president of the Palestine Arab party.

Benny Kaufman of New York won the national speedway motorcycle racing championship of the American Motorcycle Association tonight at Tri-City Stadium with a perfect score of 20 points in five starts. Earl Farrand of Glendale, Calif., was second with 17 points, and Crocky Rawding of Bloomfield, N. J., third with 16.

Securities and Exchange Commission has set Oct. 20 for a hearing on an application by Brokaw, Dixon McKee of New York City for an order declaring that the firm has ceased to be a holding company as it has divested itself of its holdingcompany interests in the Texas Gas Distributing Company of Texas and the Spencer Gas Company of West Virginia.
Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that Henry Ford was "not to blame for the working conditions in his plants."

Higher crop estimates by private experts brought more selling into the market on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and prices again hit new low levels, with the list closing unchanged to 13 points lower. The liquidation centered on the December, which sold below 8 cents a pound for the first time. The average price in the spot markets in the South was 7.99 cents.

Stocks of refined and antimonial lead in the United States totaled 179,396 short tons on Sept. 1, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics, compared to 187,654 tons on Aug. 1 and to 310,398 tons on Sept. 1, 1936.

The 1937 campaign of the combined women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities will begin today at 10:30 A. M. at a meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday.

More than twenty-five men having membership in maritime unions affiliated with the C. I. O. have been beaten on the New York waterfront during the last month and police action has been taken in only two instances, it was charged yesterday by Mervyn Rathborne, chairman of the C. I. O. Maritime Committee.
France and Great Britain tonight gave Premier Benito Mussolini twenty-four hours' grace to respond to their joint bid for a three-power discussion of the withdrawal of "volunteers" from Spain.

Sir John Thomson-Walker, a leading British surgeon and a specialist on urological diseases, died suddenly of a heart attack today at Aviemore, In vernesshire, Scotland, at the age of 60. He had performed operations on Lloyd George and Lord BadenPowell and was famed as a lecturer, making his own educational films.

Despite the slight improvement in the French franc, whose position has been a decided influence here, the local stock market continued weak today. Gilt-edge issues maintained their firmness on continued investment support; dullness again was prevalent among the foreign bonds.

Although tomorrow marks the passage of a week since "moving day," there is only a slight let-up in the Fall demand for new living quarters' according to reports received yesterday from brokers in many sections of the city and suburbs. Many realty men and movingvan owners are confident that the favorable activity will continue for some time.

Indications that thousands of properties in Manhattan may be purchased at prices far below the assessed valuations may be found by a study of the sales and mortgage lists of almost any real estate brokerage office.

Harry Thomas, wild-swinging fighter of Eagle Bend, Minn., won the Illinois heavyweight championship tonight. by outpointing Max Marek of Chicago in a bruising ten-round battle at the Chicago Stadium. Thomas weighed 195, Marek 187 1/4.

Enraged to the point or tears by the attempts of Democratic members of the Board of Estimate to make him responsible for finding the additional $12,000,000 for next year's budget. Mayor La Guardia slammed out of an executive session of the board yesterday after the bitterest battle he has ever had with Controller Frank J. Taylor.
An 87 by Mrs. Henry March of North Shore was enough to take low gross in the one-day tournament of the Women's Lcng Island Golf Association yesterday at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing.
Sir Percy Bates,. chairman of the Cunard White Star Line, sailed yesterday on the liner Queen Mary after a brief visit in Boston, Philadelphia, New York and Montreal.

Hundreds of observers watched aghast yesterday afternoon at Newark airport as a huge Douglas airliner with nineteen passengers and a crew of three settled earthward with a crippled landing gear. The two pilots, following radio instructions, made a successful landing on one wheel, rolled to a stop and were greeted with cheers and applause.

J. P. Morgan, through his Flintlock Realty Company, has leased the four-story building at 28-30 East Thirty-seventh Street to the Dartmonth Club Real Estate Corporation for occupancy by the Dartmouth Club, which now is at 24 East Thirty-eighth Street.

According to plans announced today the Duke and Duchess of Windsor will leave for Berlin by train Sunday night. From Berlin, where the Duke intends to study workers' housing and other sociological conditions, they will go to Hamburg, Frankfort-onthe-Main and Mannheim, where receptions might include- a meeting with Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

With six wickets left to fall, British Guiana's batsmen had 439 runs for four in reply to Trinidad's first-innings total of 430 as play in the intercolonial cricket championship final finished its second day.
Ambrose Francis Petry of New York died here yesterday afternoon as he was being driven to the South Norwalk railroad station after his monthly inspection of extensive property he owned here.

Cocker spaniels shared the entry lead with foxterriers as the fiftyfourth annual Danbury Agricultural Society dog show, the second oldest in the country, opened today in conjunction with the Danbury Fair. There were three dozen specimens of those popular breeds among the 550 entries for the twoday exhibition.

The Interstate Commerce Commission made public today requests by the Garden State Lines, Jersey City, N. J. and eleven other bus companies for dismissal of protests filed against increased passenger fares that they re-established between New York City and points in Bergen County, New Jersey.

Details of the connection of former Senator J. Thomas Heflin of Alabama with the Department of Justice were learned today. He was appointed July' 6, 1936, for six months and "dropped at the close of business" Jan. 19, 1937. His salary was $6,000 annually as a special assistant to the Attorney General.

The first results of Monday's defeat of the trade union leaders at the Labor party conference came today with the election of Sir Stafford Cripps and Professor Harold Laski to the party's executive committee.

Pleased by the showings made in recent primaries, labor's Non-Partisan League announced today that it would conduct campaigns in Connecticut, Rhode Island and Illinois in behalf of its endorsed candidates in coming primaries and extend its organization in every State.

Fortythree anthracite miners, voluntary prisoners 1,200 feet below the earth's surface, sent up defiant word tonight that their "stay down" strike, called at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, was "just beginning."

President Franklin D. Roosevelt's words uniting, as they have done, French and Americans in a new struggle to preserve individual liberties and respect international law, today gave fervor to the twohour dedication ceremony in the rain at the monument France has built just outside of Versailles to her comradeship with America.
THE SOUTH WIND OF LOVE, by Compton Mackenzie (Dodd, Mead, $3). Second volume of a four-volume novel.

Pig-iron production, The Iron Age reports, has declined along with steel-ingot output. At the end of September the United States Steel Corporation blew out nine blast furnaces, the independents took off two and one went on, leaving a net loss of ten -in a month. The number in blast on Oct. 1 was 181, compared with 191 on Sept. 1.

Officers of the past year were reelected and two new members of the board of governors named at yesterday's annual meeting of delegates to the United States Polo Association, held at the Racquet and Tennis Club. Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., F. S. von Stade and Elbridge T. Gerry were returned to office as chairman of the board,

The Park Department's share of the 1938 executive budget must be increased by at least $750,000 if the minimum needs of the expanded city park system are to be met, Commissioner Robert Moses warned yesterday.

Yale today ended strenuous practice for the Pennsylvania game in the Bowl Saturday with a long scrimmage in which the usual order was reversed. Defense was stressed at the start, when the backs and centers specialized in breaking up forward passes and the linemen concentrated on stopping Penn plays as interpreted by the Grays.

The Transport Workers Union, holding its first national convention at its headquarters, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street, adopted a constitution yesterday calling for the organization on an industrial union basis of all transport workers in the United States, except those employed on steam railroads.

With the tacit approval of fifty countries and the remaining two, Poland and Siam, abstaining, the League of Nations Assembly adopted tonight the resolution of its Far Eastern Advisory Committee. This resolution authorizes League members who are parties to the Nine-Power treaty to invite the United States and other interested powers to initiate the consultation provided for in this treaty with a view to ending the Sino-Japanese conflict by agreement.

" The Sleeping Beauty," opera composed by Beryl Rubinstein, with libretto by John Erskine, will have its world premiere performance at the Juilliard School on Jan. 19, it was announced yesterday by Ernest Hutcheson, president of the school.

Newark's Bears, winners of the International League pennant by a 25 1/2game margin, defeated the Columbus Red Birds, 10 to 4, tonight for their fourth straight victory to capture the little world series, four games to three.
Leaders of the All-India Congress party demanded today that the Government officially participate in a boycott of Japanese goods as a protest against the undeclared Japanese war against China.

Election of the following New York City certified public accountants to be members or associates in the American Institute of Accountants was announced yesterday by Colonel Robert H. Montgomery of Lybrand, Ross Bros. Montgomerv. president.
Eighteen persons have been sentenced to death on charges of spoiling grain supplies. Nine were sentenced in Moscow Province, four at Azov, on the Black Sea; three in Dagestan and two in Azerbaijan.

Michael Fugmann, convicted. of first-degree murder in the Good Friday parcel post bombing of 1936, in which three were killed, was sentenced to the electric chair today by Judge Samuel E. Shull of Monroe County, who presided specially at his trial.

Films to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday have been endorsed, unless otherwise specified, as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local, public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company in September amounted to $24,271,151 against $23,433,453 in September, 1936, an increase of 3.6 per cent. In the preceding month sales declined half per cent from those of August, last year.

The right of Congress to make a declaration of public policy and then to refuse use of the mails to a corporation or individual violating the policy was defended yesterday by Robert H. Jackson, assistant to the Attorney General, at a hearing on the appeal of the Electrio Bond and Share Company from a decision by Judge Julian W. Mack holding the registration sections of the Public Utilities Act of 1935 to be constitutional.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Sept. 25 totaled 307,974,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the previous week, this total represented a decline of 1,431,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 1,061,000 and 370,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

Senator Key Pittman, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, recommended an economic quarantine of Japan in a statement issued here tonight. He declared that President Roosevelt has been "very patient and has made every effort to persuade

The Appellate Division ruled today that Miss Grace A. Scott of Shawangunck, Ulster County, must return to Asa Howe a deed to his property which he lent to her for her perusal and which instrument made Mr. Howe and Miss Scott joint owners.

A warning that the "determination of some governments" to do things for the people would destroy the desire of self help, was sounded today by Harold T. Donaldson, president of the United States Building and Loan League.

A building and permanent loan for $875,000 has been arranged for Natoma Estates, Inc., A. Simon, president, by Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc., with the Equitable Life Assurance Society on the nineteen-story apartment to be erected on the northeast corner of Riverside Drive and Eighty-second Street, to be known as 100 Riverside Drive.

The New York Coffee and sugar Exchange announced yesterday that it had received the following cable from London regarding the meetings of the International Council, governing body of the International Sugar Agreement: "International meetings here reviewed the statistical situation and came to the conclusion that the
Mrs. George A. Ellis of New York gave a small dinner at Stepping Stones tonight. Among her guests were Mrs. Thomas Vardell, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Ellis and William Fanshawe White.

The presidents of the Eastern railroads decided yesterday at a meeting in the Biltmore Hotel to take steps to raise coach fares in this region from the present level of 2 cents a mile to 2.5 cents. This action was held to be necessitated by recent increases in wages granted unionized forces which, it is estimated, will increase expenses by $130,000,000 annually.

Long-delayed automobile buying of steel, which has come in large volume from the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, particularly in sheets, did not arrive in time to prevent a further dip in steel ingot output this week to an estimated 66 per cent of capacity in the country as a whole from 74 per cent last week, The Iron Age says this week.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook approved yesterday acceptance of an offer made by various banks and former officials of the National Surety Company to settle for $1,350,000 a suit for $50,000,000 brought by stockholders and creditors of the company. The offer was made last Spring.
Delegates to the convention of the Georgia division of the United Daughters of the Confederacy listened appreciatively while Mrs. Walter D. Lamar eulogized Jefferson Davis last night.
At a special meeting of the directors of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company yesterday nine of the board members resigned and nine new members immediately took their places.

The Texas House of Representatives appealed today to President Roosevelt to call a special session of Congress before Nov. 1 to relieve "serious" and "vexing" problems of the farmer caused by low cotton prices.

Probably not since the publication of Adam Smith's 'Wealth of Nations" has a book of its kind had wider circulation than the "Outlines of Economics," by Richard T. Ely, who at 83 years of age is still eagerly at work.

Diplomatic circles here were stirred by, the potentialities of President Roosevelt's comments on world affairs. There was considerable speculation in Fascist circles over whether the President, in announcing more active American cooperation in the cause of world peace, was planning an international conference to halt "international anarchy and instability"

Although the Yankees were Jubilant and the Giants downcast as a result of yesterday's contest, the players on both teams had one grievance in common. The boys were irked to a point approaching the high temperature so recently affecting Colonel Bill Terry, and none was reticent about voicing his disgruntlement, which specifically had to do with the location of seats assigned to their visiting families and friends.

A program for dealing with Brazil's problem of over-production of coffee was approved by Congress today and sent to President Getulio Vargas for signature. It incorporates a covenant concluded by eight coffee states in Havana last May.
A varied field of thirty-five campaigners, including last year's winner, Sir Abe Bailey's Dan Bulger, tonight were announced as final acceptors for next Wednesday's Cambridgeshire.
In his indictment of "international lawlessness," President Roosevelt did not name the lawbreakers. That would have been undiplomatic. Besides, it was unnecessary.

Registration throughout the city continued yesterday to lag behind both last year's figures and those of 1933, the year of the last Mayoralty campaign. The total registration in the city for the first three days of this year was 960,403, which compared with 962,072 in 1933, and 1,152,272 last year, when the all-time record was set.
Captain Joseph William Overton, retired boat builder and a trustee of this village from 1931 to 1935, ended his life with a pistol this morning at his home on Howell's Point Road here.

The business building on the southwest corner of Queens Boulevard and Sixty-sixth Avenue, Forest Hills West, Queens, was leased to Thomas C. Manning, Inc., agent for Plymouth and Dodge cars. The structure is of attractive modernistic design and was built and designed especially for the Manning organization. The Roman-Caswell Company, Inc., negotiated the deal.

Joseph A. Padway of Milwaukee, legal consultant for the American Federation of Labor, warned the federation today that if the decision of the National Labor Relations Board in the Allis-Chalmers case were favorable to the Committee for Industrial Organization nothing remained but to repeal the Wagner

The people of Spain and China are fighting a similar battle against "mliitarists gone mad," Dr. Tsunechi Yu, Chinese Consul General, said last night at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy.

Winning the first game of the match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris for the chess championship of the world, adjourned from last night, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam started auspiciously today in the defense of the title he wrested from the Franco-Russian master two years ago.
Army's plebe football team defeated Bucknell's freshmen today, 7-0, when Gillis intercepted a pass in the third quarte and ran 80 yards for a touchdown. Tate's kick provided the extra point.

Coach Mal Stevens has decided that he will start Woodrow Wittekind, sophomore blocking back, when New York University meets North Carolina at Ohio Field Saturday. Wittekind returned to the first-string back field in yesterday's practice session as the Violet polished its play for the week-end test.
Dr. Luther A. Harr, Pennsylvania Secretary of Banking, urged tonight that bankers be required to undergo training as thorough as lawyers and doctors.

More business men suffer injuries in office buildings and stores than while riding in automobiles, and more of them get hurt in and about their homes than when walking in the streets or using trains or public transportation services, it was revealed yesterday by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

City government can be divorced from politics if honest public officials are elected to office, Stanley M. Isaacs, Republican-Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, said last night in a University of the Air broadcast under the sponsorship of New York University over Station WEVD.

The first financing for the Central New York Power Corporation, a consolidation of twelve publicutility corporations operating in this State, will reach the market today in the form of an issue of $48,364,000 of general mortgage bonds, 3 3/4 per cent series, due in 1962.
Bob Feller of the Indians and his major league all-stars defeated a combination of Minneapolis and St. Paul American Association players, 7 to 5. tonight.

After having the evidence under heated discussion for exactly six hours, a General Sessions jury, with the foreman the only woman member, reported just before 6 o'clock last night inability to agree on a verdict in the abortion trial of Mrs. Emily F. Kane, 65 years old, of 233 Bleecker Street.

An admonition that "no business can afford to beguilty of fraud and deceit in presenting its case to the public" was voiced by Dean William H. Spencer of the University of Chicago in an address today before the National Restaurant Association Convention.

James R. Cherry of 40 West Seventy-seventh Street, who had been chief clerk of the trial term of the Bronx Supreme Court since Bronx County was organized in 1914, died yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Hospital after a month's illness. He was 66 years old.

Seventeen more claimants to the $877,598 estate of the late Ida E. Wood, widow of Benjamin Wood, New York publisher, were ruled out of the contest In a decision handed down by Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday.

The Committee for the Nation sent a telegram last night to President Roosevelt, urging him to raise the dollar price of gold from $35 to $41.34 an ounce as a means of offsetting the downward movement of commodity and security prices. He was asked to take this action through the power vested in him by the Gold Reserve Act of 1934.

Scott Lord, a retired New York lawyer and formerly fort five years Democratic leader of the Seventh Assembly District, Manhattan, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Sanger Brown, after a short illness. He was 84 years old.

Net assets of the General American Investors Company, Inc., on Sept. 30 amounted to $31,206,475, compared with $37,036,680 on Dec. 31, 1936, a decrease of $5,830,205. Unrealized appreciation was $6,106,826, against $14,421,055 at the end of 1936, a decrease of $8,314,229. There was a net profit of $794,819, after taxes, on securities sold in the nine months. Cash on Sept. 30 totaled $3,382,833, against $641,521 on Dec. 31.

Dividends and other cash payments amounting to $3,167,558 were distributed in the year ended on July 31 to policyholders and creditors of defunct insurance companies in this State, according to a report of the Bureau of Liquidations, Conservations and Rehabilitations, made public yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

Columbia's varsity and freshman cross-country schedules for the season were announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson. The varsity will engage in five meets with Princeton listed for the opener on Oct. 22.

A judgment for $2,386,468 against Joseph W. Harriman, president of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, was entered yesterday in the County Clerk's office by William R. Willcox, trustee in bankruptcy of the J. A. M. A. Realty Corporation, which was organized by Mr. Harriman to hold his family's property. The judgment was obtained by default when he failed to file an answer.

Baseball fans came to the opening world series game at the Yankee Stadium yesterday in a very calm and orderly manner. There was no crowding, no great excitement, nothing for the more than adequate force of policemen to do save direct patrons to the proper entrances.
After three stormy years in office, Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario was re-elected tonight by a majority almost as sweeping as that which first swept him into power in 1934.

Miss Sabra Roberts, daughter of Captain Frank Hamilton Roberts, Secretary of the Naval War College and Mrs. Roberts, has completed plans for her wedding on Saturday when she will become the bride of Smith Hempstone Oliver of New York.

A strong wave of opinion that President Roosevelt's speech in Chicago on the disturbed condition of the world represented a "warming up" to an approaching extensive national rearmament program swept the financial district yesterday, and the probable effect of any such proposals on the heavy industries was weighed.

To commemorate the hundredth anniversary of the birth of its sometime Professor of Chemistry, Dr. Charles F. Chandler, Columbia University is giving a series of memorial lectures, presenting a Chandler medal and inviting distinguished citizens to a Chandler memorial dinner.

A potent aerial attack with Vic Fusia, Manhattan back, as key man, was developed by Coach Chick Meehan in a two-hour drill at Innisfail Park, as he tuned the Jaspers' offensive formation for Saturday's game with Michigan State.

The market for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was erratic yesterday. After dipping sharply in the earlier trading, prices recovered somewhat under the impetus of the sharp upturn in stocks. Closing quotations revealed many new lows, especially among the second-grade rail issues, but prices generally were above the lowest of the day.

An appeal that the United States lend support to the League of Nations "by a statement of its concurrence" in efforts to stop Japan's war upon China was made yesterday by former Secretary of State Henry L. Stimson in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES discussing the Sino-Japanese situation.
Turkey will build a powerful fleet of 1,000 war planes, officials disclosed tonight. The announcement was timed on the eve of the scheduled military manoeuvres, unexpectedly postponed to next Sunday,

Dr. P. Ralph McFeely, school and police physician and president of the Parent-Teacher Association in Bogota, was arrested today on a charge of performing an illegal operation on Miss Eleanor Haynes, 22 years old, of New Milford. The girl,
President Roosevelt's speech at Chicago yesterday has had a more unfavorable reception here than his previous addresses of the same sort.
A commitee of prominent Protestants here is collecting funds in the name of the "United Christian Front Committee" to assist Spanish Catholics to combat anti-church influences in the civil war.

Edward B. Hall of Harris, Hall Co., Chicago, president of the Investment Bankers Association, announced yesterday that forums on regulation of the investment business, on the public utility industry, current investment problems,

Picturing a land of misery, starvation, insecurity and illness, where children cannot go to school because they have no shoes and are suffering from malnutrition and pellagra because of an inadequate diet, social workers from the mountainous areas of Tennessee, Kentucky and Virginia made a dramatic appeal for help at yesterday's sessions of the educational conference held by the Save the Children Fund at the Hotel McAlpin.

The Citizens National Committee, born of the Johnstown "right-towork movement" during the steel strike in Pennsylvania, announced yesterday that it had received a "very good response" to its appeal for a national convention committee.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas increased 1 per cent for the week ended Oct. 2, it was announced yesterday by, the United Parcel Service. An increase of the same amount was reported for the previous week.

September brought to New York City comparatively cool, smokeless, bright days, although rainfall was above normal, according to the monthly report, made public yesterday, of David R. Morris, meteorologist in charge of the Central Park Observatory of the Weather Bureau.

President Roosevelt's Chicago speech assailing war-making nations was greeted with deep satisfaction in Chinese Government circles today. His outspoken condemnation of ruthless warfare and the murder of women and children was taken to mean severe censure of Japan, and it created a feeling of strong American moral backing of China.

Redferne Hollinshead, former radio singer, who was tenors soloist of Grace Episcopal Church, New York, died this morning in St. John's Riverside Hospital Yonkers, after an illness of three weeks. He was 52 years old.

James W. Carter, acting for the Carter Coal Company and nine other producers of the Virginia-West Virginia fields, today presented to the National Bituminous Coal Commission their plan for the classification of coal, which they asked be substituted for the classification proposed by the district board.
Starting their rounds atter the rain had ceased this morning, sixty-nine golfers took part in the fourteenth annual women's. United States senior golf championship at the Westchester Country Club.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, Protestant opposition leader who is now in jail, has just become a father of his eighth child. How long it will be before the new father sees the baby depends on prosecuting authorities who are still collecting material against the minister.

Properties in Hudson County furnished the greater part of the activity in real estate deals reported from New Jersey yesterday. The four four-story buildings comprising the entire blockfront on Park Avenue, known as 507-11 Park Avenue, 104 Tenth Street and 105 Eleventh Street, in West New York, were sold by the Colonial Insurance Company to a client of Bedford,

The new Finance Minister, Vilhelm Buhl, introduced in Parliament today the budget for 1938-39, providing for an income of 447,000,000 kroner and expenditure of 475,000,000. This budget is the biggest Denmark has ever experienced although there are no unusual expenses.

Free sheeting of headsails, strongly advocated by American yachtsmen, was stressed yesterday as a real accomplishment by Philip J. Roosevelt, president of the North American Yacht Racing Union, back from the meeting in London, England, of the permanent committee of the International Yacht Racing Union, at which he and Clinton H. Crane were the North American delegates.

One of the most cherished luxuries of Ametcan women-their sheer silk hosiery-would be materially affected by a consumers' boycott on Japanese silk imported into this country, according to a representative of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers. Thousands of employes might also feel the brunt of such action, suggested as an effective' protest against hostilities in China, in the opinion of Alfred Hoffmann of Philadelphia.

Jim Londos, former heavyweight wrestling champion of the world, signalized his return to the mat game in these parts by throwing Vincent Lopez, rangy Los Angeles grappler, in the feature exhibition at the New York Hippodrome last night.

Downward price reductions ranging from 3/4 cent to 1 1/2 cents on various lines of colored yarn fabrics, and extensions of discounts on sheets, sheetings and pillowcases were announced yesterday, effective immediately, by Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills,

This Chinese capital was subjected to three Japanese air raids within twelve hours today, but only minor damage resulted, according to official reports. The raiders bombed military objectives in suburban districts and near-by airdromes.

Bitter resentment was voiced yesterday by leaders in the American Labor party over the desertion of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association and vice chairman of the American Federation of Labor committee for the reelection of Mayor La Guardia.
Rissia has begun her program looking to the purchase of prefabricated parts in this country for the construction of a battleship, but is cloaking the details in secrecy.

The National Society of Professional Engineers, alarmed by reports that C. I. O. members will attempt to invade its third annual convention this week to expound their doctrines, has determined to act as the spearhead of an attack by several national professional groups to prevent "coercion" of

Upton Sinclair's latest book, published by himself in Pasadena, is "The Flivver King: A Story of Ford-America." It is a novel of three generations of a family of Ford workers, from 1892 to the present.

The Good Will Fund, recently incorporated charitable and educational foundation, receives the major share of an estate exceeding $2,000,000 under provisions of the will of Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant-philanthropist, filed today in Suffolk Probate Court.

Senator Wright Patman surprised a capacity audience here today at the National Wholesale Druggists Association meeting when he describe a new bill which he will present to Congress at its next session. The bill deals with the ownership of retail outlets by manufacturers.

The City of New York, impatient over the long delay in the payment of taxes and interest on properties of the Manhattan Railway Company, took steps yesterday to create and buy in its own transfer of tax lien with a view to foreclosing and operating the company's lines, which are now held by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company under a 999-year lease.

With approximately twenty-five seats to be filled in the new City Council, 250 candidate have filed nominating petitions for the places, it was disclosed yesterday in a final check-up at the Board of Elections.

A sharp jump yesterday in registration in Manhattan and the Bronx, and a good showing in the other boroughs, brought this year's total for the first three days of registration to 960,403, only 1,669 below that for a similar period in 1933, when the last Mayoralty contest was fought.

Gertrud Wettergren, Swedish mezzo-soprano, arrived yesterday on the Swedish-American liner Kungsholm after several months absence. During the Summer she was in Sweden, singing and working on new roles for next Winter's opera season.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Mohammedan Mosques," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.; Egyptian collection, general tour, 2 P. M.
Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Whitmarsh gave a farewell dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Lynde Selden, who will leave soon on a trip around the world.
The American declaration on the Sino-Japanese conflict was termed a definite contribution to world stability in semi-official Austrian quarters today.

Germany's three major banks have now been returned exclusively to private ownership. The Dresdner Bank, one-time 90 per cent Government owned, announced the transfer of the last block of Government-owned stock to private hands today.

Proposals to amend the constitution and by-laws governing the Russian Orthodox Church in the United States and Canada were discussed at yesterday's sessions of the sixth general conclave of the church at the Russian Orthodox Cathedral, 105 East Houston Street.

To the meager clues that on Tuesday trapped two paroled convicts as suspects in the murder of Patrolman John Wilson in a Fulton Street hold-up on Sept. 23 were added yesterday a fingerprint and the accusations of three witnesses. The print was on the revolver of the slain man. Characterized by Police Commissioner Valentine as "as perfect a print as I ever saw,"

Headquarters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, announced yesterday that Generoso Pope, Italian publisher, had accepted the honorary chairmanship of the Italian division of the Mahoney-Taylor-Schneider campaign committee. In doing so Mr.

The Ameriean Embassy and Consulate, which formerly occupied separate buildings, are now in new premises that will house both departments. The two units are installed in a Georgian building, faced with brick and stone on a corner of Grosvenor Square, adjoining the Italian Embassy.

Henry G. Eaton, son of the late Fred Eaton, one-time Mayor of Los Angeles, has been killed in action with the Loyalist Army at Belchite in Spain, it was announced here today at the International Labor Defense headquarters.

Lewis Weiss and Frances Halek, the Queens Village couple found murdered last Sunday in the youth's coupe in Hollis Woods, Queens, were buried yesterday while detectives, searched in vain for clues to the killer.

Although his share of a holdup was only $9, Morris Geter, 27 years old, a Negro, was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge Streit to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing as a second offender. He previously had served a five-year term in St. Augustine, Fla., on an assault indictment.

Don Budge and Wayne Sabin last night defeated Germany's Davis Cup team of Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel under floodlights to annex the delayed final of the men's doubles in the forty-eighth Pacific Coast- tennis championships. Superior team work finally won for Budge and Sabin,

Nicholas Roche of 95-12 Creskill Place, Jamaica, who retired eight years ago after forty-five years of service as a member of the Sandy Hook Pilots Association, died on Tuesday. He would have been 79 years old on Oct. 15.

A real adventurer has just left us, and while he was here he made a drab, unexciting sort of place out of this newspaper office. Judd Emery Boynton, 25-year-old Californian, just back from a fourmonth trip through the Ecuadorian jungles, had an exciting time.

Wickham Steed, former editor of The Times of London, declared here yesterday afternoon that fascismswas "infinitely more insidious than communism." He spoke at a reception in his honor at the new headquarters of the English-Speaking Union, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
Angelo Musco, who was called Italy's leading comedian, died tonight of a heart attack suffered while rehearsing for a new play.

JUST as predicted by all and sundry, it was Don Vernon Gomez against Long Pants Hubbell to start the series. A couple of prominent leftists. Don Vernon whipped over a called strike on Joe Moore and the big argument was on.

Municipal Court Justice Arthur P. McNulty was warned yesterday that the Municipal Court, with more than 1,000,000 litigants a year, was "no bed of roses" when he took the oath of office in the court room at 6 Reade Street.
There is a growing feeling in Japanese circles here that changes in the high command of the Japanese Army in this area would be beneficial.

Columbia University and the American Chemical Society joined last night in opening a month's celebration of the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Charles Frederick Chandler, famous pioneer industrial chemist and founder of the School of Mines of Columbia University. The celebration,

Nature's whimsical little ways are driving the Warner Brothers to something close to a frenzy in their attempts to get the Mauch twins into as many pictures as possible before they outgrow the parts already planned for them.
In a decision apparently limiting the scope of the Committee for Industrial Organization, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a minority.

Betting on the outcome of the World Series took a bit of an upturn last night, according to Jack Doyle, Broadway commissioner. There seemed to be more Giant money in sight, despite the outcome of the opening game, but the odds naturally had shifted in favor of the Yankees.

So stiff was the opposition of the B squad this afternoon that the varsity scrimmaged against it for a half-hour without scoring. The reserves forced the regulars to punt again and again. Case, Ingram,
Under the temporary protection of a court writ, the Orangeburg dog racing track reopened tonight after being shut down since Sept. 16, when the track was raided for the second time this Summer.

Herbert R. Rutland was elected yesterday an assistant vice president of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company. The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed agent to redeem Gimbel Brothers, Inc., script certificates for $6 cumulative preferred stock.

This year's campaign of the United Hospital Fund will be opened officially on the night of Oct. 25 and will seek to raise $3,171,000 for the maintenance of the city's voluntary hospitals, it was announced yesterday afternoon at a tea and organization meeting of the women's division at the Hotel Biltmore.

Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto, sitting in Bridge Plaza court, Brooklyn, denied yesterday morning a motion to dismiss a complaint charging Isidore Kaufman and John Deegan, striking Brooklyn Eagle employes, with conspiracy.

Nelson W. Gage, chairman of the board of directors of the Gage Publishing Company, 232 Madison Avenue, and a breeder of fine cattle, died on Tuesday at his home in Delanson, N. Y., after a short illness. His age was 73.

The present Sino-Japanese war is not a conflict involving China or Japan or the peoples of' those two countries but is a struggle against the rule of military dictators, Dr. Leonard Hsu, special counselor of the Chinese 'Government to the United States for the investigation of trade and industries, yesterday declared at a luncheon given in his honor by Associated Boards for Christian Colleges in China at the Hotel Commodore.

Georgina Dieter, mezzo-contralto, gave a recital at Town Hall last night which elicited much sturdy applause from a large gathering. The youthful and comely vocalist, who is a native New Yorker, was not without previous experience before the public, having appeared here on occasion in operetta. But this was her debut on the local concert platform.
On the docket of the Interstate Commerce Commission are thirty-one cases involving the reorganization under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act, of as many railroads.

Mrs. Lillian Lowell Griswold, grandniece of President Emeritus A. Lawrence Lowell of Harvard, was married here last night to Henry Talbot de Vere Clifton of Lytham, England. The ceremony, which took place in the chapel of Boston University's School of Theology, was performed by Dr. F. Winslow Adams.

The West, where the President has been taking his soundings, is a fine country. The attitude of its people is more tolerant on public questions, more inclined to believe in the sincerity of both sides to a controversy, less disposed to personal reprisals. It is the granary,

Mrs. Charles Newbold of Wichita, present Kansas State champion, today thwarted Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare's ambition to win the women's national golf crown for the seventh time by defeating the Philadelphian, 2 and 1, in the third round of the tournament.

Protesting the alleged diversion of interest on the dollar obligations of the Municipality of Bogota, the Bondholders Committee for the Republic of Colombia has addressed a letter to Miguel A. Reuda, Mayor of that city.
The marriage of Miss Aimee du Pont to Walter F. Wickes Jr. was announced tonight by the parents of the bride, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont of Owls Nest, Greenville, Del.

Following a lower opening and intermittent flurries of selling up to midafternoon, the stock market yesterday managed a sizable rally, however technical, and closed substantially higher on the day. The turnover of 1,783,000 shares on the Stock Exchange was the largest since Sept. 27.

A valve in the boiler room of the steamship Brazos, 4,000-ton freighter of the Agwilines, Inc., burst at 10:30 A. M. yesterday and turned loose on six men live steam held at 185 pounds pressure. Three of the men, members of the crew, were killed and the others burned. Two city firemen doing rescue work also were burned.

The streptococci that infect human throats were found to be floating in the air of New York's public schools, subway cars, theatres and even in the open spaces of Central Park, it was revealed in a study of bacteria in the air of several types of locations in New York City, presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Publie Health Association in the session on public health engineering at the Hutel New Yorker.
The Times of London will publish the following tomorrow from an anonymous correspondent who is apparently in touch with recent events in Ethiopia:
Gold bullion on the open London market, in terms of British currency, off Id to 140s 61/2 per fine ounce. Price before British suspension of gold payments on Sept. 21, 1931, was 84s 9 3/4d.
G. Roland Heiss, veteran Atlantic City hotel man and manager for the last two years of the Shelburne, died today of a heart attack. His age was 55. Mr. Heiss was born in Danville, Pa;

A strike of 6,000 workers in 800 gasoline stations in Brooklyn, to take effect tomorrow morning, was ordered last night by Walter J. Burke, president of Local 20408 of the Gasoline Station Attendants Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, following rejection by the union of a contract offered by the Brooklyn Dealers Association, representing owners of the service stations.

Pleas for church unity throughout the world were expressed today by half a dozen distinguished speakers before a joint session of both houses of the general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, which is holding its fifty-second triennial meeting here.
Spanish Government forces, driving through rain and high winds, claimed small advances toward Jaca on the Aragon front south of the French border today.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, for several years an advocate of strict neutrality legislation, urged yesterday that the Neutrality Act be invoked in the Far East and warned of the danger that the United States might become involved in another foreign war under existing conditions.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek declared today in an interview: "Happily we learn that the State Department in Washington has condemned actions of aggression. For this upholding of international faith, justice and the sanctity of treaties, I am profoundly moved."
Assessments of $400,000 levied by Jersey City in 1935 and 1936 against personal property of the Colonial Life Insurance Company of America were set aside today by the State Board of Tax Appeals.

61st St, 338 E. 28x100.5; 1/2 interest; Anna Basteri to John Franceschini, 338 E 61st St; mtg $13,000 (50 cents). Park Ave, n e cor 108th St, 27x74; James A. Trowbridge Jr. to La Bouchere Realty Corp, 17 E 42d St. ($7). 5th St, 531 E, 24.11x97; Max Meyer to Dry Dock Savings Institution, consid, $1,000; foreclosure.

The Treasury will continue its weekly nine-month bill offerings of $50,000,000 on dct. 11 and 18, and on Oct. 25 will start weekly $50,000,000 bill offerings of the same type, but with maturity dates falling on or about March 15, when quarterly income tax payments are due, Secretary Morgenthau announced at his press conference today.

Radioscopes of the hands of Bronislaw Huberman, violinist, who was injured yesterday in the crash of an airliner at Palembang, Sumatra, showed today that the left radius was broken close to the wrist but was not moved from place, while two metacarpal bones of the right hand were broken.
Dr. George H. Williams, a retired physician, who practiced medicine for twenty-nine years at Beacon, N. Y., died last night in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 77 years old.

WORTH WORTH, LTD., men's apparel, 603 5th Ave.--Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankrubptcy Law, listing liabilities of $68,157 and assets of $140,570. Petitions Filed MESSER BROS., formerly at 1,589 Bathgate Ave.--Liabilities $4.366, no assets. The members of the firm, which has been dissolved, were Isidor and Mendel Messer.
A special board on battleship plans, whose members are prominent ship constructors and marine engineers, was announced today by Secretary Swanson.

Taking its stand in opposition to Mayor La Guardia's request that Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens be endorsed for re-election, the city-wide executive committee of the City Fusion party, at a meeting held last night, again endorsed its own candidate, Ambrose B. Acker, and instructed the law committee of the party "immediately to take steps to remove the candidacy of Mr. Harvey from the City Fusion party slate."
Claims paid by the railroads of the United States and Canada in the first six months of the year were the smallest on record, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, announced yesterday that the Republie of Cuba had signed a contract to participate in the fair. The contract provides for 10,000 square feet of covered space in the Hall of Nations and three acres in the amusement zone.

Following their respective governments' instructions, Lord Perth, the British Ambassador, and Jules Blondel, the French Charge d'Affaires, called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, this evening to inquire "in a friendly way" as to the reasons for the delay in Italy's answer to the Anglo-French invitation to discuss Spanish affairs.

A jury of six men and one alternate, all of whom declared to the defense that they were opposed to the C. I. O., was sworn in here today to try six former Tampa policemen on a charge of flogging Joseph A. Shoemaker to death on a lonely country road the night of Nov. 30, 1935, a few hours after he was freed from arrest as "a Communist."

Henry Wright Fisher, electrical engineer specializing in underground cables, died today at the Hillcroft Sanatorium near here at the age of 76. Since his retirement in 1930 Mr. Fisher had divided his time between this city and St. Petersburg. Fla.

The thirteen-story loft building at 344 West Thirty-eighth Street, on a plot 75 by 100 feet, has been sold by Charles Walzer, operator, who recently acquired the property, to an investor. The structure is said to have an annual rent roll of $65,000, and is reported to have been held at $325,000.
The 242-acre estate of Harris Hammond, which is a remnant of the 1,000-acre tract once owned by Joseph Bonaparte, brother of Napoleon, will be sold at auction at the Mount Holly Court House,

Prediction of curtailment in American production of rayon yarn in the remainder of this year and a report of continued expansion of productiOn of both rayon yarn and rayon staple fiber in Japan are contained in the current issue of Rayon Organoh, published yesterday.

Declaring that the acceptance of the Remington Rand Close-Shaver has been beyond the expectations of the manufacturer, E. R. Gray, acting manager of the General Shaver Corporation, Bridgeport, yesterday announced plans for an increased advertising campaign.

The Real Estate Club of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City will hold a dinner next Thursday evening at the Hotel Biltmore in honor of Emil Leitner, its chairman. Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission, will be guest speaker.

Shown in virtually perfect condition and moving about in impressive fashion, Ch. Pillicoc Rumpelstiltskin, standard black poodle dog, today won the chief honors as the fifty-fourth annual Danbury Agricultural Society all-breed show was concluded at the Danbury fair.

Plans for the proposed merger of the Frank Presbrey Company and Erwin, Wasey Co., Inc., have fallen through and "there will be no merger," it was stated yesterday by Charles Presbrey, president of the former agency, and H. D. Williams, vice president and general manage of Erwin, Wasey.

Falling for the fifth successive week, brokers' loans had dropped below $1,000,000,000 last Wednesday to a total of $982,000,000, according to the weekly condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, which was issued yesterday. The week's fall amounted to $48,000,000 and brought the net reduction in the figures since Sept. 1

For improvement with a six-story apartment house, the vacant plot of 80 by 110 feet at the southwest corner of West 227th Street and Hendrik Hudson Parkway, the Bronx, has been purchased by the MarCato Realty Corporation. Harry Volz was the seller and Isidore Katz represented the purchaser.

The resolution asking the A. F. of L. to boycott Japanese goods follows: "The militaristic fanatics now in control of Japan are waging an undeclared war and have killed and wounded many thousands of innocent people.

Fourteen of the fifteen general hospitals in Westchester County were occupied less than 75 per cent of capacity in 1936, according to an article in the October bulletin of the Westchester County Medical Society, published today.
To Stratford Hall. home of the Lees of Virginia, will be presented by the General Society of Colonial Wars Tuesday an entrance gate and gate house.
During the week ended -Oct. 6 member bank reserve balances decreased $30,000,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Williams and Mr. and Mrs. George W. Krug gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Amelia Fullan and William F. Mohan Jr., who will be married on Oct. 16 in Forest Hills, Queens, and for Mr. and Mrs. William Moore, who returned recently after passing a year in Stockholm, Sweden.

The marriage of Miss Anne Iglehart Sanford, daughter of John L. Sanford and the late Mrs. Sanford, to Daniel Boone Dugan, son of Mrs. Ferdinand C. Dugan, took place this evening at SS. Philip and James Church.

On 512-514 Broome St Giacomo and Nicolina Cocozziello gave two mortgages for $6,000 each, both due April 2, 1943, at 4 per cent, one to Carminello Cocozziello and the other to Vincenzo Cocozziello. Two mortgages for $9,000 each on 328 and 330 W 19th St, held by the Franklin Savings Bank from Chelsea Estates, Inc, Josef Nystad, president, were extended to Sept 27, 1940, with interest reduced from 5 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent.

The United States will accept an invitation to. the parley of the signatories of the Nine-Power Pacific Treaty, Secretary Hull revealed yesterday. But this country will avoid taking the initiative on any measures.

Charles F. Hosford, chairman of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, advocated today permanent regulation of the soft coal industry by the Government, but under a plan evolved by the industry Itself.

Muted strings sighed music of New York's gaslight and multipetticoat period in the WaldorfAstoria's grand ballroom last night at the golden wedding banquet of Oscar of the Waldorf and his wife, Mrs. Sophie Bertisch Tschirky.
The Far Eastern diplomatic situation developing from Geneva and now from Washington with declarations against Japan is seriously embarrassing Germany.

143d St, 270 W; to two 5-story tenements and stores; New York Savings Bank, 81 8th Ave, owner; R. Gottlieb, architect; cost $20,000. 10th St, 380 E; to 5-story tenement and stores; Vincent Cloffi, 336 Broome St, owner; Carl B. Cali, architect; cost $10,000. 8th Ave, 2,442; to 5-story tenement and stores; Beatever Holding Corp, 123 W 44th St, owner; S. Walter Katz, architect; cost $3,000.

John W. Davis, chairman of the 1937 United Hospital Campaign Committee, said yesterday afternoon that "it would be an endless misfortune for the people of New York if all their hospital services should be under political control."
Today's events: Joseph Knitzer, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; WPA Greenwich Concert Orchestra, chorus and soloists in all-Russian opera concert, Theatre of Music, 8:45 P. M.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, announced yesterday that it had signed agreements with nine companies engaged in the transportation of coal by water, calling for wage increases and improved working conditions, which will affect 2,240 men on fifty-six ships.
Directors of the Wall Street Riding Club announced yesterday that Jesse Gordon of Kuhn, Loeb Co. has been re-elected president, Francis W. Schweikhardt of J. R.

Gross assets, $34,714; net, $31,868. To son, Thomas L. Dowling Jr., $100; grandsons, Lynn T. Dowling and Donald Cuming, and granddaughter, Barbara J. Fincke, $100 each in trust; daughters, Lillian R. Dowling, specific realty and one-fourth of residuary estate; Edith L. Muller, Ruth M. Wyngard and Gertrude J. Fincke, one-fourth of residuary estate each. Chief assets: real estate, $20,100;

The movement of share prices yesterday was indecisive. The stock market opened generally lower and rallied briskly to establish the day's high mark in the second hour; leading groups moved in hesitant fashion until the final hour when many leading issues sold off rapidly. The closing was irregular.

Faced by expenses too great to meet and confessing that its home is now "too large for our purpose," the Women's University Club announced at a dinner meeting last night that it must dispose of its building at 106 East Fifty-second Street.

Defense tactics against Pennsylvania's passing game were stressed today in the final contact work of the Yale eleven for Saturday's game. No scrimmaging was essayed, but assignments worked out to check Penn's driving ground attack were reviewed in a dummy session.

Princeton University's intercollegiate sports program, providing for forty-two teams in fifteen branches of sport, was operated at a profit of $16,612 for the fiscal year ending last June 30, according to the annual financial report of the Princeton Athletic Association published today in The Alumni Weekly.

COMPTON MACKENZIE continues to spread on the record his panoramic story of a young Scotsman caught in the cross-draught of fate. Having borne John Pendarves Ogilvie into the world last Winter on a brisk eastern gale ("The East Wind of Love" was the title of the first book), he now shows him facing maturity and the warm South. The 750 pages resulting are called "The South Wind of Love."*
A strike against the eight affiliated Greyhound Bus systems was called today by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen to enforce demands for a blanket contract.

Mayor La Guardia asked Controller Frank J. Taylor yesterday to start proceedings designed to give the city title, by means of foreclosure of liens for unpaid taxes, to the elevated structures and franchise rights of the Manhattan Railway Company.

The property known as the J. Spencer Weed estate, consisting of about fifty-one acres, at New Vernon, near Morristown, N. J., has been sold by the Blue Mill Land Company, Inc., to Gustav H. Koven 2d of Summit for his country home. home.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports, bringing among her passengers General Diego Aracena Aguilar, commander of the Chilean air force; Professor Ross G. Harrison, Sterling Professor of Biology at Yale University;

The incoming president and a former head of the American Society of Civil Engineers condemned in addresses before the society today many of the Government's public works projects, including TVA, the Grand Coulee Dam, the Fort Peck Dam and Passamaquoddy, as economically unsound.
THE NEW WORLD, by Edgar Lee Masters. (Appleton - Century, $2.50.) An epic poem. DANIEL AIRLIE, by Robert Hichens. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50.) A novel about English theatre life.

Universal Television Corporation, New York City, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 500,000 shares of capital stock, $2.50 par value, to be offered at $2.50 a share.

Justice Daniel W. O'Donoghue of Federal District Court denied today the Alabama Power Company's petition for a temporary injunction restraining Rural Electrification Administration loans to the Cherokee County Electric Membership Corporation of Northern Alabama.
Dr. Hugh R. Monro, banker and philanthropist of Montclair, N. J., has been elected president of the American Tract Society, it was announced yesterday.

President, Roosevelt's visit to Buenos Aires will be commemorated by a plaque at the entrance hall of the American Embassy. The inscription on the plaque follows: "The thirty-second President of the United States of America, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, resided in this embassy from Nov. 30 to Dec. 21, 1936.

Nearly 100 representatives of eighteen New York State villages of the first class gathered yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel, Park Avenue and Forty-first Street, and adopted a resolution petitioning the Constitutional Convention meeting next year to grant home rule powers to first-class villages. William P.
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Edmund L. Palmieri, law secretary to Mayor La Guardia, over WBIL (1,100 Kc.), 6:15 to 6:30 P. M.

The marriage of Miss Constance Stewart Herbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Herbert, to Harrison C. Bettes, son of Mrs. Frederick P. Radcliffe of Great Neck and the late Joseph Bettes of Paris, Texas, took place here this evening at the home of the bride's parents.

Illness forced four "stay down" miners to the surface of shaft No. 7 of the Lehigh Navigation Coal Company here today but they left thirty-nine of their striking companions 1,200 feet underground, saying they were determined to stay there "until they die" unless the company granted their wage demands.

To study hand papermaking in Kashmir and Bengal, where it is much the same today as it was 800 years ago, Dard Hunter, paper expert of Chillicothe, Ohio, will sail tomorrow on the American Pioneer liner Unicoi for a five months' trip to India.

The report of the Lehman Corportion for the third quarter of 1937, issued yesterday, revealed sales of 228,000 shares of stock and $836,000 face value of bonds in the period, contrasted with purchases of only 71,300 shares of stock and $21,000 of bonds. Cash in banks was $2,273,917 on Sept. 30, against $1,502,671 three months before, and United States Government securities were $5,628,938, against $1,028,938, valued at cost in both instances.

Awards for engineering construction, which totaled $210,511,000 during the five weeks of September, show a 1 per cent average weekly decrease when compared with the four-week August total of $170,068,000 and a 15 per cent average weekly decrease from the four-week month of September, 1936,

James J. Johnston, athletic enterprise, in 1,501 Broadway; Fred S. Roemer, shoppers bureau, in 51 E 42d St; House of Jackson, Inc, novelties, in 5 E 47th St; Martin Munkacsi, commercial art and photography, in 480 Lexington Ave; Harry Raphaelian, in 45 W 57th St; Francis T. Schaenen, in 43-5 W 34th St; Wm. A. White Sons, broker.

The house of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Krug at White Oak Farm was destroyed by fire of undetermined origin early this morning. Dr. and Mrs. Krug and members of the household scarcely had time to escape with their belongings.

The play-by-play description of the second game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows: FIRST INNING GIANTS-Ruffing burned over the first pitch of the game for a called strike on Moore.

Plans to include all transients in the country in the voluntary unemployment registration from Nov. 16 to Nov. 20 were announced today by John D. Biggers, administrator, during a speech at a luncheon at the National Press Club.
Lacrosse is being dropped as an intrcollegiate sport at Brown as an economy measure, Dr. Frederick W. Marvel, athletic director, announced tonight.

Thomas Edward Ray, district manager of the New York territory for. Swift Co., will be tendered a dinner by the company at the Hotel Commodore tomorrow evening on the occasion of his retirement after thirty-six years of continuous service with the company.
