No statute ever set in motion the machinery for a more complete destruction of private property rights than the Publio Utilities Act of 1935, John F. McLane,

Initial steps to stop the so-called celebrity nights in hotels and night clubs were taken yesterday at a directors' meeting of the Theatre Authority, organized to eliminate racketeering in benefit performances, in the Authority's office at 1,619 Broadway.

Terming the New Jersey Republican platform "an insult to the intelligence of the working men and women of the State," Labor's Nonpartisan League for New Jersey withdrew its conditional endorsement of State Senator Lester H. Clee, Republican Gubernatorial nominee, in a statement released for publication today.
The Annalist reported yesterday that its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices had dropped on Tuesday to 93.0 (1926=100), decline of 1 point in the week and the lowest number since June 15.
David Bunim, formerly with Schenley Products Company, has been elected president of the Gibson Distilling Company, which was founded in 1837, it was announced yesterday.
Three ships of the United Fruit Company fleet will discontinue service as passenger ships and limit their activities to the transportation of freight, it was learned yesterday.

Lieut. Comdr. Charles R. Longbottom, merchant skipper who made many dangerous voyages through submarine zones during the World War, died on Wednesday morning of heart disease at his home, 95 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn.

Fishermen, as a general rule, need have no fear that legislation of one form or another will threaten their sport, but hunters are faced almost constantly with some new statute which involves a new list of "do's" or -"don'ts," or an additional taxation.

Miss Helen Josephine Hughes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. Hughes of 562 West End Avenue, was married yesterday morning in the Church of St. Gregory the Great to Robert John Robinson, son of Mrs. Robert N. Robinson of New Rochelle and the late Mr. Robinson.

Lloyd L. Spencer has been appointed general sales manager to the Stromberg-Carlson Telephone Manufacturing Company of Rochester, it was announced yesterday by George A. Scoville, vice president and general manager. For the last nine years he has been sales manager for Gross Sales, Inc.,

Pope Pius XI and General Jan Christian Smuts are the only great statesmen in a world swayed by emotional appeals, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared last night at the annual dinner of the Columbia Men's Faculty Club honoring new faculty appointees.

The stock market effected a modest turnabout today, shaking off the nervousness and liquidation that ruled trading in recent sessions. While most sections improved with good gains here and there, the volume of business was on a small scale.
Attorney General Cummings at a press conference has renewed the recommendation he made last April for a commission to study the need of changes in the anti-trust acts.

Liquidation on a broad scale developed in the wheat market today and prices on the Board of Trade here and in Winnipeg and Minneapolis were as much as 5 cents a bushel lower, the permissible limit for one day, with most deliveries closing at the extreme decline. Kansas City was 4 7/8 cents lower.
A number of German miners who crossed the border daily to work in French pits have lost their German passports, it was disclosed today.

Senator Borah told The Christian Science Monitor by telegraph today that in defending Justice Hugo Black in the Senate last August against charges of Ku Klux Klan membership, he did so in the belief that the then Alabama Senator "was not at the time and for years had not been a member of the Klan."

Nineteen scholarships have been awarded for study at the Institute of Musical Art for the season 1937-38 as a result of competitive examinations held during the past week, it was announced yesterday by Oscar Wagner, dean of the Juilliard School.

Clients of Samuel Hurwitz have purchased the following mortgages for investment: $18,000 on the six-story apartment at 320 E 103d St, Manhattan; $10,000 on the factory building at 52-6 Garden St, Brooklyn; $1,250 on the brick taxpayer at 422 Adelphi St. Brooklyn. A second mortgage of $5,000 has been placed by Felix Bartfeld on the five-story tenement at 106 Macdougal St, Manhattan, for the 106 Macdougal Street Corp, George DeMartini, president.
Execution of fourteen more persons on charges of grain spoiling were reported today from Soviet Union Provinces. Two executions were carried out in Siberia and the remainder in the Caucasus.

The resignation of Dr. John H. Denbigh as principal of the Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, effective in June, 1938, was announced last night by Lewis W. Francis, president of the school's board of trustees. Dr. Denbigh has headed the school since 1918.

In order to give the state of war a more democratic status, President Getulio Vargas today issued an order giving control to an executive committee. The committee will be composed of a civilian representative and one representative from the army and navy.

The Arnold Bernstein liner Gerolstein arrived at her Hoboken pier yesterday with a section of her aft rail missing and a part of the deck crushed. The damage was caused by a collision at sea south of Halifax last Tuesday with the German freighter Frankenwald, also bound for New York.
The voter is just as much a part of our system of government as the officials he elects. His duties are more limited than theirs,

The Public Service Commission denied yesterday the application of the Orange and Rockland County Electric Company for permission to issue $581,400 of 5 per cent preferried stock. The company proposed to use the proceeds for the redemption of an equal amount of its outstanding 6 per cent preferred stock.
Although the regular session of the Legislature was recessed last Spring until after the general election next month, Governor Hoffman said today a special session might be necessary earlier.

Almost 5,000 employers, more than a third of the number registered in New Jersey, have failed to make contributions and reports to the State Unemployment Compensation Commission for August and they will be fined $1 a day for each day of delinquency, the commission announced today.

Over the strenuous objections of the Commonwealth, Roy and Jack Garr were released under $20,000 bond each today to await trial Oct. 18 on charges of murdering Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt. At the same time the court ordered the $20,000 bond of their brother, Dr. E. S. Garr, forfeited when he failed to appear in court this morning for arraignment.

The governing council of the American Public Health Association, which is holding its sixty-sixth annual convention here this week, adopted a resolution yesterday calling for a study by a special committee to devise means by which organized medicine and Federal agencies would cooperate to "extend public health work to meet modern needs."
Louis J. Bailey, librarian of the Queens Borough Public Library in New York, was nominated tonight for president of the New York Library Association. Formal election will take place Saturday.

On Hill 204 overlooking the Marne and this town where American forces first proved their valor in the World War, Americans and their French comrades today dedicated a great monument to the dead of that memorable battle.

An interpretation of its credit policy, in which it emphasized that the Federal Reserve banks should adopt a liberal attitude in times of threatened business recession and restraint when expansion appeared to be too rapid, was given today by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System in its October bulletin, in which it reviewed the new regulations, effective on Oct. 1, covering discounts and advances.

A sudden spurt in registration yesterday lifted the total figure for the first four days this year to 1,317,367, which is 40,516 more than for the same period in 1933, the year of the last Mayoralty campaign.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's first utterance on current public questions since the Archdiocese of Detroit was created drew from the new Archbishop tonight the comment that he used "unfortunate words."

Although Rachel Crothers has been missing from our theatre for five years, all is forgiven now. "Susan and God," which was put on at the Plymouth last evening, is one of her best plays. Looking squarely at the Oxford movement, she has seen what is in it and what it lacks, for she has an enormous fund of common sense.

There were 6,285,000 unemployed in the United States in August, an increase of nearly 150,000 over the preceding month, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Lieut. Col. James Arthurs, member of the Canadian Senate since 1934, died at his home here last night. He was 71. Senator Arthurs represented Parry Sound, Ont., as a member of the Conservative party in the House of Commons since 1908.
Henry McBride, former Governor of Washington, died today after fifty-five years of public service at the age of 81. He served as Chief Executive of the State from 1901 to 1905.

Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, tonight paid high tribute to the French Government for the manner in which it handled its currency difficulties of the last few weeks. Sir John spoke at the annual bankers' dinner here.
All of the twenty-five chain store and mail order companies which to date have reported sales for September and nine months showed increases over the corresponding periods of 1936.

A large city is no place for dogs, or for people, either. One can't, as a rule, raise vegetables, chase squirrels, climb mountains, take a walk without being stopped every minute or two by traffic lights, or do a number of other healthful and natural things in a city.

This week's Federal Reserve reports present the paradoxical record of a simultaneous net fall of $30,000,000 in member bank reserve balances and a net rise of $30,000,000 in member bank excess reserves.
The plan of recapitalization of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation was declared effective yesterday by the board of directors.
-A Spanish Insurgent court martial decreed death by shooting today for Harold E. Dahl, American aviator, but the sentence was reprieved immediately.
Governor Lehman issued a warning yesterday that the State Constitutional Convention might be a failure unless interest in it was stimulated to insure the election of the proper type of delegates.

" Wise Tomorrow," now visiting in Baltimore, yesterday decided to have its Broadway premiere a week from tonight instead of next Tuesday; the delay, according to the management, being occasioned by an injury suffered by Edith Barrett. one of its leading players.....

Using a recently developed instrument which measures the efficiency of residential wiring much as a light meter grades the intensity of light, electrical manufacturers, contractors and others will shortly start a drive to re-wire homes now using antiquated equipment, Earl Whitehorne, editor of Electrical Contracting, told the closing session of the second annual conference of the International Association of Electrical Leagues yesterday.

Dr. John H. Finley was elected president of the National Recreation Association at a meeting yesterday at its headquarters, 315 Fourth Avenue. John G. Winant, chairman of the Social Security Board, was elected first vice president.

Word has been received here of the birth of a son to S. Roger Tyler Jr., United States vice consul in Mexico City, and Mrs. Tyler on Wednesday in Los Angeles. Mrs. Tyler is the former Miss Zora H. Cheever of New York.
A. L. Moon is in charge of the new department of A. W. Benkert Co., Inc., that will deal in Federal Housing Administration mortgages.

Definite announcement was made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today that the United States would accept an invitation to the conference projected under the Nine-power treaty to consider measures for meeting problems raised by Japan's invasion of China.
Prince Fumitaka Konoe, son of the Premier of Japan,
Prices of cotton fluctuated narrowly yesterday on the Cotton Exchange as the trade evened up commitments in advance of today's Government report on the crop.

The rising cost of foodstuffs, especially beef, and efforts to expand the American habit of eating out were cited today as two major problems confronting the restaurant business by Henry I. Dunnock of Baltimore, newly elected president of the National Restaurant Association.

Seventeen seamen, ranging in age from 18 to 20, were held tonight in jail for "safekeeping" after they refused to sail for Japan with a cargo of scrap- iron loaded here. Their vessel was the motorship Wind, out of Tonsberg, Norway.
The women's senior golf championship of the United States went to Mrs. John H. Lapham of New Canaan, Conn., today at the Westchester Country Club.

August Thiele, 64, today had Germany's record for paternal prolificacy. His thirty-eighth child was born. Thirty-four children and sixty grandchildren are alive. Herr Thiele married three times, two of his wives having-died.
William J. Neville, 38-year-old Genesee County District Attorney, was found dead in his home tonight, a victim of what Medical Examiner Peter J. Di Natale said was a self-inflicted bullet wound.

Circuit Court Judge Edwin T. Dickerson took under advisement today a stockholders' petition for liquidation of Continental Shares, Inc., one-time $150,000,000 investment trust founded by Cyrus S. Eaton of Cleveland.

Declaring that President Roosevelt's Chicago speech had brought "decisive moral support to the efforts of Britain and France to preserve peace in Europe," Premier Camille Chautemps, addressing the American Club today, said that French opinion was in the most complete agreement with every word the President uttered.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday that at some future date he would tell why a young "gorilla" named Johnny Dioguardi, who lived on the lower East Side, had escaped conviction on a number of arrests before he received a prison sentence after pleading guilty to operating a trucking racket.

Trading on the typical New Yorker's way of being free and easy with his money and his habit of being in a hurry to go places, several enterprising young men did a rushing business after the world series baseball game yesterday by selling four nickels for a quarter to homeward-bound fans, enabling them to get into subway stations without having to wait in line for change.

A banking group composed of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Goldman, Sachs Co., Hemphill, Noyes Co., A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., and Charles Clark Co. obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,245,000 of general improvement bonds of Union County, N. J.
Reports that a ransom demand had been made for the return of the kidnapped Charles S. Ross stirred new interest in the case tonight, eleven days after the abduction.

On what a spokesman laconically described as "a sight-seeing trip," Vittorio Mussolini, son of the Italian Premier, arrived in New York yesterday for a brief visit before going to Washington, where, it is reported, he will call on President Roosevelt.

The Argo Oil Company declared an extra dividend of 15 cents and the regular semi-annual dividend of 10 cents a share. Columbia Gas and Electric Directors of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation increased the dividend yesterday with the declaration of 25 cents a share to common stockholders.

The line-up for the third game of the world series, to be played at the Polo Grounds today, shows one shift among the Yankees, George Selkirk moving up ahead of Myril Hoag against a righthand pitcher. The batting order follows:

For the second successive year Lafayette is making a new start in football. E. A. (Hooks) Mylin has been called in from Bucknell by Esky Clark to undertake the task of restoring to the Leopards the high position they held on the gridiron in the days of Jock Sutherland and the early years of Herb McCracken's tenure.

Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., New York City, have filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Cormpany Act of 1935 for exemption as a holding company on the ground that their holdings in Northern Oklahoma Gas Company are solely for the purpose of resale and that their business is that of a broker and dealer.
Arturo Godoy, holder of the heavyweight championship of South America, and Nathan Mann of New Haven will meet in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome tonight.

Hard work ended last night for a team which, more than any other in recent years in the East, finds itself on what the movies call the spot. This morning at Ithaca, where there is a college .holiday, the Cornell squad will hold a light workout and this afternoon entrain for Princeton.

Virginia Rea, whose vocalism on radio programs during the last decade has brought her wide acclaim, gave a recital at Town Hall last night. This was not the soprano's first appearance on the local concert stage, for she made her debut in this city in 1923 at Aeolian Hall.
Trinidad batsmen ran up 91 runs for the loss of one wicket when stumps were drawn in their second innings against British Guiana for the intercolonial cricket championship today.

President Roosevelt departed at 11 o'clock tonight for Washington there to plunge into the delicate problems noted in his speech at Chicago, in which he pledged concerted action by the peace-loving nations to "quarantine" aggressors and treaty breeakers.

Members of a committee of one Hundred, which recently was organized in behalf of Irvington House, a sanatorium for cardiac children in Irvington-on-Hudson, will meet today at a luncheon at the Madison, when reports will be made on the committee's informal campaign to secure 1,000 new contributors.
A men's fashion show, with eight professional male manikins who displayed the latest creations for the near future, was given yesterday in the Sert Room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Yielding to rabbinical appeals and requests of city officials, the Federation of Kosher Butchers voted last night to discontinue its stoppage and to reopen tomorrow night the 5,000-odd member butcher shops in the metropolitan area which have been closed since Saturday in protest against what they contend is an excessive wholesale price of meat.
Canadian wheat in storage in the week ended on Oct. 1 was 74,809,000 bushels, of which 17,886,000 bushels were durum, according to the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith took part yesterday afternoon in the thirty-fifth anniversary celebration of Saks-Thirty-fourth Street. He presented a check on behalf of the store to representatives of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, beneficiary of the seven-day fete, and gave a brief talk on old New York.

Justice Francis Bergan of the State Supreme Court directed the recently created State Board of Standards and Appeals today to act "promptly" on the application of a Jamestown shop union for approval of its charter.

Resolutions urging the United States Government to enforce an embargo against Japan and join hands with other Governments to maintain peace in the Far East were adopted yesterday by the national convention of the Transport Workers Union.

Elias Rosenpaum, a prominent business man here, died yesterday at his home after a long illness. His age was 58. Mr. Rosenbaum's record here included leadership in the banking, building and loan, title insurance and furniture fields.

An action to recover $100,000 from Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers of America, an A. F. of L. affiliate, for alleged breach of contract was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court.
Certain dividend adjustments next year are planned by the Connecticut Life Insurance Company, James L. Loomis, president, stated yesterday.
Dramatic political developments are expected following the sudden Cabinet council presided over by President Ignaz Moscicki in the presence of Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz and Colonel Adam Koc.

Mr. and Mrs. John L. Tonnele of 829 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Reva Marie Tonnele, to Thomas Dunn Whittelsey, son of Mrs. Daniel Ingersoll Whittelsey of Babylon, L. I.,

Lumber production declined much more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index slumped to 77.8, its lowest point since the week ended Feb. 20. The figure was 85.0 for the previous week, while for the week ended Oct. 3, 1936, it stood at 90.2.

Thomas Neson Perkins, one time member of the World War Reparations Commission, senior member of the Harvard Corporation and former president and chairman of the board of the Boston Maine Railroad, died today at his Westwood home.

After Governor Earle had voiced "utter disgust" with Philadelphia lawyers who refused to serve as prosecutors in the present grand jury investigation into vice and crime, Charles J. Margiotti, State Attorney General, announced this evening that he had found a sufficient number of "available" men to help him.

The added inducement of splitting up erstwhile solid blocks of reserved seat tickets into single game passports did not have the fans breaking down the gates to get into the Yankee Stadium yesterday. In fact there were fewer persons present than there had been th day before.

Vernon Kennedy checked the Cubs' heavy artillery with three hits today to conquer the National Leaguers, 3 to 1, and hoist the White Sox to even terms in the second game of Chicago's twenty-second baseball championship series.

The RKO-Radio version of "Stage Door," which was opened at the Music Hall yesterday, is not merely a brilliant picture (although that should be enough), but happens as well to be a magnificently devastating reply on Hollywood's behalf to all the catty little remarks that George Kaufman and Edna Ferber had made about it in their play.

Between the tentatively emerging foreign policy described by the President in his Chicago speech and the Neutrality Act which is already on the statute books there is a fundamental conflict in philosophy.

The Rev. Frederick Sheibler Miller, Presbyterian missionary at Chosen, Korea, from 1892 until his retirement last December, died in that Far Eastern city, according to word received here. The cablegram did not give the date nor details of his death.
Coincident with the expiration by limitation yesterday of Townsend, Graff Naumburg, announcement was made of the formation of two new New York Stock Exchange firms.

For the first time since the halcyon days when a stocky little redheaded girl by the name of Alexa Stirling came out of Atlanta to begin a long reign as queen of America's women golfers, the South is once more assured of having a representative in the final of the national women's championship.

A longrange and heavily armored bombing plane, superior to anything of its kind in the world, according to military experts, is being developed for the navy. It will weigh in excess of fifty tons, probably sixty tons, and will have a wing span of about 170 feet, it was learned today.

Plans to raise $1,000,000 as their share of the $6,250,000 New YorkBrooklyn Federation campaign were outlined yesterday by the women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities at an all-day conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, attended by 1,200 volunteer members.
Five members of the Absecon, N. J., Fire Department and the community's garbage collector were arraigned today before Common Pleas Judge Joseph Corio here on an indictment charging them with arson.

Princess Concetta Leone de Nigeratze, former New York stenographer, received a "conditional pardon" today after having served ten months of an eight-year sentence for killing her second husband, Vladimir Nigeratze, Georgian prince.

The report of the Pacific Finance Corporation of California and subsidiaries covering the first nine months of this year was issued yesterday. It showed a net profit of $1,267,221 after provision for normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before surtax on undistributed profits.

Mayor La Guardia's sharp dispute with Controller Frank J. Taylor over the $12,000,000 shortage in the 1938 budget is expected to continue today, when the Board of Estimate convenes in City Hall at 10:30 for an executive session on the tentative budget.

With the Yankees ahead of the Giants by two games to none, Jack Doyle's odds in favor of the Ruppertmen took another rise last night. The betting commissioner has made it 5 to 1 against the Giants and 1 to 6 against the Yankees to take the series.
A general decline in wholesale prices in the week ended on Oct. 2 scaled down the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics by more than onehalf of a point, according to an official announcement today.
Most commodity futures worked irregularly lower yesterday in fairly active trading on the local Exchanges. Coffee and cocoa continued to register new low levels.

Columbia University has received $301,830 since June in 107 gifts endowing fellowships, scholarships and research, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday. The largest contribution, made by the Rockefeller Foundation, was $75,000 to finance research.

Business in the Pittsburgh district showed a further sharp decline last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburg. The bureau's index of business, adjusted for seasonal changes, stood at 112.4 per cent of the 1923-25 average last week, a decline of 3.1 points from the week ended Sept. 25.

A thirty-four-page typewritten document containing a list of persons and firms in various parts of the country who contributed to the Citizens Committee during the early weeks of the Bethlehem Steel strike was turned over to the National Labor Relations Board today.

A preview of a series of rooms featuring a collection of antique furniture and art accessories, creating a new trend in decoration, was given yesterday afternoon on the seventh floor of Lord Taylor's store, Fifth Avenue at Thirtyeighth Street. The rooms will be open today for public inspection.
In so many words the State Department, acting on instructions from the President and as an implement of his Chicago speech, has named Japan as the aggressor in the Far East.

The weekly statement of the Bank of Canada, issued today, shows that the bank's holdings of Dominion and Provincial Government short-term securities, which have been increasing steadily in recent weeks, rose to $69,113,094 from $63,253,235 a week ago.

Although some improvement developed in sales of women's wear wool goods in the last week, men's wear was dull and activity was largely confined to sampling of new lines of Spring suitings and topcoatings, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday.

Charles Horace Rathbone, oil prospector in the "wildcat days" of the Eighties in Pennsylvania, Ohio, the West and Mexico, died yesterday after a long illness at his suite in the Hotel McAlpin. His age was 84.
Tomorrow's sun will rise upon a celebration momentous in the history of the nation, which Oberlin College, progenitor of the movement it commemorates, regards with a gravity akin to prayerfulness.

State motor policemen questioned Harry Bates, a 37-year-old father of two, tonight about the slaying of his 11-year-old cousin, Vallie Bates, whose body was taken from an abandoned mine airshaft near Latrobe.

A1though Albert Edward, formerly England's Edward VIII, will be described with royal honors, the Almanach de Gotha will ignore his wife in the section devoted to royalty in the 1938 edition. The new volume will be published late in November.

With Jim Schwenk back in the lineup, Army will start the team against Columbia Saturday that opened against Clemson College last week. Schwenk did not take part in a scrimmage today but was at his quarter-back position for assignment drill.

Persons prominent in the dry goods and educational fields attended funeral services today for Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director and treasurer of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, who died Tuesday at his home here.

Mrs. Ellen C. du Pont Meeds of Wilmington, Del., was married to Robert Wheelwright of Philadelphia here last night in the apartment of her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. John Willcox Donaldson of the Pierre, by the Rev, Minot Simons.

Denunciation of the board of directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and E. S. Ballard, special counsel to the railroad, for their refusal to disclose facts pertinent to the reorganization of the Missouri Pacific and to the Senate's investigation of railroad finances, was contained in a petition filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by a committee for holders of bonds of the Missouri Pacific headed by Charles A. Beard.
Frank Wright Moxley, for twentyfive years an attorney in New York, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 3,900 Greysfone Avenue, Riverdale.
William Bates Ferguson, who studied medicine, became a lawyer and finally abandoned both to become one of the country's leading photographic experts, died today at the age of 84.

Order received by the General Electric Company in the first nine months this year amounted to $305,276,556, an increase of 44 per cent over the $211,891,038 received during the same period last year, Gerard Swope, president, announced today.
Persons who participated in making the public choices here today had little reason to cheer as the favorites fell like wooden soldiers on a program featured by the running of the North Beach Purse.

The New York Alumni Association of Wesleyan held a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Martinique for Harold Sanford Wood, newly appointed director of athletics and Professor of Physical Education at Wesleyan. The luncheon was presided over by John G. Paine, alumni president.

The American Federation of Labor convention will not only concur with President Roosevelt and the League of Nations in holding Japan responsible for the conflict in the Far East, but will also adopt a stringent resolution favoring boycott of Japanese goods, similar to that adopted by the British labor movement.

At the recent meeting in Philadelphia under the auspices of the American Academy of Political and Social Science to discuss our Neutrality Act, Dr. Buell thought the act would make the United States virtually an ally of Japan.

Builders, financing agencies and buyers are paying more attention than ever before to structural soundness of buildings and the type of materials being used in them. Some suburban developers have noted that prospects are displaying a surprising knowledge of lumber, brick, roofing materials,
Roy Worters, goal-keeper of many National Hockey League campaigns with the New York Americans, has been placed on the voluntarily retired list at his own request, Manager Red Dutton announced today.

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal taxes and other charges, of $9,596,885, compared with a net of $6,671,754 in the twelve months to Aug. 31, 1936.

Reserving his speed for the list half mile, Wise Will, 4-year-old Wise Counsellor gelding, today closed with a rush to carry the silks of Mrs. F. Rossiter to a half length victory at Rockingham Park in the Lancaster Purse at a mile and a sixteenth.
German music teachers were forbidden to instruct Jewish students by a newly released decree of the Reich Music Chamber.

The Eastern Conference of the Methodist Protestant Church by a vote of 63 to 18 opposed today becoming affiliated with the Methodist Church which will be formed as a result of the proposed merger of the Methodist Protestant Church, the Methodist Episcopal Church and the Methodist Episcopal Church South.

THE first game of the series may have gone to the Yankees, as the Giant rooters claim, by an accident. A trick play backfired and Marse Joe McCarthy's men took advantage of the incident to run off with the ball game. But it begins to look deliberate now. The Yankees did it over again, and by the same score. That can't be accidental. It's either phenomenal or deliberately humiliating.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Esther Willson Sands, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Jerome Sands of this place and Port Chester, N. Y., and the late Dr. Sands, to Lon Hocker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lon Hocker of St. Louis.

In yesterday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES a photograph of a horse which is to be shown in the third annual U. S. Camera Salon, opening to the public on Oct. 19 at 630 Fifth Avenue, was incorrectly attributed to Bert Clark Thaver.
Dr. and Mrs. James Phinney Baxter 3d are giving a house party at President's house. Williamstown, for the induction tomorrow of Dr. Baxter as tenth president of Williams College.
The radio public's taste has been shifting from serious to light stuff; or at least it did so change between 1927 and a couple of years ago.

Pressing irresistibly toward what may now develop into another of their famous grand slam exhibitions, Joe McCarthy's Yankee marauders again crushed the Giants yesterday in the second game of the all-New York world series at the Stadium in a manner to convince a crowd of 58,000 that there was no legal mistake about the first slaughter.

A Soviet searching party flew over the North Pole in the Arctic twilight today in a fruitless quest for Sigismund Levanesky and his five Russian companions, who disappeared last August on a trans-polar flight to the United States.

Abner J. Stilwell, vice president of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, filed suit here today for divorce from Mrs. Rosemary Ames Ketting Meyer Stilwell, 30 years old. He charged desertion, alleging that Mrs. Stilwell left him on Jan. 10, 1936, and "continues to absent herself."

The Regents of the University of the State of New York, which was in existence before the Constitution of the United States was written, marked the year 1787 by chartering the first secondary school in the State.

By winning the second game of the match for the chess championship of the world tonight, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, former titleholder, tied the champion, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam. The third game, scheduled for Sunday, will be contested at Amsterdam.

Test suits were instituted yesterday in Supreme Court to determine whether the Board of Regents can be compelled to license, without examination, duly qualified German physicians and surgeons who fled their own land to escape Nazi persecution.
A special committee of police chiefs reported today that "professional agitators and radicals are responsible for the starting of many public disorders."

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that three sergeants and sixteen patrolmen had been summoned Wednesday for trial on charges of ambulance chasing and unethical conduct. No date was announced for the trials.
Ashbel R. Elliott, founder of one of the first advertising agencies in New York, died suddenly today of pneumonia at his home here after a two-day illness.

Buying in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange was heavily in excess of odd-lot selling in the week ended on Oct. 2, with 405,659 shares bought on balance, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The purchases were made on a rising market which showed a net advance of 5.18 points on the basis of THE NEw YORK TIMES averages for fifty selected stocks.

Small quantities of Chinese merchandise are beginning to reach Hong Kong for transshipment to this country, according to cable advices received here yesterday by importers. This was the first word importers had that the Chinese are finding ways of getting goods through to fill orders booked before the outbreak of hostilities.

In the form of an interrogation to which no clear negative or affirmative reply could be obtained today, Le Figaro this morning published a suggestion that Leon Blum, Vice President of the Council of Ministers and Minister of State Without Portfolio, might shortly head a mission to the United States "for examination of the future of the tripartite agreement and French financial relations with London and New York."
Turpentine firm, 28 3/4c; sales, 80 barrels; receipts, 271 barrels; shipments, 1,073 barrels; stock, 36.373 barrels.
Estate, more than $10,000. To Elizabeth Chapman, widow, executrix, 780 Riverside Dr. FALLON, AGATHA O. (July 12). Estate, $500. To Margaret Fallon Palmer, daughter, executrix, Washington, D. C.

Class I steam railroads of the United States employed 29,570 fewer persons in September than in August, according to preliminary reports for railroad employment at the middle of September made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Blackford Jr. of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Jane Blackford, to John Vanderwart Deetjen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Deetjen of Akron, Ohio.

The campus of Erasmus Hall High School, at Flatbush and Church Avenues, Brooklyn, echoed to the unfamiliar war whoops of Indians, the stately measures of the minuet and the clumping of Dutch wooden shoes as the school began the celebration of its 150th anniversary yesterday with a pageant depicting the history of Flatbush and of Erasmus Hall.

Marse Joe McCarthy, manager of the most devastating set of diamond athletes now in the business of playing baseball, was calm and still his conservative self yesterday after his Yanks had flattened the National League champion Giants for the second time by the same score, 8 to 1.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Mahlon Buck of Philadelphia were honored tonight at a dinner given by John S. Norton in the Georgian Room of the Greenbrier.

The Rev. Victor O. Anderson, who served as a chaplain in the A. E. F., died yesterday. He had been rector of St. Agnes Episcopal Church since 1923. He was 49 years old. Mr. Anderson served parishes in Stanford and Augusta, Me., before the World War.

Aiming at reduced appropriations and a possible cut in taxes, Abraham S. Weber, State Budget Director, today called upon department heads to prepare their 1938-39 budget requests for submission at hearings beginning Oct. 18.

Leading spokesmen of both great British political parties today welcomed President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Chicago speech and expressed gratitude for the President's stand against aggressor nations. This welcome will be endorsed by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain tomorrow in a speech that is awaited eagerly as possibly the most important pronouncement on British foreign policy in months.

Family, friends and followers paid final tribute today to Edward A. Filene, economist, philanthropist and humanitarian, at memorial services in Ford Hall, a citadel of free discussion to which he had given his support.
The Federal Communications Commission took under consideration today, after hearings, three applications for the facilities of station WMBQ of Brooklyn.

The Navy Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 5: Clyde, Lt. P. M., the Enterprise, to Continue treatment at the Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C.; when discharged ordered home, relieved from all active duty. McLennan, Lt. P. S., Med. Corps, Kansas City, Mo.. to Submarine Base, Pearl Harbor, T. H.

In spite of the stoppage of billions of dollars of Federal "pump-priming" this year, American business has maintained its high level without any marked declines except in stock market values, according to a high Treasury official.

Miss M. Louise Elting of Greenwich was married to Harry Washburn Ritters of Miami Beach, Fla., on Monday at Elkton, Md. The bride was formerly physical director of the Greenwich Y. W. C. A. and for the last seven years has maintained her own studios in Greenwhich. Mr. Ritters is an anatomist.

Mrs. Harry L. Hopkins, wife of the Works Progress Administrator, died at 7:30 this morning at Garfield Hospital at the age of 37. President and Mrs. Roosevelt will attend the funeral service Saturday, and James Roosevelt, their son, will serve as one of the pallbearers.

Patrolmen Valentine J. Stumpf, from Mounted Squadron 2 to 28th Precinct, assignment to mounted duty discontinued. Bernard K. Ennis, from Grand Central Parkway Precinct to 32d Precinct, assignment to motorcycle duty discontinued. William H. McSweeney, from Borough Headquarters Squad, Queens, to 79th Precinct, assignment to duty with Warrant Squad discontinued.

Mrs. Andrew C. Zabriskie and Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Livingston will give a dinner dance on Dec. 4 in the Pierre roof garden to introduce to society Miss Frances Powis Jones, granddaughter of Mrs. Zabriskie, and Miss Eleanor M. Livingston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Livingston.
It is evident to observers here that whatever the powers may do Japan cannot now turn aside from the policy for which she has mobilized more than half a million men.

Indian Summer weather this week has slowed up the earlier expansion of consumer demand for women's apparel and accessories. The retail situation was said to have developed considerable spottiness, with popular-price lines moving more slowly than recently, although some special promotions have attracted large shopping crowds.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 6: Mitchell, Col. H. D., Adjutant General's Department, one day leave, Oct. 9. Hestor, Col. J. H., Inf., General Staff Corps, seven days' leave, Oct. 16.

Women of Westchester County were urged today "to organize and combat a whispering campaign being conducted to defeat the new county government act" by Mrs. Robert Griffith, executive secretary of the Westchester County Taxpayer's Association, in an address before the Port Chester Woman's Club.

A resolution condemning any trade treaty with Czecho-Slovakia which would permit imports of shoes into this country at prices lower than prevailing here, was unanimously passed last night by members of the Shoe Club, meeting at the Hotel McAlpin. The resolution, introduced by Jesse Adler, president' of the Adler Shoe Company,

Third national convention, National Society of Professional Engineers, begins at Hotel Commodore this morning at 10:30 and continues tomorrow. Meeting, American Public Health Association, Manhattan Opera House, 2:30 P. M. Speakers: Arthur T. McCormack, Homer Folks, Iago Galdston, Dorothy Deming, Edward S. Godfrey, Jr.

Though the mills at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer grind slowly, they do grind; and just at present there is some indication that they are about to grind out "Marie Antoinette" before the first snow falls on the orange trees out San Gabriel way.

Freight locked through the St. Mary's Falls Canal in September totaled 12,584,855 tons, according to reports to the United States engineers, maintaining the total tonnage for the first nine months of 1937 at an all-time high.
Production of all grades of slab zinc in September totaled 50,027 short tons, compared with 48,309 in August and 42,211 in September, 1936, according to the American Zinc Institute.
Edward Melroy Anderson, authority on overhead street lighting, died yesterday at his home, 34-08 193d Street, Flushing, after a long illness. His age was 69.
Senator Bridges asserted today that the National Labor Relations Board was "unfair and prejudicial" and favored the Committee for Industrial Organization rather than the manufacturers.

Several sales in Brooklyn negotiated by Slomka Brothers, Inc., brokers, were reported yesterday. Among them were the following: The one-family house at 1,577 Eighty-first Street to Damian Amerose for the Bay Ridge Builders; the eight-room house at 2,168 Eightysecond Street to Dr. Irving

The marriage of Miss Helen Marie Faissole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Faissole of Englewood, N. J., to Eugene Jose Antuna, son of Mrs. Josefa Braga de Antuna of Tenafly, N. J., and the late Bernardo Antuna, took place here yesterday morning in the church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

Unity of peace-loving nations to uphold treaties, as advocated by President Roosevelt, has brought the world nearer to peace than at any time in recent years, Mis. Carrie Chapman Catt said yesterday at a meeting of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War.

Mayor La Guardia is a "myth" so far as being a good Mayor is concerned, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate, asserted yesterday at a luncheon of the professional business men's league of his campaign committee at the Hotel Paramount.

Asserting that "we are not interested in the history of the nation under the NRA," Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone, presiding in the oil price-fixing conspiracy case here, sharply rebuked Colonel William J. Donovan, chief counsel for the defense, at the resumption of proceedings today and told him that he must stop quoting President Roosevelt in this case.
Although bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday rose above those of the previous week as a result of first-of-the-month payments the clearings failed to reach the 1936 level.

Stocks closed irregular after early strength; turnover, 1,190, 120 shares. Bonds firmer; transactions, $7,478,125. Curb Exchange Stocks' prices mixed; 206,270 shares traded. Bonds steady; sales, $1,164,000.
Harry Monmouth Herbert, a widely known civil engineer, who retired a few years ago, died suddenly at his home here yesterday. He was in his eighty-first year.
Joseph Blethen, former president of The Seattle Times Company and a widely known playwright and magazine writer, died of a heart ailment in a Reno hotel early today. He was 67 years old.

Because of the violent storms of the last twentyfour hours all telephonic communications between Rome and the north was interrupted from 2 A. M. today until late tonight. The trunk cable was damaged near Viterbo when a bridge collapsed.

John Griffiths, contractor who erected many of the largest buildings in Chicago, including the Merchandise Mart, the new postoffice, Union Station and the Civic Opera Building, died today in his home at 3,806 Michigan Avenue. He was 91 years old.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 6 unless specified: At Balboa: Charleston, Cummings. Acushnet, Washington Yard to Naval Oprating Base, Norfolk, via Dahlgren, Oct. 7.

The East River Savings Bank has sold another apartment house in Mount Vernon, Westchester County, to the Embassy Estates, Inc., it was learned yesterday. The structure just sold is the four-story building at 217 South Third Avenue. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $50,000 for five years at a per cent.

Chief Charles H. Stowell of the Mamaroneck village police was dismissed tonight after the village Board of Trustees found him guilty on two charges, both involving incompetency and conduct unbecoming a member of the Police Department. Mayor William H. Johnson and the four trustees were unanimous in their decision.

A Board of Officers is appointed to meet Sept. at Syracuse. N. Y.. at the call of the Presi- week dent thereof, to examine such persons as may be properly ordered before it to determine their fitness for appointment or certificate of capacity in the Officers' Reserve Corps.
Jesse Joseph Haines, grand old man of the Cardinals' hurling staff, was given his release today by the club he served eighteen years. a record for continuous activity with one team.

President and Mrs. Harold Willis Dodds will be hosts to more than 650 Princeton University freshmen and their friends tomorrow afternoon at the annual freshman reception from 4 until 7 o'clock at Prospect, the campus residence of university presidents.

The Democratic Committee for the election of the La GuardiaDewey ticket came into being yesterday at a meeting held at the Hotel Astor. Langdon Post, Tenement House Commissioner, an independent Democrat, was elected chairman.

Prince Ivan Engalitcheff, former chamberlain of the Imperial Russian Court and a graduate of the Russian Imperial Academy of Art, who has maintained a studio here for the last ten years, died early today at his home after an illness of three days at the age of .75.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that holders of Niles-Bement-Pond Company common stock will receive a dividend of one share of capital stock of Shepard-Niles Crane and Hoist Corporation capital stock for each ten shares held in the former company.

Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, Fannie Hurst, Gertrude B. Lane, Emily Newell Blair, J. Donald Adams, Irita Van Doren and Christopher Morley have accepted an invitation to serve on a committee with eight librarians and booksellers to choose 200 books to be presented to the nation by the American Booksellers.

Mrs. Medora Loomis Ray, head of the Romance Languages Department at Washington Irving High School, died at Post-Graduate Hospital last Tuesday. She lived at the Hotel White, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

The rainy desolation of Shanghai's streets, deserted and silent in the night except for the challenges of sentries and the occasional far-off rattle of machine guns in Chapei, suddenly crashed into an inferno of deafening sound and blinding explosive flashes when Chinese batteries in Pootung, acrQss the Whangpoo River, sent two shells across the stream to burst above Hongkew.

Mrs. Emmett Whalen of Westchester Hills turned in an 89 against women's par of 77 over the Knollwood Country Club course today to capture the low gross prize in the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament.
H. K. Worthy, b. g., by Outsider, owned by E. P. Cray, Bellows Falls, Vt., stepped the 2:07 pace in 2:06 3/4 today at the Danbury Fair to set the best time of the meeting which ends tomorrow.

Freshmen at New York University's Washington Square College took only 55 seconds to defeat the sophomores in a tug of war yesterday afternoon, after which the losing members of the team were compelled to kiss the feet of the statute of Garibaldi in Washington Square Park.

The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, returned from Italy yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia after a brief visit to the Vatican. He made the trip to Italy for a rest and to see the Pope, with whom he talked for twenty-five minutes about the church, particularly about his own work in the Holy Name Parish.

Many apartments in the Park Avenue section were included in the long list of rentals reported by brokers and rental agents yesterday. The details follow: Commander Howard A. Flannigan, in 1,060 Park Ave.; Mrs. Selby Tanner, in 27 E 79th St; Potter, Hamilton Co, Inc, broker.
None of the important items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banlks reached a new high or low figure for the year.

Fenton Ave, (16-4480), e s 50 n of Mace Ave, 50x100; Albert Kupfer to Antonio Brucato, 2,502 Barnes Ave. Tiemann Ave (16-4397), w s. 153 n Pelham Parkway N, 50x100; May G. McGregor to Christopher A. McGregor, 2,219 Tiemann Ave. Walton Ave, (11-2853), w s 150 n of 177th St, 50x116; Walton Avenue Corp to Giuseppe La Rosa, 396 E 154th St, mtg, $42,000.
Thoroughbred racing returned to Kentucky today after a three-month absence as Keeneland threw open its gates for a nine-day meeting.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

As a result of overcrowded conditions in State institutions, 150 mentally defective persons in Brooklyn alone are free to associate with the public while awaiting commitment to Letchworth Village or the Wassaic State School, according to testimony yesterday before the legislative committee investigating sex crimes.

The mace, charter, keys, records and seal of Yale University which will be used tomorrow at the induction of President Charles Seymour are quaint relics of early history of the college. The mace, which was given to the university in 1904 by the late Professor Samuel S. Sanford, is the most recent to be added to the ceremonial properties.

Any attempt to weaken the dual system of banking in, the nation by legislation which would permit national banks to open branches within their Federal Reserve districts will be bitterly opposed by the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks. This was the general tenor of discussions as the annual convention of the association opened yesterday in the Waldorf Astoria.

Short Notice, from the Jobella Stable, one of the fortunate horses in a ragged start, captured the featured Rival Purse at Jamaica yesterday, where a drying-out track contributed to several form upsets.

The Salzburg Opera Guild will make its American debut in a week's run at the Alvin Theatre, beginning Nov. 6, with Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte." The repertory will consist of five operas of varying periods to be given in their original tongues at dates to be announced later.

President Roosevelt's speech at Chicago on existing world conditions has proved the most outstanding factor in bringing him closer to Latin Americans, according to press reports showing unstinted approval from every political quarter. Even extreme left wing groups, usually inclined to play up the ideas of foreign imperialism, approve it.

Opposition to United States Senate Bill 69 providing for the limitation of freight trains to seventy cars was voted here today in a resolution adopted by the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board in the closing session of a two-day meeting in the Robert Treat Hotel.

The electric output of the subsidiaries of the North American Company showed an increase in the third quarter of this year, although at a lesser rate than earlier in the year, J. F. Fogarty, president of the company, said yesterday.

A firmer undertone yesterday ruled in the market for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Although the list was not without weak spots, especially among a few inactive issues, prices, on the average, worked generally higher in all major groups, excepting the foreign dollar obligations.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
A small two-place rubber life raft of the type used by fliers was found today on the shore at Hawi at the northwest tip of the island of Hawaii.

Anglo-French pressure on Italy to withdraw its "volunteers" from Spain has been noticeably increased during the last few days. Neither the French nor the British Government has been awed by the announcement from Rome of the arrival in Franco's territory of additional Italian forces, including a squadron of bombers of the latest type with the dictator's own son Bruno as one of the pilots.
A trio of sophomores combined in the closing minutes of a football game tonight to give Marquette a 7-to-6 victory over South Dakota University.

Word was received here today of the death at Miami, Fla., last night of Elbert L. Couch of New Rochelle, an inventor, mechanical engineer and former partner in the Couch Dean Corporation, New York manufacturers of hotel equipment. He was 65 years old.

Zenshiro Yasuda of the house of Yasuda, one of Japan's greatest banking and industrial families, died today at-the age of 60. He was president of the Yasuda Shoji or trading corporation, president of eight banks and director of many other family enterprises.
An honor which might be,envied by some of the country's leading sculptors has fallen to the lot of an unknown and untrained Negro tombstone cutter.

China is reiterating charges that the Japanese Army in the Shanghai area is using gases in increasing quantities, the official spokesman declaring that during today's severe fighting in the Lotien sector the Japanese first used sneezing gas, then tear gas and, finally, poison gas against Chinese troops.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh will arrive here soon to attend at least the opening session of the annual congress of the Lilienthal Association for Aeronautical Research at which Professor Jerome C. Hunsaker of Massachusetts Institute of Technology will report on the development of transoceanic planes.
William Harold Terry Jr. is not so much concerned about the outcome of the current world series as he is about the health of his famous dad, leader of the Giants.

Nine of the best sprinters in training on the Eastern seaboard will fight it out this afternoon in the $5,000 added Interborough Handicap, feature at the Jamaica course. The probable favorite is Hal Price Headley's Preeminent, victor at Belmont in the Fall Highweight Handicap, and the horse that started the sensational streak of luck for that stable.

An answering brief in a case brought against it by the Federal Trade Commission was filed with the United States Supreme Court today by the Standard Education Society of Chicago, a publishing house, through its attorney, Henry Ward Beer of New York.

A vigorous drive of the United Federal Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, to organize the arsenal and shipyard workers of the United States Army and Navy, came to light tonight with the announcement of U. F. W. A. officials that they had complained to the War Department of alleged "undemocratic efforts" to prevent the workers at the Frankford Arsenal, Philadelphia, from electing their own representatives on a wage board.

Larruping Lou Gehrig tied one record set by his glamorous predecessor, George Herman Ruth, when he lifted a long fly to Joe Moore in yesterday's fourth inning that enabled Red Rolfe to dash home with the Yankees' fourth run.

A temporary restraining order prohibiting State police and county officials from interfering with the operation of the dog racing track at the Fair Grounds in Orangeburg, Rockland County, N. Y., was vacated yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

Brooklyn College will open its home season against a strong Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute eleven at the Kingsmen's new athletic field, Bedford Avenue and Avenue H, today at 2:30 P. M. Aided by the Kings County American Legion Band and Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll and a host of other prominent officials, the contest will mark the first official act of the college in its new site.
Calling two surviving victims of the 1935 Tampa floggings to the witness stand, the prosecution presented evidence today to link four of six defendants to the crime.

The British Admiralty threw a bombshell into London newspaper offices late tonight when it issued the following statement: "As the result of full investigation it has been established that an attack by a submarine on H. M. S. Basilisk was not made."

Mrs. Angela Bennett received a divorce today from Richard Bennett, veteran actor and father of the three Bennett sisters of the films. "Richard Bennett is an actor and he does his roles very realistically, even off the stage," Mrs. Bennett said. "If he decides to play a role using a gun or a dagger he carries it through to the end-and I have scars to show the result."

George Washington University won its second warm-up game of the season by treating 10,000 spectators to an exhibition of tricky football when it defeated the West Virginia Wesleyan eleven tonight at Griffith Stadium, 18 to 13.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society announces that the judges for its second annual American composers contest are Deems Taylor, composer, - writer and radio commentator; Alexander Smallens, conductor, and Noel Straus, music reviewer of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Plans were filed with the Building Department yesterday for alterations to the building at 1,651-3 Broadway to accommodate radio Station WMCA, which recently announced the leasing of new quarters there.

Appointment of three special prosecutors to conduct the Philadelphia grand jury investigation into vice and crime was announced tonight by Charles J. Margiotti, State Attorney General, who has taken the inquiry out of the hands of District Attorney Charles F. Kelley.

A new register of Harvard alumni, giving the names, addresses, occupation and college records of 71,757 former students now scattered through eighty-four countries, has been published by the university.

The market for new State and municipal bonds will continue dull at least for another week, according to present indications with only $2,788,239 in new loans, represented by forty municipalities, scheduled for award next week.

Major George L. Darte, former American consul, newspaper man and military intelligence officer, died here suddenly Wednesday night of a heart attack a few hours after his arrival from Richmond, Va. His age was 63.

Edgar L. Murlin, retired newspaper man and later Court of Appeals attache, died early today at the home of his daughter in Greenwich, Washington County. He was the dean of the University Club, where he passed much of his time.
Announcement has been made of the marriage in this city on Thursday of Dr. Gerard Hutchinson Cox of Glen Cove, L. I., and Mrs. Alice Crunden of St. Louis, formerly of Middleburg, Va.

Modifications in the ecclesiastical laws of the Russian Orthodox Church in the United States, Canada and Alaska were made yesterday at its conclave at the Russian Orthodox Cathedral, 105 East Houston Street.

As the Board of Estimate prepared yesterday to hold two public hearings next week on the tentative city budget, Controller Frank J. Taylor issued a retort to the criticism of him expressed last Thursday night by former Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

Mayor Fred Warringer is a big man with a ready smile and looks somewhat like President Roosevelt, but the resemblance gave him one embarrassing momeant when he visited the President this week at Grand Forks, N. D. He tells the story thus:

The Japanese Foreign Office issued today a statement in reply to the charges by the League of Nations and the United States that Japan's actions in China are in violation of the Nine-Power treaty and the Kellogg-Briand Anti-War Pact.

Perry Ave (12-3348); e s, 58 ft n of 209th St, 66x100; N. V. S. Corp to Fanny Lelbowitz, 1,355 President St, Brooklyn; installments, 6 per cent: $10,000. Vyse Ave, 1,678 to 1,682 (11-2997): Vico Realty Corp to Augusta Epstein, c/o J. J. Breitman, 521 5th Ave; extends mtg to Sept. 1, 1940, without interest; $35,000.
Amelia Mott Gummere, Quaker authoress and widow of Dr. Francis Barton Gummere, Professor of English at Haverford College, died yesterday. She was 78 years old.

Mrs. Mary Wheeler Newberry Wright, former dean of women at Ohio Wesleyan University and onetime instructor at Pennington Seminary, Pennington, N. J., died at her home in Ocean Grove near here this morning. She was 76 years old. Her husband, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Wright, died last June.

A pledge that the British Government would whole-heartedly cooperate with President Roosevelt in the cause of peace was given by Prime Minister Chamberlain in a speech to the Conservative party yesterday. He hailed the "clarion call" from "the most powerful country in the world." He also warned Italy that friendship with Britain would depend on her response to the request for the withdrawal of "volunteers" from Spain.

General Iwane Matsui, Japanese Commander in Chief at Shanghai, in a public statement today defined the objectives of the Japanese expeditionary force in China as including a drive to "scourge the Chinese Government and Army, who have been pursuing anti-foreign and antiJapanese policies in collaboration with Communist influences."

The unconventional "Camille" which Commendatore Sterni's Teatro d'Arte perpetrated here just three years ago was repeated last evening at the Cine-Teatro Roma, but with a Marguerite who, this time, was in utter accord with the Armand of Mr. Sterni.

When the Italian liner Conte di Savoia sails today for Mediterranean ports her passengers will include Orazio Pedrazzi, Italian commissioner to the New York World's Fair, accompanied by Michele Busiri-Vici, architect, who have been inspecting the fair grounds here.

The Abitibi Power and Paper Company bondholders' defensive committee headed by Sir Henry Drayton announced yesterday a new plan of reorganization under which the funded debt would be $12,793,325 less than in the Ripley plan.

The long drawn out diplomatic conflict over Spain gave the appearance tonight of entering a new and threatening phase with well substantiated reports that Italy is rushing more supplies and men to her Spanish Insurgent allies.

Dr. James P. Baxter 3d, inducted today as the tenth president of Williams College, declared in his inaugural address that "we are witnessing the collapse of the world's system of collective security." Insecurity, he asserted, has become the "greatest characteristic of the modern world."
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The Hollywood Restaurant slapped forward its new Fall revue last week, and they were saying afterward that it was pretty good stuff in the Hollywood tradition. For the business man on life's night out, for the convention from York:

The Wagner-Steagall act granting Federal aid to local authorities should strengthen local public housing programs throughout the country, the New York Building Congress stated in a report sent yesterday to President Roosevelt, Senator Wagner and several Cabinet members.

Water St., 412-16, and 143 Cherry St, 75.2x 120.9xirreg; Mortimer J. Levie to Joseph Pitman, 29 'Front St; consideration $25,000, foreclosure. 64th St, 153-59 W, 72x100.5; Savings Banks Trust Co to 153 W 64th St Realty Corp, 153 W 64th St ($115).

Described as a "very important witness" against Max Silverman in the Drukman conspiracy case, Hyman Shiffrin, 49 years old, for seventeen years proprietor of a skirt manufacturing business at 117 West Twenty-seventh Street, was held in $15,000 bail as a material witness yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith in Brooklyn.

Air express shipments in and out of New York City scored an alltime high of 29,557 in September, Railway Express Agency announced yesterday. In March of this year, the previous high month, there were 25,678 shipments. Shipments for September were 34 per cent above those that moved to and from New York during the corresponding month last year, it was said.
Sir Hughe Knatchbull-Hugessen, British Ambassador to China, who was wounded critically by machine-gun bullets from a Japanese plane several weeks ago, arrived here from Shanghai today.

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 11 amounted to 3,910,460 shares bought or sold, or 19.44 per cent of total volume, compared with 1,730,350 shares, or 20.59 per cent of volume in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Manager Bill Terry probably will go back to his line-up against left-handers for today's game, despite Joe McCarthy's announcement that Bump Hadley, a right-hander, will pitch for the Yankees. That means that Hank Leiber will replace Lou Chiozza and bat fourth.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: That brochure by John Kieran in last Sunday's issue of THE TIMES entitled "Once Upon a Time" was most enjoyable and though no longer a callow youth I cannot lay claim to a memory of even a few of those Highlanders of bygone days.

The American Federation of Radio Artists filed a complaint late today with the National Labor Relations Board charging - the Columbia Broadcasting System and Station WKRC of Cincinnati with Violation of the Wagner act in the discharge of William Seymour, a news writer, because of alleged union activity.

After an interval of several years, Dr. Emanuel Lasker, former chess champion of the world, has decided to visit America again. He sailed tonight for New York with Mrs. Lasker on board the HollandAmerica liner Statendam to visit relatives and friends in that city and Chicago.
An Agriculture Department survey disclosed today that the Central South's high percentage of rural population is dwindling.
The Rev. Paul D. Elsesser, pastor of the French Evangelical Presbyterian Church, 124 West Sixteenth Street, died Thursday of a heart ailment at the Presbyterian Hospital. His age was 67.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Wheatie Farley, daughter of Professor and Mrs. Arthur James Farley of this city, to Henry Frederick Skelton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reinhold A. Skelton of Elmhurst, L. I., took place here tonight in the Elizabeth Rodman Voorhees Memorial Chapel of the New Jersey College for 'Women.

Registration for the fifth day this year continued at the brisk pace set Thursday and reached a fiveday total -of 1,682,901, which was 68,002 more than the total for the same period in 1933, the year of the last Mayoralty campaign.

On the surface of things it is hard to see why Mayor La Guardia should wish to have Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens on the ticket with him for re-election. Mr. Harvey has many virtues as an administrator, and as a public figure he is often entertaining. But he is not and never has been Mr. La Guardia's kind of man.

Average bookings in wholesale markets failed to expand this week, with the result that estimated volume of wholesale sales was held to 8 to 16 per cent ahead of a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported in its weekly trade review yesterday.

Without mentioning the name of his opponent, Harold W. Hastings, Democratic nominee for District Attorney of New York County, criticized Thomas E. Dewey last night for "defamation" of New York City and belittled Mr. Dewey's work as special rackets prosecutor. Mr. Hastings, an Assistant District Attorney, spoke before the Women's Democratic Club at the Hotel Commodore.

The wedding of Miss Mildred M. Woodruff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving W. Woodruff of Maplewood, and Harry L. Hesse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Hesse of Roselle Park, took place this evening in Prospect Presbyterian Church here.

Francis Gibson, oldest Masonic member in this community and formerly a member of the old Belleville Township Committee, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 90. Born in County Down, Ireland, Mr. Gibson came to this country in 1882.
Tuesday being Columbus Day and Monday Pulaski Day many pastors will preach patriotic sermons tomorrow. Some of the clergymen will comment on the Chicago speech this week of the President.

An output of wood household furniture in excess of $500,000,000 in 1937 was predicted today by Frank E. Seidman of Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, in an address here before the American Society of Mechanical Engineers on "The Economics of the Furniture Industrvy."
The Bearcats of St. Vincent College of Latrobe, Pa., overpowered the Davis and Elkins eleven by 27-12 in an exciting game before a West Virginia Forest Festival crowd of 1,500 tonight.

David T. Langrock of this city has announced the marriage of his daughter, Elaine Carlyn Langrock, to Monroe M. Schenk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Schenk of New York, which took place yesterday in New Haven.

Sales of General Motors cars to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, totaled 82,317 in September, a figure exceeded only in September of 1927, 1928 and 1929, and compared to 19,288 units sold in September last year and to 39,152 sold in September, 1935.

A little more than three weeks ago President Roosevelt was asked to comment on the charge that Mr. Justice Black had been a member of the Ku Klux Klan. On that occasion-Sept. 14--he made the following statement:

The promotions and appointments of 109 students enrolled in the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps as non-commissioned officers, were announced last week by Colonel Oliver P. Robinson, chairman of the Department of Military Science and Tactics.

An unidentified man about 55 years old was drowned yesterday afternoon while taking a ceremonial bath in the "mikva" at the Congregation of the Sons of Omsk, 26 Ridge Street. The "mikva" is a pool, in this case six feet square and five feet deep, in which orthodox Jews bathe on Fridays in preparation for the Sabbth.

Japanese authorities here evince every symptom of genuine optimism and believe the fighting in the Shanghai area will be completed within a month and that by early November all the Chinese armies in back so far that their artillery attacks will no longer menace the French Concession and the International Settlement.

Mrs. Dan Hinckley Arnold of Scarsdale has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marie Lesure Arnold of this city and Washington, Conn., to Gerald Davis, son of Mrs. J. Edward Davis, of Tuxedo Park and this city, and of the late Mr. Davis.
Before the largest crowd ever to see a football game at Moravian College the Greyhounds opened their home season tonight by sweeping the Princeton B eleven to a 26-to-0 defeat.
The Appeals Court handed down an opinion today that further imprisonment of Rev. Martin Niemoeller cannot be justified on any ordinary legal grounds.
The interest of the late Graham Young, a special partner in Stokes, Hoyt Co., ceased on Oct. 1. Climax Molybdenum Company's no-par common stock will be admitted to the Exchange's list today.

A special meeting of the stockholders of Abbott Laboratories has been called for Nov. 4 for the purpose of considering the authorization of 50,000 shares of $100 par cumulative preferred stock, of which the company proposes to offer 20,000 shares at a dividend rate of 4 1/2 per cent anually at par to increase working capital and for additional inventories and accounts receivable. The balance will be subject to Issuance in the future.

Martin J. Carroll of 1,350 Wissman Avenue, the Bronx, who had been a printer in THE NEW YORK TIMES composing room since 1884, died in Fordham Hospital Thursday of a kidney ailment which had forced him to leave work a year ago. He had been in the hospital since July. His age was 72.

On Tuesday, the 2d of November, the qualified voters of Greater New York will elect new city and county officers, including the Mayor, Controller, Council President, twenty-odd members of the City Council created by the new charter, five Borough Presidents, delegates to the Constitutional Convention, court justices and other public servants whose performance of their duties will profoundly affect the lives of all of us.

Sales of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., for the quarter ended Sept. 30 were the largest for any quarter in the history of the company and 500 additional operatives have been employed within the last sixty days, A. Joseph Newman, president, announced yesterday.

The period within which the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., may issue shares of its own $5 preferred stock for the $6 and $7 preferred stocks of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation. has been extended by the Public Service Commission to Dec. 31, 1937.

Richard D. Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., won the qualifying medal in the New Jersey Shore invitation golf tournament today. His sixover-par 77 topped a field of fortynirn contestants at the Monmouth County Country Club.

Nearly 150 geologists, representing twenty-five colleges and universities of six New England States and New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, met at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx last night to open the three-day session of the thirty-third New England Intercollegiate Geological Conference.

In a room carpeted with Autumn leaves, sponsors of the New York Plant and Flower Guild yesterday witnessed a Harvest Day pageant, presented by youngsters of the Avenue A Children's Gardens, and then awarded medals and prizes to some of the juvenile gardeners.
With six sophomores in the starting line-up, the Rutgers football team will meet the University of Delaware eleven in the fifteenth renewal of a series dating back to 1902 tomorrow.

Natty Boy, 3-year-old Catalan colt that had failed to score a single victory in sixteen previous starts this season, today closed with a rush to nose out Phil Bieber's Superwick, the 2-5 favorite for the Western purse at Rockingham Park. Company and Chickling, running as the Webber and Miss C. Morabito entry, finished in a dead heat for show, a length back of the leaders. The time was 1:123-5 for the six furlongs.

Protests by the State of Alabama against the efforts of Haywood Patterson, the Scottsboro prisoner, to overturn the conviction by which he is now serving a seventy-five year sentence, were filed with the Supreme Court today by A. A. Carmichael, the State Attorney General.

Beef has become a scarce commodity of late and in the Lehigh backfield it is practically nonexistent. It is not the beef that is red in the raw, but the kind that furnishes the raw material whereof strong football teams are fashioned.
The League of Aryan Clothing Firms is staging, in the heart of the Berlin clothing district, an "Aryan" fair to prove to buyers that they need not patronize Jewish firms.

Michael J. Quill, president of the New York local of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, was elected president of the first international executive board of the organization chosen last night at the close of the first national convention of the union, 155 West Sixty-fourth Street.

A highly touted Cornell football team will be heavily favored to turn back the Orange and Black of Old Nassau tomorrow afternoon in Palmer Stadium, when the two "Ivy League" institutions meet for the twenty-sixth time in their 46-yearold rivalry. A crowd of 30,000 is expected.

The Federal Power Commission granted today an application of the Tigre Mining Company of Mexico City to transmit electrical energy across the Mexican border from Douglas, Ariz., to its mining properties at El Tigre, Sonora, Mexico.

"Change signals. Known to Yanks." That was the contents of a telegram Colonel Bill Terry tossed on his desk yesterday afternoon about 4 o'clock for all the assembled writers to see just after his Giants had gone down for the third timeand not a life preserver in sightbefore the Yankees.

Miss Eugenia M. Coleman, daughter of Mrs. F. Stokes Coleman of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to John Connable Bennett, son of Major and Mrs. J. Walter F. Bennett of 1,105 Park Avenue, New York.

The four-story building at 650 East 165th Street, at the southeast corner of Cauldwell Avenue, in the Bronx, containing six apartments and three stores, has been sold by the Emigrant Savings Bank for cash above an $18,000 first mortgage, according to Samuel Hurwitz, broker.

The Greenwich Concert Orchestra, under Eugene Plotnikoff, gave an all-Russian program at the WPA Theatre of Music last night under the auspices of the Federal Music Project. With the exception of Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" duet, all of the offerings consisted of operatic excerpts.
The Securities and Exchange Commission learned today that one of its members, George C. Matthews, profited in a "pool" operation, but it decided not to punish him.

After negotiations lasting several weeks, a temporary agreement on the Sunday closing dispute between members of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc., and the Jewish Sabbath Observers Grocers Association has been reached, it was announced yesterday.

Protests against the nominating petitions of the Trades Union and Anti-Communistic parties, which have named Jeremiah T. Mahoney and virtually all the Democratio party slate as their candidates, were filed last night with the Board of Elections.
