In.their drive on the Peiping-Hankow Railway sector, the Japanese claim to have captured most of the town of Chengting, important city only a few miles north of the junction of the Peiping-Hankow road with the rail line to Taiyuan, capital of Shansi Province.

Turpentine firm, 28 3/4c. Sales, 151 barrels; receipts, 476 barrels; shipments, 256 barrels; stock, 36593 barrels. Resin firm. Sales, 493; receipts, 1,519; shipments, 1,427; stock, 73,503. Quote: B, D, E, $7.40; F to K, $7.57 1/2; M. $7.60; N, $7.62 1/2; WG, $7.85; WW, X $8.40.
The tenant rosters of a number of West End Avenue and Riverside Drive apartments received numerous additional names as a result of rental activity reported yesterday. The list of leases follows:

Northern States Power Company of Delaware and subsidiariesTwelve months ended Aug. 31: Net income after all expenses and charges, $5,899,119, comparing with a net of $5,170,126 in the twelve months to Aug. 31, 1936.

NOT long ago, while digging in his garden, a man I know turned up two strange objects with a single lift of the spading fork. One was a black flint arrowhead, well shaped and complete even to the sharp point. The other was an old iron candle-snuffer, badly oxidized but otherwise sound after long burial in the soil.

The Gasoline Station Attendants Union, Local 20,408, A. F. of L., announced yesterday through its president, Walter J. Burke, that it had signed individual agreements with 200 filling station owners, leaving 600 stations affected by the strike call issued Thursday night, effective this morning.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will arrive here Monday for the Duke's projected investigation of prosperity and happiness brought to the German working classes by the beneficent Nazi regime, it was semi-officially announced today. It was announced also that in the course of his visit the Duke will be received by Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Former Mayor James J. Walker's first and second appointments as assistant counsel to the Transit Commisison at $12,000 a year were both declared illegal yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman.
Alvis D. Hewitt, last of the 285 Iroquois Indians who fought for the Union in the Civil War, died at the Tuscarora Reservation near here today at the age of 95.

A gold and-crimson canopy, whisked down to reveal the stark simplicity of a memorial pylon, gleaming white, epitomized this afternoon the spirit of the celebration of a century of co-education at Oberlin College. Educators from both coasts participated in the exercises in commemoration of the successful experiment, for which Oberlin proudly assumes priority but refuses to monopolize the credit.
Alexander Grubman, private banker and retired wholesale liquor dealer, died Thursday at his home at 90-12 Einer Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens. He was 52 years old and a native of Russia.

Harry G. Gebhard,. Inc, has arranged a first mortgage of. $12,000 on the dwelling at 4 Eton Rd, Rockville Centre, L. 1., with the John Hancock. Mutual Life Insurance Company through Orrin S. Hallock, broker.

Yale will play Penn in the Bowl tomorrow for the fourth time since the colleges resumed football relations after a lapse of thirty-four years and the seventeenth time in a series which dates from 1879. A crowd of 35,000 is expected to watch the contest.

Mrs. Bessie Bartnofsky, 45 years old, accused of the hammer slaying of her mother-in-law, Mrs. Ethel Bartnofsky, in their Brooklyn home on March 8, was found guilty of manslaughter in the first degree last night by a Kings County jury before Judge Brancato.
The United States Building and Loan League's national convention urged today "the immediate tapering off of all activities of the government with private enterprise."

Grover A. Whalen was elected yesterday president of the World's Fair Corporation on a full-time basis and now will devote his entire time to the affairs of the corporation, according to an announcement made by Mortimer N. Buckner, chairman of the executive committee.

Members of Congress, in a telegraphic poll conducted by The Philadelphia Inquirer, had voted two-and-a-half to one, up to tonight, against cooperation by this country with the League of Nations "either in sanctions or active intervention" in the SinoJapanese crisis.

Dimes from school children and dollars from adults is the program of the national committee now soliciting funds to erect a memorial statue to Eugene Field, childhood poet, "In Lovers' Lane, Saint Jo."

The War Department today announced award of a $2,518,346.83 contract to the Boeing Aircraft Company of Seattle, for thirteen additional four-motored bombardment airplanes, known as the "flying fortress" type.

The cooperation of 800 millinery manufacturers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in enforcing fair trade standards by jobbers in the industry was sought in telegrams sent to them yesterday by the Millinery Workers Union.

Miss Helen Eustis Cameron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Duncan Cameron, was married here tonight at the home of her parents to George William Shine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Michael Shine of Mount Vernon.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Child, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Child of Garden City, L. I., to Arthur W. Gilbart, son of Mrs. Arthur F. Sailer of Ridgewood, N. J., and the late Arthur W. Gilbart, took place here last night in the Sherry-Netherland. The Rev.
West Side Highway as a name defines and utterly fails to do justice to the five and a half miles of new masterpiece out of
Coming from behind in the last half, Temple defeated the University of Florida in a hard-fought game at the Owls' Stadium tonight, 7 to 6, before a chilled crowd of 10,000 persons.

Ambrose V. Acker, City Fusion candidate for Queens Borough President, filed a formal declination of the nomination last night with the Board of Elections, a half hour before the midnight deadline. In declining Mr. Acker bitterly attacked Mayor La Guardia, whom he supported in 1933.

With a quickening pace as the season almost entirely leaves behind its warm-up games, football today offers several games whose importance has been emphasized by unexpected results of earlier contests.

Pleas of insanity were presented to the Court of Appeals today to prevent two convicted murderers from paying the death penalty. Attorneys for Salvatore Ossido, Brooklyn barber, who killed Einer Sporrer, a 9-yearold girl, in his barber shop March 19 last, told the court that Ossido had been drinking heavily just before the crime.
The threat of a general strike in defense of labor's freedom of coalition was averted today after Premier Felician Slawoj Skladkowski received a delegation from the Labor Federation.

A short, cocky fellow, 20 years old, placidly stood in the glare of the line-up yesterday. He asserted himself as the leader of a band of six, including two girls, accused of shooting a man in a "thrill holdup" while the American Legion was parading, and admitted holding up a dozen midtown delicatessens with another man in the last year.

The Discount Corporation of New York in its statement for the threemonths ended on Sept. 30 reported acceptance discounted at $4,877,903, against $3,305,209 on June 30, last, and United States Government securities of $66,365,083, against $65,031,158 on the earlier date. Total assets amounted to $74,513,748, against $72,522,887.
The appointment of John F. Lonergan, 34-36 Ninety-second Street, Jackson Heights, as assistant photostat operator in the State Banking Department was announced today. The salary is $1,200 a year.

Today's events: Roland Hayes, tenor, Town Hall, 8:30'P. M.; "Rigoletto," Hippodrome, evening. The New York College of Music will hold final scholarship auditions in singing, piano, violin and 'cello Monday and Wednesday afternoons from 2 to 4 P. M.

The Cheshire School of Cheshire, Conn., defeated the Amherst freshmen, 7-0, on Pratt Field today. Scoring early in the second period, the visitors were never threatened. Davis, hard-plunging fullback, whose punting was outstanding, and Holden, halfback, were responsible for the score, converting the point and carrying over, respectively.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Recurring rumors strenghten the opinion that Freddy Bartholomew may have reported back to work at M. G. M. after some months of idleness due to a disagreement over wages. Studio officials have made no statement, and doubtless will make none.
Southern States received slightly less than half of $9,500,000 allotted by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace today for government loans in the first year of the Government's farm tenancy program.

Officials of Air Cruisers, Inc., which has its main plant here, said today a deflated rubber life raft round on the shore of Hawi, Hawaii, was not the one Amelia Earhart had purchased for her round-the-world flight.

Army is ready for Columbia. The cadets today put the finishing touches on their rehearsals for the game with the Lions tomorrow, practicing in Michie Stadium instead of playing on the Plains gridiron.

President Roosevelt's Chicago speech receives from the Soviet press a degree of approval that nas never been given before to a foreign statesman. To find a parallel for the enthusiasm of today's Izvestia and Pravda editorials one must look back to their comments on the recent speeches of Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff in Geneva.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain tonight hailed President Roosevelt's Chicago speech as a "clarion call," and promised that the British Government would be "whole-heartedly with him" in a concerted effort in the cause of peace.

A story of how Jules Martin, lieutenant of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, tried to organize the transport workers of the city only to have his gangsters driven out by the hard-fisted men in that field, was told yesterday by Thomas E. Dewey, Fusion and Labor candidate for District Attorney.

In what Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson described as one of the cases developed in cooperation with the newspapers in a drive against "crooks who use newspaper advertisements to defraud persons," Joseph Miller, 43 years old, of 308 West Eightieth Street, began an indeterminate penitentiary term of not more than three years yesterday on his recent conviction in Special Sessions of defrauding a man of $1,000 in a fake job racket.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Oct. 2 amounted to 847,245 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

A well-spoken young man, whom the police believed to be an amateur thief, held up the bookkeeper of the Victor Manufacturing Company yesterday afternoon and escaped with a $1,700 weekly payroll. The robbery was executed in a hallway of the building at 621 Sixth Avenue, which houses the Victor company and several other manufacturing concerns.

Coal Conservation The attention of Chief and Company Officers is invited to Paragraph VI, Special Order 78, May 4, 1937, with regard to conserving coal supplies. Battalion Chiefs shall see that Company Commanders comply with the provisions of said order.
Colonel Joseph Fauntleroy Barnes, Field Artillery, retired, died at General Hospital here this morning. He was 59 years old, born in the District of Columbia Sept. 15, 1878.

Methodists will celebrate the silver jubilee in the Episcopate of Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Area, with a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall-on Oct. 25 at 8 o'clock. Dr. McConnell, who is also president of the Methodist Board of Foreign Missions, was elected a Bishop at the quadriennial General Methodist Conference held in Minneapolis, in May, 1912.

The stock market groped its way yesterday, up to the final hour, at least, and finally succumbed to heavy pressure on many of the steel and railway shares. In the end, weaknesses spread throughout the list.

Jack Doyle, who lays the accepted odds on all big sporting events in this section, was about in the same position last night as Manager Bill Terrry of the Giants. He did not have much to say. However, he did present figures for those who want to bet.

Eleven new industrial groups have joined the American Standards Association since last March, bringing the basic membership to a total of seventy national associations, it was announced yesterday by Dana D. Barnum, president of the association, at a meeting of its board of directors.

Operations of the General Baking Company in the thirteen weeks ended on Sept. 25 resulted in a net profit of $695,960 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for surtax on undistributed profits.

Arthur Wiesenberger, of Distributors Group, Inc., who returned recently from a survey of European financial centers, reports that foreign investment trusts and financial organizations, far from liquidating their American securities, actually have been steadily buying on balance.

The season's first snowfall in New York State hampered traffic in some sections today. Central New York reported the heaviest fall. The snow blanketed roads in the SyracuseCortlandt area, but melted quickly. Snow flurries, hail and a thirty-five-mile wind stripped trees in Sullivan County.

Jimmie Hines of the Garden City Country Club, the metropolitan champion, was one of eight who survived the first and second rounds or the Long Island P. G. A. medalmatch championship today at the Sound View Golf Club.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 686,000 bales, against 684,000 a week ago, 684,000 two weeks ago, 691,000 three weeks ago and 763,000 a year ago; of which American 224,000 bales, against 216,000 a week ago, 220,000 two weeks ago, 209,000 three weeks ago and 235,000 a year ago.
Mr. and Mrs. C. Maury Jones of New York entertained with a luncheon at the Cascades Club today for Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Scott and Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Halsey, also of New York.
Donald McDonald, manufacturer of gas meters, died of heart disease early yesterday morning at his home, 993 Park Avenue, at the age of 68.

A large bronze plaque bearing the names of 316 firemen killed in the line of duty since the establishment or the paid fire force in 1865 was unveiled yesterday by Commissioner John J. McElligott in the corridor outside the department's executive offices in the Municipal Building.

A 'client of L. J. and G. A. Shapiro, attorneys, has purchased a vacant plot 90 by 105 feet on the southwest corner of Clarkson Avenue and East Thirty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, from the DeBaun estate.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Anne Williams, daughter of Mrs. Wood Williams of Grosse Pointe and the late Mr. Williams, to George Nugent Monro 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Loftus Monro of Pittsburgh, has been announced by her mother.

It will be the North against the South all over again tomorrow as little freckle-faced Miss Patty Berg, darling of the Minneapolis galleries when she went to the last round against Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare at Interlachen two years ago, meets Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Greensboro, N. C., in the thirty-sixhole final of the forty-first women's national golf championship on the Memphis Country Club course.

Poultney Bigelow, author and traveler. was host at his home here today to several hundred persons who attended the unveiling of a small porcelain bust of Martin Luther. The bust was the gift of the exiled German Kaiser, Wilhelm II, to his friend, Mr. Bigelow.

The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, of $13,242,277.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Mansfield Spencer was guest of honor at a farewell dinner given by the congregation of the Church of the Strangers last evening in the West Side Y. M. C. A., 3 West Sixtythird.Street. Dr. Spencer,

Federal Judge William Clark, senior judge of the New Jersey District, announced today his appointment of Mrs. Louise S. Steelman of Montclair as Federal Jury Commissioner for this State to succeed James Kerney Jr., publisher of Trenton.

Funeral services for James A. Chalmers, a retired real estate and insurance man who died Wednesday at the age of 77, at his home, 240 Westminster Road, Brooklyn, were held last night in the chapel at 1,120 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Howard Dunbar, pastor of the Church of the Epiphany.

Syracuse University will admit no more students until the beginning of the academic year of 1938-39 next September, Chancellor William P. Graham announced today. The ruling is designed to prevent students from beginning their college course at the opening of the second semester, Jan. 31.
The execution of six alleged bourgeois nationalist terrorists for killing a Communist party organizer and the manager of a grain-collection office at Ruzaievka, Central Russia, was announced today.
The National Council for the Prevention of War, which today closed its threeday convention here, at its closing session opposed the putting into effect a boycott of Japan.

Joseph Schreier, 24 years old, who was arrested at the Palace Hotel in West Forty-fifth Street last Sept. 28 on a Sullivan law charge, was discharged yesterday by Magistrate Curran in the Felony Court on his not-guilty plea.

Kyosuka Tomada, one of the bestknown tragedians on the Japanese stage, played his last act today in the real drama of life and death. Mr. Tomada was killed in action on the Lotien front while leading a detachment of engineers in an attempt to bridge a creek.

Joseph B. Egan, president and general manager of Egan, Fickett Co., wholesale distributors of fruits and vegetables, and president of the Nevins Fruit Company, both of New York, died today at his home in Hydewood Park, North Plainfield. He was born in Ireland seventy years ago.

The Autumn season of amateur theatricals in Westchester County opened tonight when members of the Spotlight Players, a group sponsored by the drama section of the Contemporary Club of White Plains, presented the George Kaufman and Katherine Dayton comedy "First Lady" at the Ridgeway Theatre here.

A crop of 17,573,000 bales of cotton in the United States this year, the second largest on record, was forecast today by the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture. This indicated an increase of 1,475,000 bales over the 16,098,000 predicted one month ago, based on crop conditions at Sept. 1. The Oct. 1 estimate was based on a ?? 79 per cent of normal.

Despite Indian Summer temperatures, retail trade here made a good comparative showing during the week. Volume increases as between stores was spotty, but the average gain of department stores for the week was estimated at from 5 to 7 per cent over the corresponding period last year.

Metcalf Ave (15-3890), s w cor of Bronx River Ave, 156x104; Blum Metcalf Real Estate Co, Inc. to Emdorf Realty Corp, 1,345 Rosedale Ave. Blondell Ave (15-4135). n e cor Ponton Ave. 100x162: Bache M. E. Whitlockl to Carpglass Realty Co, Inc, 2,909 E Tremont Ave
The Rev. Dr. Clarence MacKinnon, principal of Pine Hill Divinity College and widely-known United Church minister, died at his home here early today after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

Rose Lane Garment Co, Inc, floor in 12 E 33d St; Morgan Barry. Inc, broker Nash XelvinPeor Corp, Wackman Welded Ware Co, Argentine Information Bureau larger quarters; MacLevy Health Club anc Gymnasium, additional apace, In Chanin Building, 122 E. 42d St.

Confronted with a large crop and subnormal prices, potato growers of eight States voted today adoption of AAA marketing agreements. Spokesmen said marketing of this year's crop, estimated at 403,303,000 bushels, compared with last year's 330,000,000, was under way and they expected the new agreements to be put into effect within ten days.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported to the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 5,000, including 1,000 directs. The market was steady to 10c higher than Thursday's average; top, $11.25;

A move by Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti to eliminate underlying companies of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company through the cancellation of their charters was defeated today by a four-to-three decision of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.

A sharp decline was registered in cotton-mill activity last week when a nominal recession was seasonal, and the adjusted index has dropped to 119.7, its lowest point since the week ended June 20, 1936. The revised figure for the previous week was 127.1.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in announcing today that Thomas F. Gagen, a member of the Boston Stock Exchange, had consented to the entry of an order suspending him from that Exchange for one year beginning on Oct. 11, warned national securities exchanges that failure on their part to exercise effective self-regulation over the activities of customers' men "cannot long be ignored."
Mayor La Guardia will campaign vigorously for his running mates on the Republican-American Labor party-Fusion ticket who aspire to seats on a Fusion Board of Estimate.

A $1,200,000 building program was undertaken recently by the White Plains Hospital Association only after noted hospital consultants had surveyed the area and had recommended the step, according to a statement today by John W. Appel Jr., president of the association.

Nathan Mann, New Haven candidate for heavyweight honors, outpointed Arturo Godoy of Iquique, Chile, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Hippodrome last night. A strong closing rally by the Connecticut boxer earned him the award over the rough and aggressive South American.

Americans talk more about a possible war in Europe than Europeans do, Vittorio Mussolini, son of the Italian Premier, said in an interview here yesterday at the Hotel Ambassador, where he is staying for a brief visit in New York devoted to sight-seeing.
Stocks closed lower after early gains; turnover, 1,148,700 shares. United States Government bonds steady, corporate and foreign issues lower; transactions, $7,007,450.

Another $4,000,000 destroyer was added to the navy's rapidly increasing flotillas yesterday afternoon when the 1,500-ton destroyer Fanning, built at the Staten Island plant of the United Shipyards, was commissioned at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn.
Registration for New York City's municipal election on Nov. 2 will close tonight. This will be the last opportunity for residents of the city to qualify to vote in this important election.

Mrs. Arthur- H. Mitchell of Princeton has announced the, engagement of her daughter, Miss Katherine Mitchell, to Frederick Spring Osborne, also .of this place, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hamilton Osborne of Newark.

Outweighed and outplayed almost from start to finish, Riverdale Country Day School of New York went down before the Newark Academy eleven today by a 31-0 score. It was apparent when the home team scored a touchdown shortly after the kick-off that the Bronx youths were no match for the Newark warriors, who chalked up their second victory of the season.

A definite agreement between the Croat and Serb opposition is confirmed in a joint communique that intimates early publication of the details. The original plans of Dr. Vladko Matchek, the Croat peasant leader, have manifestly been accepted by the Serbs since the main points of the agreement are understood to be as follows:

A resumption of corporate borrowing on a substantial scale swelled the total of new bond financing for this week to $113,224,300, the largest volume since the week ended June 18, when $143,577,511 in new bonds was marketed.

Miss Dorothy Belle Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy H. Johnston, was married here tonight at the home of her parents to Roger Stopford Ames, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wickham Ames also of Montclair.
'Recent world events, and in particular the aggressive acts of foreign powers, tinged the utterances of three new college presidents inducted into office yesterday.

All banks, offices and stores in the principal cities of Colombia were closed at midafternoon today to allow employes to hold open air mass meetings as an advance protest against a possibly adverse decision by the Supreme Court, which is evenly divided, six judges to six, on a labor law. Before the court is the question of the constitutionality of a law passed in 1934 requiring private

The Insurance Group Committee for Reorganization of the Denver, Rio Grande Western Railroad Company, headed by George S. Van Schaick, moved today before the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to amend the reorganization plan that it previously submitted.

Because the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 requires approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission before submission to a Federal court, details of the proposed reorganization plan for Genesee Valley Gas Company, Inc., will not be available to creditors and shareholders before Nov. 1, it was disclosed yesterday.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain went out of his way in his speech here tonight to laud Anthony Eden in what political observers interpreted as a move to scotch rumors that he plans to oust the Foreign Secretary from the Cabinet.

Out in Chicago they are announcing today the arrival at the Grand Opera House on Oct. 18 of "Madame Bovary," the Theatre Guild's second show of the season, which had been expected at the Broadhurst Theatre here, Oct. 19. It is scheduled to remain in Chicago at least for two weeks, with its Broadway opening so far unsettled. This would mean,

Today is the day! This morning at 7 the wildfowlers of the northern zone will be found crouched in all types of blinds, waiting for the ducks to come in. In New York hunting will be limited to the shores of the many lakes and rivers, as the Long Island shooting will not begin until Nov. 1.

The Bureau of Air Commerce issued new regulations today, decreeing that after Nov. 1 pilots will receive "certificates of competency" instead of licenses. Bureau officials said that flight instruction requirements were due for extensive revisions under the new rules, adopted to improve safety standards of civilian flying.

The reported Intention of the British Government to back France's threat to reopen her Pyrenees border should Italy refuse the Anglo-French invitation to tripartite negotiations was met by the Italian Government today with the official announcement prominently displayed in a1l newspapers that Italy was reinforcing her Libyan garrison.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Any discussion of our foreign policy, or lack of one, sooner or later is likely to become bogged in the mire of "neutrality." The conception which this term evokes is likely to be hazy enough at all times; at the moment, however, the word seems to escape definition entirely.

Heavy selling of wheat futures here and in Winnipeg by houses with New York connection forced the price of all deliveries on the Board of Trade below $1 a bushel and to the lowest level since July, 1936.

AMHERST VS. NORWICH-Oooh! Prince Hal Schumacher started off by walking Crosetti on four straight balls. And turned loose a twobase wild pitch a few minutes later, too! But he wiggled out of that hole without damage. Norwich may not be that lucky. One vote for Amherst.

A, sizable Town Hall audience last night played host to Joseph Knitzer, the season's first violin recitalist. A native New Yorker, Mr. Knitzer's brief career has been honored by prizes from the Naumburg Foundation, the National Federation of Music Clubs and the Schubert Memorial.
Mrs. Alice Cary Van Dien Leefe, one of the oldest residents of Ridgewood, died last night at the age of 87, at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Frederick T. Lau, in Bronxville, N. Y.

Miss Deborah Disston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Dunlop Disston of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Alfred Wakelee Swartz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Wakelee Swartz of Haverford.

Joe Cox, 226, Kansas City, and Wally Dusek, 220, Omaha, drew in the feature wrestling exhibition atthe Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night. The bout, slated to be a finish encounter, was called a deadlock after 32:40, when both grapplers fell from the ring and were counted out.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 7 unless specified: At Guantanamo. Arkansas, Texas. Pearl Harbor Yard to San Diego, Brooks, Fox. At San Diego, Partridge, Oct. 8; Bushnell, Kanawha.

Twenty-two years ago New York State had a Constitutional Convention which was attended by many of our leading citizens, did, on the whole, an excellent job, but was repudiated when its results were submitted to popular vote. Many of its recommendations were adopted later, but only after long delay.
Navy will end the first division of its schedule, consisting of three home games, with the game against Virginia tomorrow. It will start the second next week when it meets Harvard in Baltimore.

Justice Lawrence Dunham, sitting in the Children's Part of the Queens Domestic Relations Court yesterday, found two 14-year-old boys guilty on two counts of juvenile delinquency in the fatal shooting a week ago yesterday of Shirley Kopp, 17, of 78-37 Sixty-fourth Place, Glendale, Queens.

New School for Social Research. 66 West Twelfth Street, 10:30 A. M. "Creative Learning," John L. Tildsley. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Byzantine Architecture in Venice: San Marco," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "Italian Renaissance Furniture," Ethelwyn Bradish, 11 A. M.;

An irregular tendency appeared in the stock market today and the final trend pointed to weakness. Even the gilt-edge issues lost ground, and China's obligations failed to hold yesterday's modest gains.
John T. Curtis, for more than twenty-five years editor and pubfisher of The Sullivan County Republican, died this afternoon following a stroke of paralysis. His age was 69.

J. Gilbert Hall of New York, three times holder of the title, and Arthur MacPherson of New York, who has two legs on the present cup, both won their matches in the semi-finals of the Fall tennis tournament today. They will meet in the final Sunday.

Glenn Killinger's West Chester State Teachers scored their third victory in four starts when they turned back Ithaca College, 20-0, tonight before 5,000 persons. The Teachers tallied two quick touchdowns before the Ithacans got warmed up in the first period and then shoved across another in the final stanza to clinch the game.

Paul Tobias, a painting contractor of 1,577 West Sixtieth Street, Brooklyn, was robbed of a $1,200 payroll yesterday afternoon, according to detectives of the East 104th Street station. He was held up by one man, who forced him into a vacant apartment on the third floor of 152 East Ninety-fourth Street at the point of a pistol.

Advertising, in submitting a product or a service to the elective choice of the public, "brings business under more equitable judgments than can be devised by our governmental servants," Earl D. Babst, chairman of the American Sugar Refining Company, pointed out in a statement released yesterday.
The name of Frank Frisch, fiery leader of the Cardinals, has graced a major league line-up for the last time.

The National Maritime Union asked Secretary of Commerce Roper yesterday to remove Captain George Fried as supervising inspector of the New York district of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation.

Figures indicating that the United States is "probably in for a period of housing deficiency perhaps parallel with the worst period after the World War" were presented yesterday at a symposium on hygiene and housing at the Hotel New Yorker, at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

Edward B. Smith Co. offered yesterday approximately $5,200,000 of New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1947, at 99 1/2. These obligations are part of the issue recently offered to holders of the maturing 4 per cent bonds of the road and which were not entirely exchanged.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The week in the domestic wool market has been deadly dull, relieved only by the opening of bids by the Government for 1,453,228 yards 20 ounce suitings and 1,195,535 yards 10 1/2 ounce shirtings for the CCC.

The will of E. W. Howe, opened today, divides the residue of his estate of about $200,000 between his sons, James P. Howe and Eugene Howe. To the publisher-philosopher's daughter, Mateel Howe Farnham of Westport, Conn., was bequeathed one dollar.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in September amounted to $26,773,041,608, a gain of 8.1 per cent over the turnover in August and of 1.4 per cent over that in September of last year.

For the first time in history a flight over the North Pole during the six months' Winter night was successfully accomplished yesterday by Soviet plane N-170. It was piloted by Mikhail Vodopyanoff, who has the title Hero of the Soviet Union, with a crew of eight, including the commander of the expedition, M. Sheveleff, who is similarly honored.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following applications from New York for registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market:

President Roosevelt, upon returning to the White House today, heard from Secretary Wallace the Agriculture Department's forecast of the second largest cotton crop in history, a development adding weight to his hint at Hyde Park that a special session of Congress was likely.

The Kings County Republican Committee voted last night to certify six borough candidates for the City Council as those entitled to carry the party designation after their names on the proportional representation ballot election day. The six are Amy Wren, Joseph J. Kehoe, Samson Insulbuch, M. Mendel Schachne, Louis E. Isnardi and Abner C. Surpless, all of whom filed nominating petitions earlier in the week.

Estate, about $8,000. To Patrick Graham, brother, 248 W. 16th St., and Anne Crahan, sister, Wilkinstown, County Meath, Irish Free State, one-fourth residue each; Lawrence Crahan, brother, Wilkinstown, Ireland, one-half residue. Fames Farmer, cousin, 2,226 28th St., Astoria. L. I.. executor.

Although the cotton trade had expected a large cotton estimate, the actual forecast of 17,573,000 bales as of Oct. 1 that was reported yesterday by the Department of Agriculture exceeded by far the highest of private guesses.

The Board of Trustees of Rutgers University made thirty-four faculty appointments and re-elected two trustees at the Fall meeting this evening. Most of the appointments were to instructorships. Mrs. Walter W. Gosling of Red Bank, president of the Associated Alumnae of the New Jersey College

Of imports now to be prohibited by the war-emergency ordinance of the Japanese Ministry of Commerce, the United States sent Japan about $2,000,000 worth in 1935, the Commerce Department estimated today. This was less than 1 per cent of the total value of Japanese imports from this country.

Supreme Court Justice Leancer B. Faber in Brooklyn signed an order yesterday requiring the New York Newspaper Guild to show cause next Monday in the Brooklyn Supreme Court why it should not be restrained from picketing the store of Davega-City Radio, Inc., 417 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and from interfering with persons entering or leaving the store.

Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, chairman of the Board of Education's finance and budget committee, asserted yesterday that the school program for 1938 would be drastically curtailed and all scheduled improvements would have to be abandoned as a result of cuts in the appropriation requested.

Despite constant objections by counsel for the defense, who almost always were overruled by Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone, presiding, the first of the 103 witnesses subpoenaed by the Government in the oil pricefixing conspiracy case here testified today that the spot market price of gasoline remained unnaturally steady for the greater part of 1935 and in the early months of 1936.

Mayor La Guardia urged all-citizens "interested in good, clean and honest government," in a radio speech under the auspices of the American Labor party last night, to register to be able to vote to keep Tammany from returning to power.

Senator Berry of Tennessee told the convention of the American Federation of Labor today that he favored a simple Wages and Hours Bill without any Government bureau "to regulate the unions and the conduct of business."
The play-by-play description of the third game of the world series at the Polo Grounds yesterday follows:

Thornton Lee, a tall southpaw held largely responsible for the impression that the YankeeS couldn't hit left-handed pitching, looked like just another country thrower to the Cubs today as the National Leaguers defeated the White Sox, 4 to 1, to go one up in their Chicago city series struggle at Wrigley Field before 10,658 fans.

Police Commissioner valentine said yesterday that, according to the 1938 budget provisions, his deapartment would receive only 145 new patrolmen, 100 to be appointed on June 1 and forty-five on Sept. 1. He said the department should have 16,355 patrolmen, but was now 832 short of that quota.

President Roosevelt said today that the press of administrative matters would make impossible a meeting with Associate Justice Hugo L. Black during his present five-day stay in Washington, and he appeared anxious to avoid further discussion of the former Alabama Senator's past connection with the Ku Klux Klan.

Price movements of commodity futures here were mixed yesterday in moderate activity. Cottonseed oil futures fell sharply following the announcement of an unexpectedly large cotton crop estimate. Rubber, sugar and coffee futures were higher, but other futures were irregular.

ADLER, PAULINE (Aug. 3, 1937). Gross assets, $73,157; net, $64,917. To Hamilton Adler, son. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance. $62,890. Brussel Beebe, attorneys, 165 Broadway. BETTS, GIOVANNA (Aug. 19, 1935). Gross assets. S29.066: net. $26.907.

Yelverton Cowherd, regional director of the Committee for Industrial Organization, has posted $1,000 bond here on a bribery charge from Gadsden, Ala., it was said today by Charlie McCombs. chief deputy sheriff.

Seven persons were killed here tonight and four were injured, one seriously, when a Nickel Plate train crashed into two automobiles which had been in collision on the railroad tracks. Sergeant Ben Perry said that all of those involved in the accident were residents of Gary.

The Scarsdale High football team suffered a defeat in its opening game with Pelham today. The score was 6-0. After holding the visitors at midfield early in the opening period, Scarsdale fumbled a punt on its 15yard line.

The Far Eastern crisis in the light of the new American policy of international collaboration for peace was taken up by President Roosevelt today in intensive discussions with his chief advisers on foreign affairs and with his Cabinet.

Presentation of a budget calling for the expenditure of $7,500,000 on missionary and national activities within the next three years precipitated a sharp debate today at the triennial general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States.
The six-story apartment house at 2,044 East Thirteenth Street, Brooklyn, containing forty-eight suites, has been sold by Merchant Art, Inc., to a client of William Liss and associates.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, spent yesterday in this city when on his way from a vacation in the West to the American Bankers Association convention which will open in Boston on Monday.

Derying the wishes of John L. Lewis and other leaders of the United Mine Workers of America, nearly 7,000 hard coal miners threw down their tools today and walked out of five collieries of the Lehigh Navigation Coal Company.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the following dealers and concerns had entered into stipulations to discontinue certain false and misleading advertising in connection with the sale of products:

The proceeding instituted by nine Southern States before the Interstate Commerce Commission to obtain lower freight rates and destroy the freight-rate "barrier" between the North and the South, was joined today by six-interested parties permitted to intervene by the commission.
William B. Armstrong, former vice president of the American Piano Company, died here last night at his home, 437 Webster Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 79.

Specialists in mental hygiene testified yesterday before the legislative committee investigating sex crimes that failure of the courts and social agencies to make complete reports on individuals held as "mental cases" had resulted in "a chaotic condition" in the final disposition of these cases by city institutions.

Asserting that Mayor La Guardia during four years had used WPA funds to build two swimming pools on Washington Heights instead of for needed schools, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate, declared last night that, if elected, his first steps would be to direct the construction of elementary and high schools in that section of Manhattan, Mr. Mahoney spoke at Temple B'nai Israel Shearith Judah,

Oberlin College, in celebrating the hundredth anniversary of the "beginning of co-education on a college level," attains one of the "firsts" in human history-at any rate, in American educational history. Harvard last year was observing the tercentenary of the founding of a college for men.
Trading in Manhattan real estate reported yesterday centered in the East Side, and one deal involved the transfer of an entire blockfront. A number of leases for entire buildings also were announced.

The police today broke up a large demonstration en route to Abdin Palace to protest against the Palestine Government's action in deposing the Mufti of Jerusalem from his posts and arresting and deporting members of the Arab High Committee there.

In the first nine months of 1937 68,418 tourists visited here, an inorease of 2,618 over last year, the Trade Development Board reported today. Regular passenger ships brought 45,948 from the United States, 691 from Canada, 736 from England and 703 from the West Indies.

Heavy rain and windstorms slowed up both Spanish Government and Insurgent Armies in Spain today. After a brief period of fair weather a downpour flooded roads and trenches and made fighting almost impossible.

Ernest A. Bigelow, new chairman of the board of directors of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, said yesterday that the management of the I. R. T. was formulating a plan of reorganization of the company's properties and expected to submit soon a tentative plan for the consideration of the board. On Wednesday,

Striking back at the Rebel air force which bombed the coastal towns of Reus and Alicante today, Loyalist planes made six raids on Palma, Majorca, and two on Insurgent air fields at Pont de Inca and San Juan.

Miss Louise Page, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert J. Page of this place, was married tonight to Albert Scott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter K. Scott, also of Bloomfield. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Episcopal Church of East Orange by the Rev. E. P. Wright.

New York University's football team will meet North Carolina on Ohio Field this afternoon at 2:30 P. M. in what is expected to be one of the hardest battles on the Violet schedule. New bleachers have been constructed on the field and approximately 15,000 persons are expected to witness the contest.

Park Ave, 3,500, 1-story brick garage, 97.6x 150; Hilda E. Hellman against 3,500 Park' Ave Corp; due, $59,045; taxes, etc, $12,062; to plaintiff for $5,000. Hearing Ave, 1,651, dwelling, 32x100: Home Owners Loan Corp against Catherine Shea: due. $5,487: to plaintiff for $500.

The world series to date has been practically without sound effects. From the standpoint of noise and enthusiasm it has been as quiet as a dull Monday game with the St. Louis Browns. So overpowering have the Yankees been that the Giant rooters sit glumly and the Yankee ones just Chuckle to themselves.
A proposed code of fair practices for the rayon industry ran into numerous objections at a final hearing before the Federal Trade Commission today.

Although the last year was one of many "bad spots" in Northeastern agriculture, the thirty-five Production Credit Associations in the Springfield district made loans of more than $12,244,000 to more than 10,000 farmers in the first eight months of the year, compared to $10,729,000 in the corresponding period of 1936, H. B. Munger, president, told a conference of officials from twelve credit districts at the Farm Credit Administration today.

Miss Laddie Irwin, 18-year-old Glen Ridge star, ran her string of oneday golf victories to three straight today when she captured top honors in the weekly tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Baltusrol Club.

For the first time In several years Stefan Zweig has turned from biography to write fiction. His new book, to be published by the Viking Press on Friday, is called "The Buried Candelabrum" and is Zweig's version of the old Jewish legend of the sevenbranched candlestick.

Anthracite coal operators were warned today that if they could not cooperate voluntarily in a program of industrial "self-regulation" "it may be necessary for the Government to Impose regulatory measures upon the industry to force such action."

Entertainment at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club in connection with the seventeenth annual horse show to be held tomorrow and Sunday began this evening with the annual horse show committee stag dinner at the club.

The Civil Service Commission reported today 848,243 employes in the executive branch of the Government at the end of August, a decrease of 933 during the month, and a payroll amounting to $126,746,808, as against $126.974.578 for July.

Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg today summoned members of the Fatherland Front living in Vienna's inner city to assemble before the City Hall and hear his promised statement regarding the organization's future. Twenty thousand answered the summons.

General Michael Dietrichs, once a commander of Czarist Russian armies and friend of, the Czar, died today of tuberculosis at the age of 64. He had been in Shanghai since the collapse of a Siberian anti-Bolshevist movement in 1922 and recently was a clerk in a bank.

The marriage of Mrs. Hazel Ridley Bergen of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur John Ridley of 2 East Eighty-sixth -Street and Brewster, N. Y., to Maxwell Ludlam Scott of 17 East Ninety-sixth Street, took place yesterday afternoon in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle.

Engineers and others engaged in the professions were warned yesterday by Arthur V. Sheridan, president of the National Society of Professional Engineers, that the rapid growth of the American labor movement, particularly of the C. I. O., offers a serious danger to their "integrity and identity." Mr. Sheridan spoke at the opening session of the third annual convention of the society at the Hotel Commodore. The convention closes today.

Four educators in addresses here tonight, at a colorful and impressive ceremony marking the inauguration of Dr. Edmund Ezra Day as Cornell's fifth president, appealed for a revivifying of education's ideals so that a body of citizenry shall be maintained competent to challenge, through understanding, forces working for national discord and international war.

Relations between Germany and Japan have become somewhat constrained at a time when Tokyo might have expected aid or at least comfort from Berlin. Less than a year ago these two Powers announced their pact against communism and called upon the rest of the world to join them in a holy war against the Third International.

The country has "seldom been more prosperous" and the "fear" that is behind the falling securities market is not warranted, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruotion Finance Corporation, told State banking officials last night at the Waldorf-Astoria at the annual dinner of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

The old stone house formerly owned by Mrs. Bertha Howard at Bedminster, N. J., has been purchased by Dr. William A. Lowndes of Short Hills. The property adjoins the estates of Henry Luse, publisher, and Eliot Tuckerman, stock broker. Wilmer N. Tuttle negotiated the deal.

St. Nicholas Ave. 680-4, 3 8-story brick apartments, 183.9x101.5 irreg: Margaret Levy against Estamax Holding Co; due, $44,534: taxes. etc, $5,500; subject to prior lien of $210.700: to plaintiff for $216,700.

Government competition with private enterprise and efforts of State legislation to blanket all lines of business with uniform wage and hour provisions were criticized in two resolutions adopted today at the closing session of the nineteenth annual convention and exposition of the National Restaurant Association.
Miss Frances Williams entertained with a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for her niece, Miss Marguerite Decroix, who celebrated her birthday.

Ten students were elected here today to the Mercersburg Academy "Fifteen," the English honorary society. Election was announced by Headmaster Boyd Edwards and choice was made on the recommendation of Dr. Daindridge Murdaugh, head of the English Department, on the basis of excellence in English work in the academy.

The address of the three-story brownstone dwelling in Brooklyn recently purchased by Alfred Drayton is 393 Hancock Street. In a report of the sale on Thursday the address was incorrectly given as 293 Hancock Street.
The text of the inaugural address delivered today by Charles Seymour, new president of Yale University, follows: Members of Yale:

Harvard's virtually untried football team will undergo a thorough test at the stadium tomorrow afternoon against the Brown eleven. The Crimson offense which moved with such freedom against a feeble Springfield team last Saturday can be measured more accurately against Brown.

Prospects for quick action on the proposed blanket convention to generalize the forty-hour week were bright tonight after a long discussion today in the International Labor Organization's governing body during its first session here.

With Eugene Ormandy on the podium, the Philadelphia orchestra this afternoon opened its thirty-eighth season before a near-capacity audience at the Academy of Music. The playing of a Bach-Brahms-Wagner program was greeted with marked enthusiasm.

Still holding all the trumps as well as practically all the other aces while their rivals seemingly could do nothing but peer disconsolately at the deuces the deal had given them, the Yanks moved one trick nearer their cherished fourth world series grand slam yesterday by toppling the Giants for the third straight afternoon.
William R. Ludewig of the University of Pittsburgh engineering faculty died early today at his home here at the age of 71.

Lowered in its first stage, the final curtain on the long season of yachting began to go down tonight with the start of the New Rochelle Yacht Club's annual race out around Stratford Shoal, in the middle of Long Island Sound off Bridgeport.

Louis Davidson, 42 years old, of 2,800 Bronx Parkway East, the Bronx, described as a national C. I. O. organizer in the cleaning and dyeing industry, was held in $20,000 bail yesterday by Judge Koenig in General Sessions on two felony indictments. The indictments, handed up last Monday, accuse Davidson and six Negroes, five of whom previously were arrested,

A slightly heavier vote Nov. 2 than was cast at the last "off-year" elections in 1935 was presaged today by firstday registration returns from upState larger cities. Political leaders attributed the increase to interest in contests for delegates to the State Constitutional Convention.
Bond prices turned downward yesterday in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange, with most of the major groups more than erasing their gains of the two preceding sessions.
Mrs. Emily S. Andrews, who observed her 101st birthday last March 29, died today at her home here. She was born in New York, the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Halleck.
Mr. and Mrs. John Fletcher Riddell of 912 Fifth Avenue and Garden City, L. I., will give a tea dance on Dec. 21 at the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Dorothy Riddell.

A strike of nearly 1,200 employes at the J. G. Brill Company trolley car and bus manufacturing plant ended today with an agreement arranged through a State labor mediator. The employes, members of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, struck because one worker refused to join the union. L. E. Hess,

With the week-old stoppage of the Federation of Kosher Butchers in protest against the high cost of meat scheduled to end tonight at sundown, city and Federal officials met yesterday at two conferences with representatives of the butchers and meat packers in an attempt to bring about a permanent settlement.

Barnard Hall, a new building on the campus of Hofstra College, was dedicated this afternoon at exercises attended by more than 1,000 students, faculty members and guests. The building was named in honor of James H. Barnard, one of the founders of the Long Island unit of- New York University. He was unable to attend because of illness.

Pained by the frowardness of the press of his Province, Premier Aberhart of Alberta is again seeking to correct it. An Act Ensuring Publication of Accurate News and Information has been passed by the Legislature. It gives to the chairman of. the Social Credit Board power to enforce publication in the newspapers of any statement made by him as to the objects of any policies of the Government,

Providence College gained a 7-6 decision over Xavier University tonight on a final-period touchdown by Leo and extra point by Nugent. The Friars scored on a march of 70 yards in the third quarter, Cummins going across.

Dr. Vincent Gaudiani, surgeon and author of thirty books and monographs on surgery, died last Wednesday of a heart attack at his home at 65 East Ninety-sixth Street. He was 63 years old, and had lived in this country twentyseven years.

Realty men and builders who have been casting about for possible means of fostering home ownership and seeking the causes of the recent decline in suburban buying and building are turning their attention to the problem of financing costs and mortgage interest rates.

Six hundred members of the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, at a mass meeting this afternoon voted unanimously to accept the terms of a working agreement covering the 10,000 employes of the local plant of the R. C. A. Manufacturing Company.

Miss Grace Anna Bonynge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winfield Bonynge of this city, was married to Morgan R. M. Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. B. Taylor of East Orange this evening, in the First Presbyterian Church of Orange. The Rev. Raymond Irving Lindquist, the pastor, officiated.

Minor assault charges which were lodged last July 13 against three strikers in front of the plant of the Noma Electrical Corporation at 524 Broadway were withdrawn yesterday by the complainant in the Felony Court, and the defendants were discharged by Magistrate Curran. They were Jeremiah Norton.
Newark's annual automobile show will be held at the 113th Infantry Armory, Sussex Avenue, Nov. 6 to 13, it was announced today.

CHANGES have been made in the itineraries of several world cruises owing to continued hostilities in the Far East. Instead of stopping at China, Korea and Japan, ships will follow a path that includes Thursday Island, Australia.

As this time of year the virburnums are at their best. They belong to one of the groups of plants valued primarily for their Autumn color and brilliantly tinted fruits. Some virburnums have red fruits, some black, some blue, and some even have yellow fruits.

NOBODY in Hollywood but Cecil B. De Mille has ever been suspected of owning a Bible before, but the truth of the matter is that there are hundreds of bibles in Hollywood with which neither Mr. De Mille nor the Gideon Society has had anything at all to do.

Stewart Willey, Queens building operator, who recently purchased a large acreage tract formerly used for vegetable farming adjoining the new Juniper Valley Park, announces that he is preparing for an extensive development of the property with medium-priced homes. His plans provide for the ultimate construction of 1,500 houses.

Mark Warnow, musical director of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has leased for three years the former residence of Joseph Fleishman at 80 Beverly Road, Kew Gardens. The house is of Chinese pagoda architecture.

Minnesota's thoroughly deflated Golden Gophers squeezed out a 6-to-O victory over Indiana today in a Big Ten game at Memorial Stadium that found Bo McMillin's scrappy squad failing in two last period attempts to pull the game out of the fire.
THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity, continuing its downward movement for the seventh consecutive week, has dropped to 103.6 for the week ended Oct. 2.

Winding up a week of spectacular play unmatched in history, Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page, stockily built star from Greensboro, in the Piedmont section of North Carolina, today became the foremost woman golfer of the land by winning the national title on the difficult Memphis Country Club course.

A fresh attack on obligations of Japanese and Italian origin in the final hour of the session featured trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Virtually all the Japanese and Italian issues were forced to the lowest levels in several years, the former yielding fractions to 4 points, while the latter fell 1 to 3 points. Other foreign dollar bonds were steady in quiet trading.
Dr. Julius Daniel Dreher, retired United States Consul and a former president of Roanoke College, Salem, Va., died at his home here today. His age was 91.

Dr. E. A. Rumely, secretary of the Committee for the Nation, which two days ago urged President Roosevelt in a telegram to raise the price of gold from, $35 to $41.34 an ounce in order to raise security and commodity prices, admitted today that several prominent industrialists and business men have withdrawn from the committee - within the last year or so.

Miss Eleanor Ridler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Ridler of East Orange, was wed to Edward Theodore Barone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Barone of Orange, this afternoon in All Saints Episcopal Church, Orange. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Elwood C. Bogess.

A seventy-two-hour postponement of a strike of 1,200 drivers for eight Greyhound bus lines, originally called for 5 A. M. tomorrow, was announced tonight by S. R. Harvey, assistant president of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, pending further negotiations.

IN the authorized editions of the complete works of Whittier there occur some five hundred poems. The number has been extended to 900 in the bibliography which has just emerged after many years' delay.

The American Newspaper Guild filed today before the National Labor Relations Board a complaint alleging that the Daily Times Company, publisher of The Chicago Daily Times, had "interfered with, restrained and coerced" employes who belonged to the Guild.

The British Government, speaking through Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, has welcomed whole-heartedly President Roosevelt's declaration in favor of "concerted action by the peace-loving nations" in the present juncture of the world's affairs.

Clarence Voorhees Williams, superintendent of the Illinois Children's Home and Aid Society and a pioneer in child welfare work, died of heart disease tonight in the Evanston Hospital. He would have been 65 years old on Oct. 20.

Mrs. Letitia Caldwell Cornell, the oldest retired teacher in the New York City school system and believed to be the oldest teacher in the State, died today at the age of 102. Last Monday on her birthday she received a message from Mayor La Guardia.
Little Warren King, the mighty atom from Binghamton, enlivened an otherwise routine football game today by scoring twice as Dartmouth routed Springfield, 42-0.

The French Line ships carried 71,006 passengers in the transatlantic service between Jan. 1 and Oct. 1, an increase of 16,517 over the corresponding period last year, according to a report prepared by Henri Morin de Linclays, director of the line for the United States and Canada.

Sheer power of the University of California Golden Bears crushed the Washington State football fighters, 27 to 0, today. The Bears' first team took the game in hand from the opening scrimmage when Morris Pollock sprinted around right end for 16 yards.
Le-high coasted to a 32-to-0 decision over the Johns Hopkins eleven in Taylor Stadium today for its first victory in three starts.

IN the generation which followed that of Yeats and AE. Ireland gave birth to a large crop of poets, many of whom have become known here. Padraic Colum, Seumas O'Sullivan, Joseph Campbell, James Stephens. Oliver Gogarty,

Miss Margaret Elizabeth Wink daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wink of this place, was married to John Bishop Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Davis of Philadelphia, this evening in the Dobbs Ferry Presbyterian Church.

General issimo Chiang Kai-shek told his people tonight not to expect others to fight China's battles. "International sympathy, though a source of the greatest encouragement, should not be permitted -to awaken false and ill-grounded hopes,"

Dr. B. A. Garside, executive secretary of the Association of China Colleges, said last night that eleven of the twelve American-supported institutions which belong to the association had opened on schedule, although all but one were within the zone of military activity.
Plans for the nation-wide celebration of Navy Day on Oct. 27, the birthday of Theodore Roosevelt, were announced yesterday.

Funeral services for Thomas Nelson Perkins, attorney, diplomat and director of many corporations, were held today in Harvard Memorial Church, Harvard Yard. The Rev. Willard J. Sperry of the Harvard Divinity School officiated.

The Undergraduate Land and Building Fund Committee of Barnard College will sponsor a campus carnival on the college campus next Friday afternoon to open this year's drive for funds for the new building to be erected on Riverside Quadrangle.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Oct. 7: REAR ADMIRAL Simons, M. H., Battleship Div'n. 1, Battle force, to command Norfolk Navy Yard, Portsmouth, Va., and additional duty as District Material Officer, Fifth Naval District.
Fourteen persons were sentenced to death in Southern Russia today and fourteen others were reported executed in Northern and Eastern Russia for alleged anti-government activities.
Among the major groups in the stock market, chemicals, steels and tobaccos showed the greatest resistance to pressure in the first nine months of this year. On Oct. 1,

Miss Margaret Murray Crawford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. E. Druitt Crawford of the Maples, Penllyn, was married this afternoon to John B. Morgan 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rowland Morgan of Chestnut Hill.

The engagement of Miss Doris E. Fisher, daughter of Mrs. Mortimer L. Fisher of 645 West End Ave, and the late Mr. Fisher, to Robert I. Gross, son of Mrs. Felix Gross, also of this city, and the late Mr. Gross, has been announced by her mother.
Clearings of the Westchester County Clearing House Association in the week ended on Friday amounted to $3,706,274, compared with $3,436,970 in the preceding week and with $2,638,354 a year ago.

THE postmarked greetings received by President Roosevelt recently from the Minnesota towns of Franklin, Delano and Roosevelt bring to mind the old American custom of naming places after famous Americans.

Cornell undergraduates, whose attendance at yesterday's formal inauguration of President Edmund Ezra Day was necessarily limited by the presence of hundreds of guests, will have their own chance to "inaugurate" Dr. Day at two special functions planned for the near future, according to announcement from the university last night.

University of Detroit took to the air to rout a heavy Texas Tech team, 34 to 0, in an intersectional football game before 11,000 spectators today. Detroit counted two minutes after the game opened when Ed Palumbo passed fourteen yards to Alex Chesney for a score, and the rout was on.

Members of the Long Island Women's Auxiliary of the Hebrew Kindergarten and Infants Home have taken over a pre-opening performance of "Angel Island," a new play by George Abbott, the night of Oct. 18 at the National Theatre for the benefit of the organization.

Mayor La Guardia has a "rule or ruin temperament," Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday in an address before a group of women lawyers, members of the women's division of his campaign committee, at the Hotel St. Moritz.

Educational propaganda to establish rehousing in public esteem is to be the concern of the New York Women's Committee of the National Public Housing Conference. The committee has taken official cognizance of objections raised in many quarters, and through institutes and speakers' schools will train its members to "sell" the program for the rehabilitation of the slum family.
COX-CRUNDEN--On Oct. 7, 1937, in New York City, Dr. Gerard Hutchison Cox of Glen Cove, N. Y., to Alice Tweedy Crunden, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Benedict Tweedy of Milwaukee.

A building industry conference to analyze the causes of the decline in residential building and to suggest means for stimulating activity will be called at an early date by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. George H. Davis, president of the chamber,

THERE is a book about Hawaii which is exactly what a book of this kind ought to be. The publishers call it an "informal portrait" of these islands, but for once the publishers have understated the case. One can see in "Hawaiian Tapestry" an informal portrait.

Turpentine firm, 28c; sales 164 barrels; receipts 613 barrels; shipments 88 barrels; stock 37,118 barrels. Resin firm; sales 596; receipts 1,198; shipments 11; stock 74,690. Quote: B, D and E, $7.40: F, G, H. I and K, $7.55; M. $7.57 1/2; N, $7.65; WG, $7.85; WW and X, $8.40.
The Sleepy Hollow Country Club here will hold a horse show next Sunday in celebration of the formal opening of its new outdoor ring.

The two-unit plan, for Mount Holyoke College students with special interest in individual work, continues this Fall for its third academic year under the leadership of Dr. Elisabeth G. Kimball. The twenty-three freshmen, sophomores and juniors who are working under this plan have opportunity for greater concentration than the regular course permits.

Looking ahead to 1940 and the celebration of its bicentennial anniversary the University of Pennsylvania will be on parade next week, prepared to show to Philadelphians what it is contributing to the cultural, business and industrial life of the community.

A nation-wide day of protest by organized youth in this country seeking restoration of the full Congressional appropriation of $75,000,000 for the National Youth Administration has been arranged for Wednesday by the American Youth Congress.
If any one had doubted the influence America can exercise in this part of the world, the Japanese people's reaction to the declaration of the American State Department would have enlightened him.

A blustering gunman who early today broke into the home here of the Misses Elsie and Rosamond Coolidge, sisters, and distant relatives of the former President, robbed them of $100 in cash and $400 in jewelry, cut the telephone wires, and threatened them with death if they gave the alarm.

Charles D. Coburn, stage actor, the director of the Mohawk Drama Festival at Union College, Scheneotady, N. Y., left by train for Hollywood yesterday afternoon to appear in what was said to be his first motion picture. He is to play in "Benefits Forgot," a MetroGoldwyn-Mayer production, in which Walter Huston will be starred. .
UNDER the quiet surface of Washington in the off-season, a mild bureaucratic turmoil is rolling up over the question of what to do about Federal detectives.
Three charter members of Clio of New York, founded forty-nine years ago, will be introduced at a luncheon tomorrow at the Hotel Astor, commemorating the opening of its pre-jubilee year.

FOUR of London's chief orchestral organizations will open their season's activities this month. The initial concert of the Royal Philharmonic Society is scheduled for next Thursday, when Sir Thomas Beecham will conduct Beethoven's "Missa Solennis" in the Queen's Hall.

A prediction that the New York Shipbuilding Company will have to close its Camden yard within twelve months if no Government shipbuilding contracts are obtained was made today by J. W. Burnison, president of the Camden Chamber of Commerce.

AN early season recital by Fritz Kreisler, and Walter Gieseking's first appearance in this country after an absence of two years, mark the current week in music. Complete opera and concert programs follow: w:

Joseph Gonzales and Ramon Garcia, two small policy game operators picked up by Detective Joseph Cashman, attached to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's office Friday night, were arraigned before Supreme Court Justice Pecora early yesterday. Jacob J.

The decline in the wheat market came to an abrupt end today as the result of buying induced by strength in Liverpool. Prices in North American markets closed at gains of 1 cent or more a bushel, with Winnipeg showing the most strength.

Moving pictures to aid the Mount Vernon Community Chest appeal will be shown at the local theatres, beginning Wednesday, it was announced today. The campaign, now in progress, will continue until Nov. 1.

James Sterling Place of this city, vice president of the Hudson Smelting and Refining Company, in Newark, died today at Homeopathic Hospital here from injuries suffered when he was struck by an auto on Thursday while crossing Central Avenue at North Oraton Parkway here. His age was 49.
Marked by simplicity, the funeral of Mrs. Barbara Duncan Hopkins, wife of Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, who died Thursday after a lengthy illness, was held here today.

WHEN Eugene Lyons fell into the job of United Press correspondent in Moscow in 1927 it seemed to him that fate had given him a nice red apple. He was a Communist by conviction, though not a party member, and he had behind him a record of service to the left-wing cause in America.

Pure sulphur is now being produced in Canada on a commercial scale. The plant at present in operation has a capacity of forty tons of pure sulphur per day, and a second unit of the same capacity is nearing completion, says the Canadian Pacific.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin withdrew from a radio broadcasting contract to night after his new ecclesiastical superior, Archbishop Edward Mooney. had refused approval of one of the priest's statements for publication A spokesman and attorney for the priest, who for years has broadcast from the Shrine of the Little Flower, said:

Expressing the belief there will be no general European war and reporting continued brisk activity in retail trade in England, H. Gordon Selfridge, leading London merchant, yesterday expressed concern regarding the dip in unit sales of merchandise in this country.

Forty sons of Brown alumni have entered the university this Fall as freshmen. Eleven of these sons had grandfathers at Brown and two had great-grandfathers. Others have as many as twenty relatives among Brown graduates, running back four and five generations. The class of 1912 has sent back the most sons to Brown, with six enrolled.

Staving off a touchdown bid by the invaders in the final four minutes of the battle, the Poly Prep football team battled to a scoreless deadlock with the Hill School of Pottstown, Pa., on Poly's gridiron in Brooklyn yesterday.

The New York Meteorological Observatory, a unit of the United States Weather Bureau with offices in Central Park, reported yesterday that observations last Summer had shown that it was a light season for ragweed pollen, the chief cause of hay fever.
A carnival spirit reigned today as this village, the largest in New York State, celebrated the centennial of its name, changed from Saw Pit to Port Chester by legislative act in 1837.

EVER since the first new Autumn styles burst upon the horizon women have been adjusting more than their eyes to the new figures. They have been whittling down their appetites and their waistlines to meet the demands of the reborn hourglass silhouette.

A PROPOSAL that broadcasting of court trials be prohibited was made to the American Bar Association at its recent meeting in Kansas City. The special committee on publicity in judicial proceedings, of which Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, was the chairman, made the proposal.

The French Ambassador to Government of Spain, Jean Herbette, today was put on the diplomatic inactive list and was replaced by Elrik Pierre Labonne, former Minister to Mexico, who will take charge of the temporary embassy residence at Saint-Jean-de-Luz, in Southwest France.
THE Musical Art Quartet will have a new viola player this season in William Hyman son, but the rest of the personnel remains unchanged. The quartet will appear Nov. 30 and Jan. 4 in Town Hall.

A moderate but steadily growing demand for the more expensive type of houses in suburban localities is reported by the Brimar Corporation, owners and developers of the Broadlawn Harbour community at Kings Point, Great Neck, L. I.

" Peace and understanding with our neighbors and with our minorities is the guiding principle of Rumanian policy," declared Premier George Tatarescu today in a speech at Oradea, on the Hungarian border, where he has been inspecting Rumania's "Maginot line."

ATYPICAL and precious feature of the Venetian festivals, since the first concert Alfredo Casella organized in the Ducal Palace (in 1925, if memory serves), has always been the program devoted to the masterpieces of Venice's "golden centuries." Critics and art pilgrims have always relished them, both for their intrinsic merits and as a welcome "breathing space" between sessions, often taxing, of modern music making. g.

AMONG Maxwell Anderson's playwrighting gifts is the one that is most essential. He can create trenchant characters. When you look back through his long library of plays you cannot find a principal character who is lacking in individuality.

The auction sale on Oct. 23 of the remaining plots in the River View Manor development situated in Hastings-on-Hudson and Dobbs Ferry, Westchester County, is arousing considerable interest, according to James R. Murphy, auctioneer.

The Government of Brazil again became a dictatorship this week with unlimited powers in the hands of President Getulio Vargas after a short experiment in constitutional government, which had been expected to continue until after the Presidential campaign.
Captain Fielding Simmons went on a scoring rampage today as Williams College submerged the University of Vermont eleven by 53 to 6 at Centennial Field.

The voluntary hospitals of New York City admitted last year more than 400,000 patients, representing more than sixty-two countries and every known faith, the United Hospitals Campaign Committee disclosed in an announcement yesterday emphasizing that the hospitals were helping to safeguard the health of the entire community.

A memorial service for Mrs. Rebecca Hooper Eastman, author, playwright, political worker and Brooklyn social leader, will be held today at 4 P. M. in the Unitarian Church of the Saviour, 121 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. Eastman died on June 19. She was the wife of William Franklin Eastman,

World War veterans and representatives of Polish patriotic organizations paid tribute yesterday to Brig. Gen. Wladimir B. Krzyzanowski, leader of the Polish Legion in the Civil War, as the coffin, bearing his body, was brought under military escort to the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.

Vaulting to the front through a third-period field goal and then admirably protecting their slim lead during a hectic final quarter, Manhattan College's football forces thwarted the heralded warriors of Michigan State to the tune of 3 to 0 at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Playing wide open football, Rhode Island State defeated Tufts, 14 to 7, today, all the scoring coming in the first half. The Rams got away to an early lead when two passes found Jaworski crossing the line standing up on a run from the 32, and Robblee place-kicked the point.

As part of a three-month campaign to increase Jewish religious education among city children, Ivriah, the women's division of the Jewish Education Association, will stage a children's rally on the morning of Columbus Day in the West Side Community House, 100th Street and West End Avenue.

The public debt and the expenditures of the Federal Government will be the main subjects at the annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor on Nov. 10, it was announced yesterday.

A combination of steady, seven-hit pitching by Johnny Whitehead and a sixteen-hit attack gave the White Sox a 14-to-2 victory over the Cubs at Wrigley Field today, pulling the American Leaguers even with their rivals at two victories each in the twenty-second Chicago championship series.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Civic, social and fraternal organizations are cooperating in preparations for the reception to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in the ballroom of the Municipal Convention Hall next Wednesday night.
The Irving School went down to defeat at the hands of Hastings High School today by the score of 13-0.

The marriage of Miss Lois B. Pratt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kirby C. Pratt of this place, to Newton F. Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton P. Clark, will take place on Oct. 23 in the Asylum Avenue Baptist Church. The Rev. Frank B. Haggard will officiate.

Many members of the Summer colonies of the North and South Shores who are keeping their houses open until after election day will take part in the social activities attendant upon the sixteenth annual meeting of the West Hills Racing Association, which will take place Tuesday on the estates of Colonel Henry L. Stimson and Thomas F. White in the West Hills country.

Reflecting current public interest in photography as a medium of personal creative expression, the Colby College Camera Club has announced a School of Photography which will hold its first class on Monday.

Rumors are current that the Administration's Taxation Committee at Washington, now engaged in studies of income taxes with a view to revising the taxation structure, will recommend the retention of the tax on capital gains, but upon a basis of reporting not permitted as to investors since 1914.

Continued evidence of declining industrial activity featured the week's trade reports, and although sales increases in retail stores over a year ago were still apparent, there was definite indication that the distributors are feeling the effects of reduced plant operations.
