New York Aggies defeated Bergen College of Teaneck, N. J., today by a score of 14-0. Both teams were scoreless until the last quarter when the Aggies took the ball on their own 20-yard line and marched down the field in successive downs for their first tally. Kaplan went over for the touchdown.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Chapman, to Harry K. Townes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Townes of Greenville, S. C., took place this afternoon at the home of her parents here. The Rev. Owen R.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, leading opponent of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals, asserted in an interview here tonight that the issue "likely will produce a long and bitter fight."

THE 1937-New York Times National Book Fair, Nov. 5 to 21, will be held in the North International Building of Rockefeller Center under the joint sponsorship of THE NEW YORK TIMES and the American Book Publishers.
Opposition forces dominated the scene yesterday in the debate on the measure declaring a state of war in Brazil and opened up caustic criticism of the Administration.

Miss Sarah Parker Koppelman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Koppelman, and William Bradford Banks, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Banks, were married this evening in Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church by the Rev. Theodore Parker Ferris.
Four women have been included in a panel of thirty-six veniremen from which a jury will be chosen, beginning Wednesday, to try "John Montague" on a sevenyear-old robbery charge.

TO THE super-intellectual the film capital is, ordinarily, restful, and he is spared the trouble of having to go incognito. Take, for instance, the case of Aldous Huxley, who, draped in over the wheel of his flivver, came thudding down all the way from New Mexico, where the Hopi snakes are already going into the torpor of Winter.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Morgan, daughter of Mrs. Charles Morgan and the late Mr. Morgan of New York and this community, to James Hopkins Smith Jr., son of Mrs. Dwight F. Davis of New York and Washington and of James Hopkins Smith of New York and Aiken, S. C., took place today at noon in the Church of the Advent.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Bates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Bates of Scarsdale, N. Y., formerly of Waban and Washington, was married this afternoon to Russell Whitney Nichols, son of Mrs. Walter W. Nichols of Washington, in the Unitarian Church in Winchester. A reception followed at the Brae Burn Country Club. b.

With surveys revealing that a substantial portion of the lowest-price liquors is sold to consumers in the medium and higher income brackets, distillers have started to revise their merchandising tactics and advertising appeal this Fall, reports here yesterday indicated.

The retirement of Frank Flowers, whose post as senior chief commissary steward of the liner Leviathan during the World War made him responsible for the feeding of 100,000 soldiers on the way to France, was announced yesterday by A. J. McCarthy, vice president of the United States Lines Company.

Miss Fannie Robb Carvin, daughter of Mrs. W. John Wadsworth of this city and the late B. Depew Carvin, and her fiance, Felix Magnin, president of the London branch of the Comptoir National des Comptes de Paris, today took out a marriage license. They are to be wed on Oct. 23.

A million pieces of literature and an experienced corps of organizers have been turned loose by the United Federal Workers of America, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, to unionize the more. than 850,000 United States Government workers.
The body of Morris B. Close, Rochester Scoutmaster, who disappeared on July 19, was found tonight by two hunters in a patch of woods at East Henrietta, Rochester suburb.

Mrs. Charles Poletti, wife of State Supreme Court Justice Poletti, has been named candidate for State chairman of the League of Women Voters to succeed Mrs. Douglas M. Moffat, it was announced yesterday at local headquarters.
The inauguration of three college and university presidents in one day invites special attention to the splendid type of men who are called to these positions of leadership in the academic world.

IN this age of awakened political consciousness, one of the routine assignments of the Twentieth Century-Fox publicity staff is to protect Colonel Victor McLaglen of the California Light Horse (the only privately maintained militia in the United States besides that of Bundesfuehrer Fritz Kuhn) from himself.
William H. Farrand, editor of The Milford Leader, got a story and a tasty bit of fowl in one swoop yesterday.

Robert Knowlton Clark, who retired in 1931 after serving as Justice of the Peace for half a century, died at his home here tonight after a long illness, at the age of 86. He lived on land which had been deeded by the Indians to an ancestor, William Clark, one of the settlers of Bedford, in 1680.
A. W. A.--Cocktail tea dance. Haila Stoddard, guest of honor, 4:30 P. M., ??bhouse. Catholic Young Women's Club-Tea dance, clubhouse.

A large increase in the cathode tube and oscillograph manufacturing facilities of the Allen B. DuMont Laboratories, Inc., and plans for removal to a factory building at 2 Main Avenue, Passaic, early in February, 193S, have been announced by Allen B. DuMont, president.

Mr. Weatherly has been co-producer of "The Little Shows," "Gay Divorce" and "She Loves Me Not." IT all began one day a year ago last Summer. I remember it was a hot sticky afternoon and I was sitting alone in the office wondering what was going to become of me.
Miss Alice C. Erwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Erwin, has chosen Nov. 6 as the date for her marriage to Richard F. Newcomb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor E. Newcomb of Hasbrouck Heights.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.--?? coloring in its first glow, tingeing countryside forests, adds a new note to scenic beauty in this Midsouth seaside resort. de resort.

ROLL, GRACE R. (Aug. 18). Estate, more than $10,000. To Edward P. Roll, husband. executor, personal and household effects, life estate in residue; Edward P. Roll Jr., son, executor, Falls Church, Va., remainder interest.
A group of 250 American Legionnaires, back in Europe to visit battlefields where they fought in the World War, landed at Folkestone today for a four-day stay in London.

Kosher butcher shops in all parts of the city were jammed last night with women eager to avail themselves of prices 2 to 5 cents a pound lower than they were a week ago when the Federation of Kosher Butchers called its 5,000 members out on strike in protest against the high cost of meat.

The large home-building project at Hillside Avenue and 252d Street, Bellerose, L. I., is well under way, the builders announce. More than 300 detached cottages and two-story homes in the $4,000 price range are planned for the site. Arthur E. Allen is the architect.
The annual meeting of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board for the election of new officers will be held Wednesday evening at Michel's restaurant, 346 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.
IN Washington the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce talks safety. In New York, at Floyd Bennett Field, one of the best safeguards against the hazards of, bad-weather flying--a radio range--stands idle.
Robert K. Christenberry, vice president and general manager of the Hotel Astor, announces that the remodernization work, costing more than $1,500,000, is nearing completion.
Clinton Frank was Yale's Big Boy Blue today and tonight all New Haven was singing his praises after the Elis had defeated Pennsylvania for the fourth successive year, 27 to 7.
Mrs. Adele Lehman Grotta of 241 Central Park West, widow of Frederick D. Grotta, former president of the M. Stein Cosmetic Company, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness.

The American Chemical Society announced yesterday the election of sixty-five chemists to administrative and editorial posts in the society, which now has more than 20,000 members. The divisional officers are:

Victory or defeat to the Yankees and Giants will be worth the difference of $1,945.61 apiece when they share the third largest players' pool in world series history. The total pool of $417,305.97 has been exceeded only by those of 1928 and 1936, The Associated Press reports.
Classrooms and dormitories from coast to coast are crowded beyond capacity this Fall with what is presumably the largest throng of students ever to attend college in this or any other country.

Night and day classes for adults and juveniles beyond the State school age requirements will open Monday in Newark schools for the fifth consecutive year. The day classes will be confined to persons desiring to study English and citizenship.

Emerging from the cool highlands, where our expedition has spent most of the Summer, into the Tanganyika plains, where we are proceeding to photograph the wildest tribes remaining in Africa, we have encountered the greatest hazard of our trip to date in raging grass fires covering thousands of square miles and stampeding hundreds of thousands of wild animals.
Two tough football squads, Tennessee and Duke, battled to a scoreless tie today in an interConference game.

President Roosevelt will go to the country by radio Tuesday evening with a "fireside chat," in which he is expected to declare that his recent Western visit convinced him the country wants the Wages and Hours Bill, crop control and other New Deal legislation, and wants them quickly.

Patrons of the Walton Hotel were left without electric lights, elevator service, heat and running water for an hour and a half today when members of Local 356 of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers Industrial Union, affiliate of the C. I. O., struck at 11:30 A. M. in a demand for union recognition, shorter hours and higher pay. Maids, cooks,

China has expressed her readiness to attend a conference of signatories to the Nine-power treaty. Replying to an invitation sent out Wednesday by the Aga Khan, president of the League Assembly, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui cabled from Nanking:

Girl Scouts and their leaders began assembling today for their convention in the city where the late Juliette Gordon Low founded the organization twenty-five years ago. A tablet in memory of Mrs. Low will be unveiled.

Research is a social responsibility shared by all universities and its integrity must be maintained, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, set forth in his annual report, published today.

An action to test the legality of the service of summons for traffic Violations by tying them to automobile doors was filed yesterday before Magistrate McGee in traffic court by Thomas F. Galvin, an attorney.

Robert M. Hutchins, President of the University of Chicago, asserted today that despite the fact the United States had the most extensive and elaborate educational system in the world, its people, even those who took the highest degrees, were still uneducated.
A building erected nearly a century ago in Milton, Wis., and still standing, is said to be the first architectural concrete structure erected in the United States.
The Meadow Brook Club's annual Fall invitation best-ball golf tournament got under way today, with twenty-eight teams taking part in the competition.

One of the significant features in the planning of large residential centers within recent years is the careful attention being given by developers to the value of good community planning. That attitude has doubtless been intensified in many cases by the FHA housing
BOTH in "Time and the Conways" and in his more recent piece "I Have Been Here Before," Mr. Priestley is uncommonly modest in his claims. s claims.

Michigan's, dead-game Wolverines stopped Northwestern's vaunted land attack today, but their aerial defense faltered for one all-important second and the Wildcats fashioned a thrilling 7-to-0 triumph, to open their defense of the Big Ten gridiron championship.

Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Jenks of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mollie Todd Jenks, to Edward Victor Donaldson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donaldson, also of Pelham Manor.
Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor will sail Friday on the Normandie to visit England, France and Switzerland. They will return Nov. 15 and will be at Mayfair House for the Winter.

NEXT Thursday four communities will observe the eightieth birthday of a man upon whom much of their prosperity depends. On that day Binghamton, Johnson City, Endicott and Owego will pay tribute to George F. Johnson.

The Life Insurance Adjustment Bureau established six years ago at the suggestion of a special committee of the National Conference of Social Work has helped 514,406 needy families to retain insurance protection through the depression, Edwin G. Eklund, manager of the bureau, anounced yesterday.

Locusts have arrived in such great numbers that the sun is obscured. Road traffic has been impeded near La Luz and El Domingo, ten miles from Managua. Automobile driver were advised to use chains in certain sections because the cars became stuck in the mangled mass of insects reaching almost to the hubs.
Political orators ended tonight nation-wide cantonal election campaigns that they consider a test of the strength of the Popular Front Government.

Miss Ellen S. Marvin will give a tea on Thursday at the Cosmopolitan Club for members of the board of managers of the Union Settlement, under whose auspices the benefit performance of the Gilbert Miller production, "French Without Tears," will be given on Oct. 20 at Henry Miller's Theatre.

In order to get comprehensive information on the treatment accorded to citizens of the United States, with investments of $2,000,000,000 in Mexico, State Department officials met here today with all United States Consuls in Mexico. That a more realistic United States policy in Mexico might evolve from the conference seemed likely.

THE quantity of good music heard today in the Soviet Union is tremendous. From Turkestan to Arkhangelsk, from Leningrad to mid-Siberia, the works of the masters are given daily on the opera or concert stage and over the radio.

There has been much talk of boycotting Japan for her undeclared war upon China. It has been heard in Britain and in Geneva, where the Far Eastern Advisory Committee of the League of Nations is preparing to take steps in the hope of ending the conflict. Many thought it was implied in President Roosevelt's speech at Chicago.

Thomas E. Dewey, Fusion candidate for District Attorney, declared last night in an address before the American Labor party in the Seventh Assembly District, at 204 West Eighty-fourth Street, that he proposed to show how the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket was able to operate in New York City.

Evening shoes of the Winter's mode reflect the vivid sparkle of the gowns they are to be worn with. Brilliant multicolored sequins like those that shot through the Paris dress collections have been put on shoes too, so that they may scintillate with equal gayety.

Despite the severe cold spell last Winter, the Southern California citrus crop is expected to show financial returns far in excess of previous year averages. Returns from all citrus fruits handled by the California Fruit Growers Exchange may, it is estimated, exceed those of 1936 by as much as $5,000,000, with $4,500,000 set as a minimum.
Sister Rose Leontine, a member of the Sisters of Charity and a sister of Fire Chief Joseph L. Murphy of Kingston, N. Y., Fire Department, died Wednesday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Yonkers.

Mr. and Mrs. George McIntyre of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Georgia B. McIntyre, to Frank Alden Miller, son of Mrs. Frank H. Miller of Westfield and the late Mr. Miller.

EIGHTEEN pair of subscription concerts will be given by the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, under Vladimir Golschmann, in St. Louis, Mo., this season, starting Nov. 5. Albert Stoessel will appear as guest conductor at the concerts of Feb. 4 and 5. First of the soloists on the list is Yehudi Menuhin.
Crashing the University of Maine line irresistibly, a powerful University of New Hampshire eleven defeated the Black Bears, 13 to 0, before a crowd of more than 3,000 on Alumni Field today.

THE place, I imagine, as you approach a modernized-facade at 9 o'clock next Friday evening, will be ablaze with light from basement to roof, the sole tenebrous quarter through force alone of necessity, that as yet un-excavated ground-floor wing to the right of the entrance-and, the Grand Tour completed, celebrants may not, of course, find strength remaining for a descent to the boiler room and pipe trench. .

The marriage of Miss Katherine Stewart Wallace of Clear View, Va., to Sidney Bayley Silleck of Scarsdale, N. Y., took place this afternoon in St. George's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Dudley Booghter, the rector, officiated.

Class 12. Horsemanship (children under 13)-First. Miss Carol Jane Adler. Port Chester N. Y.; second, Miss Mary Hayes, New Brunswick. N. J.; third, Miss Barbara Bower, Montclair, N. J.; fourth, Miss Mary Frances Penny, Bye, N. Y.; fifth, Frank Clarke Jr., New Brunswick, N. J.; sixth, Miss Pat Kennedy, Larchmont, N. Y.

Boys High's powerful eleven recorded its sixteenth straight triumph over a span of three campaigns yesterday by conquering Samuel J. Tilden High, 25 to 6, at Boys High Field. Jack Barmak, right halfback, starred for the victors, making three touchdowns.

BALCERZAK, HELENA (Sept. 6, 1937). Gross estate, $19,905; net, $17,323. To husband, Wojciech Balcerzak. Chief assets, real estate, $6,500; jointly owned property, $13,405. Robert L. Jagocki, 99 Nassau St., Manhattan, attorney.

Among the "firsts" of the current world series,. recorded in the fourth game at the Polo Grounds yesterday, were Burgess Whitehead's stolen base and the Yankees' mass argument with Umpire Bill Stewart.

Scoring on the first play of the game, Georgia Tech went on to defeat the University of Kentucky football team, 32 to 0, on a soggy field today, thus marring the Kentuckians' first home showing before a crowd of about 7,500.

THE concept of the Noble Savage antedates Rousseau; probably goes right back to Adam wishing he was inside Eden again. And there are several actors in Hollywood today prepared to back to the limit the idea that going primitive is the way to happiness, green pastures and, by a strange anomaly, public esteem. Consider, for example,
IT is only a few months since John Dickson Carr gave us all the creeps with a masterly tale of mystery and horror that dug strangely into old witchcrafts and legendary depths of dark magic.
AS a second celebration in honor, this year, of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of its Print Department, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has just opened a large display of lithographs.

For the first time in twenty-five years, New York ill welcome the grand council officers and delegates of the twenty-three Greek-letter fraternities for women, comprising the National Panhellenic Congresss, on Thursday.
Spanish Insurgents hurled their full strength into battle today to blast a path for a final advance on Gijon, the Government's last Biscayan stronghold.

Fordham College's centennial class, the present freshman class which will graduate in 1941 when Fordham celebrates the 100th anniversary of its founding, is considered one of the best in scholastic ranking of any in the history of the institution,

ANOTHER wide fluctuation in retail trade results was the experience of the week. In some sections weather received the blame again, but in one important area, the Middle West, it was indicated that favorable weather failed to revive retail demand. The Southwest continued to put in the best reports.

Mrs. Aaron J. Levy heads a group of women working toward the success of the all-star entertainment in behalf of the Hebrew National Orphan Home, of which her husband, Supreme Court Justice Levy, is president.

Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson reserved decision today on an application by owners of the Orangeburg dog track for an injunction restraining the police from interfering with their business. Justice Patterson indicated a jury trial might be necessary and, if he did find there was a question of fact, he would call the trial early next week.

Many inquiries regarding the auction sale next Saturday of 450 plots in the Flushing Manor development in the sections bounded by 154th Street, Willetts Point and Cross Island Boulevards and Bayside Avenue, Flushing, L. I., are being received by J. Edward Breuer, auctioneer.
Wilbraham Academy today lost its opening game to Taft School, 13-7. Both teams tallied in the second half, a short pass from Provinzano to Prentis providing Wilbraham's score.
Miss Ethel Winthrop Kopper, daughter of Mrs. Robert Porter Barbour of this place, has chosen the evening of Nov. 11 for her wedding to Alfred E. Smith, son of Mrs. Walter Smith of Upper Montclair.

One of the best examples of good crabapple planting to be seen in the East is in the parks of Rochester, N. Y., where two Japanese Flowering Crabapples (the flowers of which are light pink and gradually fade to white), are planted against a dense white pine woods.
Penn State scored in the last minute of play to take a thrilling battle from Bucknell today before 11,000 fans on alumni home-coming day. The score was 20-14.

Every dog had his day in New York last week. The canine family became a prime topic of conversation despite the fact that there were wars in China and Spain, and even though a question of baseball superiority was being settled at the Polo Grounds and the Yankee Stadium.

China will ask the powers participating in the forthcoming conference to be held under the Nine-power treaty to supply her with munitions and to apply economic discipline against Japan, Dr. C. T. Wang the Chinese Ambassador, predicted today. He added that he had had no official intimation from the Nanking government as to what its policy would be and was expressing only his own personal opinion.
Mrs. Myrtle Arrington, 39, who broke her neck last Sunday and gave birth to her nineteenth child Thursday, was happily convalescent today.

Several sales of properties in Connecticut have been closed by Kenneth Ives Co. Among them was the four and one-half acre estate with a century-old remodeled Colonial house, formerly owned by Mrs. J. J. Brady at Stamford, which was purchased by A. Zeckendorf.

Designed to counteract intellectual provincialism and indifference which often characterize the attitude of a teacher of one language toward another language, a new Foreign Language Center was formed yesterday at the City College School of Business, Twentythird Street and Lexington Avenue.
The Navy Department, in association with the Weather Bureau, will establish a new station in the AlaskaAleutian Island area for aerological observations this Winter.

Members of the Wells College Club of New York will hold their annual dinner Oct. 18 at the Women's University Club. The speakers will include Dr. Richard W. Armour, head of the English department of Wells College, and Dorothy Kenyon, Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Department of Public Markets.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today discontinued its proceeding on proposed proportional grain rates between ports of the Federal Barge Line, holding that it has no jurisdiction. It suggested that if the barge line desires the commission's opinion on the reasonableness of the proposed rates it should proceed to obtain joint rates under the Inland Waterways Corporation Act.

The fighting Illini lived up to the glorious tradition of their name with the gridiron upset of the day by holding vaunted Notre Dames to a scoreless tie today in the first game between these teams in thirty-nine years.

The savings and loan associations in the country disbursed $106,796,800 in mortgage loans to 45,750 families during the month of August, reports Morton Bodfish, executive vice president of the United States Building and Loan League.
Miss Ella M. Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester W. Ford of Rahway, was married to Allison Baker Sears, son of Mrs. Alice Phillips, also of this city, here today at the home of her parents.
Dr. and Mrs. J. James Condran of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Condran, to S. Douglas Brian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Brian, also of Easton.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Rives Harding, daughter of Nelson Harding of this place and the late Mrs. Harding, to Emil Morosini Jr., son of Mrs. Emil Morosini of Scranton, Pa., and the late Mr. Morosini, has been announced by her father.

Miss Barbara Baldwin, daughter of Mrs. Myron Turner Townsend of this place, was married this morning to Lawrence A. Coleman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Coleman, also of Pelham, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Townsend here.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn Sloan, daughter of John Sloan, architect, and Mrs. Sloan of this city, to Robert Harllee Carmichael, son of William D. Carmichael of the Plaza and the late Mrs. Carmichael, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Woods.

Scores of written arguments for and against tariff concessions in the proposed reciprocal trade agreement to be negotiated with Czechoslovakia were on the way to Washington today, as foreign trade and domestic interests prepared to defend their points of view in the sharpest controversy raised since the reciprocal trade program was inaugurated three years ago.
An appeal to workers not to vote for Tammany candidates was made last night by Norman Thomas, Socialist National Chairman, at a campaign dinner at 1.422 Wilkins Avenue, the Bronx.
Five scientists will receive $2,500 each for a year's work in chemistry and related sciences, under plans announced today by the Lalor Foundation.

The marriage of Miss Helen Klintrup, daughter of Mrs. Lydia M. Klintrup of Mountain Lakes, to Van Buren Taliaferro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Pendleton Taliaferro of New York, took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's sister, Mrs. William E. Seely on Woodley Road.

A jury of six and one alternate, composed of elderly farmers, a grocer, a well-driller and an unemployed man, was puzzled today by the capsule story to which the State has been limited in its attempts to convict six former Tampa policemen of flogging Joseph Shoemaker to death after he had refused to get out of the city when told to do so by the Ku Klux Klan.

Evidently of the impression that touchdowns are apt to be few and far between from now on, Fordham made the most of its final light test yesterday, setting willing Waynesburg back on its heels by 48 to 0.

NINE-THIRTY any morning in Callander, Ont.: On a once lonely road where a few years ago a settler could on occasion shoot a wolf from his own log cabin, traffic police, as spruce and authoritative as any on Broadway, direct the seemingly endless lines of cars.

Alexander Hoffman, 35 years old, of 2,830 Olinville Avenue, the Bronx, managing director of the Cleaners, Dyers, Pressers, Drivers and Allied Trades Local 239 of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, surrendered yesterday on an indictment naming him with seven others in connection with the throwing of stench-bombs into two cleaning establishments.

Colonel Fred V. S. Chamberlain, Professor of Military Science and Tactics, announced yesterday the appointment of seventy-six cadet officers in the Reserve Officers Training Corps at the University Heights center of New York University.

Mrs. Helen Binney Kitchel, Greenwhich representative in the Legislature for three sessions and a the leader of the fight against spoliation of Connecticut scenery by billboards, has given to the State Forestry Department a 500-acre forest tract in the Town of Colebrook.

Lawrenceville conquered the Tome football team, 14-0, today. Captain Rose accounted for the entire Lawrenceville score. He went over in the second quarter on a 25-yard run and again in the fourth on a delayed run through center.
Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 6, aggregated $9,500,000,000, or 16 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week

William A. Dewane died of heart disease here today at the age of 72. He had been head of Dewane Brothers Company, farm implement dealers, in which he was associated for many years with five brothers. Three brothers had died and the other two retired.
Lewis Mumford, author and critic, will speak at the Wheaton College Founders' Day exercises Saturday on "The Significance of Modern Architecture."

A covering movement carried cotton prices up 32 to 37 points from early lows on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday when overnight consideration of Friday's bumper crop figures failed to produce a large volume of selling orders.
Halting every Wesleyan attempt to gain both on the ground and in the air, Bowdoin today scored a 13-0 upset.

In a free-scoring game that was cut I from the pattern of a grossly illogical fiction plot, Army defeated Columbia, 21 to 18, in Michie Stadium today and left a gathering of 20,000 utterly limp and exhausted at the finish.
PAINTINGS from ten of the Spanish-American nations have been assembled for the opening exhibition at the Delphic Studios, now in attractive quarters at 44 West Fifty-sixth Street.

Members of the Council of Catholic Women of the Archdiocese of Chicago voted today to resign from the Illinois Congress of Parents and Teachers unless it withdraws its recent adoption of a birth control program.

Within a few hours death struck twice in Rochester today and claimed two women who had worked together for nineteen years in building health and vitality into the lives of hundreds of children of this city.
Charles L. Lancaster, former city editor of the Pittsburgh Sun and the Pittsburgh Dispatch, died yesterday at his home in suburban Bellevue. His age was 79.

A powerful Trinity College team turned back a last-half rally by Worcester Tech today to score a 26-19 victory. After Tech opened the scoring with a touchdown by Halfback Kingsley, the heavier Trinity team took command and, with the passing combination of O'Malley-Truex clicking, made three tallies to end the first half with a 20-to-7 lead.

WHEN the first heavy snow drives the deer and elk from the high plateaus of the Montana Rockies, the old packers will start oiling their saddles and getting the kinks out of their ropes in preparation for a season of the best big-game hunting in years.

Coq Bruyere, son of Coq Gaulois, won the third and final leg to retire the Pennsylvania Hunt Cup for Owner John Strawbridge at the Fall meeting of the Whitemarsh Hunt Club today. The event was over a three-and-a-half-mile timber course.

A wider outlet in jewelry stores for better-grade electrical appliances of the gift variety is foreseen by appliance manufacturers as the result of a decision by the American National Retail Jewelers Association designating electrical appliances as proper for eighth wedding anniversary gifts.

A group of ministers' daughters who feel that they are grossly maligned in publications, on the stage and in international jokes have organized the Society of the Daughters of Preachers, it was announced here yesterday by Miss Maxine Watkins, 545 Fifth Avenue, who explained that she was secretary of the organization.
Dr. Matias Duque, 68, former Secretary of Health, today was inoculated with cancer virus in an attempt to prove that the disease is contagious.

The gallant attempt of an underrated team of Kansas State football players to continue the ties that characterized their last two meetings with Missouri was wrecked by a break in the fourth period today and Missouri walked off the field with a 14-to-7 victory in the opening Big Six contest.

Led by Big Bill Tranavitch, who scored two touchdowns and added three extra points from placement, the Rutgers football team defeated the University of Delaware Mudhens, 27 to 0, before 4,000 persons on Neilson Field today.

Sunny Thoughts, a wrong shot owned by Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark and ridden by J. V. H. Davis, won the International Gold Cup race today from a crack field of jumpers and qualified for the Grand National at Aintree, England.

GENERAL FRANCO of the Spanish Rebels has released an overprinted set of twenty-nine values to commemorate the first anniversary of the revolution. The overprint, "Viva Espana! Franco Queipo-July, 1936, 1937," is on a special delivery adhesive, several Rebel issues and numerous regular Spanish stamps which had been confiscated by Franco.

IT will be a long time before we catch up with the ancients. Of course we have rediscovered a good many things, such as artificial ice and the iodine treatment for goitre; and our movies and our machine guns are probably an improvement on theirs;

Having followed with some amusement the hot argument stirred up by the proposed time of the Toscanini broadcasts, to which I would listen even if they came at 4 A. M. on Blue Monday, I am surprised that two of the most important arguments are merely touched upon in the letter by F. W. Stix of Avondale, Ohio, without being seized immediately by your sharp-eyed department as the decisive factors:

Rehabilitation of Standish Hall, a fifteen - story apartment - hotel structure at 41 West Eighty-first Street, has been completed, P. Walker Morrison, Lazarus Joseph and Leon Leighton, trustees for Series B-K New York Title and Mortgage Company defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates, announced yesterday.

The Almoners will hold their first meeting for this season tomorrow , afternoon at Sherry's, when plans will be discussed for the organization's various charitable events for the late Autumn and Winter.
Miss Eleanor Diana Vassall Lee-Warner became the bride of Tobias Wagner this afternoon in the Leslie Lindsey Memorial Chapel of Emanuel Church.

A series of radio broadcasts dramatizing Latin-American life and problems was announced today by the Interior Department, beginning Nov. 1. Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, executive Secretary of the Committee on Cooperation in Latin America, has been engaged as technical adviser for the programs, which will have the general title of "Brave New World."

The ruling made by Colombia that the consular invoice must show accurately all charges on the merchandise up to the time that it reaches the Colombian port, which has disturbed exporters, is being taken up with Dr. Gabriel Garces, Colombian. consul general here, by the Merchants Association of New York.

Belief that the Republican party has better than an even chance of electing a majority of the delegates to next year's constitutional convention was expressed yesterday at a conference of candidates for delegates at large with William S. Murray, State Chairman, at the State party headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street.

ON Tuesday four airplanes will climb into the sky above Ciudad Trujillo, capital of the Dominican Republic, thus commencing the first leg of a 21,000 mile Pan-American good-will tour of fifty cities in twenty-six countries of the Americas.

The Norwegian whaling industry, one of the country's most important upon which about 80,000 people are dependent, is threatened with collapse. Norwegian ship owners are meeting increasing foreign competition, especially from Germany, which is developing a whaling industry.
At, the new $1,250,000 factory of the Celotex Corporation in Metuchen, N. J., two new products are now being turned out, according to B. G. Dahlberg, president of the company.
A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held in the board headquarters, 500 Park Avenue, Wednesday afternoon at 41 o'clock.
A new chapter in the history of the administration of the University of New Hampshire began today when Dr. Fred Engelhardt was inducted as ninth president.

FIRST RACE--The Baywood; purse $300; 3-year-olds and upward; one and one-half miles over hurdles. First. Richard K. Mellon's Toolbox (J. Magee); second, Mrs. Oliver M. Kauffmann's Caesar's Ghost (S. Walters); third, H. E. Talbott's Lloyd Hoen (L. Walton). Time--2:30 1-5.
Miss Lucile Forman, daughter of Mrs. Harry B. Spaulding of this city and the late George A. Forman, has selected Oct. 30 as the date for her marriage to Chauncey Jerome Hamlin Jr., also of Buffalo.

Five major two-day "battles" were fought on and around the great Leon Springs military reservation near here this week, as 12,000 regular army troops, assembled from all over the nation, completed the second phase of the most important manoeuvres since the World War.

Mrs. Charles W. Peelle gave a tea yesterday at her home in Douglaston, Queens, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Louise Peelle, to Henry Lawrence Sparks, son of Mrs. Henry Lawrence Sparks of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Sparks.
Four games were played yesterday in the New York Field Hockey Association club series at Prospect Park in Brooklyn. The Orioles defeated the Cosmo Cubs, 2 to 0; Greenfield set back Etcetera, 7 to 0;

The Port Chester High School football team, Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association champion, opened its league season with a 7-to-6 triumph over New Rochelle High at Senior Field before nearly 5,000 spectators today.

Consideration of some of the possibilitles in low-cost housing improvements provided in the WagnerSteagall bill for low-rent dwelling projects will have an important part on the program during the convention in Pittsburgh, Oct. 20 to 22, inclusive, of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
S. D. A. Grey, 48, wartime flier called "Daredevil Grey," fell to his death from a ninth floor window today when fixing a radio aerial.
THE 1938 Dodge passenger car, offered in ten body selections, was announced today by the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation.

Before President Roosevelt had started back home on his tour through the Northwest he was telling visiting members of Congress that he would see them soon in Washington. By the time he got to Grand Forks, N. D., he was confident enough of a special session to give the strongest public hints that one would be called.
MANY novelties by Dutch and other composers will appear on the programs of the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, Holland, which is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, during the current season.

A reduction in interest rates to 4 1/2 per cent and an increase in the period of amortization from twenty to thirty years would make it possible for approximately 5,000,000 additional families of moderate income to purchase their own homes, states Lowell J. Chawner, chief of the construction and real property section of the Department of Commerce.

David Lynn, architect of the Capitol, said today that workmen making improvement on the building would have to work overtime to have things in shape for a special session of Congress if it is called for November and that painting and refurnishing of certain sections would have to be postponed.

AT a time when certain leading distillers are warning the public through advertisements against driving while under the influence of liquor, the Highway Research Board has called attention to a portion of the annual report of the California Department of Motor Vehicles which analyzes the involvement of had been-drinking drivers in motor accidents. cidents.

RANK R. McNINCH, temporarily appointed by President Roosevelt as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, intimated during his first press conference during the past week that he might favor Federal regulation of radio program advertising rates.
There has been a chill in the air this week, carrying the unpleasant message of the coming of Winter. At best only seven or eight weeks of good fighting weather remain.
Harmless in appearance but at heart temperamental with a heap of bad habits, the United States freighter Ormidale lay in Three Rivers harbor today while mechanics fumed over her stubborn motors.

Miss Dorothy Dowling of Montclair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Dowling of Far Hills, became the bride of Herbert Allen Strandberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jonas Strandberg of East Orange, this afternoon.

A quartet of amateur speed boat officials and drivers representing four sections of the country has been slated tentatively by the American Power Boat Association nominating committee for the annual election to be held Oct. 28 at the Hotel Lexington.

Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, speaking last week over station WABC, called attention to some of the detrimental features of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act and also commented on some of its prospective benefits.

Miss Sabra Roberts, daughter of Captain Frank Hamilton Roberts, U. S. N., secretary of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Roberts, this afternoon was married to Smith Hempstone Oliver of New York, a son of Captain Frederick Lansing Oliver, U. S. N.. retired, and Mrs. Oliver.

VICTORIA THE GREAT," which has had a triumphant London premiere prior to its New York opening, and which has already won the Cup of All Nations at the Venice Film Exposition, is considered another outstanding example in British film making.

The new twenty-story apartment house at 565 West End Avenue, northwest corner of Eighty-seventh Street, completed a month ago, is now 95 per cent rented, according to the Wood Dolson Company, agents. The structure contains ninety-nine apartments.

A NEW pattern begins to appear in the picture of American-flag sea-travel routes. The long-debated new national merchant fleet comes into the design as an actuality, as its first and largest liner is approved for construction.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Taylor of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Taylor, to M. Edgerton Newcomb, son of Mrs. Mortimer E. Newcomb, also of Westfield, and the late Mr. Newcomb.
Distribution of $9,500,000 among tenants and share croppers for purchases of land under Title I of the Bank-head-Jones Farm Tenant Act was announced today by the Farm Security Administration.

There has been a large subscription for the card party, fashion show and tea which has been arranged by members of the Altar Society of the Church of Our Lady of Refuge in Brooklyn for next Saturday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the organization's parochial school building fund.
IT must be granted at the outset that "The Heart of the Furnace" is a novel of unusual power. The blind have, of course. been used as characters here and
Princeton University will hear nine prominent theologians at the university's Sunday chapel services during the 1937-38 term, the Rev. Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of the chapel, has announced.

General Prince Cantacuzenu, leader of the "All for the Nation" party-which camouflaged the resuscitation of the Iron Guard-died today at the age of 68. He figured in the investigation of the assassination of Premier Duca, being charged with complicity, but he was acquitted. He was one of the most fervent adherents of Rumanian fascism.

Mrs. Perry L. Miles, wife of Major Gen. Miles, commanding general of the First Division, will give a tea on Thursday at the Polo Club, Fort Hamilton, for the sponsors and patronesses of the polo game to be played Oct. 23 at Fort Hamilton between the First Division team and Squadron C of the 101st Cavalry, New York National Guard.

Christ Lutheran Church at 406 East Nineteenth Street, situated in what is called the "gas-house district," numbers among its oldest living members Mrs. Herman Witthaus, who is 80 years old and resides at 427 East Fifteenth Street.

The Federal Housing Administration points out that its activities must not be confounded with those of the United States Housing Authority which came into being with the recent passage in Congress of the Wagner-Steagall Act and approved by President Roosevelt on Sept. 1, last.
A heavier University of Wisconsin eleven wore down an inexperienced University of Chicago team today and romped away with a 27-to-0 victory in the opening Big Ten game for both teams.

Damages of [Pound]2,200 have been awarded to an 18-month-old girl in an action brought against the proprietress of a hospital in which visitors arriving to see the baby nine days after birth, found that a parrot belonging to a nurse had attacked the child while she was lying in a bassinet, eaten away the tip of her nose and crushed the tips of three fingers.

Miss Helen Dorothy Jacobus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Curtis Jacobus of Orange, was married to Robert L. Davis, son of Joseph Davis of East Orange, this afternoon in the Caldwell Methodist Episcopal Church. The pastor, the Rev. Harry Leurich, performed the ceremony.

Donoho Co. have proposed their retirement as members of the New York Stock Exchange, effective on Oct. 16. Aubrey S. Whiteley, the Exchange member of the firm, will retire from it on that date. Climax Molybdenum Company common stock, no par value, has been admitted to the list.

Miss Marjorie Adams Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Leroy Smith of this place was married here this evening to Ernest Loizeaux Lough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Lough of Plainfield, N. J. The Rev. Richard W. Gray,
BACK in 1871 the Grand Duke Alexis of Imperial Russia came to this country to hunt buffalo, under the guidance of the famous Colonel William F. (Buffalo Bill) Cody.

ON the Fox lot the only quintet in the world with six players is bringing after-lunch idlers from the Cafe de la Paix to the rehearsal stage to listen to a brand of music that is at one and the same time as free as a "jam session" and as authoritatively for mal as a Debussy cake walk-and not unacquainted with the humor of both. oth.
Vermont's State Forest Service employes had a distinct shock the other day. A letter was received at the office of the chief forester, enclosing an anonymous contribution of $2 toward reforestation.

THERE was a time, about 1830, when romanticism, which had swept over French literature, passed into manners, and society people not only warmed for the heroes of Lord Byron, Goethe or Lamartine but eagerly wished to live the lives of Lara, Werther or Jocelyn George Sand is the typical example of one who carried into her mode of existence the fury of passion and hunger for sensation she painted in her novels.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Dowling of Montclair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Dowling of Far Hills, to Herbert Allen Strandberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jonas Strandberg of East Orange, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander O. Allen of Bloomfield.

For nearly a month now Germans and others able. to look behind the scenes of the National Socialist regime have watched with concern and some amusement the efforts of the acting Economic Minister and Reichsbank President, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, to resign one or both of his offices. So far he has not succeeded.
Scoring in every quarter, Connecticut State rushed, kicked and passed its way to a 36-to-7 victory over Massachusetts State on Alumni Field today.
About 400 high school students will be guests of the college committee of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs here Saturday at their sixth annual College Day.

A field trial meeting for spaniels that has rapidly developed into one of the most interesting and important of the Autumn season is that given by the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association at Saybrook. The dates selected for this year's event are Tuesday and Wednesday, Oct. 26 and 27.

Scoring a touchdown in each of the first three periods and two in the fourth, Harvard rolled up 34 points today against Tuss McLaughry's Brown eleven. However, Brown had the satisfaction of crossing the Crimson goal line so that the final count was 34 to 7. The Bears' touchdown was made in the third period.

William G. McKibbon, 41, sat stoically today in the wheel chair to which he has been confined for the past seven years and heard a Superior Court jury convict him of manslaughter in the death of his mother, Mrs. Margaret McKibbon, 74.

As a public health and medical research center, the Yale University School of Medicine is entered into a new era particularly through its present objective, the exploration of the cancer field, due to the establishment of the Jane Coffin Childs Memorial Fund for Medical Research, which was announced in June, by James Rowland Angell, retiring president of the university.

Because his two associate lawyers are in prison at Barcelona, Benito Pabon, chief advocate for the defense of the POUM prisoners, will not return to Spain from France unless he gets a guarantee of safe-conduct from the Valencia Government.

A victory - starved Lafayette eleven eked out a close 2-0 triumph over the Gettysburg Bullets today when a swarm of Leopards blocked Hamilton's punt from his goal line to score a safety early in the fourth quarter before 1,200 on the Memorial Field gridiron in driving rain.

Miss Elizabeth Davenport Morton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Davenport Morton, was married here tonight to Harry Douglas Forsyth in the First Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Russell C. Stroupe.

This message is being sent to Peiping by means that cannot be divulged. The writer has been arrested once as a- suspected spy and has been given to understand by the Japanese that if he tries to leave this city he will be arrested again.
DIVERSITY of subject matter and approach has been very marked in the first wave of exhibitions which swept into the New York galleries in the opening week of October.
President Federico Laredo Bru tonight vetoed a bill recently approved by Congress granting sugar producers a mortgage moratorium up to 1945.

ROMULUS, son of the wolf, is creating no little stir as he moves here and there about the film capital, though a good deal of secrecy is being injected into the proceedings by the authorities as incident after incident is registered in studio conversations. rsations.
HOW does a girl get a stage job in New York City?" was the burthen of a letter published in these columns on Nov. 15, 1936.
TELEVISION is beckoning showmen and economists. Scientists, who have been nurturing the spritely images for many years, are now ready and anxious for programs to test their optical contraptions.

YANKEES-A cheer greeted Carl Hubbell as he strode to the mound and Frankie Crosetti as he stepped to the plate, officially starting the fourth game. Hubbell's first two pitches were balls. The count went to three and two as Crosetti fouled off three.
WHEATLAND, the one-time home of James Buchanan, will be dedicated by the Wheatland Foundation on Thursday, and thus formally opened, another of the homes of the Presidents will be a public shrine.

Edward Belasco, San Francisco and Los Angeles theatrical producer, and brother of the late David Belasco of New York, died tonight. His age was 63. Ill for some time, his death was hastened by a stroke.
THE great Sam Goldwyn, who already has so many feathers in his cap that he must feel like a pow-wow Indian, has probably already sent his head-dress to a hatter to make room for at least one more.

Drexel scored a 26-25 victory over Franklin and Marshall in an Eastern Pennsylvania Conference game today, tallying the winning touchdown during the last minute of play when Nannos caught a pass over the goal line.

Miss Sarah Livingston Floyd, daughter of Mrs. Webb Floyd of this city and the late Mr. Floyd, was married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church to John MacBeth Richard, son of Mrs. Joseph C. Richard, also of New York, and the late Mr. Richard.

Subscription lists for season patron memberships for the National Horse Show, to be held Nov. 3-10 at Madison Square Garden, will close this week, it has been announced by Whitney Stone, secretary of the National Horse Show Association.

A definite trend to extremely specialized retail outlets, with the object of cutting costs and eliminating markdowns and special sales, appears to be developing, with announcements last week of two innovations in store merchandising.

Along a ninety-mile front the largest forces yet engaged in China began a battle yesterday in Southern Hopeh. The Japanese were trying to defeat twenty Chinese divisions guarding the railway leading into Shansi. At Shanghai the Chinese are strongly reinforcing their defenses in Chapei but the Japanese hope to outflank them with big artillery. [Page 1.]
At last Japan is in for the final, for the knockout decision, the once for all housecleaning of all tortuous tangles in the Sino-Japanese relations which have been plaguing the East for ages.

The following Foreign Service changes since Oct. 2 were announced today by the State Department: Sidney E. O'Donoghue of Passaic, N. J., now assigned to the Department of State. assigned to Havana, Cuba, as Second Secretary of Embassy.
Bloomfield High School's power returned today to turn back a stubborn but outclassed South Side eleven of Newark, 33 to 6.

Modern Age Books, new publisher of paper-backed volumes headed by Richard Storrs Childs, president of the City Club and a supporter of Mayor La Guardia, has recalled from its several thousand outlets the 50,000-copy first edition of John F. Carter's unauthorized biography of the Mayor, "La Guardia," Mr. Childs announced last night.

DESIGN a plane": the head men say, It must be built in such a way, That the dumbest mug can fly hands off, Make the hardest landings still feel soft, Make up for brains that the pilot lacks, Make the seats lean forward and still lean back. Supply and demand will be the thing, Forget the span of chord and wing. g.

The Italian Government rejected today every suggestion contained in the Anglo-French note of Oct. 2 inviting Italy to a triangular conversation on Spain and proposed instead that the non-intervention Problem be discussed in the London committee.

" Let us keep cool heads," Sir Thomas Inskip, Defense Coordination Minister, stated in an address here tonight. Because the Nyon anti-pirate agreement was successful was "no reason for any rash adventures" by Great Britain, he said.

Having secured the passage of his Constitution, President Eamon de Valera presented to the Dail Eireann a sheaf of new bills this week, the purport of which was to give legislative effect to the new basic charter.

Administration leaders found two favorable trends today in their search for an answer to give angry housewives. Mayors and Governors who are demanding that the Federal Government do something about the high cost of food.
THE English theatre is escapist-so it is dead. That is what I have been hearing repeated since I have been in New York.

The International Labor Organization's governing body adopted today by a vote of 20 to 6 the Franco-American resolution giving consideration to the blanket forty-hour convention by putting it on the agenda of the June conference, with a final reading in 1939.

Harold Tine, an Andover Academy reserve halfback, furnished the sensation of today's annual game with the Yale freshmen when he dashed 65 yards, the longest run of the contest, for the only Andover score. With four minutes left to play, Tine registered, although the Eli yearlings finally won, 21 to 6.

Showing a fine set of backs, La Salle M. A. turned back St. Paul's School, 26 to 6, today for its second victory of the season. The winners scored in every period except the third, with the opposition counting in the last period.

HERE down South, just now, on the floors of vast, long warehouses where tobacco is sold at auction, the weird chant of a red-faced, perspiring, husky-throated auctioneer is converting a quarter-billion-dollar crop into ready cash for the farmer.

Beginning gardeners sometimes ask, "What can I plant in my borders that will go on blooming from year to year without attention?" The answer to this naive query is, of course, "Nothing." Every planting worthy of the name "garden" demands some care from its owner.
Georgia rose sensationally from a rut of mediocre offensive football on two plays today to beat Clemson, 14 to 0, and hold its place in the ranks of the undefeated.
The Association of Bank Women today elected Miss Anne Houstoun Sadler of New York as president, at the closing session of its fifteenth annual convention.
Fourteen pages of slightly soiled but highest quality rag paper are the basis for the momentous international conference that soon will seek to halt the Chinese-Japanese war.

Mr. and Mrs. Adeeb Faris of Brooklyn have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Harriet Draper Faris, to Francis Charles Long, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Alfred Long of Kent County, England.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Abby Bevin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor De Lamater Bevin of South Lawn Farm, Northport, L. I., to William Rogers Chappell, son of Mrs. Franklin A. Chappell of White Plains and the late Mr. Chappell, took place here yesterday morning in the chantry of Grace Church.

MANHATTAN'S new $24,000,000 waterfront-one of the nation's major engineering achievements-will be on display Tuesday with the opening of the upper West Side Highway. For thousands of motorists, as they drive along five and one-half miles of gleaming new concrete ribbon; the occasion will mark another vital step in the city's highway program. For many others chief interest will lie in the huge recreational development that flanks the six-lane road to east and west.
United Stataes Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. declared tonight the "best course" the United States could follow "to keep out of war is by not taking sides in foreign quarrels."
Riding hard throughout the contest, the Mexican Army polo combination stopped the San Jose team of the Argentine, 11 to 6, today in the first of a three-game series.
The University of Buffalo scored its second football victory of the season today, a 12-7 triumph over its traditional foe, the University of Rochester, before a large homecoming crowd.

The Chinese Government expresses its sincere appreciation to all the Chinese people and to all foreigners who have extended moral or other support during the present distress, Dr. Wang Chung-hui, Minister of Foreign Affairs,formally announced.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Whitwell Wilson of Spuyten Duyvil of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Mary Whitwell Wilson, to George Davidson White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howell North White of Lakeville, Conn.

Orval W. Adams, executive vice president of the Utah State National Bank of Salt Lake City, Utah, is scheduled to become president of the American Bankers Association at the annual convention opening in Boston tomorrow.

Institutions and other interests possessing large capital funds are looking more keenly than in the past to residential rental property as an investment field, points out the National Association of Real Estate Boards. If this tendency increases,
Miss Margaret Luer St. John, daughter of Mrs. Gamaliel Cyrus St. John of this place and the late Mr. St. John, has completed plans for her marriage to Elbridge Clerghorn Gale of Boston.
A large business property at the north end of the World's Fair grounds was reported yesterday to have changed hands.

THE Federal Music Project has many achievements to its credit, not the least of which is a survey conducted recently by a Michigan unit. It produced interesting and illuminating findings regarding the state of music in rural communities in that State.

Mrs. Alice Hartnett, 60 years old, of 30 West Hamilton Place, Jersey City, mother of Patrolman John Hartnett of the Jersey City police force, was killed and five others seriously injured in a head-on collision of two automobiles on Newark Turnpike under the Pennsylvania Railroad Bridge late this afternoon.

Eugene Gibson, 30 years old, of 120 West 138th Street, a Negro employed as a projectionist in a motion-picture theatre, jumped from a second floor window to escape a fire in the projection room at about 9 P. M.

IN the past few years-since 1929, this author says distinctly-there have been marked changes in general "living requirements" here. They have been changes in the direction of economy not only of money but of labor and space, and thus, of course, in the direction of simplicity and compactness.

Four hundred students, more than half the undergraduate body, are members of the Middlebury College Mountain Club. The membership is the largest in the seven year history of the organization, and an ambitious schedule of week-end outings is planned for the hikers.

Amid demands for a special session of Congress to strengthen Federal farm programs, Government economists reported today that farmers had received more dollars in the first eight months of this year than any time since 1929.

LONDON. - Comparatively indifferent to the question whether its judges have passed the age limit President Roosevelt considers desirable for Supreme Court Justices, Great Britain is disturbed over the age of its generals.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, and a group of his closest advisers headed for Atlantic City today for informal conferences preparatory to starting a detailed analysis on Monday of the organization's progress and strategy.

A determined and enthusiastic group of Wellesley undergraduates is organizing this Fall to dissipate all indifference from the campus. The Wellesley College Forum. cooperating with the Departments of History, Political Science and Economics, will start a program of intensive self-education in current affairs with a dinner discussion, the first in a series, on the subject of the Sino-Japanese conflict next Wednesday evening.
A thought detector at the University of Iowa has yielded new insight into the electrical characteristics of the mental quality most distinguishing man from animals.

THE Bureau of Air Commerce has put $15,000 into the development of a "barrel" engine for light airplanes of the type designed for private fliers, and the results, so far, are "very promising," according to John H. Geisse, who is in charge of the bureau's power-plant section.
Long runs by Sol Nechtem and Lon Braszynski featured Boston University's 20-to-0 triumph over Slippery Rock before 10,000 spectators at Fenway Park today.
A convicted wife beater was tied to the whipping post in the New Castle County Work House today and ten lashes were applied across his bare back with a cat-o'-nine-tails under a Delaware law of 1717.

As a step in its program to provide better accommodations for underclassmen in overcrowded university dining halls, Princeton University opened this week a new eating place for a limited number of juniors and seniors who do not belong to the upper class clubs.
ATLANTIC CITY AIRPORT is preparing to receive next Friday and Saturday between forty and fifty visiting airplanes, the fleet of the members of the Sportsman Pilots Association.
On the eve of Pulaski Day, Secretary Ickes announced today that all of Cockspur Island in Georgia, site of historic Fort Pulaski, has been put under National Park Service jurisdiction.
The sixteen-story apartment house known as 10 Gracie Square overlooking Carl Schurz Park will be sold at auction in foreclosure proceedings on Oct. 28 in the Vesey Street rooms by Henry Brady.

Employes of Frankford Arsenal who are associated with the United Federal Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, met in a closed session this afternoon to protest against the procedure followed at an election Wednesday and Thursday to select representatives on a wage board at the arsenal.
The thirteenth annual convention of the National Employment Board will open at the Hotel Sherman in Chicago Wednesday and continue through Saturday, it was announced yesterday.

No event that has occurred within those memorable ten years since the dance has once more been accorded its true place as one of the major arts holds more potential interest than the forthcoming exposition which is to be held in Rockefeller Center from Nov. 29 to Jan. 2 under the title of "Dance International 1900 1937."

The wedding of Miss Charlotte Elizabeth Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Stewart of Upper Montclair, to Harold Edwin Scovil, son of Mrs. Stella Scovil of Bloomfield, took place this afternoon in the First Congregational Church of Montclair. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. Archibald Black. officiated.

A warning against the use of plumbing and heating pipes as a ground for electric wiring is voiced by the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. Stray electric currents, it is explained, are frequently found on water and gas Dines.

Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, told a Mountain State Forest' festival crowd today that Congress must give the air industry rights equal to those of the railroads and motor carriers.

In the coming Russian elections, which probably will be held in the middle of December, some seventy-five millions of electors will vote for upward of two million Soviet Deputies, from the Supreme National Council -- corresponding to the American Congress--down to village and factory Soviets.

A shortage of medium-rental apartment houses exists in New York City, Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission, declared yesterday in announcing that during the past two months the commission has approved seventeen sales of real estate which now await court action or the vote of the certificate holders.

Linger Long Dare, chestnut gelding exhibited by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Y. Bell of Montvale and ridden by, Mr. Bell, won the Hoffman Trophy for saddle horses during the first day's judging at the seventeenth annual Orange Horse Show at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

PROFESSOR HAROLD C. UREY, famed and honored for his discovery five years ago of heavy hydrogen and heavy water, is now devoting his laboratories at Columbia University to an intensive effort to separate the heavy and light varieties of other common chemical elements and thus to isolate heavy nitrogen, heavy carbon, heavy oxygen, heavy potassium and light lithium. m.

Signing of a closed shop agreement covering 1,000 taxicab drivers and garage workers of the Bell Transportation Company was announced yesterday by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate.
Patrolman Joseph Knight said an unidentified man kidnapped a nine-year-old girl tonight as she was returning home from a confectionery store with her young brother.

CHARNAY-LOVEJOY-Mr. and Mrs. Morris Lovejoy, Lawrence, L. I., announce engagement of their daughter, Edith, to Mr. Bernard Charnay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Charnay, Lawrence, L. I. GOLDEN-EHRLICH-Mr. and Mrs. Harry Ehrlich, 659 West 162d St., New York City, announce engagement of their daughter, Charlotte, to Mr. Jack Golden.

Employment prospects in New York State are bright today for college graduates, including even the so-called "lost" college generation of the depression years, according to a survey just published by the University of Buffalo.

The Municipal Finance Commission of New Jersey has mailed to all known holders of bonds and notes of the Borough and School District of Fort Lee, N. J., a comprehensive refunding plan, according to an announcement yesterday by Walter R. Darby, chairman of the commission.
Little Edward of Kent, Britain's No. 1 baby boy, awoke on his second birthday today to find a pile of royal presents waiting to be opened.
A group of Americans and other foreigners received decorations from the Chinese Government today. Among those upon whom awards were conferred were:
John Leonard Driscoll will celebrate his 100th birthday Monday at his home here. He is in fairly good health, considering his advanced years.
Willoughby house Settlement at 97 Lawrence Street. Brooklyn, will be aided by a card party to be held the afternoon of Nov. 4 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Funeral services were held at the Dodge Funeral Parlors here today for Mrs. Margaret Duff Bates of 5 Avon Lane, Westbury, who died yesterday. She was 101 on Dec. 4. Born and educated in New York, Mrs. Bates lived most of her life in Westbury. Her husband, James J. Bates, died in New York sixty-six years ago.

Although the majority of Spring shirt linens will not be ready before December or January, current indications are that they will be approximately 50 cents a dozen below prevailing levels on Fall styles, manufacturers said here yesterday.

A brother passing act, Cecil to Cody Isbell, and a 16-yard dash by Louis Brock of Stafford, Kan., brought Purdue a 7-to-0 triumph over Carnegie Tech today in the Boilermakers' homecoming football game, played before 20,000- spectators in a drizzling rain.

IN a very short time--just, indeed, since the success of "Tortilla Flat"-it has become bromidic to say of John Steinbeck that no two of his books ever resemble one another. They do. however, have many traits in common. Power, for one thing, and a lovely gift of words, and an astonishing way of making the simple seem important. As for the latter trait,

The courage of Joseph McCormick, a railroad station agent whose automobile had been commandeered by five escaping Kentucky prison farm convicts, was credited today for the frustration of their attempted break.

Blithe and brisk after forty years of wrestling with some of life's gravest problems, the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers will celebrate its four decades of existence at the Waldorf-Astoria this week with one of the biggest parties in its history.

To every navy man the move of the Naval Academy Alumni Association, recorded in the current number of the Naval Institute Proceedings, to erect a memorial to "Skinny" Paul Dashiell will be a fitting and a welcome one.

The engagement of Miss Moira Flannery of this city, daughter of Edward Pearson Flannery of Glyntaff, Haverford, Pa., and the late Mrs. Flannery, to Richard Hooper Pough, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Pough of St. Louis, has been announced by her father.

A report by the National Association of Housing Officials traces the development of low-rent housing legislation in the States from 1933. when the first Federal loans and grants for slum clearance were authorized.

" The women of America represent our greatest hope for the preservation or our form of government and for lasting peace," Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, declared in an address before the Pee Dee District Council of Farm Women here this morning.

In her home city of Dallas, Texas, the new national president of the Camp Fire Girls, Mrs. Lola Duval Williams, will welcome representatives from every part of the country on Wednesday for the opening of the organization's national conference of council members.

There has been some repetition of history in the past week. Once more the United States has taken a high moral stand on an international issue and once more the United States has been given the opportunity to indicate how far it will go in backing up its position. That has happened before.
With the passage of the Wagner Steagall Housing Bill this country has, for the first time in its history, laid the foundations for a national housing program.

Leading citizens of Cumberland, Cape May and Atlantic Counties began an intensive campaign today to prove the economic justification of a twelve-foot freight canal across South Jersey, connecting the Delaware River with the Atlantic Ocean.
LONDON.--Returning prosperity has revived the various movements which seek to foster emigration from the crowded cities of Britain to the more spacious areas of the empire's dominions.
THE new 92-piece symphony orchestra which Arturo Toscanini will conduct in ten broadcasts beginning Christmas night went into rehearsal during the past week under the baton of Artur Rodzinski.
As evidence of one of the driest Summers here in living memory, Eldon M. Browne has a crop of 250 figs, the first he has been able to grow in fifteen years.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Sept. 30 shows that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation rose from 132.29 per cent on Sept. 15 to 132.91 per cent on Sept. 30.

Roland Hayes gave his first recital of the season at Town Hall last night, under the auspices of the New York Committee to Aid the Southern Negro Youth Congress. As invariably has been the case, the Negro tenor captivated his audience from the start by the artistry of his interpretations-an audience, by the way, which should have been larger, considering the nature of the occasion.

The new six-story apartment house at 1,347 Ocean Avenue has been completed and, according to the renting agents, is rapidly being filled by tenants. Suites are from two to four and one-half rooms. I. M. Kalt is the builder.
The local Radiomarine Corporation station at 1:43 o'clock this morning received a message by wire from the Savannah, Ga., station reporting the steamship Caloria in distress.

There was a touch of World Series atmosphere as the Supreme Court opened its new term last Monday. Although the sitting did not open until noon, one determined visitor from Kansas City began his vigil outside the building at 6:50 A. M.

Yesterday and today were the anniversaries of the great fire of 1871. Tomorrow the three surviving firemen of the 225 who fought the fire will be honored at a smoker under the sponsorship of the Retired Firemen's Association. They are Isaac M. Adler, 96; George Leady, 91, and Charles Schroeder, 90.

It took the flashing heels of 145-pound Sammy Pinion to bring the West Virginia Mountaineers out of a waterlogged stalemate today to defeat Washington and Lee, 6 to 0. Pinion came into the game late in the third quarter.

While residential construction volume at present is about one-third of the amount prevailing in 1926, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, points out that a small improvement was seen in August, due possibly, he explains, to a slight decline in building costs.

Young members of society headed by Miss Mildred Cartwright are aiding in the plans for the luncheon and Autumn fashion revue to benefit the Prosperity Shop which will mark the formal opening Oct. 20 of the Caprice Room in the Weylin.

Mrs. Louis E. Underwood is general chairman of the annual donation tea and reception of the Berkshire County Home for Aged Women at Pittsfield next Wednesday. She is being assisted by Miss Judith Colt, Mrs. Brenton Crane Pomeroy and Mrs. Robert H. Davenport.

The Society of Motion Picture Engineers, made up of men who design, manufacture and operate motion picture equipment, will open their forty-second semi-annual convention at the Pennsylvania Hotel tomorrow. About 300 delegates from Hollywood, Chicago, Rochester and other centers of the industry are expected to attend.
William T. Tilden, American pro tennis star, and Hans Nusslein of Germans accounted for three victories over French rivals in a series of inter national matches today.
The University of Southern California Trojans rose to unexpected heights today and sent the powerful Ohio State Buckeyes home bearing their first defeat of the season.

A last-minute field goal from placement by Acting Captain Van Ladd gave the Union College eleven a 10to-7 victory over Swarthmore today. A forward pass from Jakle to Weltmer in the end zone gave Swarthmore its first score in the last minutes of the first half.
In an address last night in this town, twenty miles south of Lethbridge, Premier Aberhart termed himself "the mosthated man in Alberta."

A half million 10-year-old girls were mustered into the League of German Girls today, donning Hitlerism's brown uniform for the first time. Each girl must undergo an athletic examination before admission.

Mr. Marquis James does not claim, in his lately published book on Andrew Jackson, to have produced a new view of the old-time Democratic leader. But that he "rehabilitates" Jackson in the matter of personality and statesmanship is intimated in the jacket to the book; also in some reviews of it.

DEATH hurled from the air seems to be a particularly terrible thing, and to live under the hourly threat of it, as Shanghai lives today, has curious effects upon the community and upon the millions of people who comprise the community.

Officials-of the Lehigh Navigation Coal Company sent word late today to the little group of "stay-down" self-imprisoned strikers 1,200 feet below the surface that its wage demands would -be- granted if the miners left their subterranean chamber which they have-occupied since Tuesday morning.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Improvement in real estate depends primarily upon improvement In net operating income, Clarke G., Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, told the members of the West Side Y. M. C. A. real estate class at the recent opening of that course for the season.

COLGAN--Mr. and Mrs. Edward, announce birth of a son, Oct. 4, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital. CORWIN-Mr. and Mrs. I. B. Corwin (nee Dorothy Goldberg) of 139 West 82d St., announce the arrival of a son on Oct. 3. at the Doctors Hospital.
The American Art Association Anderson Galleries' first sale of the season realized $35,054.50. It opened Thursday and ended yesterday afternoon with the final session netting $18,330.

Conditions on Hainan Island are quiet, but for a long time there has been apprehension owing to its utter defenselessness. It could easily be occupied by Japan and this angle of the situation is believed to be prominently before both the British and French Governments because of its nearness to their colonies.

Edward Francis Mead of Greenwich, wounded World War veteran and son of an old and well-known Greenwich family, died this afternoon at the home of Joseph Collins, a war comrade whom he was Visiting. He was 49 years old. He was stricken with a heart attack while listening to the broadcast of the world series.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation amounted to 1,047,962 tons last month, the largest volume for a September since 1929, and a gain of 86,159 tons over shipments in September, 1936.

Sixty-four of the "angels" of Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, who sought to circumvent a ruling by the Appellate Division, may register under their "heavenly" names for the general election only if they also supply to election inspectors the "earthly" names under which they were known previously, and their last addresses, Supreme Court Justice Collins ruled yesterday.
Police are looking for a modern Samson who broke into a garage in Chicopee Street Thursday and walked off with a cash register weighing 175 pounds and containing $58.96.

The twelve regional banks of the Federal Home Loan Bank System will celebrate their fifth birthday on next Friday, with gross assets of their member thrift and home-financing institutions at the peak of $3,893,695,000, reached on Oct. 1, according to an announcement today by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
