A couple of boys named Joe put a crimp in the championship hopes of the University of Washington today when Joe Gray and Joe Wendlick worked a short pass that gave Oregon State College a last-minute 6-to-3 victory over the Huskies in one of the major upsets of the day.

Fewer Manhattan properties were sold in foreclosure last month than for any month since May, which marked the lowest point in distress sales since the beginning of the depression, according to figures compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York.

Several conflicting cross-currents in wholesale market trends, the boycott against Japanese goods and reported consumer resistance to higher prices are exerting an influence on the shaping of retailers' plans for the forthcoming November and December holiday selling period.

WHEN the first tenants began moving into the Resettlement Administration's new "model town" at Greenbelt, in Maryland, near Washington, this month, a unique experiment in Federal housing was formally launched.

Predicting that with the advancing use of new materials and structural improvement, municipal building codes will undergo radical changes in the next few years, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, points out that the American Standards Association, the Federal Bureau of Standards and other groups have joined in preparing a new standard or model building code for the use and guidance of cities in rewriting their ordinances.
Sub-freezing temperatures nipped the ears of up-State New Yorkers today while farmers scanned their fields anxiously for the effects of heavy frosts reported generally.
A general meeting of the New York Circle of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae will be held Oct. 19 in the West Foyer of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 8, unless specified: At Balboa: Cummings, McDougal. Blue, at Annapolis, Oct. 9. Charleston, at Coco Solo. Conyngham, Boston Yard to sea, Oct. 9. Decatur, Mobile to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Dunlap, Boston Yard to Tompkinsville, Oct. 9.

THIS is the time of year when the automobile industry resorts to all of the tricks of the theatrical profession to work up enthusiasm over new models. Right now it is in the dress rehearsal period prior to the opening of the New York Automobile Show Oct. 27 and the various annual shows around the country.
The marriage of Miss Marie Stuart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley W. Stuart, to Edward Goursky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Goursky, took place here this evening in St. John's Lutheran Church.
ANY modern play that can survive the ordeal of revival after thirteen years, that can even be remembered that long, is something of a classic, if you accept that term in a rather loose sense.

Stanford's Indians, twice beaten in previous pigskin skirmishes and rank outsiders as they lined up today, scored an upset with a 12-to-7 victory over the University of California Bruins at Los Angeles.
PRIZE WINNER: The Nobel Prizes, awarded annually to those who have contributed most to mankind in the preceding year,

If any effort is to be made to salvage some of the color and beauty of the outdoor garden for sun rooms or sunny windows during the Winter, it will be necessary to get the plants in without further delay.

The relation of America, as a working democracy, to the Far Eastern crisis and rising European dictatorships, represents the theme of this year's program of the League for Political Education, it was announced yesterday by George V. Denny Jr., new director of the League.

At Arrowhead, a Pittsfield estate just sold by Mrs. Russell A. Hibbs, is one of the noted chimneys of New England. It was made so by Herman Melville, who bought the place in 1852 and. wrote there several of his novels, including "Moby Dick."
Finding the union had used threats and intimidation, Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer permanently enjoined the Empire Individual Window Cleaning Contractors Union, Inc.,

In what was said to be the first contested case involving the sale of alcoholic beverages under the Fair Trade Practice Act of New Jersey, Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan granted this week a preliminary injunction against Gold Drug Stores of this city, restraining them from selling two well-known brands below the wholesaler's set prices.
Labor cost per man-hour increased 14.9 per cent between July, 1936, and July, 1937, it was disclosed by an analysis made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The presidents of Harvard and Columbia Universities and a representative of Princeton will join with Yale alumni next Friday, evening at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in honoring Yale's new president, Charles Seymour, at the traditional alumni dinner for an incoming president.
Dr. William Hunter Workman, surgeon, traveler, Himalayan explorer and author, died here Thursday in his ninety-first year.

Mrs. Katherine Mackay O'Brien, wife of Justice Kenneth R. O'Brien of the New York Supreme Court and daughter of Clarence H. Mackay, president of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, has come to Nevada for the purpose of divorce proceedings, it was disclosed today.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Regina McNeill, daughter of Mrs. Alexander James McNeill of 242 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. McNeill, to Jo Martin Hicks, son of Mrs. Rosa L. Canada of Conway Ark., took place yesterday morning in Holy Innocents Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. Paul McC. Klohr performed the ceremoney.

THREE years ago Dr. Joseph B. Rhine published his "Extra-Sensory Perception," a rigorous scientific discussion of 100,000 experiments in telepathy and clairvoyance conducted at Duke University. Few studies in "psychic research" have made so profound an impression.
Miss Bertha Sherfy has decided that people either are getting more careless with their money or they have more money to get careless with. And she is an expert on such matters.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, speaking last night at a dinner of State civil service employes celebrating enactment of the FeldHamilton career bill by the last Legislature, urged the State employes to be ever vigilant against the type of bill that would threaten the integrity of the State pension and retirement system.

Mrs. Anna Clement Dowd, widow of Wyllys Edmund Dowd Jr., engineer, died on Thursday at the Hotel Weylin in New York of a heart attack. She was 52 years old and lived on Lake Street here. Mrs. Dowd was born in Rutland. Vt.,

A two-year experiment in a New York City school has changed problem children, reported by the teachers as troublesome, unruly or hoodlums, into normal, well-behaved, happy pupils, it was disclosed in a survey made public yesterday.

THREE American short-wave Stations have filed applications for temporary use of the United States Government's Pan-American frequencies being held for the proposed establishment of a government-operated Pan-American show wave broadcasting station. .
The executive committee of the National Lawyers Guild decided today to call a "deliberative convention" in Washington to consider "modernization of the Supreme Court."
Alabama's might was too much for South Carolina's fight today as the Crimson Tide overcame the plucky Gamecocks, 20 to 0, on a rain-soaked gridiron while 7,000 looked on.

Jack Koerner of James Monroe and Rolf Grote of George Washington achieved brilliant free-style performances at the second series of dual swimming meets for the senior high school team championship of the Public School Athletic League, held in Clinton's 25-yard pool yesterday.
The names of twenty-eight students of the College of St. Elizabeth here who have become eligible for membership in the college's dramatic association were announced today. The list follows:
Lilacs are best propagated on their own roots. Unfortunately, lilacs do not root readily from cuttings and the general method is to graft.

In an effort to find out what the average British housewife is doing about the rising cost of living, the British Government plans to tabulate the actual amounts now being paid for food in 30,000 families throughout the United Kingdom.

Dean Lynn Harold Hough of Drew Theological Seminary announced this week the appointment of the Rev. Norman M. Guy, Professor of Economics and Sociology in Brothers College of Drew University, to a professorship in Drew Theological Seminary.
Floyd Gibbons, former war correspondent and now a radio broadcaster, has purchased a farm in the Cherry Valley section of Monroe County, Pa. Katharine Canfield was the seller.

political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Peter V. Cacchione, chairman of the Kings County Committee of the Communist party, and candidate for the City Council, over WMCA, 10:15 to 10:30 A. M.

The marriage of Miss Edna Maria Dudley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Dudley of this place, to Burr Vanderburgh Brower, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Henson Brower of Cleveland, took place this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Emmons P. Burrill, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Miss Anne Evans, daughter of Mrs. Pliny Taylor Evans of Washington and the late Mr. Evans of Riverside, Calif., was married this afternoon at the Washington Cathedral to Charles Vines Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Vines Brown of Philadelphia.

Irrespective of what the outcome of the oil conspiracy case that started here in Federal court on Monday may be, the opinion is that it will have a far-reaching effect on future operations in the petroleum industry.

An eight-year-old girl, deaf and blind, arrived at Northwestern University, where tonight, by means of a newly invented three-finger multitactor, efforts will be made to teach her to walk, talk and hear.

More than 800 delegates from thirty States, representing the American Zionist movement and many national organizations, opened a two-day national conference on Palestine land redemption here this evening. It was the thirty-fifth meeting of the Jewish National Fund of America, at which plans for speeding up the fund's land requisition and reclamation program will be considered.

IN the realm of photography, the time has come when the Summer's collection of snapshots are being closely examined for enlargement possibilities. The first flush of pride that came when the pictures were taken and developed has passed, and now photographers are going over their prints with a critical eye. The best are being selected,

WILL begin with those that are best known and have been in most danger, the pictures at the Prado. About 500 of these, including all that are regarded as the best, are at Valencia. Most of them are stacked in the Torres de Serranos, the twin round towers which form one of the gates of the medieval town, where they occupy the ground floor of one tower.
Former Grand Duke Ernst Ludwig of Hesse died today. He was 69 years old. The former Grand Duke was the son of the late Grand Duke Louis IV and Princess Alice, a daughter of Queen Victoria.

Joseph D. McGoldrick and Raymond V. Ingersoll, Fusion candidates for controller and president of the Borough of Brooklyn, spoke briefly last night at a dinner sponsored by the women's division of the party at the Hotel Montague, Brooklyn. About 250 persons were present.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 8: MAJOR GENERAL Lynch, G. A., Chief of Infantry, one day leave. Oct. 9.

Several hundred West Point cadets in their colorful dress uniforms are expected to participate in the program at the second annual military ball for the benefit of the Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy, which will take place on the night of Nov. 13 in the grand ballroom of the Astor.

The collection of early American glass formed by Harry Hillyer Bingham of Boston in 1907-25 will be dispersed at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., next Friday afternoon.
THE time is some year before 1945, and the scene London, Berlin, Paris, Tokyo, any modern capital. Again the powers are at war. It is night. .

Governor Lehman announced today the appointment of Leo P. Dorsey of New York City as a member of the State Mortgage Commission to succeed Louis S. Posner. Mr. Posner resigned last week to resume private law practice.
Surveys in their major fields, using the college community as a source of material, will be undertaken by students of statistics at Connecticut College this year.
Robert Frazer, retiring United States Consul General, who has been appointed Minister to El Salvador, was the guest of honor at a luncheon given by the Pilgrims this week at the Hotel Victoria.

Lawrence Tibbett made his Vienna debut at the State Opera tonight as Iago in Verdi's "Othello." The American baritone was greeted with exceptional enthusiasm and received a series of ovations in the course of the evening.
For the fifth game of the world series today Bill Terry is sending Cliff Melton back, along with the same line-up that won the first victory yesterday. Harry Danning again will do the catching.

The marriage of Miss Natalie Graemer Jones, daughter of Mrs. George MacCullough of Glen Ridge, was married this evening to Quintin Frazer, son of Mrs. Frederick T. Frazer of Cranford and the late Mr. Frazer. The ceremony took place at the MacCullough home. The Rev. Orion C. Hooper of Newark officiated.

Miss Gladys Barcal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Barcal Maplewood, and Thomas Duncan Munro, son of Robert Munro of Newark, were married this evening in the Methodist Episcopal Church, South Orange, by the Rev. Dr. George E. Vogel of Rahway, assisted by the Rev. Fred E. Miles, the pastor.

The latest edition of a Khabarovsk paper, received here today, describes the combined Red army and fleet manoeuvres at Vladivostok on Sept. 27 and 28. The whole city was darkened against a Blue "air attack."
Dr. and Mrs. J. P. Jones of Inglecress, near this city, announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Porter Jones, to Robert Henry Schlesinger of Milwaukee, Wis.

The travel program of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor to Germany and later to the United States has been met here with a wall of public silence that again demonstrates how hard British leaders are trying to forget the whole abdication business.

Ninety-seven members of the Colgate University faculty of 110 have organized a new faculty club for social gatherings, discussions on social, political and other topics, and to bring a closer relationship between men in various departments.
Premier Mussolini today rejected the Anglo-French invitation to parleys on the means of withdrawing volunteers from Spain.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

As a protest against increasing rents, about 300 residents of Harlem paraded yesterday afternoon for two hours through upper Manhattan under the auspices of the Consolidated Tenants League, 209 West 125th Street.

A strike of service station attendants in Brooklyn was started yesterday morning by Local 20,408 of the Gasoline Station Attendants Union and by nightfall it was pronounced a "success" by Walter J. Burke, president of the union.

Mrs. Carlton L. Hommel of Syracuse, State president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, will preside at the opening meeting at 2:45 P. M. tomorrow of the greater New York branches of the league, to be held at 99 Park Avenue.
AMONG our more than a hundred national monuments and national parks, the least known to visitors perhaps is the Petrified Forest of Arizona.
Shortly after daybreak this morning we shouldered a long string of duck decoys and after a short walk arrived at our blind on the reed-grown shore of North Bay in Oneida Lake.

A two-day real estate conference to discuss realty topics of presents day interest will be held by the Westchester County Realty Board at the Orienta Beach Club, Orienta Point, Mamaroneck, on Wednesday and Thursday. Robert W. Lockyer, president of the board, will preside.

For the first tine salmon fishermen in the Columbia River threw out their trolls and devised hooks and poles to raise tuna. Albacore tuna appeared off the river mouth in large schools and for days fishermen were busy pulling them in.

New emphasis on educating the student to the world he must enter demands a scrapping of old methods and the adoption of a broader approach on the part of high school teachers, Dr. Allan Abbott, Professor of English in Teachers College, declared yesterday at a meeting of the High School Teachers Association of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

LAS GOLONDRINAS-the swallows-arrived exactly on time for Saint Joseph's Day, the 19th of March; now all the residents of this picturesque little mission town, as well as many ornithologists, await to see if, they will depart on schedule chedule, Oct. 23.

STRESSING the importance of education as a foundation stone of the safety program, a plan affecting more than 800,000 pupils from the primary grades to high school has been put in effect by the Keystone Automobile Club in public and parochial schools in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland.

Radio Patrolmen Edward Farrell and Joseph Goldberg of the Empire Boulevard Station, Brooklyn, arrested two men last night who, it is charged, were about to tie up a taxicab driver after robbing him. Police said the prisoners admitted a series of robberies in the Bay Ridge district of Brooklyn.

Miss Margaret scott Ferguson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ferguson of Upper Montclair, was married this evening to Frederick Arthur Mayes, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Mayes of Montclair in Union Congregational Church.

FROM an authoritative source it is learned that the Post-office Department is, in principle, in sympathy with the Treasury Department's suggested program for a series of postage stamps with portraits of all past Presidents of the United States (except Herbert Hoover, still living), and it is probable that releasing of the initial values will be begun early in 1938.
Last week the familiar metallic jangle of 12,500 slot machines was heard in Florida's sixty-seven counties, as it had been for several years.

Three Socialist printers' union locals have announced that no Rumanian printer would accept any job vacated by the dismissal of a man belonging to a racial minority. This is a direct challenge to a recent order of the Ministry of Commerce reducing the proportion of members of. racial minorities in industry and commerce.

IN Colchester, oldest town of Britain, on Tuesday, the Mayor and Burgesses, the Belgian Ambassador, Peers of the Realm and Members of Parliament, generals and admirals, distinguished scientists, churchmen, writers and other men and women prominent

Miss Muriel Mosle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Mosle of Hitching Post Ranch, this place, formerly of New York, was married this afternoon at the home of her parents to Dr. Richard G. Lyon of Santa Barbara by the Rev. Thomas E. Oliver.
No music by Dela Bartok, Hungarian composer, will henceforth be broadcast to Germany or to Italy by a special order of the noted musician to the Hungarian Broadcasting Company.

George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, reaffirmed his support of Mayor La Guardia yesterday. With fourteen other labor leaders who have been attending the American Federation of Labor convention in Denver, Mr. Meany sent a telegram to Mayor La Guardia, which read:

THE Mozart festival to be held in Prague, Oct. 23 to 31, in celebration of the 150th anniversary of the premiere of "Don Giovanni" in that city, will open with a concert of Mozart compositions, Oct. 23, in the Smetana Museum.

Miss Virginia Lee Souder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Lee Souder of this city, was married here this evening in Emmanuel Episcopal Church, to John Robert McAllister Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McAllister, also of Staunton. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. J. Lewis Gibbs.

The swapping of eleven venerable "little red school houses" for a brand new $125,000 consolidated seat of learning, with half the funds supplied by the Federal Government, is no bargain in the eyes of those simple folk of Lancaster County, in the rich Pennsylvania agricultural area west of this city, who are members of the Amish division of the Mennonite faith and among the most conservative of their co-religionists.
Stocks drifted aimlessly and closed firm and mixed; turnover, 488,980 shares. United States Government and other bonds steady and quiet; transactions, $8,371,700.
The outstanding event in world affairs this week took place at Chicago. President Roosevelt's speech there on Tuesday reverberated in Europe more than any utterance of any statesman in many months.

President Roosevelt's Chicago speech urging concerted international action for peace, the State Department's condemnation of Japan and Secretary Hull's announcement that the United States would attend a conference under the Nine-Power Treaty were discussed by rabbis in sermons yesterday.

The New Jersey Tuberculosis League announced today that its thirty-first annual meeting would be held at the Woodrow Wilson Hotel, New Brunswick, Oct. 22. Dr. J. Arthur Myers, president of the National Tuberculosis Association, will be the honor guest.
Announcement that the committee on business conduct of the New York Stock Exchange had decided to broaden its study of the nature of the market between Sept. 7 and 25 was made yesterday.

Rebounding from the Cornell defeat, Colgate's Red Raiders showed new drive and spirit today as they used combinations of lateral and forward passes and a powerful running game to down a scrappy St. Bonaventure team, 34-0, before a crowd of 4,000.

History and Biography WESTERN LANDS AND THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION. By Thomas Perkins Abernethy. 8vo. New York: D. Appleton-Century Company, for the Institute for Research in the Social Sciences, University of Virginia. $4. A study of the contest for ungranted land in America.

A MAN will spend hours reading pamphlets on how to operate a new camera, oil heater or automobile, but he won't devote ten minutes to the study of the mechanism of his own body upon which his entire happiness and success depend.
Walter Cravens, 27-year-old cowboy from Butler, Okla., was seriously injured last night at the Rodeo in Madison Square Garden when a 1,300-pound steer trampled him.

To the Editor of The New York Times Confusion still appears to prevail as to whether a state of war in the legal sense exists between Japan and China. Hostilities are being carried on by all branches of the armed forces of both nations.
Increased opportunity for association with the fine arts is being provided in art and music programs developed this Fall for students at the University of Rochester.

A tract of several hundred building plots comprising the old Heddesheimer farm and portions of the adjoining Burkart and Davis farms near the Juniper Park section of Queens has been purchased by a building syndicate known as Green Park Homes for immediate improvement with sixlstory medium-priced homes in the $5,O00 class.
Miss Beverly F. Elfros, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Elfros of Mount Vernon, N. Y., has selected Oct. 22 as the date of her marriage to Theodore E. Levy, son of Emanuel Levy of this city.
Mr. and Mrs. Donald Goodrich North of-this city and North Haven have announced the engagement of Mrs. North's daughter, Miss Jane Osborn, to James Hamilton Gould of Old Lyme, Conn.
With pardonable pride, Government plant experts revealed today that they are putting more pop in popcorn. "Popability," they said, "is the quality most desired in popcorn."
Long service volunteers now are being accepted by the labor service. Recruitment is for one year with the possibility of extending it another half year.

Amendment of the National Labor Relations Act to exempt professional men "from any requirement to be represented by any nonprofessional organization for collective bargaining" was proposed yesterday in a resolution adopted by the National Society of Professional Engineers at the closing session of their third annual convention at the Hotel Commodore.
The sale of single-game reserved seats and the promise of pleasant weather on the half holiday brought a considerably larger force of fans to the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The New York Hippodrome Opera Company last night presented "Rigoletto" before a large audience. The cast was composed of Dea Lovati, Philine Falco, Gina Castro, Ivy Dale, Elena Dale, Lawrence Power, Arturo D'Amico, Enzo Molle, Norman Roland, Foster Miller, Angelo Angelini and Alfredo Neri. Eugene Plotnikoff conducted. f conducted.

Manufacturers of national brands, particularly in the drug, toilet goods and food fields, are launching the most extensive campaigns in their history to cultivate the good-will of retailers and to buttress their trade positions under the Miller-Tydings law and various fair-trade acts, sales and advertising executives reported here last week.

Iowa State's battling Cyclones played mighty Nebraska on even terms for three periods today but two sudden, dramatic Cornhusker thrusts turned the tide and the conquerors of Minnesota scored a 20-7 victory in their first Big Six contest.

Miss Martha Hannah Parke, daughter of William More Parke of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Parke, was married to Charles Henry Carter 3d, son of Mrs. Edward H. McKeon of Baltimore, last night in Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David T. Atwater.
Sixteen persons were killed and one hundred wounded, some severely, and 300 houses were razed by a cyclone which struck early this morning at Santa Maria in Rio Grand do Sul.

The confusion of world affairs today could have no clearer exemplification than the picture presented by the sudden stiffening of the official attitude of the United States in respect to Japanese operations in China.

Profiting greatly by a moving start, F. A. Burton's Deliberator, 9 to 2, yesterday set a new record for the $5,000 added Interborough Handicap when he flashed an extremely fast six furlongs in 1:11 to finish far in the van of half a dozen other crack sprinters at Jamaica. The old record for the stake was 1:112-5, held jointly by Sation and Bill Farnsworth.

The Amherst football team smothered Norwich University today, 79-6. Even the Amherst scrubs proved too powerful for the Cadets, amassing 41 points in the fourth period. Twelve touchdowns were made by the victors, with Captain Michell and Jack Joys leading with two touchdowns apiece.
The White Rabbit looked to right and left at his companions behind the long table and cleared his throat.
The almost perfunctory brief address made by President Roosevelt here on his way from the West to Hyde Park was less important than the political aspects of his visit to Minnesota.

Harold E. Dahl, American flier for the Spanish Government who was captured, sentenced to death and granted clemency by Insurgents, tonight awaited the arrival of his wife, a former American stage singer.

With registration ended with a record total for a Mayoralty election of 2,484,312, [Page 30] the city campaign will begin to enter this week its intensive stage. Mayor La Guardia was regarded as being in a less favorable position than before registration but still appearing to have the better chance to win.

Leon Howard Worthley of Montclair, principal administrator of the division of Japanese beetle control and Dutch elm disease eradication of the Federal Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine, died today at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair after a six-month illness. His age was 60.

Miss Esme O'Brien heads a group of debutantes who will act as manikins in the fashion show to be a feature of the Halloween tea dance which will be held Oct. 30 at Sherry's in aid of the free clinic for animals maintained by the Humane Society of New York.

Peddle turned back the Newman School eleven, 12-0, today. Al Hanover made the first touchdown in the fourth quarter after a sustained drive from Peddie's 40-yard line. Acting Captain Dick Quigg went over for the second touchdown from the 1-yard line.

In the keenest battle of the women's singles competition in the Fall tennis tournament, Mrs. Frederick McBride of Short Hills, N. J., former Wightman Cup player, today defeated Miss Virginia Ellis of Boston in the final, 6-8, 8-6, 6-4, on the Casino courts.

As an offset to the higher building costs, Bernard L. Johnson, editor of American Builder, cites the fact that while the home of 1937 has such new developments as airconditioning, insulation, streamlined bathrooms, super-modern kitchens, copper and brass pipe, and other improvements, the total cost in most communities is 25 to 40 per cent less than it was in the 1926-29 era.

John H. Ensor of 5 Elm Street, Cresskill, receiver for the closed First National Bank of Secaucus, and two employes were before Joseph F. Holland, United States Commissioner, today on charges of misapplying bank funds.
Ann Cooper Hewitt, 23 years old, principal heir of Peter Cooper Hewitt, the inventor, was secretly married here yesterday to Ronald Gay, 30, a garage foreman of Oakland, Calif.

A diplomatic showdown over Spain may have been brought nearer during the past week, but a diplomatic settlement that would remove the international mischief from the Spanish war seems farther away than before.

In its first attempt to gain political control of a large city, the Committee for Industrial Organization showed surprising strength in the local municipal primaries last Tuesday, when its candidates for Mayor and Council were nominated.

WHILE getting those large musicals off his hands and onto the boards, Lee Shubert has not forgotten about the shows that don't use tunes. Indeed, these last will be hurrying along now under the supervision of Milton Shubert, head of his uncle's play department. Thus:

Stating that prospective home owners who contemplate erecting their own dwellings are entitled to a clear knowledge of all elements of construction, L. Rohe Walter, chairman of the building extension committee of the Producers Council, announced yesterday that a meeting of that committee will be held on Thursday at the Hotel Biltmore.

One of the principal features of the recently inaugurated campaign to raise $250,000 for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service will be the dinner to be held on Oct. 20 in the grand ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Miss Mary Sunderland Rich, daughter of Mrs. Edward Rich, was married to Robert Emmett Robertson, son of Mrs. R. E. Robertson and the late Mr. Robertson, this evening in St. Timothy's Protestant Episcopal Church, Catonsvllle, by the Rev. William W. Shearer.

The volume of mortgage insurance business transacted by the Federal Housing Administration during the first nine months of the present year showed a substantial increase over the similar period of 1936, despite a decline during the third quarter.

At the Cabinet meeting which Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden attended upon his return from Geneva one comment of his is said to have attracted the attention of his colleagues. The Secretary mentioned the loss of prestige suffered by Russia.

Negotiations looking toward the exchange of $2,500,000 worth of American prunes for German merchandise are under way between the California Dried Fruit Export Association and the German Government, according to reports in the wholesale markets here last week.
B. M. Gancy and Juan R. Quijano, Filipino lawyers, announced today the formation of the first Filipino party in the United States.
Two modern troubadours have parked their caravan in an economist's yard here. When Joan and Betty Rayner of New Zealand arrived here recently,

The memory of Miss Sarah Wilson, the plain-living Scotch-Irish spinster whose gift of $30,000 made possible the establishment of Wilson College sixty-seven years ago, will be honored tomorrow at Founder's Day ceremonies.

A driving Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute eleven marred Brooklyn College's home debut by scoring a 13-7 victory at the Kingmen's athletic field yesterday. Despite the setback the home team gave a brilliant exhibition before a crowd of 5,000 in the initial intercollegiate battle at the $7,000,000 plant in Flatbush.

The Board of Examiners reports that there nave been placed, as of the dates respectively indicated, upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service in day high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated, and who are entitled to have their names so placed:

Columbia University has awarded 189 scholarships and fellowships for the new academic year to students from twenty-eight States and five countries, it was announced yesterday. The awards have an approximate total value of $75,000.

STROUNDSBURG, Pa.--The Fall foliage in the Poconos has reached its peak and for the next week or ten days there will be a flaming riot of color which is expected to attract many people to the hotels of the county for a Fall vacation.

Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills had to go to the twenty-second hole to finally eliminate Henry Ciuci of Fresh Meadow in the semi-final round of the Long Island P. G. A. championship at Soundview today and gain the final against Jimmie Hines, metropolitan open champion.

Invitations have been sent out for the wedding on the evening of Nov. 6 of Miss Geraldine Bennett, daughter of Walter H. Bennett of this place, to Richard Edward Boschen, son of Otto Boschen, also of Montclair.

A total of seventy-four trade marked articles were added to the "price-fixed" merchandise group during September, according to a statement issued yesterday by R. H. Macy Co., which declared, however, that "major price-fixing is still confined to comparatively few manufacturers in the cosmetic, drug, liquor and publishing fields."

A 3o per cent decrease in the annual United States fire loss in the past decade is attributable partly to the improved distribution of water, according to water system engineers. Figures compiled by the National Board of Fire Underwriters show

The purchase here of the first clubhouse or "Hearthstone" in a chain of several to be established by the alumnae of the Kappa Kappa Gamma fraternity has been announced publicly on the eve of a national campaign to raise a Hearthstone Fund.

Brown University alumni will return to College Hill from all parts of the country next week-end for the university's annual alumni day. This year's homecoming is expected to be the largest since 1934.

Mr. and Mrs. Luther W. Bahney of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriette A. Bahney to Lieutenant J. Caldwell Wylie Jr., U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Caldwell Wylie of Glen Ridge. The wedding will take place this Winter.
The Government of this British crown colony appointed a commission today to investigate the alleged sinking of Chinese fishing junks by Japanese warships.

Wilkinsburg Will McKechnie, one of the most highly regarded managers in major league baseball, last night severed his connection with the Boston Bees and signed a contract with General Manager Warren Giles to pilot the Cincinnati Reds for the next two years.

Wearing ancestral lace and orange blossoms, Miss Edith May Hartshorn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Winfred Morgan Hartshorn of 830 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church to Alling Woodruff, also of this city.

IN CLOVER-Wednesday evening at the Vanderbilt Theatre. Postponed from last week. PROCESSIONAL-Wednesday evening at Maxine Elliott's Theatre. The Federal Theatre Project is offering a new version of John Howard Lawson's play, the revisions having been made by the author himself. Ruth Gilbert is in the cast.

Hackley School opened its football season by losing to Kingswood School of West Hartford, Conn., 12-0, today. The game was closely played, the second Kingswood score coming in the final minute of play when Viering plunged through for a touchdown.
Louisiana State University mixed power plays with the passes of Bussy, a soph? ore back, today to defeat Rice Institute, 13 to 0, before 18,000 fans.
Lowell Textile fell before Colby today, 13-0, as the White Mules staged an impressive offensive game to register their second victory in three games this season.

Official figures today show that both imports and exports of the Netherlands during the first nine months exceed the totals for the entire of 1936. This revival finds visible expression in Rotterdam's activity, where this year more than 10,000 ships called, representing nearly 40,000.000 tons.
The final count of ballots in the Sept. 5 election, completed this week, show Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz was elected President by the biggest popular vote in the country's history.

Stating that a greater volume of homes has been constructed this year than in any previous year since 1930, John E. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, told the delegates at the annual convention of the United States Building and Loan League in Los Angeles last week that need was still very urgent for more rapid expansion of home building and for better built dwellings.

An increasing use of air-conditioning in tapping formerly inaccessible supplies of raw materials is predicted by L. R. Boulware, vice president and general manager of the Carrier Corporation of Newark, N. J.

WASHINGTON. -In the embassy guard at Peiping, China, Uncle Sam maintains his only force of "horse marines." Mounted on thirty-two horses, a detachment of marines at Peiping is available for emergency duty as cavalry. "Leathernecks"

New York State librarians in convention today adopted a proposal to have minimum wages for their work fixed through an amendment to the State education law. Delegates appointed a committee to work out a wage-scale scheme similar to that now in effect for teachers.
Bells and an Empire Service from St. Paul's Cathedra,, London, will be broadcast at 10:10 P. M. over these stations: GSG, 17.79; GSI, 15.26; GSD, 11.75; GSB, 9.51 megacycles.

Five desperate convicts, being transferred from the State Prison of Southern Michigan to the Marquette Branch Prison, attempted to escape at Indian River today and the most notorious of them, Joe Scofic, was shot through the right lung by State Police Sergeant Ray Sullivan.
With Marty Glickman, the Olympic sprinter, flashing 73 and 58 yard runs for touchdowns, Syracuse's much improved football team scored a 40-to-0 victory over St. Lawrence before 10,000 persons today.
Statistics of the Vocational Guidance Bureau at Skidmore College show an increase over last year of about one-third in the number of Summer jobs held by Skidmore students.
When he came up twice in the third inning of yesterday's fourth world series game at the Polo Grounds and made two hits, Hank Leiber joined a small group of record holders in the big baseball show.
Librarians of New York State, closing their four-day conference here today, heard publicists assert that libraries should advertise their wares to a greater extent.

The Queensboro Farms Products Company of Long Island City was notified today that milk will be withheld from its up-State plants starting next Friday unless the company pays agreed prices for its milk, posts price notices in each of its plants and signs a contract with the cooperative association serving each plant.

Miss Ann Steuart Lea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Ellis Lea of Devon, was married this afternoon to Henry Ross Watson, son of Mrs. George H. Stuart 3d of Villanova and the late Robert C. Watson, formerly of New York.

LONDON.-A "finishing school" for young naval officers promoted from the ranks is being set up by the British Admiralty to make sure that the new officers will not be embarrassed when they appear at social functions.

Settlement of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's alleged income tax deficiency of $238,372 in 1931 and 1932 for $50,000 has been approved by the Treasury, the Board of Tax Appeals announced today.

The annual card party, tea and fashion show under the auspices of the alumnae of St. Augustine's Academy will be held Nov. 6 at the Delmonico. Miss Geraldine M. Donovan heads the group arranging the benefit the proceeds of which will further the philanthropic work of the organization.

Working throughout the Summer, a committee headed by Dean Edwin S. Burdell has accomplished the initial steps toward establishing a comprehensive museum in the three miles of corridors in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Platt Street, one of the small thoroughfares in the lower downtown district and whose name seldom appears in the Manhattan realty transactions, has just made a substantial contribution to the real-estate activities of the present season.

The 150th anniversary of the Dartmouth Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, the fourth oldest chapter in the country, will be celebrated on Monday afternoon and evening with the participation of leaders of the academic and scientific world, officers of the honorary scholastic fraternity and delegates from forty-five chapters.
An inquest into the death of Patrick St. John Stirling, 38, editor and partner in a London stock brokerage firm, ended today with a verdict of suicide "while his balance of mind was disturbed."

A highly touted University of Maryland football team was pressed to its utmost today to defeat Western Maryland, 6 to 0, for the mythical State championship before 10,000 fans. From the time Big Jim Meade went over standing up for the single touchdown in the opening minutes, it was anybody's game.

Miss Catherine Macphail, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. G. Macphail of Ottawa and niece of Sir Andrew Macphail of Montreal, was married today to Cecil Breuer, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Max Breuer of Buffalo, N. Y.

The Civil Service Reform Association, according to H. Eliot Kaplan, its counsel, will resort again to court action in an attempt to block the appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as assistant counsel to the Transit Commission should that body once more designate him for the post.

Miss Constance McChesney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Hazen McChesney of Cynwyd and Skaneateles, N. Y., was married this afternoon to Carl Frederik Brauer, son of Mrs. Carl Wilhelm Brauer of Danbury, N. H., and of the late Mr. Brauer.

Miss Bessie Mae Emmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Emmons of Cornwall, and Elmer J. Edwards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Edwards of West Hartford, were married this afternoon in the First Congregational Church, Cornwall, by the Rev. Wilbur. Simmons, pastor of the church.

More than a little of what the young man ought to know about his economic openings and his future prospects of livelihood is conveyed in recent preliminary reports of comparative studies of the nation's 1929-36 income sources issued by the economic research division of the Department of Commerce.

Governor and Mrs. Earle will make a quick trip to Sweden next month to present two bronze tablets on the 300th anniversary of the sailing of Swedish settlers for America They will arrive in Goteborg Nov. 27, the date that the settlers left in 1637.

Edward Meany Sr., who retired three years ago after thirty-five years of service in the Milburn pumping station of the city of New York Water Department, died today at his home here. He had been ill with heart trouble since April. His age was 76.

Montefiore Congregation, Hewitt and Macy Places, 11 A. M. Address by Justice Charles Poletti. Pulaski Day memorial parade up Fifth Avenue from Washington Arch and Washington Square north to Fifty-fourth Street, 2 P. M. To be reviewed by Governor Lehman and Count Jerzy Potocki from grandstand at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street and by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle from St. Patrick's Cathedral.

FOLKS to whom mention of Mexico generally calls up nothing more than painful images of hot tamales, occasional revolutionary outbreaks and postcard views of Popocatepetl, may be surprised to learn that there now is in that neighboring country a quite lively little motion-picture industry which is growing by the proverbial leaps and bounds.

EDWIN PARSONS and Robert Soubiran were members of the famous Lafayette Escadrille, organized in April, 1916, as a part of the French Army, and active thus as a unit until it was transferred to the American forces in February, 1918.

The wedding of Miss Elizabeth Proud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Bertram Proud of this city, and John Richard Brandeis, son of Mrs. Theodore Colescott Brandeis of South Orange and the late Mr. Brandeis, took place this afternoon in the Orange Methodist Episcopal Church. The pastor, the Rev. Everett F. Hallock, officiated.
FROM darkest New Jersey Allen Boretz the other day reported himself at work on no less than three new, original plays and an adaptation, it being anybody's guess as to which would emerge first.

After a lapse of fifteen years Holy Cross and Georgetown renewed football relations today before 12,000. Holy Cross, a slight pregame favorite, lived up to expectations and set back Georgetown, 27 to 6, Bill Osmanski getting all four touchdowns.

Attired in a Victorian gown of cream satin and a lace veil that had been worn by her mother when a bride, Miss Frances Carlene Haines Waitt, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Weymer Hinckley Waitt of this city and Ardsley-on-Hudson, was married yesterday afternoon to Esmond Brown Gardner, son of Mrs. Isaac B. Gardner, also of this city, and the late Dr. Gardner.

All Canadian security and commodity markets will be closed tomorrow in observance of Thanksgiving Day in the Dominion. On Tuesday, Columbus Day, all markets and banks will be closed in New York and in most of the principal cities in the United States.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES. receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest.

Baron Egon von Mauchenheim of Germany and his 20-year-old wife were in Windsor today, seeking a visa from Marshall M. Vance, United States Consul, which would allow them to take up permanent residence in Detroit.

The developers of the Yale Farms tract in Greenwich, Conn., and North Castle, Westchester County, are using an aerial survey as a sales map of their property. The 1,400-acre tract was received by Yale University under the will of the late John W. Sterling, a partner of the law firm of Shearman Sterling.
Retirement of Mrs. Herbert Hoover from the presidency of the Girl Scouts will be the principal feature of the twenty-third annual convention of the organization on Wednesday.

The annual card party for the benefit of the Brooklyn Children's Museum has been arranged by members of the museum's auxiliary, of which Mrs. Dean C. Osborne is president, for Nov. 5 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
The Teachers College of Connecticut today swamped the Wagner College eleven, 32-0, the teachers scoring in every period.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 29 you published a letter from Professor James E. Boyle of Cornell University which criticized the steps taken by this Administration in its effort to help cotton farmers.

A fair volume of reorders was received in the New York wholesale market last week from most merchandise divisions, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Retail stores have revised their Fall schedules, and retail sales are now well in line with anticipated volume.

Mrs. Thomas Williams of the Bannister Lane colony here was hostess tonight for her granddaughters, the Misses Barbara Williams and Dorcas O. Ferris, at a dance at her home in honor of Miss Helen de Peyster, daughter of Frederic Ashton de Peyster, and his fiance, Eric von Raits, whose marriage is to take place on Friday in New York.

With the opening on Tuesday of "Autumn," by Margaret Kennedy and Gregory Ratoff, Basil Dean, erstwhile film producer, renews two previously successful associations--with Miss Kennedy, whose "Constant Nymph" he produced, and with the St. Martin's Theatre, where he built up a reputation with a fine company and a series of interesting plays.

According Japanese figures, given out here this morning, on the numbers of Chinese dead found on battlefields in the Shanghai area and burned or buried by Japanese soldiers, the Chinese losses of men killed in action on all fronts, including those of North China, since the beginning of the hostilities must approach nearly 200,000. The wounded,

Miss Mary Gertrude Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Scott of Greenwich, was married to James Peter Webster, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Webster, also of Greenwich, this morning in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. John Q. Dolan, the pastor, officiated.

To take proper advantage of the low-rent housing projects under the requirements of the Wagner act, the National Association of Housing Officials declares that many cities should study their building codes and ascertain if some revision is not necessary. The discrepancy,

AN exhibition illustrating the development of the art of portraiture through the ages is being arranged by E. M. Benson of the staff of the Pennsylvania Museum of Art, under a grant from the Carnegie Corporation.

A test shipment of about one hundred crates of pineapples will be sent from Rio de Janeiro to New York on Oct. 20 to determine if a new refrigerating system is feasible, the Department of Commerce announced today.
ONE of the most widespread of our surviving handicrafts, ceramics, possesses a vitality which is having its effect on the factory-made pottery and china.

One of the largest country estate transactions in Somerset County, N. J., this season has just been closed in the lease for two years with option to purchase by F. L. Church of the Church Dwight Company of this city of the twentyone-acre property owned by Andrew R. Kennedy of West Palm Beach.

A memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Jefferson, who died Sept. 12, will be held today at 5 P. M. in the Broadway Congregational tabernacle at Fifty-sixth Street, of which he was the pastor for thirty-two years until his retirement in 1930.
Bucknell University's annual conference on education, to be held here Friday and Saturday, will deal with the general theme of guidance.

The marriage of Miss Jean Olney Pratt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David D. Pratt of Rochester, N. Y., and New Bedford, Mass., to Kenneth C. Ogden Jr., son of Kenneth C. Ogden of this city and the late Mrs. Ogden, took place here yesterday noon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

The names of student officers who will lead the undergraduates at New York University's divisions during the current academic year were announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university. They are:

Justices of the Supreme Court met today in a final, secret conference of the week, at which, it is believed, they decided the course they will take on the motions made Monday by Albert Levitt and Patrick Henry Kelly to refuse to Associate Justice Black his seat on the high bench.

Closing its 1937 series of forums on current world conditions, THE NEW YORK TIMES Review-of-the News Conference will present seven speakers in a third and final program Wednesday at Floral Park, L. I. The all-day sessions will be held in Sewanhaka High School for the benefit of Long Island club women, whose leaders have served in an advisory capacity in formulating the plans.
St. Mark's defeated Noble and Greenough in a close football game, 7 to 3, today Both scores were made in the second period after spectacular long runs by Tewksbury and Dewey.

While three deputy State attorneys general mapped new procedure today for the grand jury investigation into Philadelphia vice and crime, the members of the police force were mystified by receipt of a new questionnaire asking full information regarding their political sponsors.

Philippine importers who purchased American goods originally shipped to China but diverted to Manila because of war conditions can get possession of such merchandise without payment of duty by obtaining a delivery order from the steamship company and posting a bond for double the amount of duties for which the goods would be liable if not of American origin, according to advice sent the National Foreign Trade Council yesterday by the Department of State. e.
A fighting band of opportunists from the University of North Carolina dealt the New York University football team a stunning setback at Ohio Field yesterday.

Leading chain store and mail order systems made a better sales showing last month than in August. Twenty-eight companies had total sales in September of $247,555,445, against $230,158,464, an increase of 7.6 percent, according to the compilation made by THE NEW YORK TIMES. For August,

MANAGUA, Nicaragua.-The long-discussed Nicaraguan inter ocean canal project is a very real idea here in- the capital of Nicaragua. Political leaders and many' others have an abiding hope that the United States, which holds a ninety nine-year option on the canal site and plan, will soon start work. But that hope largely rests on Nicaragua's pronounced need for foreign capital.

Miss Nancy Danneman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Danneman of 25 Irving Place, Brooklyn, and Westport, Conn., has chosen the night of Nov. 10 for her marriage to Millard Fillmore Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sheffield Smith of Brooklyn, Lake George and Sheffield, Conn.

Supreme Court trial calendars here. are only twelve months in arrears, and the time is not far distant when litigants will be able to air their grievances in court within a few weeks from the filing of their suits, according to John J. Dailinger, calendar clerk.

W. H. Danielson, business agent of the Masters, Mates and Pilots Association, an A. F. of L. affiliate, announced yesterday that a contract had been signed with the New York and Porto Rico Line covering wage and working agreements on five passenger vessels and four freighters.
A spectacular run of twenty-five yards by Eddie Enstice gave Flushing a 6-to-0 victory over the Grover Cleveland High eleven at Memorial Field, Flushing, yesterday.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M.. Oct. 11: PATROLMEN-Cecil C. Southern, from 4th Division to 19th Precinct, assignment to duty in plain clothes discontinued. Michael J. Murphy, from Mounted Squadron 1 to Mounted Squadron 2, assignment to mounted duty continued. ued.

The outcome of National Labor Relations Board elections among the unlicensed personnel of more than eighty steamship lines may be rendered invalid, in the opinion of Charlton Ogburn, general counsel of the American Federation of Labor.

Neither expense nor artistry has been spared in the stage settings for Mrs. Nature's production of Autumn, which has been having successful tryouts in the suburban and rural districts and is expected to come into New York City for a limited engagement.
David O'Brien and Johnny Hall passed and rammed Texas Christian University to a 20-13 victory over Tulsa University today, but a Texas boy on the Tulsa team almost stole the show.

THE American housewife is buying more fish; more than at any other time in government record. Uncle Sam knows that a big reason is the high price of meats; but he believes that the eat-more-fish habit, having been acquired, will be given up by few families.

IN previous fictions many and varied William MacLeod Raine has ranged through Alaska, the logging camps and the old West. In this one he shifts the scene to Australia and narrates the exploits of a young adventurer from California, one William Hollingsworth, who went there to try his luck in the gold fields.

Lord Nuffield, automobile manufacturer and philanthropist, has announced a gift of ??300,000 (nearly $1,500,000) to the Radcliffe Infirmary here. He previously had given [pound]150,000 to the hospital.
The general diplomatic support of Italy was promised to Kensuki Horinouchi, Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs, by the Italian Ambassador, Giacinto Auriti, in a conversation yesterday.

Irving Vaughan of The Chicago Tribune yesterday was elected president of the Baseball Writers Association of America, succeeding Charles Segar of The New York Mirror, according to The Associated Press. Paul Shannon,
IN her second novel. "Hall of Mirrors," Mrs. Marshall has fulfilled brilliantly that promise as a stylist of which, in her first book, "Only the Fear," there was ample evidence. .

The precedent-setting Scott Brothers case, in which Division 5 of the Interstate Commerce Commission decided that the commission had jurisdiction over railroad pick-up and delivery service under the Motor Carrier Act, was reopened by the commission for reargument in an order handed down today. A hearing was set for Nov. 12 in Washington.

Miss Margaret Brosnahan, daughter of Mrs. Timothy J. Brosnahan of this place and the late Mr. Brosnahan, was married here this morning to John Wade Roche, son of Mrs. John W. Roche of Pelham, N. Y., and the late Mr. Roche, in the Church of the Assumption by the Rev. Anthony Rothlauf of New York.

Miss Roberta J. Halliday, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wesley Halliday of Middletown, N. Y., was married here yesterday morning in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church to Robert Guthrie Woodward, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Woodward, also of Middletown.

Although trade association executives are agreed that the wage and hour bill will be in the forefront of the next Federal legislative program, which may be launched at a special session of Congress early next month, industry as a whole has not prepared a case against the law, nor is it unanimous in opposition to it, it was revealed in a canvass of association heads last week.

To the Screen Editor: Having just seen a performance of "The Life of Emile Zola," I feel it almost a duty to pronounce my thanks to Warner Brothers for the courage and spirit with which they have advanced this film.

Tufts College trustees have approved plans for raising $2,000,000 through public appeal to erect a new building to house the Tufts Medical School. Dr. Louis E. Phaneuf, Boston gynecologist, is chairman of the campaign committee.

Patrons and patronesses for this season's series of Piccadilly dances to be held at the Bellevue-Stratford for the benefit of the Social Service Department of the Philadelphia Orthopaedic Hospital include
John Barbirolli, conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, will return to the United States today on the Cunard White Star liner Britannic.
Organization of theatre parties in behalf of various philanthropic enterprises continues to enlist the active participation and sponsorship of many members of society.
The Daughters of the American Revolution adjourned their annual State conference today after electing Mrs. George Duffy of Fort Plain as regent and designating Jamestown as the 1938 convention city.
SYDNEY, Australia.--Few maps show Hammond Island. But on this tiny place, a few miles east of Cape York, the northernmost tip of Australia, 130 souls have found happiness and a new design for living.
Two rival labor "shows" will vie for the first page of the nation's newspapers beginning next Monday.

The following declinations for the office of City Councilman had been filed with the Board of Elections at the close of office hours yesterday, the list including such substitutions as had been made up to that time:

Winning from Virginia today by 40 to 13, with 21 of its points being scored in the final period, the Navy redeemed a poor start by a driving finishing attack led by Lem Cooke, who established himself as the Navy's outstanding back of the year.
One hundred and twenty human test tubes give scientists at the Fels Research Institute here a chance to discover what makes one baby different from another.

Severe pressure against the franc eased in the foreign exchange market here today. Spot francs moved over a range of % franc and closed firm at 14915-32 francs to the pound against 1505-32 yesterday. Francs for three-month delivery, however, were a shade higher at a discount of 7 francs. The dollar was steady at $4.95 7-16 to the pound.

Both the House of Bishops and the House of Clerical and Lay Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church began consideration this morning of a wide range of legislative and administrative matters, but took no action on any of the more controversial subjects before the General Convention.
The St. Joseph's Orphanage Guild, St. Michael's Villa, of Englewood Cliffs, N. J., will give a luncheon bridge on Saturday at the Riviera.

Duquesne University's Athletic Council apologized today to the University of Pittsburgh for "any statement" made because of "over-enthusiasm" at a rally on the eve of the big game between football teams of the two intracity rivals.

Mr. and Mrs. Siegfried Bendheim of 316 West Seventy-ninth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Carol Bendheim, to William B. Herlands, chief assistant to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

REGISTRATION at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, Edward Adolf Whitelaw, director, opens tomorrow. Group work in all departments has been added to the curriculum, with stress on theoretical subjects. Newly added to the faculty are Aurelio Giorni, piano and ensemble; Anthony Paganucci, voice; Fritz Mahler, operatic coaching; Eugene Plotnikoff, orchestration and conducting, and Benno Rabinof, violin.

Organization of the Institute for Propaganda Analysis, 132 Morningside Drive, a non-profit corporation "to assist the public in detecting and analyzing propaganda by conducting scientific research and education in the methods by which public opinion is influenced," was announced yesterday.

A statement explaining the present financial difficulties of the landlord has been sent to all tenants occupying houses under the management of Dwight, Voorhis Perry. It cites the fact that in 1926 for every dollar paid for rent 19 per cent was allotted for taxes.

Miss Jane Fiske Pearson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Emory Pearson of West Forest Park, was married to William Andrew Gault, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Matthew Gault this evening in St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, by the Rev. J. Milton Rogers.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Adelaide Hammond of this place and Cambridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Alexander Hammond of Sudbury, to Edwin G. Johnson of Cambridge, son of John August Johnson, and the late Mrs. Johnson.
Southern California, which has quietly been making as great strides in cultural as in agricultural and industrial progress, marks an academic milestone next Thursday.

There no longer is any doubt about the Cornell football team of 1937. With 40,000 persons sitting under leaden skies in Palmer Stadium today, Cornell defeated Princeton, 20 to 7. The fact that the Ithacans earned their victory by such a margin is as eloquent a comment on their ability as can be made. The Red and White is back at the head of the parade.

Marcel Dupre, one of the world's greatest organists, and his pianist daughter, Marguerite, are to appear in a recital at Trinity College on Dec. 2. In connection with the announcement it is indicated that the college expects to continue this Winter its program of organ recitals by leading American organists. This series,

Pitt's Golden Panthers shook loose Marshall Goldberg for one 77-yard touchdown tour in the first three minutes of play against Duquesne today and then rode out this margin for a 6-to-0 triumph over their crosstown rival.

While most of the world has accepted "Shakespeare" as the spelling of the Bard of Avon's name, Harvard's celebrated scholar, George Lyman Kittredge, long insisted that the true version was "Shakspere." Last week, Professor Kittredge having retired,
For the last two months Madrid has been receiving three times as much food as is ordinarily consumed. The capital has accumulated a good stock for Winter, according to tonight's Heraldo de Madrid.

ITALY'S stamps commemorating the birth two centuries ago of Augustus, first of the Roman Caesars, are ten for regular postage and five for air-mail use. All are inscribed "Bimillenario Augusteo" and bear Latin words from the Latin classics.

A stout Oklahoma line opened gaping holes for an eel-hipped halfback as the Sooners tied the University of Texas, 7 to 7, today. Woody Huddleston, 160-pound Oklahoman, did practically all the honors in a 46-yard drive for the first score of the game late in the second period.
Vittorio Mussolini, son of the Italian Premier, was the chief guest this evening at a reception for the press at the Italian Embassy.
The Reichs-bank's statement as of Oct. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Dick Todd's churning feet were a big factor in sending Texas A. and M. to an intersectional triumph today that definitely brought the Aggies back to their old glory, a 14--0 conquest of Mississippi State Virgil Jones gave the Aggies their initial scoring chance when he pounced on a Mississippi fumble on the Bulldog's eight in the second period, and Bob Nesrsta went over.

Five Pacific Coast ports joined hands this week in a concerted effort to enlist all maritime and business interests in a fight to prevent the threatened withdrawal of six big "luxury liners" of the Panama-Pacific and Grace Company from the intercoastal trade.

In deciding whether or not to call Congress into special session early in November to resume its consideration of measures left in abeyance at adjournment in August, President Roosevelt is confronted with conflicting advice.

More than 1,000 persons attended a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night in honor of Dr. Edgar Starr Barney, principal of the Hebrew Technical Institute. The dinner celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of Dr. Barney's connection with the institute.

All records for registration in a Mayoralty year were broken yesterday when a final tally of the week's registration gave a total of 2,484,312, which exceeded the 1933 total--the year of the last Mayoralty campaign-by 161,930. The 1933 figure had been the largest for a Mayoralty year heretofore.

Richard Lunn of Washington, Mason and Dixon champion. was upset by Dr. Harold V. Garrity of Deal in the quarter final round of the New Jersey Shore invitation golf tournament at Monmouth County Country Club today. Garrity won by 5 and 4 in the lone upset of a full program which saw the field reduced to four players.

President Roosevelt will give an address and lay the cornerstone at the dedication Wednesday of the new postoffice, one of the events marking the four-day celebration of the 250th anniversary of Poughkeepsie next week.

A claim of $175,00 against New York State was filed with the Court of Claims today as a sequel to an accident last July 11 resulting in the death of Matthew J. Van Deloo, veteran employee of the State Tax Department, and his wife, and injury to their daughter, Margaret, all of Albany.

Unpleasantness between Mayors and Controllers-even when they are of the same political faith-is traditional in New York City politics; the acrimonious and unremitting feud between Mayor Hylan and Controller Craig was a classic example.

A SERIES of very practical photography "projects" launched recently among fans in the metropolitan area provides an interesting sidelight on current camera hobby trends. Turning from exclusive preoccupation with the artistic or "pictorial" type of photography, today's hobbyists, it would appear, are paying increasing attention to the importance of the camera as an instrument of record. record.

Production of silver in the Province of Quebec in August was 157,577 ounces, according to a statement from the Bureau of Mines. This figure was more than treble the output for August of last year, when production was 51,682 ounces.

RALEIGH, N. C.-An increasing amount of tobacco is being shipped from North Carolina to foreign countries, especially to Great Britain. In one week a cargo of 4,000 hogsheads of tobacco valued at $1,000,000 was shipped from Wilmington aboard the British steamship Huntress.

Hawaii will pay $30,000 for its second attempt to convince a Congressional party it is entitled to statehood. A party of fifty , including eight Senators and thirteen Representatives, is here to investigate island conditions.
Contracts valued at about $6,470,527 were let by Federal agencies under the restrictions of the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Oct. 7, the Department of Labor announced today.

GOVERNMENT officials predict for this Fall the biggest migration of game birds in several years. More than 40,000,000 ducks, geese and other water fowl will leave northern nesting grounds to Winter in the south. Allowing for resting time en route, the flight will take about two months. ths.

There are now 805 International Relations Clubs, organized under the auspices of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in colleges, universities and high schools in the United States and foreign countries, according to the Endowment's Year Book for 1937, recently published. Sixty-six new clubs were formed last year.

Taking notice of the steady rise in the number of auto accidents attributed to liquor, automobile manufacturers, officials and distillers indicated yesterday that they would expedite educational campaigns intended to bring about moderation in the use of liquor and a public understanding that "driving and drinking don't mix."

The American International College eleven of Springfield, Mass., gained its first victory in three starts by defeating Hofstra College of N. Y. U., 14-6, today on the Hempstead High School field. The game was the first football contest to be played by Hofstra.

THE murmuring rumble of a huge crowd dies down slowly to almost silence as another football game stands at the curtain rise of the opening kick-off. There is the setting of banners in the Autumn sunlight, the blue clouds of tobacco smoke giving a mauve tint to the dark, cold-weather clothes of the thousands who have blotted out the concrete of the stands.

Overcoming a six-point lead set up by the Hamilton passing attack in the first half, a completely remodeled Hobart College eleven thrilled crowd of home-coming alumni by opening a strong second-half running attack to pave the way to 19-14 victory today.
Villanova and Auburn, playing before a crowd of 15,000 spectators, were unable to settle their 7-7 Havana tie of last New Year's by battling to a scoreless draw at Shibe Park today.
THE match for the chess championship of the world between Dr. Max Euwe, the champion, and Dr. Alexander Alekhine, the challenger, now in progress in Holland, has features of unusual. interest.
Fall harvests are heavy throughout South Jersey this season and farmers are pushing the gathering of late crops in anticipation of killing frosts.

The controversy over the Supreme Court is a result of the public's failure to understand that the Federal Government is a government of delegated powers, John B. J. Gerety, a member of the faculty of Good Counsel College here, said today.
The most spectacular parade of colors in the history of the event is being planned for the annual Victory Ball, which will be held on Nov. 12 in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Presidents and secretaries of the Alumnae Committee of the Seven Colleges will be guests of the Associate Alumnae of, Barnard College from Tuesday to Thursday, at the biennial meeting of the group. Others comprising the "big seven" are Mount Holyoke, Bryn Mawr, Wellesley, Vassar, Radcliffe and Smith.

Many noted authors have already been scheduled to speak of life and writing at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair of 1937, in the International Building at Rockefeller Center, between Nov. 5 and 21. These will include:

The sixty-third annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which will be opened tomorrow in Boston, is expected to witness a determined movement on the part of the independent unit bankers of the country to enlarge their influence in the affairs of the association and to impress their viewpoint, as contrasted with that of chain and branch bankers, more strongly upon the policies and formal opinions of the organization.

A new dual champion was created among English springer spaniels today when Champion Fast was awarded the highest honors and first money in the open all-age stake for his breed, the most important event of the sixth annual meeting of the Albany Spaniel Field Trial Club.
The text of the Italian note replying to the Franco-British proposal of a conference on withdrawal of foreign volunteers from the Spanish civil war follows:

An appeal for the domination of a "live, washed sheep" to be used in a demonstration this week in its textile division was made yesterday by the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

THE outstanding literary event of the week is the announcement that the fin est private library remaining in Great Britain has become national property. Not since the bequest of the Grenville Collection in 1846 has the British Museum gained such a valuable accession as it has now acquired by the purchase of the Ashley Library from the executors of the late Thomas James Wise.

Miss Naomi Brittle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Paul Brittle, was married here this afternoon at her parents' home to August Theodore Bahr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Bahr of East Orange, N. J., by Rev. Lloyd E. Foster, pastor of Calvary M. E. Church, East Orange.

Fifteen student leaders, including the officers of three upper classes, editors of campus publications and the president of the student government, will participate in formal induction ceremonies at Georgian Court College here Wednesday evening.

Patrick H. O'Brien, C. I. O. candidate for Mayor of Detroit, today told John L. Lewis, chairman of the Commitee for Industrial Organization, that he "feels confident" he will win in the election Nov. 2.

The marriage of Miss Alice King Gutmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hellmuth Gutmann of South Orange, to Norman Kirkness Hackland, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Norman Hackland, also of South Orange, took place today in the home of the bride's parents.

Miss Virginia Marie Crowley, daughter of Mrs. George Cooper Crowley of New York and the late Mr. Crowley, was married to Douglas Dunsmuir Robertson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robertson of this city, yesterday afternoon in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.
With her time handicap, Henry H. Anderson's 32-foot sloop Clotho today won the New Rochelle Yacht Club's overnight race, the last of the season's yachting events.

The Essex House Casino-on-the-Park will be formally opened for the season next Saturday night with a party in aid of the Loomis Sanatorium for the Tuberculous at Loomis, N. Y. Mrs. William R. K. Taylor Jr. and Mrs. William E. S. Griswold head the senior committee for the benefit.

A national policy of conservation and utilization of American phosphate resources for benefit of the nation's agriculture was formulated today at a conference of representatives of Utah, Idaho, Montana and Wyoming.
The Golden Jubilee Concert to be given by Josef Hofmann at the Metropolitan Opera House on Nov. 28 in behalf of the Musicians Emergency Fund is sold out.

New York City's Board of Education-WPA campaign to teach English to foreign-born adults by radio broadcasts, as a sort of correspondence school of the air, last week entered its second year with a voluntary "write-in" enrollment of 8,000, a figure almost double that of 1986.
The Indians of William and Mary scored an upset today, defeating Virginia Polytechnic Institute, 12 to 0. The Williamsburg eleven withstood two V. P. I. drives in the opening period.

THE formation of a new league, to combine and replace the American Bridge League and the United States Bridge Association, is an accomplished fact. A majority of the directors of the American Bridge League ratified the new plan last week after the governing board of the United States Bridge Association had confirmed the arrangement.

WITH cool nights awakening the desire for congenial indoor activity, many New Yorkers are succumbing to an old juvenile urge and whittling as a hobby. Manufacturers have placed kits containing complete instructions, wood and simple designs on the market,

The marriage of Miss Constance DeForest Fredricks of Brooklyn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Barron Fredricks of- Brooklyn and Falls Church, Va., to Robert Todd Sprague, also of Brooklyn, son of the late Professor and Mrs. James Monroe Sprague of New Berlin, N. Y., took place here yesterday afternoon in the rectory of Saint Patrick's Cathedral.

Miss Flora Fergusson, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Robertson Fergusson of Bryn Mawr, was married this afternoon to Henry Dawson Furniss Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Dawson Furniss of New York and of Pelham, N. Y.

The theory of experienced observers of affairs in the Near and Middle East that the only method of governing these countries and making them safe for law-abiding citizens is a firm ironhand policy has thus far appeared to have been proved absolutely-correct in Palestine.

THE Mozart quintet in D (K. 593), in Victor. M-350, is the third of the four later and greater quintets to be recorded by the Pro Arte String Quartet, supplemented by Alfred Hobday at the second viola desk. The C and G minor (K. 515 and 516) are to be found in albums 270 and 190 respectively. In those performances,

The first teams of Textile, Curtis and Newtown scored victories in their respective divisions yesterday in the second of the series of P. S. A. L. group cross-country runs at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx. Textile excelled in Group 1, piling up 49 points, with Jamaica the runner up with 63. Group 2 honors went to Curtis with 34 and in Group 3 Newtown was low with 47.

Building permits representing an aggregate of $709,708 in new construction were issued here during the first nine months of the year, an increase of nearly $100,000 over the same period in 1936 when the total reached $610,072, Superintendent of Building Walter F. Fromm announced this week.
Niagara's Purple Eagles defeated Clarkson Tech today, 28--6, for their third straight triumph of the season. A home-coming day crowd of 3,000 saw Niagara on her longest victory streak in four years.
Tomorrow, for the first time since the general election of May, 1936, brought the Left parties into power under Socialist leadership, a test of electoral feeling will be made in France.

IT was inevitable, say the publishers, that the Abbes should go to Hollywood. And in the face of so disheartening a commentary on success in our society, it is a pleasure to be able to report that their second book is a good one, nevertheless.

TESTER: A "chemical smeller," devised by Dr. R. N. Harger of Indiana University, was used last week in Baltimore to test intoxication. Two sniffs of a man who had wallowed two ounces of liquor turned a pink liquid in the "smeller" a lighter shade.

DIRIAN ALEXAINIAN, who for seventeen years was professor of 'cello of the Casals class at the Ecole Normale de Musique of Paris, France, has come to America to head the 'cello department of the Institute of Musical Art in Philadelphia.
