Engagement of $2,497,000 gold in Canada for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. No imports of gold were received.
The American Labor party is putting on its first suit of political long pants. With Fiorella H. La Guardia as its candidate for Mayor, it expects to play a major role in the current city election.

During his attendance at the congress of the Lilienthal Association for Aeronautical Research here Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh will be the guest of Baron von Cramer-Klett at his Hohenschau Castle, sixty miles southeast of Munich.

Mrs. Mary Carroll Denison Frick, widow of Charles Frick,' an official of the Baltimore - Ohio Railroad, died today at her home here. A native of Baltimore, Mrs. Frick was the daughter of the late Robert M. and Mary Carroll Denison and for years was active in social circles. Surviving are a son, R. Denison Frick,

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Stackhouse of Restalrig on Park Avenue entertained guests at a novel party at their home tonight. It was called "Believe It or Not," a burlesque appropriate for the Halloween season.

Frank J. Bruschi, Republican leader of the Eighth Bronx Assembly District, announced last night that Mayor La Guardia had accepted an invitation to speak at a meeting at the Park Republican Club, 80 West Kingsbridge Road,

Addressing a meeting of real estate appraisers at the New England regional convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Hartford last week, John C. Kiley, appraiser, of Boston, warned that in view of the cutting off of immigration and the decentralization of cities in recent years, due to the general use of the automobile, a new status in realty values is likely to occur.

Publication today of the agreement between the Croat and Serb Oppositions was promptly followed by a declaration by Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch that the Government had decided not to submit the concordat. with the Vatican to the Senate for ratification, at least not at present.

Miss Geraldine Elma Buie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Buie of Bloomfield, was married to Raymond Koch Serfass of Rochester, N. Y., son of R. B. Serfass of Bethlehem, Pa., this afternoon in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, East Orange.

Long Island's attractions as a playground and Summer resort are described in considerable detail in the tenth and final volume of the History of the State of New York recently issued by the Columbia University Press.

After wasting much time attacking the able Blair line the Lehigh freshman backs found their strength in end runs by Melloy, who thrice outran his opponents to score, as the cubs triumphed. 14-0, today. Loomis converted twice with drop kicks.

With me largest bond issue ever proposed in this city or county to be voted on at the general election Nov. 2, municipal authorities and the Metropolitan Edison Company, owner of the electric light and power franchises covering the entire city, are girding for war over the city's proposal to establish and operate an electric plant to supply all consumers.

The marriage of Miss Lillian C. Leech, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Leech of Coscob, to Joseph P. Clarke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clarke of Greenwich, will take place in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church, Riverside, on Oct. 18. The Rev. Joseph A. Ganley, the pastor, will officiate.

More than 50,000 Polish Americans are expected to march up Fifth Avenue this afternoon in a memorial parade, marking the 158th anniversary of the death of Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski, Revolutionary War hero.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Louise Beakes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Curtis Beakes 2d of this place, to Chauncey Deming Cowles Jr., son of Mrs. Chauncey Cowles of Buffalo, N. Y., and the late Mr. Cowles.

MR. HAYS will be the first to deny it, but it begins to Look as though Hollywood has borrowed the technique, not necessarily the physique, of the strip tease and has started disrobing before the public.

With little more than a score of women candidates in the field, distributed on tickets that will carry hundreds of names, feminists will find scant satisfaction in the ballot of 1937 unless they concentrate on the caliber of the women proposed for office. A number of them are outstanding in civic and welfare work, and can campaign on their experience and a knowledge of municipal government equal to any of their rivals.

Despite the delicate situation within the American Federation of Labor concerning the choice of Robert J. Watt of Massachusetts for the governing body of the International Labor Organization, the entire matter is being held in abeyance and it will not come up on the floor of the federation convention, it was learned today, unless unforeseen circumstances develop.
To the Drama Editor: Long overdue in the American press was your forthright article on what for many years has passed in the United States as "Hungarian drama."
A bicycle won a test for speed in heavy city traffic. The distance, about one mile, was from Dearborn and Quincy Streets to Halstead and Van Buren Streets during a noon rush hour.

Mrs. Leone Evans Tener, wife of John K. Tener, former Governor of Pennsylvania and former president of the National League, died of heart disease last night in St. John's Hospital at the age of 49 after a year's illness. Since May she and her husband had been living here at 7 Fairfield Place.

Princeton's freshmen gave the Mercersburg Academy eleven its first defeat of the season, 26-13, today. Rain fell for the greater part of the game as Mercersburg tried to end the string of Nassau victories at twelve.

Stopping the Yankees' rush, Carl Hubbell pitched the Giants to their first world series triumph of 1937 before 45,000 spectators at the Polo Grounds and cut the American Leaguers' lead to 3-1 in games. Hubbell, braced by a six-run blast in the second inning, overcame three errors by his team-mates and with a six-hit performance reversed his opening-game defeat.

Realty assessments just announced by the Department of Taxes and Assessments will be the basis upon which property owners in New York will pay levies during the next eighteen months, barring adjustments which may be made because of appeals for reductions.

Miss Anne Shepard Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Chapin, was married to Simon James Stanfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Jordan Stanfield of New York and Madison, N. J., this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church here. The Rev Raymond Cunningham officiated.

Miss Priscilla Baldwin Bliss, daughter of Mrs. Walter Phelps Bliss of this place and 740 Park Avenue, New York, and the late Mr. Bliss, was married here this afternoon in St. Bernard's Episcopal Church to Stanford C. Mallory of New York.

AMERICAN travelers in Denmark now may stop in Copenhagen (in the heart of the city) and journey almost all over the kingdom without ever paying more than from 40 to 85 cents a night for a good single room, clean and well-furnished, or twice that amount for a double room, by using hostelries operated by a novel chain-the Mission Hotels Union-which controls nearly fifty establishments in various parts of the country.
THE announcement Mr. Johnson has made for the coming Winter promise the most interesting season that the Metropolitan Opera Association has offered the public in late years.

Miss Evelyn Scattergood, daughter of J. Henry Scattergood of Dundale, Villanova, and of the late Mrs. Scattergood, was married this afternoon to Ralph Clement Bryant Jr., son of Professor and Mrs. Ralph Clement Bryant of New Haven, Conn. The ceremony was performed at Dundale.
James Campion Sr., known to thousands of Dartmouth men for more than a quarter of a century, died at the Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital today. He was 73 years old.
Among the many interesting courses offered in the annual prospectus of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden a course for homemakers is featured.
Jack Burrows, New York florist, has purchased a home on East Shore Trail at Lake Mohawk, near Sparta, N. J., reports the Arthur D. Crane Company, developers.
The German Government naturally supports whole-heartedly the negative Italian reply to the Anglo-French invitation to a tripartite conference.
A dozen gray-haired alumni of the United States Naval Academy, who believed themselevs "too old to have a reunion," met anyway today and went to a football game.

WASHINGTON.--Successful families in Federal land settlement projects are likely to have certain qualifications and characteristics, according to a recent survey of the methods of picking families for colonization experiments conducted by the Farm Security Administration in cooperation with the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

Stanley W. Church, former Acting Mayor of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Miss Eleanor Cederholm, a model and art student of Hollis, Queens, were married yesterday morning in the Bronx County Court House by Judge James M. Barrett.
The Children's Play Committee for the Clare Tree Major Children's Theatre of New York has arranged for its first performance in this city on Oct. 23.

Mrs. Christopher D. Smithers heads a committee in charge of a benefit sale to be held on Oct. 19 and 20 in Veterans Hall, Glen Cove, in aid of the country home for convalescent babies at Sea Cliff, a charity in which many North Shore members of society are actively interested.

Although "mixtures" of tulips are still being offered in the catalogue, these are for use in the cutting bed and not for general garden effects. Large estates or parks that have formal beds are often supplied with ,mixtures selected for harmonious tones and for balance between light and dark varieties.
Now that small Regal lily bulbs .an be bought almost as cheaply as tulip bulbs their use has extended by leaps and bounds. Formerly only large bulbs, at several dollars a dozen, were offered.

Miss Helen Hotchkiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Carlton Hotchkiss of Old Greenwich, was married to Daniel Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Miller of Stamford, at the Hotchkiss home this afternoon.

The University of Michigan will be the first State university in the country to incorporate into its academic activities an integrated religious program under the direction of the new Student Religious Association.
Getting away in seventh position, the Valdina Farm's Teddy's Comet broke through a field of sixteen today to win the twenty-sixth running of the $5,000 added Richard Johnson Stakes.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in the smallest volume in many weeks and less than half the total announced in the preceding week. Most of the calls announced last week were for parts of issues to satisfy sinking fund requirements, and, except for a few small lots of municipal bonds and warrants, were all for later months.

When the two Polo Grounds dressing rooms, were invaded yesterday shortly after Twinkletoes Selkirk had insured a fifth game by dropping a fly ball into the glove of Hank Leiber, observers found a slightly different attitude among the world series rivals.
EVERYBODY feels better now. The way the Yankees had been maltreating the Giants was brutal and humiliating. But there was a reverse to the weak side yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Spielberg of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Spielberg, to Dr. Aaron Cagan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Cagan, also of Brooklyn.

Opposition to further chartering of Federal savings and loan associations, which are being formed "promiscuously" and are in "direct competition with existing banking institutions," was expressed in a strongly worded resolution adopted yesterday by the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks in executive session in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Dick Riffle, who scored more points than any college player east of the Mississippi River last year, demonstrated to the City College eleven how he did it yesterday, scoring three touchdowns to lead Albright to a 34-0 victory over the Beavers at Lewisohn Stadium.

OLDSMOBILE, America's oldest manufacturer of automobiles, today announced its forty-first series of cars-the Oldsmobile Six and the Oldsmobile Eight for 1938. Both cars are now on display at local Oldsmobile dealers.
Vanderbilt's Commodores blossomed out today as, a passing team and filled the air with enough footballs to defeat a stubborn Southwestern eleven, 1 to 6, before a crowd of 10,000.

Miss Madeline Tierney, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Tierney of Montclair, was married this morning to Willard Edward Meyers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Meyers, also of Montclair, in the Church of the Immaculate Conception here.

GENEVA.--The Mandates Commission in a recent report makes several criticisms of the British administration of the group of mandated territories then examined. These were Tanganyika, British Cameroons and Togoland, Nauru, Southwest Africa (which is administered by the Union of South Africa) and New Guinea (administered by Australia).

Coriolanus," one of Shakespeare's least known tragedies, which has not been produced professionally in America for more than fifty years, was the production offered tonight at the Theatre of the Four Seasons as a New York State Federal theatre project under the direction of Charles Hopkins. The theatre,

THE Marx brothers-who seldom rush into anything have finally joined forces with RKO Radio for three pictures, the first to be "Room Service," which the studio acquired last July from its Broadway sponsors for $255,000.

Mrs. Benjamin Antin will be honored for her philanthropic services with a luncheon by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, for which she is Bronx chairman of the women's division, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Leo Sulzberger, chairman of the women's division for the Greater New York campaign.

A "MUSIC AND THE DANCE" series of performances by leading virtuosos, singers and dancers of today; lectures with interpretations by distinguished artists; courses in the theory and appreciation of music; rehearsals and performances of an amateur orchestra now assembling in order to
The following is the text of the Anglo-French note of Oct. 2 to the Italian Government on the withdrawal of volunteers in Spain:
Former President Herbert Hoover will be a speaker here Nov. 11 at dedication exercises of the new Maxwell School of Citizenship at Syracuse University, officials of the university said today.

Germany's bid for colonies will be intensified by a concerted propaganda campaign both through the press and at mass meetings. It is expected that there will be official declarations to this effect soon.
One of the last official acts of Edward VIII in his short reign over the British Empire was his visit, last November, to the so-called "special areas" of Wales.

State Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie signed today a writ of mandamus ordering Asbury Park to turn over its beachfront properties and records to the four commissioners appointed by Governor Hoffman to administer the properties. It is expected that the writ will be served on Monday.

Transatlantic fares on passenger liners will be increased by $5 in all classes beginning Nov. 1, according to Harold P. Borer,. passenger traffic manager of the Cunard White Star. Line, who received word yesterday to that effect from officials of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference which has been meeting in Paris.

IN a field that is crowded with mediocrity, "South by Thunderbird" stands out as a superior book of travel, as did also Mr. Strode's two earlier books, "The Story of Bermuda" and 'The Pageant of Cuba."
SIGRID UNDSET speaks again with the still, small voice of unpretentious authority and genius. At first it is a voice that seems demure and slight for a Nobel Prize winner.

The proposed national boycott on Japanese silk and the extent of its probable effect on the textile industry in this city and in the Passaic Valley will be discussed at the meeting of the Paterson Industrial Commission here Monday night.

A new law would be required before the United States might enter a naval construction race with the world's other great powers. While Great Britain proclaims a fleet-expansion program matched "on only rare occasion" in its history, the United States is bound by its own independent action - the Vinson-Trammell Act of 1934 - to build its navy only to the strength permitted by now-defunct naval treaties.

Mayor F. H. La Guardia replied yesterday to the charge of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, his Democratic opponent, that he had been neglectful in providing adequate school accommodations for Washington Heights by saying in effect that Mr. Ma-honey did not know what he was talking about.
Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos declared tonight that "we must act" in reply to Italy's rejection of the Franco-British invitation for three-power conferences on Spanish intervention.

A witness before a marine casualty board sitting in the offices of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation at 45 Broadway expressed the opinion yesterday that live steam passing at high speed over water in the boiler pipes might have caused the fatal explosion on the freighter Brazos at her pier last Wednesday.
Wellesley College alumnae in the metropolitan area are supporting a current project to increase the scholarship fund of the New York Wellesley Club.

The growing importance of foreign affairs in American life and the increasing ease of communication between nations makes it obligatory upon American colleges to revise old methods of instruction in foreign languages, in the opinion of Dr. George H. R. O'Donnell, head of the School of Languages at Russell Sage College here.
The more the housewife ponders the meat situation, the blacker it looks. The price of poultry, which usually, declines at this time of the year, is pegged high and gives no signs of slipping soon.

IN their various outdoor activities--camping, hiking, mountain climbing, exploring and sailing--the Boy Scouts find a knowledge of how to use ropes and cords particularly valuable. Knot-tying, in fact, is a basic prerequisite; before a boy can attain the lowest rank in the movement, that of tenderfoot, he must learn how to make a square knot and eight of sixteen other useful knots.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador,-An expert wolf hunter from the Western United States may be hired to lead a campaign against the packs of wild dogs on the Galapagos Islands, according to El Telegrafo.

Baseball's financial officials sat down last night to divide the spoils of the 1937 world series, which drew a five-game "gate" of $985,994, according to The Associated Press. Fifteen per cent of the total, according to baseball's law, goes to the commissioner's office.

The Meadow Brook Club's annual Fall best-ball invitation golf tournament came to a conclusion today, with four teams gaining the top honors instead of the one pair, which has been customary in past years.

Last week repeated the phenomenon of a stock market declining by fits and starts (the averages had fallen 8 3/4 points further when prices touched their lowest), and yet of nearly all good authorities on business conditions insisting that distinctly unfavorable trade conditions were not indicated.

Official Show and Convention of the New York State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association opens at the Hotel Pennsylvania this morning at 10 o'clock and continues Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.
The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would spend $40,000,000 within the next year in an expansion program at the River Rouge plant, thereby doubling the amount spent in the 1935-36 program.

For the first time since the founding of the institution in 1863, triplets were born yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-sixth Street and Park Avenue. They were born to Mrs. Elizabeth Kelly, 28 years old, of 2,924 Twenty-first Avenue, Astoria.

It was a good omen of the musical season that its first major recital should be given by the pianist Gieseking, who played yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. It may be added it once that Mr. Gieseking, a unique musician and artist upon his instrument, has seldom afforded us more beautiful and significant interpretations.

Demands involved in the threatened strike of 1,200 drivers for eight Greyhound bus lines, postponed for seventy-two hours until 5 A. M. Wednesday, will be considered in a conference of union and company officials scheduled for tomorrow afternoon.

Topped by new high marks for attendance and gate receipts for a five-game series, despite the absence of capacity crowds, the second straight all-New York baseball warfare added a score of recordequaling or record-breaking items to the famous "Little Red Book."

Mrs. James H. Davidson of this city today announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Miss Madeleine Huson Davidson, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ezra D. Davidson, to Martin Allen Pond, son of Mrs. Clifford A. Pond of Hamden, Conn., and the late Mr. Pond.

A drive to collect funds for refugees in China was staged in Chinatown yesterday afternoon by the Chinese Women's Patriotic League. The affair lasted almost four hours and was a combination parade, mass meeting, tag day and mardi gras.

After playing for five hours and making a total of forty moves, Dr. Max Euwe of this city, chess champion of the world, and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris adjourned the third game of their return match for the title tonight. Dr Euwe, in a somewhat preferable position, sealed his fortyfirst move. Play will be resumed tomorrow.

Performing like a veteran, Bob of Montauk-Chesapeake, owned by the Dilwyne Kennels of Montchanin, Del., and shown by Mrs. Carl Erickson of Amagansett, carried off the honors today at the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club event limited to women handlers.

Mr. and Mrs. Luther Dana Fernald of 15 Mountain Avenue, this place, gave a tea at their home this afternoon at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Furniss Fernald, to Theodore Erskine Tuck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Calvin Tuck of 157 Clove Road, New Rochelle, N. Y.

Five Federal Trade Commission hearings are scheduled by the commission in New York this week. Testimony in the case involving the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., will be taken tomorrow morning at 45 Broadway.

The marriage of Miss Gertrude Eisner of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs.' Mark Eisner of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., to Edward Kolker, son of Mrs. Samuel Kolker, also of New York, and the late Mr. Kolker, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her brother-inlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Kohn, 480 Park Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. B. Benedict Glazer.
Stock exchange sentiment this week has been firm, with a tendency to ignore international issues in favor of industrials, especially those which should benefit from depreciation of the franc.
Charles Adams Prince, musical director, died early today after an illness of three months at the suburban home of his sister, Mrs. Hazel Prince Tuggle. He was 68 years old.
Sir Oswald Mosley, British Fascist leader, suffered a concussion of the brain and scalp wounds today when stoned by demonstrators at Liverpool as he prepared to make a speech.

Mayor La Guardia has until midnight tonight to veto the McManus bill providing a five-day week for all city employes except those in the schools and the Police and Fire Departments. Should he fail to veto it the bill will become law.
Fifty thousand members of the Essex Division, Newark Federation of Holy Name Societies, marched in their annual parade here today in view of 75,000 spectators who lined Broad Street.

Ralph S. Kent, general chairman of the lawyers Committee of the Ninth Judicial District, decided upon a new plan today for promoting the candidacy of former County Judge Gerald Nolan of Yonkers for Supreme Court Justice on the Republican ticket by holding

The marriage of Miss Rose Marie Harris, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Harris, to Jerome Shoenfeld of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Shoenfeld, took place yesterday morning at the home of the bride's parents, 906 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Harry Weiss of Shaari Zedik Temple performed the ceremony.

More than 800 newspapers throughout the country have signified their willingness to carry comio strip advertising, according to the plan devised and promoted by the George A. McDevitt Company, newspaper representatives.

Having granted to nineteen unions wage increases totaling about $130,000,000 annually, the railway managements hope that in return they will obtain agreements with the unions that will correct a situation considered undesirable in respect to rulings of railways labor boards of adjustment.

Referring to the recent address of the President at Chicago, it would seem to be time for Americans to realize that, just as a community cannot maintain law and order without organization of the police power of the State with accompanying financial and other support for its maintenance,
Arthur Elijah Barnes, who was born in a log house in the town of Galen seventy-five years ago and became State Superintendent of Schools, died at his home here today, following a stroke Thursday.
General Ettore Bastico, one of the twelve Italian generals named recently as fighting for the Insurgents in the Spanish civil war, conferred today with Premier Mussolini.

Worship makes possible the highest relationship of man to man, the Rev. Dr. Walton H.--Greever, secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America, declared yesterday at the Lutheran Advent Church, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

J. Gilbert Hall of New York won the men's singles of the Hot Springs Fall tennis tournament today by defeating Arthur W. MacPherson, New York, 6--2, 6--2. Hall retired a previous trophy in 1933 and MacPherson has two legs on the present cup.
Commerce Department officials estimated today American investments in China at $125,000,000 and in Japan at $60,000,000.
The engagement of Miss Frances Conant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George K. Conant, to John Lowell Richards of New York was announced today to a party of friends at the Conant home.
The Brooklyn Eagles made their first appearance of the season at Ebbets Field yesterday and played to a scoreless tie with the Newark Tornadoes in an American Football Association contest.

The engagement of Miss Maxine Sittenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Sittenfeld of this city, to Morton Joseph Hollander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Hollander of New York, has been announced by her parents.

About 110 American war refugees from Shanghai and Tsingtao were brought to Kobe today by the United States Navy's submarine tender Canopus. Most of them intend to embark on the first available ship for the United States.

Marked expansion in Peruvian banking and commercial activities was recorded in July, according to the September bulletin of the Central Bank. Banking movements in July are always higher than in other months, but the 1937 increase tops those recorded in recent years.

More than 2,000 Nicaraguans have returned from Honduras because of the recent boundary dispute. Many had resided in Honduras for years. Nicaraguans believe their return will help end the labor shortage.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,918,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

A 78-yard march for a touchdown late in the third period enabled the Detroit Lions to come from behind and defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 to 3, in a National Football League battle before 16,000 spectators today. Ernie Caddel, fleet halfback, went over from the 2-yard line, racing around right end.

Fiftythree receiverships were liquidated in September, bringing to 826 the number of banks finally closed or restored to solvency since the banking holiday of 1933, J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

Mrs. Clara Ruge, art and dramatic critic of The New York Volkszeitung for more. than thirty years, died here last night at the home of her son, Bernard A. Ruge. Her age was 81. She had been ill several months with a heart ailment. Private funeral services will be held here Tuesday.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Babtiste, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Babtiste of Brooklyn and Montclair, N. J., to James Weaver, son of Mrs. Eli W. Weaver of Washington, D. C., and the late Mr. Weaver, took place here yesterday afternoon at the Pomona Country Club.

Miss Florence Belle Platt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Platt of Waterbury, became the bride of Harrison De Witt Weed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lorin H. Weed of New Haven, in the Congregational Church here yesterday. The Rev. Moreton W. Owen officiated.

The campaign of the Anti Movie DoubleFeature League of America has been extended to San Francisco, the New England area and Westchester County, it was announced today by George H. Siegel and William R. Clay, sponsors of the movement.

Students of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here will hold a miniature country fair tomorrow afternoon in the college administration building to raise funds for the annual tour of the Preston Debating Society, a student group. Miss Eileen Toughey of Brooklyn is general chairman.

The death rate in New York State rose in August to 9.6 per cent per 1,000 population, chiefly because of heart disease and accidents, Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of the Health Department's division of vital statistics, reported today.

James Allen and Holt S. McKinney, formerly assistant treasurers of the Vick Chemical Company, have been elected vice presidents. Mr. Allen will be in charge of investments and Mr. McKinney will attend to financial and corporate matters.

Appointment of a citizens' committee of one thousand to sponsor the joint campaign for $6,250,000 of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities was announced last night by Walter N. Rothschild, chairman of the drive.

A report that Vittorio Mussolini, son of the Italian Premier, might be received by -President Roosevelt during his visit to Washington brought a protest today from Italians here who are opposed to the Fascist regime. Mr. Mussolini did not go to the White House today.
Brazil is able to increase substantially the payments on its foreign debts, according to a bulletin to be issued today by John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance.

While preaching on the subject "The Healing Shadow" in Glass Lake Methodist Church today, the Rev. William T. Wees of Averill Park died suddenly of a heart attack. His fall from the pulpit was witnessed by his wife and she was one of the first to reach his side.

Mrs.Cornelius Vanderbilt of New York has arrived at the Homestead for her annual visit. Among those having luncheon at the Cascades Club today were Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pell, Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Jarrett, Mrs. J. M. Hubbard, Mrs. George Case, Mrs. Susan Norton and Miss Jane Stock.
Six million dollars in inheritance and similar estate taxes will be at stake tomorrow in a hearing designed to settle the question of the legal residence of the late Colonel E. H. R. Green.
Fellowships totaling $10,025 have been awarded to forty-one students at the Harvard Medical School for the current academic year. Those receiving the fellowship are:

Walter Cravens, 29 years old, of Butler, Okla., contestant in the rodeo at Madison Square Garden, who was kicked and trampled by a Brahma steer in the arena Saturday night, died at 11:50 A. M. yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital.

Inspector Eugene F. Hoyt of was the State Police Bureau of Criminal Investigation said tonight he was seeking Wilfred Squires, 22, of Jr., Branchport, N. Y., for questioning in connection with the slaying of Morris B. Close, Rochester Scoutmaster, and a Pennsylvania man.

The Trade Research Institute here has estimated that the value of the gross production of German industry in 1936 was 65,000,000,000 to 70,000,000,000 marks, which is 30,000,000,000 marks above the total in 1932.

More than a score of new exhibitions are on this week's calendar. Group shows and work by women artists represent a goodly proportion of the total. A number of galleries are reopening for the season and a wide variety of exhibitions is included in the roster.
Mexico indicated its willingness today to take the lead among nations not signatories to the Nine-Power Treaty in enforcing economic sanctions against Japan.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner endorsed yesterday the candidacy of Harold W. Hastings for District Attorney of New York County. Mr. Hastings, the Tammany candidate, is being opposed by Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor.
The Spanish Government freighter Cabo Santo Tome was set afire and blown up off the Algerian coast today in an attack by two unidentified destroyers.

The National Conference on Palestine Land Redemption, at its closing session here this afternoon, unanimously voted a $2,000,000 quota as American Jewry's contribution to the Zionist land-purchasing instrument for the year 1937-1938 and a special emergency fund of $250,000 for the acquisition of what is to become known as the "American Region" in the zone north of Lake Huleh, in Upper Galilee.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Friday at his home in Columbus, Ga., of Theodore E. Golden, president of the Golden Foundry and Machine Company and the Lumis Cotton Gin Company of Columbus. Mr. Golden.

Two former State amateur champions met in the final of the New Jersey Shore three-day invitation tournament at the Monmouth County Country Club today. Charles Whitehead, Plainfield sharpshooter, who beat J. Wolcott Brown of the Homestead Golf Club, Spring Lake, for the State title last year, downed Brown 1 u?? to win the shore event.

While several hundred thousand Chinese and Japanese troops were battling 175 miles to the south, Peiping quietly celebrated the "Double Tenth" today. The "Double Tenth"-tenth day of the tenth month-is modern China's Independence Day.
The Italian reply to the FranCo-British note is unanimously considered here as purely an effort to gain time as intervention is intensified for the great struggle lying ahead.

The fact that teachers of dancing, as employers, must pay a social security tax for one or more assistants, whether instructors or musical. accompanists, when regularly emplayed as an aid in professional work, irrespective of the period of employment, was revealed yesterday at the October meeting in the Hotel Astor of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc.

Oliver D. Appleton's handsome chestnut gelding Star Run today added further laurels to a record already studded with honors by being judged champion hunter in the second annual Fall horse show of the Hutchinson Riding Academy.

United States Senator A. Harry Moore, Democratic candidate for Governor, and State Senator Lester H. Clee, Republican candidate, will make campaign tours this week in various counties of the State, their headquarters announced today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Esleeck Sheldon of 31 Midwood Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Mary Sheldon, to Robert Gillespie Fenton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Fenton, also of Brooklyn. The announcement was made yesterday at a reception given at the home of Miss Sheldon's parents.

Persons with net incomes from $2,500 to $3,000 per year, received in 1935 the largest aggregate income of any income group in the United States, while persons with net incomes from $100,000 to $150,000 paid the largest amount of taxes, Treasury statistics showed today.

A gloomy picture of the political, economic and social situation throughout the world today is painted by Sir George Paish, British economist, in an article in the current issue of International Conciliation, publication of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had certified the United Rubber Workers of America, Local 131, as the representative for collective bargaining of the production and maintenance

IT'S all over, including the shouting. Don Vernon Gomez went out there to put a stop to the series and he did it with considerable eclat, so to speak. He held the Giants to a couple of runs, struck out sundry batters, drove in the winning run himself and made the last put-out of the campaign. If they had asked him, he would have helped with the umpiring, too.

If the early returns mean anything (and they ought to), the town has a new hit. It is "Susan and God," which, installed by John Golden at the Plymouth Theatre on Thursday night, proceeded to gross a figure in the neighborhood of $11,000 in four performances.

A collection of mementos tracing the career of the late Dr. Charles Frederick Chandler will be exhibited this month in the Chandler Chemical Museum as part of Columbia University's program commemorating the 100th birthday anniversary of the noted industrial chemist who was a member of the faculty for sixty-one years.
The continued break in the stock market last week brought renewed discussion in Wall Street regarding its possible causes, both in the general business situation and within the market itself.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York will observe on next Friday the fifth anniversary of its establishment to serve as a central credit agency for the thrift and home-financing institutions in the Second Federal Home Loan Bank District, which comprises New York. New Jersey.

The seven-story apartment house at 1,618 to 1,622 Amsterdam Avenue, at the southwest corner of 140th Street, has been acquired by the Ramso Realty Corporation, Samuel Yersersky, president, for cash above a first mortgage of $196,000.

A train conspicuously marked with British flags pulled into Kowloon Station here today after a four-day journey from interior Hankow, bringing 222 members of the crew of the British cruiser Capetown and twelve civilians, mostly British missionaries.

A city inquiry into charges by kosher butchers that meat packers are "substituting" inferior grades of- meat for prime cuts at prime prices will be started today by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets.

In a colorful patriotic and religous demonstration, climaxed by a parade of 30,000 up Fifth Avenue, Polish-Americans observed Pulaski Day yesterday in commemoration of the 158th, anniversary of the death of Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski, hero of the Revolutionary War.

Count Konrad von Preysing-Lichtenegg-Moos, the Catholic Bishop of Berlin, today issued a pastoral letter in which he charges that Germany is being systematically de-Christianized in a cautious fashion calculated not to arouse too intense public protest. The letter leaves no doubt of the Bishop's conviction that the regime is set on completely destroying the Christian religion.

The Merchants and Salesmen's League put forward yesterday Theodore Roosevelt as a candidate for member of the Republican National Committee to fill the vacancy to be caused by the resignation of Charles D. Hilles, which will become effective after election.

Monness Shapiro of 513 Broadway, New York, clothiers, have entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue use of the words "government khati" as descriptive of its products and use of the word "government" with "khaki"
The Rochester Tigers of the American Football League handed the Cincinnati Bengals their first league defeat, 17 to 14, before 5,000 fans today. Both teams scored in the second period.
The American Federation of Hosiery Workers today called upon the State of Illinois and the Federal Department of Justice to protect its members and organizers from vigilante violence at Chester, Ill.
Stock companies incorporated in September numbered 1,093, lifting the total since Jan. 1 to 13,571. This, however, is below the 1936 figure of 14,031 for the corresponding period.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democratic leader against President Roosevelt's judicial reorganization proposals, declared in an address here tonight that a renewed struggle on the issue 'will result in a fight in the Senate that will tear the party to shreds."
Half of the front pages of today's Izvestia and Pravda was devoted to a mass appeal by the 14,000 Stakhanoffite coal miners in the Donetz Basin to all coal workers in the nation.

Had it not been for the great seasonal expansion in the canning industry employment and payroll figures for September would have shown an entirely different result, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner said today in announcing figures for the month.

William Donovan, 39 years old, of 210 Second Street, Hoboken, N. J., died at 9 o'clock last night in Fordham Hospital from a hemorrhage of the brain resulting from injuries in a soccer football practice game at Innisfail Athletic Field, 240th Street and Broadway, the Bronx, late yesterday afternoon.
The Chicago Bears overpowered the Cleveland Rams today, 20 to 2, in a National Football League game, playing almost the entire contest in Ram territory.

Mr. and Mrs. Julius W. Cone of this city have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Cone's daughter, Miss Frances Honnet Stern, to Ferris Sands Hetherington Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hetherington of Plainfield, N. J. The wedding will take place here on Nov. 5.

A well-dressed elderly man who walked into the New Rochelle police station Friday night and said he could not recall him name or his home was identified today at Grasslands Hospital as Louthar Nohtan, a clerk in the Memorial men's hotel, run by the Salvation Army on the Bowery in Manhattan.

Plans for remodeling the old Grand Opera House property, fourstory theatre and store building at 309 West Twenty-third Street and 261-71 Eighth Avenue, in the Chelsea neighborhood, have been filed by Thomas W. Lamb, architect, with the Manhattan Department of Buildings.
Dr. H. H. Kung, Finance Minister of China, arriving here today after a tour of the United States and Europe, said China would "call for an armistice as soon as Japan gives the lead."

With Joseph Littau as guest conductor and Miss Eva Stark as solo violinist, the New York Civic Orchestra presented a program devoted to the music of Gustav Holst, Mendelssohn and Schumann at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. Miss Stark was heard in the Mendelssohn concerto, and her performance was warmly received.

A marked increase during the last fiscal year in the appointment of non-civil service deputy collectors in the Bureau of Internal Revenue was called to the attention of Seeretary Morgenthau today in a letter from Robert L. Johnson, president of the National Civil Service Reform League.

On the eve of the second and closing week of the American Federation of Labor's annual convention, President William Green announced today that steps had been taken toward chartering international unions among cannery and agricultural workers and among white collar workers such as stenographers, bookkeepers and accountants emploved in private offices.

For the last week the Bourse has been under the influence of various factors. Local elections were not expected to be of any practical consequence but it was seen that they might give indications of public tendencies and consequently exert a moral influence.

The city has appropriated more money for home relief for the quarter ending Dec. 31 than was spent in any three-month period since the Federal Government assumed responsibility for work relief two years ago, even though the rolls of the Emergency Relief Bureau have declined by 14.8 per cent from the peak of March, 1936, an analysis disclosed yesterday.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 81.6 on Oct. 6, compared with 82.2 a fortnight before, 83 a month previously and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1934, just before the pension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Mordecai Konowitz of Jamaica, Queens, was re-elected president of the Long Island Zionist Region at the third annual convention, attended by 700 delegates and other members at Temple Israel here today.

All of the passions which possess men were in the face of Christ, but disciplined and motivated for good, said the Rev. Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, dean of Drew Theological Seminary, in his sermon yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Officials of the British Legion marched with members of the American Legion today from the Cenotaph to the tomb of the Unknown Warrior in Westminster Abbey as the latter paid a solemn tribute to the British war dead.

" Pitching?" yelled Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, gesticulating wildly and trying to make himself heard in the bedlam of the Yankee dressing room yesterday after Joe McCarthy's forces had put the clincher on their sixth and record-breaking world title.

Several hundred Princeton University alumni from all parts of the country will gather in Chicago over the coming week-end for the third Chicago meeting of the National Alumni Association, it was announced today by Donald W. Griffin, secretary of the Princeton Graduate Council.
It is now possible to give the background of the persistent rumors in political circles that Prince Ernst von Starhemberg is about to re-enter Austrian political life and perhaps the government.

The traditional jigs, reels, airs and lore of old Ireland were revived in Manhattan yesterday when over 2,000 Irish-Americans gathered for the fifth annual feis, or festival, of the United Irish Counties Association at the Windsor Palace, formerly the St. Nicholas Palace, 53 West Sixty-sixth Street.

General and Mrs. Emile Adolphe Taufflieb of Paris will arrive Thursday on the Normandie and will be at the Pierre. Mrs. Henry E. Coe and Miss Rosalie Coe will close their place in Southampton this week and return to Mayfair House for the Autumn and Winter.

The New York Football Giants defeated the Wilmington Clippers, 19 to 7, today in their final tune-up exhibition for the opening game in the Polo Grounds next Sunday. The field was slippery from an all-day rain.

Assumption of increasing obligations for human needs by governmental relief groups has left gaps which Jewish welfare agencies must fill if their existence is to be justified, Harry Greenstein, director of Jewish social welfare in Baltimore, asserted here today.

Making good on two free shots, the Argentine polo team defeated Mexico by 8 to 6 today to square the series at one game apiece. It was rough riding on a rough field and two of the Mexican players were injured as they cut in front of rival ponies.

The Rev. Dr. Raymond W. Smiley, pastor of the Westminster Presbyterian Church here for the last four years, announced to his congregation this morning that he had accepted a call from the First Presbyterian Church of Youngstown. Ohio.

Governor Lehman has named Melville A. Kelsey, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board; Frank M. McCurdy, vice president of the Brooklyn organization, and Arthur Gelston, executive secretary, as New York delegates to the thirtieth annual conference of the National Tax Association opening on Oct. 25 in Baltimore, Md.

GENERAL PIERRE POLOVTSOFF, as you probably don't know, is president of the International Sporting Club, and the International Sporting Club, as you probably do know, is more or less synonymous with the Monte Carlo Casino.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Campbell Winmill of New York and Warrenton, Va., today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Viola Winmill, to Randolph G. Duffey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Duffey of Middleburg, Va.

Ceremonies marking the laying of the cornerstone for a $600,000 addition to Israel Zion Hospital, Tenth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, was cut short by rain yesterday afternoon and a program in the hospital auditorium substituted.

Franco-Britisl- discussions, according to indications in Paris yesterday, were turning from the proposal to open the French frontier for arms shipments to plans to check Italy in the Balaerics and North Africa.

Fear of war, of failure, of approaching old age and poverty were cited as the most common of all fears by the Rev. Dr. Frank Oliver Hall, pastor of the Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last eek, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 89.8, which compares with 90.7 a week ago, 92.2 two weeks ago, 92.4 three weeks ago and 91.2 four weeks ago.

Canisius College scored its first football victory of the season today before 4,000 fans, subduing Mount St. Mary's of Emmitsburg, Md., 7-0. Russ La Tona sliced off tackle from the 7-yard line for the touchdown in the third quarter after
Complete satisfaction with New York City's registration for the election on Nov. 2 was expressed yesterday by leaders of all political parties and campaign managers for the opposing candidates.

A series of fortnightly illustrated music talks, under the auspices of the music committee of the New York Junior League, will be held at the league headquarters, 221 East Seventy-first Street, beginning the morning of Oct. 27. The other three lectures will take place on Nov. 17, Dec. 1 and Dec. 15.

McA. Donald Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan, had thirty friends from Salisbury, Conn., as his supper guests last night at the Stockbridge Golf Club. Later they had a coon hunt on Rattlesnake Mountain.
Japan's formal reply to the charges by the League of Nations and the United States of violations of the Nine-Power Treaty and the Kellogg pact throws no new light on the struggle in China.

The dispute among American Federation of Labor leaders over the city campaign continued yesterday, with supporters of Mayor La Guardia declaring that Jeremiah T. Mahoney was "making a ridiculous spectacle of himself" by claiming A. F. of L. support.
St. Thomas College defeated St. Mary's of San Antonio, Texas, by a score of 14 to 7 today. Adam Stephanek, the Tommies' right halfback, scored his team's two touchdowns.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy J. Lodor, daughter of Mrs. Charles Francis Lodor of this city and the late Mr. Lodor, to W. Chester Bottome of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard B. Bottome of Glenbrook,

As bankers from all sections of the country began pouring into this city tonight for the sixty-third annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which opens tomorrow, advance indications were that the meeting would be one of the best attended in years and also one of the least controversial.

Edmund L. Moodie, 32 years old, private pilot for.H. P. Davison, a son of the late Morgan partner, was killed last night when Mr. Davison's plane, which he was flying to New York from the Stinson factory at Wayne, Mich., crashed on a farm near Lynn, Pa.

By a brilliant manoeuvre carried out during Saturday night ard followed by a succession of swift, hard blows yesterday, General Juichi Terauchl turned the flank of the last Chinese defenses in Southern Hopeh Province and entered Shihkiachwang fortress.

Appointment of James Delinage Ross, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, as administrator of the Bonneville hydroelectric project was announced today by Secretary of the Interior Ickes.

Accused of driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident, Joseph B. Smoyak, 27 years old, of 165 James Street, Woodbridge, was arrested tonight soon after an automobile had killed one boy and seriously injured another on Amboy Avenue, near the Woodbridge line.

The Rev. Terence McNulty, since 1925 pastor of St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Dongan Hills, S. I., died yesterday in his rectory. 101 Cromwell Avenue, after a two months' illness of heart disease. Born in Scranton, Pa., fifty-five years ago, he was educated at Holy Cross College and Dunwoodie Seminary.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Rentschler of Hartford, Conn., arrived by private plane today for their annual visit at the Greenbrier, accompanied by their daughters, the Misses Helen and Ann Rentschler, and Mr. and Mrs. D. L. Brown.

Buying action lacked enthusiasm in the New York wholesale market last week, although almost all sections received attention. Dress business lagged perceptibly. However, retailers began assembling collections of formal clothes for the Winter social season.

Save in the East, where the major powers stood their ground almost without exception, Saturday's returns from the gridiron brought about as much grief to the football elect as they have ever experienced at so early a stage.

Mrs. Ruby Cunningham Dekker, wife of Cornelius Dekker, business manager of The Manchester Union-Leader, died here today following an operation. A native of South Dakota, Mrs. Dekker and her husband, prior to their coming here, lived in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich.,

The West Side improvement project in Riverside and Fort Washington Parks, although not entirely finished, will be opened to the public tomorrow, with Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and other political and civic leaders taking part in the dedication exercises, the Park Department announced yesterday.

The Weather Bureau issued the following storm warning today: "Advisory 11 A. M. northeast storm warnings displayed Boston to New Haven and northwest storm warnings south of New Haven to. Atlantic City.

For the second time in the nation's history automobiles and parts ranked first in the first six months of the year as the country's leading export products, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States showed today in an analysis of foreign trade.

Endorsement by Mayor La Guardia of the candidacy of John G. L. Molloy, his former law secretary, for the City Council was announced yesterday by Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post, chairman of the Democratic Committee for the Election of the La GuardiaDewey Ticket.
Robert Frost has left his farm in Vermont for Amherst, and is reading the first proofs of the forthcoming book about him, "Recognition of Robert Frost," which Holt will publish Nov. 23.

Joseph H. Lee has joined the Shell Union Oil Corporation as assistant manager of the lubricating department, succeeding A. T. Doane, who becomes sales manager of the company's Eastern division with headquarters at Boston.
After last week's strength and the further rise in the early part of this week, the subsequent sharp drop in wheat prices upset the British market rather badly and shook confidence.

For the fourth time in the last five years Catholic University defeated a La Salle eleven today, 27-12, as the latter dedicated its new McCarthy Stadium before 6,000 fans. Two touchdowns by Maurice (Red) Carroll, both on passes,

Incomplete returns from the French cantonal election's early this morning indicate that the parties of the dominant Popular Front have held their strength with few changes. It is difficult to see a swing to one side or the other, but the result will depend on later returns and especially on the second ballot next Sunday.

The Cubs and the White Sox, deadlocked at two victories each in their city championship series and unable to do anything about it today because of rain, will resume their battle tomorrow on the White Sox home lot, Comiskey Park.
Death and other drastic punishments were decreed today for Chinese Army officers who fail to offer "heroic resistance" to the Japanese invaders.

A warning that "the church of God is on trial as never before in her history" was sounded today by the Rev. Dr. zebarney T. Phillips of Washington, president of the House of Clerical and Lay Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the united States.
The German financial press attributes the world decline in prices of commodities except wheat in the last week of September to weakness of securities and month-end speculative selling.

A need to re-establish the principles of truth and justice throughout the civilized world is stressed by Professor Albert Einstein in a message sent to the Y. M. C. A. for its international celebration of Founders Day, which occurs today.

Harold E. Dahl, the Champaign, Ill., aviator who was sentenced to death and then reprieved by the Spanish Insurgents, walked out of the Salamanca jail on parole today to await his expected exchange for a Government-held prisoner.
An important and valuable collection of English silver, purchased during the past eight years by William Randolph Hearst, will be sold at auction at Sotheby's next month.

The proposed conference of signatories of the Nine-power treaty to discuss the situation created in the Far East by Japan's military activities in China probably will be' held in Brussels, according to information obtained today from official sources.

A gold-embossed, autographed Bible; presented by the Countess Bethlen, wife of Count Stephan Bethlen, former Premier of Hungary, was dedicated yesterday at the First Magyar Presbyterian Church, 233 East 116th Street, by Dr. Duncan J. MacMillan, 92-year-old retired Presbyterian minister who was active in organizing the church thirty years ago.

The unstable condition of the world at present can be traced directly to the work of God in "shaking out" the transient and unenduring elements of civilization, the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson, pastor of the North Presbyterian Church, 525 West 155th Street, told his congregation yesterday.
The Green Bay Packers broke loose with a devastating running and passing game today to smother the Chicago Cardinals, 34 to 13, in a National Football League game before 18,000.

More than 200 members of the Middle Atlantic Grotto Association closed a three-day conference here today by electing Sidney Cohen of Baltimore president for next year. Others elected are William G. Williams, Atlantic City, deputy president; Adolph Gaswind, Newark,
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 66 per cent ot capacity, off 8 points from the week before and representing a decline of 18 points in five weeks.

University of Santa Clara's Broncos, Sugar Bowl champions aiming for their second invasion of the annual New Year's Day football classic at New Orleans, swarmed over a scrappy University of San Francisco eleven today, 13 to 0.

With some thirty Eastern prep squads and a good number of metropolitan high school teams joining the gridiron parade, the current football season obtained a firmer grip on scholastic fans during the past week-end, while certain elevens more definitely established themselves as leading powers.

The American Association for Social Security requested the American Association of University Professors yesterday to investigate the charge that the Social Security Board had tried to interfere with academic freedom by protesting to New York University on a course given by Abraham Epstein, executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security.

New South Wales is a spirited, positive and original State. It has lately illustrated these qualities, and perhaps its sense of humor, in an unexpected way. Mr. R. W. D. Weaver, who has been a Minister under two Governments and fallen into disfavor with two Premiers, has been chosen by his party Speaker of the Legislative Assembly.

The Museum of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 122d Street and Broadway, placed on exhibition yesterday a fifteenth century book of astronomical tables of the same edition as was used by Christopher Columbus on some of his later voyages.
Buenos Aires awoke this morning to find water' in the city mains again and Saturday's waterless day remained only a bad dream to be talked about for years to come.

Totally disabled by a steam pipe explosion and with two of her engine room crew killed and several injured, the freighter Caloria was being towed toward this port, according to radio dispatches from the Coast Guard cutter Yamacraw, which responded to distress calls early today.

Celebration of the twentieth anni- aa versary of the founding of the Jewish Center, 131 West Eightysixth Street-said by its foundrs me to be the first institution of its kind in America-is now under way and will culminate in a dinner dance at the Waldorf-Astoria next Sunday evening.
Mrs. Agnes C. Baer, active in Catholic and political circles of central Queens, of 92-40 170th Street, Jamaica, died Friday in Queens Memorial Hospital.

With their long-range guns booming once more behind their streamlined left-hander, Vernon Gomez, the Yankees brought the 1937 world series to a swift and decisive close at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They found their target with unerring accuracy and brought down the Giants in the fifth and final game by a score of 4 to 2.
Liquidation developed in lard futures here last week in sympathy with grains and commodities in general, especially cottonseed oil, and all deliveries dropped to new low levels for the season.

Dr. Robert Cushman Murphy, curator of oceanic birds at the American Museum of Natural History, will return on the Grace liner Santa Rita today from an expedition to Ecuador. Others listed on the Santa Rita, which comes from West Coast South American ports via the Panama Canal, are Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott, the Rev. F. J. Huber and Thomas Black.

Jimmie Hines of the Garden City Country Club, Metropolitan champion and three-time winner of the Glens Falls open, today added the Long Island P. G. A. championship to his list of conquests, defeating Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills in the final of the medal-match play tournament over the Sound View Golf Club course.

In an afternoon of sterling competition during which the gallery was treated to a series of sound and at times brilliant spaniel work, the open all-age stake for cockers was taken today by Rowcliffe Bangaway, bred and owned by the Rowcliffe Kennels of Mrs. A. R. Moffit of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., and handled by Elias C. Vail.

The knowledge that spiritual values and the soul of man cannot be destroyed by violence should give men courage in these days of widespread fear, the Rev. Dr. Donald G. Miller said yesterday in his first sermon at the Protestant Church of the Strangers, 307 West Fiftyseventh Street.

The three-story apartment house at 403 Hopkinson Avenue, southeast corner of New York Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Industrial Capital Corporation, represented by Charles M. Hiesiger, attorney. Irving Breslow and Louis A.-atz were the brokers.

Secret manoeuvres of the Turkish army and navy designed to test defenses along the Aegean Sea were carried out today in the presence-of President Kemal Ataturk. Only Turkish Ministers and high military authorities observed the war games.

Playboy, the easy-going bay gelding owned by Mrs. Jean Guerrin of New City, N. Y., captured the jumper championship as the seventeenth annual Orange horse show closed at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.
Connie Mack, president and manager of the Athletics, who has been confined to his home by illness since early in September, said he was "feeling good" tonight after suffering a relapse Friday.

Music is the most precious of our earthly inheritances and without its presence, in both the simple form of the songs of folklore as well as the inspired masterpieces of great composers, life would be devoid of much of its beauty, the Rev. Donald B. Blackstone said yesterday morning at the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant, 310 East Fortysecond Street.

With almost no let-up Japanese Government bonds have continued to fall steadily and heavily on the market here. The current week's prices were 3 to 5 1/2 points lower than last week, and compared with the year's high, the declines range from 20 to 33 points.

Preliminary figures on department store sales in September for the country as a whole show an increase of 6 per cent aa compared with the same month a year ago, according to the report released today. by the Federal Reserve Board.

Algernon R. Morgan, whose quaint philosophy earned for him the title of "Sage of Tobacco Road," died at his home on Tobacco Road today. He was born on the lands his Welsh ancestors settled in Richmond County.

Building operations for the present year in the five New York boroughs will fall short by about 25 per cent of the $300,000,000 total anticipated early in the year, declares Myron L. Matthews in the Dow Servwice Daily Building Reports. That total includes both new construction and alterations.
We recall a pre-war jingle which thus described the vermiform appendix: "In the midst of your intestines,

Papa DiMaggio, who came all the way from San Francisco to "see Joe hit some home runs," finally was rewarded when his big son catapulted a drive a few feet inside the left field foul line in the third, inning of yesterday's finale.

Benjamin M. Des Jardins of West Hartford, -veteran inventor who contributed to the typesetting business fifty-five years ago a combination typesetting and justifying machine, was injured fatally tonight by an automobile.

Miss Ruth Elizabeth North, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Stanley North of Sunny Ledge, this city, became the bride of Frederick avid Rees of New Britain, son of Mrs. Davis Rees of Erie, Pa., yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Theodore Ainsworth Green, pastor of the First Congregational Church, performed the ceremony.

Barbara Stanwyck and young George Sanders will have the leads in "The Giant Swing" at Fox, and Gregory Ratoff will direct. This somewhat upsets a former plan, which had Henry King slated for the directorial spot. King, instead, takes over the musical, "Alexander's Ragtime Band."

Funeral services for the Rev. Paul D. Elsesser were conducted yesterday morning at the French Evangelical Presbyterian Church, 124 West Sixteenth Street. He died Thursday of a heart ailment at the Presbyterian Hospital. His age was 67.

The general depression in securities in Great Britain has been severely interrupting the offering of new industrial flotations, no important issue having been ma e since the Summer vacation period temporarily halted financing.

An Insurgent communique today announced that General Francisco Franco's troops had smashed through Asturian "iron ring" defenses and captured Cangas de Onis, strategic town less than thirty miles southeast of Gijon, the Insurgents' Biscayan objective.
Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey yesterday branded J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, fugitive lawyer, as the "top commander" of the remnants of the gang once headed by Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenhelmer.
The residence of the late Mrs. Edward K. Dunham at 35 East Sixty-eighth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, has been leased by William A. Read, banker, through Douglas L. Elliman Co.

President Roosevelt's sudden and unexpected emergence as the leading figure in the international arena, coupled with rumors of a gigantic American rearmament program, is rapidly forcing German political circles to shift their attention from the Bolshevist enemy in the East to the new front lining up in the West.

Declaring that the registration indicated that the Republican citywide and county candidates would win in Manhattan, Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican Chairman, urged last night a return to the real issue of the campaign, good government by the Administration of Mayor La Guardia.

Business influences on the week's stock markets were various and inclined to be of a contrary nature. Stockholders in the heavy industries were disappointed by the meager dividend increase voted by the Gutehoffnunghuette Steel Corporation.

A week-long observance of the 225th anniversary of the First Presbyterian Church of Trenton opened today, with the Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, stated clerk of the General Assembly, preaching at the morning service and Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, delivering an address at a vesper service this afternoon.

District Attorney L. Barron Hill of Suffolk County revealed tonight that he had submitted his resignation to Governor Lehman yesterday. Mr. Hill is the Republican nominee for county judge. His term as District Attorney does not expire until Dec. 31, 1938.

Judge William Nevin Appel, retired Orphans Court judge and son and brother of one-time leaders of Franklin and Marshall College, died today. His age was 75. He had been ill for weeks and had retired from the bench June 1.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, THE NEW YORK TIMEs learns authoritatively, will sail from Cherbourg for the United States on the liner Bremen Saturday, Nov. 6, arriving in New York the following Thursday.
Support of President Roosevelt's foreign policy was urged yesterday morning by the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn.

Rain, driven by a southeast wind, slashed through the reeds of our duck blind this morning. Long lines of black ducks and teal appeared and disappeared in the mists which clung to Oneida Lake, but the birds refused to decoy.

Moses Tanenbaum, president of the long established New York insurance firm of I. Tanenbaum, Son Co., 521 Fifth Avenue, died suddenly here today of a heart attack at his home, 15 South Broadway. He was 79 years old.

Ruby Elzy, Negro soprano, gave her first New York recital in Town Hall last night. Miss Elzy, a native of Mississippi, came to her task with a considerable background in various fields of artistic endeavor, for in addition to concert work in many parts of this country, opera, radio and the films have come into her province.

Miss Marguerita Beatrice Altieri, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Altieri of Brooklyn, was married last night to Raymond W. Kutner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kutner, also of Brooklyn, in St. Brendan's Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Joseph W. Sheridan.

The headquarters of Justice David C. Lewis, candidate for re-election as Municipal Court Justice from the Seventh District, announced yesterday that Justice Lewis has been endorsed by both the Bar Association and the New York County Lawyers Association.

YANKEES--The first ball Melton pitched brought the first put-out. It came right through the heart of the plate to Crosetti, who smashed it to deep left, where it fell into the waiting hands of Moore. Rolfe heard a strike and a ball called and then rapped a single to left.
Paul VaillantCouturier, veteran Communist Deputy and editor of the Communist official newspaper Humanite, died tonight in a Paris clinic at the age of 45.
The Compinsky Trio will make its only New York appearance of this season at the Town Hall on Thursday evening in a concert to aid the dental division of the Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy.

Alternate proposals for the Old Colony Railroad Company will be made in the reorganization plan which will be filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the protective committee headed by Francis R. Hart.

Instead of taking men's jobs -at lower wages, women should strive to develop new fields of endeavor outside the home but related to its problems Mrs. Annie Nathan Meyer, founder of Barnard College and pioneer advocate of women's rights, said last night in a symposium at the Community Church on the subject of woman's emancipation.

The strife between Church and State in Russia, Mexico and Germany is laid to the failure of the Christian churches in those countries to "identify Christian doctrine with social welfare," in a report made public yesterday by the Methodist Federation for Social Service.

Raymond Workman, for years one of the country's top-flight riders, will be employed for the 1938 season by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, it became known yesterday following confirmation from Trainer J. H. (Bud) Stotler.

The church has blundered in limiting Christianity to what derives from historic fact and what is intellectually or materialistically provable, the Rev. William Norman Guthrie, rector of St. Mark's Church - in - the - Bouwerie, Tenth Street west of Second Avenue, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. White of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy White, to Clarence J. Dauphinot Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dauphinot of Forest Hills. The prospective bride attended the Madeira School in Greenway, Va.

The week's stock market presented an irregular picture of reactionary episodes and with yesterday witnessing a sharp general decline to which the only exceptions were the securities of 4he commercial banks.

The Fort Hamilton eleven put up a stubborn battle before bowing, 6-0, yesterday to the favored Fort DuPont team of Delaware, holder of the Second Corps Area championship. The game was played at the Brooklyn army reservation. Binder of the visitors ran twentyfive yards around end in the opening quarter for the touchdown.
While no goal has been named for the United Hospital Committee campaign, the supplementary need for the support of the voluntary hospitals will be upward of three million dollars ($3,171,134).

Fascism, communism and naziism are not nearly as damaging as the "blinding atheism of the lukewarm church that neither affirms nor denies but ignores," the Rev. Dr. Christopher Jeffares McCombe declared yesterday in his initial sermon at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eightv-sixth Street.

Dr. Ralph E. Diffendorfer, corresponding secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church, said yesterday that Methodist missionaries would not be recalled from the war area in China, even though all other Americans left.
American European Securities Co. Nine months to Sept. 30: Net income on investments, after interest and taxes, was $274,470. Net profit on securities sold raised this to $276,309.
It cannot be said that the severe depression through which the financial and commodity markets here are passing shows any definite signs of lifting.

Cardinal Hayes presided at a solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, the occasion being the observance of the twentyseventh anniversary of the consecration of the edifice, the cornerstone of which was laid seventynine years ago. The cathedral was filled. many standing in the rear.

Captain William Johnson Taylor Jr., son of Mrs. Emily B. Newbold Taylor and the late Dr. William J. Taylor. of this city, died tonight following a short illness in the Pennsylvania Hospital. His age was 41.
Leonard Stevens, 48-year-old pianist, who composed some of America's bestselling popular music, including "I Faw Down and Go Boom," died here Friday of a .heart attack.
Charles A. Hilton, who, at the time he was elected a member of the Common Council, was the youngest Albanian ever chosen to that office, died today after a short illness. He was 56 years old.

Most of the economies effected by the La Guardia administration in its first year in office had to go toward making up for the underappropriations for vital services in the last Tammany budget, former Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick declared last night in a radio address.
On the eve of the C. I. O. meeting here tomorrow, John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, declared today that it was definitely out of the American Federation of Labor.

Speculative interest in oats was relatively light here last week and the market eased largely in sympathy with other grains. Closing trades in futures yesterday were at net losses of 11/2 to. 21/ cents a bushel, with the July setting the pace.

Men and women from forty States who deal with criminals in prisons and in later life assembled tonight at the sixty-seventh annual congress of the American Prison Association to exchange ideas on crime prevention.

The President has asserted that haste in adopting a new farm program is essential, and has hinted that he will soon call a special session for that purpose. The legislation that he is likely to recommend was probably foreshadowed in greatest detail by the recent speech of Secretary Wallace at Memphis, which, though particularly addressed to the subject of cotton, indicated the general policy that the Administration desires to follow with all crops.

The trial of those accused of flogging Joseph Shoemaker to death is drawing to its slow close here. Plans of the defense attorneys, learned today, indicate that the fate of six former Tampa policemen, charged with lashing him fatally because he refused to get out of town when the Ku Klux Klan ordered him out, will be placed in the hands of the jury this week, perhaps as early as Tuesday.

The Philadelphia Eagles cashed in on their only two scoring opportunities today to score their first National Football League victory over Washington, 14 to 0, as the Redskins spurned a half-dozen touchdown chances before 15,000 fans.

The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America made public yesterday a letter it has sent to President Roosevelt expressing its gratitude for "indicating to the world that AmeAca's foreign policy is not one of selfish isolationship, holding aloof from a troubled world."

Mayor La Guardia stood hatless in a biting breeze from the Hudson, and 1,500 firemen stood at attention yesterday afternoon as taps sounded for six members of the department killed in action during the year and forty-nine others who also had died.

The German wholesale price index on Sept. 29 stood at 106.2, unchanged. In the first eight months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.
The French financial markets were rather disappointed on Monday because a remolding of the Cabinet, the expectation of which had induced a sharp recovery on the preceding Friday, did not materialize.

The one-family dwelling at 88 Highland Avenue, near the boulevard, Jersey City, has been sold by Florence Jasper, executrix under the will of Harry Jasper, for a stated consideration of $10,000 to Mrs. Mary Adams.
One of the world's longest suspension bridges, the Vienna Reichsbruecke, was opened' today by President Wilhelm Miklas and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg. Work on the bridge started four years ago.

As nearly as one can remember on the morning after, there was a show put on at the American Music Hall on Saturday evening. According to a program which is stretched out at full length on this desk, it is entitled "The Fireman's Flame," by John Van Antwerp, who would probably answer to the name of Jerrold Krimsky in an unguarded moment.

The Reich Bureau of Statistics has calculated that if wheat crops of the Southern Hemisphere were to be normal, the world stock at the end of the present farm year would be only 1,500,000 tons above that of last year.

Michael J. Hartneady, State Secretary of Mining, announced late today that Governor Earle would make a personal effort tomorrow to end the strike of thirty-eight sitdown miners and the sympathy walkout of 7,500 fellow miners.

Although the immediate crisis in the franc appears to have abated, and dealings in the gold bullion market have fallen to a normal level after the big hoarding demand of the last two weeks, the holding of Bank of England notes by financially nervous folk continues.
