With dealers in other centers interested, progress is being made in the development of plans for a "blue book" system to govern allowances by retailers on radio trade-ins and indications are that the method may be inaugurated before the heavy seasonal demand materializes, it was learned here yesterday.
The feeling of uneasiness and apprehension over general political and financial coneditions, both here and abroad, precipitated here last week a general movement to liquidate long lines of wheat,

People are lacking in the understanding of religion when they believe that Christianity must work and work now, Dr. Allen Knight Chalmers declared yesterday before the congregation in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle Church, Broadway at Fifty-sixth Street.
The general headquarters of the Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union announced tonight that a State - wide picketing campaign would begin at dawn against nonunion interstate freight trucks.

The marriage of Miss Betsy Ann Avery to George D. Freeman 3d, son of Colonel and Mrs. George D. Freeman Jr. of West Hartford, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Christopher L. Avery of Eastern Point, Groton.

Royal Air Force bombers today searched the Anglo-Eyptian Sudan for Brig. Gen. A. C. Lewin, missing with his wife on a flight. General Lewin, who flew his own plane to second place in the King's Cup air race around the British Isles on Sept. 11, left here at dawn Saturday for an unannounced destination.

Countess Laszlo Szechenyi was a dinner hostess last night at the Breakers. Her guests included Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney and the latter's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. G. McCullough Miller, and their son; Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt, brother of the Countess, and Mr. and Mrs. Orme Wilson, the former an official of the American Consulate at Prague.

Hard-pressed Jewish minorities in Poland and Rumania are convinced that President Roosevelt's address constitutes moral pressure which will bring about a betterment of their lot, said Herbert J. Seligmann of the American Joint Distribution Committee upon his return from a trip of investigation in those countries today.

Rejection of the proposed partition of Palestine on economic, strategic and spiritual grounds was urged in an attack on British policy by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise yesterday morning at the Free Synagogue, meeting in Carnegie Hall.

Professor E. J. Crane of Ohio State University, editor of Chemical Abstracts, will receive the Chemical Industry Medal for 1937 for his work in abstracting technical and scientific papers in all fields of the chemical industry, the American Chemical Society announced yesterday.

Elizabeth Arden Lewis, the beauty specialist, has leased her five-story private dwelling at 4 Sutton Square, on the upper East Side, to Pierpont M. Hamilton, a grandson of the elder J. P. Morgan. The house stands on a plot 17.2 by 51.11 feet and is one of a group surrounding a community garden. Douglas L.

A number of properties in Yorkville figured in the realty transactions which brokers reported yesterday. The five-story building at 507-9 East Seventy-fifth Street, between York and Marie Curie Avenues, was sold by the Manhattan Savings Institution to Henry Herman.
John Wheelock Allen, descendant of Eleazar Wheelock, founder of Dartmouth College, and grandson of William Allen, a president of Dartmouth anu later president of Bowdoin College, died here yesterday.
Another hospital ship sailed down the Whangpoo River from Japan today carrying a consignment of urns, containing ashes of Japan's soldiers who have died on the battlefields of Shanghai.

Dr. Wilhelm Cohnstaedt, a former editor of the Frankfurter Zeitung, who has lived in this city since 1933, died yesterday at the age of 57. A frequent contributor to American newspapers and magazines, he wrote for THE NEW YORK TIMES several reviews of books on Germany, and an article, "The Two Roosevelts: A Vivid Contrast,"

The influence of the Southern holding movement in checking hedge selling caused a late covering movement on the Cotton Exchange tons. here yesterday and prices rallied moderately to close at net advances of 3 to 8 points in the face of weakness in stocks and grains.

Amid cheers of 10,000 persons and the tooting of automobile horns thirtyeight bearded, begrimed "staydown" strikers appeared just before midnight from the anthracite mine in which they had been voluntary prisoners since last Tuesday morning.

Although the fields are rather small, some of the best jumpers in training in this section will compete today in the sixteenth annual meeting of the West Hills Racing Association on the estates of Henry L. Stimson and Thomas F. White, near Huntington, L. I.
Herbie Katz, hard-hitting Brownsville middleweight, will oppose Ralph Chong, Chinese battler from New Orleans, in the star bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, tonight.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday that while he and his associates could not claim credit for planning the $24,340,000 West Side improvement that opens at 1 o'clock this afternoon, he could claim title to the "elbow grease" that translated the plans into actuality.

Admiral Nicholas Horthy, regent of Hungary, today offered a plan for separate Asiatic, European and American Leagues of Nations. He outlined the plan yesterday in one of his rare public addresses, the text of which was made public today.

The continued stock market decline has finally begun to exert an adverse influence in those merchandise quarters which in the early weeks of the recession had disregarded it, manufacturers said here yesterday. Pessimism is so widespread, it was said, that the Federal Reserve figures for department store sales last month, showing a gain of 6 per cent, came as a pleasant surprise to both producers and retailers.
After a day of rest since its battle with Army at West Point, Columbia's football squad yesterday launched preparations at Baker Field for the game against Penn at Baker Field Saturday.

David R. Wilson, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., made public prices of the 1938 line of Willys cars and trucks here today. The price at the factory here, without Federal or other taxes, of the economy coupe, a new three-passenger model, will be $499.
With khaki-colored curtains drawn across the parade grounds, Army's football forces started work today for the invasion of the ??ale Bowl next Saturday.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh flew from Frankfort on the Main to Munich in a two-seater sport plane this morning. On landing here they were welcomed by Major Truman Smith, United States Military Attache;

After discussing Federal finances with President Roosevelt at the White House this afternoon, Secretary Morgenthau and Daniel W. Bell, acting budget director, announced at the Treasury press conference that a revised summation of the budget for the current fiscal year would be made public Tuesday, Oct. 19.

The Federal Trade Commission resumed its hearing yesterday of charges of restraint of trade against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., in the officers of the commission, 45 Broadway. The proceeding had been in recess since last December.

The new Federal Art Project Gallery opened yesterday afternoon at 225 West Fifty-seventh Street. Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward, assistant administrator of the Works Progress Administration, was the guest of honor.

Chief of Police Leopoldo Rabatte of this city reported that General Felix Gonzalez, military commander of Veracruz, had been slain yesterday after he had killed State's Attorney General Adolfo Moreno.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Henry A. Julicher, John W. Van Gordon and Aaron U. Homnick of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: The Chief Justice announced the following orders of the court:

Eastern backs, gathering a rich touchdown harvest, stole the spotlight in college football scoring in early-season games, according to The Associated Press. Four Eastern ball carriers with point totals of 36 each head the nation's scorers. Each has run up his total with six touchdowns.

Ogden L. Mills provided a fine example of a citizen who devoted himself whole-heartedly to the public service; studying and mastering the details of the office in which he was installed and becoming, in due course, a high authority on the problems which he had to meet.

The Committee for Industrial Organization scored two victories yesterday in a contest with the American Federation of Labor for control of marine labor, when the ship repair men of the Grace Line and the International Mercantile Marine Company selected the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers as their spokesman.

An amended plan of reorganization for the Phoenix Silk Manufacturing Company, Inc., which has plants in Allentown and Pottsville, Pa., was filed yesterday in Federal Court for a hearing before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson on Nov. 8.

United States exports of chemicals and related products during the first eight months of the year were valued at $122,000,000, which was 20 per cent above the corresponding months of 1936, 40 per cent above the 1935 figure, and double the 1933 value of shipments, C. C. Concannon, chief of the chemical division of the Department of Commerce, announced today.

A major political sensation threatens to develop from the arrest over the week-end of Hans Rutha, "Foreign Ambassador" of Konrad Henlein's camouflaged Nazi party, under the criminal code paragraph dealing with homosexuality.

The confidence in the Chautemps government indicated in the cantonal elections in France on Sunday imparted renewed strength to the franc yesterday and the currency moved up 2 1/4 points here, to close at 3.33 1/2, cents, although it dipped to 3.32 cents during the day's trading.

Ignace Jan ship, Paderewski, the pianist and composer, has re-entered Polish politics by joining the Labor party, a new political organization that is a fusion of the Christian Democrats and the National Workers.
Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense, welcomed a contingent of American Legionnaires in London tonight at an official dinner tendered by the Government.
Frederick L. Kanst, the first landscape gardener employed by the old South Park Board and the chief horticulturist at the Columbian Exposition in 1893, died in his home today at the age of 89.

The Central Hospital in Nanking, operated by the government, has been closed because of damage in a Japanese air raid, according to advices received here yesterday. The University of Nanking Hospital is now the only large hospital operating in Nanking.

Since, under the statutes made and provided, neither of the lawyers who attacked Mr. Justice Black's judicial status had any right to institute quo warrant proceedings, his eight brethren today said so.

Joe Wagner of Newark, youthful heavyweight who opened a deep cut under Tommy Farr's eye in a sparring session before the Joe LouisFarr title bout, scored a four-round knockout over Eddie Mader of New York tonight in the feature boxing bout at Laurel Garden. Wagner weighed 179 pounds, Mader 186.
The New York State Golf Association yesterday announced the dates of its three major championships in 1938, according to The Associated Press.

WHOEVER was able to make Stephen Vincent Benet consent to this first collection of his short stories* (and the jacket implies that some one had to do some urging) deserves the thanks of all and sundry, for Mr. Benet's stories are competent to a degree that leaves the work of the average American writer far out behind, and ought to have been in book form a long time ago. They are nothing short of excellent,

A "marked improvement" in advertising of radios, mechanical refrigerators and floor covering was reported yesterday by the Better Business Bureau of New York City, in its bulletin "Fair Practice." Distributors of major radios have filed fair trade contracts, an action which has tended to eliminate exaggerated trade-in offerings on current models, it was said.
New Yorkers joining the colony at the Greenbrier today included Mr. and Mrs. William Leslie, F. Robertson Jones, Franklin Vanderbilt and C. W. Fairchild, who are annual Autumn visitors.

Mr. and Mrs. Tierney A. O'Rourke of 190 West 180th Street, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine O'Rourke, to Alexander F. Whelan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Whelan, also of New York.

Charles B. Hayward, Republican Mayor of Englewood, who would have completed his term of office on Jan. 1, died suddenly here at 8:30 tonight while listening to the radio at his home, 75 East Hamilton Avenue, of a heart attack at the age of 60.
THE FAR-OFF HILLS, a comedy in three acts, by Lennox Robinson. Revived by the Abbey Theatre -Players of Dublin. Presented by Lee Shubert. At the Ambassador Theatre through Wednesday night.

Ten railroad companies operating in New Jersey, which have protested taxes totaling $19,372,441 levied by the State for 1937, will be heard by the Board of Tax Appeals on Nov. 16, it was announced today.

Tonight was a holiday eve in Spain, for tomorrow is the "Day of the Race." It was signalized as Christmas, New Year, Epiphany and other holidays have been during this war by a terrific night bombardment. This one was the worst this city has known.
Former Premier Francisco Largo Caballero announced today that he would address a mass meeting in Madrid on Sunday on the subject "The U. G. T. and the Spanish War."

Although the State Supreme Court has under consideration the status of the Narragansett race track's license, Governor Robert E. Quinn today announced that "under no circumstances" would he permit the Fall race meeting, scheduled to open Oct. 18, to be held.

A suit to prevent Jeremiah T. Ma. honey and his running mates on the Democratic ticket from also appearing as the candidates of the "Trades Union party" has been instituted in Supreme Court, Frank P. Walsh, attorney for 146 unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, announced last night.

Isaac Stern, a young violinist who has studied with leading teachers in this country and also appeared in recital in other places and as soloist with the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, made his first New York appearance last night in Town Hall.

The Federal Government prepared today to begin the division of landed estates in the State of San Luis Potosi among communal groups of peons in line with the program adopted in other parts of Mexico by the Cardenas Administration.

From various sources are coming repeated suggestions that New York State's laws governing mortgage foreclosure procedure should undergo sweeping changes. The idea behind most of the proposals heard recently is to reduce the costs of such actions.
An ordinance making it a misdemeanor to sell a second-hand hat unless it is conspicuously marked was passed today by the City Council.

Fifty-five acres of land with a residence, orchard and other improvements, at Cold Spring, N. Y., have been sold by the Abner Merritt estate to the Caucasian Society Allaverdy, Inc., of New York. The buyers will erect a clubhouse, dormitory, tennis courts,
A ref erendum in which farmers cast 30,618 votes overwhelmingly favored a potato acreage stabilization program, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today.

With another world series hustled almost pell-mell into the records, a vast silence enveloped both banks of the Harlem yesterday. In fact, it is doubtful whether any classic of bygone years ever passed off the stage more swiftly.

Elizabeth Drew, Lecturer in English Literature at Cambridge University, has arrived here from England to fill a number of speaking engagements in the East and Midwest. Her new book, "Discovering Drama," will be published by Norton tomorrow.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, declined to comment tonight on the resolution of the American Federation of Labor convention Denver authorizing the executive council of the A. F. of L. to expel the ten suspended C. I. O. unions.

Jimmy Dykes's White Sox, with the top of the batting order providing the punch when hits meant runs, came within a game of winning their fifteenth Chicago championship today, defeating the Cubs, 6 to 4, at Comiskey Park before 11,575 spectators.
One hundred and forty-one horses brought a total of $104,315 at the first two sessions of Lexington's annual horse sales today.

When Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain delivered his major political address before the Conservative meeting at Scarborough last Friday he was suffering from a chill that had made his physician most reluctant to permit his appearance; it was learned today.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt were hosts to Vittorio Mussolini, 21-year-old son of the Italian Premier, at tea this afternoon. - Other guests were Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State; Fulvio Suvich, Ambassador of Italy, and William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy.

Miss Florence Terese Lavery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lavery of this city, was married to Edward Robbins Broughel, son of Mrs. Andrew J. Broughel and the late Mr. Broughel of West Hartford, in St. Augustine's Church here today.
Bronislaw Huberman, the violinist whose hands were injured; in last week's plane accident at: Palembang Sumatra, contracted pneumonia in the tropical rains immediately after the crash.
The West Hills race ball tonight at Ben Robyn Farm, the home of Colonel and Mrs, Francis L. Robbins in the West Hills colony, was the occasion for many house parties and dinners in the countryside.

Park-Lexington Corporation certificates of deposit for first-mortgage leasehold 6 1/2 per cent sinking-fund gold bonds due in 1953, White Motor Company common stock, $50 par value, and General Italian Edison Electric Corporation American shares representing ordinary shares of capital stock have been stricken from New York Stock Exchange listing and registration.
Preparing for next Saturday's game with Villanova at Ebbets Field, the Manhattan football team spent a busy afternoon yesterday improving its offense.

One of the most important problems facing Coach Mal Stevens in. bolstering his New York University varsity eleven is to find a capable running back to alternate with Ed Williams. The 19-6 upset registered over the Violet by North Carolina last Saturday makes this apparent.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will find a welcome awaiting them at the White House if they come to Washington and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is ready to take the former King on a personally conducted tour of the American housing projects in which she is herself so keenly interested.

After a slow start, the Green Bay Packers came back strongly during the past week's competition to assume the leadership for team offensive laurels in the National Football League, according to statistics released yesterday.

Amendment of the Federal Social Security Act to provide annuities for the widows of wage-earners instead of the lump sums they now receive on the death of their husbands is being discussed by the Social Security Board. Miss Mary W.

The report of the Phoenix Securities Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows that the net asset value on that date was $10,862,996, equal to $140.52 a share of preferred stock and to $8.39 a share of common stock.

Columbus Day will be generally observed in the important financial centers of the country today, following the practice here where the banks and the securities and commodities Exchanges will be closed.

The publication of the speeches Tibor Eckhardt and other Opposition leaders made at the Legitimist meeting yesterday have attracted wide attention here. In view of the Nazi threat to Hungary these former Habsburg opponents declared themselves to be favorable to the restoration.
The first tea and bridge this season of the Elvira Theatre Club, of which Miss Anne McCosker is founder and president, will take place on Saturday in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador.

The German Government has advised Nicaraguan merchants that in the future German merchandise sold to Nicaragua will be increased in price by 40 per cent because of the failure of merchants to pay for German goods which were delivered last year.

President Roosevelt's Chicago speech of warning to aggressor nations was hailed tonight by Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States, before a banquet of the Polish National Alliance commemorating Pulaski Day, as a step toward world stability and peace.

The movement for boycott of Japanese merchandise was placed officially before the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday in a letter sent by R. R. Albin, president of the Independent Merchants Association of Montana, who described the conflict in China as "a reign of lawlessness" which is "inhuman and a menace to the world."

Hairdressing styles for women are going back to the early nineteenth century, according to leading hairstylists of the country, who are attending the annual show and convention of the New York State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association, which opened yesterday, with the cooperation of the national association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Coach E. E. (Hooks) Mylin lost no time in getting down to work for the Georgetown game today when he sent the entire Lafayette squad through a hard drill.

Tommy Farr returned from the United States today and expre ssed hope of amassing a fortune next year. He told welcomers he expected to earn over half a million dollars and said if the terms "are good enough" he might fight in England between now and Feb. 20, when he will meet an American heavyweight, probably James J. Braddock, in Miami.

The Works Progress Administration spent $25,777,212 less in this city during July, August and September than it did in the corresponding quarter of 1936, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA chief, announced yesterday, Total expenditures dropped 40 per cent as a result of reductions in personnel and cuts in overhead costs.

John Mellen Gibbs, associate justice of the Superior Court since 1929 and former member of both houses of the Legislature, died tonight at his home in Waltham at the age of 63. His death brought to twenty the number of vacancies in the judiciary since Governor Hurley assumed office.
General weakness cropped out on the stock market today with no specific development held to be the cause other than a sense of uncertainty in the world political situation as a whole.

Japan's hopes that after the conclusion of the present hostilities she may have the cooperation of the United States, Great Britain, France and other interested powers in the maintenance of a neutralized, demilitarized zone assuring Shanghai's safety against a recurrence of fighting in the immediate vicinity of this city have been disappointed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial "Two Foreign Policies," I-should like to point out my conviction that the policy of the neutrality legislation and that of international cooperation along the lines of the Nine-power and Kellogg-Briand pacts and, to a certain extent, that of the Far East Committee of the League of Nations are not irreconcilable.
Chinese soldiers said to be suffering from the effects of mustard gas were among 700 wounded received at Nanking hospitals Sunday night from the Shanghai front.

The Green Meadow Golf Club property in Harrison, Westchester, has been sold to Irving I. and Hiram S. Lewine, in conjunction with Ringland F. Kilpatrick. There are about 125 acres in the tract, which has a frontage of 1,600 on North Street, and runs back to the boundaries of the Westchester Country Club and the Apawamis Golf Club in Rye.

Important suits affecting the right of the Government to lay income taxes on salaries of State agents, and attempts by the States to levy on instrumentalities of the Government were taken under advisement by the Supreme Court today as it issued more than 300 orders denying or granting review of lower court findings.
The Addressograph - Multigraph Corporation reported yesterday for eight months ended on Aug. 31 a net profit of $1,444,525, after charges, depreciation and Federal income taxes.
The Autumn military manoeuvres of the Portuguese Army began today in Alemtejo province east of Lisbon. This is the first time that such manoeuvres have been held in this country in many years.
Airplanes crossing the Czechoslovak border from Germany or Austria may do so only in designated sectors between sunrise and sunset and must not exceed an altitude of 500 meters [about 1,640 feet],
Two factions on the Bituminous Coal Commission argued for four hours behind closed doors today, the majority four members finally achieving these results:
Enrico Venturi, Italian battler who holds the lightweight championship of Europe, defeated Tommy Rawson of Boston in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

" President Roosevelt" and all the members of his :'Cabinet" capered on the stage of the Colonial Theater here tonight as the chief characters in a new musical comedy, "I'd Rather Be Right." satirizing the New Deal and most of its alphabetical works.

Coach Fritz Crisler sent the Princeton football squad through an hour and a quarter's scrimmage on University Field today. With most of the players who started against Cornell taking the day off, many line-up shifts were effected, presaging a radically altered first-string eleven for the Chicago game in the West Saturday.

The Belgian Army horse show team's string of eight mounts, the first of the European entries to arrive in the United States for the international military jumping events in the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 3 to 10, debarked yesterday from the United States Lines' American Merchant.

The physical condition of several backs and their chances of taking part in the game with Pittsburgh at the Polo Grounds on Saturday evoked the most interest from Coach Jim Crowley and his assistants as they sent the Fordham football squad through an intensive two and a half hour workout on Fordham Field yesterday.

Jacob Gill Gaudaur, one of Canada's famous old-time oarsmen, died at his home near here today after a long illness. The former world's rowing champion had been confined to his bed for eight weeks. His age was 79.

Alceo Dossena, sculptor, died tonight from a stroke suffered this morning. His age was 55. He was known in America through a 1928 lawsuit which disclosed his imitation of statues by Donatello and other Renaissance masters.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Dorothea O'Farrell, daughter of Mrs. Valerian O'Farrell of Jackson Heights and the late Mr. O'Farrell, to Arthur Garry, son of Mrs. Peter A. Garry of this city and the late Mr. Garry.

In a full page newspaper advertisement the 20,000 employee of Endicott-Johnson Corporation today brought Japan into their protest against the proposed trade agreement between the United States and Czechoslovakia.

The beginning of Japanese preparations for peace may be seen together with some other things in plans for a new State advisory council to assist the Cabinet which have been submitted to the Privy Council.

With prices on the securities markets continuing to decline, the possibility of a reduction of the 55 per cent margin requirement now imposed by Regulation T of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has become a subject of active debate.

Described as an "entirely new effect" in talking pictures, "stereophonic" or third-dimension sound, wherein sound effects and dialogue emanate directly from their point of origin on the motion picture screen, received its first public demonstration before the Society of Motion Picture Engineers at the Bell Telephone Laboratories last night.
President Getulio Vargas denied today that a state of war [modified martial law] had been proclaimed to prevent the Presidential election.

Mrs. Cecilla O'Hara McGovern, wife of James L. McGovern, editor of The Bridgeport Times Star and president of the Connecticut circuit of The Associated Press, died last night in the New Haven General Hospital after an illness of several weeks.
Pres ident Roosevelt asked a radio announcer today for the correct pronunciation of the name of General Wladimir B. Krzyzanowski, Polish hero of the American Civil War.

Nearly 300 dealers and salesmen of the Nash Motors division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, assembled yesterday in the Mecca Temple Casino, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street, for a preview of the 1938 Nash and to hear R. H. Israel, president of Nash Motors Company of New York, Inc., outline plans for the coming year.

IT certainly was too bad about poor old Tony Lazzeri. The doddering antique, weary and wheezing, announced some weeks ago that he was all through. He was going to retire if he could drag himself as far as the exit. He didn't want them to carry him off the field. He figured that if it didn't come on to rain or blow too hard, he might totter off under his own steam.

Arab leaders deported from Palestine arrived here today aboard the British Destroyer Active. Britain sent four Arab leaders into exile on the remote Indian Ocean island on Oct. 2, charging them with moral responsibility for four months of terror in the Holy Land.
Definite word is expected within the next day or two from the Belgian Government as to whether it will agree to hold the Nine-Power Treaty conference on the Sino-Japanese controversy in Brussels.

Angered by what they charged was a "deliberate" shortage of fresh-killed kosher meat at the local packing houses, the Federation of Kosher Butchers threatened last night to close again the 5,000-odd butcher shops owned by members In the metropolitan area.

Harry Murphy, president of the Western Stevedore Company here and unsuccessful Liberal candidate in Fort William in the Oct. 6 Ontario election, died last night on a train en route to Toronto. He was 66 years old.
Dr. Alexis Carrel, surgeon and Nobel Prize winner, told a distinguished gathering at Dartmouth College today that the only remedy for civilization was to remake man through science.

Freddie Steele and Fred Apostoli, each recognized by various boxing commissions as world middleweight champion, will clash in a twelveround over-the-weight bout at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 12. They signed yesterday with Mike Jacobs, promoter of boxing in the Garden.
The Almoners, an organization which raises funds for Catholic philanthropies, met yesterday at a luncheon in the Gold Room of Sherry's to discuss plans for the coming season.

Despite rejection by the Association of Austrian Manufacturers of a government proposal to reduce gradually the import embargoes which are now in force, it is anticipated that the Government will override the objections and modify the embargoes which are no longer deemed necessary, according to a report from Gardner Richardson, commercial attache at Vienna, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Criticizing the manner in which fair trade practice laws have worked out in the liquor industry Harry L. Lourie, executive secretary and treasurer of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, at the annual convention of that organization yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria,
The Dartmouth Indians went to work with a will today, determined to continue against Brown at Providence Saturday the improvement they showed in their victory over Springfield last week.

More than 500 graduates and former students of the College of Mount St. Vincent are expected to attend the annual Autumn tea which will be given on Saturday at the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium by the Alumnae Association of the college.
Full returns of the cantonal elections held yesterday in France show no justification for fears of a sweep of the country by the parties furthest left, which at one time were entertained.

The Museum of Modern Art has received three gifts of painting and sculpture which will go on public exhibition today in the museum's temporary galleries at 14 West Forty-ninth Street, concourse level.

" Joe the Turk," the first man to don a Santa Claus uniform and solicit funds with a tin cup along New York streets, who said he had been arrested fifty times "for being a Christian," died yesterday at his home, 120 West Third Street, at the age of 82.

Leaders in public life expressed regret yesterday at the death of Ogden L. Mills. They included former President Hoover, in whose Cabinet Mr. Mills had served; Alfred E. Smith, who defeated Mr. Mills for Governor after a particularly bitter campaign in,1926, and Governor Lehman.

The effectiveness of the Connally "Hot Oil" Act in stopping the movement in interstate commerce of gasoline made from illegally produced crude oil, and the greater use of direct sales organizations by independent refiners, rather than an alleged buying program by the major oil companies, accounted in part for the stability of gasoline prices from March 1, 1935, through 1937, according to testimony in the oil price trial today.

The spirit of the celebration marking the 250th anniversary of the settlement of the City of Poughkeepsie was grasped today by hundreds of persons who attended the ceremonies dedicating the World War memorial playground at Lincoln Center.

Paul Moss, License Commissioner, said yesterday that four burlesque theatres in the Times Square area would be permitted to operate temporarily without licenses, pending his decision on the applications of the theatre owners for renewals of their licenses.

The Eastern Conference of the Methodist Protestant Church, closing its twenty-seventh annual meeting here today, announced new assignments for fifteen pastors and returned forty-seven others to their charges for another year.

Technical and specialized problems of the banking business occupied the meetings of the nation's banking representatives who today opened the sixtythird annual convention of the American Bankers Association in the Hotel Statler here.
The Treasury's weekly $50,000,000 bill offering was sold today at an average price of 0.429 per cent,

Taxation of all advertisements in magazines and newspapers, with certain exceptions, has been enacted by the Government of Peru, according to a report from Lima made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the death of Oscar Edgerton Stevens of 400 East Fortyninth Street in the Blodgett Memorial Hospital, Grand Rapids, Mich., on Saturday, after an illness of three weeks. Mr. Stevens, who was 54 years old, was vice president of the Commercial Investment Trust Company.

Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, sitting in Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on the application of Davega-City Radio, Inc., for a temporary injunction restraining Carl Randau, president, and other officers and members of the New York Newspaper Guild from picketing the sporting goods store at 417 Fulton Street.

Mayor La Guardia charged last night that "the same old gang" is trying to get back. into City Hall in an address before the Queens County Republican Committee at Town Hall, Jamaica. "It's the same old gang trying to get back into power,"
A sharp break in foreign dollar obligations featured a resumption of the general decline in the bond market on the New York. Stock Exchange yesterday.
Reliable sources tonight disclosed that Premier Benito Mussolini has ordered Italian aviation experts aiding the Chinese Government to quit now that China is engaged in a bitter conflict with Japan.

Registration of voters in Westchester County last Friday and Saturday fell slightly under the totals for the corresponding days of 1935 and far below those for the first two registration days of 1936, according to tabulations made by political leaders here today.

The Japanese invasion of China has led in this country to demands that we make some economic reply. Three different main proposals have been put forward: (1) a boycott of Japanese goods, (2) an invocation of the Neutrality Act to stop the shipment of war supplies to both Japan and China, and (3) the official application of "economic sanctions" against Japan alone.

Miss Marjorie Borden, daughter of Mrs. H. Percy Borden of Ottawa, Ont., and the late Mr. Borden, was married here yesterday afternoon to John E. Oberne Jr., son of Mrs. John E. Oberne of Knoxville, Tenn., and the late Mr. Oberne, at the SherryNetherland. The Rev. George A.

George R. Agassiz of Boston, former president of the Harvard University board of overseers, was elected president of the Harvard Alumni Association for the current year at a meeting of the directors at the Harvard Club of Boston tonight. He succeeds Professor Emeritus Frank W. Taussig.

Columbia gained 279 yards against Army last week and Penn picked up 243 against Yale. Yet both of them lost. These two offensive powers will collide at Baker Field on Saturday and the chances are that they'll furnish another penny-dreadful thriller such as the Lions and Cadets staged at West Point.

The marriage of Miss Anna Dorothy Gerken, daughter of Mrs. Henry Gerken of Savannah, Ga., and the late Mr. Gerken, to Samuel Kellogg Stryker, son of Samuel D. Stryker of Oradell, N. J., and the late Mrs. Stryker, will take place on Oct. 20 in the Lutheran Church of the Ascension in Savannah.

The marriage of Miss Linda Leeds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Starr Leeds of 1,075 Park Avenue, to Thomas Reginald Bassett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Oppie Bassett of Dover, N.J., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
British Guiana tonight held the intercolonial cricket championship which it lost to Trinidad last February, after defeating the cupholders by two wickets in the final match.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Angela Steiner Mattern, widow of George A. Mattern, to Major Gen. John J. Phelan of New York, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, which took place on Sept. 27 in Cold Spring, N. Y., where the bride had been making her home.

Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, and his colleague, William J. (Bill) Brown, made public yesterday a letter they had jointly sent to A. Newbold Morris, counsel for James J. Johnston, demanding an immediate investigation of a statement, purported to have been made by Johnston, to the effect that the "commission must have an interest in the Twentieth Century Sporting Club."

Accusing the Board of Aldermen of having made only a pretense of providing a five-day week for 50,000 city employes, Mayor La Guardia vetoed their bill yesterday, although he said he favored its chief principle.

The third annual New Rochelle Better Homes Exposition opened here this evening in the Naval Militia Armory. Twenty-three com mercial exhibitors presented sixtyfour displays of home buildings, modernization, furnishings and equipment.

Common Pleas Court judges here upheld today Judge Elder W. Marshall's original decree of March 1, last, ordering the Pittsburgh United Corporation's preferred stock redeemed by the payment of United States Steel common stock, which is Pittsburgh United's principal remaining asset.
As an investment, the two-story apartment house at 664 Park Avenue, West New -York, N. J., was purchased by the Twin County Realty Company, Inc. The Hudson Trust Company was the seller.

Turning in a fine 31 on the second nine after a 35 on the outgoing holes, Willie Klein, Wheatley Hills professional, and his amateur partner, Jack Budelman of the Rockville Country Club, captured first place in the weekly Long Island P. G. A. pro-amateur golf tournament held today on Budelman's home course.

The Ford Motor Company plant here was closed indefinitely tonight in what the United Automobile Workers of America called a lockout and the company said was a shut-down to await settlement of inter-union disputes.
Soviet Russia today announced that its first direct secret election of a national legislative body would be held Dec. 12 when a new Supreme Soviet will be named.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler took under consideration yesterday a recommendation made by Edward R. Rayher, as referee, that he disapprove the proposed sale to the Globe Rutgers Fire Insurance Company of a controlling interest in the Lawyers Title Corporation, a subsidiary of the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company now in the hands of the Superintendent of Insurance for rehabilitation.

William R. Orchard, editor of The Council Bluffs Nonpareil since 1910, died today at the age of 71. He was outstanding in the battle to "get Iowa out of the mud," and once headed the Iowa Good Roads Association. In 1927 he was one of Iowa's delegates to the Repulican National Convention.
The full report of the American Federation of Labor's resolution committee on the Committee for Industrial Organization, as adopted by the A. F. of L. convention today, was as follows:

Colonel David Alexander Lyle, retired army officer, engineer and inventor, died at his home at St. Davids yesterday afternoon. His age was 92. Relatives said his heart failed following a violent fit of coughing.

The Rev. Peter Henn, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Thirtieth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, Astoria, since 1914, died Sunday afternoon in his seventieth year at the Astoria Sanatorium, 30-15 Crescent Street, Astoria. He was admitted to the institution three weeks ago, later undergoing an operation.

C. S. Howard's Seabiscuit, handicap champion of the American turf, will make his first start since his defeat in the Narragansett Special on Sept. 11 when he goes to the post in the $10,000 added Continental Handicap at Jamaica today.

Endorsements of Harold W. Hastings, Tammany candidate for District Attorney, by three former Police Commissioners, Edward P. Mulrooney, James S. Bolan and Grover A. Whalen, were announced yesterday by the Hastings campaign committee.
Better transportation facilities between New York and Puerto Rico were predicted today by Governor Blanton Winship, returning from conferences with the Maritime Commission in Washington.
Robert A. Pinkerton told the National Labor Relations Board today that his National Detective Agency "billed" the Bethlehem Steel Company for $16,022 for services and expenses in 1936.

Mayor La Guardia's fact-finding committee negotiated an agreement yesterday between the B. M. T. system and the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate representing nearly 9,000 of the company's employes, which granted them a 10 per cent wage increase, a $25 weekly minimum and a closed shop for the categories of workers represented by the union.

Stocks declined 2 to 5 points and closed at new low levels for the movement; turnover, 1,747,645 shares. United States Government bonds fractionally lower; corporate, foreign issues, including South American loans, weak; transactions, $7,828,850.
Harry Keller, a director of Marcus Co., jewelers and stationers, was tendered a dinner last night on completion of forty years of service with the company.

Mrs. Anna E. Hay Gallagher, widow of Edward J. Gallagher Sr., for many years one of the leading real estate men in Baltimore, died yesterday at her home here at the age of 69. Mrs. Gallagher was interested in social and church activities.
Insurgent Generalissimo Francisco Franco's forces struck hard on all major fronts in Spain tonight in what may be the beginning of the longexpected Fall drive.

All successful education must depend upon cooperation between parents and teachers, President Roosevelt said in a message yesterday to the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers, which is celebrating its fortieth anniversary in convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The city of Louisville, Ky., will enter the market on next Friday, Oct. 15, with a new issue of $1,250,000 of sewerage bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1929, and maturing on Feb. 1, 1969. This issue represents the remaining part of an authorized issue of $10,000,000 of sewerage bonds voted at an election on Nov. 6, 1928.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States declined in the week ended Oct. 7 to 146, compared with 163 in the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

In some observations made last December and reprinted in the attractive booklet which celebrates the opening of the West Side Improvement today Mr. Robert Moses laid down the axiom that "what New York needs is not' vision, with which we have always been plentifully endowed in the past, but elbow grease." The fact is,

Many of the families appearing on the latest list of new tenancies found quarters in East Side buildings. Isaac Iselin, who is connected with the Swiss diplomatic mission in this country, leased a suite in 38 East Seventy-fifth Street, through the agent Burgoyne, Hamilton Co., Inc., and Potter Hamilton Co., Inc., broker.

The Temple and Boston College football teams, coached respectively by Glenn Warner and Gil Dobie, noted veterans, will meet here tomorrow. The Boston Eagles have been heading for the Templetonians, who beat them 14 to 0 last Fall, registering the only defeat of the season against the Dobie outfit.
General liquidation developed in the grain and provision markets today, with all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats, rye and lard selling at new low levels for the season.

The twelve-room house at 147-31 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, has been purchased by the Queens Ward Church of Jesus Christ Latter Day Saints. The structure, which is on a plot 116 by 128 feet, will be used temporarily as a house of worship and later the plot will be improved with a modern church building.

Among the building plans filed yesterday was a project for the construction of a two-story brick factory building in Maspeth, Queens, at a cost of $311,000. The details of a proposed one-story taxpayer to be built on Northern Boulevard, near Main Street, Flushing, also were submitted.
Yale today started practice for the Army game with a signal rehearsal that stressed new plays. On the defense, the Elis tried to eliminate line mistakes made in the Penn contest last Saturday.

Jacob Koenig, former State Senator from the Twelfth District in Manhattan, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 58 years old. Mr. Koenig, a Democrat, served one term in the Senate, from 1918 to 1920.

The Junior Women's Auxiliary of the Flatbush Boys Club, Mrs. Gilbert M. Schmidt, president, will give its annual dance for the club's benefit on the night of Nov. 13 at the Hotel Bossert, in Brooklyn.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted the request of the Washington Gas Light Company, a subsidiary of the Washington and Suburban Companies, to withdraw an application covering acquisition by it from the latter of the Washington Suburban and Gas Company and of the Alexandria Gas Company.

Speaking on "The Presumption of Death" before the legal section of the American Life Convention today, John H. Wigmore, dean of the Northwestern University School of Law, outlined the efforts by insurance companies and others to modernize statutes now relied upon by the courts when the insured person's death becomes an issue.

After announcing a twenty-two point city platform, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, criticized last night Mayor La Guardia's budget of $682,358,486 as the highest in the city's history, condemned an 18-point rise in the tax rate, accused the Mayor of failure to keep his promise to cut city expenditures and charged him with giving salary increases to political favorites.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow: HOGS Receipts, 12,000, including 3,000 directs. The market was 10-15c higher than Friday's average; top, $11.35; bulk good and choice 190-230 lbs., $11.10-35; 150-180 lbs., $10.50-$11.25; 240-300 lbs., $10.40-$11.25;
Only force of habit will explain why people today do honor to Christopher Columbus. If we acted with true insight

Director William Wellman today signed three of the country's bestknown stunt fliers for "Men With Wings," which he puts before the cameras at Paramount about Dec. 1, or as soon as he and Robert Carson can finish the script.

State Senator Lester H. Clee of Newark, Republican candidate for Governor, reported today to the Secretary of State's office here that he spent $22,908 in his primary campaign. State Senator Clifford R.

Gov. Wilbur L. Cross, declaring that "the -problem of flood control must be settled in some way," played host today to 17 representatives of Governors of New England States, called primarily to discuss means of keeping the Connecticut and other rivers within their banks.

The attempts by Albert Levitt, former Assistant Attorney General, and Patrick Henry Kelley, Boston lawyer, to remove Associate Justice Black from the bench of the Supreme Court were tersely denied by the court today on the ground that the two attorneys lacked sufficient legal interest in the matter to entitle them to a hearing.

Despite a sharp increase in automobile accidents in the city over the week-end, there was a marked decline for last week as compared to the corresponding period of 1936, it was announced yesterday by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner.

Shoe production for September was estimated yesterday at around 37,000,000 pairs, and possibly less, compared with 38,484,000 in August and 40,975,000 in September, 1936, following a steady tapering off for the last few months. For the nine months since the start of the year 1937 production is nearly 10 per cent ahead of a year ago,

The possibility of consolidating existing communication facilities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the United States Army, Navy and Coast Guard and the State and municipal police departments as a nation-wide law enforcement service was discussed yesterday at the first day's session of the fourth national convention of the Associated Police Communication Officers at the Hotel New Yorker.

The nation's "modern problems" must and can be met within the constitutional framework, Attorney General Cummings asserted in an address tonight. He declared that "we have but scant patience with those who believe the Constitution is an unworkable document,

High Commissioner Vincent Massey of Canada, Mrs. Massey, Lord and Lady Kinnaird, Prince and Princess Wolkonsky, Sir Orme Rowan Hamilton, Chief Justice of Bermuda; Brig. Gen. Sir William Alexander and Lady Alexander, the Countess of Hardwicke, J. L. Ilsley, Minister of National Revenue of Canada; Mrs. Ilsley,
Dr. Robert Cushman Murphy of the American Museum of Natural History returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Rita from his fourth annual study of sea life off the South American Coast.

The Duke of Windsor lost no time after his arrival in Germany this morning in fulfilling the object of his visit. He has already visited one model National Socialist factory and several others are on his program for tomorrow.

An attempt to heal the party breach caused by the candidacy of Joseph V. McKee for Mayor four years ago was seen yesterday, when Christopher D. Sullivan, leader of Tammany, announced that former Mayor John P. O'Brien would preside at a ratification rally in Tammany Hall tomorrow evening.
Lehigh got down to hard work today after its easy victory over the John Hopkins eleven. With Penn State's unbeaten team as the opponent this week, Glen Harmeson has planned a series of hard workouts.

Major Gen. Douglas MacArthur, former Chief of Staff of the army and at present military adviser to the President of the Commonwealth Government of the Philippine islands and Field Marshal of the Philippine Army, will retire from active service at his own request on DeC. 31.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, former Police Commissioner, who was the original choice of Fusion for the Mayoralty nomination in 1933, yesterday declared his support of Thomas E. Dewey, Republican and Fusion candidate-for District Attorney, but inferentially indicated that he would support Jeremiah T. Mahoney, the Democratic nominee, against Mayor La Guardia.

By the Overwhelming vote of 25,616 to 1,227 the American Federation of Labor convention today authorized its executive council to expel any of the suspended Committee for Industrial Organization unions which may "refuse to return to the ranks of our movement."

Miss Dorothy Goadby gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq Rouge for Miss Helen de Peyster, who will be married to Eric von Raits on Friday. Other guests included Mrs. Sidney Mathews, Mrs. Aymar Embury, Mrs. Lester Kissel, Mrs. Manning Jacob,

Fearful that Japanese forces are poised for an attack on Eastern Shantung by landing troops at Chefoo, Chinese military authorities there are feverishly carrying on the construction of extensive defense works.

In his campaign for District Attorney of New York County Mr. Thomas E. Dewey has the advantage of being able to offer more than promises. He can talk about what he has already done to racketeers, not merely about what he will do to them if he is elected. His pictures of racketeering, given in a series of radio talks, are educational.
Italy has designated Mario Porta as her first Minister to serve in the Dominican Republic, with residence at Ciudad Trujillo.

Sal Di Buono, professional, and his amateur partner, Phil Duey from Bonnie Briar, displaying splendid team-work, toured the long Fenway Golf Club course in 31, 33--64 to top a strong field in the Westchester P. G. A. one-day best-ball tourney today.

Cornell started preparations for the Syracuse game Saturday with a scrimmage between the varsity reserves and the freshman eleven, while the regulars relaxed. The varsity had a signal drill, calisthenics and a session of tackling. Sam Stahl, center,

A healthy, bawling baby was exhibited tonight to physicians in Margaret Hague Maternity Hospital here as a child who had been born "dead" on Oct. 1. Dr. Edward G. Waters, divisional chief of obstetrics at the hospital, who had delivered and revived the child, explained the case at a meeting of staff and other physicians.

With the traditional battle between James Madison High and Erasmus Hall High topping the local holiday card, eleven contests are scheduled to be played by schoolboy football teams throughout the metropolitan area today.

From a lower opening which took full cognizance of weak markets in London, Paris and Amsterdam, the stock market moved steadily downward yesterday and finished close to the low level of the day. Leading stocks were depressed 2 to 5 points, and a few issues lost more than that.

So far as the official record is concerned, and except for some Senatorial protest which may be instituted by those members who cast their votes in ignorance of the facts, the appointment of Mr. Justice Black is now a closed incident.

The annual Fall golf dinner was held in the Empire Room at the Homestead this evening. Among those entertaining groups were Mr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Moreland, Dr. and Mrs. Oswald R. Jones, Mr. and Mrs. Beverley R. Shriver and Mr. and Mrs. George A. Ranney.

State Prosecutor J. Rex Farrior produced a police captain, a patrol wagon driver, a former policeman and a newspaper reporter today to identify three of the six defendants now on trial here for second degree murder as having participated more or less vigorously in the events that aided a band of men to flog Joseph Shoemaker to death in a lonely wood fourteen miles outside of Tampa.
It isn't so unusual these days for a fisherman to win a trophy, but when a Government awards to a fisherman its highest decoration--and for fishing--that is something.
Darkness prevented completion of the semi-final round of the first flight today in the annual Fall golf tournament of the New York Athletic Club, being held at Buckwood Inn.

Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury and a Republican party leader often suggested as a possible Presidential nominee, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 2 East Sixtyninth Street.

Political talks in the' city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Angelo Patri, educator, who will discuss "Dewey's Crusade in Relation to Juvenile Delinquency," over W3BIL (1,100 Kc.), 6:15 to 6.30 P. M. New York State Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, candidate for re-election, over WBIL (1,100 Kc.), 6:45 to 7 P. M.

Although almost all his football players came through the Brown game without sign of injury, Coach Dick Harlow of Harvard said today he does not expect to send his elevens through hard scrimmages before Saturday's game against Navy at Baltimore.
An emergency law banning the importation of nearly 700 "luxury" articles became effective today upon promulgation by the Japanese Government.

By his victory Sunday General Juichi Terauchi is believed here to have substantially attained his objective, destruction of the Chinese armies in North China as a fighting force. The Chinese are retreating from the vicinity of Shihkiachwang down the Peiping-Hankow Railway as fast as they can go.

The two Houses of the general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church took up today controversial proposals involving basic changes in the traditional policies of the church. Only the House of Bishops approached definite conclusions on the topics before it.

The United States "seeks spiritual union with all who love freedom," Presidnet Roosevelt declared today in a radio address. "Of many bloods and of diverse national origins, we stand before the World today as one people united in a common determination," he said.
A. W. Milburn, president of the Borden Company, died today in a sanatorium near Baden-Baden of pneumonia. He had been ill there for eight days. His age was 63.

Samuel Untermyer yesterday endorsed Special Sessions Justice Nathan D. Perlman, candidate of the Republican, City Fusion and Progressive parties for Supreme Court Justice, and repeated his opposition to Justice Aaron J. Levy, Democratic candidate for re-election.
The first dead heat for first position in Maryland this season resulted in the running of the Easton Purse, feature race of the Easton Purse, feature race of the program at Laurel Park today.

A Federal court jury returned a verdict of guilty early this morning against three men who were charged with conspiracy and having transported two stolen Treasuray notes valued at $100,000 each from New York to Florida. The jury was composed of two women and ten men.

Miss Katherine Woodward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Woodward of this city was married here tonight to Daniel Curtiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Curtiss, in Trinity EpiscopalChurch. The Rev. Louis Belder of Hartford, former canon of Christ Church Cathedral, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Leonard Smith, the rector of Trinity.
Crop yields per acre will average higher this year than in any recent year, according to estimates made public today by the crop reporting board.

President Roosevelt congratulated Lin Sen, President of the National Government of China, on the national anniversary of the Chinese Republic in a message dispatched yesterday and made public today by the State Department.

Delegates attending the twentieth annual convention of the New Jersey District Kiwanis International here today were urged to give active support to a public parks recreation program for New Jersey by C. P. Wilbur, director of the State Department of Conservation and Development.

Automobile production increased sharply last week as operations on 1938 models were stepped up in most plants and the adjusted index has spurted to 159.3, approaching the all-time high of 159.9 registered for the week ended Sept. 11.
The congress here of 12,000 delegates of the National Church movement, which seeks to merge National Socialism and Protestantism, has become almost a semi-official Nazi party affair.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the eight months ended on Aug. 31, and issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal taxes and other charges, of $2,421,965.

An error in the official tabulation of registration figures for the Bronx, corrected yesterday, led to an increase of 6,000 in the figures for the Seventh Assembly District in that county. The correct table for the borough follows:

Most commodity futures drifted irregularly lower in moderate activity on the local Exchanges yesterday. Coffee, an exception, continued to advance. In the cash markets, cotton and silk were higher, but all the grains, flour, refined sugar, eggs, lard, pork, tin, wool tops and rubber declined.

The German Government oscillated today between fear that the result of the Italian note rejecting the AngloFrench proposed tripartite conference on Spain would be that the French Government would open the Spanish border for increased shipments of war materials and volunteers to Valencia and the hope that Britain would prevent this.

The New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company filed suit yesterday for $404,004 against the Continental Insurance Company based ??n alleged insurance coverage of claims arising out of the sinking ??r the steamship Mohawk on Jan. 24, 1935, in which fifty-six lives were lost.

Henry Russell, director of the Boston Opera House, 1909-13, and advisory associate director of the Metropolitan Opera in New York in 1910, died of a heart ailment today in his London home at the age of 65.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Norman de R. Whitehouse have come to the SavoyPlaza from Newport. Mr. and Mrs. Elton Parks will give a dinner dance at the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis on Dec. 23 to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Nancy Parks.

As Chief Justice Hughes quoted the case of Frizzell vs. Newman today to show that Albert Levitt and Patrick Henry Kelley, opponents of Associate Justice Black, must have more than the status of ordinary citizens, John W. Davis sat in the spaces reserved for members of the court bar.
A crowd of 150 Leftists today occupied the railroad station of Ezy and imprisoned the Mayorthere for severall hours in protest against the government's repatriation of Spanish refugees.

The Japanese carried out air raids on the Canton-Hankow railway twice this morning, using two big bombing seaplanes, accompanied by four smaller machines, and considerably damaged the line, nullifying recent repairs.

Although a pawn behind to the very last, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris was successful tonight in gaining a draw in the third game of his match with Dr. Max Euwe of this city for the chess championship of the world.

Though Columbus Day has never been a favorite occasion for special matinees, exactly half of Broadway's eighteen current legitimate attractions will perform this afternoon in honor of the discovererand, naturally, in the hope of 'a little holiday trade. The nine:

More than half of China's $150,000,000 "Liberty Loan Bonds" to help finance the undeclared war with Japan had been subscribed today. Many of the bonds were paid for with materials and products of military value, including food, shoes, clothing and medicines.
Semi-annual model sail and motor boat regatta sponsored by the Department of Parks in cooperation with R. H. Macy Co., Conservatory Lake, Central Park, 10 A. M.

Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area, is under medical observation at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, it became known last night. At his home it was said that his illness was not very serious and there was nothing alarming in his condition.

Mrs. Sylvia Cleveland Weatherby of Cambridge, Mass., daughter of Mrs. D. B. Cleveland of Cleveland and Boston, was married to Richard Lardner Tobin of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Griswold Tobin of Douglaston, Queens, yesterday afternoon in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.
Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Jeremiah T. Mahoney and a host of others will participate today in a series of ceremonies marking the celebration of Columbus Day.

Mrs. John H. Church gave a tea and reception this afternoon at Bonnybank, Great Barrington, in honor of her cousin, Miss Edith Loop of Pasadena, Calif. The hostess was assisted by her daughter, Mrs. Delano deWindt.
In a speech to the members of the Central Corporative Committee, Italy's highest economic body, Premier Mussolini today urged further restriction of imports, to be replaced by Italian substitutes.

Mrs. Sylvia Cleveland Weatherby of Cambridge, Mass., daughter of Mrs. D. B. Cleveland of Cleveland and Boston, was married to Richard Lardner Tobin of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Griswold Tobin of Douglaston, Queens, yesterday afternoon in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.
Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Jeremiah T. Mahoney and a host of others will participate today in a series of ceremonies marking the celebration of Columbus Day.

Mrs. John H. Church gave a tea and reception this afternoon at Bonnybank, Great Barrington, in honor of her cousin, Miss Edith Loop of Pasadena, Calif. The hostess was assisted by her daughter, Mrs. Delano deWindt.
In a speech to the members of the Central Corporative Committee, Italy's highest economic body, Premier Mussolini today urged further restriction of imports, to be replaced by Italian substitutes.
Counsel for a defendant in a National Labor Relations Board hearing was barred today from appearing before a trial examiner after an exchange of words between the lawyer and the board's attorney.

Supreme Court rulings on the powers of the National Labor Relations Board to adjust disputes under the Wagner law between corporations and their employes were assured when the court today agreed to review cases affecting allegedly unfair labor practices in the Fore River Yards of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation and in the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

Miss Olga Colsmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Colsmann of this city, was married to William Richey Hulsizer Jr. of East Orange, N. J., this evening in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here by the RevDr. David S. Hamilton.

Movements or vessels follow; all dates are Oct. 11 unless specified: At San Juan Island: Lark, Preble, Tracy. At San Diego, Oct. 8:- Phelps, Porter. Barker, at Mouth Min River. Conyngham, President Roads to sea, Oct, 12. Cormorant, at Solomon's Island. Henley, at San Francisco.

Appointment of nine new members of the Harvard teaching and research staff for the current academic year was announced here today. Those appointed are: Dr. John R. Stehn of Milwaukee, instructor in physics;
Not for the first time since the start of the Spanish civil war, the British Cabinet will find itself in a thoroughly uncomfortable and unhappy position when it holds its regular meeting tomorrow.

With about 300 retail buyers and a greater number of the public attending, the sixth annual Drug Trades Exposition of the Drug Salesmen's Association of New York, Inc., opened at Grand Central Palace yesterday and will continue through tomorrow.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Schofield Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Jones Jr., to frohn M. Van Horson, son of Mrs. Louis K. Van Horson of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Mr. Van Horson, took place this afternoon in St. Thomas Church, Whitemarsh.
The Board of Tax Appeals determined today that Philip J. Cogan, Patrick H. Cogan and John F. Cogan, New York subway contractors, were $61,112 deficient in 1931 income taxes.
Barringer High School's eleven and West Side High School battled to a 6-6 tie today in a thrill-studded Newark High School Football League game.

Allowing the Columbia first eleven a second day of light training, Coach Lou Little turned his attention to the seconds yesterday at Baker Field in an attempt to bolster the Lion reserve strength for the Penn game at Baker Field on Saturday.

Leon Fraser, president of the First National Bank of New York, has been named general chairman of the 1937 roll-call of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, it was announced yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, chapter executive director.
George da Maduro Peixotto, American portrait painter, died here today in a convalescent home after a month's illness. Mr. Peixotto, who formerly lived in Crestwood, N. Y., was 78 years old.

Residents of Mount Vernon, Bronxville, New Rochelle, the Pelhams and other points in Southern Westchester County were disturbed yesterday at 5:08 P. M. and again around 8 P. M. by slight earth tremors which rattled window panes and. shook buildings. No damage was reported, however.

Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University and Mrs. Gauss have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Hildegarde Gauss, to Douglas B. Sfeimle of New York, which took place on Oct. 5 at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. D. Christian Gauss of 530 East Eighty-sixth Street, this city.
Frank Morrison, Secretary, American Federation of Labor, The Convention of the American Federation of Labor, Denver, Col.:
Columbus Day was celebrated here yesterday with overtones of current international and municipal conflict in evidence at ceremonies attended by governmental leaders.

The American Newspaper Guild has been selected by editorial employes of the United Press as their collective bargaining representative by a vote of 277 to 84, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

In accordance with its announcement to the Interstate Commerce Commission of several months ago, a protective committee of shareholders of the Old Colony Railroad submitted to the commission today the outline of a plan for the operation of the railroad independently of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad system. The outline,
Baroness Clemens von Ketteler is expected to arrive tomorrow on the Rex after passing the Summer at Villa Gameraia, her place in Florence, Italy, and will be at the Pierre.

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte of New York entertrained at cocktails in the Homestead Club this evening in honor of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Ranney of Chicago and their daughter, Mrs. Gaylord Donnolley; Mr. and Mrs. Wyndham Hasler and Mrs. Terrell Johnson.

Albert Reidel, a fill collector whose cash and property assets were estimated to have been $15,000, was found dead of malnutrition here today in his ten-room home at 407 Passaic Street. He was 50 years old.

The marriage of Miss Lillian Baehr of Coscob, daughter of Mrs. Charlotte Baehr, to Gilbert L. Griswold of this place, son of Mrs. Florence Griswold of Stamford, will take place here on Saturday afternoon in the home of Miss Baehr's sister, Mrs. A. J. Graves. The Rev. Frederick W. Grunst, pastor of St. Paul's Evangelical Church, East Port Chester will officiate.

Miss Pauline Nancy Watts, daughter of\ Mr. and Mrs. George S. Watts of Renovah Manor, was martried this afternoon to John Carman Inch, son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Inch of Toronto. The ceremony took place in the home of the bride's parents.

A hail of machine-gun bullets wiped out the Brady gang on Bangor's main street early today, and ended a plot to loot the Merrill Trust Company, one of the city's three large banks, police disclosed tonight.

Nearly 5,000 firemen representing many municipalities in New Jersey and a delegation from the Port Jervis (N. Y.) Fire Department paraded here today in observance of the centennial anniversary of the founding of the Elizabeth Volunteer Fire Department. About 20,000 persons witnessed the two-hour procession.

Colonel Edward H. R. Green was a thorough student of photography and a pioneer in experimental farming, one of his Texas friends testified today at the hearing in which four States, including Texas, are seeking $6,000,000 inheritance tax money from his estate.

President Roosevelt this afternoon called Congress into extraordinary session to meet on Nov. 15, and explained tonight in a radio "fireside chat" to a nation-wide audience that he wanted quick enactment of legislation for maximum hours and minimum wages, crop control, governmental reorganization, regional planning and a curb on trusts.

Tomy Eck and Albie Burke returned to the Colgate line-up today as Coach Andy Kerr began driving the Red Raiders for their gridiron battle with Tulane at Buffalo next Saturday, and for the first time since before the Cornell debacle the Maroon eleven staged a lengthy scrimmage.

A street fight over a $50 loan led to a man's being stabbed three times in the back late Monday night after a traffic patrolman had started to search him for a pistol. The wounded man, Salvatore Criscione, 21 years old, of 329 East Fourteenth Street, is in Bellevue Hospital in a serious condition.

Publication early next year of "The Greek Blue Book," listing the names and addresses of more than 55,000 Greek-American merchants throughout the United States, was announced yesterday by M. J. Case savetes, secretary of the publishing corporation, which has offices at 303 West Forty-second Street.

Former President Herbert Hoover and seven members of his Cabinet were named yesterday as honorary pallbearers to serve at the funeral tomorrow for Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, who died Monday of a heart attack in his home at 2 East Sixty-ninth Street.

An original letter about the capture of Quebec written by George Townshend, who took over the British command after the death of General Wolfe, has been brought back to America from England by Gabriel Wells on his recent return from Europe. The letter had been in England since it arrived from Canada after the capture of Quebec in 1759.
Frank E. Gannett asserted today that the American people's "common-sense, intelligence and patriotism" would block any move of the United States toward dictatorship.

Dr. Joseph Refsum, top-ranking player in the event, defeated William Spring, 6 and 5, today to win the annual Fall golf tourney of the New York Athletic Club over the course of the Buckwood Inn. The tournament was run on a handicap basis.

David Paley, Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York from 1931 to 1933, under George Z. Medalie and Thomas E. Dewey, died today in his home here after a brief illness. He was 33 years old.

Charles D. Jaffee, president of the New' York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, who has been one of the influential men in the industry during the last fifteen years, died last night at his residence, 225 West Eighty-sixth Street, of a heart ailment after a two-day illness. He was 53 years old.

At the opening of the seventy-eighth annual race meeting of the Rose Tree Hunt Club today Corky, a black gelding owned by J. G. Leiper Jr., flashed past the judges first in the Foxcatcher Plate at two miles over brush.

Dr. Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, will address the Trade Association executives in New York on "Labor Organizations-Their Types, Objectives and Activities," at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor on Thursday, Oct. 21.

Mrs. Morris Cassel, mother of Irwin M. Cassel, who wrote the words of "I Love Life," one of the favorite songs of former years, and mother-in-law of Mana-Zucca, who composed the song, died of pneumonia early yesterday afternoon at her apartment in the Beacon Hotel, 2,130 Broadway, after an illness of one week. Her age was 73.
With the domestic grain markets closed for Columbus Day, traders paid close attention today to Winnipeg and Liverpool in an effort to determine if wheat had developed a definite trend.

At the opening session of the meeting of the Lilienthal Society for Aviation Research today, at which Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh were present, the findings of the German commission investigating the Hindenburg disaster at Lakehurst, N. J., were presented by Professor Max Dieckmann.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 11: COLONEL Hayne, P. T.. Adjutant General's Dep't., two days' leave, Oct. 12. LIEUTENANT COLONEL Wright, L. F., Med. Corps, detailed as medical examiner and witness before Retiring Board for Army Nurses to meet at Fitzsmons General Hospital, Denver, Col., during the temporary absence Major J. F. Lieberman, Medical Corps.

Bidding for high-scoring honors among the nation's football teams is little Northeast Center, Louisiana State University's junior college. The Indians have rolled up 211 points in three games this year, and if you listen to the tribe's fans the scoring has just begun.

Following its agreement with the Transport Workers Union granting a 10 per cent wage increase and closed shop, the B. M. T. management Monday night signed similar contracts with three other unions, it was learned yesterday.

The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on 944,600 yards of cotton textiles, bids to be opened Oct. 20, with delivery by Nov. 20. Lots wanted were listed as follows: 579T-Broadcloth, 101x52, white and solid colors, 75,000 yards; chambray, type A, 36inch, 25,000 yards; chambray, type B,

The Park Department conducted its annual Autumn model boat regatta yesterday in the pond at Seventy-second Street in Central Park. All but five or six of the 225 contestants were boys, but it was a fair-haired 17-year-old girl who carried off the lion's share of the prizes.

Edward B. Pius, former deputy sheriff of Kings County, New York, pleaded guilty today to charges of passing Counterfeit quarters and was sentenced to three years in a Federal penitentiary by Judge W. Calvin Chesnut in the United States District Court here.
A bronze statue of Christopher Columbus, the gift of Italian-American societies, was unveiled before 5,000 persons here today at the main entrance to Columbus Park, on Columbus Avenue.
A touchdown pass in the middle of the second period, John Supulski to Bill Proach, gave the Manhattan freshmen victory today in a game against the St. Thomas College freshmen.

An appeal to the political and economic leadership of the country to deal decisively with the "sins and sinners of capitalism" and then "so restate the case for free enterprise that a truly popular passion will be aroused for its preservation" was voiced here today by Dr. Glenn Frank, former president of the University of Wisconsin, in an address to the first general session of the American Bankers Association's sixty-third annual convention.

The Parisian fad of using colored powder on the hair to match the evening gown was demonstrated last night in a colorful hair-style revue at the annual convention of the National and New York State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Associations at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Unless the last two Republican candidates for the Presidency, former Governor Landon of Kansas and former President Hoover, can work out a meeting of minds before the Republican National Committee meets in Chicago, Nov. 5, to consider the calling of a mid-term national convention next year, there is likely to be an explosion among the party leaders.

Another draw, the second f the series, resulted from the play In the fourth game of the. world championship chess match ,between Dr. Max Euwe of this city and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris tonight, leaving the rival masters on even terms.
