Scoffing at political opponents who contend that there have been no visible signs of improvement in the city during his administration. Mayor La Guardia dedicated the $24,340,000 West Side. Improvement yesterday morning with the statement that it typified the progress made during his term.
Cases in which the State Liquor Authority and the local Alcoholic Beverage Control Board agree are not subject to certiorari by the courts, the Court of Appeals held today.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, charged last night that Mayor La Guardia's campaign managers had falsely claimed exclusive credit for the construction of three gigantic, low-rent slum clearance housing projects for 10,000 women and children.
The position of the Treasury on Oct. 9 was as follows: Receipts $14,397,332; expenditures, $21,874,998; balance, $2,831,838,137; customs receipts for the month, $12,319,039.

The decline in the stock market reflects the "attacks" by President Roosevelt on business and the resultant loss in confidence, Representative Hamilton Fish of New York declared last night in an address over the Columbia Broadcasting system.

A speaking program of unusual proportions has been mapped out for Mayor La Guardia under American Labor party auspices. It is so extensive that last night Republican leaders in all the five boroughs were asking when the Mayor was going to find time to speak at Republican meetings.

First news of the death of Mrs. Nellis Cook Pearl, 71 years old, and once a nationally known circus bareback rider, then a vaudeville actress and later a theatrical booking agent in this city, came today when the Public Administrator began a search for the fortune she was believed to have hidden away.
Gil Dobie's Boston College Eagles and Glenn Warner's Huskies from Temple University fought to a scoreless tie at Fenway Park before a crowd of 27,000 today.

More than 400 members of the National Association of Broadcasters, meeting at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria yesterday, were informed of the details of a compromise plan formulated by the recently organized Independent Radio Network Affiliates to meet the demands of the American Federation of Musicians.

Addressing a plea to Latin America on Columbus Day--the Day of the Race--the Nationalist party of Puerto Rico urged united action "to check the action of a foreign nation which attempts with unheard-of cunning to destroy our souls and our very existence as a people."

Plodding along steadily for the full distance of 26 miles and 385 yards, Pat Dengis, 37-year-old airplane mechanic from Baltimore, won the thirteenth annual Port Chester marathon today, averaging better than six minutes a mile.
Miss Susan G. H`rkins, active in welfare and club circles in Brooklyn, died on Monday at her home, 302 Hicks Street.

Under the heading, "The Bogy of Bigness," the National Grocers Bulletin, published by the National Association of Retail Grocers, cites figures, which it contends "seem to answer effectively those who have been predicting that the super-markets would drive the little retailer out of business."

A new approach to a possible future Western European pact will be registered some time this week by an important German declaration that is to be made in Brussels and notified simultaneously to the Governments of the other Western powers.

The Rev. William S. Woolworth Jr., 43 years old, from Wallingford, Conn., was reported in grave condition today from a gunshot wound inflicted by a 16-year-old Turkish student at the American College of Tarsus, in Southern Anatolia.

Mrs. E. H. Vare Jr., the former Glenna Collett, of the Philadelphia Country Club, won the Berthellyn Cup qualifying medal for the second successive year at Huntingdon Valley today, following a 44 on the first nine with a 36, one over men's par, and one under women's for an 80.
The Japanese-controlled Peace Preservation Association today decided to revert to the old name of China's ancient capital.

Miss Jane Gelpcke, daughter of Herbert S. Gelpcke of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Gelpcke, was married yesterday afternoon to Joseph Cornelius Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Ryan at the home of her aunt, Mrs. J. Harold Spencer of 35 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, with whom the bride has made her home.

A few groans were heard today from the twenty-two members of Congress here investigating Hawaii's application for Statehood when they learned that President Roosevelt had called a special session to convene Nov. 15. Most of them said, however, they expected the summons.

Two of the greatest newspapers in the Soviet Union-Izvestia and Pravda-whose combined circulation surpasses 5,000,000, present today the astounding spectacle of devoting almost the whole of their doubled editions to a single topic-the forthcoming elections to the Soviet Congress.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company has applied to the interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue and sell $3,650,000 in 2 1/2 per cent equipment securities to mature annually in ten equal payments.
The three-story flat at 312 West Fifty-sixth Street, on a plot 21.10 by 100.5 feet, has been leased by J. D. Robilotto Company, Inc., as broker, to Minnie Baker.
Virtually never does the President. relinquish a major objective or project. He demonstrated that once more today when he issued his proclamation for a special session of Congress on Nov. 15.

A request that the Church Street Annex Branch of the Postoffice, dedicated last week, be called the Franklin-Lincoln Postoffice was made yesterday in a letter to Postmaster General Farley from the International Benjamin Franklin Society, of which William Guggenheim is honorary president, and the Lincoln Fellowship of New York, Emanuel Hertz, president.

Doubt as to whether Tommy Farr, Great Britain's heavyweight champion, would return to this country for Winter ring engagements was dispelled yesterday when Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. announced receipt o! a cablegram setting forth Farr's intention of returning for a Madison Square Garden bout in January.

A lasting peace in Palestine might be built out of social and economic cooperation between Jews and Arabs of the working classes, Mordecai Bentov, member of the actions committee of the World Zionist Organization, said here night.

The threat of a renewed stoppage by the city's retail butcher Shops, resulting from a charge by retailers of a "deliberate" shortage of freshkilled kosher meat at local wholesale houses to forces prices up, waned last night when packers promised a greater abundance of meat at lower prices in the city's markets within the next day or two.

Announcement has been made here by Mrs. Lilian V. S. Nunn of Farmville, Va., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Louise Virginia Nunn, of this city, to Louis Franklin Kemp of Great Neck, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. David Franklin Kemp.

Yesterday, through an assassin's bullet, the United States lost in Beirut one of its most brilliant and devoted diplomatic officers. Since the last year of the World War, as a member of the State Department and in consular and diplomatic posts, Theodore Marriner had unstintingly served his country.

New beauty and greater realism in the motion picture theatre are promised by a new mechanical invention announced and demonstrated for the first time yesterday at the Fall convention of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Coach Earl Blaik drove his Dartmouth squad hard today in a d-izzling rain as four teams were given long defensive and offensive scrimmage sessions. The jayvees could do nothing on offense against either the first or second elevens.

The trustees of Series NS-1 have sold the property at 220 Main Street, Port Jefferson, L. I., comprising a two-story brick and stucco business building with one-story frame extension. The purchaser was a client of Karl A. Blaustein. The property was bought for cash above a purchase-money mortgage of $11,000.

Alumni of the Harvard Business School have organized a committee to aid in the election of Robert K. Straus as a member of the new City Council from Manhattan. Joseph S. Oettinger, an accountant, who was a classmate of Mr. Straus in the Harvard Business School, has accepted the chairmanship of the committee.
The problem of excessive salaries of corporation managers and directors found a solution in the new German corporation law which became effective Oct. 1.

The estate of Mrs. Thomas F. Logan, in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N. Y., including eleven acres of land, entirely landscaped, and a, twentyfour-room house, was sold yesterday at auction for $35,000 to Louis N. Cohan of this city.
Robert H. Jackson, Federal Assistant Attorney General, condemned "judicial decisions" today as a check on democracy.

Many members of society gathered today on the estates of Colonel Henr, L. Stimson and' Thomas F. White in West Hills to attend the races and have luncheon out of doors or with hosts in the countryside.

Loss leader merchandising, by which many retail food chains have worked their sales up into millions of dollars annually, was declared here today to be the greatest problem in distribution, and by inference, the direct cause for the fortytwo State fair-trade laws recently enacted. F. H. Massman,

The one-family residence at 235 Thirty-second Street, Woodcliff, N. J., has been sold by William E. Lewis to Vincenzo De Grogiro, who will occupy it. The dwelling contains nine rooms and features a sun parlor, tile bath and steam heating system.

The Rev. Dr. William Andrew Nordt, last surviving member of the first graduating class of Bloomfield (N. J.) Theological Seminary, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of two weeks. His age was 87.

Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, has accepted the chairmanship of the commerce section of the United Hospital Campaign, it was announced yesterday by Clarence Francis, chairman of the commerce and industry committee.

Nearly 100 golfers are expected to tee off Friday in the qualifying round of the twenty-fifth annual Shawnee Country Club tournament. Match play will begin Saturday and continue through the final on Sunday.

Patrolman John J. Kenneally, for the last twelve years on traffic duty at Bellevue Hospital, died yesterday in the French Hospital, where he was admitted on Sept. 24 suffering from asthma and heart trouble. Hs age was 42.

Mrs. Frank M. Gould's veteran jumper Ostend, winner of many hunts meet trophies, including the Virginia Gold Cup this year, today added the Long Island Hunt Cup to his list of conquests at the annual meeting of the West Hills Racing Association on the estates of Henry L. Stimson and Thomas F. White.

A Negro woman who identified herself as Betty May McCall, 25 years old, of 352 West 117th Street, Manhattan, was questioned last night at Jamaica, Queens, Police Headquarters for information that might lead to a solution of the slaying of Lewis Weiss, 20, of 93-21 215th Place, and Miss Frances Hajek, 19, of 212-59 Jamaica Avenue, both of Queens Village.
This is a world in which we must be surprised at nothing, not even if we read almost any day now that ex-Kaiser Wilhelm is

Mrs. Violet Bennett Carlson, who helped to keep mail and cablegrams flowing between thousands of doughboys in the trenches and the home folks as leading Y. M. C. A. postmistress in France during the World War, was killed yesterday when, the police said, she "fell or jumped" from her room on the fourteenth floor of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
President Roosevelt refused today to inject himself into either the New York Mayoralty or Arkansas Senatorial races.
Germany's unemployed decreased another 40,000 in September, leaving a total of only 469,000, a new record low.

Several of the apartments on the rental lists submitted by brokers yesterday were in cooperative buildings, and were leased for the account of -owners occupying prominent places in public life, while other well known persons sublet their quarters.

WIIAT weather yesterday! Grand. Blue sky, fine breeze, Autumn colors. It was a shame to go indoors. But there was that alluring item in the Columbia Alumni News-just out-to investigate. The headline had it: "Psychology Department Starts Ape. Colony."

AUGUSTIN--Caroline W., at her home, Brookhill, West Nyack, N. Y., Oct. 12, 1937. Services at her late residence, Thursday, Oct. 14, at 3 P. M. Kindly omit flowers. BRUSH--On Tuesday, Oct. 12, 1937, Nora S., widow of the late Thomas V., in her fifty-seventh year, at the home of her sister, Sarah Jackson, 41-23 52d St., Woodside, Queens.

Total shipments of all types of hosiery in August were 10,718,302 dozen pairs, which, while under those of August, 1936, brought the total for the first- eight months of the year to 85,044,139 dozen pairs, an increase of 11.2 per cent from the 76,448,657 dozen pairs shipped in the first eight months of 1936, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported yesterday.

Tribute to Christopher Columbus as one of the immortal pioneers of mankind was paid by Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia yesterday at a Columbus Day celebration at the Hippodrome, Fortythird Street and Sixth Avenue, under the auspices of Local 89 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Aldermanic President William F. Brunner, Democratic candidate for Borough President of Queens, characterized yesterday as "an absolute falsehood" Mayor La Guardia's assertion in his Monday night, speech in Queens that Democratic members of the Board of Estimate were insincere in regard to reduction of water rates.

Nervous selling widened today the current decline in the Toronto stock market, sending the industrials to a new low for the year and the miscellaneous mining issues to within .28 point of the year's low, off more than 3 points for the day.

A. S. Cornhill won the twentyfourth annual shoot for the cosmopolitan amateur trapshooting championship over the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. He led a field' of forty gunners by breaking 98 out of 100 targets.

Credit for a marked improvement in the financial condition of the New York City Government was claimed last night by Controller Frank J. Taylor in a radio speech over station WOR. Mr. Taylor declared that when he took office on Jan. 1, 1935, the city's finances were in a most uncertain state.

Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, retired, told members of the Poor Richard Club today that this country could not remain neutral In the Far East crisis "and write sassy letters." He advised America to send a personal note to Japan reading:

Stanley L. Otis of 444 East Fiftyseventh Street, New York, an insurance broker and consultant, formerly Director of the State Bureau of Workmen's Compensation, died of a heart attack here this afternoon at the home of his son, Courtlandt Otis.
Penn State's eleven scrimmaged for a full hour against the freshmen today, Coach Bob Higgins using almost every player who has any chance of playing against Lehigh on Saturday.

Paul Dullzell, executive secretary and treasurer of the Actors Equity Association, submitted his resignation yesterday afternoon to Equity's council at its regular weekly meeting in the union's headquarters, 45 West Forty-seventh Street. Mr.
After a visit with the President today, Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee expressed the "fervent hope" that no new or increased taxes would be necessary next year.

Daily average sales of variety stores during September of this year were about 2 per cent above the same month of 1936, and higher than for any like month since 1929, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported in its monthly survey today.
From his apparently bottomless purse Lord Nuffield, former poor bicycle mechanic, now a multimillionaire automobile manufacturer, gave [Pound]1,300,000 to Oxford University today.

Sir Raymond Unwin, British housing expert, who is visiting professor in the School of Architecture at Columbia University, will speak at 8:20 o'clock tonight on housing in England and America at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

A crowded program of speeches and discussions occupied delegates to-the annual convention of the American Bankers Association here this afternoon as the savings division and the clearing house round-table conference held simultaneous sessions.

The proposal to link the communications systems of all law enforcement agencies in the Western Hemisphere in one great organization, with the Federal Bureau of Investigation inWashington as a central clearing house, was endorsed by two Government officials yesterday at the Associated Police Communication Officers' convention at the Hotel New Yorker.
Citizens of Harrison and Purchase will attend a hearing here tomorrow night before the Town Board of Harrison to discuss a suggested revision of the zoning laws of Purchase.

Seeking to add speed to Manhattan's attack as he prepared for Saturday's tilt with Villanova at Ebbets Field, Coach Chick Meehan spent most of yesterday's morning practice experimenting with new backfield combinations.

President Roosevelt chose last night to limit his address essentially to an outline of the Administration's program for the special session of Congress which he has now summoned to convene next month.

Princeton's varsity, including four virtual newcomers, scored three late touchdowns against the secondstring combination in an hour and a half of scrimmage under actual game conditions which Coach Fritz Crisler staged on University Field today.

Miss Kitty Lou Coulbourne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Evitts Coulbourne of Grmantown, was married this morning to Robert Henry Schneider, son of Mrs. Jacob M. Schneider of Los Angeles. The ceremony took place in the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul on Logan Square.
One of the effects of the depression has been to create a huge shortage in per capital production, according to comparative figures issued by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Johnny Bellus, 135 1/4, New Haven, Conn., won his seventh consecutive victory when he gained the decision over Johnny Bonito, 136, of Washington Heights, in the eight-round main event at the New York Coliseum last night before 7,000 spectators.

Colleges in China are reopening for the new academic year, despite earlier fears that the undeclared war might keep them closed, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Ralph E. Diffendorfer, president of the Associated Boards for Christian Colleges in China.
Giving a display of speed that brought back memories of his sire, Broadway, a 3-year-old son of Broadway Jones-Omar Flo, won today's featured graded handicap at Keeneland Park.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "First Maps, Engravings and Paintings in America," Alfred Busselle Jr., 11 A. M.; Roman Art, general tour, 2 P. M.; "Building the Mediaeval Abbey Church." Margaret B. Freeman, 4 P. M.

A syndicate headed by Bernard Gerla has purchased the four-story apartment house at 327 East Twenty-second Street, corner of Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn. The Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company was the seller of the building which is on a plot 40 by 88 feet and contains forty-eight rooms.
The State Labor Department said today that plans submitted in September for construction work on industrial buildings up-State called for investments totaling $1,886,220.

Capital stock of the newly organized First New England Corporation will be offered today to preferred stockholders of the United Investment Assurance Trust in units of one preferred share and one common share at $11 a unit.

The school system's effort to "reclaim" problem children is being furthered by 293 WPA teachers assigned to clinics for the physical and psychological testing of recalcitrant pupils and to recreational clubs for truants in areas where play places are few.

M. J. Gormley, executive assistant of the Association of American Railroads, asserted today that the nation's lines, suffering from a "malnutrition diet" handed out by regulating authorities, must be allowed to charge "proper rates" if they were to continue under private ownership.

Miss Louise Heim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar V. Heim of this place, was married tonight in First Congregational Church here to Harvey S. Hopkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey S. Hopkins of Newton, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Archibald Black.
The Washington Popular Opera Association, most ambitious attempt to date to bring opera to the national capital, presented "Rigoletto" tonight at Constitutional Hall as its first offering.

The Japanese Army spokesman predicted today that when the "big push" was started-as soon as the roads had dried sufficiently for the transportation of large masses of troops-the Chinese would retreat rapidly.

The friction between the Republicans and other Fusion groups in the Bronx came to the surface last night when Newbold Morris, candidate for president of the City Council, went to the Park Republican Club, 80 West Kingsbridge Road.

Involved money problems affecting the world and the increasing participation of government in the nation's business life were among the many topics discussed today at the annual meeting of the American Life Convention. More than 350 executives of insurance companies from all over the United States and Canada are attending the various sessions of the meeting.

Coach Mal Stevens sent his New York University varsity squad through more than three's hours of intensive drilling at Ohio Field yesterday. The Violet mentor concentrated on fundamentals in all departments of the game.

Aid to those who are members of other faiths and increased -religious instruction for youth were advocated by Catholic leaders yesterday at the annual memorial mass and luncheon of the New York Assembly of the Catholic Daughters of America.

After a dore M long and lively debate, the House Consul of Clerical and Lay Deputies overwhelmingly defeated this afternoon the proposal to permit remarriage by an within the Protestant Episcopal because Church of persons divorced for any cause, subject only to the approval The a of their Bishops.

While advertising volume may be disappointing in the final quarter of this year, in that gains will not equal those of the earlier months, there is no particular reason to believe that 1938 budgets will be pared sharply, one advertising executive declared here yesterday.
Grand Gardens, the six-story apartment building at 61 Grand Street, Terrace Avenue to Locust Street, Fleetwood, Mount Vernon, has been purchased by Max Rosenfeld, operator.

This afternoon I have issued a proclamation calling a special session of the Congress to convene on Monday, Nov. 15, 1937. I do this in order to give to the Congress an opportunity tO consider important legislation before the regular session in January and to enable the Congress to avoid a lengthy session next year, extending through the Summer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: General Rivers's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES advocating application of the Neutrality Act in the Far East closes with a curious sentence, one that rightly attempts to deal with the long-term implications of the present fighting.

The Alexander Hamilton High School football team turned back the Thomas Jefferson eleven, 7 to 0, yesterday at Commercial Field before a capacity crowd. It was the second triumph for the victors in three engagements and the second setback for Jefferson.

Dr. Albert Einstein Jr., 33-yearold son of the famous physicist, arrived yesterday on the HollandAmerica liner Veendam to visit his father for three months. Professor Einstein went to the pier from his home in Princeton, N. J., and they departed together after the passenger's baggage was cleared.

Coach Jack Blott tried a new pass offensive with the Wesleyan regulars today. Sonstroem, in the backfield, did the passing, with Phelps, tackle, receiving. Dege substituted at guard for Captain Petherbridge, who is out with a slight concussion.

The large apartment houses at 485 Gramatan Avenue and 10-12 Jefferson Place, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, have been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank through the office of Frederick M. Morrison, broker.
Crowding department and specialty stores in a manner suggestive of Christmas time, New Yorkers utilized the holiday yesterday for what closely approached a shopping spree.

Offering will be made today by B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., of a new issue of $275,000 of city of Niagara Falls, N. Y., 2.10 per cent bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1937, and maturing from Oct. 1, 1939 to 1955. The bonds will be priced to yield from 1.20 to 2.20 per cent, according to maturity.
Louis Mastriani of this place, former international vice president of the Brotherhood of Railway Car Men of America, died at his home yesterday after a long illness. He was 41 years old.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Louise Bannon, daughter of Joseph Vincent Bannon of Kew Gardens, Queens, and the late Mrs. Bannon, to Frederick Anthony Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael George Meyer of Richmond Hill, Queens, and Monmouth Beach, N. J., took place yesterday morning in the Holy Man i Child Jesus Church, Richmond Hill.
New machine tool orders in September jumped to 210.7 per cent in the National Machine Tool Builders' Association index.
Tibor Eckhardt's declarations favoring a Habsburg restoration as a means of combating the Nazi threat continue to arouse interest in all political circles.

John L. Le1is's Committee for Industrial Organization unanimously voted at a session here this afternoon to ask the American Federation of Labor to meet it at a conference to consider methods of unifying the American labor movement.

Decrying public agencies that have "muzzled" individual thinking in this country as well as in Europe, Dr. Rollo G. Reynolds, principal of the Horace Mann School, called on parents and teachers last night to make the American public school a place of "free inquiry" where youth can learn to think for itself.

More than 4,000 Knights of Columbus from Manhattan and the the Bronx commemorated Columbus Day yesterday with a parade on only Eighth Avenue, a rally at Columbus and Circle, and a dinner last night at the Hotel Capitol.

Testimony in the oil conspiracy case here today centered around the efforts of Government counsel to prove that all the major oil companies operating in this general area had uniform contracts with their jobbers. Three Wisconsin jobbers were called as witnesses.
A ground keeper, scouts and other team assistants will share in the $20,865.30 world series money allotted the third-place National League Pirates. Each regular player and coach will draw $734.47.

President Roosevelt received W. Bostrom, the Swedish Minister, today for a discussion of arrangements for the celebration next year of the 300th anniversary of the first permanent settlement of Swedes in the Delaware River Valley.

The wedding of the Marquess of Clydesdale and Lady Elizabeth Percy, sister of the Duke of Northumberland, will take place on Dec. 2, it was announced tonight. Their engagement was made known last week.

Miss Vera Agnes Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Verner F. Davis of West Orange, was married to Miller Franklin Naylor, son of Dr. and Mrs. Wallace F, Naylor of Somerville, N. J., this afternoon in St. Mark's Episcopal Church here.

Feminism in music asserted further claims for public consideration when the newly formed Women's Chamber Orchestra, under the direction of Jeannette Scheerer, made its first appearance last night at the Town Hall.

Mrs. Dudley Ward has become engaged to Marquis de Casa Maury, it was announced today. Her marriage to William Dudley Ward was dissolved in 1931. The former Miss Paula Gellibrand, now the wife of William Allen, Belfast publisher, formerly was the wife of the marquis.

The Juilliard Graduate School has awarded forty-six fellowships for the season 1937-38 as a result of competitive tests held during the last two weeks, it was announced yesterday by Ernest Hutcheson, president of the school.

Public support through finantial cohttibu tions for the Memorial Lighthouse to Christopher Columbus which is to be erected at Santo Domingo was urged by President Roosevelt in a A message read tonight by Sumner held Welles, Under Secretary of State, in a nation-wide broadcast from the studios of the N. B. C. here which Jose was also sent by short-wave to the other Republics of this continent.

With Henry Lewis leading the winning attack with five goals, the Red poloists conquered the veteran Earle W. Hopping's White riders, 10 to 6, in a seven-period members cut-in match on Belmont Field at Meadow Brook today.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 229-Jesse C. Duke, petr., v. United States. Motion to withhold order denying petition for writ of certiorari submitted pro se.

Belgian officials tonight postponed a reply to suggestions that a Ninepower treaty conference to seek a pacific solution of the Sino-Japanese conflict be held in Brussels It was understood, however, that Belgium would agree to play host to the conference, although Foreign Office officials said a definite decision would not be made until tomorrow.

Protesting against legislation adopted at the recent session of the Alberta Legislature but not yet assented to by the Lieutenant Governor, the board of directors of the Canadian Press at its half-yearly meeting here today unanimously adopted the following resolution:

Miss Harriet Tuft of Berkeley, Calif., arrived in New York yesterday to preside at the three-day sessions of the National Panhellenic Congress, which will open tomorrow at the Beekman Tower Hotel. Twenty-three national presidents of Greek letter sororities, composing the congress, will be In attendance, with Miss Tuft, principal of a high school in Oakland, as national chairman.
Before a Columbus Day crowd of 10,800, the Millsdale Stable's Infantry won a photo decision today from A. J. Sackett's Tabitha in the Columlus Handicap, feature of the program.
The American Farm Bureau Federation today advised Southern farmers to hold their 1937 cotton crops instead of selling at present prices.
French anti-aircraft batteries fired a warning shot today at a German airliner, which, the authorities declared, flew low over a forbidden zone of the Franco-Spanish frontier.

Six of the crew were burned to death and nine injured here today when sudden flames enveloped the engine room and galley of the tanker Paraguana. The men were trapped when a hose broke as the tanks were being flushed with kerosene and galley flames set the kerosene ablaze. The flames leaped higher than the tanker funnel.

For the first time since the Fianna Fail became the government party it was. subjected, at its annual convention today, to a scathing criticism on policy by one of its own adherents. More than 800 delegates from every constituency of the Free State assembled in Dublin for the usual yearly meeting.

A plot against the government was disclosed today as the press announced the trial of sixteen men before the Special Tribunal for the Defense of the State. The defendants are all professional men and one is a well known economist, Luzzatto Morandi.

Vera Brittain of London, who told her own story in "Testament of Youth," and will tell the story of her friend Winifred Holtby in her forthcoming book, "Brief Odyssey" (Macmillan), starts-this week on a lecture tour which will take her into the Middle West, the South and New England, and also to Montreal. She is scheduled for a talk at Town Hall here on Nov. 12.

Housing and unemployment constitute the two major problems of the Negro population of this State and both have reached the point where they are a menace to health, Assemblyman Harold P. Herman, chairman of the New York State Temporary Commission on the Condition of the Urban Colored Population, declared yesterday.
City College's football team tuned up its attack in a brisk morning workout at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The Beavers travel to Selinsgrove, Pa., Saturday to meet Susquehanna University.

The Casualty and Surety Reinsurance Company of America, New York, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 100,000 shares of $10par value common stock to be offered at $23.50 a share.

The Bethpage poloists defeated South Shore, 7 to 5, today on Hazard Field. The three Carrons brothers played well throughout to hold off the bids of the losers, who challenged right up to the final minute. George Carrons tallied four times and Richard Carrons twice.

The shift of rugged Edmund Franco from left tackle to the rightguard position he filled so acceptably as a sophomore two seasons ago, marked yesterday's preparation of the Fordham squad for the game with Pittsburgh at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

Father Thomas R. Jones, who has alleged that University of Pittsburgh football players receive pay checks, "resigned" today from the Duquesne University faculty. The resignation was announced and accepted by the president, Father J. J. Callahan.

The Spanish Government ordered the immediate evacuation today of all bank reserves and gold assets of Asturias and Santander Provinces. The Government already has been driven from Santander, taking along all bank assets.

The Socialist party in a statement by Jack Altman, its campaign manager, criticized yesterday the appearance of Mayor La Guardia and Jeremiah T. Mahoney at the Columbus Day exercises in Columbus Circle, which he declared were "arranged and run in the interest of Italian fascism" and "marked with the taint of Mussolini propaganda."

Maxie Rosenbloom, 185, New York, outboxed Bob Nestell, 193, Los Angeles, -to win a ten-round decision before 8,000 fans at the Olympic Auditorium tonight. The veteran New Yorker proved too clever for the young Californian and won Referee George V. Blake's verdict without dispute.

The strike of seventy-five artists and cartoonists, employes of the Fleischer Studios, begun nearly six months ago, was settled yesterday at a conference of representatives of the company and of the Commercial Artists and Designers Union at the office of Arthur B. Krim, counsel for the company.

Danno O'Mahoney, 220, Ireland, was declared the winner over Jesse James, 190, Hollywood, Calif., in 30 minutes in the feature wrestling match at the St. Nicholas Palace last night, The Associated Press reported. Tony Colesano, 205, Italy, and Steve Passas, 186, Greece, drew: Bennv (Crusher) Feldman,

A pledge that politics would not be allowed to interfere with institutions caring for the sick was made by speakers yesterday at the dedication exercises of the newly constructed eight-story Jewish Memorial Hospital, Broadway and 196th Street.

Unqualified endorsement of giving consumers the facts about fabrics through "fiber identification" has been expressed by retailers representing nearly $2,000,000,000 in annual sales in replies to telegrams sent by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, that organization announced yesterday.

The Princeton Theatre Intime, under. graduate dramatic organization, will launch its seventeenth annual season this Fall with two comedy productions in Murray Theatre on the university campus, it was announced today by Richard E. Baer '38, of Washington, D. C., Intime president.

The delicate European situation tonight caused changes in the already once delayed play, "Patriotism, Limited." The Lord Chamberlain consented to production of the play only on condition that none of the characters be made up to resemble Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy.

Dorothy McNulty, screen actress and former Broadway musical comedy star, and Dr. Lawrence Scroggs Singleton, dentist and flier, will be married Friday night in the Westwood Community Church, Miss McNulty announced tonight.

A regular fellow" is what many members of the American Legion are calling King George tonight after the King and Queen Elizabeth had spent a half hour chatting personally with 108 Legionnaires and their wives and families at Buckingham Palace this morning.

Plans to increase their share in the nation's petroleum business were outlined today by members of the National Oil Marketers Association at the annual meeting of the organization. More than 1,000 independent oil marketers and jobbers, members of the association, are attending.

Samuel Kronenberg, hats, In 34-38 W 27th St; Academy of Display, Inc, in 8 E 41st St; Sidney J. Beckerman, printing, in 22-8 W 21st St; Comet Envelope and Paper Co, printing, in 3 E 17thSt; Byrne Bowman, Inc, broker.

The administrative staff of the College of Engineering at Cornell for the current academic year will have as its head S. C. Hollister, associate dean. He will fill the vacancy caused by the death of Dean Herman Diederichs, and will relinquish his duties as director of the School of Civil Engineering to Professor Paul H. Underwood.

Giovanni Martinelli, Italian tenor, who will celebrate his twenty-fifth anniversary with the Metropolitan Opera Company in November, arrived yesterday from London on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania and left last night by plane for San Francisco, where he is scheduled to sing in "Aida" on Friday.

The possibility of a new challenge to Justice Black's right to sit in the Supreme Court was seen today when it was learned that the court is due to pass next Saturday on a protest of some Florida oil men against seizure of private telegrams by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Chicago's Cubs bounced back with the combination of Larry French's southpaw pitching and a substantial batting assault today to defeat the White Sox, 6 to 2, and prolong Chicago's twenty-second city baseball title warfare to its full seven-game limit.

Struck by an automobile while at-, tempting to cross the Albany Post Road here late last night, Royal Roberts, 59 years old, of Dogwood Road, a veteran of four wars, died of a skull fracture as he was being taken to the Peekskill Hospital.
Safety seekers offered a chemical test for a drunken driver that can be presented in court as strong evidence at a section meeting of the National Safety Congress here today.

AIRCRAFT ENGINE MECHANIC, $1,860 a year; aircraft engine mechanic (engine test operator),, $1,860; in the air corps at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, and Patterson Field, Fairfield, Ohio. Applications must be on tile with the secretary, Board of U. S. Civil Service Examiners, Wright Field, Fairfield Air Depot, Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, not later than Oct. 30.

Mayor La Guardia, Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for District Attorney; Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, head worker of the Hudson Guild and Stanley M. Isaacs, candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, who will speak from a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore in honor of Mr. Isaacs. WQXR, 1:30 to 2:30 P. M.

Nearly one-fourth of the children who die in the United States are victims of accidents, Alvin D. Battey, assistant statistician of the National Safety Council, told the National Safety Congress here today.
Nationwide "Roosevelt Fifth Anniversary" dinners will be held Nov. 9, under the auspices of the Young Democratic Clubs of America, in opening a drive for 10,000,000 members by 1940.

Dr. William A. McKeever, founder, teacher, physical instructor, disciplinarian and inspirational director of Oklahoma City's School for Maturates, arrived in town yesterday with one of his pupils-a strapping youngster of 83-to explain to New Yorkers why life begins at 70.

Frederic R. Coudert Jr. has accepted the chairmanship of a committee 'to further the campaign of Edward Corsi, Deputy Commissioner of Social Welfare in the La Guardia administration, for member of the new City Council. Mr.
General Paul H. Weyrauch, a native of Germany who commanded a large unit of United States troops in the World War, died at the Veterans' Hospital today. He was 64 years, old.

Sir Hubert Wilkins plans to resume-his search for the Russian fliers lost in the Arctic within about two weeks, it was learned yesterday when he completed plans for the purchase of a land plane, equipped with skis, to replace the flying boat in which he recently returned to New York.
China, with imports of twenty-two American-built land airplanes during August, valued at $1,097,547, was the best aircraft customer of the United States, the Commerce Department disclosed today.

Parades, public meetings and athletic contests were held today in the four cities and the larger villages of Westchester County in commemoration of Columbus's discovery of America. More than 9,000 persons marched in the processions, which halted at statues of the explorer to place wreaths and flowers.

Freckels, 3-year-old colt owned by the Newbrook Stable of Short Hills, N. J., trotted within half a second of the world's record for his age in winning the first heat of the feature race on the light harness racing card presented by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

The marriage of Miss Martin J. Sieder. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto F. Sieder of Maplewood, to Nils O. Ohlson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar J. Ohlson of East Orange, took place this evening in Trinity Congregational Church, East Orange. The pastor, the Rev. Dascomb E. Forbush, performed the ceremony.

The fencing season will get under way tomorrow night on the strips of the New York Athletic Club when the Amateur Fencers League of America will stage its first competition for men's prep foil candidates with the traditional Dr. Graeme M. Hammond prize for the winner.

The Lehigh Navigation Coal Company, whose five collieries in Panther Creek Valley were closed by a walkout of 7,000 miners in sympathy with a little group of staydown strikers, prepared today to reopen all its mines tomorrow morning.

More than 100 members and former members of the Westchester Hills Country Club took part today in the. Peter Clark Memorial Tournament over the club's course, during which $600 was realized for the benefit of Mrs. Clark.

In dismissing the petition of James F. Laverty, a New York City lifeguard, WhO sought to take an exaffination for chief lifeguard, the Court of Appeals today ruled in effect that a man over 40 was too old to fill the position. It SUstained a ruling by the Appellate Division.

The State rested its case today against six former Tampa policemen charged with the second degree murder of Joseph Shoemaker, former Vermont manufacturer who started an organization called the Modern Democrats in opposition to the two dominant political factions of Tampa.

Jay R. Decatur, clothing merchant, died today at his home here after three days' illness of pneumonia. He was 80 years old. Born in this village, the son of Jacob R. and Matilda McCutchen Decatur, he retired a few years ago after being for fifty-four years the head of J. R. Decatur Son, which was founded by his father.

Mrs. Clara Blum Goldrich, widow of Dr. Leon Goldrich, former director of the Bureau of Child Guidance, died early yesterday morning in Mount Sinai Hospital, where she had been a patient for two months. She was 62 years old.

Fearing the Army attack, the Yale coaches today stressed defense in the first strenuous scrimmage of the week for Saturday's game in the Bowl. The scrubs, coached by Gerald Ford, used Army plays repeatedly against the regulars, who generally were successful in halting the attack.

The football Giants moved into the Polo Grounds yesterday and for two hours the squad of thirty-one went through a passing and kicking drill. Later two elevens ran through signals preparatory to Sunday's game with the Philadelphia Eagles.

After Head Coach Hank Hardwick had gone into a huddle with his aides and decided that unusual steps must be taken in preparing for the Harvard game in the Baltimore Stadium Saturday, secret practice, the first of the season, was ordered this afternoon and will probably be continued during the week.

The election of Mark Smith as president of the New York City local of the American Federation of Radio Artists, the newly-formed American Federation of Labor affiliate for performers on the air, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Emily Holt, national executive secretary.

Three automobiles of the British Embassy were machine gunned by three Japanese planes in a group of six yesterday while the cars were on the Minghong-Nanking highway about fourteen miles from Shanghai, according to British officials. No one was hurt. The attack occurred at 4 P. M.

Foreign trade of the United States in August showed sharp gains over the same month in 1936, both in exports and imports in the case of all geographical grand divisions and in nearly all of the fifty-one countries listed in the monthly survey issued today by the Commerce Department.

Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn's bay gelding Earl Brooke captured the Class D trot and pace at the closing matinee of the season at the driving park here today to win a silver cup offered by Mrs. William D. Kraft of White Plains.
Daniel Green, 27, waived examination today when arraigned before Police Judge Frederick Skinner on charges of first degree murder growing out of the fatal stabbing last night of his wife, Eunice, 35.

Charles W. Nash, pioneer automobile manufacturer, now chairman of the board of the Nash Motors Division of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, set some 300 dealers and salesmen of this region cheering at Mecca Temple yesterday when he announced that the objective of the company for 1938 was to gain fourth place in the industry or first place among the independents.

Samuel Untermyer has accepted the chairmanship of the Lawyers Committee for Harold W. Hastings, Democratic candidate for District Attorney, it was announced yesterday. More than four hundred lawyers are members of the committee.
Some 25,000, the largest crowd of the season at Rockingham Park, today saw Coward and Coffey's Star Flower win the $3,000 added Columbus Day Handicap. The race was for 2-year-olds at a mile.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler (Democrat, Montana) declared here tonight that if the Administration sought to revive the Supreme Court reorganization issue he could assure them "they will get fewer votes than before."

Archbishop Curley on this his fiftyeighth birthday announced that the $6,000,000 left to the archdiocese of Baltimore by Thomas O'Neill, for many years a prominent merchant, for construction of a new Catholic cathedral and post-graduate hospital, had grown to $14,000,000.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses denied yesterday that his department had received a budget increase for next year of $1,650,883 as shown in Mayor La Guardia's executive budget, and informed members of the Board of Estimate that he had been the victim of "trick bookkeeping."

The San Jose poloists from Argentina defeated the Mexican team today, 10-7, in the rubber match of their international series, thus taking the trophy offered by Avila Camacho, acting Mexican Secretary of War. Mexico won the first game, 11-6, and Argentina the second, 8-6, after two successful free shots following fouls.
Having last Saturday stationed "The Fireman's Flame" at the American Music Hall, the Krimsky Brothers will try the muses again this evening-with "In Clover," opening at the Vanderbilt Theatre.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hall of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Learned Hall, to George Davol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Davol of Brookline, Mass.
The Whitney Museum of American Art this afternoon will open to the public an exhibition entitled "Contemporary American Ceramics."

Establishing himself as the leading money-winning thoroughbred in the country this year, C. S. Howard's handicap champion Seabiscuit yesterday raised his 1937 earnings to $152,780 when he captured the $12,750 Continental Handicap at Jamaica before 15,000 persons.
Joseph B. Weaver, former director of the Bureau of-Marine Inspection, blamed the Government today for "failure to control labor conditions on American-flag ships."
Joseph B. Weaver, former director of the Bureau of-Marine Inspection, blamed the Government today for "failure to control labor conditions on American-flag ships."

Ladder-climbing Columbia River salmon, cougars as- big as- some lions, a herd of antelope and dambuilding beavers will be features of the State of Oregon exhibit at the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday as State officials signed a contract-with Grover A. Whalen.
Sir Reginald and Lady Blaker, Colonel R. M. Weeks and Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. S. Franklin are sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.
The text of President Roosevelt's proclamation was as follows: Convening the Congress in extra session by the President of the United States of America.
Certain oomplications and difficulties that had arisen in connection with the Duke of Windsor's projected American tour have now been cleared up, this correspondent learns on competent authority.

Lou Salica of New York,. former world bantamweight king, won a close decision from Jackie Corcoran of Elizabeth in the feature sixround bout of the opening indoor show at Scott's Hall tonight. Salica weighed 120 pounds and Corcoran 126.

A secona-nalr rally enabled the Fort Hamilton quartet to triumph over the First Division polo team, 10 to 6, yesterday at Fort Hamilton's field. The score at the end of the third period was 5-all. John Clements, No. 2, starred for the winners with three tallies. Captain Robert Dulaney and Captain James Fish each accounted for two.

In a letter to Borough President Ingersoll yesterday, Harry Nassberg, counsel for the West End Chamber of Commerce, demanded that a 70-foot 1,000-pound pole, erected to carry a banner of Mayor La Guardia, be removed from the roof of the Interborough's Borough Hall station, directly in front of Mr. Ingersoll's office.

The first German airplane carrying a quick-firing gun has been completed by the Heinkel works. Known as pursuit one-seater HE112, with a cruising speed of about 275 miles an hour, it carries two quick-firing guns on its wings and also two heavy machine guns.

The Federation Bank and Trust Company will celebrate today the beginning of its sixth year in business at Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue by opening its completely remodelled bank quarters, which have been enlarged and airconditioned throughout.
International strife was traced today by United States Senator Gerald P. Nye to "civilization's lack of knowledge of the real causes of war."

At least [pound]250,000 (about $1,238,750) in wagers will ride with Jockey Tommy Weston tomorrow when he will attempt to bring Sir Abe Bailey's Dan Bulger home first in the ninety-eighth Cambridgeshire Stakes.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 9: REAR ADMIRAL Freeman, C. S., Commandant of the Norfolk Navy Yard, Portsmouth, Va.. Oct, 15, to commander of Submarine Force, IL S. Fleet.
Taking advantage of the drop in United States cotton prices, due to the large crop, Germany is increasing her purchases to the limit of her capacity to pay in cash.
Taking advantage of the drop in United States cotton prices, due to the large crop, Germany is increasing her purchases to the limit of her capacity to pay in cash.
Seventy members of various Fascist groups, chiefly young members of Falanga, were arrested here today and held responsible for antiJewish rioting and bombing outrages.

Henry Waltemade, Inc. has arranged a first mortgage loan of $200,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for ten years for Derlow Estates, Inc, Samuel Derfner, president, on the recently completed 6-story apartment at 2,200 Tiebout Ave, the Bronx.

Mrs. Anna Obst, 71 years old, of 290 Autumn Avenue, Brooklyn, was fatally injured at about 7 o'clock last night when she was knocked down by an automobile at Fulton Street and Autumn Avenue, near her home.
The No. 1 Texas golf team, Don Schumacher of Dallas and Morris Norton of Wichita Falls, today won the opening match of a tournament arranged as a tribute to Bobby Jones. Atlanta's grand slam golfer.

The bloody bones of the Borgias are being rattled thoroughly, if not too accurately, in "Lucrezia Borgia," the new French film at the Belmont, but when the echoes die away there is only the memory of more and grease paint, of brilliant settings and costumery, of gifted mummers in a gorgeous piece of mummery. For the film,

France and Yugoslavia renewed the treaty friendship between the two countries in official ceremonies at the Quai d'Orsay today. Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch, here on an official visit, signed for the Yugoslav Government and Yvon Delbos, Foreign Minister, for France.

The Securities and Exchange Commission scheduled today oral argument for Oct. 26 at its offices here in the case of Charles C. Wright, New York broker, and others, charged with manipulation of the common stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Company on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange.
The Brooklyn Dodgers of the National Football League crushed Dayton 35 to 6, in an exhibition game played in the rain tonight.

The shipyards of the world are building 2,902,345 gross tons of merchant ships, an increase of 19,485 tons in the last three months, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday. The report does not cover the situation In Russia, where figures have not been available for some time.

The important role of Jason Wilkins in "Benefits Forgot" at M.-G.-M. has been handed to young James Stewart and is likely to be the most dramatic part he ever has had. Walter Huston has decided against the role of Lincoln in the picture-though he still retains the lead-but he may keep it in the family nevertheless, since the studio is now testing his son, John, for the role in New York.

It probably will not be possible for Japan to cease military operations in China as long as the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] remains powerful in the Chinese Government and as long as the present Government of Kuomintang leaders continues-in power in Nanking.

When J. Theodore Marriner was sent last year from the important diplomatic post of embassy counselor in Paris to be consul general at Beirut. the State Department explained the transfer as a final training step to equip him for the rank of Minister and later of Ambassador, to which the department considered his career had fully entitled him.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, rejected tonight as "insincere" the proposal for a conference to settle the internecine labor war, made today at the conference of the Committee for Industrial Oganization in Atlantic City.

Striking late in the fourth quarter after it had appeared the result would be a scoreless tie, the Erasmus Hall football team downed its traditional Brooklyn rival, James Madison High, 7-0, at Ebbets Field yesterday. A crowd of 15,000 saw the clash, the fourteenth in a series which began in 1925.

In one of the lightest workouts in several days, Cornell's varsity football team rehearsed new plays and old ones today and perfected its defense formations against Syracuse plays. The long session was conducted in the rain and there was no scrimmage.

There are some activities of the municipal government in which a narrow-minded "economy" is just another name for waste. The public library is one of them. A library system is not buildings or librarians-it is books.

THE SECOND ADMIRAL, by Richard S. West Jr. (Coward-McCann, $5.) A biography of the Civil War Admiral, David Dixon Porter. I WAS A SHARE-CROPPER, by Harry Harrison Kroll. (Bobbs, Merrill, $2.75.) An autobiography.

Mussolini warns his people to forego foreign goods that are "not indispensable" in order to improve Italy's trade balance. Everything must be subordinated to "the supreme aim of national self-sufficiency. * * * The whole nation must acquire the autarchic mentality."

A wedding that drew many members of society to the South Shore this afternoon was that of Miss Marion Wharton, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wharton of Islip and New York, and Gerard Hallock 3d, son of Mrs. Gerard Hallock and the late Mr. Hallock, which took place in St. Mark's Church.

Sharp criticism of the present system of handling narcotic cases among women was expressed by Miss Ruth E. Collins, superintendent of the House of Detention for Women, New York, speaking at one of the sections of the annual convention of the American Prison Association here today.

The reported call of 50,000 Blackshirt volunteers to the colors as preparation for "special emergencies" tonight raised the question in Italian minds whether the Fascist High Command is planning to send new legions to aid the Spanish Insurgents.

Julian L. Marx, who purchased the two three-story and one fivestory buildings forming the southwest corner of Twenty-first Street and Second Avenue, plans to renovate the buildings, and designs are being prepared by Joseph M. Berlinger, architect, which will convert the present layout into modern apartments and stores.

Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week. The total was also less than in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

IT'S a mystery whatever became- of the old Francis Brett Young, whom some one I know used to admire fervently twelve or fifteen years ago. This was the Francis Brett Young of "Love Is Enough," "The Dark Tower," "The Crescent Moon," "Cold Harbour" and other novels that seemed the height of perfection.

While the present municipal campaign was still in its warming-up stages Mayor La Guardia turned to Stanley M. Isaacs, candidate on the Fusion and several other tickets, for President of the Borough of Manhattan, with the remark, "I don't know where you've been all this time, Stanley."

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,579,050 barrels, compared with 3,647,450 in the preceding week, a decrease of 68,400 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Richard Cresson Harlow is heading South to his old stamping ground this week. It's back to Maryland for the distinguished ornithologist from Cambridge, and he is not in quest of birds' eggs and decidedly is not looking for a goose egg.
In his address to the Civil Service Assembly at Ottawa Mr. Robert L. Johnson, president of the National Civil Service Reform League, cited the wellknown successes of the spoilsmen at Washington.

Dr Richard G. Tunison, head of R. G. Tunison Company, pharmaceutical chemists, died of a heart ailment in his home at 277 Park Avenue on Sunday. He was 57 years old. A native of Greenville, Pa., he was graduated from the Long Island College of Medicine in 1907.
A strike order for 1,200 drivers on buses of eight affiliated Greyhound systems was suspended today by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, Tom J. McGrath announced.
Funeral services were held in Madison Square Garden at midnight for Walter Cravens, 29-year-old cowboy of Butler, Okla., who was fatally kicked by a 1,300-pound steer at the rodeo Saturday night.

From Maine comes word that hunters are taking a number of the large black bears which are so plentiful there this year. These short-snouted animals are unusually plentiful in the vicinity of Athens, Island Falls, Willamitic, Topsfield, Carroll, Prentiss and Lee.

Miss Grace Georgina Ebert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Ebert of Port Jefferson, and State Police Sergeant Daniel F. Glasheen, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Glasheen of Troy, were married here this morning at a nuptial mass at the Church of the Infant Jesus.

Mayor La Guardia justified his reputation for fearlessness this week when he vetoed the five-day-week bill passed by the Board of Aldermen' and affecting some 50,000 city employes. He is, as he said, "in favor of a five-day week, orderly arranged and in keeping with the protection of life and property in the City of New York."

Scoring in every period except the third, the 101st Cavalry polo team turned back Smithtown, 9 to 5, today at Bethpage Field. Milton Kornblum, No. 2, tallied three times for the winners with Jack Singer, No. 3, accounting for two goals. The victory placed the team in the final for the Herbert Bayard Swope ITrophy.
J. Theodore Marriner, the United States Consul General here, was shot dead outside the consulate this morning by an Armenian who was incensed because a United States visa had been denied him.

The Yokohama Specie Bank casts doubt on a report that a big British bank is refusing to discount its import bills. According to the newspaper Nichi Nichi correspondent, who cabled the news, the British bank is not acting on instructions from the government but is taking precautions because of uneasiness regarding the future.

Premier Benito Mussolini received today General Atilio Terruzzi, who went to Spain several months ago as chief inspector of the Black Shirt legionnaires fighting under General Francisco Franco, the Rebel leader.

In a formal exchange of notes today the German Government solemnly pledged itself to respect at all times and under all circumstances the inviolaability and territorial integrity of Belgium except in case Belgium should participate in military action against Germany.
At the University of North Carolina Tuesday Mr. Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, complained of judicial decisions as a check on democracy.

The importation by Jamaica of Japanese goods from Manchukuo has been stopped on a ruling from London that Manchukuo is a country not recognized by the British Government. The relatively large quota of importations from Manchukuo has been responsible for agitation in commercial circles, which has now beer stopped.

Reporting to the, National Safety Congress today, the committee on pedestrian protection and control stated that of the total motor vehicle deaths in the country forty in 100 are pedestrian fatalities and only 25 per cent are the result of collision.
Pedro Ernesto Baptista, former Mayor of Rio de Janeiro, arrived here this morning from Sao Paulo under arrest. His son Odilon was arrested here.

Husking, an occupation said to have virtually disappeared here since the decline of agriculture within the city limits, will be revived on an excursion scheduled on Oct. 23 by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

More than 100 attended the annual football dinner of the Lehigh Club of New York last night at the Murray Hill Hotel. Walter R. Okeson, chairman of the Football Rules Committee, who acted as toastmaster, recalled it was at this hotel that the organization meeting of the N. C. A. A. was held some years ago.

Marking the first decline in fourteen months, retail prices in September decreased 0.3 per cent, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index, issued yesterday. The index now stands at 96.3, compared with 96.6 on Sept. 1 and 89.3 a year ago. The increase of 7.8 per cent above a year ago contrasts with the largest gain this year of 9.6 per cent, recorded on Aug. 1.

The Rev. Clinton C. Cox, pastor of the Drexel Park Presbyterian Church, made public today ten commandments for a happy home. They are: 1. God first. 2. Join a church and worship regularly. 3. Have blessings at meals and family worship. 4. Be loyal to your family always. 5. Don't air family differences to neighbors; tell God. He understands.

Officials of the Federal Trade Commission conceded the right of dress manufacturers to keep their volume of business confidential at a hearing yesterday of its case in restraint of trade against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., held in the commission's rooms at 45 Broadway.

President Roosevelt declared today that people now were "rightly" talking about "freedom of religion and of the press,." just as they were 150 years ago when the Constitution was in process of ratification.

A proposal to amend the zoning laws of the town of Harrison to permit the building of water towers, pumping stations and reservoirs at any point selected by the Westchester Joint Water Works 1 or any other water company was defeated for all
Cotton prices rallied sharply yes-terday on evidence that the South was withholding supplies from the market, and more active trade and outside buying developed.

Grain prices closed higher n the Board of Trade here today, but not until after all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats and rye had dropped to new low levels for the season on general liquidation and stop loss order selling.

Announcement of the program for the twenty-fourth annual convention of the National Foreign Trade Council to be held in Cleveland Nov. 3, 4 and 5, was made here yesterday by James A. Farrell, chairman of the organization. More than 1,000 foreign traders from all parts of the country are expected to attend the gathering.
In the current discussion of our attitude to the present Sino-Japanese conflict the most important fact bearing on the question of neutrality seems to have been lost sight of.

Langford Clinton Whitford, prominent Western New York contractor, died of a heart atttack at his homer here early today. He was 49. Mr. Whitford built many of the Larger civic, educational and industrial structures in this section of the State.
Jimmy Wilson signed today to manage the Philadelphia National League baseball team for the fifth consecutive season, ending rumors he would be dismissed.

Complete separation of mentally defective persons and ordinary criminals in diagnostic procedure and institutional care was recommended yesterday by witnesses before the legislative committee investigating sex crimes at a hearing in the County Court House.

George M. Cohan, star of the new musical, "I'd Rather Be Right," which opened here Monday night, today disclosed that he had refused to sing a lyric about Alfred E. Smith because of his friendship for the former Governor of New York.

Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-James Heavey, from office of the Second Deputy Police Commissioner, Division of Licenses to 61st Precinct, assignment to duty as Inspector of Licensed Hacks continued.

Nominations of three bishops for election as Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States were presented to the triennial general convention today by a joint commission of the House of Bishops and the House of Clerical and Lay Deputies.

The board of directors of the Rudolph Wurlitzer Company has addressed to holders of preferred stock a proposal to offer in lieu of the $36.75 of dividends in arrears to Oct. 1, 1937, $6.75 in cash and one and one-half shares of common stock, to be provided from shares now held in the treasury of the company and listed on the Cincinnati Stock Exchange.

The ophilus Baker Stork of Philadelphia, a retired member of the Pennsylvania bar and for many years a Summer resident of Jamestown, R. I., died in his apartment at the La Forge here this afternoon. He was in his eighty-fourth year. He was seized with a heart attack last evening.

Among seven factors retarding the sale of income properties held by large institutional investors, the most important is that income is not produring a return capable of supporting the investment, C. A. Mullenix,

One of the fondest dreams of the Bronx, the borough of the universities-a Bronx Symphony Orchestra-has apparently been dashed, it was learned yesterday. So scant an audience attended the orchestra's debut that the remaining six concerts are scheduled to be given in Manhattan.
The Industries Capital Corporation of New York has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 10,000

In his campaign for recognition as a contender, Dean Detton, former claimant of the world heavyweight title, last night made short work of Wally Dusek, Nebraskan, before 1,500 at the Hippodrome. With an airplane spin and body slam, Detton pinned Dusek in 19 minutes 54 seconds.

State Senator John J. Dunnigan, president pro tern of the Senate, announced tonight the list of Senators to represent the upper house tomorrow at the funeral of former Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills at St. Thomas Church, New York. Mr. Mills had served in the State Senate.

Mrs. Elizabeth Davies Dayton, widow of Henry Dayton, former insurance broker of New York, died at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Godfrey Van Deusen Titsworth, here today at the age of 86. Mrs. Dayton was founder and first president of the Greenwich Travel Club. Besides her daughter,

Midnight tomorrow is the deadline for payment of the final installment of the normal State income tax. Payments may be made in person at the office of the Income Tax Bureau in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street, or sent either there or to Albany by mail.

Yale conquered Williams by 4-2 at soccer today. Captain Bill Carter of Yale, whose twin brother, George, played with Williams; Tom Erickson and Billingsley excelled for the Eli team. Davis and Hadley were outstanding for the losers.

Two employes of Henry Ford were accused today of being active in dissemination of Nazi propaganda in the United States. John L. Spivak of New York named them at a hearing before a special legislative commission investigating Nazi, Fascist, Communist and Ku Klux Klan activities in Massachusetts.

Since the inauguration of their first national advertising campaign about three months ago, the Olympio Knitting Mills have increased sales volume on their Tish-U-Knit sweaters 75 per cent over that for last year, William Katz, president, announced yesterday.

Changing financial relationships between Federal, State and municipal governments have caused abandonment of the type of local governments which characterized early American democracy, Carl H. Chatters,

Twenty-fifth National Panhellenic Congress opens at Beekman Tower at 9 A. M. and continues Friday and Saturday. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Rugs: Asia Minor," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.; the medieval collection, general tour, 2 P. M.

Declaring that Louis Bickhofer, 38 years old, a New York apartment superintendent, was arrested unjustifiably last June 26 as a parole violator, Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme ordered his release from Sing Sing Prison today and said he believed Bickhofer had been crippled for life by New York police when they seized him.

Because Jimmy Stout was alert to his opportunities, Felix Spatola's Wise Prince, 13-5, got up in the stretch to win the Blue Point Class B Handicap at Jamaica yesterday and completed a consecutive double for the popular rider.
After four years with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Thomas J. Donegan, 30 years old, was promoted today to special agent in charge of the F. B. I.'s New Jersey office.

There are no indications of an immediate increase in the volume of railway traffic unless business becomes more active, Fred W. Sargent, president of the Chicago North Western Railway, said yesterday.

At a time when momentous events and clashing philosophies in both the nation and the world are affecting economic and political patterns with startling rapidity, the women of America must adopt a more militant attitude toward public affairs, speakers told a conference of club women here today.
A elegation of the American Legion arrived in Brussels from England today and was welcomed at the railroad station by Belgian veterans with flags.

The Roosevelt administration, in promoting Federal and individual spending, distribution of wealth and purchasing power, and maintenance of "absurdly low" interest rates, is menacing the nation's foundation of thrift, a group of business men and economists dedared yesterday at a conference at the Hotel Commodore, arranged by the Thrift and Security Foundation.

Mrs. Walter E. Wilke, 30 years old, of 16 Valley View Drive, wife of a New York City insurance broker, was injured fatally about 7 o'clock this evening when her automobile jumped a curb and crashed into a tree on Miller Road near MacCullough Avenue here.
The Haverford soccer team defeated the Stevens Tech varsity by 1-0 today. Spectacular saves by Dearborn checked the winners until the third period, when Taylor scored.

Funeral services for Staff Captain Joseph Garabed, retired, more familiarly known as "Joe the Turk," who for more than fifty years served as an officer of the Salvation Army and who was the first man to solicit funds dressed as Santa Claus, were conducted yesterday morning at the New York Temple Corps Auditorium of the Salvation Army, 120 West Fourteenth Street. Joe the Turk,

John C. Gebhart, director of the National Economy League, said yesterday afternoon that, although the President and other responsible Government financial officials may realize the need of balancing the Federal budget, Congress and large groups, which benefit from recovery expenditures, would make a balance difficult to achieve.

Complete marcel waving in full view of the audience in the Coiffure Guild of New York challenge shield for 1938 contest, a trophy valued at $1,000, was a feature of the program last night at the annual convention of the National and New York State Hairdressers and Cosmotologists Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The General Air Traffic Rules, forming one of the most important chapters in the revised and recodified Civil Air Regulations, have been signed by Secretary Roper. They become effective Nov. 1. Under this division of the regulations, Chapter 60, private, chartered commercial and airline traffic are to be governed.

Bainbridge Ave (12-3295), w s, 92 s of 198th St, 74x94; A. Neurad. Inc, to Ansal Realty Inc, 2,869 Grand Concourse. Henry Hudson Pkwy (13-3415T), s s, 31 E. of Delafield Ave, 31x67; Caroline L. Iselin to Camille J. Brady, 420 W 235th St. Olinville Ave (16-4646), e s, n of 1st St, 50x 100; Barbara Hatlak to Joseph M. Skibo, 537 E 11th St.

Holding its longest drill of the week, the Holy Cross Crusaders worked until dark today in preparing for Georgia. Captain Bob Mautner was in togs after an absence of three weeks, but it is doubtful if he will start Saturday.

Lajos Freiman, Hungarian-born portrait painter, died yesterday of a heart malady at the Knickerbocker Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old. Mr. Freiman was born April 26, 1870. He had been in this country since he was 16.

An invitation to the Netherlands to send a team of army officers to compete in the international jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 3-10 has been accepted, it was announced yesterday.
The International Intercollegiate Hockey League schedule for the 1937-38 season was announced today as follows:

The New York University women's field hockey team will play six games this season, it was announced yesterday by Miss Frances V. Froatz, director of women's athletics. Hofstra College will be met in the opener on Saturday, Oct. 30, at Hempstead.

Miss Vera Montgomery, candidate for the city council who sought to withdraw in favor of B. Charney Vladeck, American Labor party council candidate, after the final day for declinations, only to find it could not be done, announced yesterday that she would continue actively in the race.

The Polish-American Tennis Club tendered a farewell dinner last night at the George' Washington Hotel to Mile. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, tennis champion of Poland and finalist in the American tennis championships at Forest Hills, prior to her sailing for home on the Gdynia-American liner Pilsudski.

The State of South Dakota has invited bankers to submit bids on Oct. 20 for a new issue of $1,000,000 of rural credit refunding bonds. The issue will be dated Nov. 15, 1937, and will mature on Nov. 15, 1947.

Although his team bowed to the Philadelphia Eagles last Sunday, Cliff Battles of the Washington Redskins reeled off 132 yards in that contest to forge ahead, in the race for individual ground-gaining honors of the National Football League.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 13.--A caravan of automobiles carried scores of persons in a historical pilgrimage today, celebrating the first settlement of the white man in this area. It was part of the ceremonies in the 250th anniversary celebration of the founding of this city.
The New Hampshire Racing Commission today granted an extension of the Fall meeting at Rockingham Park, Salem, until Nov. 6, providing no other New England track operates.
A more highly trained personnel, supported by the understanding of the community, was declared today by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to be a chief need of the nation's penal institutions.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas increased 2 per cent for the week ended Oct. 9, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure compares with a rise of 1 per cent for the preceding week.

MANHATTAN ANDREWS, JOSEPH (Sept. 29). Estate, more than $20,000. To Theodosia B. Andres, widow, executrix, 254 Chestnut St., Englewood N. J. Bank of New York and Trust Co., 48 Wall St., excutor. BATTERSBY, RICHARD (Aug. 5). Estate $8,100.

Miss Anne Woods, daughter of Mrs. Michael Woods of 500 West 112th Street, and the late Mr. Woods, was married yesterday morning in Notre Dame Church, 114th Street and Morningside Drive, to Dr. John O'Shea of Weehawken, N. J. The Rev. Martin J. Carroll, first assistant to the pastor, performed the ceremony.

In its invasion of China, Japan feels that it is "merely copying the morality and ideology of the West," Dr. Paul Monroe, president of the World Federation of Education Association, told more than 300 students and faculty members yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University.
With only one more day of intensive practice remaining, Coach Benny Friedman sent the City College football squad through its complete repertoire of plays yesterday at Lewisobn Stadium.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 13,000, Including 3,000 directs.
Easing off on the extensive practice of previous days, Coach Ossie Solem today confined contact work for the Syracuse squad to a short scrimmage with the freshmen.

Exports to Czechoslovakia from this-country during the first eight months of this year more than doubled those in the like period of 1936, Dr. J. Kose, deputy director general of the Czechoslovak Export Institute and president of the American Institute in Prague, said yesterday before the first Fall luncheon meeting of the AmericanCzechoslovak Chamber of Commerce, held in Block Hall, 23 South William Street.
Between April 30 and Sept. 30 the Atlas Corporation bought 192,119 shares of its own common stock, $5 par value, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Dr. Hugh S. Cumming, former surgeon general of the United States, who has been delegated by President Roosevelt to attend the meeting of the permanent committee of the International Health Office, opening in Paris Sunday, sailed yesterday on the President Harding of the United States Lines.

Fighting in the Shanghai sector continued today, Japanese artillery incessantly pounding the Chapel, Kiangwan and Lotien sectors north of the International Settlement but with seemingly small effect. Machine gunning adjacent to the international areas caused the British Royal Ulster Rifles Regiment temporarily to abandon patrol posts on the fringe of the fighting.

Commissioner Warren Dixon Jr., young professor at Newark Law School, who has been investigating municipal affairs for the Supreme Court for nine months, today charged the five City Commissioners who held office duing the four-year
