Wilbur Rothar, the Bronx janitor who attempted to defraud George Palmer Putnam, the publisher, of $2,000, under the pretext that he could take him to his wife, Amelia Earhart, two weeks after she vanished in a flight over the Pacific Ocean, was committed yesterday to the Matteawan State Hospital as insane.

Eleven men were injured, four seriously, when a truck carrying thirty-six men overturned in the westbound tube of the Holland Tunnel about 1,000 feet from the New York entrance, shortly before 7 o'clock this morning.

Leo P. Dorsey, former State manager of the Home Owners Loan Corportion, was sworn in yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler as a member of the State Mortgage Commission, which is attempting to assist investors in guaranteed real estate mortgages recoup their funds.

Samuel Untermyer and Samuel Leibowitz informed Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins yesterday that each had grave doubts as to his ability to pass the examinations now given candidates for admission to the bar.

Walter P. Meinhardt, naval architect, died yesterday at the age of 55. For nearly eighteen years he had been with the Maryland Dry dock Company as navl architect. Previously he was with the Great Lakes Engineering Company of Detroit and the American Shipbuilding Compmy of Cleveland.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, candidate for re-election, was ignored by the board of directors of the New York County Lawyers Association in its list of endorsements for judicial office, it was disclosed yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia gave unstinted praise yesterday to Stanley M. Isaacs, Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, as a man whose qualifications not even his opponents would challenge.
A Great Plains of the future, with more "wide open spaces" than now, and its population clustered along life-giving streams, was pictured today to the National Reclamation Association.

Johns Hopkins University has solved the football financing problem to the great joy of fans-everybody goes to the games on passes. There'll be ticket-takers at the Hopkins-Washington College game Friday night, but all they'll do will be glance at "guest cards" available to all askers for exactly nothing.

Dr. Leslie Haden Guest, running as a Laborite, has won the North Islington parliamentary seat from the Conservatives. In a by-election caused by the death of the sitting member, Colonel A. W. Goodman, he polled 13,523 votes against 12,227 for the Conservative candidate, Sir Wilfred Sugden, thus turning the Conservative majority of 3,385 in the general election into a Laborite surplus of 1,296.

More than 200 members of the bench and bar-Catholics, Jews and Protestants- gathered in St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church yesterday morning for a Red Mass to invoke divine wisdom and blessing on the advent of the Michaelmas term of the courts. They heard severe criticism of the legal profession from a priest and doctor of laws.

Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll and yesterday tha tthe sventy-foot pole that had been erected on the roof of the Borough Hall Subway station in Brooklyn to carry a banner of Maylor La Guardia was legal.

The Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce has been informed from Havana that Cuba's export trade in raw sugar from Jan. 1 to Sept. 15, 1937, amounted to 2,123,388 long tons, compared with 2,075,597 in the same period in 1936.

Under the caption, "Roosevelt's Good Behavior Speech," the Berliner Tageblatt comments: "The proclamation of the American determination for peace, which President Roosevelt has brought forward several times in the past few days, does not exactly gain weight from repetition.
Four Atlantic liners are due today from Europe with 6,015 passengersthe Europa with 1,970, the Normandie with 1,570, the Rex with 1,586 and the Washington with 889.

Prices were steady or slightly lower yesterday in most of the local commodity futures markets, although cottonseed oil futures rose briskly in active dealings and hides and silk improved moderately in price. On the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, flour and cotton gained,

Alf M. Landon, Republican candidate for President in 1936, is seeking the support of members of his party in Congress in opposition to a midterm convention favored by former President Hoover and Frank O. Lowden.

Minimum retail prices for several of its branded cigar products under the Feld-Crawford act were established yesterday by P. Lorillard Company, Inc., the largest company in the industry which has taken price action under the price maintenance law thus far, it was announced yesterday by William A. Hollingsworth, president of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc.
Tallulah Bankhead was warmly received by an audience here tonight for her portrayal of Cleopatra in the premiere of Laurence Rivers's Production of the Shakespeare version of "Antony and Cleopatra."

Twenty students from thirteen States and one foreign country have enrolled in the Cooperative League Institute, a college for prospective cooperative executives, Dr. James P. Warbasse, director of the institute and president of the Cooperative League, announced yesterday.

Funeral services for Albert J. Bone, mining engineer and metallurgist, were held on Monday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Cathedral, Toronto. Burial took place on Tuesday at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Mount Pleasant, N. Y. Mr. Bone, who was 56 years old. died in Toronto on Friday.

Twenty leaders of foreign-born groups pledged their support to Mayor La Guardia yesterday when they visited him at City Hall. Francis X. Mancuso, former General Sessions judge, led the group and introduced its members to the Mayor.

A Joint Conference on the Constitutional Convention was formed last night by representatives of more than twenty-five organizations who met at the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street, under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild.

New methods of studying the protein molecule, most important constituent of living matter, have opened up new means for the preparation of more powerful serums for disease, and also promise to provide medical science with new methods for diagnosis,
Captain J. C. Townley, who has commanded the Cunard White Stat liner Queen Mary for eight consecutive voyages, is now master of the Aquitania, which sailed yesterdays He will remain on that ship.
A declaration signed by forty-two politicians, among whom are former Premiers Tsankoff and Malinoff, was handed to King Boris's private secretary tonight.
Gold imports in September amounted to $145,623,466, the Department of Commerce reported today. This compared with $105,013,011 in August and $171,866,183 in September, 1936.

The Coats twins, with the aid of the judiciary, corrected today what they said was their last mistake. They got their marriages to the Sharpe twins annulled, on the ground that they were not divorced from their first husbands.

A silk mill payroll of $6,400 was stolen here this morning by bandits who escaped in two automobiles. The money was taken from Alfred Buchner of 258 Illinois Avenue, paymaster for the Audiger Meyer Silk Company of 208 Twentieth Avenue.

Joe McCarthy, who has just finished piloting his New York Yankees to their second successive world championship over the New York Giants, was inducted yesterday into the Circus Saints and Sinners at the organization's first luncheon of the season at the Hotel Commodore. Mayor La Guardia, an unexpected visitor at the luncheon and a- veteran member of the Saints, congratulated Mr. McCarthy just before his initiation.

Development of an atmosphere of security rather than authority, discussion of taboo questions within the family . circle, admission of one's mistakes and participation in games together were urged as means to establish happy family relationships at yesterday's session in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria of the Parents and Teachers Conference.

President Roosevelt's call for a special session of Congress was criticized yesterday at a luncheon of the Board of Trade, Inc., at the Hotel Astor as offering little encouragement for business and industry. Percy C. Magnus, president of the board, set forth this view.

Brown concentrated on forward passing in another lengthy drill today. The varsity polished its aerial game in a scrimmage against the reserves, who had been drilled in Dartmouth plays, to perfect the pass defense. The drill was the third this wek on forwards.
John Henderson Whitehead hurled the American League to another victory at Wrigley Field today as the White Sox conquered the Cubs, 6 to 1, for their fourth consecutive Chicago championship.

The National Association of Food Chains, ending its fourth annual convention sessions here at the Hotel Mayflower today, went on record as favoring an intensive drive to acquaint the consuming public with the economies in operation that have been achieved by this group in the field of mass distribution.

The State bank division of the American Bankers Association, which is the largest and, at the moment, the dominant division of the organization, adopted today resolutions declaring "unalterable opposition to branch banking across State lines,"

Trouble which had been brewing for several weeks broke out in the taxicab industry yesterday when drivers opposed to the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, went on strike in three garages operated by the Sunshine Radio System.

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Com-mission ordered today public hearings on Oct. 21 into fares charged by the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company. The commission disclosed that it had information indicating present rates were "unjust and unreasonable, and produce an excessive rate of return."
A switch in the cast for its women's prison story, "Condemned Women," has been made by R K O. The picture was to have been made as a small-budget picture with Sally Eilers and Lee Patrick,

While, business failures declined in three business groups in the week ended Oct. 7, compared with the corresponding period last year, two other groups, manufacturing and wholesale, showed increases, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. The detailed report is as follows:

Revell McCallum, in 901 Lexington Ave.; Chauncey De Pew Steele, in 21 E 99th St, Mrs. Livingston Lund, in 39 W 55th St; Gertrude R. Cummings, in 136 E 36th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers. Russell Pratt, in Barbizon Plaza, Central Park South.

PARIS, Oct. 13.--The powerful People's Front-union of Leftist parties that has governed France since Leon Blum came to power in May, 1936-split openly tonight over the same united front election program that put them in office.

About this little town and for miles around dogs are barking tonight, and they are not barking at the moon. Tomorrow about one thousand dogs will go on the auction block under the hammer of Nathaniel Bacon Kinsey.

Pleas for party unity and pledges of it from the leaders of the Democratic organizations in the city, in their campaign to recapture City Hall, were sounded last night at "ratification meetings" at Tammany Hall and in the Bronx and Brooklyn.

Stocks recovered after declining sharply to lowest levels since July, 1935, but closed lower; turnover, 2,567,030 shares, the largest since last March. United States Government bonds steady, Italian and Japanese loans rallied, other bonds weak; transactions, $10,344,075.

The 1937 international exhibition of paintings will open here with a reception and preview tomorrow evening, immediately after the founder's day exercises in Carnegie Music Hall. The canvases are hung,

Miss Jean Forsch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Forsch, has chosen Nov. 10 as the date for her marriage to Hugh Russell Jackson of this city, son of Mrs. Dellem O. Jackson of Lexington, Ky., and the late Mr. Jackson. The wedding will take place in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

The National Bituminous Coal Commission granted today exemption from the bituminous coal code under the Guffey-Vinson act to the Wheeling Steel Corporation in respect to the mine it owns at Beechbottom, W. Va., and the output of which it consumes.

Mr. and Mrs. Ed. ward Atkinson St. John of New York gave a party tonight at the Greenbrier for Mr. and Mrs. Wade Fetzer, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Fetzer, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford C. Jones, Miss Jean Baniff, Thomas Baniff, Thomas L. Bean, James H. Henry, Thomas J. Graham, John M. Haines, John T. Harrison, A. Duncan Reed and John G. Goetz.

A second fight over the millon-dollar estate of Ruth Roland was threatened today. L. E. Kent, Miss Roland's first husband and her manager for twenty year, declared in Probate Court that she made a gift of a $38,000 trust deed to him during a
Interest rates may be expected to fall instead of rise, as generally expected, Dr. David Friday of Washington, an economist, asserted today in an address before the American Life Convention.

MANHATTAN BUTLER, NELLIE (May 18, 1937). Gross assets, $34,124; net, $32,454. To Bridget Butler, sister. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $28,244. B. Robert Bodner, attorney, 291 Broadway. COHN, GEORGE (Sept. 21, 1936). Gross assets, $35,957; net, $34,349.

After the Yale varsity put in two hours of scrimmage, with defense emphasized, in a secret practice in the Bowl today, Head Coach Ducky Pond told the squad that it had not had enough drill to run the new plays smoothly.

A United States radio man was wounded, but not seriously, on the flagship Augusta last night when a Japanese shell burst near the river bank on the Pootung side. Several shell fragments hit the Augusta's decks.

HANOVER, N. H.. Oct. 13.--Dartmouth staged another long scrimmage today as Coach Earl Blaik drove his team for the Brown game at Providence Saturday. The Indians worked defensively against Tuss McLaughry's triple wing-back formations, with the jayvees having little success against the varsity line.
Former Supreme Court Justice John R. Vunk of Patchogue was sworn in as District Attorney of Suffolk County today by Supreme Court Justice Philip A. Brennan.

Events this week indicate that adjustment of steel production to the current small volume of handto-mouth buying has been virtually completed, according to Iron Age. In the Wheeling area, where sheet and strip capacity is an important factor,

That considerable portion of the football followers of New York, waiting since the start of the season for the first glimpse of just how much this year's edition of the Fordham team has to offer, begins to get the answer tonight.
Discover of the skeleton of an infant in a cave near Great Salt Lake has provided science with a missing link in the story of man in North America, the Smithsonian Institution stated today.

Setting what both parties to the transaction doubtless hope will be an admirable example for their ball players next Spring, Marse Joe McCarthy, head man of the world champion Yankees, and his employer, Colonel Jacob Ruppert, lost little time yesterday coming to terms on a new contract to take the place of the one that expired this season.

Mrs. F. Ronald Mansbridge has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss Janet St. Clair Mullan of 225 East Seventy-ninth Street, daughter of the late State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. George Vincent Mullan, to Frederick G. Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Duncan of 1 East Eighty-seventh Street.

Federal agents today back-tracked the outlaw trail of the Al Brady gang, which yesterday came to an abrupt end when two of its members perished in a hail of machinegun bullets and the third was captured.

The New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards will hold its monthly luncheon meeting tomorrow at the Maplewood Country Club, Maplewood. Samuel D. Walker, president, will preside. The Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood will be host to the meeting.

An amendment to rules under the Public Utility Holding Company Act, extending from Jan. 1, 1938, to Jan. 1, 1939, the period in which independent officers or directors of financial institutions may continue to act as officers or directors of registered holding companies or subsidiary companies, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Benny Lynch of Scotland retained his claim to the world flyweight championship tonight with a thirteenth-round knockout of Peter Kane, liverpool slugger. Lynch scaled 111 pounds to 110 for Kane.

Miss Julia Berwind of New York, arrived here this morning, and was joined by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at luncheon. Mr. and Mrs. J. N. Carpenter of Greenwich, Conn., entertained at a cocktail party in the Homestead Club before their departure for. home last evening.

Harry H. Woodring, the Secretary of War, and Mrs. Woodring have come from Washington to the Waldorf-Astoria. President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell have gone to the Traymore, Atlantic City.

The Curb has listed 1,308,049 issued and 218,008 unissued shares of American Republics Corporation common capital stock, $10 par value, and voting trust certificates representing 465,113 issued and 128,231 unissued shares of Hartford Rayon Corporation common stock.
Canon G. L. Craven, representative of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster, has resigned from the organization responsible for bringing the Basque child refugees here.

The threat of a general labor tie-up developing from the struggle between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization for control of lumber workers worried Portland tonight.

5th Ave. 2,089; 4-story tenement. 75x100: Lart Corp. against Conde Realty Corp.; due, $8,921; sub to mortgage of $85,000; to plaintiff for $92.600. 109th St, 26 E; 5-story tenement, 31.3x 100.1 irr; Central Savings Bank in the City of New York against Bailiwick, Inc.; due, $22,150; taxes, etc, $853; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The extra session of Congress conveing Nov. 15 will be able to begin early consideration of the Wages and Hours Bill, on the basis of assurances attributed today to Chairman John J. O'Connor of the House Rules Committee.

Experimental evidence indicating that old age may be the result of the body changing its tissues to build up defenses against accumulating poisons, which may open the way to a new approach in the study of the aging process and the possibility of postponing it by chemical

The officers who will direct the affairs of two leading New York realty organizations for the coming year were chosen yesterday. The Real Estate Board of New York selected Clarke G. Dailey to suoceed himself as president of that group, and the Brooklyn Real Estate Board named Frank M. McCurdy as its head, to succeed Melville A. Kelsey.

Frank J. O'Malley, Superintendent of Police, reported a "back-to-work" movement' today among workers at furniture factories here, where strikes have been called by the United Automobile Workers of America.

Following is the statement of 175 Catholic clergymen and laymen in reply to the open letter of 150 Protestant clergymen and laymen who took issue with the pastoral letter of the Spanish hierarchy on the Spanish civil war:

The Duke of Windsor was made acquainted today with the principles on which National Socialism is creating its own aristocracy for the new Third Reich and inspected one of the four "castles" in which its scions are being trained for their future roles.
A temporary traffic jam marked the inauguration of the West Side Express Highway on Tuesday. Several people got into a tangle on

The trial of sixteen intellectuals accused of plotting against the Government ended last midnight with twelve convictions and four acquittals. Eight, including Rodolfo Morandi, writer, were sentenced to ten years' penal servitude, one to four years and three to three years.

In a decision filed here today Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief granted a preference on the November trial calendar to Frederick Grewen of New Rochelle in his $100,000 automobile damage suit against Mrs. James Roosevelt and Louis E. De Pew, both of New York. Mrs. Roosevelt is the mother of the President and De Pew is her chauffeur.

The Brooklyn College football squads. resumed practice yesterday after the Columbus Day respite. The Kingsmen reported in. poor physical condition as a result of their hard-fought contest with Rensselaer.
Stockholders of the Francisco Sugar Company have approved amendments to by-laws in conformity with listing requirements of the New York Stock Exchange.

Kathleen Long, English pianist, who made her American debut at the Town Hall last night, is the season's first newcomer from overseas. The character of her program and the quality of its performance stamped her as a desirable alien.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage on Oct. 23 at St. James Episcopal Church, My Lady's Manor, of Miss Elizabeth Sparks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Alan Sparks, to Wallace Dow of Lynn, Mass.

John H. Dwyer, civil engineer who was actively identified with the development of rapid transit in Brooklyn for fifty years, died on Tuesday night in his home at 531 Third Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

New Deal policies were praised and -condemned today by speakers at the general session of the annual convention of the American Bankers Association here. The praise was faint; it was limited to the endorsement of the reciprocal trade treaties negotiated by Secretary of State Cordell Hull and came in the course of a discussion of the outlook for foreign trade by Eliot Wadsworth, chairman of the American section of the International Chamber of Commerce.

The Rose Bowl champions are coming- to town Saturday. The team that beat Washington at Pasadena Jan. 1 has a rendezvous with Fordham at the Polo Grounds and by general consent it's tagged the class of the East.
The task of rebuilding hsi backfield, hard hit by the sudden loss of George Peck with a back injury, was started tonight by Cornell's coach, Carl Snavley.

In view of the unsettled condition in securities markets and because it is deemed no longer advantageous to the company, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., withdrew yesterday from prospective offering to the public of its proposed refunding issue of $60,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent debentures included in a proposed financing program aggregating $80,000,000 of debentures.

The spirit of Moon Path, an Indian from away back, dissolved today in the cold light of science. Experts at the Bureau of Ethnology, after listening to a record of Moon Path's "revelations" at a spiritualist seance, announced that the ethereal redskin spoke a language unknown to them and that his account of life with his ancestors 300 years ago did not check with known facts.

John V. Jewell, chairman of the board of directors of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank of Brooklyn since 1934, died suddenly of a heart attack this morning at his home, 113 Nassau Boulevard, here. Mr. Jewell, whose banking career in Brooklyn began more than half a century ago, was in his eightyeighth year.

HANS OTTO STORM'S short novel about an American engineer in Peru* has something that most novels, short or long, never come within a mile of having-enough vigor and directness to make the reader overlook whatever he may not wholly like about it and admire the rest.

Secretary of Commerce Roper commented today on the gradual downward trend of imports since March, and said he was impressed with "the tendency, prevailing at present, for exports to be sustained somewhat above present revels and for the value of imports to contract."

Leonard Bright, Socialist candidate for City Councilman here, issued a statement today proposing that Westchester County condemn property of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad and operate the railroad as a county enterprise.

W. T. Walsh will leave here about Oct. 23 for New York City with a truck loaded with Matanuska potatoes and canned salmon. The truck will be ferried to Prince Rupert, B. C., and then go under its own power, driven by Al Radero.

At the annual meeting of shareholders of the Electric Bond and Share Company here yesterday, C. E. Groesbeck, chairman of the board, described the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 as a deliberate attempt by the Federal Government to remake the utility map of the United States.

Short Stories, Inc., in 9 Rockefeller Plaza, Rockefeller Center. Omon Van Dyck, studio in 535 Fifth Ave; William H. M. Riker and George Robinson (Par Co). toys, penthouse in 14 W 23d St; Puritan Fruit Products Co., in 213 W 29th St; James Bell, in 292 Madison Ave, through Cushman Wakefield; Rapid Service Co., advertising, in 280 Madison Ave, through Albert B Ashforth, Inc; Cross Brown Co, brokers.

The text of President Roosevelt's address today at the cornerstone laying for Poughkeepsie's new postoffice was as follows: I have come today, not in an official capacity, not to make a speech, but as one of your neighbors to take part in your celebration.

The text of the note delivered today by Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, to the Belgian Minister, pledging the German Government to respect the inviolability-and territorial integrity of Belgium, follows:

At the conclusion of his Chicago speech a week ago President Roosevelt left hanging in mid-air the question of what he meant concretely by a "concerted effort" on the part of the peaceloving nations to uphold the principles of international law. He did not answer this question in his fireside talk on Tuesday.

After a year's investigation, Chairman Paul R. Jordan said today he was about ready to recommend to the Amateur Athletic Union Records Committee recognition of Jesse Owens as holder of the world 100-meter dash mark.

THE tourist traffic will be rather heavy this Saturday. Princeton hikes off to Chicago, Tulane comes North to meet Colgate; Georgia rambles up to tackle Holy Cross and Harvard takes a sleeper-jump to play Navy at Baltimore. It has been some time since John Harvard went farther than Princeton or New Haven to play a football game. Maybe Ornithologist Harlow's 1937 Harvard team has stronger wings.

Bob Pastor, Washington Heights heavyweight who made a name for himself by staying ten rounds with Joe Louis, will appear in a bout at Madison Square Garden next month under the direction of Promoter Mike Jacobs, if present plans materialize.
BREAD AND CIRCUSES, by Willson Whitman., (Oxford, $1.75.) A study of the Federal Theatre. THE REST OF MY LIFE, by Carolyn Wells. (Lippincott, $2.75.) Autobiography.

The tapering off of the Public Works Administration and the reorganization of the agency on a regional basis forced Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director, yesterday to notify fifty-one members of his engineering and clerical staff that their services would end on Nov. 1.

For the first time since the establishment of WPA a group of relief workers will be graded and paid on the basis of the amount they produce, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday. The change will apply to 2,114 employes of the WPA sewing project, and its effectiveness as a spur to output will be closely watched by Federal relief officials here.

Since the President, in his latest fireside chat, did not give any answers to many of the most active questions in the public mind, it is probable his radio speech left many wondering why he had made it at all.

Formations designed to stop the running attack of Villanova at Ebbets Field Saturday were given to the Manhattan football team by Coach Chick Meehan in a stiff twohour drill at Innisfail Park yesterday.

Bonds suffered yesterday another severe decline in the heaviest trading on the New York. Stock Exchange since May 7. Domestic corporation issues of virtually-all descriptions were forced to new low levels.

The Libbey-Owens-FordGlass Company in its report for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $8,848,159 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings.

Mrs. Mary Ingersoll Sterling, widow of a law associate of Joseph H. Choate, one-time Ambassador to England, died today. Mrs. Sterling, who made her debut in Washington, was married to Willis Betts Sterling in New York in 1891.

Three tiny Negroes, only slightly awed by their arrival in this city of tall buildings and large crowds, became the temporary wards of the Travelers Aid Society yesterday morning, when they reached here unaccompanied from Florida.
Arthur A. Madison, formerly Father Divine's chief legal adviser, failed yesterday to appear in Supreme Court for a scheduled examination on the finances of Divine's Peace Missions.

Harvard today went through its final hard preparation for Saturday's game with Navy. Coach Dick Harlow held to his intention to have no contact work all week, but the defensive drill was long and thorough, and fully an hour was spent in rehearsing plays, still with the aim toward more precision, speed and timing in the blocking.

The Goncourt Literary Academy today elected Francis Carco as a member to succeed Gaston Cherau, who died last April in Boston, Mass. The Goncourt Academy is made up of ten members and awards a yearly money prize aiming to encourage budding French writers.

The better tendency which developed in the stock market here late yesterday was well maintained today and most sections improved. Bargainhunters again were active and further rises in gilt-edged issues stimulated buying in general.

The Propeller Club of the United States adopted a resolution today demanding that Government agencies take immediate steps "to permanently stop and prevent any future distuption of American shipping" by radical elements which are "attempting to seize control of transportation."
The report of the Electric Bond and Share Company for the third quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows that net income after expenses and charges amounted to $2,571,601.

Correction Paragraph II, Special Order 185, Oct. 11. 1937, in so far as it relates to applications being received from members for the examination for promotion to the rank of lieutenant in this department, is corrected to read.

H. C. Hagen has sold his Colonial-style dwelling on Woodlawn Drive, Plandrome, L. I., to Thomas Lavery, sales manager of the International Cellucotton Products Company. The house, of eight rooms, is constructed of stone and clapboard and is situated on Mapproximately one-third of an acre of ground.

Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education, in a statement issued yesterday, assured "parents, pupils and teachers" that despite the cut in requested appropriations the 1938 school program would not be curtailed nor would any of the scheduled activities be abandoned.

Betty May McCall, 18-year-old Negro who was arrested on a vagrancy charge after admitting, according to the police, that she had faked a story of having witnessed the murders of Frances Hajek and Lewis Weiss of Queens Village, Queens, on Oct. 3, was committed to the Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn, by Magistrate Anthony P. Savarese yesterday for observation.

The complete roster of ninety-two musicians of the new symphony orchestra now being rehearsed for the ten-week broadcast series which Arturo Toscanini will conduct beginning Christmas night over a nation-wide network was announced late yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company.

Establishment of a grievance committee in the insurance industry to cooperate with State authorities in keeping the industry's practices on the highest possible plane was approved last night by Louis H. Pink,

Lieutenant Hank Hardwick, Navy's football coach, is making no secret of his plans for the game between the middies and Harvard in Baltimore Saturday. "I will start the strongest team I can muster, trike hard from the start and keep the first team in the game as long as I can," Hardwick said today.

Mrs. James Todd and Mrs. J. Randall Creel gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Helen Van C. de Peyster, whose marriage to Eric Alexander von Raits will take place here tomorrow. Other guests were Mrs. Duncan Van Norden, Mrs. Spencer Eddy Jr., Mrs. Cruger G. Fowler, Mrs. George Lincoln de Peyster, Mrs. Charles A. Moore 3d, Mrs. William C. T. Gaynor, Mrs.

Whether the small amount of public housing and slum clearance already achieved in New York City is to be credited to Mayor La Guardia, Secretary Ickes, the depression or an old gentleman in Peoria, Ill., who for the present prefers to remain anonymous, may be a matter of dispute up to and including election day.

In a cable today to Secretary of State Cordell Hull, Representative George Holden Tinkham, Republican of Massachusetts, charged Secretary Hull and President Roosevelt with defying the law and Congress by not invoking the Neutrality Act.

The feud between the Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Labor was injected yesterday into the affairs of the Actors Equity Association, an A. F. of L. union, after the disclosure that Miss Edith L. Christension,

The Committee for Industrial Organization formally affirmed the sacredness of union contracts with employers at its session here today. Leaders of the thirty-two national and international unions comprising the C. I. O. voted to adhere to contractual relations in one of three resolutions unanimously adopted.
The New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday listing of 72,531 shares of Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation cumulative prior-preferred 4 1/2, per cent convertible stock, $100 par value;

Counsel for the Government in the oil conspiracy case here brought out today testimony to the effect that changes in the tank-car prices of gasoline between March 1, 1935, and through 1936, the period of the alleged conspiracy to fix prices, were substantially fewer than in the two years immediately preceding.

Charging that the recent open letter of Protestant clergymen and laymen "misrepresented the facts and issues in sapin," and calling for the end of all foreign intervention on both sides in the Spanish civil war,
Government policies were put under scrutiny today as the League of Women Voters began a three-day State meeting here.

Mayor La Guardia was criticized by a speaker at the Board of Estimate hearing on the tentative 1938 budget yesterday for favoring the "Reds" too much, while a spokesman for the New York State division of the Communist party told him he would be a better Mayor if i he were "pushed to the Left."

Democratic leaders of communities in Westchester and Rockland counties embraced by the Twenty-fifth Cngressional District tonight nominated Homer A. Stebbins of Hastings as their candidate for Representative in the November election.

Coach Lou Little continued to concentrate on the task of fashioning an adequate reserve team yesterday as Columbia prepared for its battle with Penn on Saturday at Baker Field. Although the work of the whole squad was varied, defensive tactics formed the keynote for the practice.

Frank H. Parsons, lawyer and banker, who was treasurer and a trustee of Adelphi College, Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home 200 Hicks Street, Brooklyn. He was born in Brooklyn, had lived there all his life, and was prominent in many Brooklyn organizations.

What's going on around here anyway? Everything looks reasonable enough in the program of "In Clover," which was trounced up and down at the Vanderbilt last evening. Allan Scott, co-author of "Good-bye Again" and affluent scenarist, appears in clear type as the author.

Coach Mal Stevens will be forced to make several important changes in his line-up when New York University meets St. John's College of Annapolis Saturday at Ohio Field. The series of injuries to the Violet squad will make it necessary for reserves to start at left end, left guard and center.

American Legionnaire Stephen Vincent Kenney died of a heart attack at the maritime station here today as he was about to board the Queen Mary. He was accompanied by his mother and a sister. Mr. Kenney was 50 years old. His residence was in Brooklyn, N. Y.

Henry George Zander, widely known in real estate and civic circles, died late last night at his home in Barrington, Ill., after a brief illness. He was 68 years old. Mr. Zander was chairman of the board of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago, past vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, past president of the Chicago Real Estate Board and of the Civic Federation of Chicago.

Milton C. Weisman, receiver for the Fox Theatres Corporation, was authorized yesterday by Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to accept $22,500 in settlement of its suits for $1,577,500 against the American a Telephone and Telegraph Company, Western Electric, Inc., and Electrical Research Products, Inc.

Walter W. Stewart was elected yesterday president of Case, Pomeroy, Inc., to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Walter S. Case. Mr. Stewart formerly was chairman of the board. Hadley Case, who has been with the company for two years, was elected a director to succeed his father.

Inspired by the recent success of the stoppage by retail kosher meat dealers to enforce lower prices by wholesalers, the organized smoked fish jobbers of the city will begin a similar movement this morning.

In a memorable address delivered nearly forty years ago by Mr. Justice Holmes (whom thousands came to know as "The Captain" long before he was known as a member of the United States Supreme Court) he spoke of the things the men of the North learned from "noble enemies in Virginia or Georgia or out on the Mississippi":

The colors of Hal Price Headley, president of Keeneland Park and owner of the 2-year-old champion, Menow, were again carried to victory today when Heritage scored by a nose in a featured allowance race for juveniles.

Characterizing the condition of the 3,000,000 Jews in Poland as "by far the saddest of any group in Europe," Joseph Baskin, secretarytreasurer of the Workmen's Circle, Jewish labor-fraternal organization with a membership of more than 75,000, declared yesterday that only "the moral intervention of civilized mankind and particularly of the United States can save the Polish Jews from slow extinction."

New York's Court of Appeals was asked today to hold unconstitutional sections of the State Education Law and the New York City Charter permitting the reading of the Bible and assembly of religious groups in public schools.

John Timlin, former Sheriff of Richmond County and chairman of the Republican county committee until poor health caused him to retire last August, died early yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 100 Stuyvesant Place, St. George, S. I. He was 69 years old.

After imposing a prison sentence of five years upon Henri Solliez, former assistant steward on the French liner Paris, who was arrested last Sept. 8, when customs searchers found six pounds of pure heroin in his possession, Federal Judge Samuel Mendelbaum promised to reduce the term if he identified his confederates within ninety days.
Delsgates to the convention of the National Association of City Passenger Agents returned today to business is after electing officers at their fifteenth annual meeting here.

An increase of nearly 20 per cent in the French army budget for 1938 was asked today by the Minister of National Defense, Edouard Daladier. The Minister, in a tentative combination of the ordinary and extraordinary budget submitted to Parliament for study, asked 12,900,000,000 francs for next year, as compared with 10,900,000,000 francs tfor 1937.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today; CUSTOMS 4071--Cohn Lewis v. United States, Argued for both. Appellant grated leave file reply brief instanter;

After a series of sharp speeches in which the National Labor Board, its regional directors and its employes were Mr. raked fore and aft in language seldom heard at American Federation of Labor conventions,...

A banking group headed by F. S. Moseley Co. and including Kean, Taylor Co. and R. W. Pressprich Co. will offer today a new issue of $1,275,000 of 2 3/4 per cent equipment-trust certificates, Series D, of the Texas Pacific Railway.

Pope Pius XI, at the request of Cardinal Hayes, has honored twentyfour priests of the Archdiocese of New York. He has conferred the rank of Domestic Prelate on thirteen and the rank of Cameriere Segreto, or Private Chamberlain, on eleven priests. Announcement of the conferring of the Vatican honor was made yesterday by the Cardinal at his residence, 452 Madison Avenue.

Reports from refining companies owning 89 per cent of the 4,159,000barrel estimated daily potential refining capacity of the United States indicate that the petroleum industry as a whole last week ran 3,350,000 barrels of crude oil to stills daily.

The estate called "Wheatland," from which James Buchanan rode to the White House, will be made a national shrine tomorrow. The great house, where Buchanan spent the last days of his life, bowed by the misfortunes of his administration, has been restored by civic leaders, headed by Lieutenant Colonel James Hale Steinman.

Robertson Honey Jr., 31-year-old lawyer of this city, was lost overboard from the Furness Bermuda liner Monarch of Bermuda on Tuesday evening about 100 miles from New York, it was learned yesterday when the liner docked at West Fifty-fifth Street.

A cooperative enterprise which will link the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and the Carnegie Institute of Technology in a new program of engineering training was announced today by President Doherty of Carnegie Tech.
We went on our last weakfish jaunt yesterday and after some hours of chumming without a single strike gave up and headed for home.

The United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company has purchased the four-story fireproof officebuilding at 71 William Street. adjoining their New York City headquarters at 73-7 William Street, which is on the southwest corner of Liberty Street.

The failure of several amateur players to make an appearance detracted from the initial day's play as the first "open" tennis tourney began today. Four defaults were recorded in the first round's competition.

Deans of women of four local institutions of higher learning will participate in the sessions of the National Panhellenic Congress, opening today at the Beekman Tower Hotel. The national presidents of the twenty-three Greek letter fraternities for women comprising the congress will attend.

Plans for the marriage of Miss Gertrude Laughlin, daughter of Irwin Laughlin, former Ambassador to Spain, and Mrs. Laughlin, to Lieutenant Hubert Winthrop Chanler on Oct. 23 were announced today. The wedding will take place in St. Paul's Church.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today the dates set for oral arguments in the reorganization proceedings of three railroads. The hearing in the Western pacific case before the full commission is scheduled for Nov. 16 and 17, on which days the commission will hear also arguments in the Spokane International reoganization proceedings.

Colonel Mark O. Kimberling, Superintendent of the State Police Department, told a meeting of the State Association of Township Committeemen here today that 200 more troopers are needed for proper enforcement of traffic laws.

A lecture and concert will take place tonight at the meeting of the Harmony Guild of New York, 38 West Tenth Street. The New Singers, beginning their fourth season under the conductorship of Lan Adomian,

Although the National Hockey League race, opening on Nov. 4, will be making the earliest start in its history, neither of the New York clubs will be on view for metropolitan fans during the first week of the campaign.

Dexter Fellows, circus press agent, is ill of influenza in a Hattiesburg infirmary, where he has been a patient for five days. Mrs. Fellows, was was at his bedside, said his temperature had dropped today and that his general condition was improved.
Realty men, economists and builders are paying more and more attention to the possibility of developing that vast untapped market for houses which families of low income can afford to purchase.

The silver jubilee convention of the Girl Scouts convened this morning in the city of its birth and within a stone's throw of the first meeting place of the charter members and Juliette Gordon Low, founder of the organization.

Completion of the East Side Highway is the next important step in the fight to control traffic in the city, spokesmen for commercial and civic organizations declared yesterday as police reported a heavy volume of traffic with some ccngestion on the new West Side improvement linking the West Side Highway with the Henry Hudson Parkway at Dyckman Street.

John C. Lewis of Des Moines, Iowa, member of the Federal Coal Commission, disclosed today a split in the seven-man board over distribution of patronage and personnel. He threatened to resign unless a settlement is reached.

Lawson Purdy will retire today as chairman of the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society after holding that post for twenty years. In recognition of his service he will be guest of honor at noon at a luncheon at the Downtown Association, 60 Pine Street, given by Walter S. Gifford, president of the society.

Aaron E. Manbeck, founder of Central Institute, a commercial private school, which he operated for thirty years, is dead here at the age of 70. Many of his former students, numbered in the thousands, are leaders in the city's business and professional life.

The long-expected Loyalist offensive on the Aragon front is now under way. Large bodies of Valencia-troops are concentrated all along the line with the support of 500 tanks, 200 airplanes and ample artiller,

Cynthia Haynes, 11 years old, a student in the Brearley School in East Eighty-third Street, was so convincingly clear yesterday in her testimony against a Negro burglar in General Sessions that the defendant hastily entered a guilty plea as she left the witness stand. Judge Nott remanded him to the Tombs for sentence Oct. 22 as a second offender.

Plans for a fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building, with stores, to rise at Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street at an estimated -cost of $850,000 were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings.

Joseph F. Coufal, secretary of the City Fusion County- Committee in Queens, offered yesterday to go before the District Attorney to deny charges that certain members had received offers of $5,000 to support George U. Harvey for borough president.
Mrs. E. H. Vare Jr., medalist, was among the favorites to come through the first round of the Berthellyn Cup women's invitation golf tournament over the rain-pelted Huntingdon Valley course today.

The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed from Aug. 1 to Sept. 30, amounted to 972,619 tons, compared to 697,289 tons in the corresponding period a year ago. Cotton seed on hand at mills on Sept. 30 amounted to 988,590 tons, compared to 834,834 a year ago.
Colgate's Red Raiders tapered off today for their intersectional clash with Tulane in Buffalo Saturday. Coach Andy Kerr sent the Maroon through a two-hour drill with emphasis on defensive play.
Making his first start- of the Fall season in this State, Biscayne Blue, running in the silver and gold of the Bomar Stable, led virtually all the way to take the Grade B Handicap today.

Another rearrangement of the Lehigh backfield for the Penn State game on Saturday appeared certain when Jack Beriont, sophomore, was at fullback for practically the entire offensive scrimmage against the freshmen today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13.--Indications of carelessness, perhaps of sabotage, aboard the cruiser Vincennes have been found by a naval board of inquiry, appointed recently by Admiral William Leahy, following a breakdown of reduction gears during dock trials at Boston.

Mrs. Cornelius W. Van der Hoogt of The Hague, -Holland, died yesterday of pneumonia in the Hotel Grosvenor, 35 Fifth Avenue, at the age of 72. She arrived in New York on Oct. 5. Mrs. Van der Hoogt, who had lived here until her marriage in 1914, was a member of the D. A. R., Netherland-America Foundation, Sansoray Club and the Church of the Ascension.

Eight fillies from the C. V. Whitney farm, two of them daughters of the great Equipoise, were sold tonight in the Lexington Paddock for $14,300, an average of $1,787. All told, seventy-two young racers were sold for $44,300, an average of $617.
High Chinese authorities tonight charged that the airplane machine-gunning of British Embassy automobiles yesterday at Minghong was an attempt by Japanese to kill Generalissimo Chiang Kal-shek.

Charlie Yates and Dick Garlington, Georgia's No. 1 team, jumped into the favorite's role today by eliminating South Carolina's entry, 10 and 9, in the inaugural Southern States fourball rolf tournament.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding in the twelve Federal Reserve districts on Sept. 30 was $344,419,113, or $537,359 more than a year before, according to the monthly survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced yesterday.

Directors of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, and the regular quarterly distribution of $1.75 on the preferred. Both are payable on Nov. 1 to stock of record of Oct. 25, On Jan. 25 the company distributed $2.25 a share on the common, having resumed dividends on the issue with a 50-cent payment on Oct. 6, 1936.
Films to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee,
Park Commissioner Robert Moses has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the Independent Committee for the election of J. G. L. Molloy to the City Council, it was announced yesterday. Langdon W.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13.--Warren Milton Persons, statistician, author and Professor of Economics at Harvard University, died on Monday at his home at the age of 59. Funeral services will be held tomorrow. Born in West De Pere, Wis., Mr. Persons was graduated from the University of Wisconsin.

Dr. Stella M. Taylor, former superintendent and resident physician at the New England Hospital for Women and Children for twenty-five years, died yesterday in a Boston hospital. Born in Melbourne, Australia, daughter of William H. and Sarah Taylor, she was graduated from the Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania.

SHANGHAI, Thrusday, Oct. 14--Unrest in Manchukuo and desertions from the Manchukuoan Army have forced Japan to enlarge her garrison forces at all strategic points, according to foreigners who recently arrived in Peiping, Tientsin and Shanghai from Manchukuo.

Numerous increases in salaries made last year by the New York Central Railroad were noted in a report made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. The salary of F. E. Williamson, president remained unchanged at $60.000. He also received $2.495 other remuneration.

Formation of the "Dewey Volunteers," a group, of young women to work for the election of Thomas E. Dewey as District Attorney of New York County, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Allen Yorke, cochairman of the Dewey Citizens' Committee.

The President in his fireside chat, replying to those who call the cropreduction program an "economy of scarcity," argued that the Government was working on essentially the same principle as shoe manufacturers who "never hesitate to shut down their own huge plants, throw men out of work and cut down the purchasing power of whole communities whenever they think they must adjust their production to an oversupply of the goods they make."
The body of Mrs. Frances Parsons, 38 years old, of Mount Kemble Lake, near here, was found in the lake near her home this morning.

Considering President Roosevelt's speech entirely apart from its context, where domestic affairs are concerned, there was some disposition in Wall Street to regard his tone as conciliatory, rather than condemnatory, inasmuch as he had taken particular pains to explain to the country the purpose of the legislation to be considered at the special session of Congress.

Seventeen seamen of the Norwegian motorship Wind, who quit the ship last week in Mobile when they learned that she was being loaded with scrap iron for transport to Japan, defended their action yesterday afternoon at Ellis Island, before Rudolph Reimer, Commissioner of Immigration for this district.
President William E. Benswanger of the Pirates announced tonight the purchase of Johnny Rizzo, hard-hitting outfielder with the Columbus (Ohio) team of the American Association.

District Attorneys who boast about records in terms of the numbers of persons convicted were condemned last night by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey as having built their records partly upon sentences for the "two-cents a play" victims of the policy game when he claimed the District Attorney should have been engaged with bigger game.

A fight between cat and rabbit fanciers in this community was imminent today over an ordinance introduced last night in the Borough Council providing that cat owners pay a $1 a year license the same as dog owners and also put a bell on feline pets.

Mr. Cohan and "I'd Rather Be Right" are to stay on the road for a bit longer before settling down at the Music Box. Scheduled there for the evening of Oct. 26, the Kaufman-Hart, Rodgers-Hart symposium on the New Deal now is to spend the entire week of Oct. 25

Dr. Simon Fraser Tolmie, former Premier of British Columbia and member of the House of Commons for five terms, died here tonight after a long illness. He was 70 years of age. Dr. Tolmie, veterinary surgeon, farmer and breeder of livestock, who was formerly president of the Dominion Holstein Breeders, was a member of the Dominion's wartime Union ministry.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Oct. 11: REAR ADMIRALS Brown, W., Commander of Training Detachment, United States Fleet, to duty as Superintendent Naval Academy, Annapolis, Md., Jan. 5.
The Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences will open its 114th year with a special program at the Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place, Brooklyn, at 8:30 o'clock tonight.

The fine work of Leland Shaffer, former Kansas State blocking star, has earned him a starting post in the New York Football Giants' backfield for their Polo Grounds opener with the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Coach Steve Owen.

Edward Washburn Kellogg of the R. C. A. Manufacturing Company received the annual "Progress Medal" of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers last night at the society's semi-annual dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

" Album of the Great" (Knopf), a juvenile novel by Rolf Klep, has been chosen by the Book Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts as the best designed trade book of September. "America's Sixty Families," by Ferdinand Lundberg,

The Japanese Government has not yet received an invitation to attend the Nine-Power conference. Until it arrives' officials decline to suggest what the answer will be. But it is now understood that acceptance is not to be expected.

President Roosevelt has taken the risk that in calling Congress into special session next month he will be embarrassed at a delicate time in the conduct of foreign affairs but has done so deliberately because of what he considers the overwhelming importance of proceeding without delay to the enactment of legislation on important domestic questions.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Anna Stevens, daughter of Mrs. Frank Harvey Stevens of Maplewood and the late Mr. Stevens, to Willard Robert Bishop. son of Mr. and Mrs. Emery Elbert Bishop of Bloomfield, took place this evening at Marlboro Inn, Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph R. Roby, pastor of Vailsburgh Methodist Church.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, has written a book discussing various steps by which world peace may be approached. It will be published Jan. 3 by H. C. Kinsey Co. of this city.

Several industrial and business properties in New Jersey changed hands in transactions reported yesterday. After a continuous ownership of more than fifty years, the two twostory business buildings at 126-128 Paterson Plank Road, Union City, N. J., have been sold by Frances Fankhauser to an investing client of J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

Kelly St, 850 (10-2710): Jaypol Realties. Inc, to Union Square Savings Bank, due as per bond: $49.500. Tremont Ave, 3,631 (18-5427); Rebecca Chadaby to Bronx Savings Bank; extends mtg. to July 1, 1940, at 5 per cent; $15,000. Concord Ave. 611 (10-2642): Minnie K. Rosenheim to Ethel Morrison. 1,282 Stebbins Ave; extends mtg to Dec. 1, 1942, at 5 per cent; $20,000.

Miss Dorothy M. Shotwell, daughter of Mrs. John F. Journeaux of this place, was married to George Jessup Chambers 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Chambers of Fanwood, in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Clarence S. Wood.

-Major R. Glover's Artist's Prince, a colt by Artist's Proof from Princess Galahad, today made the most of a generous handicap allowance and led a field of twenty-six in the ninety-eighth Cambridgeshire Stakes.

Trading was active to slow yesterday. Choice and prime steer hinds and ribs were strong and others lower. The lamb market was steady to lower; other classes showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be about in line with Tuesday's close as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The French franc staged a strong forward movement yesterday and advanced 5 1/4 points to close at 3.37 3/4 cents. The extension of the gains of Monday reflected France's confidence in the government as a result of the municipal elections, while covering of short positions also was an important factor in the franc's action.

Lord rose, publisher of The Daily Telegraph, took the witness stand in court in his libel action against the magazine Action, organ of Sir Oswald Mosley's Fascist organization, for picturing him as a member of an alleged organization of international Jewish financiers.
Mugurditsch Karaian, Armenian held for the slaying of Consul General J. Theodore Marriner of the United States, learned today that the American may have been the victim of a tragic mistake.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 804-October term 1936--Railroad Commission of the State of California et al., applts., v. Pacific Gas and Electric Co. 13--Original-Ex parte L. H. Heymann, petr.

Taking the lead right at the start of the six-furlong fourth race today C. S. Howard's Coramine, the favorite in the betting, maintained her advantage until the wire was reached to gain a head victory over Mrs. Louise Palladino's Bubblesome at Rockingham Park.

Offering will be made today of a refunding issue of $1,300,000 of Virginian Joint Stock Land Bank of Charleston, W. Va., 3 per cent Farm Loan Bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1942, optional Nov. 1, 1939, by a banking syndicate comprising E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; Halsey,

The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today an application by John Lawless Jr., a stockholder of the International Paper and Power Company for a rehearing in connection with an order promulgated on July 31,

8th Ave, e s, block from 124th to 125th St, 100 ft deep; Junior Ehret Realty Corp, Taylor Phillips, secretary, to Doric Properties, Inc, 51 Chambers St, c/o Phillips, Mahoney Fielding ($702). Henry St, s e cor Pike St, 111.4x25; Silvermore Realty Corp to Americo A. Frassanito. 35-11 101st St, Corona ($18); same property, Americo A. Frassanito to Abraham Dyckman, 31 Pike St.

A change in command of the Soviet Black Sea naval fleet was indicated by an obscure item in the newspaper Pravda today. A dispatch from Sevastopol sid a parade of graudates of the Naval Academy there was revieed by Admiral smirnoff, commander of the Black Sea fleet.

Ten British and French naval units patrolling the narrow strip of water between the Balearic Islands of Majorca and Minorca form today the background to all the diplomatic conversations going on regarding the situation in the Mediterranean that

An injunction suit charging Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate, with forcing contractors on private construction and on work for city departments to boycott the products of fourteen large manufacturers of electrical equipment will come to trial at 10 A. M. today before John Kirkland Clark, special master.
Princeton's football forces turned on the pressure through two hours of intensive drill today in the final full practice session at home before they entrain for the game with Chicago on Saturday.

The entire blockfront on the east side of Eighth Avenue, from 124th Street to 125th Street, with a depth of 100 feet, has been sold by the Junior Ehret Realty Corporation, Taylor Phillips, secretary, to Doric Properties, Inc., for an indicated consideration of $702,000.

The reversal of several important factors which had depressed the London market, with low marks registered in many stocks below any levels of recent years, gave new strength to trading today, and created a much brighter situation.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Wright Wilson of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Wilson, to Charles Frazier Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt H. Roberts of Old Greenwich, Conn.

The financial community hailed yesterday the address of Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, in which he laid responsibility for the current break in security prices to excessive governmental regulation.

William M. Jeffers, new president of the Union Pacific Railroad, told an audience of several hundred educators and industrialists at the 150th anniversary celebration of Franklin and Marshall College today that business would thrive by "service to the public."

Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, the Democratic floor leader, returning from Europe yesterday on the Italian liner Rex, expressed his opinion that the Federal budget would be balanced next year, probably without the imposition of any new taxes.

The Compinsky Trio, an ensemble long favorably known in this city, made its sole appearance of the season at Town Hall last night, under the auspices of the Dental Division of the Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy.

Dartmouth's football team will face Brown on Saturday with only one change in the line-up from last week, it was announced today. Dick Campbell, sophomore, will be at guard in place of the injured Gus Zitrides.
Members of the committee In charge of the current United States open tennis championship gave a dinner tonight at Kate's Mountain Lodge in honor of the players.

The stoppage in the millinery industries which has affected 250 firms and more than 2,000 employes making hats wholesaling from $7.50 down, will be officially terminated this morning, following the agreement reached between the union and the jobbers represented by the New York Association of Wholesale Distributers of Ladies' and Children's Hats, it was announced last night by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the Millinery Workers Union.
Robert (Red) Rolfe, star third baseman of the world champion !Yankees, yesterday underwent an operation at St. Elizabeth's Hospital for the removal of a bone } growth on his right leg.

Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. today abolished three jobs as the first step in carrying out the assignment from the President to "put the commission's affairs in order."

Miss Marjorie Kaye, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Kaye of 210 West Seventieth Street, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents to Edwin S. Werdenschlag, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvain Werdenschlag, also of this city, by the Rev. Dr. Louis Newman.

The American Federation of Labor took a step of its own today toward peace in the union ranks by sending a proposal for negotiations to the Committee for Industrial Organization, answering the latter's suggestion for a parley to discuss terms under which the rival groups could end their feud.

A small increase was registered in electric power production last week when both seasonal and longterm trends called for a larger gain, and the adjusted index has eased further to 104.1, its lowest point since the week ended Jan. 2.

Mayor La Guardia promised a new junior high school for West Side Manhattan yesterday at a luncheon of the West of Central Park Association at the Hotel Westover, 253 West Seventy-second Street. A site will be picked in the near future and funds for construction will be included in the 1938 capital outlay budget, he pledged.
Spanish Government carabineers are thought to have killed nineteen of a group of 300 Spaniards who tried to flee from Loyalist territory into Andorra.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--Western railroads will put into effect on Oct. 22 a freight rate of $12 a ton on soy beans and meal from the Central West to the Pacifio Coast.

A French inventor, R. R. Case, is now conducting public experiments of an invention with which he claims to be able not only to operate and navigate warships by radio but also launch and steer airplanes and torpedoes and to fire guns on ships.
All save one of this year's Carnegie International awards have been given by the jury to European artists, the single American whose work was chosen being Robert Philipp of New York.
The report of the United Corporation of Delaware for the third quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $2,185,351 after expenses and charges.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Maynicke of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Holden Maynicke, to John Oppie McCall, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Oppie McCall of Larchmont.
Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, said today that funds from dormant bank accounts turned over to the State since July 1 totaled $527,030.

Wheatland, the three-story brick colonial house once owned by President James Buchanan, was dedicated today by Lancaster as a historical shrine for the American people. The ceremonies were attended by Frederick Watson, British Consul General at Philadelphia; by State officials and representatives of historical societies.

Hoping to settle the question once and for all, the New Jersey Council, Junior Order of United American Mechanics, adopted a resolution today asking Congress, the National Geographic Society and other interested groups to make an investigation to determine the origin of the American flag.
Lawless Boy, white and orange pointer dog, today won the National Pheasant Championship Stake over the Sheri an Drive course with spectacular ground work.

In a memorandum today Dr. Hoo Chi-tsai, director of the Chinese permanent delegation to the League of Nations, charged that Japan was violating "all international conventions prohibiting the use of poison gas and dum-dum bullets."

Lady Heathcote Amory--better known as Joyce Wethered--teamed with her husband, Sir John Heathcote Amory, in the open mixed foursomes golf tournament today and lost in the fifth round by one hole to Miss Kathleen Garnham and A. S. G. Thompson.

Appointment of a committee authorized to draft fair trade practice rules to be submitted to the Federal Trade Commission was voted at a hosiery industry conference attended by more than 200 manufacturers and sponsored by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

Miss Anne Newton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kent Newton of Shaker Heights, has chosen next Thursday as the date for her marriage to Charles Alexander Kirkland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirkland of East Orange, N. J. The ceremony will take place here in Plymouth Church.
Mrs. Marie Stafford, daughter of Rear Admiral Robert E. Peary, will unveil a monument tomorrow in honor of the man who discovered the North Pole.

Secretary Hull denied to J. Kennard Johnson, manager of the Binghamton (N. Y.) Chamber of Commerce, in a letter made public today, that so low a tariff on shoes was to be agreed upon in the projected reciprocal trade agreement with Czechoslovakia that American producers would be injured.

One of the most progressive steps in football history was taken yesterday when the Touchdown Club of New York, at its weekly luncheon .held at the Williams Club, announced its intention to sponsor and promote the use of a propersized football for youngsters up to 12 years of age.

In the rectory of St. Hugo of the Hills, Bloomfield Hills, this noon, Miss Ann May Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Walker of this city, became the bride of Howard Carrington Kresge, son of Mrs. Anna E. Kresge and Sebastian S. Kresge of New York, owner of the chain store system. Mgr. William Murphy officiated.
Taxicabs went round and round in the heart of London's fashionable West End early today in a unique protest against the police.

Mrs. Elizabeth Sturges Field, daughter of Mrs. Hollister Sturges of this city, will be married to James Finan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Finan, also of New York, tomorrow afternoon at Ridgely Manor, Stone Ridge, Ulster County, N. Y., the home of her aunt. Mrs. David Margesson.
The invitation from Belgium for the Ninepower treaty conference on the Sino-Japanese conflict-to be held in Brussels-is expected momentarily by the State Department and will be acted upon promptly.

Dr. Max Euwe of Arnsterdam, world chess champion, recovered the lead in his match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris tonight in the Assembly Hall at the Zoological Gardens, when he defeated the challenger in the fifth game of their series after 41 moves.
Columbia's varsity crew yesterday won the Bangs Cup regatta, an annual intl'acollege event, over a onemile course on the Harlem River, beating the lightweight varsity and jayvee boats.

At the request of Wendell J. Wright, counsel for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey, the Federal Power Commisison has continued until Nov. 22 the hearing originally scheduled to be held on Oct. 27 concerning applications for approval of the merger of six underlying companies of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey into its chief subsidiary, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, principal subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, reaffirmed yesterday prices for all standard finished and semi-finished steel products for the first quarter of 1938, subject only to any change in freight rates at the time of shipment.

A social approach to the prosecution of crime was urged yesterday by Thomas E. Dewey, Republican; Fusion and Labor candidate for District Attorney, who said it had been in his rackets prosecutions in "lit-. erally hundreds of cases."

The report of the Collins Aikmall Corporation and subsidiaries for the six months ended on Aug. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $2,084,959 after depreciation, Federal, State and Canadian income taxes and other charges.

Equipped with an abundance of manpower, the New York Football Giants will introduce the two-team system when they make their season's home debut at the Polo Grounds against the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday.

Vyse Ave (11-2992) s w cor of Tremont Ave, 127x103; Bancroft Management Corp to Bronx Savings Bank extends mtg to Sept. 1, 1942 at 4 per cent; $167,500. Mosholu Pkwy, N, 115 E (12-3326), Upper Heights Holdings, Inc, to Joseph Strenger, 2,764 Webb Ave, installments, 6 per cent; S20,000.

A building trades agreement between Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and a group of general contractors provided the opening wedge yesterday in the Federal injunction suit brought by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association against the electrical union.

The Empire Power Corporation declared a dividend of 75 cents a share yesterday against accumulations on the participating stook. On Sept. 15, a 50-cent payment was made toward clearing up arrears on the issue.
Secretary Morgenthau announced today the last offering of weekly 273-day Treasury bills to be sold to meet maturities of earlier short-term issues.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Kassebaum Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Kassebaum, to Thomas Burpee Ellsworth of New York, son of Mrs. John Stoughton Ellsworth of Simsbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Ellsworth.
The Archduke Franz Josef of Austria and his wife, the former Baroness Kahler, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie on their wedding trip.
Mrs. Douglas M. Moffat of New York City, retiring president of the New York State League of Women Voters, recommended today a "period of assimilation" of legislation already on the statute books.

Members of the Belgian Army horse show team which will compete in the international military competitions of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 3 to 10, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington.

A 34-year-old bartender was found murdered yesterday morning in that district in the West Forties which used to be notorious as "Hell's Kitchen." The victim, Deminick Raimondi, of 412 West Thirtyseventh Street, was found lying back of the bar in a tavern of which he was part owner, at 455 West Fortieth Street.

Gowns by Adrian and settings by Cedric Gibbons do not entirely conceal the underlying shabbiness of "The Bride Wore Red," one of those seasonal rediscoveries of Cinderella which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer turned into the Capitol yesterday.

Credited with two shutout victories in as many starts, the Lawrenceville School football team will arrive at the half-way point of its season on Saturday, with the coaching staff still regarding the squad as an unknown quantity in some respects.

With a little help from the weather the Duke of Windsor was able today to take a day off from his strenuous tour of National Socialist Germany. He had intended to fly to Brunswick to inspect the new housing project being put through there with great success. About midnight, however, Lufthansa notified him it would be no weather for flying, so Brunswick and the textile industry at Bielefeld have been skipped.

Robert K. Straus, candidate for the City Council from Manhattan, who is backed by the City Fusion party and the Citizens Non-Partisan Campaign Committee, appealed yesterday for support to editors, publishers and special writers representing thirty-one foreign language newspapers at a luncheon at the Hotel Iroquois in West Forty-fourth Street.

In closed sessions and at "members only" luncheons, delegates to the National Panhellenic Conference at the Beekman Tower Hotel yesterday deliberated conditions and prospects of the twenty-three Greek letter fraternities for women comprising the membership.

James Dalhover, sole survivor of the Brady gang, was returned from Bangor, Me., by airplane today, and was being held in a cell under $50,000 bond here tonight while Federal, State and local authorities strove to decide where to bring him to trial on one or more of many charges of robbery and murder. He was manacled hand and foot in his cell.

A $275,000 mortgage for ten years at 5 per cent has been placed on the large apartment house on the e s of 73d Rd, 136 n of Austin St, Forest Hills, L. I. Rosenbloom and Eisenberg are the owners of the structure. The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co, is the mortgagor, J. Halperin Co, Inc, arranged the loan.
A first degree murder trial with women as jury foreman, chief of defense counsel and defendant will open in General Sessions today following the selection of two alternate jurors.

George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, set at rest yesterday fears that he might desert the La Guardia cause, following the entry into the Mayor's campaign of John L. Lewis, head of the C. I. O., nov under a ban of the American Federation of Labor.

Andrews Ave (11-2878), n e cor of 175th St. 166x26; Cotteret Realty Corp to Henry Sonn Co, 119 W 25th St; mtg $119,000. Fox St, 1,072 (10-2726), Leo Goldberg to Irving Stern. 1,072 Fox St. Waring Ave, 1,142 (16-4369); Hattie Goodman to Ruth G. Lichtenstein, 1,142 Waring Ave. Wilson Ave, 3,346 (16-4735); Julia Ruy to Carmela Cancellierl, 3,346 Wilson Ave.

James V. Rank's Scottish Union, a colt by the 1931 Derby winner, Cameronian, out of Trustful, today defeated the Aga Khan's heavily backed Mirza II by a head to win the rich Middle Park stakes, six-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds.
The Socialist party, which has the largest represensation in Parliament, polled the largest vote in the first ballot in the cantonal elections, according to the Interior Ministry.

Tammany Hall was the scene of a very pleasant party Wednesday evening. Senator Copeland was there, sitting beside Mr. Mahoney, whom he described just a month ago as "tarred with the stick of the Ku Klux Klan."

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $80,000. To Augusta B. B. Coster, widow, executrix, 128 Central Park South, fifty shares Consolidated Gas, household effects and specific insurance; Helen B. C. Ashdown, daughter, Barrule, Warwick, East Bermuda, onefourth residue;
Plans for a new police station, prison and garage to house the present West Forty-seventh Street Precinct were filed yesterday on behalf of the Police Department by Byron P. Wilson, the architect.

Apartment rentals in Manhattan showed an average rise of slightly less than 5 per cent during the season just closed, and multi-family buildings in the borough now show an average occupancy of nearly 95 per cent, according to reports made by brokers yesterday to the apartment house group of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe expressed belief yesterday in the good faith of all concerned in the reorganization of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, saying that he appreciated the difficulties involved in drafting an effective plan in view of a highly complicated set-up.
Darkness prevented completion of the semifinal bracket in the inaugural Southern States four-ball golf tourney today, with a Louisiana and a Georgia team all square at the end of forty-two holes.
William C. Bullitt, Ambassador to France, "fathered" President Roosevelt's Chicago speech on foreign policy, Raymond Moley, former "brain truster," charged yesterday in the latest issue of Newsweek.

In order to continue the relief afforded by the existing mortgage moratorium, which he visions as necessary to avoid the forfeiture of many homes and properties in the State, Assemblyman Phelps Phelps announced yesterday that he will introduce a bill in the next session of the Legislature providing for a continuance of the moratorium for six months, until Jan. 1, 1939.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 68--Puget Sound Stevedoring Co., aplt., against the Tax Commission of the State of Washington, et al., etc. Argument concluded for the appellees.
The yachting department of the New York Athletic Club will observe closing ceremonies at Travers Island tomorrow.

The New York State Board of Standards and Appeals announced today that it viewed "with suspicion the motives of instigators and organizers of any independent union with membership confined solely to employes of a single employer."
