The Rev. Walter David Knight, pastor for sixteen years of the Mount Washington Church, 84 Vermilyea Avenue, has been elected Field Representative of the Board of National Missions and Christian Education for the Presbyterian Synod of New England.

With the bite of real Fall weather spurring them, Yale's football forces completed preparations today for the invasion of Army. Tomorrow there will be a bit of limbering-up, probably in the Bowl after the cadets have worked there, but tonight saw the end of hard work for the game.
The Ford Motor Company charged today that an "intolerable" situation had arisen because of the picketing of its Kansas City plant and indicated that it was considering closing the plant permanently.

Jack Reed, veteran theatrical manager, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 2,517 Nineteenth Street, Sheepshead Bay. Mr. Reed, who was manager for "Stage Door," was at his job in the Music Box Theatre when stricken.

Miss Virginia Guilfoil, Syracuse University student, featured the second round of the women's Berthellyn Cup golf tournament by winning from Mrs. W. G. Hamilton Jr. of Huntingdon Valley over the latter's home course today. The youthful ;tar triumphed, 1 up, on the twentieth hole.
Once again Germany pledges to respect the neutrality of Belgium, and promises also to grant it assistance should Belgium "become the object of aggression or invasion."

Bill Ingram, Navy's ace runner of last year who was injured in Saturday's game against Virginia, was on the field today and Coach Hank Hardwick expects to use him in the Harvard battle. However, Lem Cooke will start.

Paramount was not giving, it was only trading, when it let Twentieth Century-Fox have Randolph Scott for the Shirley Temple picture, "Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm." It now appears that Don Ameche was the actor Fox exchanged for Scott.
Robert Underwood Johnson, poet, editor, director of the Hall of Fame and former Ambassador to Italy, died at 3:50 o'clock yesterday afternoon at his home, 327 Lexington Avenue. He was 84 years old.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday that Dean Milton E. Loomis of the university's Washington Square College at Washington Square East, had received a "sabbatical leave of absence" for the current academic year and would return at the end of the year as Professor of Government, a position he formerly held at the university from 1913 to 1916.

Stuart Otto has been elected president and a director of the American Centrifugal Corporation. The special meeting of stockholders of the Minneapolis-Moline Power Implement Company on the plan for recapitalization has been adjourned until Oct. 21.
Full agreement on classification of coals in the Pocahontas district of West Virginia was filed with the National Bituminous Coal Commission today.
Coach Lou Oshins sent the Brooklyn College football squad through a long practice session yesterday for the Wagner College contest tomorrow.

The following Marine Corps changes, dated Oct. 11, were announced today: Bennett, Major F. W., Navy Yard, Cavite, P. I., to the Department of the Pacific. Burger, Capt. J. C., Peiping, China, to Quantico, Va., via the President Hoover, sailing from Kobe, Japan, about Oct. 28.
The Merchants Salvage Corporation has purchased the two-story building at 1,131 Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, from Elizabeth R. Wellington, as trustee, through the Levitt Operating Corporation.

The Works Progress Administration told Senator Smathers of New Jersey today that President Roosevelt had approved, subject to review by the Controller General, eight projects for New Jersey, totaling $37,049.

Charles Becker, who headed a committee of twenty-five taxpayers that brought about the investigation of Newark's governmental affairs, announced today that he was considering the advisability of petitioning Governor Hoffman to appoint a receiver for Newark's finances.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent discussions of railroads in receivership, especially between Mr. Mahaffie of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the authorities of the New Haven, bring a new element into the situation for those particular railroadsviz., the matter of sinking funds.

Gustin-Bacon Manufacturing Co, railway, oil field and mill supplies, in New York Central Building, 230 Park Ave. Newburger, Loeb Co, stock brokers, in 99 Madison Ave; Williams Co, Inc, broker. Wing Co. importers of Oriental art, jewels and accessories, through Wm. A. White Co, in 439 Madison Ave; Albert M. Greenfield Co, Inc, broker.

The National Labor Relations Board replied today to attacks from both wings of organized labor with a brief statement to the effect that the addition of some 4,000,000 workers to the union ranks in the past year was evidence that labor was being protected.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 14.--Impaired efficiency of the stock market was responsible for the severity of the break in prices which started early in September. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, told a luncheon meeting of the Rochester Chamber of Commerce today.

George F. Johnson, chairman of the board of the Endicott-Johnson Corporation, celebrated his eightieth birthday today and said that he would do everything he could "to see that labor gets a square deal."

" Between the Devil," a musical comedy with a dramatic plot, had its premiere in the Shubert Theatre here tonight with more than a hundred New Yorkers of the world of the theatre, the night club and the operatic stage among a large audience of Yale undergraduates and New Haveners.

H. G. Wells, British author, arrived last night from London on the liner Washington of the United States Lines to make his first lecture tour in this country. His subject will be "Organization of a World Brain."
Scientists and educators will participate tomorrow in the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the New York State Museum.
Men, women and children shed tears without fear of ridicule as puppies, pet male and female dogs, were put on the auction block here today.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain tried to assure Italy by implication tonight that the British people were always ready to let bygones be bygones in international affairs.
Fordham is ready for the Pittsburgh game at the Polo Grounds tomorrow. Coach Jim Crowley sent the Rams through a defensive dummy scrimmage against the freshman eleven at Fordham Field yesterday.

Michael J. Meehan has severed his last tie with Wall Street, according to a New York Stock Exchange announcement issued yesterday. Effective today, he and James F. McConnochie, a partner, will retire from membership in M. J. Meehan Co.

Selig Liese, a musicians' contractor employed by the Roxy Theatre Corporation, entered the Rockefeller Plaza branch of the National City Bank, 9 West Fifty-first Street, yesterday morning at 10 o'clock and withdrew a payroll of $2,270, salaries for the musicians at the theatre.

While Bruce Barton, Republican candidate for the House of Representatives from the Seventeenth District, is seeking a job as a maker of laws, he declared yesterday that he would spend much of his time in Congress, "during my first term," in an effort to unmake laws already on the Federal statute books.

The majority of the cast of the twelfth annual world championship rodeo played "medicine man" yesterday morning to one of their most appreciative audiences, as they again performed before the 3,000 inmates of Bellevue Hospital's children wards.

Lower wool values and clearances of stocks of Fall fabrics unsettled the wool goods markets this week, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday,. and added that business was at a low ebb on men's wear Spring fabrics.
Walter R. Davies, a retired New York law: yer, died today at his home, 160 Summit Avenue, after an illness of several years. He was 71 years old. Mr. Davies was a graduate of Columbia Law School.
The London-to-Broadway movement continues tonight with "Wise Tomorrow," by the English Stephen Powys, which Bernard Klawans is setting down at the Biltmore Theatre on behalf of the Warner Brothers.

Too much responsibility has been placed on a few psychiatrists in Bellevue Hospital and an inadequate staff, and lack of information from other agencies has resulted in incomplete diagnosis of mentally defective patients, according to testimony in the County Court House yesterday before the State legislative committee investigating sex crimes.

Bill MeKechnie today signed a two-year contract as manager of the National League's last-place Reds and, with a guarantee of $25,000 annually plus a bonus, became, officials said, the third highest-paid skipper in the majors.

The stripers seem to have been as numerous at points along the New Jersey coast as they were off Montauk this week. According to George Schneider, who would actually rather fish for stripers than eat, they literally boiled in the surf near the Belmar Fishing Club's pier on Monday and Tuesday.
In spite of cold weather which bothered the players, the quarter-final brackets of the first open tennis tourney were filled today. All of the occupants are professionals.
The strike of taxicab drivers, characterized by owners as a revolt of the men against the C. I. O., was extended yesterday to seven garages involving more than 1,000 men.

Japan's thoughts were diverted momentarily from military matters today as Emperor Hirohito, announcing the theme of the 1938 new year poetry contest, struck a peaceful note. The subject set was "Early Morning in a Shrine Garden."
Jeremiah T. Mahoney denounced Mayor La Guardia for what Mr. Mahoney called the demoralized condition of the city, citing the police, relief and agitators.

Forthcoming Harcourt, Brace books include "Man Against Himself," by Dr. Karl Menninger.; "Heinrich Heine," by Louis Untermeyer; "Last Flight," by Amelia Earhart, and "The Washington Correspondents," by Leo C. Rosten.

Beating down strong opposition to some of the changes as "undemocratic," the House of Clerical and Lay Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States concurred today with most of the changes in the status and tenure of the Presiding Bishop already approved by the House of Bishops.
President Roosevelt received a courtesy visit today from Premier T. D. Pattullo of British Columbia, returning the visit Mr. Roosevelt paid to Victoria during his Western trip.
Blinded by a flash of lightning last Wednesday, Jeannette Pepin, 20, will recover her sight within a week or two, Dr. Victor Lavoie said today.

Half Time, owned and trained by Milo Shields, captured the featured Chatford Handicap at Jamaica yesterday as all six favorites fell by the wayside, making for the lowest percentage of winning choices at any New York meeting this season. Less than 30 per cent have triumphed thus far at the session.

While Congress has virtually completed hearings on the bills for creating seven regional conservation authorities throughout the country, President Roosevelt's plan for enactment of this legislation at the extra session may be interrupted by court proceedings again focusing attention on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority, it was learned today.

The marriage of Miss Mildred Ruth Jones, daughter of Lieut. Col. Nathaniel A. Jones, U. S. A., and Mrs. Jones of Mitchel Field, and Lieutenant Audrin R. Walker, U. S. A., of Kelly Field, Texas, took place this afternoon at the Officers Club of this post. The bride's father, chaplain of Mitchel Field, Performed the ceremony.
Domestic stocks of copper increased 18,137 to 144,321 tons in September, the Copper Institute announced yesterday. Deliveries to domestic consumers during the month amounted to 66229 tons.

Several large suites were reported yesterday to have been taken in apartment buildings on the East Side. Auguste Richard, president of the Spool Cotton Company, took a unit consisting of eleven rooms and five baths in the cooperative house at 1,172 Park Avenue through Sumner Gerard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14.--Although one of the principal objectives of the special session of Congress called for Nov. 15 is farm legislation, with emphasis on some form of crop control, the measure on which Administration leaders and Secretary Wallace are at work is still far from completion, it was learned today.
Transatlantic passenger traffic in the westbound trade reached its peak yesterday when four large ships arrived in port with a total of 5,997 passengers.

Mrs. Norman J. Marsh of Tarrytown, N. Y., formerly of this city, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Weeks Marsh of New York, to Paul Davier, son of Mrs. John Davier of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr. Davier.

Due to lack of public support, the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra will not be able to give its concerts scheduled for this season, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Theodore Steinway, chairman of the committee. Four Monday evening concerts at Town Hall were listed for what would have been the orchestra's third annual season. Hans Lange is artistic director of the ensemble, Otto Luening associate conductor.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: PATENTS 3796--Coshocton Glove Co. v. Buckeye Glove Co. Petition of applt. for rehearing denied.
Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index continued its downward movement, easing to 76.1 from 77.8. The figure for the week ended Oct. 10, 1936, was 90.4.
The four major telegraph companies of the country will eliminate charges for punctuation marks in domestic messages, according to announcements made yesterday. The new plan is effective today.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The Appellate Division was asked yesterday to determine whether District Attorney William C. Dodge can recover the $13,515 which the city deducted in pay cuts from his salary between Jan. 1, 1934, when he took office, and last June 30.

The Times Square gridiron season gets under way this morning with the arrival of "Over the Goal," with William Hopper and June Travis, at the Criterion, and "Saturday's Children," featuring Van Heflin and Marian Marsh, at the Palace.

Still concentrating on Villanova's attack, the Manhattan College football team went through its last stiff workout yesterday at Innisfail Park in preparation for tomorrow's game with the Wildcats at Ebbets Field.

American shipping men will seek a revision of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 on the ground that its provisions covering profits and the conditions under which new tonnage would be built are considered too stringent, it was learned yesterday.

Whatever the bases of the reported disagreement between Herbert Hoover and Alfred M. Landon over the proposed mid-term Republican conference, the dispute is discouraging to all who want to rebuild an effective opposition to the party in power.
East Side realty formed the bulk of the transactions announced by brokers yesterday. Interest was centered in residential properties, and several of the deals involved large private dwellings.

Ralph Guldahl, 1937 national open golf champion, and Billy Burke were 3 points to the good and stepped in front of a select field of sixteen crack professionals in the opening round of Oklahoma City's first annual $5,000 four-ball golf tournament today.
FIRST MILITARY AREA The following Reserve officers, recently released to the First Military Area, are assigned as follows: 389th Infantry-2d Lt. Leland E. Carr, Inf.Res., 36 State St., Albany, N. Y.
Captain Pepherbridge and Daddario, both injured last Saturday, were out for practice at Wesleyan today, but neither took part in the scrinlmage with the seconds.
Charles Rollinson, noted engrosser and illuminator of manuscripts and resolutions, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 61 West Ninth Street. He was 80 years old.
Up-State New York experienced the season's coldest weather today. The lowest temperature reported warn 10 degrees above zero at Owl's Head in the Northern Adirondacks. It was freezing in Buffalo.

Japanese reports declare their forces have advanced along all fronts, the most important movement being in Suiyuan Province, where the capital, Kweisui, was captured yesterday. After capturing the city the invaders advanced westward, cutting the railway in an attempt to prevent flight by the Chinese troops.

Two distinct price movements characterized the course of the bond market yesterday, the first being a somewhat broad recovery from the recent lows, and the second, and final, stage a resumption of the decline which more than eliminated gains registered early in the session.

A sudden drop in the price of the guilder yesterday occupied the attention of traders in the local foreign exchange market as evidence accumulated that traders in The Netherlands were heavy purchasers of United States stocks. No rallying tendencies were visible in the guilder, which closed 3 points lower to 55.26 1/2 cents.

Today's events: Michael Zadora, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Gordon String Quartet, Washington Irving High School, evening; New York State Symphonic Band, WPA Theatre of Music, evening; Dorothy Dell Potter, soprano, Barbizon Hotel, 8:45 P. M.; Bernice Stochek, violinist, and Sarah La Barbera, pianist, Apollo Hall, Brooklyn, 8:15 P. M.

Trial Results Fireman 1st Grade Frank H. McVey, Engine 18. Charge 1: Absent without leave. Guilty. Fined two days' pay. Charge 2: Disrespect to superior officer. Guilty. Fined two days' pay. Charge 3: Making a false statement on report with intent to deceive. Guilty. Reprimand.
In the presence of leaders in politics, society and finance, funeral services were held yesterday morning at St. Thomas Church for Ogden Livingston Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury.

The Queens County Savings Bank has sold the three-family house at 15-11 150th Street, Whitestone, L. I., and the one-family residence at 59-35 162d Street, Flushing. An investing client of the Kennedy Agency, broker in both deals, purchased the Whitestone property.

The estimated operating revenues of ninety-two Class 1 railroads for September were $296,716,259, against $295,022,415 in the same month last year and $383,158,962 in September, 1930, according to figures made public today by the Association of American Railroads.

Trading was active to slow yesterday. Lambs sold steady, other classes uneven. There was some business in all classes of kosher meats at steady prices as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mrs. George Callendine Heck Jr. entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for her sister-in-law, Miss Marie Brooke Heck, whose marriage to James Tileston Baldwin will take place tomorrow in the Church of St. John in Lattingtown, Locust Valley, L. I.

Mrs. Glen Seymour Treglown of Plainfield has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth Treglown to William Sillo MacFarlane of New York. Miss Treglown is a daughter of the late Mr. Treglown, and granddaughter of the late Henry T. M. Treglown of Buffalo and Daytona Beach, Fla.

William A. Ayres of Kansas, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret Ayres, to William Frederick Weigester of Washington, a patent attorney, son of William Weigester of Troy, Pa.

Mrs. Howard Carroll and members of the Westchester Committee of the Metropolitan Opera Guild will be hostessses at a musical and tea to be held today at Carrollcliff, Mrs. Carroll's home in Tarrytown, N. Y.
Woman's Forum, Hotel Roosevelt, 11 A. M. "Retrospect and Prospect in Federal Legislation," William S. Bennet; "Drinking Habits of Youth Since Repeal," Mrs. John S. Shepard.
The throwing end of New York University's forward-pass attack will be shared by Ed Williams and Ed Cella when the Violet meets St. John's College of Annapolis at Ohio Field tomorrow.
Dr. L. R. Alderman, director of the Works Progress Administration's education division, said today that the division's adult classes are speeding up the decline of illiteracy in the South.

With more than 81per cent of the preferred stocks of the New York Steam Corporation now deposited for exchange for preferred stock of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of Consolidated, sent a letter yesterday to holders of the remaining preferred shares of Steam notifying them that their stock might be offered in exchange on the same basis until Nov. 15.

The Twenty-third Street Association will hold its annual luncheon meeting on Wednesday, Oct. 20, in the George Washington Hotel. New directors will be elected and following the meeting the board of directors will hold an election of officers.

Herbert Steele Kellogg, retired business man, died of a stroke early yesterday in Nantucket Hospital. His age was 73. He founded Kellogg's Teachers Agency at 31 Union Square, a teachers' employment service, in 1897.

Two apartment houses on a plot 100 by 257 feet at 131-135 Harrison Street, East Orange, N. J., were purchased by the Boulevard Realty Associates, Inc., a subsidiary of Metropolitan Realty Holding, Inc., Isidore Wolff, president, from the Prudential Insurance Company.
Army's football team today went through its last practice before entraining for New Haven for Saturday's contest with Yale. The squad will make Roxbury School its headquarters until game time.

The exchange of notes between Germany and Belgium guaranteeing the latter's independence was hailed in German quarters today as the crowning achievement of Chancellor Hitler's "dynamic peace policy" which opens the way for the peaceful reorganization of Europe under auspices so powerful that nobody dare resist by resorting to war.

BILBAO, Spain, Oct 14.--A big battle is in progress fifteen miles southeast of Saragossa in Northeastern Spain. Government artillery is pounding Insurgent positions along an eight-mile front stretching in a semicircle from Fuentes de Ebro past Mediana to Mount Sillero.

After a final rehearsal of plays and another intensive session on ways and means to stop the attack expected from Navy on Saturday, the Harvard football squad of thirty-seven players departed for Baltimore tonight.
Pennsylvania concluded its home practice today for the game with Columbia and made a surprising change at left end, where Harlan Gustafson, rangy sophomore, replaced the veteran Ned Fielden.

Three midtown hotels were without normal elevator and other services for. several hours yesterday as a result of a strike called by the Hotel Service Employes Union, an affiliate of the Building Service Employes Union, Local 32B. The hotels, operated by the Dreier chain, were the President, Plymouth and Cadillac.

The minstrel bard-once a fixture in every English tavern-returned to a London "pub" today when Robert Walter, gold medalist of the London Poetry Society, gave a reading of poems while glasses clinked at Redcliffe Arms, Chelsea.

In an address at Rochester yesterday, Winthrop Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, presented a careful analysis of the individual and cumulative effect of the various governmental controls that now influence the stock market.

Your telegram of Oct. 12 as authorized by the group of organizations meeting in conference under auspices of the Committee for Industrial Organization and addressed to the American Federation of Labor has received the attention of its executive council.
China's foreign trade recorded "a healthy growth" during the first eight months of this year despite the Sino-Japanese hostilities, the Commerce Department reported today.

In connection with the public hearing planned today in the Bar Association Building by the joint legislative committee investigating the guaranteed mortgage situation, it was learned yesterday that the committee, headed by State Senator Lazarus Joseph, is seeking to enlist Federal aid in clearing up the mortgage certificate tangle.

Although a sharp decline in bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday from the preceding week was owing in part to the Columbus Day holiday, the clearings also fell below the corresponding period of 1936. Curtailed activity and lower prices in both the security and commodity markets were said to be largely responsible for the shrinkage in transactions.
Expert handling on the part of Basil James, and the courage of Alice G., a daughter of Macaw, brought the Tranquillity Farm chief money in the Aragon purse, today's feature at Laurel Park.

A reversal from the recent upward trend in cotton prices occurred yesterday on the Cotton Exchange when profit taking attracted by the recent advances of about $4 a bale supplied a less active demand.

14.-The one-week tour of Swedish Foreign Minister Richard Sandler and Ecclesiastical Minister Jonas Arthur Engberg and the Finnish Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti and Education Minister M. Hannula to Northern Sweden and Finland for the purpose of investigating school conditions, particularly the language question near the frontier, ended today at Helsingfors.

Governor Davey granted a full pardon tonight to Kenyon V. Painter, Cleveland banker and big game hunter, who had been serving a one to thirty-year sentence for misapplication of Union Trust Company funds.

Postmaster General Farley, in an interview here today, said that President Roosevelt, if he should seek a third term, "would carry forty-six States again, and you can throw in Maine and Vermont, too." But, he added, the question of whether President Roosevelt would run again "is one that only the President can answer."

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society has received a total of $21,600 in new subscriptions, representing 1,033 seats and eighteen boxes, it was made known at the final Fall meeting of the committee on subscription activities held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the Stadium Concerts, Inc.

The French liner Normandie, sailing today for Europe, will take out William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France; Paul Fuller, consul for Monaco in New York, and Mrs. Fuller; Sir Samuel G. Joseph and Lady Joseph, Stanley Adams, Mr. and Mrs. J. D. Mooney, Mischa Auer, actor; Ray Ventura, orchestra leader;
During the week ending Oct. 13, memberbank reserve balances decreased $84,000,000. Reduction in memberbank reserve rose from increases of $16,000,000 in money in

The State Street Investment Corporation sold an aggregate of $7,500,000 of stocks in July and August, realizing a profit of $1,672, 731. During the latter part of August and in September purchases of $1,200,000 were made, the net result being an increase in cash from $1,922,464 at June 30 to $7,532,062 at Sept. 30, or from 3 per cent to 16 per cent of total assets.
Movement of livestock market in Chicago today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follows:

Lafayette's jayvees opened their season today with a 7-to-0 victory over the Lehigh junior varsity eleven. Bryant went across from the five-yard line in the second period after his long pass to Sweeney had set the stage.
Meadow Brook members' polo continued today, with G. H. (Pete) Bostwick's White riders turning back a Red combination, 4 to 3, in a seven-period match on Belmont field.

Farmers are paying their land bank debts at such a brisk rate that the Farm Credit Administration will call and retire $71,911,540 of Federal Land Bank Bond issues which are callable on Nov. 1, W. I. Myers, Governor, announced today. No offering of refunding bonds will be made, he added.

Stocks weakened in final hour and closed lower after moderate gains; turnover, 1,681,530 shares. United States Government, Italian and Japanese loans higher; other bonds lower; transactions, $8,575,000.

A test of the rule of the trustees of the State Employes Retirement Fund against "death-bed retirements" may be provided by an application for payment of $24,000 filed today by Mrs. Charles J. Merrell of Bound Brook.

The Grand Chapter, Order of the Eastern Star, New York State, elected yesterday at the close of its sixty-eighth annual session at the Hotel Astor Mrs. Beulah L. Walters of Buffalo as Grand Matron. The conclave, which began on Tuesday, was attended by more than 2,000 delegates.

Led by Matthias A. Harrington, chief supervisor, fifty inspectors of the Department of Markets started a city-wide investigation yesterday of charges by retail butchers that local wholesale meat houses were selling crated pork loins, chickens and hams at short weight.
The investigation into the recent alleged attempt to corner September corn on the Board of Trade here "and matters collateral thereto" is expected to get under way next week.

WHILE those football fellows are running through signals for the big games tomorrow, there's a chance to go back to second base, which was a point of vantage for the Yankees in the recent world series.

Two airplanes met in the air at Municipal Airport today and two pilots and a student escaped death. Vance Breese, a Northrop Airplane Aircraft Corporation test pilot, brought a new type Navy "bullet" plane to a safe landing despite a bent propeller, torn wing and battered aerial mast.
John Beckett, editor of the Fascist publication Action, today declined to take the witness stand in defense of a libel action brought by Lord Camrose, publisher of The Daily Telegraph.

The Appellate Division was asked yesterday by the- New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild to amend the rules of practice in the Supreme Court in order to eliminate or reduce judicial patronage, which, it said, has given rise to "many grave abuses." It proposed the establishment of rostating panels for the impartial seelection of referees, receivers and special guardians instead of the present system.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Oct. 14, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Fairfax, Tattnall. At Puget Sound Yard, Oct. 13: Preble. Tracy.

Television pictures broadcast from the National Broadcasting Company's transmitter atop the Empire State Building were flashed across fifteen city blocks last night to be projected on a 3-by-4-foot screen to entertain members of the Society of Motion-Picture Engineers assembled at Radio City.

Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-Edward J. Bidanset, from 14th Prec. to Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, assigned to duty as chauffeur. From precincts indicated to Emergency Service Division:

Senator Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin, who returned last night with Mrs. La Follette in the George Washington of the United States Lines from Europe, said that had he known of Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black's Ku Klux Klan membership, he would have felt constrained to vote against his appointment.

Payments on open-credit accounts of department stores were made at a lower rate in August than during August, 1936, and July of this year, while payments on installment accounts were slightly lower in August than in August. 1936, but higher than in July of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Andre Lenglet of France will square off against Jorge Brescia of Argentina in the feature ten-round boxing bout at the New York Hippodrome tonight.

City College's chances of winning from Susquehanna University at Selingsgrove, Pa., tomorrow received a blow yesterday when Dr. Duckers announced that Arthur Jacobs, regular left end, would not be able to leave with the team because of an elbow dislocation suffered in the game with Albright.

Line Coach Hoops Snively ordered another stiff defensive drill for his Williams forwards today. The line the Purple faces on Saturday has won the Maine State championship for Bowdoin the last two years and the emphasis here all week has been on strengthening the forward wall.

Princeton University's gridiron battalion, thirty-five strong, was rattling on the way to the Middle West tonight after concluding four days of intensive preparation for the Chicago game with two and a half hours of work this afternoon on University Field.

Real Winter has descended on the MacGregor Arctic Expedition camp during the last twenty-four hours. Snow began to fall yesterday afternoon. The wind set in from the north, increasing in force and reaching fifty miles an hour this morning.

Italy's new Libyan defense force was brought to 33,000 today with the departure of 7,000 more men from Naples. This gives Premier Mussolini an Italian army on the North African coast more than matching the 30,000 men France maintains in Tunisia, bordering Libya on the west.

An appeal to President Roosevelt and to Congress to restore last year's level of government assistance to college students was drafted last night by young men and women representing many of the high school and college groups of this area. The letter will be sent to Washington today. The protest asserts that the reduction of aid during the present academic year will
The membership of Everett G. Speyer has been transferred to Stanley Schiff of Schiff Young. The interest of the estate of the late Alpheus C. Beane in Fenner Beane ceased on Sept. 18.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 14 (AP).--With five men weighing more than 200 pounds each, beef and brawn are not lacking in the Rutgers freshman football squad. Heaviest of the forty-seven aspirants to regular positions is John Pullian, 255-pound tackle from Collingswood.

The marriage of Miss Madeleine Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Eliot Curtis of 400 East Fifty-eighth Street, to James W. Walsh Jr. of this city and Lawrence, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon in the clubhouse of the National Society of Colonial Dames, 215 East Seventy-first Street.

Reiterating that the cut in the requested appropriations had unbalanced the school budget and would force drastic curtailments in the 1938 educational program, Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, chairman of the Board of Education's finance and budget committee, challenged yesterday the statement issued by Henry C. Turner, board president, that the cuts would not seriously interfere with scheduled services.

In one version of the description of the celestial city in the Book of Revelation it is called a House of Many Tenements (or abiding places) instead of the House of Many Mansions, which suggests that the word "tenement" did not in its earlier uses have the associations which it has come to have in the overcrowded cities.
To HAVE AND HAVE NOT, by Ernest Hemingway (Scribner, $2.50.) A novel laid in Florida. THE BURIED CANDELABRRUM, by Stefan- Zweig (Viking, $2.50.) A story of Jewish folk lore.
Turpentine firm, 271/2c; sales 193 barrels; receipts 431 barrels; shipments 1,625 barrels; stock 36,166 barrels. Resin steady; no sales; receipts 915; shipments 2,042; stock 76,958.

Chinese land forces in Chapel, supported by airplane raids last evening and early today, attempted to break through the Japanese lines in a battle that terrified the foreign areas of Shanghai because of the dangers from falling bombs and shells.

The country's auto traffic toll, despite "spotty improvement" in States and cities which have conducted vigorous safety campaigns, is running about 20 per cent ahead of last year, according to the American Automobile Association.

Holders of coupons of Polish External Loan Bonds, due between this Oct. 1, and April 30, next year, will receive interest at the rate of 4 1/4 per cent annually, instead of the flat 35 per cent cash payment previously offered, under a new offer made by the Polish Government and announced yesterday through the financial counselor of the nation'sembassy here.
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Paul J. Kern of the Civil Service Commission, "Proportional Representation," WNYC, 2:45 to 3 P. M.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against TRUTONOPHONE, INC., manufacturers of hearing aid devices, 101 5th Ave.-By Diener Dorskind, Inc., for $1,067; The Journal-News Corp., $29; Business Letter Service, Inc.. $79.

A government program for a compulsory insurance scheme against war damage to property was advocated today by the National Federation of Property Owners and Rate Payers because standard insurance companies refuse to take war risks.
Although the volume of business was generally restricted, a confident undertone continued to dominate activities on the stock market today.

THE strange case of Ernest Hemingway is reopened this morning with the publication of "To Have and Have Not,"*, his first novel since "A Farewell to Arms." It is a turbulent, searching story of Key West and Havana in these strange years of grace.

In a sharp reply tonight to recently expressed utterances of J. Edgar Hoover on the subject of parole, Austin H. MacCormick, New York Commissioner of Correction, inferentially accused the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of sponsoring "the machine-gun school of criminology."

Marica, the French Lick Stable's queen of the West, today accounted for the second running of the Breeders Stakes in a two-horse race which for thrills will go down as one of the most dramatic in Kentucky turf history.

Norman Thomas and Harry W. Laidler, Socialist candidate for the City Council, appearing for the Socialist party, asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to increase the 1938 budget allotments for health, hospitals. parks and education.
A long session in offensive work was the program for Holy Cross today. Coach Anderson spent much time with a backfield composed of Osmanski, Cahill,

Total liabilities of the Bank of Canada increased to $394,862,720 yesterday from $391,115,771 a week before, largely because of heavier deposits 'by the Dominion Government, which rose to $35,658,516 from $32,301,658, according to the weekly statement issued today.
Fresh outbreaks of terrorism in the Jerusalem area tonight resulted in the death of two Arabs and the wounding of sixteen Jews.

Charles Englehardt, who was Mayor of Ridgefield, N. J., five times and who received a Congressional Medal while serving in the United States Army, died last night at his home here. He was 80 years old.

National Bond and Share Corporation--Sept. 30: Net assets were $57.86 each on 180,000 capital shares, after providing for a dividend of 25 cents a share payable today, compared with $61.12 a share on June 30, last, and to $62.19 on Dec. 31, 1936.

Any doubt the public might have that the Fifth Avenue Association has not changed its policy in opposition to night openings by retail stores on that thoroughfare should be removed by action of the board of directors at its meeting this week reaffirming that policy, Thomas W. Hughes, general manager of the association, declared in a statement issued last night.

Brokers' loans continued to dedine for the week ended on Wednesday and fell to $968,000,000, according to the weekly condition statement of reporting banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, issued yesterday.
Prices of the 1938 Dodge automobiles were

The decline in return received by insurance companies from investments is due to Government activity in the lending field and a slow demand for funds from sound private sources, Leroy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, New York, asserted today in an address on "Assets" before the American Life Convention.

An exhibit of Princetoniana illustrating nearly two centuries of the university's history and tradition has been placed in the Princeton Library for the benefit of freshmen. It will remain on display until Tuesday.

New York State was charged yesterday, at a hearing before the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Law Revision, with attempting to impose its insurance requirements on other States and to make its insurance code the "norm" for the nation. The hearing was held in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street.

Testimony of witnesses for the government in the oil conspiracy trial here today showed there was a great similarity in the regular form of contracts between the oil companies and their jobbers, but it also revealed that in almost every instance there was "an understanding" or an agreement that made a material difference in their terms.

Captain George E. T. Eyston, after driving for half an hour through a pelting rainstorm, halted at 4:39 P. M. (7:39 P. M., Eastern standard time) today his attempt at a world speed record for 24 hours.

The keystone of Mexico's policy is "the reconquest of Mexico for Mexicans," Ramon Beteta, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, informed United States State Department officials, consuls and diplomats in Mexico, whom he addressed yesterday at their invitation.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Thalheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Thalheimer of Hamden, Conn., to Arthur Moss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Moss of this city, took place here last evening at the Hotel Warwick. The Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise performed the ceremony.

The six-story apartment house at 2,420 Bronx Park East, known as the Botanical Court Apartments, has been sold by the Manufacturers Trust Company to Irving W. Karpf. It contains 219 rooms, divided into sixty-six suites, and occupies a plot 125 by 131 feet. The building is said to be fully occupied.

MANHATTAN BROWNE, HANNAH (Jan. 7, 1937). Gross assets, $29,173; net, $26,668. To Margaret Browne and Bridget Browne, sisters, onehalf residue each; two specific bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $26,798. Stephen W. Collins, attorney, 41 Park Row.
The engagement of Miss Carolin Babcock, woman tennis star, to Richard Salisbury Stark of Santa Monica, Calif., was announced here today by Miss Babcock's mother, Mrs. Lewis Chapin Babcock.

The decline in commodity prices went unchecked last week and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices dropped a full point to stand on Tuesday at 91.9, compared with 92.9 a week before and 94.0 on Sept. 28. The average is now -at the lowest level since January.

The State of Maine will be in the market on Oct. 21 with a new issue of $1,000,000 of highway and bridge bonds. The issue, for which bidders are to name the rate of interest will mature serially from 1939 to 1948.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Bovenizer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Wallace Bovenizer, to George William Armstrong Jr. of Brooklyn, took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Samuel Macauley Lindsay of Brookline, Mass., who was assisted by the Rev. L H. R. Hass of Brooklyn.

New life insurance production for September was 1.1 per cent greater than for September, 1936, while the total for the first nine months of 1937 was 6.6 per cent over the 1936 period, according to a report of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.
Harry C. Mealey has been appointed Western regional manager of household appliances for the Kelvinator division ?? Nash-Kelvinator Corporation.
United States professionals won two matches and lost one today in a series of 36-hole golf exhibitions against Argentine pros.

In an effort to block the AntiCommunist and Trades Union parties, formed to promote the election of Jeremiah T. Mahoney and other Democratic candidates, Kenneth F. Simpson, president of the New York County Republican Committee, filed yesterday with the Board of Elections a detailed set of specifications in support of his demand that they be denied places on the ballot.

Prime Minister Chamberlain last night in a speech evidently intended to reassure Italy, said Britain was willing to let bygones be bygones. Foreign Secretary Eden told Ambassador Grandi of .the understandings on which Britain and France were seeking settlement of the Spanish problem and urged quick decision.
President Roosevelt's likeness will appear soon on a Guatemalan postage stamp, but postal officials here are not overjoyed about it.

Miss Katherine Eleanor Kreitler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Kreitler of Maplewood, was married this evening, the twenty-fifth wedding anniversary of her parents, to Stanley Russell Ellison of Buffalo, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ellison of South Orange. The ceremony was performed in Prospect Presbyterian Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Butz.

Mayor La Guardia, taking the offensive in his campaign for re-election, yesterday blasted away at his opponent, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, and Mr. Mahoney's supporters, with a series of speeches, and a lesson" on city government, released for the "benefit" of the opposition.

The period from Nov. 1 to Nov. 7 was designated today by Governor Lehman as "Cancer Crusade Week." In his message urging observance of the week he advocated early examinations so that not only cancer but all diseases might be discovered in their incipiency.

The United Automobile Workers of a America is determined to bring about the unionization of all plants owned and controlled by Henry Ford and to this end will pursue an intensive organization campaign among Ford employes, Homer Martin, president of the union, declared today at the conference of the Committee for Industrial Organization in session here.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 13th: Parmenter, Lieut. Col. E. L., Med. Corps, Ft. Barrancas, Fla., to retirement. Platt, Major R. J., Med. Corps, promoted to Lieutenant Colonel.

Marcel Olivier, president of the French Line, who was recently appointed by the French Government to head that nation's section at the New York World's Fair, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to complete arrangements for the French participation in the fair.

The United Federal Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, is conducting no active organization drive in the local office of the National Labor Relations Board because some employes believe C. I. O. membership would put them in the position of partisans in passing on jurisdictional disputes involving A. F. of L. unions, Miss Ann Wharton, regional organizer for the John L. Lewis group, disclosed yesterday.

The Fisheries Bureau reported today that the herd of fur seals in Alaska totaled 1,839,110 animals on Aug. 10, an increase of 8.8 per cent in a year. The herd, which contained only 130,000 animals in 1910, "is rapidly reaching a state of complete restoration," the bureau said.
The National Safety Council's annual conference was told this afternoon that 1937 would set an alltime record in night traffic fatalities, accounting for probably 67 per cent of the year's total.

A children's revue, with the presentation of hair-styling on seven young models, was a feature of the closing session of -the annual convention of the National and New York State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

J. P. Morgan Co., sinking fund administrators for French Republic 1924 external loan 7 per cent bonds due on Dec. 1, 1949, have announced that $2,036,200 of the bonds has been drawn for redemption on Dec. 1 next at 105 and interest. The method of payment will be announced by the French Government.

The tenth annual Boston horse show, under the direction of the 110th Cavalry, Massachusetts National Guard, opened in Commonwealth Armory tonight before a gathering of 2,000 spectators. Some of the nation's outstanding show horses competed.
The grain markets on the Board of Trade here continued erratic today. An early upturn of around 1 cent a bushel in wheat and corn was followed by a recession when securities started to ease.

The two generals who have been in command of the Italian forces in Spain have been permanently recalled to this country. They are General Ettore Bastico, the commander-in-chief, and General Attilio Teruzzi, chief inspector of the Blackshirt legions. The command has been given to General Berti.

10th St, 256-258 E, 43.41/2x92.3; Owen E. Reilly to Harlem Savings Bank, consid $5,000, foreclosure. 105th St, 239-241 E, 40.8x100.9; James J. Lanzetta to same, consid $4,000, fcl. Cherry St, 153-155, 39.11x60.31/2; 301 E 7th St.. Inc., to Carpenter Equities, Inc., 1,450 Broadway, care of Goodman Mabel (50 cents).

Miss Catherine French, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie 'rench of Des Moines, wa, was married to Richard Odell Ferris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Ferris of Scarsdale, this afternoon at the home here of her uncle, Dr. Winn Waters. The Rev. Alan Chalmers of the Church of St. James the Less, Scarsdale, performed the ceremony.

Miss Margaret Gants, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milfred Gants of this city, was married to Leslie Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Schwartz of Stamford, Conn., this evening at the home of her parents here. The Rev. Dr. Jacob Schackman of Temple Israel of this city performed the ceremony.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

For the first time in several weeks engineering construction awards in the short week ended yesterday rose above the figure for the corresponding period of 1936, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Dealers from New York and New Jersey had their first view of the 1938 Chevrolet models yesterday in Mecca Temple. More than 400 men heard J. E. Simmons, zone manager, describe the cars that will be shown to the public on Oct. 23.
A thousand Jewish university students staged a quiet strike today against inauguration of class room "ghetto benches" marked to show they were for Jews.

Miss Margaret Gants, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milfred Gants of this city, was married to Leslie Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Schwartz of Stamford, Conn., this evening at the home of her parents here. The Rev. Dr. Jacob Schackman of Temple Israel of this city performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden captured low gross prize with a 46,43-89 in the weekly oneday tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association over the picturesque Shorehaven Country Club course today.

The Hon. Michael Langhorne Astor, son of Viscount and Viscountess Astor, who arrived on the Europa, is at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse has come from East Hampton to the Plaza. Dr. and Mrs. George F. Chandler, who had -been on a world cruise, returned on the Europa and are at the Berkshire.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following order today, dated Oct. 12. REAR ADMIRALS Fairfield, A. P., Commander of Squadron 40-T, to duty as member of the General Board, Navy Department, Washington, D. C.

A nearing has been called for Oct. 20 by the Securities and Exchange Commission at its offices here on an application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration on that Exchange the no par value common stock of the Warner Quinlan Company of New York City.

Governor Lehman has appointed a board of high-ranking National Guard officers to examine the professional qualifications of Colonel John G. Grimley, commanding the 369th Infantry, N. Y. N. G., it became known yesterday.

An innovation in the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers will be made at the second day of their forthcoming convention, when a joint conference between members and invited advertising agency representatives will take place, it was announced yesterday.

Commissioner Harry J. Heinz, director of Public Works here, died at North Hudson Hospital in Weehawken soon after midnight of a heart ailment from which he had suffered for several years. He was 44 years old.

Miss Gertrude Schwartz of Washington, daughter of Mrs. Emanuel Schwartz of New York, was married today in the Washington Hebrew Congregation Syngagogue to Harry Sylvester Wender of Washington. The ceremony was followed by a reception in the Temple library.
Headed by Daniel J. Doherty, National Commander of the American Legion, members of the Legion visiting here today placed a wreath on the tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

Penn State's coaching staff polished up the Nittany Lion's pass defense during a large part of today's practice and then worked on State's aerial attack, with Wear and Rollins doing most of the tossing.
Burt P. Seelye, former principal of Public School 3 at 368 East 157th Street, the Bronx, died here today at his home at the age of 74.

A survey of the epidemic situation in China, dealing especially with the possible effects of military operations and movements of refugees, was laid before the League of Nations Health Committee's subcommittee for technical cooperation with China when it met here this morning.
Delegates representing 42,000 coal miners in Western Pennsylvania have decided to organize their wives into leagues of women buyers designed to boycott goods which do not bear the union label.

Sales of staple dry goods this week have remained quiet, despite the lower quotations recently made to stimulate buy ?? and the advance in raw cotton which produced sharply better activity in gray goods.

Putting its proposals in writing at the request of London, the French Cabinet today sent a somewhat lengthy note defining what it considers should be done next to try to relieve the tension over the Italian exploitation of the Spanish civil war.
Mr. Birchall's description of Germany's great new motor highways is not without a hint for us. We can have such fine roads

Declines in wholesale prices of farm products and foodstuffs in the week ended on Oct. 9 caused a pronounced recession in the general level of wholesale prices, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

It was officially announced today that 102 Italian troops, including forty-one officers, and an unspecified number of native troops had been killed in Ethiopia in September when strong groups of natives attacked small isolated garrisons in the central highlands.

The fatal flogging of Joseph Shoemaker when he refused to heed a Ku Klux Klan warning to leave Tampa, where he had been engaged in political activity in opposition to the city's two dominant political factions, officially became today another of Central Florida's unsolved murders.
Cornell's football forces avoided contact in a long practice, most of which was devoted to signal drill and kick-off formations, tonight.
Current reports from London and Paris give the impression that Italy has once more successfully outplayed the democratic States in the tortuous game of power politics.
Earle Insley, a lawyer in Jersey City for many years and a resident here since 1872, died yesterday at Nyack Hospital after a short illness. He was 79 years old and a native of Jersey City.

Four concerns in New York engaged respectively in selling pipes, wine, carbon paper, and dry goods, have entered into stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue certain alleged misrepresentations of which the commission complained, it was announced today.
Government agencies reported today that both domestic consumption and exports of cotton the first two months of the current season were larger than the August-September totals last year.

It was not precisely a love of alma mater that had Lou Little bemoaning Penn's defeat by Yale. That may have had a slight something to do with it, but lugubrious Lou, Pennsylvania '20, was more concerned yesterday with the almost hopeless psychological task that the setback to the Quakers left him in tuning up his Columbia eleven for the meeting with the Red and Blue tomorrow at Baker Field.
A reliable Vatican source said tonight that the Holy See condones Japanese military activity in China wherever communism appears to be the enemy.

A cultured person cannot be a reactionary, nationalist, Democrat, Republican or an isolationist, Mrs. Cornelia Stratton Parker, author, declared yesterday in an address at the closing sessions of the fortyfirst annual convention of the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers, meeting at the Waldorf Astoria.

TOKYO, Oct. 14 (AP)--Railway stations and docks in many parts of Japan were jammed today by departing soldiers, indicating that the empire is sending heavy additional reinforcements to its armies in China. Troop movements were believed to be more active than for some time.

A secret tribunal sentenced seventeen persons today to from six months to eighteen years' imprisonment for alleged activity against the State. They were arrested after officials discovered what was termed a secret Communist organization in Bologna, affiliated with a Communist group in Paris.

The Rev. Carl E. Poensgen, pastor of St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church here for the last twentynine years and former president of the Northern New Jersey Conference of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, died here this afternoon in Christ Hospital. His age was 60.
Broadway traffic between Fortyseventh and Forty-eighth Streets was halted for twenty minutes about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon by a fire in Fred Kelly's hat store at 1,579 Broadway.
Baseball shared the spotlight with football today as Colgate's Red Raiders went through their last stiff workout before the Tulane game at Buffalo Saturday.

The marriage of Mrs. Rowe McCune of Greens Farms to Thomas Coggeshall of New York took place this afternoon at the McCune home. The Rev. Malcolm James MacLeod, rector emeritus of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, New York, performed the ceremony in the presence of the immediate families.

Village Attorney Gordon Miller said today he had been instructed by village trustees to appear in the Federal court in New York on Oct. 29 to oppose suspension of service on the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad, as proposed in a bondholders' foreclosure suit to be argued at that time.

The bodies of nearly 200 Amerlean and British volunteers were found by agents of the non-intervention committee along the Franco-Spanish frontier during the Summer, Colonel C. D. O. Lunn, a Danish officer, said today.

The University of the State of New York, at its seventy-third annual convocation tonight, conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Science upon Dr. Alexis Carrel of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, Nobel Prize winner, and Dr. John C. Merriam, president of the Carnegie Institution at Washington.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is unsettled and weak, with the price trend still downward, although it is not easy to fix prices with any assurance. Some consider the market value for fine topmaking wools of decently good staple and character about 85 cents, clean basis;

Imports of cotton hosiery during the first nine months of this. year fell short of the pro rata proportion of the annual quota under the quota agreement with Japan by 40,000 dozen pairs, indicating that the pact is working satisfactorily, a report submitted at the Hosiery Industry Conference sponsored. by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday showed.

The Duke of Windsor visited Krupp's, the weapon smithy of the Reich, today, but the privileges given. to Premier Mussolini of Italy on his recent visit were not accorded to him and he saw no armaments. His visit, in fact, was rather hurried, lasting altogether two and one-half hours.

Continued Chinese successes in Shansi were reported here in inilitary dispatches from that northern province. A small mobile unit of the former Communist Eighth Route Army is said to have recaptured Pinghsingkwan, in Northeast Shansi, and to have destroyed many miles of roads along Japanese lines of communication.

Carnegie Hall, Inc, M. Murray Weisman. Old Greenwich. Conn., president, has agreed with the Union Dime Savings Bank that five mortgages aggregating $370,000, dated variously between March, 1915, and June, 1922, on 144-50 W 57th St and 139-53 W 56th St be extended to Aug. 1, 1940, at 4 per cent.
At least three Canadian newsprint concerns have decided to reduce production to the extent of 20 per cent.

Lights gleamed from many windows and in tiny stalls where students of today and tomorrow will burn the modern equivalent of midnight oil, as Vassar College tonight dedicated her newest and proudest acquisition, Van Ingen Hall.

Evergold, 8-year-old son of Ladkin, gave further proof of his liking for this track today by winning the Annapolis Purse. The veteran was never headed after the opening strides of the mile and a sixteenth test and came to the wire a length and a half ahead of Mrs. Gwladys Whitney's Red Rain and T. Lee Evans's Alexandrine, in a dead heat for second.

The extreme left flank of the Insurgent forces in Asturias has moved after nearly a month's comparative inactivity. Its objective was Pefia Lasa, the great massif dominating the valley of the Villamanin and the approaches to Puerto de Pajares, half-way between Leon and Oviedo on the main road.
President Roosevelt is "trying hard to balance the budget" and he has a "very, very good chance" of doing it, Joseph P. Kennedy said after a long conference with the President today.

In two months the Shanghai war of 1937 has caused a total public and private property damage to this city at least three times as great as the loss resulting in the six weeks hostilities in 1932, according to a survey completed today by an American economist attached to the United States consulate here.
Four New England States have more than half of the women members of State law-making bodies in the country.

Edgar Varese, composer and sound technician, left Santa Fe. N. M., last night for Hollywood and San Francisco after spending his second Summer there. During his stay in Santa Fe he organized the Schola Cantorum, an a cappella chorus of 100 local voices for the performance of ancient and modern choral music.

In order to simplify the procedure on routine applications for delisting securities registered on national Stock Exchanges, the Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted rules under which, in certain uncontested cases, it will be possible to dispense with the formality of an appearance at a hearing by the applicant.

The runner-up record for the shortest run of the new season now is held by "In Clover," which ceased activity at the Vanderbilt last evening after giving only three performances and without bothering to await even the end of the week. Notices and business trouble.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Waldo Wenk entertained last night with a dinner in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for their daughter, Miss Margaret Wenk, and Edwin L. Amberg, whose marriage will take place tonight in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Three long sprints by Halfback Andy Farkas helped Detroit University romp to an easy 30-to-0 gridiron triumph over Catholic University tonight before 10,000 fans. In the second period Farkas shot toward left end, cut back, then sprinted 80 yards for a touchdown. He took the third period kick-off and pounded down the center for 94 yards. In the final quarter Farkas shot through the line, evaded the secondaries and was off on a 57-yard trot.

Anthony Joseph. beauty parlor, additional store in 1,367 6th Ave; Frank Blumenfeld, laundry, store in 914 7th Ave; Irving E. Gottlief, ladies' wear. store in 352 W 125th St; L. J. Phillips Co, broker. Funk Wagnalls Co. Inc. floor in 354-60 4th Ave: Joseph Zeimbinski, novelties,

The capitulatory system, in existence in Egypt since the Middle Ages, was ended at a final ceremony this afternoon in the Mixed Tribunals Building at Alexandria. King Farouk was present as well as Cabinet Ministers, the diplomatic corps, judges of both mixed and native courts, and many local notables.

Dorothy McNulty, a niece of Postmaster General James A. Farley, and Dr. Lawrence S. Singleton were married here tonight. The bride is the daughter of Bernard Joseph McNulty of Philadelphia. Dr. and Mrs. S. G. Singleton of Santa Barbara are the parents of the bridegroom.
Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, has declined a challenge from Frank E. Gannett of Rochester to debate the Supreme
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for District Attorney, "The War on Organized Crime," WEVD, 10:15 to 10:30 A. M.

A funeral service will be held at 10 A. M. Monday at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, for Grenville Temple Emmet, United States Minister to Austria, who died in Vienna on Sept. 26. Mr. Emmet's body, accompanied by his widow and three children, Grenville T. Emmet Jr. and the Misses Pauline and Patricia Emmet, arrived in New York aboard the United States liner Washington on Thursday.
A small shack used by 11-year-old Samuel Bell /Jr. and his neighborhood friends for "councils of war and peace" went up in flames tonight and Samuel was burned to death.

In the light of after-events, the execution last June of Marshal Tukhachevsky and seven other of the Red Army's high-ranking generals can now be viewed as part of a vast and vague movement the meaning of which is not yet completely clear even to Russians themselves.

President James Bryant Conant of Harvard and President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia spoke at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria given last night by the Yale alumni of New York in honor of President Charles Seymour of Yale who took office recently.

For some reason that was not apparent in the results, several people went through the motions of giving a play at the Biltmore Theatre last evening. It was denominated in the program as "Wise Tomorrow" and ascribed to one Stephen Powys.

Irregular price movements characterized trading on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. Early declines in sympathy with easiness in Liverpool, Alexandria and Bombay were followed by recoveries on renewed trade price-fixing in the face of light offerings, but business was restricted by a disposition to await a clearer view of farm legislation at the coming session of Congress.

United States Ambassador Nelson Johnson forwarded today to the State Department at Washington a copy of the protest of the American community of Szechwan Province against Japanese aggression in China.

Retail trade here continued notably active during the week, with the pace set by the Columbus Day increase well maintained on the following days. An increase of 10 per cent over the corresponding week last year was estimated by department store executives.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the Star Oil and Refining Corporation of Fort Morgan, Col.; E. G. Markley, Charles H. Woodin, P. C. Saunier and C. T. Ahlstrand had been enjoined today by Judge Foster Symes of the Federal Court of the District of Colorado from making untrue and misleading statements in the sale of the stock of that corporation in violation of the Securities Act of 1933.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Oct. 28 at its offices here on a declaration filed by the Copper District Power Company, Ontonagon, Mich., a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, covering the issuance of $225,000 of unsecured notes to meet

That Robert Underwood Johnson was born in a house that stood where the rotunda of the House of Representative;; Office Building now stands seems a happy augury of his coming into the national fame to which his verses have given him title as an American laureate.
Stricken by a heart attack as he left the office of his physician, Thompson Buchanan, Louisville playwright and former newspaper man, fell dead here today. His age was 60.
A Hollywood story with a slightly different angle has been bought and scenarized by RKO and will be put into production next week with Lee Tracy in the leading role.

Charges of violations of the National Labor Relations Act against the Book of the Month Club have been filed with Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the NLRB, it was learned last night. Mrs. Herrick said she could not disclose the nature of the alleged violations until she had studied the charges.

The removal of M. L. Rukhimovitch from his post as Commissar of Defense Industry was disclosed today. His job was given to Mikhail M. Kaganovitch, former Vice Commissar of Defense Industry, who went to the United States recently to visit airplane factories.

The belief that a mass emigration of industry from New York City might follow Mayor La Guardia's re-election.was expressed last evening by Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan in a radio speech over station WOR.

Chess enthusiasts of this city and vicinity are preparing to welcome the two world-famous chess master, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, who are scheduled to play the sixth game of their championship series here tomorrow night. The place of play will be in the concert hall of the Municipal Institute of Music.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced textile contract awards as follows:

The Bronx Eye and Ear Infirmary, 321 East Tremont Avenue, which was built at a cost of $500,000, was opened yesterday without ceremony for private inspection. The public will be permitted to visit the hospital tomorrow from 2 to 5 P. M.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., one of the country's largest manufacturers of chemicals and high explosives, is making consignments of TNT to official representatives of the Chinese Government, according to an announcement by the company yesterday. Delivery of the explosive is being made at the company's plant in Barksdale, Wis.

The joint legislative committee investigating the desirability of extending mortgage moratorium legislation heard appeals today from mortgagors and real estate men for an extension of the emergency period, and demands by banks and insurance companies for "tapering off" the law.
Miss Agnes Frazier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin West Frazier of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Henry Kurtz Canby, son of Mrs. William Marriott Canby of Thornlawn, Germantown.

King Carol, who will celebrate his forty-fourth birthday tomorrow at Sinaia with' Crown Prince Michael while festivities in his honor occur throughout the land, made declarations to which some importance is attached at a dinner tonight following the military manoeuvres.
Three striking employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle were paroled yesterday for further hearing on Oct. 26 by Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino in Bay Ridge Court on charges of disorderly conduct.

While realty and housing interests have been awaiting the naming of the man who will direct the Federal low-cost housing program under the Wagner-Steagall act, many States have been preparing legislation which will make them eligible to participate in the benefits of that program.

Dr. John C. A. Gerster, chairman of the New York City Cancer Committee, announced yesterday the establishment of the Clement Cleveland Medal to be awarded annually for educational work in cancer control.

167th St (10-2609), n e cor of 3d Ave. 104x 32; Margaret J. Donovan to Veronica D. Hoenninger, 19 Morris Crescent, Yonkers, N.Y. Andrews Ave (11-3218). e s 150 ft n of 183d St, 50x100; Bowery Savings Bank to Arbee Estates, Inc, 21 E 40th St.

Miss Janet Creighton daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Creighton of Bayonne, was married here this afternoon to Charles Willet Miller Pursel, son of Mrs. Frank P. Pursel of Bloomsburg, Pa., and the late Mr. Pursel, at the home of her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Brandegee. The Rev. William C. Kernan performed the ceremony.

The new Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River will be formally dedicated on Dec. 21 and opened to vehicular traffic at 4 A. M. on Dec. 22, Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port Authority, announced yesterday.
Harvard's varsity cross-country team defeated Holy Cross in their annual race today, but the Crusader freshmen won from the Crimson cubs.

In the presence of high-ranking naval officers and two members of his recent expedition to the South Polar regions, Rear Admiral Byrd received today from Secretary Swanson, on behalf of Congress, a medal commemorating the second Antarctic expedition.

Mrs. Marie Barrows Porter, socially prominent former wife of Seton Porter, head of National Distillers Products Corporation, was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum to answer questions before a Federal grand jury engaged in trying to find out where her friend, Philip H. Philbin Jr., kept himself when he was a fugitive from a mail fraud charge for two years.

Henry Kendall Mulford, a chemical. manufacturer who pioneered in the making of antitoxins and vaccines, died at his residence at the Hamilton Court, West Philadelphia, today of a heart ailment. He was 71 years old.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of Paragraph 6, Special Orders 138, June 15, 1937, continuing Capt. Carl Carrillio; F.A.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until Jan. 14, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until Dec. 4.

Marty Gallagher, veteran Washington heavyweight, was returned the winner over Andre Lenglet of Paris in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome last night. Referee Joe Vaccarelli, after warning Lenglet repeatedly for butting and for hitting low, disqualifled the Frenchman after two minutes, four seconds of the eighth round for what he deemed "conduct unbecoming a sportsman."
Dr. Bernhard Dernburg, Colonial Secretary under the Kaiser and Minister of Finance under the Republic and a leading figure of Democratic Germany, died here today at the age of 72.

Anthracite operators and miners split sharply today over proposed State regulation of the industry. At a meeting here with the Governor's anthracite commission, the operators rejected the plan, while both the "bootleg" miners and members of the United Mine Workers of America indorsed it.
Herbert Rush Preston, for thirty-one years general solicitor for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, died here today of heart disease at the age of 76.

Crube rubber consumption by manufacturers in the United States during September is estimated at 43,893 long tons, compared to 41,456 long tons in August, an increase of 5.9 per cent, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Consumption for September, 1936, was 46,449 long tons.

Miss Charlotte Upton McNabb Darling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Darling of Kew Gardens, L. I., and of Rauhala, Chestnut Hill, was married this evening to John Prizer of Lancaster, son of Dr. Elmer Tower Prizer and of the late Mrs. Prizer.

Closing yesterday at 16.480 milreis to the dollar, foreign exchange registered today a heavy drop, closing quotations ranging from 17.100 to 25 milreis to the dollar. Exchange oscillations in the last two weeks have brought about a decline of 2 milreis a dollar, and this has engendered much uneasiness in import circles.

A special jury in a British court administered a smashing blow to the fascist movement today when it awarded total damages of [Pound]20,000 to Lord Camrose, publisher of The London Daily Telegraph, and to the newspaper for libel by the Fascist organ Action.

It may be treason, but it's pretty certain a couple of Passaic High School boys will be rooting for East Rutherford High when the old rivals meet in football a week from tomorrow. Not that they're inherently disloyal to their school. It's just that if East Rutherford wins, they definitely won't have to serve thirty-day jail sentences they're subject to if Passaic triumphs.

A funeral service for Robert Underwood Johnson, the poet, will be held tomorrow at 4 P. M. in the chapel of New fork University, University Heights, at 181st Street, the Bronx. Burial will be Monday at Stockbridge, Mass.

Gold production in British Guiana continues to mount steadily, an official statement revealed today. Production for the first nine months of the year totaled 27,257 ounces, valued at $708,383, an increase in value of $66,477 as compared with the first nine months of 1936.

Replying to the latest peace proposal by the Committee for Industrial Organization, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor reinterated today that its standing committee was authorized to meet a committee from the C. I. O. and ended by asking when the latter group was ready to meet.

Trading was fairly active in some cuts and slow in others yesterday. Fresh pork cuts sold unevenly, other classes of traefa meats were mostly unchanged in price. Early trading in kosher meats indicated the beef market to be uneven, veal steady to lower, lamb weak to lower as' reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Asserting that modern youth is "not antagonistic" to temperance education, Mrs. John S. Sheppard, only woman member of the New York State Liquor Authority, addressing the opening Autumn session of the Woman's Forum at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday, declared that raising of the minimum age requirement from 18 to 21 for liquor purchases "will make hypocrites out of our young people."

Thirteen juveniles will face the starter this afternoon in the featured Remsen Handicap at Jamaica. Mountain Ridge, stablemate to Tiger and Sky Larking of the Milky Way Farms, looms as the probable favorite for the six-furlong dash which will gross close to $10,000. The 2-year-old event will share the spotlight with the Long Island Stakes, a mile and a sixteenth test for older horses.

Fifty members of the Independent Veterans Committee on Americanism adopted a resolution last night at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore accusing Mayor La Guardia and his administration of encouraging "un-American activities," which have resulted in "a breakdown of law and order" in New York City.

The League of Nations Health Committee's subcommittee on technical cooperation with China adopted this afternoon a detailed plan for anti-epidemic assistance to that country. While details were, not published, it was learned the plan is along the lines the Chinese Government requested, except that only three anti-epidemic units will be sent.

The city in South Africa that will be the site of the next quadrennial convention of the World's Sunday School Association will be selected on Tuesday at the headquarters of the organization, 51 Madison Avenue, this city, when the North American Administrative Committee holds its semi-annual meeting.
Mrs. Mary Ellen Prindiville Biddle of 3 Mitchell Place, formerly of Chicago, and George F. Johnston of 230 East Fifty-first Street obtrained a marriage license at the Municipal Building yesterday.
The thirty-acre estate of Louis Baer at Georgetown, Conn., near South Norwalk, has been purchased by Frederick J. Gates of Danbury, who will occupy it after modernizing the main house. Warren L.

Four radio sales corporations and eight owners or employers of them were sentenced in Special Sessions yesterday to pay fines or serve workhouse terms on convictions of having sold inferior radio sets by misrepresenting them as the product of well-known makers.
Diplomas were awarded tonight to twelve students of the Westchester School of Nursing at Grasslands Hospital here. Miss Ruth Taylor, Westchester County Commissioner of Public Welfare, presided.

16th St, n s, 175.2 ft w of 8th Ave, 49.9x 69.4; Central Savings Bank to Clara Kritzer, 125 W 16th St; consideration, $30,000. Broadway, s e cor 89th St, 100.8 1/2x80.6; 7576 Corp to Ariento Realty Corp, 119 W 40th St, care of C. G. Bernhelmer; mtgs, $733,750 ($23). Riverside Dr, n cor 83d St, 112.3x167.9; Gertrude Glennon to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co; consideration, $1,000,000; foreclosure.

Rear Admiral Robert Edwin Peary, explorer and discoverer of the North Pole, was honored here this afternoon when a life-sized statue was unveiled at-the site of his birthplace just on the outskirts of the town.
