Exports of American-made automobiles in the next few months will exceed greatly those of any recent year and will be carried at higher rates, according to shipping operators. The season will get under way in the next two weeks.

The wife of White Russian General Eugene Karlovitch Miller, charging he had been "kidnapped by Bolsheviks," appealed tonight to President Albert Lebrun for an order to search the Soviet Embassy for evidence of his disappearance.

Buying of wheat futures by cash interests and exporters combined with a let-up in liquidation by scattering longs gave the wheat market a much firmer undertone today and closing trades were about the highest level of the day.

A list of new rentals covering a wide area of the city constituted the report of apartment leasing submitted by brokers and agents yesterday. A number of apartment buildings in Long Island and Westchester also were selected by families seeking new living accommodations.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker ordered the Essex County grand jury this afternoon to make an investigation of Newark's municipal affairs between May, 1933, and May, 1937, in reference to the acts of Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and the four other city commissioners who held office during that period.

Although the United States Supreme Court refused this week to pass on the issue, candidates for admission to the practice of law in New Jersey were asked today by the State bar examiners if Associate Justice Hugo L. Black is eligible to retain his seat.
Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN-John McTernan, 18th Division. 11th Detective District, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 7, 1902.

Several churches will start tomorrow evening a feature in the form of a question box, the pastor answering written questions which have been placed beforehand in a box in the vestibule to take the place of the usual sermon.

Laszlo Halasz, conductor of the St. Louis Opera Company, has returned to St. Louis from Hollywood in preparation for productions which will include those of "Tristan und Isolde" with Kirsten Flagstad and "Lohengrin" with Maria Jeritza.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, tonight advised the nation and the oil industry to conserve its petroleum supply for war defense and peaceful industry. Addressing delegates to the Independent Petroleum Association's convention here, he said:
The gates were thrown open at the Naval Academy this afternoon for the first open practice the Navy has had this week in preparation for the game with Harvard in the Baltimore stadium tomorrow.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 726,000 bales, against 686,000 a week ago, 684,000 two weeks ago, 684,000 three weeks ago and 741,000 a year ago; of which American 258,000 bales, against 224,000 a week ago, 216,000 two weeks ago, 220,000 three weeks ago and 221.000 a year ago.

Today's events: Fritz Kreisler, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Mary Felts, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Montgomery Davis, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Hippodrome, evening; Ezra Rachlin, pianist, Washington Irving High School, 8:30 P. M.

Bucknell and the University of Miami battled to a 6-6 deadlock at the Memorial Stadium tonight before 8,000 persons. After an even first half, Bucknell began a drive from Miami's 46, Tomasetti's 15-yard pass to Rhodes opening the way. Two first downs by Tomasetti put the Bisons on the 5, and a lateral pass, Lane to Funair, netted the touchdown. Quick's attempt to convert failed.

Official tabulation of the registration for the coming election showed yesterday that 2,483,387 voters had qualified to cast their ballots on Nov. 2. S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, made public the figures, showing registration by boroughs. Brooklyn had the largest number, 869,030. The table follows:

Gains in four classifications offset declines in general, automotive and financial advertising in September, with the result that total newspaper advertising increased 2.5 per cent for the month, according to the monthly compilation for fifty-two cities issued yesterday by Media Records.

Samuel D. Riddle, owner of War Admiral and Man o'War, strongly criticized the standing start and overweighting of race horses tonight at a dinner given in his honor by the Thoroughbred Club of America.

Secretary Hull emphasized the desire of the American nations to become better acquainted with one another in inaugurating this evening a series of radio programs to LatinAmerican countries under the auspices of the Pan American Union.

The actors who tomorrow afternoon will draw a crowd of about 50,000 persons to the Yale Bowl arrived on the scene of action today and went- through the dress rehearsal for the resumption of a successful drama--Yale-Army football.

The divorce suit of the Count of Covadonga, eldest son of former King Alfonso of Spain, and his Cuban commoner wife, the former Marta Rocafort, was dismissed this morning when the Count failed to appear at a hearing at which it had been expected the decree would be granted.
A miniature "Ryder Cup match" was staged by the Long Island P. G. A. at the Lido Country Club today, with a team of homebreds defeating a group of foreign-born pros, 4 to 2.

Controller Frank J. Taylor, Democratic candidate for re-election, was charged yesterday by Mayor he La Guardia and by two of Mr. Taylor's opponents, Joseph D. McGoldrick, who is running on the La Guardia ticket, and Frank Crosswaith, the Socialist nominee, with using city funds to defray the cost of transmitting "misleading political propaganda" to employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 14 unless specified: At San Diego: Brooks, Fox. Tompkinsville to Norfolk, Oct. 15: Texas. Wyoming. Acushnet, Indianhead to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Arkansas. Philadelphia Yard to Norfolk Yard. Oct. 15.

A firstperiod drive, covering 40 yards with Cancro on the scoring end, gave Ithaca College a 6-0 decision over Panzer College today. Cancro went over from the 1-yard mark. Panzer stopped another Ithaca march within a foot of the goal late in the fourth period.

Palestine's new wave of terrorism is continuing. Early this morning two British constables. S. Malia and R. Harrison, were fired on from ambush and killed while in a car patrolling the Hebron road near Solomon's Pools.

One of the original advantages of Manhattan and, therefore, one of the reasons for locating a city in this vicinity was that the area was an island, accessible from the Atlantic, from Long Island Sound and from the North or Hudson River.

The marriage of Miss Catherine E. Lochart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Lochart of East Orange, to Charles Edward Shipman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shipman, to also of East Orange, took place this evening in Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. L. Ward McCreary, pastor of Disciples of Christ Church, East Orange.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 456--Ocean Accident and Guarantee Corporation, Ltd., petr., v. Rebecca Torres. Motion for leave to file brief of Roy A. Bronson as amicus curiae, submitted and motion denied.
Hun School, unbeaten for the last two seasons, opened its 1937 schedule by gaining a 26-0 victory over the Pennsylvania Military College freshmen today.

Clearing the way for the election tomorrow of a Presiding Bishop with enhanced powers, the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States concurred today in the amendment adopted yesterday by the House of Deputies advancing by two years the age at which the Presiding Bishop should retire.

Eight loans totaling $53,800 have been arranged by J. Halperin Co, Inc. for Sol Atlas on dwellings built at 215th Pl, south of 43d Ave, Bayside, and two loans for a total of $22,300 have been placed by the same broker for Ernest G. Blaich on buildings in his Flower Hill development.

With the scheduled return of John Dell Isola, former Fordham star, to a guard position, the New York Football Giants will have three veterans in the starting line against the Philadelphia Eagles tomorrow at the Polo Grounds, where the local eleven will make its home debut.
Several multi-family properties on the upper West Side of Manhattan figured in the real estate transactions reported by brokers yesterday. In most of the day's deals banks were the sellers.

Miss Aline Clare Jovershof, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Jovershof of this city, was married this afternoon to Joseph Ellis, son of Mrs. Hyman G. Ellis of Watertown, N. Y., and the late Mr. Ellis, at the home of her parents here. The Rev. Henry Kagan officiated.
Frederick J. Munder, former Suffolk Assistant District Attorney, was nominated unanimously for District Attorney by the Suffolk County Republican Committee meeting at its headquarters here tonight.
John Szavuy, 50 years old, a cook, and Jennie Beneditson, 35, a waitress, were found shot to death in an apartment they occupied at 213 East Fortieth Street at 11:30 o'clock last night.
The Stork Club, fashionable rendezvous at 3 East Fifty-third Street, was cited on charges of unfair labor practices in a complaint issued yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board.

Reports that President Roosevelt is preparing to change the Neutrality Act and plan the redistribution of world raw matrials have aroused interest but little enthusiasm here. "Whether or not America changes her neutrality provisions is her own business," says the Angriff.

New York University will engage a small but rugged opponent, St. John's of Annapolis, today at Ohio Field. The game, listed to begin at 2:30 P. M., will mark the first time the two institutions have met on the gridiron, although they have been rivals previously in basketball and lacrosse.

Following a four-hour conference of representatives of the Sunshine Radio and Atlas-Liberty taxicab companies and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, it was announced last night that the union had agreed to supply the operators with drivers for some 150 idle cabs.

Manuel Gonzalez Marin, who is representing General Francisco Franco in the organization of Spanish residents in Latin-American countries into Fascist units in support of the Rebel movement in Spain, will proceed to Guatemala when his work here is completed. With Spanish and Italian Fascists and German Nazis, virtually all the Latin-American countries now have three foreign political groups actively opposed to the democratic form of government.
American folk dancing, in which Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, members of the faculty, students and guests took part, was a feature of the campus carnival held at Barnard College yesterday afternoon.
Samuel G. Cornish, son of the late John Cornish, who was founder of the D. H. McAlpin Tobacco Company of New York City, died at his home here last night.

The State Supreme Court today set aside a State racing division order suspending the license of the Narragansett racing track, and Walter E. O'Hara, managing director, after a hurried meeting with the track's board of directors, declared that the "unanimous decision makes it possible for the Fall meet to be held at Narragansett, commencing Monday."
Complaints against three New York concerns, alleging misrepresentation of materials used in clothing, have been filed by the Federal Trade Commission, according to an announcement today.

A charge that Mayor S. Davis Wilson had turned Democrat in a deal with the Democratic organization whereby the grand jury investigation, which conceivably might have been embarrassing, was to be muffled, was made today by Jay Cooke, chairman of the Republican City Committee, in replying to the Mayor's statement of yesterday.

Columbia's football team will meet Pennsylvania today at Baker Field in the twenty-first renewal of a rivalry that dates back to 1878. The opening kick-off at 2 P. M. is expected to be witnessed by 22,000 spectators.
Another extensive slate of schoolboy football games has been arranged for today. Undefeated teams will participate in standout attractions in every section of the metropolitan area.

Horton Smith and Harry Cooper of Chicago took command of the Oklahoma City $5,000 four-ball golf tournament today by posting four points on the plus side of their score sheet at the end of the third round.

In a generally weak market yesterday strength was shown by many of the steel and metal shares, so that the capital goods industries were more strongly represented in the stock action than producers of consumers' goods.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Venetian Decorative Arts," Edith B. Abbot, 11 A. M.: "French Renaissance Furniture Through the. Seventeenth Century," Ethelwyn Bradish, 11 A. M.; "The Hercules Tapestries," Margaret B. Freeman, 2 P. M. Motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, former New Jersey State champion, led one of the largest fields of the season to win low gross honors with 85 in the New Jersey women's one-day golf tournament at the Braidburn course today.

Aggregate. deposits in the mutual savings banks of New York State were $5,291,259,241 on Sept. 30, according to the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York. This was a gain of $16,201,-636 for the third quarter of the year. or less than $23,500,000 of dividends accredited to accounts in the period.

The basic principles of proportional representation--P. R. for short--are simple enough to be understood by any one who can read. At the same time the technicalities involved in counting P. R. votes are sufficiently complicated to give any one short of Professor Einstein a headache.
Acting Premier John M. Andrews, in answer to Eamon de Valera's campaign to bring Ulster into the Irish Republic, declared today "We will never. yield or betray our birthright."

La Salle Military Academy's eleven registered a 14-to-0 victory over La Salle Academy of Providence, sixtime winner of the State scholastic football championship, tonight. The Oakdale (L. I.) squad outplayed the local team from the starting whistle, scoring two touchdowns in the first period on passes from Frank Odinetz to Chester. Smolenski.

Turpentine firm, 27 1/2c; sales, 159 barrels; receipts, 322 barrels; no shipments; stock, 36,488 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 1,588; receipts, 1,603; no shipments; stock, 78,561. Quote--B to N, $7.25; WG, $7.60; WW, X, $8.20.
Dr. William Lincoln Noble, former president of the University of Illinois board of trustees and of the Illinois Medical Society, died yesterday at his home, 1,560 Asbury Avenue.

The Board of Gcvernors of the Federal Reserve System held a short meeting this morning but it was said that the much-debated question of margin requirements for stock exchanges had not been discussed and there was no intimation that immediate action was contemplated.

Aside from the fact that moderate strength was imparted to many of the leading steel stocks by the overnight news that the United States Steel Corporation's principal subsidiary had reaffirmed prices for the -first quarter of 1938, the share market moved yesterday in erratic fashion and closed lower.
The United States marines have had the Shanghai Park Hotel tower situation in hand for a couple of weeks, but the Japanese Army just found out about it today.

Bobby Wolff's interception of a forward pass and his 70-yard run for a touchdown with three minutes to play enabled Woodmere Academy to climax an uphill battle by defeating Brooklyn Friends School, 14 to 7, today. Earlier in the quarter Woodmere knotted the score at 7-all when Dave Seidman ran eleven yards around end and crossed the line, then converted the extra point. The game was a Metropolitan Private School Association test.
An estate of $1,050,000 was left by William Boyd, former vice president and advertising director of the Curtis Publishing Company, probate of the will indicated today.

Testimony that there was a great similarity in the contracts entered into in 1935 and 1936 between major oil companies and their jobbers in the ten Midwestern States was brought out by Government counsel in the proceedings today in the oil conspiracy case here.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 9 amounted to 815,122 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

A preliminary hearing to determine the validity of the second will made by the late Mrs. Frederick De Peyster Foster of Tuxedo Park, wherein she left her $2,000,000 estate to a butler and maid, was held today before Surrogate Charles E. Taylor, with counsel for the domestics charging collusion between witnesses to the second will and beneficiaries of the first.

John S. Knight and associates acquired ownership today of The Miami Herald from Frank B. Shutts, who founded the morning newspaper in 1910. The price was not announced. The buyer and his associates own and operate The Akron (Ohio) Beacon - Journal and The Massillon (Ohio) Independent.

It is improbable that the current decline in business will develop into a real depression, according to Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company. In the current issue of the bank's business bulletin, Colonel Ayres says that the chief reason why the fears business men have of a new depression are probably unfounded is that we have not yet made full recovery from the old depression.

Detective Randal J. McCarthy, for more than thirty years in the Police Department and for the last seven years a member of the Wall Street squad, died early yesterday in his home, 420 East 154th Street, the Bronx, at the age of 56.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in an address broadcast from New York tonight, praised the program of the Camp Fire Girls as a means toward better citizenship.

Veterans of Nazism wildly cheered Chancellor Adolf Hitler today in this city, where men wearing brown shirts and swastika brassards subdued their opponents by the free use of fists and clubs just fifteen years ago.
City College of New York, beaten by Albright College of Reading, Pa., last week in New York, will try a comeback tomorrow against Susquehanna in this Central Pennsylvania town.

Municipal LIFT SPAN OPERATOR--Salary: $2,100 per annum, pension, fair sick leave. Vacancies: One vacancy in Triborough Bridge Authority. List will also be used for Marine Parkway Authority. Ages: Through 40 on Oct. 26. Applications: Received to 4. P. M. Tuesday, Oct. 26. Room 1400,

"Spring Plowing; Mexico," a picture painted this year by Mrs. Marion Freeman Wakeman, Smith '14, was bought recently by Seward Prosser of New York and given to Morrow House as a surprise for Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow when she attended the Fall meeting of the trustees of Smith College today.

A confident Manhattan football team will meet Villanova this afternoon at Ebbets Field, with the kickoff set for 2:30 o'clock. More than 20,000 persons are expected to witness the tenth meeting of the Wildcats and the Jaspers since football. relations were started in 1897.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $7,311,880, to be represented by four States and forty-two municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $4,038,239 for this week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Goldstein's letter was indeed timely. I, too, have been afflicted with infantile paralysis these past fourteen years. At present I attend college, but I am faced with the eternal problem of what field to pursue upon being graduated.

The ranks of the unbeaten, already reduced at an alarming rate, will be further riddled today as the nation's football teams swing into the third week of the season for most of them. To a campaign that has seen more upsets to the square inch than any in recent memory will be added still more as leaders the country over collide.

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW'S simple, wholesome pleasure in talking about himself has become one of the world's permanent sources of entertainment. He never speaks more invigoratingly than when he is justifying the works of Shaw to man. It is a procedure that has been going on long enough to have cheered generation after generation of the same family. Fortunately the diversion can be renewed from time to time by recalling pieces from limbo,

Japan is apparently contemplating some extraordinary step, for at 10 o'clock this morning the embassy, army and navy spokesmen jointly announced that all foreign correspondents holding passes permitting them to cross the Garden Bridge were summoned to assemble at the Japanese Consulate General at 4 P. M.

Removal of headquarters of the National Association of Manufacturers from 11 West Forty-second Street to 14 West. Forty-ninth Street to make provision for expansion of services was announced yesterday by William B. Warner, president of the association. Included in the changes, which became effective yesterday, is the transfer of the law department from Washington to New York.

The vacant plot at the southeast corner of 202d Street and Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Dorsay Building Corporation, Samuel Abramowitz, president, which recently erected a sixstory apartment house on the northeast corner of 201st Street and the same avenue.

All Poland's Jews will strike Tuesday in a demonstration against the introduction of "ghetto benches" for Jewish students. Jewish shops, offices and factories will be closed all day. The strike appeal, signed by all Jewish political parties, says the new regulations violate the Polish Constitution, which guarantees equal rights to all citizens. It describes this new discrimination as a part of a Jewish extermination policy.

William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, said yesterday that Raymond Moley was suffering from an "overworked imagination" in charging in a magazine article that President Roosevelt's Chicago speech on neutrality was inspired in a great measure by Mr. Bullitt. The envoy sailed for Paris on the French liner Normandie.

Marcel Olivier, French commissioner general to the 1939 New York World's Fair, pledged his country's full participation in the exposition at a luncheon tendered to him by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, in the new administration building at Flushing Meadows Park yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Leola Wootten, daughter of Mrs. Harry Alfred Marshall of Summit, to John Boycemith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Boyce-Smith of Los Angeles, took place tonight at the Central Pressyterian Church.

Mrs. Emma Louise Allen, daughter of Mrs. Charles William Schwartz of Walnut Lane, Germantown, was married today to Joseph de Viar Keefe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. de Viar Keefe of En La Sombra, Bala.

The third of a series of auction sales involving real estate owned by closed national banks in the New York district will be held at 2:30 P. M. today in The Jamaica High School, Jamaica, L. I. About 110 properties owned by eight Long Island banks will be offered, including forty dwellings and forty-five store, apartment and business buildings.

MANHATTAN ASHLEY, VICTOR (July 14). Estate, $450. To Minnie A. Ashley, sister, 120 W. 102d St. BORLAND, MARGARET W. (June 20). Estate, less than $5,000. To Alexander M. Christie, nephew, executor, Biltmore Hotel.
The annual stag dinner was held tonight at the Rumson Country Club for the members of the Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association and visiting owners and their friends.

Another sharp decline in second grade railroad issues was the feature of trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Several times during the day almost no bids appeared for many of the secondary rails and the group registered one of its most severe breaks in the current downward movement with net losses from 1 to almost 9 points.

Miss Frances Hewitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Vance Hewitt of 970 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in Christ Church to Charles Clark Austin, son of Mrs. Eberhard Hugo Heller, also of this city, and the late Charles Wilbur Austin. The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo performed the ceremony.

United States Senator A. Harry Moore does "not intend" to appoint Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City to fill his unexpired term if he is elected Governor of New Jersey next month, according to a letter from the Senator made public today by William A. Lord of this community.

The Committee for Industrial Organization named a committee here today to meet with representatives of the American Federation of Labor in Washington on Oct. 25 to arrange a conference to unify the nation's labor movement.
Will E. Chapin, cartoonist and writer, died at his home here today at the age of 80. Mr. Chapin, was born in Rahway, N. J., and at 17 he was doing cartoons for Leslie's Weekly.
Stackpole will publish on Oct. 25 an unofficial biography of Arthur Brisbane by Oliver Carlson, coauthor of "Hearst: Lord of San Simeon." The title is "Brisbane: A Candid Biography."
Mysterious Billy Smith, former world welterweight boxing champion, died here today at the age of 66.

Four thousand Italian and German war prisoners soon will earn their keep-by building a government railway from Madrid to Cuenca. Under-Secretary of Justice Mariano Anso said the government plan would follow the practice in many wars of working the prisoners-but humanely and

The Rev. Dr. Thomas Hanna Mackenzie, minister for thirty-two years of the First Reformed Church of Flushing, Bowne Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens, announced yesterday the acceptance by the congregation of his resignation effective "about Feb. 1, 1938," when he will reach retirement age.

The Pennsylvania Railroad today stated it would be willing to place in the hands of trustees for a period of ten years the stock it owns in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, and such stock or other securities as may be issued to it in exchange for its present holdings as a result of the reorganization of the New Haven.

THOUGHT, by Frank Herbert Brabant, M. A. (Longmans, Green, $5.) This is a series of eight lectures delivered at Oxford last year on the Bampton Foundation. The Rev. Mr. Brabant, principal of the Mackenzie Memorial College, Zululand, discusses the relation between the temporal and the eternal.

Additional transactions in equity securities in August and earlier months by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations were made public today in a supplemental summary issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MANHATTAN CAFFERATA, GEORGE (Oct. 19, 1936). Gross assets, $28,884; net, $26,807. To Delicia Cafferata, sister. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $14,445. Charles Zerbarini, attorney, 337 Broadway.
Dr. Ramon Parpacen, president of the Federal High Court of Repeal and author of important judicial works, died here yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Stella Rae Carter, daughter of Mrs. Oliver Goldsmith Carter of 1,440 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Carter, to Alvah Weeks Haff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvah Cornell Haff, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother. The Rev. John Howard Melish performed the ceremony.

The Government made a formal charge of tax fraud today against Richard M. Cadwalader Jr. and wife, of Fort Washington, Pa., recently accused by a Treasury official of incorporating their $2,000,000 yacht, the Savarona, in an effort to reduce tax payments.

There have been many rumors recently to the effect that the Government is planning to move to Barcelona, but it was not until today that anything authoritative has been divulged and then only indirectly through an article in the newspaper Adelante in Valencia.

A celebration of the centenary of the birth of Dwight L. Moody, the evangelist, will be held in Carnegie Hall Oct. 27 at 8 P. M., under the auspices of the New York Moody Centenary Committee, the Greater New York Federation of Churches and near-by church federations.
Automobile production this week rose to 89,635 cars and trucks, compared with 71,959 last week and 50,585 in the corresponding week a year ago, Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today.

Although per capital crop production is much lower than during the Nineteen Twenties, this year's production is only 6 per cent below the peak reached in 1920 and is the largest since 1928, according to an analysis made by C. M. Purves of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and published in the October issue of The Agricultural Situation.
The rights and title of the Florenz Ziegfeld estate to seventy-two musical productions were sold at public auction in the Westchester County Court House today for $28,000.

Reflecting the uncertainty that has gripped the new issue-market as a result of the unsettled conditions in security markets, the volume of new bond financing this week dwindled to $2,850,000, the smallest total for any period since the week ended Aug. 6, when only $2,288,000 in new loans were marketed.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

As a preliminary to the Army-Yale game of tomorrow, the Jayvee elevens of the rival institutions clashed on Yale Field today. The Elis won, 13-6, scoring two touchdowns soon after the opening whistle. Both markers came after stubbornly contested advances. The first was the result of a series of short gains totaling thirty yards, with Johnny Graham taking the ball across.

V. E. Townsend, representative of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced today that coastwise longshoremen had voted to strike at midnight in South Atlantic ports. Some 1,200 workers walked out at Tampa, on the Gulf coast, this morning.

Reviewing the work of the Licenses and Docks Departments in the last four years as Lessons 3 and 4 in the educational series he is giving for Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Mayor La Guardia delivered a blistering attack yesterday on the "unbelievable" conditions under which licenses were administered by Tammany.

Miss Marjorie Tomlinson was introduced to society here today at a reception for 400 given by her mother, Mrs. Aglar Cook, at her home. The debutante was graduated in June from Westover School. The family formerly lived in Montclair. Miss Tomlinson will be honored The again Dec. 27 at a dance at Morris County Golf Club.

Driving to a touchdown in the first two minutes of play, Bayonne High School's eleven downed Lincoln of Jersey City today, 6 to 0, for its first Hudson County football victory. A 13-yard pass from Sid Duckman to Eddie Szycher\in the end zone climaxed a 50-yard march for the score. Bayonne made ten first downs to Lincoln's three.

When the Hamburg American liner Hansa arrived at Quarantine yesterday from the Channel ports with 866 passengers she was held an hour and fifteen minutes at anchor while Dr. C. V. Aiken, the Public Health officer, boarded the ship and examined the crew.

The marriage of Miss Isabel Wallace Andrew, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Henry Andrew of 163 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, to John Moffett Beery, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Beery of 118 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Phillips P. Elliott.

Working at full time and parttime jobs 617 students at the City College are expected to earn more than $5,000 during the first month of the Fall semester, according to a report issued yesterday by Alfred L. Rose, manager of the college employment bureau.

Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, was honored last night at a "decennial" dinner tendered him by his associates in the local advertising field during the last ten years. More than forty were present at the event, held in the Hotel Lafayette.

Colonel Frederick Pope, Count Theo Rossi, Arnaldo Cortesi, Colonel Vincenzo Coppola, military attache of the Italian Embassy in Washington, and Mrs. Coppola; Countess Leonardo Vitetti, Joseph Bissett and Robert P. Farnsworth are booked to leave today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex.

John P. MacSweeney, old-time actor in comic opera in New York, died last night in the Brunswick Home here, in his eighty-first year. Mr. MacSweeney had lived at the home for several years and before that at the Percy Williams Home, East Islip, L. I.

Hope for a cure for the chronic alcoholic, within certain restrictions, appeared today on the horizon of medical achievement, as the first report of a pioneer study of alcoholism was published in The New England Journal of Medicine.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 13: REAR ADMIRALS DeFrees, J. R.. Commander of Submarine Force, U. S. Fleet, to duty as director of Shore Establishments, Navy Department, Washington, D. C., Oct. 25.

Agricultural Adjustment Administration officials estimated today that 185,050 farmers in New England, New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania would share payments of about $8,000,000 this year for participating in the 1937 soil conservation program.
Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale Brothers, will be guest speaker Wednesday at the annual Fall luncheon meeting of the National Notion Association in the Hotel McAlpin.

What is probably the best competitive field that has been seen in any hunts meet in the metropolitan area this year is promised for the twelfth running of the Monmouth County Hunt Gold Cup, feature of seven events at the annual meeting of the Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association today on the estate of Amory L. Haskell at Red Bank, N. J.

Miss Marta Laird Goldsborough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Goldsborough of this place, was married to Russell Wetmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Wetmore of New York, this evening in Christ Church, Pelham Manor. The Rev. Edward Thomas Taggard officiated.

Mr. John L. Lewis and Mr. William Green have been burying the hatchet in each other so savagely for so many months that it will not be easy for them to bury it anywhere else. The rift in the ranks of union labor has been marked by great bitterness of feeling.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Fayant have left the Barclay for their Winter home in Miami Beach, Fla. Lord Decies, who arrived on the Normandie, is at the Plaza.
The eleven-room Colonial residence at 105 Hamilton Avenue. in the Highwood Park section of Weehawken, N. J., has been purchased for occupancy by William S. Stuhr, an attorney.

Miss Nancy Penn Smith, daughter of Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart, was introduced to Philadelphia society tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Stewart at a dinner dance which they gave at Brooklawn, their home in Unionville.

Possibility of obtaining Federal aid in solving the guaranteed mortgage certificate problem and the creation of a system of State mortgage banks were explored yesterday at a hearing at the Bar Association Building conducted by the Joseph-Pack legislative committee on guaranteed mortgages.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st grade William F. Mullins of Engine 246 died Oct. 13. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 1,989 E. 29th St., Brooklyn, at 10 A. M., Saturday, Oct. 16. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery, Borough of Brooklyn.

Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers almost doubled its membership in the metropolitan area in the last two years by organizing semiskilled and unskilled workers in electrical equipment plants in Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island, Bert Kirkman, president of the local, testified yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Ruth Hutchinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Hutchinson of Hastings-on-Hudson, to Malcolm Young Jr., son of Mrs. Robert H. Strahan of Sands Point, L. I., and of Colonel Malcolm Young of Santa Barbara, Calif., took place here this afternoon in the South Presbyterian Church.

Former Mayor James J. Walker said last night that the twenty-acre estate known as St. Timothy's Farm, at Northport, L. I., had been put up for sale by the corporation of which he and Mrs. Walker are members.

Clarence J. Shearn, former justice of the Appellate Division and former president of the New York City Bar Association, recommended last night the election of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, and, describing himself as an independent Democrat, said he would "rather be right than regular."

Continental Securities Corporation--Sept. 30: Net asset value estimated by the company at $80.15 a share of preferred stock, on which accumulated dividends amount to $28.75 a share. This compares with $149.75 a preferred share on Dec. 31 and with $123.95 a share on Sept. 30, 1936.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Since my own college days, nearly a decade ago, I have been following college football enthusiastically every Fall. While attending a number. of the games played by my alma mater, I also have made it a point to see other leading elevens in action in the course of a season.

Miss Jean Daniels of Worcester rode the chestnut gelding Erin's Son, owned by the Audwill Stables, to victory for the third time in a row in the ladies' hunter class and retired the coveted Copley-Plaza Challenge Trophy at the annual Boston Horse Show at the Commonwealth Armory tonight. More than 3,000 witnessed the seeond-day program.

Colder weather and heavy Columbus Day buying lifted retail trade to the fastest rate this Fall, and the volume for the country was 2 to 8 per cent above the previous week, but gains over last year were reduced to 4 to 16 per cent, according to the weekly trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

The fashioning of scientific apparatus which constitutes "windows into life," through which man has been enabled at last to observe the various building blocks out of which nature has designed her infinite variety of living creatures, and to study their patterns and sizes, was described here today by Professor The Svedberg, of Upsala University, Sweden, Nobel Prize winner and one of the world's leading scientists.

Sally Ryan, 21-year-old daughter of Allan A. Ryan and granddaughter of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, will open the first New York exhibition of her sculpture on Monday at the Marie Sterner Galleries, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street.

More and more countries, some of which were at first opposed to the idea of reopening the Paris exhibition next year, have recently informed exhibition authorities that they will now agree to its continuation. While some are willing to pay the cost of keeping their buildings in repair, others seem to expect the exhibition authorities-that. is to say, the French Government-to do so and provide heating.

Al Brady's body went into a grave today, unmourned, unattended and unmarked. The Indiana gang leader, killed with his chief aide, Clarence Lee Shaffer Jr., in a Federal machine gun coup here on Columbus Day, was buried in an isolated section of Mount Hope Cemetery.

Another blunt warning that the British Government does not propose "to acquiesce in dilatory tactics" in the renewed efforts to solve the problem of foreign intervention in Spain was voiced by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden tonight on the eve of the revival of the Non-Intervention Committee to take up the Spanish problem.

The United States Treasury has issued a call to its depository banks in this Federal Reserve district for the repayment on next Monday of $9,897,800 or 5 per cent of the amounts on deposit for the account of subscriptions to the 1 3/8 per cent and 1 3/4 per cent Treasury notes dated June 15, 1937.

Justice Charles Poletti of the Supreme Court, addressing the convention of the State League of Women Voters today just before his wife was elected president of the league, urged that delegates to the State Constitutional Convention be elected on a nonpartisan basis.

A drill against Syracuse plays marked Cornell's workout tonight for tomorrow's fourteenth meeting of the Orange and the Red. The Orange squad stayed overnight in near-by Cortland. Cornell has won all but three of the thirteen games played since 1891.
Deliveries of refined sugar by refiners, beet sugar companies and importers were smaller in September than a year before, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today.

The Commerce Department announced today cold-storage holdings of fishery products in the United States on Sept. 15 totaled 69,322,000 pounds, or 18 per cent less than a year ago. Holdings, however, were 2 per cent greater than the fiveyear average of 67,633,000 pounds. During the month ended Sept. 15 15,674,000 pounds of products were frozen, compared with 17,752,000 pounds in the corresponding period of 1936.

The marriage of Mrs. Clara Barclay Gilbert of Hewlett, L. I., daughter of Mrs. John Lord Boatwright of this city and of J. Victor Onativia, to Paul Frederick Bubendey took place yesterday afternoon at 3 East Seventy-seventh Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Philip C. Jones.

Lord Decies, Irish peer who arrived in New York on Thursday on the French liner Normandie without his passport, which had been stolen last Saturday in the Gare St. Lazaire in Paris, sailed yesterday on the Normandie for Havre.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Law Revision heard yesterday pleas for greater safeguards on the unearned premium reserves and loss reserves of insurance companies and for greater latitude in permitting insurance companies to make foreign investments, especially in Canada.

Cotton-mill activity was unchanged last week, when the seasonal trend called for an increase, and the adjusted index has eased to 118.2 from 119.7. For the week ended Oct. 10, 1936, the figure was 123.2.
The Ripley plan of reorganization of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., was approved today at a meeting of bondholders here.
The Government offered surplus big game for sale today on four of the Western preserves supervised by the Biological Survey.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on exhibition this morning the discoveries of its 1936 Iranian expedition, including pottery which "opens a new chapter in the history of Islamic ceramics, according to Dr. Maurice S. Dimand, curator of Near Eastern Art.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York has been appointed trustee under the trust mortgage indenture of the Central New York Power Corporation, on the terms of which $48,364,000 of general mortgage bonds, 3 3/4 per cent series, due on Oct. 1, 1962, have been issued.

The two-story business building at 40-24 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, near Roosevelt Avenue, has been sold to an investing client of Arthur Friedenheit Company by the Genevieve Realty Corporation.

Walton. Ave, 721 (9-2473); Arlington Estates, Inc. to Brewster Properties. Inc, 295 Madison Ave, due as per bond, 6 per cent; $24,000. Bathgate Ave, 1,721 (11-2915): Jo-An Arbor Trading Corp to Bowery Savings Bank, extends mtg to Aug. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent ; $30,000. Walton Ave, 721 (9-2473): Arlington Estates, Inc. to Nerwal Realty Corp, 522 5th Ave. installments, 5 1/2 per cent; $31,125.

The Navy Department today forwarded to the Commandant of the Third Naval District, New York City, a silver life-saving medal for presentation to Richard M. Hesselman, 42 years old, ex-seaman second class, of Kilbourne Road. Garden City.
Mr. Bruce Barton is run for Congress on a repealer platform. He thinks there are too many statutes on the books, and if elected he promises to wipe out a law a week.
Professor Frederick W. Revels, director of the Department of Architecture, Syracuse University, died yesterday after a two-year illness of heart disease.

Reports of construction of various types begun during September in the thirty-seven Eastern States show a drop of about 10 per cent from the figure for the same month of last year, according to the F. D. Dodge Corporation.

Miss Lois Parker Wilkinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vinton Parker Wilkinson of Silverholm, here, was married to William J. Hardiman, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cleveland Hardiman of Watertown, N. Y., this evening in St. John's Chapel here. The Rev. Dr. Charles T. Walkley officiated.
The war Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 14: COLONEL James, L. R.. Inf., to retirement.
Shunted back and forth by two bodies more than a week, a compromise Chain-Store Tax Bill won final legislative approval tonight when the House concurred in the Senate measure, 66 to 11.

Suffield Academy opened its home season today by playing a 7-to-7 deadlock with the Hopkins Grammar School eleven of New Haven. Suffield scored on a long pass from Rogers to Pira in the second quarter and Kelley bucked the line for the extra point. Hopkins came back strong in the second half, but did not score until early in the fourth quarter.
Percy C. Brooks, executive vice president of Fairbanks, Morse Co., died today at his home here after a long illness.

Paul Kaufman, an official of the Bushwick Clothing Company, 199 Cook Street, Brooklyn, was robbed of a $2,000 payroll by three men who accosted him in a second-floor hallway of the building about 1 P. M. yesterday.

Will Vote on Stock Split A special meeting of common stockholders of the Hercules Powder company has been called in Wilnington, Del., on Nov. 4 to vote on proposed two-for-one split of the commonn shares. If approved, stockholders of record of Nov. 12 will receivee one additional share for each common share held.

The pianist Michael Zadora, no stranger to the Town Hall, appeared there in recital last night. A considerable audience heard a program that began with Scarlatti's E major sonata, the pianist's own arrangement of a Bach Preludio familiar to violinists as part of the E major solo sonata, and List's Phantasy and Fugue on the theme B-A-C-H.

A Japanese Army spokesman said today feverish efforts of General Yen Hsi-shan to save his personal fortune of $10,000,000 in art treasures was the major inspiration of the stubborn Chinese resistance against Japan's invasion of Shansi Province.

Dr. Carl Jung, Professor of Psychology of the Technical University at Zurich, Switzerland, arrived yesterday on the Hansa of the Hamburg American Line to give the Dwight H. Terry lectures at Yale University. He will deliver four lectures on "Applied Psychology and Religion."
John E. Cope Morton, a partner in Biddie, Whelen Co., stock brokers, until his retirement, died of pneumonia Wednesday in the Bryn Mawr Hospital in his sixty-first year. His home was in Devon.

Izzy Gastanaga, Cuban heavyweight who scored a sensational two-round knockout over Lorenzo Pack last month, won a ten-round decision from John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion of the world, in an overweight bout tonight.

The consolidated report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $195,504,204.
Harold R. Young was the broker in the sale of the H. C. Hagen dwelling on Woodlawn Drive, Plandome, L. I., to Thomas Lavery.

A Georgia team will meet rivals from Louisiana or Arkansas tomorrow in the Southern States four-ball golf tournament for the newly offered Bobby Jones Trophy. Semi-Finalists Fred Haas and Edwin McClure of Louisiana and Frank Stiedle and Collins Gaines

The Pennsylvania Utilities Commission today lost its fight to impose a temporary reduced rate schedule on the Edison Light and Power Company of York, Pa., in a two-toone opinion in the Federal Circuit Court here.
Miss Mary-Martha Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Lawrence of Maple-Brae, Moylan, was married this evening to James Percy Sill Jr., son of Mrs. Richard Crockford of Media.

Preliminary plans for the new Hunter College building, which will replace that which burned at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street in 1936, were submitted yesterday to the administrative committee in charge of the project.
74th St, 9 E, 5-story dwelling, 20x100.2; Mutual Life Insurance Co of New York against 9 E 74th St Corp; due. $91,258; taxes, etc, $6.066: adjourned sine die. By THOMAS F. BURCHILL
Dissension developed today between the White Plains City Council and the Board of Education over the granting of full salary restorations to school teachers.

With its speedy captain and left halfback, Nick Cavagnaro, showing the way, the Brooklyn Prep football.team scored its first victory in three times out this season by overpowering Fordham Prep, 18-7, at Fordham Field yesterday. A crowd of 1,000 saw the game.

Miss Margaret Maitland Houston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Houston 2d, of Houstonia, Chester, and Welch, W. Va.. was married this afternoon to Charles Stuart Brown, son of Mrs. Medford J. Brown of Merion.

Acting on the belief that Tony Lazzeri has a chance to sign with a "major league club either as a coach or as assistant manager," the Yankees announced yesterday that they had given their veteran and star second baseman his unconditional release.

Pointing out that the railroads had increased the factor of safety in train operation continuously for many years, W. J. Patterson, director of the Bureau of Safety of the Interstate Commerce Commission, in a speech before the New York Railroad Club in the Hotel Commodore last night urged the managements to continue these efforts with particular application to new types of trains moving at 100 miles an hour or more.
Stocks fluctuated erratically and most of them closed lower; steel shares higher, motor and specialties weakened; turnover, 2,538,270 shares.

Member trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 22.41 per cent of the total volume in the week ended on Sept. 18, against 19.44 per cent in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Western Maryland conquered the Upsala College eleven in the first game under lights here tonight, 19 to 0. The Terrors stuck to straight football to tally touchdowns in the first, third and fourth periods. The line plunging of Baylesh for Western Maryland and Grugash's passing to MacQuillan featured the attack.

BROWN vs. Dartmouth--The information contained herein has been secured from usually unreliable sources and is not guaranteed. Shake well before using. The horse race known as the Withers was not named after the ridge between the shoulders of a horse but after one David Withers who was one of the rulers of racing back in the days of the American Jockey Club.

Representatives of women's clubs and consumers' organizations throughout the city met yesterday afternoon with William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, at his offices at 139 Center Street and laid plans for a city-wide drive to enlist consumer support for a proposed city ordinance which would make compulsory the government grading of all meats.

The Vatican semi-official news service published today an official denial of assertions attributed yesterday to private Vatican sources that instructions already had gone to missionaries in the Far East regarding their conduct in the conflict between China and Japan.

Cooperation by cotton mills with the Department of Agriculture in experiments in the use of cotton fabric for cotton bale covering was urged by Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, in a letter to mills made public yesterday.

For the second time within a week the government today conferred various classes of the newly instituted Order of the German Eagle on foreigners. Among the thirteen receiving the Grand Cross was Achille Starace, secretary general of the Fascist party.

The judges of the New Jersey coast prize fishing competition, conducted by the Beach Haven Tuna Club, have come forward to announce the winners in this contest, which has eight classifications. The awards will not be made until Tuesday, when the club will hold its annual dinner at the Hotel New Yorker.
Mrs. Frederick H. Brooke of Washington was elected president of Girl Scouts, Inc., today to succeed Mrs. Herbert Hoover.
Officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today plans to remove 25,000 bushels of this year's large potato crop from normal trade channels.
The Rev. Dr. Alonso J. Turkle, a leader in National and Pittsburgh Lutheran Church circles, died yesterday at the age of 78.

Miss Mary E. Welsh, retired public school teacher, died here Wednesday in St. Francis Hospital. She was born in Poughkeepsie, daughter of James and Anna Farrell Welsh, and taught the third grade in Robert Livingston School, Poughkeepsie, for several years.
A dispute involving six workmen at the Fisher Body Plant No. 1 this afternoon caused the company to close the factory for the remainder of the day. Several thousand men were sent home.

The tone in most sections of the stock market today was irregular, but in late dealings, under the impetus of renewed buying, numerous higher prices were recorded. Gilt-edge issues and prime investments were well supported, but the Far Eastern list was generally lower.
Brown and Dartmouth drilled on the same field today in preparation for tomorrow's twenty-eighth meeting in a series that dates back to 1894.

The annual black-and-white exhibition by members of the Salmagundi Club opened last evening in the club gallery. Etchings, pencil drawings, illustrations, lithographs, sanguine sketches, crayon drawings and wood-block prints are included.

Miss Carolyn Flagler Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Heber Morgan of this city, was married tonight in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church here to Norman Brassler, son of Mrs. Otto Brassler of Englewood and the late Mr. Brassler. The Rev. Donald MacAdie officiated.
James A. Marcus, veteran stage and screen actor, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.
William Henry Meadowcroft, who was an assistant and confidential secretary of the late Thomas A. Edison, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home here.
Head Coach Fritz Crisler led his Princeton Tigers into the city today for their intersectional clash with the University of Chicago Maroons at Stagg Field tomorrow.

"Clearly avoidable by the police" was the verdict placed on the South Chicago steel strike disorder of Memorial Day, in which ten men were killed, in a resolution made public today by the executive committee of the Citizens Emergency Committee on Industrial Relations.

Manhattan Alterations Washington St, 507-9; to 5-story warehouse; Vito Genovese, 184 Thompson St, owner; A. R. Fritz. architect; cost, $10,000. 10th Ave, 756; to 5-story tenement and stores; Louis Ellinger, Mill Rd, Valley Cottage, N. Y., owner; De Rose Cavalleri, architects; cost, $4,000.

President Roosevelt today said that mediation between Japan and China was one method contemplated by this country as an active step to end the international lawlessness which, he declared last week, menaced the security of the United States.

Treasury officials and Congressional leaders will not be ready for tax legislation during the special session of Congress starting Nov. 15, but an Administration bill will be introduced at the regular session beginning in January.

The dance recital season was officially opened last night when Betty White made her local debut in a program of her own compositions at the Barbizon-Plaza. It was a modest opening, indeed, for the program was a brief one and the audience was small, but within the limits of its dimensions it reflected nothing but credit upon Miss White.

Twenty-three more claimants to the $800,000 estate of Ida E. Wood, widow of Benjamin E. Wood, were stricken yesterday from the list of heirs, which originally numbered more than 1,000, by Surrogate Foley on a motion of Joseph A. Cox, counsel for the Public Administrator.

Julio Bird Cerra, who was in charge of Puerto Rican Civilian Conservation Corps camps, died here today as a result of three stab wounds received in a fight with Manuel Sabo Rodriguez, public bus starter, following a quarrel over traffic with a bus driver.

Samuel Leibowitz, New York lawyer, filed suit today against Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean for $15,000, which he said was due him for defending Richard Bruno Hauptmann, German carpenter executed for the kidnap murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

Because of the rapid recent decline of the market value of its general consolidated 5 per cent mortgage bonds and the pressure of banks for more collateral, the Lehigh Valley Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to pledge and repledge more of these bonds as security for $1,800,000 in notes held by the Philadelphia National Bank, the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo and the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York.

Effective for the period Oct. 18 to 31, the German import duty on pig iron has been reduced from 1.00 reichmark to 0.10 reichmark per kilo, according to a cabled message from Commercial Attache Douglas Miller at Berlin, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Miss Marjorie Gordon Currie, daughter of Mrs. Harry Greene Currie of this city and the late Mr. Currie, was married to Wilson Frank Reeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay W. Reeder of Norwalk, Ohio, this evening at the Woman's Club of Orange. The Rev. Harold E. Nicely, pastor of Central Brick Presbyterian Church here, performed the ceremony.

The resignation of Dean Milton E. Loomis as head of New York University's Washington Square College was due to "faculty opposition" to his program of "progressive education," the presence of' which "jeopardized" the success of the program, according to a letter Dean Loomis wrote to The Washington Square College Bulletin, undergraduate publication, which appeared yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia, accompanied by Mrs. La Guardia, officiated at the opening of two playgrounds at opposite ends of the city within three-quarters of an hour last night. He opened one at South Jamaica, Queens, at 8:15 P. M. and another in Harlem at 9 P. M.

Dr. Albert Shaw retired yesterday as editor of The Digest, the weekly news magazine representing the merger of The Literary Digest and Review of Reviews, transferring the entire Shaw interest in the Review of Reviews Corporation, publishers of the weekly, to a syndicate headed by George F. Havell, it was announced by the concern.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, accused Mayor La Guardia last night of failure to keep a 1933 campaign pledge to eliminate fire-trap schools and to provide a seat for every school child.

Answering an appeal of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek for help to fight Japan, China's women are converting their wedding rings into bullets. Every day thousands of pieces of gold and silver jewelry are turned in to the Government's national war fund.
Dr. Frank A. Garis, who had practiced medicine here for forty-five years, died at his home in Germantown today at the age of 70.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by teh United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Two of America's outstanding women golfers, Mrs. E. H. Vare Jr. of the Philadelphia Country Club and Miss Jean Bauer of East Providence, R. I., will meet in the final round of the Berthellyn Cup Tournament at Huntingdon Valley tomorrow.

The section of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's speech in which he referred to Italian intervention in Spain follows: Events of the past year-so cruel in the sufferings they have imposed on the Spanish peoplehave not caused us to modify the judgment that intervention is a
Reflecting continued business improvement in the industry, the Union Oil Company of California yesterday reported that its earnings to Sept. 30 were the best for

Pittsburgh's Rose Bowl champions, heralded as the strongest football force in the East, were encamped at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, last night preparatory to meeting today the Fordham team whose Rose Bowl hopes last year were sunk by the margin of a point in the final game of the season.

From plant diseases to electrocardiography; from the colonial rivalries of France and Spain to the baffling problems of pellagra, the story of the "free inquiry" into the unknown made possible under the fellowship plan of the American Association of University Women is told in an attractive little booklet soon to be issued.
The AAA spent about $285,000 this week buying 1,265,040 dozen eggs, officials said today, in an effort to improve prices received by farmers.

The convention of the American Bankers Association annually affords an occasion for sampling the financial sentiment of the country. At these forums there are gathered together from all sections of the country several thousand representatives of the banking system, together with a liberal sprinkling of government officials.

Miss Harriet Farnham White, daughter of Mrs. Harry Kent White of this city, was married this afternoon to Stephen Brace Hibbard, son of Judge and Mrs. Charles L. Hibbard of Pittsfield, Mass. The bride is a sister of Mrs. L. Lawrence White of New York and Henry Kent White of Boston, whose wife is the former Miss' Priscilla Colt of Pittsfield.

A bill dent's proposal for navy reorganization which of the executive would create a "Navy General Staff" similar to the War Department, and thus abolish the present Navy General Board, will be introduced early in the next session of Congress by Representative Maas of Minnesota, a member of the Naval Affairs Committee.

A group of members of the Inwood Country Club, at Inwood, L. I., purchased a plot 140 by 170 feet at the foot of Montgomery Avenue with ocean frontage at Atlantic Beach and plan to organize the Inwood Beach Club.
A well-balanced Princeton cross-country team captured seven out of the first ten places today to conquer the New York University harriers, 16-45, in the opening meet of the Fall for both teams.
"Official honor" in Austria is regarded as such a tender plant that charges before courts of "wounding official honor" have become as typically Austrian as whipped cream or "The Blue Danube."

Mary Felts, Kansas City pianist, who made her debut at Town Hall last season, returned to that auditorium yesterday afternoon in a recital, during the course of which she made manifest the fact that her talents as interpreter find their most satisfactory outlet in works of the modernist school.

Several committees of prominent men and women haves been organized to assist with arrangements for the New York debut of William Fleming of California, young American pianist, on the night of Dec. 3 at Carnegie Hall. His recital will be a benefit for Huntington House, a residence club for girls which is conducted by Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

E. T. Bedford Davie, 23-yearold pilot from Tuxedo Park, N. Y., established a new world record for Class X outboard motor boats today by averaging 77.754 miles per hour in two spins over a one-mile course on Green Pond. The listed world's standard is 74.4 miles per hour, made by Jean Du Puy of France in Paris in the Spring of 1936.

War Admiral is virtually assured a post position in the Maryland Handicap here next Saturday. The Man o' War colt turned in by far the most impressive trial since he returned to training, going a mile and an eighth this morning in 1:52 2-5, and after being waved down went on to a mile and a quarter in 2:07.
IN 1896 Marya Sklodowska, a 29-year-old Polish assistant in the physical laboratory of Henri Becquerel in Paris, "while developing a photographic plate noticed that it showed two images:

Mrs. Elizabeth S. Field, daughter of ! Mrs. Hollister Sturges of Stone Ridge, and former wife of Henry Field of Chicago, was married to James Finan, a New York newspaper man, this afternoon at the residence of Mrs. David Margesson in Stone Ridge.
United States Consuls in Mexico, meeting here this week with high State Department officials and the embassy staff to consider the situation of United States investments in Mexico,

The firm of Arnold Co., which has membership in the New York Stock Exchange and associate membership in the New York Curb Exchange, has executed and delivered to the New York Stock Exchange an undertaking to dissolve on or before Oct. 20, according to an announcement this afternoon by the Securities and Exchange Commssion.

Australia's internal prosperity and the disturbed international situation are factors favoring Prime Minister J. A. Lyons in the general election Oct. 23. He has been Premier since January, 1932, shortly after the United Australia party under his leadership routed J. H. Scullin's Labor Government, of which Mr. Lyons had been a member.

Trustees of the Public Utilities Securities Corporation and the trustee of the Webster Securities Corporation have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 for approval of a plan of reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, the commission announced today.

In a threefold discussion of the labor movement, the employe, the employer and the consumer will advance their opposing points of view when representatives of each group are brought together at a labor forum called for Friday by the Westchester County Federation of Women.

AMERICA'S YESTERDAY. By F. Martin Brown. 8vo. Philadelphia, Pa.: J. R. Lippincott Company. $3.50. A study in American archaeology. SORROW BUILT A BRIDGE. By Katherine Burton. 12mo. New York: Longmans. Green Co. $2.50. A biography of Rose, youngest daughter of Nathaniel Hawthorne.

Norman Thomas of New York, Socialist leader, told the National Negro Congress here today that "war against fascism" should begin "at home in our own country" against such "evil forces" as "Jim Crow" discrimination and Ku Klux Klan terror.

Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean denied today that she had promised any payment to Samuel Leibowitz of New York for helping defend Bruno Hauptmann in the Lindbergh kidnap-murder case. Through her attorney, Nelson T. Hartson, she said she was "not indebted to Leibowitz in any sum whatsoever."
Five Philadelphia women were rescued from their burning automobile today after it rammed the rear of an oil truck, overturned and caught fire. Warren E. Walt, aged 40,
Arkansas bewildered the University of Texas eleven into a 21-10 defeat today. The victory ruined a hopedfor triumphant return of the Longhorn coach Dane X. Bible to Southwest Conference warfare.

The American Chamber of Commerce in Argentina has cabled Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission in Washington, urging the commission to approve a project to put fast, modern vessels in the New York-Buenos Aires service.

St. Lawrence Pe University, scoring two touchdowns Le in the second quarter and one in an the third, defeated Cortland Normal, 20-0, today. Goodrich and Leckonby made the first two tallies on off-tackle plays.

F Frances Brett Young never wrote another word he could well be content to rest his reputation on this magnificent book in which he tells the story of the great South African trek. It is not only far and away the best work he himself has done.
THE Forty-niners went west for gold. The Nineteen Forty-niners may cross the Rockies to Hollywood in quest of television.

Mlle. Suzanne Reynoud, French exchange student who is spending this year at the University of Vermont, said in a recent letter to The Vermont Cynic that American universities are more utilitarian than the French.

Recent plaints of women's college heads that women donors are not so generous as men in giving to education are called in question by figures just collected by Acting President A. C. Marts of Bucknell University.

Recommendations urging the people of the State to disapprove two proposed changes in the State Con-stitution were made public yesterday by the Board of Directors of the New York County Lawyers Association.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, heads the list of patrons for the annual Armistice Ball of the British Great War Veterans of America, which will be held on Armistice night, Nov. 11, in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

VIENNA. ANY one reading the Viennese papers the day after odor Mazaroff, the Bulgarian tenor, made his debut at the Staatsoper as Radames might have thought that Caruso had undergone the miracle of resurrection. "Habemus tenorem," "phenomenal," "sensational,"

NEVER a citadel of consistency, an uncrowded Times Square is now seeing a revival of one of the business practices of richer years. Though there are few shows, theatre owners are asking weekly guarantees of producers-in one case, a house seating less than 800 persons has set a figure of $2,500.

A preview opening of the Glass Hat, a new rendezvous at the Belmont Plaza, will take place on the night of Oct. 26 as a benefit for the Masters School, Day Nursery. The room will be opened to the public the following day.

SYDNEY, Australia. -- When the Australian Government announced that the national debt was 1,262,911,646 pounds and one penny, somebody signing himself "Patriot" forwarded to the Prime Minister a penny stamp. It was to be used, he stipulated, "to reduce the debt and bring it to round figures."

A series of lectures dealing with the different phases of the new Building Code will be given at the Federation Technical School, 116 East Sixteenth Street, beginning next Tuesday evening at 8:30 o'clock and on successive Tuesday evenings thereafter through Jan. 18, 1938. Experts prominent in va rious fields will lecture.
Circuit Judge H. R. Holland of Oakland County today granted an uncontested decree of divorce to Mrs. Dorothy Kemp Roosevelt, sister-inlaw of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Real estate trading in Manhattan, as shown by the transfers filed in the County Register's office, showed a marked improvement during the first nine months this year over the same period of 1936. Gains were noted in the number of deals recorded, the dollar volume of trading and in average market prices.

On income-producing properties probably the greatest single factor in retarding construction is lowrental income, declares Jones Wilder merserean, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York in the current Real Estate and Building Management Digest.

Millersville State Teachers College downed the Montclair Teachers, 7 to 6, in a thrilling battle today at College Field. Both teams tallied in the opening quarter, the Pennsylvanians scoring first when Frank Torok, fullback, plunged across from the 1-yard line.

TAKE Norman Douglas's "South Wind" and throw out the somnolent atmosphere, the Isle of Capri background of sea and grotto, substituting therefore the Queen City of Denver as it was yesterday and is today,
Mrs. Willard Parker Little, widow of Willard Parker Little, the architect, died on Friday night at her home, 23 East Seventy-fourth Street, after a long illness.

TWO compositions by Sibelius figure on the program this Thursday and Saturday nights in Cleveland, Ohio, by the Cleveland Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski. These are the symphonic fantasia, "Pohjola's Daughter," and the violin concerto, the latter with, Albert Spalding as soloist.
Dr. David Allen Robertson, president of Coucher College, has appointed a committee from the board of trustees to make plans for the celebration of the fiftieth birthday of the college next October.

David Lloyd George speaking at Carnarvon, North Wales, today described Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden as a "first class chauffeur" but added that he has an assembly of nervous wrecks behind him always pulling his elbow.

The hat an office worker wears, the tint of her nail polish and other points, both of appearance and manner, have been subjected to a critical analysis from her employer's viewpoint to form the basis of a "Personality Chart" now being distributed as a guide to the young business woman.

A moot trial in which both men and women will serve as jurors has been planned by the League of Women Voters of Queens for Tuesday evening as an answer to objections that have been made that jury schools for women only imply feminine intellectual inferiority.

MISS SHEILA BARRETT, the acidulous impressionist, has retrieved the Rainbow Room from such Summer indiscretions as badminton and "The Big Apple" dance and once again offers a program of her inimitable characterizations.

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW has been invited to broadcast to America on Nov. 2 from 4:20 to 4:35 P. M., opening a WJZ series of talks by leading thinkers of Great Britain, speaking under the general title, "As I See It." The speakers' list for later broadcasts includes: H. G. Wells and Lady Astor.
In a dramatic struggle Ray Morrison's Vanderbilt Commodores today defeated the Southern Methodist University team captained by his son. 6 to 0.

THE report is that the Eagles are screaming, partly with rage and partly in defiance. The Eagles are Bert Bell's professional football team representing the fair city of Philadelphia in the Eastern section of the double-jointed ro league and they have won just a single game of six played so far this season, which is enough to make anybody angry, beginning with Mr. Bert Bell, the old Penn quarterback.
TO all students of or readers interested in American history William Baringer makes a valuable contribution;
MR. JEFFERS goes back to an old Scots ballad, "Edward, Edward," for his title and he asks us to consider an old story as a modern symbol.

The wedding of Miss Florence J. Biggar, daughter of Mrs. J. Leslie Biggar of this place and the late Mr. Biggar, to F. Gilbert Wheeler of Locust Point, N. Y., took place here in the First Presbyterian Church this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Minot C. Morgan, the pastor, officiated.
A 57-yard touchdown by Ed McCormick, substitute halfback, gave the Princeton freshman eleven merited 7-0 triumph over the Columbia yearlings today on University Field before 1,000 spectators.
With the stock markets here closed, weekend. loans were plentiful- today at one-half of 1 per cent; three-month bills were steady at nine-sixteenths of 1 per cent.

The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, in conjunction with its junior league, will hold, as its first benefit in two years, a dinner and dance on Thanksgiving Eve at the Waldorf-Astoria. Two orchestras will provide music for the dancing, and various other divertissements, including a revue of stage, screen and radio artists, have been arranged for the evening.

Business in the New York wholesale market was spotty last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. The report continues:

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Bishop of Virginia since 1927 and for twenty-five years previously a missionary in Japan, was elected Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States at its triennial general convention today.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, former Police Commissioner, was "talking through his brass hat Friday night," when he expressed the opinion that a mass emigration of industrial plants might follow the re-election of Mayor La Guardia, Thomas A. Murray, president, and John J. Brennan, secretary, of the Building Trades Council, declared yesterday.

Arkansas will fill the Senate seat of Joseph T. Robinson in a special election Monday. Veteran observers predicted that not-more than 110,000 votes would settle the three weeks' campaign which split the Democratic party over Candidacies of Governor Bailey and Representative John E. Miller.

Miss Barbara Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Williams of this city, was married to Charles R. Nichols Jr., son of Mrs. Charles R. Nichols, also of Jersey City, and the late Captain Nichols, here this afternoon in St. John's

The marriage of Miss Amelia Scott Fullan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. -Henry Constantine Fullan of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, to William F. Mohan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Mohan of this city, took place yesterday morning in the chapel of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Forest Hills. The Rev. Joseph McLaughlin performed the ceremony.

We have been long accustomed to the complaints of employers against decisions of the National Labor Relations Board, but it was something of a novelty last week to see the board attacked by the country's two leading central labor organizations.

Mrs. Christopher D. Smithers of Dunrobin, heads a committee in charge of a sale for the country home for convalescent babies at Sea Cliff, which is to be held in Veteran's Hall, Glen Cove, on Oct. 19 and 20. Mrs. Paul Pryibil, president of the home, is co-chairman and Mrs. Charles V. Hickox of Westbury is assistant chairman.

URBAN New York having become garden - conscious, whether those gardens are tiny back yard patches or elaborately landscaped terraces, many residents are endeavoring to tempt migrating birds to the little bits of country they have managed to create in the midst of city brick and mortar.

The marriage of Miss Regina Therese Higgins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Francis Higgins of Flushing, to Lieutenant John Lathrop Throckmorton, U. S. A., of Kansas City, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Andrew's Church, Flushing. The Rev. Albert Steffens performed the ceremony.

Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington High School's middle distance ace, who until a month ago had never competed in a crosscountry run, yesterday. showed the way to a record field in the fifteenth annual Manhattan College interscholastic meet at Van Cortlandt Park. "The New York youngster impressively ran the two-anda-half-mile course in the excellent time of 11:33.3.

Karel Kozeluh and Joseph Whalen advanced to the singles semi-finals of the national open tennis tournament by capturing their quarter-final tests today. Kozeluh defeated Herman Peterson is straight sets, 6-4, 6-2, 6-1. The match was featured by lengthy rallies. Peterson made an auspicious start, forcing Kozeluh into errors and breaking through the latter's service once in the first set, but could not hold this pace.

A spectacular aerial thrust of 73 yards in the final period gained the favored University of Washington Huskies a 7-to-7 tie with the Washington State Cougars today in their Pacific Coast Conference football game before a home-coming crowd of 17,000.

IT does seem sometimes as though a certain kind of sociological romance had been reduced to almost a motionpicture formula, as follows: radical quarrels with capitalism; radical falls in love with communism and goes to Russia; radical quarrels with Russian communism; radical returns home, makes up with capitalism and lives happy ever after.

Miss Alexandrine du Pont of St. Amour, Wilmington, a distant cousin of Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., the former Miss Ethel du Pont, was married to Howard AI-fred Perkins Jr., also of this city, this afternoon in Westminster Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. John W. Christie performed the ceremony in the presence of a large gathering of relatives and friends.

La Nacion, Government-owned newspaper, denied today that former Finance Minister Gustavo Ross was visiting Washington to trade the Port of Arica to Bolivia in exchange for payment of Chile's foreign debt.
Premier John Metaxas left tonight for Turkey accompanied by several high Foreign Office officials and the Turkish envoy to Athens. He will arrive at Istanbul Monday,

Plans for the campaign to be made by Republican candidates for delegates to the constitutional convention were discussed yesterday at the second conference of candidates for delegates at large with State Chairman William S. Murray at State headquarters, 41 East Fortysecond Street.
