The College of New Rochelle, one of the largest Catholic colleges for women in the United States and first to be chartered in New York State, will celebrate its twentyninth annual Founder's Day on Saturday, Oct. 23, on the campus.

Robert Moses, Park Commiissioner, chairman of the Independent Committee for the Election of John G. L. Molloy as Manhattan COuncllman, urged yesterday all supporters of the La Guardia Administration to vote for Mr. Molloy.

THE large and well-selected exhibition, "American Contemporary Ceramics," now beautifully installed at the Whitney Museum, is the collection assembled by the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts for a tour of Sweden, Denmark, Finland and England last Spring. At the close of its stay at the Whitney it will go on tour to other American museums.

The first itemizing of the cost of the development of North Beach Airport came up last week when the Municipal Art Commission granted preliminary approval of the airport building plans. Having started at about $8,000,000 for the job, estimates for all items of improvement and new structures now approach $15,000,000.
-One hundred and fourteen patients, thirty of them bedridden, were removed to safety tonight when fire destroyed a cottage at the Newberry State Hospital.
Novices in rock-gardening ask in the Autumn, "What bulbs should I use?" One recently complained: "I've tried Dutch hyacinths, trumpet daffodils and Darwin tulips.

The marriage of Miss Anne Whitney Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose Whitney Rose of West Neck and Block Island, and Donald Frederick Hackstaff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Hackstaff of Huntington, took place tonight in the Presbyterian Church here.

A default judgment for $10,650.70 against James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Philip J. Dunn, personal attorney to John F. Curry, former Tammany chieftain. The judgment is for a personal loan of $7,500 made by Mr. Dunn to Mr. Hines on Nov. 20, 1930. Mr. Hines was served with the suit last Sept. 23 at his residence, 225 West 105th Street.
Former President Herbert C. Hoover was entertained by Professor Elliott Dunlap Smith, master of Saybrook College, at today's ArmyYale game and at a party given tonight by the Aurelian Club of Yale.
The Ku Klux Klan seems still to hold an important place in the life of the small towns of the deep South, if one can judge from the conversation of leading citizens of this little county seat.
Reports from Canadian mining companies for September show the industry-as a whole is maintaining normal production.

New York City's 40,000 educational employes, presenting a united front, will make a concerted effort to obtain State legislation this Winter enabling the city to erect $100,000,000 worth of new school buildings, materially reduce the size of classes and provide free kindergartens for thousands of children, officials disclosed yesterday.

Three thousand night workers on the Brooklyn-Manhattan. Transit Corporation lines, members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, voted unanimously yesterday morning to ratify the closedshop and 10 per cent wage increase agreement recently negotiated between their union and the company.

Lieut. Col. William P. Wattles, Signal Corps Reserve, U. S. A., and Mrs. Wattles of 2,301 Connecticut Avenue, Washington, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Brewster Wattles, to Lieutenant Neale R. Curtin, U. S. N., son of Mrs. T. A. Solberg of Stevenson, Md., formerly of Washington, and of the late Lieut. Comdr. Roland I. Curtin, U. S. N.

IF Rachel Crothers absents her self from the felicity of Broadway for five years at a time she is well within her rights. After writing Broadway plays for thirtyone years she is entitled to a few continuous sabbaticals. She began writing full-length plays with "The Three of Us" in 1906. Her first notable success was "A Man's World," in 1909.
TRADITIONAL: The Adams family of New England has been associated with the name of Harvard for nearly two centuries, ever since John Adams, second President of

IN the first half of the eighteenth century two young French boys were convicted in Abbeville of perpetrating sacrilegious jokes and were immediately sentenced to have their tongues torn out and their heads cut off. One was pardoned but the other suffered the full penalty.

A problem that has drawn much comment in financial circles in recent years is the difficulty in reaching holders of bearer bonds to acquaint them with organizationin proposals, liquidating dividends, conversion privileges, or plans for exchanges among the varied matterms which must be brought to the attention of such bondholders for the protection of their rights.

One of the most important weddings of the Autumn took place here this afternoon when Miss Mary Adeline Prentice, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Parmalee Prentice of New York, was married to Benjamin Davis Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Thorne Gilbert, also of New York, at Elm Tree House, ,Mount Hope Farm, the country residence of the bride's parents.
Another tradition carried on at Woman's College this week with the assignment to Professor A. C. Hall's junior class in American literature of the theme "Puritan Ancestors."

A single scoring thrust through the air in the second period gave James Monroe High School's football team a 7-to-0 victory over Evander Childs High eleven at Monroe Field yesterday before a crowd of 4,000.

Scoring its first point of the season, the University of Maine football eveven turned back a light Arnold team, 13 to 0, before nearly 3,000 at Alumni Field today. Maine's first touchdown was made midway in the first quarter on a 30-yard pass from Smith to Elliott, who raced 8 yards to tally.

In the interest of the MacDowell Colony for creative artists at Peterborough, N. H., the endowment fund committee of the organization is now seeking to increase the present inadequate endowment of the colony by $100,000 in order to assure its permanent maintenance. Ernest Schelling, president of the Edward MacDowell Association, is returning this week from Europe to resume leadership of the committee.

The Westchester County Clearing House Association reported a turnover of $3,267,028 in checks for the week ended on Friday. This compares with clearings of $3,706,273 in the preceding week and $2,999,324 a year ago.

If there is such a thing as being both the goat and the hero of a football game, Corby Davis, a 200-pound fullback from Lowell, Ind., was that today as Indiana, University pounded to a 13-to-6 victory over the University of Illinois.

American Red Cross nurses established a new record during the year ending June 30, 1937, by making 1,035,764 visits to or on behalf of sick persons, James L. Fieser, vice chairman in charge of domestic operations, announced today, coincident with the twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of Red Cross public health nursing.

Gettysburg's eleven unleashed a potent running attack coupled with some brilliant passing to topple Drexel's Dragons from the list of the unbeaten on Memorial Field today before 2,00, spectators. By virtue of the triumph Hen Bream's charges went into first place in the Eastern Pennsylvania Football Conference.
YOUNGHILL KANG -- born Chungpa Han thirty-four years ago in a Korean village-is not riding any theories as he sets down the tale of his adaptation to American life.
Stephen Hackett, 74 years old, of 2.111 Adams Street, a member of the Hoboken Board of Education for twenty years, died at his home last night of a heart attack.

The second season of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra, beginning Oct. 24 in Tel-Aviv under the direction of Hans Wilhelm Stein berg, will include three concerts berg, will include three concerts conducted by Arturo Toscanini, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will speak on "Problems of Youth" at a luncheon tomorrow at the Hotel Astor to open a campaign for $100,000 for the Women's League for Palestine. The fund will be used to build a home for immigrant girls in Jerusalem, and will be the third of its kind erected by the organization.
The University of Missouri had a defense today for everything except its own fumbles and bowed to Michigan State for the second straight year, 2 to 0.

A fighting St. Paul's School eleven today defeated Hackley School, 15-0. It was the first triumph in two starts for St. Paul's. Ed De Roy scored in the first quarter by running 30 yards after receiving a 10-yard pass from John Coughlin, and Kashmar added two points with a safety. Coughlin inade the final tally in the fourth period on a 5-yard jaunt around end.
Scoring two touchdowns in the first quarter and two in the final period, the Alfred University gridiron squad defeated the University of Buffalo, 25 to 13, tonight at Tonawanda Stadium.

Miss Dorothy Marie Sander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Henry Sander. was married here tonight at the home of her parents to Alfred Henry Meyer, son of Mrs. Elbert H. Meyer, also of Westfield, by the Rev. Arthur Francis O'Donnell.

Mr.and Mrs. Chester E. Saxton of Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, formerly of this city, have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie A. Saxton, to James Whitney King Jr. of 533 East Eighty fourth Street, this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. King of Birmingham, Ala.

As the result of a ten months' study of real. estate conditions throughout New Jersey, Samuel D. Walker of Keansburg, president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, declares that lower interest rates on mortgages is essential for definite realty progress.

The cornerstone of a community center in Dutch Colonial style at the School of Living, near Suffern, N. Y., will be laid at 3 o'clock this afternoon, it was announced by Ralph Borsodi, director of the school.

The semi-annual dean's list of honor students at the Stevens Institute of Technology was made public today by Dean Franklin DeRonde Furman. Forty-five students in the three upper classes whose work was "consistently excellent during the second and supplementary terms of the last college year," were named, as follows:

Members of the class of 1941 at Pembroke College in Brown University are a bit smarter, all around, than the entering classes of the previous two years, according to statistics at the admissions office. The inference is based on reports of the psychological tests given to all members of, the entering class.

Edward P. Haines, an engineer and inventor, died of a heart attack today at his home in Mount Airy. He was about 62 years old. Mr. Haines was a graduate of Westtown Boarding School and Cornell University, where he was an honor student.

Miss Cary Nicholas, daughter of Mrs. Harrison Trent Nicholas, of this city, and Pelton Phelps of Springfield, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Phelps of Winsted, Conn., were married tonight at Grace Memorial Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Richard Henry Lee. A reception followed at the home of the bride's mother.

HOPE HAMPTON has long been a name to reckon with in American stage, screen, operatic, and publicity annals. In spite of her retirement to domestic life, which she passes mainly in excursions to or from the Riviera under the name of Mrs.

Italy today agreed to the "partial withdrawal of a certain number of volunteers n equal quantity from both sides" n the Spanish civil war. Count Dino Grandi announced his government'ss acceptance in these carefullyy qualified terms at a meetng of the Non-Intervention subcommittee which had been called by Britain and France in a new and determined attempt to get foreign fightingg men from Spain.

PROPOSALS to build a new hotel at St. John, Antigua, and to clear Shirley Heights of jungle growth, has brought this British possession in the Leeward Islands again into the limelight. Lying about 200 miles southeast of the Virgin Islands, Antigua is a popular stop for West Indies

More than fifty faculty members of the University of Pennsylvania had left or were preparing to leave today for cities throughout the country to speak on Monday night at the opening of the university's $12,500,000 campaign in anticipation of its bicentennial celebration in 1940.

Walter N. Rothschild, chairman of the joint $6,250,000 campaign of the New York and Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities for 116 affiliated agencies, announced last night the chairmen of fund-raising groups in 141 trades and special divisions.
The scarcity of heavy frosts has kept the foliage of the Poconos at its most beautiful point for another week and it is expected that many will motor into the mountains this week-end.

The University of California's undefeated Bears put on the power in spurts to win a football double-header today, blanking the California Aggies, 14 to 0, and the College of the Pacific Tigers, 20 to 0, before more than 20,000 fans.
Class A was the most popular division of outboard racing in Eastern. regattas this season, according to the figures of Charles F. Chapman of New York, national racing commissioner.

Fermor S. Cannon of Indianapolis, who was elected president of the Society of Residential Appraisers at the recent convention in Los Angeles, told the delegates in his address that development of a new construction technique for houses will doubtless be noticeable in the future in those areas which are not highly standardized.
NOW as leaves turn gay and home fires brighten there is an increasing fragrance of cakes, pies and fancy breads a-baking for the national table. The Autumn "bake season" is on.

Insurance of mortgages on residential construction issued through the New York, Brooklyn, Jamaica and White Plains offices of the FHA during the first nine months of this year was 25 per cent more than the amount issued by the same offices during the similar period of 1936, Thomas G. Grace, State director, announced yesterday.

The development of a plan to combine liberal arts and commerce courses in the curriculum of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science was an outstanding step in maintaining the "threatened influence" of the humanities in a changing world, it was stated yesterday by Dean Irving H. Berg in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Hibbard Benson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Benson of East Orange, to Robert William Grace, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Grace of Bay Shore, L. I., took place this evening in the chapel of Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church here. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. Lloyd E. Foster, officiated.

Miss Helen Hinsdale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson H. Heath, and John P. Faude were married this afternoon at St. John's Church by the-Rev. William T. Hooper, rector. He was assisted by the Rev. Charles L. Taylor of Cambridge, Mass.

Vittorio Mussolini, twenty-oneyear-old son of the.Italian Premier, and who is an aviator and motion picture producer, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Rex for Naples accompanied by his friend and interpreter Mario del Pappa. They had been touring this country since Sept. 23.

The engagement of $1,832,000 gold in Canada for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Gold in London continued to fetch a premium over New York parity, shutting off the flow of gold here from Europe. No imports of the metal Europe. No imports of the metal were received here.

Yale's freshmen flattened Exeter today, 34 to 0, accounting for the highest score made in many years against the preparatory school boys. Reilly led the way with three touchdowns. The outcome was never in doubt, and the freshmen scored in every period but the second, when Exeter made a stubborn goal-line stand.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia are scheduled to speak at the thirtyeighth annual meeting of the New York State Conference on Social Work in New York City Tuesday through Friday, it was announced yesterday. The general headquarters of the conference will be at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The singing put forth by Montgomery Davis at his recital in Town Hall last night had much to commend it within the limits imposed by certain vocal shortcomings. His interpretations were sensitive. They had style and reflected unerring good taste.
Aubrey Williams, deputy administrator of the Works Progress Administration, said today that "government will have to keep up its workrelief program."

A typewriter which goes "backward" and writes in Hebrew today was presented to A. J. Goodman by his four daughters as a birthday gift. The machine was made by a nationally known typewriter concern, which Mr. Goodman said, maintained it never before had constructed one like it.

PHOTOGRAPHY has conquered in its own right so wide a field, become so flexible a medium in the hands of the camera man--reporter or artist--that it is possible to take from any large representative collection of the work of the country's best photographers today a group illustrating almost any sector of human, scientific or technical interest, or any artistic trend--classic, romantic or "modern."

Increase of interest in dramatics at Smith College during the last few years has resulted this Fall in three new features of the Dramatic Association's program, an additional production, a readjustment of the organization's technical activities and a new method of training apprentices.
Northwestern's Wildcats sharpened their claws between halves today and came back raging to conquer Purdue, 14 to 7, in a dramatic defense of their Big Ten gridiron championship.
Emory A. Stedman, retired vice president of the Railway Express Agency, died here late last night of pneumonia at the age of 75. He retired five years ago.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company and vice chairman of the 1937 Community Mobilization for Human Needs, said yesterday that gifts to community chests throughout the depression had been maintained at a more stable level than net incomes or total contributions shown in income tax reports to all philanthropies, including colleges and churches.

Public conceptions of the average college freshman are wrong, according to the conclusions of Charlotte Moody, who annually reads over 4,000 papers for the contemporary civilization course at Middlebury College. These papers give the reactions to current events in practically every country in the world.

The Westchester County Children's Association has completed plans for a benefit performance of "Susan and God" on Tuesday evening, Oct. 26, at the Plymouth Theatre in New York. Mrs. Ralph H. Matthiessen of Irvington-on-Hudson heads the committee in charge.

Among all post-war British political movements probably the one with the least effect on public life is Sir Oswald Mosley's Fascist organization. Consisting at most of a few hundred members, it would probably have died long ago despite Mosley's generous financial support and spectacular escapades if it were not that Communists and other anti-Nazis in overzealous position usually unwittingly find a way to make the Fascists news.
China's National Associated Chambers of Commerce appealed by cable today to the United States Chamber of Commerce to take economic action against Japan.

When the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria is formally opened on Thursday night for the late Autumn and Winter season, the occasion will be a benefit for the New York Exchange for Woman's Work. Many reservations for dinner and supper parties have been made for the opening celebration.

THESE collected poems by Lord Gorell are the work of an English poet who is probably little known outside England, where books from his pen have been appearing from time to time for something over three decades.

Miss Sylvia Quetting Bunce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Bunce of 451 East Eightyfourth Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Alexander Graham Siener, son of Mrs. Andrew Kruss of Long Island City, in the Church of the Holy Trinity, East Eighty-eighth Street, by the Rev. William Dietrich.

Miss Eleanor Lunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Washington Lunn of this place, was married this evening in the home of her parents to Rudolf Werner Leuthauser, son of Mrs. Theodore Leuthauser of Newark and the late Mr. Leuthauser.

Miss Catherine Marie Byrnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Byrnes of this place, was married here this morning in the Church of the Immaculate Heart of St. Mary to Robert Francis Flood of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice S. Flood of New Rochelle. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William Little.

Mrs. Frank M. Gould's Ostend soared on to his second conquest within a week when he got home in a stirring finish today to capture the Monmouth County Hunt Gold Cup to the cheers of a crowd of 8,000 who lined the rails and dotted the hillsides on the estate of Amory L. Haskell. On Columbus Day he captured the Long Island Hunt Cup at West Hills, L. I.

Sales of Czechoslovak merchandise of the types on which duty concessions may be granted in a reciprocal trade agreement with that country have fallen sharply in the last several weeks, importers complained here yesterday.

Foreign anxieties will push domestic necessities into the background when Parliament reassembles next Thursday after a recess of almost three months. For understandable reasons no great issue can rouse such anger among the Opposition parties as the British policy toward aggressor nations.
PROBABLY few living white men know more about the American Indian than Oliver La Farge, who is an anthropologist by profession and a director of the National Association on Indian Affairs.
A 22-yard forward pass play, with Fred Quarantillo taking the toss from Joe Brunskole, gave Canisius College a 7-0 victory over La Salle in their game at McCarthy Stadium today.

The marriage of Miss Agnes Louise Gill, daughter of Mrs. John J. Gill of 308 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Gill, to John Edward Rudden, son of Mrs. John Rudden, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Rudden,

MONTREUX. THE death this Sumer of Jean Bartholoni, honorary president of the Geneva Conservatory, was the occasion for a commemorative address by Alexandre Mottu, broadcast some days ago from Radio-Geneve.

THE thing about Gregory La Cava is that he does not want to jell. As Nature abhors the vacuum, so he abhors the exact. To him the optimum state is a perpetual state of flux. And that is probably why he is one of the most spontaneous directors in all of Hollywood.

Mrs. Sigrun Magnusson Lowden, 29 years old, obtained a divorce today on grounds of desertion from George Mortimer Pullman Lowden, 40, son of former Governor Frank 0. Lowden, after a brief hearing before Judge John J. Lupe.

IN 1787 Dr. William Rogers and Bishop William White asked permission to preach to the inmates of Philadelphia's infamous Walnut Street jail. Their request was so unheard of that the keeper refused them admittance.

The first contingent of the Salzburg Opera Guild, including thirtyfive principal singers, conductors and the technical staff, arrived yesterday from Europe on the French liner De Grasse to begin final rehearsals for the company's first American season.

Ken Mills's passes for a touchdown and Waleman Price's successful try for, the extra point late in the game gave Texas A. M. a 7-7 draw with Texas Christian University today in a mud battle before 27,000 fans.

Narragansett Park Race Track and the territory surrounding it for a distance of one mile on all sides were declared in a "state of insurreaction" by Governor Robert E. Quinn late tonight. The Governor, as commander of the military forces of the State, ordered Adjt. Gen. Herbert R. Dean to lead National Guardsmen there and take command with martial law prevailing.
Science as we know it is the child of democracy. Freedom of thought and of expression is the essence of both-a heritage from the British and French revolutions. That freedom is in peril.
Anthony Eden may be a They good Foreign Secretary, Shake but as a student of linHands guistics he leaves some thing to be desired. We are reminded of this by our London dispatches the other day.

"Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," given last night by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company, attracted a large audience. In the first, Norina Greco was the Santuzza, Myra Manning made her debut as Lola,

Paul Keres of Estonia, who won the international chess masters' tournament at Semmering, Austria, notwithstanding the participation of Jose R. Capablanca, Samuael Reshevsky, Reuben Fine and. Salo Flohr, introduced a novelty in his game with V. Ragosin, the Soviet representative, at his fourth move.

Senator Wheeler told an audience here last night that the United States could not rid the-world of "international anarchy" by going to war. "We would come out of war with more anarchy in the world than we have now," he said.

The New York Field Hockey Association has listed a series of interclub matches to be played at Prospect Park, among teams representing the Carroll, Clansman, Greenfield, Knickerbocker, Oriole and Cosmopolitan Clubs, Cosmos Cubs and the Etceteras.
Miss Elizabeth Cartier Gilbert Carter, daughter of George Carter of the St. Moritz and the late Mrs. Carter, was married yesterday morning at Sherry's to Hamilton Gates Ford, son of Mr. and Mrs.

THE English critics are as enthusiastic as were those in America over the performance of John Clements as the Red Commissar in "Knight Without Armour," which recently had its London premiere, and the English public agrees with them.

The Berlin State Opera plans for the coming season, according to its printed prospectus, include new productions of "Fidelio," "The Marriage of Figaro," "Der Freischuetz," "Tannhaeuser," "Lohengrin, "Tristan," "Zar und Zimmermann," "The Merry Wives of Windsor" and Gluck's "Armide."
An extra session of the Tennessee General Assembly, called by Governor Gordon Browning to enact into law a county-unit plan for determining primary nominations for Governor,

ONE of the most recent of United States issues to be counter feited is the Hawaiian Commemorative set of 1928. The issue consisted of the regular 2 and 5 cent stamps with the. surcharge "Hawaii, 1778-1928." The counterfeiters did an excellent job and only an expert can tell the difference between the real and forged items.
THEY say that I am the French playwright whose plays are most widely produced throughout the world. They tell me that my two novels have been translated into eight foreign languages.

"Save Plymouth" is the slogan under which will soon be revived the campaign to honor the memory of Calvin Coolidge by buying the property which includes the Coolidge homestead, the village store and the cemetery at Plymouth Union,

Highpressure living and keen competition for success are causing a dangerous prevalence of "the preoccupied mind," said Professor Roy F. Nichols of the University of Pennsylvania in an address today at the dedication of the new $250,000 Liberal Arts Building at Franklin and Marshall College.
The Pan American Grace airline will extend to Peru the c. o. d. freight service it has been operating between the United States and Caribbean republies.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Walton High School Exhibition Hall, 196th Street and Reservoir Avenue, the Bronx20 easel paintings, 39 graphic prints and 15 textiles of designs.

Athena Club of Freeport-Meeting, literature department, on "Milestones in American Literature," 2:30 P. M., home of Mrs. Robert G. Anderson. Bergenfield (NJ J.) Woman's ClubSenior-junior party, 8 P. M., Murray Hill Arms.

The State Mortgage Commission, organized in the early part of 1935 to unravel the tangled guaranteed mortgage certificate problem, is making steady progress in reorganizing the assets behind investments in these certificates and now has reached the half-way mark in its rehabilitation work.

The People's Front political machine, supporter of Premier Camille Chautemps's government, succeeded today in pulling the Socialist, Radical Socialist and Communist parties back into general accord on the eve of Cantonal run-off elections.

The marriage of Miss Ann Foster Eldredge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Eldredge of Cape May, to Lieutenant Linscott Alden Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hall of St. Louis, took place today in Glen. Ridge Congregational. Church. The Rev. Dr. William Patton officiated in the presence-of the immediate families and close friends.

Trinity earned a well-deserved victory over Hobart today, 7-0, in the most thrilling football contest seen in recent years on Trinity Field. The superiority of Trinity's rushing and passing game gave it 21 first downs to Hobart's 7, and kept most of the play in Hobart territory.

KING GEORGE VI opens his first Parliament next week, driving in the gilded state coach from Buckingham Palace to Westminster to read the speech from the throne in the House of Lords. It will be a gorgeous occasion.

A little more than six months ago, the world's worst school disaster occurred in this little town in the East Texas oil fields. Today workmen are making excavations for p the foundation of a new, more imposing building to replace the one destroyed by the blast, which caused nearly 300 deaths.
The' French Army was given the first choice today to buy large quantities of arms and munitions taken from Spaniards who have entered France since the beginning of the Spanish civil war.
With Brockmyer in a star role, the Union College eleven gained its third consecutive triumph today, defeating the University of Vermont, 17 to 6. Brockmyer scored two touchdowns.

THE author of this book, who already had traveled through Albania's wild districts as well as in the narrow streets of its towns, returned to that country in 1930 with a plan for establishing a tourist organization. He was also writing some articles based on his firsthand studies of Albanian affairs. All went well for a time.

THIS is Mr. Hemingway's first novel since "A Farewell to Arms" was published eight years ago. He has in the meantime produced a volume of short stories, "Winner Take Nothing," and two other books, "Death in the Afternoon" and "Green Hills of Africa."

The marriage of Miss Marie Brooke Heck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Callendine Heck of Linwood in this community, to James Tileston Baldwin, son of Mrs. James Clarke Tileston Baldwin of Chestnut Hill, Mass., took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattington at Locust Valley.

Dr. Mary Ashby Cheek, former dean of Mount Holyoke College, was inaugurated as tenth president of Rockford College today before scores of alumnae, from distant points and many dignitaries from other institutions. In her address, Dr. Cheek said that the woman's college had a definite contribution to make in the country's educational scheme.
Pope Pius expressed sympathy today for sufferings of German Catholics. His statement was made while he spoke to a group of pilgrims, among whom were twentytwo Germans from Duesseldorf.

With some lines already opened, current indications are that practically all types of men's clothing and furnishings will be either unchanged or slightly lower in price for Spring, manufacturers said here yesterday.

Milton Cramer and Shepherd Schaffer, seniors in the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University at Washington Square East, were named co-chairmen of the school's senior promenade which will be held the latter part of February, it was announced at the university yesterday.

Charles Bell Guthrie,. freight tariff expert, died today at the age of 71. Mr. Guthrie invented and patented a formula for indexing freight tariffs and wrote numerous books and bulletins on them, including the "Official Tariff Directory for the United States Shipping Board."
Secretary Perkins announced today that the United States Employment Service reported an increase in placements and a decline .in job applicants during September.
The Rev. Dr. John Calhoun, Pastor Emeritus of the Mount Airy Presbyterian Church, which he served forty-one years, died tonight at his home in Mount Airy after an extended illness. His age was 74.

NEARLY every conspicuous library that has been assembled in America during the last seventyfive years has gone the way of the auction room. When collectors come to make their final choice, as to whether they want their efforts to be crowned by a great sale or a great monument, the decision is almost invariably in favor of the former.

Measures embodying President Roosevelt's recommendations for reorganization of the executive branch of the government are ready for consideration, giving rise to a belief that this subject will command the attention of the special session of Congress Nov. 15 ahead of any of the other five items listed in the call, except the wages and hours bill.
The opening last Tuesday of the new West Side Improvement is causing much interest in real estate properties in communities north of the New York City line, reports James R. Murphy, auctioneer.
West Virginia's rugged Mountaineers pulled a victory out of the fire in the final period on a long pass to win over Xavier University today, 13 to 7.
Scoring eleven touchdowns practically at will the St. Benedict's Prep School eleven overwhelmed Lincoln College Prep of Pennsylvania today by a score of 75 to 0.

A brilliant Auburn line fashioned a 33-to-7 upset of Mississippi State today before 15,000 fans. The victors, held to scoreless ties by Tulane land Villanova in their last two starts, scored by virtually every known fashion, including a blocked punt in the second period.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Wenk of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Waldo Wenk of Chicago, to Edwin L. Amberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman A. Amberg of Deerhead Lodge, Gray, N. Y., took place here last night in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent.

The largest gathering of alumni, parents of students and friends in the history of Colgate University is expected next week-end (when Duke meets Colgate) in an inter-sectional football game. The new James C. Colgate Student Union Building will be dedicated, and Phi Kappa Psi and Phi Gamma Delta fraternities will celebrate the fiftieth anniversaries of their foundings.

SYDNEY, Australia. -- A unique industry is now being started along the Great Barrier Reef, Queensland, the 200-?? buttress of this island continent against the bluster of the Pacific Ocean. This is fishing for the reef eels.

Repeal of Section 213, widely heralded and acclaimed by women's organizations from one end of the country to the other, has been followed thus far by the reinstatement of less than one-tenth of those who lost their jobs in the government service by and because of the so-called married-persons clause of the old Economy Act of 1932.

Mrs. Shepard Krech, president of the Maternity Center Association, has announced, that the annual theatre benefit of the association will be the new Lee Shubert musical comedy "Between the Devil," starring Jack Buchanan and Evelyn Laye.

THIS is a thoroughly nice, old-fashioned story of the kind that parents used to permit their daughters to read when the Alcott books. the "Five Little Peppers" series and other "girls' books" had been read to death and were becoming too juvenile anyhow.

Confirming previous reports, officials of the Oceanic and Oriental Navigation Company have announced a dissolution of the corporation, with allotment of its vessels equally to the Matson Navigation Company and the American-Hawaiian Steamship..Company, the O. and O.'s only stockholders.

The sharp gusts of wind whipping around New York's office buildings these days are causing city dwellers to fasten that last button on their coats and reach for their gloves, but across the Hudson, in Palisades Interstate Park, the same wind is tossing crisp brown -leaves to the ground in a dry matting at the base of already dry trees.

ON June 20, 1837, at six in the morning, a young girl of eighteen rose from her bed, threw a shawl around her loose white nightgown and thrust hef small bare feet into slippers. Her long flaxen hair flowed down her back.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin B. McAlpin entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Among their guests were Major and Mrs. J. Roderick McAlpin, Dr. and McAlpin and Mrs. Benjamin B. McAlpin Jr.

The English-Speaking Union will show at Dartmouth House on Oct. 21 two sets of American documentary films from the collection at the Paris exhibition. Lord Strabolgi will be the chairman and Richard' de Rochemont the speaker.

BARONICK--Mr. and Mrs. Jack, announce birth of a daughter, Oct. 12, 1937. at Polyclinic Hospital. DRUGER--Mr. and Mrs. Arthur, announce birth of a daughter, Oct. 12, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital. FRIEDELL--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Friedell announce the birth of a daughter, Oct. 15, at Park West Hospital.

Scoring in the first two minutes of play, Williams College never relinquished its lead over a game Bowdoin football team to register a 12-to-6 upset before 6,000 spectators at Weston Field today. Bill Stradley and Captain Fielding Simmons led the Purple attack with Simmons scoring from the 5-yard line on the eighth play.
Miss Ruth A. Harper, assistant inspector of playgrounds and recreation in New York City, died tonight in a New Britain nursing home following an illness of several months. Her age was 62.

To the Music Editor: May I add my protest concerning the time set for the Toscanini series of radio broadcasts? I live in a small town where there is no music, and where we rely largely on the radio for our concerts.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Marjorie Elizabeth Campbell, daughter of Mrs. Alexander Carlyle Campbell of 363 Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Campbell, to Robert Lethbridge Foshay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Addison Youngs Foshay, also of Brooklyn, which will take place on Nov. 19.

Thirty-three coal miners perished early today in a terrific explosion in a mine four miles from its entrance. Crushed, burned and suffocated, the victims were moved from the blasted shaft at Mulga, Ala., to a morgue in near-by Bessemer.

A placement kick by Mondorff High from the 43-yard line in the final times quarter gave Maryland a 3-to-0 vicLory over Virginia today. The Cavaliers played a superb defensive game and advanced the ball to Maryland's 4-yard line in the final period.
Edmund L. Dolan, City treasurer in the last Curley administration, was indicted today in connection with profits on bond transactions for the city.

Dr. Francis C. M. Wei, president of the Hua Chung College, Wuchang, China, and Dr. Mary Emma Woolley, president emeritus of Mount Holyoke College, are among the educators scheduled as speakers at New Jersey College for Women for the current term. Following are the speakers and topics:

The marriage of Miss Ethel Kattrein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kattrein of this city, to Robert H. Birchenbough, son of Professor and Mrs. Harry Birchenbough, also of Albany, took place in St. Andrew's Church this afternoon.

Miss Caroline H. Kirsten, daughter fro of Mrs. George E. Kirsten of Greenfield Hill and the late Mr. Kirsten, became the bride of W. Forrest, Davenport of Bridgeport, son of Mrs. Peter Johnston Davenport of Abingdon, Vt., in the Greenfield Mill Congregational Church today.

Miss Janet Elizabeth Urion, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Urion of this place, was married to Elmore Schuman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Schuman of Briarcliff this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Edward Campbell, pastor of the church, officiated. The ceremony was followed by a reception at the Urion home.

Philip G. Phillips, regional director or the National Labor Relations Board, recommended today that the board refuse to certify the results of a series of collective bargaining elections among employes of the Greyhound Bus Lines in several States pending a hearing.

Evidences of real estate improvement in some sections of New York City are noted in the October real estate market letter of the New York Title Insurance Company. Attention is called to a survey recently completed by a large brokerage house to determine the extent of tax arrears on apartment buildings of eight stories or more in the section east of Fifth Avenue, from Thirty-fourth to Ninety-sixth Strept.

Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., co-leader of the local Democratic organization, expects more than 1.500 Democrats to be present Tuesday at the second annual dinner of The Hundred Dollar Club, which he formed to raise party campaign funds.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Hovenden, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Hovenden of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Hovenden, to Ralph Edward Ogden of New York, son of Mrs. J. Edward Ogden of Cornwall, N. Y., and the late Mr. Ogden, took place here yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Harold F. Lemoine performed the ceremony.

With telegrams and letters flooding in upon the Shrine of the Little Flower in Royal Oak and upon the Archdiocesan offices in Detroit's Chancery Building, supporters and opponents of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin are busily speculating on what will be his next move, if any.
A FEW weeks ago a baffled and confused gent, suffering from a case of Hollywood mal de mer, climbed wearily into a car and, leaving the sunset behind, headed eastward toward the dawn of a new day.

One of the most interesting effects of the Soviet election campaign is the progressive diminution in the columns of the provincial press of attacks on the "people's enemies." Indeed, unless these and other indications are fallacious the "purge" appears to have nearly run its course.

Several benefits will be conducted during the next few months in behalf of the various departments of the Silver Cross Day Nursery. The first of these is a rummage sale, arranged under the auspices of the junior auxiliary, which supports the kindergarten of the nursery.

In the past two months stock prices have fallen more than 26 per cent. Since Aug. 14 THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average has dropped from 135 to below the 100 mark. Considering the short space of time, the decline is one of the steepest since the 1929 debacle.

Many Summer plants that are now in full bloom will be cut down by the first "black" frost. Those who dread seeing them go, and who yet do not have room indoors for more than a few, may try the interesting experiment of attempting to save a small collection of them by means of rooting slips or cuttings.

New York University's football team started on the comeback path yesterday after its defeat by North Carolina last week, with St. John's of Annapolis being the victim, of the Violet's avenging drive at Ohio Field.
Davis and Elkins turned back West Virginia Wesleyan today by 7--0. The Scarlet Hurricanes, with Tebor, triple threat back, as their spearhead, pounded way over in the second half for the touchdown.

Members of Congress, when they return here Nov. 15 for the special session called by President Roosevelt, are expected to be more cost-of-living conscious than they have been during any previous New Deal sessions.

Japanese propaganda in the United States has been completely knocked. Qut by Chinese reports,' according to Premier Konoe's brother, Viscount Hidemaro Konoe, symphony conductor, who has just returned after conducting at Hollywood and elsewhere.

THE scene is Duke University's Lab oratory of Parapsychology. At a table sits young Dr. J. B. Rhine, and opposite him a student On the table Is a pack of twenty-five cards-not playing cards but cards of five suits bearing simple designs-a square, a rectangle, a circle, a plus sign, a star, three parallel wavy lines. The cards are thoroughly shuffled and laid face down.

Dedication ceremonies of the new headquarters of the Home Thrift Association, 350 East Eighty-eighth Street, will be held tomorrow afternoon at 4:45 P. M., according to an announcement. William M. Wener, director of the association, announced that Open House Week would be celebrated by the association from tomorrow through Saturday.

With thirty-one of the thirtythree-man squad seeing action, Amherst's eleven made a rout of its annual battle with the University of Rochester today, winning 41 to 0. Captain Bill Michell of Syracuse, the Lord Jeffs stellar halfback and captain, had a field day as he ran through, over and around the outweighed Yellowjackets to score two touchdowns.

Modern French paintings and drawings, British portraits, American landscapes and other works from the estates of Altha C. Beaufort and Sara Stern and other owners will be sold at auction on Thursday evening at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

News of the appointment of Dr. Erzebet Kol of Hungary to a post on the faculty of the University of Szeged-the first woman in her country to be so honored-is gratifying many friends she made here during the Winter of 1935-36, when she was the Crusade Fellow of the American Association of University Women.

St. Anselm's College conquered Providence College, 26-0, today before a crowd of more than 4,000. Ray McLean and Joe Butchka led St. Anselm's attack, the former twice breaking loose for 50yard gains. Jaworeko's punting was a big factor in keeping the Friars out of the victor's territory.

The operation of the Department of Sanitation has been made efficient, economical and scientific under his administration and its policies shaped for long-range development to meet the city's growing needs, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in a summary which he termed Lesson 5 in his series of educational messages for Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democrati candidate for Mayor.

Playing in a downpour of rain Kansas State defeated Marquette University, 13-0, to open its home season today. A small crowd of 3,500 watched the Big Six Conference representative take quick advantage of two scoring opportunities and beat the Wisconsin school for the first time since 1925.
The population of war-ravaged and terror-stricken Shanghai is increasing by an average of 700 births a day, according to figures issued today.

After killing frost cuts down the dahlias and cannas, it will be time to dig the Summer flowering bulbs and store them over Winter. These may be numerous and include any of the following: gladiolus, tuberose, Peruvian daffodil (Ismene calathina), tuberous rooted begonia, Madeira vine, tritoma (red hot poker), galtonia, tigridia, montbretia or fairy lily.

A cooperative research program in which faculty members and students work together is being undertaken this year by the Departments of Latin and Greek in the Graduate School of Bryn Mawr College. It is considered likely that the project may lead to the publication of articles or books by those engaged.

Seventeen chapters of national fraternities at Brown University opened the Fall social season on College Hill this week-end with house parties beginning yesterday and continuing through Sunday. Many houses are arranging informal suppers tonight and dinners tomorrow at resorts along Narragansett Bay.

Carnegie Tech's Skibos, who have surprised some of Notre Dame's greatest elevens, rose from the ashes of two defeats today to beat another hitherto undefeated South Bend team, 9 to 7, in the stirring fifteenth meeting of their rivalry.
Senator La Follette called the Tax Bill proposed by the Treasury "a great mistake" today and promised to renew his fight for a broader income tax base and higher surtaxes on middle-bracket incomes.
THE idea which prompted Mr. Cowley's symposium was eminently sound. American literature, in the second decade of this century, turned a corner.

Miss Shirley Wilder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Wilder of Verona, became the bride of Edward Burkhardt Loehr of Montclair this afternoon. The Rev. Charles G. Richard, pastor of the Verona Presbyterian Church, officiated at the bride's home, Glen Oaken.

Harold T. Donaldson, retiring president of the United States Building and Loan League, in his address on future building progress before the recent convention of the organization in Los Angeles, indicated that he did not entirely agree with the view recently advanced by Some housing associations that decreasing monthly payments and increasing the term for the homemortgage loan would benefit home ownership.

While the State Board of Social Welfare prepared to consider Mayor La Guardia's charge that Controller Frank J. Taylor had used public funds to distribute "misleading political propaganda" among employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau, the Association of Workers in Publio Relief Agencies, which includes 4,300 workers in the city relief agency, announced yesterday its intention of supporting the Mayor for re-election.

NORMAN MARSHALL, who, at the Gate Theatre, which is free of the censorship, gave the first performance of "Victoria Regina" and the first performance in England of "Parnell," has now made another Victorian experiment in "Mr. Gladstone" by Hugh Ross Williamson.

Chopin Concert, observing the eighty-eighth anniversary of the composer's death, broadcast from the house near Warsaw where the Polish musician was born. Henry Sztompka, pupil of Ignace Jan Paderewski, will perform on Chopin's old piano.

A Yale team that moved with drive, precision and spirit through sixty minutes of hard football was too good for Army today and won by 15 to 7. The Elis now own their first victory over the West Pointers since 1929, when Yale's Little Boy Blue, Albie Booth, staged his famous second half rally. Today Yale was the better team by just about the margin of the score.
A fivepoint program, by which President Roosevelt expects to achieve some of the remaining Ne?? Deal objectives, was laid at the door of Congress in the Presidential speech this week.

Miss Edith May Jackson, daughter of Captain Edward N. Jackson of 147 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Jackson, was married to John Paul Fitzgerald, son of John Patrick Fitzgerald, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Fitzgerald, yesterday morning in Holy Cross Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. John Costello.

Miss Marian Barclay Graff, daughter of Mrs. Wesley M. Graff of this place and the late Mr. Graff, became the bride of John Edward Greaves, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor C. Greaves, also of this place, in the First Congregational Church here this afternoon.

The names of 161 students on New York University's uptown campus who attained the honor roll by high scholastic standing during the academic year 1936-37 were jointly announced yesterday by Dean Irving H. Berg of the College of Arts and Pure Science and Dean Thorndike Saville of the College of Engineering.
Middlebury defeated R. P. I. today by 20-0. Two passes from Boehm to Kirk counted twice and a line buck by Guarnaccia in the third period gave the Midmen another score.

A two-story business building will be erected on the blockfront on the east side of Eighth Avenue from 124th to 125th Streets, the Charles F. Noyes Company, renting agents for the proposed structure, announced yesterday. Doric Properties, Inc., are the owners.

Thirty thousand spectators saw England defeat Australia, 5-4, today in the first of three test matches to be played under English Rugby League rules. The tourists led, 4-2, at half time, but a brilliant try scored midway through the second. half gave the victory to England.

TO keep abreast of world development in railroads and to meet the challenge of private ly owned road and air transport companies, the State-owned railroads in Victoria, Australia, have just buift a $700,000 streamlined allsteel, air-conditioned train that will run between Melbourne and Sydney at an average speed of more than seventy miles an hour.
President Day of Cornell University announced today the first substantial gift received during his administration, $50,000 to establish the "Henry Strong Denison Fund for Agricultural Research."

Bitter newspaper comment has been provoked by the suit that resulted in an award of [Pound]12,500 to Lord Camrose and [Pound]7,500 to his London Daily Telegraph in connection with libels on them published in Action, the journal controlled by Sir Oswald Mosley's Fascist organization.
A FESTIVAL devoted to Arnold Schoenberg and related composers was held last week in Denver, Col., under the auspices of the Cooke-Daniel Foundation.

Hundreds of curious natives lined the King's Wharf landing pier here late this afternoon to witness the landing of Raymond Vande, Francoi Freau and Paul Renucci, Frenchmen, and Battistoti Govianni, an Italian, escaped convicts from Devil's Island.

Announcement is made by the Bronx Board of Trade that the hearing before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on acquiring title to the sections for widening Eastern Boulevard and other thoroughfares to provide a suitable highway leading from the Triborough Bridge to the Pelham and Hutchinson River Parkways has been postponed until Nov. 19.

Led by Vincent Zuntano, who scored two touchdowns, Iona Prep's football team overwhelmed the St. Catherine of Genoa eleven of New York, 26 to 6, today. The other Iona scores were made by John Bartley and Bill Sexton. St. Catherine tallied in the second period against the Iona reserves.

William H. Roberts Sr., retired agricultural implement manufacturer, died at his home last night at the age of 79. Mr. Roberts was one of the founders of the Moorestown Field Club and a former treasurer of Moorestown Friends School.
With the utmost insistence on unanimity, the Soviet press, spokesman and radio declare there never will have been anything in the world like the coming election campaign.

Ursinus, playing on Patterson Field today, held Albright, heavy favorite, to a scoreless tie. A long pass at the end of the first half by Captain Dick Riffle of Albright to John Mueller was incompleted on the goal line.

Fifteen thousand persons saw the closing races in the Fall meeting of the Rose Tree Hunt Club today. The Rose Tree Hunter Challenge Cup for 4-year-olds, at about three and a half miles over timber, was captured by Seafarin' Dan of the Ewart Johnston Stables, after a shoulder-to-shoulder race with J. G. Leiper's Toymaker during the last part of the course.
ENGINEERING developments in four categories are among the features of the 1938 Buick line, first placed on public view in dealers' show-rooms last week.

The appointment of James D. Ross of Seattle by Secretary Ickes this week to be custodian of a power system which ultimately will produce five times as much energy as is generated at Niagara Falls is viewed as a step in implementing the policy of farms first and factories second in the distribution of Federal hydroelectric power in the Pacific Northwest.

Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes gave a dinner last night in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for their debutante daughter, Miss Shirley Noyes, and took their guests later to the Rodeo. The party included the Misses Barbara Connick, Ida Louise Larkin and Patricia Zettelmeyer of Cleveland, and Minot Milliken and Eugene G. Grace Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa.;

ANOVEL method of distributing prizes will be inaugurated in the team-of-four tournament for the Vanderbilt Cup, scheduled for the Ambassador. during the week of Nov. 16. Cups will be awarded, as usual, to the leaders in the qualifying rounds and to the finalists; but during the knockout rounds they will be awarded to losers.

A hard-running New Hampshire eleven romped to an easy 33-to-0 victory today against Colby. The Wildcats scored in the first five minutes of play, Karazia plunging through center for eleven yards and the first of five touchdowns. The winners tallied in every period in scoring their fourth straight victory.

While heavily armed police and Federal agents guarded the hearing room doors and windows James Widmer, 31-year-old desperado from the Middle West, was held in $100,000 bail today, at a hearing before William H. Wacker, United States Commissioner.
For the fifth successive quarteryear the fifteen largest banks in this city have made substantial reductions in their holdings of United States Government securities.

Flexibility calculated to increase the chance of success for proposed legislation governing the practice of nursing for pay in New York State will differentiate the bill now in process of being drafted from that which died in committee during the last session.

The Jooss European Ballet gave the first of the four performances which it has scheduled for itself here this season at the Alvin Theatre yesterday afternoon. The program contained no novelties, and will contain none this year, for Mr. Jooss is apparently a careful rather than a prolific composer.

Cramp's shipyard, shut down in 1927 after ninety-seven years of operation, will be reopened Monday. Down the ways that launched war vessels, liners and private yachts will slide welded-steel oil motor barges for coastal trade.

The conviction today in Los Angeles of Ernest R. Woolley of that city on a charge of perjury arising from false statements, given under oath in an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into sales of stock of the Cota Oil Company,

The appointment of Gerrit V. Reyntjes as chief purser of the new passenger ship Nieuw Amsterdam of the Holland America Line was announced yesterday by Peter van den Toorn, general manager of the line in New York.

As a means of encouraging more liberal home financing, the suggestion was made by Horace Russell, general counsel for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, at the recent convention in Los Angeles of the United States Building and Loan League that a uniform real estate mortgage and foreclosure law be enacted in the several States.
SEVERAL grave questions confront those who dispense funds and those who administer the funds granted for the various art projects which the United States Government has maintained by generous

Plans were elaborated last week for the rare books and collector's section at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair of 1937, to be held from Nov. 5 to 21 in the International Building at Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON. -- Applying the cult principles of genetics, Federal experts have set out to improve the popping qualities of popcorn, an edible peculiarly American. Cultivation and use of corn for popping are almost entirely confined to the New World.

ADLER--TERNER-Mr. and Mrs. Louis Terner of 468 Avenue S, Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Beatrice, to Robert Adler of 287 Amherst St., Manhattan Beach. BERNSTEN--COHEN--Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Cohen, 164 Grumman Ave., Newark, announce engagement of their daughter. Jessica Z., to Arthur Bernstein, New York.

Co-Sport made it a one-horse race today in the second running of the Lexington Stakes, the feature of Keeneland's final p program of a nine-day Fall meeting, by beating five other 2-year-olds over'a six-furlong route.

Haj Amin el Husseini, Mufti of Jerusalem t and until a fortnight ago president of the Moslem Supreme Council and president of the Arab High Committee, has escaped from Palestine to Syria. Since last July, when it was rumored a warrant had been issued for his arrest, he had been in the Mosque of Omar area, where he knew no one would dare come to arrest him.

To keep cemeteries from crowding out golf links, the Assembly has approved. legislation making cremation lawful. Referring to the density of the population, Attorney General Thomas M. Dill explained that senior health officers believed the time had arrived for Bermuda to have a crematorium.

Dusolina Giannini, the American operatic soprano, broke off a successful European tour today to come here and give a concert before several thousand employes of the I. G. Farben Company, the great German dye trust.

Dartmouth ran rough shod over Brown, 41 to 0, today. The Indians tallied 7 points each in the second and fourth periods, 14 in the first and 13 in the third, and held the Bruins completely at bay. A crowd of 12,000 watched.

CHAMBERLAIN, WILLIAM I. (Sept. 28). Estate. $8,000. To Alma Chamberlain Andersen. daughter, petitioner, 36 Gramercy Park, life estate; William-Alexander Andersen, grandson, $3,000 and remainder interest.
It is reported from Batavia, Java, that another bomber--the third in a few weeks--has been lost from the navy in the Dutch East Indies, with the death of five crew members.
Two flying aces of the World War, an American and a German, were in the same hotel here today but did not care to meet. Captain Eddie V. Rickenbacker, now an airlines executive, laid:

In the opinion of William E. Best, director of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Pittsburgh, the FHA risk rating system is destined to be of material help in promoting a sound money structure in the country.

Miss Margaret Elizabeth Slocum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stewart Slocum Jr. of this place, was married here this afternoon to James Dodd Savoye, son of Mrs. Richard G. Savoye, also of Westfield, and the late Dr. Savoye,

Miss Josephine Marie Caruso, daughter of Mrs. Louis Caruso of Maplewood and the late Mr. Caruso, was married this afternoon to Philip Marfuggi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Marfuggi of Bloomfield, in Our Lady of Sorrows Church, South Orange. The Rev. William D. Sheehan officiated.

The conversion of surpluses by United States corporations here into dollars as a result of the threats of prejudicial action by the government and-heavy government expenditures are held in financial circles here to be principally responsible for the fall in the reserves of the Bank of Mexico this week to 52.2 per cent from 62 per cent on Aug. 1. Fifty per cent reserves are required by law.

The New Bauhaus, American School of Design, founded by the Association of Arts and Industries, will open in Chicago on Monday with an enrollment drawn from the progressive art centers of the country, including California, Massachusetts, New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Minnesota and Illinois.

The banking institutions of New York City, especially the savings banks, deserve great credit, points out I. Jerome Riker, president of the realty company bearing his name, for their work during the last few years in renovating and modernizing hundreds of obsolete structures. Finding themselves, following the advent of the depression, forced to take over extensive realty holdings,
More than fifty persons were injured when the grandstand collapsed last night at a football game here between John Reagan School of Houston, Texas, and Mexico Polytechnic.
Tulane squeezed out a 7-to-6 football victory today over a Colgate team that fought smartly to prevent a more resounding setback. A crowd of 32,524 spectators saw the game.
Penn State today defeated Yale at soccer, 2 to 0. Arand Taylor kicked the first goal between the posts in the initial period and Captain Miehoff got the second in the third quarter.

Albin L. Clough, 73, hermit, poet, banjo player and prophet, proclaims himself also "the world's champion woman hater." "I've had two 'of 'em," says he, "one soft as squash, the other a holy terror. I've seen hundreds of others, but I wouldn't be found on a ten-acre lot With any of 'em."
THERE is always something slightly embarrassing about the public statements of writers and artists, for they should be able to say whatever they have to say in their work, and let it go at that.

General Carlos Ibanez, former President of Chile, who returned to Chile a few months ago after five years in Argentina, made his first public statement today, revealing that he is a candidate for the Presidency in the elections early next year.

Almost completely revamped in personnel, the New York Fobtball Giants will open their thirteenth home season at the Polo Grounds this afternoon against the Philadelphia Eagles with the kick-off scheduled for 2:30.

The new store in the seventeenstory apartment building at 280 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Forty-eighth Street, will be occupied on Wednesday by Harry F. Marks, Inc., booksellers and art dealers, now at 39 West Forty-ninth Street.
Miss Ruth Gordon Harrington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wentworth Lewis Harrington of this place, was married this afternoon to Dr. William F. Thornley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Thornley

Dickinson High School's football team took another step in the direction of the New Jefsey State Group Four championship today by conquering Passaic, last year's cochampion with Bloomfield, 12 to 0 before 10,000 at Roosevelt Stadium.

A survey of the apartment house situation in many localities in the suburban areas of Northern New Jersey reveals a definite scarcity of the more desirable suites, states David Cronheim, Newark broker and manager of many apartment properties.
American General Corporation--Sept. 30: Net assets equivalent to approximately $136.35 a preferred share and $10.44 a common share. On Dec. 31, 1936, asset value of common stock was $16.11 a share.

With an extensive school system of its own, comprising more than 1,100 school buildings as well as libraries of 1,500,000 volumes, the Civilian Conservation Corps is entering upon a new school year better prepared than ever before to meet the educational and job-training needs of its 300,000 enrollees.

Postmaster General Farley assured the Jackson Club today that as long as President Roosevelt remained in the White House the people of America need have no fear of war. In an address, which was broadcast over the Columbia -network, he declared:

The forthcoming nine-power conference, to be called to consider the undeclared war in the Far East, may turn into a yardstick of strength, a measuring ground of power of the world's differing political faiths.

The Standard Oil Company of Louisiana will undertake a $3,000,000 plant-expansion program in Baton Rouge, La., under a contract signed last week with Governor Richard W. Leche granting ten years of property-tax exemption on the new construction.

CUBA, an infrequent visitor to these columns, has released three attractive stamps commemorating the fourth centenary of the sugar-cane industry on the island. This is a belated series, because, as the inscribed "1535-1935" suggests, the anniversary was two years ago.

James A. Mollison, British aviator, said tonight that he had received permission from General Francisco Franco, leader of the Spanish Rebels, to fly tomorrow with Mrs. Harold E. Dahl to rejoin her husband, who is a prisoner in Salamanca.

THE recent announcement that the "Concours International Eugene Ysaye," inaugurated last May in Brussels, would henceforth be (1) an annual affair, (2) open to contestants not only in violin but in piano and conducting, has not met with unanimous approval. Objections have been expressed in a letter to the

Coach Larry Kelley's undefeated, St Untied and unscored on Peddie H football team continued its winning to streak today by downing Poly Prep, be 19 to 0. The game was played be- to fore a crowd of parents assembled for the Fathers Day luncheon.

Mrs. Edward Burton Robinette of Chestnut Hill, Pa., has joined her son-in-law arid daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Harald Paumgarten-Hohenschwangau-Erbach at the Pierre. Mrs. Leslie Morgan Johnston, accompanied by Mrs. William Howard Parke and Mrs. Theodore W. Friend, has come from Pittsburgh to the St. Regis.

Maurice J. Convey of 688 Park Place, Brooklyn, a retired acting police captain, died early yesterday morning in the Nassau County Hospital, Mineola, L. I., from injuries received in an automobile accident at Garden City, L. I., on Tuesday. He was 64 years old.

More than 2,000 leaders in education and politics, including the former students of Dr. Paul Klapper, former Dean of the School of Education at City College and President of the new Queens College, will gather at a testimonial dinner to be given for him in the Hotel Astor on Oct. 30, according to an announcement by Professor Nelson P. Mead, head of the City College Department of History and chairman of the committee on arrangements.

A group of CCC boys, with practically no modern road-building equipment but with energy and enthusiasm, are working on a long-range project which will finally see a road cut through the wilderness from this northernmost New Hampshire community to Canada.

What some persons thought was a slump in the La Guardia campaign was merely a pause in preparation for the final assault on Tammany, which will bring a sweeping victory to the anti-Tammany ticket, William M. Chadbourne, chairman of the Fusion Campaign Committee, declared yesterday.

Holy Cross's fleet backs and stubborn linemen outfought the much heavier Georgia Bulldogs during all except the last four minutes of play today to gain an upset 7-6 intersectional victory before 20,000 at Fenway Park.

Dartmouth is starting the experiment of developing motion-picture script writing with the arrival this week of Walter Wanger, '15, Hollywood producer. He will promote instruction in this field as a memorial to Irving Thalberg.
William Mollison's "Laughing Cavalier," a romantio musical with Franz Hals and the original of his famous portrait as the two leading characters, will be presented at the Adelphi on Tuesday.

One hundred and sixty-seven co-eds escaped safety early today from fire which swept the historic North Hall on the campus of Slippery Rock College. No one was injured. The office of President Charles Miller estimated the damage at approximately $400,000. The fire originated in the kitchens.

With Fritz Kreisler's appearance in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, the season may be said to be on its way. Not alone in the sense that this was the first Autumn recital in the Fifty-seventh Street auditorium, but predominantly because Mr. Kreisler achieved standards of artistry that will seldom be surpassed in the coming Winter months.

IN his biography of the Swedish inventor John Ericsson, whose screw propeller marked a new era in shipping a hundred years ago and whose Monitor was a turning point in our Civil War, Gustav Lindwall concentrates slightly more on the

Commenting on the action recently taken by the Federal Reserve Board regarding national credit fafilities, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, points out that for the first time it has put mortgages on real estate among bank assets acceptable as collateral for "advances."

Definite proposals from both industry and labor for revision of the anti-trust laws, which President Roosevelt last week indicated would be considered at the special session of Congress next month, are already taking shape and by the time Congress convenes they will be in concrete form and ready for submission, it was learned here yesterday.

Twelve homes in various sections of Westchester County were sold during the last ten days by brokers for the Bowery Savings Bank for a total of $137,000. They were among the large number of residential properties taken over by the bank in recent years, and which are now being offered to new owners through the cooperation of local brokers.

The expected free-scoring game between Columbia and Penn at Baker Field yesterday was free scoring only in one direction as the Lions crushed the Quakers, 26 to 6, to the practically complete delight of a gathering of 28,000.
Susquehanna University played inspired football against the C. C. N. Y. eleven before a large Parents' Day crowd on University Field today, but failed to cope successfully with the invaders.

Meeting surprising resistance from a stubborn Lehigh eleven, Penn State scored a 14-7 victory over the Engineers before a crowd of 10,000 today. Repeatedly thrusts into Lehigh territory were stemmed by the Brown and White line.

The open alI-age stake for springer spaniels, first event of the second day of the Bath County field trials, was taken today by Hollywood Abandon, owned and handled by Harry I. Caesar of New York. He turned in/ perfect performances three times out.

The income from many properties on Manhattan Island might be materially increased and their values brought more into harmony with present-day assessments by wise modernization, points out A. Phillip Sweet. tax consultant.
A benefit theatre party will be held under the auspices of the Girls Club Association of Brooklyn at the performance on Nov. 8 of the new musical revue "Between the Devil" at the Imperial Theatre.

Weakening gradually after a brisk start, the Harvard football team had to content itself with a tie in its battle with Navy today, while a crowd of 54,000 looked on. The rival aggregations pounded each other vigorously and without stint, but when the final whistle sounded neither side could point to anything in its scoring column.

THIS is the story of a man who found out, one midnight recently, that he had to be in Cheyenne, Wyo., by dinner time of the coming day. Air travel was obviously in order, but a quick glance at the schedule of the direct route into Cheyenne revealed that the urge, or orders, to go from .New York to Cheyenne had come too late in the day to use the United Mainliners.

Mrs. Margaret Paton, most worthy grand matron of the Order of the Eastern Star of New Jersey, died today at her home here after an illness of one year. She was born in Newcastle, England, fifty-four years ago, the daughter of Thomas Anderson,

Miss Grace Stanley Pitfield, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lucas Pitfield of Germantown, was married this afternoon to William Stevens Anthony, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lawrence Anthony of Quisset, Mass.

That Soviet military authorities believe that Japanese operations in China are largely, if not principally, intended as a prelude to an attack on outer Mongolia was indicated by an article published today in the army newspaper Red Star.
ONE of the many interesting pictures which enrich the text of Helen Wills's autobiography is a photograph of the famous tennis champion in the company of the present Queen of England.

UNDER the direction of the British conductor, John Barbirolli, the Philharmonic Symphony opens its ninety-sixth season of concerts Thursday night. Purcell's Suite for strings, four horns, two flutes and cor angiais, arranged by Mr. Barbirolli, will be give its first New York performance on this occasion.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, will give an address on "How Can Supervisors and Teachers Foster the Democratic Ideal?" before the Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association Tuesday at 4 P. M. at the Hotel McAlpin.

Combining a powerful attack with an equally strong defensive performance, Greenwich High School's Cardinal tide today romped to a 31-to-O victory over Irving Prep of Tarrytown on Havemeyer Field. In holding the visitors scoreless the home team ran its string of the consecutive victories to three and maintained its undefeated, untied and unscored-upon record.

Justice William Harman Black gave a luncheon yesterday in the Ladies Annex of the Metropolitan Club for Miss Minnie Hopkins and Dr. Charles Louis Gilbert, who will be married on Saturday, and members of their prospective wedding party.

Miss Hariet Ellis Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wyckoff Wilson of West Hartford, and Willard Copp Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Jones of West Roxbury, Mass., were married this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church, West Hartford.

First of the field-trial meeting as for retrievers to be given in t he Eastern section is that carded th is week at Ligonier, Pa. The tria. is will be run Thursday, Friday an Saturday in the covers of the Rolling Rock Club, sponsor of the meet ing, which is located on the Lincoln Highway, forty-seven miles east of Pittsburgh.

Five small boys were injured, four of them so seriously as to necessitate their remaining in Lincoln Hospital, when an explosion believed to have been caused by benzine fumes showered them with pieces of tin and pebbles at about 5:30 P. M. yesterday.

An alert University of Wisconsin football team checked a rugged Iowa offense today and treated a homecoming crowd of 31,000 to a 13-to-6 victory, the fourth consecutive one for the Badgers this season.

Twenty-six thousand commuters would suffer and many real estate developments would face serious depreciation through discontinuance of service on the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad, commuters and realty operators said here today, discussing a last stand to be taken in their campaign for preservation of the thirty-one-mile transit system.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh has accepted a five-year renewal of his commission in the Army Air Corps Reserve, quieting rumors that he planned to become a British subject.
IN new, attractive, even quite waggish quarters (225 West Fifty-seventh Street) the WPA Federal Art Project began its third exhibition season in New York last week.

HAD to get up early this morning to make the 8:18 in order to get me in town to see a color sample that the painter had ready for me. He wanted to get it settled so that he could lay in the color of the big set today.

Operations of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and subsidiaries in the September quarter of this year resulted in a net profit of $1,846,833 after depreciation, Federal and State income taxes and other charges, it was announced yesterday. No provision was made for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass. THOUSANDS of city dwellers are heading toward Western Massachusetts and Connecticut thisweek-end to enjoy the last showing of Autumn's foliage.

Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are Peter V. Cacchione, Communist candidate for City Council, "Why the Italian People Should Vote Labor and Communist," WMCA, 10:15 to 10:30 A. M.

William Watson Clark, veteran left-hander who finished the 1937 season as coach to Manager Burleigh Grimes, received his unconditional release from the Dodgers yesterday, but almost on the same move had another job offered him.

The R.-K.-O. Hamilton Theatre at Broadway and 146th Street was cleared of an audience of 1,800 within five minutes last night when smoke from a fire in the basement stockroom of an adjoining clothing store poured into the heatree auditorium. No one was hurt.

Formal acceptance by the United States of the Belgian Government's invitation to confer with other signatories of the Nine-power treaty on the situation in the Far East was announced today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

SOMETHING lighter in the sky, something tingling in the air, something that in the limbs aches for adventure, some great contented drowsiness at the heart of nature-that is the something we call Autumn.

In the oval Diplomatic Room at the White House a small-group gathered last Tuesday evening beneath the portraits of Zachary Taylor and Ulysses S. Grant and Chester A. Arthur. In this room, which has no fireplace, President Roosevelt was making his tenth fireside chat to the nation, outlining the immediate program for the second New Deal.
Their transfer from a station a few degrees from the Equator to Sitka, Alaska, has put the crew of the navy aircraft tender Teal in the market for heavy red flannel underwear.

Two evenly matched teams battled to a deadlock today as Oberlin College and Hamilton College played a scoreless tie. The Ohio team threatened in the second quarter when they advanced to the 14-yard line. One attempted place kick by each team failed to break the deadlock.
