John Marbach, head of John Marbach, Inc., of White Plains, has been named president of the Westchester County Realty Board for the coming year. Other officers to serve with him are Herbert R. Houghton of Mamaroneck, Edgar G. Johnson of Riverdale, Edward H. Hufnagel of Mount Vernon and Matthew A.

CLINTON, N. Y.--Twelve members of the freshman class at Hamllton College are sons of alumni while two are grandsons of alumni, according to a survey. Two of the twelve are also grandsons of graduates.
A four-year college course is too long for the "superior student," in the opinion of Dr. Mazie Earle Wagner of the University of Buffalo, quoted by The Associated Press.

The Committee for Industrial Organization took the final preliminary step toward peace negotiations with the American Federation of Labor today when it telegraphed A. F. of L. officials in Denver that the C. I. O. would send a committee to meet with the A. F. of L. committee in Washington, D. C., on Oct. 25.
Almost one-third of the freshmen entering Hunter College this term have chosen to major in the fields of business, English or biology, according to a survey of 1,060 of the 1,200 entering students.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Oct. 15 unles specified. At Balboa: Charieston, Cummings, McDougal. Acushnet, at Norfolk Yard.

To Edwin a Fish, surf man, of the Coast Guard, has been awarded a silver life-saving medal for rescuing a girl on June 25 from the surf near the Squan Beach (N. J.) Coast Guard Station, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.
New England State governments, now evenly divided between the two major parties with three Democratic and three Republican Governors, want no "little TVA" in this section.
Rutgers University chalked up its fourth straight gridiron triumph of the season in turning back Springfield College today, 26 to 0, before 3,000 fans.

Below are printed dispatches from twelve important cities telling of the public reaction to President Roosevelt's call for "quarantine" of aggressors and a "concerted effort" by the nations to avert war.
F. and M. won its first Eastern Pennsylvania Conference game today by turning back Muhlenberg College, 22-6. Roeder scored two touchdowns for F. and M. and kicked two extra points.
Francis Lederer, film actor, and Margarita Bolando, stage and screen dancer known as Margo, were married here today. The bride was attended by her aunt, Mrs. Luz De Alanso. Jerry Asher was best man.

We arrived here in the heart of the Verm? nt bird country before dawn today and were met by Ira Sollace, State tame Warden. The air was sharp I but dry, and after a leisurely breakfast with Jack Swanson, whose setter Duke was to be one of our I party, we set out for Ripton Townsh. to. in Addison County.

Three hundred and sixty-two young women were guests this week-end at the annual Autumn dances at Wesleyan University. Smith College sent the largest number of girls with Connecticut College for Women and Mount Holyoke following in the order named.

FROM the days when museums were "frequently directed by quietly charming old men, traveled and unscientifically cultivated, their most frequent visitors being painters unable to bring themselves to paint on that

Better training of engineering students in "the art of human relationships" was advocated today by Dr. Warren Kendall -Lewis, Professor of Chemical Engineering at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Athwart the Western Mediterranean lies a cluster of strategic islands, the Spanish Balearics. In terms of swift ships and swifter planes, they are but a few hours from the British "lifeline of empire" through the middle sea. They overshadow the trade route from French Marseilles to French North Africa. They look eastward to Italian Sardinia and westward to the near-by coast of Loyalist Spain.

Distinguished representatives of the arts and of letters, public officials and educators will attend the funeral service today at 4 P. M. for Robert Underwood Johnson, poet and director of the Hall of Fame, in the. chapel of New York University,. University Heights, at 181st Street. the Bronx.
Increases in transatlantic passenger fares effective Nov. 1 were announced today as a result of a recent meeting here of the North Atlantic Steamship Conference.

Miss Virginia Austin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Arnold Austin of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Oliver Wills Tuthill of North Caldwell, N. J., which will take place the afternoon of Nov. 27 at 4 o'clock in Christ Episcopal Church here.
Hampden-Sydney displayed power took in routing Swarthmore, 25 to 0, on Homecoming Day today, Co-Captain John Richardson paced the Tigers with spectacular running and accurate punting.

Minnesota's Golden Gophers, displaying belatedly the irresistible power that won for them the mythical national football title last year, crushed Michigan, 39 to 6, today to enter a thunderous bid as a contender in the Western Conference campaign.

Miss Lelia Varner Rucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Ambrose Rucker, was married to Harry Wilson Porter of Arlington, Va., this afternoon in Upperville Baptist Church by the Rev. C. W. McElroy. The bride's sister, Mrs. Melville Fadeley of Washingtdn, was matron of honor, and Miss Elizabeth Maddox of Louisa, Va., maid of honor.

More than 300 persons attended an American Labor party rally held last night in Public School 44 Beach Ninety-fourth Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Rockaway Beach, and heard Samuel Seabury urged the re-election of Mayor La Guardia to 'continue good government and keep Tammany Hall and Tammany politics out of the city."

Of all the French customs that foreign visitors may take home with them from the Paris Exhibition, the one they are most likely to have "caught" is the habit of carrying on as much as possible of everyday life in the open air, and especially of al fresco eating.

Charles 3. Margiotti, State Attorney General, today invited Jay Cooke, Republican city chairman, to explain to the October grand jury his veiled charge of yesterday that Mayor -S. Davis Wilson made a "deal" with the Democratic party to "muffle" the jury's investigation into Philadelphia vice and crime.

The War Department released the fOllowing orders today, dated Oct. 15: Musgrave, Col. T. C., Inf., Fort Sam Houston, Texas, detailed as a member of the General Staff Corps and ordered to Fort Hayes, Ohio, as chief of staff of the Fifth Corps Area, Jan. 2.

Massachusetts State College is making plans for observance of its diamond jubilee next year. According to the present program, the principal celebration will take the form of a special convocation, to be held in the Spring.

Scoring touchdowns in all except the last period, Tufts overcame a stubborn Bates eleven today, 20 to 7. A touchdown by Abdu early in the first period, after a march down the field on straight football, put Tufts. of on the right foot, and it never relinquished the lead.

The following foreign service changes since Oct. 9 were announced today by the State Department: Elvin Seibert of New York, assigned to Bangkok, Siam, as vice consul and third secretary of. legation; orders to Havana canceled.
PERHAPS the Irishman Stephen MacKenna was an almost great man, but "out upon these easy namings!" as MacKenna himself cries out in one of his letters.

W. Leslie Walker, an architect of New York and Montclair, N. J., died on Wednesday at Lake Placid, N. Y. Mr. Walker, who had offices at 103 Park Avenue, was responsible for the design and development of the town of Coatesville, Pa., for the Midland Steel Company.

Miss Alice Bradford Beves, daughter of George Edward Beves of this city and London, England, and of Mrs. George Edward Beves of Haverford, was married this afternoon to Thomas Harlan Libby of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Libby of Haverford.

The marriage of Miss Betty Godsell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Godsell of this place, to David Guy Andersori Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. David Guy Anderson of New York and Philadelphia, took place here this afternoon in St. Elizabeth's Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Charles S. Armstrong.

President W. E. Weld of Wells College addressed the student body this week at Cap and Gown Day exercises. "It is the duty of you seniors to keep in touch with the college activities," he said. "Much is in your hands, college self-government, honor system, the spirit of the college."

Miss Catherine E. Stroud, daughter of sister, Mrs. R. Sanford Saltus of Hollow Tree, Villanova, was introduced to society this afternoon by her mother and stepfather at a tea which they gave at their home.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 14: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS McEldirff, J. V., detached as officer in charge, Navy Motion Picture Exchange,
The interest of sportsmen here is now focused on the first annual tournament of the Seaview Golf Club, to be held next Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

The New York State committee of the Communist party announced yesterday that it would present on Nov. 13 at Madison Square Garden a play entitled "One-sixth of the Earth," by Ralph Crane, William Crockett and Henry Stern.

WASHINGTON.--In the hope of preventing credit abuses which may encourage a false boom, a special unit in the Market Research Division of the Department of Commerce is undertaking an analysis of current trends in installment buying.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their maturity dates were in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding week due principally to the calling of several large blocks of public utility and foreign bonds.
THE traditionary day is an early Tuesday of March. Does there happen to exist, between Casco Bay and Frenchman's, a community so odd as to hold its annual town meeting on another day of the week?
Miss Margaret Irene Curran, daughter of Mrs. Philip Myles Curran of Newark and the late Mr. Curran, was married this morning to Francis X. Keegan, son of William J. Keegan of Newark.

NO nation, not even Germany during the World War, has ever been so glaringly singled out for the world's condemnation as has Japan in these last few weeks. And Japan has gone on its way in China as if the rest of the world had not spoken officially and unofficially in words of horror-as if the rest of the world did not even exist.

Led by Daniel Beard, National Scout Commissioner, more than 6,000 Boy Scouts will make their eighteenth annual pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt here next Saturday. The late President's seventy-ninth birthday anniversary will be observed on Wednesday, Oct. 27.

Port Chester High, defending champion, suffered its first setback in twenty games played over a period of three seasons when it was upset by Gorton High's football team, 13-6, in a W. I. A. A. battle on Gorton Field today. The reversal also was Port Chester's first after ten successes in a row, two of which were gained this season.

The Aluminum Company of America told the Supreme Court today that it opposed the Justice Department's action in filing anti-trust proceedings in New York against the company after similar action had been prosecuted in 1912.
Asturian defenders stiffened their resistance today against Insurgents driving from the east and the south toward Gijon, last Spanish Government stronghold on Spain's northwest coast.

Mrs. Edna Leedom Doelger, a former principal in Broadway musical shows and wife of Frank G. Doelger, died Friday night at their residence, 33-41 Eighty-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. An 8-year-old son, Frank G. Doelger Jr., and a sister, Irene Leedom, also survive.

Police Chief George Shippee made public today the following confession by Paul Dwyer to the murder of Dr. and Mrs. James .G. Littlefield, as taken down by police stenographers with interpolated questions, explanatory remarks and notes on checking details:

16.-Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Hovey of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth de Peyster Hovey, to Roderick Stephens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Stephens of New York.
Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Esther Johnson Cain of Indianapolis to Harry Mace Wootten of this city. The marriage took place here on Oct. 9 at the Riverside Church.

Miss Polly O'Donnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Colgan O'Donnell of Wilkes-Barre, was married to Joseph Patrick Nugent, son of James J. Nugent of 237 East Seventy-second Street, New York, and Cedarhurst, L. I., and the late Mrs. Nugent, today at Mary of the Mount Church, Mount Pocono, by the Very Rev. D. W. McCarthy.

The Rev. Gerald L. K. Smith, national chairman of the Committee of the One Million, will address thE Eastern New York Federation of the Women's Relief Corps, auxiliary to the Grand Army of the Republic, at its semi-annual meeting Thursday at the Hotel McAlpin.

The legislative provision to the Mortgage Moratorium Act, stipulating that where a mortgage becomes past due and the holder can prove there is surplus income over the operating expenses, taxes and interest, he may go into court and cause the owner to turn over such surplus in reduction of the mortgage at stated periods, presents the difficulty,
Several meetings will take place during the coming week in the interest of a joint campaign being conducted by the Visiting Nurse Association and the United Hospital Fund.

Many sportsmen will be in Berkshire for the opening of the bird shooting season on Wednesday. Harold Stanley of New York passes part of the open month each year at his hunting lodge in New Marlboro. Mr. and Mrs. Rodney W.
Northeastern University, led by Bill Little, handed Lowell Textile an 18to-O defeat today. Although he failed to score, Little figured prominently in the three Husky scoring marches.

The new Federal housing program, mortgage problems and home financing will be among the topics to be discussed at the thirtieth annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, which opens on Wednesday in Pittsburgh.

SYDNEY, Australia.--Australia's trade balance with the United States went out of the red in 1936-37 to the extent of pounds 1,310,000 (about $5,240,000) for the first time since the federation of the Australian States in 1901.

Not in a long time has the kaleidoscopic European situation been presenting so remarkable a psychological phenomenon as the present tour of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor through Germany. It has many aspects.

Delegates of forty-eight unions throughout the city voted yesterday to establish a permanent trade union committee to assist in the rehabilitation of members of the Abraham Lincoln bridge who have been engaged in the Spanish civil war since the end of last year.

Plans for naval manoeuvres in the Pacific that will engage all available ships and plans were made known today by Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn, commander in chief of the fleet, upon his return after a month of conferences with Navy Department officials in Washington.

Brilliant dashes by Milton Sullivant and the line smashing of Clarence Douglass brought the University of Kansas a 14-to-6 triumph over Iowa State in a Big Six Conference football game today. It was Kansas's first conference victory in two seasons.

Rhode Island State College defeated Maysachusetts State, 12 to 6, today. Massachusetts State scored first on a pass, Towle to Larkin. Rhode Island marched 43 yards to score in the second period, with Jaworski scoring on a reversefrom Duranleau from the 18-yard line.

With three acres of floor space occupied by about 1,500 exhibits, the thirty-fourth annual National Business Show will open tomorrow In Commerce Hall, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, and will continue through Saturday. Admission is confined to adults and is only by invitation, of which over 200,000 have been distributed by the 100 exhibitors.
Miss Marjorie Jane Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harley Irwin Wood of Fishers Island, N. Y., was married this evening to Edmund Hegeman Sutton son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Sutton of this place.

Miss Edith Grace Smyth, daughter of Judge George W. Smyth of the Westchester County Children's Courts and Mrs. Smyth of this place, was married this afternoon to Carl J. Weisenbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Weisenbach of Wayne, Pa., in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Orin A. Griesmyer, the pastor, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Westchester Hills Golf Club, White Plains.
The mystery of the missing Lord Justices' wigs was solved today with the arrest of a messenger who police said admitted stealing them.

Charles Evans Hughes, chief justice of the United States Supreme Court, is regarded as the "greatest living American" by members of the freshman class of Princeton University, results of the annual class poll disclosed today. Justice Hughes polled 70 votes, 14 more than President Roosevelt. Henry Ford ranked third and Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh fourth.

Senator Alben W. Barkley told a homecoming crowd of 2,000 today that there was no danger of a dictatorship in the United States so long as the government remained "efficient and responsive to the wills and needs of the Ameican people."

Crop condi-tions in the Southern Hemisphere came to the fore today as the dominating influence in the world's wheat markets, good rains in the dry sections of Australia being reported and also improvement in conditions in Argentina.

The Rose Tree Fox Hunting Club ran its second and final races of the Fall meeting today at the famous Dumbbell course in Rose Valley near Media. The first races were run on Tuesday. Features of today's meet were the Ormead Cup steeplechase at two and a half miles;

A new development has been announced by Miss Edith Stedman, director of the appointment bureau at Radcliffe College, in the evolution of the editorial course which the bureau had sponsored for two years into a course in "Manuscripts--Their Preparation and Publication."

Urging that merchants banish fear generated by the stock market decline, as the "public is not in the market and on the whole is little affected," I. A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, declared yesterday that the cycle of business is still headed forward, with the current recession merely a "detour."

Judge Charles Solomon of New York City told an election rally audience today that the 1938 State constitutional convention needs "men and women of proven liberalism." Judge Solomon, an American Labor Party candidate to the convention, came here to speak for Thomas L. Holling, Democratic candidate for Mayor of Buffalo.

EXHIBITS of antiques in county fairs are always enjoyed by the collector. for they offer the chance of seeing in a short time choice examples which it might otherwise take days to search out and examine.
IN preparation for the National Automobile Show, the doors of which will open at 2 P. M. on Wednesday, Oct. 27, Grand Central Palace these days hums with activity.

The city's assessment for the years 1932-35 on the Barbizon, twenty-five-story hotel structure on Lexington Avenue and Sixty-third Street, has been reduced. A recent decision handed down by Referee Louis Lande cut the tax valuation of $9,850,000 on the property for those years by $923,000.

The call for a special session of Congress came to the Corn Belt as a matter of course. Owing to frequent reference to the "urgency" of farm legislation, the area had been expecting such an announcement for some weeks and was inclined to agree with the desirability of getting this and at least some of the other subjects mentioned out of the way before the regular session convenes.
IN its recent report the American Artists Group, Inc., 106 Seventh Avenue, summarizes the progress of the organization since its establishment in 1935.

Two developments which dominated the attention of Europe this week-the new Mediterranean crisis and the new German promise to respect Belgium's neutrality-illustrated the tendency to revert to the methods and to the alignments of pre-war times.

Since the adoption of the percentage method of recognizing gain or loss on capital transactions for Federal - income tax purposes the importance of distinguishing "ordinary losses" from "capital losses" has been greatly emphasized. A loss sustained from the sale of a capital asset held for more than ten years, for example, is deductible only at the rate of 30 per cent of the amount of such loss.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Harris Ewing, a Protestant Episcopal clergyman who served as health officer of the Borough of Yeadon, died in Rush Hospital here on Thursday after a month's illness. He was 57 years old.
W. H. Donald, friend of. General Chiang Kai-shek, said today that he expects the Chinese conflict with Japan to be a long and bitter struggle, with China the eventual winner.

Connecticut State conquered the in Worcester Tech, 21 to 6, in their cid annual game today. With the game only a few minutes old, Posner circled left end and reversing his field raced 55 yards to put Connecticut State in front, Thompson converting.

ARONSON--SARNOFF--Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Sarnoff, 1,406 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, announce the marriage of their daughter, Dorothy, to Dr. Shepard G. Aronson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Aronson, on Oct. 14, 1937.

Mrs. Dwight Whitney Morrow gave a tea recently at the Colony Club for members of her patrons committee for the Welsh Concert to be given at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 19. At the reception it was announced that a large group of men and women of prominence would serve as patrons and patronesses.
The controversy which has kept many taxicabs of the Sunshine Radio fleet idle since last Wednesday seemed ended last night.

Aided by a fifteen yard penalty which put the ball on South Carolina's one yard line in the final period, Davidson College managed to stave off a shut out, losing 12-7 after Dennis went over for a touchdown. Carolina scored two touchdowns in the second quarter, one by a forward pass, Lyon to Urban and the other by Robinson on a line plunge.

New York City's voluntary hospitals lose more than $1,000,000 annually on their operating rooms, John W. Davis, chairman of the United Hospital campaign, declared yesterday. He cited figures for eighty-three member hospitals of the fund on which comparable figures were available, which showed a net loss for 1936 on operating rooms of $1,137,616.

Pennsylvania's proposed $50,000,000 super-highway, from Harrisburg to Pittsburgh, will provide this country with its first modern national defense road and will rival the best military roads in Europe, according to Walter A. Jones of Pittsburgh, chairman of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission. He spent several weeks in Germany recently studying the network of military highways.
Dr. and Mrs. Charles G. Child of 333 East Sixty-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Esther Wheelwright Child, to Dr. Frank Glenn of this city, formerly of St. Louis.

Miss Edna Scharg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. C. Scharg of this place, was married today to Henry E. Neidengard of Steubenville, Ohio. The ceremony was performed in the Evangelican Presbyterian church in Carlstadt by the Rev. F. N. Kohler.

Japanese forces in North China now control a block of territory measuring from east to west (Tientsin to Suiyuan) 350 miles and from north to south (Kalgan to near Shunteh) 250 miles. This area, approximately 90,000 square miles, roughly equals the States New York and Pennsylvania combined.
More than 2,000 persons are to attend in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel beginning tomorrow a series of meetings which will mark the fiftieth anniversary of the American Institute of Accountants.

Manhattan's record of not having scored a point against Villanova in four games is intact for at least another year. Yesterday at Ebbets Field, with a crowd of 20,000 rooting vainly for them, the green-clad Jaspers went down before the Wildcats, 20 to 0.

Invitations were issued today by Secretary Perkins for the annual conference on State Labor legislation to be held here Oct. 25, 26 and 27. The invitations went to Governors of industrial States and all are expected to send representatives to discuss problems of State labor law administration.

An extensive home and training program for boys will be aided by the performance of "French Without Tears" at Henry Miller's Theatre on the night of Oct. 26. This theatre party has been arranged as a means to provide scholarships at the Berkshire Industrial Farm at Canaan, N. Y., for boys who could not otherwise take advantage of the institution's benefits..

Those of us who realize the necessity of a strong opposition party must regret that the proposal for a Republican convention to draw up a list of Republican principles for use in '38 has increased strife, of which there was already a surplus.

Locked in a conference room, the Supreme Court justices presumably acted today on a petition submitted by Florida oil men which, if denied next Monday, could form the basis, it is asserted, of a new fight to oust Justice Black from the bench.

There will be no more slavery in Africa if our latest adventures are any criterion. So great is the native fear that when we attempted to reproduce for the camera an episode of Stanley's search for Livingstone in which Stanley encounters an Arab slave caravan, our blacks rebelled at being taken for slaves and made such a rumpus that we had to call in government authorities to settle the issue.

Two all-Chicago teams provided the thrills in Oklahoma City's $5,000 four-ball golf tournament today. When the pros came in at the end of the fifth round, Horton Smith and Harry Cooper had regained the lead they relinquished temporarily to Ky Laffoon and Dick Metz earlier in the day.

ALL of a sudden, apparently, the dance season has decided to get under way, and has proceeded to do so with a vengeance. The honor of having given the first official performance falls to Betty White for her debut recital at the Barbizon-Plaza day before yesterday.
A dance and amateur floor show will be held Friday night to benefit the Bedford Hills Community House, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Edwin J. Merrill, at the community house here.

STEFAN ZWEIG'S superb technical mastery would be a shallow triumph were it not in itself an expression of a literary purpose almost unique today. For he has turned his back on the Parnassus of the naturalists, to preside calmly and serenely on a small literary hillock of his own.

Mrs. Harold H. Hackett is chairman of the committee in charge of the large bridge party to be held the afternoon of Nov. 3 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery.

Andorra's General Councilthe combined Cabinet and Parliament of the tiny principality in the Pyrenees between France and Spain-was reported today to have been put to flight by Spanish riflemen while on an errand of inquiry.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday that she had taken the initiative in canceling a scheduled employee election at the Book of the Month Club.
Amherst vs. Wesleyan at Amherst. Arkansas vs. So. Methodist at Fort Smith. Army vs. Washington (St. Louis) at West Point.
Deeper waterways for commerce in New Jersey, Delaware and Eastern Pennsylvania are planned in twelve channel projects now under construction or being surveyed by army engineers.

Sir Oswald Mosley, leader of the British Fascists, who was struck on the head by a stone while speaking at Liverpool last Sunday, left the hospital today, saying he was "going into the depths of the English country."

Supreme ,Court Justice Edward Riegelman, in chambers in Brooklyn early today, denied an application for an order to invalidate the nomination of Thomas J. Towers, Queens County clerk, as Democratic nominee for City Court Justice in Queens.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the President's Chicago speech THE TIMES has given much space to the discussion of how war may be outlawed, boycotted or forcefully suppressed. Righteous indignation, Mr. Stimson suggests, may invoke the Nine-power treaty, the Kellogg pact, the League covenant and numerous disarmament agreements to shame the belligerent nations into peace.

Setting an all-time record in Eastern intercollegiate football, the mighty Pittsburgh Panthers, supposedly the strongest eleven in the East, and Fordham fought to a scoreless draw for the third successive year yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

An official mission of the Italian aviation services composed of twelve prominent aces, headed by General Longo, and twenty-four assistants arrived today with twelve modern airplanes for a week's exhibition here.

EARLIER in the month a Berlin correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Otto D. Tolischus, cabled two artices on the Paschke-Peetz process of utilizing low-grade iron ores-a process which Herman A. Brassert, an American citizen born in England, was the first to reduce to commercial success.

LAKE CHAPALA, the largest lake in Mexico, may soon be reached over a new three lane Federal highway from Mexico City. Leaving the latter city, the road leads to Toluca, Morelia, Lake Patzcuaro, and Guadalajara, the last renowned for its good climate, handsome buildings and ancient cultures.

ONE of the most important Scout events in the Eastern United States takes place next Saturday at Oyster Bay, L. I. This is the eighteenth annual pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt, whose seventy-ninth birthday anniversary falls a few days later on Oct. 27.

Turpentine firm, 26 3/4c; sales, 152 barrels; receipts, 418 barrels; shipments, 110 barrels; stock, 36,796 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 627 barrels; receipts, 1,309 barrels: shipments, 5 barrels; stock, 7.865 barrels.

The wedding of Miss Muriel Charlotte Hodgkiss, daughter of Mr., and Mrs.. Hurry Senior Hodgkiss of East Orange, and Walker Mills Witt, son of Mrs. August C. Witt of West Orange, touk place today at the home of the bride's parents.
Under the direction/of Ralph D. Pendleton, the Paint and Powder Club of Wesleyan University will undertake this year what will probably prove to be its most ambitious season.

I have listened with interest to statements made by the British and French representatives in behalf of their governments. I shall not fail to communicate them immediately to my government and report to the committee their reply.

SOME 3,000 Seminoles of Oklahoma are making plans to migrate to Mexico. There have been mass migrations from one part of the country to another-and Indian tribes have figured in many of them-but this would seem to be the first time a body of American citizens have renounced their citizenship to take up residence in another country.

Miss Mary Barrow Andersor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Anderson of this city, was married this afternoon to William P. de Saussure 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. de Saussure of Englewood, N. J.

Miss Aleta Van Sant of Atlantic City, N. J., won the girls' championship in the national moth class regatta today. She sailed Cassiopeiae across the line 50 yards ahead of Miss Violet Cohoon of Elizabeth. City in Rippling Rhythm. The team from the Palm Beach (Fla.) Yacht Club won the

As an aid to students to improve their speech by pointing out lingual defects, Centenary Junior College has installed a speechrecording machine which exposes peculiarities of speech, nasal twang, the slurring or overemphasis of the "r," lisps and other defects.

Although the fair trade acts and the Miller-Tydings law have focused attention chiefly on the price-maintenance activities of national brand manufacturers, a definite trend to establishment of price control by wholesale distributors on their own brands has set in, particularly in the drug field, and will probably extend to other industries, comment from executives last week indicated.
Annette Mulry has been chosen editor-in-chief of Vox Studentium, student publication of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here. Other staff members are Elizabeth Hanley, assistant editor;
Bruce Barton, Republican candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, announced yesterday that he was trying an experiment and was not answering any questionnaires.
At a meeting of directors of Loew's, Inc., yesterday, Al Lichtman was elected a director to succeed to the place left vacant by the late Thomas N. Perkins.

PICTURE frames fashioned from birch bark, portieres made from potato sacks, hooked rugs and children's dresses which once were sugar bags-in booth after booth, in the thousands of county and State fairs held throughout the country during the Fall, farm women proudly display their handiwork for the visitor to see.

The story of the forty-year struggle of Teachers College, Columbia University, to raise teaching from the status of a trade to that of a profession is to be recounted by its chief protagonist, Dean Emeritus James E. Russell, in lectures at the Horace Mann School on Wednesday and Friday afternoons of this week.

The disappearance of Arthur Forester, 6-year-old son of William Forester, after his father refused to take him along on a hunting trip caused considerable concern for a while. A police search for the boy was under way here when Forester reached Manistee, 100 miles north of Muskegon.

Metropolitan Musuem of Art. "Dutch ?? Flemish Painting Before 1550," (Tour of Collections) Roberta M. Fansler, 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2 P. M.; "American Small-House Design: French Types" (Gillender lec lure), Talbot F. Hamlin, 3 P. M.; "D itch and Flemish Painting After 1550" (Tour of Collections), Roberta M. Fansler, 3:15 P. M.

The "candid camera woman" has come into her own this month at Bennington College. A new picture bulletin was found to be needed by the faculty committee on publications to supplement the general announcement in telling outsiders about the college. So, instead of calling in professional photographers, the committee decided to throw the Job open to the students.

The best home for the homeowner is the home he can afford, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in presenting some factors which he considers of prime importance in deciding the question of home ownership.

To the Editor of The New York Times: General John F. O'Ryan writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES: "For nearly twenty years past the policy of our government has, in effect, stymied the efforts of the more responsible-minded peoples to organize and to maintain an effective police power."

Southern California's football team, with Ambrose Schindler leading the way, rode to victory over Oregon today, 34 to 14. Blasting Oregon's hopes of defeating the Trojans for the first time in more than twenty years, Southern California sounded a warning to California and its drive for Pacific Coast Conference supremacy.

More than 2,000 accountants, representing all of the States, will attend the annual meeting of the American Institute of Accountants at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria beginning tomorrow and ending Friday. The institute will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary.

FRIEDER WEISSMANN, young German conductor, is a recent arrival to these shores. After extensive operatic and symphonic experience in Europe and South America, he has come to this country to take part in its musical activities.

The charge that the District Attorney not only failed to break up the loan sharks, but turned down a complaint with the suggestion that it should be taken to the Magistrates' Courts, was made yesterday by Thomas E. Dewney, Fusion and Labor candidate for District Attorney.

A prize contest for work in many fields. promoting highway safety was announced yesterday by the C. I. T. Foundation, a unit of Commercial Investment Trust, Inc. The competition repeats one held last year under similar terms.

THE "heavenly voice" referred to in the title is a most unusual Japanese gong in the form of a large bronze urn. It stands in the living room of Edith Mary Merker, a writer of detective stories who has gone stale and is trying to make a living by taking in paying guests whom she instructs in the technique of writing mystery stories.

CALLING television a "celestial art," Dr. Alfred N. Goldsmith, consultant radio engineer, in a recent address on the future of the art, said that New Jersey residents will have a front row seat in the "theatre of the air."
Judge Harry E. Kalodner today directed the Goldstein and Levin dress manufacturing firm to reopen its Philadelphia plant and rehire 300 employes.
The University of Kentucky today defeated its ancient football rival, Washington and Lee, 41 to 6. The Wildcats displayed marked improvement over their previous efforts.

Frank E. Clarke of this city, an attorney and for many years an active civic, political and fraternal worker in White Plains and Westchester County, died today at White Plains Hospital. He was 57 years old..

Lawrenceville's football team was held to a 6 to 6 tie by a heavier Penn freshman second eleven today. Laurentians took the ball on the kick-off and marched 41 yards to a touchdown, Captain Rose going over from the 12-yard line. His placement kick for the extra point was short.

The favorable impression created by Britain consenting to hold another meeting of the Non-Intervention Committee gave place today to pessimism. Already Virginio Gayda writes in the Giornale d'Italia that today's session of the London committee seems to indicate it is concerned not so much with seeking a frank solution "but with a search for, or, better still, the creation of, non-existent responsibilities."
NEAR Reims in France lie the rolling hills and quiet valleys of the Champagne, where the visible scars of the war to end war--the trench lines and the shell holes and the rusty wire--

The low price and abundant supply of "cooking eggs" contribute one of the most encouraging aspects of the current food market for the menu planner faced with giving her family nutritive meals despite the high cost of-meat.

Marty Glickman, a whirlwind sprinter from Brooklyn, who has been a thorn in the side of Cornell throughout his collegiate football career, was more of a menace than ever today as Syracuse perpetrated one of the season's major surprises in scoring a 14 to 6 victory over the Ithacans on Schoellkopf Field.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 13, which included only five business days in most of the reporting centers, aggregated $7,088,000,000, or 25 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, 'and 3 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included only five business days in most of the reporting centers.

THE ease with which shortwave radio leaped 3,000 to 4,000 miles out of the Arctic to Times Square is revealed by Raymond Booth, radio operator on the recent Wilkins expedition in search of the Russian polar fliers who have been lost since Aug. 14.

Miss Margaret Rabitte, president of the New York City Alumnae of Alpha Delta Pi, will be honored this afternoon at a formal tea given by the unit at the Beekmann Tower Hotel, in recognition of her appointment as chairman of the 1938 convention of the fraternity, to be held in Ottawa, Ont.

ETAIL sales last week responded in highly encouraging fashion to cooler weather in various parts of the country. Sluggish trade was replaced by brisk buying of seasonal apparel. Columbus Day in many centers is a high point for such business and the results were quite favorable.

The Bronx Board of Trade reports that the improvement of various waterways in the borough is progressing at a very satisfactory rate. The engineers of the War Department, it is stated, have received appropriations of $227,000 for completion of the work in straightening the channel in the Harlem River near the old Johnson iron works at Spuyten Duyvil;

The Move the Olympics Committee that claimed to have gathered a million signatures in the campaign to prevent the holding of the games in Berlin will launch a drive to cancel the 1940 Olympic award to Tokyo, according to a statement issued last night by Samuel K. Maccabee of 170 Broadway, organizer and chairman of the committee.

Five upper class men at Princeton University, including three residents of the metropolitan area, were elected to important campus positions this week. Walter W. Johnston Jr., '38, of Pelham Manor, was elevated to the presidency of the Princeton Managers Club and in that capacity will serve on the Undergraduate Council, campus governing body.

Foreign buying, principally for Bombay account, yesterday imparted a steadier tone to prices on the Cotton Exchange here, but the market lost part of its gains in late trading under the pressure of week-end liquidation.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Belle Fruchtman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Fruchtman of this place, to Dr. Garrison Youngelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Youngelson of Dover, which will take place the evening of Oct. 31.

Carriers by water which report to the Interstate Commerce Commission earned a net income of $1,103,390 in 1936, in contrast with a net deficit of $259,075 in 1935, and paid taxes, both Federal and local, amounting to $2,010,225 last year, according to statistics made public today by the commission.
Seven acres of land adjoining Barnard Camp at Ossining, N. Y., were given to Barnard College last week by the Associate Alumnae organization of the college.

A ten-yearold fight between two brothers over the. estate of a third brother, Virgil M. Brand, wealthy brewer and coin and stamp collector, seemed to be nearing an end in the Probate Court when Judge John F. O'Connell divided properties, libraries and other possessions between them.

Dr. Joseph Peter Hoguet, whose long career as a surgeon includes practice on the staffs of many local hospitals and military service overseas, was appointed yesterday administrative assistant and medical director of the New York World's Fair of 1939, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair, announced.

MIAMI, Fla. ON a Florida key which two years ago was the center of a hurricane and tidal wave that swept human lives from many f the Florida keys, there will be dedicated on Nov. 14 a monument commemorative of those who died during that hurricane.

The ideal college would avoid regimentation, provide for the development of the individual, maintain an independent, unworried faculty and admit' a diversified student body representing all strata of life, Dr. Rosswell Gray Ham, newly appointed president of Mount Holyoke College, declared yesterday.

Miss Else Hausdorff of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hausdorff, will be married this afternoon in the Bensonhurst Jewish Community House, Seventyninth Street and Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, to Samuel Kislak of Hoboken, N. J., son of Mrs. Abraham Kislak and the late Mr. Kislak.

Attempts of writers and mathematicians since the fifteenth century to solve accounting problems are traced in a collection of old books' and manuscripts being exhibited this month in South Hall, Columbia University, as part of the fiftieth anniversary celebration of the American Institute of Accountants.
Great pressure is being exerted to force the largest possible number of men and women to join the Fatherland Front before the membership lists close Oct. 31.

Fifty thousand Japanese troops are virtually cut off in Shansi Province south of the inner Great Wall as a result of Chinese victories in North Shansi, Chinese military headquarters reported today. The Chinese declared they recaptured strategic Yenmen Pass following the retaking of Pinghasing Pass to the northeast by the former Communist army.
AY is somehow the persisting word for this year's Carnegie International, which opened in Pittsburgh with a reception Thursday night and to the public on Friday.

The realty holdings of eight closed national banks in New Jersey will be offered at auction by Joseph P. Day, Inc., in conjunction with Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., and William A. White Sons, on Nov. 6 and 10 at Odd Fellows Hall, Jersey City, N. J., and Nov. 13 in the Orange High School, Orange.

The Hotchkiss football team today scored a splendid 13-to-7 victory over a fighting Kent outfit on alumni field. The victors' powerful running attack prevailed against the determined stand of the Kent players, with Vivian, Howe and Taylor in prominent roles.
Two galloping speedsters turned in a tie today-a dead-heat between Seabiscuit and Heelfly in the twentyfourth running of the $7,500 added Laurel Stakes.
Boston University defeated Clarkson Tech, 35/to 2, at the Watertown Fair Ground field today. Lou Blazynski and Gary Famiglietti starred for Boston.
Dr. Wilbur Fisk Horn, probably the oldest active druggist in America, died today at his home here after a long illness at the age of 92. He opened his drug store here in 1869.

To the already incredible night life of Manhattan comes a new accession on Nov. 1, when thirty-five taxicab drivers, members of the Transport Workers Union, will start a course at 3 o'clock in the morning on public speaking and parliamentary procedure.

Miss Mary Kathleen Louise Durham, daughter of Mrs. Cleophas Hunt Durham of Turks Islands, B. W. I., and the late Mr. Durham, was married last night in All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, to Frederic Harold Pollard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter D. Pollard of Glenwood Road, Brooklyn. The Rev. Edward M. Pennell Jr. performed the ceremony.

Spirited bidding for the "women's vote" as represented by seven feminine organizations will be heard on Wednesday evening at a political meeting at the American Woman's Club, to which the leading candidates on both the Democratic and City Fusion tickets have been invited.

Absorption of office space in Manhattan during 1936 and 1937 has exceeded the expectations of many realty observers, and there is a possibility, "even a probability," that a "normal" occupancy level of about 90 per cent may be attained next year, says Loring M. Hewen, vice president of William A. White Sons.

A "fairly bright" ape could give some humans a half-length handicap and still beat them to the wire in an intelligence Derby, according to Dr. Philip H. Dubois of the University of New Mexico Psychology Department.

The annual Autumn flower show of the Horticultural Society of New York-better known as the Fall Chrysanthemum Show-to be held this year Nov. 4 to 7, inclusive, will mark the thirtieth anniversary of the society.

Scoring three times in the first half, the Pawling School football team conquered the Riverdale Country School eleven, 19-0, at Riverdale Field in the Bronx yesterday. It marked the second setback in a row for the local squad.

The Trade Development Board's 1936 report just issued estimates the minimum value of the tourist trade to Bermuda last year at about [pound]1,683,000. Estimating that 52,000 of the 54,262 passengers from the United States were on regular ships for tourists, the board computes that they spent [pound]1,548,613;

Investment bankers are expected to express their feelings concerning the recent break in security values and its effect upon the business of new security distribution at the twenty-sixth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America, which will open in White Sulphur Springs W. Va., on Nov. 3.

Showing an improvement over their work in the Cornell game last Saturday, when they were overwhelmed by Carl Snavely's Ithacans, Princeton's Tigers conquered the University of Chicago today by a score of 16 to 7.

Miss Mary Hayward Cowles, daughter of Dr. Edward Spencer Cowles of New York and the late Mrs. Jaquith Cowles of Boston, was married today in St. John's Church to Willard Reed Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Reed of Cambridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed this morning by the Rev. Oliver J; Hart, rector of St. John's, and was followed by a reception at the 1925 F Street Club.

The full support of Governor Lehman has been pledged to Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, and his running mates, it was announced yesterday at Mahoney campaign headquarters. The Governor, in a letter, acclaimed the Democratic Mayoralty candidate as a man equipped in every way to administer the affairs of the city.

Reports of an interesting development in the multi-cylinder field were verified by Nicholas Dreystadt, general manager of CadillacLa Salle, last week with an announcement that an unusual new sixteen-cylinder engine will be included in the 1938 model program.

Paced by Joe Kilgrow, one of the South's most versatile backfield performers, Alabama combined passing and power today to overcome Tennessee, 14 to 7, and strengthen its bid for Southeastern Conference honors.

Miss Betty Fayerweather, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Oakley Fayerweather of this city, was married to Maurice Averell Shillington, son of Thomas Courtney Shillington of Belfast, Ireland, and the late Mrs. Shillington,

Madison Square Garden reverberated with the cheers, whistles and juvenile "yippees" of 15,000 crippled, orphaned and underprivilegged children from 250 institutions in and around the city, who witnessed a special benefit performance yesterday morning of the twelfth annual world championship rodeo.

GEORGE KAUFMAN, whose new satire, "I'd Rather Be Right," probably will make enough money to buy him a comfortable hide-away in Maine or Vermont, did another play not so long ago in collaboration with Edna Ferber.

W. W. Crocker, president of the Crocker First National Bank of San Francisco, in an announcement made public here yesterday, stated that James K. Moffitt had been made chairman of the board of the bank. Mr. Moffitt, who is president of the wholesale paper company of Blake, Moffitt Towne, has been chairman of the executive committee of the bank since 1926.

To the Drama Editor: As one of your readers of long standing and as one who has just seen something very fine in the theatre, I would like to call your attention to the performances of "Coriolanus" now being given at the Theatre of the Four Seasons at Roslyn, L. I.

Whatever the causes may be, the severe decline in security values is serving to accentuate controversy over the effect of many policies of the Administration, not only on the stock markets but also on business progress.
Pushing across touchdowns in the second and third periods, the Choate School football team defeated the Taft School eleven, 14 to 0, at the latter's field today.

Retail volume expanded in most sections of the country last week as lower temperatures spurred consumer purchases of Fall apparel. In some areas, such as New York, where volume rose sharply on the Columbus Day holiday, the showing was the best of the season thus far.

The fourth annual conference of the National Association of Assessing Officers will be held this week at the Hotel New Yorker beginning Wednesday. The sessions will continue through Friday. John A. Zangerle, of Cleveland, presiden of the association, will preside.

Miss Katherine Bowman, daughter of Mrs. Katherine Fox Bowman, and Charles Farrar, son of Mrs. Anna Hallerman Farrar and the late J. W. Farrar, of Leesburg, Va., were married this afternoon at Yorkshire House, Bethel road, Warrenton, home of the bride's mother.

Miss Frances Heffernan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dennis W. Heffernan of Framingham, Mass., was married to Peter Prime of this city, son of Mrs. Orton L. Prime of Milwaukee and Crooked Lane Farm, Oconomowoc, Wis., and the late Mr. Prime, here yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector.

Current events will influence and coming ones cast their shadows before in the programs of three large convocations of women's organizations this week. Through affiliation with the New York State Federation of men's Clubs, these groups will be concerned with matters to be considered in the 1938

Roadside improvements and billboard control in Westchester County will be discussed at a meeting of the Westchester County Conservation Association in the County Center here on the evening of Oct. 20, according to an announcement today by Raymond L. Ditmars of Eastchester, president of the associtation and curator of reptiles at the Bronx Zoo.

The Neutrality Act will be no hindrance to any American cooperation with other governments to enforce peace under any treaty to which this country is a party, Senator Key Pittman, Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and coauthor of the law, said today in an interview telegraphed to the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES from his home in Reno.

NESTLING into the hillside to take advantage of the south-west exposure for the principal rooms, is the new home of Frederick C. Kendall on Hardwell Road in Short Hills, N. J. The owner, who is editor of Advertising and Selling, got Oscar Bryant Smith, architect, to plan the residence in American

Boys High recorded its seventeenth straight football victory over a three-year stretch -by defeating Manual Training, 7 to 0, before a crowd of 4,500 at Boys High Field yesterday. The winning streak of the Red and Black was extended by virtue of a 60-yard runback of a punt by Eddie Rosenthal in the third period.

Pointing out that last Friday was the fifth anniversary of the establishment of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, George E. Palmer, secretary-manager of the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association, declared yesterday that the system is now the nucleus of the modern savings and loan movement.
About 4,000 men, women and children, including half a dozen in baby carriages, circled City Hall yesterday to demand a 40 per cent increase in city relief allowances.

The city soil, from which lofty office buildings and apartment houses have grown in profusion, produced more than 600 tons of fresh vegetables for relief gardeners during the harvest season, now ending, the Works Progress Administration announced yesterday.

The Landowners Mutual Protection, Inc., an organization formed here eight years ago to keep trespassers off private property in Westchester and Putnam Counties, and Fairfield County, Conn., issued a warning today that its investigators will be especially vigilant during the hunting season opening Monday in New York State.
DEARBORN, Mich. NOWHERE in all the land is the drive to enlist mass production workers in the C. I. O. fraught with more drama or historic significance than on the shore of the River Rouge,

Formation of the Lawyers' NonPartisan Information Committee on the Judiciary to support Supreme Court Justices Aaron J. Levy and Thomas F. Noonan, candidates on the Democratic ticket, was announced yesterday.

One of the most brutal and apparently most senseless crimes on record was revealed shortly before dawn this morning when policemen in a radio patrol car found an expensive automobile parked near a filling station here with a shabbily dressed 18-year-old boy asleep on the front seat.

HOLLYWOOD is viewing the foreign scene these days through anxious eyes and with suppressed alarm, chiefly because of the new and more stringent restrictions which are being placed on its product in the world market.

The New York Junior League, through its music committee, will inaugurate a new feature in the organization's activities on the morning of Oct. 27, when the first of a series of four illustrated music talks by Olin Downes will be given at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Harold Bauer will be the artist and the subject of the lecture will be "Humor and Characterization in Music."

Hofstra College gained its first victory in two starts by winning from Bergen County College of New Jersey, 19--0, today at the Freeport Municipal Stadium. A 1-yard-line plunge by Ev Shaw in the first quarter climaxed a 75-yard drive after the opening kickoff to give Hofstra the lead.

Plans have been completed for the October Ball fore Philadelphia debutantes of 1937-38 which is to take place at the Warwick on Oct. 22. A feature of the evening is to be a pageant of debutantes symbolizing the "Day of a Debutante."

Another roller-skating party entitled Carnival on Wheels is being planned by the Vocational Service for Juniors. Patterned after the popular event of the same name given by the organization last year, the party will take place on the night of Nov. 12 at the Mecca Temple Casino,

With a study of national defense included for the first time in its reference material, the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War issued yesterday two kits for marathon round-table use for 1938 by its cooperating members.

An Army Douglas observation plane from Mitchel Field, L. I., crippled by engine trouble, drifted to a forced landing 1,000 feet off shore opposite Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, at Dover Street, yesterday afternoon.
Seven new appointments of chairmen for standing committees and two reappointment have been announced by Miss Earlene White, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women.
A contribution of $20,000 for the establishment of a new welding laboratory at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute is announced by President Hotchkiss.

The first of a series of ten foreign films to be sponsored by the Fine Arts Department of the College of William and Mary will be given tomorrow afternoon at the Williamsburg Theatre. These foreign films are a part of the program planned by the Fine Arts Department to present plays, operettas, musicales, campus sings and art exhibits throughout the year.

Suggestions to simplify the present cumbersome and costly method of foreclosure proceedings are made by Walter Fairchild, attorney and President of the New York Towens Title League, in the current issue of The Brooklyn Law Review, Published by the Brooklyn Law School.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 3,000 head, including 2.800 direct. Market steady. One load 220-pound average, S11.20 a hundredweight. Shippers took none. Estimated holdover, 1,000. Compared with week ago, packing sows 10 to 15 cents lower; others steady.
Pensioned On his own application. To take effect 12 noon, Oct. 16: PATROLMAN--Frank S. A. Crepeau, 8th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 11, 1912.

THE outstanding achievement of the recent Pan-American aviation conference at Lima, Peru, will undoubtedly prove to be the stimulation of Government interest in supplying aviators with efficient weather reports and the coordination of the various weather services into a vast inter-American hook-up.

Charlie Yates and Dick Garlington of Georgia defeated Fred Haas Jr. and Edward McClure of Louisiana, 5 and 4, today in the thiry-six-hole final of the inaugural Southern States four-ball golf tournament.
Heinrich Himmler, leader of the Hitler Elite Guards and head of all the German police, left Berlin tonight for Rome, ostensibly to take part in "The Day of the Italian Police."
Nothing stops political evolution. It continues even beneath the poisonous fog of civil war. Two new factors are emerging in Loyalist Spain.

To commemorate the birthday of Simon Bolivar, the South American liberator, the Club Las Tres Americas will give a dance on the night of Oct. 30 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Dr. Diogenes Escalante, Venezuelan Minister to the United States, will be represented at the event by Dr. Jacinto Fombona Pachano, Counselor of the Venezuelan Legation, and Mrs. Pachano.

A total of 379 cases has been filed with the State Labor Relations Board since July 1, according to a tabulation, made public yesterday. Of these 192 were filed by A. F. of L. unions, 121 by C. I. O. groups and 66 by independent unions.

IT can be only coincidence that gives us in the same month album sets of two Bach secular cantatas, the first appearance of anything more than an occasional aria from these comparatively little known works.

Dr. Ned H. Dearborn, dean of the New York University Division of General Education, announced yesterday that two public forums on current problems would open this week in Hoboken and Long Branch, N. J., under the auspices of local organizations and the university.

Supreme. Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler announced yesterday he would grant the request of the Lawyers Mortgage Company's reorganization managers that he designate one or more of the managers as trustees to serve without comsensation in the rehabilitation of specific certificate issues of the company.
A POTENTIAL 450,000 travelersdue to sail from Atlantic Coast ports to Europe and the British Isles next Spring and Summer are concerned with the announcement that the price of fares is going up.

Miss Harriet Ellis Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wyckoff Wilson of this place, was married here this afternoon to Willard Copp Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Jones of West Roxbury, Mass., in St. John's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. William T. Hooper.

WHEN President Roosevelt announced this week that he was calling a special session of Congress for Nov. 15 to take up certain legislation, he made no mention of a law having to do with a hobby close to his heart.

FEW spots in the country today are as gloomy as the narrow street that runs from Trinity Churchyard to the East River. Recent falls in the stock market, like alarms in the noontime of national recovery. have signaled Wall Street's pessimism to

BURLINGTON, N. J.--Miss Alice Conrad D'Olier, sister of Colonel Franklin D'Olier, executive vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, who was the -first national commander of the American Legion, died at her home here today after an illness of several years.

I HAVE been asked frequently, as an Englishman who has spent most of his theatrical life on the London stage but who has also played in America several times, for my opinion as an actor as to whether I prefer playing on the-London stage or the New York stage. It may sound slightly unpatriotic, but I infinitely prefer playing in New York.

Max Rubin, the union official former straw boss in the flour and trucking rackets who decided to become a state witness for Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey and was shot for it, yesterday was reported recovering and more determined than ever to tell what he knows.

Although the slackening in the movement of freight over the railroads, as reflected in the weekly carloading totals, indicates a lessening of freight-car purchases, a "stand-by" demand for modern cars and also for certain accessories on a substantial scale is seen among equipment makers.

Amityville High's eleven remained undefeated in its last nineteen games, a record compiled since late in the 1934 season, when it crushed Lindenhurst, 33 to 6, today. The victors scored three times in the second quarter.
The search for Kidnapped Charles S. Ross-dead or alive-led to a water hole in Schiller Park today, but failed to yield a trace of the victim.

Dr. Glenn Frank urged today that the Republican party offer the country a restatement of principles based on "traditional liberalism." Dr. Frank, a Republican who was hired as a "liberal" to run Wisconsin University and released after a break with the La Follette Progressives, said in an interview that "the so-called Republican forces are the only forces left to champion" what he regards as "real liberalism."

BEING permanent conductor of an organization like the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra is serious business. John Barbirolli does not underestimate the responsibilities he is assuming this week when he takes over the orchestra-the season begins Thursday evening-as chief conductor for three years. But he is tackling his task with a quiet assurance, aided, no doubt, by the feeling that he has already worked with the men whom he must lead.
HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- With tennis and golf tournaments out of the way for this season, the field will now be turned over to the hunt.

DR. CHARLES SEYMOUR assumes the presidency of Yale University with the same easy smile that has long brought him the good-will of the New Haven community, both town and gown. It is an urbane, tactful and encouraging smile, and, by all accounts, it is imperturbable.

The engagement of Miss Mary Andrews, daughter of Mrs. Oliver Andrews of this city and the late Mr. Andrews, to Robert Lee Wolff, son of Professor Samuel L. Wolff of Columbia University and Mrs. Wolff, has been announced by her mother.

The call of the wild and the call of the city might seem to be two different things, but they are not. This fact was made evident the other day when our State Conservation Commissioner, Lithgow Osborne, felt himself obliged to explain at some length to a gathering of sportsmen in Yonkers why hunting in Westchester County could not be as good as it used to be and was likely to grow worse.

The American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization by an exchange of telegrams today "cleared all decks" for a conference in Washington, Oct. 25, to discuss possible bases for a peaceful adjustment of the craft-industrial union dispute which has divided organized labor into warring factions for two years.

All but one of the components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity declined in the week ended Oct. 9 and the number has finally slipped under a year ago. The index has fallen to 101.1, which compares with 103.5 (revised) for the previous week and 102.5 for the corresponding week last year.
On the platform of Tammany Hall last Wednesday, while the audience cheered, Jeremiah T. Mahoney threw his arms around Senator Royal S. Copeland. Then Mr. Mahoney spoke:

The College of William and Mary co mpletely outclassed the visiting fo otball team from Guilford College to day, defeating them, 37 to 0.. The Ii idians were never threatened, p washing through for first downs rep heatedly and tallying in every period.

THOUGH small in size this volume by the distinguished British economist and scientist is packed full with ideas concerning the impact of science and other influences on the modern world and contains many fruitful suggestions for research as a basis of understanding the consequences and implications of that impact and, possibly, as a means of controlling or directing the forces that have increased the complexities and intensified the maladjustments of modern life.

Applications for mortgage insurance submitted to the New Jersey office of the FHA are being acted upon within about seven days, as contrasted with thirty-five days, which was the average time between submission and commitment on an application when the New Jersey office began operations, states Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey FHA Director.
A suit for $30,000 damages was filed today in Federal court against the Cunard White Star, Ltd., because Thomas Mulryan, aged 60, of Chicago, was buried at sea.

Mrs. E. H. Vare, the former Glenna Collett, fought an uphill battle against Miss Jean Bauer of East Providence, R. I., today to win the Berthellyn Golf Cup for the sixth time. The final margin was 2 and 1.

In a spectacular demonstration of offensive power, unloosed under the cover of an effective aerial bombardment, the Blue Devils of Duke capitalized on a single mistake today to blast aside the Engineers of Georgia Tech, 20 to 19, before 26,000 thrilled spectators.

The trading tone among bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was a continuation of the situation on Friday. United States Government obligations continued to move moderately higher in light trading, but prices in other sections again' were soft.

Wesleyan defeated Haverford today, 6-0, in a game replete with fumbles and devoid of thrills. Daddario carried the ball successfully on ground plays for the Cardinals and Petterson did the punting. DeBeaussett punted for the visiting team and Derr excelled in carrying the ball.

Appointment by Federal Judge Frank Cooper, Northern District of New York, of M. T. Montgomery of Drexel Hill, Pa., former rail operating man for some South American subsidiaries of the Electric Bond and Share Company as co-trustee of the Fonda,

A curb on Federal legislation for the control of advertising and an extension of "self-regulatory methods in advertising" were urged today by the distribution committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Wesleyan defeated Haverford today, 6-0, in a game replete with fumbles and devoid of thrills. Daddario carried the ball successfully on ground plays for the Cardinals and Petterson did the punting. DeBeaussett punted for the visiting team and Derr excelled in carrying the ball.

Appointment by Federal Judge Frank Cooper, Northern District of New York, of M. T. Montgomery of Drexel Hill, Pa., former rail operating man for some South American subsidiaries of the Electric Bond and Share Company as co-trustee of the Fonda,

A curb on Federal legislation for the control of advertising and an extension of "self-regulatory methods in advertising" were urged today by the distribution committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Dr. Christian Gauss, Princeton dean, and Mrs. Gauss have announced She the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Gauss, to George S. Stephenson, son of Mrs. Robert Storer Stephenson and the late Mr. Stephenson of Westport, Conn.

Experimental modification of the Harvard tutorial system, to meet the needs and abilities of the individual students, has been adopted this Fall by most of the college departments, involving over 60 per cent of the upper-class men.

With the score in the world clress championship match standing at 2-1 in favor of Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the title-holder, with two matches drawn, the sixth game of the series was captured tonight by Dr. Alexander Alekhine in the Concert Hall of the Municipal Institute of Music to deadlock the series.

REPUBLICANS from the Back Bay, their Democratio overlords from the State House, theatrical celebrities and ticket brokers from New York, all counted it a privilege to rub shoulders in the throng that clogged the lobbies at the opening of "I'd Rather Be Right" in the Colonial Theatre here Monday night.

Germany leads in exports to Brazil, according to official statistics just published. Imports Aem Germany in the first six months of this year were 24 Per cent of the country's total. The United States was next with 21.93 per cent. On the other hand, the United States purchased 37.20 per cent of Brazil's total exports.

Miss Frances Harrison McNeill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. McNeill, was married tonight. to Joseph Davidson Easley, son of Dr. Philip S. Easley of St. Louis. The ceremony was performed in the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. William S. Abernethy, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church.

Based on statements of opposing counsel and the testimony so far taken, the oil conspiracy trial here, which has just closed its second week, promises to give before its conclusion, probably two months hence, a good cross-section picture of the political and economic life in the United States in the last five years.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission conducted yesterday without a hitch the largest examination in its history, with some 41,000 persons, distributed among twenty-two schoolhouses; taking the test for clerk, Grade 2.

There should be uniformity of appraisal methods throughout the country, Leonard Downie, chief appraiser of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, told the delegates at the recent convention in Los Angeles of the Society of Residential Appraisers. He declared that standard appraisal policies should be
The Rutgers cross-country squad defeated Lafayette, 23 to 32, today over a 4 1/2-mile Buccleauch Fark course. Kearney High Schools runners beat the freshman squad, 24 to 31, over a two-mile course.
Five motorists, including a six-yearold boy, were killed instantly and another was injured in a head-on automobile and truck crash eight miles southeast of here today.

The twenty-first anniversary of the Summer Play Schools of the Child Study Association of America will be marked by a dinner on Oct. 27 at the Commodore. Mrs. Howard S. Gans is chairman of the arrangements committee for the event.

Miss Harriet Ellis Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wyckoff Wilson of this place, was married here this afternoon to Willard Copp Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Jones of West Roxbury, Mass., in St. John's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. William T. Hooper.

WHEN President Roosevelt announced this week that he was calling a special session of Congress for Nov. 15 to take up certain legislation, he made no mention of a law having to do with a hobby close to his heart.

FEW spots in the country today are as gloomy as the narrow street that runs from Trinity Churchyard to the East River. Recent falls in the stock market, like alarms in the noontime of national recovery. have signaled Wall Street's pessimism to

BURLINGTON, N. J.--Miss Alice Conrad D'Olier, sister of Colonel Franklin D'Olier, executive vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, who was the -first national commander of the American Legion, died at her home here today after an illness of several years.

Osservatore Romano, the Vatican's newspaper organ, today renewed a denial of reports that the Holy See had instructed its missions in the Far East to cooperate with Japan in combating communism. The newspaper said:

BY ANY OTHER NAME: Sports writers were requested last week not to refer to Notre Dame athletic teams as the "Ramblers." The nickname arose from Notre Dame's many intersectional contests, but now, it is urged. many other universities do more traveling than Notre Dame. The university vould prefer to have its teams called the "fighting Irish."

Almost half of the books circulated by the New York Public Library from its central branch at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue are nonfiction, with works on business and advertising showing a recent sharp gain in popularity, and materials on photography holding a steady demand, Dr. Harry Miller Lydenberg, director of the library, said yesterday.

When New York's voters go to the polls on Nov. 2 they will find that their electoral duties have been divided into two parts. First, as in former times, they will vote for Mayor, Borough President and a variety of other offices, on a voting machine.

One fact that Is sometimes overlooked in an analysis of political events is that the foreign policy of every nation in Europe is dictated today chiefly by the fear of war. While every government perhaps sincerely believes it Is arming only for defense, struggles in diplomatic, economic and military fields are going on to secure strong strategic positions.

The popularity of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in the Third Reich is reaching the point of idolatry. Today the pent-up gratitude to the former King of England for his interest in Germany's accomplishments finally found full. expression.
Odd-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday were reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as follows:

THE manuscript of William Henry Chamberlin's forthcoming book, "Japan Over Asia," was received by Little, Brown Co. three days before the outbreak of current hostilities. It was planned not as a hasty tribute to the news interest of the Sino-Japanese war but as a thoroughgoing analysis of Japanese economic and military aims and of Japanese psychology. Nevertheless,

A sparkling 220-yard free-style swim by Jack Koerner of Monroe enlivened the third series of dual meets for the Manhattan-BronxRichmond senior high school championship of the P. S. A. L., conducted in the twenty-five-yard pool of DeWitt Clinton High yesterday.
A slight weakening in the domestic demand for farm products in the remainder of 1937 was indicated today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

North Carolina State College defeated Virginia Tech tonight, 13-7, in a Southern Conference football game. State scored in the first period when Art Rooney bucked over from the 1-yard line, and again in the third when Eddie Berlinski climaxed a 71-yard drive with a 6-yard sweep off tackle.

Rallying for W. and J. in the last period, Glenn Etzweiler, Sunbury (Pa.) halfback, went 24 yards for a touchdown to gain a 7-7 tie with Dickinson College today. Etzweiler, who started on his touchdown run by taking a lateral from Melvin Meals, also kicked the extra point.
Virginia Military Institute scored three touchdowns and kicked three extra points today for a 21-to-7 victory over the University of Richmond. Eleven thousand persons witnessed the contest.

Two years after the Atlantic City convention of the American Federation of Labor put into motion the forces that led to formation of the Committee for Industrial Organization as a rival labor organization the warring factions are about to meet in a peace conference.

Tony Rozman, versatile halfback on the Lebanon Valley football team, kicked three field goals, scored a touchdown and kicked 2 points after touchdowns to tally 17 of his team's 23 points in defeating Delaware today, 23 to 7.

The Misses Frances Taft, Providence; Nancy Warren, Newton, Mass.; Mary Monahan, Providence; Lee Sherman, Providence; Linn Reese, Providence; Dorothy Drake, Newark, N. J.; Helen West, Cleveland Heights, Ohio; Betty Foxwell, Lakewood, Ohio; Helen Newberry, Narragansett Pier, R. I.; Marjorie Greene, Providence.

All-College Dance, the first social event of the season, was held at Skidmore College last night. An unusual feature of the ball, which was held in the historic old Canfield Casino, was the inclusion of a "Jam Session." A demonstration of the "Big Apple" was given in the middle of the evening and at various intervals thereafter the 600 guests were asked to participate in this dance.

Almon N. Taylor, first president of Northern Arizona Normal School, Flagstaff, Ariz., died on Thursday at his home here at the age of 81. Mr. Taylor served the normal school as president from 1899 to 1909. Prior to that time he had been principal of high schools in Westfield and Jamestown, N. Y.
HEATRICALLY speaking, the White House is now wherever "I'd Rather Be Right" is playing, and F. D. Roosevelt, for all practical box-office purposes, is G. M. Cohan.

BASCHE--Oct. 15, Milton, beloved husband of Edith Basche. Funeral services at 535 Bay St., Stapleton, S. I., Sunday. Oct. 17, at 2 P. M. Interment Baron Hirsch Cemetery. Philadelphia papers please copy.

Concentration of the head offices of virtually all of the government financial and revenue institutions to Nanking is to be effected by the end of this month, according to a Finance Ministry spokesman.

Police at Reichenberg announced today that Heinrich Rutha, Walther Rohn and twelve other members of the Sudenten Deutsche party, Czech Nazi organization, had been arrested for moral offenses contravening paragraph 129 of the Czechoslovak penal code [homosexuality].

Heralded as momentous, an announcement by the highest Japanese officials in Shanghai, which was expected possibly to pertain to the withdrawal of Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe as a step leading to a formal declaration of war, proved to be a demonstration designed to prove the Chinese were using phosgene gas shells in the Shanghai sectors.
An insurgent minority of the Federal Coal Commission, backed by a promise of Senatorial support, won a fight today to examine the commission's list of jobholders and their salaries.
