As the late Fall and Winter seasons approach, the deserts of our Southwest come into their own as meccas for American tourists.

When Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, in a forceful speech last week before the Rochester Chamber of Commerce charged that governmental restriction was the primary cause of the drastic decline that has taken place in security prices since mid-August, it was not the first time that he broke what is supposed to be conservative banking tradition.

SCENES of stirring romance, unbelievable riches, bitter rancor and bacchanalian rev elry-the sort of life that called for the ability of a Mark Twain and a Bret Harte as chroniclers-are recalled by the Mother Lode region of California, which in Autumn invites the camper and picnicker.

The health of members of Congress would be better if they were not obliged to run so many errands, Dr. Ira Drew, the only osteopath in the House of Representatives, said last night at a meeting of the Osteopathic Society of the City of New York at 205 East Twentieth Street.

Three undefeated teams of the New York Field Hockey Association continued their winning streaks when Greenfield defeated the Clansmen, 7-0, the Carroll Club won from Cosmo Cubs, 3-1, and Cosmopolitan downed Sutton, 7-0, at Prospect Park yesterday.

The pace of white-collar hir'ings in the metropolitan district has bogged down, according to the report issued yesterday by the National Employment Exchange, based on figures showing that requests for workers shrank rapidly during the Summer to a point 27.2 per cent below those of a year ago.

Premier Mussolini's newspaper, the Pepolo d'Italia, said today that "in the month of September the United States exported arms and munitions totaling upward of $20,000,000, of which nearly $10,000,000 was bought by the Soviet Union, which in turn sent the arms and munitions to Red Spain."

The marriage of Miss Ruth Phillips, daughter of Mrs. Frank Elbert Phillips of Richmond Hill, Queens, and the late Mr. Phillips, to Edward Milton Foote Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward M. Foote of New York and Cornwall Bridge, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon in the Church in the Gardens, Forest Hills. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. R. Wilbur Simmons, who was assisted by the Rev. John Rahill.
German exports suffered an unseasonal 9 per cent drop in September, but with A total of 494,200,000 marks they remained 20 per cent above September of last year.

Mrs. Elizabeth A. Dolan Mandel, wife of Edward A. Mandel, associate superintendent of schools, died yesterday morning at their residence. 44 Jewel Street, Forest Hills, at the age of 72, after a three weeks' illness.

The New York Military Academy's football team scored a clean-cut victory over the favored forces of Adelphi Academy of Brooklyn today on the cadets' gridiron. The score was 7 to 0, Victor Anido plunging over for a touchdown shortly after the start of the second half. Captain Johnny Bath kicked the extra point from placement.
WASHINGTON. AD weather overspreads the East. It is raining at Newark, busiest air terminal in the world. The clouds hang low over the towers of Manhattanbelow the topmost spires.
THIS is the season for amateur map-making. The hobby enables the tourist to hang on a wall of his study an attractive, self-made diagram of his trip to the Mediterranean,

Phil D. Cook, 43-year-old radio entertainer, was arrested on three charges of atrocious assault and battery last night after an automobile which he was driving was in collision with another car on the Pulaski Skyway at the Tonnelle Avenue ramp, in Jersey City, N. J.

THE Republican party is preparing to return to the political wars. The National Executive Committee has met and passed on plans for a midterm convention to prepare for 1938 and 1940. Chairman John D. M. Hamilton is taking soundings and getting leaders together.

THE Postoffice Department has made public the central design of the United States 3-cent purple stamp which will be issued on Nov. 25, with first-day sales at San Juan, Puerto Rico, as part of the series of four which 'direct public attention to American ownership
Under the provisions of the new charter, voters will have their first opportunity to elect members of the City Council by the proportional representation method at the general election on Nov. 2.

France has not abandoned its plans to establish regular transatlantic flying service to the United States and will project three experimental flights next year, it was learned from Marcel Olivier, chairman of 'Air France Transatlantique, who was in New York yesterday en route to Washington to further his country's international flying relations.

Almost every forecast which has been made up to now regarding the probable duration and ultimate outcome of the Spanish civil war has proved wrong and this is especially true of those made by the leaders of the forces engaged.

A METHOD of steel-engraving never before identified with the producing of postage stamps was used in making the 46-centavo commemorative which Honduras has issued as that Central American republic's contribution to the United States Constitution sesquicentennial celebration.

For the fifth consecutive year, Wesleyan University's local fraternity, Phi Nu Theta, has won the Jackson Cup, the trophy given annually at Wesleyan to the fraternity with the highest scholastic average for the year.

China, continuing to prepare for long resistance and battling against the strangling Japanese blockade, is now seeking a new highway route for imports of arms and munitions necessary for war supplies.

The Rev. Michael J. Ahern of Weston College, Mass., will succeed Hervey J. Skinner of Boston as chairman for the next year of the northeastern section of the American Chemical Society, it was announced yesterday.

Students at Columbia University should grapple with current labor problems through the development of a broad labor economics program employing the New York industrial area as a laboratory, Dean Roswell C. McCrea of the School of Business recommended in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday.
A general strike of longshoremen in southeastern ports from Wilmington, N. C., down around the Florida peninsula and up the Gulf Coast to Tampa crippled coastwise shipping today. Piers were picketed.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the firm of Donoho Co. will not retire as Stock Exchange members, but will be dissolved with a new firm of the same name being formed with the following partners:

North Carolina's heavier squad beat Wake Forest, 28 to 0. The contest, part of Wake Forest's homecoming day program, attracted 10,000. The Tar Heels tallied once in each quarter. First score came on Sophomore Stirnweiss's 8-yard pass to Halfback George Watson.

The White House program of official entertainments during the coming season was announced today by Mrs. Roosevelt. Neither an inauguration, as last year, nor construc- certs under tion and repair work within the White House, which twice previously served to postpone the resumption of social activities, had to be reckoned with this season.

The marriage of Miss. Katharine Howe Foote, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Will Howe Foote, to Roland Webster Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Thompson of Pomfret, Va., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
Howard Yeager, Santa Barbara State College halfback, paid his speeding fine on the gridiron. Two days ago Judge Fred T. Harsh told Yaeger at Santa Barbara:
A declaration against any boycott of Japanese goods in the United States because of the conflict in China was made public yesterday by the Fellowship of Reconciliation, 2,929 Broadway.

A notice published practically one hundred years ago in The Newburgh Gazette of Dec. 30, 1837, advertising a large farm in Sullivan County, N. Y., for sale, reveals the fact that accessibility to transportation facilities was regarded, just as is the case today, as a valuable asset toward creating interest in the property.
Investigation of rates charged by municipal power plants was extended today by the Public Service Commission to Hamilton, in Madison County, and Endicott, in Broome County.

The gridiron game's third big Saturday of the season attracted contests 50,000 saw Yale down Army for the first time since 1929 and 53,000 watched Fordham battle to a scoreless tie with Pittsburgh for the third year in a row.
Lafayette College's forward passes clicked in the closing minutes of its football game today with the slightly favored, though crippled Georgetown team, and the visitors recorded a 6-0 victory.

In line with the awakening recognition throughout the country that housing is one of the most important contemporary problems, Vassar College is introducing into its curriculum a program of instruction in this field.
At the annual Convocation of Elmira College, held Friday in honor of highranking students. Dean Margaret S. Morris of Pembroke College was the chief speaker.

Mrs. Ernest E. Smith of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carol Smith, to August Zinsser Jr., son of Mrs. H. Moore Zinsser and of August Zinsser, both of New York. Miss Smith, who is a member of the Junior League, was introduced to society in 1928.

IF it's Arabia, with its attendant sand wastes, spicy odors, harem girls and wild horsemen that a movie producer is after, the man he goes to see is Jamiel Hassan. For the past ten years Hassan has been the unofficial ambassador of Arabia to Hollywood, and many's the camel he has set against a sky-line in that time.

The Animals Friends' League has been founded by the Rev. Clarence J. Harris, minister for twenty years of the Washington Heights Universalist Church, at West 178th Street and Wadsworth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

Bishop Emmet M. Walsh of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Charleston, S. C., in accepting yesterday afternoon from 125 members of St. Saviour's Branch 1028 of the Ladies Catholic Benevolent Association a gift of $1,000 to build a chapel, announced the chapel would be located at Camp St. Mary's, on the Okeetee River, in Beaufort County, S. C. He was guest of honor at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.

Rain and the stubborn opposition of Oklahoma quenched today the flaming hopes of Nebraska's Cornhuskera of continuing as one of the nation's undefeated and untied football teams. After four quarters of play in the mud, the Big Six encounter ended in a scoreless deadlock.

Debating the question, "Do we need legislation to make unions legally responsible?" Noel Sargent, secretary of the National Association of Manufacturers of the United States, listed eight acts which he said should be prohibited to labor unions, while Louis Waldman, labor attorney, contended existing laws were adequate, before an audience of 250 persons at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street, yesterday afternoon.

J. Rudolph Kirsch, sales agent for the developing syndicate which recently acquired a tract of thirty acres on Grove Street, Ridgewood, N. J., announces that improvement plans involve the construction of prefabricated houses in the $3,500 to $4,000 price class. They will contain four and five rooms and will be built on 60 by 150 feet plots.

More than 10,000 undergraduate students will return to classes at Brooklyn College tomorrow for the opening of the eighth academic year, the first at the new $5,500,000 forty-acre campus at Avenue H and Bedford Avenue in Flatbush. Exercises will begin at noon on the campus with Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, presiding.

One of the important weddings of the little season on the North Shore took place at noon today when Miss Beatrice Winthrop Kellogg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Winthrop Kellogg of Fieldston Farm, near Roslyn, was married to Harvey Childs McClintock Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McClintock of Bronxville.

BERGAMO. ONE of the most commendable efforts in recent years to encourage new native opera in Italy is the initiative now taken by the Teatro Donizetti of Bergamo, which has decided to give henceforth a prevailingly experimental trend to its lyric seasons.

Leesville, La., high school repeated its 1935 football victory over the American School of Mexico City today, winning, 12 to 0, on two ,long runs. In' the third quarter Mattison, who played an outstanding game for Leesville, dashed 60 yards for the first tally.
Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, sailed on Friday night on the Europa for a three-week business trip to aris, it was announced yesterday by the bank.

The directing of interest, through the revived program of completing his Riverside memorial, to the career and character of General U. S. Grant will bring anew to public attention his strangely mixed personality.

EAGERLY awaiting the arrival of Maestro Arturo Toscanini, ninety-two musicians have turned the largest studio in Radio City into a beehive of activity for twelve hours a week as they rehearse under the baton of the drill master Artur Rodzinski.

Any one who snoops about closet and bath equipment showrooms or pokes inquisitively into some of the recently opened model rooms in decorating and department stores, cannot help. acquiring ideas about dressing up bathrooms and closets.

Behind the brilliant exhibition turned in by its star back, Sid White, the Brooklyn College eleven rode to a 50-to-0 victory over Wagner at Grymes Hill, S. I., yesterday. Despite an injured left hand, White, who entered the game early in the first period, accounted for six of Brooklyn's eight touchdowns.

Union garment workers in St. Louis joined today with their employers in a fight against "style pirates." It was said by both sides to be the first time in the history of the clothing industry that such a compact had been made.
Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, has given to Rollins College a motion picture sound reproducing system for use in the Annie Russell Theatre.

Licensing by the city of all local retail and wholesale butchers as well as packing houses will be required in the proposed city ordinance which, if adopted, will make compulsory government grading of all meats sold here, it was learned yesterday from an authoritative source.

IT was anticipated in some quarters that Barrie's would prove to be the largest fortune ever left by a British author. That position, however, is still held by Hall Caine's [pound]250,000, but Barrie's [pound]173,000 removes Kipling's [pound]155,000 from the second place.

WASHINGTON. -- Intelligence tests for dogs are now being conducted by the Bureau of Animal Industry here as a start to a comprehensive survey of the intelligence of farm animals and the relationship of inheritance to efficient performance.

RKO was all set to film "Condemned Women" as a smallbudget film with Sally Eilers and Lee Patrick, but changed its mind when Barbara Stanwyck expressed a desire to make it after a quick look at the script prepared by Lionel Houser.

With the dedication on Nov. 22 of the new College of Medicine Building, Syracuse University will have acquired the fourth unit in the plan started in 1925 to construct a hospital and education center adjoining the campus.

OOTLEG journeys into prohibited regions have a zest that makes the bottled-in bond tour seem flat in comparison. Miss Forbes's travels over the forbidden road mentioned in the title of her book provide a story that, while it is not one hundred proof, is stimulating enough for all practical purposes.
District Attorney Ralph L. Emmons announced today that the eight men convicted of kidnapping John J. O'Connel Jr. of Albany must finance their own appeal.

THE publishers of this absorbing book on the German Secret Service in America before and after the entrance of the United States into the World War assure the reader that Captain Landau worked on the case of the Black
President Roosevelt today went on a picnic with his mother, Mrs Roosevelt and a few other relatives and close friends of this neighbor hood.

Miss Helen Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Taylor of this place, was married this afternoon to Roger Oliver Van Duzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Vanderbilt Van Duzer of Stapleton, S. I., at the residence of her parents here. The Rev. John Henderson Powell Jr., rector of the Bronxville Reformed Church. performed the ceremony.

Bourbon King drove through a narrow opening at the head of the stretch at Jamaica yesterday and then dashed on to capture the $9,250 Remsen Handicap to continue the good fortune of Hal Price Headley of Kentucky. So fit did his young nephew, trainer Duval Headley, have the son of Whichone that the margin was two lengths at the end of the six furlongs.

A capacity crowd witnessed the third night's program of the tenth annual Boston horse show at the Commonwealth Armory tonight. Skerbach Flame, owned by the Dawn o' Day Stable of Freehold, N. J., scored in the single harness championship sweepstakes for the challenge trophy offered by Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Page, defeating Jix, winner in 1936.
Albert. Levitt, a former assistant attorney general, cited this biblical verse last week as his reaction to a decision of the United States Supreme Court.

THESE are the days when phones start to ring early in the morning and invitations pour in for luncheon and bridge, matinee and cocktails. Therefore one shops about with the idea of finding the latest in the dresses that look well when one takes off one's coat.
The first regular meeting of the New York State Safe Deposit Association in New York City will be held in the Hotel Martinique on Wednesday evening.

An investigation made for the Emergency Relief Bureau by one of its own field supervisors in District Office 11, on the lower East Side, disclosed that during the first week in August the Workers Alliance, a left-wing organization of relief recipients, had solicited members in the ERB office, brought in grievance committees three times as large as those permitted by ERB

The engagement of Miss Mary Ellison, daughter of Mrs. Bennett Ellison of 320 East Seventy-second Street and Bendale Farm, Amenia, N. Y., and the late Mr. Ellison, to E. Talbot Donaldson of Kent, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Donaldson of Turkey Knoll, Tuckahoe, N. Y., has been announced by her mother.

Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. V. Hoppin will return from Newport this week and will be at the SavoyPlaza before going to 45 East Sixtysixth Street. Charles E. Sampson and his sister, Miss Gertrude E. Sampson, left the Pierre yesterday for Bar Harbor, Me.
Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, charged in a radio address last night that Mayor La Guardia, by his tactics in transit matters, was seeking to destroy the five-cent fare.

Mrs. Mae Hensley Rice, wife of Charles St. Clair Rice of Calhoun Drive, Greenwich, and New York City, died at the Greenwich Hospital today at the age of 54. Also surviving are a son, Charles S. Jr.; a daughter, Mrs. Thomas B. Felder of Greenwich and New York, and two brothers, William L. Hensley and Charles Hensley of New York.

Fred B. Snite Jr., victim of infantile paralysis, has arranged to leave here tomorrow for Miami Beach, Fla., in the "iron lung" that has kept him alive for eighteen and a half months. He looked forward to the' 1,497-mile journey with eagerness.

Dr. Frank Morley, distinguished American mathematician and for many years Professor of Mathematics at Johns Hopkins University, died here late today at his home, 100 West University Parkway, at the age of 77.

Whereas until recently most Dutch commentators were inclined to explain the American, British and Continental stock-market reactions as caused mainly by vague political fears, opinions mostly have narrowed down to general discouragement.
Charges that controllers of the former Van Sweringen rail empire are seeking to perpetuate their hold on the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad in the present reorganization proceedings,

Appointment of Walter C. Teagle, chairman of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, as chairman of the Industry Section of the United Hospital Campaign was announced yesterday by Clarence Francis, chairman of the commerce and industry committee.

A police investigation was under way tonight of the mutilation of Wilbur E. Johnson, well-known yachtsman and advertising executive, aboard his yacht in Jones Inlet. Mr. Johnson, 54-year-old widower, was reported in a serious condition tonight at his home, 700 South Long Beach Avepue, Freeport.

A promising young dog came through to the highest honors today in the seventh field trial meeting of the Dachshund Club of America, held in the covers of Kilsyth Farm, the estate of Gerald M. Livingston, a few miles west of this town.

Mayor La Guardia and Jeremiah T. Mahoney will appear on the same platform when they attend the twenty-fifth annual dinner of the Yorkville Chamber of Commerce on Oct. 26, the civic association announced yesterday.

Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners, announced yesterday that 2,648 men and women have applied for high-school licenses in fourteen general and special subjects, for which 240 positions are available.

Paced by the sterling play of Collister (Coddy) Johnson, Yale polo captain, the Burnt Mills Polo Club defeated Shrewsbury, 7 to 5, today. The shore team defeated the local riders, 6-5, a week ago. The line-up:

With seventy-five members of the Rhode Island National Guard patrolling the entrances to the Narragansett race track here tonight, there seemed to be little likelihood that the track would open tomorrow, as scheduled, for the Fall season.

There is little to say of the past financial week, except that the stock market decline continued. At the week's lowest, the averages had lost nearly 9 points more, going below par for the first time since July 1935. Trade news, as usual, was mixed.

The new St. Francis Home for Cardiac Children, at Flower Hill, Roslyn, L. I., which will care for patients from Kings County Hospital, will be opened tomorrow with a tea. The Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of Brooklyn, will be the guest of honor.

With passage of several "bills" and election of officers, the Model Youth Legislature conducted by the New Jersey Branch of the American Youth Congress adjourned sine die at the Y. W. C. A. auditorium here late today. Sessions began yesterday.

Although in general the percentage paid out in taxes increases as total income rises, persons with incomes of $2,000 and less pay more taxes proportionately as their incomes decrease, according to a report made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,999,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Dr. Jacob Heller, in 853 Broadway; Texej, Inc., floor in 60 E 11th St; Sara Rosen, in 395 Broadway; Pacific Vineyard Distributing Co, through Herbert Lawrence Co, store and basement in 18 E 17th St; Carstens. Linnekin Wilson, brokers.

Miss Etta Helen Shackelton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Shackelton of this place, was married to Gordon Townsend Scovil, son of Mrs. Stella Scovil, this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Dr. Raymond W. Smiley, pastor of Westminster Presbyterian Church.

Joe Freeman, traveling hardware salesman, arrived here today with the comment that the Far North is getting a bit "sissy." The "last frontier" that Freeman covers has reached such a stage of civilization that customers in the interior are demanding "modern chromium gadgets of the trickiest design,"

Captain Robert B. Irving, who arrives this morning in command of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, will be the permanent mas- ( ter of the ship. Commodore Reginald V. Peel will not go to sea again on account of ill health.

Unable hitherto to settle upon the ideal food, following pleas for the native Connecticut, the European, and the metropolitan dishes, the Gourmet Club this afternoon, after three-hour speeches, called in Chef Scala and Landlord Gydney of the Outpost Inn and nominated today's menu, which they served at the club's Autumn banquet.
The Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor has bought for cash from Mrs. A. Murray Young the dwelling at 29 Park Avenue.

Turning temporarily from dropping bombs, Japanese aviator assumed the role of volunteer newsboys today and bombarded Chinese front lines with bundles of newspapers. The Japanese newspapers of Shanghai, which have pooled their resources to serve the dwindling Japanese community, issued a Chinese language edition designed

ONE of the most curious cases in modern letters--one a trifle too curious for this reader's taste, it may as well be said at the outset-is that of Franz Kafka, who died in 1924 on his forty-first birthday and whose work is gradually becoming known outside Germany and Austria.
Mrs. Agnes G. E. Shipley, widow of Samuel R. Shipley, a Philadelphia banker, died yesterday at her home, Windon, in West Chester, after a year's illness. Her age was 88.
The annual convention of the Japanese Federation of Labor will adopt today a declaration pledging its members against strikes during the hostilities in China.

Another card party in the series conducted by the Loyal Workers will take place this afternoon at the McAlpin. Mrs. Mary E. Bensel and Mrs. Annabelle Pratt will be host esses. Proceeds will be devoted to the children's camp fund of the organization and to its annual donations to charitable institutions.
Social security has been established in New York City, despite political opposition, "while in other communities they have been talking about it," Mayor La Guardia

Dr. Charles Thomson Jr. of Scranton, physician to the St. Thomas College football team for the last six years, died of acute indigestion today outside Shibe Park at the close of a football game between St. Thomas and St. Joseph's Colleges. His age was 37. He became ill after treating six injured players.

The Reich Chamber of Economy has adopted a resolution advising business interests to return to the system of payment by bills of exchange, which, at present, if the Reich's rearmament bills are excepted, are almost not in circulation.

More than 1,000 men and women attended the twentieth anniversary celebration of the Jewish Center last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. President Roosevelt sent the following message: "I send hearty congratulations to the Jewish Center of New York on the occasion of its twentieth anniversary.

The unveiling of the statue of Admiral Peary in the little Pennsylvania town where he was born will keep it on the map of the world though it has barely two thousand inhabitants. The condensed story of the life that was born there, as told by Professor Hobbes at the unveiling, should find a place in the school libraries, for it has a lesson that should never be forgotten.
179th St, 615 E (11-3069): Randolph Trading Corp to Harlem Savings Bank; due as per bond, $19,500. 135th St, 603 E (10-2548): 603 E 135th St Corp to Harlem Savings Bank; due as per bond, $27,000.

New York's two National Hockey League teams, the Rangers and Americans, will open a sixgame exhibition tour of Western Canada cities next Saturday in Calgary, where the Americans are training, Manager Lester Patrick of the Rangers announced today.

Lydan Realty Corp. sold to an investor the first mortgage of $12.755 on the dwelling at 160 Victory Boulevard, New Rochelle. William J. Hamilton, an investor, has purchased the following mortgages: $6,500 on 57-10 Maiden Lane, Maspeth; $3,500 on 61-29 160th St., Flushing;

American military history was written on the plains of Texas recently when for the first time our army tested an anti-mechanized battalion, equipped with 37-millimeter anti-tank guns and truck-transported. This unit--now an integral part of most European armies--is still in experimental development in this country, and the recent test was part of larger and more important manoeuvres--the most significant in

William F. Hudgings of 10 Montague Terrace, Brooklyn, one of the editors of the Pro-Palestine Herald, who was secretary of the AmericanChristian Conference at the Hotel Astor last December, died yesterday in the Long Island College Hospital of a heart attack.

An effective forward-passing offense played a prominent role as the Brooklyn Eagles blanked the Bushwicks, 10 to 0, in an American Football Association game at Ebbets Field yesterday before 4,000 fans.

The struggle of tendencies between election-generated optimism and traitor-generated pessimism mentioned in a recent dispatch is increasingly evident in provincial newspapers subsequent to Oct. 12, when the election date was announced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Speaking recently at a Founders Day celebration at the University of North Carolina, Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, delivered what was probably the most amazing address ever made by a law officer of this government.

The Banca Commerciale Italiana Trust Company, fiscal agent, will notify holders of Benigno Crespi, Societa Anonima 7 per cent first mortgage thirty-year bonds due on May 1, 1956, that bonds totaling 300,000 lire have been drawn for redemption through the sinking fund on Nov. 1.
Day-to-day loans are currently quoted at only 1 1/2 per cent and capital put again at the market's disposal probably is partly invested in Treasury bills.

In an attempt to check the drive for organized labor support for Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, Alex Rose, State executive secretary and campaign director of the American Labor party, made public yesterday photostatic copies of letters purporting to have been written by Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation,

The taxicabs of the Sunshine Radio System, representing a combination of twenty-five fleet operators, which have been idle since last Wednesday, were again moving yesterday, it was announced by Otto Gutfreund, secretary and general manager of the company.
The trend in the present campaign for the election of four county officers and fifteen judges in Philadelphia and Mayors in Pittsburgh and Scranton is Democratic.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 89.5, which compares with 89.8 a week ago, 90.7 two weeks ago, 92.2 three weeks ago and 92.4 four weeks ago.

Wheat and other grains declined early last week to the lowest levels for the season as the result of liquidation induced by uneasiness over the recession in the security markets, but aggressive buying appeared and drew in the broadest European demand for cash wheat to date this season.

New and stringent air traffic rules to make flying safer will go into effect Nov. 1. The regulations, announced today, are the result of nearly two years of study by the Bureau of Air Commerce in airway traffic control.
The Cleveland Rams bowed to the Green Bay Packers in a National Football League game before 12,000 fans today by 35-10.

While in recent weeks the behavior of the stock markets so frequently has confounded the prophets by persisting in their steep declines, even though conditions are interpreted as favoring recovery, it now finally appears as if prices on the securities exchanges have reached some sort of bottom.

Reversing Saturday's verdict in Newark, where they suffered a 6-1 setback, players representing the New England division of the American Soccer League put on a brilliant exhibition at Starlight Park in the Bronx yesterday to defeat the metropolitan group team by 4-1. A crowd of 4,000 witnessed the game.

The educated toes of Harry Newman and Les Post today provided the Rochester Tigers with two field goals and a 6-0 triumph over the Boston Shamrocks in an American League football game before 4,000 spectators at Fenway Park.

Members of the Penland Board of the Church of the Ascension will give their annual bridge party and tea on Nov. 9 on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis in aid of their Appalachian School at Penland, N. C. The school, situated in the mountains about sixty miles from Asheville, provides instruction and training for children up to twelve years of age.

Ideal Autumn weather brought many visitors to the Berkshires and there was much entertaining over the week-end. At Maple Manor, New Marlboro Mr. and Mrs. George Greer of Rye, N. Y., observed Mr. Greer's birthday with a dinner party tonight.

The promotion of fourteen students enrolled in the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps was announced yesterday by Colonel Oliver Prescott Robinson, chairman of the Department of Military Science and Tactics. The fourteen students were all assigned to the R. O. T. C. band at the college.
The University of Santa Clara football team, pointing for a second invasion of the New Orleans Sugar Bowl, defeated Portland University, 27 to 0, before 7,000 today.
The Chicago Bears won their fourth victory in as many National Football League games this season by defeating the Chicago Cardinals, 16 to 7 today, before 23,000 fans at Wrigley Field.

Mankind needs a greater faith in the law of the unforeseen, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street, said in his morning sermon yesterday.

J. O. Moses, a Negro, sought in connection with the slaying of two policemen here yesterday, was shot and critically wounded by police tonight. Chief of Police E. D. Vaughn said that Moses, found in a closet of a dwelling not far from the City Jail, resisted arrest.

Stocks declined sharply to lowest levels since July, 1935, in heaviest weekly trading since April; turnover, 9,854,905 shares. United States Government issues steady, corporate and foreign bonds weak; transactions, $42,189,775.
Stuart Chase, economist, said tonight that balancing the Federal budget was "minor compared to balancing our account with nature."

The expansion of Great Britain's foreign trade continues at a satisfactory rate. It is to be noted, however, that imports are rising faster in value than exports, which, however, are increasing faster in volume than imports,

Sid White of Brooklyn College and Bill Tranavitch of Rutgers scored 37 and 20 points respectively over the week-end to climb into a tie for the East's individual football scoring honors with 50 points each.

Dr. Emanuel Lasker, chess champion of the world from 1894 to 1921, who arrived in New York from Rotterdam Saturday night, announced yesterday that he had decided to play In an international masters tournament to be held in Moscow next February and March.
The program for the visit to Canada this week of Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, and Mrs. Hull was announced tonight. They will be accompanied by James C. Dunn and Harry A.

The Paterson Panthers and Newark Tornadoes battled to a scoreless tie today before 12,500 at Hinchliffe Stadium. The result allowed Newark to maintain its lead in the southern division of the American Professional Football Association.

The rapid transformation of the United States from a nation predominantly rural to one predominantly urban has created new problems which the church must solve, Dr. R. J. Colbert. chief of economics and sociology in the extension division of the University of Wisconsin, said here tonight.

Ten children of the toddler age have been enrolled in Fordham University's Department of Psychology, the Rev. Walter G. Summers, head of the department, announced yesterday. The youngsters, five boys and five girls from 3 to 5 years old, all have passed physical and psychological "entrance" examinations.

The Academy of American poets, founded several years ago to create fellowships for worthy American poets, will give'a reception and tea today in the Garden of the Ambassador for Frederick R. Higgins, Irish poet.

British steel production in September reached a new high record of 1,163,000 tons, comparing with 987,700 in August and 1,027,000 in September, 1936. The previous high record was 1,109,500 tons for last March.

George Lott and Vincent Richards staged a brilliant rally after they had dropped the first two sets to defeat Bruce Barnes and Karel Kozeluh, 1-6, 6-8, 6-3, 7-5, 9-7, in the final of the national open tennis doubles championship tournament today.
The Rev. Walter L. Shaw, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church here, died last night at the church parsonage after an illness of three weeks. He was 65 years old.

The Bethpage Polo Club, winner for the past two years, was upset by the 101st Cavalry of Huntington, L. I., 6-4, in the final of the third annual Herbert Bayard Swope Trophy competition today at the Bethpage State Park.

Barnes Ave (15-4321), w s, 365 ft n of Lydig Ave. 200x100: Max Nlsnewitz to Inwood Courts, Inc., 2,160 Wallace Ave. Davidson Ave (11-2863), e s, 237 ft s of Burnside Ave, 45x80; Rudolph Rosen.berger to Rutlyn. Realties, Inc., 163 E. 87th St.

Germany's import duty on pig iron has been reduced from ten marks to one mark a ton. The production of pig iron in September amounted to 1,349,000 tons and in the first nine months of this year to 11,766,000 tons, against 11,409,100 tons in the same period of 1936.

Credit for an administration that transformed the city's "dilapidated, ramshackle hospital system" into "a modern, scientifically equipped, efficiently manned service" was claimed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in a statement which he called "Lesson 6" of the series started for the benefit of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, his Democratic opponent.

The continued operation of 259 ships in the Atlantic and Gulf coastwise trade and 193 vessels in the intercoastal trade is threatened by provisions of the Pettengill bill, according to Cornelius H. Callaghan, general manager of the Maritime Association.

Defending Federal regulation of financial markets, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora said yesterday that "the sooner the leaders of the financial community realize the futility of trying to re-create the old happy hunting grounds, the sooner they will attain the stable market they profess so much to want."

With the exception of Wednesday, which witnessed a substantial recovery, owing apparently to the Berlin-Brussels neutrality affirmation, the Boerse continued along an irregular and weak course this week.

Rose and Alberta Seibel of Pittsfield, Mass, gave a mortgage to Amy Friou on 447 E 83d St, for $3,000, due three years hence at 5 per cent, and this money must be used only for payment of tax arrears.

The cantonal election results and the recovery of the franc naturally have reacted on the Stock Exchange here. Industrial securities already were in favor last week, their prices being very low, and with the depreciation of the franc, they advanced much more.

The imminent necessity for the Chinese military to obtain substantial imports of supplies and war implements which are manufactured only abroad is raising the question among foreign military observers here as to how these. imports can be brought into the country because of the Japanese Navy's tight blockade of the Chinese coast.

Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in America, today called for "a new political instrument to defeat reactionism" and pledged Communist support to President Roosevelt until that "instrument" could be devised.
The lowest levels in three years for lard futures were established last week as general liquidation, induced by weakness in cotton, cottonseed oil, stocks and grains, carried prices down.

"An Anti-God Exhibit" will take place at the headquarters of the Trinity League, an Archdiocesan Roman Catholic organization, 32 West Sixtieth Street, of which the Rev. Paul B. Ward, a Paulist Father, Is the spiritual director, at 8:30 o'clock tonight.

Mrs. Johanna Riley Sullivan, superintendent of St. Joseph's new cemetery, died at her home here today. She was 83 years old. Mrs. Sullivan was the only woman cemetery superintendent in the United States.
Alfred M. Landon, Republican Presidential nominee in 1936, announced tonight that he was calling "a nation-wide mass meeting" over the radio Tuesday night to discuss "certain questions of the day."

In an address which he delivered at the University of Delaware to commemorate the founding of the Swedish colony on the banks of the Delaware 300 years ago, Nobel laureate Professor The Svedberg seemed to have fitted into its lock the key which may some day be turned to open the door of life's chemical mystery.
Fort Hamilton scored its first football victory in three starts by topping the Bay Ridge Phantoms, 7-6, in a thrilling contest yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn.

The fire Saturday night that caused 1,800 persons to file out of the R. K. O. Hamilton Theatre at Broadway and 146th Street did not start in the stockroom of the women's and children's wear store owned by Mrs. I. Berger at 3,566
St. Mary's turned back a stubborn Loyola University Lion pack today, 13 to 7, before 25,000 football fans.

A campaign motion picture of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's fight on rackets, in which victims appear as actors and tell their stories, was shown in a preview last night at Dewey headquarters. Tonight, and for the rest of Mr. Dewey's campaign as candidate for District Attorney, it will be shown on street corners through the city.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:

Thre more cowboys were added to the injured list at the rodeo yesterday. Only one received major injuries. At the evening performance, attended by 12,800 spectators, Jimmy Nesbit, well-known cowboy clown, was gored by a steer.

Mrs. Mabel Susan Walker, daughter of. Mrs. Frank Rose Sr. and the late Mr. Rose, and Maurice William Schuk, both of Huntington Station. were married this afternoon in St. Peter's Evangelical Lutheran Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Paul H. Pallmeyer.

The American Institute of Architects announced yesterday that Henri Madelain of Paris has received a scholarship for travel in the United States. He is the eighth foreign student of the arts to receive, the award, established by William A. Delano and Chester H. Aldrich of New York to advance

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Christine Connor, daughter of Mrs. Charles B. Wanamaker of this city, to Shelton Dee Hawkins, also of New York, son of Mrs. Frances Hawkins, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Riverside Church.

One who has been honored by his party with selection for high office owes to his party a degree of regularity not expected of the average citizen. None the less it comes as a blow to admirers of Governor Lehman that he has endorsed the Tammany candidate for Mayor as against Mr. La Guardia, during whose Fusion Administration the decency which Governor Lehman has perpetuated in Albany has been brought to this long-suffering community.

Although more births were recorded in this city last month than in any September in the last five years, the birth rate on the basis of estimated population was lower, with two exceptions, than that of any September in history, it was reported yesterday by Thomas Duffield, registrar of records of the Department of Health.

More than 500 Lutherans from churches in Brooklyn and Queens attended the first of a series of meetings arranged under the auspices of the Long Island Lutheran Conference yesterday afternoon at St. Peter's Church, 1,006 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

Three performances were enough for, "Wise Tomorrow." which opened at the Biltmore last Friday evening, gave a matinee Saturday, and departed after Saturday night's showing. With another of last week's incidents, "In Clover," it thus shared the distinction of one of the shortest runs of the season....

Several results of a surprising nature were registered on the various fronts in the scholastic football world during the past week-end as a number of previously unbeaten squads, including a few of last year's leaders, felt the sting of defeat.

Helen Keller Tribute Year, a period for special recognition by the adults and school children of America of the devotion and achievements of the celebrated blind teacher of the blind, begins today. Initiated by the American Foundation for the Blind, it will culminate on next March 3, which is expected to be designated by President Roosevelt as National Helen Keller Day.

Fiftieth Anniversary of the American Institute of Accountants, Waldorf-Astoria, 11 A. M. Continues to Friday. Meeting of the Women's League for Palestine, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, Rabbi Israel H. Levinthal.

Olay J. S. de Brun of 19 East Eighty-eighth Street and Groton Long Point, Conn., has announced the marriage of his daughter, Miss Patricia de Brun, to Douglas Britton Leigh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Leigh of Atlanta, Ga. The couple were married secretly in this city on Sept. 8, the bride's eighteenth birthday.

Finding a use for old newspaper mats-the molds for casting the stereotypes from which daily newspapers are printed-George Bijur, Inc., local advertising agency, will utilize them for ceiling insulation in the new offices at 9 Rockefeller Plaza which it will occupy today.
It is not quite enough to be born a genius. One must arrange with one's parents to be born into the right century. Alceo Dossena,

Under the capable guidance of Captain C. C. Jadwin of Olympic riding fame, Black Beauty turned in a superb performance to feature the closing program of the 110th annual Boston Horse Show at the Commonwealth Armory tonight.

Mrs. Dodge Sloane of Locust Valley, L. I., has arrived to pass three weekss at the Greenbrier. United States Attorney General Homer A. Cummings and Mrs. Cummings are here with Mr. and Mrs. William Stanley of Laurel, Md.

Miss Ethel Catharine Fleming, educator, died while visiting here Saturday. Her age was 62. She was born in Brampton, Ont., daughter of the late James Fleming, M. P., and Mrs. Fleming. For ten years she was a teacher at the Niagara Falls Collegiate Institute, then went to the Sorbonne in Paris, where she took a post-graduate course in French.

In sentencing a pastor of the Protestant Confessional Church, of which the Rev. Martin Niemoeller is the head, the Prussian Superior Court decided the Confessional Church was legally no longer part of the official German Evangelical Church.

Isidore Nagler, American Labor party candidate for Bronx Borough President, called yesterday upon James J. Lyons, his Democratic opponent, to declare whether or not he would vote in the Board of Estimate to reduce the salary slash decreed by Mayor La Guardia for John J. Knewltz, Bronx Commissioner of Records and Bronx County Republican leader.

With the Fair corporation pushing its construction program "at double quick speed," an investment of $10,500,000 in actual construction contracts and commitments already has been made in the New York World's Fair 1939, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair corporation, announced yesterday.

President Roosevelt interrupted a quiet Sunday at home today to confer with Secretary Perkins on labor matters in general. It appeared probable that the two had discussed the future of the Wages and Hours Bill, which is high on the agenda to be pressed upon the special session of Congress which meets Nov. 15.

France's general wholesale price index on Oct. 9 stood at 618, against 616 on Oct. 2 and 617 on Sept. 25. The weekly trend of French wholesale prices, by groups and based on the average of 1914 as 100, is shown in the following table, giving figures for the last two weeks and for Sept.12, 1936, before devaluation of the franc last year:
Captain Ed Channing of Elizabeth City won the national moth boat championship today by sailing his Imp to victory in a three-bote field in the final event of the three-day regatta.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, who attended the General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church at Cincinnati, told his congregation at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, yesterday that "the Episcopalians have fumbled the divorce question again."

"The answer to the question, Is civilization worth saving?' depends on our conception of the meaning and the purpose of life," the Rev. S. E. Gerard Priestly declared yesterday before the congregation in the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Seventy-sixth Street and Central Park West.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hicks Kerr entertained with cocktails in the Pilgrim Room of the Homestead last evening. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Huntington Hartford, Miss Lesley Bogert, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Ellis, Mr. and Mrs. Worthington Johnson, Hugh J. Grant, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Moreland, Mrs. Terrell Johnson, Mr. and Mrs. Carroll B. Alker,

Officers have been elected for the fourteenth annual Westchester Music Festival which will be held at the County Center at White Plains next May, it was announced yesterday. Mrs. Valentine E. Macy is the president. Hugh Ross has been Ca named the musical director.

Boito's rarely heard opera, "Mefistofele," was presented at the New York Hippodrome last night and evoked the approval of a goodsized audience. The cast was headed by Mina Horne as Margherita and Elena, Lawrence Power as Faust and Nino Carboni as Mefistofele.

A substitute guard today kicked a point after touchdown on the first play of his varsity football career and gave the undefeated St. Thomas College of Scranton, Pa., a 7-to-6 victory over St. Joseph's College, before a crowd of 8,000 at Shibe Park.

The body of William Donaid Beard, former assistant general counsel of the legal department of the Hercules Powder Company, Wilmington, Del., was found in his automobile at the edge of woods near here today.

Government supply contracts numbering eighty-three and valued at about $7,943,173 were awarded by ten Federal agencies in the week ended on Oct. 14 under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, according to the Department of Labor.

In services as short as his life was full and as simple as he would have liked, some 200 friends paid final tribute yesterday in the chapel of New York University to Robert Underwood Johnson, poet, editor, director of the Hall of Fame and former Ambassador to Italy, who died Thursday in his eighty-fifth year.

Chinese planes surprised the Japanese at Shanghai by a series of sharp raids last night and early this morning and the International Settlement was sprayed with fragments of shells from anti-aircraft batteries. New craft from France and Russia were supposed to be in the attacking force.

Woman, once superior to man has declined to his equal in the days of "the so-called modern woman," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University, Washington, told the Ladies Auxiliary of the Christian Brothers at their comunion breakfast in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Brooks Bauman, 23 years old, of 430 Highland Avenue, Salem, Ohio, a student at Yale University, was instantly killed early today when the car in which he was riding swerved from the Cat Rock Road near Garrison and rammed into a stone wall.

An internal fight among Arkansas Democrats over selection of a successor to the late Joe T. Robinson in the Senate will reach its climax tomorrow at a special general election. The candidates, Governor Carl E. Bailey and Representative John E. Miller, last night wound up a three-week campaign, one of the briefest but the bitterest in the State's history.

A series of robberies throughout Manhattan and the Bronx, including one Saturday night in which a policeman's service pistol was stolen from his apartment, was belived solved last night by the death of a burglar in a four-story fall and the subsequent arrest of his brother.

The New York Vassar Club has taken over the matinee performance of the revival of Verdi's "Otello," with Martinelli and Tibbett in the leading roles, on Jan. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of its scholarship fund.
Charles H. Huggins Jr. has been appointed assistant department head in the wash goods division of Pacific Mills. He will assist in the development and sale of popular price rayon fabrics.
China, it is learned, will participate in the Nine-Power Conference in Brussels, adopting the stand that the treaty provides full scope for the application of economic sanctions against Japan.

Hailed as "the most efficient Mayor the city has ever had" and as a sincere friend of labor, Mayor La Guardia was endorsed for re-election by Typographical Union No. 6 (Big Six) at a meeting in Stuyvesant High School, First Avenue and Fifteenth Street, yesterday.

Soviet actors, singers and other concert artists were disclosed today to have been graded according to their talents and put on a fixed wage scale by the All-Union Art Committee. The newspaper Soviet Art said the action was taken to scale down high salaries of some stan, encourage the development of new talent and make good concerts cheaper for workers' clubs.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hurst Martin of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Mabel Martin, to Thomas Burnett Dorman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dorman of Upper Montclair, N. J.

Election of Philip George Lang Jr., engineer of bridges of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, as president of the American Welding Society was announced here tonight at the opening of the society's eighteenth annual meeting and exposition.
Governor Lehman will open the Democratic drive to elect fifteen delegates at large to the coming State Constitutional Convention with a radio address tomorrow night, over a State-wide hook-up.

Wheat has had another bad week here, heavy speculative liquidation meeting comparatively small resistance. It is quite probable that further liquidation may be encountered, while political influences will continue to disturb sentiment;

Gold imports last month amounted to [pound]15,439,327, lifting the nine-month total to [pound]258,135,165, against [pound]229,085,585 correspondingly last year. September exports totaled [pound]21,645,913, with [pound]183,773,432 in the first nine months, against [pound]38,910,516 similarly in 1936.
John F. Dezell, president of Dezell Co., linen importers, of 58 White Street, died on Saturday at his home, 344 West Seventy-second Street, after a short illness. He was 70 years old.
Speculative interest in the grain markets increased last week, but the activity was at the expense of prices, as all grains sold at new low levels for the season. An increase of 9,000.
Niagara's undefeated Purple Eagles were upset by St. Bonaventure today before 8,000 spectators, the largest crowd ever to see a game at Niagara. The score was 14 to 7.

Harald Kreutzberg's return to New York in a recital at the Guild Theatre last night after an absence of nearly two years proved to be a thoroughly heart-warming occasion, not only because it was a welcome to an old friend but especially because the old friend seemed so much finer a dancer than he had ever seemed before.

Sentiment concerning the situation of and outlook for home business has improved this week. Especially welcome were the official and party denials of any general design to cheapen goods through the medium of decreed price cuts or the summary reduction of industrial profits.

Export sales of around 1,000,000 bushels of soy beans, largely to Germany, are reported to have been made this season, and the development of this business was largely responsible for an advance of 3 to 3 1/2 cents a bushel in futures last week.

The Giants fired away with two barrels at the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds yesterday. One barrel was the first team and the other was the second, although such fine distinctions as first and second were practically impossible to identify.

The Hergo Realty Corporation, an investor represented by O'Gara Co., Inc., bought from the holders of Series B-1 Mortgage Certificates the six-story apartment house at 3,105 Brighton Third Street, Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

Scott Fowler, 74 years old, a retired furniture dealer, was found dead with a fractured skull late last night at the foot of cellar stairs in his home at 5 Dundee Road here. His body was found by a maid, who said he had been missing for four or five hours.

Today was a perfect day for hunting the Vermont covers, but a bad one for three nimrods. Even the setter looked at us with something of disgust as we missed bird after bird. Of course we had an excuse. More than one, but they are never as consoling as partridges in the back pocket of your hunting coat.

Declaring that "in the midst of the present world scene the theme of peace must be a prominent part, if not the foremost part, of our message," the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliott in a sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street, Brooklyn, said yesterday morning "the church must not be idle nor silent."
Paul Dwyer's motive for slaying Dr. James G. Littlefield, 64-year-old South Paris physician, and his wife, Mrs. Lydia G. Littlefield, also 64, was robbery, an official said definitely here tonight.

As typical of the maze of taxes that manufacturing companies with offices and branches in key sections of the United States must meet annually, the president of a large corporation has received from the controller of his company a list of taxes paid by the company this year.

The first results of the French local elections induced a complete turnabout in the tendency of the market, because, even if the run-off balloting on Sunday should bring a very unfavorable modification, the final result already is evident.

Ray Mangrum, slender Dayton (Ohio) shotmaker, today toured the rainsoaked country club course with a 66, five under par, to boost him and his partner, Johnny Revolta, into second place in the Oklahoma City $5,000 four-ball golf tournament, only one point behind the leaders,
The New York Yankees tallied ten points in the final period of an American League football game today to break even in a 17-17 tie with the Cincinnati Bengals.

Maurice Combs, 37, of Comstock, N. Y., was killed instantly near here today by a shot from another deer hunter's gun. Forrest Olden, 39, of Warrensburg, N. Y., one of his two companions, was wounded slightly in the leg.
Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn dedicated an edifice yesterday morning for St. Bernadette's Shrine Church, Eighty-second Street and Thirteenth Avenue, Brooklyn.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor made the first hotel-window appearance of their German tour here tonight to appease a vociferous crowd that refused to go away after the arrival of the Duke's party.

It was learned here yesterday that Mrs. Jay F. Carlisle, daughter of James A. Moffett, chairman of the California-Texas Oil Company and former head of the Federal Housing Administration, has established residence outside Reno, preparatory to filing for divorce.

William F. Humphrey, president of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, will report today to stockholders that the company's earnings for the third quarter of this year will show a substantial improvement over the same period of 1936.

The First Presbyterian Church of Mount Vernon closed today its week's observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the church. At the morning service the Rev. Dr. Louis Matthews Sweet, Professor of Systematic Theology at the Presbyterian Seminary, Chicago, spoke.

Flashing its most powerful attack of the season, the First Division quartet crushed the Governors Island Yellows, 17-5, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation. In rolling up the largest score of the campaign at the Brooklyn Field the First Division avenged earlier setbacks at the hands of its army foe this year.

A tender and life-transforming sympathy is indispensable to true Christianity, yet it is all but a "lost chord" in the religion of many today, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Mrs. Julius Bliss of Bronxville, whose hunters and jumpers have been turning in notable exhibitions throughout the season, saw her entries score splendid victories at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club horse show today.

William A. Lord of this community, former Mayor of Orange and brigadier general in the New Jersey National Guard, charged today that United States Senator A. Harry Moore was "evasive" in replying to his question whether the Senator would appoint Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City to fill his unexpired term if he was elected Governor.

Notice that service to and from eight stations on the New RochellePort Chester division of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway will be discontinued at midnight on Oct. 31 has been posted at the affected points, Edwin L. Garvin and James L. Dohr, co-receivers of the line, announced yesterday.

A citizens' nonpartisan committee has been organized to work for the election of the thirty-two City Council candidates endorsed by the Seabury group, George Brokaw Compton, manager of the group, announced yesterday. The thirtytwo include enrolled Democrats, Republicans, Socialists and American Laborites. Headquarters for the committee are in the Hotel Roosevelt. Following are the candidates endorsed, by boroughs:

Last week, standing before 1,500 of his men at the department's annual memorial service at 100th Street and Riverside Drive. Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott referred to the bronze plaque installed in the Municipal Building two days before to record the names of firemen killed in action.
The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, spoke of the "tremendous debt which we owe to physicians" in his sermon at the morning service in the Cathedral yesterday.

The Democratic city-wide candidates have chosen to fight their campaign on "prejudice, subterfuge and confusion of issues, the three greatest enemies of democracy," Newbold Morris, RepublicanFusion and American Labor candidate for President of the City Council, declared last night in a radio address over WEVD.

Ernest Brown, Minister of Labor, will begin tomorrow a year's inquiry to find out the cost of living in Great Britain. The wages of 1,250,000 workers still are governed by an index figure on living costs compiled from pre-war prices.
Graham Peel, composer of music for about 100 songs, died yesterday at the age of 60. Among his best-known works were settings for "Songs of a Shropshire Lad." He was unmarried.

Frederic Cameron Church, insurance executive for more than fifty years, industrialist, banker and philanthropist, died of a heart attack last night at his home on Belmont Avenue at the age of 80. Services will be held at All Souls Church here Tuesday at 2 P. M., with burial in Lowell Cemetery.

Miss Catherine Elizabeth Cameron of West Hartford and Wallace Watson King of Southbury were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. King. The Rev. Dr. J. F. Johnstone of the First Presbyterian Church officiated.

A program to provide enough highly skilled workers to supply industry's growing needs and to guarantee thorough trade preparation for apprentices was begun today by the Department of Labor with an announcement by Secretary Perkins's office of the appointment of a Federal Committee on Apprentice Training as provided by the Fitzgerald act, passed at the last session of Congress.

The Detroit Lions romped to their fourth victory this season today by swamping the Brooklyn Dodgers, 30 to 0. Flashing their best attack of the season, the Lions had no difficulty in completely routing the team coached by their former mentor, George (Potsy) Clark. as 21,000 looked on.

Paul Goetz, real estate appraiser for the Law Department of the city, executive member of the Regular Democratic Club of Canarsie and for many years a leader of efforts to obtain civic improvements for that section of Brooklyn, died in Beth-El Hospital, Brooklyn, yesterday morning of injuries received in an accident Oct. 9. His age was 56.
The only lips that ever could have told the tragic story of Saturday's explosion in Mulga Mine were sealed today by the death of Ivan Fox, which brought the toll to thirty-four lives.

There is need in the world today for a realization that human values are more important than material values, Dr. Shailer Mathews dedared in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. Dr. Mathews is dean emeritus of the divinity school of the University of Chicago.

The German wholesale price index on Oct. 6 was 106, against 106.2 the preceding week. In the first nine months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

They called it a soft-ball game at the international polo field here today but like the report of Mark Twain's death, the story was greatly exaggerated. About 1,000 persons, most of whom paid $3 for a chance to see two big-name teams cavort for the benefit of Roosevelt Memorial Park in Oyster Bay, shivered during the contest, which Umpire-Announcer John Golden and Announcer-Umpire Gene Buck might have called "no contest" but forgot.

Great Britain's Fifty Books of the Year (1936) will be exhibited at the American Institute of Graphic Arts, 115 East Fortieth Street, beginning Oct. 27. This is the ninth annual showing of the volumes chosen by the committee of the First Edition Club of London, and is similar to the annual showings of the American Fifty Books.
Edmund Cummings, attorney for the family of kidnapped Charles S. Ross, 72year-old retired manufacturer, released a signed statement today from Mr. Ross's wife which said:
Europe's diplomats are back in the land of make-believe tonight at the start of what had been advertised as a realistic new effort to take the international mischief out of the Spanish civil war.

Mrs. Thomas Hardy, widow of the famous poet and novelist, died today at her home, Max Gate, at the age of 56. She was taken ill in London three months ago and insisted on returning to the home she had shared with her husband since they were married in 1914, two years after the death of Mr. Hardy's first wife.
The results of the second ballot of the Cantonal elections, which were virtually complete at midnight, indicated there had been no important shift in opinion in France.

BARKHORN--At Newark, N. J., on Sunday, Oct. 17, 1937, Clara Webner, widow of Charles H. Barkhorn. Funeral service at her home, 223 Fairmount Ave, Newark, on Wednesday, Oct. 20, at 2:30 P. M. BLOOM--Casper, beloved husband of Diana, devoted father of Beatrice, Yvette and Saul, brother of Sarah, Samuel, Ray, Harry, Louis, Carl, William, Joseph and Lottie. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., today, 11:30 A. M.

The Spanish Insurgent regime moved today to assume control of all mining property in its territory. A decree issued at Salamanca in the name of Generalissimo Francisco Franco annulled all transactions in mining property, bonds, machinery or other equipment carried out since July 18, 1936, when the civil war began.
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Samuel Untermyer, attorney, on behalf of Harold W. Hastings for District Attorney--WHN, 8 to 8:30 P. M.

Senate investigators announced today that they would open a public inquiry on Wednesday into the reorganization plans of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company and its Southwestern affiliated companies.

The figures for September, issued this week, show that France's external trade still was unfavorable. The value of imports, 3,486,000 francs last month, against 3,158,000 france in August, increased more than that of exports, which was 1,411,000 francs against 1,297,000, so that the deficit in the trade balance increased in the month.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 63 per cent of capacity, off 3 points in a week and 11 points in a fortnight. The average in the first nine months of the year was 83.12 per cent.

Germany, it was stated in semi-official quarters today, is willing to consider the French five-point plan for withdrawal of foreign volunteers from Spain as submitted to the Non-Intervention Committee yesterday and will do so "with sincere wishes and a will to cooperate in a solution of the Spanish problem."

Coastwise shipping remained crippled today by a general strike of longshoremen, checkers and clerks in ports from Wilmington, N. C., down the Atlantic seaboard and up the Gulf coast of Florida to Tampa.

While the stock market decline is having its effect on conditions, business generally will hardly parallel the "blues" of the market, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declares in the monthly review of business which is being sent today to the 20,000 members of the association in banking, manufacturing and wholesaling fields.

Thirty-five Japanese color block prints, copies from noted artists of a 250-year period, cut and printed for collectors by Toyohisa Adachi, a Tokyo artist-craftsman, were placed on exhibition at the art gallery of the Greenwich Library this afternoon. The show will end on Oct. 31.

Cary Grant's new line-up with RKO calls for three pictures a year, and the scheduled three will begin Nov. 1--or as soon thereafter as Grant finishes with Katharine Hepburn in "Bringing Up Baby"with "Joy of Loving," in which he and Irene Dunn will attempt to repeat their impressive success in Columbia's "The Awful Truth."

Fierce fighting is reported in Northern Shansi Province. The Chinese were said to be attacking Yuanping, sixty-five miles north of Taiyuan, the provincial capital. [Fifty thousand Japanese have been reported to be nearly surrounded in Northern Shansi.]

A real Catholic must be a good citizen and may only question civil authority when it is unjust, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared in a sermon yesterday at the high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. He also took note of the plight of Catholics in other lands as he asked for generous peterpence offerings, which were taken up throughout the Archdiocese yesterday.

John Pflug scored from a scrimmage after four and one-half minutes of an extra period to give the Governors Island Blues an 8-to-7 victory over the Fort Hamilton poloists yesterday at Morris Memorial Field.

The Adams Express Company in its report for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 shows a net asset value for the common stock of $17.26 a share, against $22.84 on Dec. 31, 1936, and $19.19 a share on Sept. 30, 1936.

Taken at its face value, the address of the British Foreign Minister on the eve of reconvening the nearly moribund. London Non-Intervention Committee, was a clear warning to Italy that Britain's patience is about exhausted.
Funeral services for Mrs. Anna Terwilliger, who died Friday at her home here at the age of 100, were held here today. The Rev. Mitchell T. Anckner of First Presbyterian Church officiated.

Eight of the best sprinters in training in this district are scheduled to compete today in the $3,500 added New Rochelle Handicap, inaugural feature at the Empire City meeting, which will continue until Oct. 30. The meeting is the last of the Jockey Club season, which has been unusually successful this year.

The Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street, marked its sixty-ninth anniversary yesterday with tribute to the Rev. Dr. George U. Wenner, who was its pastor 64 years, from the founding until his death at the age of 91 in 1934.
A Government offensive in the Saragossa sector in Northeastern Spain today brought on one of the bitterest battles of the civil war. Military dispatches said 400,000 men were engaged.
The Fort Jay eleven, with Joe Stancook, former West Point star, leading the attack, defeated Fort Hancock by 20-6, at Governors Island yesterday.
Michael Riley, 72 years old and an invalid, was carried from his home today after flames from an adjoining burning building spread to the house.

Reims Cathedral, completely restored after nineteen years from damages suffered in the World War, will be consecrated and returned to worship tomorrow. Nothing could be done, of course, to replace the statues, stained glass and other artistic treasures that were destroyed, but, thanks in large measure to gifts by John D. Rockefeller Jr.,
The main feature of the cotton market here last week was a rally of more than $2 a bale from the low levels of the season reached in the previous week.

Pravda today devotes a short editorial to the anti-Japanese "partisan movement" in Manchukuo which, it declares, has reached far greater proportions than are generally known abroad. It is said to involve more than 100,000 rebels, mostly operating in small groups in various regions.

Referring to the United States cotton crop estimate, trade journals here emphasize that Germany in no way is dependent on the American staple, and continue that the Reich should reject offers of United States credits and not alienate the Latin-American countries, which are better customers for German goods.

Presenting a powerful ground and air attack, the New Rochelle Bulldogs routed their Westchester rivals, the Mount Vernon Cardinals, 24-7, today at Memorial Field in an American Football Association contest.

Third Ave, 1,760, 25.3x100; Shepherd Knapp to Ransom S. Morgan, 61 W 130th St ($1). 129th St, 2 E, s e cor 5th Ave, 100x74.11; Emanuel Butter to Fremont Realty Corp, 22 E 40th St, c/o M. Schlesinger; consid $7,600 (foreclosure).

Following eight months of preparation, the International Display Executives Association has been formed by a group of display men active in the chain store, national advertising and department store field and will hold its first luncheon meeting on Nov. 3 at the Hotel

THE TRIAL, by Franz Kafka (Knopf, $2.50.) A posthumous novel by the author of "The Castle." PEACEFUL CHANGE, by William T. Stone and Clark M. Eichelberger (Foreign Policy Association, 35 cents.) A survey of proposed solutions for the problems of raw materials, colonies, markets and foreign trade.

A. A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States; Lord McGowan, Lady Kennard, the Raj Kumari Chennajammani of Mysore, India; Sir Edmund and Lady Vestey, Lewis Einstein and Dr. Louis Alexy are among the passengers due today from Europe in the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

The WPA Federal Theatre Project's three-ring circus, which closed its tenting season on Oct. 9 in Flushing, will open its Winter season on Oct. 30 at the Jamaica (L. I.) Arena, project officials announced. After playing to 225,000 paid admissions under canvas, the show will be completely reorganized under the direction of Burns O'Sullivan.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will open the twenty-fifth season of Columbia's Institute of Arts and Sciences tonight with an address on the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution. He will speak in the McMillin Academic Theatre. Broadway and 116th Street, at 8:15 P. M.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Skillman Clark of 321 West Seventy-seventh Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jessie Byrnes Clark, to Robert Wallace Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Graham of Framingham, Mass.

A woman was dead and her husband critically wounded tonight in what police said was a slaying and suicide attempt here. The couple were from East Islip, L. I. Mrs. Louise Wharton, 57 years old, was found dead near a cabin on the Tupper Lake Road and Percy C. Wharton, 55,

Mrs. Arthur C. Holden will give a tea today at her home, 57 East Seventy-eighth Street, for members of a committee, of which she is chairman, in charge of the sale of tickets for the performance of "I'd Rather Be Right" at the Music Box Theatre on Nov. 4 to aid the United Neighborhood Houses of New York.
William Morgan, manager of the hotel and travel advertising division of The Boston Herald, died yesterday at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street, of a coronary thrombosis.

Charles McAlpin Pyle, 44 years old, of Ellicott City, Md., was arrested at the International Casino, 1,514 Broadway, last night on complaint of a waiter who charged that Mr. Pyle had struck him with a bottle.

A score or more of new exhibitions, including a wide variety of media and subject-matter, crowds the art calendar for the current week. More galleries have reopened and two museums are among the show places offering new attractions.

A new picture of the Government's financial situation will be hung on the wall tomorrow, when the Treasury publishes its annual "interim" report on the state of the budget. Coming six months after the last official estimates were published, and nine months after the President's budget message, the new figures will be of special interest for three reasons.

Driving his super-powered Class X outboard motor boat through the calm waters of Green Pond near here today, E. T. Bedford Davie, 24-year-old Tuxedo Park (N. Y.) pilot, registered the fastest speed ever made in outboard craft history by averaging 78.121 miles' per hour in two spins over the mile course.

The sixteenth annual British harvest festival was held yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway and Fulton Street. It took the form of a religious service in which 1,000 persons, many of them members of British societies, united in giving thanks for the fruits and the yield of the earth.
Harry A. Mereness, recently Federal textile expert on consumer goods' standards, has become director of research for the National Federation of Textiles, according to announcement made today.

Miss A. Viola Smith, American trade commissioner at Shanghai, is singled out for special honors in the 1937 edition of the "Survey of Women in Public Office," made public today by the National League of Women Voters.

An army airplane, obtained through an appeal to President Roosevelt, will be used tomorrow to carry Dorothy Ruth Chastain, 16, an infantile paralysis victim, to her home at Wichita Falls, Texas. The plane, fitted with an "iron lung," was to have arrived here today, but was halted at Oklahoma City by bad weather.

The congregation of Brick Presbyterian Church, attending the last Sunday morning service to be held in the 80-year-old edifice at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, was told yesterday by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, that "God is a real presence with us always, wherever we go or stay."

Far above the icy waters of Lake Cayuga and the majestic Hudson, the tumult and the shouting have suddenly become stilled and a strange silence has fallen upon the scene. A pall hangs over Pittsburgh, and it isn't smoke. The wind sighs mournfully through the sycamores in South Bend, and the goblins are on the loose in Lincoln, Neb., where the corn isn't the only thing that's shocked.

While corn sold off with wheat and securities last week, the decline in the yellow grain was by no means severe and the loss was largely recovered later, the active futures closing yesterday on the Board of Trade with prices unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel lower than a week before.

Dr. H. F. Ettinger, an Austrian physician with an American medical background, was playing a man-of-thehour role today behind the Chinese lines.
