With Chinese wounded streaming to the rear from the Shanghai front at the rate of 1,500 a day, Dr. Ettinger directed organization of China's hospital services.

Miss Mathilda Newman of 229 East Seventy-ninth Street, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nedhum Newman, was married yesterday afternoon at Essex House to Joseph Cotler of Brooklyn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cotler.

The Mexican public, studying the statement of President Lazaro Cardenas, regarding the nation's finances, this morning came to the conclusion that it meant that the cost of Mexico's land division program and first big public works endeavor have strained finances to the breaking point.

Francisco Largo Caballero, ex-Premier, who has threatened for three months to launch a stump campaign against the government, was permitted by that government to address an open meeting in Madrid today.
Cliff Battles made three long touchdown runs to pace the Washington Redskins to a 34-to-20 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in a National Football League game today before 12,835 fans.

Announcement late last week by the leading steel and wire producers of extension of prices on most products through the first quarter of 1938 is expected to help stabilize buying by clarifying the market for that period, according to the magazine Steel, out today.
A tenyear-old Yemenite Jewish boy was killed early this morning when a band of Arabs fired on the Jewish colony of Tirath Shalom near Ness Zionah in Southern Palestine.
Arthur Leffingwell Shipman, one of the leading lawyers of New England and a director in many banks and insurance companies, died yesterday of a thrombosis at his home here. His age was 72.

Present-day national and local welfare programs deal exclusively with material needs, ignoring the individual and spiritual needs of the underprivileged, the Rev. Dr. Floyd Van Keuren, executive secretary of the Social Service Commission of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared yesterday in his sermon at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

The Wagnerian Festival Singers, a group of Swedish, Dutch, Czechoslovakian and German artists, all identified in various parts of Europe with the Wagnerian repertory made their appearance yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

"The one hope for an indivisible and democratic peace lies in the collective security of quarantine," said Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, speaking yesterday morning on "Our Country and the War in China" before the Free Synagogue congregation in Carnegie Hall.

IT'S safe to come out of the storm cellars now. But that was some cyclone that hit the gridirons Saturday, wasn't it? Or was it a tornado? Notre Dame ambushed once more by a Carnegie Tech brigade. Shocking! The Nebraska team that had humbled mighty Minnesota held to a scoreless tie by Oklahoma.

The potency of Beethoven's music as a contemporary drawing card was once again illustrated last night when a capacity audience including many standees turned out for the first of a series of Beethoven concerts at the WPA Theatre of Music. Many persons were turned away.

With reports from election boards in several towns in Northern Westchester County missing, the total registration in the county for four days was estimated today at 229,738, compared with 233,410 in 1935, a falling off of 3,672 votes.

William Farson, a municipal bond broker, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 830 Park Avenue. He was 49 years old. Mr. Farson was senior partner of the firm of Farson, Son Co., bankers and brokers, at 111 Broadway. The firm was founded by his late father in 1906. Before the war Mr.

Bostwick Field was the scene of another of the weekly polo matches today, with the home team riders easily turning back John M. Schiff's Roslyn four, 11 to 6. Peter Grace, playing at the back position for the winning side, took scoring honors with six goals.

The Rev. Robert W. Gardner of the Maryknoll Fathers Mission tonight said a cable had been received from Ken Kien, Kwangsi Province, China, reporting the death, from typhoid fever, of the Rev. Leo Foley, M.M., of Medford, Mass., at the age of 38.
Richard Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., won the Buckwood golf trophy today with a 4-and-3 victory over John Papson of Stroudsburg in the final match of the annual Shawnee Country Club tournament.

The number of unemployed persons in Germany in September declined by 40,000 to 469,000, of which 157,000 are not wholly employable. Persons having jobs in September numbered 19,620,000, compared with 14,297,000 in September, 1933.

Business was irregular in the wholesale market last week, with seasonal lulls noted in such lines as furs and boys' wear, and a number of accessory lines inactive. Dress business was slow and prices softened in the lower end.

Miss Jean Saunders, formerly of Calgary, today won her second title in two days at the Queen's Club. Paired with Miss V. E. Scott, she took the women's doubles final of the national covered courts tournament.

One thrust through the air in the opening period gave the Fort Totten football team a 7-to-0 triumph over the Carlisle Field Barracks eleven of Carlisle, Pa., on the victors' Bayside field yesterday. A 30yard forward pass from Gallagher to Sefryn was the winning play.

As long as Hitler is dictator, the outlook for Jews in Germany is hopeless, Joseph C. Hyman of New York, secretary of the Joint Distribution Committee of Jewish Welfare Funds and Federations, declared at a conference of the east central division of the federation here today. He also told of anti-Semitic campaigns in other countries.

Secretary Wallace and Representative Marvin Jones, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, will be among the speakers at the annual convention of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation at Baltimore, Nov. 1, 2 and 3, it was announced today.

The engagement is announced of Miss Leonie Migeon Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Parmelee Williams Jr. of Waterbury and Madison, to John Ogden White of Waterbury, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sage White. Miss Williams ws graduated from St. Margaret's School, Waterbury, and attended Pine Manor at Wellesley, Mass.

Nearly 1,000 Princeton University undergraduates will compete in six branches of sport this Fall as members of upperclass club, dormitory and class teams, according to a report today by William F. Halsey

Unidentified assailants clubbed and severely injured an American woman, Mrs. Steven Davies, near the Italian Consulate in Yokohama tonight. She was removed to a hospital there in what was believed to be a serious condition.

Official announcement was made yesterday that the State of West Virginia would open sealed bids on Oct. 26 on a new issue of $500,000 of road bonds. The issue will be dated May 1 and will mature serially from May 1, 1938 to 1962.

Francis Aranyi, Hungarian violinist, makes his debut at Town Hall tonight. The Academy of Allied Arts is offering high school students a scholarship in piano with Prince Irakli Orbeliani; a scholarship in violin with Frank Kneisel, and a scholarship in 'cello with Bogumil Sykora.

Miss Barbara Scripture and Philip C. Judd, both of New Britain, were married in the First Baptist Church here last evening by the Rev. Ellery Dakin. A reception was held afterward at the Shuttle Meadow Club.

The Goldman Band, under the direction of Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, gave the first concert in a Fall and Winter series of seven yesterday afternoon at Kismet Temple, 92 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn. An audience of 200 heard the band introduce a new march, written for the occasion by Dr. Goldman.

The fusion of the three Nazi movements--the Arrow-Cross Nazis, the Sickle-Cross Nazis and the Anti-Semitic National Front--it was announced last night, is a sign of increasing activity of the Hungarian Rightists.

The new Beth David Hospital, a $1,000,000 nine-story brick building at 161 East Ninetieth Street, was dedicated yesterday afternoon. More than 1,000 attended the exercises in front of the institution.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Douglas McGeorge of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Reynolds McGeorge, to Blaine A. Davis of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Samuel A. Davis of Duquesne, Pa., and the late Mr. Davis. The announcement was made today at a tea at the McGeorge home.
The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices for September, based on 1930 as 100, is 111.2, compared with 111.4 in August and 96.1 in September, 1936.

Scientists who have served as "medicine-men" in building matrials of warfare were condemned by John Haynes Holmes of the Community Church in his sermon, "The New Warfare of Science and Religion," yesterday morning at the Town Hall, 123 West Fortythird Street.

Today the American Foundation for the Blind initiates the Helen Keller Tribute Year and embarks on a campaign for a fund of $2,000,000 to "perpetuate and extend" Miss Keller's work for her fellow-blind.
The question mark no longer is back of Minnesota's gridiron name. The Golden Gophers erased it themselves in re-establishing their team as the powerhouse of the Western Conference.
THE JOURNAL OF EUGENE DELACROIX, translated by Walter Pach. (Covici, Friede, $7.50.) The first English translation. THE GREEN GRAPE, by Simonne Ratel. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A novel of a French family.

The Federal Reserve Board conferred today with the presidents of the Federal Reserve Banks. It was assumed that the stock market drop was a topic of discussion, but officials declined to give out details.
California's Golden Bears, unranked nationally a year ago when The Associated Press started its annual poll, stand at the head of the college football class for 1937.
John (Red) Beatty, speedy Boston Bruins' forward, in a hospital here suffering from influenza, is progressing "very well, indeed," his ?hvsician reported tonight.

An interesting example of early American farmhouse architecture figures in the real estate news today. It is the old fieldstone mansion near Bloomsbury, in Warren County, N. J., a part of which dates back to 1677 and which for seven generations was owned by the Kennedy family.

After the well-earned victory against Georgia, Head Coach Anderson declared a complete holiday for the Holy Cross varsity squad today. Several of the first stringers complained of minor injuries. Bill Osmanski, star of the backfield, will be confined to the hospital a few days for observation with a back injury.

Studies abroad during the academic year, 1937-1938, have been made possible for 154 American students through fellowship awards announced yesterday by the Institute of International Education, under the direction of Professor Stephen P. Duggan.

Phil K. Wrigley, owner of the Cubs, said tonight that Tony Lazzeri, recently given his unconditional release by the Yankees, has accepted an invitation to come to Chicago for a conference relative to his signing with the Chicago National League team.

The proposed promotional campaign of the Producers Council, drawn up by the council's building extension committee, will be referred to the semi-annual meeting of the entire membership in Washington on Nov. 19, John Gowen, secretary, announced here yesterday.

Colonel Grayson Mallet-Prevost Murphy, financier and first European commissioner of the American Red Cross during the World War, died yesterday morning at Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, of bronchial pneumonia. He was 58 years old.

Pope Plus successfully withstood today the extraction of a molar that had been causing him much suffering. The dentist had hesitated several days before deciding to extract on account of the Pope's weak heart.

Miss Louise J. Cooke, for thirty years a teacher at Public School 20, Sanford Avenue and Union Street, Flushing, died on Sunday night at her home, 143-11 Franklin Avenue, Flushing, at the age of 66. She retired two years ago.

Miss Lillian Catherine Leech, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Leech, Cos Cob, was married to Joseph P. Clarke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clarke of Greenwich, in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church, Cos Cob, this morning by the Rev. Joseph A. Ganley, the pastor.

The Fall meeting at Narragansett Race Track failed to open here this afternoon because 300 steel-helmeted members of the Rhode Island National Guard, mobilized by Governor Robert E. Quinn, covered all entrances with even machine guns set up as part of their war equipment.

Alumni and friends of the University of Pennsylvania, at more than seventy-five dinners held tonight throughout the world, participated in a reunion by radio, sang together the university's traditional song, "The Red and Blue," and began a campaign for $12,500,000 with which to carry out the 1940 bicentennial program.

The public has been misled on the question of crime by a "mass of misinformation and vituperation," Sanford Bates, former Federal Director of Prisons and now executive director of the Boys Club of America, told the thirtieth annual conference of New York State Probation Officers yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin.
Coach Benny Friedman did not put the City College football squad through a drill yesterday. Instead he assembled the squad for a review of the flaws in the game with Susquehanna last Saturday.
The Navy football squad will leave Friday evening for South Bend, Ind., where it will meet Notre Dame Saturday in the eleventh contest between the two colleges.

Imprisonment of two Greater Boston milk dealers, "unless and until" they obey a court decree calling for compliance with the Boston Milk Marketing Act, was asked by Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, in a petition filed in Federal court today.

Trading was fair to mostly slow yesterday. Steer cuts were steady to sharply higher, veal and calf steady to weak, lamb weak, fresh pork steady to lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady, veal and calf weak to lower, lambs lower as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Although his recital at the Town Hall last night was his New York debut, Francis Aranyi is a violinist who has seen something of the world, and the world of him. A native of Budapest, he was taken into Hubay's master class when he was 13 years old, and later he studied with Willy Hess and Henri Marteau.

With more than 100 exhibitors showing a wide range of new developments in office equipment, the thirty-fourth annual National Business Show opened yesterday at the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, and attracted hundreds of interested business men and office workers.
Decisions of the New York courts were upheld in two instances by the Supreme Court today, but rejected in another as about thirty orders dealing with various appeals were handed down.

The stock market here started the new account confidently today and there were advances in almost all lines. Gilt-edged issues held steady, while among the foreign bonds German and Far Eastern loans improved.

The last issue in the Treasury's series of 273-day bills was sold today at an average interest rate of 0.362 compared to 0.429 last week and 0.436 the week before, Acting Secretary of the Treasury Magill announced today.
Joseph Bruce Ismay, former chairman of the White Star Line and a survivor of the Titanic disaster in 1912, died here last night. He was 74 years old.

Henry Armstrong, 131M, Los Angeles Negro, knocked out Joe Marciente, 130, Montreal, in the thi of a scheduled ten-round bout at the Arena tonight. Armstrong, who will fight Petey Sarron for the world featherweight title on Oct. 29, outclassed the to Canadian chamDion. He floored e:

Kerry won the Gaelic football championship of Ireland by defeating Cavan yesterday; 4 goals and 4 points to 1 goal and 7 points, before 50,000 at Croke Park. Four players were injured. Spectators rushed on the field when the players started fighting and it took police many minutes to restore order.

Contributions totaling $34,360 were announced yesterday by the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York at a campaign luncheon at the Central Branch Y. W. C. A., 610 Lexington Avenue.

The text of President Roosevelt's radio address tonight opening the annual campaign of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs was as follows: Chairman Taft, Community Chest Workers, Friends of Human Needs:

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today the application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the 4 3/4 per cent convertible debentures of the El Paso Natural Gas Company.

Sixteen hundred cantinas or bars have been closed in Mexico during the three years of President Cardenas's administration, the official organ El Nacional revealed today. These are in addition to many "vice centers."
The first street collection here yesterday for this year's Winter relief produced, according to figures released today, almost 600,000 marks, surpassing last year's figure by nearly 30,000 marks.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange membership was reported yesterday at $61,000, down $11,000 from the last previous transaction on Sept. 24. The price was the lowest since 1919, when the price was $60,000.

The record of the Non-Intervention Committee may be considered tragic in some quarters, but Britain still is able to see ironic humor in it. David Low, New Zealand-born cartoonist of The Evening Standard, depicted Premier Mussolini of Italy today as a melodramatic villain stepping on the toes of a timid hero, Anthony Eden, Britain's Foreign Secretary.

Mary Nolan, former Follies actress who has been undergoing medical treatments at the Brunswick Home, Amityville, L. I., was taken seriously ill yesterday from an overdose of a sedative. She was rushed to Bellevue Hospital where her condition was reported as serious.

An open invitation was given by the Spanish Embassy today for a mixed delegation of religious elements in this country that have been in controversy over phases of the Spanish civil war to go to Spain and visit both sides in order that "the whole question could be objectively clarified."

The Prosperity Shop at 1,279 Third Avenue, a thrift shop maintrained to raise funds for eight charitable organizations, will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show tomorrow, marking the opening for the season of the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

After three months of bickering between his aunt and Metro-GoldwynMayer Studios, Freddie Bartholomew today got an increase of .$50,000 a year in pay-plus $1 a week spending money. The new contract, presented to Superior Judge Clement L. Shinn for ratification after last week's settlement of differences,

Henry J. Fischer, a resident of Bayside for more than forty-five years during which time he cultivated an extensive farm on West Alley Road, died Sunday night at his home, 45-58 Bell Boulevard, after an illness of one year. His age was 84.

Members of the St. Mark's Ladies Emergency Society will sponsor a bridge party at the McAlpin on Nov. 4. Proceeds from the event will augment the organization's general fund, from which contributions are made to various charitable organizations in emergencies.

Robert (Red) Rolfe, Yankee third baseman who underwent an operation in St. Elizabeth's Hospital after the world series, yesterday was reported making an "uneventful recovery" by Dr. Robert E. Walsh, attending physician.

Brooklyn College started its eighth academic year yesterday with classes meeting for the first time on the new campus and in the college's own building at Avenue H and Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. I Mayor La Guardia, Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll,

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margot Millham, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Tracy Millham of 38 East Fifty-third Street, and the late Mr. Millham, to Douglas Turnbull Hopkins, son of Mrs. Allison Turnbull Hopkins of this city and of John Appleton Havens Hopkins of Washington.

Miss Dolorita Sullivan, daughter of Mrs. Mark Neston Sullivan of this city and the late Mr. Sullivan, was married to John Frederick Tidgewell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. F. Tidgewell of East Haven, in St. John's Roman Catholic Church here today by the Rev. David Hutchinson.

Strenuous objection to the proposed plan of reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad as it affects the Providence Worcester Railroad, and a counter-proposal have been sent to the Interstate Commerce Commission by counsel for the State of Rhode Island, and will be filed formally on Nov. 9, when the New Haven reorganization hearings reopen.

From all reports we've had thus far, the opening days of the New York deer season proved disappointing to many a hunter. Those who returned to the city after three days of hunting had hardly enough venison to grease the pan, but most of them had an alibi that couldn't be beaten--"the woods were too dry."

United States Steel common stock outstanding in brokers' names on Sept. 30 amounted to 2,246,164 shares, or 25.81 per cent of the total, an increase of 41,593 shares from June 30, 1937. Investors held 6,457,088 shares, or 74.19 per cent, against 74.67 per cent on June 30.

Mr. and Mrs. George E. Stringfellow of Montclair, N. J., entertained at dinner last night in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria for Mr. and Mrs. Dan M. Kelly and their daughter, Miss Gay Kelly, of Butte, Mont. Other guests included Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey and Mrs. Hoffman; Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Feist,

Federal Judge Tillman D. Johnson in Utah has permanently enjoined United Prosperity Plan, Inc., Isom Lamb, Meriam Lamb, Con Theuson, Mabel Smith and J. D. Lamb, from selling "prosperity certificates" without registering them under the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Mrs. Olivia Kerrisk Burns, wife of James A. Burns, died yesterday at her home here after a long illness. Her age was 75. She was a Past Regent of Lady Jersey Chapter, Daughters of the British Empire, and a member of the Woman's Club of Orange.
The progress of German aviation, both civil and military, was displayed to Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh today by Air Ministry officials to an extent never before shown to any foreigner.

Found dead of carbon monoxide gas poisoning in a garage in the rear of his home at 464 Park Street here this morning, David E. Lamborn, 20-year-old son of the late Arthur H. Lamborn, senior member of the New York brokerage firm of Lamborn, Hutchings Co., was pronounced a suicide by Dr. George M. Olcott, assistant county medical examiner.

Dr. and Mrs. Oswald R. Jones of New York gave a party in the Pilgrim Room of the Homestead this evening. Henry S. Sutton of Litchfield, Conn., entertained at luncheon in the Colonial Room for Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Walsh, Mrs. Henry G. Mendenhall, Mr. and Mrs. William Campbell and Walter Howett. Mr.

Dr. Warren Hildreth of New York and Southampton, who retired in 1935 after many years as an obstetrician in New York, died at his home here today an hour after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was born in Southampton fifty-three years ago.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The spirit of conquest which sweeps over the world has now reached this relatively peaceful hemisphere to add to, or subtract from, the burdens of the President in the European and Asiatic embroglios.

Ways to rejuvenate the Republican party were discussed today at a meeting of Republican leaders representing Virginia, Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia, with the party's national chairman, John D. M. Hamilton, presiding.

These are the officers elected yesterday for the New York Drama Critics Circle: George Jean Nathan, president; John Mason Brown, vice president; Burns Mantle, treasurer; John Anderson, corresponding secretary; Helen Deutsch, executive secretary.

Stocks broke 2 to 15 points and closed weak in broadest market on record; turnover, 3,227,520 shares. United States Government bonds steady and higher, other issues weakened sharply; transactions, $11,945,650.

From Springfield (Mass.) on Sunday evening Frank Crumit said by telephone that he hadn't decided what to do about his production of "Great Lady." Yesterday, having come to town and surveyed the situation, he announced that he had postponed his musical temporarily "on account of the uncertain stock market situation."

Stanley High, commentator on world affairs, will be a speaker at the annual convention of the Tanners Council of America to be held at the Palmer House, Chicago, on Oct. 28 and 29. Mr. High will make an address on "The Political Horizon" at the luncheon session on Oct. 29.
George J. Beihoff, an insurance broker with offices at 119 Broadway, died yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Alamac, Seventyfirst Street and Broadway, after a year's illness, at the age of 58.

Martin Bates Fisher, dealer in furriers' and hatters' supplies, died on Sunday at his home, 8 South Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 79 years old. Mr. Fisher, who had been associated with the firm of Fisher Thompson, 13 Astor Place, Manhattan, for many years, was born in Cranston, R. I.

Assurance that the Alabama State liquor monopoly will discount its bills in the future has been received by importers and distillers here from their representatives in that State, it was reported yesterday.

President Roosevelt today predicted a net deficit for the current fiscal year of $695,000,000, which is $277,000,000 greater than his prediction in his April budget statement and $732,000,000 more than he forecast in January.
The fashioning of a strong reserve team occupied the Columbia coaches as they sent the football squad through a lengthy but light workout at Baker Field yesterday.

Brig. Gen. P. L. Miles, commanding the First Division, has designated Saturday as Brooklyn Charity Day at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn. A varied program, including a polo game between the First Division and the Squadron C riders, has been arranged for the day.

Nicholas Gouverneur Rutgers, who had been associated with the Le Roy Shot and Lead Company and later was treasurer of the Norfolk and New Brunswick Hosiery, Company, died here yesterday at the age of 86.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. King gave a reception yesterday at their home here, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susannah Mason Kint, to Willoughby F. Richardson Jr.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor's German tour will reach its social nigh point tomorrow when the Duke of Coburg, himself a member of the British royal family, will give a gala dinner in Julius Streicher's home city of Nuremberg. However, that high priest of anti-Semitism will not be present.

A decline of 3 per cent in the gold value of world trade between July and August, 1937, the latest month for which figures are available, is noted in the October number of the League of Nations' monthly statistics bulletin, published today.

The N. Y. U. freshman eleven lost to the Lafayette cubs by 6-0 today in a game arranged for the annual State convention of Kiwanis Clubs. Early in the third period Moyer Maroon halfback, made a twentyfive-yard pass to Howell to provide the game's lone score.

Ellsworth Vines and Frederick J. Perry have started strenuous training 'for their 1937-38 professional tennis tour. Before a sizable gathering at Beverly Hills Tennis Club yesterday Vines defeated Joe Hunt, local amateur star, in one set, 11--9.
Margaret Drennan, 20-year-old Iselin secretarial school student, went on trial for murder here today before a jury of eleven men and one woman in Oyer and Terminer Court.

A meeting of stockholders of Consolidated Funds Corporation has been called for Nov. 2 at Dover, Del., to vote on the dissolution of the corporation. The company has about $200,000 cash which it proposes to use to pay off in liquidation 3,076 preferred shares at $50 and 10,830 shares at $5 a share.

A plea to New Yorkers to use the new political weapon of proportional representation to elect candidates for the City Council endorsed by the Citizens' Non-Partisan Committee and free the lower branch of the city's legislature from the stranglehold of Tammany was issued last night by Thomas D. Thacher, who was chairman of the commission that drafted the new city charter. He spoke from radio station WOR.

An early curtain one night each week in the Broadway theatres was approved unanimously yesterday at a luncheon sponsored by the American Theatre Council at the Hotel Astor and attended by representatives of seventy-three organizations, chiefly women's clubs in Manhattan and the suburbs.

Grove Patterson, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, urged today "a campaign of education through which the average American citizen can be convinced that this freedom of the press, of which he hears so much, is not a meal ticket for editors but life itself for him and this nation."

Great political confusion has been caused by a Supreme Court ruling holding unconstitutional the Presidential decree of March 21, 1936, on which the House of Representatives based its contention that only the coming Constitutent Assembly had a right to fix the term of office of the present Congress.
In a stormy session yesterday the Board of Elections threw out more than 100 petitions designating independent candidates for various offices in the election next month.

As a gesture of reciprocation for the Oxford scholarships for German youths created by the bequest of Cecil Rhodes, an anonymous Hamburg merchant has established four scholarships for British students to German universities, it was announced today.

Sales billed by the General Electric Company in the first nine months of 1937 amounted to $260,773,533, against $189,263,156 in the same period last year, an increase of 38 per cent, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday.

BERMAN, SAMUEL (March 4, 1934). Gross assets. $19,518; net, $16,588. To wife, Sarah Berman (deceased), one-third of residuary estate; daughters, Elaine, Natalie and Roslyn Berman, equal interest in two-thirds of residuary estate. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $1,193; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $621; miscellaneous property, $17,603. N. William Welling, attorney, 233 Broadway, Manhattan.

The quantity of crude rubber imported into Argentina in the first nine months of the current year appears to have been about 13,742,060 pounds, compared with 7,213,470 pounds during the corresponding period of 1936, according to an estimate based on a compilation of cargoes of incoming shipments made by Joe D. Walstrom, assistant trade commissioner at Buenos Aires, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The text of President Roosevelt's statement in summation of the 1938 budget was as follows: The attached summation presents revised estimates of receipts and expenditures for the fiscal year 1938, reflecting the changes which have occurred in the budget subsequent to the revision of estimates contained in my message of April 20, 1937.

Mrs. William H. Talbott, a founder of the Institute of American Genealogy and for several years vice president general of the National Daughters of the American Revolution, died yesterday at her home in Rockville, Md., at the age of 73. She and her husband recently celebrated their fifty-second wedding anniversary.

Dr. Bailey Townshend, 42 years old, for the last seven years manager of the research laboratories at the Manville, (N. J.) factory of the Johns-Manville Corporation, was found dead of poisoning by illuminating gas here today in the kitchen of his home, 721 Division Street.

All of the fears and most of the hopes that were entertained regarding the outcome of the communal elections that were held during the past two Sundays were fairly completely dissipated by the final results announced last night and this morning.

The Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Passaic, was elected moderator of the Synod of New Jersey, the Presbyterian Church in the United States, at the opening session of the Synod's 115th annual meeting here today.
Cotton futures opened steady to higher on the Cotton Exchange yesterday but slipped off about $1 a bale as the stock market weakened and closed with losses of 2 to 10 points.

Two men were killed here this afternoon when a scaffolding from which they were painting a water tower broke, hurling both to the ground more than 170 feet below. The victims were identified as John Battalio, 36 years old, and George Zamptos, 40, both of Philadelphia.

Chairmanship of the professional section of the United Hospital Campaign has been accepted by Arthur A. Ballantine, an attorney and former Under-Secretary of the United States Treasury. Mr. Ballantine will organize sixteen committees to solicit contributions among professional men and women for the ninety-two member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund and Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn.

Gaining momentum as the day progressed, the decline yesterday in bond prices was the broadest in more than three years. Domestic corporation issues crumbled under the steady pressure of selling, the worst declines being shown among the secondary and convertible bonds.

A summons against Mrs. Sarah B. Huling of the Margaret Mask Chapter of the Colonial Dames of the Seventeenth Century was withdrawn yesterday before Magistrate William A. Farrell in Yorkville Court when attorneys for Mrs. Huling and Mrs. John F. McDougall of the national executive board of the organization explained that their dispute had been settled.

Bagging eight birdies and beating par by five strokes, a pair of amateurs from Lakeville led home a field of forty-one teams in the Long Island Golf Association's final amateur-pro tournament of the season at the Brookville Country Club today.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Edwin B. Wolchok and George G. Tyler of New York were admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had: The Chief Justice announced the following orders of the court:

The motives and objectives of the Workers Alliance were defended yesterday by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts in the La Guardia administration. Speaking in place of the Mayor at a meeting of the Theta Club, an organization of Protestant clergymen, Mr. Blanshard said that the alliance's manners were often "bad" but that its moral aim was "fundamentally good."

Affidavits made by 100 officials of as many trade unions requesting that Jeremiah T. Mahoney and his running mates be denied the right to run as candidates of the "Trades Union party" were submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins.
The Carolina, Clinchfield Ohio Railway Company, which leases its lines jointly to the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company and the Louisville Nashville Railroad Company,

A method of predicting sales volume for a year in advance within a limit of 10 per cent variation was described yesterday by Edmond S. La Rose, assistant controller of the Bausch Lomb Optical Company, at a meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants held in conjunction with the fiftieth anniversary convention of the American Institute of Accountants in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The American Smelting and Refining Company reduced yesterday the price of lead 1/4 cent a pound to 5.50 cents at New York. The St. Joseph Lead Company made a similar reduction at St. Louis to 5.35 cents a pound.

Concentrations and reinforcements of Insurgent troops are mentioned in all dispatches from the Aragon front in Northeastern Spain today, Moreover, there is known to be a considerable number of Italian troops in the neighborhood of Huesca.

Despite Saturday's setbacks of the unbeaten, no less than fifty-three college football teams remain undefeated and untied, according to The Associated Press. The teams represent large, small and medium-sized institutions in all parts of the nation.

Army's football team did not come out for practice today. Coach Gar Davidson prescribed a day of rest despite the fact that there are no severe casualties as a result of the Yale game. But the bruising effects of three hard games in succession are evident.

A move to extend the city's anti-syphilis campaign to vice resorts brought threats of death today to Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, president of the Board of Health. He disclosed that he had received a letter this morning which warned:
Apartments in the Fifty-seventh Street neighborhood and along Park Avenue, were involved in many of the multi-family residential rentals reported by brokers yesterday. The list follows:

Despite six unsuccessful flights over the Arctic in search of the six Russian polar fliers missing since Aug. 13 last, Sir Hubert Wilkins will leave this week-end for another series of attempts to find them, it was learned yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia, in fighting form, charged last night that when Tammany talks of restoring "law?? and order" to the city it means the bringing back of the thugs and racketeers whom he has driven out. He charged that Leo Byk, recently identified as a slot-machine man, was closely associated with the political leaders backing Jeremiah T. Mahoney.

The two Democratic members of the four-man bi-partisan Board of Elections refused permission yesterday to Aaron Benenson, chairman of the law committee investigating illegal registrations for Thomas E. Dewey, Republican,

The "return of prosperity" means that the Federal Government will "more and more narrow the circle of its relief activities and reduce the amount of Federal revenue to be expended in the amelioration of human want and distress in the various communities of our land," President Roosevelt said tonight.

Paul Dwyer, 18, accused of killing an elderly couple and taking their bodies on an aimless drive through several North Atlantic States, was arraigned today, pleaded innocent and was held without bail for the grand jury.

Al Lane, sophomore right guard who started for Princeton against Chicago on Saturday, will be out of football for the rest of the campaign with a fracture of the left wrist, suffered in that contest, it was revealed today by Dr. Harry R. McFee, team physician. This is the first major casualty of the season for the Tiger squad.

Yale today began preparations for the Cornell game Saturday in the Bowl. Every regular reported and the team had a signal drill in which moves designed to take advantage of Cornell's most vulnerable points were made.

Harry E. Thompson, 62 years old, of 62 Walker Boulevard, West Orange, N. J., who has a securities office at 25 Broadway, was arrested yesterday in the office of the Attorney General on a bench warrant charging grand larceny and keeping, operating and conducting a bucket shop.

A buyer for two defendant oil companies testified in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case today that he discussed with representatives of eight other major companies in St. Louis on March 5, 1935, a plan to buy gasoline from certain small refineries.

With a warning that the re-election of Mayor La. Guardia would be taken by Left Wing labor leaders as an endorsement of "Red terrorism," R. Caldwell Patton, chairman of the Republican Committee for Safety in Manhattan, yesterday urged Republicans to vote for Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor.

A series of four lectures will be held at the Plaza on Thursday mornings, beginning Oct. 28, for the benefit of Auxiliary No. 6 and the Social Service Auxiliary of Stony Wold Sanatorium. The other three will take place on Nov. 4, 11 and 18. Dr. William Starr Myers, Professor of Politics at Princeton University, will speak.

For almost half a century Dr. Albert Shaw has been reviewing month after month the gathered news of the world in his column of editorial comment and interpretation. Of more than forty volumes he has written a considerable part.
Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary from a three months' visit to Russia.
Dissatisfied with the work of some of his veterans last Saturday, Head Coach Harvey Harman predicted a general shake-up in the Pennsylvania football squad today.

Attired in a sweat shirt, football trousers without their pads and his inevitable baseball cap, Dr. Marvin A. Stevens, head coach of New York University's football forces, moved about Ohio Field yesterday to supervise the start of another week's work for the Violet.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 21,000 including 5,000 directs. Good and choice hogs 170 pounds were down and scarce; 10-15 cents lower than Friday; heavier weights and sows, 25-35 cents off:

The usual downward trend of commercial and industrial failures was reversed for the week ended Oct. 14, when the total was 174, compared with 146 in the preceding week and 139 in the corresponding 1936 week, according to the report issued by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., yesterday.
The Syracuse football squad was excused from work today for its fine victory over the favored Cornell team. Preparations for the Maryland game at Baltimore on Saturday will get under way tomorrow.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 13: An increase of $40,000,000 in commercial,

The Department of Commerce will begin tomorrow afternoon a new series of radio broadcasts in which once each week some leading American business man will "discuss some topic of timely interest pertaining to current economic and social problems."
The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported an increase of almost $40,000,000 in exports to the

The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it was assuming regulation of the entire radio spectrum, including frequencies from 10 to 300,000 kilocycles. This decision means that the government has undertaken to regulate ten times the amount of radio space it, hitherto controlled.
At the Comedy Theatre last evening Miss Mary MacArthur Noble presented, for the first time in America, a play in three acts, "Wall Street Scene," by John Lawrence.

Jerome Ave (12-3327a). n e cor of 208th St, 100x100: Rachel F. Fink to New York Life Insurance Co; extends mtg to Oct 15, 1947. at 4 per cent; $53,000. Fulton Ave. 1,739-41 (11-2930), Fulton Crotona Corp to Caroline Bussing, 205 E Lincoln Ave. Mount Vernon, N. Y.: extends mtg to Oct 1, 1942, at 4 3/4-5 per cent; $110.000.

Although he is a veteran of many hard-fought ring battles, Bobby Pacho of California still possesses enough ability to show some of the up-and-coming boxers a few tricks. Pacho demonstrated this last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, where, before a crowd of 3,500 fans, he carried off the decision over Frankie Cavanna, East Side youngster, in the feature bout of eight rounds.

Miss Elenore Montague, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Everett Montague of Riverside, Greenwich, has completed plans for her marriage to Robert Vincent Harry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Guy Harry of Brooklyn, which will take place on Nov. -6- in the Second Congregational Church here. The Rev. Daniel Bliss, the pastor, will officiate.

Richard A. Brennan, executive vice president of the Brevoort Savings Bank of Brooklyn, has been elected a trustee of the bank. The Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company has announced the appointment of George P. Shoemaker as general agent in New York City with offices at 70 Pine Street. He succeeds Edmund H.

Colonel Henry B. Fairbanks was elected president of the New York chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution at the annual meeting of the chapter at the Hotel Plaza last night, succeeding Frederick H. Cone. Colonel Fairbanks is Past

BARKHORN--At Newark, N. J., on Sunday, Oct. 17, 1937, Clara Webner, widow of Charles H. Barkhorn. Funeral service at her home, 223 Fairmount Ave. Newark, on Wednesday, Oct. 20. at 2:30 P. M. BEIHOFF-George J., husband of Lillian, father of Robert. Funeral strictly private.

Charles Fitch. a retired business man, who was associated for many years with Julius Kayser Co., manufacturers of apparel, jumped or fell to his death, according to the police, at 5:45 o'clock last evening from the bathroom window of his tenth floor apartment at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street. He was 70 years old.

The Federal Power Commission ordered today an investigation to determine the extent to which public utilities under its jurisdiction have been ordered or directed by affiliated companies having or purporting to have control,

For its third successive scoreless tie against powerful Pittsburgh, the Fordham football squad was rewarded yesterday with a short workout confined to calisthenics. After Glen Carberry, assistant coach, had put the Rams through their exercises, Head Coach Jim Crowley sent them indoors.

Schimmer, Kerner Feder were the brokers in the recent sale of the property at 221 West 141st Street. Ten loans totaling $38,200 have been placed by J. Halperin Co. for the Benreiz Investing Corporation on houses being erected on Little Neck Parkway, north of Eighty-third Road, Bellerose, L. I., and on 112th Street, north of 150th Avenue. Richmond Hill.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. report consolidated net earnings of $62,799,523 for the first nine months of 1937, including $22,002,195 received from its investment in common stock of the General Motors Corporation, equal after provision for dividends on the debenture and preferred stocks to $5.33 a share on the common stock, compared to $5.31 a share earned in the same period of 1936.

Four ship lines operating in the coastwise trade announced yesterday that they would withdraw their tonnage pending settlement of a strike of longshoremen and dock workers in Southern ports. Resumption of operations, they said, was dependent upon settlement -of the demands of the workers for higher wages and other conditions.

Samuel (Cappy) Hoffman of Atlantic City was committed to the Mercer County jail today in default of $10,000 bail after his surrender to the Federal authorities here on a charge of violating the Mann Act by conspiring to transport women from New York and Philadelphia for immoral purposes.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 17 unless specified: At Norfolk Yard, Oct. 16: Arkansas, Wyoming. At Shanghai: Chaumont, Edsall. At Pearl Harbor, Oct. 16: Langley, Pelican. Alden at Chinwangtao. Asheville, at Amoy, Oct. 18.

Roland L. Cummins, 50 years old, of 28 Samban Boulevard, Trenton, is believed to have been burned to death this afternoon in a fire that destroyed his six-room Summer cottage at Browns Mills. Mr. Cummins was president of a life insurance company in Trenton that bears his name.
A-penthouse of eleven rooms and four baths in 720 Park Avenue has been leased by Charles U. Bay through Brown, Weelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and Douglas L. Elliman Co.
Walter M. Jeffords's Regal Lily turned in her fourth victory in seven starts this year and qualified for Saturday's Maryland Handicap by winning the Crisfield Purse before 8,000 today.

Terrorism, shooting, sniping, murder and banditry again are reigning throughout Palestine. Arabs in the towns and villages are being told by agitators that they should not fear the British because the latter are themselves afraid of that "great man" Mussolini.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had authorized the holding of a trade-practice conference for all bra ?? of the fur industry. The conference will be held in New York on a date to be announced later.

Premier John Metaxas of Greece, who arrived this afternoon on the Greek cruiser Averoff, escorted by two Turkish destroyers, left by train for Angora tonight to return the visit of Premier Ismet Inonu and Foreign Minister Tewfik Aras a few months ago.

Captain Albert Stevens set a world altitude record of 72,183 feet in his 1935 stratosphere flight, according to official calculations by Prof. Earl Church just completed at the College of Applied Science, Syracuse University, Prof. Church announced today.

Horton Smith and Harry Cooper of Chicago won the first annual Oklahoma City $5,000 four-ball golf tournament today by defeating Ralph Guldahl, national open champion from Chicago, and Billy Burke of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., 3 up. They posted a final score of plus 12.

On Oct. 26 Scribners will publish Gilbert Seldes's new survey of the motion picture industry, "The Movies Come From America." There is a preface by Charlie Chaplin and a frontispiece in color by Walt Disney. Mr. Seldes is now director of television for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Increased duties on Czechoslovakian shoes, instead of tariff concessions through a reciprocal trade treaty, were called for yesterday by the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association through Jay O. Ball, president of the organization, in the first public statement the association has issued on the question.

Trial of Laverne (John Montague) Moore on a seven-year-old indictment charging first-degree robbery will start here tomorrow morning. In contrast with Moore's return from Hollywood under escort of State troopers last August, when Summer visitors flocked about for a peek at "the Paul Bunyan of the bunkers," the town's one street was deserted tonight.

Awards of $12,398,738 were made to owners of 6,767 condemned parcels of land in Kings, Queens and Richmond counties in the year ended on Sept. 25, according to a report made public yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn.

A vigorous protest of Florida oil investment men against threatened seizure of their private telegrams by the Securities and Exchange Commission was rejected today by the Supreme Court, and to every outward appearance Justice Black joined other members of the bench in making the decision.

Acting Governor James Jarrett convened the Legislature today and announced that as a consequence of tourist trade and building activities the year's revenue had reached [pound]417,159, exceeding the estimate by [pound]93,034.
The right of Haile Selassie still to call himself Emperor of Ethiopia was brought up in Chancery Court today when the Negus sued Cable and Wireless for $50,000.

Hitting at "manifestations of a world-wide distemper," the House of Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church, at the general convention here today, called attention to the "undeclared war" in the Orient in which, it said, international law was nullified while the great powers stood helplessly by.

Andrew Ponzi captured the first two engagements as his six-block exhibition pocket billiard match with Joe Procita began at the Strand Academy yesterday. Ponzi took the afternoon block by 125 to 72 in fourteen innings and annexed the night test by 125 to 91 in nine frames.

Norman H. Davis received his instructions today as delegate of the United States to the Brussels conference on the Far Eastern crisis, held a final conference with Secretary of State Cordell Hull, and left for New York with plans for conferring with President Roosevelt at Hyde Park tomorrow. He and his assistants will sail Wednesday on the liner Washington.

Frederick L. Smith, secretary of Peck Peck, women's apparel merchants in New York, and an official of six affiliated concerns, died here today at his home. He was 83 years old and had been ill one week. He was with Peck Peck twentyeight years.

Medals for bravery were awarded yesterday to three members of the crew of the United States Coast Guard cutter Pontchartrain for the rescue of a companion in the Hudson River during the intercollegiate regatta at Poughkeepsie June 22.

Since about the middle of 1914 the old theory that civilization is enervating has had little evidence to support it. In fact, it might be argued, on the basis of twenty-three years of history, that the simple-minded savage, who rarely killed except for food, or in order to complete the frieze of heads or scalps without which no home was considered in good taste, was a mollycoddle compared with modern man.

Coach Wilder Tasker sent his Rutgers football forces through a long drill today in preparation for the Princeton game. The backs spent all their time perfecting new plays to be used against the Tiger, while the linemen practiced on the tackling dummy before holding a dummy scrimmage.

One hundred and fifty members of the International Longshoremen's Association walked off the French Line pier at West Fortyeighth Street and the North River yesterday afternoon in a strike over the arrest of two of their number on charges of disorderly conduct.

District Attorney John R. Vunk announced today the appointment of three assistants to succeed those who served under L. Barron Hill, his predecessor. Frank J. McMann, former village counsel of Greenport, becomes a first assistant. Second assistant is George H. Ward of Centerport, former assistant corporation counsel of New York City, and the third assistant is Harry A.
President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell have left their country place in Freeport, L. I., and are at 270 Park Avenue for the Winter.

Reversing the policy tested a week ago of keeping the varsity backs out of scrimmage, Coach Tuss McLaughry today announced a week of contact work for all available Brown football players in preparation for Columbia.

Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme of Bronxville, Democratic candidate for a full term on the Supreme Court bench, expressed dismay today when informed that his campaign manager, Frank A. Saporito, a Mount Vernon attorney, had been speaking at public meetings in Support of Frank H. Coyne of Yonkers, Republican candidate for Westchester County judge.

Ken Overlin, Richmond, Va., middleweight, technically knocked out Tiger Roy Williams of Chicago in 1:26 of the fourth round at the Westchester County Center tonight. Overlin weighed 162.4 pounds and Williams 169.
Objects old and quaint, ranging from Louis XIV lace to American butter molds, attracted lovers of antiques yesterday afternoon as the ninth New York Antiques Exposition was opened in Hotel Commodore.

One of the tightest finishes this season marked the opening of the Fall meeting at Empire City yesterday when Crossbow II gained a nose decision over Little Miracle in ithe $4,325 New Rochelle Handicap that featured the six-race program.

Mrs. Edward Everett Hughes of Llewellyn Park, widow of Thomas A. Edison, and prominent officials of the Edison industries attended the funeral service today for William Henry Meadowcroft, former confidenial secretary of the famous inventor, who died at his home here Friday in his eighty-fifth year.
There is nothing new in the statement that the President is bent on striking a "layman's balance" of the budget in 1938. He has said this repeatedly for over a year.
An Amerlean woman who has been a Chinese citizen for ten years and the wife of a Chinese is playing a leading role in Chinese war relief in Shanghai.

The Natonal Collegiate Athletic Association, seeking a show-down on an old controversy with the Amateur Athletic Union, petitioned today for adoption of an amendment giving , colleges control of American Olymple teams in four sports-track, crew racing, swimming and wrestling.

The third United States Camera Salon, comprising about 800 photographs by professional and amateur photographers in many parts of the country, opened with a preview last night on the mezzanine floor of the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue.

Any thought he mih nave entertained of promoting a heavyweight battle for Tommy Farr, Great Britain's champion, in London this year or next, was abandoned by Promoter Mike Jacobs yesterday following a conference with Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley, English promoter.
A citizens' committee for continuation of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad was formed here tonight at a meeting of 160 commuters at the Larchmont Tennis Club.

The Japanese publication Newspaper News charged today that the work of foreign correspondents "borders on open espionage." It declared that military authorities may invoke the military secrets protection law, "subjecting violators to rigorous punishment."

Residential properties of various types figured in the real estate transactions reported from scattered sections of the city yesterday. The six-story elevator apartment house at 2,194 Barnes Avenue, on the southeast corner of Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, was purchased by Isadore Tankus in association with Samuel Friedman from the Bronx Trustees.

Following the record - breaking travel during the Summer, transportation companies and travel agencies are launching intensive campaigns to prevent the expected slump in their business which has been predicted would follow the stock market decline, reports yesterday indicated.

Among today's major events will be the first local appearance this season of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall and recitals by Gertrude Borzi and Thelma Spear at the Town Hall, Miss Borzi is to appear in the afternoon and Miss Spear in the evening.

Two newsreel men, passengers on the United Air Lines transcontinental transport plane which crashed southwest of Evanston, Wyo., were heading to the West Coast to complete the work they had begun on a film showing "The Safety of Transcontinental Flying," it was learned yesterday.

While underwriters are perforce marking time in the face of deeply unsettled conditions in the securities markets, the large commercial banks are witnessing an increasing flow of requests for accommodation by large organizations in process of increasing plant.
Several thousand persons, many of them women shoppers, yesterday afternoon saw a crash in which two firemen were injured and a third badly shaken up at Sixth Avenue and Thirty-third Street.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st grade Joseph A. McNamara, of Engine 239, died Oct. 17, in the discharge of duty, from smoke narcosis, while operating at fire at 311 8th St., Brooklyn. Funeral will take place from the late residence of the deceased, 115-96 225th St., St. Albans, Queens, at 10:30 A. M.. on Wednesday, Oct. 20. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery, Borough of Brooklyn.

Richard Tauber, operatic and concert tenor arrived yesterday on the Queen Mary to sing in this country for the first time in six years. The German artist will give his first recital over the radio on the General Motors program at Chicago and then return to New York to give two concerts at Town Hall on Oct. 26 and 30.
Accompanied by William Fellewes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, Mayor La Guardia made an inspection tour yesterday morning of the Bronx Terminal Market, Exterior and 151st Street.

The Belgian Government's exhibit at the World's Fair will be an impressive diamond show and a colonial exhibit from the Belgian Congo, it was disclosed yesterday at a luncheon to Dr. Joseph Gevaert, Belgian Commissioner General to the Fair, in the Administration Building at Flushing Meadow Park.

Twenty-eight former employes of the Narragansett Race Track who are without work because of Governor Quinn's closing order, picketed the State House entrance this afternoon with signs blaming the Governor for their plight.

The Augsburg of the North German Lloyd Line arrived yesterday at the New York Free Port, Stapleton, S. I., with the largest cargo received at that port since it opened in January. The cargo, reconsigned to other countries, would have been taxed $227,000 if distributed in the United States.
J. A. Flores da Cunha, Governor of Rio Grande do Sul, whose political ascendency dated from the 1930 Vargas revolution, resigned last night with his entire Secretariat.

A General Sessions jury, including three women, one of them the foreman, heard testimony yesterday in the first-degree murder trial of Mrs. Rose Marie Dann, 39, in the shooting of her 56-year-old husband, Hans, a lighter captain, in their home at 42 La Salle Street on March 31.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas for September were higher than for any like monttr since 1929 and showed an advance of almost 32 per cent from August to September, or about twice the usual seasonal amount, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today.

Despite the hopes expressed on all sides, there is little real confidence here tonight that the Non-Intervention Committee will get to grips with the problem of foreign combatants in Spain when it resumes its discussions tomorrow.

Miss Dorothy Ruth Chastain, 16-year-old infantile paralysis victim, came home today in an army freight plane put at her disposal by President Roosevelt. The plane was fitted with' an "iron lung" for the trip from Tulsa, Okla., where she had been in a hospital for five weeks.

Mrs. William Penn Cresson entertained at Chesterwood, Stockbridge, this afternoon in compliment to Mrs. Frederick B. Robins and son, Charles Reed of Glen Head, L. I., who are occupying for a month Mrs. Cresson's cottage, the Dormouse.

A report submitted today to the national convention of Exchange Clubs by its committee on citizenship charged that the Committee for Industrial Organization was formed as a "political machine" to gain control of the government.

Ignoring appeals from certain labor leaders to remain neutral in the Mayoralty campaign, Robert F. Wagner, United States Senator who has been a New Deal leader in Congress, appeared at Cooper Union last night and urged 1,700 members of an audience at a labor rally to complete the job that has been done in the State and nation by giving New York City a Democratic administration at City Hall.
Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday that an election of approximately 400 employes of the Book of the Month Club, Inc.,
The American Medical Association warned today of a drug preparation which, the association said, apparently caused nine deaths in Tulsa, Okla., and which had been widely distributed elsewhere.

Fairly numerous fill-in orders continued to appear in the local merchandise markets yesterday, along with reports that retail trade in most sections of the country held up well last week, according to manufacturers and resident buyers. Cooler weather was given as the stimulus to trade.

Slicing three strokes from par on the incoming nine after going out in 34, one under perfect figures, the Branch Brook pro-amateur pair of Maurie O'Connor and Mike Cestone captured the New Jersey P. G. A. event at Twin Brooks today with a 67. Nineteen teams played.

Chinese authorities said today that a "death battalion" of 1,400 Chinese troops and more than 3,000 Japanese attackers had been killed in a battle in front of Tachang, about five miles northwest of Shanghai.

Nearly 10,000 men and women obtained application blanks yesterday at the State Building, Centre and Worth Streets, for State Civil Service examinations for the positions of junior, assistant and senior clerks.

On police surgeon's certificate: PATROLMAN-William B. O'Connor, 69th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 10, 1915. PATROLMEN-Thomas F. McGivney, 64th Precinct, at $1,260 per annum. Appointed Jan. 10, 1921. Charles J. McGee, 79th Precinct, at $840 per annum. Appointed Sept. 20, 1926.

The Brooklyn College football team enjoyed a day of rest yesterday after the victory over Wagner College. The Kingsmen will begin heavy workouts today for the game with Lowell Textile Saturday at the new Brooklyn College athletic field and will endeavor to score their first home victory before the vast student following which organized with the official opening of the new school yesterday.

Transactions on the New York Curb Exchange amounted yesterday to 799,000 shares, the heaviest since Feb. 25, when 994,625 changed hands. Memphis Commercial Appeal Company fifteen-year 4 1/2 per cent sinking-fund debentures due in 1952 have been admitted to listing by the Curb Exchange.

In the German press, whose every paragraph is inspired and coordinated by official authority, Czechoslovakia suddenly leaped into the limelight today, overshadowing editorial speculation on the negotiations over Spain in London.

E. H. Lever of the Prudential Assurance Company of London, England, announced upon his arrival from abroad yesterday that the purpose of his visit was "financing the purchase of the United Artists Film Corporation by Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda."

Thirty-eighth annual meeting, New York State Conference on Social Work, opens at the Hotel Pennsylvania at 9 A. M. and continues to Friday. Child Study Association, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, 11 A. M. "Women in Modern Books," Clifton Fadiman.
Mrs. Carolyn Snowden Andrews Fahnestock, widow of Gibson Fahnestock, New York and Washington financier, died suddenly today, after a brief illness, at the Sulgrave Club. She was 75 years old.

Miss L. Verdilla Strader, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Strader of this place, was married this evening at the home of her parents, to Reginald James Walrath, son of Dr. and Mrs. Otto J. Walrath of Bloomfield. A reception followed the ceremony.
A native searching party today reached Brig. Gen. A. C. Lewin and Mrs. Lewin, stranded in a swamp since their plane made a forced landing nine days ago while en route from England to Kenya.

Automobile production continued to rise last week in preparation for the show but the gain was less than computed for seasonally. The index receded from 157.1 from 159.3 in the previous week and compared with 97.2 for the week ended Oct. 17, 1936.

Whoever carried to the home of Dr. George W. Webster a bundle of laundry found in the vestibule there on the morning of July 16 is the person who murdered the physician, Coroner Conrad K. Strauss stated today in his inquest report.

Turpentine firm, 27 1/4c; sales, 129 barrels; receipts, 245 barrels; shipments, 5 barrels; stock, 37,036 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 589; receipts. 1.216; shipments 155; stock. 80,926. Quote: B to N. $7.50; WG, $7.67 1/2; WW, x. $8.20.

With a placard on a vacant seat proclaiming that "this seat is reserved for Mr. Jeremiah T. Mahoney," a double-deck bus rolled away from City Hall plaza yesterday morning, carrying fifty-five New York clubwomen on a "Know Your New York Tour," arranged by Robert K. Straus in connection with his race for City Council and Mayor La Guardia's campaign for re-election.

Dr. H. H. Kung, Chinese Finance Minister, returned to Shanghai today after an absence of five months to find China's principal' seaport and largest city blockaded and half ruined. Dr. Kung attended the coronation of King.George last May.

Nineteen persons probably died when the United Air Lines palatial "Mainliner" shot into a peak high in the Uinta Mountains, air searchers said tonight. "I don't see how any one could be alive there," said Wesley Meyers, Western Wyoming rancher, after a flight over the wreckage of the airliner which carried fifteen men and four women.

Bottjer, Wesleyan first-string center, hurt in the Haverford game, will be on the sidelines for several days and Coach Jack Blott will use Marter or McCabe at the post. Horne, halfback; Alibrio, guard, and Green, end, are others on the injured list.

The American freighter Cold Harbor tonight was beached off Deer Island to prevent her from foundering after she had struck a sunken object in the outer harbor. The inwash of water extinguished the steamer's fires as the vessel neared the end of a seven-mile run back to the inner harbor.

From a high point reached in midsummer, THE TIMES index of, business activity has now run jaggedly downhill for eight consecutive weeks. Some observers find in this performance the beginning of a new depression.
Harry C. Mealey has been appointed Western regional manager of household appliances for Kelvinator division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, Ralph C. Cameron, sales manager, announced yesterday.

The arrival of $878,000 in gold from India was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. No new engagements of gold abroad were reported and the price of gold in London continued above the New York shipping parity.

Coach Bernie Berman gave a chalk talk today to the thirty-six Minnesota players who trounced Michigan on Saturday. The Gopher head coach said, however, the squad would return to serious practice tomorrow, even with the Notre Dame game almost two weeks away.

The passenger list of the Holland America liner Statendam, sailing today for Rotterdam via Plymouth and Bologne, includes: Kenneth Stuart Patton, Consul General at Amsterdam, and Mrs. Patton; James G. Carter, Consul at Calais, and Mrs. Carter;
Now it is Alfred M. Landon who goes in for unilateral exchange of ideas. He has called for tonight a nation-wide radio "mass meeting" in which he proposes to discuss certain questions of the day.

John J. Carroll of 471 Grand Street, for the last twelve years secretary to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, died Saturday at the age of 81 after a week's illness. A life-long resident of the lower East Side, where he became an intimate friend of Alfred E. Smith, he saw much of the former Governor in Florida last Winter.
Home Office experts tomorrow will try gas masks on fifty orphans in one of the Dr. Barnado homes at Hawkhurst, Kent, to determine the minimum age at which a child can bear the strain of a respirator.

The Federal Theatre Project's own subway circuit, opening Nov. 2, will find "No More Peace" at Hunt's Point Palace, the Bronx; "The Singing and the Gold," by Howard Koch, at the Community Gardens, Queens; "Patience," at the Brownsville Labor Lyceum, Brooklyn,

Sir Alfred Butt's Near Relation retained first place in the betting at 100 to 9 today in the latest callover on the Cesarewitch, to be run at Newmarket Oct. 27. Other odds were: Epigram, 13 to 1; Harewood, 100 to 7; Polar Bear, 15 to 1; Punch, 100 to 6;

An example of how one section of a prospectus filed under the Securities Act of 1933, dealing with provisions as to the release and substitution of property securing an issue of bonds, could have been boiled down

If the older generation is going to help solve the problems of youth it must first face its own shortcomings and then deal honestly with youth, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday in an address before 1,200 members of the Women's League for Palestine.
William Toby Snyder, for more than fifty years custodian at the New York University College of Medicine, died on Sunday morning in Bellevue Hospital after a long illness at the age of 77.

The marriage of Miss Mary Sampson Flanders, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Chapin Flanders of this city and Cooperstown, N. Y., to Oscar Edward Boline, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Boline of Lindsborg, Kan., will take place on Saturday at noon in the chantry of Grace Church.

Replacement sales of rubber tires by independent dealers have dropped from 98 per cent of the total volume in 1925 to 54 per cent at present, W. W. Leigh, professor in the College of Engineering and Commerce at the University of Akron, told dealers from thirty-eight States today at the opening of the convention of the National Association of Independent Tire Dealers, Inc.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company and Barr Brothers Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,000,000 of metropolitan water bonds of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts on their bid of 100.275 for 2 1/4s.

Sweeping and fundamental weakening of anti-trust laws has resulted directly from resale price fixing laws, Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., declared at a dinner of the Sales Managers Association of Philadelphia at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel here tonight.

An appeal to retail merchants to cooperate with consumers in their demands for fairness, accuracy and honesty in merchandising and advertising was made here today by H. W. Brightman, president of the National Consumer-Retailers Relations Council and vice president of L. Bamberger Co. of Newark, N. J.
The play, "The Fight's On," by Hagar Wilde, Ernest V. Heyn and Elliott Nugent, now running in London, has been purchased by Paramount as a possible vehicle for Irene Dunne.

The Informazione Diplomatica, a recently created agency edited by the Foreign Office, issued today a scathing denunciation of the "shameless manoeuvres" said to be going on in Paris and London to create a "war psychosis" by spreading "absolutely fantastic figures" on Italian volunteers in Spain.

Automobile accident fatalities declined sharply in the city last week, as compared with the corresponding period of last year, for the third successive time in October, it was announced yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.

Sprinkling on the high altar Gregorian water which contains salt as a symbol of incorruptibility, ashes as a symbol of penitence and wine as a symbol of generosity, Cardinal Archbishop Suhard of Reims today consecrated the Cathedral and reopened it after twenty-three years for public worship.

Another "call" for repayment of deposits held in commercial banks, the fourth in ten days, was issued yesterday by the United States Treasury. The latest notice called for the repayment by depositary institutions in this Federal Reserve district of $9,402,800 on Thursday and a like amount on Friday.
President Manuel Quezon, addressing the opening session of the National Assembly today, strongly reiterated his recommendation for Philippine independence in 1939.

A number of tenement properties in Hudson County changed hands in New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday. The two four-story tenements at 210-212 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City N. J., have been purchased by the Realty Investment Corporation. George Richards was the seller. The buildings are on a plot of 50 by 103 and contain sixteen apartments.

Formal inquiry into the sinking' of fishing .junks by a Japanese submarine on Sept, 22 was opened today with the Chief Justice presiding. The Japanese Consul was notified, but he declined to attend or to be represented.

Mrs. Beatrice M. Bergersen of Glenwood Landing, daughter of Mrs. George Baldwin of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Baldwin, was married to the Rev. Harry Lee Rice, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church of this place, this morning in the church.

William Alexander Winston; 39year-old member of the law firm of LeBoeuf, Winston, Machold Lamb, 15 Broad Street, committed suicide at his apartment in Sutton Manor, 411 East Fifty-third Street, some time between Sunday noon and yesterday morning at 7, accordine to the police.

Gross operating revenues of Philadelphia Company and subsidiaries, not including the Beaver Valley Traction Company (in receivership) and its subsidiary, for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, 1937, amounted to $55,522,294, compared with $50,176,882 for the year ended Aug. 31, 1936.

For the first time this season Coach Bob Higgins gave his Penn State players a complete rest today, calling off all practice until tomorrow when preparation will get under way for the Syracuse game Oct. 30. Penn State has an open date Saturday.

A new set of leaders was at the head of the nation's individual football scoring parade yesterday, but the Eastern pace-setters still showed the way to all other sections, according to the Associated Press.

About 1,000 American and other foreign residents of Shanghai who fled the city at the outbreak of hostilities between China and Japan returned today to face the showers of shrapnel and bullets that make the foreign areas as dangerous as when they left.

President Roosevelt today appointed Nathan Straus of New York to be administrator of the United States Housing Authority and as such to direct the government's long-range $526,000,000 program for slum clearance and lowcost housing.

Wallie Davids, sophomore back from Pleasantville, N. Y., rejoined the Colgate squad today after being out with an injury since the Cornell game and he may be in shape to be used against Duke Saturday in the alumni and Fathers' Day game.
A questionnaire seeking detailed information on hours, wage payments, number of employes under 16 years old, 16 to 18 and over 18, and data on seasonal schedules was sent to 3,500 industrial

Wheat prices declined 2 to 3 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today on selling induced by weakness in Liverpool, generous rains over part of the dry territory in the Winter wheat belt, and more favorable crop reports from the Southern Hemisphere.

Mrs. Helen Tracy Hudnut of Northampton, Mass., widow of Dr. Paul A. Hudnut, was married to her brother-in-law, the Rev. Dr. William H. Hudnut, yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Chapin of 563 Park Avenue.

The New York Giants and the Green Bay Packers are well on the way to establishing new offensive and defensive marks, statistics released yesterday reveal. The Packers, in addition to leading the scorers with 104 points, have smashed their way to a total gain of 1,459 yards in five engagements for an average of 291 per game.

While Republican and American Labor party leaders were going into court in an effort to have the Trades Union party, recently organized to support Jeremiah T. Mahoney, ruled off the ballot on the ground that its title was misleading and an attempt to deceive

Plans for a small apartment house in upper Manhattan, estimated to cost $100,000, and for alterations to many tenement buildings, were filed yesterday. No projects costing more than $2,000 were reported to have been submitted in Queens and the Bronx.

The American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday that operations of the steel industry in the United States were 55.8 per cent of capacity this week, a decline of 7.8 points, or 12.3 per cent, compared to last week, when the rate was 63.6 per cent.

SOUTHERN partisans, volunteer or ex officio, ought to be interested in a book called "Seed From Madagascar,"* for it is by a South Carolinian who sprang from a long and distinguished line of Combahee River rice planters and has himself been a rice planter and Governor of the State--Duncan Heyward.
The Japanese forces advancing along the PeipingHankow Railway penetrated Honan Province for the first time today, it was officially announced by the Japanese spokesman here.
Roy and Jack Garr went on trial today charged with murdering Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt, whom they accused of killing their sister, but Dr. E. S. Garr, the third brother, remained in a sanitarium.

Peter J. De Vine, regular Democratic designee for supervisor in Long Beach, obtained the nomination of his party in a decision handed down yesterday by Justice James T. Hallinan in Queens Supreme Court at Jamaica.

Normally fought on 'purely local issues, the French cantonal elections, concluded last Sunday, were of unusual national interest. An active campaign by the Radical Socialists, the Socialists and the Communists against the Rightist parties had made the voting a test of the present strength in the country of the Popular Front.

Funeral services for Grenville Temple Emmet. United States Minister to Austria. who died on Sept. 26 in Vienna, were held yesterday at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street.

Charles McAlpin Pyle, 44 years old, of Ellicott City, Md., who said he is a member of the family which built the McAlpin Hotel, pleaded not guilty in Felony Court yesterday to striking a waiter on the head with a bottle shortly after midnight in the International Casino at 1,514 Broadway.
