The stock market suffered yesterday its worst decline in six years. Heavy liquidation, much of an urgent character, together with hasty selling by investors, sent prices of leading stocks down from 2 to 15 points.

DAVIS, FRANK W. Jr. (Aug. 23). Estate, more than $20,000. To Floyd F. Nicholas, employee, 49 7th Ave., $5,000; Ernest Wilson, employee, Tannersville, N. Y., $2,000; Annie Moore, 206 E. 53d St., $2,000 and $75 per month for life; Elizabeth Davis Dwight, sister, executrix, Cannes, France, $10,000, stock of 290 Park Ave., Inc., real property at Hunter, N. Y., personal effects and residue.

The Manhattan football squad was given a respite from practice yesterday by Coach Chick Meehan. The Jaspers will have a scrimmage session this afternoon in preparation for the clash with the University of Kentucky at Lexington on Saturday.

Miss Frances Waddy Riddleberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Riddleberger of Jackson Heights, was married to William Albert Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Bennett of Elmhurst, last night in' St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Jackson Heights, by the rector, the Rev. Raymond L. Scofield.

Sleepy Jim Crowley told the Football Writers Association yesterday all it wanted to know about the Fordham-Pitt game. "You want to hear about the inner workings of our scoring plays," said Somnolent James with a twinkle in his eye.

Exports of trucks and buses in August totaled 16,830 units valued at $10,439,210, which was not only the highest for the year, but the greatest number of units for any month since August, 1929, and the greatest valuation since July of that year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, denounced yesterday the provision in the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act that limits the amount of loans that can be made to any one State to 10 per cent of the total.

A bridge and mah jongg party will be held in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador on Nov. 15 for the benefit of the Infants Relief Society. Needy children who have been asthmatic cases in several New York hospitals receive additional medical care through the organization's charitable fund,
Tabulation yesterday of the results of three auction sales of Long Island properties held on Saturday showed that final bids totaling more than $208,000 were received.
Voting under proportional reppresentation is like a "lottery" and will not last long in New York City, Justice James Y. Hallinan declared yesterday in the Supreme Court in Jamaica.

The Honest Ballot Association started yesterday its annual campaign to prevent illegal voting by moving in Supreme Court to strike twenty-two names from the list of registered voters. Monroe Percy Bloch, attorney for the association, indicated that a number of similar motions affecting other names will follow shortly.

Representatives of five large chain store organizations that operate more than 2,200 grocery and butcher shops in the metropolitan area pledged their cooperation yesterday afternoon to William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, in his department's campaign to educate housewives to the use of eggs, fish and poultry as a substitute for meat during the present meat shortage and resultant high prices.

IN view of the situation in Rhode Island, it is suggested with due deference that the Chief Executives of certain other sovereign States and commonwealths come to the aid of various parties with the following proposed proclamations offered free of any charge, including malice prepense:

Alabama is the prolific mother of statesmen and judges, but her politics is peculiar and to the outlander past finding out. Only the other day Governor Bibb Graves's machine was said to have everything "sewed up."

Mayor La Guardia drew the battle lines on the 1938 budget last night by virtually defying the Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate to restore the jobs of sixty-five politically connected officeholders in county agencies, whose jobs he slashed from the budget.
George V. Brown, promoter of amateur and professional athletic events and president and general manager of the Boston Garden, died last night at his home in Hopkinton. He was 57 years of age.

Long Island regained the Myrs D. Paterson Trophy, won by New Jersey last year, with an overwhelming victory over Westchester, the holder of the prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association annual intersectional matches at the Queens Valley club in Forest Hills yesterday.
The use of newspaper advertising to help the sale of electrical appliances has proved to be highly successful, Walter Seilern, president of the CramerKrasselt Advertising Agency,
Miss Betty Stagles, 17, of Rochester survived a 190-foot drop from the Veterans Memorial Bridge to the Genesee River here today. Rescued by three men, she was taken to a hospital critically injured.

Encouraged by the success of the anti-Bolshevist display last year all National Socialist propaganda organizations have combined forces to stage a larger exhibition styled "The Eternal Jew," opening here Nov. 8.

Mrs. J. Walter Wells of Coudersport, Pa., wife of former Assemblyman John Walter Wells of Potter County, Pa., died Thursday in Williamsport (Pa.) General Hospital, at the age of 67. She had been Regent of the Allegheny chapter of the D. A. R. for eleven terms, and was a member of the Huguenot Society of Pennsylvania.

Dr. Jeronimo Ramirez Brown, Nicaraguan Minister of Government, advised political leaders in all deapartments of Nicaragua to treat all citizens of Honduras residing in Nicaragua with consideration and courtesy and to report immediately any one insulting or persecuting Hondurans.

Eustace Seligman, attorney, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Sciences (the University in Exile) at 66 West Twelfth Street. Mr. Seligman, who succeeds Ira A. Hirschmann, is the son of Professor E. R. A. Seligman, who was associated with Dr. Alvin Johnson in forming the graduate body.

Several officers and members of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association have reserved tables for dinner or supper in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton on Oct. 27, when that rendezvous will be formally opened for the season.

Ferry William Leach, a pioneer in the investment banking business in the Middle West, died today at his home here. He was 71 years old. Mr. Leach was one of the original members of the firm of Farson, Leach Co., organized in the early Eighteen Eighties. Later when A. B. Leach Co. was organized he became the resident partner here.

The Newsprint Committee of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, in a bulletin sent out yesterday, notified the association's members that the Great Northern Paper Company, leading manufacturer in the United States, had announced an increase of $5.50 a ton for the first six months and of $7.50 a ton for the last six months of 1938 over 1937 prices.
The Abbey Theatre Irish Players and their manager, Frederick R. Higgins, were the guests of honor yesterday afternoon at a reception given by the Academy of American Poets at the Ambassador Hotel.
Five persons were killed and two others injured critically early today on Pennington Road in Hopewell Township when two automobiles collided.

An exhaustive survey of the qualifications of 28,650 "skilled" construction workers on the WPA rolls in this city showed that 4,074, or 16.5 per cent, were not equipped for their jobs, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

Harvard began working in earnest today for Saturday's game with Dartmouth. A check-up of the squad by Coach Dick Harlow revealed that there were no serious injuries in the hard game with Navy last week.
Warwick A. Shaw, retired Chicago attorney, died here tonight of a heart attack at the age of 78. Mr. and Mrs. Shaw had been visiting here.

George Lowell Mayberry, one of the State's leading lawyers for many years and a past president of the Massachusetts Bar Association, died today at his home, 1,563 Beacon Street, Brookline, at the age of 77. He was mayor of Waltham at the age of 32, and was returned to that office three times.

Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Neuberger of 180 East Seventy-ninth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adelaide Neuberger, to Richard B. Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel B. -Levy, also of New York, formerly of Boston.
Although registration totals in the

Mrs. Mary Childs Draper, for twenty-five years a volunteer worker with the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, took office yesterday as its president. She is believed to be the first woman to hold such a post in the nation.

The five members of the United States Army team who will compete at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 3 to 10 were aramed yesterday, it was announced by J. Spencer Weed, president of the National Horse Show Association.

A sum of $15,000,000 is needed to establish boys' clubs in communities where there are none, Herbert Hoover declared last night at a dinner of directors of the Boys Clubs of America in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A jury was chosen yesterday in Supreme Court to try a $175,000 libel and slander suit brought by Dr. Clarence Richards, former veterinarian for the Jockey Club of New York, against Isadore Bieber, owner of the B. B. Stable and agent for other owners of thoroughbreds.

Giro L. Mei, also known as Jerry May, 16-year-old Union City boy accused of the hammer murder of Sergio Sciarra, his 7-year-old cousin, on Dec. 31, 1935, pleaded guilty today to a charge of manslaughter. He had been indicted for murder, but Prosecutor Danel T. O'Regan agreed to the lesser charge.

In an editorial published on this page and under this title more than ten months ago the opinion was expressed that "none of the boroughs that comprise the City of New York has ever had a more useful public servant than Raymond V. Ingersoll, President of the Borough of Brooklyn."

Although it has received three reversals in as many starts, the Blair Academy football squad exhibited consistent improvement in each game this Fall, so as the team resumed practice today hopes were high that its visit to New York on Friday would be a highly successful one.

Mr. and Mrs. James M. Banner of New York gave a dinner tonight in the Colonnades Room of the Greenbrier in celebration of their fifth wedding anniversary. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Englehard of Bernardsville, N. J., entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig Keck of Switzerland.

In a long and tense struggle the veteran Karel Kozeluh downed Bruce Barnes today in five sets to win the national open tennis singles tourney. The scores were 6-2, 6-3, 4-6, 4-6, 6-1. Both players gave splendid exhibitions of court strategy.

Net income of the Dayton Rubber Manufacturing Company for the fiscal year which ends Oct. 31 will amount to at least $3 a share on 176,535 common shares outstanding, after one year's dividend requirements on the Class A stock, J. A. MacMillan, chairman, said yesterday in announcing cancellation of plans for the sale of 25,000 additional common shares.

The voters of Arkansas today promoted Representative John E. Miller of Searcy to the United States Senate as successor to the late Joseph T. Robinson. Mr. Miller defeated Governor Carl E. Bailey in a special election by a poll of three to two.

Funeral services will be held on Saturday at 2 P. M. in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, for Arthur W. Milburn, president of the Borden Company, milk concern. Mr. Milburn died on Oct. 11 at BadenBaden, Germany.

Buckley M. Byers's Thorson found both the muddy track and his opposition to his liking at Empire City yesterday and made a show of a small field to capture the Glenbrook Handicap for all ages at a mile and seventy yards.

Ernest Hutcheson, president of the Juilliard Foundation, New York Music School, will come to Toronto next week to discuss with officials of the Toronto Conservatory of Music the conservatory's present position and its future developemnt.

An investing client of the Kramshor Realty Corporation has purchased the two-family brick dwelling at 2,520 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn. This is one of seven similar houses recently bought by the seller from a financial institution. It was resold for cash. Charles M. Hiesiger, attorney, acted for\the Kramshor Corporation.

The New Jersey Board of Health voted today to support legislation to make compulsory pre-marital tests for venereal diseases. Under a proposed bill, all couples seeking to be married would be required to have Wassermann tests.

George Henry Payne, member of the Federal Communications Commission, was disqualified today by the vote of five of his fellow-commissioners from sitting in a hearing on the disbarment from practice before the commission of Paul M. Segal and George S. Smith, Washington lawyers.

Reflecting the nervous condition of the security markets yesterday, most commodity futures broke sharply in early dealings, with some touching new seasonal lows. Toward the close, however, trade and commission house buying developed and most prices ended irregularly under Monday's closing.

The Treasury Procurement Division today asked bids as of Oct. 29 on 729,000 yards of textiles for shipment by Nov. 30 to South Boston, Mass.; Little Rock, Ark., and Los Angeles. The bids will be opened Oct. 27. The specifications follow:

A student referendum yesterday gave 516 of 785 votes in favor of having the international student fellowship drive at Barnard College this year. A fund of $1,000 will be sought from the students to send a member of the class of 1938 abroad to study next year.

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, was elected president of the Bankers Club of America, Inc., on Monday, it was announced yesterday. LeRoy W. Baldwin, F. W. Lafrentz and Garland Powell Peed were elected vice presidents.

The Public Service Commission is sued today a report criticizing the Associated Gas and Electric Company for including as operating expenses what the commission termed "huge costs of lobbying activities conducted by the system."

United States ASSOCIATE REFUGE MANAGER, $3,200 a year; Assistant Refuge Manager, $2,600. Bureau of Biological Survey, Department of Agriculture. Applications must be on file not later than Nov. 15, if received from States other than those named below. Nov18, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming,
At'a press conference today before his departure for Washington in the evening, President Roosevelt again linked the state of the Treasury to the spending proclivities of Congress.

Police here are investigating today clues in the attempted kidnapping and hold-up of City Manager M. G. Farley, who early last evening escaped from two armed men by jumping from his automobile while it was going forty-five miles an hour. Mr. Farley,recovering at his home from multiple bruises, told police the two Negroes jumped into his car while he was waiting for a traffic light to change on Main Street at 6:30 o'clock last night.

A burglar forced police and town officials to spend a sleepless night in an unsuccessful effort to catch up with him. Between 11:55 o'clock last night and 1:50 A. M. today he broke into four places, including the Town Hall. After each break he called

LONDON, Oct. 19.--Lord Rutherford, director and guiding genius of the world famous Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge University, died tonight after undergoing a severe operation yesterday. He was 66 years old.

Five factors in the drop in stock market prices were listed today by Henry H. Heimann of New York, executive manager of the National Credit Men's Association, before the American Hardware Manufacturers Association, which is meeting simultaneouslv with the National Hardware Association in the Palmer House.

An application of the Davega-City Radio, Inc., for an injunction to prohibit members of the American Newspaper Guild from picketing its stores because it advertised in The Brooklyn Daily Eagle was denied yesterday by Supreme.' Court Justice Leander B. Faber in Brooklyn Supreme Court.
Determined to forsake basketball because of its menace to his valuable legs and arms, Joe DiMaggio, Yankee outfielder, entrained yesterday for his California home, via Chicago.

Funeral services for Colonel Grayson Mallet-Prevost Murphy, financier and first European Commissioner of the American Red Cross during the World War, will be held today at 10 A. M. in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Seventy-first Street and Madison Avenue.

All the officers and directors of the United German Societies have resigned, admitting the failure of their attempt to unite the numerous groups of German origin in New York, it was learned yesterday.

Rev. W. T. Hill, retired Anglican minister, died at his home here today at the age of 86. He held several posts in England before coming to Canada in 1877 when he was appointed Classical Master at Dufferin Military College. In 1881 he was placed in

Mr. and Mrs. George Starr Scofield gave a reception yesterday afternoon in the Persian, Room of the Plaza for Miss Minnie Fox Hopkins of this city and Dr. Charles Louis Gilbert of Richmond, Va., whose marriage will take place here on Saturday in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

More than $27,300 changed hands in payment for early United States postage stamps at the Collectors Club yesterday when part of the collection of the late Robert S. Emerson, who was an associate justice of the State District Court of Rhode Island, was auctioned by Walter S. Scott through Daniel F. Kelleher, a Boston dealer.

It is a very modest little show that serves to introduce to the New York public America's latest "find" in the realm of sculpture, the Tennessee Negro, William Edmondson. Nine or ten of his small, quite "primitive," untutored and unpretentious figures have been installed in a recessed space at the Museum of Modern Art (temporary quarters on- the Concourse level at 14 West Forty-ninth Street).

A high requiem mass was celebrated yesterday for William Toby Snyder, 77-year-old custodian of New York University's College of Medicine, who died on Sunday after serving the college for more than fifty years.

Underneath a canopy of leaking skies that hovered over Innisfail Park, Manhattan College's home stamping ground on weekdays, John F. (Chick) Meehan yesterday began whipping the Kelly Greens into shape for their engagement with the University of Kentucky at Lexington on Saturday.

In view of the widespread decline in security markets and the conditions surrounding the market for new security offerings, the second largest piece of utility financing that had been scheduled for offering this Fall was abandoned yesterday, the Appalachian Electric Power Company notifying the Securities and Exchange Commission of its intention to withdraw a registration statement covering $67,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds and sinkingfund debentures.

The Chinese Women's Association, of which Mme. Chiang Kaishek, wife of the Chinese generalissimo, is honorary chairman, has taken a block of seats for the recital of Julia Peters, soprano, at Carnegie Hall, Oct. 29.
Senator Wagner did his bit for Tammany Monday evening when he said a number of kind words for Mr. Mahoney and the Democratic party at a "labor rally" held in Cooper Union.

The gist of the President's budget statement is the unpleasant fact that the Government must borrow nearly three-quarters of a billion dollars to pay its bills this year, even though its income is now at the highest level ever reached in the whole history of the United States.

James J. Braddock, former world's heavyweight champion, and his manager, Joe Gould, yesterday were told by the State Athletic Commission that they have until Dec. 1 to pay the $1,000 fines levied against them for Braddock's failure to fulfill a contract to defend his title against Max Schmeling on June 3 last under the direction of the Madison Square Garden Corporation.
More than a hundred citizens who have served as foremen of grand juries in New York County in the last five years have endorsed the candidacy of Harold W. Hastings for Districit Attorney,

" Changing New York," an exhibition of photographs taken by Bernice Abbott to record for the future today's aspect of the city, will be opened to the public today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street.
A method of minimizing the danger of deafness for airline pilots and for aiding pilots who have become deaf to hear again is being tested by the Bureau of Air Commerce.

A few cardboard boxes containing orange skins, cantaloupe rinds and other refuse cost the Cunard White Star Line $500 yesterday when Albert E. Wright, attorney for the line, confessed that an employee on the Queen Mary had tossed that refuse into the Hudson River when the vessel was docked at Pier 90 on Aug. 9.
Christopher Foster Coombs, a retired New York investment broker, died here yesterday at his home at the age of 64. He was born in Islesboro, Me., and had resided here for nine years.

The Irving Trust Company has leased the ground floor store, mezzanine and part of the basement in the building at 22-26 West Fortyeighth Street for a new banking office. More than 10,000 square feet of space will be utilized by the bank, which plans to move into the structure about the first of the year.

Of the fifty-three railroads which borrowed from the Railroad Credit Corporation to meet their bond interest, thirty-three have repaid, E. G. Buckland, president of the corporation, announced yesterday at the sixth annual meeting in Washington.

The bulk of the New Deal business legislation, including particularly the tax on undistributed earnings of corporations, was assailed yesterday by Arthur A. Ballantine, Under-Secretary of the Treasury in the closing period of the Hoover administration, as responsible for the current Qstock market slump.

Mrs. Willis J. Physioc of this city has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Frances F. Physioc, to Walter J. Rowan of Brooklyn. Owing to the recent death of Mr. Rowan's father, only members of the immediate families attended the ceremony in New York City on Oct. 12.

Narragansett Race Park failed to open today for the second day of the Fall meeting while 300 National Guardsmen continue to patrol the entrances under a proclamation issued by Governor Robert E. Quinn.

Miss Esther Willson Sands, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Jerome Sands of Port Chester, N. Y., was married this afternoon to Lon Hocker Jr. of St. Louis in the First Congregational Church of this shore line town.

Norman H. Davis, the United States delegate to the conference on the Far Eastern crisis of the signatories to the Nine-power treaty to be held in Brussels Oct. 30, will enter that conference "without any commitments on the part of this government to other governments," President Roosevelt said today.

It's still a trifle early in college football's annual rodeo to distribute the All-Star accolades with any degree of conviction. The crucial tests have yet to be passed, but October's swift pace already has produced a flock of individual headliners, some of whom may be hard to overtake in the stretch drive.

The decline of the national rate of steel production to 55.8 per cent this week has resulted in the adoption of "spread-the-work" policies at numerous mills throughout the country, it became known yesterday.
The New York Aggies soccer team played a tie with the Garden City High School today, 1 to 1. H. Morones scored for the Aggies and B. Behrer for the school team.

A reduction in rates of the Philadelphia Electric Company which will result in an annual saving to both domestic and commercial consumers of approximately $3,107,000 was ordered today by the Public Utility Commission. The order is effective on Nov. 1.

Today's events: Mary Munn, pianist, Town Hall, evening; Patricia Patterson, song recital, Town Hall, afternoon; Composers Forum-Laboratory, music of Herbert Inch and Elie Siegmeister, WPA Theatre of Music, 8:45 P. M.; Gudmundur Kristjansson, tenor, Steinway Hall, 8:30 P. M.
Whenever Dwight Moody preached it was always a mass. meeting. If he were speaking in Carnegie Hall next Wednesday night, the great hall would be filled to overflowing.

Price reductions were announced yesterday on several dry goods items, ranging from 5 to 8 per cent and, while some producers reported the lower prices stimulated moderately good buying from jobbers, others said they received no immediate response.
Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins was guest of honor at a tea given by Mrs. Walter H. Gardner, wife of Passaic County's State Senator, at the City Club this afternoon.

WPA expenditures on parks, roads, public buildings and other physical improvements in the Bronx in the two years ended July 31 totaled $57,922,055, according to a report made public last night by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator here.
The keen eye of George (Twinkletoes) Selkirk, right fielder of the world champion New York Yankees, brought him a fine ringnecked pheasant yesterday.

Prophets of ill omen, who see in stock market declines a dark forecast for the business future, were taken to task yesterday by W. C. Cowling, director of sales of the Ford Motor Company, at a luncheon meeting at the Park Lane, at which the 1938 models of the Lincoln-Zephyr motor cars were shown.

Mrs. Evangeline Stokowski, second wife of Leopold Stokowski, was reported today to be at Las Vegas, Nev. Her attorney. Roger Marchetti of Los Angeles, declined to discuss rumors of plans for a divorce suit.

The Danzig Senate's attacks on Catholics may seriously affect the Free City's relations with Poland. The Danzig National Socialists, after exterminating the Socialist opposition, are now redoubling efforts against the Catholic Center party with many arrests of clergy and laymen.
A disaster was averted at dawn today when a bomb was found on the track on which a train was traveling from Egypt to Haifa, Palestine, between Rafa and Gaza. It was removed by track guards.

A driving rain that left deep puddles seeping into University Field failed to disrupt Fritz Crisler's practice schedule today and the first two Princeton elevens climaxed a.twohour session with forty minutes of hard scrimmage in preparation for Rutgers' visit Saturday.

Former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers and John C. Kelly of Scarsdale, advertising executive, were named members of the board of directors of the Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of New York at a meeting yesterday at the Center Club, 120 Central Park South.

Attacking Tammany Hall for having failed to buy needed new equipment for the Fire Department during Democratic administrations, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the improvements in fire protection during his term had cut per capital losses from fire to the lowest point in Fire Department history.
Mrs. Faye Lippmann sued for divorce today from Walter Lippmann, asserting that he used a gift of invective against her and habitually indulged a violent temper. She charged extreme mental cruelty.
Freed of previous restrictions against direct, forceful action, Federal agents started today their heralded widespread search for the kidnappers of Charles S. Ross, 72-year-old retired manufacturer.

That marvelously proper institution, the New York Board of Censors which probably still has a file of Godey's Lady's Books somewhere), has had its highly moral way with Jacques Deval's "Club de Femmes," the new film at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse.

Despite excessive cold and - rain, 3,000 Japanese golf fans followed Gene Sarazen, the American pro, in an exhibition foursome today. It was one of the largest Japanese galleries ever assembled for a match other than a tournament.

Fewer than 14 per cent of those believed to be eligible in this State for cash payments under the Social Security Act have made formal application for the sums due them, James D. Hayes, assistant national director of the old-age insurance division of the Social Security Board, disclosed yesterday.

Because the Municipal Civil Service Commission has no funds with which to pay them thirty examining assistants, who mark civil service test papers, are being asked to work under waiver of salary pending the voting of additional funds by the Board of Estimate, James E. Finegan, president of the commission, disclosed last night.
The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to abandon six segments of its lines, totaling 17.5

The four-story brick apartment house at 43 Van Wagenen Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., has been purchased as an investment by Caroline Zimmer. The Sixteenth and Park Avenue Corp. was the seller. The structure contains eight fiveroom apartments. J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers. arranged the sale.

Sir Rigby Swift, senior judge of the King's Bench, who had been associated either as counsel or judge with some of the most famous British trials of recent years, died today at his home in Crowborough, Sussex, after a short illness, at the age of 63.

Women were eliminated today as possible jurors in the trial of Laverne (John Montague) Moore, indicted here seven years ago on a charge of first-degree Robbery in connection with an $800 roadhouse hold-un.

Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State, said in a prepared statement tonight that Japan's policy concerning China was not reconcilable with the Pact of Paris, which he was co-author with Aristide Briand.

Unfavorable weather was no deterrent yesterday to Coach Jimmy Crowley, who sent his Fordham football squad through a two-hour workout at Fordham Field, featured by a scrimmage in which a varsity eleven composed of second and third stringers worked on offense against the freshmen In preparation for the game with Texas Christian University at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

The Army varsity rested again today. Coach Davidson kept the players in the gymnasium rather than send them out on the practice field in the rain and mud. The Army coach showed the team moving pictures of Saturday's game with the Elis.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 19.--Paul N. Dwyer, the South Paris youth who is alleged to have confessed murdering Dr. James G. Littlefield and his wife, was today ordered committed to the State Hospital for the Insane in Augusta for observation by Justice George L. Emery of the Maine Superior Court.

James G. Stahlman, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that the press of America has not lost its power and prestige, but needed to be ridded of "its professional termites."

William H. Duryea, Secretary of the State Department of Agriculture, submitted today his resignation, to be effective Jan. 1, at which time he plans to engage in commercial work. He has held the position for more than twelve years.
The fiscal committee of the League of Nations ended its seventh session today by abandoning the proposed convention to prevent tax evasion by persons who transfer capital from one country to another.
Melville Untermeyer, 58 years old, of 995 Fifth Avenue, was killed shortly after 5 o'clock last evening when he jumped or fell from a window of his apartment on the tenth floor of 995 Fifth Avenue.

New York Central Railroad Company bonds are being forged, according to a warning sent out yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. So far, according to the Exchange, none have appeared in New York, but fifty-three of the ten-year 3 3/4 per cent secured sinking fund bonds due in 1946 were reported found in Chicago.

Fourt annual conference on assessment administration, National Association of Assessing Officers, Hotel New Yorker, 9 A. M. Luncheon at noon at which speakers will be Mayor La Guardia and John A. Zangerle. Continues Thursday and Friday.

France decided today to dispatch more than eighty first-line planes to North Africa--the greatest air force ever sent to a French colony--for Fall manoeuvres demonstrating her air power to the empire.

Jews of Poland today took part in a national strike against the introduction of "ghetto benches" in the universities. Warsaw's usually busy Jewish quarter was silent until noon. Jews prayed in synagogues or attended meetings.

The Workers Alliance of Greater New York, which shares offices with the WPA Teachers Union, Local 453, A. F. of L., at 781 Broadway, announced yesterday that it would throw its full support to the District Attorney.

The Brooklyn College football team held a long practice session on the new athletic field at Bedford Avenue and Avenue H yesterday in an effort to polish its offensive and defensive play for the game with Lowell Textile Saturday.
The Cuban Government will invite all countries of the Americas to make a joint effort toward bringing about peace in Spain, according to a resolution adopted by the Cabinet this afternoon.

The National Labor Relations Board, in a ruling in line with a Federal District Court decision which it had once ignored, certified today an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor as the sole bargaining agent for employes of the Nationat Electric Products Company of Ambridge, Pa., rejecting the claim of a union linked with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The mobilization of the nation's intelligence to cope with unemployment, war, social insecurity and other problems created by the impact of invention and technology on modern civilization was urged last night by a group of scientists and industrialists who participated in a symposium dealing with the social implications of science.

Inventions designed to play a great part in the future development of industry in the United States and make this nation more independent of certain foreign products are on exhibit at the National Metals Congress in the Municipal Convention Hall here.
The Cabinet approved today reductions of 202,000,000 yen (about $59,000,000) in government expenses for the remainder of the fiscal year.
A WAR veteran from the Rhode Island front reported that the besieged O'Hara troops weren't down to the last extremity yet. They hadn't begun to eat the horses.

The Farm Administration said today 3,176 northeastern farmers had received a total of $157,692 as payments for participating in the 1937 soil conservation program. New York farmers received the largest amount-$101,290- to 1,905 farmers.

In the face of criticism from labor leaders supporting Mayor La Guardia, United States Senator Robert F. Wagner announced yesterday that he would make three more speeches before the campaign is over urging the election of Jeremiah T. Mahoney as Mayor.

The marriage of Miss Joan Corboy Strahan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. J. Strahan of this city, to Edward Daniel Hurley of Belmont, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon in the Friar's Chapel of the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. The Rev. Martin Killian performed the ceremony.

Supreme Court Justice James T. Hallinan in Queens yesterday signed an order requiring Borough President George U. Harvey to show cause why Mr. Harvey's name should not be stricken from the Fusion column on the ballot.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission of New York City must conduct a non-competitive examination for assistants for the count of votes cast for the election of Councilmen by proportional representation, the Court of Appeals ruled today.
Following is the prepared text of the radio address of Alf M. Landon: I have called a meeting of the 17,000,000 men and women who voted for the Republican ticket last Fall. I have taken it upon
Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 19,000 including 4,500 directs.

BARKHORN-At Newark,-N. J., on Sunday, Oct. 17, 1937. Clara Webner, widow of Charles H. Barkhorn. Funeral service at her home, 223 Fairmount Ave, Newark, on Wednesday, Oct. 20, at 2:30 P. M. BAUM-Grace, beloved wife of Henry Baum. Services Thursday, 2 P. M., funeral parlor, 40 West 58th St.

Miss Helen Holmes of Allentown, N. J., near here, found today in the back seat of her automobile ten New York City Police Department summonses, intended to direct as many motorists to appear in magistrate's court in New York today to answer charges of overtime parking.

The State Board of Social Welfare and the Emergency Relief Bureau pledged a joint effort yesterday to improve relief administration in this city, with specific reference to "the orderly handling of pressure groups."

Paul Dullzell, executive secretary of the Actors Equity Association, narrowly escaped censure by Equity's council yesterday for objecting publicly to the appointment of Miss Edith L. Christenson, an organizer for the Committe for Industrial Organization, as the new executive secretary of the Chorus Equity Association. The vote on a censure was not made public.
George A. Ball of Muncie, Republican National Committeeman from Indiana since 1928, submitted his resignation today in a letter to Chairman Hamilton.

While communications being received in the local wholesale markets indicate many retailers throughout the country are becoming increasingly apprehensive about the potential effect upon retail trade of the declinein Wall Street, leading merchandisers here said yesterday they will continue plans to feature medium to better grade goods, but one of them warned that inventories should be gradually reduced by 15 per cent or so by Jan. 1, with current buying confined to actual needs.

Silver feeding spoons bearing the seal of the City of New York were awarded yesterday to twenty-four babies whose mothers had shown the "good sense and judgment" to make the best attendance records at baby clinics in Astoria. The presentation took place at the Astoria District Health Center, 12-26 Thirty-first Avenue, Astoria.

On yesterday's stock market occurred a spectacular decline, followed (perhaps for the first time this season) by an equally spectacular recovery. This market came when Monday's 7-point average decline had again made the stock market the uppermost topic of conversation in a perplexed business community. Three questions had arisen,
A movement was announced today in support of Father Charles E. Coughlin's "right to speak freely."

Miss Geraldine Novak was selected yesterday from twenty-six show girls, representing twenty-six different countries, as International Fur Queen for National Fur Week, Nov. 8 to 13. Wearing a coat of Siberian sable valued at $25,000, Miss Novak was the overwhelming choice of twenty-six consular representatives, three illustrators and a number of stage, screen and musical artists, who met at the International Casino to cast their votes.
Mr. Landon did not need last night to argue the case for a strong opposition party. The crying need of such an opposition is manifest on the face of the facts themselves.

The end of, the governmental "borrowing era" -is approaching, Aubrey Williams, deputy WPA Administrator, told more than 1,500 social workers last night in a speech in which he attacked business leaders who hold governmental interference responsible for the stock market decline.
Premier Juan Negrin has postponed announcement of the Government's intention to move from Valencia to Barcelona. It will be made at a rally Thursday.
Powerful support poured into the New York Stock Exchange shortly before noon yesterday and checked a decline that had promised to be a complete rout.

The appearance of substantial blocks of stock some time after the opening of trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at sharply reduced prices, followed by brisk recoveries in subsequent trading, gave rise to reports that in several instances groups of directors of companies had decided to furnish support for their stocks, regardless of how this action might be interpreted later by regulatory officials.

To gain actual game experience Coach Art Winters today assigned all, except two, of his Hamilton College sophomore football players to par: ticipate in an interclass contest with the freshmen. Relinquishing their

Miss Pauline Gunnison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond M. Gunnison of this place, was married to David Lars Enequist, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Enequist, this evening in the Hitchcock Memorial Church here.

Opposition to the proposed Republican off-year convention in 1938was voiced today by former Senator James E. Watson with the assertion that the party's first objective was to "get possession of the ball."
Walter Neusel of Germany staged a great rally to gain a twelve-round decision over Maurice Strickland, New Zealand heavyweight, at Wembly Stadium tonight, but the loser won the crowd's acclaim.

A serious shortage of vocational and industrial teachers faces the New York City school system, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, charman of the Board of Examiners, announced yesterday. He disclosed that only 1,430 candidates applied for the examinations to be held next month in 113 vocational, shop and technical subjects.

The letter from Konrad Henlein, leader of the Nazi Sudeten Deutsche party, to President Eduard Benes, with its peremptory demand for autonomy for the Sudeten Deutsche district of Czechoslovakia, taken together with the outbursts in the German press, is seen here as confirming the results of the official Czech investigation into the recent disorders in TeplitzSchoenau.

Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association, said tonight that laboratory experiments made it quite evident that the diethylene glycol, not the sulfanilamide of an "elixir of sulfanilamide" was responsible for the deaths of thirteen persons using the solution.

Young Rubicam's poster for Life Savers, Inc., won first prize in the outdoor advertising design for competition, sponsored by Outdoor, Advertising, Inc. Gustave Sigritz was art director. Second award was given to N. W. Ayer Son's poster for American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Rollin C. Smith, art director; third to

The charge that Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers is a "closed" union.. Waving a "monopoly" of, labor in the electrical trades, was made yesterday by Walter Gordon 'Merritt, counsel for the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, in the association's suit to enjoin the union from violating the Sherman anti-trust act.
Chinese bombing planes raided Japanese lines in the Shanghai sector today with a mystifying absence of Japanese anti-aircraft fire.
It was announced tonight that Rudolf Hess, deputy Nazi leader, had accepted Premier Mussolini's invitation to attend the fifteenth anniversary celebration of the Fascist regime on Oct. 28 and 29.

The outlook for a partnership between Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. and Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley of London for the promotion of boxing in London next year took a new and more favorable turn yesterday following a second conference between the promoters.

Coaoh Harvey Harman of Pennsylvania used a new backfield combination today in a scrimmage against the freshmen on rain-soaked River Field and was impressed by the playing of Mike Burke and Walt Daly, both sophomores.
Mrs. Huntington Tappin gave a large luncheon yesterday in the penthouse of the St. Regis to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Elise Irving van Siclen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George
Political talks n the city cam day are: George L. Meany, president of the New York State Federation of La Guardia Says I Labor, "Why Labor Supports Mayor La Guardia," WOR, 6:45 to 7 P. M.

President Roosevelt was accused yesterday by Raymond Moley, editor of News Week and Professor of Public Law at Columbia University, of creating discord rather than peace between employers and labor, within labor, between sections of the country and between government and business.
President Seymour of Yale announces that Dr. Alvin S. Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research,
Secretary and Mrs. Hull left late this afternoon for their official visit to Canada as guests of the Governor General and Lady Tweedsmuir.
The Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, dedicated the new St. Francis Home for Cardiac Children in Flower Hill this afternoon

Mr. Abbott is opening his Fall season this evening with a mystery story called "Angel Island," the work of Mrs. Bernie Angus. Among the players are Joyce Arling, Lea Penman, Betty Field, Eric Wollencott, Morgan Conway, Doro Merande and many more-most of them being graduates of other Abbott shows as well as members of the "A- Acting Company."
One of the longest scrimmage sessions of the season was held on Penn State's practice field today as the Lions began their preparation for the Syracuse game a week from Saturday.

When the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act was decorated with seven bay windows, a mile and a quarter of fancy scrollwork and as much red ribbon as would stick and then turned over to the Department of the Interior, certain conclusions seemed justifiable. It looked as though we would have an absolutely honest, thoroughly sound and awfully

Miss Agnes P. Schalker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Schalker of Fort Leavenworth, Kan., was married here this afternoon to George Pfaff Jr. of New York, son of Mrs. George Pfaff of New York and Center Moriches, L. I., and the late Mr. Pfaff, in the chapel of the Choate School.

Directors of the Buenos Aires wheat market today imposed restrictions on dealings in the October and November deliveries of wheat. The action was taken because of speculation which arose when many brokers were caught with commitments while old wheat supplies were at low levels and the new crop had not come to market.

Nearly 200 persons representing State, county and municipal bodies and civic and business organizations attended today a meeting here at which Colonel John H. C. Lee, United States Army engineer, presided, for discussion of a proposed barge canal across the southern end of New Jersey.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, Fusion candidate for Controller, charged yesterday that Controller Frank J. Taylor, his Democratic opponent, was sending political propaganda to home-relief recipients, in the form of an enclosure in the semi-monthly relief check envelopes distributed by the Controller's office.
The Interstate Commerce Commission was informed today that the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway can catch up with its deferred maintenance program within five years. The estimate was made by

Lieutenant Francesco Rebizzi, Italian naval officer attached to the Italian naval mission in China, accompanying German, Chinese and Russian civilians in two cars arriving here on Tuesday night from Shanghai reported that the group was heavily machine gunned near Soochow by three Japanese planes that swooped over them four times.

Mayor La Guardia received the pledge of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union last night at a meeting in the Hippodrome, Forty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, that he would have the votes of the 150,000 members of that organization and their families.in his fight for re-election.

Representative John J. Q'Connor of New York City demanded today that the Federal Reserve Board lower margin requirements on stock purchases, while greatly increasing requirements for speculative activity, if not actually prohibiting short selling entirely.

Frank L. Ryan and Ryan Florida Corporation announced today that they would petition the Supreme Court for a rehearing "in the absence of Justice Black" as a result of an order denying appeal in their suit attacking the Securities and Exchange Commission attempt to subpoena their telegrams.

Mrs. Mary McClellan Wright bought from Mrs. Avonne Blackwell of New York the estate at Brookfield, Conn., consisting of an eleven-room residence, superintendent's cottage, three-car garage, modernized barn and thirty acres of land. The seller bought the property in 1934 and remodeled it from plans by Robert Charles Kilborn, architect.

Princeton University is going to make a survey of radio's influence on present-day life. Dr. Harold W. Dodds, university president, announced today a grant of $67,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation to the school of public and international affairs
Charles E. Davis Jr., dean of the Port of Philadelphia's active shipping operators, died suddenly today at his home, 6,233 McCallum Street, Germantown. He was 75.

Although we've heard little from the sport fishermen for the past few days, Captain Walter Willis of the Long Island Railroad's fishing bureau called us yesterday to report that a commercial fisherman had taken twenty-three striped bass on Monday, the largest weighing 49 pounds 6 ounces. On a rod and
Dr. Charles Herty announced today perfection of a process for manufacture of newsprint from- black gum wood, a characteristic tree of Atlantio and Gulf Coast river swamps.

Stockholders of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company approved yesterday an increase in authorized shares from 2,000,000 to 2,500,000 shares, waived their pre-emptive rights to 400,000 common shares, and authorized the directors to sell up to that number of shares or to engage in other methods of financing involving the sale of securities convertible into common stock.
The Philadelphia Orchestra appeared for the first time this season in New York last nigt in Carnegie Hall, with Eugene Ormandy as conductor and Fritz Kreisler as soloist.

Repeated stock market selling waves have failed to sweep the "little fellow" from his position as a net buyer. While stocks were breaking sharply yesterday, odd-lot securities traders bought considerably more than they sold, the Securities Commission reported.

Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, on his way to the Nine-power treaty conference on the Far Eastern situation in Brussels, is sailing today for Europe on the steamship Washington of the United States Lines.

Rosario Candela, architect, filed yesterday plans for a seventeenstory and penthouse apartment building at 955 Fifth Avenue, near Seventy-seventh Street, for the 955 Fifth Avenue, Inc., of 33 West Forty-second Street. The building, which will be erected at an estimated cost of $700,000, will occupy a plot 62.6 by 100 feet.

Ernest Angell, director of the New York Regional Office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was called to Washington by the SEC today to make a report on the latest developments on the Exchanges and investigations of causes for the collapse of values, but an official said there would be no statement concerning his visit tonight.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Fortyfourth Street, voted at a meeting last night to table for one week a resolution by its Judiciary Committee endorsing the candidacy of Thomas E. Dewey for District Attorney of New York County.

The Bank of Mexico in a statement issued today indicates that its reserves have fallen to 51.58 per cent from 52.20 per cent last week. The official coverage required is 50 per cent, but President Cardenas decreed several weeks ago that the bank need not meet the official requirements until August, 1938.
Bernie Friedkin, 1301/2, Brownsville, scored a two-round knockout over Nicky Jerome, 127, Williamsburg, last night in a scheduled eight at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn before 5,200.

The recurrent declines in the stock market and, particularly, the severe drop yesterday, have affected adversely sentiment in advertising circles, but as yet there is no disposition on the part of advertisers to start slashing budgets hysterically, agency executives declared yesterday.

The City College football squad went through an intensive two-hour drill yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium in preparation for the engagement with Hobart at Geneva on Saturday. Although two injured players reported, two others were on the sidelines.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,602,150 barrels, compared to 3,579,050 in the preceding week, a gain of 23,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 11,500 and 9,400

H. Russell Ryder, 41 years old, the erstwhile "playboy of Broadway," who in 1931 was sent to Sing Sing in the $2,000,000 failure of Woody Co., brokers, was taken into custody yesterday as a parole violator.
Forced selling and nervous liquidation which produced the heaviest volume of trading in more than four years was stemmed finally in the late trading yesterday by an aggressive investment demand.

Defending his balanced budget with courage and force Geeorges Bonnet, Minister of Finance, today succeeded in getting the Cabinet to approve what is in reality a half measure toward satisfying the demands of civil servants for an increase in salary. Had it been granted it would have increased the deficit on the present year and wiped out the surplus which has been provided for next year.
The Interstate Commerce Commission permitted Western and Southern railroads to increase today their first-class, or Pullman, passenger rates from 2 cents to 2 1/4 cents a mile.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just read in THE TIMES the letter of Taneo Taketa deploring the "increasing misunderstanding between the American and the Japanese people because of the unfortunate conflict in China." He speaks of the distortion of much of "the news" about China, and attempts "to call attention to the actual situation in China."

Affected by the slump in Wall Street, the stock market here developed general weakness today and prices were marked down in all sections. Giltedge issues were dull and foreign bonds, where changed at all, were easier. Transatlantic stocks sagged.

Bishop Robert L. Paddock, speaking for 150 liberal Protestant clergymen and laymen engaged with a Catholic group in a controversy over Spain, accepted yesterday the invitation of Ambassador Fernando de los Rios to send representatives on a bipartism commission to investigate conditions in both Loyalist and Rebel territories in Spain.

Freeland Jewett, former president of the Eastern Talc Company and the Eastern Magnesium Tacl Company, died yesterday of heart disease at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, where he had lived for several years.

Miss Mary V. Donohue, retired school teacher, died Monday at her home, 48-08 Springfield Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, after a brief illness. She was a sister of Thomas M: Donohue, former principal of the old Parental School in Flushing. Born in the Bronx,
Richard Nussbaum of New York University won novice saber honors in the tourney staged at the New York Athletic Club by the Amateur Fencers League of America last night. He defeated Leo Kellerman,
Rosemary Cottage, the Mount Kisco, N. Y., estate of Fred W. Schultz, has been leased by Mrs. Oscar Graves through Julia Beverly Higgins and Previews. Inc.
Miss Anna Remsen Alexandre was a dinner hostess tonight at the Lenox Club in honor of her niece, Miss Anne Remsen Schenck of London, who is visiting Mrs. Hayden Channing at the Ledge.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--The Democrats' four-to-one majority in Congress, some legislators contended today, may be a source of embarrassment as well as assistance to the Administration in the coming special session.

MANHATTAN ALLEN, JAMES FRED (Sept. 19, 1930). Gross assets, $232,722; net, $83,243. To Mary Will Allen, mother, under terms of will a life interest in a trust of $150,000; estate of Beader Lawrence Battle, to James Allen Battle, nephews, and Marie Allen Lonsdale, sister, residue equally; nephews also share remainder in mother's trust. Chief assets, stocks and bonds. $222,708. James P. Smith, attorney, 49 Wall St.

The establishment of a pension plan for officials, supplementary to the provisions of the Railway Retirement Law, was announced yesterday by the New York Central Railroad.. At the same time the retirement of numerous officials was announced.

THE RAINS CAME, by Louis Bromfield. (Harper, $2.75.) A novel of India. APOLLO SLEEPS, by Daphne Greenwood. (Messner, $2.50.) A novel with an Oriental setting. GYPSY LUCK, by Chesley Kahmann. (Messner, $2.) A novel of gypsy life.
Steel ingot production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index has moved downward to 90.1 from 94.3 in the previous week. It was 108.7 for the week ended Oct. 17. 1936.

One of the longest defensive drills ever given a Harvard varsity football squad was handed the Crimson players today by Coach Dick Harlow. Reports that Dartmouth has what is potentially the strongest team of Earl Blaik's regime has aroused the local coaches.

Independent milk distributors in the metropolitan area agreed yesterday to cooperate with representatives of producers throughout the State in the enforcement of price regulations in the industry which became effective last May with the enactment of the RogersAllen bill.

A suit against the city for $106,152 that has been pending in the courts since 1908 has been tentatively settled for $325, Alvin McK. Sylvester, assistant corporation counsel, disclosed last night. Earlier in the day a motion made by Mr. Sylvester to dismiss the action was set down for argument on Oct. 26.

The question whether it is democratic to exclude revolutionary parties from parliamentary representation occupied the lower house today when it debated the principal feature of the Government's bill for modification of the Constitution.

Among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday was one taken by the Dalton Pharmacy, Inc., Max Schwartz, president, on the large store and basement in 602 Madison Avenue which formerly was occupied by the Dry Dock Savings Institution. Butler Baldwin, Inc., were the brokers.

The War DePartment released the following orders today, dated Oct. 18: Short, Brig. Gen. W. C., ten days' leave, Nov. 15. Schley. Col. J. L., Eng'rs, appointed Chief of Engineers, with rank of Major General, for a period of four years, beginning Oct. 18, to rank from that date.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor received a royal welcome this evening to ultra-National Socialist Nuremberg, where they are occupying Chancellor Hitler's party congress suite in the Deutscher Hof. As they near Munich and Berchtesgaden, where they are expected to visit Hitler Saturday, their tour assumes an increasingly official character.

In spite of a constant drizzle and a muddy field, Coach Mal Stevens sent his New York University football squad through two hours of intensive drill yesterday afternoon at Ohio Field in preparation for the contest with Lafayette Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.

Also in March he remarked: "I wish some of those learned ecclesiastics who have so much concern for the well-being of society would become and sit here. It would not be long before the divorce laws were altered."
Gertrude Borzi, American coloratura soprano, who made her New York debut at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, had everything in her favor except the gift that only nature can bestow.

After showing considerable resistance to the influence of early sharp declines in other markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday rallied about $1 a bale from the day's lowest levels, and closed unchanged, to 6 points higher than Monday.

Walter P. Jacobi of Tulsa, Okla., gasoline buyer, told a Federal court jury here today that prices of gasoline had responded to a buying program by which thirteen oil companie bought gasoline from small refiners in the Mid-Continent field in 1935 and 1936.
Several large leases, a number of which were for quarters in buildings on Park Avenue, featured the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. William Stanley gave a dinner tonight in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier for Attorney General and Mrs. Homer S. Cummings. Mrs. Charles L. Bradley gave a luncheon at the Casino for Mrs. Cummings, Mrs. Stanley and Mrs. Samuel F. Pryor Jr.

Comparatively light, but possessing admirable spirit and a keen zest for the game, members of the Hill School's football squad are nearing the halfway mark in their 1937 schedule with the distinction of being undefeated after three contests with formidable rivals.

The two four-story buildings at 399401 West Broadway and 162 Spring Street, southeast corner, have been sold by Mrs. Lydia E. Leslie to the Cranford Holding Corporation, which several months ago bought several adjoining properties and now controls a plot of more than 10,000 square feet. Jerome Tanenbaum was the broker in the assembling of all the properties.

Opinions of business men as to how the conflict between China and Japan may be terminated are being sought by World Peaceways, Inc., through a questionnaire distributed at the National Business Show, which opened Monday at Commerce Hall, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

For the first time since the beginning of the return match between Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris for the chess championship of the world, the latter took the lead by winning the seventh game tonight.
The International Non-intervention Committee today ran straight on the same jagged rocks of disagreement that had all but wrecked its efforts last July.

Mayor La Guardia, in absentia, was the storm center yesterday of the annual political forum of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, with Thomas E. Dewey as the Mayor's champion and Jeremiah T. Mahoney as a challenger.

The Duro-Test Corporation has elected to the board of directors Dr. Emanuel Spielholz, director of the Tungsten Research Laboratories, Inc., and Jack M. Ross. Stockholders voted to change the date for annual meetings to Jan. 15.
Earnings of Remington Rand, Inc., and subsidiaries for the six months ended on Sept. 30 were the largest for any corresponding period since 1929, the company said in issuing its report yesterday.

Paul Muni arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Paula at the beginning of his first real vacation in thirty years of acting. He said that he and Mrs. Muni hoped to be vagabonds for at least six months, with no purpose in mind except a desperate determination to escape totally from acting, "talking shop" and being "on parade."

Christians need a definite plan to prevent inroads on the observance of the Lord's Day, which must be strictly observed to preserve the foundation of the church, the Rev. Dr. Harry L. Bowlby, general secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance, told the Presbyterian Synod here today.

It doesn't look right and possibly there have been typographical errors, but, anyway, there it is in the record as bold and plain as type can make it. Listed among the handful of teams in the East that have won all of their games to date are none other than Lafayette and Rutgers.

Coach Andy Kerr put Colgate's Red Raiders on defense tonight against plays that, it is believed, will be used here Saturday by Duke in the annual homecoming day game. Eddie Van Orden and Eddie Wilson. sophomore backs, impersonated Honey Hackney and Eric Tipton, Duke stars.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew will give a dinner dance on Nov. 26 at the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society Mrs. Loew's daughter, Miss Catherine Dodge Rogers. Wolmar Bostrom, the Swedish Minister, and Mrs. Bostrom have come from Washington to the RitzCarlton.

The discovery beside Kensico Lake today of the automobile and clothing of Maurice E. Lasser, New York security dealer, caused police to drag the lake, but after six hours the search was abandoned until tomorrow. Mr. Lasser is a member

Brown's varsity eleven again went against the freshmen, equipped with Columbia offensive and defensive plays, in a scrimmage today. Charles Blount and Irving Hall looked particularly good for the big team, turning in long runs. The varsity and freshmen each scored twice.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman appealed over a State-wide radio network last night for the election of Democratic delegates to the coming State Constitutional Convention on the ground that the Democratic party has proved, over a period of rears, that it is the real friend of progressive and humane legislation for the people of the State.

Norman Taurog was named by Universal today as director of Deanna Durbin's next Universal epic, "Mad About Music." Taurog recently completed "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" at Selznick International, and is regarded by Hollywood as an outstanding director of youthful players, his work with them dating back to "Skippy,"

Milton Herndon, Negro member of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, was killed in the Loyalist attack on Saragossa Saturday, according to a cabled report received here yesterday by the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, 125 West Fortyfifth Street.
The Japanese armies in North China are nearing the Yellow River. It has been supposed for some time that they will not advance beyond this stream, the natural boundary of North China.

Beginning Oct. 25, the insuring office of the FHA which now is located at 122 East Forty-second Street will function in the new Federal Building, which occupies the block bounded by Vesey, Barclay and Church Streets and West Broadway, Manhattan, according to Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the Federal Housing Administration.

The Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate joined battle with Major La Guardia yesterday when tey began restoring the positions of sixty-five county office-holders whose jobs the Mayor had cut out of the 1938 budget.

While the second team developed a defense against Yale plays put on by the scrubs, Cornell's varsity warriors, with line-up shifts after virtually every play, staged a long scrimmage on offense against the freshman squad today.

Five witnesses, one of them a 14-year-old boy, testified in Oyer and Terminer Court here today to having seen the "woman in red" flee the Iselin (N. J.) home of Paul Reeves, 25-year-old father of two children, the day of his murder.

The Citizens Union, making public yesterday its recommendations to the voters on candidates for the principal offices to be filled on election day, endorsed Mayor La Guardia, Joseph D. McGoldrick for Controller, Newbold Morris for President of the City Council, and Thomas E. Dewey for District Attorney of New York County.

Walter S. Jardine, at one time one of the "twenty men who ran Omaha," died today. He was 80 years old. Crippled since he was 2 years old, Mr. Jardine only last Monday morning expressed a desire to have his crutches buried with him.

In preparation for the opening of the Lincoln Tunnel between West Thirty-eighth Street and Weehawken, N. J., set for Dec. 22, 130 newly appointed traffic policemen will be sworn in at 11 o'clock this morning, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.
Following is the text of the pastoral letter adopted today by the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States:

Expressing complete confidence in his re-election, Mayor La Guardia declared last night that the Mahoney labor meeting Monday evening, which was addressed by Senator Robert F. Wagner, was a fake and attended only by men dragged from the back rooms of Tammany clubhouses, without one respectable, bona fide labor leader.

THE new Louis Bromfield novel about India* might have been a major novel. It turns out not to be because Mr. Bromfield, after two long and obviously intelligent periods of study of that country, chose to convert his impressions into what becomes at the end a love story, with most of the conventional effects thereunto appertaining.

Acting, he said, against his own judgment, Attorney General David T. Wilentz today appointed Warren Dixon Jr. a special assistant attorney general to present to the Essex County grand jury allegations of criminality resulting from the Supreme Court investigation of Newarks last administration.

The birth rate continued low and the infant mortality rate rose sharply in the week ended Saturday, Oct. 16, Dr. John L. Rice, Health commissioner, reported yesterday. The birth rate was 13.5 per 1,000 population, with 1,923 births reported.

Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was the same as in the preceding week, the total was well below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings published in THE TIMES. The number was again 833 for the week and 1,042 in the same period last year. Buyers reported in town yesterday totaled 383, which compared with 362 listed last Tuesday.

Liquidation of the Cliftona Print and Dye Works, Inc., of Clifton was ordered here today by Federal Court Judge Guy L. Fake on application of the company's attorney, William H. Osborne, who stated that an effort to reorganize the firm had failed.

Being in the publishing business is "very interesting and lots of fun," even though problems of distribution, make-up, deadlines, circulation and format harasa the editors, the three young grandchildren of Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis admitted cheerfully yesterday in recounting their experience in editing a newspaper.
William Fanshawe White of Shrewsbury, N. J., entertained at luncheon in the Colonial Room of the Homestead today for Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Moreland and Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hicks Kerr.
Walter Peer, one of the last of the old Morris Canal boat captains, died at his home here today after an illness of two weeks. He was 91 years old.

Airegla, owned by Miss Mollie Cullum, tossed mud at four other juvenile fillies and won the Bolivar Purse with speed in reserve today. Showing a liking for the sloppy track and forgetting to quit, the Bubbling Over filly came to the wire three and a half lengths in advance of W. S. Kilmer's Sun Flo.
The Red Cross gave advice today to hunters. "Hunting accidents," said Vice Chairman James L. Feiser, "caused 2,000 deaths in 1936." His recommendations are as follows:

New models of Chrysler, Dodge, De Soto and Plymouth automobiles, details of some of which have already been made public, were displayed yesterday at a sort of prepreview for newspaper men at the Chrysler Salon at -Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Walter D. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company, will address some 500 office managers at the opening session of a two-day conference sponsored by the American Management Association at the Hotel Astor tomorrow, devoted to study of office organization, methods, personnel practices and environmental influences.

A few sales of copper were made yesterday in the export market at 11.50 to 11.52 cents, c. i. f., European base ports. However, they did not reflect the full drop on London Metal Exchange, where quotations were equivalent to 10.84 cents a pound. On Monday, sales in the export market were made at 11.62 cents.

Declaring his belie that United States Senator William E. Borah of Idaho was incompletely informed when he voiced his objection to the proposed pre-convention meeting of Republicans, former President Herbert Hoover issued a statement yesterday restating his reasons for supporting the movement.

Work in carrying out blocking assignments and other individual duties was ordered for the Syracuse squad by Coach Ossie Solem today as the Orange prepared for its next opponent, Maryland, which will be met at Baltimore on Saturday.

Sir John Timpson, Mayor of Portsmouth from 1918 to 1921, died today. He was 74. Sir John was director of several transport companies and governor of Royal Portsmouth Hospital. He was knighted in 1922.

A discovery by "an amateur on adhesives," Benjamin K. Albrecht, 59 years old, an "unemployed" resident of Rowayton, Conn., has made possible the commercial use of copper sheets as wall decoration in the board of directors' room of the New York World's Fair of 1939 in the Administration Building at Flushing Meadow Park, it was reported yesterday by the fair corporation.
The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce will begin tomorrow at 10 A. M. an investigation of railroad reorganizations now pending before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

With London buying American dollars yesterday when British investors came into the market here as purchasers of stocks in the early afternoon, sterling sold off 5-16 cent. At a close of $4.951/2, the pound was slightly under the best price of the day.
Funeral services will be held at the Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md., on Thursday morning for Rear Admiral Nobel E: Irwin, U.S.N. (retired), who died at Warm Springs, Calif., Oct. 10.
Disclosure of the execution of twentyfour anti-Soviet terrorists today raised to 462 the known dead toll in five months for sabotage and espionage.

A seven-room residence of FrenchNormandy- design on Mercer Avenue in the Manor Woods section of Hartsdale, Westchester County, was purchased by a client of Myron L. Blum Co., broker in the sale. Earl W. Corman was the seller.

The International Longshoremen's Association asked the coastwise ship lines operating from North Atlantic ports to increase wages of pier workers by ten and fifteen cents an hour at a conference yesterday at 80 Broad Street. The lines asked for a few days in which to reply.

While business failures increased in three business groups, in the week ended Oct. 14, compared with the corresponding period last year, two other divisions, wholesale and commercial service, showed declines, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. The detailed report is as follows:

The Amherst football squad today began serious preparation for the first real test of its season, the game with Wesleyan on Saturday. Coach Jordan drove his charges through a strenuous hour of scrimmage on Pratt Field.
Bonds tumbled yesterday to new low levels on the New York Stock Exchange in the heaviest trading in the listed market in more than seven months.
Within twenty-four hours after the resignation of Governor Jose Antonio Flores da Cunha of Rio Grande do Sul, President Getulio Vargas decreed Federal intervention for that State.
John E. Miller, who will step into the Senate seat of Joseph T. Robinson Nov. 15, emphasized today that he was unbiased and unpledged with respect to the Roosevelt program.

Declaring that what President Roosevelt needs is less rather than more power, former Governor Alf M. Landon told a nation-wide radio audience tonight that the President's "readiness to assume the responsibility of a one-man government in international affairs is far more dangerous than the same tendencies in dealing with domestic matters."

Justice Swift, who received his knighthood in 1920, the year of his elevation to the King's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice, had previously been a very successful legal practitioner for many years, and from 1910 to 1918 a Conservative member of Parliament from St. Helens, his birthplace. He was a son of the late Thomas Swift, barrister.

The glass-brick idea seems to be spreading. Another structure utilizing this type of exterior soon will rise in lower Manhattan. It will be a six-story building for the site at 16 Desbrosses Street and 119-21 Watts Street, near Canal Street. The new structure will

The American Newspaper Publishers Association issued a statement last night denouncing the announced intention of major Canadian newsprint manufacturers to demand a price for their product $2 above the $48 per ton six months' price of the Great Northern Paper Company.

Princeton University's freshman soccer team, playing in a heavy downpour, broke into the winning column today for the first time this season by turning back Pennington Central High School, 6-0. Center Forward Bob Ewing paced the Tiger offensive with a pair of tallies, with Jim Hill giving a splendid performance as the schoolboy goalie.

Surrogate James A. Foley in a decision yesterday confirmed the report of Referee John Godfrey Saxe that the attorneys in the estate of Mrs. Rebecca A. D. Wendel Swope be paid $270,000 for their legal services.

With three line regulars excused from practice because of minor allments, Columbia's football squad was sent through a long offensive drill in the rain against the Brown defense at Baker Field yesterday. Lou Little expects all three incapacitated players to be in the lineup when the Lions meet the Bruins on Saturday at Baker Field.

The annual dinner of the Queens North Shore Chapter of the Long Island Real Estate Board will be held tonight at the North Hills Golf Club, Douglaston, L. I. Speakers will include George U. Harvey, borough president of Queens, and Frank S. O'Hara, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York. John J. Halleran will preside.

The five-and-a-half-story apartment house at 1,934 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Northbro Realty Corporation, William L. Rosan, president, to the Shafecraus Realty Corporation, Bernard Crausman, president. It contains 113 rooms and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $99,000. Robert E. Hill, Inc., and Max Weinstein were the brokers in the deal.

Quincy Howe, author of "England Expects Every American to Do His Duty" (Simon Shuster), and Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington correspondent for The Times of London, will debate the question of "Does England Expect Every American to Do His Duty?" at a luncheon to be sponsored by the Association of Foreign Correspondents at the Hotel Astor on Oct. 30.
Stocks rebounded and closed stronger after sharp decline at the opening; turnover, 7,287,990 shares, largest since July, 1933. All classes of bonds weakened; transactions. $20.770.900.

Weakness in the foreign markets and in securities caused a break of more than 3 cents a bushel in wheat in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, but the selling was not particularly aggressive and buying by houses that frequently act for cash and export interests absorbed

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19.--Hailed as one of the most successful and enthusiastic gatherings in the long history of the church, the fifty-second triennial general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States came to a close here this afternoon.

Tony Lazzeri, veteran Yankee second baseman, was given his unconditional release at the suggestion of the Chicago Cubs, according to an official announcement yesterday by Ed Barrow, secretary of the New York club.

Vyse Ave (11-2995), e s, 100 ft s of 172d St, 50x100; Ruth Schoen to Dorsam Properties Corp, 1,488 Vyse Ave; mtg, $36,000. Fenton Ave, 3,362 (16-4738); Cohoes Savings Bank to Louis Galatioto, 4,318 DeReimer Ave. Lurting Ave, 1,634 (15-4105); Banton Moore to Stephen J. McNamara, 163 W 171st St.
Relief from the high prices of beef and pork was promised today by the Department of Agriculture, but the relief will not come until early next year.
Lieut. Col. Thornton Rogers, retired, died last night at Walter Reed General Hospital here, the War Department was advised this morning. He was born at Relay, Md., Jan. 19, 1876.

Before a group of Republicanendorsed candidates for city offices, Mrs. Harold C. Mathews, chairman of the Republican Committee of One Hundred, said yesterday afternoon that she was "not fond of either of the Mayoralty candidates."
For the first time-in its history, the town of Oyster Bay will have no' tac rate, it was 'announced' to day at a special meeting of the Town Board at which the 1938 budget was adopted.
The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation reported yesterday that its net assets were $42,128,600 on Sept. 30, or about $200 a share on 210,000 shares of first preferred stock.
