Although Andrew Ponzi defeated Joe Procita, 125 to 87, in fourteen innings, in the fourth block of their pocket billiard match at the Strand Academy last night, he lost ground to his rival in the day's play, the latter having won the afternoon session, 125 to 39, in ten innings. Ponzi still leads, 414 to 376, with two blocks to go.

An application has been made to the Securities and Exchange Commission by trustees of the Public Utilities Securities Corporation and the trustee of the Webster Securities Corporation for a report on a plan of reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation for the purpose of soliciting assents to the plan. The date for a hearing has not been set.

Nine men and three corporations became defendants in Special Sessions yesterday following the filing of informations ordered by the New York County grand jury in an investigation into charges that second-hand watches are being sold in various parts of the city as new goods.
Reims Cathedral, unlike Louvain Library, comes back without undue emphasis on its diruta in the World War, but chiefly on its restituta since the armistice.

William J. Fox, president of Long's, Inc., owners of a chain of men's retail clothing stores, died yesterday at his home, 290 West End Avenue, after a three months' illness of heart disease. He was born in this city fifty-six years ago.
Production of crude petroleum from Canadian wells showed a gain of over 55 per cent during the first half of the current year. The increase was principally due to a higher output in Alberta.
After a meeting this morning the Italian Cabinet announced a 10 per cent extraordinary capital levy on all stock companies and an increase in the sales tax from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent.
In the hullabaloo about spies, traitors and sabotage the Russians themselves seem not to realize the speed which mechanization is developing in this country.

In many matters the Supreme Court deliberately leaves the public uninformed or tells a tale by inference instead of directly. This procedure is an outgrowth of the natural dignity of a high court and the dignity its members inevitably acquire with black robes,

The State of Mississippi has authorized the sale of a new issue of $2,150,000 of highway notes. The issue is to be dated Oct. 1, 1937. and will mature serially on Oct. 1, 1938 to 1955. The exact date of the sale was not announced, but is expected to be soon.

Dr. John Napoleon Brintoh Hewitt, linguist and ethnologist for the Bureau of American Ethnology of the Smithsonian Institution, died of a bronchial attack Thursday at the age of 77. Although far from well

Satisfied with the way the "twoteam" system worked against Philadelphia, Coach Steve Owen of the New York Football Giants plans to continue the idea of using alternate elevens against the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds Sunday.

Eliminating $16,394 from proposed salary restorations for school teachers despite remonstrances from the Board of Education, the White Plains City Council adopted last night a 1938 municipal budget of $4,233,648. This is an increase of about $200,000 over 1937 expenditures,

An order has been issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission revoking the registration of Jesse Hyman and Seymour Klein, doing business as Jesse Hyman Co., 29 Broadway, New York, as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market.

Thirty thousand Armenian residents of Syria and Lebanon addressed today a petition to the Syrian Government demanding the death penalty for Meguerdich Karayan, accused of slaying United States Consul General James Theodore Marriner.

MANHATTAN GRISWOLD, JOSEPHINE H. (Sept. 29). Estate, more than $10,000. To the Salvation Army, $10,000; Louis Gillett. employe, 783 Park Ave., $10,000, Michael Canfield, adopted grandchild; Cass Canfield Jr., Laura C. Wood, John C. Wood, William L. Wood Jr., grandchildren, all of 783 Park Ave., $10,000 each: three
One of the National Socialists' principal charges during their fight for power was that "Jews and Marxists had taken control of the government and undermined the whole governmental bureaucracy."
Navy worked in the rain today as it began special preparations for the game with Notre Dame in South Bend next Saturday. The squad shifted from its usual practice field to firmer ground near by.

Mrs. Jennie Dodes of 142 West Forty-sixth Street arrived yesterday in -Supreme Court twenty minutes late for the trial of a damage action in which she is a juror. Summoned before the bench by Justice Peter J. Schmuck, she said she was very sorry for her tardiness and explained that she had been detained at the bedside of her daughter, who was about to become a mother.

An elevated express on the Third Avenue line swayed' southward out of the 125th Street station shortly before 9 o'clock yesterday morning and a young woman passenger, looking up at a standee who had just got on, laughed.
British markets in both stocks and commodities weakened today while puzzled "experts" tried to gauge the effect that the latest Wall Street recessions may have here.

A first mortgage loan of $100,000 on the recently completed six-story apartment house at 2,977 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, has been arranged by Ivor B. Clark. Inc., with a life insurance company for the 2,977 Bainbridge Avenue Corporation, Louis Minoff, president. The loan will run for ten years, with interest of 5 and 4 1/2 per cent.

Trading was slow on most classes of locally dressed meat yesterday. Lamb and fresh pork cuts were lower and veal and calf hindsaddles weak to lower. Some steer cuts were sharply lower but the bulk held steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and veal to be about steady, calf weak, lamb lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Queena Mario, Metropolitan Opera soprano, sang Strauss waltzes here tonight at a benefit for the fiveman police department of North Castle, and thereby fulfilled herpart of a bargain with a motor cycle patrolman who was on the verge of giving her a ticket for speeding in North Castle three days ago.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $322,195 after preferred dividends and provision for Federal taxes, including the undistributed profits surtax. This was equal to 66 cents on each share of common stock.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 19.--Searchers reached the crumpled Mainliner high in the Uinta Mountains and reported this morning all nineteen occupants of the luxurious United Air Lines plane dead.
Despite a steady rain, 7,500 persons crowded the Mineola Fair Grounds here tonight to take part in an old fashioned rally staged by the Republican party of Nassau County.

While there are no penalties for passing on the 3 per cent tax on foreign shipments into Mexico to the buyer there, private contracts stipulating payment by the buyer do not relieve the shipper of primary responsibility. Henry Paine Crawford of the division of commercial law of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce said yesterday at a meeting of the Export Managers Club

Mayor La Guardia threw a switch yesterday morning that put the new incinerator at Fifty-sixth Street and the Hudson River in operation on current generated by its own heat. Heretofore the city has had to buy current from the Consolidated Edison System for its needs at the plant.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals denied today an appeal of the National Labor Relations Board, seeking an order requiring the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company to reinstate five men who lost their jobs as a result of the 1935 strike.
Mrs. Kate E. Bradshaw, who had been a public school teacher for sixty-three years until her retirement last year, died today at the age of 83.
Major Frederic McLaughlin and his estranged wife, Mrs. Irene Castle McLaughlin, watched a fire together last night at the McLaughlin suburban estate in Lake Forest.

Mrs. Frederick A. Tyler of Albany has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Miriam Tyler Doty of this city, to Bayard Boyd Webb of Mountain Lakes, N. J., son of Mrs. George C. Webb of Fulton, N. Y., and the late Mr. Webb.
Howard H. Banker retired on Oct. 16 from Charles E. Quincey Co. William Post Haring Jr. and Frank K. Sturges have proposed retirement from Lawrence Turnure Co. on Nov. 1.

Judge Charles Harwood fined Edward Gormely, American canal employee, $200 and sentenced him to one year in jail upon Gormely's plea of guilty, to a charge of involuntary manslaughter in the District Court at Ancon today.

The Fahnestock-South Seas expedition that cruised the South Pacific in the 65-foot schooner Director for two and one-half years colelecting specimens for the American Museum of Natural History, arrived yesterday on the liner President Lincoln after adventures suggestive of a tale by Conrad.

The marriage of Miss Peggy Anne Kauffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lee Kauffman, to William Charles Blind, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Alfred Blind of Westfield, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. 911 Park Avenue.

Brazil has established as part of her new state-of-war regime one of the most efficient censorships ever devised in South America. It not only prevents the egress of any news except what the government wants to let out but also establishes close control over all business and private mail entering or leaving the country.

The names of Albert Marinelli and James J. Hines were used last night by Samuel Seabury as representing two Tammany Hall powers opposed to each other but united in their fight to prevent the election of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey as District Attorney.

The charge that Thomas E. Dewey obtained the endorsement of labor organizations by favors to the radical elements within them was made last night by Harold W. Hastings, Democratic candidate for District Attorney of New York County, at a meeting of candidates at the American Woman's Association, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.
A general decline in activity of the cotton spinning industry during September compared with August and September last year was shown today in official reports by .the Census Bureau.

An exceptionally large volume of business developed yesterday in the export copper market at prices ranging from 10.84 to 11.06 cents a pound c.i.f. the European base ports. The best prices were obtained in the late trading.

Maude Adams, the Peter Pan of yesteryear, drew from an old French book on acting today to tell how she feels at 64 about the theatre. "It is the mission of all art," she said, "to refine and cultivate the instincts and the emotions."

Beginning an investigation of plans for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce sought today to show that pressure had been brought to delay the filing of the audit report of the railroad made in 1933 and 1934 by Price, Waterhouse Co. Price,

The program of price maintenance initiated by the New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association at its inception eight months ago has now reached a point where price cutting among wholesalers has virtually been eliminated in this area, Thomas Barclay of Argenti Co., Inc., president, declared following a meeting of the association at its headquarters, 300 Fourth Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

Robert H. Jackson, assistant attorney general, today offered to debate with Frank E. Gannett, Rochester publisher, on the proposition: "Was President Roosevelt justified in sending his court proposal to Congress?"

Dr. Thomas Outerbridge celebrated his ninetieth birthday today and Bermudians are wondering if he can't claim two records-one, as the oldest legislator in the British Empire and possibly the world, and, two, for the lengthiest legislative service.

Mid-morning gains were lost in later trading on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. Prices moved over a range of 11 points in a quiet market, with the opening and closing within a few points either way of Tuesday's final quotations.

The four-story apartment house on the northeast corner of Ocean and Newkirk Aves., Brooklyn, known as 1,001 Ocean Ave., has been sold by the Dale Management Corporation to Fannie Greenberg. The structure contains twentythree apartments and stands on a plot 90 by 121 by 131 by irregular feet.

William C. Kurrle, assistant cashier of the First National Bank, was held tonight for lack of $25,000 bail on State and Federal charges of embezzling $400,000. The deficit forced the closing of the bank today.

Expressions of regret at the death of Felix M. Warburg were made public yesterday here and abroad by statesmen, civil leaders, financiers and philanthropists, who gave spontaneous testimony of his position in the world. Among them were the following:
No news has been received here for four days regarding the fighting at Niangtzekwan, the main pass in the mountains between Hopeh and Shansi Provinces in North China.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, seeking re-election on the Democratic ticket, was criticized last night by Samuel Untermyer and the National Lawyers Guild. Mr. Untermyer's criticism was voiced at a rally in Hunts Point Palace. the Bronx. The lawyers'
In a long offensive scrimmage held by Lehigh today, Ed Bradway and Hulme Thomas were at tackle and guard, respectively.

Five hundred persons attended the first ski meeting of the season last night in the Wanamaker Auditorium as preparations for the Winter got under way. It was announced that a New York Chapter of the Gore Mountain Ski Club had been organized.

MANHATTAN CARNELSON, HERMAN (July 12). Estate, more than $10,000. To Ida Carnelson, widow, executrix, 425 Riverside Dr., life estate in residue. EMMET, GRENVILLE TEMPLE (Sept. 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To Pauline Anne Temple Emmet, Elizabeth Patricia Emmet, daughters,...

Mrs. Martha D. Hinchman Turner, mother of Dr. John Roscoe Turner, Dean of Men at the College of the City of New York, died yesterday after a three-month illness at the home of her, daughter Mrs. J. W. Mankin, in Washington, D. C. Her age was 90.

Well-informed political circles learn that German Ambassador Franz Von Papen will leave for another post. Rome has been suggested. The date of his departure cannot yet be fixed owing to the difficulty of appointing a successor to him.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $10,013,033, equal to $1.11 a share on 9,000,743 shares. This compared with $10,505,740, or $1.17 a share, in the second quarter; $9,947,712, or $1.11 a share, in the first quarter, and $8,111,897, or 90 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1936.

Mrs. Esther Jacobsohn Romaine, a teacher in the public school system for thirty-five years, died Tuesday night in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 59 years old. At her death Mrs. Romaine was on the faculty of Public School 42, Belle Harbor, Queens.

Henry Graff Trevor, sportsman, of 823 Park Avenue, died yesterday morning in the New York Hospital after an illness of eight weeks at the age of 72. He was the son of John B. Trevor, financier, and the former Louisa Stewart, daughter of Lispenard Stewart.

Army's Plebe football eleven was turned back, 6 to 0, by Williamsport Dickinson Seminary on Howze Field today. The gridiron was deep in mud, but the rain stopped half an hour before game time and a big crowd turned out to see the schoolboys push over a touchdown in the first period after a drive from midfield Cordisco,

Samuel Larcombe, internationally known grain grower and winner of the title of world wheat king in 1917, died in a hospital here tonight at the age of 86. Mr. Larcombe was injured by a fall several days ago, and his injuries developed into pneumonia.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society will open its ninety-sixth season at Carnegie Hall tonight with John Barbirolli conducting the orchestra. The program will include Berlioz's "Benvenuto Cellini" overture, Beethoven's Seventh symphony, Mr. Barbirolli's arrangement of a new suite of Purcell music, Balakireff's symphonic poem, "Thamar," and the prelude to "Die Meistersinger."
The Wesleyan football squad practiced on a wet field today in preparation for Saturday's game at Amherst. The second team used Amherst plays against the varsity, Seybolt carrying the ball.

George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor and chairman of the A. F. of L. Non-Partisan Committee for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia, declared last night that organized labor was supporting Mr. La Guardia because he was the first Mayor of New York City who ever had given labor a square deal.
In the second day's trading after the Wall Street slump the London stock market held fairly steady today while traders continued to exhibit extreme caution.

As Norman H. Davis, Ambassador at Large, today set sail for Brussels with his interesting and able associates he made a remark which should fill with admiration even the most astute practitioners of Oriental diplomacy.

Retail package deliveries showed an increase of 11 per cent for the week ended Oct. 16, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The week included the heavy business done by the stores here on Columbus Day.

Yale's mid-week scrimmage today was curtailed to an hour and was limited to supervised drill in which heavy tackling was omitted. Head Coach Ducky Pond worked the squad in rain which was times heavy, while the wind blew hard.

Sharon Steel Corporation fifteenyear 4 1/2 per cent convertible debentures due on March 1, 1951, which were suspended from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange on Oct. 13 after having been called for redemption, have been stricken from listing and registration by the Exchange.

Space has been leased by Charles Counes, who operates a chain of confectionery stores in Manhattan and the Bronx, for a fifth unit at 11 East Forty-ninth Street. The entire ground floor will be occupied, after alterations which will provide room to seat about 100 persons at tables.
The text of President Roosevelt's address at the official opening of the Federal Reserve Building today was is follows:

Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein made public yesterday an open letter he has sent to Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker of New Jersey, objecting to the latter's charge to the Essex County Grand Jury last week as preventing a "fair, impartial and unprejudiced" investigation of accusations against him and other city officials, and asking that a copy of the letter be given to each juror.

Selection of a model for a monument to the memory of Father Isaac Jogues, to be erected on State land at Fort George Park, Lake George, today narrowed down to two of the ten submitted. Father Jogues, discoverer of the lake, was slain by Indians nearly 300 years ago.

Johnny Blood, player-coach of the Pirates, and Gaynell Tinsley, former L. S. U. star, now with the Cardinals, are tied for the leadership in scoring in the National Football League statistics released yesterday. Both have tallied 30 points.

The elimination of the center jump after each basket as recommended by the Rules Committee last Spring was the major change adopted by the National Basketball Committee of the United States and Canada, according to the 1937-38 rules contained in Spalding's Official Basketball Guide, which was released yesterday. Oswald Tower,

Jimmy Wehrell, sophomore from Midland Park, N. J., ran at right halfback for Colgate's Red Raiders today as Coach Andy Kerr sent the team through a scrimmage against the freshmen to prepare it for the intersectional clash with Duke here Saturday.
Three members of the English Wightman Cup team that bowed to the United States women players at Forest Hills last August sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

The Rev. Dr. Orlin O. Fletcher, clerygyman and educator, died yesterday after a short illness at the home of his daughter, Mrs. R. L. Lee, at 1,097 Prospect Place, Brook lyn. Dr. Fletcher was a Baptist minister and formerly Professor of Philosophy and Political Science at Furman University.

Alleging various misrepresentations, including one that investors might earn up to 100,000 per cent, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that it had filed a bill of complaint in the Federal Court for the Northern District of Illinois seeking permanently to enjoin six individuals from the sale of securities of the Westcoast Minerals Company, Ltd., and the Mineral Trust Estate.

The Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound will hold its annual meeting on Oct. 29 and the North American Yacht Racing Union will meet on Nov. 19, both at the Yale Club, it was announced yesterday.

The annual award of academic honors at Tufts College took place today in Goddard Chapel before the student body and faculty of Tufts and Jackson. The acting president of the college, George S. Miller, made the presentations, prefacing the awards with a brief message.

John A. Hughes of Chelsea, Mass., who three years ago was a guest aboard the Mistress, an auxiliary schooner owned by George Emlen Roosevelt, yesterday asked his host to pay him $50,000 for injuries which he alleges he sustained in an accident on the yacht.

The proposed ordinance providing for the licensing of meat packers and dealers and for the mandatory grading of meat advanced a step nearer reality yesterday when the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers, which previously had expressed opposition to such a measure, withdrew its objections during a discussion with William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets.

In an effort to prove that charges of radicalism made against Mayor La Guardia are "utterly unfounded," a group of men and women prominent in social, financial and educational circles yesterday opened headquarters at the Royalton Hotel in West Forty-fourth Street to aid in the Mayor's reelection.

Frank J. Ryan, oil royalty operator who has announced plans to challenge the eligibility of Associate Justice Hugo L. Black in a Supreme Court case, was arrested today on a charge of selling securities not registered with Florida's Commission

Tony Lazzeri late of the world champion Yankees, may wind up as a first lieutenant to Philip K. Wrigley, owner of the Cubs. Owner Wrigley, talking today of his desire to move Lazzeri into the organization, was indefinite on just which spot the former Yankee would fill in the ranks.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 20.---The Palestine Government today promulgated an ordinance restricting Jewish immigration in the sense that it abolishes the principle of immigration based on the economic absorptive capacity of the country.

John J. Cavanagh, restaurant man, was elected president of the Twentythird Street Association yesterday at the annual meeting at the Hotel George Washington, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street. 'He had been serving since last June, after the death of Dr. Paul H. Fairchild.

LONDON, Oct. 20.--Last-minute concessions by Italy and Germany today broke the long deadlock in the Non-Intervention Committee on Spain, with the result that the diplomatic atmosphere improved as if by magio and faces were saved all around.
Mayor La Guardia's 1938 executive budget of $589,222,376 was increased by the Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate yesterday by $764,643.

President Roosevelt has wisely refrained from following the advice of those who would have him pull another rabbit from the hat which produced so many rabbits during his first Administration. His address yesterday at the ceremonies dedicating the new Federal Reserve Building in Washington hinted at no change in the Government's present monetary policies.

The Federal Reserve Bank's monthly report on department store sales in this region in the first half of October, which was issued yesterday, seemed to indicate that retail business has not suffered the severe set-back that is being shown in industry.
Larry Kelley, the Yale All-American who rejected a handsome National Football League offer. several months ago, today agreed to be a commuting end for the Boston Shamrocks of the American League.

The marriage of Miss Alice Louise Goodwin, daughter of Mrs. Clifford Coddington Goodwin of Arrochar, S. I., and the late Mr. Goodwin, to Hendrik Willem Fredrik Reitmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. van Vleuten Reitmeyer of Edmond ad Hoen, the Netherlands, took place yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church, Clifton, S. I. The Rev. Dr.

John R. Lots has been elected president of the Stone Webster Engineering Corporation, succeeding James H. Manning, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Lotz, who has been with the Stone Webster organization thirty years, has been executive vice president of the engineering division for seven years.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 19 unless specified: At Norfolk Yard, Blue, Gridley. Badger, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to to New York Yard. Oct. 20. Bobolink, at San Pedro.

Harvard's three football teams hardly could see one another through the rain today, but the preparation for Saturday's game here with Dartmouth went on. I was very dark before Coach Dich Harlow sent the players to the showers, but there would have beer more work had there been any lights on Soldiers Field.

Joseph F. Abbott, who has been president of the American Sugar Refining Company since 1929, was appointed yesterday chief executive officer of that company, it was announced by Earl D. Babst, chairman.

The advice sent to 150 stores to reduce inventories by John Block, head of Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, on Tuesday, brought sharp criticism yesterday from executives of trade associations in the dress and coat fields.

Columbia's football squad, garbed in waterproof uniforms, ran, slid and wallowed on rain-soaked Baker Field for three hours yesterday rehearsing its offensive and Aefensive play. The Lions are preparing to meet Brown on Saturday at Baker Field in their fourth contest of the current campaign.

Wallace Ave, 2,231, (16-4345), Camer Realty Corp to Victoria Friedman, 829 Adee Ave. Hazel St, (16-4756), w s 100 n of Syracuse Ave, 75x100; Anna Taylor to America Turbota Corp. 3,209 Ely Ave. Fteley Ave, (14-3780), w s 242 s of 172d St, 28x100; Henry G. McDonough, Referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

The two-family colonial dwelling at 35-18 149th Street, Flushing, has been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank of New York to Edward Spooner for occupancy. The house contains two six-room apartments with sun porches on a 50 by 100 foot plot, upon which there also is a two-car garage.

Complaints by laymen that stock market prices have suffered because of a system "which requires 55 per cent margins for purchases and only 10 points for short sales" have aroused much amusement in Wall Street.

Mayor La Guardia estimated the amount of graft and extortion under the Markets Department before he took office at $25,000,000 a year yesterday and invited his Democratic rival, Jeremiah T.' Mahoney, to figure the exact amount involved.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 3 per cent for the thirteen shopping days from Oct. 1 to 15, in comparison with the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

While attendance at the show has been held down by the stock market and two days of rain, exhibitors agreed that the interest shown in various new devices and improvements on established equipment has held up well and a higher percentage of those attending have been prospective buyers than was the case a year ago.

Amenaments to its rules relating to exemption of certain types of security issues where the aggregate offering price does not exceed $100,000 from registration under the provisions of the Securities Act of 1933 were announced today by the SEC.

Felix M. Warburg, financier, and champion of many philanthropic causes, died yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 66. He was stricken at 4 A. M. last Monday in his home at 1,109 Fifth Avenue, but his illness at first was not regarded as serious.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, answered yesterday the charge of Mayor La Guardia that the Democratic labor rally at Cooper Union on Monday was a "fake" labor meeting, by listing twenty-one labor unions represented and eighty-two labor union officials who took part in the meeting.

The Republican and Democratic Gubernatorial candidates advanced their campaigns today, with United States Senator A. Harry Moore, standard bearer of the Democrats, concentrating on Atlantic County while State Senator Lester H. Clee, his Republican opponent, toured Passaic County.

Miss Mary Burges Bristow gave a luncheon yesterday at the Cafe Continental for members of the junior committee, of which she is chairman, for the performance of Mozart's comic opera, "Cosi Fan Tutte," by the Salzburg Opera Guild on Nov. 6 at the Majestic Theatre in aid of the Community of St. Johnland.

change here reacted briskly today to the new tax measures approved yesterday by the Cabinet. Gains of 1 to 10 points were registered in almost all groups, excepting State bonds which, nevertheless, remained firm.
Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to Great Britain,. sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after spending six weeks here.

Pressure exerted at economically propitious times by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O. brought to steel workers higher real earnings than ever before in the history of that industry. according to a report today by the industrial relations section of Princeton University.

Mary Munn, blind Canadian pianist, gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall last night. She has just returned from a European tour.. She received her early training in Montreal, and then studied at the Royal Academy of Music in London. Last night's audience was friendly.

Engineer Colonel Norbert Champsaur, Air Attache at the French Embassy in Washington, and Mrs. Champsaur; General Frank Parker, U.S.A., and Mrs. Parker; Albin Johnson and Salvatore Capodice are passengers due today from Europe on the French liner Champlain.

The Salzburg Opera Guild will begin its week's run of opera on Nov. 6 at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, and not at the Alvin Theatre as originally announced. Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte" will be presented the opening night.

Pennsylvania's varsity, which plays Georgetown here Saturday, scrimmaged with the junior varsity for more than an hour on River Field today, using its revamped backfield, and showing general improvement.

Developments of the past few days have indicated that Mayor La Guardia has made substantial gains over Jeremiah T. Mahoney, his Democratic opponent, or more probably have made it clearer that the Mayor has even greater strength among the great mass of the voters than had been supposed.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation attributed today to a "lack of sufficient funds" its inability to construct more rural electrification lines in the twenty-eight up-State counties which it serves.

Fordham's football players worked out in their stocking feet yesterday. The idea had nothing to do with any new strategy planned by Sleepy Jim Crowley to repel the invaders from the Southwest on Saturday. It was forced on the players by the weather.

Mr. and Mrs. John Winfree West of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Anne West, to Robert Nelson Davie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Davie of Norfolk, Va. Miss West was graduated this year from the Scudder School in New York.

Height Profitt, a young trapper in Northeastern Utah, told today that he saw the United Air Lines' twenty-one-passenger "Mainliner" barely miss towering pines in his backyard Sunday night during a blizzard, watched the craft's lights vanish in the storm, then heard it plow into a granite ridge.
They've come across a sport up in British Columbia which is attracting new devotees every dayfishing for six to twelve pound cohoe salmon with a fly in the open sea.

Seven retail watch dealers were arrested yesterday on Special Sessions warrants in the investigation by Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson of the so-called counterfeit watch racket. It is alleged old timepieces were refurbished and sold as new.

With the price of scrap steel soaring as a result of the armament race in Europe and the Far East, the city government has realized $427,241 in the last two years from the sale of old surface-car tracks taken up by the WPA.

Sir Hubert Wilkins said last night that he would leave "some time Friday" on his second flight in search of the six Russian fliers lost Aug. 12 in the wastes north of Point Barrow, Alaska, in an attempt to hop from Moscow to the United States.

The State of California will consider tenders today for an issue of $3,350,000 of registered warrants, the proceeds from which will be used for unemployment relief purposes. The issue will be dated Oct. 23, 1937, and become payable on Feb. 23, 1938.

Delegates attending the second annual conference sponsored by the New Jersey Advisory Committee on Public Recreation, held today at the War Memorial Building here, were told by Judge Richard Hartshorne of the Essex County Common Pleas Court that better recreational facilities would curb juvenile delinquency.

Suites on the East Side of Manhattan continue to draw a large proportion of the families seeking new living quarters, according to brokers' reports. Yesterday's list represented a wide coverage of the section bounded by Fiftieth and Ninetieth Streets from Fifth Avenue to the East River.

Army defeated the Brown University soccer team, 1 to 0, today. Odom scored for the cadets late in the second period, but play was so even that the outcome was not assured until the final whistle. The field was heavy and play was difficult, handicapping both teams.

The body of Maurice E. Lasser, New York City security dealer, was recovered from Kensico Lake this afternoon, forty-eight hours after he had disappeared from his home at 115 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains. Dr. Amos O. Squire,
In an article in the Zeppelin Works' official organ today Dr. Hugo Eckener said the problem presented by the use of helium in all future Zeppelins had been virtually solved.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Hillas of Byewater, Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of Mrs. Hillas's daughter, Miss Virginia Randolph, to Herman Henry Ridder of St. Paul, Minn., and this city.
F. Ambrose Clark's Cadeau II, ridden by the veteran Fred Bellhouse, came from behind to win the Chevy Chase Steeplechase Handicap, outstanding jumping event of the meeting, today.
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Isaac Siegel, candidate for City Council, "Juvenile Delinquency and Its Cure," WQXR, 6 to 6:15 P. M.
A Senate subcommittee today heard Georgia's dirt farmers voice approval of compulsory crop control, but offer divergent views on how the program should be achieved.

After hearing argument here today on a motion by William F. Brunner, President of the New York City Board of Aldermen, to restrain the city Board of Elections from placing the name of George U. Harvey, Queens Borough President,

Various points which had caused considerable disagreement were clarified at a meeting of high school football coaches and officials under the auspices of the P. S. A. L. at The Herald Tribune auditorium last night.

Paul N. Dwyer, 18-year-old South Paris youth accused of slaying Dr. and Mrs. James G. Littlefield of that town, arrived this afternoon at the Augusta State Hospital, to which he was committed for observation yesterday by a Superior Court order.

Twelve double-headers are listed for the coming basketball season at Madison Square Garden, according to an announcement made yesterday by Ned Irish, director of the sport at the arena, at a luncheon tendered to basketball writers, coaches and officials at the Hotel Lincoln. The first twin bill is scheduled for Saturday, Dec. 18, and the final for March 2.

An exemplified copy of the will of Dr. Samuel King Johnson of Glenville Road, Greenwich, and proceedings approved in the Surrogate's Court of New York on Sept. 9, was admitted to probate by Judge Harold L. Knapp in the Greenwich Court today.

Serious crimes committed by paroled prisoners are always-and properlyemphasized in the news. The crimes that paroled prisoners do not commit are not news, except when the whole subject of our parole laws is considered,

George Conway, trainer of War Admiral, king of the 3-year-olds, said today the colt would not run in the $7,500 added Maryland Handicap Saturday. Conway declared Samuel D. Riddle, owner of War Admiral, advised him not to start the colt "under any conditions" in the mile-and-aquarter event.

The Bureau of Air Commerce announced today that effective Nov. 1 all "stunt" and acrobatic flights would be prohibited over congested areas in cities and towns or within 1,000 feet of an airport. Other new "stunt" flight regulations are:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last Sunday night, a woman rang our doorbell. She was a very nice person, even if she did call when we were thinking of going to bed. Perhaps statistics show that people are more willing to say "yes" at that time of night.

The now customary boisterous reception was given to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor on their arrival here tonight. A crowd of several thousand gathered before the hotel chanting "Dear Duke, be nice, come to the window."
The War De apartment released the following orders today, dated' Oct. 19: COLONELS Bain, J. J., Eng'ns., detailed for duty wit] the Organized Reserves in addition t6 other duties at Charleston, S. C.
In a sudden reversed price trend that was as spectacular as the previous day's decline, bonds staged yesterday the sharpest recovery on the New York Stock Exchange in more than four and a half years.
Alf M. Landon's radio speech of last night is interpreted by some Republicans here as an attempt to assert his leadership of the Republican party and put himself in the role of titular leader.

IF every New Yorker who has been tripped, trapped or otherwise abused as a result of the obscene process now going on along Sixth Avenue were to buy a copy of Archibald Black's new book,* Mr. Black would soon become the best-read author -in town and could forget his job as special writer for the Port of New York Authority and spend the rest of his life lolling in a hammock.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Albright of New York, who were accompanied here by their daughters, the Misses Barbara and Jeanne Albright, gave a- cocktail assembly at the Greenbrier for forty guests tonight. Miss Dorcas Campbell of New York entertained a large group in the Spring Room.

Belated judgment on the responsibility for Malaga's fall was rendered today in orders to imprison General Jose Asensio, who was Francisco Largo Caballero's Under-Secretary of War, and General Martinez Cabrera, who was General Asensio's chief of staff.
Police Captain Oscar Paul Himmell of the Parkville precinct, Brooklyn, died of pneumonia yesterday in his home at 1,094 East Thirty-first Street, Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.

Films to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Bail of $5,000, furnished last Summer in General Sessions for Kenneth MacLaren, 49 years old, of the MacLaren Company, Ltd., investment brokers in Toronto, and Frederick E. Ziegler, 35, of Woodstock, N. Y., was quashed yesterday by Judge Allen.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 10,000, including 2,000 directs. The market was around 10 cents lower than Tuesday's average;

A general increase in freight rates in water-borne trades war predicted yesterday by Frans C. Bouman of Rotterdam, managing director of the Holland America Line. Mr. Bouman arrived in New York earlier in the week to confer with officials of the line in New York and cities in the South and West.
Declaring that any change n the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company's passenger rates means "absolute and complete bankruptcy and destruction for the company," Federal Judge George A. Welsh

Cornell's backfield took more definite shape in a long drill tonight, Coach 'navely planning to start Vin Eichler, quarter; Whit Baker, left half; either Dick Morgan or Bob Boocheever, right half, and Ken Brown. fullback. against Yale.

Two large dance performances to be given in the Center Theatre and a series of fifteen afternoon recitals in the Rainbow. Room, under the auspices of the forthcoming international dance exposition in Rockefeller Center, "may well envision regular festivals of international scope in New York," according to Anne Morgan, one of the exposition's sponsors.
Alexander Hull Jr. learned to read and recite the multiplication tables when he was 4, and now, barely 9 years old, he is a high school freshman.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $24,658,822 This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.69 a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $24,430,272, or $2.65 a common share, in the twelve months to Sent. 30. 1936.

A proposed settlement for more than $2,000,000 of two suits for alleged damages of approximately $12,000,000 filed in 1934 in Supreme Court against former officers and directors of the Paramount-Publix Corporation, now known as the Paramount Pictures Corporation, will be discussed on Nov. 3 before Federal Judge Coxe.
The McClatchy Broadcasting Company, operating four radio stations in California, announced plans today to start the first facsimile broadcasting on the Pacific Coast.

A housing program financed by the State and city in conjunction with the Federal Government to the possible extent of $100,000,000 a year for ten years was envisaged yesterday by Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

The itinerary of a 3,000-mile road trip, the longest in the history of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania, was announced today as a company of more than seventy undergraduates continued rehearsals of the club's golden jubilee production, "FiftyFifty."

Paul A. Freund, a government attorney, stood before the Supreme Court today and called it a "puzzle." Chief Justice Hughes. smiled broadly at the remark by the special assistant to Attorney General Cummings.
Oklahoma National guardsmen patrolled ten strike-bound leases tonight as Governor Marland came here to take personal command of the situation.

Miss Helen F. Galey, daughter of Mrs. Harlod Rezin Hammond of White Grass Ranch, Moose, Wyo., and of Bryn Mawr, was married this afternoon to Alfred Garrett Scattergood 2d, son of J. Henry Scattergood of Dundale, Villanova, and the late Mrs. Scattergood.

Governor Lehman has accepted an invitation to speak to more than 1,000 leaders in education and politics at a dinner in honor of Dr. Paul Klapper, president of the new Queens College, on Saturday evening, Oct. 30, in the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by Nelson P. Mead, head of the City College History Department.

Miss Hazel F. Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Silas E. Moore of this city, and Harold E. Crane Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Crane of Atlantic City, will be married on Oct. 30 in St. John's Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Dr. Lyttleton E. Hubard, the rector.
Stocks advanced and closed strong with widest gains since March 15, 1933; turnover, 4,336,620 shares. United States Government and other bonds recovered sharply; transactions, $15,203,125.

Four hundred and three students of Pace Institute of this city received diplomas or certificates at the annual commencement of the institute held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The three sophomores whose work stood out in the Georgetown game will again be given the starting call when Lafayette meets New York University Saturday, it was made known today.

A heavy, driving rain failed to discourage over 600 persons from attending the cornerstone laying ceremonies of the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades yesterday, where they heard city and school officials extol the benefits of this structure to the educational system.
Edgar Johnson is speaking tonight at 8:30 at the New School for Social Research on the Journals of Arnold Bennett and other diaries and journals.

An attentive courtroom crowd got a glimpse of the dramatic scene which took place in the home of Margaret Drennan the night of Sept. 7 when she shot and killed Paul Reeves, married father of two children, supposedly to defend herself from an attack in his home, when she opened her defense this afternoon at her trial for murder before Judge Adrian Lyon.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Rugs: Persia," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M. The American Wing (general tour), 2 P. M. Luncheon, Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, noon. "A Business Man Looks at His Government," Bruce Barton, Frank E. Tupper, F. W. Nichol, L. C. Stowell, Thomas J. Watson.

The council of the Authors League of America, meeting yesterday afternoon at its headquarters, 6 East Thirty-ninth Street, completed a program of reorganization under which the Screen Writers Guild will receive greater autonomy.
Cordell Hull, Secretary of State of the United States, arrived today on a visit which both he and Prime Minister Mackenzie King declared "purely social."
Mrs. Dudley Ward, one-time dancing partner of the Duke of Windsor and internationally known Mayfair hostess, was married at the Marylebone Registry office today to Marquis de Casa Maury.
The United Lutheran Church in America finds itself in the unusual position of having more pastorates to fill than qualified ministers to fill them.

Leaders in civic, philanthropic and social work joined yesterday in honoring Mrs. Benjamin Antin, chairman of the Bronx Women's Division of the American Joint Distribution Committee, at a testimonial luncheon of the Women's Division of the Greater New York Campaign of the Joint distribution Committee at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

Booth Tarkington, novelist and art collector, has bought three paintings by old masters from the E. and A. Silberman Galleries, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, to be added to the varied collection in his home in Kennebunkport, Me.

This coming Saturday is one of those days that make you wish you could be in a dozen different places at one and the same time, what with the day's football schedule literally filled with interesting and important combats.

Evidently fearing hostile demonstrations or attempts at assassination, Japanese authorities today took extraordinary precautions in Peiping in preparation for the formal visit of General Count Juichi Terauchi.

There will be no night baseball at Sportsman's Park in 1938, officials of the Browns and Cardinals decided today at a meeting. A statement, signed by President Sam Breadon of the National League Cardinals and President Donald L. Barnes of the American League Browns, ended with the optimistic note that "both clubs are hopeful that lights will be erected in 1939 by a joint undertaking."

Funeral services were held yesterday morning for Colonel Grayson Mallet-Prevost Murphy at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Seventy-first Street and Madison Avenue. Colonel Murphy, who died on Monday, was the first European Commissioner of the American Red Cross during the World War and founder of the Stock Exchange firm of G. M.-P. Murphy Co.

By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Pierce Ave. s s, 50 ft w of Tomlinson Ave, pvt dwelling, 25x100; W. Edward Foster, trustee, against Harold McGann; due. $11,065: taxes, etc, $1,282; to plaintiff for $10,000. By JAMEB R. MURPHY Webster Ave, 2,502, 2-story frame store, 24.9xl00.11; Dollar Savings Bank in the City of N Y against Albert T. Reynolds; due, $10,947; taxes, etc, $406; to plaintiff for $5,000.

Leading honors for the All-Americe swimming, diving and water polo team for 1937 were taken by Ralph Flanagan of Miami, according to an announcement yesterday by George W. Graves, chairman of the A. A. U. Aquatic Committee, which made public its choices.
In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 17--Texas New Orleans Rr. Co., et al. petrs., V. Emma E. Neill, et al. Argued for both.
A border clash between Haitians and Dominicans in which several of the former were shot is reported to have occurred a week ago. No official confirmation has been obtainable.

New York University's football squad practiced for two hours yesterday afternoon in the gymnasium because of inclement weather. Following the workout Coach Mal Stevens put his charges through a thirty-minute drill on Ohio Field when the rain let up.

The annual "At Home" of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, to be held Friday evening, Nov. 26, at the Metropolitan Opera House, will be devoted to music of Richard Strauss and will enlist the services of Lotte Lehmann,

Despite a downpour which rendered the field a quagmire, the Dartmouth football team held its most rugged workout of the year today in preparation for Harvard. The drill included long offensive and defensive scrimmage and did not terminate until after the floodlights had been in use for an hour.

Construction work in the New York area during the first nine months of this year ran more than $100,000,000 ahead of the total for the corresponding period last year, according to a monthly summary of contract awards prepared by the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

Unless government concerns itself with the conservation of human qualities among relief recipients, relief may operate as "a drug which will destroy a personality," Commissioner David C. Adie of the State Department of Social Welfare told field officers of the Social Security Board yesterday.

In the first action of its kind prosecuted in this district, Harry Schacht, owner of the Rialto Theatre Ticket Office, 132 West Fortysecond Street, went on trial yesterday before Federal Judge God-'. dard and a jury on the charge that last March he had sold four theatre tickets which had not been stamped in accordance with the terms of the revenue law.
Trading was slow in most classes of traefa meats yesterday. Veal, lamb and pork were weak to lower. Choice and prime steer cuts were steady to strong and others steady to lower.
The recovery in stock market values was carefully watched today by officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve Board.

Retaliating for all-day Japanese air raids over the Chapei and Pootung districts of Shanghai, Chinese fliers raided Japanese positions in Yangtzepoo and beyond seven times between 7 P. M. yesterday and 2:30 A. M.-today.

A discussion of a new lead and magnesium alloy for use in shotgun pellets to stop lead poisoning in wild ducks held the attention this afternoon of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, in convention at the Hotel RitzCarlton here.

Mrs. Cecil F. Shallcross entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Hubert F. Milligan of London. Other guests were Mrs. Jocelyn H. de Grasse Evans, Mrs. Hoppin Pool, Mrs. Allison Wright Post and Mrs. Beekman H: Pool.

Edmund L. Dolan, City Treasurer in the last Curley administration; Edward J. Supple, former president of the Legal Securities Corporation, and J. Walter Quinn, treasurer of the Curley-for-Governor campaign in 1934, were indicted today by the Suffolk grand jury on charges of conspiracy to steal from the city.

William Elliott Gonzales, editor and publisher of The State; and former Ambassador to Peru, died at his home in this city today shortly after noon at the age of 71. He was taken ill early in the Summer.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Rosenman ruled yesterday that Federal legislation enacted in the banking crisis of 1933 released the Bethlehem Steel Company of its obligation to pay interest on its bonds held by foreigners in foreign currencies at the rates specified in the coupons.

There is no assurance that next week will not bring another drop in production of steel ingots as new business is coming to the mills in disappointingly small volume, The Iron Age says in its weekly summary of the industry. Production is now at the lowest point since March, 1936, the estimated rate for the week being 55 1/2 per cent, against 63 1/2 per cent last week.

The New York Community Trust has disbursed $180,207 so far this year for philanthropic purposes, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of the trust's distributing committee at the' Downtown Association.

The parole system, which has been the subject of considerable criticism by J. Edgar Hoover and others, was defended vigorously last night by Governor Lehman before more than 1,000 social workers assembled at the annual dinner meeting of the New York State Conference on Social Work at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mrs. Van Santvoord Merle-Smith of 27 Beekman Place and The Paddocks, Oyster Bay, L. I., gave a luncheon yesterday at her home here for the members of the committee on patroness invitations for the annual opera benefit of the New York Vassar Club.

UTICA, Oct. 20.--The right of collective bargaining by employes and employers alike was upheld today in a report by the committee on social education to the New York Synod of the Presbyterian Church. Violence on either side in industrial disputes was condemned.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Rives Harding, daughter of Nelson Harding of Plandome and the late Mrs. Harding, to Emil Morosini Jr., son of Mrs. Emil Morosini of Scranton, Pa., and the late Mr. Morosini, took place this morning at Christ Church, Manhasset. The Rev. Charles H. Ricker officiated.
Owing to the presence of many Japanese warships in the vicinity of Hainan, there is a revival at Canton of apprehension of the seizure of that island.
Japan's Privy Council today approved regulations for the new planning board formed by amalgamation of the old planning board with the Natural Resources Bureau of the Cabinet.

Official ballots for candidates for the City Council in Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond were made public yesterday by the Board of Elections. In Brooklyn the ballot is more than four feet long, and contains ninety-nine candidates, thirtyseven running with party designations'and the rest independent.

In the third game of the chess championship match between Dr. Max Euwe and Dr. Alexander m Alekhine, now in progress in The Netherlands and the eighth game of which is scheduled for tonight at Leyden, Dr. Alekhine demonstrated that a draw can sometimes be forced in an ending in which one of the players is a pawn behind, even though the bishops remaining on the board are on squares of the same color.
It is beginning to look as if it might be a good idea for some one to put on a flannel shirt, climb into a secondhand car and go out among
The Lower House of the Netherlands today voted down by a vote of 100 to 60 a proposed amendment excluding the revolutionary parties from Parliament.

The International Paper and Power Company, Boston, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 3,672,153 23/40 shares of $15 par value common stock, of which 2,324,405 will be for conversion of its cumulative convertible 5 per cent preferred stock and the reminder reserved for the exercise of outstanding common stock warrants.

Gudmundur Kristjansson, tenor, was heard in recital last night at Steinway Hall. The program was of musical interest by reason of its inclusion of seldom-heard Icelandic music byLeifs, Isolfsson, Bjornson, and an arrangement of an ancient melody by Otterstrom.
The Indians today named Oscar Vitt to replace Steve O'Neill as manager and gave the Newark International League pilot his first managerial opportunity in major league baseball.

Army's varsity appeared on the practice field today for the first time since the Yale battle and staged a long scrimmage in the mud in preparation for the game with Washington University of St. Louis on Saturday.

Gas, tar, oils and chemicals valued at more than $133,000,000 were produced by the steel industry in 1936 as by-products of coke production for use as fuel for the industry's blast furnaces, according to an estimate made yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Ecuador is threatened with a smokers' strike as a result of an increase in prices by the government tobacco monopoly. The new prices are termed exorbitant. The monopoly controls the sale and importation of tobacco in any form.
A "fifty-fifty break" for the investor was advocated here today by Mark Graves, New York State Tax Commissioner. as "the best way to prime the business pump."

Nobody minds its raining like cats and dogs; but when it rains like Brachiosauri and Diplodoci, something ought to be done about it. Water is very well in its place, but New York is no place for such a submersion as it had to endure yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, rabbi-emeritus of the historic Congregation Shearith Israel of New York, died at 10:15 this morning at his home here. He was 85 years old last April 13 and the occasion brought a flood of congratulatory messages from leaders of all faiths throughout the nation.

A. Chester Beatty, chairman of the Roan Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., told stockholders at their meeting in London yesterday, according to a report received here, that copper producers outside the United States had reduced their output slightly to steady the market and to keep supplies adjusted to requirements so far as practicable.

A demand for residential and business properties in Harlem was indicated in sales and leases reported yesterday. The five-story building at 11 East 119th Street, between Madison and Fifth Avenue, has been purchased by Rosenstock Bachrach, operators, from the Cori Realty Corporation.

Wet fields and rain hampered both the Giant and Dodger elevens yesterday as they continued preparations for their meeting on Sunday at the Polo Grounds. The Giants were limited to a short workout but the Dodgers went through an intensive defensive drill.

The new building code for New York City, which is to go into effect Jan. 1, is the "best ever written anywhere," Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association, declared last night at a dinner at the Hotel Astor in honor of those who took part in preparing and adopting the code.

Princeton University's varsity battalion swung into action today against the undefeated freshmen for the first time this season and after seventy-five minutes of hard combat on University Field went to the showers in possession of an unofficial 18-0 victory.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Anderson of New York, who are at the Berkshire Inn here, were honored tonight with a dinner party given by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rockhill at Crane Hill. The other guests included Mr. and Mrs. John H. C. Church, Dr. and Mrs. John Dodge Peters, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Nisbet, Mrs. Benjamin Durant Ticknor and Miss Helen Hawthorne.

The search for Charles S. Ross and his kidnappers was active today as individuals in many parts of the country, encouraged by information given out by the Federal agents in charge, began to report suspicions, but all new clues had apparently proved futile.

Hebrew University of Jerusalem opened its academic year today. President Judah L. Magnes in his opening address announced that the French Government had endowed a chair of French culture, also providing means for French books for the university library as well as two scholarships.

Driven by a forty-mile-an-hour south wind, rain that began early Tuesday morning and continued intermittently until nightfall yesterday caused widespread damage throughout the city and a few minor accidents.

Dean Detton, 207, Salt Lake City, claimant of the world heavyweight wrestling championship, and Vincent Lopez, 220, Los Angeles, grappled 1 hour and 16 minutes to a draw before 2,000 persons at the Hippodrome last night. The bout was halted by the 11 o'clock curfew law.

Charles M. Fickert, former San Francisco District Attorney, prosecutor of Tom Mooney and Warren Billings in the 1918 Preparedness Day bombing case, died here early this morning of pneumonia. He was 64 years old.
Distribution of the assets of the Northern Securities Company may be delayed as a result of stock market conditions, according to a notice by the trustees in dissolution.

Ruling that it was not the function of the courts to determine whether the sponsors of independent political parties actually espouse the policies indicated by their choice of a name, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins dismissed yesterday an action brought by various labor unions to enjoin Jeremiah T. Mahoney and his Democratic running mates from appearing on the ballot as the candidates also of the "Trades Union party."

The most important shake-up thus far this season was made by Head Coach Hank Hardwick at the Naval Academy today when Art Franks, 200-pound blocking back, and Emmett Wood, chunky 175-pounder, were assigned to the varsity backfield. They were used, respectively,

Jacob Epstein will show his latest figure of Christ to critics tomorrow and already there are indications that another "Epstein storm" is about to break. A recumbent figure, hewn from a massive block of translucent Derbyshire alabaster, depicts Christ in a tomb.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday that its net assets on Sept. 30, based on market quotations for securities owned, were valued at $115,265,835, equal to $23.44 a share on 4,918,406 shares of stock.
Arthur Rose, a schoolmaster for forty-eight years and an organist for fifty-six years in this city, died last night at his home, 79 Manhattan Avenue, after a long illness, at the age of 74.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Oct. 9 totaled 309,009,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
Listed for a tryout next Monday and for Broadway Nov. 10, Delos Chappell's production of "Father Malachy's Miracle" was suddenly and indefinitely postponed yesterday. "General conditions,"

The Rev. Clifford C. Cornwell, for ten years pastor of the Twelfth Street Reformed Church, Brooklyn, died on Tuesday night in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital after an accident he suffered a week ago when he was struck by a motor car at Eighth Avenue and Ninth Street, Brooklyn.

President Roosevelt, Secretary Wallace and Secretary Morgenthau prepared today to go ahead with loans to corn producers in advance of the special session of Congress. A loan of about 46 cents a bushel probably will be approved.

Norman H. Davis, United States delegate to the Nine-Power Treaty conference opening in Brussels Oct. 30, sailed yesterday on the United States liner Washington without expressing a view on America's expectations.

The convention of the American Legion here from Sept. 20 to 24 resulted in an increase of 2,000,000 riders on the combined Interborough subway and elevated lines in that week, according to the monthly report of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company for September, filed yesterday with Federal Circuit Judge Mack by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the company. The increase, however,

Robert Burke, who became a C. I. O. organizer after his dismissal from Columbia University, was fined $300 and costs today and received a suspended thirty-day sentence for inciting a riot during the steel strike.

Mr. and Mrs. John Henry MacCracken of 9 East Eighty-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise MacCracken, to Robert Groves Olmsted of 45 Park Avenue, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Welch Olmsted of Ludlow, Pa.

While eighteen candidates of four political parties explained this afternoon why they should be elected to Westchester offices on Nov. 2, members of the Westchester League of Women Voters sat with pencils poised over lists of the candidates and jotted down their impressions. The candidates spoke at a meeting of the league at the Briar Hills Country Club here.

Four German physicians who applied last week to the Supreme Court for a mandamus order compelling the Board of Regents to license them without examination were notified yesterday that the board, without waiting for a court decision, had reversed its earlier ruling and had issued them

The riders who will represent the Irish Free State Army in the eight nights of international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 3 to 10 were announced yesterday by J. Spencer Weed, president of the National Horse Show Association.

The recently formed Paragon Stable, which has run most of its horses in New England, scored a metropolitan success yesterday at Empire City when Deep End was first at the end of the short six furlongs of the Castle Hill Purse.

Stock market quotations have gone far below any probable decline in earnings for most securities, Professor O. M. W. Sprague of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, declared in an interview published today in The Boston Globe.

Nathan Straus of New York was sworn in today as Administrator of the Federal Housing Authority. He stated immediately afterward that he would assume the duties Nov. 1 and would take over the personnel of the PWA Housing Division to aid him in administering the $526,000,000 slum clearance program.

One hundred and thirty-six members of thirty-four election boards in Hudson County, in which districts a primary election recount disclosed a 10 per cent or larger discrepancy, were dismissed by the Hudson County Board of Elections at an executive session late this afternoon.
For the first time in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, two separate markets in a single stock issue will be conducted as the result of a ruling announced yesterday by the Exchange.
That department stores are experiencing slowness in the sale of men's clothing was indicated yesterday when one large store cut the price of its leading brand for the first time in fifteen years.

Dr. Tsune-Chi Yu, Chinese Consul-General in New York, expressed gratification yesterday at the new American foreign policy of concerted action against aggressors and urged that public opinion here be "crystalized' into concrete measures to aid his country.

Railroad statements for September show varying results. ReportIng yesterday, the Texas Pacific listed increased gross but lower net income for the month, while the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) reported lower gross and net.

A field of thirtyseven leading handicap horses, including two former winners, was announced today as final acceptors for the Cesarewitch Stakes, to be run here next Wednesday over a course of two and one-quarter miles.

In what is believed to be the first action of its kind taken, Abraham M. Lowenthal, attorney for the Progress Corporation, has requested newspapers here to ban cut-price advertising on Packard LektroShavers and other products distributed by the company, which are protected by Feld-Crawford contracts. From time to time, he said,

The appearance today of the largest foreign demand for North American cash wheat in several weeks and a continuance of the rally in the securities markets furnished the background for a substantial upturn in the wheat market, with Winnipeg in the lead.
Fifty-four persons were shot Oct. 12 at Ulan Uday. formerly Verkhme Udinsk, capital of the Buryat-Mongolian Soviet Republic, east of Lake Baikal, on charges of espionage and kindred activities.

Manufacture of new products involving risks to the consumer or the factory worker should be subject to acceptance of public health authorities before they are produced and put on the market, Dr. Haven Emerson, director of public health in the College of Physicians and Surgeons, declared last night in Columbia University's McMillin Theatre.
Rear Admiral Purnell Frederick Harrington, U. S. N., retired, who was an ensign at the Battle of Mobile Bay in the Civil War, died yesterday at his home in Yonkers, in his ninety-fourth year.
Fred B. Snite Jr., 27-year-old victim of infantile paralysis, arrived today from Chicago by train and was taken ten miles to his father's home where he was ensconced on a sun deck for. the season.

Members of a police emergency squad and an ambulance surgeon from Broad Street Hospital worked for two hours yesterday afternoon In a vain effort to revived Mrs. Mary Banks, 54 years old, of 370 Convent Avenue, who had fallen or jumped into the water from the Staten Island ferryboat Queens just after it had left its Whitehall Street slip. Service on the ferry line was delaved a short time.

The need for more practical planning of cities of the future, the rebuilding of blighted urban areas, and for tax adjustments to promote home ownership and realty investment, were emphasized here today at the opening session of the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Swollen streams inundated several Virginia towns today after taking one life, sweeping away crops in lowlands, carrying out bridges and causing property damage which may reach several million dollars.

Louis A. Seyffert, a director of the Ohio Fuel Gas Company, testified today before the State Utilities Commission that the company mixed inert gases with natural gas and sold it to consumers in Columbus in 1934. The mixture, he said, was used to stabilize the heat content of the natural gas.

A sharp rise in the Swiss tranc, reflecting, apparently, some repatriation of funds from this market, was the outstanding development in the foreign exchanges yesterday. The Swiss unit rose to 23.10 cents, the best price for the year to date, and closed at 23.09 cents, up 7 points net.
The Syracuse eleven is threatened with the task of meeting Maryland at Baltimore on Saturday without the services of Jack Hinkle, right halfback, who was injured in the Cornell game.

Following a hard two-hour scrimmage on the muddy flats of Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, thirty. Manhattan players were chosen by Coach Chick Meehan to make the 800-mile journey to Lexington, Ky., where the Jaspers and the University of Kentucky eleven will resume football relations in an intersectional contest Saturday.

The criticisms by Winthrop Aldrich of present governmental policies as they affect the stock market were sober, detailed and closely reasoned. As much cannot be said for the reply that Ferdinand Pecora, once a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission but now a justice of the Supreme Court of this State, thought fit to make to them. "In effect,"

Supreme Court Justice Shientag granted yesterday an application by State Attorney General Bennett to enjoin H. Russell Ryder, the exconvict, from disposing of $100,000 or more which he is said to have obtained recently from investors in a "cooperative speculating plan" in which he promised 24 per cent profit.

Old Kate, 90-year-old Indian woman, was receiving hospital treatment today at Fort Simpson, N. W. T., after modern science had intervened, disregarding the tribal custom which decrees that the aged squaw should have lain down to await death in the lonely wilderness when her people deserted her.
Mr. and Mrs. Allen Skinner Hubbard will give a tea dance on Nov. 24 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Harriet Elizabeth Hubbard.

" Gay Blades," international skating ballet featuring Karl Schafer, seven times world champion and present Olympic titleholder, and Miss Maribel Y. Vinson, present North American champion, will be presented in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 15, it was announced yesterday at the offices of Francis T. Hunter and Bill O'Brien, producers of the show.

In three campaign speeches last night Mayor La Guardia attacked the Democratic members of the Board of Estimate for adding $762,670 to the city budget, including allbtments for sixty-five county jobs he had declared useless, and said he would modify this budget after Jan. 1.

Yale defeated Massachusetts State College twice today by the same score, 2 to 1, in soccer games between the first and second varsity teams. Mustin and Captain Bill Carter scored the Yale varsity goals and Charley Rodda the goal for the visitors.

C. I. O. Group Asks Certification The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, a unit of the C. I. O., asked the National Labor Relations Board yesterday to certify it as the bargaining agent of the men employed in the maintenance of ships of the Grace Line when in port. In a telegram to J.

The mailing of a postcard asking reimbursement for a "rubber check" amounts to publication of a libel, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin ruled yesterday in a $50,000 suit brought by Sidney Ostro, an insurance broker of 17 John Street, against Abraham Safir and the Safir Construction Company, Inc.

Electric power production was slightly lower last week for the week, but the daily average was higher.. The gain showed a greater increase than allowed for by seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index has advanced to 104.4 from 104.1. The figure for the week ended Oct. 17, 1936, was 104.8.

A study of the trend of new financing of real estate by the Real Estate Board of New York shows an increase of 93 per cent in new mortgage money invested in Manhattan during the first nine months of this year over the corresponding .period of 1936.

Governor Quinn, in an unprecedented radio address here tonight, told Rhode Island residents that he had balked the efforts of Walter E. O'Hara because the Narragansett race track operator had sought to seize control of the State Government.

Continuing the upsurge with which Tuesday's trading closed, stock markets yesterday recorded impressive gains, closing 1 to 10 points higher. Gains were not limited to speculative favorites, as in the Tuesday market.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following today dated Oct. 18: Himan, Lt. Comdr. M. A., Captain of Yard, Navy Yard, Cavite, P. I., to home. relieved from all active duty, about Dec. 1.

Andrew Ponzi and Joe Procita divided the concluding two blocks in their exhibition pocket billiard match at the Strand Academy yesterday. Ponzi scored 125 to 103 in ten innings, each having a high run of 50. Procita then triumphed, 125 to 71, in twelve frames, running 39 to Ponzi's 34. Ponzi won four blocks to two and outscored his opponent, 610 to 604.
ANGEL ISLAND, a mystery in three acts and nine scenes, by Mrs. Bernie Angus. Settings by John Root; staged and produced by George Abbott. At the National Theatre.

While the Non-Intervention Committee in London discusses ways and means of withdrawing all foreign volunteers from Spain, it may be said that the conquest of Asturias during the last six weeks has been carried out exclusively by Spanish troops.

The bondholders' committee of which Charles Francis Adams is chairman announced yesterday that it had sent a letter to the holders of the 51/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds of the Brown Company urging them not to approve any plan of reorganization for that company "until they have had an opportunity to review the proposals and recommendations that will be made by this committee."

The stock market here displayed today a generally brighter tone, following yesterday's late rally in Wall Street. Prices in most groups recovered part of yesterday's losses, but in the afternoon some home industrials turned easier. Iron and steel shares, tobaccos and motors were well supported. Gilt-edge issues. after holding steady, became dull.

ACCORDING to some of the severe critics, laying about them with a strange mixture of delight and venom, the country is going to the dogs, the world is spinning rapidly downhill, citizens are either racketeers or racket victims, college athletes are brutal hirelings, everything is wrong, nothing Is right, the whole mess grows worse by the minute-and there is no hope.

Compositions of Herbert Inch and Elie Siegmeister were presented at last night's session of the Com- I posers Forum-Laboratory at the WPA Theatre of Music. Mr. Inch was represented by a sonata for 'cello and piano and a string quartet;
H. L. Mencken, literary titan of the Twenties, took the public platform yesterday to discourse on Gertrude Stein, the American language and the vocal ability of President Roosevelt.

A full jury and two alternate jurors were seated tonight to hear evidence against Laverne (John Montague) Moore, who was returned here from Hollywood in August as a fugitive to face a seven-year-old charge of first-degree robbery.

Miss Julia Berwind of New York entertained at luncheon in the Colonial Room of the Homestead today for Miss Margaret Stewart, Mrs. Huntington Hartford and the latter's house guest, Miss L. E. Bogert. Robert Appleton of Southampton, L. I., was host at the same time to Mrs. Paul H. Deming and Miss

Rain and a muddy field forced the City College football players indoors yesterday as they continued preparations for the game with Hobart at Geneva Saturday. An intensive blackboard drill was held, with the Beaver and Hobart plays being reviewed.

Miss Elna Frances MacFarlane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William MacFarlane of this place, was married this afternoon to Reginald Buchanan Beam of Chicago, son of Mrs. Nathaniel Board Beam of Hackensack, N. J., and the late Mr. Beam, in the Bronxville Reformed Church.
The Caprice Room of the Weylin was opened yesterday for the Autumn season with a luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Prosperity Shop, 1,279 Third Avenue. Mrs. W. Gustav Triest,
The Interstate Commerce Commission adjourned today until Feb. 28 the reorganization proceedings of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company.

Miss Mary A. Glynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Glynn of Winsted, was married to Alfred M. Decicco, son of Italian Vice Consul and Mrs. Pasquale Decicco of New Haven, yesterday in St. Joseph's Church, Winsted. The Rev. Bonaventure McIntyre, pastor, performed the ceremony.

Robert P. Hooper Jr., 36-year-old executive of a textile concern and son of a Philadelphia financier, was found dead of gas poisoning yesterday morning in the one-room apartment which he had occupied at 317 West Twenty-ninth Street for three weeks.

The National Association of Independent Tire Dealers, Inc., closed its three-day convention here today with the adoption of resolutions bearing on the welfare of the industry. One resolution advised the industry to take advantage of the TydingsMiller act and other. fair trade laws, but did not recommend any method as to pricing.

A volume containing representative articles written by the late Ray Henderson, theatrical publicity man, will be published as a memorial to him by the New York Theatrical Press Agents, it was decided at a special meeting of that organization last night at the Hotel Algonquin. Mr. Henderson,

" Welcome" and "Standing room only" signs were dusted off in honor of Galli-Curci, grand opera star, when she appeared here for a recital tonight. Hailing the famous coloratura soprano in what was believed her first appearance in so small a community-Wadena's population is 2,500 -dairy farmers, turkey ranchers and loggers joined merchants and civic dignitaries in the rush for tickets.
