PARIS, Oct. 20.--Five Spanish Loyalist war planes and a French commercial plane bringing fugitive officers from Gijon landed at the Biarritz-Parme airdrome today.

President Roosevelt dedicated the new home of the Federal Reserve Board today, and declared in his address that the nation's monetary and credit machinery "must be perfected and coordinated with all other instruments of government to promote the most productive utilization of our human and material resources."

The fifteen-story brick apartment house on the southwest corner of Central Park West and Eighty fourth Street, known as 235-9 Con tral Park West and 2-8 West Eigh ty-fourth Street, was sold at auction yesterday to the plaintiff, Jc seph B. Miller, as trustee, on a bid of 1.000.
Myrna Loy and William Powell return to the Capitol today in "Double Wedding," which is said to be a modernized version of a Ferene Molnar play called "Great Love."

Mrs. Ralph I. Lloyd, a member of the board of directors of the Brooklyn Young Women's Christian Association, died on Tuesday in her home at 14 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. She was 61 years old.

Patricia Patterson, mezzo-soprano, who made her first Town Hall appearance yesterday afternoon, sang a program that almost seemed calculated to present her in an unfavorable light. It began with two groups of Schubert and Brahms songs: "An die Musik,"

The retention of "the traditional methods" of real estate taxation rather than the adoption of "new untried theories" was advocated yesterday at the annual conference of the National Association of Assessing Officers held in the Hotel New Yorker.

He fitly bore the name "Felix"-a name which the ancients used to give to a tree of the nobler sort offered to the superior deities. A "nobler sort" he was among men-in his very name a good omen not only to his own community and country but even to the ends of the earth.

Major executives of great companies have larger vocabularies than college professors, according to Johnson O'Connor of the Human Engineering Laboratory of Stevens Institute of Technology, a speaker yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Accountants in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Drill on offensive tactics occupied the entire practice session of the Rutgers squad today as Coach Tasker sought to perfect the plays which have been specially devised to pierce the Princeton defense Saturday. Bob Aubry was at left end'

William St, 71, 24.10x71.9; Grace B. Underwood et al to U. S. Fidelity Guaranty Co; consideration, $55,000. Monroe St, 136, 123.6x100; Monroe-Willet Estates, Inc, to Emigrant Bank; mtg, $14,100, held by bank. Gouverneur St, 37-39, 49x62.5; Harry S. Wallenstein to Emigrant Bank; consideration, $1,000; foreclosure.

The Brooklyn College football eleven, in a long practice on the rain-soaked new athletic field yesterday, practiced a new defensive formation, discarding the five-man line in favor of the six-man line.

" Distant Fields," an unproduced play by S. K. Lauren, was purchased today by RKO for Barbara Stanwyck, giving the studio three vehicles for the actress and presenting the problem of which to do first.

Eager to become Herbert M. Kempton's seventh team in as many years of coaching at Mercersburg Academy to achieve a percentage of better than .500 in victories, the husky Blue and White football players are polishing their plays this week determined to clinch that distinction in the Tome game here Friday.
The body of Mayor John W. Morrison of Harrisonburg, missing since Monday, was found today under an apple tree on the farm of M. L. Pence, near Rockland Mill.

Urging business men to retain their equilibrium in the face of the stock market decline, Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale Brothers, said yesterday that "retail trade, with its hand on the pulse of public confidence, has kept up well and gives every promise of continuing to do so."

Wherever there is a physics laboratory, moods must be tinged with sadhess. For Lord Rutherford is dead, latest but fortunately not the last of that boldly imaginative dynasty of Cambridge scientists that began with Newton.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations on candidates for the new City Council in Manhattan and the Bronx. Declaring the committee charged with the recommendations had based its judgment on character, experience, training, ability and aptitude, without regard for partisan considerations, the announcement pointed out that candidates were designated by. the terms "Endorsed" or "Qualified."

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Baerwald of 9 East Eighty-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Baerwald, to Jack R. Aron, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Aron of Great Neck, L. I., and New York.

The Czechoslovak Government, through Dr. Adalbert Mastny, its Minister in Berlin, lodged an official protest with Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, today against the tone assumed by the German press in its discussion of the incidents at Teplitz-Schoenau, Where the Czech police last Sunday broke up forbidden demonstrations by Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed registrar for 104,750 Class B 7 per cent preferred shares, 104,750 shares of Class A 5 per cent preferred and 41,900 shares of priorpreferred first series 5 1/2 cent stock, each of $100 par, of the Pittsburgh Steel Company.

Mrs. John T. Pratt and Wadsworth R. Lewis entertained jointly last' night with a dinner at the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of the museum's ten-year development program. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. Barclay K. Douglas,
Coach Jack Blott today tried a new offensive for Wesleyan to use in the Little Three game at Amherst on Saturday.

Walter C. Teagle, chairman of the industry section of the United Hospital Campaign, announced last night that Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, had accepted the chairmanship of the public utilities committee for the campaign's annual drive.

Lou Gehrig's announced campaign to eclipse some of the marks Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb set for the record books didn't get far during the 1937 season, but it was a big year for the "Iron Horse," nevertheless.

Buying of shares in odd lots by customers of brokerage houses, which is believed to indicate the trend of public participation, was exceptionally heavy yesterday during the recovery in values on the New York Stock Exchange, purchases exceeding sales by 555,214 shares, according to preliminary statistics reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Mayor La Guardia received 1,320 votes and Jeremiah T. Mahoney, 72, from City College students in a straw vote conducted by the undergraduate newspaper, The Campus.

At the second session of the auction of properties owned by closed Nassau and Queens County national banks, held Wednesday evening in the auditorium of the Jamaica High School, twenty-one parcels were disposed of for a total of $65,650.

H. G. Wells, British historian and novelist, said today that he could notimagine a more honest man than President Roosevelt in control of a great State. Asked at a press conference whether he had found any quality of a dictator in Mr. Roosevelt, Mr. Wells said:

The prediction that governmental price-fixing of milk could not continue on a permanent basis was made today before the New Jersey Consumers Food Institute at Rutgers University here by Dr. Leland Spencer, Cornell University economist and authority On milk marketing.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates Oct. 20 unless specified: At Villefranche, Oct. 21. Hatfield, Raleigh. Balboa to San Diego, Cummings, McDougal. Moffett.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 21--Herman C. Groman, petr., v. Commissioner Internal Revenue. Argument eoncluded for petr.; continued for respondent. 33--Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petr., v. Raymond I. Bashford. Argued for both.

Mr. and Mrs. S. W. Walker purchased a home at 630 Lenox Avenue, Westfied, N. J., through T. B. and N. F. Reynolds, brokers, who also sold the house at 515 North Chestnut Street in Westfield for the Mechanics Trust Company to Mr. and Mrs. W. B. Millen.
Japanese planes raiding the Chinese section of the Canton-Kowloon Railway today machine-gunned, a train carrying passengers and freight en route from Canton to Kowloon.

One national office is to be filled at next month's election in this city-an empty seat in the House of Representatives. Mr. Bruce Barton, Republican and Fusion candidate for that office, has qualifications which recommend him strongly to the voters of the district in which the election will be held, the Seventeenth. He is a man of demonstrated ability.

Mrs. Mary Brenner Morse, wife of Perley Morse, auditor who has served the Federal Government and large corporations, died yesterday at her home, Morse Lodge, here at the age of 65. Mrs. Morse, who had been ill for a year, was born in Jersey City Sept. 19, 1872. She and her husband came to Rockland County twentytwo years ago.

The Public Service Commission denied today a petition of the Eastern Greyhound Lines, Inc., of New York asking removal of restrictions prohibiting it from transporting passengers between Lockport and Buffalo.
A field hospital here in which Adolf Hitler nineteen years ago recovered. from blindness-the result of being gassed on the Ypres front-was dedicated today as a national memorial.

The score was 1 and 1 for Red Dutton, manager of the Americans in the National Hockey League, today. Two days ago he had two holdouts, Nels Stewart, stalwart center ice perfromer, and Dave (Sweeney) Schriner, fast left winger.
The resignation of Benedict Wolf as secretary of the National Labor Relations Board was announced today. Mr. Wolf will leave the board on Nov. 15 to resume the practice of law in New York City.
Ruth Breton, violonist, will appear in a recital this evening at the Town Hall. An Italian program, second of the opera concert series, will be given tonight at the WPA Theatre of Music.

THE illustrious men of medicine provide an endless gallery of stirring characters for novels, biographies and plays. At random, think of Sidney Howard's "Yellow Jack," a brilliant play about Walter Reed, or Pasteur on the screen, or De Kruif's "Microbe Hunters"-to keep the list very short-and you have started a long train.

A London (Ont.) dispatch to The Daily Star today said that John S. Labatt, brewer kidnapped in 1934, had paid $5,500 to David Meisner, convicted of the kidnappiing and released after serving one year of a fifteen-year penitentiary sentence.

A technicality in passport papers threatened last night to detain about half of the troupe of Colonel Wasily de Basil's Ballet Russe, which arrived on the French liner Champlain for its fifth season in, the United States. Many of the ninety-four members of the ballet and technical staff had passports with limited validity, and immigration officials on the liner were required to hold them under the labor laws.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21.--John Boyd said it was because he joined a union, but the attorney for the White Tower chain restaurants said Boyd was dismissed as a chef because he spared the onions and spoiled the hamburgers.

Christian H. Maurice leased from Edward Swann the three-story dwelling at 76 West Twelfth Street through H. Stanley Hillyer, Inc. The three-story dwelling on a lot 16.8 by 100 feet at 357 West 117th Street was leased by Louis C. Moser Co.. as brokers, to Viola Lamb.

Nunes, Inc, opticians, store in 535 5th Ave; The Cross Brown Co, broker. Pal Blade Co, in 745 5th Ave; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, broker. Jerome Venetian Blind Co, in 1,833 Washington Ave; Dr. Aaron Levitt, dentist: Dealers Sign Display Corp, renewals in 370 7th Ave; Potter Tool Machine Works, Inc; Ralperin Knitting Mills, Norlin Laboratory Products, Inc, in 1,916 Park Ave; Arthur Eckstein, Inc, broker.

An audience of 3,200 persons stood for ten minutes tonight and applauded the debut of Pittsburgh's new symphony orchestra in Syria Mosque. Dr. Otto Klemperer, guest conductor from Los Angeles, was called back for a number of bows after Beethoven's Fifth symphony.

Manhattan's varsity cross-country team will open a six-meet schedule tomorrow morning when it faces a strong squad of harriers from Penn State in a dual meet over the fivemile course in Van Cortlandt Park, starting at 11 o'clock.

MANHATTAN BRAINBRIDGE, ARTHUR C. (April 20, 1936). Gross assets, $48,586; net. $44,403. To Violet A. Brainbridge, widow, life estate in stock of Kimpton Haupt, Inc., and residue; John G. and George K. Brainbridge, brothers, remainders in stock trust. Chief assets. stocks and bonds.
Dr. A. S. Calhoun, Covington County health officer, reported tonight the death of six patients for whom he said he had innocently prescribed. a new elixir.

Wheat futures fluctuated in an erratic manner on the Board of Trade here today within a range of 1 1/2 cents a bushel and finished at intermediate figures with the December unchanged and the deferred deliveries 3/8 to 7/8 cent lower. Buying of the May was attributed to cash and export interests.
As a reward for his playing against Columbia and good work in scrimmages this week, Fred Straub, former junior varsity end, has been selected to start for Penn against Georgetown here Saturday.

Inventory of the estate of Sylvester Z. Poll, theatrical proprietor, who died in May, filed today by the Hartford-Connecticut Trust Company as executor and trustee, disclosed a total of $3,853,274. The valuations fixed -by the trustees were:

Another ally is joining the ranks of the sportsman, or so it seems, for the National Association of Audubon Societies has come forward to announce that it is fostering a movement to prevent the government from spending money on swamp and marsh drainage projects.

Harold W. Hastings, Democratic candidate for District Attorney, speaking last night at three meetings, charged that his opponent, Thomas E. Dewey, was giving people the impression that "this Is a bad city and racketeering is its main industry."

Walted S. Steele of Washington, managing editor of The National Republic Magazine, denied yesterday that he and his magazine were distributing propaganda for the German Government in the United States.

Chairman O'Connor of the House Rules Committee asserted today that both the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O. were "hurting the chances" of wage-hour legislation at the coming session of Congress by statements criticizing the pending bill.

Roger Norton, who served a1most two years for participation in the Kin Hana roadhouse robbery at Jay, near this place, seven years ago, identified Laverne (John Montague) Moore today as an accomplice who slugged Matt Cobb, a 67year-old victim of the robbery, with gun and blackjack.

Drunken bicycle riders are a new menace on the highways, Miss Doris Greenwood of the Massachusetts Safety Council today told a meeting of the Parent-Teacher Association. She said that last year automobiles struck 1,100 bicycles.

The increasing importance which Italy atteaches to her Air Force as a war weapon is seen in the Cabinet's approval today of a measure for the regular enlistment (conscrlption) of pilots, mechanics and auxiliary ground crews. Hitherto these have been supplied by volunteers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 15 noted a report from the United States Chamber of Commerce urging abandonment of national wage and hour legislation and a return to State control. But in this territory within the past few years, under the old State system, we have seen 12 1/2 cents an hour paid to common labor. Some kind of national regulation seems clearly indicated.
By HENRY BRADY 35th St, 36-8 W; 7-story brick apartment, 40x98.9; Mortgage Commission State of N. Y. against Oakdale Holding Corp; due $138,583; taxes, , 20,425; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Arthur W. Lawrence, president of the Westchester County Park Commission and member of the State Council of Parks, died of leukemia here this afternoon in the Northern Westchester Hospital, where he had been a patient for more than two weeks. His age was 62 and since 1935, when he moved from Bronxville, he had lived in this village.

Under the leadership of railway stocks, which were influenced by hopes of higher freight rates, the stock market yesterday fought off an onslaught of profit-taking and closed from 1 to 4 points higher.

A leaking pontoon on a Sikorsky amphibian that makes daily sightseeing flights over the financial district and the bay gave four Mexican college students and the plane's pilot, Carl Evans, an exciting time yesterday afternoon until a police launch came to their rescue.

Staging its final hard drill of the week, the Holy Cross football squad worked until dark tonight in a long offensive session. Much time again was given to the reserves. The starting line-up for Saturday against Western Maryland is still uncertain.

The World Championship Rodeo made a temporary detour from Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon for a visit to a lot on Seventh Avenue, between Twelfth and Thirteenth, Streets, where it was host to 3,000 lower West Side youngsters who responded with unstinted enthusiasm.

One of the phenomena of the current campaign is a candidate eager to reduce her own salary, if and when she is elected. Mrs. Anita D. Leon, who never before has run for office, went into the fight for County Register without any expectations. Experts now concede her more than an even chance to win.

Renard A. McGee, in 135 Jefferson Ave, Tenafly, N. J.; New Jersey Realty Co, broker. Albert Peter Tessier, in cor Davis and Stratford Aves, Highland section of White Plains, Westchester; Robert E. Farley Organization, broker.

GOVERNORS ISLAND The following officers on duty with the National Guard are detailed as members of the Corps of Instructors for the Command and General Staff Extension School: Major Harry R. Simmons, Inf. Major Dwight Hughes, Cav.

By GEORGE J. KEARNS Eagle Ave, 567, four-story brick tenement and stores, 25x90; Harlem Savings Bank against Bursterier Realty Corp, due, $10,504, taxes, etc., $150; to plaintiff for $2,000. 125th St, 635 E, five-story brick tenement. 25x100; Harlem Savings Bank against Bursterier Realty Corp, due, $20,228, taxes, etc., $274: to plaintiff for $2,000.
Bishop J. S. H. Brunault of Nicolet died today after a long illness. He was 80 years old and had been Bishop of the neighboring diocese for thirty-three years.

Secretary Ickes, who listened to Tuesday night's radio address by Alf M. Landon, drew therefrom these five conclusions, which he stated at a press conference today: "That the speaker was not the Alpha but the Omega of the Republicans.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Morrison of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Morrison, to John Thomas Rendall, son of Mrs. John Thomas Rendall of New York and the late Mr. Rendall.

Hopes for a successful season for Kent School's football squad are mounting day by day, for two first-string tackles who have been out with injuries received in pre-season practice are well on the road to recovery.

The plant formerly occupied by the Dunlap hat factory, on the block front on Park Avenue, from Sanford Street to Nostrand Avenue, in Brooklyn, has been sold to the Park Sand Realty Corporation through Riker Co., Inc., broker.

Wholesale prices again declined in the week ended on Oct. 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The recession is attributed largely to sharp decreases in market prices of farm products and foods.

Trading continued slow in most classes of locally dressed meats yesterday. Lambs sold slightly below Wednesday's early quotations and some fresh pork cuts were lower: other classes showed little change in price. Thursday being an off kosher day, the slaughter of those classes generalIv dressed kosher was light.
Ranald H. MacDonald Jr. of Dominick Dominick has sold his New York Stock Exchange membership for $61,000 to Stanley Kallman. He became a member of the Exchange in July of last year.

Federal agents were hot on the trail of the kidnappers of Charles S. Ross tonight as they worked on their first tangible clue, a ten-dollar bill identified as part of the $50,000 ransom paid for his release.

Mutiny, murder, strikes, desertions and a drowning marked the three months' cruise of the steamer Algic, an 8,000-ton government-owned freighter which docked here yesterday, it was reported today by Captain Joseph Gainard.

That yachting is an uncertain sport is commonly accepted but cannot be proved by the figures announced yesterday by Secretary Kingsley Kunhardt for the 1937 championship season of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

The first meeting of the United Serbo-Croat opposition movement, which is demanding a revision of the Constitution and the restoration of civil liberties, took place this evening in the home of a Catholic priest near the Croat village of Frakarsitch, near Sisak.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, petitioned the State Labor Board yesterday to investigate employer-employe relations on the city's Independent Subway System and to certify the union as sole bargaining agent for the system's 5,400 employes.

Senator A. Harry Moore's record on the problem of funds for rural roads was attacked in a statement today by State Senator Lester H. Clee, Republican Gubernatorial candidate, who pledged, at the same time, his full support for an adequate program of farm-to-market roads.

Officials of nearly 150 New York villages were told today that extension of the Civil Service Commission's work to them, without money to make it effective, would cause great delay in supplying eligible lists.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 13,000, including 3,500 directs. The market was uneven and mostly 10-15c lower than Wednesday's average after a stronger start; top $10.40 early, late top S10.25; bulk good and choice 190-230 pounds $10-$25; 150-170 pounds, $10-$30;
RUMBIN GALLERIES, by Booth Tarkington. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50.) A novel set in a New York art gallery. UNDER THE FIG LEAF, by Edwin Greenwood. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.) A satiric novel.

Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation announced yesterday that under a decree issued by the Brazilian Government in 1934, $875,000 of dollar bonds and [Pound]320,200 of sterling bonds of the State of Sao Paulo 7 per cent Coffee Realization Loan of 1930 had been purchased and canceled.

With the persistent gavel of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, pounding over the roar of bitter debates, the Central Trades and Labor Council last night reaffirmed its recent unanimous endorsement of Mayor La Guardia, refused to fight against the re-election of Borough President George Harvey of Queens and denounced the Trade Union party, which recently endorsed Jeremiah T. Mahoney.

The retail buyer expects salesmen in all lines to help him interpret to manufacturers the requirements of consumers, and through such a method improved efficiency in distribution can be achieved, Charles S. Shaughnessy, merchandise counselor of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., told the Furniture Manufacturers Representatives of New York, Inc.,
Tile Athletics, take it from Connie Mack, aren't looking for an assistant or a new manager because Mack himself expects to stay at the helm "for several years to come."

Choking back her sobs, Margaret Drennan; 20-yer-old secretarial student who is on trial for murder, told from the witness box of the Court of Oyer and Terminer here today how she shot and killed Paul Reeves in his home at Iselin, N. J., last Sept. 7.
Victor Kurbyweit was elected yesterday secretary of the Continental Insurance Company, it was announced by Bernard M. Culver, president of the company and affiliates of the America Fore group.

The agreement reached yesterday at London by the Non-Intervention Committee was received with satisfaction in Rome, where-the press and official circles consider it further proof of Italy's willingness to collaborate in the solution of the Spanish problems.

The Marine Corps announced the following changes for the week ended Oct. 18: MAJOR Fenton, F. I., Fourth Marine, Shanghai, to Department of the Pacific. sailing via the Henderson, due at San Francisco about Dec. 13.

The War Department issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 20: COLONELS FitzGerald, S. W. (lieutenant colonel) (Air Corps), General Staff Corps, one month leave Oct. 25, with permission to visit foreign countries.
Daring riders of the Belgian Army jumped their thoroughbreds to a triumph over the American Army team today in the initial competition of the Inter-American Horse Show.

City College's varsity swimming team will take part in six dual meets and two championship meets, according to an announcement made yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France issued today shows the following changes in francs:

The State Highway Department announced today an experimental lighting project on Route 4, through Bergen County, to determine whether this method of illumination would reduce fatalities on the twelve-mile stretch between the George Washington and Passaic River Bridges.
The United Lutheran Church in America has started a program of interneships for seminary graduates to maintain high standards of training for them.

Archibald Adams, cashier of the Equitable Life Assurance- of the United States, died on Wednesday in his home at 112-15 Fife Street, Forest Hills, Queens, after a lingering illness. He was 58 years old.

Declaring that "we are paying the penalty in America of fifty years of neglect and contempt of politics on the part of business men," Bruce Barton, candidate for Congress, said yesterday that "the best thing that could happen to this country would be the election of a hundred business men to Congress."
Clemson College used a plain power attack today and crushed a light University of South Carolina football team, 34 to 6, in gaining its fourth straight victory in the annual State Fair game.
Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Mills Jr. of Scarborough, N. Y., were hosts at a supper party and dance for more than 200 persons in the Cameo Ballroom of the Greenbrier tonight.
Coach Dick Harlow today 'announced his decision on Harvard's quarterback problem for the Dartmouth game here Saturday, naming Chief Boston, his heavy blocker, as the man to run the Crimson eleven.
Due largely to a seasonal retirement of $39,000,000 of money in circulation, member banks of the Federal Reserve System had their reserve balances increased $20,000,000 in the current statement week.

Former fellow officers in the Kentucky National Guard termed Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt "domineering" and "power drunk" in giving testimony today at the murder trial of Roy and Jack Garr, charged with murder of the former adjutant general.

Representatives of local packing houses conferred yesterday afternoon behind closed doors with William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, at his offices at 139 Centre Street, on the proposed city ordinance that would make compulsory the government grading of all meats sold here as well as the licensing of packers and butchers.

By winning the eighth game of the series at the Municipal Auditorium tonight, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris increased his lead over Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world in their title match.

Isidore Nagler, candidate of the American Labor, City Fusion and Progressive parties for Borough President of the Bronx, attacked Borough President James J. Lyons, his Democratic opponent, from two directions last night in a speech at a rally at Hunt's Point Palace.

The famous mare Captivation and five other harness horses owned by Mrs. Loula Long Combs of Kansas City, Mo., have been entered for the rational harness horse championship in the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 3 to 10, it was announced yesterday by Ned King, manager of the show.

123d St, 51 E, 19.5x101; William C. Beller and wife to Hospital for Joint Diseases, 1,919 Madison Ave ($27). Pearl St, 431-433, running through to 27 1/229 New Chambers St, 25.4 on former and 40.4 on latter; John F. Goonan to Mae Callahan, Katherine Guerin and Dorothy Bagley, 8,301 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn; mtg $5,000.

The Johns-Manville Corporation and subsidiary companies showed for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 consolidated net profits of $4,592,191 after all charges, including provision for depreciation, depletion and income tax accrual but before provision for surtax on undistributed income, Lewis H. Brown, president, announced yesterday.

The creation of a post for a highly paid publicity man to coordinate the promotion program of the WPA Federal theatre, music, art and writing projects is being considered by WPA officials, it was learned last night.
Defeat of two State constitutional amendments and approval of a $40,000,000 bond issue to be voted on Nov. 2 were urged by the State Federation of Labor in a bulletin sent out to members today.

An executive session of the Supreme Council, Thirty-third Degree, Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite Masons of the Southern Jurisdiction of the United States, named two Masons. today as emeriti members of honor.

Alonzo B. Cook, candidate for Mayor, whose nomination papers were challenged by the Boston Ballot Law Commis sion, disappeared today just as a Suffolk County grand jury was returning an indictment against a South End man accused of circu lating falsified papers for him.

James A. Gray, president of the Reynolds Tobacco Company, announced yesterday that the directors had adopted a new dividend schedule which will comprise four quarterly interim dividends and a fifth or final dividend in each year, instead of the four quarterly dividends hitherto paid. The new plan will be effective beginning next sear.

The engagement of Miss Lillian S. Yaffee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard -Yaffee of South Glens Falls, to Dr. Julius S. Perelman of Newark, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. M. D. Perelman of Burlington, Vt., has been announced by her parents.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain tonight accepted without reservations Italy's repeated assurances that she had no territorial or strategic designs upon Spain, the Balearic Islands or the Spanish colonies.

The effectiveness of cooperation between public and private health agencies and the usefulness of the system by which the city has been divided into sections served by local health units were praised yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and other speakers at the unveiling of a plaque in the lobby of the health center at 158-164 East 115th Street.

Mrs. Alice Wykoff Flood of Princeton and Miss Louise MacDowell of Rock Tavern, N. Y., will play the feminine roles in the Princeton Theatre Intime's initial production of its seventeenth annual season.

Victories in the world-wide fight against leprosy in the last quarter century were described and the dire need for a continued fight against 'this most shunned and dread pestilence" was urged by representatives and field workers of the American Mission to Lepers at their thirtieth annual meeting yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.
Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, announced today that. the commission had fixed minimum wage scales and rules for working conditions on all government subsidized ships.

Benjamin Ferber, dealer in antiques, has bought the building at 204 East Fifty-sixth Street from Stephen Paul Boochever in a deal arranged by Henry B. Root, Inc., broker. The structure will be altered and occupied in its entirety by the new owner.

Retail credit collections declined 0.07 per cent in September, according to the index of twenty local "key" stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The dip compares with an increase of 0.7 per cent in August and a decline of 0.21 per cent in September a year ago.
Mr. and Mrs. Paul Garrett of Bluff Point, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Virginia Garrett, to Douglas Bowman Weed of Morristown, N. J.
Dr. Chengting T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador, said tonight his country was grateful for the "characteristie American respect for the rights of other nations."
Stockholders of the Westinghouse Air Brake -Company have been called to vote on Nov. 16 on a proposal of the board of directors to distribute as dividends a paid-in surplus of $6,344,221.

Dr. Carl G. Jung of Zurich, psychologist, said today in a Terry lecture at Yale that an authentic religious function existed in the unconscious mind and that there were dreams in which the religious attitude was liberated from the external qualities of an organized creed.

Leasing of apartments in houses on Park Avenue Was brisk yesterday. Dr. George A. Wyeth took a suite in 791 Park Avenue in a lease arranged by Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers, who also rented an apartment in 1,230 Park Avenue to Mrs. Johanna Brender. Other rentals reported follow:

Funeral services will be held today for Felix M. Warburg, financier and philanthropist, who died Wednesday at his home at 1,109 Fifth Avenue. Expressions of regret at his death continued to be made public yesterday by business associates, civic leaders and religious and charitable organizations.

Heavy fighting on all fronts in the Shanghai area reached an impressive culmination after nightfall yesterday when the Chinese launched determined counter-offensives in wo sectors in the vicinity of Tachang, six miles northwest of Shanghai.

A national conference of local housing authorities to discuss the Federal $526,000,000 slum clearance program and lay plans for putting it into effect quickly will be called in Washington shortly after Nov. 1, Nathan Straus, Administrator of the Federal Housing Authority, announced yesterday.

A commission appointed to investigate shortage in the government's currency note fund, dating from 1922 to 1931, today reported "evidence points irresistibly to the conclusion a retired Treasury official took advantage of the inadequacy of the system of control to appropriate to his own use notes valued at $200.000."
The-possession of more than 15.4 pounds of food was made a criminal offense by a new decree issued today by the food supply department.

Stockholders of the Kinsey Distilling Company approved yesterday an increase in its authorized stock as follows: prior preferred, from 60,000 to 80,000 shares; participating preferred, from 60,000 to 100,000 shares, and common, from 60.000 to 100.000 shares.
Lord Rutherford started this business of transmuting the atoms, but he was skeptical about the goal on which the old

Dr. Robert William Bainbridge Mayo, a noted diagnostician, died here today at the age of 53. He was born at Fortress Monroe, Va., the son of the Rev. Charles J. Mayo, a Protestant Episcopal clergyman, and Mary Reynolds Webber Mayo.
Mr. and Mrs. Spruille Braden have announced that the marriage of their daughter, Miss Maruja Braden, to William Hart Lyons of St. Paul, Minn., will take place here Saturday.
None of the important items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year.

The United States Treasury notified depository banks in this Federal Reserve District yesterday that it had called for the repayment on next Monday of $8,462,400, or 5 per cent of the funds on deposit with these banks for the account of subscriptions to the 1 3/8 per cent and 1 3/4 per cent Treasury notes dated June 15.

France is disposed to give the credit-and also the responsibility-for yesterday's accord in the Spanish Non-Intervention Committee to Great Britain. In all quarters there is praise for the skillful diplomacy that turned an almost impossible situation into a success, and everywhere the agreement, despite its shortcomings, is recognized as such.

President Roosevelt moved today to coordinate the executive activities of the eighteen largest independent and emergency governmental agencies, designating his eldest son and secretary, James Roosevelt, as the person through whom matters intended for the President's attention will be cleared.

Because of the increasing proportion of old people in the population, the nation may need to reconsider its whole old-age policy, Dr. Niles Carpenter, dean of the University of Buffalo School of Social Work, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York State Conference on Social Work at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Professor William Wright, dean and Professor of Anatomy at the London Hospital Medical School, died today at the age of 63. He was thrice Hunterian Professor of the Royal College of Surgeons and three times president of the Anatomical Society. A former member of the Senate of the University of London, he was also a distinguished archaeologist.
Donie Bush, baseball veteran who has piloted four major league clubs, said today he was considering a "flattering offer" to manage the Boston National League club.
In an effort to follow the success of "Lloyds of London," Twentieth Century-Fox today launched plans for another British saga, "The Rise of Disraeli," in which Tyrone Power will be featured.

Three varsity elevens worked on running plays, pass formations and pass defense as Coach Jim Crowley sent the Fordham football squad through a two-and-a-half-hour workout on Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for the Ram's first intersectional engagement of the season against Texas Christian at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

Aided by the large turnover of securities and commodity trading, income tax receipts and middle-ofthe month settlements, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday rose above the short week preceding and exceeded the 1936 figure for the first time since Sept. 22.
Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Post Haight of this city and Litchfield, Conn., will give a dinner dance on Dec. 27 at the Colony Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Tracey Haight.

Maurice J. Flynn, retired business man, died at his home in the Northgate Apartments here today after a long illness. He was 66 years old. Mr. Flynn, a native of New York, engaged in-the soapstone quarrying business in Virginia from 1898 to 1916, was proprietor of the Alta Vista Lodge at Saranack Lake, N. Y., for the next ten years and then retired to this place.

Joseph M. Gantz, general agent of the Pacific Mutual Life at Cincinnati, opened the fifty-second dinner season of the Life Underwriters Association of the City of New York, Inc., last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania with an address on "Life Insurance Can Be Merchandized."

With only one other tournament remaining to be played this season, one of the largest fields of the year competed today in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association competition at the Rye Country Club, with Mrs. Charles Eastman of Greenwich winning low gross laurels with 43. 43-86.
Southern Oklahoma's oil strike zone was partly demilitarized tonight as Jones Oil Company officials and C. I. 0. union representatives agreed to a resumption of emergency operations at ten leases.
A. Minor Wellman, assistant clerk of the State Senate and prominent in Republican ranks in the State, died of a heart attack while at breakfast at his home here today. His age was 70.
Women acquitted themselves so well in last Spring's municipal election that their suffrage was extended by King Boris in a new election law signed today.
Twenty-three scholarships were awarded today to Cornell freshmen as the basis of competitive examinations held at the opening of the university. The total value of the awards was $21,200.

In the week ended yesterday awards for engineering construetion in the United States reached a total of $43,946,000, representing a gain of 2 per cent over the $48,120,000 reported for the same week of 1936, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Justice Department officials said today that they would seek to indict James Dalhover, survivor of the Brady gang, next week at Hammond, Ind., for violating the Federal Bank Robbery Law. They added that they still were undecided whether Dalhover would stand trial on State or Federal charges.

The discovery that a small quantity of chromium added to brass makes it much smoother and workable has resulted in the development of a number of new uses for brass, according to reports today to the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, meeting at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton here.

Frederick P. Cone, Florida's sixfoot Governor, who arrived in town Wednesday, talked yesterday in a soft Southern drawl about oranges, lemons, floggings, and under what circumstances, in his opinion, a man may take the law in his hands to string another man on a tree, or ride him on a rail.

A syndicate of .investors bought from the New York Savings Bank the two five-story apartment houses at 198-200 and 202-204 Brown Place, the latter house being at the southeast corner of East 137th Street, the Bronx. Philip Cohn, broker in the transaction, has sold several other parcels to the same syndicate.

The three-acre property of L. A. Van Bomel on Harbor Road, Halesite, Huntington, L. I., has been sold to W. H. Wright for occupancy. Besides the twelve-room residence there are a four-room guest cottage and a two-car garage on the tract, which is said to have been held at $80,000. William J. McNiff was the broker.
It would be easy for the man in the street to get the idea that the action of the Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate in restoring the
Business men Who blamed the City administration for the Closing down of the Ford assembly plant here were assailed as "union busters" today by labor spokesmen.
Coaches and players on the squad, who realize what they are up against, are considerably distressed at the attitude of many followers of Yale toward the coming of Cornell tomorrow.

Representatives Jerry J. O'Connell of Montana and John T. Bernard of Minnesota with Mrs. O'Connell and other members of the American Congressional party who are here in Madrid got a good taste of Insurgent artillery fire last night. The Americans, who have been here for two days, are on the eve of their return to Valencia and the United States.

A deficiency assessment of $477,860 imposed on the National Grocery Company of Jersey City by the Federal Board of Tax Appeals was set aside today in a two-to-one decision of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

A trend toward increased real estate values in a large proportion of cities of 100,000 population was reported by C. E. Rightor, statistician of the Federal Census Bureau, at yesterday's session of the annual conference of the National Association of Assessing Officers in the Hotel New Yorker.

The proposed Federal reconstruction of the Delaware and Raritan Canal as a New Jersey link in a water connection between New York Bay and the Delaware River was approved here today by Commander S. S. Yeandle of the United States Coast Guard at a hearing before a board of United States Army engineers.

Miss Anne Newton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry K. Newton of Cleveland, was married to Charles Alexander Kirkland Jr. of East Orange, N. J., today in Plymouth Church by the Rev. Dr. Miles H. Krumbine.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone opened the way today for attorneys representing twenty-three oil companies which are charged by the government with conspiracy to fix prices of galosine, to present a defense based on the invalidated NRA and conditions in 1935 in the oil industry.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred V. Norton denied today a petition of William F. Brunner, President of the New York City Board of Aldermen, to restrain the City Board of Elections from accepting petitions nominating George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, for that office on the city Fusion ticket and to restrain the Election Board from placing Mr. Harvey's name on the voting machines as a nominee of that party.

Working under floodlights until long after dark yesterday, Coach Mal Stevens's New York University football squad went through two hours of intensive practice at Ohio Field. The drill was the final one prior to the game with Lafayette at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow.
A crowd of 25,000 is expected to turn out tomorrow night to see Carnegie Tech of Pittsburgh and Temple University meet in the eighth renewal of their gridiron rivalry.
The motor vessel Delane, one of the first big ships named after a journalist, was launched here today at Harland Wolff's yard.

The Princeton football squad cast custom to the winds this afternoon on University Field and instead of starting the usual tapering off process for Saturday's game with Rutgers, ran the gamut of heavy contact work for more than an hour and a half.

A group of Japanese studying agrlculture arrived here today. The commission announced that Japan could purchase the entire cotton crop of Nicaragua, giving in return Japanese products, mostly textiles.

The Coast Guard announced the following changes during the week ended Oct. 20: Searles, Capt. H. R., San Francisco Division, assigned to await further orders. Parker, Capt. S. V., to commander, San Francisco Division, effective upon detachment of Capt. Searles.

More than 500 leaders in the furniture and allied trades will pay tribute to Barney Marks of Gimbel Brothers at a testimonial dinner to be given in his honor on Sunday evening at the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the furniture division of the joint distribution committee and the United Palestine Appeal.

The world consumption of tin in the year ended on Sept. 30 was 175,580 tons, while production was 192,868 tons, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council. In the year ended on Aug. 31, 1936, consumption was placed at 160,950 tons.
Rollin A. Wilbur, former Cleveland financier and associate of the late Myron T. Herrick, Ambassador to France, died yesterday in a Toledo hospital which he entered on Oct. 11. His age was 65.

Milk distributors in the metropolitan market answered a strike threat of up-State members of the Dairymen's Union tonight with a decision to negotiate prices only with producers' cooperative associations organized under the Rogers-Allen Law.

The report of the Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Sept. 30, issued today, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $8,410,891.

Payment of the fourth return to depositors of the closed New Jersey National Bank and Trust company in Newark will begin next Monday, according to a statement today by C. P. Rogers, receiver for the bank, Which closed in 1932.

The church can do more than it is doing now to rescue juvenile delinquents from crime, said A. E. Gold of Binghamton, Assistant Federal Attorney, addressing the New York State Presbyterian Synod here today.
Mrs. Emma Stern Wertheim, widow of Jacob Wertheim, New York cigar manufacturer and philanthropist, died today of heart disease at her home here after a short illness. Mrs. Wertheim was 70 years old.
Lumber production increased slightly more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index has moved up to 76.9 from 76.1. The figure for the week ended Oct. 17, 1936, was 83.3.

An increase of more than $8,000,000 in deposits by chartered banks was noted today in the report of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday, while notes in circulation dropped $299,507. Short term securities of the Dominion and Provincial Governments were increased from $71,109,812 to $74,396,013.

Frank K. Houston, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, New York, and president of the New York State Association of Bankers, advocated tonight repeal of the capital gains and undistributed earnings taxes as a means of restoring confidence among business men, in an address before Group 2 of the State Association at the Oak Hill Country Club.

Recent advances in licensing legislation have given realty investors assurance of greater protection than ever before against fraud or incompetency on the part of brokers and land developers, delegates to the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards were told today.

Funeral services for the Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, distinguished rabbinical scholar, will be held at the Congregation Shearith Israel, Seventieth Street and Central Park West, on Sunday, at 10 A. M. Dr. Mendes, who died at his Mount Vernon home on Wednesday, had been leader of this congregation for forty-three years, retiring in 1920.

The usually mild-mannered Sleepy Jim Crowley flailed away at football's "forward fumble" play yesterday before the Touchdown Club, characterized it as perniciously unfair and demanded that the rules committee abolish it by proper legislation. The Fordham coach even went a bit farther than that.

TIME out. Put that football away for a minTute. There's a row going on. A citizen of St. Louis started it by questioning a statement made by this observer to the effect that in a world series game in Washington in 1925 four umpires saw Firpo Marberry bat out of turn and not one of the umpires batted an eye or raised a voice in criticism of Mr. Marberry's illegal gesture.

The British policy to "take the most vigorous measures to combat terrorism" in Palestine before attempting to carry out the partition program was emphasized by William G. A. Ormsby-Gore, Secretary of State for the Colonies, in the opening session of the House of Commons today.

Miss Mary R. Griffin, daughter of Mrs. Mary C. Griffin of Rumson and the late Patrick Griffin, who was Mayor of Hoboken for seventeen years, was married to City Magistrate Eldon C. Presley, son of Charles L. Presley of this city, today in the rectory of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church here.

Miss Geraldine Novak of New York, who was selected by consuls of various fur-producing countries as queen of National Fur Week, called today at the White House and was received by Marvin McIntyre, secretary to the President.

A painting by Jean Louis Forain, "Scene de Tribunal: Appel des Temoins," brought $1,500 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at a sale of paintings from the estate of Altha C. Beaufort and Sara Stern, and from the collections of Mrs. Clarence Crittenden Calhoun and Edward M. Bratter.
Postmaster General James A Farley will make a radio appeal next Tuesday night for the election of the Mahoney-Taylor-Schneider ticket, it was learned authoritatively yesterday.

The Coal Commission, a month late with its plans to set minimum prices for bituminous coal, cracked down on Eastern soft coal operators today on the ground that they were delaying the commission's biggest job in regulating the industry.
Stocks closed higher, rail shares strong, after dipping early; turnover. 3,636,051 shares. All groups of bonds strong, rail and convertible issues leading; transactions,. $14,754,025.

The Keystone Hotel will be permanently closed unless its striking employes accept wages in line with those paid in other hotels in the city, James E. Knott, vice president of Knott Hotels Corporation, said today as he left here after failing to settle the strike.
Mayor La Guardia charged that Tammany Hall had sought to instigate a strike on the B. M. T. and that he had succeeded in averting a tie-up.

183d St. 114 W (11-3224); Hall of Fame Building Corp to Seamen's Bank for Savings; instaliments, 4 1/2 per cent ; $35,000. Briggs Ave, 2,886 (12-3296) ; Glovanni Pacella to East River Savings Bank; extends mtg to Sept. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 percent; $68,800.

John V. Schaefer, former city engineer of Long Beach and builder of many large residences in this part of the country, died tonight of heart disease at Long Beach Hospital. Mr. Schaefer, who was 65 years old, had lived here a number of years.

The first public hearing at which the audience will be composed largely of persons completely or nearly deaf, with the meeting room wired for sound, will be held at 8 o'clock tonight by the Legislative Commission on the Hard of Hearing at 480 Lexington Avenue.

The engagement of Miss Jane Honour McCreery, daughter of Mrs. Robert S. McCreery of this city and Pasadena, Calif., and the late Mr. McCreery, to Henry Theodor Schaps, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Henry Schaps of Lankenberg, Germany, and Sacramento, Calif., has been announced by her mother.

Business conditions and not "mistakes of Treasury experts" were responsible for the downward revision of revenue estimates in the President's revised budget statement made publie on Tuesday, Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today.

In the area of Shihkiachwang, south of Peiping, the Japanese military forces are making great efforts to restore communications with those forceS in the mountains which, for some days, have been fed by biscuits dropped to them from Japanese planes.

The price of corn has been falling, and the universal assumption in Washington appears to be that something must be done about it. The farm lobby wants loans of 60 cents a bushel against corn. Secretary Wallace says the loans will be made, that "human ingenuity" can find some way to raise the money, but that they will probably be made at about 46 cents a bushel.
The Citizens Union made public its recommendations on City Council candidates from Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond. Its recommendations on Manhattan and the Bronx were announced Wednesday.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli, conductor, opened its season of 1937-38 last night in Carnegie Hall. There was a big and brilliant audience. There were enthusiastic greetings of the young conductor, who now assumes the very responsible and exacting post of leader for the next three years of the Philharmonic-Symphony.

General Manoel Cerquiera Daltro, Federal Interventor for the State of Rio Grande do Sul, advised the Ministry of War today he had "commenced to gather war material" distributed by the resigned government of Jose Antonio Flores da Cunha and "the entire State is tranquil."

The Brooklyn College football squad was heartened yesterday by the return to action of Julie Zenowitz, halfback, who had been out for two weeks. Zenowitz starred in the R. P. I. game and will be in the line-up when Brooklyn faces Lowell Textile tomorrow.

Plans for a new bank to-succeed the defunct Union Trust Company here will go forward at once, Samuel H. Squire, State Superintendent of Banks, said tonight after receiving a "go ahead" signal from Attorney General Herbert S. Duffy.

Union dock workers returned to their jobs here and in Miami today. Tampa overseas shippers and longshore union officials signed a tentative agreement for an eight-hour day, an increase of 10 cents an hour for straight time and 15 cents for over time. Under a contract which expired Sept. 30, wage scales ranged from 33 cents to 50 cents an hour for a ten-hour day.
The first column of Insurgent troops entered Gijon, last important government port on the Bay of Biscay, at 5 P. M. today, according to a broadcast from Rebel headquarters at Salamanca.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday its opposition to Proposition 1, to be voted on at the coming election, which calls for a $40,000,000 State bond issue for the construction of hospital, charitable and correction institution buildings.

With 30,000 tickets disposed of and a larger crowd in prospect than that which saw the Army game, Yale went through a last rigorous workout on Anthony Thompson Field today before tapering off for the meeting in the Bowl with Cornell on Saturday.
After a strong start, the stock market yesterday had to contend with considerable profit-taking, but it closed higher when railway shares led a brisk rally in the final hour.
A representative throng of members of society filled the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for a gala party marking the formal opening of the room for this season.

The fortyfive executions reported today from Irkutsk, following the fiftyfour reported yesterday from Ulan Uday, further stresses the importance the Soviet attaches to the Japanese espionage danger in the South Baikal region in East Central Siberia. The verdicts were identical in both cases, for espionage and sabotage "undertaken by instructions of foreign secret service agents."

In preparation for the Automobile Show, a number of advertising managers of various companiess yesterday paid tribute to the effectiveness of newspaper advertising and outlined plans for increased linage on the 1938 models.

Professor Julian Huxley had a new example of the genuinely philanthropic spirit today. He told guests at a luncheon of the Political and Economic Planning Association that a woman had written to the Zoo, of which he is now the secretary, complaining that officials apparently were unaware of the fact that the sun had made the rocks on "Monkey Hill" so hot that some of the baboons had been badly scorched.

When the British Parliament reconvened yesterday Mr. Anthony Eden was able to inform it that something has at last occurred to relieve, rather than to increase, the tension prevailing in Europe. This development is the unaerstanding which has now been reached by the chief Powers concerning Spain. It is, to be sure, a carefully hedged agreement.

The establishment of the East Harlem Health Center sixteen years ago was primarily for the purpose of demonstrating the value of such a service to a neighborhood. It was undertaken hopefully by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, which after the World War turned its attention to the care of public health.

A northwest shift of a gale that reached seventy miles an hour is believed to have caused the big United Airlines Mainliner to drift from its course into the mountain where it crashed Sunday night in Utah with nineteen fatalities, Major R. W. Schroeder, vice president of the company and formerly assistant director of the Bureau of Air Commerce, said in a statement issued last night by the New York office.

We can't imagine any better way to learn football than under Columbia's Lou Little and his hustling band of assistants. It wouldn't be the easy way, for Columbia Lou is a Jekyll and Hyde on and off the field.
Time Allowances It is ordered that the following firemen be allowed the time served by them in the Police Department, which shall be included and counted as service in the Fire Department:
Luis Angel Firpo, heavyweight fighter, nicknamed in the United States the "Wild Bull of the Pamspas," was ordered arrested today by the Criminal Court of Appeals.

Christian H. Ruhl, lawyer and banker, died of pneumonia late today at his home here after a short illness. He was 84 years old. His illness was aggravated by shock over the death a month ago of his wife, the former Elizabeth A. Runkle.

Faced with steadily mounting expenses without' comparable increases in operating revenues, the Southern railroads of the United States, through the Southeastern Passenger Association, filed notice today with the Interstate Commerce Commission that they would increase one-way passenger coach fares from 1 1/2 cents a mile to 2 cents.

Charles Markell of Baltimore has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Jeannette Markell, to Charles Greenleaf Page, son of Colonel Henry Page, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Page, who now live in Florida.

Mr. and Mrs. William Kingsland Macy of Islip, L. I., and 18 East Eighty-first Street, this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Kingsland Macy, to W. Cary Potter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo Potter, also of this city.
Morris Umansky, whose undated resignation as judge of the North Hudson Distract Court was held valid by a jury, asked the Supreme Court today not to oust him without further hearing.

The election of Ernest E. Norris as president of the Southern Railway to succeed Fairfax Harrison was announced yesterday. This was the first change in the presidency of the company in twenty-four years. Mr. Harrison had requested that he be retired.
A tousel-headed youngster won the hearts of Philadelphia music levers tonight in an appearance with the Philadelphia Orchestra.
A further drop of $39,000,000 in brokers' loans was reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve In New York City in their condition statement as of Wednesday, issued yesterday.

With much larger than average fruit supplies in prospect for market in the Winter months, prices throughout the Winter marketing season are expected to be generally low, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today in its October fruit situation report.

United States Treasury notes worth $674,209 with coupons were recovered early yesterday from a subway lock box by a representative of the United States Attorney's office and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Harry L. Magee, son of a carpet manufacturer, today won control of two Bloomsburg factories in settlement of a court fight involving the $4,000,000 estate left by his mother, Mrs. Ella G. Magee.

News from Danzig of the dissolution of the Catholic Center party and all its auxiliaries means that the National Socialist organization there, which forms a third gau (district) of the German Nazi party, has made itself sole master of the Free City, thereby establishing the first totalitarian State outside the Reich itself.

Taking advantage of the splendid weather yesterday after three rainy days, both the Giants and Dodgers went through intensive drills on their gridirons in preparation for their engagement on Sunday at the Polo Grounds.

Daniale Amfitheatrof, young Russian-born conductor and composer, arrived yesterday on the Vulcania to take up his newly accepted duties as associate conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, of which Dimitri Mitropolous is conductor.

The American International Corporation reports a net asset value of $24,626,576 on Sept. 30, 1937, equivalent to $2,141.44 on each $1,000 of outstanding debt and to $13.12 a share on the common stock, compared to $28,917,718, or $2,514.58 on the debt and S17.41 a share on the common stock on June 30.

During the week ended Oct. 20 member bank reserve balances increased $20,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from a decrease of $39,000,000 in money in circulation and increases of $7,000,000 in Reserve bank credit and $4,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by increases of $11,000,000 in Treas ury cash other than inactive gola and $21,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.
The first offering of the Treasury's new series of weekly $50,000,000 bill issues, maturing about March 15, was announced tonight by Secretary Morgenthau.
Official ballots for candidates for the City Council in New York County showed yesterday that thirty-six of the forty-seven candidates will run with party designations.

Lines of men's wear fabrics for Spring, which have been withdrawn by several leading mills, will be reinstated either today or early next week at prices showing reductions expected to range up to 12 1/2, cents a yard, according to reports in the woolen market here yesterday.

The Duke of Windsor's BrownShirt hosts spent the most embarrassing quarter of an hour of his German tour here today when their guest had them take him into the "Colonial Demand and Foreign Germanism Exposition" under the mistaken impression that he was visiting the royal palace of the former Kings of Wuerttemberg.
Every one of Pennsylvania's needy "on relief" is likely to be called upon again to apply and prove that help is required.

Motors securities Company, Inc., Shreveport, La., engaged in automobile financing, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 750 collateral trust notes for an aggregate proposed offering of $1,000,000.
The practice of the Navy eleven was curtailed this afternoon in order for the players to make ready for their trip to South Bend, Ind., where Notre Dame will be met on Saturday.
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast to, day are: Surrogate Frank I. Smith, "How to Keep a Court Clean,"- WHN, 6:45 to 7 P. M.
Dartmouth's football team went through its last Hanover practice before the Harvard game today, and practically the entire session was spent on signals and forward passing.

In his annual message to Parliament, read by Premier Pandelo Evangheli today, King Zog, after saying friendly, relations were being maintained with all States, outlined the various economic and public works projects for the current and following year.

Harry Lillis (Bing) Crosby came home today and received an honorary degree of Doctor of Philosophy and the key to the city he left ten years ago with "two shirts, a pair of socks and a battered Tin Lizzie."

Thirty confident Manhattan football players left New York City yesterday afternoon for Lexington in the Bluegrass country, where they will -meet the University of Kentucky tomorrow in a return game of a home-and-home series started in New York City last year with a 13-7 victory for the Jaspers.
Severiano Pulido, acting President of the Council, was wounded by an unknown assailant during a meeting of the Council in the Provincial Palace today. Ramon Espinosa, a policeman, also was shot.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Oct. 15 showed that the ratio of the bank's gold reserve to notes in circulation was 132.34 per cent, against 132.91 per cent on Sept. 30. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities was 90.40 per cent, against 91.16 per cent.

State police guarded the homes of several State officials tonight because of an attempted kidnapping earlier today of the infant son of Louis W. Cappelli, Secretary of State and a member of Governor Quinn's Cabinet.

The marital troubles of Prescott Van Wyck, grand-nephew of the late Robert A. Van Wyck, first Mayor of Greater New York, and his wife, Lolita Cordova Van Wyck, a musician and dancer, were taken to the District Attorney's office yesterday when Mr. Van Wyck, who lives at 24 West Fifty-ninth Street, received a subpoena.

Dr. Andrew Wilson Lawrence. Sr., a practicing physician in Brooklyn for more than fifty years and on the staff of St. Catherine's and St. Cecilia's Hospitals, died on Tuesday in the North County Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L. I., in his seventy-ninth year.
George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart's political satire, "I'd Rather Be Right," now playing a preliminary engagement in Boston, will be published in November by Random House.

A sentence of seven to ten years in State's prison was imposed by Judge Robert V. Kinkead today in the Court of Oyer and Terminer on 16-year-old Jerry May of Union City, who on Dec. 31 1935, killed his 7-year-old cousin, Sergi Sciarra, with a hammer.

More than 300 persons attended a meeting last night of the Technology Club of New York at 22 East Thirty-eighth Street. The gathering was held to disouss plans of a campaign to raise $1,650,000 among the alumni of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for new recreational buildings and equipment at the institute.

Enrico Venturi, lightweight champion of Italy, and Davey Day of Chicago will clash tonight at the Hippodrome in the feature tenround bout that probably will provide the next challenger for the lightweight crown held by Lou Ambers.

The Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union is now seeking an appointment with the labor committee of the League of New York Theatres for the discussion of minimum wages for box-office men in the Broadway houses, it was said yesterday by Theodore Mitchell, president of the T. M. A. T. A tentative scale will be set at a meeting tonight of the executive board of the union and its committee on this subject.

A Decision on whether to adopt a definite labor relations policy may be decided upon by the board of governors of the Associated General Contractors of America, representing two-thirds of all the general construction in the United States, at its Fall meeting tomorrow and Saturday in the Hotel Ambassador here.

While the annual convention of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York closed today without any official hint on the subject, it was learned that there was much discussion of the problem of meeting the competition of savings assembled by other organizations and the possibility that something should be done about the present discrepancy between savings bank dividends and mortgage interest rates.

Turpentine firm, 27 1/2c; sales 92 barrels; receipts 27 barrels; shipments 11 barrels; stock 38,228 barrels. Resin firm; sales 772; receipts 1,261; no shipments: stock 85,161. Quote: B. D. E. $6.85: F to N, $7.02 1/2; WG. S7.25: WW. X. $7.50.

Coach Art Winters ran the risk of pregame injuries by ordering a scrimmage for Hamilton's eleven today, but his squad came through intact. The result was a much-polished pass defense with which Hamilton hopes to halt Rochester's aerials.

Regular checking of salaries of office workers, including individual appraisal of the quality of work produced and adjustments where merited, was recommended yesterday by L. M. Guelich, office supervisor of the National Cash Register Company, Dayton, Ohio, to more than 500 office managers at a conference on office management problems sponsored by the American Management Association at the Astor Hotel.

The growth of the trade union movement in this country will face a test of survival in the event of adverse economic conditions and the "movement will be hard to keep going no matter what its leadership or sources of support," Dr. Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University and former member of the Labor Advisory

Sales of General Motors cars and trucks to dealers overseas in September amounted to 30,109 units, a gain of 27 per cent over last year, it was announced yesterday. For the first nine months of 1937, sales were 276,524 units, a new high record for the period and a gain of 11.7 per cent over the same months in 1936.

Purchase of the Consolidated Water Company by the city of Utica was declared off today by Mayor Vincent Corrou. He said the city could not sell the $7,900,000 in bonds for the purchase because buyers would not bid under the ruling by the State Water and Power Control Commission giving several suburbs permission to buy parts of the water system in their areas at any time.

Improvements over a broad front ruled the stock market today. Influenced by a more cheerful international outlook, prices advanced sharply in all sections. Gilt-edged issues were strong and bonds on the foreign list were better.

SHEFFIELD, England, Oct. 21.--Territorials forming a guard of honor for King George and Queen Elizabeth outside Sheffield Town Hall tonight were forced to cross rifles and swords to prevent crowds from overwhelming the royal car.
The Lambs, a theatrical organization whose membership includes many prominent performers, held its annual election of officers yesterday afternoon at the clubhouse, 128 West Forty-fOurth Street.

Miss Elizabeth Eileen Levins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Levins of this city, has chosen Nov. 25 as the date of her marriage to John D. Schott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Schott of Newark. The wedding will take place in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here.

Dr. Silas S. Neff, founder and president of the Neff College of Oratory, died in the American Stomach Hospital here yesterday after a threeday illness. He was 84 years old. He had taught day and evening classes regularly until he was stricken on Sunday.
Miss Julia F. Deane, social and temperance worker before her retirement in 1933, died today in the Sherman Hospital. Miss Deane was born in Elgin seventy years ago.

The Lawyers Non-Partisan Information Committee on the Judiciary. of which General Louis W. Stotesbury is chairman, announced yesterday that 2,691 lawyers in Manhattan and the Bronx had gone on record as endorsing the candidacies of Supreme Court Justices Aaron J. Levy and Thomas F. Noonan.

Had the. voters of Arkansas elected Governor Bailey instead of Representative Miller to succeed the late Senator Robinson, the administration's political managers would now be claiming a sweeping personal endorsement of the President and the New Deal. The archaic ritual of politics calls for such proclamations.

Even in Brooklyn, where the desire to serve on the new City Council seems to be practically universal, the Proportional Representation ballot for next month's election is not so wide as a church door nor so deep as.a well. It is, in fact, as the sample prepared by the Board of Elections shows, only a little over four feet long-or about two feet shorter than was predicted by President S. Howard Cohen.

Gross revenues of the Western Pacific Railroad in the latter part of September and in the early part of October have run from 5 to 6 per cent ahead of the corresponding levels of a year ago, Thomas M. Schumacher, chairman and trustee in bankruptcy of the company, said yesterday.

Eight charitable organizations receive a total of $710,434 from the estate of Miss Mary de Peyster Carey, descendant of Jan de Peyster, who came to New York from Holland in the early seventeenth century, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Miss Carey, who died Aug. 28, 1936, left a gross estate of $928,199 and a net estate of $833,610.

Maurice E. Gilmore, now PWA State Engineer Inspector for New York, has been appointed director, with headquarters in New York City, of Region No. 1, including Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, New York, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware and New Jersey, in the new set-up placing the entire field staff on a regional basis.

Stanley Washburn Jr., who will marry Miss Nina Phillips, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Phillips of Wenham, Mass., next Friday, in Wenham, gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for his fiancee.
The Italian liner Vulcania arrived last night after a stormy passage from Mediterranean ports. Officers described last Monday and Tuesday as the roughest days in the Vulcania's experience.

As Saturday's election in Australia 1 draws near an otherwise dull cam- if paign has been enlivened by a na- ex tional defense issue. The issue arose with a declaration from all Labor party platforms last week that Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons's acceptance of the Imperial Conference scheme for cooperation in a plan of imperial defense committed Australia to war and made conscription in wartime inevitable.

Following negotiations with the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., of New York, Jose Richling, Minister of Uruguay to the United States, announced yesterday that arrangements were being made to offer to holders of the outstanding 6 and 7 per cent dollar bonds of the city of Montevideo -rights to convert them into bonds of the Republic of Uruguay.

A $65,000 mortgage on 28-34 West End Ave, held by the Seamen's Bank for Savings from Rae V. Brill, was extended to May 1, 1943, the interest rate reduced from 5 to 4 1/4, beginning next May 1. The house at 326 E 85th St was sold by Hattie Manhelms to Sylvia Creager for a consideration shown as $12,000, the buyer giving back a purchase money mortgage for $8,750. at 4 per cent.

Controller Frank J. Taylor, replying yesterday to Mayor La Guardia's charge that he had made a "desperate and despicable raid on the city treasury" by backing the restoration of county jobs in the budget, contended that the Mayor's statements were "reckless and inaccurate."

A concert which will be the first event of the Helen Keller Tribute Year, commemorating the meeting of Miss Keller with her teacher, the late Anne Sullivan Macy, fifty years ago, will be given tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall. The Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, will appear.

Marion Ave. (11,3026), e s, 50 ft n of 188th St, 50x103; Henry Goldberg to Philip Rubenstein, 243 Dahill Rd. Brooklyn. Longfellow Ave, 1,060 (10-2756); Max Kimmel to Etta Gorkin, 985 Simpson St; mtg $10,000. 198th St, 362 E (12-3283), John A. Ambrose to Frank J. Carlie, 362 E 198th St.
Miss Eleanor A. McCann of this place has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Cathryn W. Popple, to Edwin Francis McLaughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. McLaughlin of Pittsfield, Mass.

For the second time in as many days, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins refused yesterday to bar the Trades Union party, which independently nominated William T. Mahoney and his Democratic running mates, from the ballot. He declared that the Election Law should be construed liberally and held the party's petitions valid, although they did not comply fully with all the provisions of the law.
Miss Alice H. Anthony, daughter of Mrs. Mark Anthony of this place and the late Mr. Anthony, will be married on Nov. 20 to Charles H. Mayo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Mayo of Stewart Manor.
MANHATTAN BARTH, HARRY (Aug. 25). Estate, $250. To Bella Barth, widow, 114 E. 52d St., residue. Arthur Schwarz, 1,125 Park Ave., and Alex Goldsmith, 215 W. 88th St., executors.

The sale of $4,800,000 of Territory of Hawaii bonds, originally scheduled for last month, has been set for Oct. 27, it was announced yesterday. Sealed proposals will be received on that date by W. C. McGonagle, Treasurer of the Territory, at his temporary offices in the Bankers Trust Company.
The Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York announced yesterday the receipt of gifts totaling $5,411.46, bringing the amount raised to date in its $200,000 campaign to $39,942.21.

Having found a kicker in Riggs Sullivan, regular right end, Army's problem seems to be solved without changing the line-up for that purpose. The big Kentuckian was booting the ball 60 yards today in full-speed practice, and got one off for 70 as Coach Gar Davidson smiled in satisfaction.

Les Hart, backfield coach, was used to impersonate Eric Tipton, Duke star, today as Colgate's Red Raiders worked against a team of reserves using Duke formations. Hart broke away for several long runs and passed well, but was stopped late in the practice.

Quiet trading within a narrow price range marked business on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. Slight opening gains were followed by moderate losses that were recovered in the last few minutes of trading, with final quotations unchanged to 2 points higher for the day. The December showed the maximum fluctuation; it eased from 8.36 cents a pound to 8.28 cents and closed at 8.32 cents.

Mayor Charles Gold of Long Beach was eliminated as an independent candidate for re-election in a decision this afternoon by Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman, who ruled out 147 names on the Mayor's nominating petitions because of a technical deficiency.
United States Senator A. Harry Moore, Democratic candidate for Governor, linked taxation, Unemployment and the problem of attracting new industries to New Jersey in a series of speeches today.

The strength in the Swiss franc which had appeared in the foreign exchange market on Wednesday vanished yesterday and the unit fell 5 points to 23.04 cents. Other important foreign exchanges were either lower or unchanged.
