The Belgian Government's invitation to attend the Brussels conference was received in Tokyo today. Foreign Minister Kokl Hirota circulated copied to the various departments concerned, including the Prime Minister and Ministers for War and Navy.

Preparation of minimum budgets for women workers, as a basis for determination of the minimum wages to be paid them, was discussed today at the Seventh Minimum wage Conference, which, called by Secretary Perkins, opened a two-day session here. Delegates included labor commissioners and State minimum wage administrators.
The Maritime Commission today announced that it had accepted bids totaling $991,111.93 for the purchase of twenty-two steel cargo vessels of its laid-up fleet.

Settlement of the long-standing boundary dispute between Honduras and Nicaragua is to be attempted through a tender of good offices which was made today by the governments of the United States, Venezuela and Costa Rica.

The charge that Bruce Barton, Republican candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, had subscribed to the principles of Mussolini was made yesterday by Stanley Osserman, Democratic candidate for the same post, in a telegram to Mayor La Guardia.
Practicing on a dry field for the first time this week, the Williams eleven went through a long session today, its last before it leaves for Medford tomorrow to face Tufts on Saturday.

Archbishop Celso Costantini, Secretary of the Congregation for the Propogation of the Faith, today called on Catholic missionaries to wage relentless combat against communism and not to limit themselves to prayers and devotions in that struggle.

Henry M. Walker, who was a judge of the Chicago Municipal Court from 1920 to 1926, died Tuesday night in his home at 628 Barry Avenue. He was 72 years old. He was born in Germany and came to Chicago with his parents when he was a year old.

All sorts of candidates are seeking night and day to recommend themselves to the women voters. If the practice of members of the Westchester League of Women Voters is common in other regions, the seekers of feminine political favor are submitted

An increase of 18 per cent in automobile fatalities in the State during the first eight months of this year, compared with the same period last year, was characterized as "alarming" by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

Despite a truce in the strike of longshoremen in Southern ports which calls for their immediate return to work,' operators of coastwise lines who withdrew their tonnage this week because of the tieup of their Southern terminals, will not resume operations for several days.

The might. eat fighter in the army air force was delivered to army officers today after a final test flight. The' big bomber left for Wright Field at Dayton, where the army will continue its own teats.

As Cornell's football squad prepared to leave tomorrow for the Yale game, the possibility developed that George Peck, halfback who has been out with a chipped vertebra since the Princeton game, may play Saturday.
The Windsor Apartments, a fivestory building at 1,468 Midland Avenue, overlooking the Bronx River Parkway at Bronxville, has been sold by a client of Raymond R Beatty to Frederick Brown, operator.

D. B. Hanna, president of the Western Canada Flour Mills, Ltd., announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Toronto his decision to retire from the presidency. He said he would be succeeded by A. J. Mitchell, vice president. He will continue a director of the company.
The four honorary societies of the senior and junior classes at Cornell University announced new members today for the year.
Business in the Pittsburgh district again declined last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Lee Pressman, general counsel for the Committee for Industrial Organization, said today he had filed with the National Labor Relations Board a petition for a national election among the 17,000 employes of the Postal Telegraph Company, Who, he explained, are seeking. to be represented exclusively by the American Radio Telegraphists Association.

Manhattan 132d St, 638-42 W, 75x99.11; for 1-story garage; the Borden Co., premises, owner; H. B. Lindberg, architect; cost, $20,000. Alterations 14th St, 229 W; to 5-story rectory; Augustine Fathers, premises, owner; G. E. Steinback, architect; cost, $9,800.
Financial circles here estimated today that pay cuts of 5 to 25 per cent and staff reductions of 5 to 30 per cent had been put into effect in this city's brokerage houses since June.

Asserting that Tammany had instructed its workers to "forget Mahoney, beat Dewey," Joseph D. McGoldriek, Fusion nominee for Controller, declared last evening that many politicians would face jail If Thomas E. Dewey, rackets prosecutor, is elected District Attorney of New York County.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Harry Westbrook Dunning of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Dunning, to Edmund McLaughlin, son of Mrs. D. E. McLaughlin of West Newton.

Intelligence and good musician; ship characterized the singing put forth by David Blair McClosky at his recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The young baritone, though hitherto unheard here, has made numerous appearances in Boston, his native city, including several with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and his work was projected with the poise that comes of experience.

Edward B. Hall, president of the Investment Bankers Association, announced yesterday that T. Jefferson Coolidge, vice president of the First National Bank of Boston and former Under- Secretary of the Treasury, will address the forum on
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
Investing client of Samuel Hurwitz have purchased mortgages on Brooklyn properties as follows: ,000 on the 3-story dwelling at 1,325 Dean St. and $2,250 on the 2-story frame house at 2.684 E 23 St.

George Miller Taylor, retired private banker, died yesterday of mark, pneumonia at his apartment in the Hotel Van Rensselaer, 17 East Eleventh Street, after a week's illness. Mr. Taylor, who had been retired fifty years, was 84 years old.

With plans for a new corn-loan program in abeyance pending a search for funds by Daniel W. Bell, the acting Budget Director, it developed today that the Administration has in mind a modification of some phases of production-control policy which it had intended to propose when general farm legislation is offered at the extra session of Congress.

A plot on the southwest corner or Montgomery Street and Ocean Avenue, Atlantic Beach, L. I., 140 by 170 feet, fronting on the Boardwalk and the Atlantic Ocean, has been sold by the Atlantic Beach Sales Corporation to the Inwood Beach Club, Inc.

As of the end of this theatrical 'week, Broadway will be darker by the departure of two shows. Thus: (a) After sixty performances at the Center Theatre, "Virginia" will conclude its run tomorrow night, and with it will end the Rockefeller interests' first solo flight into theatrical production.

A shout for aid by William J. Eckhart, assistant treasurer of the General Shaver Corporation, frustrated an attempted hold-up of the company's $6,200 payroll today by three bandits who fled from the scene in their automobile.
The Biological Survey enlisted the aid of "fishermen, stevedores and ferry boat captains" on the North Atlantic coast today in a study of the migratory habits of herring gulls.
A mimic "war" of flour bags and cameras will enliven Long Island Sound on Sunday, as sportsmen in yachts and airplanes battle each other for prizes, according to an announcement yesterday.

Judge Charles S. Bell recessed the murder trial of Anna Marie Hahn this afternoon, announcing that he would reserve until tomorrow his decision as to the admissibility of testimony concerning deaths of persons other than Jacob Wagner, 78.

Secretary Hull and his party, visiting Canada, attended a dinner tonight at Government House, tendered by Governor General and Lady Tweedsmuir in honor of their United States guests. Mr. Hull is returning visits made to Washington earlier this year by the Governor General and Prime Minister Mackenzie King.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan said yesterday that the new Criminal Courts Building and City Prison to be built on the site bounded by Leonard, Center, White and Baxter Streets would have nine stories, a Cellar, subcellar and -a penthouse structure for ventilating and elevator equipment.

The 104th convention, New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, opens at the Hotel Astor at 10 o'clock Afternoon session, 2 P. M. Luncheon, Citizens Security party, in honor of N. Kousmith Kous, St. Moritz Hotel, 2 P. M.

Further recoveries marked the course of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Led by the railroad issues, which registered gains ranging as high as 8 and 10 points, other obligations advanced from 1 to 4 points in a turnover only slightly smaller than Wednesday's.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Kemp Fry, daughter of Mrs. Wilfred W. Fry of Ayer House, this place, and the late Mr. Fry, to Randall Hunt Decker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Randall H. Decker of Montclair.

A jury is to be chosen today in Supreme Court to determine whether Leo Greendlinger, accountant and one of the founders of the Alexander Hamilton Institute, died before or after midnight of Oct. 10, 1935.
Denny Shute, Byron Nelson and Henry Picard, United States professionals, had little trouble surviving first round matches today in the pro match play golf tournament arranged in their honor.

The keel of the $60,000,000 battleship North Carolina, first capital ship to be constructed in this country in fourteen years and one of four on the navy's present building schedule, will be laid at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn next Wednesday--Navy Day-at 12:15 P. M.

Wool goods markets were unsettled this week as buying of piece goods continued slow and wool and yarn values drifted to lower levels, according to the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. The price situation was not improved by some clearances of men's wear Fall fabrics at prices considerably below the last quoted levels.
The total value of Manchukuo's foreign trade during August was placed at $29,933,000 by the Commerce Department today, based on reports from the American Consul at Dairen.
Paul Codd, who trains his own horses, scored a consecutive double at Empire City yesterday when his Pageboy provided a big surprise in the featured Winsted Purse.
More than 800 of the 1,400 former employes of the Northrop Aircraft Corporation returned to work today after signing anti-strike contracts with the company.
Baldwin M. Baldwin, grandson of the late E. J. (Lucky) Baldwin, married Mrs. Rowena Schneider White of South Pasadena, Calif., today.

A two-hour drill yesterday, in which the linemen were given considerable contact work, with blocking stressed, wound up City Coilege's work for tomorrow's game with Hobart in Geneva, N. Y. Coach Benny Friedman and twenty-two players will depart tonight.

Miss Loriel Martens Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Halsey Johnson, has chosen the afternoon of Nov. 12 for her marriage to William Livingston Desloge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Firmin Desloge of St. Louis.

Laurence L. Baehr has returned to the Curtis Furniture Company, Inc., as general manager, after an absence of five years, during which time he was with Thonet Brothers, Modern Age Furniture Corporation and the Hecht Company, Washington.
Mrs. Bertha D. Woodling of Southfield Point, Conn., widow of Edwin G. Woodling, New York investment broker, died today of a heart attack while walking at Hinman Avenue and Grove Street, Evanston.
Germany's efforts toward raw material independence are brought out in an exhibition of shoes and gloves manufactured from fishskins.

A dinner to Benny Gottesman, who, as one of Thomas E. Dewey's witnesses in the restaurant racket trial, told how he resisted through a year of terror the efforts of racketeers to take over his union, will be held Tuesday at Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, asserted tonight that opponents of the Roosevelt Administration were preaching the doctrine of fear in an effort "to destroy confidence and scare the country into giving them another shot at the Job they muffed so badly."

A "balanced perspective" and "dispassionate judgments" on the stock markets' decline were counseled last night by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in an address outlining the nation's need for opening up its avenues of capital expansion as "more desperate" than at any time since the war.

The London Non-Intervention Committee, saved from a break-up yesterday by an "accommodation" by Germany and Italy, for which both governments are taking due credit today, will face a new complication when it reassembles tomorrow to implement its agreement.

Columbia's varsity basketball schedule, listing eighteen games for the 1937-38 season, was announced yesterday. In addition to their regular Eastern Intercollegiate League contests, the Lions will meet six non-league quintets: Springfield, Williams, Fordham, Union, Navy and Army.

Davis and Elkins scored in the last two minutes of play tonight to win a football thriller from Salem College by a point after touchdown, 7-6. Basil Sharp, 130-pound halfback, reeled off a 59-yard run to the Salem 5 as the game entered its dying moments.

Maritime Commission officials disclosed tonight that they were insisting upon several major changes in the set-up of the Dollar Steamship Company before allowing a subsidy to the company. Details of the commission's demands were not made known.

Miss Louise Quinn's Prince Charming II captured the lightweight hunter blue as the Wissahickon Horse Show got under way today. Taking the jumps in perfect form, Prince Charming II gained a wellearned victory over Hexameter, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer of Greenwich, Conn., and Randle's Trojan, from the stables of Mr. and Mrs. U. S. Randle, Fairfax, Va.
The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 19: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Bruckshaw, H. A. N. (MC), to duty Involving flying at the Naval Air Station. Pensacola. Fla.

Reginald Charles Barker, writer of Western stories, died yesterday. He was 55 years old. Mr. Barker wrote "Grizzly Gallagher," "Wild Horse Ranch," "Gentleman Grizzly," "Hair-Trigger Brand," between 1927 and 1929. He was also a prolific writer of of short stories published in Blue Book, Complete Stories, Western Story Magazine and other fiction periodicals.

The Syracuse football team, headed by Coach Ossie Solem, left for Baltimore tonight where the Orange will meet the Maryland Terrapins in an intersectional game Saturday. Thirty-five players are making the .trip.
World industrial production rose sharply in August, recovering from the "pause" of July, according to the monthly review of foreign economic conditions in the current issue of The Annalist.
Freight rate increases on a limited list of basic commodities, expected to yield an additional $47,500,000 a year to the railroads, were authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A boy who is going blind and a Forest Hills housewife whose husband is a chauffeur heard yesterday the good news that by 10 o'clock next Wednesday, if the horses at Newmarket, England, run true to form in the classic Cesarewitch, they will each be winners of $150,000 in the rish Hospital Sweepstakes.

The financial policies of the La Guardia administration were debated last- night by Fusion and Democratic representatives at a meeting- at Carnegie Hall held under the auspices of the Citizens Budget Commission. Jeremiah T.

The Pure Oil Company today concluded settlement of its recent underwriting through receipt from Edward B. Smith Co. of $43,439,400 in payment for an issue of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred notsubscribed for by shareholders. The company has delivered the stock.

District Attorney Dodge sent an investigator to Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert, delegate of the chicken truckers' union now in prison for embezzling union funds, "to let the racket leaders know that a union member had made a complaint of racketeering in the union against them," it' was charged last night by Special Rackets Prosecutor Dewey before an American Labor party rally at Public School 4, Rivingston Street between Fifth and Ridge Streets.

Mainly due to declines in the final hour of trading, led by industrial shares, the stock market closed lower yesterday. As had been forecast earlier in the day, the Interstate Commerce Commission after the market's closing made its long-awaited announcement granting the railroads higher freight rates.

Investment bankers of Philadelphia were asked yesterday by Colley S. Baker, chairman of the 10 Pennsylvania Securities Commission, whether it would be helpful to the bankers to appoint a permanent committee to represent them and to meet with the commission at regular periods for informal discussion of problems.

It is not to be lightly assumed that the freight rate increase just granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission will solve all the railroads' financial problems. It is estimated that the increases would provide- approximately $47,500,000 a year in additional revenue on the basis of the 1936 volume of traffic.

Amherst's football team ended preparations today for the first Little Three contest of the season on Pratt Field tomorrow, when Coach Lloyd Jordan sent his squad through an hour of signal drill. The game will be the forty-fifth of, the Amherst-Wesleyan rivalry,
Generalissimo Francisco Franco, armed with more complete power than ever before as dictator of Insurgent Spain, today turned his attention from the conquered northwest to the vital eastern fronts.

Meyer Frankenburg, bond thief, whose tip to Federal agents resulted Thursday in the recovery in a subway station lock box of $674,209 worth of stolen United States Treasury notes, was rewarded yesterday for his "willingness to cooperate."
A human chain of strikers on a railroad track today turned back repeated efforts to run a lumberladen freight train onto the siding of the Treen Box Company plant here.

The fifth American season of Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe opened last night at the Metropolitan Opera House in its customary atmosphere of festivity and high occasion, with the audience filling all the seats and overflowing into several circles about the back of the house.

Blair Academy's attempt to break into the winning column was frustrated by the Horace Mann football team yesterday as the local forces downed the Blairstown, N. J., squad, 13-7, at Horace Mann Field. It was the opening game of the season for Horace Mann.

Designs submitted in the Outdoor Advertising Award competition have been hung in one of the large galleries on the mezzanine floor of International Building, Rockefeller Center. The show opened last evening with a preview and. beginning today, this work may be seen by the public until Nov. 2.

Frank E. Gannett, Rochester publisher and sponsor of the "National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government," today refused to debate with Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, on the Supreme Court issue.

A number of producers, including the Shuberts, have expressed an interest in "Father Malachy's Miracle," the Delos Chappell production which was postponed after rehearsals had been completed. A reading for the benefit of potential angels has been arranged by Worthington Miner, who directed the play, and by the cast.

Stephen Leacock, the Canadian humorist, has decided to leave the lecture platform and will issue in book form a collection of the lectures he has been delivering for many years. It will be published by Dodd, Mead on Nov. 10 under the title "Here Are My Lectures."

Sharp competition between the milk and brewing industries has developed in England, with producers in both fields running intensive advertising campaigns. Charles L. Davis, managing director of Davis Elterich, the English division of H. N. Elterich, Inc., said here yesterday. Mr. Davis is visiting this country on a business trip.

A few minutes after a radio announcer told Loyalist Spain tonight that Gijon was lost, Premier Juan Negrin stepped to the microphone in the Presidential Palace here and in an hour's address assured the listeners that the final victory would be won by the Loyalists, and that it would be a Spanish victory.

Mrs. Ella Margaret Gray Wiley, mother of Dr. George M. Wiley, assistant commissioner in charge of secondary education in the State Department of Education, died today. She had made her home with her son for the last twenty years, following the death of her husband, the Rev. George M. Wiley of Hebron, Washington County.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 20: Calkins, Lt. Comdr. R. D., Portsmouth, Va., to the Honolulu and on board as supply officer when commissioned. Barbot, Lt. L. J., the Herbert, to the Nokomis.

Mrs. Charles C. Griswold had a dinner party tonight at Hillhome, Stockbridge. Her guests were her sister, Mrs. Austin W. Ackroyd, Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Holloway, Mr. and Mrs. John Bross Lloyd, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ivison Parsons and the Rev. Edmund Randolph Laine.

Next Wednesday is annual Navy Day and some churches will observe tomorrow as Navy Sunday. Lessons will be drawn from the fluctuation of stocks in Wall Street this week. Several clergymen will refer to the local political campaign.

A capacity field of fourteen, inEluding half a dozen thoroughbreds in the first flight, have been named for the Yorktown Handicap, richest race of the Empire City meeting, which will be run at the Yonkers course this afternoon. The famous mare, Fair Knightess. a 4-year-old who has won five stakes in New England, is the probable favorite for the mile-and-an-eighth test, which will gross in excess of $10,000.

The Cotton States Portland Cement Company, Jackson, Miss., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 30,000 shares of $50 par value 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock and 30,000 shares of no par value common stock to be offered in units of one preferred and one common share at $50.10 a unit.

Activated by the belief that a wife may- be instrumental in making or breaking her husband's career, Teachers College officials have introduced seventeen courses for wives of 'future school administrators to equip them for the responsibility of being married to prominent men, it was announced yesterday by Gertrude L. Belser, recorder of the college's Advanced 'Sdhool of Education.

Substitution of the name of Isidore Nagler for Julius J. Umansky as the candidate of the Socialist party for Borough President of the Bronx was barred yesterday by a decision of Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer.

New York University's football team will take the field this afternoon against the undefeated, untied and unscored-on Lafayette College eleven coached by E. E. (Hooks) Mylin. The game is scheduled to begin at 2:30 P. M. at the Yankee Stadium.

General adoption of the principle of the natural business year under which each business unit would end its accounting period at a date coincident with the close of the normal cycle of operations in that particular business was advocated by the council of the American Institute of Accountants at the close of the institute's fiftieth anniversary meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The cooperation rendered by civic organizations and social agencies to the American Red Cross in the flood emergency last Spring will aid its expansion into wider fields of social service, officials of that organization said yesterday at a regional conference at the headquarters of the New York chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue.
Chagrined but not surprised-that defines the Soviet reaction to the proceedings of the Spanish Non-Intervention Committee in London and Italian Ambassador Count Dino Grandi's proposed "concession."

Presbyterians in this area will celebrate next week the centenary of the Board of Foreign Missions of that denomination. The opening event will be a women's luncheon Wednesday at 1 P. M: at the Hotel Commodore.

This nation has "scarcely" touched its social welfare problems and a broad program, including health insurance, is essential to ameliorate the ravages of the "widespread insecurity" which still exists throughout the country,

Bruce Barton, Republican nominee for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, declared yesterday for a five-day week for political speakers. In declining an invitation to make a speech Sunday afternoon, Mr. Barton wrote:

Stanley M. Isaacs, candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, told an American Labor Party rally last night that he welcomed its support because the party platform "embodies the things for which I have been working for years."

E. J. Kulas, president of the Otis Steel Company, announced today that the company's earnings for the three months ended on Sept. 30 were $948,285 after all charges and provision for estimated Federal normal income tax but without provision for Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

The Rev. William J. Duane, president from 1923 to 1929 of Fordham University, will observe the golden jubilee of his entrance into the Jesuit'Order by offering a solemn mass of thanksgiving tomorrow at 11 A. M., in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier,

Davey Day, Chicago lightweight, removed Enrico Venturi of'Italy from his path to a lightweight title bout last night at the Hippodrome before a gathering of 2,609. In a torrid ten-round battle Day earned the unanimous decision of Referee Billy Cavanaugh and Judges Charley Lynch and George Lecron.
A sharp contra-seasonal drop took place in cotton-mill activity last week, and the adjusted index has fallen to 113.3 from 123.6 (revised). The figure for the week ended Oct. 17, 1936, was 128.1.

The Dominican Legation tonight announced that the cordial relations existing between Haiti and the Dominican Republic "have not been impaired" as the result of a recent border incident in which several civilians were reported injured.

Two Roman Catholic pastors are to be transferred Sunday, Nov. 7, in the Diocese of Brooklyn and a priest has been assigned, effective the same date, to the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows, Morgan Avenue and Harrison Place, as administrator. The latter is the Rev.

Raymond Cooper, master of the State Grange, said here today that the "whole relief system" has a tendency "to lower the morale of our American people." Present relief conditions are resulting in a reduction of self-reliance, he said in an interview.

Quite a new answers win De grven to questions that have been of widespread interest in football by the time nightfall ends the firing on the gridirons of the country today. As usual, the spotlight will shift from point to point, and the usual unexpected results will stud the final scores as they do on nearly every playing day.

Professor Einstein the other day spoke of the world as divided into two parts. There are the countries dominated by the new post-war dictators, whose motto is "Right is that which serves us," and there is the rest of the world, where men are growing accustomed to such moral decay.

Park Ave, 502; to 32-story hotel and stores; Nielmo Realty Corp., Premises, owner; Charles Glaser, architect; cost, $30,000. 7th Ave, 2,263; to 5-story tenement and stores: Dan Roe Realty Corp. 48 W 125th St, owner; Harry Hurwit, architect; cost, $4,500.

Wheat prices on the Board of Trade here were on the downgrade today as the result of a continued slow foreign demand for cash grain, easiness in Liverpool and more favorable crop comments from the Southern Hemisphere.

Another Mauretania will soon sail the seas. The new 40,000-ton liner now being constructed at Birkenhead for the Cunard-White Star Line will revive the name made famous by the one-time Atlantic blue-ribbon holder.

The prosecution's principal witness in the government's gasoline pricefixing case against twenty-three major oil companies testified today under cross-examination that prices recomended in the purchase of gasoline from small refineries in 1935 merely followed the published market quotations.

Patrolman William J. Farrell, 42 years old, of the Simpson Street station, the Bronx, shot and killed himself with his service pistol about 11 A. M. yesterday in the dining room of his home, 4,518 Clarendon Road, Brooklyn. Police said he had been ill for some time.
Contracts under invitation 61 for vegetable ivory and zinc buttons for the Army clothing factory were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot here today. The invitation included:
Breaking his silence of the past few days in regard to the activities of Japanese troops in North China, the Japanese spokesman here today announced advances on all fronts and sectors.

Several hundred persons from the theatrical and newspaper worlds attended memorial services for Ray Henderson yesterday noon at the Church of Transfiguration. Mr. Henderson, theatrical press agent, was killed in an airplane crash in Greece. The Rev Randolph Ray, rector of the church, conducted the services.

Sir Hubert Wilkins took off from Floyd Bennett Field at 3:02 P. M. yesterday and landed at Cleveland at 5:54 P. M. (E. S. T.), officials of the field said, on the first hop of his return to the Arctic to search for Sigismund Levanevsky and five other Russian fliers who have been missing since last August.
Twelve-year-old Donald Ray Fulkerson, who raised a $25 calf to a grand champion, proudly stood by today and watched the American Royal auctioneer sell his prize. winner for $900.

Dakota, veteran of American Army jumping horses, met the challenge of Belgian thoroughbreds today with a faultless performance that easily won individual honors in the InterAmerican horse show's military competition.

Frank Heino Damrosch, founder of the Institute of Musical Art, a member of a great family of musicians and a man who did much for the spread of musical learning in New York, died early yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his home, 120 East Seventy-fifth Street. He was 78 years old.

Governor Frederick P. Cone of Florida, who says that any one who advocates revolution ought to be hanged, was not received by Mayor La Guardia when he visited City Hall at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

Miss Jane Harrison, daughter of O. L. Harrison and Mrs. George E. Holmes was married to Byron Ivancovich, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ivancovich of Tucson, at her mother's home here today. The matron of honor was Mrs. Victor Gore of Tucson. Harry Powers, also of Tucson, was best man.

Over the picturesque Rockaway River Country Club course in the foothills of the Ramapo Mountains a good field of forty-six golfers was led home today by Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches with a score of 42, 39-81.
Mrs. Elizabeth Alonso is here to ask a divorce from Manuel Alonso, who was once the second ranking tennis player. She will charge cruelty. They were married in Philadelphia in the Spring of 1935.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Averell Harriman gave a dinner and dance tonight at their home in Arden for their debutante niece, Miss Nancy Penn Smith of Unionville, Pa. The dance opened the festivities in connection with the annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held tomorrow night at the Tuxedo Club.

The proportional representation canvassers who will check the votes cast for members of the new City Council will be finger printed and checked for possible criminal records before they are appointed to the $10-a-day jobs, it was revealed yesterday in a Municipal Civil Service Commission notice printed in The City Record,

This afternoon the New York Public Library's Open-Air Reading Room in Bryant Park will fold up its big umbrella and move its books indoors after its third and most successful season. More readers read more books than in either of the previous years.
The Yale freshmen vanquished Cheshire School, 28-0, today, pressing the attack and preventing the visitors from reaching their 20-yard line.
Despite military operations and heavy rains, China will have a record cotton crop of 4,000,000 bales, according to a report from Shanghai made public today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking on "The Relation of the Press to the Democratic Ideal," addressed last night an enthusiastic, cheering crowd of 2,500 Negroes in the Mother A. M. E. Zion Church, 170 West 137th Street.

Byron Nelson fell before young Enrique Bertolino, but his mates on an Argentine golf tour, Denny Shute and Henry Picard, advanced through the quarter finals of a professional invitation match play tournament today.
Thomas J. Towers was declared by the Court of Appeals today to be the regular Democratic candidate for justice of the City Court in Queens County, and Lawrence T. Gresser's name was eliminated.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP).--Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today that the output of the motorcar manufacturers this week would total 91,905 units, compared with 89,635 last week, and 64,310 in this week a year ago.
The Chalmers Hattersley Realty Corporation has sold to an investing client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., the four-story apartment building at 2,004 Glenwood Road, on the corner of Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

Mgr. William P. Shannahan, former president of St. Ambrose College, died last night at Mercy Hospital. He was 67 years old.- He was president of St. Ambrose College from 1907 until 1915 and at the time of his death was pastor of Sacred Heart Cathedral.

The international boundary bristled with guns tonight as Texas ranchers fought off cotton raiders in a new version of the Southwest's rustler wars. Paid riflemen and heavily armed officers patrol the Rio Grande border ranches as. they did in the days of cattle wars, but now they are guarding cotton fields.

The Horned Frogs of Texas Christian, who can and do strike through the air better than the garden variety of horned frog ever could, will test Fordham's unbeaten football forces at the Polo Grounds this afternoon at 2 o'clock before a gathering of some 30,000.
New bond financing this week was restricted to a total of $9,150,000 primarily because of the postponement of at least two sizable corporate loans as a result of the decline in security values.

Under a ruling by the New York Stock Exchange governing committee yesterday, the committee on stock list was empowered to place on the list the voting trust certificates representing listed shares, without preliminary report to the governing committee.

Ruth Breton, violinist, returned to the local concert platform last night at Town Hall in a recital in which she was assisted at the harpsichord and the piano by Ernst Victor Wolff. Since last heard here Miss Breton obviously had been working with a will, for her performances at this latest appearance displayed marked improvement, particularly in matters of intonation.

It is reported from Malaga, Spain, Herbert Merrick, Colonial Auditor of Gibraltar and one of the senior British officials here, has been detrained by the Spanish Insurgents at Malaga. The reason is not stated.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Lewis MacDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Walker MacDonald of Brooklyn, to Philip Faxon Mygatt of the Hotel Grosvenor, this city, took place yesterday afternoon in the Memorial Presbyterian Church. Brooklyn.

The marriage of Miss Helen Underwood Schureman, daughter of Mrs. James Percy Schureman of this place and the late Dr. Schureman, to Dr. Joseph Tatnall Lea Nicholson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Nicholson Jr. of Moorestown, N. J., took place here tonight in the First Reformed Church.

Mohandas K. Gandhi, 68 and ailing, started "daily talk fasts" today to save his health. He is so weak that the slightest conversation tires him, so he decided on periods of silence, lasting many hours each day.

Ave D, 71, 28x89; 1/2 interest, Fannie Ertel to Helen Rosenreich, 967 53d St, Brooklyn, mtgs $21,000. 2d St, 255 E., 20.6x63.1; S. James Kennedy to George Willy. 3,985 Saxon Ave, Bronx, consideration $500, foreclosure. 12th St. 59-69 W, 108.6x103.3; John T. Javasile to Feer Realty Corp, 119 W. 40th St.

Three players tied for the medal in the qualifying round of the first annual tournament of the Seaview Golf Club on a rain-swept course today. Dick Chapman of Greenwich, Spencer Overton, Rolling Road, and R. H. Lansdell of Arcola, all posted 74's for the eighteen holes and will play off for the silver plaque either tomorrow or Sunday.

An examiner for the Labor Relations Board recommended today that the board require the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company of Stamford, Conn., to cease restraining union activities of its employes and to rehire with back pay five former workers alleged to have .been discharged fr union activity.
Columbia's freshman football team downed the Rutgers yearlings, 19-0, at Baker Field yesterday. The last half of the game was played in a driving rain.

Italian Kitchens. Inc, restaurant, store and basement in 1,625 Broadway; Kane Realty Co. Inc, broker. Le Sager Perfumer. floor in 35 W 19th St; M. D. Greenwald, men's fur caps. in 693-7 Broadway; Schlegel Lithographing Corp, in 374-80 2d Ave; M. L. Hess, Inc, broker.

Signing of a contract for a sister-ship of the Manhattan and Washington of the United States Lines at a cost of $15,750,000 was announced today by Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission. It will be constructed as a successor to the liner Leviathan, soon to be scrapped.

Margaret Drennan, who at 20 is an unmarried expectant mother, was acquitted of murder here today. She was accused of killing Paul Reeves in his home at Iselin, N. J., last Sept. 7, a charge which she did not deny, but in testimony at her trial sought to justify.

Resolutions condemning "wasteful and unnecessary public spending" and urging an easing of the tax burden on real estate were adopted today at the final session of the annual convention of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York.
The Silverman brothers, surplus army goods dealers, and two others accused with them lost a decision today in their fight against trial on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the government.

Word has been received by relatives here of the birth of a son on Tuesday in Pontiac, Mich., to Mr. and Mrs. Watson Ambruster 2d of that city, formerly of Westfield. Mrs. Ambruster is the former Miss Helen Hutchins of Westfield, daughter of the late Mrs. Walter Emmons.

Judge William H. Wallace. prohibitionist, cynic of politics and prosecutor of the Jesse James gang in the 1880's, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old. Since his retirement from law twenty years ago, Judge Wallace had been known publicly only to members of his church and toprohibition societies, but for a half century prior to that time few men led a more active life in the affairs of Kansas City and Missouri.

A sealed verdict awarding Dr. Clarence R. Richards, former veterinarian for the Jockey Club of New York, 6 cents damages in his $175,000 libel suit against Isadore Bieber, agent for the B. B. Racing Stables, was opened yesterday in Supreme Court. Justice Louis A.

West Virginia Wesleyan and St. Vincent battled to a scoreless tie in the mud tonight as a rain-drenched crowd of 1,500 looked on. The St. Vincent Bearcats, who bowed to Duquesne a week ago for their first defeat of the season,

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is re flected in the following list of representative high-grade -State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $13,763,086, to be represented by one territory, one State and sixtyone municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $11,471,680 for this week.

MIERSDORF, Prussia. -- The architects of the newly erected Town Hall in the town of Miersdorf, near Berlin, have taken asubtle revenge on the bureaucrats who have doled out the money for this building.

Joachim von Ribbentrop with his wife and daughter arrived from Berlin this afternoon for an unexpected visit to Rome. It is reported that he is charged with a "special mission" from Chancellor Hitler to Premier Mussolini.

The comparative advantages of sanity and a mild form of lunacy frequently have tempted playwrights of many tongues. Last night a small but appreciative audience up in the Nora Bayes Theatre enjoyed a good performance of "La Sirena Varada" (The Stranded Siren), the problem drama with which the young Spanish writer, Alejandro Casona,
Herman W. Seidel, 26-year-old army deserter, this afternoon was found guilty of second degree murder in the slaying five years ago of George Butler, a Bridgeport taxicab driver.

Miss Mary Vail Hewitt, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dexter Wright Hewitt of this place, was married to Edwin H. Mairs 2d, son of Mrs. John D. Mairs of New York and the late Mr. Mairs, this afternoon in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church here.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22.--Belief that European statesmanship will avert war, because nobody wants war, was expressed by Thomas W. Lamont in an address before the Commercial Club here tonight.

Commuters and localities served by the New Rochelle-Port Chester branch of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway took their troubles to the Public Service Commission yesterday in an effort to stave off the abandonment of service on the line, now scheduled for Nov. 1 under an order recently issued by Federal Judge John C. Knox.

The recent drastic decline -in the market price of all securities was bewildering and unjustified "in the case of our stock," Frank Phillips, president of the Phillips Petroleum Company, said yesterday in announcing the earnings and dividend declaration of his company.

Calling for the election of Democratic candidates for delegates-at-large to the State Constitutional Convention, Senator Robert F. Wagner set forth tonight for the first time the sevenpoint program for which the Democratic delegates would work in that body.
A total of $14,258,790 was deposited in school savings banks in the year ended on June 30, last, according to a report of the Savings Division of the American Bankers Association, issued yesterday.

Women are less cynical than men and therefore make -better jurors, said William Clark, Senior Judge of the United States District Court of Newark, addressing yesterday afternoon a meeting of the New York City Committee of the, National Woman's Party in the'Hotel Wellington.

Concentration of written instructions to office workers in the hands of a single department, and reduction of such instructions to essentials was recommended by John F. Pierce, director of the office service department of the Tennessee Valley Authority, before about 500 office managers at the closing session of the conference on office management sponsored by the American Management Association at the Astor Hotel yesterday.
Leonardo, 13-year-old son of Andres Segovia the Spanish guitarist, was electrocuted yesterday at Versoix, a suburb of Geneva.

Investment buying of apartment houses in scattered sections of Manhattan featured realty activity yesterday. The three five-story and one fourstory tenement houses at 321-27 Pleasant Avenue, northwest corner of 117th Street, were sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to a client of Nicholas -Rago, who intends to renovate the buildings and hold them for investment.
Two North American statesmen denounced international treaty breakers today and called for world cooperation by the family of nations to preserve peace by peaceable means.

The Equity Corporation reported yesterday that its net assets on Sept. 30 were equivalent to $6,741.40 for each $1,000 of assumed debentures, to $72.41 a share for the $3 convertible preferred stock and to $1.22 a common share, compared to $8,273.66, to $90.43 and to $2.23 respectively on June 30, 1937.

On the basis of recent predictions that the national budget will be brought into balance next year, Postmaster General Farley believes that "this particular source of worry" is now "nearing the evaporation point." But it is not the fact that the budget is unbalanced which causes the greatest concern to thoughtful observers of the Government's fiscal position.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct, 21 unless specified: At Shanghai: Bulmer, Ramapo, Tulsa. At Coco Solo: S-42, 43, 44, 46, 47. Cachalot, at New London, Oct. 22. Canopus, Tslngtao to Woosung, Oct. 22. Case, Provincetown to sea, Oct. 22.
The October Ball for debutantes of 19371938 was attended tonight in the Warwick "Hotel ballroom by 400 guests and was preceded by many dinner parties.

With thirty-six candidates still in the field and the weather. picture constantly changing, the outcome of Wednesday's renewal of the historio Cesarewitch Stakes appeared tonight to depend more and more on the amount of rain that falls between now and the day of the big race.

Nicaragua and Honduras formally accepted today in notes to the State Department the tender of good offices by the United States, Costa Rica and Venezuela for a solution of their long-standing boundary dispute.

Miss Mae King Chandlee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Earle Chandlee of Moylan, Delaware County, and of Bay Head, N. J., was married here this afternoon in Christ Church to Wilson Perkins Foss 3d, son of Mrs. William K. Yarrow of Redding Ridge, Conn., and of Wilson P.

Striking in the first few minutes of play, Temple's football team made touchdown which encompassed 7-to-0 defeat for the Carnegie Tech eleven tonight. The Owls, playing a strong defensive game after scoring, successfully fought off all efforts of the game Tartan aggregation to overtake them in the last three periods.

Referring to the column of John Kieran in which he said, substantially, that football coaches prefer double figures as numbers for their charges, I want to say that the same thought occurred to Dr. Williams, famed Minnesota coach of bygone days, some fifteen years ago.

Guilty pleas to grand larceny indictments were entered in General Sessions yesterday by two brokers and the employee of a New York Stock Exchange concern they had used as a tool in appropriating securities of the latter's employers as collateral to finance loans for speculation.
The Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday that appropriations in the proposed 1938 budget for City, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges were more than $400,000 in excess of legal requirements.

A buoyant tone in the railroad issues was outstanding yesterday in a continuation of the upward course in bond prices on the New York Stock Exchange. Under the stimulus of the expected announcement by the Interstate Commerce Commission, after the close, granting an increase in freight rates, the market for rail obligations, particularly the secondary bonds, was active and strong all day, and operations in this light absorbed most of the session's trading.

The action of the White Plains City Council in reducing the Board of Education's 1938 budget will be tested in Supreme Court, the board announced today. Setting a precedent, the City Council eliminated a $16,394 salary restoration item from the school budget last Monday.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and PWA Administrator, Mayor La Guardia, Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey and Deputy Commissioner Walter D. Binger will be among the speakers at the dedication of the city's new sewage treatment works at Wards Island, East River .at 110th Street, at 11- o'clock this morning.
Harry Cooper, former vaudeville actor and an organizer of many benefit entertainments for charity, died yesterday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases of an infected foot. He was 59 years old.
The State closed and the de fense put on three witnesses today in the trial of Laverne Moore (known in Hollywood as John Mon tague) on a seven-year-old indict ment for first-degree robbery.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Betty Kassebaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Kassebaum Jr. of this city, to Thomas Burpee Ellsworth of New York and New Canaan. Conn.

Completion of the permanent organization of the Maritime Commission was announced today by Joseph P. Kennedy, its chairman. As set up, Mr. Kennedy said, the organization has been designed to relieve the five Commission members of routine and to leave them free for the exercise of their quasi-judicial, regulatory and technical functions.

The engagement of $614,000 gold in India for shipment to this country was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Gold in London continued at a substantial premium over the price at which shipments can be made to this market at a profit, but transfers of the metal from India continue profitable because of relatively favorable shipping rates.

With covers laid for fifty-four, the Eastern Polo League put the final touch to a successful season with a dinner at the New York A. C. last night, presided over by President Jack B. Quisenberry of Blind Brook.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Katherine Cybulsky, sister, 460 W. 49th St., $3,000: Franz Eiswirth, brother, executor, 460 W. 49th St., residue; John Eiswirth, brother, executor, 22 Grove St., Brooklyn, $500. GRANT, JOHN J. (Oct. 5). Estate, more than $20,000. To Emma McG. Lyons,

Generally improved business conditions in Panama and the installation of two new hydroelectric plants in the Province of Chiriqui lead to the belief that the Central American republic may prove a good market for American electrical equipment, says A. R. Randolph, Assistant American Trade Commissioner, in a report made public today by the Department of Com-merce.
The New York State Legislative Commission for the Hard of Hearing held its first public hearing last night at the offices of the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, 480 Lexington Avenue.

World production of refined lead in August amounted to 156,425 tons, compared with 157,995 in August, 1936, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Production in the United States was 37,989 tons, against 42,460.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. School Art League lecture, "Design in Display," Polly Pettit, 9:30 A. M.; "Gothic Architecture and Sculpture in Venice," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "French Furniture: the Regency," Ethelwyn Bradish, 11 A. M.; "Oriental Influences in European Ceramics," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.

Five successful years as manager of the Minneapblis American Association Baseball Club and the pleasant associations built up here outIweighed today for Donie Bush a "flattering offer" to manage the Bees.

Owing to the failure of the district boards to reach agreement on coordinating minimum prices for Districts 1 to 8, inclusive, embracing the entire Appalachian field except Alabama, the National Bituminous Coal Commission decided today by unanimous decision to invoke the section of the law which permits it to do the coordinating.

Strikes by capital, large and small, explain the present "uncertain and unsatisfactory" conditions of business in the United States, W. O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, said today.

An increase of 10 per cent in toy sales this Christmas, bringing the volume to about $230,000,000, the largest since 1929, was foreseen yesterday by James L. Fri, managing director of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A.

INDISCRETIONS about other people never lessened the interest of a published diary, but its integrity depends upon personal candor. No one reads Pepys just to find out how he ran Britain's sea-galled and politically bedeviled navy.

Mrs. Samuel Schiffer of Elberon, N. J., owner of the Kilkare Farm, gained a blue ribbon today with Flashing American, a chestnut gelding, at the Wissahickon Farms horse show. Flashing American scored in a saddle class for horses over 14.2, defeating the Willisbrook Farm's chestnut mare My Betty Peavine.

Gross assets, $32,405; net, $16,708. To daughters, Florence Adlerman, Lucie Repko, Edna Friedman and Eleanor Kornblum, one-fourth of residuary estate each. Chief assets. real estate, $12,500; stocks and bonds, $4,980; mortgages. notes. cash and insurance, $14,925. Finkelstein Jacobs, attorneys, 521 5th Ave., Manhattan.

Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri, acting chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, which is investigating reorganization plans of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company and other roads, issued this afternoon a statement in which he declared that an earlier statement by John W. Stedman,

Passengers arriving today on the United States liner President Roosevelt, coming from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, are Ruth Slenczynski, child pianist, accompanies by her father, Josef; Lieut. Col. W. C. Porterfield, James C. Anderson, Judge and Mrs. Abram Klenert and W. C. Beers.

G. K. Throckmorton has been elected president of RCA Manufacturing Company, Camden, N. J., according to an announcement yesterday by David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America and chairman of the board of directors of the manufacturing company.

The railroads plan to ask for another increase in rates approximating the $47,500,000 rise granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday, it was said in official circles following the commission's announcement. This would mean a total increase of about $100,000,000 in freight rates, if the plans of the managements are successful.

The International Longshoremen's Association called its men from the piers of the Clyde Mallory and Savannah steamship lines yesterday in protest against the withdrawal of ships from the coastwise service. The Clyde Mallory Line immediately announced the cancellation of the sailings of the passenger and freight ship Shawnee and freighter Medina, which were scheduled for today.

While the rule calling for uniform discounts was opposed, substantial progress has been made in negotiations with the National Retail Dry Goods Association on other trade practice provisions adopted by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, it was announced yesterday by Oliver W. Pearson of the commission.
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 773,000 bales, against 726,000 a week ago, 686,000 two weeks ago, 684,000 three weeks ago and 781,000 a year ago;

The defeat of Aaron J. Levy, Democratic candidate for re-election to the Supreme Court, was urged yesterday by the Citizens Union in its recommendations on judiciary candidates. The report, made public by George H. Hallett Jr., secretary, carried an endorsement for Justice Charles Poletti, Edward J. Glennon and Thomas F. Noonan, sitting judges, and Nathan D. Perlman, the Republican candidate.

The funeral was held yesterday morning in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street, for Felix M. Warburg, financier and champion of philanthropic causes, who died last Wednesday. Nearly 2,000 men and women filled the great central aisle and the galleries of the synagogue, among them leaders in finance, politics and religion.

Mercersburg Academy maintained its winning streak today by defeating the Tome School eleven, 20 to 0. The stands were filled with parents here for the annual celebration of the Mercersburg field day tomorrow.

Member trading in round lots for their own-, account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 25, while stocks were declining sharply, represented 21.75 per cent of the total volume compared with 22.41 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

" Aside from some dickering on wools suited to the requirements of mills which have been successful bidders on government contracts, there has been very little business done in wool this week. Rumors of exceeding low prices on scoured pulled B wools are discounted considerably.

George Horace Lorimer, noted editor of The Saturday Evening Post, died at 11:30 o'clock tonight at his home, Belgraeme, in Wyncote. His age was 69. With him at his death were his wife and two sons, Burford and Graeme.

What both sides agree is the most important struggle thus far around Shanghai is continuing in the vicinity of Tachang, about six miles to the north, the retention of which by the Chinese is conceded to be vitally necessary to the maintenance of the Chinese positions in Chapel and Kiangwan.

Thomas Reynolds Williams, Pittsburgh newspaper man and secretary of the Pittsburgh Publishers Association for the last five years, died last night at his home, 6,822 Thomas Boulevard, following a two weeks' illness of pneumonia, He was 59 years old.

The Brooklyn College football squad was in fine shape today for the game with Lowell Textile on the Kingsmen's new field, Bedford Avenue and Avenue H. The Kingsmen held a short practice yesterday, concentrating on their kicking and passing. The Drobable line-uD:

The difficulties of combating leprosy in the far-flung corners of the earth, because of the barriers set up by war, national economic policies and racial prejudices and suspicion, were described yesterday at the closing session of the two-day annual meeting of the American Mission to. Lepers at the Broadway Tabernacle, Broadway and Fiftysixth Street.

The report of the Southern California Edison Company,Ltd., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after expenses and charges, of $12,235,116. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.26 a share on - the common stock outstanding at the end of the period, and compares with a net of $12,694,003, or $2.41 a common share, in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1936.
Recession in security markets has developed, so far as Canada is concerned, in the face of improving trade and maintained industrial activity, according to a report by the Bank of Montreal.

James R. Murphy will sell at auction at 2:00 P. M. today 152 building lots in River View Manor, Hastings-on-Hudson and Dobbs Ferry. The lots are located on Villard Avenue, Calumet Avenue, Broadway and adjacent streets, overlooking the Hudson River.

Four issues of stock of the National Supply Company, representing the result of the consolidation of the National Supply Company of Delaware and Spang, Chalfant Co., Inc., have been listed by the New York Stock Exchange.

Sales of pianos for the first nine months of this year totaled 72,867 units, an increase of 27.82 per cent over the corresponding period in 1936, 80.97 per cent ahead of 1935 and 302.94 per cent ahead of 1932, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Piano Manufacturers Association.

Abner J. Stilwell, vice president of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, obtained a divorce today from his second wife, the former Rosemary Ames, a motion-picture actress and member of a prominent

" Research and action" will be the two main features of the program of the American Retail Federation during the next few years, Dr. David R. Craig said yesterday at the annual meeting of the federation, in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Dr.

Three separate attempts to eliminate the five-cent fare were made by Mayor La Guardia and his supporters, it was charged last night by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, in speeches at meetings in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.

Mgr. Edward J. Carr, permanent rector of the Sacred Heart Church in Fall River and former supervisor of parochial schools in that city for ten years, died last night at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Brighton. He was in his fifty-eighth year.

The country's oldest intercollegiate gridiron rivalry will be renewed for the thirty-fifth time tomorrow afternoon in Princeton University's Palmer Stadium, with the outstanding Rutgers team of recent years meeting the Sons of Nassau Hall before some 25,000 spectators. Invading Princeton will be the first undefeated untied and unscored-upon Scarlet team to ever confront a Tiger unit.

A veteran Yale team, at full strength almost to the last man on the squad, will defend its winning streak in the Bowl tomorrow against a Cornell eleven eager to make amends for its downfall against Syracuse as well as for the 23-0 drubbing it received here a year ago.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that Oharles M. Hair and Floyd M. Jones of San Antonio, Texas, had been fined $3,000 each and sentenced to serve four years- in the United States Southwestern Reformatory, El Reno, Okla.

A mortgage for $5,800 on the eight-story office building at 91-93 5th Ave and the four-story house at 6 E 17th St, surrounding the southeast corner, was assigned on Dec. 2 by Elizabeth Thompson to Jacob R. Schiff, and Mr. Schiff now assigns this mortgage together with his Interest in another mortgage for $26,000 on the two parcels to Kate Heichman of 313 Crown St, Brooklyn.

With three successive Stadium victories behind them, the Dartmouth Indians will again invade the Crimson's lair tomorrow. This time Earl Blaik has an eleven as yet untried under big-game pressure, while Harvard, in its third year under Dick Harlow's coaching,. has fought the sturdy Navy to a scoreless tie in its one major test.

Today's events: Katherine Bacon, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Helen Keller Tribute Concert, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Rosa Lynne, pianist, and Ester Dordoni, dramatic disease, Comedy Theatre, evening.

Prices were deadlocked in dull trading on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. Quotations failed to move more than 2 points over or 4 points under the previous closing. Southern offerings continued small, owing to the holding movement, and trade demand was restricted because of dullness of spot cotton.

Grand Concourse (11-2813), n e cor or Bush St, 102x100; Minerva Peper to 2,028 Grand Concourse, Inc. 10 E 43d St; mtg $111,500. Bathgate Ave (11-2921), e s, 50 ft s of 174th St, 50x95; Julius Backer to Daniel Baker, Seattle, Wash.

An electrician testifying in the injunction suit against Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electricians yesterday told of having been ousted from two successive jobs and forced to go on relief because the union local organized his employers'shops but refused to admit him to membership.

Retired Lt. Joseph Reilly, formerly member of Engine 250, residing at 120 E. 42d St., Brooklyn, died Oct. 21. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, Oct. 23. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 12th Division shall detail one Captain, one Lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.
After Walter Pierson had scored in the first five minutes on a 55-yard end run, the Brunswick School eleven of Greenwich added four touchdowns and conquered Columbia Grammar School, 31-0, today.
France sent notes today to both factions in the Spanish civil war, urging careful treatment of prisoners, political or military.

Miss Hilda Emily Hutsel, daughter of Mrs. Robert Hutsel of 24 East Eighth Street and the late Mr. Hutsel, was married to William Harold Bokum, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bokum of Philadelphia. last night in Grace Church.

Charges against Paul Edwards, administrator of the WPA four-arts project in New York City, and an urgent appeal for his removal were made here today by a delegation representing the supervisors and musicians engaged on the project.

Harold W. Hastings, Democratic candidate for District Attorney of New York County, charged last night that Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican rival, had the largest slush fund ever gathered for a candidate for District Attorney in the history of New Yorkrk. Mr. Hastings made this accusation in a speech before 400 persons at the Greek American Club, Inc., 804 Sixth Avenue.

Sir Josiah Stamp, one of Great Britain's outstanding economists and a director of the Bank of England, warned Britons tonight against following America in gloomingg and grandmothering" themselves into a slump.

Merger with the New York and Baltimore offices of the United States Advertising Corporation and O'Dea, Sheldon Company, Inc., was announced yesterday. The enlarged agency will be known as O'Dea, Sheldon and Canaday, Inc.
Improvements in design and In methods of construction have made possible a modernization in freight car types camparable to what has been accomplished in recent years with passenger equipment,

Three expert bird men arrived yesterday morning, two of them for their first visit to this city, and almost immediately classified New Yorkers as a queer lot of scurrying birds hardly worth conserving or collecting.
Three members of the Aurora polo team from the United States, captained by Seymour (Shorty) Knox, arrived today on the steamship Northern Prince.

Now that the Beach Haven Tuna Club dinner is with the past, prizes awarded and the season's fishing in New Jersey officially cussed and discussed, with an occasional interruption by a Nova Scotia fan on the matter of "really big tuna," we can settle back and breathe deeply.

Fordham's cross-country team defeated C. C. N. Y., 20-35, in a driving rain at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Running the intercollegiate five-mile course, the Rams, led by Captain Gus Paoli, George Leary, Dick Peterson and Mike Dolan, who finished one, two, three and five, almost made a clean sweep of the dual event.

Almost $70,000 already has been contributed by some 1,000 persons to the $100,000 fund sought for the erection of a music shed to house the concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at the Berkshire Symphonic Festival held annually at Tanglewood near Stockbridge, Mass.

Dr. Carl G. Jung, Professor of Analytic Psychology at Zurich, said today in the third and last of the annual Terry lectures at Yale University that not only is there an authentic religious function in the unconscious mind, but the manifestations of it have followed the same pattern for more than 2.000 years.

The postponement of municipal elections in 500 communities was decided on yesterday in a Cabinet Council in view of the general excitement in the German section. For the next fortnight all political meetings have been prohibited throughout the country.
King George in a speech proroguing Parliament today echoed the deep concern of his Ministers in their efforts to prevent the Spanish conflict from spreading beyond Spain's borders.

Mayor La Guardia and Jeremiah T. Mahoney met for the first time since the actual campaign. got under way at 12:30 o'clock this morning. As Mr. La Guardia was leaving a dinner of the Honor Legion of the Police Department at the Hotel Astor, he ran into Mr. Mahoney in the lobby of the grand ballroom.

The Board of Governors of the Associated General Contractors of America, representing two-thirds of the nation's construction concerns, has decided to act in an advisory capacity to its 104 city, State and regional chapters on labor relations policy.

Yale's 150-pound eleven started its defense of the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship by beating the Pennsylvania lightweights on Franklin Field today, 14 -0. The Red and Blue held the Elis in check until early in the second period when Captain Paul Wargo

Weequahic High School's football team scored its first victory of the season tonight by defeating a favored Central High School team, 7 to 0, in a Newark High School Football League game. Weequahic tallied in the last period when Seymour Pfeferstein crashed off left tackle from the 4-yard line after a sustained march of fifty yards. Seymour Masin added the extra point on a plunge.
A friendly competition in housing and factory inspection seems to be under way between the Duke of Windsor and his

The General American Transportation Corporation, which operates the world's largest fleet of tank and refrigerator cars, is planning to enter the field of streamlined passenger-car building in conjunction with the Pressed Steel Car Company, Pittsburgh, a subsidiary, Max Epsteinz

Trading in steer hinds and ribs was fair and pork loins fairly active yesterday. Other classes continued to move slowly. Pork loins where stronger, other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats was slow with beef, veal and lamb about steady; calf lower as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Meehan's Manhattan eleven, the first Eastern team ever to invade the Bluegrass country, will face the University of Kentucky. in an intersectional battle tomorrow that is expected to draw a crowd of 15.000 to Stoll Field.
Premier John Metaxas of Greees returned to Istanbul today at the conclusion of his official visit to Angora. He was to leave for Athens in the Greek cruiser Averoff at midnight.

I am deeply appreciative of this opportunity to visit the University of Toronto. Institutions of learning have, of necessity, much briefer history on our side of the Atlantic than they do across the sea.

Wider diversity in retail buying developed this week, but gains over the substantial sales of last year were restricted and were estimated at 4 to 12 per cent, according to the weekly trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Joseph Dallett Jr., 30 years old, formerly of Woodmere and Youngstown, Ohio, where he was a candidate for Mayor on the Communist ticket last year, was killed in action in Spain while fighting with the Loyalist forces, according to word received today by his father, Joseph Dallett, of 115 Wyckoff Place, Woodmere.
The Voelkischer Beobachter announces this morning that Roland E. Strunk, its star traveling correspondent and Hitler Elite Guard leader, was killed in a duel defending his own and his family's honor.

The marriage of Miss Joan Modell, daughter of Mrs. Olga Madeleine Modell of Riverdale, this city, to Fred Fletcher Patten, son of Captain Fred C. Patten, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Patten of Toms River, N. J., took place last evening in the Terrace Club of the St. Moritz.

Former President Hoover, as chairman of the board of the Boys Club of America, will inspect the Greenwich Boys' Club headquarters tomorrow and be the guest of honor at supper at the home of Mrs. Samuel F. Pryor Sr.

Mrs. William Pitman Earle Jr., an honorary member of the Junior League and an active participant in social and civic affairs for thirty years, took the stump for the reelection of the La Guardia administration yesterday by appearing at Wall and Broad Streets and pleading with some 3,000 workers in the financial district to "put the new city charter in the hands of its friends and not in those of its recorded and proven enemies."

Three local officials from the Margelan region of Uzbekistan were sentenced to death today as alleged members of a nationalist band purportedly headed by Akmal Ikramoff, deposed member of the central executive committee.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Droege, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto H. Droege of 220 East Seventysecond Street and Lake Mahopac, N. Y., to Frank Edward Irsch Jr., son of Mrs. Frank E. Irsch of Westfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Irsch, took place yesterday in St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Fifty-fourth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Mayor La Guardia filed a report yesterday with the Board of Elections on his primary campaign expenses, showing no receipts and no expenditures. The International Ladies Garment Workers Union committee for the election of Isidore Nagler as Bronx Borough President reported receipts of $14,652 and expenditures of $10,083.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Solomon S. Goldsmith of New York City was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: 28-State of Texas and J. C. Clopton et al., etc., petrs., v. David Donoghue, trustee, etc. Submitted for both.

The La Salle Military Academy and Lawrence High elevens struggled to a scoreless tie in a rainstorm tonight at Lawrence High Stadium. A crowd of 5,500 saw the cadets miss a chance to score one minute before the first half ended as Fred Odentz's 15-yard placement for a field goal was short.

When the statistics of those who make up the membership of the Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York and enjoy its advantages are resolved into individual human beings they tell of thousands who have been brought to more vigorous health, kept fit in spite of trying jobs and through trying times, helped to acquire skills that are "social assets" and furnished with opportunities for fuller and richer experience.
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Isidore Nagler, candidate for Borough President of the Bronx, "Campaign Issues," WEVD, 10:15 to 10:30 A. M.
The Danzig situation after dissolution of the Catholic Center party is regarded here as a menace to Poland's vital interests.

John Barrymore and his wife, Elaine Barrie Barrymore, have been signed by Paramount and will be co-featured in a picture as soon as a suitable story can be located. Barrymore has been at Paramount for four successive films while Mrs. Barrymore's screen career has been limited to a short, "How to Undress in Front of Your Husband." Until the vehicle is found,

Superstitious Jack Maher, Choate School's head football coach, who knocks wood frequently while talking of his team's good qualities, thinks that the law of averages will catch up with the Blue and Gold tomorrow' and that Deerfield Academy will win the sports feature of the father's week-end card here.

Columbia's eleven, at full strength again with the return of the three linemen who had been on the sidelines with minor ailments most of the week, will meet Brown at Baker Field today. The kick-off, opening the eighth game between the schools, will be at 2 P. M. The series is now tied, each having won three games, while one resulted in a deadlock. The veteran Lion eleven is a decided favorite today.

While the British Government rushed its program for participation in the Ninepower treaty conference at Brussels, Sir Samuel Hoare, Home Secretary, emphasized the "common outlook" on foreign relations of Britain and the United States tonight in a speech before the Newcastle Chamber of Commerce.

BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Oct. 22.--The Duke and Duchess of Windsor received a rather puzzling reception today at Chancellor Hitler's mountain home herd. The Fuehrer was cordial, but the former British King must have realized that his host evidently makes a distinction between abdicated royalty and reigning monarchs or dictators.

James Barton, actor, has purchased the eight-acre plot known as Recreation Park, on the Jericho Turnpike at New Hyde Park, L. I. The purchaser plans to improve the property with an indoor and outdoor athletic arena with facilities for football, baseball, miniature automobile racing, boxing, wrestling and ice hockey, as well as with a cafe and dining room, where floor shows will be given.

The metro politan Police Board is considering recruiting women to replace policemen called for military duty. The board believes that "the strongest of the weaker sex" would be more useful than "the weakest of the stronger sex," and thus may fill vacancies with husky women.
Eastchester High School kept its record for this season unmarred by giving Pelham Memorial High its first defeat of the campaign, 13 to 0, in the rain before 1,000 spectators today.

Price movements of commodity futures were generally lower yesterday in moderate activity on the local Exchanges. Coffee and lead futures were the exceptions, registering fair-sized gains. In the cash markets sugar, rubber and wool tops were higher, but all the grains, cocoa, lard, tins, cotton and silk declined.

The names of six more claimants to the $877,500 estate of the late Ida E. Wood were stricken from the record yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley on the ground of insufficient evidence that they were in any way related to the wealthy recluse.

The Non-Intervention subcommittee's "love feast" of Wednesday, when Italy dramatically accepted the British compromise plan for the withdrawal of foreign volunteers from Spain, was followed by another meeting today, at which it appears that monkey wrenches were sent flying into the machinery.

Another chapter was completed tonight in the tragic romance of Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt and Verna Garr Taylor when a jury acquitted Roy Garr, brother of Mrs. Taylor, of killing Denhardt. The jury, composed of twelve tobacco farmers, returned the verdict one hour and fifteen minutes after receiving the case.
A new streamlined Rock Island "Rocket" train crashed into a bus loaded with high school students at the southwest city limits here today, killing ten persons and injuring eighteen.

An exhibition composed of drawings by Thomas Benton has opened at the galleries of the Associated American Artists, 420 Madison Avenue. This work will continue to be shown there through Nov. 6. Many of these excellent drawings reappear as illustrations in Mr. Benton's just published book, "An Artist in America" (Robert M. McBride Co.). Like the book, they cover a great deal of ground.
Jacob Epstein, whose creactive work has aroused more discussion than that of any other modern sculptor, became the center of a violent storm of controversy tonight.

Prices made public last night for 1938 Chevrolet automobiles represented increases ranging from 3.4 per cent to 5 per cent, or from $26 to $34. Including standard accessories such as front and rear bumpers, spare tire and tube and, in deluxe models, the right-hand tail lamp, the new models were priced as follows:
Central New York Power Corporation 5 per cent preferred stock, $100 par value; Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., Class A stock, $1 par value, and 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $25 par value;

Brig.Gen. Harold C. Reisinger, paymaster of the Marine Corps, was ordered today to face a general courtmartial at Quantico on Monday on charges of conduct to the prejudice of good order and discipline.

Miss Mary Elsie Holmes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Samuel Holmes of this place, was married in Watcnung Congregational Church tonight to John Gregg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Gregg, also of Montclair.

Miss Doris Bliss Richardson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Richardson of this place, was maried this afternoon to Murray H. Coggeshall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray H. Coggeshall, in St. Peter's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David K. Montgomery,

The six-story Mandel apartment house on the Riverside Drive blockfront from 162d to 163d Street, was sold at auction yesterday by Ralph W. Long to. the. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the plaintiff, on a bid of $275.000.

The marriage of Miss Elise Helen Fay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rodman Fay of this city and Northeast Harbor, Me., to James Lindsay Ware took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Church. The Rev. James A. Paul, associate rector, performed the ceremony.

Quiet firmness ruled in the stock market today, and yesterday's improvement was broadly held, reflecting the better atmosphere in Wall Street. Internationals opened well, although the bellwethers were not in harmony, United States Steel losing 1/8 point, while International Nickel gained.

The "permanent" slum-clearance program which is being undertaken by the Federal Government under the Wagner-Steaga Act will, if properly carried out, prove to be "the greatest possible boon" to real estate wherever it is put into operation, declared Secretary Ickes tonight at the closing session of the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
