The annual meeting of shareholders of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was postponed yesterday for the second time because of the lack of a quorum. Ernest A. Bigelow, newly elected chairman of the board of directors, called for an adjournment until Nov. 22.

A. Lordi, for a number of years with Nelson-Hickson, Inc., has been appointed controller of JayThorpe, Inc. Jopling's, a new store for men, will open on Tuesday in the building at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.
Two Roxbury men were swept to their death through a sewer main in Chelsea today. They were Walter Staats, 45, of Roxbury and Arthur F. Peterson, 37, of Roxbury.

Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria paid a surprise visit to Hungary today, arriving this early morning at Kisber, ostensibly to join a hunting party which he was invited to months ago by Premier Koloman Daranyi. It is reported he will return to Vienna Sunday or Monday.

John Hunter Bennington, who rose from conductor with the old Brooklyn City Railroad to real estate and tax agent of the BrooklynManhattan Transit Corporation of New York, died suddenly today of a stroke at his home here. His age was 67.

A gay-and quippish musical, topical as a fireside chat and lighter than a magic carpet, Eddie Cantor's "Ali Baba Goes to Town" emerged yesterday at the Roxy as one of the better entertainment risks of the season.
September export of Canadian newsprint paper was 6,173,095 hundredweight, valued at $11,303,766, against 5,567,360 at $9,775,549 in September, 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
Railroad officials were pleased not only by the increases in freight rates awarded them yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission but also by the manner in which they were awarded.

Harry Nicodemus, brother-in-law of the late Governor Edwin Warfield and for forty years associated with the Fidelity and Deposit Company, which Mr. Warfield founded, died today at his home here at the age of 73.

Severiano Pulido, acting president of the Provincial Council, who was shot by an unidentified assailant during a meeting of that body yesterday, died at 1:45 this afternoon. His testimony concerning the shooting fray was being taken by a judge of the Instruction Court when his heart failed and he died from loss of blood.
Two milk drivers of the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., will receive Pasteur medals for bravery at exercises this morning in the company's offices at 524 West Fifty seventh Street.
Following is the text of the findings of the Interstate Commerce Commission in granting freight rate increases:

President Roosevelt said today that it was hoped to lay before Congressional tax committees in November the administration's revision program, but he added that it would be a matter for the regular session of Congress to deal with and that no recommendations concerning taxes would be made to the extra session convening Nov. 15.

A contract providing for wage increases and improvements in working conditions was signed yesterday between RCA Communications, Inc., and the American Radio Telegraphists Association, C. I. O. affiliate. It was the first contract ever signed by the company with any union and the first contract with any major company obtained by the C. I. O. in the communications field.

M. Elie Lescot, the Haitian Minister, today conferred on Michael Francis Doyle, attorney of Philadelphia, the title of Commander of the Order of Honour and Merit of Haiti in recognition of his services in maintaining the independence of that nation, and for his services of international good-will and peace.

Druidaig Bess, a black and white waistcoated cocker spaniel owned by William K. Dick of Islip, L. I., and handled by the veteran Harry Cameron, today won the open all-age stake as the three-day meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association opened.

Investigators of the Charles S. Ross kidnapping focused their attention today upon an automobile abandoned in a South Side garage about five miles from Blue Island, where a ten-dollar bill of the ransom turned up yesterday.

Whether a financial crash be one that follows a "thick," free and unmanaged stock market, as in 1929, or a "thin," regulated and curbed one, as today's, any financial system which permits a loss of $25,000,000,000 in values within a peacetime period of two short months is little short of lunatic.

Joseph C. Jahn, 54 years old, an internal revenue agent attached to the New Haven (Conn.) office, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning in the private garage adjoining his home, at 103 Candee Avenue here, this morning.

Captain Edgar Stripling led the New York University cross-country team to a 25-30 victory over Lafayette on the five-mile campus course today. He finished third, behind Captain Walt Williamson and Archie Sparks of the Maroon, who placed first and second. resnectively.

AMHERST VS. WESLEYAN-This should be dedicated as Be-Kind-to-the-Birds Week. The National Association of Audubon Societies is starting its annual convention and is requesting cooperation from all kindly citizens. Please do not throw stones at birds while the convention is in session. Not even at grackles. One small vote, about the size of a Savannah sparrow, for Amherst.

The $400,000 Max and Flora Einhorn Memorial Building of- the Lenox Hill Hospital,. at 131 East Seventy-sixth Street, was dedicated last night in the presence of: 300 persons, including many physicians and surgeons.

Inquiry among New York broadcasters disclosed yesterday that they are not in accord with the proposal of George Henry Payne, member of the Federal Communications Commission, to license broadcasting stations based on standards of radio programs.

Following is the complete list of those from the metropolitan district, New Jersey and Connecticut, who drew horses still slated to start in the race, with the current odds quoted against the horses, which are carried in order of favoritism:

Claims aggregating approximately $850,000 have been filed by attorneys and trustees against the Cities Service Company for expenses incurred in connection with the reorganization proceedings of the Warner-Quinlan Company, a, subsidiary of Cities Service, it became known yesterday.
Miss Caroline Glander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clare Glander of Glen Ridge, was married this after noon to William Leonard Smyth, son of Mr. and Mrs. LeonardClair Smyth, also of Glen Ridge.

A school for women jurors will be conducted at the Westchester Women's Club here on Monday afternoon and Tuesday evening, with a mock trial held at the final session and the evidence submitted to three experimental juries-one of women, one of men and the thirdof men and women.

IN England a ballet dancer who wishes to be taken seriously is often tempted to assume a Rus sian name, for our prejudices die slowly, and the English are still inclined to believe that only Russians can dance.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Walton High School Exhibition Hall, 196th Street and Reservoir Avenue, The Bronx 20 easel paintings, 39 graphic prints, 7pieces sculpture and 15 textiles of design.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administra tor, said yesterday on his return from conferences with Harry L. Hopkins and other WPA executives in Washington that he was going to make an estimate of the number of unemployed- persons here, but that his effort would not resemblea "count" or census.

Hood College started a program of all college sightseeing trips this week-end, with one group of stu dents making a two-day excursion to Williamsburg, Va., and an other visiting places of educa tional and historical interest inand around Washington.

At Quoddy Village, Me., the Na tional Youth Administration is rounding off the first period of an unusually interesting experiment in the field of vocational guidance and work experience. The purpose of the experiment is to find a sound and flexible way to provide inexperi enced young people with a practical knowledge of a variety of occupa tions so that they may be betterable to select a lifetime job.

New York City, generous parent, will spend a grand total of $11,000, 000 for the higher education of al most 60,000 full and part-time stu dents next year in its four city col leges, according to a statistical sur vey prepared by the Citizens BudgetCommission, Inc.

The dominant football power so proudly displayed by Louisiana State University for two years came to an end today at the hands of Vanderbilt's Commodores on the cold, wind-swept turf of DudleyStadium.

THE financial responsibility law which we have in New York is based upon the the ory that every dog is enti tied to one bite. If a motorist com mits a serious infraction of the highway law. or fails to pay a judg ment, he must then prove his fi nancial responsibility before he ispermitted to continue to drive.

Miss Grace Jessie Kirby, the sea son's only debutante in Wilkes Barre, will be introduced to society at a party to be given by her par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Allan P. Kirby the evening of Dec. 28 at the Westmoreland Club here.

Ernest Hem ingway's film, "The Spanish Earth," has been banned by the censor here until he sees the original text. The picture was to be shown in London tonight in connection with the British Con gress of International Peace cam paign. The censor's action wasnot expected.
Events of a night in a hospital will be dramatized in a pageant to be given by the women's division of the United Hospital Campaign, fol lowing a dinner tomorrow eveningat the Hotel Commodore.

DO you believe the power to pro pel your car will ultimately come from the ether waves? Do you believe traffic signal lights will ultimately-be on your instru ment panel instead of the street corner? Do you believe a master switch in some remote radio tower will ultimately slam on your brakesif you are headed for danger?
REFERENCE was made last Sunday to the high per centage of repeat appear ances in the American sec tion of the 1937 international atPittsburgh.

An educational exhibit that de tails the unusual manner in which Brazil nuts are harvested in the wilds of the Amazon jungle and eventually brought to American nousewives is on view at the Packard-Bamberger Co. marketin Hackensack, N. J.
She Is Married to John Eldred, Farnham in Ceremony at theFirst Presbyterian Church

Evidence sup porting the belief that an early end of the Sino-Japanese war is still possible is seen in a microscopic reading of remarks made by Fi nance Minister Okinobu Kaya in atrain interview last evening.

Stocks closed sharply lower after rails opened weak on higher freight rate news; turn over, 1,565,020 shares. United States Government and other bonds lower, rail issuesweakest; transactions, $7,721,175.

Fred Kramer, 19 years old, or 263 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, was accidentally shot in the abdo men and left wrist yesterday by Edward Lowe, 17, of 630 West 170th Street while both were examining a pistol which Lowe told the policehe found in Washington Park.
John Marini, 74 years old, of 624 Garden Street, Carlstadt, was killed by an eastbound passenger train of the Erie Railroad near the Rutherford station at 6:45 o'clock tonight.

Arkansas politicians construe Gov ernor Carl E. Bailey's defeat by Representative John E. Miller for the Senate seat of the late Joe T. Robinson as a clarification of the State's attitude toward President Roosevelt's policies, rather than asa repudiation of the New Deal.

Miss Mary Muriel Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Walsh of this city, was married to George Low Farns worth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Almon M. Farnsworth of Camden, N. Y., this afternoon in St. Ursula's Church here by the Rev. FrancisO'Reilly, the rector.

An Americans delegation is on the high seas, bound for participation in what may be a historic effort of the peace-loving nations of the world to restore and preserve that tran quillity and order to which this country, in common with the other democracies, believes it is firmlycommitted.

The Bergen Building, a modern office structure, has been completed at the northwest corner of Cottage Place and East Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood, N. J. The exterior walls are of glass block and black struc tural glass, plate glass being usedfor the show windows.
Mrs. Henry Ford's conditional offer of $15,000 to help finance the Wom an's National Farm and Garden As sociation won quick acceptance today from the organization's council.
A certain liveliness is apparent," as they used to say in World War bulletins, on the Nazi fronts in Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Austria following aprolonged quiescence.

IT is Autumn in New England, and as the flaming leaves drop from sumac and maple the evergreens come into their own against the rich brown hill sides. Haze' softens the outlines of thiscity on the Merrimack.
Automobile plants of the United States and Canada produced 5,110,000 pas senger cars and trucks in the twelve months ending with Sep tember, the Automobile Manufac turers Association announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent letter of former Secretary of State Stimson on the crisis in the Far East, although representing an orthodox conception of American Far Eastern policy, requires clarification of a few of the more salient points dealtwith.
One of the most interesting plays of the sea son, James Agate's "I Accuse," based on the Dreyfus case, opens at the "Q" Theatre on Monday. It is an adaptation from the Germanof Dr.
Be cause Pennsylvania had twelve men on the field when a field goal was--kicked in the last 30 seconds, it had to be content with a scoreless tiewith Georgetown University today.
Fourteen women ambitious to be members of the new City Council are driving toward that objective in the present campaign, but any attempt at classifications endsthere.

Knitwear this Fall is smart, feath erweight and perfectly cut. The newest cardigan style fits in trimly at the waist and some of the most becoming jumpers have high yokes and close boat-shaped necks. Car digans and jumpers are made to match, with harmonious finishingdetails on both garments.

AS resorts prepare for the Win ter season, the increasing ver satility of America's play grounds becomes once more apparent. It used to be that vaca tionists followed the seasons as unalterably as the birds: To Florida,

The life and work of Dwight L. Moody, the evangelist, will be me morialized at a meeting on Wednes day evening in Carnegie Hall in celebration of the 100th anniversary of his birth. A feature of the meet ing will be the singing of some of the hymns which Mr. Moody used at meetings held in .the same hallmany years ago.

Cruise traffic during the season that starts early in October, reaches its peak in December, January and February and continues until mid April promises to reach new high marks this year, according to traffic executives.

ELLIS CREDLE has earned a well-deserved reputation for her picture-book por trsyals of Southern moun taineers and of plantation life, and in this new book she goes even farther South, across the border into Mexico to tell the storyof a fat little Mexican puppy.

In the heart of the World War's Western front stood Reims Cathedral, gaunt, wracked symbol of France. Ger man shells whined over its lofty spires and sometimes struck, crushing priceless sculpture, stained windowsand ancient masonry.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has received upward of $22,000,000 in cash in this city as a result of the recent re funding program of the United River Plate Telephone Company, Ltd., of Argentina, its largest telephone operating affiliate.

Kan sas State defeated a stubborn Creighton University eleven, 15 to 7. before a homecoming crowd of 8,000 today. Howard Cleveland, Kansas State halfback, scored a touchdown on two sparkling runs of 21 and 23vards in the firste nerind

WHILE the annual totals of deaths resulting from automobile accidents throughout the country has risen steadily since 1930, fatali ties in cities over 10,000 population have actually shown a 10 per centdecrease during the same period.

The nine-story professional build ing at 116 Central Park South has been exchanged by Frieda Braf man, its former owner, for the twenty-seven-acre estate with a twenty-two room house, known as "Brandywine," on Sleepy Hollow Road, Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., itwas announced yesterday.
TEN artists are represented in the Fall exhibition in the Daylight Room reserved for exhibitors of established reputation at the Downtown Gallery.

THE Mayoralty campaign now reaches the homestretch. For weeks New Yorkers have heard the issues discussed. Everything from finance to relief, from municipal planning to major crime, has been bruited from ear to ear and from microphone to loud speaker, not once but many times. The ground has all been covered. And it seems all to have boiled down to oneissue: La Guardia.

An in crease of railroad coach fares from 1 1/2 cents to 2 cents a mile in South eastern territory was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Com mission. Representatives of the railroads declined to estimate what the increase, effective on Nov. 1, would amount to in terms of annualrevenue.

Debutantes of the Winter, as members of a special committee under the supervision of Miss Helen Michalis, will sell flowers, bouton nieres and home-made candy at the benefit performance of "The Star Wagon" Thursday night at the Empire Theatre.

Formation of a new group among the girls of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here was announced today. The group is the Fishing Club. And the girls intend to fish, too, not merely talk about it. Not only will the fair anglers catch fish, they hope,but they will clean them.

The outpouring of offerings of stock on Tuesday produced the tenth heaviest volume of trading in the history of the Stock Exchange. The day's turnover of 7,287,000 shares was exceeded only on fourdays at the end of October, 1929;

Trenton Teachers and Arnold College of New Haven battled to a 6-6 dead lock today. Trenton took the lead with a touchdown early in the sec ond period, but the visitors coun tered with a six-pointer in the thirdstanza.

The winged hoofs of Dakota, brown gelding of Olympic achievements, carried the United States Army team to the front today in the inter national military jumping competi tion of the Inter-America HorseShow.

The United Hospital campaign for funds to carry on work in nine ty-two voluntary hospitals and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brook lyn will get under way tomorrow with a dinner at the Hotel Commodore.
King Leopold of the Belgians is to pay a State visit to the King and Queen at Buckingham Palace in November, and some interesting innovations in royal entertaining are likely to result from his stay.

Mrs. Kenneth B. Norton of Bronx ville, director of the Westchester Lighting Company, will speak on "Women in Big Business" at the Fall assembly on Friday of the Eastern Federation of DelphianChapters.
Governors of the six New England States, an nouncing the thirteenth New Eng land Conference, called today for "united, cooperative action" tomeet Southern competition.

The marriage of Miss Jane Cornelia Goodlove, daughter of Mrs. A. Francis Goodlove of New York and of Covert LeFevre Goodlove of Ridgewood, N. J., to Curtis Diet rich Morgan,,son of Mr. and Mrs.Francis H. Morgan of Tampa, Fla.,
In terior Department officials drew a mental picture today of the beauty of New Jersey's Raritan River as it will be restored soon through pollution abatement.

In a communique issued today the Foreign Office warns London and Paris that Rome will make no further concessions toward the solution of the Spanish problem and will disclaim all re sponsibility if the Non-Intervention Committee fails to reach an agreement because of Russia's attitude.

Hackley ran roughshod over River dale in a Triangular League foot ball game today, scoring by 27-6. Early in the first quarter Hackley took the ball on its own 42-yard line and marched for a touchdown,Touart going off tackle.

THE White House Library is about to be augmented by a gift of 200 new books chosen by a committee act ing for the American Booksellers Association. Among the mem bers of the committee are Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, author andformer Minister to Denmark;

THE automobile industry is an nouncing its new models with the belief that 1938 will be a good year and with the conviction that because of its impor tant influence on the general eco nomic life of the country through the disbursement of funds for pay rolls, raw materials, transportation and other services, the industry will be able to continue its traditionalcontribution to national prosperity.

The re gional office of the National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint today against the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, in which it was charged that employes were "forced to join" the Brother hood of Mine Workers of captive ore mines "to obtain or retain employment and to avoid demotion."
The Supreme Court Justices assembled today to decide whether to review the conviction of Haywood Patter son, one of the Negroes involved in the famous Scottsboro, Ala.,cases.
Mrs. Anna George de Mille, daughter of Henry George, the economist, will present a death mask of her father to Princeton University at exercises Sunday, Oct. 31, in theuniversity library.

AIRMEN rarely "walk away" from collisions in flight, but it was done recently by Vance Breese, veteran test pilot, and Ross Seeley, student instructor, when their planes came together overMines Field in Los Angeles.
AN increasing national income and a pronounced trend dur ing the more recent recovery years to qualify buying seem to indicate an entirely satisfactory year for the automobile industry in1938.

An indica tion that the pacifist movement in British universities has sur vived the rearmament clamor and the turmoil that followed the adopting by the Oxford Union of a resolution "not to fight for King and country" came toGlasgow today.

Appointments to,four named pro fessorships and one promotion are announced by the board of trustees at Smith College. Harold U. Faulkner of the De partment of History since 1925, has been named to the Dwight W. Mor row Professorship of American History. Arthur W. Locke, Professor

The house in Ebury Street, near Victoria Station, where George Moore spent many years of his life and where he wrote a number of his books, has undergone a strange transformation since his death. The old house has been turnedinto a school of interior decoration.

The marriage of Miss Helen El berta Gustafson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer W. Gustafson of Maplewood, to Arthur Kline Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Evans, also of this town, took place this evening in the First Lutheran Church, East Orange. The cere mony was performed by the pastor,the Rev. Karl E. Mattson.

Miss Jean McKinley Strait, daughter of Ernest Charles Strait of this place and the late Mrs. Strait, was mar ried this afternoon to Chester T. Birch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Birch of New York in the First Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Mitchell T. Ancker. The ceremony was followed by a small reception at the Chilmark Club.
THE worldly wise men of the Society of Jesuits living in the wilderness frontiers of New France had a pretty clear idea of their purpose in the annual reports which the Superiors sent back home.

BELA BARTOK'S music for strings, percussion and celes ta will be given its first Amer ican performance Thursday night by the Philharmonic-Sym phony Orchestra. The program on this occasion will also include Weber's overture to "Euryanthe"and Brahms's First symphony.
THE nineteenth-century fourth Marquess of Hertford is re sponsible for the largest part of the Wallace collection and for its pervading eighteenth-centuryFrench flavor. The fourth Marquess

With talk of balancing the budget in the air and with the continued dissatis faction expressed in many quarters over certain of the present taxes, political observers are convinced that there will be a revision of the tax system at the next regular ses sion of Congress-how great is stilla matter of uncertainty.

EHRLICH--ROSENFELD--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rosenfeld, 940 Ocean Ave., Brooklyn, announce the marriage of their daughter, Florence Roberta, to Mr. Lester S. Ehrlich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Ehrlich, on Oct. 20, 1937. FURST--DE GOFF--Mrs. Len De Goff wishes to announce the marriage of her daughter, Harriet, to Mr. William H. Furst.

THERE was a time when hairdressers and beauty parlor operators could learn all they needed to know just by working in a shop. But not any longer. The "beauty business" has become one of the largest in dustries in the country, and there is an increasing demand for operators with diplomas.

More verbal fireworks impended tonight in Rhode Island's battle be tween Governor Robert E. Quinn and Walter E. O'Hara, turfman publisher, which has halted racing at the Narragansett track by theuse of National Guard troops.

THE position of the independent in the automobile industry will be considerably strengthened during 1938. The big increase in sales in the middle-price market which began during 1937 reflects an appreciation on the part of the buying public of the accomplish ments of the independent manufacturers.

Several thousand gourds, ranging from pumpkins and squashes six feet in circumference to gooseberry gourds less than an inch in diame ter, will be shown at the First New York Gourd Festival in the RCA Building in Rockefeller Cen ter from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M., Fri day through Sunday. Dr. Albert J. Irving of Brewster, N. Y., headsthe committee planning the festival.

Sock and Buskin, Brown University dra matic society, concluded its 150th performance in Faunce House The atre last night, marking the anni versary by presenting Sutter Vane's melodrama, "Outward Bound," with a cast of Brown and Pembroke College undergraduates, assisted byguest players.

Louis Greenberg of 666 West End Avenue, a retired that manufacturer, who was active in Jewish philanthropic work, died yesterday after a brief illness at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Shirley Jacobs, 514 West 110th Street. He was 76 years old.

Industry itself was credited today at the annual Industrial Research Conference for the emancipation of its workers from "long hours and inhuman working conditions." W. J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company declared that industry "has been the sole originator of those improvements of industrial practice that are acknowledged tohave lifted the social level."
ALTHOUGH familiar with the earlier work of L. A. G. Strong, I had not seen his more recent novels until "Laughter in the West" fell tomy lot.
WHEN the late Franz Kafka's "The Castle" was published in this country some years ago, it created no general stir, but it was immedi ately seized upon by a few people as a very distinguished book.

The WPA is planning no census of the unemployed and will cooperate to the fullest with the voluntary regis tration by mail to be taken under direction of John D. Biggers pur suant an act of the last session of Congress, a WPA spokesman saidtoday.

Field trips in which students and faculty members of the University of Pennsylvania participated during the past Summer yielded about 20,000 botanical specimens, which are being added to the herbarium of the Department of Botany and that the of the university's Morris Arboretum in Chestnut Hill.
A recent arrival on the campus of Pembroke College is Miss Afife Sayin of Istan bul, Turkey, who is to do graduate work in economics at Brown Universitv.
Alexis Meronivich Yatchmeneff, chief of all the Aleuts, died yester day at the age of 72. He reigned thirty-five years over the AleutianIsland natives.

Paul Edwards, administrator of the PWA arts projects, whose re moval is sought by members of the Supervisors Council of the Federal Theatre for "playing politics with the taxpayers' money," denied the allegations of his accusers yester day and defended the stand he hastaken.

A somewhat confusing situation has arisen as a result of the popular meetings now being held everywhere to nominate candidates-selected by an open vote by show of hands-because al most all of them want to nominateJoseph Stalin and other leaders.

The Commonwealth of Kentucky will write the final chapter in the tragedies of Verna Garr Taylor and Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt when murder charges against her brother, Dr. E. S. Garr, are dismissed in February.
NOT in years has so much good fruit poured into October city markets from every corner of the country.

Miss Maruia Braden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Spruille Braden, was married here this afternoon to Wil liam Hart Lyons, son of the late Dennis Francis Lyons and ' Mrs. Anne Francis- Gall Lyons of St. Paul. Mr. Braden is United, States delegate to the Chaco Peace Conference.
Miss Margaret H.'Fonville, daughter of Mrs. Emory Thompson Miller of this city, was married tonight to Dr. John Boyd Coates, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Boyd Coates of Glenside, Pa.

The. Hillside, N. J., Woman's Club will be hostess to the Fifth District Conference of the New Jersey State Federation of Wo men's Clubs on Thursday. Mrs. Robert L. Ashley is chairman of ar rangements for the sessions open ing at 10 A. M. and continuing through the day at the HillsidePresbyterian Church.

Construction volume throughout the country for the first nine months of the present year reveals a substantial gain over the similar period for 1936, reports E. M. Craig, executive secretary of the National Association of Building Trades Employers. His report was based upon a recent survey by Rob ert D. Steele, statistician for the association, covering forty-four States and thirty-seven leadingcities.
Secretary Wallace of the Depart ment of Agriculture and Mayor La Guardia will officiate on Nov. 4 at the preview of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair of 1937in Rockefeller Center.

Miss Muriel Edith Wright of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Holly Wright of Olean, N. Y., was married to Lieutenant Richard Henry Carmichael, U. S. A., son of Colonel and Mrs. Horace H. Carmichael of Austin, Texas, here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church by the rector, the Rev. Dr.George P. T. Sargent.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Vanderveer of Forest Hills of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Louise Vanderveer, to Dr. Edward H. Schwiebert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Schwiebert, also ofForest Hills. .

Milton I. Schwalbe of 940 St. Nicholas Avenue and Benjamin Glaser of 109 East 153d Street filed suits in Federal Court yesterday to compel the Bethlehem Steel Com pany to redeem their holdings of first consolidated mortgage gold bonds of the company, aggregating$173,917, in Dutch guilders.

Alderman Newbold Morris, Joseph D. McGoldrick and a score of other speakers endorsed the candidacies of Isadore Nagler for Borough President of the Bronx and Frank D. Tufano for councilman at the fifth anniversary dinner of the Westchester Independent Political Club held last night at the Con course Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, Bronx. Morethan 700 persons were present.

Four engineers of the National Broadcasting Company made radio history today when, after weeks of painstaking preparation, they suc ceeded in transmitting "voice sig nals of broadcast quality" by radiofrom a fully submerged submarine.
More than 500 persons attended the first Piccadilly supper dance of the sea son tonight in the Bellevue-Strat ford ballroom. The supper dance was preceded by a special dinnerdance in the Planet Room.

One of the new developments con training large residences and estates on the North Shore of Long Island is the community from part of the holdings of the Robert W. De For est and Mrs. L. K. Elmhirst families at West Hills in Suffolk County.

President Roosevelt's speech on Wednes day at the dedication of the new Federal Reserve Building is regard ed by Administration fiscal experts as his first public endorsement of the policy of the present Board ofGovernors of the Federal Reserve

And although he was at that time being prepared for West Point his parents finally decided that he might give up the army career and follow his odd naturalbent instead. His parents, indeed,

Miss Barabra Leal Hadden of 704 West End Avenue, New York, daughter of Mrs. Edward Hadden of Plainfield and the late Mr. Hadden, was married to Hugh Wallace MacDonald, son of James MacDonaid of New York and the late Mrs.
Mrs. John S. Lawrence of Boston and Topsfield, long a leader in Bos ton and North Shore society, died early today at the Beverly Hospital after an illness of three weeks.She was 49 years old.

ANNOUNCEMENT is made by the publishers of the Amer ican standard postage stamp catalogue that Cuba's "Asso ciation of American Writers and Artists" postal series "will not be accorded regular catalogue recog nition" on the ground that it was released primarily "to exploit stampcollectors."

Commander T. M. Craven, member of the Federal .Communications Com mission, and R. Harry Norweb, American Minister to the Domini can Republic, were designated today delegates to the Inter-American Radio Conference in HavanaNov. 1.

Supporters of Mayor La Guardia became more confident yesterday of the election of the Fusion city wide ticket and Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for District Attorney of New York County, on receipt of week-end reports from the fiveboroughs of the city.
Nearly 100, 000 fascist leaders and minor chief tains will begin to "march" on Rome Monday night for a celebra tion Thursday of the fifteenth an niversary of the rise to power ofBenito Mussolini.
With snow falling intermittently throughout the game, Tennessee defeated Sewanee, 32 to 0, todaybefore 4,000 shivering spectators.
Tulsa University sped over the ground and sailed through the air to four touchdowns that counted and two more than didn't today and handed Oklahoma A. and M. a 27 to 0 setback.

IN four or five years the tourists visiting South Africa will see a new Cape Town as a result of the City Council's approval of plans for a project to cost $50, 000,000-a project so big that com panies in England, France, Italy and the United States have already asked for details so that they mayenter bids on the work.
THE annual gasoline bill of the American motoring public, based on the retail price, is about three and one-half billion.

Two dramatic developments in the Narragansett Race Track contro versy this week served to draw even more clearly the battle lines between Governor Robert E. Quinn and Walter E. O'Hara, president and managing director of thetrack.

Like lightning stabbing through the murky afternoon, two long runs gave Dartmouth victory over Har vard today, 20 to 2. There was an other touchdown scored by the Green, but that was during the lat ter part of the second half and any thing could have happened then inthe Harvard Stadium.

With "purposeful action" the key note of their program, at least 100 Mount Holyoke College girls, work ing in the service commission of the Fellowship of Faiths, will offer guidance and companionship to Holyoke and South Hadley childrenthroughout the academic year.
George U. Harvey, Borough Pres ident of Queens, made public yes terday eight petitions for public improvements which his office has received from local boards. ThePetitions follow:

TRAVELERS who have made a beaten path to the gardens and homes of Natchez, Miss., typical city of the Old South, will soon have an added interest. They will drive over "the oldest road in the United States," the Natchez Trace, made into a park way extending from Natchez toNashville, Tenn.

Of George Lorimer now gone we re peat with added praise what we said of him living. He was true to himself and to his America to the end. Son of a Scotland-born divine, a business man with a fortune in prospect, a reporter with promise of a successful career as a daily newspaper man, he hewed out a unique and notable career for himself as an American editor.

Sloppy playing conditions, which accounted for much fumbling by both elevens, failed to halt the Uni versity of Detroit's undefeated and untied team today as the Titans from Michigan defeated Boston Col lege, 14-0, before 7,000 at AlumniField.
VISITORS to the Automobile Show will see the most exten sive use of plastics for in terior appointments in motor carhistory.

TEXAS in 1868 is this book's real hero. A hero more colorful would be difficult to find. "I'm told." com ments one of Major Thomason's characters, "there is a newfan gled self-cockin' revolver on the market now. When it appears in these parts I tremble for the pop ulation of this State: I do. indeed."

Owing to the in flux of refugees from Gijon, Spain, the French Government has issued new orders for the expulsion of Spanish refugees, and no' men of fighting age from either side in Spain will be allowed to take up residence in France except in extraordinary cases.
ROYAL ENGINEER: The pastimes of royalty have been various. Louis XVI was a locksmith, Franz Josef a hunter, George V a stamp collector. Unique among mod-...

North Jersey entries today carried off half of the blue ribbons during the third program of the annual Wissahickon horse show. Prince Charming II, a bay gelding from the Claredda Farm of Shrewsbury, N. J., continued his triumphs by annexing top honors in the thoroughbred hunter class.
All government employes will donate one month's salary for rearmament purposes, the payments to be mademonthly, it was announced today.

The 1937 Remington Honor Medal will be presented to Dr. J. Leon Lascoff, chairman of the American Pharmaceutical Association Recipe Book committee, at a dinner in his honor to be given tomorrow night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

HENDAYE, France (On the Spanish Frontier), Oct. 23.--Insurgent General Francisco Franco to day swung his strengthened army east to the Aragon front, next major theater of Spain's civil war, for what his aides said would be "the decisive offensive of the war."

The University of New Hampshire Wild cats scored their fifth straight vic tory, 34-0, against a fighting Ver month University team today. A 50-yard Wildcat drive was good for the first touchdown, Abbot scoring, and a 30-yard touchdown pass from Horne to Durie culminated the second advance.

Thomas Mongan, a fireman in Pub lic School 3 here, who yesterday al legedly attempted to assault Mayor Bernard N. McFeely, was being sought tonight on a warrant follow ing his failure to appear at policecourt for a hearing.

Germany's new drive for the reorganization of Central Europe by means of Hit ler's "dynamic peace policy," pre dicted immediately after the Ger man declaration guaranteeing the independence of Belgium, got under way this week.

Formation of the Columbia Stu dent Christian Association, uniting the religious work of eleven Prot estant groups at Columbia, was an nounced yesterday by Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of the university. Social welfare projects, visits to churches in the metropolitan area, lectures and discussion groups havebeen planned.
AT the big automobile shows and in display rooms across the continent, automobile-minded Americans this year will see the finest motor cars that have everbeen produced.
The Neighborhood Music School will be the beneficiary of the first matinee performance for the sea son at the Metropolitan OperaHouse on Dec. 10.

The Criminal Courts Building and City Prison destined to be erected on the site bounded by Leonard, Centre, White and Baxter Streets, near Foley Square, at an estimated cost of $12,500,000, has been hailed by the Municipal Art Commission as the most comprehensive public work of its kind in the history ofthis city.

A fire that started at 3 o'clock this afternoon in a beauty parlor in the center of the city destroyed half a dozen buildings and the Convent of the Immaculate Conception, one of the earliest Roman Catholic mis sions established on the island and conducted mainly by American nuns. The loss thus far is estimated at [Pound]40,000.
Miss Elizabeth Sparks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Alan Sparks of My Lady's Manor, Md., was wed to Wallace Edwin Dow of Lynn, Mass., this evening in St. James Episcopal Church at the formerplace.

The board of trustees of Manhat tan College has completed plans for a retirement system for the members of the lay faculty and ad ministrative department employes, it was announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, F. S. C., presidentof the college.

Lady Marler, the wife of Sir Her bert Marler, Canadian Minister to the United States, was the guest of honor yesterday afternoon at a tea given by the Canadian Women's Club at its headquarters, 130 EastFifty-seventh Street.
TRADE reports from the coun try grew spottier last week but not in the way of a lower average. Results showed wider variation and a brisk upturn in New England territory was a feature.

Supplying an extracurricular out let for the cultural, religious and departmental interests of Hunter College students, forty-seven clubs under the supervision of the stu dent council have elected almost 300 officers to guide their programfor the semester.

The days when automobiles were sold with top and wind hield as optional equipment and testing grounds were unheard loth the maker and the protive customer were seeking the er to the all-important question performance.

Now that it is practically decided that the Paris Exposition will be opened in 1938, Americans in Paris are wondering if the United States pavilion will have a more adequate equipment ofexhibits for next year.
The fever chart of European diplomacy has been quite as spectacular this week as the graphs on the stock market pages which have recorded the gyra tions of Wall Street from day today.

Miss Martha Eleanor Bounds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Bounds of Hebron, was married to George Repold Vickers 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Vickers 3d of Balti more, this evening in St. Peter'sProtestant Episcopal Church here.

John H. Morris, president of the Morris Realty Service Corporation of Far Rockaway, has been elected president of the Long Island Real Estate Board succeeding Edward F. Hosinger, who held the presi dency for two terms. Other officerselected were:

Thirty-four students at Upsala Col lege here are enjoying dean's list privileges, permitting them to take a maximum of three extra credit hours, because of scholastic ratings made last semester, it was an nounced today by Dr. Frans Erics son, acting president. The list follows:
The mother of a week-old baby was wounded slightly and the maternity ward of Springfield City Hospital thrown into turmoil tonight,
AIRLINES recently have be come something more than an available means of trans portation between the six Central American countries. They are now primary arteries for shipping and trade.

An awakened interest in public speak ing at Lehigh University has result ed in an enlargement of the speech program. Registrations for the first semes ter exceed by 20 per cent the total enrollments for both semesters lastyear.
Columbia High School of South Orange and Maplewood defeated Westfield High on the gridiron, 46 to 0, today. It was the fourth game in as many weeks that the EssexCounty eleven won by that score.

More than 1,200 delegates who attended the annual convention of the Na tional Association of Real Estate Boards here this week were return ing to their homes today prepared to put into operation a broad pro gram of activities to advance theirwork.
Merger of three subsidiary companies with the parent Public Service Elec tric and Gas Company was ap proved today by the State Boardof Public Utility Commissioners.
JUST as the Mediterranean is the lifeline of the British Em pire, so may the foreign market be considered the lifeline of Hollywood producers.

Free schooling on office time is now offered to government em ployes by thirty-five Federal agen cies, in an effort to teach them to cope with the new technical de mands of government, according to a survey just completed by Earl Brooks of the Department of Labor's Personnel Office.

RUTH SELWYN apparently is taking up theatrical produc tion in a big way. Not only is she to be co-sponsor with Milton Shubert of Ian Hay's "The Housemaster," but here the two of them come along with plans for thedestiny of "The Day Is Gone."

Charles M. Talley, father of Marion Talley, the singer, died today in a one-room apartment he shared with a friend. He was about 70 years old. Mr. Talley was a tel egrapher for the Missouri Pacific Railroad for twenty-six years. Mrs. Talley has been with her daughterin Beverly Hills, Calif.

The marriage of Miss Rita Eliza beth Fraser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Fraser of 171 West Twelfth Street and Beechhurst, Queens, to John Waterhouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Water house of Echo Point, Wheeling, W. Va., took place yesterday morn ing in the rectory of St. Joseph'sChurch, Waverly Place.

A brief sit-down strike of the en tire crew of the liner Oriente of the New York and Cuba Mail Line delayed the vessel's departure for Havana for three hours yesterday. The ship sailed at 3 P. M. after union negotiators had conferred with B. C. Edwards, general super intendent of the line, and receivedconcessions on their demands.

The Wilson College Peace Council is starting a campaign to enlist all of Wilson's 425 students in the fight against war. Under the chairmanship of Anita Poole, '38, of Philadelphia, the council, which is composed of the heads of all student groups, is planning a year-round program of lectures, rallies, and discussions built around the theme of worldpeace.

Michigan's Wolverines, who have prowled unsuccessfully through Big Ten football sectors since October, 1935, finally found a victim today when they defeated Iowa, another victory-starved team, 7 to 6, before18,000 dad's day guests.
The Georgia Bulldogs, led by a sopho more halfback, Vasa Cate, defeated Mercer University, 19-0, today be fore a homecoming-day crowd ofonly 3,000 fans.

Miss Ida Sadler of this city and Daniel O'Day, son of Mrs. Caroline O'Day, New York Representative, were married in the First Presbyterian Church here today. Gillespie Sadler gave his daughterin marriage. Mrs. Nathaniel H.

Miss Adine Antoinette Haviland, daughter of Henry Field Haviland and Mrs. Laura C. Haviland of this place, was married to Roger Garis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Garis, also of East Orange, this morning in Our Lady Help of Christians Church here.

Miss Catherine Page Underwood, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence F. Underwood, was mar ried here this afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church to Richard Benson Edwards, son of Charles H. Edwards of Greenwich and the late Mrs. Edwards, by theRev. Gerald A. Cunningham.

An advanced school for traffic training will be held at Rutgers University Nov. 1 to 13, Professor Norman C. Miller, director of the University Extension Division has announced. The two weeks' course will be open to New Jersey munici pal police officers who attained an average of 85 per cent or better in their classes while attending the two courses in traffic training held herein April and September.

The Amer ika-Deutscher Volksbund, the pro Nazi organization directed by Fritz Kuhn, is to hold its national con vention in St. Louis on Nov. 20 and 21. But within recent days pro tests have been heard in many quar ters against permitting its members to float their swastika banners andshout their "Heils" in a city which

WITH an increasing number of ships going to the east coast of South America this Winter and a record number of cruises touching both east and west coasts as well as the Strait of Magellan, tourists will find it easy to arrange trips foralmost any month.

DEFINITE strides have been made this year in improv ing the distributive end of the automotive industry. Substantial increases have been re corded in both unit and dollar vol ume by all groups. All departments of the dealer business have bene fited as a result of the improvementin general business.

The annual hound show of the Masters of Foxhounds Association of America and the National Beagle Club will be given in the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue at a Ninety-fourth Street, Friday, Jan.28, 1938.

Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Brill gave a dinner last night at their home, 1,542 Union Street, Brooklyn, at which they announced the engage ment of their only daughter, Miss Helen Claire Brill, to Dr. Harry Gordimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam Gordimer of 915 Whitlock Avenue, the Bronx.

Six persons were injured, three seri ously, when a 142-foot brick tower supporting a tank with 285,000 gal lons of water keeled over in a strong wind at 7:55 A. M. today, strewing the surrounding area with building materials and deluging theneighborhood.

Colonel Joseph H. Bigley of this city has been selected as general chairman of the Elizabeth cam paign of the Community Chest of Elizabeth, Linden, Hillside, Roselle and Roselle Park. The campaign, which usually continues for a week,will open Nov. 12.

PRINTS are used today not only for their charm of subject but to create spe cific decorative effects. Especially is this true in colonial style interiors, and, fortunately, it is not at all difficult to obtain prints contemporary with thefurnishings.

The old Munson-Beaver Building, the downtown counterpart of the Flatiron Building, which stands at the apex of the triangle formed by the junction of Pearl and Beaver Streets and which recently was ac quired in foreclosure by the Bow ery Savings Bank, soon will under go extensive alterations, at an estimated cost of $200,000 to $300.000.

Niagara's Purple Eagles ended their best home season in five years today with a victory over St. Lawrence, 19-0. Bob Freeman scored, twice and Morgan Davies once to give Niag ara her first triumph over a St. Lawrence eleven in six years. It was Niagara's fourth success infive starts.

The eyes of labor, of business and, in a sense, of the nation are focused on the committees representing the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organ ization, which are scheduled to meet in a conference here nextMonday.

Bonds called last week for re demption prior to maturity were featured by the calling of several issues of joint stock land bank bonds. Aside from these calls, the announcements, except for several issues of industrial bonds, were principally for small amounts ofmunicipal obligations.

Alfred W. Foley, 41, assistant classified man ager of The Chicago Tribune, and his wife, Frances, 32, were killed today when the car in which they were returning from a vacation crashed through the guard rail of a bridge forty miles west of this city and plunged down a thirty-footbank into Black River.

Jumping up on a bed to catch a football being passed to him, Mathew Gallop, 9 years old, of 2,195 Morris -Avenue, the Bronx, fell against a fourth floor window at that address early last night, tore out the sash and fell to therear yard. The boy was taken

Thursday night Chairman and Post master General Farley made a speech at a dinner of California Democrats. Tuesday night on the radio he will en treat the voters of this town to electthe straight Democratic ticket.

The English furniture, oriental rugs and other decorations of the home of Mrs, Arthur W. Pearce at Hlewlett Bay Park, L. I., were sold yesterday afternoon at the resi dence by the American Art Asso ciation Anderson Galleries. Thesale netted $29,060.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Stacy Lakin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Lakin of this place, to George Geoffroy Hoffman of Pleasantville, N. Y.

Mrs. Henry V. Raymond is gen eral chairman of the annual card party and tea for the benefit of the blind under the care of the Brook lyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, which will be held the afternoon of Dec. 4 at the association's headquarters, 401State Street, Brooklyn.
The School for Workers in Industry, said to be the first permanent State wide school in the United States de signed to train labor leaders, is being started this month by the University of Wisconsin.

THIS book is a description of rituals practiced long ago in certain small islands of the Hellenic Archipelago, partici pated in only by women who were at the age when they be come no longer capable of bearing children.

Katherine Bacon, who long since established herself hereabouts as a pianist of parts, was-- heard in a recital at Town Hall yesterday. As usual, Miss Bacon's interpretations displayed taste, sense of proportionand scholarly insight.
NIGHT traffic fatalities, the National Safety Council was told at its annual confer ence in Kansas City a few days ago, will account for approxi mately 67 per cent of 1937's automobile death total.

President Roosevelt was among the many persons who sent mes sages to the family of the Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, rabbi emeri tus of the Congregation Shearith Israel of New York, who diedWednesday morning.

A fly ing caravan of women, ardent ad vocates of peace, will leave Wash ington next Saturday for the start of a six-week cruise of South Amer ican republics to stimulate the movement for ratification of the treaties approved by the Inter American Conference for the Main tenance of Peace at Buenos Aireslast December.

WHEN he set out on his voyage in -1787. Lieu tenant William Bligh would have been sur prised had he imagined that his adventures would be writers' meat for over a century and that some day his exploits would becelebrated in a popular movie.

Three May ors of Chicago, Edward F. Dunne, William Hale Thompson and Wil liam E. Dever, all wrestled with the city's traction problem and all failed to solve it. Now Mayor Kelly has tackled it. After years of studyhe has produced a plan.

Sir Herbert Marler, Canadian Min ister to the United -States, and Lady Marler will be guests of honor at a dinner to be given by the .Cana dian Club on Tuesday in the organ ization's clubrooms at the WaldorfAstoria.

While coat trade officials declared coat and suit prices remained firm last week, reports in the local mar ket yesterday indicated that many coat producers in the $7.75 and $11.75 brackets have brought out lines which are $1 cheaper, thus restoring pre-season levels.

Taxes from business received by the Fed eral Government during the first three months of the current fiscal year, not including income taxes, which reflect conditions last year, were approximately $4,000,000 less than in the corresponding period of 1936, according to internal revenue figures made public today.

The immediate appointment of nonpartisan special assistant at torneys general to investigate fraudulent registrations and to prevent illegal voting was re quested yesterday of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. by Monroe Percy Bloch, counsel ofthe Honest Ballot Association.

On a field covered with a blanket of snow, Notre Dame turned back a powerful Navy team, 9:to 7, today, achieving a dramatic victory in the last few minutes of the game to thrill 45,000 spectators, who sat shivering through a steady fall ofheavy, wet snow.
AGAIN the smoking, clanging car fac tories-those mills of magic!-pre pare to unveil new wonders and en chantments at the National Auto mobile Show. For all the sit-downs, theyhave not been idle.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.-The severe cold snap of the past several days has ended the Fall foliage in the Poconos, which this year drew the largest crowd of Fall visi tors in the history of this mountainresort area.

Prevailing over Lehigh for the past eleven years, Gettysburg continued its reign of gridiron supremacy in Taylor Stadium today when the battlefield collegians crushed the Engineers of Lehigh, 19 to 6, before a crowd of 8,000 spectators. It was a well-earned victory in which Paul Fulmer tall backfield replacement, ran wild and was the dominant factor in the Engineers'defeat.

Automobile dealers here announced through Jackiel W. Joseph, an at torney, tonight, that they were clos ing service departments "indefinite ly" because of labor troubles. Mechanics of ten automobile firms responded to a strike call of the Automobile Workers Union earlythis week. Joseph alleged they had

The thirty-third annual conven tion of the National Association of Audubon Societies will be climaxed with a dinner on Tuesday in the Colonnades Room of Essex House. The association will be in session tomorrow and Tuesday at the American Museum of Natural History.

Miss Carol Wilmot Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilmot M. Smith of Waibridge Road, West Hartford, and Raymond Stanton Patton Jr., son of Admiral and Mrs. Raymond S. Patton of Washington, D. C., were married this evening in Trin ity College Chapel by the president of the college, the Rev. Dr. RemsenB. Ogilby.
Campaigning for and against the proposed new county charter was in full blast throughout Westchester County this week.
St. Louis University scored a surprise 7-to-2 victory over Catholic University of Washington, D. C., in an intersectional Catholic football battle today.

The hitherto uneventful Governor ship campaign in New Jersey, in which United States Senator A. Harry Moore and State Senator Lester H. Clee, Democratic and Re publican candidates, respectively, are the chief contestants, promised a major political sensation today when Common Pleas Court Judge James R. Erwin issued warrants for the arrest of 144 Democraticand Republican election officers.
IN its 1938 line Chrysler has achieved the combination of cars that are soundly engineered and excellently manufactured. This ac cord between the two departmentsis essential to complete success.
HE was not much taller than Ernest Truex, and he wasn't particularly handsome. Yet he was the matinee idol of his day and women swooned at hisattentions.

Troops were called out tonight to quell serious anti-government rioting in which sixty persons were wounded as a special session of Parliament gave Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha's government a vote of confidence.

Federal in vestigators widened their efforts to day to trace the kidnappers of Charles S. Ross, retired greeting card manufacturer, through the numbers of the bills that were paid for his ransom. Filling station at tendants and tavern keepers have been asked to watch for the bills. So far as could be learned, only one bill, of $10 denomination, hasbeen identified.

After a lapse of about six weeks Japan has resumed heavy exports of gold to this country, it became known yesterday. A shipment of $6,571,100 of the metal has been re ceived in San Francisco, the daily gold statement of the Federal Re serve Bank of New York showed, and a second shipment of $6,600,000 was engaged yesterday in Japan for transfer here, according to reportsreceived by the Reserve Bank.

The Citizens Nonpartisan Com mittee, of which Samuel Seabury is chairman, is urging the election of a list of candidates for the new City Council along with the re-elec tion of Mayor La Guardia as vital to the cause of good government inNew York City.

Playing under wraps, a powerful Rowdoin team opened its quest for its third straight State title with a 10-0 triumph over Colby today. The same was remarkably well played despite a heavy rain. Karsokas and Joule led the scoring with two buchdowns apiece, and Frazier Bullied the other.

Now that early frosts have killed the top growth -of dahlias, cannas, gladioli and other Summer flower ing bulbs, careful gardeners are los ing no time in getting the roots out of the ground and into safe keeping.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Oct. 23.--The resignation of President Federico Paez, presented to Congress last night, was announced in an extra edition of the newspaper Telegrafo today.
Leo E. Kelly, publisher of The Island News, Suffolk County supplement of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, who suffered a heart attack Wednesday, died tonight at his home here atthe age of 39.

Because modern methods have so increased the supply of St. Law rence County turkeys, farmers this year fear low prices. Substitution of the incubator for nest hatching has increased flocks to the extent that "small flocks no longer prevail," one large raisersaid.

Trailing by one point at the half, Virginia Tech swept on to beat Washington and Lee, 19 to 7, be fore 5,000 in the thirty-sixth meet ing of the rivals in Miles Stadium. Tech scored in the first, third and fourth periods and Washington andLee in the second.

A delega tion of Chicago Italians in formal attire awaited the arrival of Dr. Fulvio de Suvich, Italian Ambassa dor, at a railroad station today. They gathered around a car. A short man stepped out. "I am happy to be. in Chicago," hebeamed.

England has found a clever, sharp-shooting set of for wards that may carry the Rose to victory in the international soccer tournament this season. Before 40,000 spectators today England's representatives scored a decisive A5-1 victory over Ireland in the firstmatch of the tourney.
Franklin and Marshall defeated Pensylvania Military College in a hard-fought game today, 12-0, before a crowd of 4,000.

That Africans make good film actors, my late husband Martin and I have always been sure-almost everything they do is dramatic. But on this expedition the chief problem is to keep them from tak ing their stage roles too seriously, especially in the battle scenes, where we have to restrain themfrom wiping each other out.

Tavern sages and cracker-bar rel philosophers steamed the rain misted windows of the local bar and general store her today, discussing the feats of Laverne (John Monta gue) Moore and his chances of beat ing the seven-year-old first degree robbery indictment on which he isbeing tried.

Miss Rebecca Willis Graves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ernest Graves of this city, was married to Reginald Geary Conley, son of Major Gen. and Mrs. Edgar Thomas Conley, tonight at Rosedale, the country home of the bride's par ents, by the Rev. Dr. P. Manning Hank of Richmond, formerly pas tor of Centenary Methodist Churchhere.

Unless Japanese effective at Shang hai, at present estimated to number 150,000, are increased by at least two divisions, it seems unlikely that the Japanese Army will attemptany really extensive push westward.

Dedicated to a belief that "Christianity must gird itself for a real struggle," the New York State Council of Churches marshaled its forces to day for four days of religious activ ity in Albany, Troy and Schenectady.
Don't you think you might give some space in your section of the paper over to the discouraging of further importations? I refer in particular to the fairly recent influx of British actors.
After its two day recovery, the Boerse had an other setback today, following the deadlocked negotiations of the Lon don Non-Intervention sub-commit tee. Quotations dropped throughoutthe list.

New York League of Girls' Clubs Party and dance, auspices Theta Iota Club, 7 P. M., League House. Theta Upsilon (New York Alumnae)--Tea, auspices member groups of City Panhellenic, Hotel Beekman Tower.

Twelve more death sentences were reported today in the Soviet rural regions. Seven persons convicted of "un dermining" collective farms in the Volga Republic and five convicted as "destroyers" of cattle and grain at Sverdlovsk, in the Urals, received the supreme penalty.

Many improvements were made on Broadway during the past year or are now under way. Several new buildings have been erected or are under construction and many old structures have been renovated and remodeled or are at present in various stages of repair. The cost of these improvements is estimatedat approximately $11,000,000.
The Haverford College eleven was de feated today by Johns Hopkins, 13-12. Kerstetter of the Doctors made the outstanding play of the game when he returned a kick-off94 yards to score.

THE ingenuity of the white fish erman pales before that of the natives who fish in the tropic seas to the north of Australia. Be tween these shores and Papua and New Guinea there are monster sharks, huge swordfish, sailfish,sawfish and mackerel.
The fifth annual bridge party for the benefit of the Hudson Avenue Boys Club will be held the after noon of Nov. 19 at the Hotel Towers, Brooklyn.
Forty University of Michigan fraternities pledged 494 men during the rushing period which ended last week. This was 81 below the 1936mark.

That Americans may see the out standing developments in the cur rent design and manufacture of rugs and carpets, both in this coun try and Europe, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has gathered a col lection of these objects from the studios of designers and from manufacturers in thirteen coun tries, to be placed on public exhibition on Tuesday.

Recent moves by Alfred M. Landon, former President Herbert Hoover and other Republican leaders to "re juvenate" the Republican party and to work out a "constructive" program were ridiculed by Post master General Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, at a dinner here tonight.

Conflicting estimates of the num ber of workers laid off by the Con solidated Edison Company and its affiliates in recent weeks were given yesterday by the company and the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, a C. I. 0. affiliate.

Maurice Arnold Strothotte, a composer known professionally as Maurice Arnold, died yesterday in the House of Calvary Hospital, the Bronx, at the age of 72. His widow, a pianist, plays under the name of Johanna Clark.
The junior class of the University of Pennsylvania, following traditions of 106 years, will 'celebrate Junior Week beginning Wednesday andending Saturday.

ROME.-Following the very satis factory outcome of the tests that Italian airplanes have undergone in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict and, more recently, in the Spanish civil war, new impetus is being given to the carrying out of a vast airprogram to be completed by 1941.

ORGANIZED early this year by the united automotive indus try, the Automotive Safe ty Foundation is carrying, out the program which forms the basil of the industry's contribution toward highway safety.

Teaching civics and city govern ment on the flat-topped deck of a municipal-owned ferryboat, con ducted experimentally this Fall by the New York City school system, has added to the education of 20,000 boys and girls from forty high schools who were taken on water front trips, Winifred L. Rice, act ing director of civics, declared yesterday.
EARLY in 1937 the American Automobile Association pre dicted that motor vacation travel in the current year would be far and away the highest on record. A midseason check-up,recently completed,
Argentina's discriminatory 20 per cent surcharge against imports from the United States was criticized by William R. Fraser,
Trustees of the Brown Company, largest pulp and paper producer in New England, filed today in Fed eral Court an engineering reportdisclosing that its Canadian and

Mrs. Nina S. Ballard, wife of Ellis Ames Ballard, consulting counsel for the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Com pany, died today at her home, Four Way Farm, Roxborough, after a long illness. Her age was 73. Mr and Mrs. Ballard observed their fifty-third wedding anniversary yesterday.

Saying that the Democratic mem bers of the Board of Estimate, by restoring useless jobs, had thrown the Mayor's budget out of balance, Joseph D. McGoldrick, Fusion can didate for Controller, challenged last night Controller Frank J. Tay lor, his Democratic opponent, to tell how, if elected, he intended to re store the balance. Mr. McGoldrick spoke at an American Labor party rally at Eastern District High School, Marcy Avenue and KeapStreet, Brooklyn.

Declaring that the election, so far as he is concerned, already was won, Mayor La Guardia at an American Labor party rally last night in the Eastern District High School, Brooklyn, urged the elec tion of a Fusion Board of Estimate. An audience of about 2,000 receivedthe Mayor with enthusiasm.

The four most prominent candi dates in the coming city election will appear together at a luncheon under the auspices of the League for Political Education at the Hotel Astor next Saturday, it was announced yesterday.

Two events were completed in the field trials sponsored by the New Jersey Beagle Club near here today. As darkness fell the judges were dead locked in the State championship and this stake will be re-run tomorrow.

THIS Winter the deb will shine resplendent, set in gold and silver and studded with handsome but not neces sarily costly jewels. Every advan tage that the cunning of dress maker and milliner has devised isto be put at her disposal.

Mrs. Louis Clarendon Thurston of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Thurston, to Gerardus Hilles Wynkoop 2d, son of Mrs. Daniel Woodbury Wynkoop of Merrick, L. I., and the late Mr. Wynkoop.

Miss Dorothy Helene Madsen, daughter of Mrs. Ingfred The ophilus Madsen of 1,046 Hillside Avenue and the late Mr. Madsen, was married today to Alfred Gaw throp Genung, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Mitchell Genung of thiscity.

Asserting that the recent d?? in the stock market was an "eco nomic event of the first magni tude," John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Commit tee, declared today that the Amer ican public is "jittery" about Presi dent Roosevelt, and not, as he said the President has implied, "jittery"about Europe.

Threatened in 1935 with the -loss of his citizenship, Karol Cassel, a diamond merchant, entered this typewritten plea in Federal court: "Jantelman of the United States District Court, give me a chance tobe a good sitisin.
For the first time in the United States a kind of white list of en gineering schools has been drawn up by a representative body of engineers.

THE Third Attack Group of the General Headquarters Force is planning new tactics at Barksdale Field here to test new attack planes recently de livered. The new planes are pow ered by two engines and carrypowerful armament at great speed.

HAVING re-recorded two of Tchaikovsky's symphonies, Victor turns to the violin concerto-in D, Op. 35-and we have an addition to the sterling series by Heifetz and the London Symphony under- John Barbirolli(Album M-356).

The recent course of the security markets has opened a path for the consideration of real estate as a possible field for investment or speculation for those who have heretofore disregarded the possibili ties in realty buying, points out William Zeckendorf of the Leonard S. Gans, Zeckendorf, Morris Company.

Under pressure of the new Mnimum Wage Law for Women the New York State Department of Labor announced yesterday that it is, as nearly as that feat is pos sible, preparing "to stick a price tag on the 'life, liberty and pursuit of happiness' which is a birthrightof every American girl."

While the world marches slowly toward a great international bat tlefield the work of fighting for peace goes forward in a clerk filled, humming skyscraper office on Forty-first Street and Park Ave nue, New York City, and in a du plex apartment school for children from 2 to 12 years old on Ninetieth Street and West End Avenue.

H. G. Wells's new novel "Bryn hilde," a return in some measure to his early comedy manner, heads the list of best-selling novels in London. Immensely popular, too, is A. J. Cronin's novel about doc tors, "The Citadel," which is to be filmed by Victor Saville for M.-G. M. with, it is said, either Robert Donat or Clark Gable in the chiefrole.
Checking a last period attack, the Baldwin High eleven remained un defeated in four starts by halting Valley Stream, 13-9, in a thrilling encounter at Firemen's Field today.

Bob Bloom, high-scoring Hiram quar terback, made two touchdowns to day to lead the Hilltoppers to a 19-to-12 victory over Thiel College of Pennsylvania. Thiel led at half time, 12 to 6, producing a touchdown in each of the first two periods with Lewisand D. Breckenridge crossing.
IN his last two books of poetry Wallace Stevens has been pre occupied with the relationship between the world of the imagi nation and the real world. "Owl'sClover," reprinted in this

Joseph E. Widener suggested today that horse racing "affords a painless method of collecting taxes." "People are willing to pay if they get something back," said the Philadelphia capitalist, who is president of the Miami JockeyClub.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor left Munich tonight for Paris with their two-week tour of German in dustries and social institutions completed.

A panoramic view of contempo rary Jewish life and a survey of Jewish history for the last twenty five years will be among the major features of the convention of Hadas sah, the women's Zionist organiza tion, opening Wednesday in Atlantic City.

The Lenox Club is to be kept open all Winter as a result of requests made by members who are to pass most of the Winter here, or thosewho will be frequent visitors.

The Long Island Women's Field Hockey Association, through its secretary, Miss Arline Magaw, has announced an interesting schedule for the season. The Long Island women started the campaign suc cessfully by winning from Manhat tanville College in a hard-foughtgame last Sunday.

A funeral service for Arthur Wil son Milburn, president of the Bor den Company, was held yesterday afternoon at Christ Methodist Epis copal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. Mr. Milburn died at Baden-Baden, Germany, on Oct.11, at the age of 63.
Sir Samuel Hoare, Home Secretary, is work ing out a plan of scientific inves tigation of increasing juvenilecrime.

Once again the "Dark Continent"--land of rival imperial aims in days gone by-is of primary importance to European diplomacy. The significance of the North African (and Near Eastern) colo nies, mandates and "spheres of in fluence" in the strategic scheme of Europe has been eloquently em phasized in the past fortnight as British and French naval forcespatrolled near the Balearic Islands,

With wide attention centered upon them, the candidates for elec tion as Representative in the Sev enteenth Congressional District in Manhattan wound up a week's campaigning yesterday and pre pared for a final drive in the coming week.

Vigorous opposition to govern ment-controlled health insurance, through the Social Security Act, was expressed yesterday by Willard J. Parker, a director and former president of the Trade ExecutivesAssociation of New York.

Chief U. S. Bureau of Public Roads HIGHWAY construction sup ported by Federal funds is near the end of a period of transition from large ex penditures of emergency funds to more normal operations with regular Federal aid.

HAVE often been asked, and I know that many automobile purchasers have often wondered without asking, just where the independent manufacturer can hope to go in a field that is so well rep resented by big volume manufac turers. Graham's new car for 1988is a visual answer to this question.

Young Democrats of seven States met here today, heard the praises of the party sung by many speakers and discussed informally campaign plans for 1938. Secretary of War Woodring as serted that the Republican party "can have no appeal for youth. Itseves are fastened on the past.

The former Miss Mary Read of Manchester, England, and Dr. Don ald L. Clark, Professor of English at Columbia University, who were married in a civil ceremony on June 12 in a register's office in London, had a religious service yes terday morning in the rectory ofSt. Malachy's Church here.

Consistent punting and a hard-charg ing line brought Hobart College a 13-to-7 victory over C. C. N. Y. in a downpour today. The slimy ball turned the game into a punter's duel with the Hobart eleven pounc ing upon City College's fumbles and converting therm to Hobarttouchdowns.
Easing further, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business ac tivity for the week ended Oct. 16 stands at 100.2, which compares with 101.3 in the preceding week and 102.3 a year ago.
