The Missouri anti-aircraft guns jammed for a few fleeting seconds today and the raiding Nebraskans bombed their way to a 7-to-0 vic tory over the team early rated as the biggest hurdle in their path toanother Big Six championship.

Excessive blowing of train whistles and clang ing of bells were charged by 150 residents of near-by Watervliet in a complaint filed with the Public Service Commission against the Delaware Hudson RailroadCompany. J. A. O'Connor,

Captain Michael Kearney, a hero of the war with Spain, who retired in 1926 as an officer of the United States Marine Corps in which he had served for thirty years, died Thursday night in St. John's Hos pital, Brooklyn, following an oper ation. His age was 63. Captain Kearney, who lived in the Hotel Pierrepont, Brooklyn, was ill forfive days.

IN dealing with the present and future problems of traffic ac cidents and traffic congestion in our great cities, it is no longer profitable to deal solely with superficial aspects of the situation nor with superficial relief measures.

In its three-year drive to put agriculture on a new basis the Mexican Gov ernment has created 5,985 com munal farms on 25,000,000 acres of former landed estates for the bene fit of 569,000 former peons, thePress Department revealed today.

Expanded to include several new features, while retaining all the de partments previously included, the November number of the new D. A. R. magazine, the first to be issued by its recently appointed editor, Frances Parkinson Keyes, wife of former Senator Henry Wilder Keyes of New Hampshire, will appear tomorrow, in a brave new dress and enriched with manystriking and attractive illustrations.
Charles C. Nichols, former Mayor, selectman, solicitor and school com mitteeman here and one time State Representative, died yesterday atthe Whidden Memorial Hospital.

Rep resenting the San Francisco Cham ber of Commerce, the Allyear Clubs of Southern California and the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce, of which he is an executive member, Stanley T. Olafson is on his way to Washington to present before the Maritime Commission Califor nia's protest against the proposed removal of Panama Pacific's lux ury liners to the New York-BuenosAires route.

To ban or not to ban sororities is the question facing women students of the University of Rochester. In the last few years there has been definite dissatisfaction on the campus with the sorority system, but things have come to a sudden head with the "postponement" of rushing by one sorority, Sigma Kappa Upsilon, pending a decision by the administration as to whetherthe sororities shall continue.
FRANCE is paying off her war debt these days-in the most acceptable of currency-the latest remittances being Danielle. Darrieux to Universal Pic tures and Annabella to TwentiethCentury-Fox.

IN the opinion of impartial and critical observers within the in dustry itself, and certainly by all standards of outward comparison, the automobile industry as a whole offers the greatest values in its his tory in the new 1938 motor cars to be displayed at the AutomobileShow.

Herbert Charles Ballord. Baltimore man ager of the Crucible Steel Company of America, died yesterday at the age of 58. Born in Ashford, Eng land, Mr. Ballord came to this country as a child and settled with his parents at Syracuse, N. Y. He had been connected with the Crucihle Steel Company for thirty years.

Debutantes from Boston, Phila delphia, Baltimore and the metro politan area attended the fifty first annual Autumn Tuxedo ball tonight in the Tuxedo Club. It was the largest attendance of debu tantes in the history of the ball, which always opens the debutanteseason in New York and vicinity.
Ohio Wesleyan spotted Rollins College two touchdowns in the first five minutes, then rolled up a 26 to-13 victory over the Florida team today. It was the Bishops' firstvictory.
An 18-year-old Radcliffe soph omore asserted today that a gun man beat her senseless last night after forcing her to give him a ride because "the police are chasingme."

Fifteen fraternities at Columbia College have pledged 157 students since the annual "rushing" period started two weeks ago, Dean Her bert E. Hawkes, chairman of the Pamphratria Council, announcedyesterday.
Plans for the speedy removal of snow this Winter have been mapped out by the Department of Sanita tion, Deputy Commissioner William J. Powell declared yesterday.

Senator Logan, a member of the Senate subcommittee investigating methods of judicial reform, pro posed today that infirm and in competent judges be removed by a special court acting under the "good behavior" clause of the Constitution.

THE Imperial Japanese Army has turned to propaganda--"spiitual mobilization"--to strengthen those deep traditional ties which in Japan have united the army and people. Great army planes, each wing enjeweled with the Rising Sun, swoop over congested cities, scattering like colored confetti leaflets exalting the army.

FOR the last twelve years John Howard Lawson's "Proces sional" has been one of the theatre's fond traditions. For the last eleven days it has been a clangorous reality at Maxine Elliott's, where the Federal Theatrehas energetically revived it.

FIVE composers have been invited by the Columbia Broadcasting System "to write in whatever form they please" music which they believe is specially adapted to broadcasting. The "commission" comprises Quincy Porter, Robert Russell Bennett, Leo Sowerby, Jerome Moross and R. Nathaniel Dets.
Shadows of the stock market's gy rations are falling across the pic ture of the coming special session of Congress as drawn by PresidentRoosevelt in his fireside chat.

THE orchestra class of the New York College of Music begins rehearsals this Satur day at 3 P. M., under Carl Hein. Auditions for those in the school and for outsiders are heldat 4 P. M. daily at the school.

SECOND novelty in Bergamo's experimental opera season at the Teatro Donizetti was the three-act lyric tragedy of the two Venetians Mario Ghisalberti and Mario Jacchia, entitled "Stella d'Oriente," a prize-winner of theBaruzzi contest at Bologna.

Miss Mary Sampson Flanders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Chapin Flanders of this city and Cooperstown, N. Y., was married yesterday at noon in the chantry of Grace Church to Oscar Edward Boline, son of Mr. and Mrs. EdwardN. Boline of Lindsborg, Kan.
HUGE tanks atop a sixty-five foot tower opened their gates a few weeks ago and unloosed 130,000 gallons of water in the deluge that provides the climax of Samuel Goldwyn'sman-made hurricane.

Avinoam Yellin, senior inspector of Jewish schools in the Government Educa tion Department, died tonight of wounds received when he was shot by an Arab Thursday. Mr. Yellin, 37 years old and amember of an old Jerusalem

Tradition may have got a jolt last week when the capitulation of the Bar Association of New York, "at long last," admitted women mem bers into its sanctum, but professional standards suffered not at all.

The po litical doctors have been very busy recently diagnosing X the disease from which the Republican party is suffering, but at this writing they are still in disagreement as to the precise nature of the ailment, andhence as to the treatment indicated.

As a result of the shortage of teachers existing in the industrial and vocational high schools of this city. another examination covering more than fifty trade subjects will be held next Spring; Dr. Louis Marks, chairman of the Board of Examiners committee on industriallicenses, disclosed yesterday.

The Works Progress Administration in formed Senator Moore today that President Roosevelt had designated eleven New Jersey projects as eli gible for allotment of a total of $82, 342. The projects are subject to review by the Controller General.
Every local Chamber of Commerce, Ro tary or Kiwanis Club, civic and service organization in this part of the State has been asked to join thenew South Jersey Association, Inc.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today warned several hundred women students at Cornell University that they could not succeed in life by merely trying to "get by." Arriving here from Washington this morning with Mrs. Henry F. Morgenthau Jr., Mrs. Roosevelt, in a vocational talk sponsored by thestudent Council. remarked:
There has been no change in the healthy conditions underlying business an nounced by the Department of Commerce on Oct. 6, Secretary Roper declared today in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
THIRTY-FIVE years ago mo toring was far from being pleasurable. Cars were ex pensive-only persons whose incomes were in the upper bracketscould afford them; roads were

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Holmes of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Holmes, to Dr. Lloyd Seaman Saltus, son of Mrs. Lloyd Saltus of Morristown,N. J.

A reorganization of the student gov ernment at the Pennsylvania State College, to be accomplished by ex panding the Student Council so that its members will come from all undergraduate schools at the col lege, is being considered and will be presented for formal action of thecouncil at its next meeting.
Members of the Brooklyn Junior League are arranging for the ac tivities of the Winter, among which will be the Boston Symphony con certs, for which the organizationtakes over several rows of seats.

Competition among apparel firms to sell the chains and other so-called "big users" is decreasing in in tensity due to a realization on the part of many firms that it has been difficult to derive a profit from sales to those organizations, Mor ris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers,Inc., declared yesterday.

Premier Koloman Daranyi and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria conferred today at a hunt ing party in Western Hungary. No communique was issued, but it is understood that they discussed general European problems with particular reference to the AustroGerman relations.

The public prosecutor has asked sentences of fifteen months' imprisonment or fines of 20,000 pesos each against eighteen motion picture distributors, including the local American representatives of leading Hollywood producers, on the ground that they have violatedthe Anti-Trust Law.

Giving almost their whole atten tion to a discussion of the Ameri can composer, and to appreciation of some of his works, members of the New York State Federation of Music Clubs will convene on Fri day at the Great Northern Hotel, under direction of their president,Mrs. John McClure Chase.

The reactions of prominent figures in education to the time-worn ques tion, "What makes for the ideal college career?" have been pre sented in the columns of The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate news paper, over the past fortnight forthe benefit of the class of 1941.

Through a number of programs scheduled throughout the boroughs, women's clubs are preparing to give their members last-minute instruc tion during the coming week in issues of the campaign, and in the method of voting under the newcharter.

A performance of Ed Wynn's new show, "Hooray for What!" will be taken over as a benefit for the Music School Settlement at 55 East Third Street. The show is sched uled for an opening date next month and as yet no date has beenset for the benefit performance.
The leading industry of this valley is the manufacture of golf tees. More than 50,000,000 tees are shipped out, the business giving employment to an average of thirtypersons through the year.

JUDGING from the record breaking consumption of pe troleum products and the pay ments of the biggest motor tax bill in history, the automotive peregrinations of the American peo ple in 1937 constituted the greatest unorganized mass movement theworld ever has known.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, presi dent of City College, announced yes terday the names of 206 graduates who completed their work at City College during the 1937 Summer session and to whom degrees andcertificates were awarded this week.

Charles A. Jones, general manager of the Home Owners' Loan Corpo ration, issued a statement today saying that the board of directors of the corporation "is unanimous in its conviction that no reduction from the present interest rate is justifiable" on loans of the corporation.

TOURISTS are inveterate collec tors. Boston's champion tour ist, Captain Joseph P. Hanton of the Fire Department, collects scenic postcards. In the last twenty five years he has visited 1,357 cities, towns and villages in the United States and Canada (a visit mean ing a stop for a night and two meals, at least) and for each of these he has twelve postal cards,or a total of 16,284 views.

TELEVISION from Pet's Corner at the London Zoo have been voted "a great success" by British observers. A television the atre has been installed at Selfridge store so the public may view thetelecasts from Alexandra Palace.

BOSTON, Oct. 23.--Johnny Andrews made a 75-yard return of a punt to give Western Reserve of Cleveland a thrilling 7-to-0 victory over Boston University at Fenway Park in a driving rainstorm before6,500 spectators today.

Turning loose reserve power, the Middlebury Panthers overwhelmed a fighting Norwich team by 32-6. Scoring in every period the victors forced the Cadets to take to the air to score from the 38-yard line,Hatfield to Stone.
The former six-story tenement at 76 Suffolk Street has been com pletely renovated into a modern apartment house by its owners, the 76 Suffolk Corporation. CharlesB. Meyers was the architect.

Rangy Jack Pingel, fleet footed halfback, ended Michigan State's touchdown famine here to day as the Spartans put on a late rally to conquer Marquette, 21 to 7. Pingel scored all three State touchdowns, the last one on a sensational 80-yard sprint.

The Conversity of Pittsburgh announced tonight a revised athletic policy which Athletic Director James Hagan said "is designed to bring football to a proper plane in rela tion to other college educationalactivities."

I do not agree that In the matter of radio we are getting only "crumbs." What we are actually getting is a succession of indigesti ble meals of quantity and not qual ity. Several factors have gone into the making of the present situation, such as too many broadcasts, too lengthy programs, the banal andoften silly comments of announcers.

Japan is fighting two distinct, as yet nearly unrelated, wars in China, and with different objectives. In the north the military operations are a classic ex ample of rapid movement and pitched battles to destroy or disorganize the enemy armies and clear the way forthe occupation of conquered territory.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 24.--Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons's coalition government re tained its majority in the House of Representatives today on the basis of the first day's tabulation of Aus tralia's election for the Federal Parliament.

Strong protests against President Roosevelt's administrative order, discontinuing PWA allotments, were voted here today by the board of governors of the Associ ated General Contractors of Amer ica, closing its meeting in the HotelAmbassador.

A FAR Western journey through crowds which tossed their caps as high for him as in 1936; a sonorous and ex citing attack at Chicago on the treaty-defying policies of Japan, Germany and Italy: a "fireside" radio chat designed to nudge Congress, in special session,along the path of the Second New Deal:

A delegation of forty members of the International Longshoremen's Association, claiming to represent ten New York locals, called upon Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yes terday afternoon and told him that the rank and file of the union's membership was solidly for his reelection.

Constituting one of the largest theatre benefits of the season, the performances of "Angel-Island" at the National Theatre on Tuesday and Wednesday nights have been taken over as a means to raise funds for the work of the auxiliary to the Tuberculosis Division and the Convalescent. Relief Committee of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service.

Tax delin quency of New Jersey farm and rural lands is decreasing, accord ing to a recent survey of the State Planning Board. Almost 900,000 acres of farm and rural lands were tax delinquent for from one to six or more years asof Jan. 1, 1936, the board reported.
Not a single rent delinquency has marked the two years' operation of First Houses, New York City's initial venture in rehousing.
Police of sixteen municipalities and agents of county departments of Passaic County will soon have at their dis posal a modern laboratory for the scientific detection and solution ofcrime.

In protest against the 30-year age limit imposed on affiliates in the junior department, the Ridgewood Junior Woman's Club has sent in its resignation to the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, Mrs. Ward C. Denison, president,said yesterday.

IT is particularly at the automo bile show that one may observe how important a factor the American woman has become in the choice of the new family car. It is the woman of the family who gives Automobile engineering credit for having solved purely mechanical problems so thoroughly that they no longer call for critical consideration on her part.

The navy's new submarine Skipjack was launched today at the Groton shipyard of the Electric Boat Company. Crowds stood in a pour ing rain as the sponsor, Miss Fran ces Cuthbert Van Keuren, cracked a bottle of champagne on the bowof the 298-foot fighting vessel.
Drake's highly geared eleven con quered Iowa State, ancient Big Six rival, by a score of 30 to 0 in a homecoming football game today.

COMING unheralded from Brazil is an attractive 300 reis light blue stamp, in scribed "Bi-Centenario da Fundgao do Rio Grande do Sul," which-commemorates the founding of the city of Rio Grande do Sultwo centuries ago.
A meeting of the Board of Edu cation will be held Wednesday at 4 P. M. at 500 Park Avenue. Elec tion of an associate superintendent is scheduled to take place.

Drought has not withered the Corn Belt this year and as a result a bumper crop of 2,560,000,000 bushels--1,000, 000,000 bushels more than last year has been harvested. Abundance has also marked the Wheat Belt and theCotton Belt.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 23.--Mayor S. Davis Wilson in an at tack today on the Committee of Seventy declared that this election reform organization was a "hypo critical" body "cooperating withthe Republican high command."

THIS is to all intents and pur poses David Lichine Week at the Metropolitan Opera House, for three new ballets for which he has composed the choreography are to be revealedthere by the De Basil Ballet Russe.
Formation of a Fusion Lawyers Committee to support, Mayor La Guarida and his running mates was announced yesterday by William M. Chadbourne, chairman of the Fusion Campaign Committee.

An adventure which started on July 14 with the escape of four .prisoners from Devil's Island was brought to an abrupt end for two of the men today when immigration authori ties, on instructions from Wash ington, held Giovanni Battestoti andPaul Renuccl for deportation.

It's only natural the yachtsmen should get martial in this day and age of wars in China and Spain. A year ago some of the United States Power Squadron skippers teamed up with the Marine Corps reservists for battle manoeuvres in Octoberat Point Lookout, Long Beach,
The principal feature of the social activities attendant on the National Horse Show will be the annual horse show ball on the night of Nov. 6 in the grand ballroom ofthe Waldorf-Astoria.
A pair of aerial thrusts late in the second quarter gave the University of Arkansas Razorbacks a 13-to-0 victory over the Southern MethodistMustangs before 9,500 fans today.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Oct. 24.--The battle north of Shanghai con tinued for the fourth day today with a Japanese announcement that the Chinese forces were retreating along the entire front and with a counter-assertion by the Chinese that they not only were holdingtheir own but were advancing.

A group of men distinguished in pub lic life will serve as honorary pall bearers at a funeral service Mon day for George Horace Lorimer, retired editor of The Saturday Eve ning Post, who died of pneumonia last night at Belgraeme, his homein Wyncote.

The first dinner dance in a series known as the Post Deb Cotillions will be held on Nov. 5 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. The dances are strictly invitational and restricted to post-debutantes, youngmarried couples and young men.

Dayton made good a last-second "des peration" pass to beat Ohio Uni versity, 6 to 0, today and retain its lead in the Buckeye Confer ence football race. A substitute halfback, Padley, took a 26-yard toss from Riegel on the 5-yard line and crossed the goal just as the final gunsounded, administering to the

The fiftieth wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Willan of Orange, which falls on Monday, was celebrated tonight with a reception for a company of 100 at the home of their son and daughter-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. Edward H. Willan, withwhom they live.
For the best reasons Russian attention is concentrated in the northern area of the Sino-Japanese conflict.
Tailored leathers for sportswear are various and smart, and Alix has an all-suede tailored dress in bright green, with wrap-over skirt and bodice yokegathered into fitted neckband.
North Carolina struck twice in the second quarter today, displaying beautiful deception and power, and defeated Tulane University, 13 to 0, for the Green Wave's first defeatof the season.

If the proposed trade pact with Czechoslovakia is to be satisfactory to American exporters it must con tain substantial concessions, it be came clear yesterday when sum mary of the brief filed with the Committee for Reciprocity Infor mation by the National Foreign Trade Association, Inc., was madeavailable.

Ronald A. Westgate of Glen Ridge has been named editor-in-chief of The Peddle News, student publica tion of the Peddle School here, it was announced today. Associate editors are Robert A. Lincoln, C. Merrill Austin, Edmund W. Wollmuth Jr. and Thomas H. Gosnell.

THE Maguires and the For sythes and the plain John Smiths have been doing a lot of traveling this year and a large share of them have gone by bus. Estimates are that close to half a billion people will have pat ronized intercity buses this year by the end of December, and that's a lot of people and an all-time recordfor any one year.

Contentions that the SEC's 55 per cent margin rule has aggravated the decline in security values are begin ning to be heard in Wall Street. This apparently paradoxical statement is based on the assertion that the high margins imparted a false sense of security and that margin calls, instead of being spread over an extended period, piled one on topof another.

Farouk, Egypt's 17-year-old King, has set Jan. 6 as the date of his marriage. He previously had planned to be married early in December, but it was changed because of the in tended festivities throughout thecountry.

The first fighting of the Spanish civil war-back in July and August of 1936--split Loyalist territory in two. One part lay to the north along the Bay of Biscay; the other lay to the south and east with access to the Mediterranean. Between the two, from the Pyrenees to Gibraltar, stretched a thick barrier ofInsurgent soil.
FROM the horse and- carriage days to the present high compression era, a thing to do in San Francisco has been to drive to Fishermen's Wharf for a cocktail of the sea-food variety-right off the boat.

Former President Herbert Hoover stressed again tonight his advocacy of a mid-season Republican conven tion as a means of formulating a definite policy on which to base the parts fight against the Roosevelt Administration.

HUNTER'S weather, the cool dryness of the atmosphere that provides clearest visi bility, is now just starting in North Carolina, preceding quail and duck sportsmen over the numerous inland fields and seacoast marshes.

Unbounded enthusiasm and a bi cycle today carried Ward B. Zim mer, 20, of Chicago, a Dartmouth College junior, 150 miles from Hanover, N. H., to Harvard Sta dium to see, as he put it, "Dartmouth beat Harvard."

While construction activity has lagged in this country, some Ameri can firms have found considerable work to do abroad. One of these is Hegeman-Harris of New York, builders, who have just completed two outstandingstructures in London.

FOR the first time a book has been published com posed entirely of self-por traits of artists. It is ex tremely interesting. Many of these canvases are in inaccessible col lections, and thus have rarely ornever been reproduced before, so

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe denied yesterday the motion of Wil liam Rosenblatt, a creditor and member of the protective commit tee for holders of Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation 5 per cent bonds and debentures, for an order directing certain officers of Postal to submit to an examination regarding the "acts, conduct andproperty" of the corporation.

The funeral services for Arthur W. Lawrence of Bronxville and Mount Kisco, president of the Westchester County Park Commission, treasurer of the Westchester Republican County Committee and a leading real estate developer in Westchester, were conducted at 11 A. M. today in the Reformed Church on Pondfield Road. Mr. Lawrence, who was 62 years old, died in Northern Westchester Hospital at Mount Kisco Thursday after a long illness. .

In an effort to attract more metro politan New Jersey residents to Jenny Jump State Forest, whose thickly wooded slopes decked with multicolored leaves become espe cially fascinating in the Fall, the State Department of Conservation and Development has opened up new picnic areas in the 1,100-acre forest located twelve miles west of here. Elevations of the recreationalcenter range from 399 to 1,108 feet.

Production schedules at carpet mills were reduced further last week by several manufacturers, and in the market here it was reported the curtailment was undertaken to avoid accumulation of stocks. How ever, inventories were said to be at levels not considered dangerous tothe price structure.
The Uni versity of Washington made the first downs but Stanford University made the touchdowns to win a Pacific Coast Conference footballgame today, 13-7.

Building activity in practically all of the development centers in Queens and adjacent sections of Long -Island is showing no evi dences of depression and the month of October, it is stated, will close with an exceptionally large volume of residential deals, chiefly formedium-priced homes.

The La fayette 150-pound eleven dropped its first game of the season today, los ing to the Princeton 150s by 13--0. The Tiger team was the master throughout the game but did not produce a score until the third period, when Caney went over aftera 65-yard drive.

The renewed weakness in securities was almost entirely responsible for the decline in grain futures on the Board of Trade here today. While wheat ral lied rather sharply from the inside figures the closing trades were at net losses of 1/4 to 1 cent a bushel,the latter on the May.
The Police Band entertains from Johannesburg at 1:45 P. M., over ZTJ on 6.09 megacycles. Budapest presents songs from Hungarian operettas over HAT4's9.12 megacycle channel at 7 P. M.

The marriage of Miss Mildred E. Wohnsiedler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wohnsiedler of Hollis, Queens, and Amityville, L. I., to Harry Eugene Tyler, son of Henry Tyler of Elmhurst, Queens, and Jamesport, L. I., and the late Mrs. Tyler, took place last night in Queens Valley Country Club, ForestHills. The Rev. Dr. Charles D.

NOT inapt at all is the de scriptive furbelow of "in timate musical" which the authors apply to "Between the Devil," the new Howard Dietz Arthur Schwartz piece produced by the Shuberts which, opening Tues day evening at the Chestnut Street Opera House, brought us our firsteye and ear novelty of the year.
Although the general public had not heard much of Alf M. Landon's activities since the 1936 election until his broadcast this week, the former Governor has had a busyyear, politically and personally.
Three-year-old Harry W. Rettke Jr., who knew 393 words when he was eighteen months old, now has such a large vocabulary that hismother reports that she has "lost count."

Miss Susan D. Pearson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Alexander Pearson of St. Martin's, was introduced this afternoon at a tea given by her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. T. Wil son Sharpless of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and York Harbor, Me., at theirhome in Chestnut Hill.
A dinner dance for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will be given on Wednesday in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton, marking the formal opening of thegarden for the season.

Virginia Military Institute's eleven conquered Virginia today, rolling up 26 points to 7 for the Cavaliers. Two of the touchdowns by the Cadets followed blocked kicks. Robeson and Shu starred for thevictors.
THE absorption of The Morn ing Post by The Daily Tele graph brings to an end the independent existence of a journal that will occupy an hon orable place in the history ofEnglish literature.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Clawson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank T. Clawson of this city, to Clifton Clark Candee of Bound Brook, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Asa M. Candee of Postville, Iowa, took place this evening in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Miss Fannie Robb Carvin, daughter of Mrs. W. John Wadsworth of 580 Park Avenue, New York, and Love lane Lodge, this city, was married to Felix Magnin of London in two religious ceremonies today in thiscity.
One of the features of the Navy Day celebration here on Wednes day, commemorating the birthday of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, will be a dinner andnaval ball at the Biltmore.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Horton of this city that the marriage of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Hor ton, to Francis H. Orr, son of Mrs Mary Orr of Rahway and the late Harry J. Orr, will take place in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception here onNov. 24.

New Jersey is well prepared, in the opinion of officials here, to do its part in the performance of a function vital to successful operation of the unem ployment compensation phase of theFederal social security program.

The current recession in business and the accompanying severe defla tion of security prices have provided a decisive test of some of the New Deal's basic economic theories, ac cording to the prevailing viewamong Wall Street bankers.
It might not have happened if Mr. Povondra, G. H. Bondy's porter, had followed his first impulse to tell Captain van Toch that his employer was out.
Captain Milo F. Draemel was assigned today as commandant of midship men at the Naval Academy to suc ceed Captain Forde A. Todd, on Dec. 29, in Navy Department orders received at the academy.

WHEN the season for con structing highway closes, in the course of a week or two, it will be found that during 1937 New York State has built slightly in excess of 255 miles. This was accomplished with an appropriation from the State of $28,036,480 and $10,935,027 from theFederal Government.

ALTHOUGH you may have a true collector's enthusiasm for colonial houses, covered bridges, windmills, light houses and the like, you have prob ably long since given up the hope of owning a representative collection of any one of them.

May I beg the privilege of a little of your valuable space to say that in my opinion your often excellent reviewer, Eda Lou Wal ton, missed the bullseye when shooting at Robert Hillyer's "A Letter to Robert Frost andOthers" in your issue of Sept. 19?

Many Summer homes within com muting distance of New York City frequently are used as year-round residences and builders should bear this fact in mind when construct ing such dwellings, states William L. Winthrop, head of the Ridge field Lakes development at Ridgefield Lakes, Conn.

Centre's Praying Colonels, playing their best football of the season, de feated the Davidson Wildcats to day, 8--0. Choosing to run instead of kick in the end zone, Lafferty attemptedto circle his left end, but was
Two men were killed and a 78-year old woman fatally injured here to day in a crash of a tri-motored sightseeing airplane at Tacoma Field. Seven other persons, including two women, were injured.

BRUNO WALTER recently brought forward at the Staats oper the Salzburg "Eury anthe." There is nothing to say about the production which was not said in these columns some weeks earlier except that it benefited by the superior acoustics of the Viennahouse.

ONCE again the automobile tire industry will complete a year of stability and profit making when the - curtain rings down on 1937 operations. Manufacturers and dealers- alike will, share in the improved condi tions that have marked the industry's activities during the last year.
APHRASE about his brother in Carl Van Doren's auto biography. "Three Worlds," is worth considering. "Apparently frank, actually impenetrable," he wrote about Mark.

Miss Constance Vernette Bill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence A. Bill of this place, was married here this afternoon in Christ First Presbyterian Church to Alton Austin Cheney, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ben jamin A. Cheney of New Haven, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. FrankM. Kerr.

LIGHTNING may strike twice, so far as the opening night opera at the Metropolitan is concerned. Another work by Wagner may be chosen to lead off the new season, which begins onMonday evening, Nov. 29.

Scoring a touchdown in the final twenty-four seconds of the game, the John Adams football team reg istered a 7-to-0 triumph over Flush ing yesterday at Dexter Park. The defeat was the first handed Flush ing since the season of 1935 and marked the first time that its goalline has been passed in that time.

The develop ment of games in the Soviet Union, especially association football, with matches attended by 60,000 to 70,000 excited spectators, has brought in a new popular sport of "booing theumpires"--or rather,

THERE is nothing new-to learn in driving with the Oldsmobile automatic safety transmission. In fact, the new device, now ob tainable as optional equipment at extra cost on 'both the six and eight, actually relieves the. motor ist of many former responsibilities and enables him to do a better allaround job of driving.

A new York girl and a Toronto boy met in the front yard of Dr. A. R. Dafoe while on a visit to Callander to see the Dionne quin tuplets. Now Dr. Dafoe plans to accept an invitation to be guestof honor at the wedding.
" Moderate revision" in the price of men's clothing for Spring will be made by manufacturers, as a result of the cut in worsted and woolen piece goods, according to local executives yesterday.

Miss Robera Sickels of. Albany has an unusual job: She calls herself a "party engineer." Miss Sickels makes a specialty of helping youngsters to give the kind of parties they dream about. She says she developed the idea from her hobby of story and game collecting.
AFEW years ago a small group of men and women in Cin cinnati, Ohio, launched a movement to save the old side-wheeler packet boat of the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers as amuseum piece.

Undefeated Baylor added a vaunted Texas A. and M. eleven to its list of victims today, 13-0. Bullet Bill Patterson, Baylor's passing expert, loosed two tremend ous touchdown aerials that dropped to completion beyond the losers'goal stripe.

Eight hundred and fifty thousand tourists visited France during the first ten months of this year, according to figures submitted to the consultative com mittee on tourism by Roland Mar cel, General Commissioner of Tour ism, based on legitimation cards,visas and customs reports.

Emil Jannings, the German actor, is seriously ill with influenza at a hotel here. Herr Jannings has been touring Scandinavia, making per sonal appearances at the first nights of his latest German film, "The Conqueror." He was in good spir its at a dinner last night, afterwhich he suddenly collapsed.

On charges that he plotted a revolt of State forces in Rio Grande do Sul, the former commander of the Rio Grande do Sul military brigade, Colonel Joao Canabarro was ar rested today. Captain Jose deMoura also was seized.

The 150th anniversary of the birth of higher education in the old North west Territory will be celebrated throughout the Midwest next Wednesday. Exercises will com memorate the signing on Oct. 27, 1787, of the Northwest Ordinance, a land contract between the Ohio Company of Associates and the United States Congress, which pro vided for the establishment of OhioUniversity.

DURAND-RUEL offers a group of Monets, all of the canvases landscapes save one, the large "Chrysanthemes" of 1888. Claude Monet, acknowledged leader of the Impressionist school, can hardly be expected to stir nowadays a fever ofexcitement in Fifty-seventh Street.

Taking city cars for a hay ride, 433 New Yorkers by count, augmented by some seventy reserves from Stam ford and-South Norwalk, thronged aboard the first "husking bee" train in history-a new wrinkle in railroad promotion-and spent the evening here in enjoyment of such bucolic pastimes as husking corn (the field variety), square-dancing and consumption of country victuals.
Captain John Van Doren Young of 44 Morningside Drive, an em ploye of the Lafayette National Bank, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after an illness of twoweeks. He was 36 years old.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 23.--An attack was made yesterday by an eagle of enormous size on a 13 year-old Negro girl who was pick ing cotton on the farm of Ed Syperts of the Jarrett communi ty, about forty miles north of Austin.
The board of directors of the Home Owners Loan Corporation today made its contribution toward bal ancing the budget by announcingthrough Charles A. Jones, general

A new step in man's control of weather, this time to help the farmer, by use of glass "wool" to keep plants alive in Winter, was announced today at Cornell University. Made of fibers of glass finer than human hair, the "wool" is laid on the ground as a new form of "mulch," the blanket which farmers have used for thousands of years, first as dried grass.

Miss Martha Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Johnson of this city, was married to John H. S. Acheson Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. S. Acheson, also of New Rochelle, this afternoon inTrinity Lutheran Church here.
A forty-seven-mile-an-hour wind blowing up from the southeast combined with a high tide yester day morning to send the waters of the bay up to within two feetof the top of the Battery sea wall.

The sixth annual Miami Biltmore Fashion Show and Ball will take place on Dec. 10 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Sponsored by Colonel Henry L. Doherty, president of the Florida. Year - Round Clubs, the event will raise funds for the Goddard Neighborhood Center, which conducts a program of social service for hundreds of families in the central East Side district between Twenty - sixth and Fifty - second Streets.

Unbeaten in its previous nineteen starts, Amityville High went down to defeat for the first time since 1934 as the Huntington eleven re corded a 6-0 victory today. The streak included eighteen triumphsand one tie.

Terming the recent meeting on boys' wear as the type-of model conference which retailers and man ufacturers can utilize to solve their mutual problems, Harold Bright man, vice president of L. Bamber ger Co. and chairman of the merchandising division of the Na tional Retail Dry Goods Associa tion, said yesterday that plans will be pushed this Fall for an exten sive program for better relationsbetween buyers and sellers.

Frank E. Learned, vice president in charge of operations of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Com pany, died today of a heart ailment at his home in Merion after anillness of a month. His age was 57.

The preliminary report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corpo ration and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows an operat ing income of $34,828,011, compared with one of $35,905,609 in the preceding twelve months.

Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel of New York City, charged here to night that Postmaster General Far ley would attempt to control the coming State Constitutional Con vention as a step in his campaignto obtain the Governorship.

In leg islating the new farm program, President Roosevelt warned Con gress leaders today, the budget should be protected with an eye to "expected balancing" and any ad ditional burdens on the Treasury should be covered "100 per cent by additional receipts from newtaxes."

DON'T look now, but those Green Bay Packers have scored exactly 95 points in their last three games in the pro or post-graduate football league. The Chicago Bears are still undefeated, but that record may go to smash before sundown or what passes for "twilight and evening bell"along the Lake Michigan front.

Butler's Bulldogs conquered a stub born Washington and Jefferson eleven, 12 to 0, amid snow flurries today. Led by Tom Harding and Inman Blackaby, Butler pounded consist ently at the Presidents' goal line.In the second period.

Two of the season's records were broken at the fourth series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx Richmond senior high champion ship of the Public School Athletic League, conducted yesterday in the25-yard pool at De Witt Clinton.

Ala bama's Crimson Tide, striking once with its versatile running attack and twice through the air, bumped George Washington University from the unbeaten ranks and earned a 19-to-0 intersectional victory todaybefore 24,666 fans.

Miss Margaret Loretto Haynes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Chester Haynes of Flushing, was married to Valentine G. O'Connell, son of Mrs. Timothy J. O'Connell of New York and the late Mr. O'Con nell, yesterday morning in the Church of St. Andrew of Avellinoin Flushing.

Nation al Airlines, Inc., of St. Petersburg, Fla., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering 130,000 shares of $1 par value common stock to be sold for $487,500 to the issuer and to stockholders through an underwriter. The money will be used for purchase of equipment andworking capital.

The Dairy Farmers' Union tonight called a State-wide milk strike against all dealers supplying fluid milk to metropolitan markets, to take effect Thursday morning. Archie Wright, chairman of the union, said that the strike was de cided upon at a meeting of unionofficials at Utica this afternoon.
Trinity was toppled from the undefeated ranks today as Connecticut State's power plays prevailed, 15 to 0. Runs by Bayuk, Thomson and Posner brought the first score, the lattergoing over.
Led by Captain Charlie Spreyer, the Choate football team downed a fighting Deerfield eleven by 19--6 today before a Fathers' Day crowdof 3,000.
Two American golfers, Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., and Denny Shute of Boston, will meet tomorrow in the final round of the professional match play tournament.

YEAR after year the path of the American hobbyist leading to the collection of phonograph record issues is becoming a better worn one. Still largely confined to the desire for owning the recognized works of the concert hall, the trend is showing more recognizable marks of becoming a true hobby in the avidity with which foreign record catalogues are being seized anddiscussed by American collectors.

A plea for the United States to take a definite stand for cooperative ac tion in international affairs in order to maintain its traditional liberties and prosperity and lead the world peacefully toward a high er civilization than any yet known was made today by Raymond Leslie Buell of New York, president of the Foreign Policy Association, atthe City Club forum here.
Samuel Gertner of 525 West End Avenue, attorney, son of Herman Gertner, the restaurateur, and Mrs. Gertner. died on Friday night in Mt. Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 29 Years old.

Almost 5,000 Boy Scouts in troops from New York City, Suffolk, Nas sau, Rockland and Westchester Counties, New Jersey and Connec ticut made their eighteenth pil grimage this afternoon to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery hers The for mer President would have been 69years old next Wednesday.

Debits to the individual accounts as re ported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 20 aggre gated $10,379,000,000, or 47 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days in most of the reporting centers, and 10 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

WITH the steady accumula tion of experience upon which sound judgment may be based, the place of the Diesel engine truck in the transportation picture has become an absorbing topic of debate in thetrucking and allied industries.

More than 650 older high school boys are expected to attend the New Jersey State Older Boys' Conference, which will be held at the Y. M. C. A. of the Oranges here from Dec. 3 to 5 under the auspices of the New Jersey State Y. M. C. A.

The Boys High football team came to the end of its long victory trail yesterday. The Red and Black eleven bowed to the power ful James Madison High outfit, 19--6, before 10,000 persons at Boys High Field, and the setback was its first after seventeen successes in a row, a record compiled over a spanof three seasons.

The first of a group of Colonial farmhouse-type homes will be open for inspection today at Piping Rock, a new residential develop ment at West Nyack, N. Y. The Douglas Bar Corporation is thebuilding syndicate.
ALEADER in the development in this country of knee action front wheels, Buick announces for 1938 the introduction of "torque free springing," involving coilspring rear suspension.

Generalissimo Francisco Franco's capture of Gijon Friday and the constitution of his National Council mark, in opin ion here, what may be a vital turn ing point in the Spanish civil war. It will be possible for the Insur gent leader to withdraw troops from Gijon for use elsewhere, for there will be no serious menace onthat flank.

Providence College rallied to defeat Springfield, 9-6, today for the Friars' second victory over the Ma roons in ten meetings. Springfield took a 6-0 lead early in the second period when a Providence fumble gave the visitors the ball on theFriars' 3-yard line.

Indians in native costumes will sing tribal songs and play their own musical instruments as part of a cultural history course on In dians Wednesday afternoons, beginning at 3:30 o'clock thisweek, at the Brooklyn Museum.

Coming from behind in the last two minutes of play, Fordham's unbeaten team gained a 1-point triumph over Texas Christian University in New York's big game of the day. Yale downed Cornell and Dartmouth routed Harvard in two other major Eastern contests.

NOW that the 1937 edition of New York's annual auto mobile show is about to open, it might not be out of place to review briefly the his tory of the automobile in this State, or rather its history since it first became the object of legislative action and governmental regulation.

Presi dent Roosevelt, proclaiming the celebration of Armistice Day as the anniversary of the ending of the "most destructive, sanguinary and far-reaching war in human annals," today again denounced the "law lessness and strife in many parts of the world" which he said threat ened international security andeven civilization itself.

THE new Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, directed by Otto Klemperer, opened its season last Thursday. Months of effort were involved, including a successful campaign and reorgani zation of the orchestra. The selec tion of the personnel was in thehands of Dr. Klemperer.

BOTH London and Rome hope quite sincerely that some way can be found for lessening the tension that has characterized Anglo-Italian relations since Mussolini two years ago began his conquest of Ethiopia. The hopes cannot yet be placed much higher thanthat It would be too much to expect that

FREDDIE - BARTHOLOMEW and Metro reached a finan cial settlement during the week and the youngster has been restored to the studio payroll with a substantial increase in salary. Under the agreement he will

Employer-employe cooperation to stabilize conditions in the painting industry here was reflected yester day in the establishment of a joint industrial control committee, rep resenting the Association of Master Painters and Decorators and District Council 9 of the Brotherhood

THIS novel has three unusual qualities: it captures the sensitivity of an adolescent boy so that he becomes in teresting as an individual; it al lows a virgin, over 40. to be,nevertheless, endowed with sheer,
For the first time in recent years paper ballots will be used at a gen eral election in New York City on Nov. 2 when the voters select their choices for the members of the newCity Council.
Playing before a record crowd of more than 14,000, Bloomfield High School's Bengals scored a 12-to-7 victory over Dickinson High ofJersey City today.

Miss Marjorie Geichman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Geichman of Brooklyn, N. Y., was married this morning in the Log Chapel at the University of Notre Dame to Leo V. McLaughlin, son of Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Alonzo G. McLaughlin of Brooklyn. The cere mony was performed by the Rev.Edward J. Finnegan.

The proper segregation of multi family and business properties is as important in planning small-homes communities as it is in the laying out of neighborhoods containing more expensive homes, declares Seward H. Mott, chief of the landplanning section of the FHA.
The German press offensive against Czechoslo vakia, which seemed abating yes terday, was resumed with new vigor today as the result of twonew developments.

The University of Buffalo scored its third victory in four starts today, down ing Kent State, 13-0, in a game played in the rain. Danny Dalfonso, brilliant Buffalo back, did all the scoring, plugging across the invaders' goal line in the second and fourth periods and add ing the extra point after the last touchdown by an accurate placekick.

THE fight against loss of life and property through fires is a year-round activity of the Boy Scouts. Fundamental in the movement's requirements for ad vancement is a knowledge of how to guard against and combat thethreat of flames.
A Halloween tea dance and fashion show will be given on Thurs day afternoon at Sherry's in aid of the-free clinic for animals main trained by the Humane Society ofNew York. Brig. Gen. Louis W.

The consolidation of 100 teaching positions and the establishment of a compulsory average class size of thirty-one has seriously impaired the efficiency of the evening schools, "threatening their very existence," the Teachers Union charged yesterday in a brief sent to Mayor La Guardia and members of the Board of Education.

The engagement of Miss Carole M. Wiener, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Wiener of this city, to Dr. Milton M. Ehrlich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Ehrlich, also of New York, has been announced byher parents.

Brig. Gen. Perry L. Miles, com manding general of the First Divi sion, will complete next Sunday a career of forty-six years in the regu lar army, during which he attained recognition as a notable combat leader and staff officer. His head quarters are at Fort Hamilton,Brooklyn.
EXCEPT for new devices de signed to make gear shifting easier, there are relatively few major changes in the chassis scheduled to appear at thisyear's shows.

TWENTY years ago, on the night of Oct. 23, 1917, Americans went to bed lulled by the growing optimism of allied communiques and propa ganda. The soldiers were already settling down in the trenches to the comparative tranquillity of Winter. We were encour aged to believe that Germany would not even wait for the final, overwhelming drive of the allied armies in the Springof 1918.

A luncheon for the benefit of the People's Institute, United Neigh borhood Guild, Inc., will be held on Nov. 16 at the Astor. Mrs. Dudley D. Campbell is general chairman of the event, with Mrs. Tracy S. Voorhees and Mrs. JohnS. Roberts as co-chairman.
General Manager, Cadillac-LaSalle THE statement is often made that the automobile pulled the country out of the depression, yet many people are unaware of thefull significance of that statement.

Army had a rather easy time with Washington University of St. Louis, Mo., today, burying the Westerners under a 47 to 7 count in a one sided game. Only 5,000 spectators braved the elements to go to Michie Stadium where rain and high windsprevailed for most of the afternoon.

Matters of dollars and cents were of more concern to America last week than in many a month. Wall Street crowded politics and foreign affairs off the stage by acting as though it wished to repeat the show it put on eight years ago in October, 1929. As on the earlier occasion, the public did not seem to beamused.

The twelfth annual world's cham pionship rodeo will close tonight at Madison Square Garden, when the cowboy and cowgirl contests will be decided. Many of the entrants have been weeded out in the three weeks the rodeo has been here. Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, pres ident of the Garden corporation, will present the trophies from thecenter of the ring.
Eigh teen seamen were charged tonight with violating mutiny laws during a13,000-mile round trip to Buenos
" Wells of Discontent," a "study of economic, social and political as pects of the chain store," written by Charles G. Daughters, made itsappearance last week. The volume,
ARMOUR--Mr. and Mrs. Irving E., announce birth of a son, Oct. 22, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital. BAIN--Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert C., announce birth of a daughter, Oct. 20, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital.

Northeastern continued its reign over Rhode Island State by scoring an 8-to-6 victory on a water-cov ered field today. After Duranleau of State scored from the North eastern 4-yard line in the third period the Rams were driven back in the fourth and decided on anintentional safety.

Miss Ella D. Milbank, chairman of the debutante committee for the December Ball to be held at the Ritz-Carlton on Dec. 2, will give a tea on Tuesday at her home, 1,026 Fifth Avenue, for a large group of the season's debutantes who are assisting her with arrangements for the ball, net proceeds from which will benefit the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

THE National Symphony, un der Hans Kindler, which opens in Washington, D. C., next Sunday, with the Wag nerian Festival Singers as assisting artists, plans to give a number of works their first hearing in thatcity this Winter.
There have been signs recently of a growing opposition to the "arbitrary powers" exercised by Federal commis sions. One of the most notable exam ples is the Securities and ExchangeCommission.

The Andes range will be flown over for the first time by a fleet of ten airplanes in mass formation when an Italian group of flying experts, now visiting Chile, crosses the frontier to Mendoza, Argentina, whence it will continue to Buenos Aires next week, it was announced today.

THE President's call for a special ses sion means that there will be a hia tus in the usual vacation period for Congressmen. That vacation had already been cut short by the length of the session which kept Congress in Washington until late Summer.

The future "war of manoeuvre," in which motorized forces sweep around flanks and rear of the "enemy" like "Jeb" Stuart's cav alry in days that are gone, was rehearsed here on the plains ofTexas during the past week.

Waves of selling washed over the stock market in yesterday's short session and prices crumpled by 1 to 10 points. THE NEW YORK TIMES combined averages closed at 94.39, representing a loss of 3.70 for the day and 4.33 for the week. Volumewas 1,565,000 shares.

Cordell Hull's visit to Ottawa and Toronto follow ing hard on President Roosevelt's recent stay in Vancouver has served to remind Canadians how much more pleasant and openly friendly their relations with their neighbors to the south have grownin little more than two decades.

WASHINGTON. - As a needed adjunct to its fingerprint records of gangsters, kidnappers, bank robbers and other criminals, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has set up a moniker or nickname file, it was recently revealed byDirector J. Edgar Hoover.

Called to give earnest considera tion to problems touching on inter national affairs, civic government and their own club activities, dele gates to the Kings County Confer ence of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs will assemble at the Central Branch Y. W. C. A. in Brooklyn on Friday for an all-daymeeting.

Joseph P. Curry of the Brimar Corporation, developers of Broad dawn Harbour on the shore of Man hasset Bay at Kings Point, an nounced yesterday plans for a beach club and sporting center to cost$100,000.
A New York committee under the leadership of Mrs. John Hampton Barnes Jr. and Mrs. William Hale Harkness will conduct next month a membership enrollment for TheSeeing Eye throughout this city.

Cir cuit Judge Edwin Dickerson re served action today for sixty days on petitions and cross petitions ask ing liquidation or reorganization of Continental Shares. Inc., an in vestment trust holding company founded by Cyrus S. Eaton ofCleveland.
Dr. Harvie Branscombe of Duke University told a regional confer ence of the Association of American Colleges today that college libraries were still in the "horsehair andwhatnot stage."

In a paradoxical setting, in which unbeaten, untied and unscored upon Lafayette was cast in the role of underdog, the surprisingly aggres sive Leopards from Easton, Pa., turned the tables on a heavily favored N. Y. U. eleven yesterdayat the Yankee Stadium.

Upon his retirement as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, James M. Landis is sued a statement in which he de clared that odd-lot buying had been providing a cushion for the stockmarket.

LAST FRONTIER: At Anchorage, Alaska, last week arrived Joe Free man, traveling hardware salesman of the Far North. Demands from his cus tomers in the region have led him to characterize the Arctic as "sissy." People on this last frontier, he found, want chromium gadgets and all sortsof modern designs in hardware.

A series of bridge parties will be held throughout the county under the auspices of the Westchester Smith College Club, of which Mrs. Edward G. Murray is president. The pro ceeds will go toward the scholarship fund for Westchester girls.

The discovery of an alleged widespread espionage network was announced today by the Barcelona police chief. It was one of the best organized plots yet uncovered, and what made it par ticularly dangerous was the fact that it was military in character and that its members worked under the direction of the Rebels' highcommand.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Abbie Louise English, daughter of Mrs. Richard W. A. English of this city and the late Dr. English, to George Clark Jelliffe, son of Mrs. Maltby D. Jelliffe, also of Jersey City, andthe late Mr. Jelliffe.
SPECIAL taxes assessed against motorists for construction and maintenance of an adequate highway system are legally, morally and exclusively dedicatedto those purposes.

On Nov. 1 they will begin shoot ing ducks and geese in New Jer sey, and to most wild-fowlers this means Barnegat Bay. But the tide is on the ebb at Barnegat, and in its slow fall-it has swept most of the "old bay" out into that fabledsea of the past.

THERE could be no more posi tive proof of the rapid growth of interest in serious music throughout this country during the past few years than the surprising number of new orchestras which have been formed in smaller communities of late.

Warning that public hysteria" may develop if the stock market continues its downward trend, Rabbi Louis I. Newman asserted yesterday in his sermon at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty third Street, that sufficient evi dence exists to lead to the belief that "certain sinister forces" are accentuating the economic difficulties for their own personal gain.
Dr. Sylvan D. Lazarus of 847 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, who specialized in pediatry, died in Bushwick Hospital on Thursday in his forty sixth year.

RAINBOW hues of new cars to go on display at the Automo bile Show indicate that at last metropolitan centers may follow the swing to brighter colors that is under way throughout the country. Except on the Pacific Coast and incertain Southern States,

City Judge Robert J. Summers reversed the usual procedure in a traffic case here. He discharged the defendant and fined the complainant $10. "What have you to present to this court to prove that the defend ant (John E. White) drove reck lessly?" asked Judge Summers of the complainant, Benedict Kosnikowski.
United States Senator A. Harry Moore and Mayor Frank Hague will be the principal speakers on Nov. 4 at the cornerstone was completed several new $3,000,000 Hudson County Tuberculosis Hospital.

The longest sit-down strike in the his tory of New Jersey-a sixty-nine day session-ended this afternoon with the signing of an agreement between the Amalgamated Associa tion of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers and the management of the Central Foundry Company's plant on Murray Street and Avenue D, Newark.

CORONATION year is drawing to its close and the final Promenade concert of the season provided a fitting salute to it with Sir Arnold Bax's "London Pageant." Sir Arnold was knighted during the coronation fes tivities and this work may be takenas directly inspired by those events.

The Japanese are weighing carefully the possible advantages and disadvantages of the Brussels conference called to meet under the Nine-Power Pacific Treaty. So far, Tokyo has neither accept ed nor declined the invitation. The Belgian Government announced yesterday that the date of convening the meeting had been post poned from Oct. 30 to Nov. 3, the purpose being to give the Japanese more time to consider the situation.

Another hec tic chapter will be added this Win ter to the tumultuous political his tory of Seattle. Pacific Northwest leaders of the Committee for Industrial Organiza tion plan to defeat Mayor John F. Dore by running against him the most extraordinary politician in the region, Lieut. Gov. Victor Aloysius ("Just call me 'Vic' ") Meyers ofthe State of,Washington.
BACK in the peaceful days at the close of the nineteenth century when the automobile was just emerging from the horseless carriage stage, legislators saw that some regulations wereneeded.
AMES THOMAS FIEXNER. worthy scion of a worthy stock, has brought forth a study of America's earliest great physicians Separate chapters are devoted to Morgan.

The un employment-insurance program of the Social Security Board will shift into second gear on Jan. 1, when more than 11,000,000 workers in twenty-one States and the District of Columbia will become eligible to draw unemployment benefits from trust funds which by that time probably will total about $350,000,000.

With the Middle West leading with a gain of 11 per cent, retail trade during the first half of Oc tober reflected renewed public buy ing, which boosted the average gain to 8 per cent over a year ago, ac cording to a survey made by the National Retail Dry Goods Asso ciation of sales of member stores inthirty-five cities.

WITH something akin to the awe with which a Moslem presumably approaches Mecca, this mi gratory Hollywood correspondent came breezing down the sacred route of U. S. Highway 41 the other day toward this birthplace of the Mo hammed of the movies, the hometown of Will H. Hays.
The Belgian Foreign Office dis closed today that the government was considering postponing the Nine-Power Conference on the Chi nese-Japanese conflict from Oct. 30to Nov. 3.

A "deliberate effort" by the Board of Elections to help out James J. Lyons, Democratic can didate for re-election as Borough President of the Bronx, was charged yesterday by the AmericanLabor party. Matthew M. Levy,
The Meadow Brook team from Long Island pounded through deep mud today to win the Foxhall Farm Challenge Cup, feature race of theElkridge-Harford Hunt Club meet.

The decline in the stock market has not affected the number of new charge accounts being opened, according to A. B. Buckeridge, manager of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, who reported yesterday that the number of spe cial reports issued on new ac counts last week showed an in crease of 8 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago.

Pitt's mighty Panthers rolled in great waves up and down a soggy gridiron today and three times the tide splashed over Wisconsin's goal line for touchdowns to give the Rose Bowl champions a 21-to-0victory.
Need for new missionaries in foreign fields was stressed today at the annual meeting of the American Board for Foreign Missions.

Miss Carol Elisabeth Hornsey, daughter of Mrs. John William Hornsey of Summit and the late Mr. Hornsey, was married to Roger Montgomery Spalding, son of Dr. Roger Spald ing of Duxbury, Mass., and Boston, and the late Mrs. Spalding, here this afternoon at the home of hermother.

BUYERS of the improved trail ers exhibited at this year's Automobile Show will get ex tra intangible values. Behind the exhibits are country-wide forces endeavoring to smooth the trailer ite's progress when he is hitched upand ready to roll.

A new medium-priced home com munity will be formally opened in Irvington, N. J., with the early completion of five houses now un der construction by the Irvington Housing Corporation organized by John R. Franke Jr. and WalterCastle Jr.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 23.--Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Day Mallory gave a Tyrolean party in honor of the twenty-first birthday of their son, Clifford Day Mallory Jr., in the barn on the estate of the latter's aunt, Mrs. Charles H. Mallory,Byram Shore, Greenwich, tonight.
The 104th anniversary fair of the Orphan Asylum Society of the City of Brooklyn will be held the after noon and evening of Nov. 11 and 12at the Masonic Temple, Brooklyn.

More than 3,000 school children, crammed into the Metropolitan Opera House today, sang ditties about "Johnny B. Careful" and "Mary B. Ware" at a safety rally conducted under the auspices of the Governor'shighway safety council.

Scoring two touchdowns and toss ing a pass for the third, Sid White stole the show as the Brooklyn Col lege eleven repulsed Lowell Textile, 19-0, before a crowd of 3,000 on the Kingsmen's new athletic fieldyesterday.

Dock workers at Marseilles have blacklisted Jap anese ships and refused to unload the cargo of the Kasima Maru when it arrived. They refused to give an explanation except that they were following orders from leaders inParis.
Ownie D. Muir, Jr., Vice president of the United States Refining, Smelting and Mining Company, died today after a heart attack. His age was 53.

Inventories of local department stores continued at a high point during September, with almost all sections showing increases. The gains for leading departments ranged from 6 to 103.4 per cent over the same month last year, accord ing to the monthly report issued yesterday by the Federal ReserveBank of New York.

Mayor William H. Williams and other officials here are working on details of a plan to accelerate sale of more than 600 properties, most of which were acquired by the mu nicipality through tax title liens. The plan is based on a relaxed price policy and public auction of properties in groups.

THE relationship of television lighting, make-up and costume is described as "very tricky business," according to "the Scan ner," reporting in Radio ??mes, journal of the British BroadcastingCorporation.

Announce ment has been made of the engage ment of Miss Carolillian Edith Wexler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Wexler of Westmount, to Bernard H. Payton of New York, son of Mrs. Harry Payton of Provi dence, R. I., and the late Mr.Payton.

In connection with Crown Prince Michael's sixteenth birth day anniversary tomorrow; he was promoted to a lieutenancy in the Rumanian Army and made King Carol's honorary aide de camp. He will be attached to the First Battalion, King Carol's ownunit, of the Mountain Rifles.

WED much rather read about Reggie Fortune but if Mr. Bailey insists upon foisting Joshua Clunk upon us, there is nothing that can be done about it Clunk is such an unpleasant person that one always hopes to see him caught in something that willland him behind the bars.

When the Secretary of Agriculture, Henry A. Wallace, went before the Senate Agriculture Committee several months ago to warn its members that tumbling farm prices might follow a single season of unlimited planting, he was all but laughedout of court.

For the second time since the October grand jury began investigating vice and crime in Philadelphia, political charges have far overshadowed the behind-the-scenes plugging of thejurors and special prosecutors.

Judge Richard Hartshorne of Es sex County will be the principal speaker at the Morristown High School Auditorium for the Morris County celebration of the 150th an niversary of the ratification of the Constitution, Nov. 4. His talk will follow a torchlight parade in which the American Legion drum and bugle corps and all patriotic and civic organizations in the countywill take part.
PERHAPS during no similar period has more study been devoted to discovering the causes of motor vehicle acci dents than in the last twelvemonths.

THE schedule of exhibitions an nounced for the Newark Mu seum by Beatrice Winset director, includes a selection of ceramics by outstanding Ameri can craftsmen in this field; a col lection of paintings acquired during the current year, and a series of shows of works of art from NewJersey collections.

THE executive committee of the new bridge organization formed to combine the previ ous American Bridge League and United States Bridge Associa tion held its first meeting last week. Among the committee decisions was the choice of "American ContractBridge League" as a name.

Flash ing a passing attack in the second half, Swarthmore scored two touch downs to tie Oberlin College, 13-13, today before a large crowd of re turning alumni. A pass, Jakle to Weltmer, over the goal line produced a touchdown in the third period, and anotheraerial, Jakle to Warrington, brought

The Uni versity of Maryland football team swept the Orange host of Syracuse from the seat of the mighty today. Effectively bottling up the New Yorkers running attack and tak ing advantage of their many lapses, the Maryland players were in al most complete command of . the game, which they won by thescore of 13 to 0.

Two blocked punts led to as many touch downs to give Duke University's Blue Devils a 13-to-0 victory over Colgate's young Red Raiders as a sad celebration of Homecoming Dayon a rain-soaked field today.

A memorial service for Amelia Earhart, lost on the transpacific crossing of her round-the-world flight in July, is being planned by the New York branch of the Wo men's International Association of Aeronautics, an organization of wo men pilots and others interested inthe promotion of aviation.

Villanova mixed a nice running at tack with forward passes today to defeat Bucknell, 21 to 0, before a crowd of 10,000 at Shibe Park. It was Villanova's third victory in four games, the other being a scorelesstie with Auburn.
Scoring twice in the second half, the James Monroe High School Football team conquered Stuyvesant, 14 to 0, yesterday on the Monroe Field to continue undefeated andunscored upon in three games.

President Roosevelt was speeding toward Hyde Park this afternoon to stay at his mother's house until after the local election on Nov. 2. Contrary to his usual custom, he made most of the trip by daylight. The special train with the Presi dent's car on the rear left Wash ington at 2:15 o'clock this after noon bound for Highlands on the west shore of the Hudson, whence his route ran, by automobile, to hismother's house.
THESE three Russian books*--one by Soviet and two by emigre writers-have little in common with the excep tion that they all have a great in terest, although for dissimilar reason.

" Another Language," the stage and movie success of a few years ago, will be the varsity presentation when Hunter College revives one of its oldest student activities on Friday evening, Nov. 19; Saturday afternoon and evening, Nov. 20, and Sunday evening, Nov. 21, at the Heckscher Theatre, Fifth Avenueat 104th Street, Manhattan.
Undergraduates were advised today by Elihu Root Jr. of New York City to spend their lives in the "army of useful citizens who pay the taxes and sustain the more public figures."

Charles E. Bedaux, who will guide the Duke of Windsor during the royal visitor's study of Ameri can laboring conditions, is a self made multi-millionaire who came to the United States from France about thirty years ago to find his fortune and started looking for itas an itinerant common laborer.

While it is too early to judge how the new 10 per cent extraordinary levy on the cap ital value of stock companies, which the Government decreed this week, will affect Italy's situation, it is generally conceded that this meas ure was very skillfully prepared to minimize as much as possible its in fluence on the nation's economiclife.

Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance So ciety, charged today that the Ad ministration was "blockading" investment channels of the country.

Timber by timber and brick by brick, a 235-year-old house, built by a ship's carpenter of Haverhill be fore the birth of George Washing ton, is being moved to Pittsford, N. Y., where it will be reconstruct ed exactly as it stands for habita tion by the family of Mitchell Pierson of Rochester.
SPANISH entertainment not to be confused with the Andalu sian Mickey Finns from Father Divine's bailiwick is provided at the Havana-Madrid, a new sub-sidewalk parlor next to theWinter Garden Theatre.

Washington State upset the Uni versity of California at Los Angeles today, scoring a field goal in the final quarter to win, 3 to 0. Backers of the Bruins among the 20,000 onlookers waited in vain forthe Uclans to score.

Panzer College scored its first victory of the season in defeating Wagner on mud-covered St. Benedict's Field to day, 18-7. A pass, Stodt to Cummings, tal lied for Panzer at the start of the second quarter, but Wagner went into the lead a few minutes later ona blocked punt, a pass from Nillsen

Am herst's football team made good in its first major test today, defeating favored Wesleyan, 12-2, on rain soaked Pratt Field before 3,000. Thus Amherst gained revenge for last year's reverse at Middletown as the series for the Little Three began.

All money-raising activities for Barnard College have been under the supervision of a recently formed coordinating committee, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve an nounced yesterday. The commit tee is made up of members of the fiftieth anniversary fund commit tee and of the associate alumnae, with Dean Gildersleeve as chair man. It will meet monthly in heroffice.

The Good Neighbor League now has 15,000 members in nearly 2,000 cities and towns in this country, ac cording to a report made public yesterday by Dr. Charles Stelzle, executive director. About 3,000 mem bers are clergymen representing Protestant, Catholic and Jewishfaiths.

Worcester Tech scored a 14-to-0 vic tory over Massachusetts State be fore a gathering of alumni on home coming day. A driving rain and frequent fumbles slowed the game. A sustained march of 75 yards in the opening period with Gustafson going over from the 4-yard markerput Tech in front.
FEW Visitors to the National Automobile Show will realize the amount of preparation which went into the design ing of the shiny new models for1938.
The time is coming when Atlantic City will have to restrict large sections of the beach by admission fees, "but it may be a long time before we decide," according to MayorCharles D. White.
Palestine has again been experiencing for the last week one of its recurrent spells of the terrorism that has cropped up intermittently during the- lastyear and a half.

The law of averages caught up with Fordham and Fordham caught up with Texas Christian University in the final two minutes of a hair-raising football battle at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Rams jammed across a touchdown, converted the extra point and stopped the Horned Frogs, 7 to 6,to remain unbeaten.

ATLANTIC CITY.--Halloween celebrations will hold, the center of the social stage in Atlantic City during the com ing week. Special programs are being prepared by all of the larger hotels for their visitors here overthis period.

ONE pleasing feature of the last week in the New York Gal leries was the giving of four unusually promising first shows. Two of the four artists introduced are water-colorists; the other twowork primarily in oil.

News from Washington conveys meager promise, if any, of either re peal or revision of the corporate undistributed profits tax in respect to this year's taxable income. Among the subjects of legislation scheduled for consideration at the forthcoming special session of Congress, taxes is not one.
COLORED mirrors that are being put up on the fronts of restaurants and stores are making New York as beau tiful and glittering and artificialas Baudelaire's dream city.

The Westminster eleven fell before a determined Kent team by a score of 6 to 0 today. Although the home team invaded the visitors' territory many times and once held the ball on the 5-yard line with four downs to go, it wasunable to cross.
