Plans to replace the Brooklyn city prison are ready and are await ing action by the Board of Esti mate, Austin H. MacCormick, Com missioner of Correction, said last night in the Central Court Building, Schermerhorn and Smith Streets, Brooklyn, at a meeting of the KingsCounty Grand Jurors Association.

Scoring the tendency of municipal taxing authorities to rely on over assessment of real property to meet the financial needs of the commu nity, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, in a prepared statement yes terday declared that property own ers in Manhattan alone had beenovertaxed $33,000,000 in 1937.

Calling attention today to the sixteenth ob servance of Navy Day-the birthday of President Theodore Roosevelt which will be celebrated on next Wednesday, Secretary Swanson pointed to the progress made under the present administration in building up the navy to treaty strength.

Harold L. Ickes, Secreetary of the Interior and Federal Publio Works Administrator, exchanged compli ments with Mayor La Guardia yes terday on the completion of the city's $30,000,000 sewage disposal plant on Wards Island in the East River off 110th Street, which was partly financed by a $11,360,250 Federal grant.

IN Mexican villages where old tra ditions still rule, Indians are busy preparing for their annual Days of the Dead-Oct. 31 and Nov. 1. Visitors to Mexico at this time of year will find the marketplaces filled with candles, with delicaciesand with gifts.

Charles G. Dawes, former Ambassador to Lon don, and Mrs. Dawes were enter tained at luncheon at the Belgian Embassy by Baron de Cartier de Marchienne, whose other guests in cluded the Earl of Granard, Vis count and Viscountess Runciman, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Franck Jr., Lord and Lady Cadman and Wing Commander Sir Louis and LadyGreig.

Well - located and well - rented apartment houses in the borough of the Bronx have been attracting the interest recently of realty in vestment buyers, and several good properties have changed handsduring the last few weeks.

The undefeated Holy Cross football team capitalized on fine punting today to thrust over a touchdown early in the first period that defeated a big and surprisingly strong Western Maryland eleven, 6-0, on a wet and slippery field ina driving rain.
CITY folk who like a good walk, whether it be a leisure ly fifteen-minute stroll or a vigorous four - or - five - mile hike, have reason to be thankful for the completion of the West Sideimprovement.

United States Government supply contracts valued at about $3,835,788 were awarded by twelve agencies in the week ended on Oct. 21 under the terms of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

FAVORITE HUEY LONG STORIES. Edited by Hugh Mercer Blain. Paper covers. Baton Rouge La.: Otto Clattor 501 Third ST. 50 cents. Anecdotes by and about the late politician. THE RECTOR FAMILY.. By John Franklin Carter. 12mo. New York: Coward-McCann. $2.50.
GREATER values must be ap parent to the eye as the pub lic appraises the 1938 models with which the automobile industry has just launched its campaign for the forthcoming year.

Mark ing a new era dating from Genghis Khan, of which this is called the year 732, Suiyuan Province pro claimed yesterday its independence from China, its opposition to com munism, and its determination to establish a new government which will rule in accordance with the principles of the "kingly way" as displayed by the Government ofManchukuo.

The recovery in stock prices last week and the reversal of the down ward movement in speculative com modities has, to a certain extent, changed the attitude of industrial purchasing agents and inclined them to the belief that many mate rials are now in a "buying zone," according to opinions expressedhere yesterday.

Lawrenceville's football team defeated the Princeton freshman seconds, 12-0, in a hard-fought game today. Late in the first quarter Captain Rose tallied from the 7-yard line. In the second quarter Ellis inter cepted a pass on the 35-yard line and lateraled to Pearson, who went to the 14-yard marker before beingbrought down.
Kutztown and Montclair (N. J.) Teachers battled to a scoreless tie today on a muddy field. Kutztown threatened several times, once being halted on the Montclair 2yard line.
THOSE who write about rivers, and their number is on the rapid increase, tend to go moony in the presence of flowing water.

State High way Commissioner E. Donald Stern er announced today that applica tion would be made immediately to the War Department for a permit to build a new bridge to span the Raritan River as the final link for the elimination of the "Amboys bottleneck" through relocation of Routes 4 and 35 in Perth and SouthAmboy, Middlesex County.

Announcement has been made here by Mrs. Elizabeth Abbot Sargent of Pine Ridge Farm, Concord, Mass., and Chebaco Island, Essex, Mass., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Abbott Sargent, to John Sleeper Hartwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Martin Hartwell of Bronxville.

IN the 1938 cars, Hudson selective automatic shift transmission, which has led the procession in the growing trend toward automatic gear shifting, has many important new features. These make the transmission more completely au tomatic in its action than previously.

Under the auspices of the Inter national Statistical Bureau, a con ference will be held on Nov. 10 at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel to dis cuss the subject of the "Outlook for the Building and Construction Industries for 1938."

PHOTOGRAPHIC enlargement is now one of the chief aims of television research experts. Having achieved black and white pictures of 441-line texture on a 7 by 10 inch screen, the engi neers are concentrating on bigger pictures so that eventually a family may see the telepictures withouteye fatigue.

Professor Douglas Johnson, noted geologist, has been appointed head of the Department of Geology and Mineralogy at Columbia University, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, presi dent of the university, announced yesterday in a list of faculty ap pointments, resignations and leavesof absence.

The Japanese spokesman explained to day that no advances had been made in Shansi Province because the Japanese Army was consolidating its positions and bringing up men and supplies for the projected drivetoward Taiyuan.

Apparently there are still a More few things to find out about Child children. The identical twins Study on Amsterdam Avenue were reunited some time ago and the results compared as between con ditioned Jimmie and unconditionedJohnny.

The Department of Health of New York City has started a vigor ous campaign against pneumonia, which causes some 7,000 deaths a year in New York City, it was re vealed yesterday by Dr. John L.Rice, Health Commissioner.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23,--Mrs. Elizabeth Browning Donner Roosevelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Donner and former wife of Elliott Roosevelt, second son of the President, was married at noon today to Curtin Winsor, son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Winsor Jr. of Hedgeley, Ardmore.

While in many districts retail sales continued to show gains over those of a year ago, wholesale vol ume in most markets was spotty and there was continued evidence of curtailment of industrial operations.

Several important changes in the business section of this village are under way, including a five-year lease under which the Strauss Stores' auto supply unit, which has occu pied the premises at 98 West Main Street for a number of years, will take over a store in the AckerlyBuilding at 89-91 East Main Street.
With Merlin Hathaway the spear head of an effective running at tack, Cortland Normal trampled the Stroudsburg (Pa) State Teach er's College, 28 to 0, in a homecoming game today.

The "greyjackets" of the Seventh Regiment, New York National Guard, will give their annual Fall military ball on Dec. 4 in the regi mental armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The theme for this year's event will be "Mexican Fiesta" and the huge drill shed of the armory will be transformed for the occasion into a reproduction of the market place of a Mexican village.

Senator Steiwer, Republican, and New Deal critic, :who has served in Congress for ten years, said to day that he had decided not to seek re-election next year. Mr. Steiwer, who was the keynote speaker at the last Republican Na tional Convention, will resume practice of law here.
D. An thony Usina, general patent attor ney of the United States Steel Cor poration, died last night in his home here. He was in his sixtyseventh year.

BRUSSELS, Belguim, Oct. 23--The Belgian press today predicted the early resignation of Premier Paul van Zeeland to facilitate theinvestigation of charges that he had accepted unwarranted payments from the national bank.

The Citizens Union yesterday recommended an affirmative vote on the proposed $40,000,000 bond issue for State hospitals and prisons and on the three proposed constitu tional amendments to lengthen the terms of the Governor, other State officers and Assemblymen and to allow sheriffs to succeed themselves.
Two of the tallest stained glass windows in the world will be installed in the University of Pittsburgh's Heinz Memorial chapel, starting nextweek.

The Federal Government is playing hide-and-seek with shrimp along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts. Agents are tagging the shrimp and trying to catch them a few months later to determine the wintering grounds and general movements of the shrimp, saidthe Bureau of Fisheries.

Hartwick College of Oneonta, N. Y., defeated Teachers College of Connecticut, 7 to 0, today. In the first play of the third period Smith threw a 15-yard pass to Hemens, who ran 35 yards for a touchdown, Savino kicking for theextra point.

Growing inter national confidence in Finance Min inter Georges Bonnet's direction of French finances was indicated by the announcement here tonight that a loan of 200,000,000 Swiss francs by Switzerland to the French railways was successfully subscribed.

The marriage of Miss Catherine Virginia Woodruff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burnett Woodruff of Flushing, to Richard Jones Mead, also of Flushing, son of Mrs. Elizabeth Jones Mead of Bingham ton, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Flushing.

Miss Minnie Fox Hopkins, daugh ter of the late Mrs. John F. Daniell, and of the late Russell Fox Hop kins, was married at St. James Church yesterday to Dr. Charles Louis Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Pierce Gilbert of Richmond, Va.
Almost all of the space allotted to the British Textile Exhibition has already been taken, according to announcement by the exhibitioncommittee.

Shading Rutgers in virtually every department of the gridiron sport but not in gameness and pluck, Princeton overpowered the Scarlet warriors, 6 to 0, in Palmer Stadium today in the thirty-fifth edition of intercollegiate football's oldest classic.

The Rensselaer Poly eleven held Union College to a 6-to-6 tie today in a driving rain. Andrews scored early in first period for R. P. I. after a series of penalties and Union's fumble of a punt gave the Engineers the ballon the 21.

A. B. Davis High School of this city took the lead in the West chester Interscholastic Athletic As sociation football race today by de feating Charles E. Gorton High of Yonkers, 13 to 0, marring the vis itors' previously unbeaten and untied record.

A return of 8.7 per cent for an- avia tion operating company should not be regarded as excessive in view of the frequent changes necessitated by government regulations and the rapid development of air naviga tion, Francis W. Brown, Air Ex aminer for the Interstate Commerce Commission, says in a report made public today. He held that thisprofit was not unreasonable.

The back yard garden of Mrs. Maximilian Elser at 136 West Eleventh Street, which recently won the prize offered by the Little Gardens Club for the best "back yard garden" in the Greenwich Vil lage section, is an instance of what can be accomplished with unprom ising material under city conditions that are often to some extent unjustly execrated by the gardener.

There were just two long runs in the forty-second renewal of the Hamilton-Rochester series today, but the invaders pushed across touchdowns in each case and also gained a safety on a poor pass from center to defeat Rochester,16 to 0.

Real estate in the Bronx, as a whole, is not overassessed, accord ing to Dominick A. Trotta, a mem ber of the Board of Taxes and As sessments, who points out that the assessed value of all Bronx proper ties as tentatively fixed for 1938amounts to $1,644,326,216. For 1937 the total assessment was $1,625,,918,151.

An amazing 39-yard placement kick of a soggy ball for a field goal by Fullback Dave Colwell in the first few minutes of play and a 68-yard dash for a touchdown by Captain Clinton Frank that ranks among the season's masterpieces of open field running gave Yale a clearly earned victory over Cornell in theBowl today.

Several curricula at New Jer sey College for Women were en riched by an increased tendency on the part of academic departments to coordinate their work which marked the past college year, ac cording to Miss Margaret T. Corwin, dean of the college.
Rice Institute's aggressive eleven again exerted a "jinx" over the University of Texas today, triumph ing the fourth year in a row overthe Longhorns, this time by 14-7.

Arch bishop Simeon died here today of pneumonia at the age of 98. Bul garia's oldest bishop, he was ap pointed Archbishop of Varna in 1872, when the country still was under Turkish domination. He played a prominent part in the struggle for independence. King Boris has postponed his tripabroad until after the funeral.
Phillips H. Lord, radio enter tainer, has purchased the old De Coppett estate consisting of 240 acres of land with a six-room Cape Cod house at Surry, Me., near BarHarbor.

THE pipe of peace which, under the leadership of the Stock Exchange, Wall Street lit three years ago with the Securities and Exchange Commis sion has gone out. The Bor ough of Deal, in Monmouth County, has been authorized by the State Funding Commission to issue $320, 000 bonds for construction of ocean front jetties. The commission made a survey last year before approv ing a similar application and foundthat an emergency existed.

Expressing confidence that the work of the State Mortgage Com mission will be completed next year, Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman, said yesterday that during the three months ended Sept. 1 the board had relinquished, through substitution of successor trustees or cash liqui dation, 506 series of guaranteed mortgage certificates amounting toabout $50,000,000.

Miss Nana Louise McKinney, daughter ,of Mr. and Mrs. William Scranton McKinney of Bala-Cynwyd and granddaughter of the late Louis Nana Megargee of this city, was married this afternoon to Donald Alexander Duncan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Alexander Duncanof Wynnefield.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Anna Parton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Taylor Parton of this city, to the Rev. John Mosher Mulligan, son of Ralph Richardson Mulligan, also of Yonkers, and the late Mrs. Mulligan, took place here this aft ernoon in St. Paul's EpiscopalChurch.

Members of the New York City visiting committee of the State Charities Aid Association will meet tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. Francis Rogers, 144 East Sixty-second Street, to discuss pre liminary plans for a benefit per formance of "Die Meistersinger" the afternoon of Jan. 14, at theMetropolitan Opera House.

A speedy and aggressive Williams College football team, making the most of its opponents' miscues, splashed its way today to a 13-to-0verdict over Tufts.

THE rim of Autumn foliage that only a few weeks ago formed a ragged border along the trim green forests below the snow line of the Austrian Alps has broadened until now each white peak is wearing a fancy dress of yellow splotched with red andgreen.

The engagement of Miss Margue rite Hannah Lyons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Lyons of this place and Falls Village, Conn., to James Joseph Kearney, son of Peter Kearney of Chicago, and the late Mrs. Kearney, has been announced by her parents.

Only galloping at 'the finish, Mrs. E. Friendly's Jacola outclassed ten other juvenile fillies today to cap ture the twelfth running of the Selima Stakes and bring her ownerthe winner's sha?? of $24,430.

MANY MANSIONS-Wednesday evening at the Biltmore Theatre. A play about a young liberal in the ministry, the authors being Jules Eckert Goodman and his son Eckert. The players will include Alexander Kirkland, Flora Campbell, Gage Clark,Harry Irvine, Seth Arnold and William Post Jr.
" Dry Hole Andy" Urban came back to Ranger Thursday and so did sev eral thousand others who knew this town in the days when it was the brightest spot on the map of fortune.

A torrential rainfall lifted one branch of the Anacostia River over the lowlands of Prince Georges County, Md., today, forcing more than 100 persons to flee from their homesand doing unestimated damage.

Kansas University's Jayhawkers put all their chips on a final aerial thrust today and stunned 15,000 fans when they came up with a 48 yard touchdown pass in the last ten seconds to defeat Oklahoma, 6to 3.

Miss Gertrude Laughlin, daughter of Irwin Laughlin, former Ambassa dor to Spain, and Mrs. Laughlin, was married here today to Lieu tenant Hubert Winthrop Chanler, U. S. N., son of Mrs. Winthrop Chanler of Geneseo, N. Y., and the late Mr. Chanler, in St. Paul'sChurch.

What British school children think of the United States is revealed in the analysis of a questionnaire, just made by the writer. Influenced mainly by Hollywood and by their school training, boys and girls be tween the ages of 13 and 16 have extreme ideas on the prevalence of racketeering in the United States, on the language spoken by Amer icans, and on our worship of sports,wealth and tremendous speed.

Tammany and the supporters of Mayor La Guardia fought bitterly last week for the votes of organ ized labor-estimated in impartial quarters at about 750,000, disregard ing the influence the workingman might have on his wife, his brotherand other relatives.
SHORT-WAVE stations at Sche nectady will broadcast daily news reports to "Americans, re gardless of what far corner of the world they may be in," beginningNov. 1.

A sustained march of 76 yards down muddy Garcelon Field by the Bates eleven led to a touchdown at the beginning of the second period to give the Bobcats a 7-0 triumph over the University of Maine in a Stateseries game today.

Mrs. Julian P. Fairchild of 45 East Sixty-second Street has an nounced the engagement of her stepdaughter, Miss Helen Louise Fairchild, to Stanley Edward Young Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs.Young of Ossining, N. Y.

In nose finishes that brought thousands rushing to the rails re gardless of the sweeping rain, Thorson and Chaps were the stake winners yesterday at Empire City in the $10,050 Yorktown and $8,100Ardsley Handicaps respectively.

The New York Aggies won their third consecutive game, defeating Hofstra College today by 12-6. Both tallies for the Aggies came in the second period, the first on an end run by Goldenberg and the second as the result of a 30-yardpass from Kaplan to French.

Current shipments of Florida's crop of oranges and grapefruit are of improved quality. Fine medium sized oranges are selling here now at about 3 cents, a drop from the price a week ago of 5 cents each.Grapefruit in good quality ranges in price from 5 to 7 centseach, according to size.

Senator A. Harry Moore will speak on the economic situation in the United States at a luncheon meeting of the Maplewood Woman's Club on Wednesday. Others on the program arranged by the inter national relations and legislationdepartments are Dr. Laurence J.

Gardenmakers who wish to have a singing note of blue in the burst of Spring color for next season may still make sure of it. All that is necessary is to plant now a few dozen (or a few hundred, for the expense is little) of the several early little bulbs that bring a bluebird tint to the vernal landscape.

Fu neral services for Rear Admiral Purnell F. Harrington, U.S.N. (re tired), who died Wednesday at the age of 93, were held today at the home, 20 Dudley Place, here. Burial will be in Silver Lake Cemetery,Dover, Del., on Monday.

The Fine Arts Department of the College of William and Mary will present the first play of the year next Thursday and Friday evenings in the Phi Beta Kappa Memorial Hall. The production will be Ayn Rand's "The Night of January16th."
THE entrance to the "whistling" cavern at Wind Cave National Park, South Dakota, has re cently been improved and beauti fied by Civilian Conservation Corps members of the National ParkService.

Domestic customers served by the manufacturing and natural gas public utility companies throughout the country numbered 15,816,700 on Aug. 31, an increase of 252,000 dur ing the first eight months of this year, according to an announce ment yesterday by Paul Ryan, chief statistician of the AmericanGas Association.

St Peter's Prep School took another step in the direction of the Hudson County football championship today by toppling Memorial's eleven of West New York, 12 to 0, for its third straight triumph. Dick Hig gins ran 65 yards for a touchdown in the second period to feature thegame.

The death of two newsreel photographers in a transcontinental airplane crash last week, while they were out to film a story on "the safety of flying," ironically raised the question: Just howsafe is flying on the scheduled airways of the United States?

A section of a coat of arms carved on the river frontage of the British Mouse of Parliament has been pre sented to the School of Journalism of Missouri University by Reuters, a news-gathering association of Great Britain, reports the university.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Bruce Stuart of South Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Elinor Stuart, to Kenneth Charles Ruffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Ruffman of Lovaine, Elm field Park, Gosforth, Newcastleupon Tyne, England.

Miss Lilian Wing Burrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Loomis Burrell of this place, was married here this evening in the First Presbyterian Church to Edwin Morgan Fisher, son of- Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin James Fisher of Utica. The cere money was performed by the pastor,the Rev. J., Harold Thomson.

Helen Keller, celebrated blind and deaf teacher of the blind, was honored last night in Carnegie Hall at a special concert given under the auspices. of the American Foundation for the Blind by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eu gene Ormandy, with Sergei Rach maninoff, Russian pianist, as soloist. ABEL-RATETT-Mr. and Mrs. M. Ratett of Mount Kisco. N. Y., announce the engagement of their daughter, Josephine, to Mr. Bernard J. Abel, son of Mrs. Sarah Abel of the same city. BREGMAN--OSTERMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Osterman of 790 Riverside Drive announce the engagement of their daughter, Shirley, to Mr. Elmer Bregman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lew Bregman.

The Manhattan cross-country team opened its season yesterday morning by defeating Penn State, 20 to 35, in a five-mile run over the rain-drenched paths of Van Cort landt Park. Tom Tynan, Jasper sophomore, led Frank Maule, Penn State sophomore, home by 100vards.

Publication of the official order that henceforth the eighteen largest independent and emergency government agencies shall take their problems to James Roosevelt instead of directly to the President makes generally known what has long been no secret in Washington. This is the very great in fluence and importance of the President's eldest son and secretary,and Mr. Roosevelt's high estimate of his abilities.

Border reports that General Saturnino Ce dillo has revolted against the Fed eral Government in the State of San Luis Potosi are untrue, it was learned in a telephonic conversa tion with the State capital this evening.

PRACTICALLY every year at the Automobile Show some one says to me, "What more can you do to improve cars? They seem just about perfect now." My usual answer is, "Well, I hope they're not. If they are, I'll be outof a job."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently, a tramp came to my house and asked for food. As he ate, I talked to him. He had ridden the freights from Colorado to California, and back as far as El Paso, looking for work, but had found none. He was on his way hometo try to get back on the WRA.
The Pure Oil Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, net earnings in excess of $9,000,000, after all charges, compared with $4,800,000 for the corresponding period of1936.

Dean Margaret Morriss of Pem broke College, Brown University, national president of the American Association of University Women, will speak at a luncheon of the New York branch, to be given on Saturday in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. Her topic will be "University Women as Leadersin American Life."

NATIVE Yugoslav wind instru ments are discussed in a new book, "Wind Instru ments With Vibrating Reeds," by Dr. Bozidar Sirola, just pub lished in Zagreb. In this work the musicologist, who has writ ten many dissertations on the folk music of Yugoslavia, is speciallyconcerned with the "diple,"

IL piu bel teatro d'Italia." That was Guido Salvini's verdict when your correspondent que ried him on the ancient Teatro Olimpico (1585) of this city, where he had just mounted "The Seven Against Thebes" (Aeschylus), withmusic by Arrigo Pedrollo.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Departmentof Agriculture, follow:
Recent changes in the curriculum at Amherst College have followed the current trend toward a greater em phasis of the social sciences even in a college of strong classical traditions.

A FIVE-HOUR program on the air today from 1:15 to 6:30 o'clock will celebrate the opening of the new transmitter and studios of WNYC, identified on the air as "the Municipal Stationof the City of New York."

District Attorney Buron Fitts, Los Angeles county prosecutor, wants a body guard, but only applicants 6 feet 5 inches in height, 227 pounds in weight or over and forty inches inchest expansion need apply.
A daylight robbery several days ago in the apartment of Henry M. Bankhead, commercial attache of the United States Legation, wasdisclosed today by police.
Theos Bernard, American Bud dhist scholar, has arrived at Kal impong from Lhasa, where he was an honored guest of the Tibetan Government for somemonths. His original intention

An early 55-yard touchdown dash by Seymour gave Andover a 7-6 victory over the Harvard freshmen on a rain-swept gridiron today. Andover kicked off and, after two unsuccessful attempts at rushing, the Harvard cubs punted to Andover's 45.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Demo cratic candidate for Mayor, pledged himself last night to cleanse the Democratic organization in New York City and the city administra tion of grafters "when I am elect ed." Mr. Mahoney made the pledge at a dinner of the Italian-American Democratic Campaign Committee at the Hotel Commodore attendedby more than 1,800 persons.

Westchester Check clearings through the West chester County Clearing House As sociation in the week ended on Fri day amounted to $3,092,402 against $3,267,028 the week before and$2,452,702 a year ago.

A roaring gale swept a wide area of Great Britain today, lashing 40-foot waves over some sections of the southern coast and forced a shipping tie-up. The Channel Islands were cut off from the mainland when the sub marine cable snapped, shutting off all telephone and telegraph com munication. At Portsmouth boats were washed to the center of thecity.

The Earl of Derby, wartime colleague of David Lloyd George, revolted today against the former Prime Minister's speech of last week, in which he demanded that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden "stand up for what he reallybelieves."

The "practical projects" of the course in State and local govern ment of the division of social stud dies at Union College were started this week when the first two of the year's series of governmental execu tives and legislative and judicial experts visited the campus to speakwith the students in the course.

THIS novel by Georges Bernanos (who was already a winner of the Femina Prize) has been awarded the Grand Prix of the Academie Francaise, has naturally been very widely read in France and has been translated into four otherlanguages In an English translation
MINING is booming in Can ada's North West Territo ries, not so long ago con sidered too remote for com mercial exploitation except by thefur trade.

The marriage of Miss Frances Wade Salmon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Salmon of Manila, P. I., to Andrew Bell Black, also of Ma nila, took place this afternoon at the home of Dr. and Mrs. GeorgeE. Kanouse here. The ceremony,

THE symphonic associations have begun their annual se ries of concerts. Crowded Into Saturdays and Sundays during the Winter will be the weekly and biweekly programs of six and sometimes seven orchestras, given, all of them, in the form ofafternoon concerts.

Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Perry of this place have announced the engagement of Mrs. Perry's daughter, Miss Mar garet Ruth Adams, to Dr. William L. Peltz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. L. Peltz of Albany, N. Y.

Remodeling of the oldest landmark on the Wellesley College campus has provided completely modern quarters for the department of geology and geography, the last to escape the cramping and incon venience of the reconstruction period of Wellesley's history.

MUNICH-The city of Constance has completed its plan for the illu mination of the entire German side of Lake Constance. The row of lights along the lake front com mences at about one and a quarter miles beyond the city limits and continues along the north shore and the entire length of Adolf Hitler Strasse as far as the bridge overthe Rhine.

The more than fifty years of service which James Colby Colgate of New York City has given to Colgate Uni versity was commemorated here to day with the dedication of the new $250,000 James C. Colgate StudentUnion Building named in his honor.

In return for the vacating of several old "paper" streets in the Eliza beth meadow area dating from pre Revolutionary times, Elizabeth has received a deed from the Central Railroad of New Jersey and E. J. Grassmann to a proposed eighty foot highway. which will aid the development of the meadow tract for industrial purposes, after it has been improved under a $235,500WPA grading project.

How does President Roosevelt. now feel toward business? This question ab sorbed Washington and the rest of the country this week-a week which was ushered in with a big stock-market drop and a revised budget estimate indicating a greater government deficit for the present fiscal year than had been expectedlast April.

A dramatic story of the advance made in women's clubs, as repre sented by one of the largest metro politan groups, will be unfolded on Tuesday evening when the Amer ican Woman's Association marksits first quarter-century milestone.

After one of the most brilliant ly contested open all-age stakes in the fourteen years of the English Springer Spaniel Trial Association, Hollybrook Abandon tonight was awarded first prize in the chiefevent of the annual meeting.

Many votaries of rare plants have been interested to see in flower during the past week a specimen of the Golden Lycoris-reportedly the first to be shown in this coun try within a quarter of a century. Unlike many rare botanical plants, the Golden Lycoris is not merely a horticultural curiosity but a flowerof unusual beauty.
IT has been suggested on vari ous occasions that a really good play should be greeted by dancing on the sidewalk. If a really good novel is to bereceived in the same manner,
French Colonial forces were reinforced tonight to guard against native agitation after put ting down a riot of Moroccan Na tionalists in the strategic northerntown of Khemisset.

While temperatures hovered in the chilly 30s, the highland sec tions ofWest Virginia were covered by the season's first big snow to day. Nearly every section in the moun tains had from two to six inches of snow. The Sewell Mountain sec tion of Fayette County had six inches of snow and road commis sion crews were called out to openthe highway.

Recent stock market conditions have had an adverse effect to some extent on Westchester County real estate activities, according to Al bert W. Lockyer, retiring president of the Westchester County RealtyBoard.

IF this unusually late beginning of the Fall season is in any way indicative of the rest of the year's dramatic offerings, I may safely predict a boom for theGerman stage.

A quarter century of charitable activities will be commemorated by the Women's Auxiliary of the New York Inner Mission Society with a dinner Wednesday evening at Schrafft's, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street, when over a hundred women will hear a review of the group's family welfare work.

California's Golden Bears sounded another challenge today in their drive toward national football championship recognition with a stunning 20-to-6 victory over the University of Southern California'sTrojans.

Speaking of the recent decline in stock market prices and the busi ness recession at the convention in Pittsburgh last week of the Na tional Association of Real Estate Boards, Joseph H. Greenberg of Philadelphia said he felt these con ditions were merely temporary and that a more prosperous outlookwould soon appear.
Scoring twice in each of the first three periods and keeping their own goal line clear through out the game, William and Mary downed American University, 38 to0, today.

Mrs. Lewis Thurston Reed, wife of the general secretary of the pen sion boards of the Congregational and Christian Churches of the Unit ed States, and herself an active church and social worker for nearly forty years, died yesterday morning in Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Reed. who was 67 years old, lived at 39Fifth Avenue.

The engagement of Miss Clare Killeen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward V. Killeen of 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, to William Hamilton Sullivan, son of Frederick B. Sullivan, also of Brooklyn, and of Allenhurst, N. J., and the late Mrs. Sullivan, has been announcedby her parents.

Mr. Roosevelt's tribute to the found ers of the Federal Reserve, at Wednes day's dedication of the system's new Washington headquarters, properly de scribed a momentous episode in ourlegislative history.
After being trounced by both Harvard and Dartmouth, the Brown Bears rose on their hind legs on. Baker Field yesterday and clawed out a sensational and surprisingvictory over Columbia's Lions.

A new type of curriculum and classroom teaching technique de signed to meet the needs of emo tionally sick children who do not like school is being evolved here through an experiment with 600 pre-delinquent boys in the elemen tary grades, Dr. Benjamin B. Green berg, Assistant Superintendent ofSchools, disclosed yesterday.

The New York Football Giants, seeking to strengthen their hold on first place in the Eastern division of the National League, will clash with the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds this afternoon withthe kick-off scheduled for 2:30.

The marriage of Miss Edith Louise Muller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frederick Muller of Englewood, N. J., to Lieutenant Robert Hall Safford, U. S. A., of Fort Hoyle, Md., son of Roby How ard Safford of Leominster, Mass., and the late Mrs. Safford, took place here last evening in All Angels Church, West End Avenueand Eighty-first Street.
The farmer feeds the fleet, the navy noted today in a Navy Day sug gestion that agriculture has aheavy stake in its welfare.

M.; "American Painting After 1850" (Tour of Collections), Edith R. Abbot, 3:15 P. M.

A candle was lighted, then extin guished, in memory of Felix M. Warburg, at the forty-first annual dinner of the Home of the Daugh ters of Jacob at the Waldorf Astoria last night. Twelve hundredpersons were present.

As the re sult of a remarkable showing under adverse weather conditions, Win gam Boots, owned by Jay F. Car lisle, today captured the Members' Stake in the sixteenth annual Au tumn field trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association held over the course of the Brentwoodflying field.

Reorders continued to arrive in fair volume in the New York whole sale market last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, and arriving buyers reported satisfactory gains at retail, in line with their revisedFail schedules.

OPENING the way for radio experimenters to push up to the frontier of micro-waves, the Federal Communications Commission has announced it will allocate waves to various classes of services in the ethereal spectrumfrom 10 to 300,000 kilocycles.

THE literary birthday of a heroine who made her home here in real life and then gained immortality in the lines of a poem will be celebrated in this town on Oct. 30, the ninetieth anniversary of the publication of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's"Evangeline."

Auburn, midseason surprise package of the Southeastern Conference, downed Georgia Tech, 21 to 0, before 19,000 shivering fans at Grant Field today. Led by Henry Kelly, the Plainsmen won their fourth straight gamefrom the Engineers.

Asserting that "the city needs La Guardia" and that "one good term deserves another," Samuel Seabury declared last night that the Mayor had "converted the city govern ment from a den of thieves into a source from which humanitarian activities radiate." Mr. Seaburyspoke over radio station WOR.

Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas of New port is at the St. Regis for the Winter. Mrs. J. Griswold Webb and her daughter, Miss Leila G. Webb, who arrived yesterday from the G M Ranch, Dubois, Wyo., are at thePierre.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Earl Thomas, substitute back from New York City, raced 95 yards to a touchdown to give Peddie School of Hightstown, N. J., a thrilling 7-7 tie with Hun School of Princeton today. The game was played on a field so mud-soaked that neitherteam tried a forward pass.

With the arrival of crisp Autumn days, hiking again becomes popu lar in the 45,000 woodland acres and along the shores of the thirty eight lakes of the reservation ad ministered by the Palisades Interstate Park Commissioners.

A TEREE-DAY celebration will begin next Friday morning, ending literally in blazes of glory on Sunday night, to mark the completion of the seven teen-and-a-half-mile Darwin cut off on the 150-mile road connecting Death Valley, 279 feet below sea level, with Mount Whitney, 14,496feet high.
Martin J. Coen Jr., 32 years old, Deputy District Attorney of Santa Barbara County and presi dent of the East Side Social Center, died at St. Francis Hospital
LISTED below in alphabetical order are descriptions of the new 1938 cars as furnished by the manufacturers. The line-up of cars for this year's show is somewhat different from 1937's.
LONDON.-Irishmen seeking a new land of promise are now flock ing to England in waves almost as great as those which at one timemoved on the United States.
LAST December the President's son was cured of a septic sore throat, which might have caused his death, by a patented German compound whichwas a form of sulphanilamide.

THE automobile has largely built our age. Our goods are moved by it, the business of cities is founded on it, great industries have grown from it, mil lions find employment because of it. It takes us on pleasure bent, and our armies move on wheels drivenby motors.

Presi dent Roosevelt and the Democratic National Committee will not active ly oppose the renomination of Sen ators and others who fought the Administration's court plan, but will not be disappointed if thesemen are defeated.

Sales of pianos in the South, espe cially in the Carolinas, have ex panded sharply in the last few months, it was reported yesterday. Salesmen recently returned from Southern trips have booked busi ness on new pianos about 40 percent ahead of that of a year ago,

Fantastic ornaments to lend height and importance to the eve ning coiffure, and to dramatize the whole evening ensemble, are very much the vogue of the moment. Women seem to have got over their original resistance to them; the more elaborate the ornaments arethe better they like them.

Ohio State knocked Northwestern from the heights of the unbeaten teams today, winning, 7 to 0, and practi cally erasing the 1936 Big Ten cham pions from the title picture. The victory, achieved before 67,521 fans, kept the Ohio slate clean for twoWestern Conference games.

Twenty-four States and the Dis trict of Columbia reported an in creased death rate due to tuber culosis for 1936 over 1935, Dr. Ken dall Emerson, managing director of the National Tuberculosis Association, announced yesterday.

Uncle Sam, who during the past decade or so has been increasingly atten tive to a large number of the in dividual activities of his fellow-citi zens, has warrant of late in adding the appellation ticker watchman tohis long list of titles.

Open threats against Czechoslovakia made this week by the official German press in a propaganda attack were ascribed in Central Europe to Ger many's new sense of security on the Western front resulting from her declaration promising to re spect Belgium's neutrality in con formity with the new Belgian policy of diplomatic independence.

An effort to win the U. S. Government's support for the evacuation of families of Asturian miners and other anti Fascists in the predominantly Loy alist Asturias district will be made by Representatives Jerry J. O'Con nell of Montana and John T. Ber nard of Minnesota, they said yesterday or leaving Madrid.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Elizabeth Ritter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. P. Ritter of South Orange, to Barth F. Mon aghan, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. F. Monaghan of South Orange, took place this morning in the Church of the Holy Comforter, Rahway. The Rev. R. W. Elliott performedthe ceremony.

Miss Emily Estelle Blaine, daugh ter of Mrs. Anthony P. Blaine of Elmhurst, Queens, formerly of Toronto, and the late Mr. Blaine, was married to Edwin Kendall Cliver, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard Cliver of Asbury Park,N. J., here last night in the Park

Miss Lois Bliss Pratt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kirby C. Pratt of West Hartford, and Newton Fred erick Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Percy Clark of Hartford were married here this afternoon at the Asylum Avenue BaptistChurch.

A State-wide conference on the care of dependent and retarded children will be held Friday at the North Jersey Training School at Totawa, by the child welfare and social hygiene departments of the New Jersey League of WomenVoters. Miss Jane M. Hoey,

Coincidental with the eighty-fourth anniversary of the turning of the first sod for the European North American Railway, New Bruns wick's first railway, the city of St. John witnessed another event in the transportation history of the Province when the latest innovation in land transport, the auto-railer, made its first appearance in regular service over the Canadian Nationalbetween St. John and Moncton.

Special Rackets Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey disclosed last night that the La Guardia forces had arranged to have a "tough gang" of 2,000 longshoremen, hat pullers and others from among their labor supporters on hand on elec tion day to make sure there is no vote stealing by thugs working forthe political machines.

THE primitive industries that made New Salem, Ill., a pioneer center when Abra ham Lincoln was a young man, are being restored today by the CCC. When the work is com pleted, wheels will hum as in the early nineteenth century, making it easier for visitors of today to visualize the New Salem of yesterday.

Among the changes in university organiza tion made by President Seymour of Yale since he assumed office the appointment of a standing commit tee on educational planning is feltby many to rank as foremost.

ONE of French Switzerland's characteristic enterprises in folk theatricals, second only to the Theatre du Jorat at Mezieres, is the dramatic company of the Thea atre Valaisan, at Finhaut. Founded in 1933, by Chanoine Louis Poncet, with the musical collaboration ofChanoine Broquet, this native

Mrs. Berton J. Delmhorst heads the junior committee for the bridge party to be held on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 4 for the benefit of the Wil loughby House Settlement. Her aides include Mrs. Charles Perkinand Miss Virginia Felter.
Athletics for all is the major aim of the $1,650,000 alumni program for comprehensive development of new recreational facilities for stu dents of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Looms and spindles in actual op eration, collections of period cos tumes and decorations, and demon strations of various hand crafts will be housed in a Hall of Textiles at the New York World's Fair, ac cording to plans for the building made public yesterday by GroverA. Whalen, president of the fair.
The clatter of a riveting hammer will sound the keynote of a nation wide observation of Navy Day-an niversary of the birth of TheodoreRoosevelt-next Wednesday.

THAT amazing "other world," the domain of the insects, has entertained curious hu man visitors for centuries. But this is the first generation in which people in general have taken insect colonies into their ownhomes to study and enjoy.

An apartment house under con struction on the East Side that is attracting attention because of its unusual design is the twelve-story structure being put up at 25 East Eighty-third Street, northwest cor ner of Madison Avenue, by the Lusk Operating Corporation, owner.

West Virginia University turned back Waynesburg College today, 13--0, scoring touchdowns in the third and fourth period, on a muddy field. Sammy Pinion, midget half back, scored both times for theMountaineers.

The marriage of Miss Mary E. McDermott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McDermott of this city, to Daniel A. Lynch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Lynch, also of New York, took place yes terday morning in the Church of the Holy Spirit. The Rev. WilliamCrowley performed the ceremony.

A shortage impends in the supply of FHA insured mortgages available for investment purposes and in creasingly higher premiums are im minent as a result, states A. L. Moon of A. W. Benkert Co., Inc.,stockbrokers.

INNOVATION and improvement are at the very roots of business stimulation. That is why the new models. at the automobile show are fundamentally connected with the energy that keeps the wheelsof business turning.

Miss Eldora Van Buren, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Deyo of this city, was married to Lucas Boeve Jr., son of Mrs. Lucas Boeve of Arlington, Va., and the late Dr. Boeve, this afternoon in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Robert Gardner Mc Gregor. A reception at the VanBuren home followed the ceremony.

Spanish Government sailors re ported today how Insurgent planes sank the government destroyer Ciscar in Gijon harbor in a violent aerial bombardment. The refugees arrived here in the Spanish Government launch Mitote.

Charging that she had paid $66,000 blackmail in an unsuccessful effort to keep the German Government from confiscating her entire property holdings of more than $1,000,000 a German Jewish expatriate appeared in Felony Court yesterday against her own first cousin when he was arraigned on a charge of suspicion of extortion.

John E. King, active in Democratic circles in Central Queens, died on Friday at his home, 87-03 166th Street, Jamaica, after a two weeks illness. His age was 41. He was a former president of the now defunct Cosmopolitan Democratic Association of Jamaica.

A fault by the last horse on the final jump of the three-day competition cost the American Army team the InterAmerican Horse Show's military jumping championship today as the Belgian cavalry officers rode to a 65 3/4 to 67 triumph.

The tendency to put too much faith in legislation as a cure for the liquor evil was condemned yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

An 18-year-old youth who said he sailed alone blindly for two days and three nights, living on crackers, was arrested early today after a 38-foot yacht police charge he stole struck a breakwater and sank in a forty-mile gale. He was booked as Robert T. Johnson of Braintree.
Mrs. Joseph Zubow of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sylvia Zubow, to Dr. Jules David Gordon, son of Mrs. Samuel I. Gordon, also of New York.
General Alberto Enriquez, new "Supreme Chief" of Ecuador, today decreed the establishment of a popular tribunal of justice to deal with persons charged with tampering with public funds.

W. C. McGonagle, Treasurer of the Territory of Hawaii, announced yesterday that the Territory proposed to redeem on Nov. 15 an issue of $1,500,000 of 4 per cent public-improvement bonds due in 1947. The bonds may be presented for payment at the office of the Treasurer in Honolulu, or at the office of the Bankers Trust Company here.

The "free use of firearms" by the police at Ponce, Puerto Rico, on March 21, in which nineteen were killed and more than 100 wounded, "indicates a trend that may have unfortunate repercussions not only on Washington's relations with Puerto Rico, but those with Latin America as well," according to Earle K. James in a Foreign Policy Association report made public today. Mr. James recently returned from Puerto Rico.

Young Fred B. Snite Jr., the man in the iron lung, was allowed today for the first time since his arrival Wednesday to see the girl to whom he was engaged when he was stricken with infantile paralysis eighteen months ago.

Any sportsman knows better than to bag a hen pheasant, but Charles Wells of Columbus did it unintentionally today when one of the female game birds crashed through the windshield of his car on State Highway 39 near here.
Ingot steel out-I put in Germany in September amounted to 1,690,500 tons, and for the first nine months of 1937 the total was 14,552,600, compared with 14,487,900 in the same period in 1936.
The New Jersey Beagle Club's field trials were marred by rain and poor scenting conditions today, the second of the meeting.

The official September estimate of German crops shows slightly larger yields to the hectare of Winter wheat and rye than given in the August estimate, and considerably larger yields of barley and oats.

Two proclamations designating Wednesday next as Theodore Roosevelt Day and Navy Day were issued today by Governor Lehman. For the observance of Roosevelt Day, he directed that flags be flown from all State buildings and urged the same for homes and places of business. As a part of the observance of Navy Day, the Governor requested citizens to visit ships of the navy wherever possible.

The British freighter Kaitangata, loaded with a cargo of gasoline, burst into flames last night after leaving Hong Kong for Haiphong, French Indo-China. The British destroyer Thracian was dispatched to aid the burning vessel after receipt of a distress signal giving the Kaitangata's position as "somewhere in the South China Sea."

Champion Nancolleth Marquis, graceful moving liver and white pointer owned by Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge's Giralda Farms of Iadison and handled by McClure Halley, took bestin-show laurels as the twenty-fifth annual all-breed exhibition of the Newark Kennel Club was concluded at the Centre Market Building tonight.

The smashing of several Jewish-owned shops and attacks on Jewish traders yesterday marked the climax of the antiSemitic drive ordered by the Danzig Nazi leader, Albert Foerster, in his closing speech at a Nazi party convention here a fortnight ago.

The Tonopah Mining Company of Nevada has made a contract with the government to increase its mining operations on the East Coast of Nicaragua, near Siuna in the district of Prinza Polca, Department of Zelaya.

Establishment of an institute, headed by renowned scientists, to be devoted exclusively to research in cancer and instruction in methods of combating the disease was announced today by Dr. Max Cutler. To be known as the Chicago Tumor Institute, it will open March 1.

Savings by the city on rentals and realty purchases were effected in the one year Fusion had the office of Controller. Joseph D. McGoldrick, Fusion nominee for the post, declared last night at the Forum of the Fusioneers in the Y. M. H. A., Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue.

The engagement of Miss Pauline Louise duPont to Alfred C. Harrison 3d, son of W. Frazier Harrison of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and Mrs. Louis C. Clark of New York, was announced here today by the brideelect's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Francis duPont.

Dr. and Mrs. James T. Shotwell of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret Grace Shotwell, to Llewelyn L. B. Summers, son of Mrs. Leland Lafflin Summers of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Mr. Summers, which took place on Saturday afternoon at Cluaran, the Shotwell country home in Woodstock, N. Y.

Stocks weakened again and were lower on the week after recovering sharply from earlier crash; turnover, 22,165,791 shares, largest since 1934. All groups of bonds lower after rallying in the week; transactions, $84,500,500.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Nannes of 110 West Sixty-ninth Street, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Nannes's daughter, Miss Maxine Harriet Bruenn, to Sander T. Heyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Heyman of Brooklyn.
It has been many years since the security and commodity markets have experienced movements comparable to the violent fluctuations of the last week.

The marriage of Miss Peggy Schwarz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Schwarz, to Edwin H. Stern Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stern of 1,009 Park Avenue, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 1,125 Park Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise.

Contributions received to date in the $200,000 campaign of the Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York will be made known today at a luncheon of 400 women campaign workers at the Central Branch, 610 Lexington Avenue.

Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of the American Social Hygiene Association, announced last night that General John J. Pershing had agreed to serve as chairman of the organization's national anti-syphilis committee.

Plans were announced yesterday for a nation-wide campaign for $1,000,000 to carry on the activities of Yeshiva, American institution for higher Jewish learning, and Yeshiva College, a college of arts and sciences, both of which are situated at Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.

Bishop Francis K. McConnell, superintendent of the New York Methodist Area and president of the Methodist Board of Foreign Missions, will deliver an address on "Social and Religious Change Through Twenty-five Years" at the mass meeting of Methodists

Three dance performances competed for attention last night and, in spite of their rivalry, all managed to attract comfortably filled houses, and one of them, the season's farewell of Harold Kreutzberg at the Guild Theatre, played to absolute capacity and many standees.

Opponents of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens are planning to release a flood of false and misleading statements against him, John J. Halleran, Commissioner of Public Works and independent Democratic leader, declared yesterday.
The Rev. John E. Healy preached the sermon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, 323 East Sixtyfirst Street, in celebration of the golden jubilee of the church.

Cotton prices declined further last week, although they displayed more stability than in most weeks for several months. Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange tended to seesaw in most of the trading sessions, with the result that net daily changes were small.

Among the passengers to arrive here today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen are the Duchess of Westminster, Harrison Williams, financier; W. Ledyard Mitchell, Lady Cathleen Rollo, Leslie Charteris, British author;

The Atlas Powder Company reports for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $1,264,310, equal, after preferred dividends, to $4,03 a common share, compared with $1,113,738, or $3.28 a share for the same period in 1936. Earnings for the 1937 period include provision for the surtax and undistributed profits tax.
Spencer Overton of the Rolling Road Country Club, Baltimore, won the first annual invitation tournament of the Seaview Golf Club today.

While admitting disagreements with the Mayor, Park Commissioner Robert Moses last night urged the re-election of Mr. La Guardia over station WJZ. "As to differences between the Mayor and myself, they have existed and no doubt will continue to exist so long as we are associated," Mr. Moses said.

JUST breathe deeply and relax. But it was a stunning Saturday, wasn't it? Simply stunning! Somebody should watch that man Lou Little. He may want to get away from it all. Brown was supposed to be deep-dish apple pie for hungry huskies in Columbia uniforms. But what happened? Don't mention it. Not on Morningside Heights, anyway.
With the completion of the puppy and members' all-age stake today, the fourteenth annual fieldtrial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association came to a close.

A continuance of the demand for apartments in houses on the East and West Sides was indicated in lists of new tenancies announced over the week-end by brokers and renting agents. The brisk renting is keeping up well beyond the seasonal Fall rush.

The Presbyterian Church, with 317 entering students at Cornell University expressing a preference for that denomination, leads all others in a comparison of religious preferences compiled annually by the Cornell United Religious Work.

The steel industry in 1937 granted vacations with pay to approximately 300,000 wage-earners at an added payroll cost of $12,000,000 to the companies, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, turned yesterday to the record of Paul Blan shard, Commissioner of Accounts, to support his charge that the La Guardia administration was linked to the Communist party.

With the American delegation on its way to take part in the Nine Power Conference at Brussels, the extent to which the United States is likely to influence the course of events in what is rapidly becoming a world battle between the practices of democracy and dictatorship, becomes of more than passing interest.

Royal Ulster Rifleman W. Mae. Gowan, 27 years old, was killed by machine-gun fire from a Japanese pursuit plane at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon at a British defense 'outpost in Keswick Road near Tunsin Road in the western foreign residential district of Shanghai.

Maxfield's Onaway Beau, a white and black English setter owned and handled by T. O. Maxfield of Maplewood, N. J., ran a spectacular race over the Brentwood Flying Field course today to capture the open all-age stake which climaxed the field trials of the Brookhaven Game and Protective Association.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 80.7 on Oct. 20, compared with 81.6 a fortnight before, 82.2 a month previously and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Moses Reis, owner of one of the largest chains of legitimate theatres in the country before the motion pictures brought a new era in public entertainment, died of bronchial pneumonia at his home, 817 West End Avenue, Saturday afternoon after a short illness. His age was 87.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Europe on the Cunard White Star motorship Georgic was Herbert J. Seligman, director of public information of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, who has been studying conditions in Eastern Europe, including Poland, Rumania and Latvia.

In memory of Felix M. Warburg, who died last week, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra played the Dirge from Edward MacDowell's "Indian Suite" yesterday afternoon at its Carnegie Hall concert. Mr. Warburg had been a member of the board of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.

As a belated effect of the Wall Street recovery of Tuesday, the stock market here became active and strong in the second half of this week. As a market factor, the compromise reached at London concerning volunteers in Spain played only a secondary part.

Trustworthy sources reported today that more than 300 persons were killed ten. days ago in outbreaks along the Haitian-Dominican frontier. An equal number was said to have been wounded; Most of the victims were Haitians.

On successive days, first as regards Czechoslovakia and then in Danzig, Germany has acted with challenging boldness, apparently confident that no country or combination of countries will take up the gage.

With more than 150 entries firing, the Fall matches of the Veteran Military Rifle Association of Manhattan were run off here today on the Camp Smith range. Four individual, one special and three team matches were shot under the direction of Colonel Edward H. Snyder.

Fire of undetermined origin destroyed this morning the 166-yearold building of the First Reformed Church of Pompton Plains, one of New Jersey's famous Colonial churches, which celebrated the 200th anniversary of its organization last year. The pastor, the Rev.

The German wholesale price index on Oct. 13 stood at 105.9, against 106 a week before. In the first nine months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

The placing of a loan of $3,750,000 at 4 per cent on the Stone Webster Building at 90 Broad Street was announced by the Paul Hammond Company, brokers. This is an extension of the existing first mortgage, with a reduction in the interest rate from 4A to 4 per cent.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Anderson gave a cocktail party at the Berkshire Inn here this afternoon. Among arrivals at the inn are Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Topping of New York and Mr. and Mrs. James S. Elliott of Ridgewood, N. J.

After a solemn high mass, attended by a score of visiting clergy, the new $200,000 St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church was dedicated and blessed this morning by the Right Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of Newark Diocese.

Our democracy has only partly solved the problems on which its future rests. Algernon D. Black, leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, said in an address yesterday morning at the society's meetinghouse, Central Park West and West Sixty-fourth Street.
A display of potential strength in time of emergency and evidence of renewed interest in national defense were seen yesterday afternoon at the Greater New York Navy Day parade in Queens.

According to the latest survey, another five weeks should find "Of Mice and Men," John Steinbeck's dramatization of his own novel, ready for Broadway. For the Sam H. Harris office now hopes to place it in rehearsal about Nov. 4 and then install it at the Music Box without benefit of the Philadelphia tryout that previously had been planned.

On the eve of the annual congresses of the Radical and Socialist parties and as a prelude to the reopening of Parliament next month Premier Camille Chautemps delivered a program speech at Chateauroux, in Touraine, today.

The steamship Manchester Regiment struggled back to Liverpool early today after a collision with the outbound steamship Clan Mackenzie during a raging gale near the Mersey Bar Lightship. There were no injuries on either vessel.

Cantsius College and Xavier University of Cincinnati played to a scoreless tie today, handicapped by a muddy field and a driving snowstorm that at times veiled the players from the crowd. A total of forty-five punts and nineteen fumbles marked the contest.

The Episcopal Church has no doctrine on divorce because it knows of no way that a marriage, once it has been spiritualized in the church, can be revoked, the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Wall Street at Broadway, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

A nationwide race with death, seeking recovery of more than 700 bottles, mostly pints, of a new liquid medicine named elixir of sulphanilamide, which has already caused thirty-six verified deaths, was described today at the headquarters of the American Medical Association.
Howard Bissell, president of the Niagara National Bank of Buffalo since 1933, died tonight in Millard Fillmofe Hospital after a week's illo ss. His age was 59.

Civil servants not having obtained from Finance Minister Georges Bonnet a salary increase as large as they wanted, are dissatisfied and intend to show their attitude publicly in order to impress Parliament, which will have the final say in adopting the salary increases.

The material harm inflicted on general business and industry by the recent labor disputes in the larger industries, while important, is small compared with the indirect adverse effects of weakened confidence that they have occasioned in many business quarters, the Guaranty Trust Company says in a discussion of the current labor situation contained in its monthly publocation, the Guaranty Survey.

As a result of a practical joke, Robert Hickson, 28-year-old Negro of 125 West 134th Street, is in a hospital today, a bullet wound in his thigh and a prisoner accused of an attempt to kill Detective James Gillen.
Now that the ducks and geese are flying and hunters may legally take them, the officers of Ducks Unlimited, Inc., are launching a drive to finance a five-year program of wildfowl restoration.

Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Commissioner of Health, has named an advisory board of five for the new bureau of narcotic control in the department. The personnel comprises representatives of State dental, veterinary, medical and pharmaceutical associations, and manufacturing druggists.

On the eve of the 'peace" conference beteween committees of the American Federation of Labor and the Cornmittee for Industrial Organization little hope was held out for im-mediate constructive results from the parley, which opens' at 10 A. M., tomorrow.

The Council of Foreign Bondholders and the League Loans Committee, London, in a statement issued today, emphasize that they still are of the opinion that the unilateral offer by the Greek Government to pay 40 per cent on the remaining coupons of its external loans falling due within the financial year April 30, 1937, to March 31,

Police Captain Ora Dewees said that a 26-year-old man was taken into custody late today and identified by a filling station attendant as the motorist who gave him a counterfeit $20 bill in payment for gasoline.

The only way to attain true academic freedom in the United States is to see that our educational institutions are run by experts-and not by vested interests that seem determined to suppress open discussion among teachers and students of this country,
Two New York University backfield men, injured in the Lafayette game Saturday, probably will be out for the remainder of the season, according to the university's athletic office.

The Shenandoah Presidents of Pennsylvania met with a surprising 22-7 setback at the hands of the Brooklyn Eagles yesterday at Ebbets Field. The Presidents made only one serious gesture and that resulted in their touchdown late in the final quarter.
Mount St. Mary's College, aided by the brilliant all-around playing of Frank and Tony Apichella, defeated La Salle at McCarthy Stadium today, 14--6.

Dr. John Joseph Kindred, a Representative in Congress in 1911-13 and again from 1921-29, representing the Second New York District as a Democrat, died Saturday afternoon after a brief illness in his home at Wolcott Avenue and Kindred Street, Astoria, Queens. He was 73 years old.

While the foreign demand for soy beans was less active last week it was estimated that about 150,000 bushels were sold, and this had some effect on futures, which were 1 1/4 cents a bushel higher to 1/2 cent a bushel lower, compared with a week before.
The Fort Jay football team from Governors Island defeated Fort Dupont before 5,000 spectators, 13-6, today. Fort Jay scored in the first quarter on a 30-yard pass from Wikowski to Flook.

Aroused to the possibility of losing .the District Attorneyship as well as the' Mayoralty, Tammany is putting on a last-week- drive for the election of Harold W..Hastings, its nominee for District Attorney, it was learned yesterday.

Three policemen who were killed in the performance of their duty will have their names added to the Tablet at Police Headquarters and receive posthumous honorable mention under general orders issued by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine at midnight last night.
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Isaac Siegal, Republican candidate for the City Council, "Proportional Representation"-WOV, 2:25 to 2:30 P. M.

Nearly 700 men and women filled pews, aisles and galleries of the Shearith Israel Synagogue, at Central Park West and Seventieth Street, yesterday morning, where the funeral of its distinguished rabbi emeritus, the Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, was held. Dr. Mendes died last Wednesday at his home in Mount Vernon, N. Y., at the age of 85.

Chronologically, last week's stock market staged the culmination and "round-up" of the severe decline, virtually continuous during the six weeks after Labor Day. This did not mean, when the long-deferred "buying movement" went definitely into action Tuesday afternoon, that the 18-point recovery achieved by the averages, whereby in two days more than a third of the six weeks' loss was regained, was bound to continue uninterruptedly.

The Claredda Farm's bay gelding Prince Charming II, ridden by Miss Charlotte Ives Montgomery of Villanova, won the highest honors as the annual Wissahickon Horse Show closed today. Named champion hunter, Prince Charming gained a leg on the John Peel Gold Cup.
Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Smith Jr. of this city, formerly of Atlanta, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Louise Smith, to Ensign William Walker Hyland, U.S.N.

Acceptance by F. Abbot Goodhue, president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, of the chairmanship of the finance section in the United Hospitals Campaign was announced last night by Clarence Francis, chairman of the Commerce and Industry Committee.

The American Guild of Musical Artists, of which Lawrence Tibbett is president, announced yesterday that it had been recognized as sole collective bargaining agent for all solo singers, dancers, stage directors, stage managers and prompters employed by George De Feo and the Century Grand Opera Company.

The Meadow Brook Club golfers took the semi-annual quadrangular team match on their own links yesterday by scoring 39 points. The Rockaway Hunting Club representatives were close behind with 36, one more than the total of Piping Brook. The Nassau County Club finished with 10.

Harold Henry, pianist, will give a recital tonight at Town Hall. Dr. Ernst Lert of the Curtis Institute gives an illustrated lecture on "Gustav Mahler, the First Reformer of Opera Production," at the New York Public Library tonight at 8:15 o'clock. Free tickets for this lecture, which is sponsored by the Library in cooperation with the Bruckner Society of America, may be obtained at the music department of the Library.

Morris Fleischer, 32-year-old engineer from Long Island City, made a "runaway" of the 30,000-meter national senior championship walk yesterday at Victory Field, Woodhaven, L. I., finishing two full laps in front of the second man in 2:48:16.6.

" Municipal Menace No. 1" is the title of a campaign booklet just issued by the Citizens Committee for the Election of Mahoney-TaylorSchneider. The reference is to Mayor La Guardia, who is denounced in it as "a lawless, promise-breaking, rabble-rousing Mayor."

In a review of the external debt situation of the republic of Poland, concerning particularly the recent offer by the Polish Government to pay at the rate of 4 1/4 per cent annually the coupons due from Oct. 1. 1937, to April 30, 1938,

The coat and suit market led in apparel action last week, as improved retail business brought in orders for dressy coats in the higher brackets and sports coats at all prices. The dress market was dull, chief activity favoring cocktail, don't-dress-for-dinner and formal types. Evening wraps were called for. Furs were inactive.

Admiral Sir Edward Charlton, president of the Naval Interallied Commission of Control which supervised the carrying out of the naval disarmament of Germany under the Versailles Treaty, died today at the age of 72.

Miss Emily Goodenough Sessions was married here to William Penfield Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Blake Gordon of Danbury, last evening at Beleden, home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Kenneth Sessions. The Rev.

Fort Hamilton and Fort Totten, keen metropolitan military rivals, continued to remain in the competition for the Second Corps Area football championship by battling to a 13-all tie yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation before 2,500 fans.

The wheat market continues to fluctuate in a most erratic manner and while there has been good buying of choice varieties of cash grain by mills, the foreign demand last week fell far below trade expectations, and a number of professional operators and commission houses said lower prices would be seen for domestic grains unless there was a material expansion in the volume of business with importing countries.

Denny Shute, United States P. G. A. champion, won a professional invistation match play golf tournament and a first prize of 1,000 pesos (about $320) today by downing Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., 1 up, in the thirty-six-hole final.

The Park Association of the City of New York, in a letter yesterday to both candidates for Mayor, asked them to pledge themselves to work for greater recreational facilities for the people of the city, for adequate funds in the budget for the operation of facilities now under the jurisdiction of the Park Department, and a larger police force in the city parks to protect the young and old.

France's general wholesale price index on Oct. 16 was 620, against 619 the week before. Native products stood at 644, against 636; imported products were 576, against 590; food, 612, against 619; industrial materials, 627, against 620. The world gold index of twenty-two raw materials was 49.4, compared with 49.2.

President Roosevelt went to church today and heard the pastoral letter adopted last Tuesday by the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church, which saw danger to the world, first, in the threats of war and, second, in the "exploitation of the weak and helpless by the strong."

Six persons were injured today in a recurrence of student rioting against the Government of Premier Mustapha Nahas Pasha. The Giza University students who yesterday battled police in an attempt to demonstrate against Nahas Pasha at the opening of a special session of Parliament today staged a stay-in strike at the university.
While snow flurries whirled past the tavern windows under the whip of a cold wind here today Laverne (John Montague) Moore awaited resumption of his trial for first-degree robbery.

Agricultural economists of the Works Progress Administration declared today a growing interest in the mechanical cotton picker might lead to the displacement of half a million field hands within five or ten years.
Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader of half of the Second Assembly District, was described as a politician with many underworld consections by Special . Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey yesterday.

The fourth annual conference on State labor legislation under the auspices of the Department of Labor will open here tomorrow for a three-day session. Secretary Perkins announced today that representatives of the Governors of forty-five States would attend, only Montana, Oregon and New Mexico being unrepresented.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Has not recent newspaper discussion about the importance of the office of the county District Attorney, crediting this official with the power to shield the criminal or to bring him to justice, to loose or to bind, to ignore or to take cognizance of criminal suspects, given this officer of the law more power than the law has given him?
After some fluctuations due to the international political situation, the share and bond markets here improved and maintained the gains.

The Baltimore branch of the National Maritime Union today asked-President Roosevelt to remove Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the National Maritime Commission, because of the arrest of fourteen seamen aboard the steamer Algic on charges that they violated the mutiny laws.

A Pennsylvania Railroad work train crashed into the rear of another work train at Lenover, ten miles west of here, tonight, injuring more than a score of workmen. The injured were brought to the Coatesville Hospital, which reported at least six were in serious conedition.

New York City's police pension fund will receive $125,000 as its share of the $10,317,569.39 alcoholic beverage taxes and license fees collected during the quarter ended Sept. 30, State Controller Maurice S. Tremaine announced today.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Lily Stungo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul S. Stungo of Edinburgh, Scotland, to Dr. Donald K. Binder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan J. Binder of this city.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday withdrew his endorsement of Samuel J. Foley, Democratic District Attorney of the Bronx, because Mr. Foley has aligned himself with the supporters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor.

Long Island's first and reserve BERLIN, teams defeated New York's repre- defeated No sentatives in two fast field hockey games on the Adelphi Academy grounds in Queens Village. The Long Island firsts won by 3-2 and the reserves by 2-1.

Last April the American Foundation issued a two-volume report--"American Medicine: Expert Testimony Out of Court"--which digested 5,000 letters written by some 2,100 physicians to express their dissatisfaction with the medical care now available and to suggest means whereby medical science may be advanced, the standard of medical practice raised and medical education improved.

The first successful "pirate" attack in the Mediterranean since the conclusion of the Lyon agreement and the establishment of the Anglo-French-Italian naval patrol was reported by the French Ministry of Marine tonight.

Mrs. Annie Stuart Leeds, widow of William Bateman Leeds, New York lawyer, died yesterday at her residence, 555 Park Avenue, at the age of 88. She was born in this city, a daughter of James Stuart, head of J. J. Stuart Company, bankers, and at one time president of the old Hanover National Bank, and Elizabeth Wheelwright Stuart.
The theft of a locomotive was reported to the police of the West Forty-seventh Street station last night by the New York Society of Model Engineers, Inc., 152 West Forty-second Street.
