The Brazilian Congress has consented to ratification of the convention on the nationality of women, and the government is preparing the necessary instrument of ratification, Miss Doris Stevens, chairman of the Inter-American Commission of Women, announced today.

Corn futures here dropped to within striking distance of the lowest level of the season yesterday and trade sentiment generally is bearish, with receivers expecting there will be a material enlargement in the movement in the next few weeks, especially if weather conditions continue favorable.

This week's official surveys and forecasts for industry are unqualifiedly favorable. That the boom depends on capital undertakings exclusively is brought out by the fact that since 1932 the number of persons employed in the steel and machinery industries increased 157 per cent;

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 89.3, which compares with 89.5 a week ago, 89.8 two weeks ago, 90.7 three weeks ago and 92.2 four weeks ago.

Inhabitants of an Indian village high in the mountains of northwestern Guatemala, living in the 1900-year-old traditions of the Maya civilization, learned for the first time last April of the existence of the United States from a field worker of Columbia University's Department of Anthropology, according to a study made public at the university yesterday.

The Illinois Central Railway System reported today that net operating income in September amounted to $2,454,488, against $1,529,556 in September, 1936. Gross operating revenues for the month amounted to $9,731,304, against gross income of $9,706,859 last year.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,348,009,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

Miss Anne Remsen Schenck, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Schenck and the late Mr. Schenck, is visiting her aunt, Mrs. Helen L. Hoppin, at 150 East Seventy-second Street. She made her debut here last Winter and- was presented later at the Court of St. James.

Although commuters on the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad Company lines fear they have little chance of saving the road from abandonment, a petition signed by 26,000 riders will be presented tomorrow to Federal Judge John C. Knox, who has ruled the Port Chester-New Rochelle branch must go out of existence on Nov. 1.

Miss Jessie A. Gebauer, daughter of Mrs. George John Gebauer of this place and Erie, Pa., and the late Mr. Gebauer, has chosen Nov. 25 as the date for her marriage to Adrian Archbold, son of Mrs. John F. Archbold of New York and the late Mr. Archbold, and , grandson of John D. Archbold, one of the founders of the Standard Oil Company and an associate of the Rockefellers.

A program of rare interest and artistic distinction was given by Alice Tully, soprano, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Miss Tully showed her musicianly zeal and catholicity of taste in a list of arias and songs from Gluck, Haydn, Erich Wollf, Hugo Wolf, Gustav Mahler, Cesar, Franck, Henri Duparc, Florent Schmitt, Albert Roussel, Francis Poulenc, Maurice Ravel, and some songs by English and American composers.

While consumers are buying only in hand-to-mouth fashion and are using backlogs of material purchased earlier in the year, producers firmly believe that the present setback in the steel output is temporary and not the beginning of a major recession, according to the current issue of the magazine Steel.

Larry Kelley, former Yale star, was ill with influenza and watched from the sidelines today while his team-mates, the Boston Shamrocks, easily took an American League football game from Pittsburgh, 27 to 7.

The Morgan interests, including J. P.u Morgan Co. of New York, Drexel . Co. of Philadelphia and a group of allied banking institutions, were accused today of dominating the control of both the anthracite-produring companies and the anthracite-carrying railroads, in violation of the spirit of Supreme Court decisions of 1920.

Cole Porter, song writer, received compound fractures of both legs when he was thrown from a horse on a bridle path of the Piping Rock Club here this afternoon. Knocked unconscious by the fall, Mr. Porter was taken to the North Country Community Hospital at Glen Cove.

By its decision to postpone the communal elections scheduled for Nov. 14 and by its prohibition of political meetings throughout Czechoslovakia, the Government has shown its determination to come to grips with the agitation by Konrad Henlein's Nazis.
The Aurora polo team from the United States won its first practice match in preparation for the Argentine open championship today, defeating the low-goal Venado Tuerto four, 10 to 5.

While the sharp decline in commodity prices inflicted some damage on trade in certain directions, notably in textile industry, the recession left unhurt the majority, nor as yet has it impaired recovery in the raw-material producing countries.

A recommendation that students of foreign languages in the city's schools spend part of their time in learning the customs, ideals and aspirations of the people whose language is being studied, thus imbuing the students with "cultural internationalism"

Results of the run-off ballots last Sunday confirmed the favorable impression created by the first cantonal elections the week before, and right from the opening of the markets on Monday the influence of the counts was reflected in favorable foreign exchange quotations and buoyancy on the Bourse.

The world faces the same crisis today that the early Christians did 1,900 years ago, the Rev. Vincent Donovan, national director of the Catholic Thought Association, said yesterday at the fifth annual communion breakfast of the Giuditta Guild at, the Hotel Biltmore.

In the rain, snow and mud that made for the most execrable conditions of the season in the East, as well as on the sun-flooded gridirons of the South and Far West, the football bandwagon all but wore out its shock absorbers Saturday as journey's end came for another bumped-off host, some of whom had had the idea that the ride would carry clear to the Rose Bowl.

Cardinal Hayes presided yesterday at the services at St. Francis Xavier's Church, Sixteenth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, at which the Rev. William J. Duane observed his golden jubilee as a Jesuit. Father Duane celebrated solemn high mass.

A fellowship service at which the three ministers of the combined congregations spoke celebrated the union of the Brick Presbyterian Church and the Park Avenue Church yesterday at the latter church on Eighty-fifth Street.

Art exhibitions opening in the local galleries this week are fewer in number but no less diversified than in the first weeks of the Autumn season. They range from abstraction to illustration, and from oils and water-colors to prints and photography.
Miss Virginia Center Nichols will be presented to society this Winter at a series of teas to be given by her parents, Mr./and Mrs. Spencer Van Bokkelen Nichols of 30 East Fifty-fifth Street.

Fairly general liquidation developed in lard futures here last week, with the October selling at a new low level for the season to date. Heavy deliveries of cash lard on October contracts and weakness in cottonseed oil had a depressing effect and the latter closed on Saturday at $9.35 for 1 00 pounds, showing a decline of 97 1/2 cents for the week.

The engagement of Miss Beatrix Busch, daughter of Mrs. Fairchild Busch of this city and Verbank, Dutchess County, and of Briton N. Busch of New York, to 0. Winston Miller Jr., son of Oscar Winston Miller of Los Angeles and the late Mrs. Miller, has been announced by her mother.

A member of the former royal house of Hawaii, David Kalakaua, 33 years old, was held today while the police investigated the death of his reputed common law wife, Arvilla Kinslea, 22, during a party in their home.

A plot 202 by 107.5 feet at the southeast corner of Northern Boulevard and 112th Street, Corona, L. I., has been purchased by the Gulf Oil Corporation. It is two blocks from Grand Central Parkway and the World's Fair site and was assembled in two parcels through the Fred Berger Company, as broker.

Speaking today at Union College to students and faculty, Dr. Bertrand M. Wainger, Assistant Professor of English, described in detail the work which has gone into the creation of the 350,000-word tourists' guide book to New York State.

After indecisive oscillations in the first half of the week, the stock market became active on Thursday and again yesterday. There was general firmness, but the close brought a reaction owing to the development of professional profit-taking.

Labor pickets paraded in front of Grace Episcopal Church in Whitestone, Queens, yesterday for the second successive Sunday, causing members of the congregation to threaten to "escort the pickets out of town."

The coming city elections will show whether there are more or fewer citizens with political blindspots than we supposed, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, said in his sermon' yesterday morning. He continued:

A debate on the proposed county charter, to be submitted to the voters on Nov. 2, will be held tomorrow evening at the Pelham Memorial High School under the auspices of the League of Women Voters, the Manor Club, Men's Club, ParentTeachers Association, Pelhamwood Association and the Manor Tax Payers Association.

Almost exhausted by the bad weather she had fought during the last two days of her record solo flight from Austrahia, Jean Batten of New Zealand landed the little silver monoplane she had used on her previous a flights at Lympne, Kent, at 3:45 this afternoon [10:45 A. M. New York time], 5 days 18 hours and 15 minutes after she took off from Darwin. Australia.

The fact that two men can face the same experience, religious or otherwise, and dome to opposite conclusions, was discussed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
Why is it that among our illustrious great of today we find so many contradictions in the public record?

A series of exhibitions designed to acquaint housewives with the method of grading meat will be held beginning this week under the auspices of the Department of Health, the Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures and the United States Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.
Turkey hens and gobblers, fatter than their ancestors of the 1936 holiday season, await this year's Thanksgiving and Christmas diners.
Editor Clyde W. Fiddler, fresh from an assault on school fraternities, struck out again tonight in his Kenmore High School Trumpet, this time in the direction of the faculty.

The policies of President Roosevelt, together with other political and economic manifestations in recent weeks, were discussed in several New York City pulpits yesterday. New Deal measures designed to keep the United States out of war were among the topics.

Two intercepted passes, a 68yard run and a tricky lateral gave the Rochester Tigers a -touchdown in each period today as they defeated the New York Yankees, 24--0, in an American Football League game before 6,000 spectators.
Bob Glynn, sophomore ball-carrier of little Alfred University's undefeated football forces, is the East's new individual scoring leader.

GOODSPEED'S is hardly the only old book shop in Boston, but it is one of the most famous and its proprietor one of the best-known dealers in the country. Hence it isn't surprising that when an old lady found a pamphlet in her Worcester attic a dozen years ago a local librarian advised her to write to Goodspeed's about it.

The schedule of operas which the Salzburg Opera Guild will present during its season at the Fortyfourth Street Theatre beginning on Nov. 16 was announced yesterday by S. Hurok, who will present the company in its first American tour. The full program follows:

Hollington K. Tong, newspaperman and former editor and publisher in Tientsin and Shanghai, yesterday was appointed head of the Department of Publicity and Propaganda under the Military Affairs Commission. He replaces Chen Kung-po, ex-Minister of Industries.
John P. Gahan, formerly of Doyle, O'Connor Co., Inc., is with the trading department of Amott, Baker Co., Inc. F. S. Moseley Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange,

Because of the large number of inquiries received by the Federal Music Project for clarification of the terms governing its competition for choral works, the sponsors of the contest announced yesterday that the submitted compositions must be for unaccompanied mixed chorus, have English text and not require more than two to four minutes in performance.

The Rawlinson or Bolleian copperplate, showing a scene in early Williamsburg, which was presented to John D. Rockefeller Jr. by the curator of the Bodleian Library of Oxford, England, has been sent here for exhibition by Mr. Rockefeller.
In spite of the loss of a few seats to labor and a substantially increased labor vote the Ministry of Premier Joseph Lyons scored a decisive victory in the general election on Saturday.

Robert (Red) Rolfe, third baseman of the world champion Yankees, was discharged yesterday from St. Elizabeth's Hospital, where he was convalescing from an operation to remove a muscle growth from his right thigh. Dr.

A dinner dance, floor show and fashion parade will be held on Nov. 12 at the Lombardy for the benefit of the Manhattanville Nursery Association. Proceeds will be used to increase the personnel of the nursery, which provides daytime care for needy children who cannot receive attention at home.

In a rambling discussion of life, politics, and the accomplishments of his cult, Father Divine told a cheering crowd of his followers last night that he could not "wholeheartedly endorse" the present city administration for re-election. There were frequent interruptions of "Peace, ain't it wonderful," and "We won't do it, father."

Members of garden clubs throughout Westchester County received invitations today from Samuel Untermyer to visit his outdoor display of chrysanthemums at his country estate at Greystone, Yonkers, on Oct. 27, 28 and 29.

Ernst Victor Wolff, who made his debut here last season, gave his second New York recital at Town Hall last night. As previously, the program set forth was about equally divided between numbers for harpsichord and for piano.

The Flour, Feed and Cereal Workers, Local No. 21021, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, has been certified as the collective bargaining representative of the production workers of General Mills, Inc., at the Washburn-Crosby mill in Buffalo, the National Labor Relations Board announced today.

On this Sunday night Shanghai offers one of the sorriest prizes of war that can be imagined. This once great trade and shipping center of the Far East lies silent, its streets deserted and almost all of its buildings shuttered and sand-bagged.
The turn taken in the discussions of the Non-Intervention Subcommittee in London has dispelled the serious fears previously induced by the prospect of a total failure in the discussions.

The Packers of the National Football League, making their last appearance of the season at home, handed the Cleveland Rams their second setback in as many Sundays by defeating them, 35 to 7, today. It was Green Bay's fourth consecutive circuit victory.
Wilmer B. Whitney of 4,063 Hudson Boulevard, North Bergen, N. J., dropped dead of a heart attack while golfing alone on the Belmont Manor course here this morning. His age was 56.

The contributions made from pulpits to all fields of human activity were emphasized in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams.

Joe DiMaggio of the Yankees hit a home run for the benefit of his home-town admirers as he aided a major league team defeat a coast league outfit, 15 to 4, in an "allstar" exhibition game here today. Di Maggio's circuit clout was made in the park where he started his professional baseball career a few years ago.

Joseph P. Kennedy's informal discussion of his brief months of stewardship of the Maritime- Commission, as delivered extemporaneously to the press last Friday, accompanying the issuance of minimum wage and minimum manning standards for the 10,000 seamen who man our Government-subsidized vessels, was in the nature of a preview of the forthcoming report.

The triangular area formed by the intersection at Houston Street and Avenue D on the lower East Side was officially dedicated as Gustave Hartman Square yesterday afternoon with ceremonies at which Mayor La Guardia, Borough President Levy, Rabbi Israel Goldstein and others praised the late City Court justice.

Oats showed independent strength here last week, closing yesterday with the December and May positions at 30 3/8 cents a bushel and the July at 29 1/4, prices being 1/4 cent higher to 1/4 lower compared with a week ago, December showing the most strength.

A brief and simple funeral service was held yesterday afternoon for Frank Heino Damrosch in the white recital hall of the school he founded in 1905, the Institute of Musical Art, which is now connected with the Juilliard School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue.
Edward H. Harris, Richmond publisher and a leader in national publishers' organizations, died at his home here tonight. His age was 57. He had been ill since July of a glandular ailment.
Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, challonger, resumed play tonight in their return match for the title.

The Cathedral of Soissons, rebuilt from war ruins, was reopened with religious ceremonies today. The Soissons Cathedral is smaller than that at Reims, which was reopened last Monday. Its shattered tower was a landmark for American troops fighting in the sector in 1918.
Sir Joseph Isherwood, distinguished naval architect who developed the system of longitudinal framing now used in shipbuilding throughout the world, died today of pneumonia at the age of 68.

The long-promised Japanese big push," finally launched yesterday morning, has already brought results of tremendous importance following the breaking of Chinese defense lines in various Shanghai sectors, according to official statements by Japanese Army and Navy spokesmen.

The City Affairs Committee, in a statement signed by John Haynes Holmes, chairman; John Lovejoy Elliott and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, vice-chairmen, and Frederick L. Guggenheimer, executive director, recommended yesterday the election of nineteen candidates for the City-Council.

Shortwave radio communication between undersea craft and the surface or air became an established fact today, when National Broadcasting Company engineers and announcers succeeded in broadcasting "voice" signals direct from the submarine R-14 from the ocean depths off New London, Conn.,

The list of eligible jurors on the 1938 classification in the county, Supreme and Surrogate's Courts of Westchester County, which Commissioner 'M. W. Hays is preparing, will show an increase over 1937 of more than 50 per cent on Feb. 1, when women will be legally entitled to serve as trial jurors in Westchester.

A reduction of $32,900,184 in the proposed tax budget for 1938, bringing It down to a total of $557,086,834 and effecting a 20-point drop in the tax rate, will be urged upon the Board of Estimate today by the Citizens Budget Commission. Twelve other civic organizations are joining the commission in asking for substantial cuts in twentyfour items.

With fundamental conditions clearer the stock market's tendency turned favorable on Thursday. The stabilization fund, although at times obliged to sell small amounts of sterling or United States dollars, was able finally to add considerably to its foreign exchange resources.

Herbert J. Brown, president of the $75,000,000 Brown Company, largest pulp and paper manufacturer in New England, in a statement issued here today following the filing of the Coverdale Colpitts survey, said:

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Phyllis Graves of Boston and Chatham, Sass., daughter of the late Edwin R. Graves, to Jacob Dolson Cox of Cleveland, son of Mrs. Jacob Dolson Cox of Cleveland, Pasadena, Calif., and Magnolia, Mass.

Causes for the slowing down of residential construction throughout the country will be examined by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States at a special conference to be held on Nov. 17 and Nov. 18.

Snow and rain lashed across Western New York today, impeding highway traffic along the Lake Erie shore. Automobiles skidded into ditches from the slippery pavements during the storm, which began last night with snow flurries. Buffalo reported a temperature of 33 at 3 P. M.

The new studios of New York City's broadcasting station, WNYC, which put the Municipal Broadcasting System ahead of all other radio stations in some technical details, were dedicated yesterday afternoon.

Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., America's incorporated Santa Clauses, announced yesterday that toys manufactured for the 1937 Christmas were at a seven-year peak, 10 per cent greater than last year and had a total value of $230,000,000.

A Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train carrying the Duke University football squad was in collision today with a Lackawanna Railroad milk train near Portland, Pa., and at least four trainmen were injured.

A total of ninety-eight singers is listed in the prospectus for the coming season of the Metropolitan Opera Association. Made public yesterday, it revealed that six members of the company of the last Spring season have been retained for the coming year.

Amateur bombers in nineteen planes and non-professional antiaircraft gunners in ten 26 to 46 foot cabin cruisers, brought together by an idea of the man who started the Tennessee evolution trial twelve years ago, vied on Long Island Sound yesterday with flour-sacks for bombs and highspeed cameras for guns.

Both financially and politically, London believes the French situation has undergone improvement in recent weeks. Financially, France undoubtedly has benefited from the depreciation of the franc, as well as from the spectacular slump which occurred in the security markets here and in the United States.

Japanese planes, when raiding the CantonKowloon Railway today, dropped several bombs on the Namsha station, about four miles from Sheklung, wrecking the station and damaging a train, which also was machine-gunned.

The threat of overproduction of oil in the Miller County, Arkansas, area of the tri-State Rodessa field by reason of the unusually active drilling campaigns there, has been averted by a proration order issued yesterday,

Indicating a change from the lethargic comedy and drama which has marked his recent pictures, Paramount has assigned Bing Crosby to "Top Speed," which Wesley Ruggles will produce and direct and which will be written by Claude Binvon.

Charles Scotto, internationally known chef and favorite pupil of the late Auguste Escoffier, famous cooking authority, died yesterday morning at the Midwood Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 51 years old and lived at 1,192 East Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn.
Mr. and Mrs. Olaf E. Mogensen of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sonia Mogensen, to L. Paul Ahlers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Ahlers of Summit.

Former President Hoover urged here that Republicans tell "the constructive story" of the party. He spoke last night at a supper meeting at the home of Mrs. Samuel F. Pryor Sr., attended by twenty-six leading representatives of the State Republican party and of Young Republican organizations in the State,

Monroe Percy Bloch, counsel of the Honest Ballot Association, expressed gratification yesterday that Attorney General Bennett had decided to appoint special assistant deputies for the election from lawyers nominated by the Republican, American Labor and Socialist parties, as well as nominees of the Democratic party.
Organized workers were urged by George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor to vote "yes" on proposed Amendment 4, which would make sheriffs eligible to succeed themselves.

National Challenge Cup Swedish F. C. 6, Brooklyn ScotS-Americans 0. American League Paterson Caledonians 4, Brooklyn Hispanos 2. Philadelphia Germans 1, Irish-Americans 0. St. Mary's Celtics 1, Brookhattans 1.

The Chicago Bears, playing before the largest crowd ever to see a professional football game, here, gained their fifth straight National League victory today by defeating the Detroit Lions, 28 to 20, in a hair-raising battle at Wrigley Field.
Germany defeated Norway by 3 to 0 today in an international soccer match before a crowd of 120,000 jamming the Olympic Stadium.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 56 per cent of capacity, down 7 points from the week preceding, and 28 points from the average rate in August.
Dr. and Mrs. Charles H. Conley of Guilford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoire Conley, to Richard B. Griffin of Washington.
About 500 leaders in the furniture, bedding and carpet industries honored Barney Marks, merchandise manager of Gimbel Brothers, at a testimonial dinner last night in the Hotel Astor.

The twelfth annual World's Championship Rodeo ended last night at Madison Square Garden before more than 15,000 persons who, after seeing the final exhibition of Wild West antics, witnessed the awarding of new championships.

Governor Quinn is bound to drive Mr. O'Hara, managing director of the -racing association, out of the State of Rhode Island. The State Racing Division took away the track's license. The State Supreme Court, a good Democratic body, restored it. So the Governor fell back on the law martial.

The President's appeal last week for contributions to community chests really accomplished two purposes. It reminded those of us who are more fortunate that the need of generous support for private welfare agencies continues in spite of governmental relief programs, because these private agencies meet problems and situations with which public agencies are not equipped to deal.

A sharp attack on the publication of consumer magazines by food chains has been made by the National Association of Retail Grocers, Chicago, which declares that this form of competition may force independents to publish similar magazines.
James Matthews, for forty-six years connected with the National City Bank until his retirement in 1931, died last Saturday night in London, England, where he was visiting. His age was 69.

Chinese military circles here deny that the Japanese hold Sinhsien, the key point in the Central Shansi plateau. They say heavy fighting in this vital position is still going on with the Chinese still in possession. The Shansi situation has changed little in the last few days.

Members of the lodge of Elks will be summoned this week to fight the "insidious evil" of traffic ticket "fixing" and to eliminate some major traffic hazard- in each of the 1,400 cities where a lodge is located, Major Charles Spencer Hart, national Grand Exalted Ruler, announced here yesterday.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, is either ignorant concerning the real facts of the slum clearance and model housing program of the past four years or else he is misleading the public, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor returned from Germany today and set about planning their November voyage to the United States. They went to the Meurice Hotel, which they left two weeks ago to inspect conditions among workers under the Nazi regime.

Death sentences for fourteen persons convicted of sabotage of Soviet agriculture were reported to Moscow today. Eight were doomed to die as "Trotskyist, Rightist wreckers" in the Russki district of Moscow Province.

The Chicago Cardinals turned on sufficient power for two touchdowns in the second half today to set back Pittsburgh, 13 to 7, in a National Football League game witnessed by 8,963 chilled spectators .

Two hundred women employed in a new WPA project will be ready tomorrow for emergency housekeeping duty in needy homes, Mrs. Aneita Keating of the women's and professional division of WPA here, announced today.

The Citizens Union recommended yesterday fifty-nine candidates for district delegates to the constitutional convention on the report of its committee on local candidates. In accordance with its policy of making no commitments on Statewide candidates, the union made no recommendations for candidates for delegates at large.
Count Konrad von Preysing, Catholio Bishop of Berlin, issued another urgent appeal to Catholics today to contribute to the support of missionary work near labor camps.

Violent tremors rocked the ranks of the undefeated in the scholastic football world during the past weekend, shattering the hopes of many leaders, including several that had been highly rated for quite a long time.

In the calendar of Saints' Days today is St. Crispin's, the patron saint of shoemakers. The legend is that two Romans of wealth and distinguished family, joining the persecuted sect of Christians in an early century (one Crispin or Crispian and the other Crispinian), learned secretly the craft of shoemaking, and as missionaries carried their Gospel message into Gaul with their cobblers' kits until they reached Soissons,
Absent six days because she was afraid to show her school report card at home, 11-year-old Nellie Stevens was found here today, weak and hungry. A State-wide search had been in progress.

Joachim von Ribbentrop left here this morning for Germany to acquaint Chancellor Hitler with the outcome of his mission to Rome. It is stated that he was satisfied with the result of his meetings with Premier Mussolini and Count Gaeleazzo Ciano, which is taken as an indication that the Rome-Berlin axis once again functioned satisfactorily.

Lafayette Blanchard Gleason, secretary of the Republican State Committee since 1906 and nationally known in Republican circles as general secretary of the last seven Republican national conventions, died yesterday at 9:40 A. M. at St. Luke's Hospital.
The annual field trials of the Babylon Fox Hunt Club started this morning when sixteen hounds ranged Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim's North Babylon estate.

The following instructions on how to vote for candidates for the City Council by the proportional representation method were issued yesterday by Charles C. Burlingham, vice chairman of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee. as one of a series of lessons:

Sir Hubert Wilkins landed his big Soviet-owned monoplane here today on his way back to the Arctic to resume search for six missing Russian transpolar fliers. He and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, who took off from New York Friday, flew from Fargo, N. D.

Hammering the ball through the uprights six times in the last two sessions, the First Division quartet conquered the Ramapo Blues of Tallman, N. Y., 10--8, in an exciting polo match yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt of Oyster Bay will serve as honorary chairman of a non-partisan lawyers' committee to support the candidacy of Elvin N. Edwards, former Nassau County District Attorney, for Supreme Court Justice in the Second district, it was announced today.
A 27-yard field goal by Riley Smith in the last thirty seconds of play today gave the Washington Redskins a 10-to-7 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Football League game.

A group of French Reserve officers visiting here as guests of the Yugoslav Reserve Officers Association this morning witnessed a demonstration against the government by members of the Serbian Opposition, which is now united with the Croats in a campaign for the restoration of a democratic Constitution.
Navy patrol squadrons 3 and 5, a total of twenty-two planes, will depart from the fleet air base at Coco Solo, C. Z., tomorrow for Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, for three weeks of special training.
The personnel of the Canadian Army jumping team for the international military events at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 3-10, was announced yesterday.
Vincent Zumpano turned in a sterling performance in leading the Iona School eleven to a 7-6 verdict over Mount St. Michael High of the Bronx today at Haag Field.

Overcome with excitement when the automobile in which she was riding hit and seriously injured an 8-year-old boy, Mrs. Rose Schecter, 70 years old, of 2,163 Seventy-ninth Street, Brooklyn, dropped dead yesterday afternoon in an emergency room at the Jersey City Medical Center, where the boy had been taken.

The noblest people are those who are grounded in the great standards of character and who are dependable; their goodness not a fashion of the moment, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick. pastor of the Riverside Church, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Farm horses in Normandy are being sold this season for almost $40 more than last year and the supply is-not adequate to meet the demand. Six-month foals of the Percheron breed are fetching between $100 and $150 and their rate of sale indicates clearly what has been suspected for some time, that the French farmer is turning against agricultural machinery and that the horse is coming back into its own.

America must awaken and put the "God standard" before the "gold standard," the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Underhill Burdett of Englewood, N. J., announced yesterday at a tea they gave in their Maple Street home the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Mary Burdett, to Anson Boulton Herrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newbold Lawrence Herrick of Woodmere, L. I.

" Pennsbury,"' the home of William Penn, patron of- Pennsylvania, whose 293d birthday anniversary was observed today, may be restored to its former glory if. Public Works Administration officials in Washington approve a $237,000 project planned by the State Authority.

Of the many legends about David Garrick, that almost legendary figure of the eighteenth century theatre, count as one of the most amusing "The Great Garrick," which Mervyn LeRoy turned loose at the Rivoli during the week-end.

Samuel Untermyer, in a radio speech last night, urged the election of Harold W. Hastings, Tammany's candidate for District Attorney, and ridiculed the accomplishments of Thomas E. Dewey, his Fusion opponent.

A. Sulka Co., for the last twenty years at Fifth Avenue and Fortythird Street, will open today their new store at 661 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets. The entire establishment is air-conditioned.

The Jewish National- Fund of America gave a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of former Magistrate Bernard A. Rosenblatt in recognition of his twenty-five years of service to the Zionist cause and on the eve of his fifteenth visit to Palestine.

German industry is perturbed by the bank balance sheets for Sept. 30. These figures, just released, show an unexpectedly sharp rise in indebtedness to the banks and a rather heavy decline in deposits, which compelled the banks to sell Reich short-term securities.

Prince Serge Wolkonsky died here today after a brief illness at the age of 75. He arrived ten days ago with the Princess, the former Mrs. Seth Barton French of New York, on a visit- to Colonel and Mrs. Arthur Kelly Evans of Malvern Hall.

Mr. and Mrs. G. Sidney Leach of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Elizabeth Leach, to Willard H. Thatcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Linden A. Thatcher of Cos Cob, Greenwich, Conn.

The local press, commenting on the expenditure of the special appropriation of $1,000,000 given by 'President Roosevelt for the construction of the Inter-American Highway, says that El Salvador has not received one cent and that the government is in a position to complete the work without assistance.

The third of what is understood to be a series of heavy gold purchases in Japan for shipment to this country was revealed yesterday when the Federal Reserve Bank announced that $6,600,000, of the metal had been engaged there.

On the eve of another difficult and perhaps quarrelsome meeting of the Non-Intervention Subcommittee tomorrow, Russia is nearer diplomatic isolation than at any time since the start of the Spanish civil war.

The Appellate Division denied today the appeal of Surrogate William J. Sheils of Westchester County from a Supreme Court decision rejecting his claim to election in 1936 to a six-year term. In a 4-to-1 decision Justice Daniel V. McNamee dissenting the tribunal upheld Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan's decision refusing Mr. Sheils a declaratory judgment.

Willowshores Jerry, a hound owned and handled by Dr. R. H. Swain of Paterson, was the winner in the thirteen-inch all-age dog stake sponsored by the New Jersey Beagle Club today. There were thirteen well-matched hounds in the event and four series were required for the decision.

Frank A. Knapp, chairman of the American Lutheran Church board of trustees and investment committee, died today at his home here. His age was 72. Mr. Knapp, a native of Germany, had long been prominent in religious, commercial and financial fields in Ohio.
Numerous trains packed with Japanese troops and field equipment are moving northward along the Peiping-Mukden Railway through Shanhalkwan into Manchukuo, it was reliably reported here yesterday.

The Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, through George Brokaw Compton, campaign manager, continued yesterday its lessons on how to vote for candidates for the City Council by the proportional representation method. The lesson said:

If the President remains firmly the friend of a balanced budget, encourages sound tax revision with particular attention to the capital gains and corporate surplus levies and does not oppose reasonable modification of certain sections of the Stock Exchange Act, his associates here seem to believe that American business and finance should be satisfied for the time being.
Charley Coniglio raced fifty yards for a touchdown in the first period today to give Union Hill High a 6-to-0 victory over Lincoln of Jersey City.
Mr. and Mrs. Viggo Edward Bird of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Thora Bird, to Gordon Chase Streeter of Boston.

After denying a charge of bookmaking, Joseph Gottfried, 55 years old, of 40-17 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, dropped dead yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions, Jamaica, before Justices Brady, Gresser and Hofmann.

The Poetry Society of America will hold its first meeting of the season on Thursday, Oct. 28, at 8:15 P. M., at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street. Lin. Yutang, author of "My Country and My People" (Reynal Hitchcock), will speak.

With the abandonment of the metric system for track events among the major changes proposed, a total of seventy-six amendments to the constitution, by-laws and rules of the Amateur Athletic Union will be offered at the fortyninth annual convention of the A. A. U. at Boston on Nov. 18, 14 and 15, it was revealed yesterday by Secretary-Treasurer Daniel J. Ferris.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Kenneth Greeley Carpenter of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carol Carpenter, to Franklin McKee Gates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin H. Gates of Montclair, N. J.
A search which covered all New England continued today for Robert Deneou, 16-year-old son of Professor Francois Deneou of the Department of French at Dartmouth College.

Common Pleas Judge James R. Erwin reversed himself here today on the issuance of warrants he signed on Saturday for the arrest of 144 district election officers accused of violating the Election Law by irregularities in counting the primary vote cast on Sept. 21.
Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, Republican of Massachusetts, said today New England manufacturers "are terribly afraid" of the effects of a proposed trade treaty with Czechoslovakia.

With Election Commissioner David B. Costuma charging his colleagues with "the worst Tammany Hall steal on record," the Board of Elections yesterday permitted State Senator Elmer Quinn's specifications against two Fusion petitions to become a subject of inquiry by the Board of Elections.

The amount raised to date in the $2,000,000 campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York was brought to $46,712 yesterday, when contributions totaling $6,780 were announced at a luncheon at the Central Branch, 610 Lexington Avenue.

The pent-up offensive fury that failed to click against Rutgers last Saturday was released today at the expense of Princeton University's battered scrub eleven and in seventy-five minutes of hard scrimmage the varsity reserves romped to cleancut 30-0 triumph.

Hamilton J. Chapman, chief consulting engineer during the construction of the Grand Central Terminal and the Flatiron Building in New York, died here yesterday at the home of his nephew, Donald B. Chapman.

Widespread education was seen as a means of insuring democracy against those who "profess allegiance to its ideals" by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University in his annual report to the university council, made public yesterday.
Italy's position on the volunteers in Spain follows the oldest form of human logic. When the Neolithic man was

J. P. Morgan Co. yesterday issued a statement characterizing as "sheer nonsense" the charge made by the Anthracite Coal Industry Commission at Philadelphia that the Morgan interests and "a group of allied banking institutions" dominated both anthraciteproducing companies and anthracite-carrying railroads.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens vigorously denied charges yesterday that he "is or was a member of the Krusaders, foreign-born branch of the Ku Klux Klan." The charges were voiced by Dr. Louis D. Gross of Brooklyn, editor of The Jewish Examiner, at a meeting earlier in the day of the Committee Against Religious Intolerance in Politics, which was formed several weeks ago.

A more "deadly warfare against free speech" probably will be waged in the next ten years than America has known for several generations, was the warning sounded last night by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area.

The junior committee of the Italian Welfare League, which helps needy and unemployed Italian families in New York who are unable to obtain relief from other charitable agencies, will give a "Gay Nineties Party" as its annual benefit on Saturday night at the Central Opera House, 205 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Eight mounts to be used by the Irish Free State team in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 3 to 10, England's star jumper, Jimmy Brown, arid three hunters arrived yesterday aboard the United States liner American Banker.

New York University's football squad went through an intensive workout in all departments of the game yesterday afternoon at Ohio Field in preparation for the meeting with Colgate Saturday at the Yankee Stadium. Fundamentals were the order of the day, with emphasis on running and passing.
The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors accepted today the offer of William K. Vanderbilt to dedicate the right of way of the Long Island Motor Parkway in Suffolk County to the county without cost.

Mr. Kathleen Curtis Wagstaff has arrived here to seek a divorce from Alfred Wagstaff 3d, who is now living in Beverly Hills, Calif. Mrs. Wagstaff, who lives at 1,030 Park Avenue, is the former Miss Kathleen Hastings Curtis and the daughter of Mrs. George William

Some progress was made at the opening of peace parleys between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization today, but there was no indication whether the conclusion of the conferences would mean peace or war. Another session will be held tomorrow morning.

The twenty seventh annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons, composed of the leading surgeons in the United States and Canada, began its sessions here today with several thousands, many of whom have come from distant parts of these two and from other countries, in attendance.

A solemn high mass will be celebrated at 10 A. M. tomorrow at the Church of Our Lady of Refuge, Ocean and Foster Avenues, Brooklyn, for Charles Scotto, head chef at the Hotel Pierre. Mr. Scotto, who died in Brooklyn on Sunday at the age of 51, will be buried in Monte Carlo his birthplace.

Mrs. Harold Koppelman of the Shoreland Hotel, this city, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Claire Koppelman, to Wilfrid S. Joseph, son of Mrs. Noel Isaacs of The Hurlands, Dunsfold, Surrey, and London, England.

Coach Tasker ordered rest today for all the Rutgers regulars who played in the Princeton game Saturday, but sent the reserves against the freshmen in a long scrimmage. Five touchdowns were tallied by the reserves, while the cubs were unable to get much beyond midfield. Bob Aubry, tackle, was at center for the reserves.
The DeBasil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House announces a change in schedule for its performances on Thursday evening and Saturday afternoon.
George F. Coffin Sr., secretary-treasurer and general manager of the Nazareth Portland Cement Company and a former president of the Cement Institute, died today at his home here. His age was 67.

Nelson T. Johnson, United States Ambassador, left Nanking yesterday aboard the United States gunboat Luzon, going down the river to Chinkiang for a short recuperation trip. He will return here this evening.

Columbia University's Institute of Arts and Sciences paid tribute last night to the memory of Thomas G. Masaryk, founder and first President of Czechoslovakia, in a program of addresses and music in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street.
Mr. Thomas E. Dewey has torn away part of the screen which ordinarily conceals the relationship between organized politics and organized crime in certain parts of this city. He has.

Arms and ammunition to the value of $500,000 were ordered from Germany by J. A. Flores da Cunha, former Governor of Rio Grande do Sul and now in exile, according to the newspaper A Noite today. A shipment consisting of fifty-eight cases has already been apprehended by the military upon arrival at Porto Alegre, it is said.

The power of New York City to impose a 3 per cent tax on the gross income of public utilities to finance relief of the unemployed will be scrutinized by the Supreme Court through an order today granting a review in contests brought by the New York Rapid Transit Corporation and Brooklyn Queens Transit Corporation.

THERE came a letter from a man in Asheville, N. C. He had read something written in this corner about the old baseball team known as the Highlanders and it stirred up in him a mild spirit of retaliation. It seems that he lived in New York City as a youngster and he classified the Highlanders among the lower forms of animal life.
A Seven-room house on a large plot in East Lake Boulevard, Morristown, N. J., has been purchased by Jackson H. Schoenly Jr. from Hugh M. Babbitt through L. C. Phifer, broker.

Word has just reached New York of the sudden death in Berlin of Senate Mueller, popular German film actress. Miss Mueller, who was 31 years old, was first seen and heard here in January, 1931, in "Der Grosse Tenor," where she acted opposite Emil Jannings.
French authorities, acting swiftly to suppress a resurgent Arab nationalist movement, tonight arrested four leaders of the Nationalist party, including its chief, Allal El Fassi.

Data on the living costs of working women, collected by eighteen field worker's who are returning to New York this week, will be submitted to aid in preparation of the tentative budget that will be presented as a guide to the wage boards in the prospective hearings on the new Minimum Wage Law.

General Baron Sadao Araki, who's Minister of War directed Japan's conquest of Manchuria in 1931-33, declared today that "it probably is necessary for Japan to strike directly at Russia" to eliminate Communist influence from the Far East.

The election results after today's counting altered little the situation in the House of Representatives. The progress of the Senate count slightly clarified the outlook, but generally the final issue is still most uncertain.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx, accused by Mayor La Guardia of making a "deal" with 'James J. Hines, Manhattan Tammany district leader, replied last night by inviting the Mayor to put his charges in writing, waive immunity before the Bronx grand jury and face prosecution for criminal libel.

The Army coaches took advantage of the fact that their varsity did not see much action Saturday and scheduled a scrimmage today in preparation for the V. M. I. game. With only a minor injury resulting from the contest with Washington University of St. Louis, the whole squad with the exception of Engstrom, substitute guard, was able to participate.

A promise to hear arguments on the question of the government's authority to finance publicly owned electric utility plants in competition with private enterprise was given today by the Supreme Court, which agreed to review the battle waged by the Duke Power Company against the Public Works Administration.
Prominent Washingtonians came here tonight to see George M. Cohan lampoon the President, but none would say publicly what they thought of "I'd Rather Be Right," musical satire on the New Deal.

A gunman, who smiled as he emptied two pistols into George (Les) Bruneman in a dingy little night spot early today, killed the gambler and night club operator in the second attempt on his life in four months.
General Francisco Franco's northern front has disappeared. He has defeated the entire enemy army of more than 100,000 men that only four months ago was on a mountainous battleline 200 miles long.

The A. S. Campbell Company, Inc., of Boston, manufacturers of automobile bumper guards, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering an issue of 113,233 shares of no-par common, 50,000 shares of which are to be sold for $300,000.

Miss Wilmoth Cosby Gibson and Miss Jane Bedford are among the debutantes who will be introduced to society in December. Miss Bedford is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Bedford of this city and London, who will give a reception for her on Dec. 21 at their home here, 141 East Seventy-second Street.

John D. Biggers, administrator of the voluntary registration of the unemployed soon to be made, emphasized tonight in a radio speech the thoroughness with which the census will be conducted. He was heard over a National Broadcasting Company network.

The Social Security Board announced today that it had asked the Department of Justice to prosecute criminally bogus collectors of funds in connection with the old-age insurance program of the Social Security Act.

Efforts of both independent and chain grocery interests to win the favor of farmers through marketing surplus crops which otherwise would burden the market brought favorable comment from food manufacturers-and others here last week.

According to an announcement yesterday, the Bell System plans to offer reduced rates for long distance telephone service on Thanksgiving Day. The reductions will be made effective by the application of the long distance rates now in effect at night and all day Sunday to messages sent on Thanksgiving Day between points in the United States.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $35,535,067.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who urged the re-election of Mayor La Guardia in a radio speech on Sunday night, came out yesterday for Controller Frank J. Taylor, Democratic candidate for re-election, thereby causing temporary confusion in the Fusion camp.

With forward passing efficiency on the upgrade a new- record for the National Football League is in prospect, according to statistics released yesterday. At the halfway mark the record is 2 per cent better than last year's record 36 mark.

Julius Kaufmann, who retired in 1922 after fifty years as a member of Kaufmann Brothers, produce importers, died yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 395 Riverside Drive, after an illness of three weeks.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve Officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Capt. Addison R. Gibb, Inf.-Res., May 5. Capt. Benjamin Perricone. QM.-Res., May 5. Capt. Harry Myers. CA.-Res., May 8. Capt. Seymour A. Blum. CA.-Res., May 12. 1st Lt. Donald F. Boichot, Fin.-Res., May 14.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: CUSTOMS 4063-United States v. Alex. Schecter Corp. Opinion by Judge Graham. The United States Customs Court Judgment affirmed. 4090-United States v. Freedman Slater Co., Inc. Opinion by Judge Graham.

Current accounts in Canadian-chartered banks at the end of September amounted to $713,627,549, an increase of $27,000,000 from Aug. 31 and almost $66,000,000 larger than on Sept. 30, 1936, according to the monthly return of

The campaign receipts and expenditures statement filed by Thomas E. Dewey with the Board of Elections "proves a bare-faced attempt to purchase, for cash, the District Attorneyship of New York County," it was charged last night in a statement issued by Harold W. Hastings, Democratic candidate for District Attorney.

Miss Irene M. Arsenault, daughter of Mrs. Margaret A. Arsenault of Groton, was married to Lieutenant John C. Hollingsworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Hollingsworth of Atlanta, Ga., this Morning in the Sacred Heart Rectory at Groton by the Rev. R. J. Clabby, the rector.

Karl Lindemann, chairman of the board of the North German Lloyd, arrived here yesterday on the lined Bremen for his annual visit to the New York offices of the company, He said the line planned no passen. ger ships at this time. The ship yards, he said, are booked to capacity constructing naval vessels for the German Government and commercial ships for other countries.
Sale of the publication Social Justice, official voice of Father Charles E. Coughlin's National Union for Social Justice, to an organization led by Walter Baertschi of Toledo, was announced today.

As part of its promotional campaign to stimulate small homes building, the National Lumber Manufacturers Association will begin publication of a consumer magazine, called "Home," which will be distributed to the public through retail lumber dealers, beginning 1938.

American sources deny accepting the Japanese explanation of the bombing last Friday of the United States marines' sector of the International Settlement defense. That explanation is that the "missile" was a detached gasoline tank.

For the first time in months wholesale and retail sales volume in the grocery industry last week ran slightly below the levels of a year ago, the American Institute of Rood Distribution reported yesterday. Retailers have suddenly become extremely cautious in their buying.

A birdie 3 on the thirty-seventh hole gave Walter Scheiber of Milburn -and John Hines of the Garden City C. C. first honors over Willie Klein, Wheatley .Hills, and Joe Ford, Green Mansions, in the metropolitan P. G. A. Scotch foursome championship at the Pomonok Country Club at Flushing yesterday. Both pairs were tied with 145s at the end of thirty-six holes.

A witness before a legislative commissionn investigating Communist, fascist and Nazi activities in Massachusetts asserted today that two justices of the United States Supreme Court and Governor Lehman of New York were "members of the invisible government at Washington."

The marriage of Miss Virginia Frances Murray, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Murray of 68 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, to Francis G. McKee, son of Mrs. James McKee, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. McKee, will take place on Nov. 6 in the Church of St. Francis of Assisi. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Thomas A. Gately.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 20:
J. Vincent O'Shea'4 hound Pompoon emerged victor in the final heat of the Babylon Fox Hunt Club's annual two-day field trial meet at Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim's North Babylon estate today.

A truck load of rayon valued at between $4,000 and $5,000 was stolen from in front of 114 East Twenty-eighth Street early yesterday morning by two men who bound and gagged the driver of the truck and held him prisoner while they loaded the loot into another truck.

Coach Benny Friedman gave the City College football players a long lecture yesterday on their shortcomings in the game with Hobart on Saturday. He showed that the team's fumbling was largely responsible for the setback and indicated that he would try to remedy this during the week.

Weirdly contrasting defense witnesses held a crowded court room spellbound here today with testimony which they hope may save Laverne (John Montague) Moore, the Hollywood golf wonder, from a possible ten years in prison for first-degree robbery.

The State of California will consider tenders tomorrow for an issue of $4,524,050 of registered warrants, proceeds from which will go into the general State fund. The warrants will be dated Oct. 27, 1937, and will be payable on Feb. 23, 1938.

Reports filed with the Board of Elections yesterday showed that the largest sums contributed or spent in the current campaign had been in behalf of-the candidacy of Thomas E. Dewey for District Attorney of New York County.
After a hesitant opening in which some substantial declines were recorded, listed bonds staged a complate turn-about yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Micromatic Hone Corporation has purchased the business of manufacturing, servicing and seling of honing tools and replacement parts of the Hutto Machine dievsion of the Carborundum Corporation, which has sold the business of manufacturing,

Pennsylvania Central Airlines will inaugurate tomorrow a passenger, mail and express route linking Washington and Buffalo, - N. Y. Two ships will leave Washington airport at 8 A. M. Harllee Branch, Assistant Postmaster General; S. A.

The principal trouble with "I Accuse," adapted by James Agate from the German of Dr. Hans Rehfisch and Wilhelm Herzog, is that it presupposes the detailed knowledge of innumerable twists and turnings in "l'Affaire Dreyfus."
An overflow crowd of 14,000 saw the Irvington High eleven conquer Belleville, 31 to 0, tonight and continue undefeated in its quest of the North Jersey title.

The President's letter to the chairmen of the House and Senate Agricultural Committees laid down an admirable budget principle: It is, of course, especially important [the President wrote] that any new legislation should not unbalance the expected balancing of the budget.
Fifty-five C. I. O. taxi drivers parked their cabs last night bumper to bumper along the desolate stretches of River Avenue near the Bronx Terminal Market and "waited for fares." Harry Gehn,

Haywood Patterson, one of the nine Negroes in the Scottsboro case, who was convicted four times of rape, three times condemned to die and is now under sentence to serve seventy-five years in prison, failed today in the Supreme Court in an appeal from his last conviction.

Profit-taking and covering by the short interests yesterday sent New York Stock Exchange prices 2 to 10 points higher. Volume was 2,335,000 shares. The market opened weak, virtually every leader continuing the downward trend of Saturday. Toward the close of the first halfhour, however, bear speculators decided to take profits.

Reductions ranging from 7 1/2 to 17 1/2 cents and averaging about 121/2 cents a yard were announced on Spring and Summer suiting fabrics by two leading producers of wool piece goods yesterday, when lines which had been withdrawn for sale were reopened.

Miss Hildegard H. Erler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Erler of this place, has selected the afternoon of Nov. 6 for her marriage to Clarence P. Schneider, also of Clifton. The ceremony will take place in St. John's Lutheran Church, Passaic.

Dr. James Robinson English died here yesterday at his home after suffering a stroke Saturday. His age was 71. He was a consulting surgeon on the staff of Irvington (N. J.) General H spital and held a similar position at St. Mary's Hospital in Orange.

Through the generosity of a few wealthy men, Chicago is to have a Tumor Institute, to be directed by a distinguished scientific committee of experts in various fields. Like similar institutes here and abroad, it is to devote itself exclusively to research which is to enlarge our knowledge of cancer.

Federal officers spent much time today searching the liner Coamo of the Porto Rico Line on her arrival today from New York. Mrs. Elena Bazan de Vives, first-class passenger, had reported the theft of jewelry she valued at $3,500.
Eastchester Rd, 3,328 (16-4744); Arthur Wachtel, referee, to Mortgage Commission State of N. Y., trustee. 212th St, 713 E (16-4657); Louis J. Ciavarella to Rachel Zingariello, 3,209 Radcliff Ave.
Chinese refugees arriving in Canton tell of ill treatment at the hands of Japanese after the seizure of Pratas Island early in September. The refugees said the Japanese took twenty-nine Chinese,
Premier Paul van Zeeland and his entire Cabinet resigned tonight to defend themselves against charges growing out of alleged irregularities at the National Bank.

Twenty-four indictments, accusing forty-four men and women, were returned here today by the Federal grand jury investigating white slave traffic. Four others had been indicted previously and additional true bills may be handed down before the inquiry is completed.

Mutual savings banks will distribute this year Christmas Club deposits amounting to $51,657,361 for holiday spending, an increase of approximately $8,000,000 over 1936. A gain was likewise recorded in the number of depositors in the fourteen States in which these clubs operate, the total rising to 1,226,891, an increase of 163,000. The average account was estimated at $42.10.

Curtailment of steel production in the Pittsburgh district made itself felt today in the pay envelopes. While the proportion of workers laid off as a result of a production drop in the last few months from 90 per cent of capacity to less than 50 per cent is relatively small, many others have seen their work week reduced from forty to twenty-four hours.

The marriage of Miss Zoila Maria Bates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Escalante Bates of this city and Miami Beach, Fla., to Edgar Warren Bright of Marblehead Neck, Mass., and Fort Myers, Fla., took place here yesterday in the rectory of the Church of the Holy Name.

Hallgarten Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co., fiscal agents for the external dollar bonds of the Republic of Colombia, announced yesterday that they had received funds to redeem in full the outstanding balance of dollar arrears certificates of Republic of Colombia of 1933, which matured on Oct. 1,
Earle S. Hoyle, at 35 Prescott Rd, for Ada E. Maslin; Dr. Percy W. Roberts, at 98 Grandview Ave, for Dr. Enoch G. Brian; White Plains leases by Chauncey B. Griffen, broker.

Realty experts who attended the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards have carried home with them an enlightened picture of real estate and building conditions in other parts of the world.

Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, an organization sympathetic to the Spanish Government, told The Associated Press yesterday that they had been informed by wireless that the following nine American members of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade had died in action during an offensive against Belchite on the Aragon front:
The Inurgent drive to force a wedge between Catalonia and Valencia encountered stiff resistance today along the Aragon front in northeast Spain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Whenever a drastic decline occurs in the stock market prejudiced observers love to ascribe it to the unconscionable short seller. I suppose there is no practice in all the mechanics of the stock market which is subject to such wholesale and bitter attack.

Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn yesterday came to the defense of Isidore Nagler, American Labor party candidate for the Bronx Borough Presidency, by pointing out that he had been closely associated with Mr. Nagler as impartial chairman in the cloak and suit industry and had never found the labor leader with communistic tendencies.
Women members of the electorate have frequently been called too idealistic to be effective in politics, but Mrs. Leopold K. Simon,
Fees totaling $125,000 were allowed today by Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker to Warren Dixon Jr. and three assistants in the court's investigation of Newark affairs.

MANHATTAN BOVEE, ELEANOR (April 22). Gross assets, $277,677; net, $254,393. To Lorna Livingston and Mary Bovee Taylor, greatnieces, $10,000 and contingent interests in $25,000 each; Gertrude Bovee Johnson and Mary Bovee McAdoo, nieces, $10,000 each; William J. Schieffelin Jr., $14,000; Bessie Bovee Vernan, $2,500 and contingent interest in $5,000; Robert Jackson, $2,000 and contingent interest in $2,000;

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Rhythm and Pattern," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; Near Eastern art (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Color in Peasant Art," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Egypt: Life in the Middle Kingdom," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 4 P. M.

The Rev. Dr. William Adams Brown, Research Professor Emeritus in Applied Theology of the Union Theological Seminary, will conduct the funeral service at 8:30 o'clock tonight for Lafayette Blanchard Gleason at the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street.
Fred W. Whiteside, twice candidate for Governor of Delaware on the Socialist ticket, died today in his Arden home at the age of 70. Mr. Whiteside was long active in the Socialist movement.

Have you ever returned in the Spring to your favorite stream and found it choked with industrial rubbish and barren of fish? Have you ever returned to find a dam and a mill on the site of your favorite pool? Have you ever sat by a ruined stream and devised strange tortures for the members of your State public service commission who countenanced this ruin?

For the first time in their reign King George VI and Queen Elizabeth are expected to ride down Whitehall in their crystal coach tomorrow to open the new session of Parliament. The last session, which ended Friday, was opened by King Edward VIII, now the Duke of Windsor, who went to Westminster through a rainstorm in a closed car only a month before his abdication.

The three-story industrial building at 35-19 Thirty-sixth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Northfield Schools, represented by the trust department of the Bank of Manhattan Company, to Charles Srebroff.

Men and women distinguished in public life, journalism, business and the professions paid their last tribute today to George Horace Lorimer at a simple funeral service held at Belgraeme, the Lorimer estate in Wyncote.

The government of the Province of Quebec will not tolerate "ruinous overproduction" in the Province's newsprint industry, Premier Duplessis said today. In an interview at the government offices here, the Premier said:

ARNOLD-Maurice, Oct. 23, 1937, husband of Johanna Arnold. Funeral services at Campbell Funeral Church, Broadway and 66th St., Tuesday, Oct. 26, 1 P. M. BAUM-Jacob, of Los Angeles, Calif., formerly of Jersey City, in his seventysecond year, beloved father of Elsie Rosenthal, Ruth Baum and Hilda Balter.
Mrs. C. Dixon Fagan of Germantown has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Florence Zell Fagan, to Edward Finley Boyd Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Finley Boyd of Westport, Conn.

Princeton University's Theatre Intime, undergraduate dramatic organization, opened its seventeenth annual- season tonight in Murray Theatre with a presentation of Robert Nail's "Time of Their Lives," a satirical drama of student life at old Nassau first produced in 1933, the author's senior year.

Miss Elsa Maxwell gave a dinner dance last night in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for Vicomte Sosthenes de la Rochefoucauld, who is visiting here from Paris. A special entertainment, in which several of the guests participated, featured the party.
The cameras clicked with regularity at Empire City yesterday as the result of an unusual series of close finishes that kept the crowd on its toes. Five of the six races were decided by photos.
For the first time in many years Tammany Hall will fail to stage its final big rally of a political campaign in Madison Square Garden on the Saturday night before the election.

The escape of the Italian Socialist, Glacomo Costa, and four companions from an Italian prison on the Island of Lampedusa in the Mediterranean was reported today by the newspaper Le Soir in a dispatch from Tunis.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced last night that shipowners in New Orleans had agreed to sign a new contract with their pier workers that would provide an hourly wage of 95 cents for regular time and $1.40 an hour for overtime.
Contracts were awarded on three of the six items under invitation 65 at the Army Quartermaster Depot here today. These included: (1) 36-inch bleached duck, 8.2-ounce weight, 225.793 yards:

The visit to Rome of Viscount Kimitomo Mushakoji, Ambassador to Bertin, has revived press reports that Italy desires to adhere to the German-Japanese agreement that is reputedly aimed at the Communist International.

An official announcement was made tonight that Premier Benito Mussolini would pay public homage on Oct. 29 to Italians who have fallen in Spain by placing a crown of oak leaves on the tomb of the Unknown Soldier in their honor.

Miss Barbara J. Day, daughter of Mrs. E. McCormack Day of 150 East Thirty-ninth Street, will be married next Monday to Edward John Noble, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Noble of Round Hill, Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony will be performed in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
Mrs. Alice de Trafford, formerly Miss Alice Silverthorne of Buffalo, N. Y., today received a divorce decree from Raymond Vincent de Trafford, on grounds of adultery. Her suit was not contested.

John R. Jones, Democratic candidate for District Attorney of Westchester County, requested Governor Lehman in a telegram today to force District Attorney Walter A. Ferris, Republican candidate for re-election, to try two men who have been under indictment since 1931 for the murder in a North Castle roadhouse of Lawrence R. Volpe, alias Bob Mason.

The consolidated net profit of the American Rolling Mill Company in the first nine months of this year, according to the statement issued yesterday, amounted to $9,289,295 after provision for taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.
Producers yesterday lowered the price of zinc 1/4-cent a pound to 5 3/4 cents at East St. Louis. This is the first change since Oct. 15 when the price was reduced from 6 1/4 cents to 6.
All those aboard the British freighter Kaitangata, which caught fire in the South China Sea yesterday, have been accounted for except nineteen Chinese members of the crew.

Counsel for the government introduced interoffice letters today in their effort to prove thai some of the defendant oil companies in the anti-trust case being tried here engaged in a concerted buying program to' further an alleged pricefixing conspiracy.

A greater measure .of protection for more than 140 species of birds which annuallyy migrate between Northeastern United States and Mexico will be afforded in the future as the result of. a treaty now being negotiated between this country and Mexico, Dr. T. Gilbert Pearson, president emeritus of the National Association of. Audubon Societies, told the convention of that organization yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.
Last-minute touches will be put today on the thirty-eighth annual National Automobile Show, which will open tomorrow at 2 P. M. in Grand Central Palace for a run of eight days.

Mrs. Elizabeth Cox Binney Lansdale, an officer of Chapter 2, Colonial Dames of America, and a member of the Acorn Club, died at her home, Shrubbery, in St. David's yesterday after an illness of seven months. She was 87 years old.

Andy Farkas of the University of Detroit, whose light had been hidden not under the traditional bushel but under the fact that his team doesn't play in any of football's big leagues, bobbed up yesterday as the leading touchdown getter of the 1937 season, according to The Associated Press.
Wheat prices were higher on the Board of Trade here today as a result of firmness in Liverpool, a strong rally in stocks and the development of independent strength in corn. At the top,

The Fordham football squad went through a light workout on Fordham Field yesterday as preparations were begun for the intersectional game with undefeated University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on Saturday.

Showing surprising tenacity, thirtyeight large and small college football teams throughout the nation remained on the select list of the undefeated and untied, while only fifteen were removed from last week's list of fifty-three, according to the records compiled by The Associated Press.

Fred Ivamy of Watchung died today in Muhlenburg Hospital, Plainfield. He was born in Winborne, England, and was 87 years old. Shortly after coming to this country about fifty years ago, he was employed as a steward at the Rumson Club and later at the Plainfield Country Club and the Union County Country Club of Plainfield.

A large junior committee, under the chairmanship of Miss Mary Burgess Bristow, is assisting with arrangements for the performance of Mozart's comic opera, "Cosi Fan Tutte," by the Salsburg Opera Guild the night of Nov. 6 at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre for the

Dr. Otto Mattes of 62 Livingston Avenue, who practiced dentistry in New York for fifty-five years, died here this afternoon in St. John's Riverside Hospital following an operation performed ten days ago. His age was 78.
Mayor La Guardia issued yesterday a proclamation directing pub-lic attention to the fact that tomorrow is Navy Day and also the birthday of President Theodore Roosevelt.
Making two goal-line stands in the second half, Emerson High of Union City battled to a scoreless tie with Bayonne today before 2,000 spectators in a Hudson County game.

Charles Baskerville, portrait painter, in the 38. Central Park S; G. Keith Funston, in 166 E 96th St, through Pease Elliman, Inc; Charles F. Fuller, in 145 E 55th St; Mary E. Frost, in 36 E 40th St, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, 'Inc; Culver, Hollyday Co,--brokers.

Charles J. Hardy received a $67,564 salary as president of the American Car and Foundry Company in the year ended on April 30, according to a report made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.

Expansion of Arnold Constable Co.'s store at Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street reflects further evidence of the confidence of merchants in Fifth Avenue as the foremost merchandising thoroughfare of the world, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared at a ceremony in connection with the unveiling of a bronze plaque erected by officers and employes of that store in dedication of the new, six-story extension yesterday afternoon.

Business failures in the United States totaled 191 for the week ended Oct. 21, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 174 for the five business days of the week before and 160 for the corresponding week last year.

With 1,300 cases of gold ingots and millions of dollars worth of money, jewels, securities, pictures, plate and treasures of every sort stored in her hold, the British tramp steamer Middle steamed into Havre several days ago from Gijon.
Due to delay by Ford in resuming production, automobile output last week made only a small gain and well under the calculated seasonal rise.
Aggressive comments of the German press on events in Czechoslovakia continue with the same vigor. Beyond the facts already known, they are fed today by two new developments.

The scheduled court-martial of Brig, Gen. Harold C. Reisinger, Marine Corps paymaster, on charges of making erroneous reports in connection with his travel accounts was delayed indefinitely today because former Brig.

Average daily sales of milk last month were up 5.36 per cent compared with September, 1936, according to reports reaching the Milk Industry Foundation here yesterday from 136 leading markets. Sales during September averaged 6,672,322 quarts daily compared with the average of 6,332,912 quarts in the corresponding month last year.

A Midwest desperado seized $1,200 from a cashier on the eighth floor of the John Wanamaker store here this afternoon, shot a socially prominent broker who tried to intercept him, raced down stairways to the street and jumped into a taxicab.
Crown Prince Michael's promotion to a lieutenancy in the army on his sixteenth birthday today was celebrated with great military pomp and popular enthusiasm at Sinaia Castle.
The two-family residence at 2,323 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, was sold for cash by the Kramshor Realty Corporation to an Ba investing client of Charles M. Hiesiger, attorney in the deal.
Ken Overlin, Richmond (Va.) middleweight, knocked out Joe Lynch of Jersey City in the seventh of their scheduled ten-rounder tonight.

The great of the land paid final tribute today to Lord Rutherford, "the greatest experimental physicist since Faraday," at an impressive funeral in Westminster Abbey. His ashes were placed in "science corner," where Newton, Faraday, Darwin and Kelvin are buried.

Countess Clanwilliam, wife of the Earl of Clanwilliam of London, and Mrs. Percival Brooks of Norwalk, Conn., are at the Waldorf-Astoria. Miss Florence Van Rensselaer and Miss Sarah D. Gardiner, who have been in Santa Barbara, Calif., are expected to arrive tomorrow at the Plaza.
Troubles on the frontier between Haiti and the Dominican Republic are being ironed out amicably, the ministers of the two nations indicated tonight.
Today's major events: At the Town Hall, Jorge Bolet, pianist, in the afternoon, and Richard Tauber, tenor, in the evening; at Carnegie Hall, the Vienna Choir Boys and Joseph Schmidt, tenor.

Mr. and Mrs. Minton Cronkhite entertained at dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mr. Cronkhite's niece, Miss Ruth Mary Ruxton, and Roy D. Chapin Jr., whose marriage will take place here on Friday in St. Bartholomew's Church.
