State police sent out an eight-State alarm tonight for a motorist accused of deliberately running down a 13year-old school girl here this morning, placing her in his automobile and driving her to a point near Tuxedo Park, N. Y., where he dropped her at the roadside.

Opening work for the Penn State game here Saturday featured Syracuse's session today. An extensive drill on offensive tactics occupied most of the time, but a heavy casualty list handicapped the work. Vic Baylock and Jack Hinkle, backs;

Dr. Edward Lee Meierhof, retired eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel Westover, Seventy-second Street and West End Avenue, after an illness of several months. He was 76 years old.

The Department of Commerce adjusted index figure. for the value of retail sales of new passenger automobiles declined sharply from 120.5 in August to 105.0 in September, the department announced today.
Prosecutor John C. Kelley said tonight he would file a second-degree murder charge against David Kalakaua Kawananakoa, 33 years old, in connection with, the death of the girl he called his wife.

The formal resignation of Premier Ismet Inonu and the appointment in his place of Jelal Bayar, who has been acting as Prime Minister since Sept. 22, was announced tonight after a meeting of the Council of Ministers.

General Nuri as Said, last survivor of the great triumvirate which worked with King Felsal in winning the independence of Iraq, returned by air from Damascus today and is expected to resume an active part in Controlling his country's affairs before long.

Miss Virginia Craig, daughter of Harry J. Craig of this city, has chosen Nov. 11 as the date for her marriage to Wilbur S. Pratt, also of Hartford, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Irving Pratt of Oswego, N. Y. The ceremony will take place in the Immanuel Congregational Church.
Steady rain tonight cheered trainers preparing their charges for Wednesday's ninety-ninth Cesarewitch, while turf followers continued to wager huge sums on the outcome of the important handicap.
Following his recent conference with Serbian opposition leaders, Vladimir Matchek, leader of the Croat Peasant party gave THE NEW YORK TIMES the following statement:

Despite an increase in automobile accidents and injuries in the city last week as compared with the corresponding week of 1936, the number of fatalities declined, statistics made public yesterday by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner, showed. The reverse was true for the week-end.

Monroe Percy Bloch, counsel of the Honest Ballot Association, said yesterday that the association would be able to assign several thousand instructed Non-Partisan workers to the polls on Election Day. Volunteers had been obtained, he said, from the League of Women Voters, Non-Partisan Aviation Committee, Citizens Union and other civic organizations.

Keenly anxious to gain its first major victory of the season by defeating Pennsylvania at Philadelphia Saturday, Coach Hardwick departed from routine and held a stiff scrimmage for his Navy regulars this afternoon.
A first mortgage loan of $52,500 at 5 per cent for five years has been arranged by Samuel Kronsky Co for the 68 E 55th St Corp on the five-story building at that address.

Col. Gen. Hermann Goering's official Four-Year. Plan organ, entitled The Four-Year Plan, announces today that German blood citizens of other countries must now be organized to aid the self-sufficiency plan.

Dr. Juan Mendoza, counselor of the Peruvian Embassy in Washington, who is supervising the activities of the paying agency for the Republic of Peru here, announced yesterday that the paying agency had bought, up to the close of business yesterday, coupons, in accordance with the offer made on Aug. 25, from a total of $26,000,000 principal amount of bonds.

With reports from out-of-town stores indicating that last week's retail sales were, on the average, ahead of a year ago, possibly, by 5 per cent, a fair amount of business was placed in the local merchandise markets yesterday, according to manufacturers and resident offices.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Dorothy Coleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Richard Coleman of this place, to Howard Gilbert Engler, son of Mrs. Charles H. Engler of South Orange. The ceremony will take place the evening of Nov. 5 in St. George's Episcopal Church here.
One of the Confederacy's heroines, Mrs. Joseph L. Griswold, who aided two fugitives from a Union prison camp, died here today in her ninety-eighth year.

The AAA made a 2,000,000-acre reduction today in the cotton crop goal for next year. Approving the 1938 agricultural conservation program, Secretary Wallace fixed its goal so far as cotton is concerned at 27,000,000 to 29,000,000 acres. Previously it had been placed at 29,000,000 to 31,000,000 acres.

The Lawyers Committee for the Re-election of Supreme Court Justice Thomas F. Noonan, formed when he was denied nomination by the Republican and American Labor parties, yesterday made public endorsements from Max D. Steuer and former Justice Joseph H. Proskauer. Justice Noonan is on the Democratic slate.

Although almost three weeks remain before the annual renewal of the oldest prep school football classic, Andover has started to point for its traditional game with Exeter, scheduled Saturday, Nov. 13, at Exeter, N. H.

Dr. Marvin A. Stevens could build up quite a private practice for himself among the injured members of his New York University football team. He has lost seven regulars to date, four more backs going to join the wheel-chair brigade on Saturday.

Beginning with the meeting of United States Steel directors this afternoon, the board meetings of Bethlehem Steel, Chrysler, General Motors and other principal corporations will follow in what is becoming known as "the big industry week" of the quarter.

Final play began at the Westchester Country Club here tonight in the seventh annual Westchester County contract bridge tournament for the J. Noel Macy Trophy. Twenty-eight pairs took part and will complete the play tomorrow night, when the trophy will be awarded.

Brown's varsity eleven had a rest today as a reward for defeating Columbia. All players, including the reserves, were excused from the drill and the varsity coaches watched the freshmen remain undefeated by downing the hitherto unbeaten Worcester Academy, 6 to 0.

Following the bombing and sinking of the French cargo boat Oued Mella in the Mediterranean yesterday by an "unknown" airplane, a French boat belonging to the Company Air France has been bombed and burned at Fornells in Minorca.

The Treasury's first issue of short-term bills maturing about March 15, the quarterly income tax payment date, sold at an average interest rate of 0.261, compared with an average of 0.362 on the last issue of ninemonth bills sold last week, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

The New YorkCity voter this Fall has a good deal of home work to do if he is to keep up with his lessons. It is too bad, in a way, that there must be added to his duties that of selecting delegates to next Spring's State Constitutional Convention-a convention called urider the terms of the Constitution, Article XIV, Section 2.

Every Yale regular breezed through nearly an hour's work today, including individual assignments and signal rehearsal. New plays which Coaches Ducky Pond and Earl Neale believe are ideally suited for the reception of the unbeaten Dartmouth Indian tribe here Saturday were tried.

The Bees today named Casey Stengel, former manager of the Dodgers, as their pilot for 1938, succeeding William B. McKechnie. J. Robert Quinn, president of the Bees, telephoned Stengel at the latter's home in Omaha, Texas, and offered him the job.
The entire blockfront on the east side of Amsterdam Avenue, from Ninety - second to Ninety - third Street, has been sold by the Methodist Episcopal Church Home to Henry Kaufman and Emery Roth.

Premier Duplessis of Quebec and Mayor Raynault of Montreal served notice today that they would fight in this province everything which savors of communism-and they will be the arbiters of what constitutes communism.

Trading was only fair to slow. Lamb sold strong to slightly higher and other classes were steady to lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady. veal and calf strong to higher. lamb sharply higher as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
B. P. Schulberg announced today that "Permit to Kill," a story of violation of the Federal Food and Drug Act, would be placed in immediate production.

To a great degree the aggressiveness of the Japanese Governmet may be attributed to contacts Japanese statesmen have had with Western civilization, the Right. Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop-elect of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, said in an interview here yesterday.

The Uruguayan Minister, Jose Richling, said today he would be in New York on Nov. 3 to sign a readjustment agreement on Republic of Uruguay bonds with the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council of New York.

In the Fall of 1887 Pete Kelly, an East Broadway lad of 14, walked into an office at 198 Broadway and asked for a job with the young New York Telephone Company. In his father's downtown barber shop he had heard customers agree there was a great future in the new invention that could send voices to any part of the city by a crank of the wrist.

Members of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association met yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Francis Rogers, 144 East Sixty-second Street, to make plans for a benefit matinee performance of "The Meistersinger" on Jan. 14 at the Metropolitan Opera.

Joseph Fell, Inc, dresses, additional space in 463 7th Ave; Maurice W. Kalman, cigars and cigarettes, store at 101 W 37th St; Bruno J. Loeb, ladies' neckwear, in 12 W 36th St; Barney Bloom, silk and rayon broker; in 151 W 40th St; Spear Co, Inc. brokers.

Without resuming play in the ninth game of their world championship match, which was adjourned last night after forty-one moves, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris today agreed to a draw.
Suit for divorce was filed against the Count of Covadonga, eldest son of former King Alfonso of Spain, today, by Marta Rocafort, his Cuban commoner wife, in the court of first instance.

" Emotionally Mayor La Guardia is not a normal person," Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, his former Police Commissioner, declared in a radio address last night. "If re-elected he would bound emotionally from the gloom of uncertainty and perhaps despair, now covered with a veneer of bravado, to the peak of confidence and arrogance.

Whitney Randolph Truman, New York real estate operator, died of ? heart attack yesterday at his home, 136 Whitson Street, Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 53. Mr. Truman had been active in real estate circles here for the last twenty-five years.

Harry Doane of 842 Lake Street, treasurer of a calendar manufacturing company and a former newspaperman, died tonight of a heart attack in an elevator at 9 Clinton Street shortly after he had left a meeting of a building and loan association.
FormerPresident Hoover and former Governor Landon are understood to have assured party leaders that they will not seek the Presidential nomination in 1940.

Thrusting aside memories of the 19 to 0 defeat by Kentucky, the Manhattan football squad went through a short drill yesterday afternoon at Innisfail Park as Coach Chick Meehan began preparations for the clash with Georgetown on Saturday in Washington.

Al Reid, 127, Bronx featherweight, gained the decision over Johnny Defoe, 127, the West Side, in the feature eight-round bout at St. Nicholas Palace last night. Reid, scoring heavily with hard rights to the head, floored the loser for no count in the seventh.

Miss Doris Vivian Van Buskirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wood Van Buskirk of Norfolk, was married here yesterday to Ralph Raymond Rogers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. R. R. Rogers of Housatonic, Mass., by the Rev. Dr. James H. Potter, pastor of the Norfolk Congregational Church.

The Bank of New York and Trust Company has been appointed registrar of 140,000 shares of 6 per cent non-cumulative $100-par preferred stock and 560,000 no-par common shares of the American Ice Company. Daniel Simonds 2d, vice president of the Simonds Saw and Steel Company, has been elected a director of the Luscombe Airplane Company.
Governor Lehman told the National Preaching Mission today "once again religion must come to rescue the world from barbarism and destruction."

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Edward J. Ennis, Henderson Mathews and A. V. Cherbonnier of New York were admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had: 434--Municipal City of South Bend, Ind., applt., v. John P. DeHaven, Treasurer of St. Joseph County, Ind., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Indiana. The motion of appellees to dismiss the appeal granted, for want of properly presented substantial Federal question.

A reduction of $20,000 a month, or 40 per cent, has been effected in the administrative budget of the four WPA Federal arts projects in this city, Paul Edwards, administrative officer, announced yesterday.

A new two-story business building will be constructed at 18-20 West Forty-eighth Street, opposite Rockefeller Center, for occupancy under a long-term lease by an old bookselling firm, according to an announcement made yesterday.

Clint Frank, Yale's All-America back, found himself in the spotlight today, the leading man in a football play that threatens to become a new problem for rule makers and officials. The play occurred in the third quarter of the Yale-Cornell game here Saturday, which the sons of Eli won, 9 to 0.

President Roosevelt, in a letter, and Secretary Perkins, in an address, today told- representatives of the Governors of forty-five States that much had been accomplished -in labor legislation through Federal and State cooperation and declared that State aid would be needed to attain the ultimate goal.
The Public Works Administration announced today completion of its reorganization from a State to a regional basis and appointment of regional personnel.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has arrived here for a brief stay at Bessett Hall. Among arrivals at the Williamsburg Inn are Mrs. Alfred E. Smith, Mrs. Josephine O'Brien, Mrs. Danfel Mooney, Dr. Edmond Leroy Dow, Mr. and Mrs. A. W. McCain,
Quietly, and with a certain amount of grimness, Columbia's football forces started work yesterday on preparations for the visit to Ithaca and Cornell this week-end and the games which lie beyond.

Two women foiled a landlord attempting to evict two families in Brooklyn yesterday morning by chaining themselves across the hallway of the tenement at 389 Riverdale Avenue, near Powell Street, in the Brownsville section.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler disapproved yesterday a plan for reorganization of the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company under which Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, would be authorized to turn over control of the Lawyers Title Corporation, a subsidiary, to the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company in return for preferred stock redeemable for $1,300,000 at the end of five years.

President Roosevelt received an invitation today from his Business Advisory Council to have a meal with them soon, but, according to W. Averell Harriman, the head of the council did not discuss the stock market or business recession which many business leaders see now as current.

Manufacturers' sales of confectionery and competitive chocolate products attained higher levels in September, 1937, than for any like month since 1929, according to estimate made by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce from reports from 286 manufacturers.

The Brooklyn College football team enjoyed a day of rest after the victory over Lowell Textile Saturday. Coach Lou Oshins held a short board session, discussing the various mistakes occurring in the Kingsmen's offensive and defensive play, concentrating on the poor handling of punts and the poor downfield blocking.
The Viceroy of India was involved in an accident today when a canopy under which he was sitting at a ceremony of presenting colors to a native regiment collapsed.

The hearing scheduled by the Interstate Commerce Commission for Nov. 16 in the reorganization of the Spokane International Railway Company may serve as the focal point for arguments by leading attorneys practicing before the Interstate Commerce Commisison on the question of altering the traditional rights of security holders in railroad reorganizations, it was learned today.

Early losses which had carried some deliveries on the Cotton Exchange here below 8 cents a pound were recovered later when Wall Street interests rebought and Southern selling again was light. All months closed unchanged on the day except the January, which was 6 points lower. The December, after selling off from 8.10 cents a pound to 8.02, rallied to 8.19 and closed at 8.14 cents.

Frank L. Polk, Acting 'Secretary of State under President Woodrow Wilson, has accepted the chairmanship of the special gifts committee of the 1937 roll-call of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, it was announced yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the organization.

All those shows that Max Gordon hopes to produce some day have been joined by another. For Mr. Gordon has bought a play called "Honey," by Ward Green-the same Mr. Green whose novel, "Death in the Deep South," turned into the motion picture called "They Won't Forget."

Miss Mary Elizabeth Shaughnessy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Shaughnessy Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., was married this evening in the First Congregational Church here to Donald Smith Valden, son of D. Harvey Valden and the late Mrs. Valden of Ridgefield. Conn.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, declared today that the union was "going to get the scalp" of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission.
Waldvogel Brothers, Inc., 420 Lexington Avenue, have been appointed sole distributors in the New York metropolitan area of the acoustical products of the United States Gypsum Company.

The State, through Governor Earle, decreed today that there must be no extension of natural gas use-in Pennsylvania until the affairs of the coal industry, including disposition of the "bootleg" mining problem and other difficulties besetting the bituminous and anthracite trade, had been set right.

The unsolved Redwood murder case was injected into the New Jersey Gubernatorial campaign today when James F. Murray, Jersey City lawyer, foe of Mayor Frank Hague of this city and independent candidate for Governor with the label "Roosevelt-Labor-Anti-Hague," criticized the "inactivity" of Prosecutor John J. Breslin of Bergen County in the case.

The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Oct. 18 totaled 11,068,319 running bales, compared with 8,569,476 to that date last year, and 6,590,402 in 1935. Round bales, counted as half bales, included totaled 186,174, compared with 148,827 for 1936, and 103,676 for 1935. American-Egyptian included totaled 3,669 bales, compared with 4,158 and 4,885 in the previous two years.

The discovery of an elixir for the trans formation of plant life which enormously accelerates evolution, which can produce new, better, bigger and hardier flowers, fruits, vegetables and perhaps trees, and which turns annuals into perennials and makes sterile hybrids fruitful, was announced here today at a meeting

Intimidation of storekeepers supporting American Labor party candidates and the wrecking of a number of the party's campaign offices was reported to the police last night. Following several complaints special police orders were issued for the protection of the campaign offices and for neighborhood stores displaying banners of the American Labor party.

Using the slogan "we've just begun to fight," Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, lashed out last night at the American Labor party, and charged that it had been organized as a vehicle through which Luigi Antonini, its State chairman, could collect money to give advancement to the cause of communism throughout the world.
Two pairs tied for topmost honors in the final pro-amateur golf tournament of the New Jersey P. G. A., today by shooting four under par best balls of 67 at the Echo Lake Country Club.

The New Zealand cartoonist, David Low, directs today's cartoon in The Evening Standard at the muchacclaimed Italian "rescue" of non-intervention last week. In the drawing Ivan M. Maisky, Soviet Ambassador;

In the face of a demand for recognition of the Financial Workers Organizing Committee, a C. I. O. affiliate, as collective bargaining agent for its forty-four employes, the Bank of Yorktown set forth yesterday its belief that banks, as public institutions, were immune from strikes in the same sense as government departments.

Mrs. Bessie Bartnoisky, 45 years old, of' 1,733 West Fifth Street, Brooklyn, who was found guilty of first-degree manslaughter by a jury on Oct. 8 for the hammer slaying of her mother-in-law, Mrs. Ethel Bartnofsky, 75, was sentenced yesterday by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato to serve from five

Gladys Breitfeller, a 15-year-old Jamaica High School student, stabbed her father to death yesterday morning in their home at 90-03 207th Street, Bellaire, Queens, after he had resumed a quarrel with her mother that had started at 3 A. M.

Movements vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 25 unless specified: At San Diego: Bobolink, Oct. 23; Cincinnati, Oct. 24. At Woosung, Oct. 24: Canopus, Henderson. At Mare Island Yard, Oct. 23; Brazos, Quincy. At Guantanamo Bay: Gannett, Oct. 23; Winslow.

United States PURCHASING OFFICER $3.200 a year; ASSISTANT PURCHASING OFFICER, $2.600; JUNIOR PURCHASING OFFICER, $2,000. Procurement Division, Treasury Department. Applications must be on file not later than Nov. 22 if received from States other than those named below, Nov.
The general increase in freight rates granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission last week will benefit the Great Northern Railway little, W. P. Kenney, president, said yesterday.

The fact that. ten years ago world consumption of American cotton amounted to more than 61 per cent of the total and today is only slightly more than 42 per cent is the reason behind a new advertising campaign which Wellington, Sears Company, representing seventeen cotton mills, is launching on a nation-wide scale, Norman Horm, advertising manager, said yesterday.

An appeal to the hearts as well as to the pocketbooks of New Yorkers to rally to the support of the city's ninety-two voluntary hospitals, which this year are seeking a minimum of $3,171,134 toward their maintenance, was made last night as the 1937 United Hospital Fund campaign was launched at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore.

Among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White, Star liner Aquitania are the Earl and Countess of Granard and their son, Viscount Forbes; the Ranee of Sarawak, author; Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, Brig. Gen. Wallace Wright and Efrem Zimbalist, violinist.
A Constitution Ball, sponsored jointly by the State societies of Delaware, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, may open the capital's Winter social program.

The greatest speed ever attained by a normally designed racing car was reached today when Bernd Rosemeyer, the German auto union's star driver, covered 405.138 kilometers on the motor road between Frankfurt and Heidelberg in an attempt to break several records.

If the claims of Japanese Army spokesmen concerning the situation in the vicinity of Shanghai at dawn today are correct, then the Chinese armies defending Kiangwan and Chapei are in an extremely precarious position.

Clayton R. Burt, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association, appealed today for closer cooperation between the Administration at Washington and American industry in creating production of more and better goods and improved working conditions.

Exclusion from Westchester County jury service of persons who do not own real estate or are not married to owners was criticized this afternoon by speakers at the opening session of a school for women jurors under the -auspices of the Westchester League of Women Voters.
" The primary cause of the current business recession may be traced to aggressive labor movements early in 1937 which brought shorter hours and higher pay which were wholly unrelated to efficiency,"

A check-up yesterday revealed that more than $160,000 was realized on Saturday at auction sales of properties located in Westchester County, Long Island and Brooklyn. A total of 161 parcels changed hands.
In a book to be published tomorrow Professor'Thurman W. Arnold of Yale declares that the old myths on business and capitalism are. on the way out. The book is entitled '"The Folklore of Capitalism."

To translate literally the title of an officer of the wrench Academy, Lafayette B. Gleason was Perpetual Secretary. An educated and a cultivated man, a good lawyer, he went into politics fifty years ago.

Albert Marinelli, New York Couny Clerk and leader of half of the Second Assembly District, was challenged yesterday to submit his district organization of county committeemen and election inspectors for fingerprinting by the Police Department.

As the first step in a campaign against personnel cuts in the Consolidated -Edison system, the Utility Workers .Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, called-a strike yesterday of linemen and chauffeurs employed in the Elmhurst division of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company.

In 1888 Sidney Lanier asked in a magazine article what we should say of an art which is becoming so much the daily companion of man as to sit by every fireside and in every church, which even thrusts itself into crowded streets, presides at weddings, at feasts, at great funerals, which marches at the head of battle and opens the triumphant ceremonials of peace ?
A new record was set yesterday in Downtown Traffic Court when 1,351 motorists were arraigned before Magistrates Thomas A. Aurelio and Harry G. Andrews. The traffic violators paid in $1,371 in fines.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 22: CAPTAIN Child, W. G., when discharged from treatments at the Naval Hospital. Mare Island, Calif., to await orders at home pending retirement; relieved from all active duty.

Harold Henry, American pianist who has not appeared here for several seasons, gave a recital at the Town Hall last night. He has played in Europe and South America and has been soloist with orchestras here and abroad.
King George II of Greece, who is expected here early in November, will include Rome and Paris in his first trip abroad since he returned to the throne in 1935.

Mayor La Guardia opened a Board of Estimate hearing on budget reductions in City Hall yesterday morning with the statement that if revenue were not found to offset the $12,000,000 cut in water rates voted by the Board of Aldermen, there would be no 1938 budget.
A special meeting of stockholders of the W. T. Grant Company has been called for Nov. 26 for action on a plan designed to simplify the corporate structure of the concern.

The National Peace Conference, composed of forty national organizations, in a statement transmitted to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today, supported the action of the United States in agreeing to participate in the Nine-Power Treaty conference on the Far East at Brussels.

Applications for Transfer Applications for transfers to the Marine Division will be considered from members who are desirous of studying for the positions of marine engineer or pilot. Preference will be given to those members who have had marine, machine shop or boilermaking experience. Applications, briefly stating experience, shall be forwarded, through official channels, to the Office Chief of Department, on Wednesday, Oct. 27.

New York University's varsity basketball team will engage in twenty-one games this season, according to Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics. Eight games will be played in the University Heights gymnasium, seven at Madison Square Garden and six on the road.

Aroused over the charge that civil service examiners accepted bribes in return for high ratings on papers, James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, wrote yesterday to the Progressive party asking it to retract the statement.

FOR presumably good reasons of his own, the Governor General of Canada has picked this as the proper time to bring forth a laudatory study of the Fuehrer principle in politics.* Not, of course, the principle as it is applied today; at this moment in history that would be both unexpected and embarrassing in. an official of the British Commonwealth of Nations.
Ralph Greenleaf, defending champion, and Benny Allen of Kansas City emerged triumphant in the opening matches of the world's pocket-billiard championship before 400 spectators tonight.
The American College of Surgeons issued here today a list of 2,621 approved hospitals in the United States. Those of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are as follows:

Walter O'Gorman, who was released on Oct. 16 from the Federal House of Detention, where he had been locked up for violating his parole after serving seventy-two days of a year's sentence for impersonating a Federal officer, was held in bail of $3,000 yesterday when he was arraigned before Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, on a similar charge.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 52.1 per cent of capacity this week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This rate compares with 55.8 per cent last week, a decrease of 3.7 points, or 6.6 per cent.

Coach Harvey Harman of the University of Pennsylvania today issued a statement saying that Penn's disallowed field goal in the last 30 seconds of play against Georgetown on Saturday was nullified not because of twelve men on the field, but for delaying the game.

The Visiting Nurse Association in Brooklyn will be represented for the first time in the annual campaign for the United Hospital Fund, which will be opened officially tomorrow with a luncheon at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

Postmaster General Farley, saying this country "is on the way to experience the greatest prosperity it has ever had," urged today the election of Democratic delegates to the State Constitutional Convention. Speaking at a luncheon meeting of almost 1,000 Monroe County Democrats, the State and national party chairman said that "no greater issue than the Constitutional Convention has been presented to the people of this State in twenty years."
Indian Summer has come to the Arctic. Last week the temperature was thirteen below zero. It looked- like real Winter had arrived for good.
Frank Crossley of Bradford, member of the vaudeville team of Willie West and McGinty, died today while on his way to a hospital here in an automobile from Bradford. His age was 55.

Declaring that he was certain of re-election, but could not work alone, Mayor La Guardia appealed last night for the election of a Board of Estimate and a City Council that would work with him to give New York City the same kind of good government that it has had for the past four years.

Mayor La Guardia at rally in Brooklyn said that the raising of the "Red" issue proved that his rival, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, had become panicky. He also ridiculed the charge that the American Labor party was in any way communistic. [Page 1.]

In an austere police room Captain John McQueeney, over 6 feet tall and called "tough and cold-eyed," proved yesterday in the Liberty Avenue station in Brooklyn that the night-stick is not the Police Department's only method of settling disputes.

The streamlined vogue has reached a period of consolidation in automobile body design. The general outlines of motor car bodies have been undergoing a gradual development since streamlining started a new, conventional, modern styling.

The first contract for the World's Fair spur from the Queens Boulevard line of the Independent Subway System was awarded yesterday by the Board of Transportation to the lowest bidder, the P. T. Cox Contracting Company, at the bid price of $308,770.

Ralph H. Sweetser, New York consulting engineer, was quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 22 as saying that "a high percentage of iron carbide gives a hardness to iron which makes it ideal for manufacture of fine steel." This was an error.

The City A. C., defending champion, started the season with a victory last night in the opening interclub matches of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association. In the first test in Group One, the City A. C. defeated the Midston House S. C. in a close fight, 3 to 2, at the City A. C. courts. Midston replaces Block Hall in the league.
Spanish Government sources asserted tonight that Generalissimo Francisco Franco was concentrating Insurgent troops, artillery and aircraft to launch a major offensive against Madrid Thursday.

A meeting of the Congregation of Sacred Rites attended by Pope Pius and nine Cardinals recognized today the heroic virtues of Mother Francis Xavier Cabrini, founder of the Institute of Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart, who died in Chicago in 1917.

The New York Automobile Show, opening today at Grand Central Palace,- marks the inception of a new year In the automobile industry. The 1938 models, taking their premiere bow before the New York audience, represent the finest in motoring luxury and value.

Highways of the future will be built lighter as traffic gets heavier, Bernard Gray, chief highway engineer of the Asphalt Institute, predicts. Pointing out that the two chief road-building aims in years to come will be to make driving safer and pleasanter and that most of the present trunk line highways achieve neither aim, Mr. Gray holds that the only logical solution lies in the construction of more non-trunk line roads.

This town, which has a clean government and is bound to keep it, must wish well to the efforts of State Senator Clee, Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, to bring about the same end in that State.

Knowledge of the fact that safety, comfort and appearance are of paramount importance to the motor car buyer has led to a further stressing of these cardinal points in the creation of the new "unisteel" turret-top Fisher bodies for the 1938 General Motors cars.

Mr. and Mrs. James Cusator of Liberty, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Laurinas Cusator of Westfield, to George Willard Bauer of Elizabeth, son of Mr. and . Mrs. George F. Bauer of Rochester, Pa. The wedding will take place on Nov. 26.

From a highly placed official personage the writer received today the first authentic account of the Czechoslovak Government's considered views on the significance of the present German propaganda offensive against Czechoslovakia, which was renewed in a hostile German broadcast tonight.

The arms embargo against Spain was declared to be in violation of treaty obligations of the United States with the Spanish Republic and the State Department was charged with failure to enforce laws that operate against the Spanish Insurgents in a report today of the committee on international law of the National Lawyers Guild.

The present ratio of the Reichsbank's reserve to its outstanding circulation, 1.6 per cent, compares with 1.6. per cent a week ago, 1.5 two weeks ago and 1.6 a month ago. Highest ratio in 1937 was 1.7 per cent, reached on June 25; the ratio of three weeks ago, 1.4, was the lowest. In 1936, highest was 2.17,
This county voted dry last week, so John Fowler moved his beer stand to the middle of the Neches River, mounted it on stilts and declared himself ready for business.

Conceived on a more dynamic basis than ever before, the thirtyeighth annual National Automobile Show will open in Grand Central Palace at 2 o'clock this afternoon. Representing a cross-section of the leading American industry, which expects to produce 5,000,000 vehicles in 1938, its displays are exhibits of motion to a greater extent than in any former year.

The newspaper Asahi reported from Odawara, Japan today that an aged Japanese admiral had risked his life to write to his former United States Naval Academy classmates explaining Japan's position in the Chinese-Japanese conflict.

The Great Northern Railway declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on its preferred stock, the road's only stock outstanding. The payment was the first of its kind since a $1 dividend paid on Feb. 1, 1932. The latest dividend was described by W. P. Kenney, president, as an "irregular" one.

Turpentine firm, 263/4@271/4c: sales, 116 barrels; receipts, 399 barrels; no shipments; stock, 39,458 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 549; receipts, 1.354; no shipments; stock. 91,297. Quote: B. D. E, $6.75; F to 1. $6.85; K, M, N. $6.90; WG, $7.15; WW, X, $7.35.

The Schacnt crisis, which has been. so to speak, chronic since early In September, has become acute again. Dr. Hjal mar Schacht himself told a newspaper correspondent day that he had resigned his post as Minister of Economics last August. He said that the resignation became effective yesterday.

The Census Bureau reported today that flaxseed crushed in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 amounted to 214,649 tons, producing 151,278,120 pounds of linseed oil, compared with crushings of 136,142 tons, producieng 91,805,153 pounds of linseed oil, in the corresponding quarter of last year.
Demonstrations of what queer things can be done with the static electricity in the body will be conducted daily at the National Automobile Show by the Dodge Division of Chrysler Corportion.

Rising use of high anti-knock fuel is exercising a marked influence on the marketing programs of jobbers of petroleum products. Distributors in increasing numbers are turning to premium gasoline, the outlets for which are undergoing notable expansion.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Adah R. Henry of this place, widow of Edward Ewen Henry, to John Brion Foulke, superintendent of the American Museum of Natural History in New York.

With the exception of Bobby Stuart, whose injured shoulder is mending, and Bob Burnett, who was battered in yesterday's scrimmage, Coach Dick Harlow had his full force of football players on the field today as he started to get drive into his team for Princeton.

Naval preparedness for "the preservation of our democratic ideals and the maintenance of a righteous peace" was emphasized by President Roosevelt tonight in a letter to Secretary Swanson in connection with Navy Day, which will be observed tomorrow by the navy, with ships and shore stations open to the public and special programs to mark the day.

Enraged by what he termed "an insult to the people of Queens" by the administration of Queens College, Borough President George U. Harvey stalked angrily out of yesterday's formal dedication exercises in the college's auditorium because he thought the program had included insufficient participation for him as President of the borough.

The prepared text of former President Hoover's speech before the Republican Club of Massachusetts tonight follows: This club has made this evening an especial occasion for the younger Republican leaders.

It now seems that Labor candidates will be returned in the Senate from New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania, giving Labor thirteen Senate seats in all, since in New South Wales a fourth candidate will be elected to fill a vacancy left by the retirement of a Senator whose term has not expired.

Nicholas S. Kaltchas, college instructor and author, died yesterday in his apartment in the Bedford Hotel in New York at the age of 42. He had taught history and politics at Sarah Lawrence College here since 1932.

Economists of the Bureau of Agriculture are sticking by their forecast that the world will buy 95,000,000 bushels of wheat from the United States this year, although they said today that purchases in the first three and a half months of the season had been only 17,000,000 bushels.

F. E. Kruesi, vice president of the Middle West Service Company, has been elected to the new office of executive vice president, it was announced today. He will be in charge of the company's operations.

Blindfold tests, conducted in a sound-proofed room, proved the effectiveness of a newly developed spray-on type of insulation used on the door and rear deck panels of a new car seen here at the Automobile Show.
Pieter C. Maas, assistant treasurer of H. Duys .Co., tobacco importers at 141 Water Street, died on Monday at his home, 115 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.

Statistics made public by the Interstate Commerce Commission show that of the 5,398 persons killed in railway accidents last year, 1,519 or 28.14 per cent met death in automobiles at grade crossings. The number killed in such accidents in 1935 was 1,442.

The Atlas Corporation, of which Floyd B. Odlum of New York is president, has agreed to withdraw from its fight against the appointment of an independent trustee for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation,

The National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace and the scores of similar exhibits to be held in all the leading cities throughout the country during the next six weeks will give the public additional evidence of the automobile industry's ingenuity in discovering new ways of improving its products.
Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, returned yesterday-on the Aquitania from a month in Europe during which he said he had played fifteen concerts in Scandinavian and Baltic countries and in England.

The General Motors show for 1938 will open today at 2 P. M.- in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Running concurrently with the National Automobile Show, which is at Grand Central Palace, it will be open daily from 10 A. M. until midnight through Nov. 3.

The Public Service Commission deferred action yesterday on the application of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway to discontinue its New Rochelle-Port Chester branch. The case will be taken -up by the commission again today.
Henry O. Holmes has sold his 158-acre farm estate in the Bullet Hole section, between Carmel and Brewster, N. Y., to David Isrin, president of the Isrin-Oliver Corporation, New York importers.

The report by Supreme Court Commissioner Warren Dixon Jr. on his investigation of municipal affairs in Newark was characterized tonight as a "distortion of facts in a deliberate attempt to impress the public that the investigation was a good business proposition for the city" by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein in a speech over Station WOR.

" We have plenty of roadways leading to our resort but where are we going to put the cars when they get here?" This is the question which is echoing from one Summer resort to another along the entire Atlantic seaboard, particularly those within the metropolitan area,

Introduction of a vacuum gear shift, which permits gear shifting by remote control and eliminates the conventional gear shift lever in the floor, is one of the innovations in the automotive field for 1938.

The reserves of the Bank of Mexico fell more than 1 per cent last week, despite official attempts to increase the metallic coverage. The bank's weekly statement today places the reserves at 50.24 per cent, compared with 51.58 per cent a week ago.
Laverne (John Montague) Moore was acquitted tonight of the seven-year-old first degree robbery charge on which he was brought back from Hollywood in August. The jury was out 4 hours and 45 minutes.

Dr. Halvdan Koht, Norwegian Minister of Foreign Affairs and a leading Scandinavian historian, arrived yesterday on the liner Stavangerfjord to lecture at Harvard and Columbia Universities and confer with President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.
The following firemen are directed to report at the Motor and Pump Operators School, 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, at 10 A. M. on the dates specified above their names:

The Brown varsity football team will play nine games, including six major contests, in 1938 and will close with Columbia on Thanksgiving Day in this city. Lafayette will be met on Oct. 8 for the first time in twenty-six years. Other major tests are scheduled with Harvard, Yale, Dartmouth and Holy Cross.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Henrietta S. Allison of Elizabeth of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Phoebe Allison, to Erving Arundale, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Arundale of Westerly, R. I. The wedding will take place in the Spring.
William Timothy Lane, a partner of the local firm of W. T. Lane Bros., manufacturers of canvas bags and baskets, died last night at his home after a long illness. He was 67 ears old.
Oscar H. Rowe, indicted here two months ago on charges of swindling several Newark residents out of $88,000, surrendered today to Prosecutor William Wachenfeld of Essex County.

One of the unusual exhibits at the forthcoming show at the Grand Central Palace will be a glass-block structure which will occupy a good share of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation's exhibit. According to Henry M. Hempstead, director of advertising, the building will be 28 feet long and 8 1/2 feet wide.

State Senator L. J. Sulak, who protested vigorously last Spring when the State University hired Nebraska's coach, Dana X. Bible, at $15,000 a year, was defeated today in his mock proposal to retain Bible for life, lest the tenyear contract expire before any material benefit will accrue."

In a weird and thrilling but uncannily clear natural color motion picture, taken with a high powered microscopic camera through a "window" in the ear of a living rabbit, members of the National Academy of Sciences today saw a fragment of cancerous tissue detach itself from an implanted tumor and float into the animal's main blood stream.

Mrs. George S. Kaufman, who is chairman of the theatrical and literary division of the Citizens Nonpartisan Committee for the Election of George Backer, American Labor Party candidate for Congress from the Seventeenth district, will entertain at a tea in his honor at her home, 14 East Ninety-fourth Street, this afternoon.

A new mobile motion-picture and photographic power truck, capable of producing 40,000 watts, has been developed and placed in service by the photographic department of the Ford Motor Company for camera work under adverse lighting conditions.

Former Vice President Charles G. Dawes and Major General James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, returned on the-French liner Ile de France yesterday after having attended dedication ceremonies of American battle monuments in France.

Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., issued warrants yesterday for the arrest of thirtyone persons on charges of illegal registration from one building in the Eighth Assembly District where the Tammany leader is Assistant Attorney General Charles A. Schneider.

The first in a series of lectures by Miss Eunice H. Avery under the auspices of the Speedwell Society, the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service and the New York Diet Kitchen Association will take place the morning of Nov. 4 at the Pierre.
Special editions of the newspapers here today circulated the toasts exchanged by the Serb and Croat opposition leaders at their recent conference at Farkashich.

Surviving a shaky start after the losers had forged ahead to a 12point lead, the Alexander Hamilton High School football team rallied and triumphed over Samuel J. Tilden, 19 to 12, yesterday at Commercial Field in Brooklyn.
Holy Cross's cripples returned to football practice today as the Crusaders put in another strenuous session in preparation for Saturday's clash with unbeaten Temple.

While protest meetings were being held by workers in different parts of the city, the Committee for Industrial Organization announced last night that it had "just thrown the entire weight of its 500,000 members in New York" into a campaign to halt lay-offs of employes of the Consolidated Edison Company.

A large illustrated pamphlet entitled "Life, Health and Hospitals," describing the work of the ninetytwo institutions in the United Hospital Fund and activities of the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, was published yesterday by the fund.
Alexander Korda, British film producer, arrived yesterday on the French liner-Ile de France to continue negotiations for the purchase of control of the United Artists Distributing Corporation.
Hydraulic brakes are wanted on their next cars by 93 per cent of the motorists responding to the latest survey of the customer research staff of General Motors.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, questioned regarding reports arising from his recent letter to a Polish party congress, told this writer today with an air of finality that he had no intention of returning actively to politics.

In the present era, when the opinion of the people carries more weight than in any previous time in history, customer research is the "most vital and dynamic tool of industry," Henry G. Weaver, director of customer research for the General Motors Corporation,

The price of copper for domestic delivery was lowered yesterday 1 cent a pound, to 12 cents, by leading producers. For nearly a month the producers have been quoting the metal at 13 cents, while a custom smelter has been offering it at prices ranging from 12 to 123/4 cents.

The statement of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $6,786,336 after depreciation, normal Federal income taxes and other charges.

Gross assets, $539.752; net, $513.907. To John C. Mayer, husband, personal property, $20,000 in cash or 10 per cent of net estate and life estate in residue. Chief assets: stocks and bonds, $531,674. Davidson, Moses Sicher, attorneys, 160 Broadway.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Georgian Style in America," Alfred Busselle Jr., 11 A. M.; the Egyptian collection (general tour), 2 P. M.; "Medieval Pilgrimage Roads," Margaret B. Freeman, 4 P. M.
Dr. George F. Keenan, chief surgeon at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Brighton, and a retired brigadier general in the Massachusetts National Guard, died today in St. Elizabeth's Hospital.
At the annual meeting of the Wilson-Jones Company in Boston yesterday Benjamin Kulp was elected to the new office of chairman of the executive committee.
The names of many of the best known aviators of France were affixed tonight to a declaration calling on aviators everywhere to condemn and refuse to participate in acts of piracy.

Plans for the new Criminal Courts Building and city prison, to rise in the two blocks bounded by Center, White, Baxter and Leonard Streets, near Foley Square, were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings by Harvey Wiley Corbett and Charles B. Meyers, architects.

John Barnes, 28 years old, a laborer, of 28 St. Nicholas Avenue, was found guilty in Traffic Court yesterday by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio of "dangerous driving" with a bicycle. He paid a fine of $5.

A year ago General Motors produced the first "unisteel" turrettop body. Formed by welding the inner and outer panels into one homogeneous unit of steel, it afforded greater protection for the driver and his passengers than had ever before been known.

After two months of strenuous battling the Japanese have finally begun to dislodge the defenders of Shanghai. Having captured Tachang yesterday the invaders pushed on and early this morning hoisted the Rising Sun flag over North Station, at the same time driving the Chinese from ruined Chapei.

The Maritime Association warned the Navy Department yesterday that proposed Federal legislation and labor troubles threatened the continued operation of American shipping, particularly in the coastwise and intercoastal trades.

You never can tell about football these days. A week ago any one who fancied Brown's chances against Columbia could have got almost any odds he asked for. Yet on Saturday night the score showed Brown 7, Columbia 6.

The automobile industry has every reason to look forward with confidence in the future. It is almost certain that production in 1937 will total 5,000,000 motor cars, so that we can look back with pride upon the year's results.
Starting another attack on the "milk trust," leaders of the Dairy Farmers Union furthered plans here today for their strike which starts Thursday.

Deplying-once more to Mayor La Guardia's assertion that he had made a "deal" with James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx last night denounced the Mayor as a man who was "willing to assassinate a character for a passing moment of advantage." Mr. Foley spoke over radio station on.
The Madrigal Singers, Lehman Engel, conductor, will give a program devoted to works of Orlando di Lasso tonight at the Theatre of Music.

Bettering the world distance record for seaplanes, the Lieutenant de Vaisseau Paris ended today a flight of 3,435.3 miles at this Atlantic port. The huge craft was in the air 34 hours 28 minutes, after having taken off Monday at Port Lyautey, French Morocco.
Sam Winograd yesterday was appointed assistant to Nat Holman, basketball coach of C. C. N. Y. The announcement was made by Professor Walter Williamson, faculty manager of athletics.

One-third of a century ago two men arrived in New York City by automobile and were heralded widely for having completed a transcontinental motor trip in sixty-three days. Given today's highways, even the pioneering machine they used probably could make that same journey in two or three weeks, with a current model being able to do the job easily in six or seven days.

Burfield Argentum, a fifteen-inch hound, captured the third annual New Jersey Beagle Championship today. The event brought together Argentum, a dog belonging to William Dowd of Livingston, N. J., and Blue Ray Lassie, owned by Dr. L. Klopmann of Wortendyke, N. J.

Experts of the United States Bureau of Public Roads have emphasized that "the nation-wide program of changing mud roads into all-weather highways depends largely upon new ways of waterproofing the subsurface."

Outstanding Republicans and Democrats of city and State joined last night in paying tribute to Lafayette B. Gleason, veteran Secretary of the Republican State Committee, at funeral services held in the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Carl Sandstrom of Second Street, Ronkonkoma, pleaded not guilty before Justice of the Peace Harold C. Sorenson here today on a charge of keeping their 13-year-old daughter, Grace, from attending school.

General Alberto Enriquez, the new President, is acting promptly to relieve the conditions that caused unrest and dissatisfaction with the dictatorial regime ended by the resignation of President Federico Paez.

Wililam H. Brown, former president of the Corporation of the Berkeley- School, New York, died at his home here today after a five weeks' illness at the age of 75. His widow, who was Orlie J. Brown at their marriage in 1889, and a daughter, Mrs. Percy R. Jacobs, also of West Haven. survive.
Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, former chess champion of the world, increased his lead over Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, current titleholder, when he won the tenth game of their series tonight.

Declaring a common dividend of $1 a share, the first disbursement voted on the stock in more than five years, the board of directors of the United States Steel Corporation yesterday approved important changes in its high executive personnel, among them the proposed retirement of Myron C. Taylor as chairman of the board next April and the election of Edward R. Stettinius- Jr. in his stead.

After deliberating for five hours and twenty minutes, a General Sessions jury, including three women, acquitted Mrs. Rose Marie Dann, 40 years old, last night on a firstdegree murder charge in the shooting of her common-law husband, Hans, 56, a lighter captain, last May 31. Dann% was shot in their home at 42 La Salle Street.

After a long respite Amoy today experienced a bombing by Japanese planes and a brief shelling by Japanese warships. Two planes flew over the port and dropped four bombs on the fortifications, killing two civilians.
Whitfield Woods, president of the Institute of American Meat Packers, said today that the decline in meat production, to which has been ascribed high prices, apparently has reached its low point.

A preliminary report on the results of treating several hopeless cases of cancer by a new technique, which involves direct or indirect lowering of the temperature of the affected parts or of the body as a whole, was presented today at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

What appears to be a solution to the expensive maintenance work on secondary highways and lesser traveled country roads is found in the wide success of the new "oil mat," or "inverse penetration," method developed on the Pacific Coast this year.

Reiterating his charge that supporters of his opponent were trying to "buy" the election, Harold W. Hastings, Tammany candidate for District Attorney of New York County, declared last night that the report of the treasurer of Thomas E. Dewey's campaign committee showed that radical labor was in partnership with the Rockefellers and the Whitneys.

Six competent post-and-rail jumpers are scheduled to go to the post in the Mount Defiance Cup test, one of the features of the annual two-day Essex Fox Hounds race meeting which will open on the Fro-Heim estate of E. B. Schley tomorrow. The meeting will end Saturday.

Under its policy of dating new issues so that they will mature immediately after March 15, the Treasury Department today invited tenders on about $50,000,000 of 133-day bills to pay off a maturing issue of similar size.

Although cut over both eyes in the early rounds of the feature eightround bout at the Coliseum last night, Irish Eddie McGeever, 140 1/2, of Scranton gained the decision over Leonard Del Genio, 144 1/2, of Harlem. Eight thousand saw the battle.
Two distinct Ford V-8 cars, differing in appearance, appointments and prices will be presented this afternoon in an advance showing of 1938 models at-the Ford metropolitan showrooms, 1,710 Broadway.
Princess Alexandre de CaramanChimay of Paris, who arrived recently from Europe after passing the Summer at St. Jean, Cap Ferrat, France, is at the Pierre.

Williams' leading reserves, including the powerful sophomore contingent, were worked into the first team for a signal drill against the third team today. In past games Coach Charlie Caldwell has been sending in his sophomores as a unit whenever possible.

Six buses of the Palestine Potash Company, en route to Jerusalem from the Dead Sea, were attacked by Arab terrorists this afternoon. An Arab policeman accompanying the buses was wounded severely and fell from a bus, dragging the chauffeur with him.

An unusually convenient steering wheel-standard on all eight-cylinder models and installed on all sixes when equipped with automatic safety transmission--is offered on the new Oldsmobile Eight for 1938.

Three investment trusts have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the issuance of securities estimated to total $19,052,240.

Thomas E. Dewey's investigators have won their long fight for the extradition of Alexander Pompez, New York racketeer indicted in connection with the New York policy rackets. Accompanied by Sergeant Graefnecker of the New York police and another police officer, Pompez left this evening by express train for New York via San Antonio and St. Louis.

Solution of the Ministerial crisis by a transition government to be formed before the opening of the Nine-power conference, which has been postponed to Nov. 3, was in prospect tonight. At Socialist headquarters, which is claiming the right to the Premiership, it was expected the crisis would be of short duration.

All three series of Nash automobiles for 1938 will be known as "the cars with sea-legs." This is because the cars utilize new skyliner-type, double-acting, hydraulic shock-absorbers so mounted that they resemble the straddling legs of a sailor standing on deck and bracing himself against the roll of the sea.
Preparations for the visit of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor to America are now nearly complete and their announcement may be expected tomorrow or soon afterward.
Attempts to untangle the conflicting dates among the Hippodrome, St. Nicholas Palace and Seventyfirst Regiment Armory failed yesterday at the weekly meeting of the New York State Athletic Commission.

The current lull in business was described as a normal recession and only a temporary interruption of the forward movement evident early this year and through all of 1936, by W. W. Wachtel, vice president of the Calvert Distillers Corp., yesterday.
A vast plot to reconstitute the ancient Arab dominions stretching from Mecca to the Atlantic has been discovered following last night's riots in the native quarter of Casablanca.

The old six-story store, showroom and loft building at 932-8 Broadway, corner of Twenty-second Street, will be altered at an estimated cost of $100,000, it was announced yesterday. Completion is expected by Jan. 1.
French plane service between Marseille and North Africa was resumed tonight with two French heavy destroyers guarding Air France's supply base on the Spanish island of Minorca.

A plea to bankers to shape their merchandising so as to get business from the average man was made yesterday by Frank V. Lovejoy, sales executive of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, in an address before a luncheon meeting of the New York \Financial Advertisers Association in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.
The Lafayette second team battled the freshman football squad to a standstill today while the varsity eleven worked on new plays for the Franklin and Marshall contest here Saturday.

A conference of regional officers held the attention today of many of the delegates here to attend the twentythird annual convention of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization in this country, which opens here tomorrow night.

William Herbert Murphy of this city has sent out invitations for the marriage of his daughter, Miss E. Bernice Murphy, to Thomas Millar Whyte Jr., n of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Whyte Sr., also of Elizabeth, which will take place on Nov. 15 in Christ Episcopal Church here.

The prime requisite for the preservation of democracy calls for a widening of the group of intelligent and educated people, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University declared yesterday before a group of 100 educators assembled at City College at the annual meeting of the Association of Colleges and Universities of the State of New York.

Indictments returned a year ago charging Lawrence Timen and A. Reginald Von Keller, both of New York City, with conspiracy to extort in alleged plots to "fix" New York City contracts were dismissed in Federal court today.

Carl K. Withers, Commissioner of Banking and Insurance of New Jersey in charge of the Esenbe Building and Loan Association, sold to S. B. Penick Co. of New York for $20,000 the five-story brick building on a plot 100 by 100 at 1,422-30 Grand Street, Hoboken.

The new Queens asphalt plant costing $900,000, heralded as "the largest and most modern of its kind ever built by an American municipality," was dedicated yesterday by Queens Borough President George U. Harvey at brief ceremonies at the plant, Harper Street and the Flushing River.

Introduced as a prospective President of the United States, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. today in a Boston address denounced the New Deal's neutrality law as "putting the country automatically on the side of the power controlling the seas in a war between weak and strong nations."

Government reports exist in sufficient quantities perhaps to cover Manhattan Island above the topmost pinnacle of the Empire State Building. Most of these, unread, gather dust on the shelves of libraries and lumber-rooms.
Most liquids get lazy and flow more slowly when the temperature drops, according to E. C. Biglow, district branch manager of the Sun Oil Company, and motor oil is no exception.

A perfected automatic vacuum gear-shift, the lever of which angles out from the center of the instrument panel to a point near the right-hand position on the steering wheel, has been announced as an optional extra feature of the Nash automobiles for 1938.

204th St, 330-340 E (12-3332); 25th Properties, Inc, to Central Savings Bank; extends mtg to Sept. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $114,000. Briggs Ave, 2,821 (12-3301); Lillian A. Storms to Dollar Savings Bank: extends mtg to Oct. 25, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $58.000.
Paul Andolino's Gay Balko, second choice in the betting, today won the Whitefield Handicap, the fea- I ture event for three-year-olds at Rockingham Park.

A red-winged airplane crashed in a field near here tonight, and farmers found in the wreckage the bodies of two men and part of a woman's body. From papers found in the ship Coroner James A. Kneller said the two men had been identified as Pilot Richard Babcock, 23, of St. Johns, Vt., and Austin J. Feuchtwanger, 27, of Riverside, Conn.

Some 578 miles of "cotton roads" have been constructed throughout the United States within the past year. Twenty-four States, cooperating with the Bureau of Public Roads of the United States Department of Agriculture, have been supplied with special cotton fabrics for use in experimental construction of rural highways.

In an effort to reduce congestion, increase safety and provide easier access between various sections of New Jersey in the metropolitan area, miles of spacious and modern highways, either reconstructed or on new alignments, as well as many bridges and grade-crossing eliminations, have been built during the past year throughout that State by Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner.

Upon completing a trip by air a traveler is apt to recollect the smooth, quiet, comfortable cabin of the. airplane in contrast to the jolty, noisy, drafty-and occasionally smelly-bus in which-he was transported to and from the airport. If the same traveler has a good memory he will recall just the contrary reaction after a similar trip five years ago.

The Court of Errors and Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of a 1932 law restricting the withdrawal of deposits in building and loan- associations and heard argument in a suit challenging the validity of the 1933 Bank Reorganization Act.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 21,000, including 6,000 directs. The market was around 50c lower than Monday's average: top, sparingly, $9.35; bulk good and choice 150-250 pounds,

An early advance of 2 cents a bushel in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here today in sympathy with Liverpool and Winnipeg brought in considerable liquidation by longs and the greater part of the upturn was lost, closing trades being at net gains of only 1/3 to 1/4 cent.

R. H. Macy Co. announced yesterday that its thirteenth annual Thanksgiving Day parade would follow a new route this year, cooperating with traffic agencies in an effort to ease congestion and offer better facilities to spectators.

The text of the radio address of James A. Farley last night in behalf of Jeremiah T. Mahoney and his associates on the Democratic ticket follows: Two considerations- have motivated my return to New York during the closing days of the municipal campaign:
The British-Japanese tension was markedly aggravated this morning by another Japanese airplane attack upon a British outpost in the western defense sector of the International Settlement.

Uncle Sam has gathered almost a billion dollars from the nation's wage earners under provisions of the Social Security Act, the Treasury ledgers showed today. The act provides for building up a reserve fund which eventually will aggregate more than $40,000,000,000 if the law remains unchanged.

With a bullet from the service pistol issued to him when he enqtered the United States Naval Academy in 1911, Boleslaw Leonard Dombrowski, formerly of Milbrook, Greenwich, Conn., killed himself yesterday in his room in the George Washington Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

Two motor torpedo boats, a type of "mosquito" man-of-war unique in the United States Navy, but much employed abroad, will be included in the navy's next annual building program to be submitted to the regular session of Congress next year, Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, revealed last night.
Foreign and local buying imparted steadiness to prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday morning, but after rallies of 40 to 65 cents a bale the market eased as stocks turned reactionary.
Jorge Bolet, 23-year-old Cuban pianist, made a striking debut at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, injecting excitement into a season that has leaned heavily thus far on mediocrity.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, of $15,996,840.

It is up to the consumer to tell the retailer that she desires adequate merchandise information and "to make him realize the movement for more factual information for merchandise is a genuine and widespread movement," Harold Brightman,

State legislation for the establishment of a system of mortgage banks is needed and would become a "dire necessity" if any kind of real estate boom developed, the joint legislative committee on guaranteed mortgages was told yesterday by Wendell P. Barker, former chairman of the State Mortgage Commission.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market in the week ended yesterday was practically the same as in the preceding week but less than in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
Thirty-three racers were listed today as probable starters in tomorrow's ninety-ninth Cesarewitch Stakes as Sir Abe Bailey's Maranta and James V. Rank's Epigram continued joint favorites at 100-90.

Assistant Secretary Charles Edison said in an interview today that the Navy Department would request the incoming Congress for funds to build two more $60,000,000 battleships He said two vessels of this type now were under construction, the first since the World War.
Federal agents in charge of the search for the kidnappers of Charles S. Ross still were pinning their hopes today on an intensive tracing of numbered bills, paid without result as a ransom for him.

Pennsylvania-Central Airlines formally opened a new skyway today for passenger, mail and express traffic between this city and Buffalo, a route that is expected to link eventually the capitals of the United States and Canada. The regular schedule calls for an 8:30 A. M. takeoff daily except Sundays and holidays.

With its highway program unfolding rapidly and a new traffic code in force, New York City now seeks a solution to what is perhaps the most baffling aspect of. its traffic dilemma This is the parking problem, which stands foursquare in the way of any complete and satisfactory settlement of the city's general motor transportation problem.
The three-story building at 26 Avenue O, near Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, containing a store and five apartments has been purchased by the William Penn Realty Company. Bertha Bunkin was the the seller.

The Association of the Bar of the tends City of New York, by an overwhelming vote at an adjourned meeting last night at 42 West Fortyfourth Street, endorsed Thomas E. Dewey as Fusion candidate for District Attorney of New York County.

The Committee for Industrial Organization laid its maximum demands for peace treaty terms before the American Federation of Labor today and the latter's committee will reply tomorrow, probably with minimum concessions.

The investigation that had been ordered by the United States Tariff Commission into alleged unfair methods of competition or unfair acts in importation or sale of cigarette-making machines and parts has been- discontinued and dismissed, the National Council of American Importers and Traders announced yesterday.

The investment of the petroleum industry in keeping the typical motorist moving on the road is greater than that of the motorist himself, recent figures show. In 1936 the petroleum industry had a capital investment of $13,775,000,000, or an average of $490 for each of the 28,000,000 motor vehicles registered. The investment of the typical motorist is estimated to be less than $200 per vehicle.
Max Schmeling tonight accepted Mike Jacobs's offer to fight Harry Thomas on Dec. 13 in Madison Square Garden, New York. Thomas has not yet definitely agreed to terms, it was said.

Two judges of the Lower Court were removed today by order of the Nicaraguan Supreme Court following the clearing of David Castrillo, secretary of the National Electoral Board, in the court inquiry into the killing of Jose Garcia in the Hotel Primavera last week.

Moses Joseph, 46 years old, of 228 West 142d Street, a Negro fruit peddler, was charged last night with killing a 9-year-old Negro boy, who, he said, had been among a group of boys stealing fruit from Joseph's pushcart.

The report of the Inland Steel Company and subsidiaries for the third quarter of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $4,433,375, after depreciation, depletion, interest and estimated normal Federal income taxes, but before Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Business failures increased in four business groups in the week ended Oct. 21, compared with the corresponding period last year, and declined in one group, commercial service, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. The detailed report is as follows:

Speed-boat drivers and owners arrived yesterday from many boating centers for three days of meetings that will culminate tomorrow in the annual gathering and election of the American Power Boat Association.

George Drew, superintendent of the Southampton Club since it was founded forty years ago and an intimate acquaintance of many of its internationally known members and visitors, died at his home here today of a heart attack. His age was 69.

Mayor Bernard N. McFeeley was placed under technical arrest in his office in the City Hall this afternoon in connection with a $100,000 suit for damages instituted by Thomas Mangan, a public school janitor.

Forerunners of air-conditioning for passenger cars and trucks are indicated at the automobile show. One type of ventilating system exhibited provides for intake of fresh, filtered outside air, even with all windows closed, and the rapid ejection of foul air, fumes, gases and odors.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, appealed last night over the radio for the election of Jeremiah T. Mahoney as Mayor on the grounds that Mr. Mahoney was qualified for the job, was militantly liberal, was a New Dealer, and that the success of the Democratic party in the municipal election was important because "any weakening of the Democratic party is bound to retard the liberal movement It espouses."

Dominic Polilli, 238-pound junior who started the season at left tackle on the Pennsylvania varsity team, was used in place of the veteran Joe Ober today in a scrimmage with the freshmen on River 'Field and may start against the Navy here Saturday.

A trust mortgage for $2,730,000 was given by the Madison, Inc. A. Bruce Bielaski, president, :o the Sterling National Bank Trust Co of New York, as trustee, on the 14-story Madison Hotel, at the n w cor of Madison Ave and 58th St, half the block on the Avenue and 145 ft on the street,

Steel-ingot production -continued to decline more than seasonally last week, bringing the adjusted index down to 81.3, compared with 90.1 for the previous week. For the corresponding period last year, the index was at 108.8.

Dr. Robert Cushman Murphy, Associate Curator of Oceanic Birds of the American Museum of Natural History, was elected president of the National Association of Audubon Societies yesterday at the annual convention at the American Museum of Natural History.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today new trade practice rules for the rayon industry, designed primarily to prevent misrepresentation and deceptive advertising of rayon products.

The one-time demilitarized Rhineland saw today its first major military ceremony since 1918. Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, the War Minister, and Colonel General Werner von Fritsch, the Chief of Staff, presented 136 stands of colors to units of the Fifth, Ninth, Twelfth and Thirteenth Army Corps and the Second Tank Division.

Bertram T. Lee, who had been engaged for more than thirty years in the mining and oil business in Lima, Peru, dropped dead last night while walking near the home of former United States Senator Miles Poindexter, at Greenlee. His age was 59.

The four-family dwelling containing fifteen rooms at 1,137 Croes Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold to a client of P. C. D'Onofrio Co., brokers in the deal. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $5,500.

Gladys Breitfeller, 15 years old, who stabbed and killed her father Monday in their home at 90-03 207th Street, Bellaire, Queens, cleared of a charge of juvenile delinquency yesterday in Children's Court, Jamaica.
Sales of American motor vehicles in foreign markets during the current year are expected to reach 630,000 units, a gain of 24 per cent over the 508,000 vehicles sold abroad last year.

State Senator Lester H. Clee, Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, assailed today Common Pleas Judge James R. Erwin of Hudson County for revoking the warrants he had issued for the arrest of 144 district election officers accused of violating the Election Law by irregularities in counting the primary vote cast on Sept. 21.

Richard Tauber, who toured this country in the season of 1931-32, returned last night to open his second American tour in Town Hall. He had reason to be gratified with the size of the audience and its reception of his art.
Mr. Mahoney sees the Reds dominating the Fusion campaign. Mr. Mahoney's running mate for District Attorney of New

Denial was made today by the National Council for Prevention of War, the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom and the Emergency Peace Campaign that the statement issued yesterday by the National Peace Conference implied any relaxation in the demand for the carrying out of the Neutrality Law. They demand its application to the Far East.

The following infantry reserve officers are relieved from assignment to 37th InfantryRAI, and are assigned to 309th Infantry (78th Div.): 2d Lt. Charles W. Bowden Jr., 142 Harrison St.. Wilmington. Del.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, brought his campaign to Columbia University yesterday. He emphasized his party's record of social legislation and mentioned his progressive influence as a member of the Board of Education more than twenty years ago.
