GRASSROOT JUNGLES, by Edwin Way Teale. (Dodd, Mead, $3.75.) The story of insects told in picture and text. HENRY GRATTAN, by Roger McHigh. (Sheed Ward, $1.75.) A biography of the Irish statesman.
British trade experts have advised the government there is "no fundamental unroundness" in the trade position of the United States, Viscount Halifax told the House of Lords this afternoon.

To bring the highways of the United States into some conformity with the demands of present-day traffic, more than 22;000 miles of modern roads were completed with Federal funds administered by the Bureau of Public Roads during the last fiscal year.

Research with a theoretical race of supermen, which included the building of life-sized dummies for in excess of normal physical proportions, forms one of the interesting chapters behind the development of the 1938 Cadillao Fleetwoods. The company created its supermen through reference to measurements obtained during the war on the dimensions of the average man.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Hancock of Paris, Ky., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Clay Hancock, to D. Farley Cox Jr. of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J.

Recognizing Fall as the season when on frosty nights "thoughts turn to cider and doughnuts," scientists at the Agricultural' Experiment Station have announced development of an apple cider "far superior" to the product now on the market. The formula is explained in a new pamphlet.

The Brown reserves who missed action in the Columbia game scrimmaged against a freshman eleven today. The Bruin varsity started work on passing, kicking and timing and ball handling in polishing up its offense for the Tufts game.

Grand Concourse (11-2808), S w cor of Burnside Ave, 110x130: Column Holding Corp to Cabin Holding Corp. 565 5th Ave. 203d St (12-3309), n s, 220 ft e of Grand Concourse, 100x100; Morris Sophin to Molirose Realty Corp, 227 E 203d St; mtg S138.125.

Russia, recalcitrant on the granting of belligerent rights to the two parties in Spain, was on the way yesterday to isolation in the London Non-Intervention Committee, where Britain, France, Italy and Germany agreed to grant such rights upon "substantial progress" in the withdrawal of foreign combatants. There was some indication, however, that the Soviet would yield before the committee meets again Friday. [Page 1.]

Mayor La Guardia and Welfare Commissioner William Hodson have indicated their intention of attending the third annual dance of the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies, a C. I. O. affiliate, to be held Saturday. evening at Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Sorkin, general manager of. the union.

Instructions dealing with the care of fabrics used to upholster the new "unisteel" turret top Fisher bodies will be furnished purchasers of 1938 General Motors cars in the form of a booklet entitled, "'Good Housekeeping' in Your Car."
A. Newbold Morris and Harold W. Hastings, "Issues in Municipal Campaign," WNYC, 11 A. M. to noon. Salvatore Salvio, candidate for City Council, WOV (1,130 kc.), 2:25 to 2:30 P. M.

Jame C. Dolan, a lawyer of Gouverneur, N. Y., formerly a St. Lawrence County judge, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the Hotel Lexington where he had been living for several months. His age was 67.

Unfavorable weather conditions confronted the cocker and springer spaniels competing in the opening day's tests of the fourth annual Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association meeting today on the Ingham Hill Game Farm.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 25, unless specified: San Pedro to Oakland: Astoria, Indianapolis. At Shanghai: Edsall, Oct. 26; Parrot. San Pedro to San Francisco: Pensacola, San Francisco. Saratoga, Tuscaloosa.
More than ten thousand workers in the Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills were notified today of a curtailment in working schedules, the first :since the prosperous era set in.

Martin W. Souders, head coach of Exeter's football squad, thinks that the Red and Gray's ancient rival, Andover, is three touchdowns better on paper than his charges, but regardless of the present season's records, he is confident of victory in their traditional game here on Nov. 13.

104th St, n s, 189.8 ft e of Columbus Ave, 27x101; Shepard Green to Harlem Savings Bank; consideration, $2,000; foreclosure. 106th St, 307 E, 25x101; Emanuel Eschwege to same; consideration, $2,000; foreclosure.

The New York Rangers came from behind to defeat their intracity rivals, the Americans, 6-5, in overtime tonight in the second game of the National Hockey League teams' Western Canada exhibition series. The first game in Calgary was a 2-2 tie. A third contest will be played in Calgary tomorrow.

Carl Clausen, author, and world traveler completed the first of five days in jail today on a traffic law violation, with no comment on how he liked it. He began his jail term at 1 P. M. yesterday after he refused to pay a $12.50 fine to Justice William N. Walton. He said he did it in a "protest against the motor code."

When Stub Allison's Golden Bears of California pushed three touchdowns over the Southern California goal line in the first half last Saturday, they not only crumbled the Trojans' defenses but the last redistance of the nation's football critics as well. At least, so it would appear from the latest returns in The Associated Press national ranking poll.

Paul Connor, 46, was found shot to death, with a revolver by his side, in his home here today. Medical Examiner Frank F. Simonton gave a verdict of suicide. Mr. Connor was a native of Denver and a graduate of Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Lord Warrington of Clyffe, who had a long judicial record as a member of his country's and empire's highest tribunals, died in Market Lavington, Wiltshire, today at the age of 86. He built up a reputation and a large practice as an equity lawyer.

For the first time in the history of the Automobile Show trailer's equipped with a complete, portable air-conditioning unit will be shown at Grand Central Palace. The Curtiss Aerocar Company, Coral Gables, Fla., is said to be the first trailer company to install Pleasantaire units in its models.

Ten minutes in one of the "quiet rooms" at the General Motors proving ground, with the lights extinguished, would be sufficient to make anybody expressing a desire for solitude change his mind, in the opinion of research engineers in charge of the new acoustical laboratory, whose work has had much to do with the quiet ride that marks the 1938 cars with the 'unisteel" turret top body by Fisher.
The Was Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 23: Hedrick, Lt. Col. L. H., Judge Advocate General's Dep't., Hawaii, to office of the Judge Advocate General, Washington, D. C.

Mrs. Elizabeth Eaton Guggenheim obtained a divorce here today from Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim of New York City on grounds of cruelty. The complaint set out that property matters had been settled out of court. It was reported that Mrs. Guggenheim will receive slightly less than $2,000 a month.

On his own application: PATROLMAN Charles J. Olson, 70th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct 28, 1912. Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANT John J. P. Quinn, from 3d Division to 10th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued. PATROLMAN James J. McArdle, from 52d Precinct to 8th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur.

Captain Gordon Stavely Horsburgh, marine superintendent of the Cunard White Star Line at Liverpool, England, and formerly commander of ocean liners, died last Thursday at his home in Liverpool after a brief illness.

Frederick V. Goess, receiver of the defunct Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, has instituted suit in Supreme Court to set aside transfers made by Joseph W. Harriman, former president of the bank, to his four grandchildren, it was disclosed yesterday with the appointment of guardians ad litem for the grandchildren.

Following the overnight improvement in Wall Street, the stock market here had a more cheerful appearance today and most sections went ahead. Giltedge issues were in good demand and foreign bonds improved.

Surprising results from the use of amino acids in the treatment of anemia were revealed today before delegates to the Fall meeting of the National Academy of Science by Dr. George H. Whipple, dean of the University of Rochester School of Medicine since its founding in 1921.

A first mortgage loan of $140,000 for ten years on the recently complete apartment house at 99 Marble Hill Avenue has been arranged by Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers. The 228 Marble Hill Corp., are owners of the building.

Publication of Lin Yutang's "The Importance of Living" (Reynal Hitchcock) has been postponed from Nov. 4 to Nov. 23. Dr. Lin's book and Virginia Sackville-West's "Pepita" (Doubleday, Doran) are the December selections of the Book-of-the-Month club.
Trading in. knit goods markets this week has shown some improvement, attributable in some divisions to easier prices, and in others to the completion of the introduction of Spring lines.
In full agreement with much of the spirit and logic of your editorial "Liberalism and Tempo," I should like to note two points at which At seems to me the argument limps.
Lehigh's football forces, seriously hampered by injuries, went through a long drill this afternoon preparing for the game at Rutgers Saturday.

Daily average gross crude-oil production in the United States last week was 3,613,300 barrels, compared to 3,624,450 in the preceding week, a decrease of 11,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Foreign Minister Patijn in a written answer to a National Socialist member of the upper house indicated the government was not disposed to treat with any power [meaning Germany] concerning the territorial inviolability of The Netherlands.

The Public Service Commission listed twenty-eight railroad crossings today which it said had been suggested for elimination in 1938 at an estimated cost of $9,811,000. A hearing on the program was called for Nov. 4 in Albany.
Secretary Hull declared today that the State Department would not be "bluffed" by special interests in negotiating a reciprocal trade agreement with Czechoslovakia.

W. Jett Lauck of Washington, chairman of the Pennsylvania Anthracite Industry Commission, reiterated today that financial interests dominated, through directors, both railroads and the hard-coal industry.

" Better Living" is today's theme song everywhere in the United States. Workers in every line of endeavor are enjoying increasing income. Farmers this year have had bountiful crops, and they are getting good prices for their products.
The De. Basil Ballet Russe will present a revival of Leonide Massine's "Jeux d'Enfants" tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House after its absence from the repertoire for several seasons.

In reply to last week's speech of Senator Robert F. Wagner advocating the election of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, George Meany declared last night that the Senator, in effect, had withdrawn the name of the candidate opposing Mayor La Guardia and substituted the Democratic party.
Coach Benny Friedman pu the City College football squad through a two-hour drill at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday in preparation for Saturday's game at home with Providence College.

Thanks to modern lubrication methods, motorists can buy their new cars at the Automobile Show and safely break them in during the Winter months. Scientifically refined lubricants are said to nave eliminated most of the hazards of cold weather driving and the motorist's new car can be as well protected for the Winter break-in as it would be on a warm Summer day.

The movement to make local cat owners pay an annual license fee of $1 and tie a bell around the cats' neck appeared to have come to naught here tonight as the Borough Council referred the matter back to the ordinance committee, which is expected to forget the matter.

Back in the races after a five-month lay-off, War Admiral galloped a mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 today easily to win his "comeback" dash. The brown coated son of Man o' War got away fast and wasn't headed except for a second or two at the first turn.
Clark Hinkle of the Green Bay Packers forged far in front in the race for individual scoring honors in the National Football League last Sunday, according to statistics released yesterday.

Washburn Studios, photography, in 602 Madison Ave; Butler Baldwin, Inc, agents. Riker Restaurant Associates. Inc.: store in 515 Hudson St; Fayso Corp, store in 95 7th Ave S; J. D. Robllotto Co, Inc, broker.

William Wyer, who became secretary and treasurer of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company when that system was brought within the Van Sweringen network of railroads and other properties, charged before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today that he was forced to give false testimony before the committee last Thursday.

Now that the violent Autumn decline on the Stock Exchange has been arrested, and the alternating bewilderment and consternation caused by it have been allayed by continued recovery, more judicious attention will be paid to the question of trade reaction. That question, always aroused by prolonged decline of stocks, was discussed during the recent break from two wholly opposite viewpoints.

Major Frank Wandle, trainer of Yale athletic teams, suffered a stroke of apoplexy today while the football squad was preparing for the Dartmouth game. The popular trainer, directing a calisthenic drill for the football players, was demonstrating the socalled bicycle exercises, which demand that the athletes lie on their backs and kick with a bicycling motion, when he reeled.

Marie Pierre Camille Louis Helie de Talleyrand-Perigord, Prince of Sagan and fifth Duke of Talleyrand, was a principal in one of the international marriage of the first decade of this century. He married Anna Gould, heir to more than $80,000,000 of the fortune of her father, the late Jay Gould, after she had divorced his cousin, Count Boni de Castellane.

Stockholders of the Third National Bank of the City of New York, which was merged more than forty years ago with the National City Bank, are to receive a final liquidating dividend of $3.52 a share, it was announced yesterday by the liquidating committee of the bank, consisting of Chauncey B. Garver and Joseph W. Drake.
Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius W. Wickersham of Lawrence have as their guest Miss Elizabeth Wistar Craighill of Leesburg, Va., who is the fiancee of their son, George W. Wickersham 2d.
Mrs. William Maffitt entertained with a luncheon at her home, the Patch, today in honor of her house guests, Mrs. Charles L. Palms and the latter's daughter, Mrs. Edward Murphy of California.
A determined Japanese drive to take Taiyuan, the capital of Shansi Province, opened yesterday from two directions-along the Shihkiachwang-Talyuan railway and along the Tatung-Taiyuan highway.

The keel of the largest and most powerful man-of-war ever built in this country will be laid at the navy yard in Brooklyn at 12:15 P. M. today in the principal ceremony of a nation-wide observance of Navy Day.
General Robert Lee Bullard announced yesterday that he had not authorized the use of his name in connection with the local Mayoralty campaign, as endorsing any candidate for Mayor.

The Wesleyan regulars had a stiff scrimmage against the second team today with the jayvees using the Trinity style of play. Coach Jack Blott is concerned about the line, which proved to be one of the weak points in the Amherst game.

Princess Hermine, wife of former Emperor Wilhelm of Germany, returned last night after two months' absence. Following an appendectomy performed in Germany in August she visited the north of Italy for her convalescence.

Driving effort is greatly reduced, and control over the car is increased, by the new "Tiptoe-matic" clutch, of revolutionary. design, which is being introduced on all the new 1938 Chevrolets, both passenger cars and trucks.
With the approach of the Hallowe'en season, parents and school teachers are strongly urged to instruct children against the practice of defacing automobiles as part of their merry-making activities.

Mayor La Guardia made public a letter yesterday from Mrs. Austine Vail of 124 East Fortieth Street, which expressed her gratitude for the work of Radio Policeman Edward T. Sharkey of the East Fiftyfirst Street station, who assisted her to recover from a serious heart attack on the night of Sept. 29.
Stocks closed steady at Irregularly. lower levels after moderate gains; turnover, 1,815,640 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other issues firm and mixed; transactions, $8,142,500.

An additional gift of $250,000 has been made to Harvard University by Lucius N. Littauer of New York City, to make possible construction of a larger building for the Graduate School of Public Administration than was originally planned.

Tonight it is "Many Mansions," or the tale of a young liberal in the ministry, the work of Jules Eckert Goodman and his son, Eckert Goodman. The theatre is the Biltmore, the hour 8:40 and these people are in the cast: Alexander Kirkland, Flora Campbell, Gage Clarke, Seth Arnold and William Post Jr.
Mrs. Harriet Bullock Purdy, wife of W. E. Purdy, former vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York, died at the Brevard Hospital here early today of pneumonia. Her age was 68.

The Boy Scouts of the Philippine Islands will be on Jan. 1 a separate group not governed by the Boy Scouts of America, it became known yesterday. The organization will be known as the Boy Scouts of the Philippines. Exequiel Villacorta of Manila will be the chief executive there.

The performance of "Angel Island" tonight at the National Theatre will be for the benefit of the welfare and relief work conducted by the auxiliary of the Tuberculosis Division and the Convalescent Relief Committee of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service.

The Rev. W. Dyer Blair, newly appointed director of the International Association of Daily Vacation Bible Schools of the International Council of Religious Education, and Mrs. Blair were guests yesterday at a farewell luncheon in their honor at the Parkside Hotel, Irving Place and East Twentieth Street.

New York's State Constitution, like the Constitutions of other States, is more than a statement of general principles of government-it is also a catchall for a number of what are really legislative acts.
Summit High scored a 6-to-0 football victory over Glen Ridge today. It was the first defeat in four starts for Glen Ridge. Passes led to the downfall of the home team in the second period.

The Herman Arns Company has merged with Riker Co., Inc. Herman Arns has been elected vice president of the Riker organization and will be in charge of that firm's New York offices at 137 East Fifty-seventh Street.

In his Boston address last night Mr. Hoover insisted that a strong opposition party is an essential part of the democratic system and argued that some agreement as to "constructive convictions and positive purposes" is necessary if such a party is to exist.

Although last year saw a marked increase in motor travel in New York and New England as indicated by increased consumption of gasoline, this section led the nation in highway safety, according to figures compiled by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company.

A plea for the development of broadly equipped scientists, rather than narrow specialists, to grapple with problems in biology and medicine was voiced tonight by Dr. The Svedberg, Professor of Physical Chemistry at the University of Upsala, Sweden.
The stock market moved erratically yesterday, with leading issues fluctuating within a range of about 4 points. The closing was irregularly lower.

Mrs. Muriel Schlegel, 32 years old, of 25 Holloway Street, Roosevelt, L. I., was killed instantly today at the Brookside Avenue crossing of the Long Island Railroad after she had waited for a westbound train to pass and then stepped into the path of an eastbound train.
Production of cars is running higher than for any October since 1925, William R. Tracy, vice president in charge of sales of the Hudson Motor Car Company, reports.

More than twenty times as many motor trucks are now in use as when America's rubber industry put the truck on pneumatic tires in 1916, according to P. W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

Leaders in social work who are candidates for city office declared health and welfare overshadowed mere political issues in the campaign at a meeting held yesterday under the auspices of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, Inc., at 99 Park Avenue.
Benjamin James Hiner, potentate of Beni Kedem Temple of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine, died here tonight of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 59.

Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the National Socialist party, left Munich for Rome today with a delegation of party officials to attend ceremonies on the anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome. Julius Streicher.
Henry Hull, whose memorable performance as Jeeter in "Tobacco Road"' attracted Hollywood's attention, will return to the screen under the auspices of Metro.
The Rev. Joseph A. Leddy, assistant pastor of Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church and chaplain of Veterans Hospital at Lyons, died of a heart ailment last night. He was 48 years old.

The few New York City hotels which increased their room rates last Spring are being followed by many others, with advances ranging from 10 to 15 per cent, it was learned yesterday. The Hotel Association of New York City for several months had been advocating such a step because of increased operating costs.
The cornerstone of the new quarters of the Ninth Street Day Nursery and Orphans' Home at 393-5 East Eighth Street will be laid at 2 P. M. on Sunday.
The Department called the attention of postmasters throughout the country today to the circulation of a counterfeit note, described as follows:
More than 400 dealers and. salesmen of the New York metropolitan area attended the annual show session of the Buick division of General Motors yesterday at the Park Central Hotel.

When it comes to bird dog fanciers there are as many -schools of thought as there are breeds and cross breeds, and not infrequently you come across individuals who prefer one breed for working quail and another for working partridge.

Miss Doris Haines, 24 years old, of 500 East Durham Road, Mount Airy, Pa., was fatally injured when she was thrown from a horse here this afternoon. She received a fractured skull and died four hours after her arrival at a hospital.
Gasoline taxes paid by United States motorists to State and Federal Governments during 1937 are expected to amount to about $1,000,000,000, or four times what they paid ten years ago.

Judge Isadore Haber officially replaced Judge Umansky on the bench of the First District Court here 'today, apparently ending the legal contest over the $4,100-a-year position which began almost a year and a half ago.
Miss Anne Livingston Eustis, daughter of Mrs. William Corcoran Eustis of this city and the late Mr. Eustis, has chosen Nov. 20 as the date for her marriage to Grenville Temple Emmet Jr. of New York.

Trading was generally slow on non-kosher meats yesterday. The lamb market was about steady; veal and calf very weak; other classes lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be about in line with Monday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The death of the famous National Socialist journalist Roland Strunk of Hitler's own Voelkischer Beobachter in a duel on Friday has upset some of the revived ideas of Germanic honor.

Two hundred and fifty school children were urged yesterday afternoon to use the ideals of Theodore Roosevelt in guiding their own lives. The occasion was the annual celebration of the birthday of the former President in the house where he was born at 28 East Twentieth Street.

Electrical equipment is one of the best indicators of automotive evolution. Those persons who are more than 35 years old recall the happy, simple days when the electrical system of a motor car embraced three elements: battery, coil-and-timer system and spark plugs.

The Social Justice Publishing Company through its attorney rejected today "directions" from Archbishop Edward Mooney that it publish texts of statements by the Archbishop and by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin.

The death rate for the city last week was 9.9 per 1,000 inhabitants, continuing for the fourth week below the cumulative average of 10.6 for the forty-two weeks since the first of the year, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday. Total deaths were 1,416, compared with 1,375 the preceding week.

Just to show how broad a field the automobile industry draws upon for its raw materials and parts, it might be cited that the various components which go into the making of a steering wheel and gear unit may pass through fifteen different kinds of industrial establishments before they reach the automobile assembly line.

The increasing use of- automobiles and consequent need for more comfort and convenience have dictated today's "big-package" car, in the opinion of Frank E. Watts, vice president and chief engineer of Hupp Motor Car Corporation.

Mr. and Mrs. Andre de Coppet gave a supper last night in the Sert Room of the Waldort Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw, Mr. and Mrs. Hdnry Gassavay Davis 3d, Mr. and Mrs. Julius W. Noyes and Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Rice.

The Hudson County grand jury handed up fifty-five indictments to Common Pleas Judge Robert V. Kinkead here today, alleging sex offenses against six Union City (N. J.) men. The men were accused of assaulting three girls, two of them 11 years old and the other 13 years old.
State officials and employes will be required to pay a State tax on their salaries under a decision of the State Supreme Court today.

Since the tragic passing of Knute Rockne, the system of football that he perfected, to make Notre Dame synonymous with winning football and create a wide demand for his pupils as coaches, has lost some of its vogue.

ANDREINI--On Tuesday, Oct. 26, Ippolito, at his residence, 4 Locust St., Massapequa L. I. Survived by three sons, three daughters and one sister. The deceased will be reposing at Perazzo's Funeral Church, 199 Bleecker St., Thursday. Services Friday at 9 A. M.

Addressing three meetings in Brooklyn last night; Mayor La Guardia attacked Frank' V. Kelly, Democratic county leader, and Dis trict Attorney William F. X. Geogh an, promised to give Kings County "another Dewey" to stop racketeering and declared that the "Red" campaign of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, his Democratio opponent, was a clear sign that Mr. Mahoney had become panicky.

Jesse James, 190, Hollywood, Calif., threw Steve Passas, 188, Greece, with a flying tackle and body hold after 52 minutes 15 seconds of wrestling last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, according to Associated Press.

The tenant rosters of apartments in many sections of the city received many new listings as a result of the leasing activity reported by agents and brokers yesterday. Interest in large suites continues to be a feature of the demand for new quarters.
Brown Harriman Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $500,000 of road bonds of the State of West Virginia on a bid of 100.1079 for $120,000 as 3 1/2s, and $380,000 as 2 1/2s.

With 74 per cent of total dwellings equipped with central heating plants now using oil burners, Charleston, S. C., leads American cities in percentage of oil burner installations, the Oil Burner Institute announced yesterday. Hartford is second with 69 per cent and San Francisco is third with 60 per cent.
The Brooklyn College. football team, in a long practice yesterday in preparation for its game with Hofstra College in Brooklyn..Satur day, concentrated on its running and passing game.
Complying with an order from the Maritime Commission at Washington, the Dollar Line is about to modernize sixteen ships, including eight in round-the-world service.

Mayor Meyer Ellenstein of this city today appointed Henry L. Cullen, president of the Newark Newspaper Mailers Union, a member of the Newark Labor Relations Board. The union is an A. F. of L. affiliate.

Coach Steve Owen sent the New York Giants through a lengthy practice on the Polo Grounds gridiron yesterday as one of the first moves to prepare them for the assault of the undefeated Chicago Bears next Sunday.

A plan to alter slightly the site of a proposed 1,000,000-gallon reservoir in Purchase to meet the objections of Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority, was disclosed today when papers were filed in Supreme Court here in a suit brought by the Westchester Joint Water Works 1 to obtain an easement on additional land owned by the Lorac Corporation.
Army's football team staged another long scrimmage tonight-with the B squad as Coach Gar Davidson tried to select a starting team for the game with Virginia Military Institute Saturday.

Under oath before a tribunal at Lyon today Andre Tardieu testified that as Premier and Minister in several Cabinets from 1926 to 1932 he paid government subsidies to Colonel FranCois de la Rocque for services rendered by the latter's militant Fascist organization, the Croix de Feu.

Warning that the brewing industry could not survive unless moderation prevailed, W. S. .Alexander, Federal Alcohol Administrator, told the national convention of the United States Brewers Association, which began a three-day session today, that whole-hearted acceptance of government regulation, combined with rigid self-regulation, must be the industry's policy.
The curtailment of Federal expenditures "is in line with the improvement in the private demand for construction," V. G. Iden, secretary of the American Institute of Steel Construction, said today.

Dwelling properties in scattered sections of the city furnished the major part of the activity in Manhattan realty reported yesterday. The four-story American basement dwelling at 527 West 113th Street, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue,

This year Studebaker has adopted Lueite, a new, transparent plastic, on the instrument panel of the 1938 Studebaker cars. It is as transparent as glass and yet it does not break or shatter under impact. In addition to its transparency, it adds another factor of safety.

President Roosevelt said again today that he expected to balance the budget for the next fiscal year. The statement was made at a press conference after he had said he agreed with Secretary Morgenthau's remark in Washington that nobody could tell now.

Estate, less than $10,000. To Helen D. Bennett, mother, 47 Union St., Montclair. N. J., residue. Raymond E. Burdick, 71 Dorchester Ave., Montclair, N. J., and John A. Bennett, 143 Eagle Rock Way, Montclair. N. J. executors.

Before the synchromatic shift was approved for the 1938 Cadillacs and LaSalles engineers conducted numerous tests to prove operating ease. Cars equipped with the new lever were placed in the hands of uninitiated men and women drivers. No advance instruction on the shift would be given.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, telegraphed to President Roosevelt today urging "justice" for the fourteen members of the crew of the steamship Algic, jailed at Baltimore for insubordination, and demanding the resignations of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, and Daniel S. Ring, an employee of the board.

A resolution endorsing maximum hourminimum wage legislation by Congress was introduced today at the second day's session of the Conference on Labor Legislation. It was referred to the committee on resolutions. Approval and adoption by the conference are expected tomorrow.
Eleven English boy choristers, ranging in age from 11 to 16, three of whom sang at the coronation of King George VI, arrived here yesterday morning on the Red Star liner Pennland.

The 1938 automobile is an outstanding value as compared with previous years. On the basis of car weight alone, the 1938 new car purchaser gets $1.62 in value for each dollar he would have spent in 1926.
Dr. Harold Benjamin Fantham, head of McGill University's Zoology Department, and scientist, died here today after a month's illness at the age of 62.

With the introduction of a new two-toned upholstery treatment seen in the sixes and eights to go on display at the Automobile Show on Wednesday, Hudson has created a style surprise for 1938, according to stylists in the industry.

The sleeping car arrangement which Nash pioneered is again a feature of the four-door sedan model in each series of the 1938 cars. This year, it is said, the sleeping car arrangement has been so simplified and improved that the conversion can be made in less than ten minutes. The change into a sleeping-car is accomplished in four simple steps.

The sixteenth award of the Charles Frederick Chandler Medal of Columbia University will be made tonight to Dr. John Howard Northrop of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research' in a ceremony at 8 o'clock in the Horace Mann Auditorium, Broadway and 120th Street.

Perry St. 106, 3-story tenement and 3-story rear tenement, 25.1x94.11 irregular; City Bank Farmers Trust Co, administrator, against Relkap Realties, Inc; due, $35,700; taxes, etc., $345; to plaintiff for $25,000. 3d Ave, 1,678; 5-story tenement, 25.8x100; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against William Roediger: due, $29,932; taxes, etc., $496; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The Fordham varsity basketball and swimming schedules for the coming season were announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics. Nineteen contests have been arranged for the courtmen and nine dual meets for the swimmers.

Governor Robert E. Quinn announced early today that Walter E. O'Hara, publisher of The Providence Star Tribune and managing director of Narragansett race track, had been arrested on a warrant charging him with civil libel.
Let us take a look at the exterior of the modern motor car in order to see how the body design division of engineering science has progressed. It has applied the theory of dynamic symmetry.
The British Government hinted for the first time today that it would not approve any peace settlement in the Far East based on the dismemberment or subjugation of China.

The French franc continued to fall yesterday. A decline of 3 3/8 points, following upon one of 1 3/4 points on Monday, carried the exchange down to 3.33 1/4 cents. Pressure also widened the discount on ninety-day forward francs to 14 points, an increase of 4 7/8 points over the previous day.

Albert J. Potts, 39 years old, and Samuel H. Winet, 36, both of New York City, were held here today following their arrest last night in connection with swindling Essex County owners of building and loan shares out of about $500,000.
An anonymous gift of $250,000 to the University of Pennsylvania's bicentennial fund campaign was announced today by President Gates.

Coach Mal Stevens sent his New York University football squad through a hard all-around workout yesterday afternoon at Ohio Field. The session lasted for three hours with the final half hour's drill under floodlights.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Post of Englewood, N. J., gave a cocktail party tonight in the Spring Room at the Greenbrier, honoring Mr. and Mrs. Clyde G. Conley.

Mrs. John Harlan Amen, co-chairman of the Democrats for La Guardia and daughter of President Grover Cleveland, made public yesterday a statement signed by a number of women, urging re-election of the Mayor. Historically, President Cleveland was a foe of Tammany. The statement follows:

Nicholas Lane-Jackson, grand old man of British sports, died today. He would have been 88 years old on Nov. 1. Known to the sporting world as Pa, he founded the famous Corinthian Amateur Football Club and the London Football Association and assisted in the formation of the Lawn Tennis Association council, on which he served for many years. He was vice president of the Football Association.

The financial district was pleasantly surprised by the action of United States Steel's directors yesterday in declaring a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, as it had expected something in the nature of a year-end distribution at next month's meeting of the board and felt that nothing would be done before that time.
Donald W. McGee, who was connected with the sales department of the Atlantic States Gas Company, with headquarters at Lewistown, Pa., died today at his home here at the age of 54.

Pronounced weakness in secondary railroad issues was the feature of an otherwise firm undertone in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The decline in the rail loans, however, which, incidentally, was attributed in trading circles largely to profit-taking,

Not merelythe head of a great empire but master of himself, King George VI opened Parliament today with an eighteen-minute speech from the throne which showed barely a trace of his old speech impediment.

Every third family of the 30,000,000 in the United States will have purchased an automobile, new or used, during 1937, the American Petroleum Industries Committee predicts. Sales of new cars for 1937 are expected to stand at about 4,300,000, and sales of used cars, which for the last ten years have been greatly in excess of new cars, are expected to exceed 7,000,000, making a total of approximately 11,500,000 automobile sales transactions for the year.

The spectacle of a justice of our highest court disqualifying himself from sitting in judgment on a case involving a fundamental question of civil liberties is a humiliating spectacle, which this country should never have been forced to witness.
A bushel basket filled with revolvers and pistols was deposited today in the Westchester County Sheriff's office by Lieutenant Maurice Thomas, acting chief or the Mamaroneck village police.

A bushel basket filled with revolvers and pistols was deposited today in the Westchester County Sheriff's office by Lieutenant Maurice Thomas, acting chief or the Mamaroneck village police.
Drivers who are taller than average or somewhat under average hight were in the minds of the engineers when they designed the new adjustable front seats of the 1938 Chrysler Royals and Imperials.

Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto, in Coney Island Court yesterday, indefinitely postponed the cases of two striking employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle who had been charged with conspiracy by the newspaper management.

Employment in motor vehicle and parts plants in 1936 gained 3 per cent over 1929 and the industry's employment stabilization program succeeded in increasing greatly the percentage of employes working forty-six or more weeks during the model year.

In a crowded "court room" of 900 "spectators" three different types of juries brought in agreeing verdicts tonight in a reconstruction of a damage suit conducted with all the panoply of a real trial by the Westchester County League of Women Voters at the Westchester Women's Club here.

The American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the extension to Jan. 15 of the time for the exchange of the $6 cumulative preferred stock into $5 prior preferred and common stock.

Walter Senior of San Francisco announced today he was forsaking amateur tennis ranks and joining the Ellsworth Vines-Fred Perry professional tour. The winner of the Midwestern, Wisconsin and Michigan State championships completes a professional quartet which will inaugurate its 1937-38 campaign Jan. 11.

As a prelude to its regular season, which begins next Monday, the French Theatre of New York presented last night at the intimate theatre in the Barbizon-Plaza the Theatre des Quatre Saisons in a performance of Carlo Gozzi's comedy of the eighteenth century, "Le Roi Cerf."

The Yale eleven spent two hours today developing a spirited offense in the hope of scoring against Dartmouth in the Bowl next Saturday. The regulars spent nearly an hour testing their plays in dummy scrimmage against the Grays, and almost another in actual contact work.

Seeking a backfield combination that will set the Jasper attack rolling against Georgetown on Saturday in Washington, Coach Chick Meehan made frequent changes in the secondary as he sent the Manhattan football squad through a two-hour offensive drill at Innisfail Park yesterday.
Casey Stengel, who has been "fooling around with a little oil" here on the rim of the East Texs oil fields, was eager tonight to take up the managerial reins of the Boston Bees.

Solly Krieger, 164, Brooklyn, knocked out Eddie Maguire, 160 1/2, Ireland, in the seventh round of the scheduled twelve-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Referee Young Otto intervened after 1:13 of fighting in the seventh to save the loser from further punishment.
The list of the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, leaving today for Southampton via Cherbourg, includes: Lord McGowan, chairman of Imperial Chemicals, Ltd.;
Accountants started today to figure out how many automobiles will use, the proposed $65,000,000 highway stretching from Harrisburg to Pittsburgh.

The Vienna Choir Boys, the tenor Joseph Schmidt and a good-sized audience last night jointly inaugurated the concert enterprise known as the Hurok Carnegie Hall series. The vocalists were filling the capacious boots of the presently indisposed Feodor Chaliapin, for whom the inaugural honors had been originally reserved.

Marcel Camp of Detroit and Charles Seaback of Boston won their matches tonight in the world pocket billiard championship tournament, duplicating achievements of Willie Mosconi, Philadelphia, and Erwin Rudolph, Cleveland, who triumphed this Afternoon.

Nation-wide service for Hupmobile owners has been improved through the provisions of a new dealer franchise, according to John F. Bowes, service manager of Hupp Motor Car Corporation. Under this franchise, adopted just before the introduction of Hupp's new 1938 models, each dealer is required to maintain complete, modern service facilities for all cars in his territory and to furnish the company's standard inspection service on all new cars sold.

Frank D. Holmes Jr., assistant secretary of the State Board of Commerce and Navigation, said today that a check covering New Jersey's contribution of $275,000 has been sent to the Federal Government for a project designed to save Barnegat Lighthouse from toppling into the Atlantic Ocean. Ocean Countvy,

THERE was once a contest for the Republican nomination for Governor of the Empire State and one of the candidates was a man noted for his wit. His "bons mots" and "jeux d'esprit" (wisecracks in a dinner coat) were repeated the length and breadth of the land and he had no rival as a producer of post-prandial hilarity. He was learned, able and industrious,- too, but the other fellow received the nomination.

When the new Building Code goes into effect on Jan. 1, it is likely to start a vogue for nine-story apartment houses in place of the sixstgry buildings which now are the rule outside of the high-rental districts.

Mayor La Guardia twitted his Democratic colleagues on the Board of Estimate yesterday for raising a question of the legality of the $12,000,000 water-rate cut they supported and pointed out that the legal question should have been settled before official action was taken.

Dr. William Robertson Watson, an ear, nose and throat specialist, died of heart disease last night at his home here after a long illness. He was 67. Born in Houston, Texas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pleasant Beverly Watson, he was educated at Sewanee University and the Medical School of the University of Pennsylvania.

When, twenty-five years ago this month, New Jersey constructed its first concrete highway, there were only about fifty miles of such highways in the United States. Now, there are 2,800 miles of them in the State of New Jersey alone.

Miss Joanne Hunt Husson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Francis Husson of Madison, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married to John Randolph Hopkins of New York and Palm Beach yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Increasing indignation felt in democratic circles all over this country against the aggressive fascist and Nazi propaganda has prompted several public meetings to adopt resolutions demanding suppression of anti-democratic associations.

Two hundred boys reported yesterday at the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh) Armory for the first formal drill of the 1937-38 Knickerbocker Greys Cadet Battalion, the fifty-six-year-old junior military organization which carries on its muster rolls the names of the sons of some of New York's most prominent families.

District Attorney William C. Dodge declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Lions Club in the Hotel Astor that investigations of district leaders by. Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey had resulted in nothing but "mud-slinging without an indictment."

Bryant High School harriers, with the lowest total of 35 points, won a quadrangular cross-country run yesterday at. Van Cortlandt Park, defeating Morris High, La Salle Academy and Drake Prep in that order. The others scored 44, 58 and 73 points respectively.

The formation of two groups, one of war veterans and the other of writers, was announced yesterday to support the campaign of Bruce Barton, candidate for Representative in Congress for the Seventeenth district.

While net operating income of the first thirty-one. railways to report earnings for September did not follow their increase in gross revenues, a closer hold on expenses enabled them to show a better record in this respect than they did in August.
John E. Miller, Senator-elect of Arkansas, demanded today a seat among Democratic Senators in spite of his election as an independent on the State ticket.

The refusal of Patrolman Frank Hartnett to believe that a man he saw being carried into 1,409 Amsterdam Avenue at 5 A. M. yesterday was intoxicated led to his discovery that the man had been murdered.
Herbert Hoover declared tonight that the Republican party must see to it that justice was done to "the great economic middle class," which now embraced the truly "forgotten men."

Alfred M. Landon expressed today an insistence that if any mid-term National Republican Convention was held, the rank and file of the party should be represented in the deliberations as well as in the consideration of any report on behalf of the policy committee."

Safety engineers and traffic officials, 7,000 of whom attended the annual National Safety Congress, sounded a warning to automobile designers not to let modern fender styling interfere with easy inspection of tires and application of tire chains.

The average United States motorist lost year was short-changed 16 cents out of every dollar he paid in automotive taxes for more and better highways. Figures released by the United States Bureau of Public Roads reveal that 16 per cent of all special automotive taxes paid by motorists into State treasuries was diverted to non-highway purposes.

The formation of two groups, one of war veterans and the other of writers, was announced yesterday to support the campaign of Bruce Barton, candidate for Representative in Congress for the Seventeenth district.

While net operating income of the first thirty-one. railways to report earnings for September did not follow their increase in gross revenues, a closer hold on expenses enabled them to show a better record in this respect than they did in August.
John E. Miller, Senator-elect of Arkansas, demanded today a seat among Democratic Senators in spite of his election as an independent on the State ticket.

One of Studebaker's contributions in the field of highway safety, introduced within the past year, has been the dual-control driver training car, designed especially for the training of inexperienced drivers.
Albert Megginson, 26-year-old laborer, of 111 West 115th Street, leaped to his death yesterday afternoon from the observation tower on the eighty-sixth floor f the Empire State Building.

Plans for nation-wide observance of an "Industrial Progress Week," designed to publicize the ideals and principles of American business, will be completed at a meeting of the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers here on Friday, it was learned yesterday.

Syracuse had a long lesson today on Penn State's attack as it was imitated by the freshmen in a scrimmage. A heavy drill lasted till dark as Coach Ossie Solem endeavored to correct faults shown last week.

Greater safety for children on their way to and from school, and other pedestrians is expected as a result of a new law permitting the State to build highway sidewalks with regular road construction and maintenance funds.

Any automobile of standard specifications and recent manufacture in a safe car to drive. The efforts of engineers and manufacturers have been steadily devoted to the solving of all elements of control.

The defense in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case produced today a tabulation to show that the Barnsdall Refining Corporation and its predecessor companies always had purchased large quantities of gasoline from small independent refineries.

The City Fusion party nominations of Isidore Nagler, Joseph L. Zoetzl, George Salvatore and Alazar Kushner for Borough President, District Attorney, Sheriff and Register, respectively, in the Bronx were all declared invalid yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer.

Safety engineers and traffic officials, 7,000 of whom attended the annual National Safety Congress, sounded a warning to automobile designers not to let modern fender styling interfere with easy inspection of tires and application of tire chains.

The average United States motorist lost year was short-changed 16 cents out of every dollar he paid in automotive taxes for more and better highways. Figures released by the United States Bureau of Public Roads reveal that 16 per cent of all special automotive taxes paid by motorists into State treasuries was diverted to non-highway purposes.

The estate of C. K. G. Billings, financier and sportsman, was valued at $14,400,000 in an appraisement filed today. The will left $100,000 to his son-in-law, W. R. Vander Poel of New York, and the remainder in equal shares to the widow, Mrs. Blanche E. Billings, and the daughter, Mrs. Vander Poel.
The death of Horst Krutschinna, who killed Roland Strunk, reporter on Chancellor Hitler's newspaper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, in a duel, was disclosed today.

Invoking a 96-year old statute, the Apex Hosiery Company filed suit today against Philadelphia County to collect $1,026,793 as damages allegedly incurred during a sit-down strike at the company's plant here in the late Spring.

In speeches in two out of three meetings in Queens last night, Mayor La Guardia again urged the re-election of Borough President George U. Harvey and declared that the one issue of the campaign was whether the people wished .to continue honest and efficient city government or go back to Tammany Hall.
No doubt was left today that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht is finally out as German Economics Minister, although official spokesmen still profess to know nothing about it.

One of the few recent examples of financing by a holding company for its operating units will reach the market today in the form of a public offering of $13,000,000 of tenyear secured notes of the North Boston Lighting Properties.

The changes in the official staff of the United States Steel Corporation, approved by the company's directors at their meeting Tuesday, are notable for their infusion into the high executive personnel of what might be called...

Success in the experiment of models in a tank for the development of the America's Cup defender Ranger has resulted in that procedure being resorted to for the two new international twelve - meter yachts that are being designed by Olin J. Stephens of Sparkman Stephens, collaborator with W. Starling Burgess in the plans for Ranger.

The Chinese defense line has been greatly strengthened by the retreat from Chapei, Kiangwan and other strongholds, according to Chinese spokesmen here and in Nanking. They said the Japanese drive had been halted throughout the new line.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney declared yesterday that Mayor La Guardia was responsible for the injection of the "Red" issue into the Mayonalty campaign by failing to renounce the endorsement of the Communist party, and followed this with a declaration that the Mayor had fostered the cause of communism in the city school system.
New orders in the furniture industry last month fell 7 per cent below the level for the corresponding month last year, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, reported yesterday.

Major Gen. Sir Frederick W. B. Landon, who as chief inspector of quartermaster general services had the responsibility of delivering vast quantities of food and other supplies needed by British armies during the World War, died in Newcastle today at the age of 77.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Osborn of 123 East Seventy-third Street and Garrison, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Osborn, to Josiah Macy Erickson, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Wentworth Erickson of Swampscott, Mass., and Nassau, B. W. I.

An advanced technique for produring a germ-eating bacteriophage, which promises to forge a new tbol for attacking certain disease baciteria, was described' at Columbia 'University last night by Dr. John H. Northrop of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

Several sales of properties in Connecticut were reported yesterday by the G. LeRoy Kemp Company, Inc., brokers. Included in the parcels sold was the remodeled Colonial house with four acres of land at the corner of Newton Avenue and Cranbury Road, Norwalk. This property was purchased by John A. Dallett,

Cotton fluctuated over a range of about 9 or 10 points on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, prices again moving largely in sympathy with changes in securities. Moderate morning rallies on light foreign buying were followed by losses under commission house liquidatinn.

With a high run of 67, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia tonight defeated Charles Seaback cf Lawrence, Mass., 25 to 102, in the world pocket billiard championship. The Philadelphian bettered the previous high run of 59 made by Ralph Greenleaf on Monday.

Mrs. Rose Marie Dann, 40 years old, who was acquitted by a General Sessions jury on Tuesday night of the charge of murdering her common-law husband, Hans, in their home at 42 Lasalle Street, was arraigned in the Felony Court yesterday for possessing the pistol used in the killing.

The deer in northern New Hampshire seem to have been multiplying in numbers during the past two yearn, and the opening of the season in Coos, Carroll and Grafton Counties on Monday will find better conditions awaiting the hunter than have been found in some time.

Both wings of organized labor will reach the climax of their campaigns for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia within the next two days. The American Labor party, C. I. O. dominated but including in its membership many American Federation of Labor unions and members, will stage its big rally tonight in Madison Square Garden.

The two oldest horses in one of Empire City's longest races showed the way yesterday at the Yonkers course when Mamas Choice scored by three-quarters of a length over Easiest Way it the mile and a half test that was fifth on the program.

After a lapse of six years, Princeton University's football team will face Columbia once more in the Fall of 1939, according to the 1939 Nassau schedule released tonight by Asa S. Bushnell, '21, graduate manager of Princeton athletics. The game will be played in New York.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Orlando Blodgett Willcox of Englewood, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Willcox, to Thomas L. Robinson, son of Mrs. Thorndike Howe Endicott of Boston and of Dr. Samuel Robinson of Santa Barbara.

Petey Sarron and Henry Armstrong, approaching the end of their training for tomorrow night's world championship featherweight bout at Madison Square Garden, yesterday were reported in excellent shape for the impending struggle. Sarron, the champion, boxed six rounds at the Pioneer Gymnasium and went four additional rounds on the floor.

Secretary Swanson declared at a Navy Day press conference today that the Navy was in better shape than at any time since the World War. The establishment was fine, the shooting was fine, everything was in first-class condition, he said.

The New York Curb Exchange membership of N. P. de Mauriac has been transferred to. Seymour Blauner of Blauner, Simons Co. That of Gilbert U. Burdett has been transferred to Lorraine F. Pitman of Laidlaw Co.

The public had its first opportunity yesterday afternoon to see the 1938 Ford models when the Ford Motor Company, which does not exhibit at the National Automobile Show, opened its newly decorated display rooms at 1,710 Broadway. Many body styles in standard and de luxe V-8 passenger cars as well as newly styled trucks were on exhibition.

Charles D. Copeland, retired president judge of Westmoreland County Common Pleas Court and in 1934 Governor Earle's opponent for the Democratic nomination for Governor, died today in his sixty-fifth year.

Giving as finished a performance as could possibly be desired, Dalshangan Golddigger of Clarion, owned by the Clarion Kennels of Kingston, N. J., was first in the open all-age English Springer Spaniel Stake, which featured the closing session of the fourth annual Connecticut Spaniel Trial Association competition on the Ingham Hill Game Farm today.

In a surprise move at a meeting of motor-boat owners and drivers In the Hotel Lexington last night, slow boats were barred from future Gold Cup races, which for more than thirty years have been the blue-ribbon classics of the American speed-boat world.

Speaking with pride of a parade of new equipment of the Sanitation Department yesterday, Mayor La Guardia proclaimed the demonstration as typical of other accomplishments in his Administration and invited public inspection of every city department.

The three-story store and dwelling property at 479-81 Bergenline Avenue, West New York, N. J., has been sold by the Hudson Trust Company to the Annette Realty Corporation. The building is on a plot 45 by 90 feet and contains two stores and eight four-room apartments. Hopkins,

A first mortgage loan of $230,000 at 41/2 per cent has been arranged by Quinlan Leland for the 725 Realty Corp (Samuel Alexander and Leonard S. Kandell) on the recently completed six-story apartment at 725 W 184th St, occupying the blockfront from Bennett Ave to Overlook Terrace.

Deeming it inadvisable to feature John Montague, acquitted of robbery charges in Elizabethtown, N. Y., on Tuesday, in Bing Crosby's "Badge of Policeman O'Roon," Paramount today canceled arrangements made between Emanuel Cohen's Major Pictures and Everett Crosby, Montague's manager, for the latter's services.

Hereafter all American marine posts ashore at Shanghai, like British troops, will open fire immediately against any airplanes, regardless of whether they are Japanese or Chinese, that attack American forces or noncombatants in the sectors they are defending.

Thousands of applicants, four abreast, formed a line around three sides of the State Office Building most of yesterday as they waited for blanks for State Civil Service examinations for clerks, stenographers and typists. Owing to a delay in the arrival of the blanks from the printer, distribution did not begin until noon.

Sinclair Lewis lost his bifocal glasses here last night and thereby added a "Main Street" touch to his lecture appearance. When the audience became impatient, giving bursts of applause to hurry the curtain, the custodian of the city's Memorial Auditorium stepped to the microphone and said:

Louis E. Stoddard Jr.'s aged gelding Blackcock came back to one of his best races today and easily captured the Froh-Heim Chase which featured the opening of the sixteenth annual meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds.

A five-letter last name may be easier to handle than a fourteenletter one, but Waldmir M. Sarof of 1,386 Palisade Avenue wants to swap facility for family fame. Born Zarotscheneff in Russia in the days of the Czar, he wants to get back his name and undo the abbreviation

The engagement of $2,829,000 gold in Canada for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank announced a net decrease of $1,125,300 in the amount of gold held by it under earmark for foreign account.
Guinns Judy was judged the Lest of the 13 inch all-age bitches today in the seventh event of the field trials being sponsored by the New Jersey Beagle Club near here.

The report of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $19,419,397. This was equal,

The stock market here, although quiet, was generally firm today and most sections went ahead. Gilt-edge issues were well supported, while foreign bonds were steady in an unspectacular day. Transatlantic shares,

Ellery W. Stone, who is in charge of the radio telephone and telegraph operations of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its subsidiaries, has been elected a vice president of All America Cables, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

The State Mediation Board began yesterday an independent survey of all facts relating to labor unrest in the Consolidated Edison Company. Jules T. Freund, executive secretary of the board, said that the study was being made by the State agency on its own initiative in an effort to determine whether the situation lay within its jurisdiction and whether any useful purpose would be served by the board's intervention.

The engagement of Miss Faith Trumbull Corrigan to Charles M. Fair Jr., son of Mrs. Edward S. Knapp and of Charles M. Fair, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Joseph E. Corrigan of 1,212 Fifth Avenue.

The first permanent registration figures from the State's sixty-seven counties, under the new elections code, show that 3,968,361 Pennsylvanians are eligible to vote at Tuesday's municipal elections, 99,820 more than were registered for the primary election.

As a curious sequel to a raid on his home by four men whose British Fascist leader said they were looking for "seditious and Bolshevist literature," Major Wilfred F. Vernon, a high Air Ministry official, was fined 40 today at Farnham, Surrey, on a charge of improper possession of secret documents.
The fight against the "ghetto benches" in the universities continues unabated, the Jewish students being aided by some progressive Polish students and professors.

The statement of the Continental Oil Company for the first nine months of this year, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $11,614,575, after charges, depreciation, depletion, intangible -development costs and taxes.

On the eve of his visit with the Duchess to the United States the Duke of Windsor today at the weekly luncheon of the Anglo-American Press Association in Paris in a vigorous speech called for fair play by the press.
Arturo Toscanini, world-famous orchestra conductor, threw down his baton and agrily walked out on a rehearsal of a British Broadcasting Corporation orchestra tonight.

A scrimmage session, postponed from yesterday because of rain, was held in wet weather today by CornelPs squad. The work was hard, but the coaches frequently blew their whistles to halt action just short of tackling.

With Gallagher starring for the visitors, Army's soccer team suffered its first defeat of the season today, losing to Williams, 3 to 2. Gallagher scored twice from his center position. Butcher also tallied for Williams, while Barnard and Crown scored for the cadets.

The marriage of Mrs. Catherine P. Moseley of this town to Brig. Gen. William F. Ladd, Adjutant General of the State of Connecticut, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James A. Prophett.

United States Senator A. Harry Moore, Democratic Gubernatorial candidate, derided the Republican record on taxation today as he carried his campaign to Cumberland County in several speeches. "If it were not so serious a problem, I would be compelled to laugh at the attitude of our opponents," Senator Moore said.
Directly across from the sector guarded by United States marines, a Chinese dare-to-die detachment of from 200 to 300 men engaged today in a fight to the finish with Japanese.

Leopold McLaglen, brother of Victor McLaglen, motion picture actor, is under arrest, together with Stanley Glimm, former secretary to Philip Chancellor, pending an investigation into an alleged attempt to obtain money from Mr. Chancellor.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Sullivan, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Aloysius Sullivan of Town Path, and Gerald Boyd, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Boyd, also of Glen Cove, took place this morning in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Charles Boyd of Brooklyn, a brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

Charging that all except one of the sixty-three assistant district attorneys now on the staff of'William C. Dodge are "active members of Tammany political clubs," the New York chapter of the National Lawyers Guild announced yesterday its disapproval of the candidacy of Harold W. Hastings, Democratic nominee for District Attorney.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 15,000, including 4,500 directs. The market was strong to 10c higher than Tuesday's average; top, $9.40; several loads sold at that price; bulk good and choice 150-250 pounds, $9-$9.30; 260-300 pounds, $8.75-$P.20; most good packing sows, $7.90$8.30: best lightweights and outstanding mediumweights to $8.40. Shippers, 1,200; estimated holdover. 3.500.

The Harvard football coaches decided today that it was too much to expect Cliff Wilson to make the anticipated shift from center to guard. After seeing Wilson in the running guard position again Coach Harlow made up his mind that against Princeton Saturday, Harvard would be better off with Joe

Bo Ekelund, honorary secretary of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, today published letters he sent to Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of the American A. A. U., protesting the refusal of the A. A. U. to allow American athletes to compete in Germany last Summer.

The leases on the three-story building at 23-15 Forty-first Avenue and the one-story garage at 39-16 Twenty-third Street, Long Island City, have been renewed by the Works Progress Administration which sponsors the child nutrition project to furnish lunches to undernourished children in New York City schools.

Britain dispatched the mighty battle cruiser Hood to Majorca today to keep an eye on the strategic Balearic Islands. The Hood, the world's largest warship, sailed from Gibraltar to relieve the cruiser Despatch.
More than 800 persons attended a requiem mass for Charles Scotto, head chef at the Hotel Pierre, held in the Church of Our- Lady of Refuge, Ocean and Foster Avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

The Duke Power Company announced yesterday that it has made a final settlement of patent litigation which has been pending for several years, and will make a pro rata distribution to common stockholders of the net income accruing from this source. On Nov. 6,

Sweet Briar College will observe its annual Founders' Day celebration on Friday, with Dr. Mary E. Woolley, former president of Mount Holyoke College, giving the principal address, speaking on "Noblesse Oblige."

E. F. du Pont, personnel director of the du Pont company, said today that a shortage of trained college graduates capable of entering the rapidly expanding organic chemical industry had existed for some time.

The reply of Charles A. Schneider, Tammany district leader, to Thomas E. Dewey's charges last night follows: I have listened with a great deal of interest to the speech which was concluded a few short min-. utes ago by the Republican candidate for District Attorney of the County of New York.

Frank E. Gannett, publisher, proposed today that the government offer "tax relief" as an incentive to companies which distribute profits to their employes. Addressing the convention of the National Association of Commercial Organization Secretaries, Mr. Gannett said:

The automobile makers are sitting on the top of the world in this year of grace. Selling is no job at all. It's the making of cars that has taxed the industry's ingenuity and resources. Five million motor vehicles in 1938! Only in 1929 was that performance surpassed.

Hirosi Saito, the Japanese Ambassador, in a speech broadcast tonight over a Columbia Broadcasting Company network defended Japan's course in China, declaring that "the present conflict has been forced upon Japan, and Japan wants to end it as quickly as possible."

ALL OF A PIECE, by E. V. Lucas. (Lippincott, $2.) Essays. SHAKESPEARE'S YOUNG LOVERS, by Elmer Edgar Stoll.. (Oxford, $1.75.) Three lectures given on the Alexander Foundation at the University of Toronto in 1935.

The Newark City Commission today authorized James F. X. O'Brien, Corporation Counsel, to take legal steps to stay an order of Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker assessing on the city the cost of a Supreme Court investigation of the municipality's affairs. The cost,

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Long Summer vacations for school children are out of keeping with modern needs, and community responsibility extends to all-yearround. education as well as to providing nursery schools and adult education, Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education,
Colgate's Red Raiders today began tapering off for their game with N. Y. U. as Coach Andy Kerr sent his first and second teams through a lengthy dummy scrimmage to polish the offense.

J. Burns Allen, an insurance broker, died yesterday at his home in Germantown in his seventy-sixth year. He began his business career with the firm of Whiton Tredick in 1879 and at his death was president of Charles Tredick Co., Inc. He served on the executive committee of the Philadelphia Fire Underwriters Association for four terms.

A suit alleging that the City Bank Farmers Trust Company and its predecessors as trustees of a $2,500,000 6 per cent convertible gold bond issue of United American Utilities, Inc., had been derelict in their duty was filed yesterday in Supreme Court.

Standard Brands, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the third quarter of 1937 a net income of $2,326,490 after expenses and Federal and foreign income taxes, but before profit-and-loss items. No provision was made for Federal surtax on undistributed profits.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications from New York City for registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market:

There is good reason for the statement that with the quiet efficiency characteristic of the Reich's military organization, the fourteenth corps of the German Army is now being created. The new corps is not yet and probably will not come into existence until Spring. However,
Two hours spent this morning walking, slipping and climbing amidst the ruins of Chapei reveal the enormous extent of the damage from shells, bombs and recent conflagrations.

Harry Freshman, 49 years old, a salesman for a razor-blade company, was found dead of poisoning yesterday in the Hotel Paramount, 235 West Forty-sixth Street. His wife, Mrs. Lillian Freshman, hastened to the hotel after she had received a letter from her husband saying, "When you receive this I'll be dead."

The operators of coastwise ship lines offered a new wage contract to longshoremen in North Atlantic ports, calling for 95 cents an hour for -regular time and $1.45 an hour for overtime, at a conference yesterday with union delegates representing the longshoremen. Nearly 5,000 men would be affected.
Prescott Bigelow, a partner in the Boston banking firm of Hayden Stone Co., died of a heart attack tonight on a train while he was on his way to his Chestnut Hill home. He was 53 years old.

Dr. and Mrs. Truman Laurence Saunders have purchased Plaisance, on Ledge Road, which they have occupied for the last four Summers. The estate, which overlooks Bailey's Beach, comprises an acre and a half of land and a residence.

While production of metallurgical products in France in the first eight months of this year was larger than in the same period in 1936, production of pig iron remained below the peak level of 1929, while German and British production increased, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Following are the text of the Japanese Government's reply to the Belgian invitation to the Nine-Power conference at Brussels and a statement issued by the Foreign Office tonight:
Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, in his third-quarter report translates the cost of social security taxes into added cost of each automobile produced by the company.

The electric light and power industry during August showed gains in energy generated, sales to consumers and total revenues, according to statistics released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute. Comparative tables for August and the twelve months ended Aug. 31, are as follows (000 omitted):

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary P. Regensburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melville E. Regensburg of 895 Park Avenue, to Leonard Feist, son of Mrs. Leo Feist of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Mr. Feist.

Whether the President would under any circumstances seek a third term is being increasingly discussed in this country, and there are no signs of a popular. uprising against the idea There are, of course, several reasons for the surface placidity.

Brilliant with color, agleam with shining metal and pulsating with life and motion, the thirty-eighth annual National Automobile Show opened in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon. It will be open each day and evening through Nov. 3.

Defense against passes and the perfecting of two new plays occupied the Rutgers eleven today as the line-up which. started against Princeton last Saturday appeared as a unit for the first time this week.

The introduction of a new move by Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris in the sixth game of his championship match with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, which was played at Haarlem, caused much speculation among followers of chess the world over and not a little skepticism.
Coach Gar Davidson used two re vamped backfields on the first team today as Army prepared for Saturday's game here with V. M. I. with a long scrimmage with the B squad.

Participating in what actually will be its last full drill before meeting -North Carolina at Chapel Hill on Saturday, the Fordham football squad took advantage of the clear, crisp weather yesterday and spent almost three hours on Fordham Field tuning up both its offense and. defense.
The Maritime Commission completed today the sale of twenty-five obsolete steel cargo vessels by accepting a bid of $194,500 on the remaining three from G. E. Marden of New York City.

After many rumors and denials, proffers and refusals, the resignation of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht as Germany's Minister of Economics has at last become a fact. Dr. Schacht will retain his post as president of the Reichsbank, but it is hinted that this too will be but temporary.

Declaring that if taxpayers wish to be treated as adults they must approach Congress with "something stronger than resolutions," Robert H. Montgomery of Lybrand, Ross Brothers Montgomery, tax consultants, told the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., at its annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday that "Congressmen understand only one language, and that language is votes."

Rufus K. Dryer, for many years one of Rochester's leading bankers and business men, died today at High Acres, Geneva, N. Y., where he had made his home since 1914, although continuing his banking interests in this city. He was 91 years old.

Strong opposition to proposed compulsory crop control and a wide divergence of opinion on numerous other issues marked the meeting today of the House Committee on Agriculture, creating doubt that agreement would be reached on a draft of general farm legislation before the special session of Congress convenes on Nov. 15.

Results of operations in the quarter and the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were announced yesterday by four steel companies. The report of the National Steel Corporation for the quarter showed a net profit of $5,227,071, equal to $2.41 a share on 2,167,777 outstanding capital shares.

Lee Knitwear Corp, floor, Debi-Rose, Inc, dresses, floor in 48-56 W 38th St; House of Tre-Jur, Inc, toilet articles, additional floor in 19-23 W 18th St; Goldsmith Perlman, millinery, in 49-57 W 37th St; Peterson Rug and Carpet Cleaning Co Ine, in 245 5th Ave; Adams Co, Real Estate. Inc. broker.

Two men were arrested today near the FordMotor Company plant and charged with aggravated assault as an aftermath of the abduction and flogging of Harry Bowen, 33, former employe of the Kansas City Ford plant.

Technical liquidation of the Lawyers Mortgage Company, which has about $250,000,000 in guarantees of real estate mortgages and mortgage certificates outstanding, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler as a step toward carrying into effect the plan for reorganization of the company that he approved recently.
Army's powerful plebe eleven turned back the New York University freshmen, 7 to 0, in a hardfought game on the Michie Stadium gridiron today.

Archaeologists expressed the belief today that they had uncovered ground slate implements giving evidence of human habitation in Vermont about 1,500 to 2,000 years ago. Discussing the result of excavations at the junction of Otter and Dead Creeks, John H. Bailey of the Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences asserted:

The Watertown National Bank, as trustee for Frederick H. Babcock and others, took a mortgage from the Oceanic Investing Corp, G. E. Chalinder Allen of Greenwich, Conn., president, for $197,500 on 601 5th Ave, 27x100, a six-story building, payable Sept. 30, 1941, at 31/2 to 4 per cent and to be amortized $2.500 semi-annually.
Joseph Aquilla Enslow, formerly manager of the Brooklyn agency of the National Biscuit Company, died at his home here today after a two-week illness. His age was 68.

The report of Westinghouse Electrio and Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries, issued yesterday by A. W. Robertson, chairman of the board, for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 showed a net profit of $16,726,520 after depreciatioh, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Reaction of Wall Street leaders to the Federal Reserve Board's announcement last night of regulations of stock market margin requirements was cordial.
