Brokers, interviewed in their homes, hailed the development as a sign of a more cooperative attitude on the part of Washington, declaring that this, rather than any technical improvement in the market to be made by the new regulations, was the important consideration.

ARONSON--Maurice, devoted son of Philip and brother of Benjamin, Anna and Dr. Henry Aronson. Funeral private. ABONSON-Maurice. Piatt Lodge, No. 194, F. and A. M., sorrowfully announces the loss of our dear brother. Services 10:30 A. M. today, 187 South Oxford St., Brooklyn.

An advertising campaign in the United States, which may develop into the largest ever undertaken by any nation to promote its products, will be launched by the Argentine Republic probably in the Summer or Fall of 1938, Eugenio Riva Corti, official delegate from the Argentine Government, revealed here yesterday.

The Public Service Commission denied yesterday the application of the receivers for the New York, Westchester Boston Railway for permission to abandon service on its New Rochelle-Port Chester branch on less than the required thirty days' notice.

The United States will commit itself to action at the Nine-Power Conference only if the program devised offers a practical and peaceful solution of the Sino-Japanes dispute, Norman H. Davis emphasized on his arrival here today en route to Brussels.

A new plan to settle the controvery over Hollywood financing of Broadway plays is now under consideration by the Dramatists Guild and at least one major motion picture firm, it was leained yesterday The plan provides that the price for motion picture rights to a play would be dependent on the length nf the run of the play.

An extensive advertising campaign will be launched in New York and New England for the new Jacob Ruppert Ale, next month, it was announced yesterday. Details of the campaign have not been worked out as yet but some announcement copy will probably be carried in newspapers.

F. Gladden Searle of Bronxville, N. Y., has been elected to the board of directors of Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation. He is also vice president in charge of sales and advertising of Continental Can Company and a director of Vincennes Packing Corporation.
New York's Court of Appeals ruled tonight that Surrogate William J. Shiels of Westchester County was not entitled to a six-year term of office and must stand for re-election next week.

With two of the injured line regulars still confining their activities to light work, Columbia's football team was sent through a hard defensive drill at Baker Field yesterday in preparation for its game with Cornell at Ithaca: on Saturday. Opposing a "Cornell" team made up of first-string freshmen the Lion varsity in a contact scrimmage repulsed a varied aerial and ground attack.

They tossed a party for Slingin' Sammy Baugh yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln. Before the eyes and ears of the critical press the young man who used to play football for Texas Christian and glory and who now labors for George Preston Marshall's Washington Redskins and gold gave. a pretty' good account of himself in the role of after-dinner speaker.

The first wax recording ever made of a human voice turned out today to be a quotation from Shakespeare. The man responsible for the historic message, which for fifty-six years has been locked in a vault of the Smithsonian Institution here, probably was Alexander Graham Bell, inventor of the telephone.

The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company reported today its total insurance in force on Sept. 30 was $3,837,737.489 in 1,024,653 policies. This represented net increases of $80,052,923 and 22,331 policies in the year.

Coach Benny Friedman, who has devised new plays for-C. C. N. Y.'s first game at home in three weeks against Providence College Saturday, summoned the squad to Lewissohn Stadium yesterday and put his linemen through a scrimmage that stressed a deceptive attack.

Twenty-six persons were killed and twenty-four seriously injured in an accident at Yokohama yesterday when a troop train plowed through a large throng gathered along the track to cheer a departing train on an adjoining track.

Farms Inc., Pensacola, Fla., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 75,000 shares of 60-cent cumnulative participating Class A no-par value stock to be offered at $10 a share.

A spokesman for the Boston Shamrocks of the American Football League today expressed "surprise" but declined comment when informed Larry Kelley; former Yale star, had announced he had abandoned the idea of playing professional football.

The board of governors of the Federal Reserve System tonight announced, effective Nov. 1, a reduction from 55 per cent to 40 per cent in the margin requirements by brokers and dealers and by banks for the purpose of purchasing or carrying securities.

Declaring that the "saturation point in automobile use is not even in sight," Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation and of the Automotive Safety Foundation, told nearly 100 officials of most of the automobile manufacturing companies, publishers of trade journals and advertising men yesterday that use of the automobile would increase in proportion to the effectiveness of the handling of traffic safety problems.

When the Nazi delegation headed by Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the party, which Chancellor Hitler has sent to participate in the celebration of the fifteenth anniversary of the Fascist revolution, arrived here this afternoon, it found the city's walls plentifully placarded with large posters bearing inscriptions such as "Arriba Espana!"

Conversations directed toward the negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement between the -United States and Norway were conducted informally tonight at the Norwegian Legation by Secretary Hull and Dr. Halvdan Koht, Foreign Minister of Norway, who arrived in the capital today for an official visit.

George J. Guess Jr., 19-Year-old sophomore at Fordham College, received yesterday the prize in a national essay competition, sponsored by the National Patriotic Council, for his essay, "What the C. M. T. C. Means to Me."

The Federal Land Banks have been "whittling away at their backlog of supply" for more than a year, and selling more farms than they have been acquiring, Albert S. Goss, Land Bank Commissioner of the Farm Credit Administration, told a meeting of the presidents of the twelve banks today.

" THE LONG WAY HOME"* is another historical novel, at least the nth since Margaret Mitchell startled the public (and her publishers) last Summer. Defined with classic precision by my colleague Mr. Poore as one in which Napoleon wins the Civil War and marries Queen Victoria, the genus appears to have become the principal object in the current literary scene, and promises to remain such for some time to come.
Stanley Ditzel, switchboard operator in the Town Hall here, received a call today from an excited woman, who asked for the Board of Health. "The line is busy, madam," said Mr. Ditzel.

A reception and tea will be given this afternoon by Mrs. William P. Goldman at her home, 575 Park Avenue, for persons interested in the success of the annual dinner dance to be given jointly by the Children's Welfare League and the Jewish Settlement House of the East Side on Nov. 21 at the WaldorfAstoria. The settlement,

Sidney Howard's latest play, "The Ghost of Yankee Doodle," had its world premiere under the Theatre Guild banner at the Auditorium tonight. It had a mild welcome. The scene of the drama, indicting war promoters and propagandists and ironically showing them driving protesting pacifists and other opponents of armed conflict into futility, is a home in a Western American city, presided over by a widowed mother.

Leases of apartments on the East Side furnished the major part of the rental activity reported by agents and brokers yesterday. Buildings on the side streets in the Seventies and Eighties attracted many of the new tenants.

In the same building, but ten stories apart, Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey and Assistant Attorney General Charles A. Schneider, Tammany leader of the Eighth Assembly District, engaged last night in the most dramatic encounter of the current campaign.

Behind rumors of the surrender of Madrid that swept European stock markets to day the only substance appears to have been a report from Valencia that the question was being discussed there whether it was worth while for the old capital to hold out.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday authorized Milton C. Weisman, receiver for the Fox Theatres Corporation, to pay a second ad interim dividend of 3 per cent to creditors whose claims have been adjudicated.

The Bank of Smithtown, Smithtown, L. I., announced yesterday that an offering of its capital stock had been oversubscribed. The offering, which consisted of 500 shares of a par value of $100 each, was sold at $150 a share, yielding $75,000 of new capital, of which $50,000 was added to capital and $25,000 to surplus.

Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, issued today a proclamation charging Dr. Theophil Wurm, the Bishop of Wuertemberg, and the Confessional Synod with "siding with the open enemies of the German nation and supporting those who are attacking their Fatherland."

A poll taken by a non-partisan canvassing organization in the Seventeenth Congressional District and made public yesterday showed Bruce Barton, Republican nominee for Representative, running far ahead of Stanley Osserman, Democrat, with George Backer, American Labor candidate, running almost up to Mr. Osserman.

The local Communist political campaign over the radio will have cost the party about $9,000 by election day, it was estimated yesterday by William E. Browder, State treasurer, who added that the amount would cover approximately fifty broadcasts by various candidates or their supporters.

President Lazaro Cardenas apparently has broken the opposition to his policies in the Northwestern State of Sonora, which has stood out against his land reform and prolabor policies and where it has long been feared that the smoldering opposition to his regime might break into an open flame.

Yale's only strenuous and long session of contact work this week took place today in the Bowl, with portals barricaded to sightseers. The type of formations expected to be used by Dartmouth here Saturday were stressed as the Elis devoted the first hour of their drill to defensive strategy.
William Hosmer Ives, retired New York lawyer and publishing house executive, died here yesterday at the Northern Westchester Hospital. His age was 67 and he lived at Stanwood, Mount Kisco.

During the year between the 1936 birthday of the late President Theodore Roosevelt and the observances yesterday more than 1,800,000 persons visited the Roosevelt Memorial at the American Museum of Natural History, it was announced yesterday by Wayne M. Faunce, vice director of the museum.

Preservation and growth for more than a year of bits of human tissue in a solution containing known chemicals, an experiment which medical experts believe provides an important new approach to the study of cancer, is announced today in the American Journal of Cancer.
Twenty men and women, carrying placards, picketed the Commodity Exchange at 81 Broad Street for an hour yesterday afternoon in an attempt to persuade traders to cancel new orders for Japanese silk.

George Backer, Amierican Labor party candidate for Congress from the Seventeenth, district, declared yesterday that sample polls taken by his workers give him an excellent chance of election in a district which is normally rock-ribbed Republican.

A new title, "Botticelli" (Oxford), is being published today in the Phaidon Art Series of reproductions. Among the volumes already published in this series, which ranges over the whole history of art, are "The Art of Ancient Egypt," "The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy" and "Five Hundred Self-Portraits."

William G. Morrisey, former director of exhibits and concessions of the New York World's Fair 1939, has been appointed executive director of the extensive display to be made at the exposition by manufacturers of apparel and accessories, Joseph Love, chairman of the advisory committee on apparel and accessories announced yesterday.

Governor Lenman, in a radio address tonight to the voters of the State, urged election of Democratic candidates for the Assembly and declared that, to his "utter amazement," these candidates have not been endorsed by the groups who support, with the Democratic party, "liberal and humane legislation."

A large assemblage of his fellow-townspeople as well as many men prominent in the political life of the State were present here today at the burial services for Lafayette B. Gleason at Woodland Cemetery.
Mr. and Mrs. John W. Davidge have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Davidge, to Mark Sullivan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Sullivan of Washington.

Alienists reported today to Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich that Joseph Tomich, 19 years old, of 50 Penn Boulevard, Scarsdale, is a mental defective and should not be prosecuted on a charge of blackmail.

The Treasurer of the Territory of Hawaii awarded yesterday an issue of $4,800,000 of bonds, of which $1,500,000 of short-term refunding bonds went to a syndicate headed bonds went to a syndicate headed by Lazard, Freres Co., Inc., on a bid of 100.089 for 2.70s, and $3,300,000 of new public improvement bonds to Laurence M. Marks Co.

Dr. Francis J. McConnell is by office and title Bishop of the New York Methodist Area, but his area of usefulness is an even ampler one. He is widely beloved by people of other denominations as well as his own, whose spiritual life he has enriched and whose burdens he has lightened by helping to bear them.

Twenty Americans won $1,800,000 in the Irish Sweepstakes, minus taxes and in some cases shares in tickets sold to London brokers, yesterday on the first, second and third horses in the Cesarewitch Stakes, at Newmarket, England,

Under a wave of selling pressure in the railroad issues, bonds on the New York Stock Exchange declined yesterday in the lightest trading session since Oct. 11. Sales in all bonds fell to $7,853,525, compared to $8,142,500 on Tuesday.

Four missionaries of the First Church of God of Lancaster, Pa., who sailed for Bogra, India, yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, were guests at "missionary farewell party" given by 450 members of the church who came from Lancaster, Harrisburg and other Pennsylvania cities and towns. They are the Rev. and Mrs.

Net earnings of the General Motors Corporation and subsidiaries for the third quarter of 1937 amounted to $44,412,734, which was equal, after preferred dividends, to 99 cents a share on the 42,727,651 average number of common shares outstanding in the period, compared with $34,626,078, or 75 cents a share, in the same period of 1937,

Powers Hapgood, organizer for the United Shoe Workers of America, asserted today that an epidemic of wage cutting dangerous to the nation'J prosperity might result if tariffs, on shoes were lowered in a proposed reciprocal trade agreement with Czechoslovakia.

Pennsylvania will be obliged to us inerperienced ends against the NavY here on Saturday. This became evident today when Head Coach Harvey Harman received word that Bob Schuenemann and Ned Fielden, both veterans, will not-be available because of injuries.

Dr. John H. Mulholland has purchased a vacant plot of about 12,000 square feet at Villard Hill, in Dobbs Ferry, Westchester, upon which. construction of a Colonial dwelling for him has been started by Charles A. Anderson, builder.

Coach Lou Oshins sent his Brooklyn College football team through a long practice yesterday in an effort to perfect the timing of a new set of plays to be used in the game with Hofstra College at the new Brooklyn College athletic field at Bedford Avenue and Avenue H Saturday.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, one of the principal labor unions supporting Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor, charged in a radio address last night that John L. Lewis had told him Mayor La Guardia was with Lewis and the C. I. O. in disputes between that organization and the A. F. of L. in New York City.

A prediction that Mayor La Guardia of New York will be re-elected Nov. 2 by a 2-to-1 majority over Jeremiah T. Mahoney, his Tammany opponent, will be made on Sunday by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Freight rate increases authorized recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission and which are expected to yield an additional $47,500,000 revenue to the railroads will be put into effect. on Nov. 10, it was disclosed today by the Association of American Railroads.

In this lake-refrigerated city, where the flurries of snow have already given warning that Winter is coming, members of the National Academy of Sciences heard today the scientifically established news that the unprotected human body was no more capable of insulating itself from the atmosphere than was a tank of warm water.

The fourth conference of State labor executives ended today with the unanimous adoption of a resolution urging Congress to enact a maximum-hour, minimum-wage law which would include a prohibition against the transportation in interstate commerce of goods produced by child labor.
A testimonial dinner will be tendered Max J. Kramer, builder and president of the Hotel Edison, on Sunday, by the First Ottynier Young Men's Benevolent Association in the Hotel Edison.

The Appellate Division upheld today the ruling of Frank P. Graves, State Education Commissioner, that the foreign motion picturee "Ecstasy" is "immoral and indecent." Unanimous decision was handed down after the tribunal had passed an hour and fifteen minutes in viewing the picture.

When New York's football Giants face the Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds Sunday they will be able, for the first time in the dozen years of rivalry, to match George Halas's undefeated outfit in re serve strength.
Tony Lazzeri slipped into Chicago today to find out why his release from the world champion Yankees was engineered by Phil K. Wrigley, owner of the Cubs.

Howard W. Dunbar of Worcester, Mass., was elected president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association today, succeeding Clayton R. Burt of Hartford, Conn; Other officers named at the closing session of the association's convention here, were:

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn issued a statement yesterday in which he charged Mayor La Guardia with uttering a "malicious falsehood" at a political meeting in Brooklyn on Tuesday night, when the Mayor asserted that Leo P. Byk, former Brooklyn slot-machine operator, had purchased steamship tickets for Mr. Geoghan.
The Appellate Division held constitutional today the power of the State Department of Agriculture to restrict the sale of milk by distributors to limited areas.

" Father Malachy's Miracle" is going to take place after all, and under the management of Delos Chappell, who announced it in the first place and then postponed it more or less indefinitely. On the stage of the St. James Theatre, where the cast performed the play privately on Monday night for the benefit of other prospective producers, Mr. Chappell and Worthington Miner, director, yesterday explained the new set-up to the company.

Miss Audrey Lewisohn, daughter of Frederick Lewisohn of 726 Park Avenue, and granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seligman of this city and Elberon, N. J., will be married on Nov. 11 in London to Matthew Baird 3d, son of Matthew Baird 2d of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Baird.
Harvard's varsity soccer team moved up into second place in the New England Intercollegiate League today by beating the Tufts eleven, 5-0. The line-up:
President Roosevelt sent a wreath to be placed on the grave of former President Theodore Roosevelt today, to mark the seventyninth anniversary of his birth.

Princeton's football forces put in their last really hard workout for Harvard this afternoon. For the better part of two hours, the varsity and the scrubs moved about University Field, touching every phase of football from fundamentals to the highly involved hidden ball attack of Harvard.

The Clement Cleveland Medal, recently established by the New York' City Cancer Committee. of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, was awarded for the first time last night to Henry R. Luce, president of Time, Inc., at a dinner in the Town Hall Club, 125 West Forty-third Street.

Twelve jurors and an alternate, who for the last several days have been listening to testimony in a Mann Act case that has brought crowds to the Federal Building, were disappointed last Tuesday night when they were unable to see a movie at the Paramount Theatre, it was revealed yesterday when the trial was resumed.

Japan's refusal to attend the Brussels conference on the ground that it would find itself condemned in advance is not expected to alter the plans of the other signatories of the Nine-Power treaty to confer together with a view of finding, if possible, a basis for peace in China.

The Rev. Dr. Sartell Prentice, who was pastor of the First Reformed Church in Nyack, N. Y., from 1904 -to 1923, when he resigned because of ill health, died yesterday morning in his apartment at 17 East Eleventh Street. He was 70 years old.

In recognition of their distinguished achievements for humanity, the Roosevelt Medal for 1936 was presented to Helen Keller and the award for 1937 to Dr. James Hardy Dillard, Southern educator, at the annual dinner of the Roosevelt Memorial Association last night at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

Reports from Amoy state that Japanese marines occupied Quemoy Island, opposite Amoy yesterday, after a severe bombardment by at least ten warships, while planes also heavily bombed the fortifications recently erected on the island.

Thomas Roberts, 58 years old, of 161-22 119th Drive, Jamaica, was killed by an automobile at 6:50 P. M. yesterday while crossing New York Boulevard at 120th Avenue. The driver of the car was Harold Taylor of 66 Clinton Avenue, East Rockaway, L. I.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Beverly Harvie of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Katherine Chamberlayne Harvie, to Dr. Victor Spencer Huggins of Evansville, Ind., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Huggins of Halifax, Nova Scotia.

Presentation in an impressive ceremony of national colors and flags of each State and territorial unity of the United States by the National Society Daughters of the American Revolution, to the regiment of midshipmen marked the observance of Navy Day at the Naval Academy today.

Miss Sarita S. Blagden, chairman of the junior committee for the New York debut of William Fleming, pianist, at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 3, gave a tea yesterday afternoon at the home of her aunt, Miss Miriam P. Blagden of 113 East Sixty-fourth Street, for the other members of her group. The guests were Mrs.
With Harry F. Wolf, national champion, assuming a new post as No. 1 man of the Montclair A. C. squash tennis team, the Metropolitan League Class A matches inaugurated another season last night.

John H. Cunningham, inspector of grounds and buildings at Syracuse University for fifty-four years, died last night. He was known to thousands of alumni and students, and was an honorary alumnus of the university.

William Wyer, secretary and treasurer of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, and others who were high in the councils of the Van Sweringens were charged before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today with having submitted false statements to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the State utility commissions of Missouri, Louisiana and other States,

Advancing along a front of approximately twenty-five miles three Japanese detachments today completely occupied Niangtzekwan and adjacent sectors in mountainous country on the Hopeh-Shansi border where Chinese forces have been entrenched for several weeks, according to a Japanese communique issued here today.

Realty experts and city planners are bending their efforts to the task of rehabilitating blighted neighborhoods and preventing deterioration which would adversely affect property values in growing industrial and residential centers.

Princess Brinda of Kapurthala, Baron Hubert Lejeune, Lady Bain, Count Jean de Beaufort, Baron and Baroness de Lustrac, Mr. and Mrs. P. G. Wodehouse and Mr. and Mrs. Jules Fribourg are sailing today for Europe on the French liner Ile de France.

Henry Galiato, 14 years old, of 11 Columbus Avenue, Bloomfield, was-freed tonight from an exit turnstile of the city subway after a police emergency squad had burned away the wedging bars with an acetylene torch. Henry,

Denis Mulligan, chief of the regulations and enforcement division of the Bureau of Air Commerce since that bureau was reorganized by Secretary Roper last April, was appointed to be assistant director of the bureau.
A questionnaire requiring a large amount of information within seven days was mailed today by the Federal Power Commission to every public utility within its jurisdiction.
John C. Korn was appointed yesterday assistant secretary of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Korn has been secretary of the committees on bonds and arrangements since 1934 and 1935, respectively.
Mrs. Florence Morse Kingsley, novelist, wife of the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Kingsley, died yesterday afternoon at their home, 116 Kingsley Avenue, Westerleigh, Staten Island, after a short illness.
Mayor Adhemar Raynault is believed to be planning the conversion of about half of Montreal's funded debt of $278,000,000 through a New York syndicate.

The Reich Official Gazette announces today that Theodor Wolff, former editor of the Berliner Tageblatt and probably the best known German journalist, has been stripped of his citizenship. The law of July 13, 1933, empowering Hitler to take their German citizenship from those "who have proved themselves- unworthy" has been applied. Herr Wolff is now, residing ,abroad.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operation of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income charges but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Joseph Paul Smith, baritone, will be heard in recital tonight at Town Hall. "How Not to Look at Dancing" is the subject of a lecture to be given tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by John Martin.

Thirty-four manufacturers of curtains and draperies have already applied for space in the second semi-annual national drapery exhibit to be held Jan. 10 to 14 at the Empire State Building, James H. Casey Jr., secretary of the National Drapery Associates, its sponsors, announced yesterday.
New running and passing plays for use against Georgetown this Saturday were. tested thoroughly during a brief scrimmage held by Manhattan at Innisfail Park yesterday.

Junior League plays were presented to about 300,000 children in 127 cities throughout the nation in the year ended Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday by- Miss Agnes Grant, secretary of the Children's Theatre Department,' in a report to the board of directors of the Association of Junior Leagues of America at a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Electric power production increased last week, but the daily average was lower and the index dropped to 103.6, the lowest since the week of Jan. 2. The previous week's figure was 104.4 and for the corresponding week last year it was 103.0.

IF anybody cared to listen, this is what they were saying in a large football huddle recently: "Alabama is certainly aiming for another go in the Rose Bowl. They're sitting pretty. Undefeated, only one touchdown scored against 'em in five games, and the only big game ahead of them is Vanderbilt."

Mrs. Lillian D. Kent obtained today her second divorce from J. M. Kent, founder and former president of the Richfield Oil Company, whom she divorced in 1933 when she won a property settlement reported as $250,000. After promising "to reform,"

The radio speech of Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for District Attorney of New York County, last night follows: Murder is my subject again to-night-the murder of Billy Snyder in Avenue A. It was the night of Sept. 13, 1934, in Garfein's Restaurant, at 10 Avenue A.

Robert C. Beal, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, who sold his seat in 1929 for $625,000, still the record price, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home, 55 East Eighty-sixth Street. Mr. Beal was a native of Danbury, Conn. His age was 67.

The Bureau of Mines reported today that sales of heating oils reached a new high of 99,257,000 barrels in 1936, a gain of 29 per cent over 1935. Sales of range oil amounted to 27,292,000 barrels in 1936, a gain of 27 per cent over the volume in 1935.
Four Moors were killed and nine other persons were wounded in a clash today between Moorish Nationalists and French policemen outside the mosque at Port Lyautey after afternoon prayer.
Extending the tradition that no horse ever wins the race twice, T. Westhead's Punch today captured the ninety-ninth Cesarewitch Stakes over two miles and a quarter of muddy going.

Secretary of State Hull, in a letter made public today, lashed out at opponents of the Administration's reciprocal trade program, cited figures in an attempt to show that the program was not injuring farmers, denounced the old Smoot-Hawley tariff and declared that the present liberal trade policy offered the only solid foundation for peace.

After conferring here yesterday with Mayor La Guardia and Postmaster Albert Goldman, John D. Biggers, administrator of the Federal voluntary unemployment census which is to begin Nov. 16, announced plans for an intensive campaign to acquaint the unemplayed of New York City with the nature and purpose of the census and the part they must take in it if it is to be successful.

The Ulric Holding Corporation, Estelle Greene, secretary, has bought from Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, a vacant plot 101 by 55 feet on the west side of the Grand Concourse, 107 feet south of 140th Street, the Bronx.

Miss Virginia Potter, member of a well-known New-York family, who devoted her life to improving the living standards of women in employment, died yesterday in the Faulkner Hospital, Jamaica Plains after a lingering illness. She was 80 years old.

Army scored an easy victory over Fordham in a dual cross-country run on the Mount Independence course today, placing five among the first six men to win by 19-36. Paoli of Fordham finished in second place behind Schellman, the Army leader, but the next Ram runner to break the tape trailed home behind the fifth Army man.

Under alternating lighting effects of sunset, moonlight, starlight and dawn, the new Crystal Garden of the Ritz Carlton was opened for the season last night with a gala party attended by many persons of prominence who were in various dinner and supper parties.

Followers of the progressivism of Theodore Roosevelt are "bitter" over the fact that so many people "have been fooled" into thinking that the policies of the New Deal are identical with those of the Bull Moose movement, according to Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., son of the late former President.

Six suggestions for amending the undistributed profits tax and resolutions urging that retail competition in credit accounts be discouraged, that a down payment on new accounts be required in every case and that the maximum time for payment be reduced to twenty-four months were endorsed by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at its meeting here yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Eichhold of 565 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Eichhold, to Clifford M. Ellinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Ellinger of this city and Nantucket, Mass.

Mme. Bidu Sayao, the young Brizilian lyric soprano who made a successful debut at the Metropolitan Opera House last season in "Manon," arrived yesterday from Rio de Janeiro on the steamship Eastern Prince of the Furness Prince Lines.

Counsel for the defendants in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case drew from a government witness today testimony that Charles Arnott, an official of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, was known as the "chief stabilizer" of the oil industry under its NRA code. Mr. Arnott,

Continuing its distinctive series, the Madrigal Singers presented a program last night at the Theatre of Music devoted to works of the Netherland master of the sixteenth century, Orlando di Lasso. Lehman Engel, conductor, provided a selection of chansons, madrigals, duets, motets for women's voices, and the mass, "In Die Tribulationis."

Vincent Lopez, Los Angeles, triumphed over Cliff Olson, Minneapolis, before a crowd of 4,000 at the Hippodrome last night after 20 minutes and 12 seconds, when the Minneapolis grappler hurt his shoulder in a dive through the ropes and was unable to continue.

Abbott Laboratories have called a special meeting of shareholders for next Thursday to authorize 50,000 shares of preferred stock and to sanction sale of a first series of 20,000 shares of 41/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, the remainder to be issuable in series.

Sanford Bates of New York City, former director of the Federal Bureau 'of Prisons, was nominated today for Moderator of the general conference of the American Unitarian Association. Accepting, he said: "We seek in company with all others of like mind to preserve and
The statement by the Federal Reserve Board on its action in reducing margin requirements on stock purchases and imposing a 50 per cent margin requirement on short sales, was as follows:

Queen Wilhelmina has assured the continuance of the dynasty's family name for at least one more generation by a decree today stipulating the Crown Princess Juliana's children shall bear the name of Prince or Princess of Orange-Nassau preceding their father's name and further titles such as Prince or Princess of the Netherlands.

A record of the position held by State and municipal candidates on educational questions has been obtrained by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations, and will be sent to the 37,500 New York City teachers this morning, Robert Comin, chairman, announced.

The Rev. Dr. George Sidney Webaster, for the last twenty-three years secretary of the American Seamen's Friend Society and for the previous twenty-four years pastor of the Church of the Covenant, 310 East Forty-second Street, died yesterday at his residence, 1,834 Caton Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 84.

The Cabinet this afternoon approved the reply to the Belgian Government rejecting its invitation to the Nine-Power Conference to be held at Brussels Nov. 3. The Foreign Office tonight issued a statement outlining its position with regard to the situation in China.
Warren St, 94, 24.11x62; Bowery Savings Bank to South Trading Corp, 92 Warren St. ($12). ?0th St, 237 W, 25x98.9; Myer 1. Kleinberg to Greenwich Savings Bank, consid., $30.-000 (foreclosure).

Adoption of a form designated as U-14-3 under the Public Utility Holding Company Act for the use of registered public utility holding companies in making annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission was announced today by the commission.
Lafayette College, one of the nation's few undefeated, untied and unscored upon football teams, has just been "lucky," Coach Edward Everett (Hooks) Mylin said today.

The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Behringer, rector of Grace Episcopal Church here for the last seven years and State chairman of the New Jersey department of the Spanish-American War Veterans, died last night at his home after a brief illness.

Sales of tenement houses in Harlem formed the bulk of the realty turnover in Manhattan yesterday. Some of the buildings will be altered by the new owners. The six-story apartment house at 11214 West 103d Street has been sold by the estate of Bernard May to John P. Flnneran.

Mr. and Mrs. G. Hermann Kinnicutt entertained with a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, later taking their guests to the performance of "Angel Island" for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau.

Julius Caesar worked Most harder than any common Active soldier. Thomas A. Edison Mailman kept longer hours than any of his employes. James A. Farley covers ever so many more miles than the average letter-carrier.

New York's new marriage law, giving a seventy-two-hour "breathing spell" between a wedding license and wedding bells, brought a "decided decrease" in September marriages, the State Health Department disclosed today.

Premier Milan Hodza took the occasion of the unveiling of a tablet honoring Professor R. W. Seton-Watson, British associate of the late ex-President Thomas G. Masaryk, at Rosenberg, Slovakia, today to make a firm pronouncement regarding Germany's efforts to establish a claim to interfere in Czechoslovakia's affairs on behalf of the German minority.

Peace negotiations looking toward healing the breach that has divided organized labor into two warring Camps for the last two years were deadlocked today when the American Federation of Labor committee handed to the spokesmen for the Committee for Industrial Organization a proposal that was immediately rejected.

Charges, counter-charges and replies marked- the appearance of rival political candidates in the municipal campaign yesterday on the dais at a luncheon meeting of the Real Estate Board in the Hotel Commodore.

Vigorous opposition developed today in Federal court to the plan of reorganization for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation proposed by Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, largest creditor of Utilities Power and Light.

Jewish settlers in the Valley of Jezreel, aided by 100 troops and police from Nazareth, fought desperately today to quell a fire believed started by incendiaries in the famous Balfour pine forest, covering hundreds of acres on the Nazareth hills.

William H. Jeffers, new president of the Union Pacific Railway, said today that freight rate increases were necessary to prevent bankruptcy of many railroads, a corplate breakdown of the rail transportation system and ultimate government operation. Be urged a "horizontal or blanket increase of at least 15 per cent."

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Houghton Cowles of Alameda Padre Serra, Santa Barbara, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Cowles, to Douglas Ewell Parshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. De Witt Parshall of Montecito.

What was announced as the first local all-Sibelius song recital was given last night at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall by the soprano, Carina Orasto, under the auspices of the Municipal Opera Association. The songs were set to texts of Rydberg, Froeding, Wecksell, Calamnius, Runeberg, Rehbaum. Susman and Dehmel.

The dollar volume of wholesale trade, based on reports from 1,300 wholesale establishments, showed an increase of about 7 per cent during September of this year over same month of 1936, Secretary Roper announced today. September sales,

The manufacture of confectionery for pets appears to be a growing industry. "Charge," a vitamin candy was recently introduced and now Kandi-Bone, Inc., 302 Broadway, is putting on the market Kandi-Bone, a vitamin confection, shaped like a bone.
The Japanese War Office today officially placed Japanese casualties in the war with China at 9,640 slain, as of Oct. 24. No figures for wounded were given..

H. G. Wells voiced the opinion here today. that the New Deal was "not triumphant at the present time," but he blamed "fate," not President Roosevelt, for the condition. Mr. Wells described the New Deal as "a magnificent attempt to reorganize economics" in this country and asserted that it had "failed in part" because of the rigidity of the

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission, after hearing testimony on long-distance rates of the Bell Telephone Company within Pennsylvania, ordered today an investigation into all the operations of the company. This,

Henry J. Sendericker, a retired patrolman of this city, died Tuesday at his home, 90-12 218th Place, Queens Village. He was born in Brooklyn fifty-four years ago and had resided in Queens for twentyone years. He retired two years ago, after more than twenty-five years of service.

General Anastasio Somoza, President of Nicaragua, announced today that James H. Edward, New York manager of the Nicaraguan National Bank and financial adviser to the Nicaraguan Government, would go to the United States to make certain financial arrangements.
Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday that 2,450 registration challenges have been received by his office and that warrants will be asked in all cases where fraud is indicated.

Operations of the steel industry have dropped so sharply in some districts that the present low rates would suggest that a bottom has been reached, The Iron Age says this week. Reporting a decline of ingot production to 51 per cent this week from 55 per cent last week the publication adds that the-industry is looking to additional orders from the automobile factories to prevent a further recession.
His valuable collection of American art and antiques and acres of park land were bequeathed for public enjoyment in the will of George Horace Lorimer, filed for probate today at Norristown.

The bane of every football coach's life is overconfidence, which is chiefly responsible for most of the so-called upsets that happen in a season. It is the most dreaded of all gridiron diseases, easily diagnosed, but one for which no sure-fire cure has yet been discovered.
Mayor La Guardia, "An Answer. to Mahoney," Advertising Club, WMCA, 1:15 to 1:45 P. M. Mrs. Abram I. Elkus, "The Women's Viewpoint of Why I Am for Mahoney," WINS (1,180 kc.), 1:15 to 1:30 P. M.

President Roosevelt gave his approval today to a plan whereby "yardstick" rates for the power soon to be produced from Bonneville Dam on the Washington-Oregon border will be established on a basis of amortization of the Federal Government's investment over a forty-year period plus 3 percent interest.

More than 200 members of the Advisory Committee on Women's Participation in the New York World's Fair obtained yesterday a first-hand view of the construction now going on at the site of the fair. Mrs. Vincent Astor, chairman of the committee, led the tourists.
Following is the text of the address of Governor Lehman: My plea to you tonight is direct and clear. I ask that you elect Democratic Assemblymen next Tuesday.

Entering the local municipal campaign and speaking in behalf of Mr. Mahoney, Postmaster General Farley says that there is one aspect of the situation which amuses him. He is amused, and at the same time somewhat resentful, that the La Guardia Administration should "seek to usurp credit for those accomplishments"

Repeating to detectives the same story of his love of "high living" that he had told on a previous arrest in 1932, Frederick Feltman, 54 years old, a bookkeeper, of 1,240 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, was held without bail in Felony Court yesterday by Magistrate McGee, following his appearance in the line-up.

Furnishings and objects of art from the apartment of Mrs. Charles Page Perin, 755 Park Avenue, were sold at auction yesterday under the management of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries,Inc., for a total of $21,020. A portrait of Miss Scott by Sir Thomas Lawrence went to an agent for $975. Mrs.

Ivon J. Bromwich, in 510 Bradley Blvd, Bradley Beach, N. J.; Lewis B. Travis, in 74 Magnolia Ave, Bergenfield; Raymond Williams, in 5-8 Bendermere Ave. Interlaken; Otto J. Edelmann, in 273 Sterling Rd, Englewood; Frank K. Baker, in 166 Moore Ave, Leonia; Paul B. Willson, in 353 Bogert Ave, Ridgewood; J. Arthur Springer, in 74 Floral Terrace, Tenafly; John Nurml, in 33 Floral Terrace, Tenafly; The New Jersey Realty Co, broker.

Mrs. Norah Palmer, a lifelong resident of Flushing and a member of the Gold Star Mothers of America, died at- her home, 136-61 Thirtyninth Avenue, Flushing, on Tuesday afternoon after an illness of ten days. She was 69 years old.

Rain turned the regular practice gridiron into a bog today and Coach Hardwick sought the firmer ground of an adjoining field before putting his Navy charges through their drill. Handling and falling on a slippery ball was included in the routine.

A call to all brewers throughout the country to close ranks for an intensive resistance to what speakers characterized as the new rising tide of prohibition sentiment was issued today in resolutions adopted by the diamond jubilee convention of the United States Brewers' Association in session here.

Setting as their goal the sale of 1,000,000 units in their first year, executives of the Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., yesterday introduced their new completely automatic home laundry to several hundred dealers at a showing at the Windsor Theatre.

" Compared with last year the work of each of our services has greatly increased," said General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross, at the thirtyfirst annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the chapter house, 815 Lexington Avenue.
Severe curtailment of already restricted communications between Nanking and Shanghai has resulted from the Japanese advance on the Shanghai fronts.

Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson, after listening- to arguments and testimony, today approved a settlement whereby ten banks in this city and New York and the General Electric Company will turn over $4,636,088 for the benefit of holders of debentures and notes, respectively, of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company, the two defunct Insull investment concerns.

One of the few major prep elevens having a perfect record thus far, Groton School, well stocked with experienced players, has just two more obstacles to hurdle this Fall, but Head Coach Larry Noble expects difficulty in both instances.

Bernie Bloom was pitching strikes again yesterday, and the apparent return to physical form of the greatest passer Dr. Mal Stevens has uncovered acted like a tonic on his New York University teammates in a swiftly paced workout on Ohio Field.

In an overtime soccer game which lasted until dusk, Brown and Yale Universities, New England Intercollegiate League leaders, played a scoreless draw today. Jackson, with well-placed shots, and Dearden, with effective goalprotecting, starred for the visitors.

The awarding of sixty-two insignia to Columbia men for participation in rowing last Spring was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletic manager. Twentyseven varsity "C's" were awarded, with crossed oars added to the letters of the varsity crew which rowed in the Poughkeepsie regatta.

Tribute was paid last night to the "wholesome and sane" religion of Dwight L. Moody, the vangelist, by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, at a "Moody mass meeting" held in Carnegie Hall "to immortalize the life and work of America's greatest evangelist."

One of the worst of Mr. Mahoney's series of blunders is his attack on the police and the Commissioner of Police, and his slander of this town, "the greatest and normally the most lawabiding city in the world," but in his distorted picture become the scene of riot, mass disorder and so on.

Four ballets were seen for the first time this season in the performance of the De Basil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. These were Leonide Massine's "Jeux d'Enfants" and "The Three-Cornered Hat," "L'Apres-midi d'un Faune," after Vaslay Nijinsky; and Michel Fokine's restaging of his own Poloytsien dances from "Prince Igor."

Two officers of the Netherlands army team that will compete in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, starting next Wednesday, arrived yesterday aboard the Holland-America liner Edam.

The Court of Appeals concurred last night in the action of the Appellate Division earlier in the day in restoring the Socialist and Progressive party nominations to Isidore Nagler, candidate for Borough President of the Bronx, and to his running-mates for District Attorney, Sheriff and Register.

A letter from President Roosevelt felicitating the residents of Flushing, Queens, on the community's 100th anniversary as a chartered village was made public yesterday by John J. Halleran, Commissioner of Public Works and chairman of the Centennial Celebration Committee.

Alvah A. Hart, 34 years old, former assistant secretary of the Princeton Bank and Trust Company; and director of Hart's Band, pleaded guilty to three charges of embezzling $13,000 this afternoon before Recorder Kenneth Stevens in Borough Court. Hart,

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Oct. 16 totaled 307,897,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the figures of the previous week, this total represents a net decline of 1,112,000 barrels,

The Dollar Steamship Line will maintain its passenger services without interruption while carrying out a program of modernization ordered by the Federal Maritime Commission, it was announced yesterday by Hugh Mackenzie, vice president in charge of passenger traffic.
Miss Sarah Wayne Ashhurst, retired head of a Cuba mission school and member of a prominent Philadelphia family, died at her home in Montrose, Susquehanna County, today in her sixty-fifth year.

Many men and women, some-obviously shopping and others just looking, swarmed into the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock when the General Motors show for 1938 opened.

The Citizens Budget Commission submitted a revised list of recommendations for budget reductions yesterday to Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, calling for a $9,365,895 saving in miscellaneous items; $10,536,649 in pay cuts and elimination of useless positions, and $3,555,164 through reorganization of pension systems and the county offices.

The nation's largest celebration of Navy Day since its inception sixteen years ago was staged yesterday and last night as bands played "Anchors Aweigh" over radio networks and some of the country's highest officials joined in stressing the importance of sea power.
Animal experiments which indicate that the body's "white blood stream," AT T known as the lymphatic system, plays a highly important role in Dr. F the protection of the organism Surgeons;
Marriage statistics for the first nine months of 1937, reported today by David S. South, State Registrar, showed there was a total of 26,352 during the perinod. an inrease of 2.479,

MANY MANSIONS, a play in two acts and fifteen scenes, by Jules Eckert Goodman and his son, Eckert Goodman, with an incidental score by Milton Lusk. Scenery by John Koenig; lighting by Stanley R. McCandless; produced by Many Mansions, Inc. (John F. Wharton, Manuel Gorman and Gertrude Tarle).
Mr. and Mrs. William H. Tew of 157 East Eighty-first Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Tew, to Prince Georges Dadiani of Paris.

Abandoning his plan for a "name" actress as his leading lady, Harold Lloyd today selected Phyllis Welch, a screen unknown but one with a record on Broadway, for "Professor Beware," which he will start next month for Paramount. Miss Welch was brought to the coast by Metro following appearances with Ernest Truex in "Prodigal Father" and in "High Tor."

Appointments to the executive council and to the chairmanship of various commissions and committees of the American Bankers Association were announced here yesterday by Orval W. Adams, newly elected president of the association. Four New York bankers were among those appointed.

Stockholders of the Draper Corporation, manufacturer of textile weaving machinery, have been called to vote on Nov. 16 on a proposal to cancel shares now held in the treasury and to pay a 25 per cent stock dividend on the outstanding shares.

President Roosevelt accepted "with the greatest reluctance" today the resignation of Miss Josephine Roche as Assistant Secretary of the' Treasury in charge of Public Health Department personnel and welfare, a position which she has held since Nov. 15, 1934.

Mr. and Mrs. J. George Newhall of the Mill Run, Phoenixville, have announced the engagement of Mr. Newhall's daughter, Miss Sybil K. Newhall, to Charles L. P. Townsend of Altamont, N. Y. Miss Newhall was graduated from Dobbs Ferry and studied art at Gloucester, Mass. She made her debut in 1934.

The first in a series of four illustrated lectures under the auspices of the music committee of the New York Junior League was given yesterday by Olin Downes at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventyfirst Street.

Colonel Celestino Baizan, Governor of Havana Province, was lodged in jail at Principe Fortress at 9 o'clock this morning in connection with the killing of Severiano Pulido, Acting President of the Provincial Council. Sefior Pulido was shot during a Council meeting last Thursday.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will open its season's second week at tonight's concert in Carnegie Hall. The event will begin the Thursday evening series. John Barbirolli will conduct the Weber Overture to "Euryanthe," the Brahms First symphony, and the first local performance of Bartok's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta.

The trend in recent months of increasing exports and decreasing imports continued during September, Secretary Roper of the Department of Commerce said in a statement today, with the result that exports in September were $19,000,000 greater than in August of this year, and $76,000,000 more than in September of 1936.

Michael J. Healy, Supreme Director of the Knights of Columbus, died here today in the Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 46. Mr. Healy, an attorney for the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington, D. C., became ill in Chicago two weeks ago while on his way to a Knights of Columbus meeting in Dubuque, Iowa.

Emphasizing the need for more diversified courses to meet the requirements of both bright and slow students, Dr. Stephen F. Bayne, associate superintendent of schools, gave sixteen recommendations yesterday in a report designed to improve high schools.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-she, China's supreme military and civil authority, declared today that it was the "responsibility" of the United States and Great Britain to uphold the Nine-Power Treaty. The Generalissimo said that "Japan must be stopped in her mad aggression and imperialismbefore it is too late."

" Tammany Hall couldn't be honest even if it tried," Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel for the Commissioner of Accounts, declared last evening in a speech over radio station WHN. Recalling the disclosurem of the Seabury investigation, in which he had an important part, Mr. Cooper said of Tammany:

Dr. Robert E. Speer, retired senior secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, welcomed leaders from the foreign field at a luncheon held yesterday as part of the centennial celebration of the establishment of this branch of missionary work.

The Estonian Government, in a sharp diplomatic note to the Finnish Government, draws attention today to alleged anti-Estonian manifestations here at the funeral of the exiled Estonian Fascist leader, Artur Sirk.
With the largest attendance in the history of the organization, the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers opened at the Homestead today.

Plans for a good-will tour of Latin-American ports by a group of American business men and commercial organization representatives were announced here yesterday by Max Tucker and Morris Alprin of Foreign Trade and Exposition Tours, Inc. The voyage,
John F. Kraemer of New York, captain of Princeton's 150-pound crew, today annexed the university's lightweight sculling crown for the second consecutive year, negotiating a mile course in 6:51.8.
The State Department of Labor reported today the settlement during September of sixty-seven strikes involving 37,242 workers in New York State industries.

Charles Henry Meigs, a fire prevention expert, who was formerly president of the Foamite Firefoam Company, died early yesterday morning in the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital after a two-day illness of oedema of the larynx. He was 70 years old.

In the Review Section of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 24 it was said that Senator Robert F.-Wagner, who had endorsed Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor, had not "extended his endorsement to Harold W. Hastings, Democratic opponent of Thomas E. Dewey for Distridt Attorney." This was an error,

The City Planning Commission to be created under the new City Charter will be the means of "pushing measurably forward in orderly fashion" sectional and city-wide improvements which in the past have been carried out in rather haphazard fashion, George McAneny, head of the Regional Plan Association, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of architects, engineers and planning experts held in the Architectural League.
Still harassed by injuries, the Pennsylvania varsity squad showed improved form in a two-hour offensive tune-up today for the .annual clash with the Navy here Saturday.

The theft of a jeweled gold snuffbox, reputedly a gift of the late Shah Nasr-ed-Deen of Persia to Marie, Czarina of Russia and mother of the last Czar, was reported yesterday by Dr. Armand Hammer of the Hammer Galleries, on Fifth Avenue just south of Fifty-fourth Street.

Dr. Halvdan Koht, the Foreign Minister of Norway, ended his official discussions with Secretary Hull today and returned to New York, having found that they were in general agreement on broad commercial and peace principles.
Plans for a public school to cost $382,000 and numerous small dwellings in scattered sections of the borough comprised new construction submitted yesterday to the Bureau of Buildings in Queens.

Warning that the taxation of capital is "just reaching the point where it is but a few steps ahead of confiscation," William S. Knudsen, president of the General Motors Corporation, expressed hope in the text of an address prepared for delivery here tonight that this "class movement" could be checked "before it becomes so strong that nothing can stop it."

No modification of its peace proposal will be made by the C. I. O. committee when it resumes conferences with the committee of the American Federation of Labor next Thursday, it was announced today by Lee Pressman, general counsel of the C. I. O.
A total of $270,190 will be spent on medical and public health work in Palestine by Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, during the coming year.
William Martin Proctor, Professor of Education at Stanford University, and an authority on vocational guidance, died here today after an illness of several weeks. He was 62 years old.

Mrs. Harold C. Richard gave a tea yesterday at her home, 1,060 Fifth Avenue, for members of the debutante committee aiding in the plans for a performance of Ed Wynn's new show, "Hooray For What," for the benefit of the Music School Settlement.

Trading was slow in most classes of nonkosher meats yesterday. Salesmen were asking higher prices on lamb while other cuts were steady to lower. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at higher prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Price reductions averaging 20 per cent went into effect yesterday on wholesale prices of "Old Overholt" and "Mount Vernon" bottled-inbond rye whiskies of the National Distillers Products Corporation. The price cuts will not be reflected at retail for ten days because of existing fair trade price contracts.

Closed meetings on questions involving media and space-buying methods occupied delegates attending the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Association of National Advertisers at the Homestead Hotel here today!
Samuel Bienstockof 43-33 Fortysixth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, a retired druggist, died Wednesday. He was 64 years old. Born in Russia, he came to the United States forty-four years ago.

Charles and Mary Beard are working on a one-volume history of the last ten years in the United States. It will be published by Macmillan. "The Rise of American Civilization," by the same authors, first issued in 1927, has gone through three successive revised editions and is now in a fifteenth printing.
Flood waters of the Gallego and Ebro Rivers today halted military operations in Northeastern Spain, where the Insurgent armies are attempting to end the civil war by cutting Valencia from Barcelona.

THE incomparable Mr. Wodehouse has one story he likes above all to tells Through many masterpieces designed to make this a better world to laugh in he has told it over and over and over again. It is none other than the story of boy meets girl. He usually tells it in the course of a narrative filled with the most engaging inanities this side of Charlie Chaplin.

A wreath bearing the name of a Bronx branch of the Jewish War Veterans Association is resting on- the memorial to Germany's war dead on Unter den Linden tonight and military afthorities do not know what to do about it.
The National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace swung through its second session yesterday, called International Day, with large and interested crowds despite the gloomy skies.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee, an drawn for redemption through the sinking fund on Dec. 1, at 102 1/2, a, total of $837,000 of National Steel Corporation first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due on June 1, 1965.

The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 net earnings of $6,572,666 after deducting regular reserves, depreciation and estimated Federal normal tax, but before surtax on undistributed profits.

Ellis S. Duvall of Riverhead was elected president of the Suffolk County Bankers Association at the annual dinner meeting held this afternoon and tonight at Canoe Place Inn. Harry L. Brown of Smithtown was re-elected secretary-treasurer. Other new officers are:
Harry H. Cook of Toledo, Ohio, a labor leader, told the Committee on Reciprocity Information today that "cheap foreign competition" was responsible for serious unemployment in the glassware industry.

Coordination of high school and college examining agencies to bring about a common program of research and study in the field of predictive tests was recommended last uight by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, at the dinner meeting of the sixth joint educational conference.

Predictions of wide extension of Diesel power in railroad and truck operation, because of economy and efficiency, were made yesterday before 300 leaders in finance and industry at a luncheon given by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of General Motors Corporation, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

W. Jett Lauck, chairman of the Pennsylvania. Anthracite Commission, challenged J. P. Morgan Co. and its financial affiliates today. to cooperate in an anthracite rehabilitation program which would avoid the need for State or Federal regulatory legislation.

A telephone company executive from Washington, John A. Remon, became the ninth president of the American Power Boat Association at yesterday's annual election and convention of delegates at the Hotel Lexington. He succeeds George W.

Mrs. William R. Philler of Haverford will give a luncheon on Saturday and a tea on Sunday for her house guest Mrs. John Lowell of Boston. A dinner dance will be given by Mr. and Mrs. Philler on Dec. 28 before the Benedicks Ball for their debutante granddaughter, Miss Elizabeth Chapman Philler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Winsor Philler of Wynnewood.

Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, High Commissioner for Palestine, who has been under increasingly heavy fire for his lenient policy toward the Arabs, will retire in the early part of next year, William G. A. Ormsby-Gore, Colonial Secretary, announced in the House of Commons today.

The program given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall showed Mr. Barbirolli as a progressive-minded conductor, who feels that an audience must be kept abreast of developments in contemporaneous music.

Veterans who have been around New York tracks for years pronounced the finish in the third race at Empire City yesterday the closest they had ever seen. Six horses came to the wire within a length of each other.

For the first time official representatives of the governments of three South American countries, Chile, Bolivia and Peru, will meet at the Port of Arica tomorrow with representatives of the national commercial airlines operating in their respective territories, in order to reach an agreement for the coordination of the different services.
Three grandsons and fourteen sons of former Manlius School students or faculty members are now cadets at the school. The grandsons are:

Hamlin Garland said today he was "disgusted-at the kind of stuff being written and published now." "Progress doesn't consist in a return to the morals of the barnyard," he said in an address before the California Writers Guild.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Allabough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Allabough of this place, to Harold Stanley Ford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Ford, also of Ridgewood.
Basque children are to be returned to Spain- as promptly as possible following the report of the Legal Commission headed by Sir Holman Gregory, former Recorder of London, which was issued tonight.

Reflecting both the possibility of a large carryover of current fur stocks and the price decline in recent months, the first quotations made to trappers for the new catch of domestic furs made their appearance yesterday and show reductions ranging up to 25 per cent or more under this time last year, and up to 35 per cent or more under the Dec. 1, 1936, levels, when the advance was under way.
The consolidation of the Rainier Pulp and Paper Company, Grays Harbor Pulp and Paper Company and the Olympic Forest Products Company into a new organization to be known as Rayonier, Inc.,
The Treasury was not consulted on the change of margin requirements ordered yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board, Secretary Morgenthan said today at his press conference.

Harold W. Hastings, Tammany candidate for District Attorney, attacked Thomas E. Dewey, his Fusion opponent, in seven speeches yesterday. Speaking at a luncheon at the Hotel Victoria, Mr. Hastings announced that, -"win or lose," he plans to subpoena one of Mr. Dewey's assistants immediately after election to expose the falsehood of a report, published several months ago, of a bribe offer supposed to have been made to this aide of the racket prosecutor.

Changing from the role of the invaded to that of the invrader for the first time since 1934, Fordham moved toward the South last night, confident that the journey will bring the Rams nothing less than victory.

A fifteen-game basketball schedule for Rutgers University, opening against the University of Delaware Dec. 4, was announced today by George E. Little, director of athletics. Featuring the schedule are home-and-home games with Princeton, Lehigh and Lafayette, the last-named Middle Three rivals of the Scarlet, and a game at New York with N. Y. U., the only team to defeat Rutgers in its regular fourteen-game schedule last year.

Mrs. Mary Bowles King, daughter of Samuel Bowles, who won fame in a long career as editor of The Springfield (Mass.). Republican that began before the Civil War, died today in her home at Winnetka, a suburb of Chicago, where she had resided for fifty-four years. Her age was 83.

The American' Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers is resisting efforts of radio interests to curtail its activities in various States, Gene Buck, president of the society, told 400 members who attended the society's semi-annual meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday afternoon.
Tony Lazzeri turned his back on a dozen sparkling years with the Yankees today to. start a new career in the National League with the Cubs.

State banks are subject to the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law, according to an opinion by John J. Bennett Jr., Attorney General, denying the claim that State banks which are. members of the Federal Reserve System are instrumentalities of the United States and therefore not subject to the law.
J. W. Alger, special master in the reorganization proceedings of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, adjourned yesterday hearings on the proposed plan of reorganization until Nov. 15.

Wheat fluctuated erratically today within a range of around 2 1/2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here, advancing as much as 1 1/4, cents at the opening on buying induced by unexpected strength in Liverpool and in sympathy with securities, ...

Judicious observance of the tenets of taste and a deference to vocal limitations marked the singing of the American baritone, Joseph Paul Smith,-whose first local, appearance took place last night at the Town Hall.

Colonel John K. Brown of the United States Cavalry was re-elected president of the Metropolitan Equestrian Club of New York at its annual meeting and dinner last night at the Hotel Commodore. More than fifty members attended.

Mrs. Livia Nye Simpson Poffenbarger, author, lawyer, editor and politician, died yesterday. She was 75 years old. Born at Pomeroy, Ohio, on March 1, 1862, Mrs. Poffenbarger studied at West Virginia University. She was owner and manager of The Point Pleasant (W. Va.) State Gazette from 1888 to 1913, a member of the Governors' Congress at Washington in 1908 and served on several national Republican women's -committees.

Dr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Sanford gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of the museum's ten-year development plan: Among those present were Dr. and Mrs. Frank M. Chapman, Mrs. Lucius Robinson, Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred J. Worcester, Dr. and Mrs. -Adrian Lambert, Mr. and Mrs. J. Gamble Rogers and Mr. and Mrs. Dean Sage.

William Wyer, secretary and treasurer of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, in a statement today before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce branded as "misrepresentation, distortion and libel" parts of the statement made yesterday by Senator Harry H. Truman of Missouri, acting chairman of the committee, .in which he charged that Mr. Wyer had been involved in questionable transactions and deceptive practices.

The estimated net earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Oct. 2 were $5,276,000 after all charges, depreciation and Federal taxes, except. undistributed profits taxes, according to a statement issued yesterday.
Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin, nephew of the famous inventor of the same name, died today at the age of 62. They were closely associated in developing airship construction.

The Federal Trade Commission today issued a complaint against Good Humor Corporation of America, Maspeth, L. I.; Popsicle Corporation of the United States, New York City, and-their exclusive licensing agent, Joe Lowe Corporation,

New Deal Democratic control of the coming Constitutional Convention would mean the adoption of the policies involving the "same contempt for American institutions and the same disregard for our courts" which have characterized New Deal policies at Washington, according to George R. Fearon, former Republican leader of the Senate, who spoke at a rally here tonight.

Miss Frances McKee Ives, daughter of Mrs. Marguerite Ives of Forest Hills, Queens, and of the late Will H. Dilg of Chicago, was married yesterday afternoon to Merritt Judson Dannatt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Merritt J. Dannatt. also of Forest Hills, in the chapel of the Church of the Transfiguration.
Usually well-informed persons reported tonight that tentative plans for financing a new corn loan program had been drafted and would be submitted tomorrow to President Roosevelt.
Major Gen. Sir F. W. B. Landon, chief inspector of Quartermaster General's services in the World War, died yesterday at the age of 77. He retired in 1919.
Permission to the French Government to continue the International Exhibition next year, if it so decides, was granted today by a majority of the Bureau of International Expositions.

The awards for engineering construction in the United States for the week ended yesterday rose 40 per cent over the corresponding week of 1936, according to The Engineering News-Record. This year's figure was $62,866,000; last year's was $44,849,000.

Columbia's football squad received the finishing touches in offensive and defensive instructions at Baker Field yesterday in preparation for the clash with Cornell at Ithaca tomorrow. A fifteenhour rain, which ceased just before the Lions emerged from the locker room, made a quagmire of the practice field.

Count Emanuele Castelbarco of Venice and his wife, who is a daughter of Arturo Toscanini, arrived here yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. The Count, a portrait painter, brought several canvases which will be exhibited next month at the Marie Sterner Galleries, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street. Most of his subjects are European notables.

Monroe Percy Bloch, counsel for the Honest Ballot Association, announced yesterday that the association had offered the services of its volunteer watchers t those parties interested in an honest election.

Professor Albert von Szent-Gyorgyi, Hungarian medical research worker of Szeged University, Hungary, was announced today as the winner of the 1937 Nobel Prize for Physiology and Medicine valued at about ??8,000.

The National Labor Relations Board directed the Stylecraft Leather Goods Company, Inc., of Scranton, today to offer to reinstate with back pay Benjamin Marsala, a pocket-book framer, on the ground that he was discharged because of union activity.
Investors in the Irish Sweepstakes, if investors is the word, get back approximately 60 per cent of their money.

The proportion of the bank's reserve to public and private deposits was 28.6 per cent. Last week the ratio war 28.1 per cent, against 24.6 two weeks ago. The highest ratio this year to date was 42 per cent, on Jan. 21, and the ratio on Aug. 5, 16.6, was the lowest. The highest for 1936 was 43.40, on Oct. 22, and the lowest 23.10, on Dee. 31. The low record was 7.25

It was revealed this morning that Mme. Chiang Kai-shek has been lying in her Shanghai home for a week suffering from a fractured rib and shock resulting from the overturning of her automobile as she was on her way to Shanghai, accompanied by W. H. Donald, her husband's Australian adviser, and a military officer.
Mussolini pledged full support for Germany's colonial claims in a speech at Rome yesterday commemorating the fifteenth anniversary of the Fascist march on that city.

In a gala atmosphere, marked by exaltation at recent membership gains rather than by melancholy at deserting the old home, members of the Women's University Club from "everywhere east of Chicago" last night bade farewell to the edifice at 106 East Fifty-second Street, which will shortly be evacuated.

Coroner Paul V. Marceau said today that investigation by his office "seems to show" that a woman, not yet definitely identified, whose body was found `n the St. Charles River, was Mrs. Virginia H. Toler of New York.

Daily average retail sales in small and rural areas during September were 13 per cent higher in Eastern sections, as compared with the same month of last year, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today.

Protesting New York University's dismissal of a Negro porter because of "union activity," the Washington Square College Bulletin, official undergraduate newspaper, editorially charged the university yesterday with "an anti-union bias."

There are now coming into view the problems in German administration opened up by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's retirement from the Ministry of Economics and his foreshadowed relinquishment of the Reichsbank presidency when his term expires next Spring.

William F. Decker, retired member of Decker Brothers, piano manufacturers, of New York, and a prominent resident of Greenwich, Conn., died yesterday in a hospital in Bethlehem, Pa. He was in his seventies.

Those who hold that short selling in the stock markets is ordinary gambling will be disconcerted to learn that the New York Stock Exchange Survey, published today, reveals that 38 per cent of all such sales represents hedging and selling "against the box," both simple business precautions.

Mrs. George Merck entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Mrs. Cyril F. Damon of Honolulu, the former Miss Muriel Colgate of New York. Other guests were Mrs. Elliott Debevoise, Mrs. George W. Perkins, Mrs. Herbert Jagels and Miss Mary Battin.
Arthur J. Kreutzer, Republican Supervisor of Huntington Township, was exonerated today by the October Suffolk County grand jury of the charge of violating Section 1868 of the Penal Law.

The caution with which the British Government is conducting the trade treaty negotiations with Washington was illustrated anew today when Rupert De La Eere, Conservative member, asked in the House of Commons if Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, in view of the "present favorable conditions," would take steps to establish an Anglo-American "economic partnership."

Dr. Frank J. Tone, president of the Carborundum Company at Niagara Falls and father of the motion-picture actor, Franchot Tone, has won the 1938 William H. Perkin Medal of the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry for "valuable work in applied chemistry, including the development of abrasives and refractories," it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When a family falls upon hard times the head thereof usually assembles its members and tells them in effect that times are not as good as we would like them to be.

The New York Philharmonic Orchestra, under the direction of John Barbirolli, will open Princeton University's 1937-38 concert series in McCarter Theatre here Saturday evening, Mrs. William F. Magie, chairman of the concerts committee, announced today.

The daily food price radio broadcasts by the Department of Markets through which thrifty housewives saved millions of dollars in the last four years is facing elimination as the result of action taken last Friday by the Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate, it became known yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia pledged a continuation of his drive against unnecessary noise yesterday when he made public figures showing an increase in the number of anti-noise summonses served in the first seven months of this year.
Contract awards were made at the Army Quartermaster Depot today on three items under invitation 65. The other three items were awarded some days ago. George Wood Sons Co.
The National Safety Council reported today that 28,140 persons died in traffic accidents during the first nine months of 1937, a 9 per cent increase over the same period last year.

During the week ended Oct. 27 member bank reserve balances increased $12,000,000.
