Additions to member bank reserves arose from a decrease of $27,000,000 in money in circulation and increases of $5,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by increases of $3,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold,

The marriage of Miss Elinor Gunn of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Newton Gunn, to James W. O'Connor, also of New York, will take place here tomorrow in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

Officials of sixteen Westchester cities and villages participated here today in laying the cornerstone of a two-story building being built by Arnold Constable Co. The structure is at Main Street and North Avenue and on completion in a few weeks wil house the only Suburban store of the concern.
Oliver Halsey Rogers, president for the last ten years of the Babylon National Bank and Trust Company, married today Miss Ethel Foster of Kew Gardens.

A report that Germany is building 100-ton tanks, with 60 mm. armor almostt 2 1/2 inches)-which would probably be the largest "land battleships" ever constructed-is published in the current issue of The Field Artillery Journal.

Edward McGrady, former Assistant Secretary of Labor, asked yesterday for an invitation to sit on the speakers' platform at the rally to be held tonight at the Hippodrome for the American Federation of Labor Nonpartisan Committee for the Re-election of Mayor La Guardia.

With a flood running on two of the principal business streets and all theatres closed, Cumberland suffered a scare today as it recalled last year's St. Patrick's Day flood when a loss of $3,000,000 was caused here.

With one story announced and others contemplated, Warners today entered the race to be the first to the screen with a film based' upon poison deaths. "The Clarion," a novel of newspaper life in a small American city by Samuel Hopkins Adams, has been purchased and will be adapted to center on the fight of an editor in behalf of food and drug laws.
Word has been received here of the death yesterday in the Navy Hospital in Baltimore of Captain William Bertrand, naval officer during the World War and skipper and pilot of commercial Vessels.

WITH a featherweight championship fight coming up, every follower of the fancy seems to be talking about Hurry-Up Henry Armstrong, the coffee-colored clouter from East St. Louis. They say that Hurry-Up Henry, pound for pound, is the best fighter in the world.

The general excellence of the Fusion Administration which has governed this city for the last four years derives a handsome tribute from the fact that in the closing days of a long and bitter campaign Mr. Mahoney can find nothing more important to talk about than Mr. La Guardia as the spearhead of communism.
The future course of the Spanish Non-Intervention Committee, and perhaps Russia's future role in European diplomacy, depended tonight upon the will of one dictator, far away in the Kremlin in Moscow.
As commodity markets continued to decline, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices dropped 1 1/2 points to 89.9 in the week ended on Tuesday. A year before the index stood at 84.7.

Declines of $150,000,000 in brokers' loans and $38,000,000 in business loans were reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their condition statement issued yesterday.

Leon Cherson bought for investment from the Orpheum Realty Company the two three-story apartment houses at 523-5 Newark Avenue, corner of Chestnut Avenue, Jersey City. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

The second day of the exhibition of new 1938 Ford, Lincoln and Lincoln-Zephyr cars at the Ford showrooms at 1,710 Broadway closed at midnight last night after handling more visitors than on Wednesday, when the show opened, according to company officials.

Convinced that the market for small homes throughout the country could be considerably broadened if financing terms were made easier, some builders are organizing a movement to make 10 per cent the customary down payment on dwellings.

Lawrence Marks, 49-year-old exconvict, on trial in County Court, Brooklyn, for the murder of 8-yearold Paula Magagna, took the witness stand yesterday and swore that he was innocent of the crime, that he never had seen the slain child and that he had been beaten by the police into making an alleged confession.

Plans for active participation of local store and consumer groups in the informative advertising and labeling program of the ConsumerRetailer Relations Council were advanced yesterday at a meeting of the council in the Town Hall Club.
Terming the Roosevelt Administration a "preview to chaos," Senator Vandenberg, in an address today, urged the country to follow. the "common-sense highway of the middle ground."
A high Japanese source disclosed to The Associated Press today what were said to be the minimum conditions on which Japan was willing to negotiate peace in China.
Additional contributions totaling $15,411 were announced yesterday at a report luncheon in connection with the $200,000 campaign of the Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York.

Mrs. Mary A. Haggerty, Democratic co-leader of the Twelfth Assembly District, North, and deputy clerk of the Fourth District Municipal Court, died yesterday at the Post Graduate Hospital. Mrs. Haggerty, who suffered a stroke on Oct. 13, was 70 years old and lived at 321 East Forty-third Street.

Tax cuts and a revision of industrial relations policies because of mounting costs to consumers are being studied by the Administration with the aim of freeing business from restraints so it may assume a greater share of the burden of recovery. [Page 1.]

The United States Treasury notified depositary banks in this Federal Reserve District yesterday that it had called for the repayment on Monday of $16,078,300 or 10 per cent of the amounts remaining on deposit for the account of subscriptions to the 1% per cent and 1% per cent notes, dated June 15.

Playing in a continuous downpour of rain, the Colgate University freshman eleven today maintained its two-year undefeated streak at the expense of a previously unbeaten Manlius Academy team, the final score of the muddy battle being 13 to 6.

Statistics showing that professions are overcrowded and salary averages are disappointing should be "no obstacle to men and women who have confidence in their ability to develop some distinguishing qualification that will lift them above the rank and file of their competitors,"

Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting of 15 East Eighty-eighth Street and Wheatley Hills, L. I., have announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Mary Josephine Cutting, to Alexander B. McFadden, son of Mrs. Bernon S. Prentice of this city and of the late George McFadden.

Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, the joint president of the League of Nations, will be guest at the White House over the week-end of Nov. 13, it was announced here today. Lord Cecil is one of Britain's elder statesmen and has long been an ardent advocate of the League of Nations. In announcing that Lord Cecil would stay with the President,

What is called the "world's smallest operatic organization," the London Intimate Opera Company, composed of three performing members, will be presented here for the first time early in December, it was announced yesterday.
Captain George E. T. Eyston sent his big automobile "Thunderbolt" over the salt flats today at 309.6 miles an hour, the fastest man ever traveled on land.

The American Smelting and Refining Company reduced yesterday the price of copper in the domestic market from 12 cents a pound to 11 3/4 cents. Producers, however, made no change from the twelvecent level. As a result, there are again two prides for domestic copper.

Ralph Greenleaf of New York to night regained the high-run record in the current world pocket billiard championship after George Kelly and Willie Mosconi, both of Philadelphia, had held the honor for a few hours each.

Miss Ruth Gwendolyn Hatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Butler Hatrick of this place, was married this evening to Gregory C. Draddy, son of Mrs. William Draddy, in the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church, by the Rev. Robert Russell, the pastor.

Wholesale commodity prices declined fractionally in the week ended on Oct. 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The decline was owing to weakening prices for foods and hides and leather products.

None of the important items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday received word that a shipment of $6,600,000 gold was on the- way here from Japan. This will be the fourth consignment of-about this amount to be reported since last Saturday and will bring the total of gold sent here by Japan since the middle of last March to $197,400,000.

A wet, slippery field today slowed up Holy Cross in its drive for the Temple battle. Coach Anderson confined the practice to an hour's signal drill. Captain Bob Mautner and Ronny Cahill were excused entirely from work.

In an atmosphere of informality, Professor Steve Owen and Assistant Professor Bo Molenda lectured to the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday on the strength and shortcomings (if any) of the Chicago Bears. A blackboard completed the classroom illusion. But there it ended.

Five hundred striking lumbermen who have been cutting pulpwood for export to England demanded an increase of 50 cents a cord yesterday, boarded a steamer loading the wood for Bowater Lloyd of England, and threatened to wreck. the ship and. do violence to officials.

Representatives of Puerto Rican sugar cane growers asked the Department of Agriculture today to allocate the island's 1938 sugar quota, determine the normal carryover inventory of sugar and settle the rates of payments by sugar mills to growers.

Over the objection of a Boston delegate, the general conference of the American Unitarian Association today approved a resolution deploring "outbreaks of terrorism and vigilantism in certain areas of the United States."

Reports of minor violence in scattered up-State' counties brought today from Archie Wright, organizer of the Dairy Farmers Union, an admonition to all milk farmers on strike to "stop unnecessary violence."
State Senator Lester H. Clee, Republican Gubernatorial candidate, charged

Despite a slight drop in this city, bank clearings for twenty-two leading cities of the United States for the week ended on Wednesday were S5,846,201,000, compared with $5,782,673,000 for the corresponding week last year, an increase of 1.1 per cent, according to a- tabulation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

At least partial fulfillment of manufacturers' predictions that 1938 would be an excellent year for the automotive industry was manifested yesterday at the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, where the General Motors Show for 1938 wound up the second day of its week's showing of new models.

The Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association concluded a singularly successful season with a one-day tournament today over the south course of the Westchester Country Club, with Mrs. F. J. Holleran of Greenwich and Mrs. George E. Learnard of Innis Arden tied for low gross honors with scores of 42, 43-85 and 41, 44-85 respectively.

The Rangers defeated the Americans, 3-1, tonight in the fourth game of the prairie exhibition hockey series between New York's two National League teams. The Rangers have won two, the Americans one and one contest was tied.

The unique plan of the Associated Railways Company for the dismemberment of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, a 1,300-mile railroad which has been in receivership since 1923, was disapproved today in a report to the Interstate Commerce Commission by C. E. Boles, assistant director of the commission's. Bureau of Finance.
George C. Miller, retired business man and former member of the city Board of Education, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 39-12 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, Queeps. He was 72 years old.
Creation of the new post of supervisor of private brands for the Gimbel organization was announced here yesterday by Ellis A. Gimbel, executive head of Gimbel Brothers, New York.

In a statement published in THE TIMES today six eminent lawyers who have served as president of the Bar Association of this city unite in urging the importance of defeating the candidacy of Justice Aaron J. Levy for re-election to the State Supreme Court.

The engagement of Miss Marion Jeffrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jeffrey of this city, to Wilbur T. Woodland of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Woodland of Watertown, Mass., has been announced by her parents.

Gross premiums of the Maryland Casualty Company for the first nine months of 1937 totaled $22,826,000, an increase of $1,340,000 over the corresponding period of 1936, Silliman Evans, chairman of the board, announced yesterday at the quarterly meeting of the directors.

Death Announced Retired Lieutenant Thomas P. Gibney. formerly a member of Engine 62, residing at Milton, N. Y., died Oct. 18. Band Orders The members of the Department band shall be directed to report to Captain Julius A. Unrath at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, at 9 A. M. Saturday, Oct. 30, in full band uniform.
Many parties were given at the Halloween tea dance and fashion show yesterday at Sherry's for the benefit of the free clinic for animals-of the Humane Society,of New York.

A great flood- rushed down from the hills northeast of Damascus today and swept through the town of Dmeir, where almost all the houses were washed away. Dozens of bodies were recovered by troops and police from Damaseus. One hundred persons were missing.

Victoria ascended England's throne in 1837. In a sense, then, "Victoria the Great," which ascended to the Music Hall's screen yesterday, is a centenary observance, conducted with pomp and dignity, with splendor and reverence, with fidelity and affection.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, speaking last night at the big Tammany rally of the campaign, linked Mayor La Guardia and Nikolai Lenin as stockholders in the Russian-American Industrial Corporation, which he declared was a communistic organization.

Moderate early gains were not maintained on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday when light Southern selling and liquidation encountered an indifferent demand in the afternoon. Prices held with in a narrow range as business continued limited. Final quotations were within 2 points either way of the previous finals after the market had moved over a range of 8 to 11 points.
The net result of a day marked by several individual and distinct price movements was generally higher prices yesterday for all major classifications of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

Brewers here from all parts of the country for the convention of the United Brewers Industrial Foundation, headed by Colonel Jacob Ruppert, today adopted a code of fair trade and practice for the industry, designed to promote its economic interests and standing with the publie.

The Federal Government has acceded to the request of Premier Aberhart to have the power of Federal disallowance of provincial legislation tested by the courts. Prime Minister Mackenzie King announced here tonight that the Supreme Court of Canada would be asked to decide this question at the earliest opportunity.

Our distinguished visitor from Norway, Dr. Halvdan Koht, like his Norse forebears, has touched many coasts-but in his case only as a student of history and politics, an intellectual viking. He has written biographies of men of his own land as Ibsen and Bjornson and Sverdrup.

The world featherweight championship situation may be cleared up somewhat tonight when two claimants for the 126-pound crown, Henry Armstrong of Los Angeles and Petey Sarron of Birmingham, clash in the fifteen-round bout which will feature the opening of the 1937-38 boxing season at Madison Square Garden.

Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard yesterday named Assistant Attorney General Charles A. Schneider, the Tammany leader of the Eighth Assembly District, in a $5,000 fixing case the negotiations for which, it was declared in testimony which he made public, were carried on at the Schneider home in the bedroom of the Democratic leader's son.

Increases in certain special passenger fares, to add about $5,000,000 annually to the revenues of Western railroads on the basis of the present business, were approved today by the Western Association of Railway Executives, Harry Guy Taylor, chairman, announced tonight.
A squad of thirty-five Colgate Red Raiders seeking their first major victory of the season left here via bus tonight and entrained for New York in Utica.
Carl E. Petersen, New York marine engineer and naval architect, obtained a divorce today at Minden from Mrs. Olga Petersen on the grounds of cruelty. Later he obtained a license to wed Ann Suber.

Injuries to several key players have handicapped the St. Mark's School football team's offensive this Fall, but those boys are well on the road to recovery and are expected to be ready for the traditional game with Groton School here Nov. 10.
Public announcement of the Government's removal from Valencia to Barcelona was made tonight by Minister of the Interior Julian Zugazagoitia in a broadcast from Madrid.
Lumber production declined less than seasonally last week, advancing the index to 78.3 from 76.9 for the previous week. For the week ended Oct. 24, 1936, it was 86.7.

The Delta Phi Epsilon fraternity has leased quarters in 7 Washington Place, to be used as a clubroom, through the Cross Brown Company, broker. Other leases reported during the day included a number of stores. The list follows:

A charge that commuters would be threatened with a "triple tax" on their incomes in the event of the election of State Senator Lester H. Clee, Republican candidate for Governor, was made by United States Senator A. Harry Moore, Democratic candidate, at rallies in Bergen County this afternoon and tonight. Senator Moore also addressed about 5,000 persons at a rally in Newark tonight.

Rutgers football team went through a two-hour session today, drilling on Lehigh plays and formations for the Middle Three title clash here Saturday. With secondstring players using the Engineers' plays, the varsity spent the major part of the afternoon on defense.

Testimony that United Air Lines was informed of a storm sweeping Northeastern Utah the night the Mainliner carried nineteen persons to death on a mountain slope was given today by A. S. Mooney Jr.; pilot for Western Air Express, before the Commerce Department's special investigating board.

The value of. United States exports in September was 7 per cent higher then in August and was $76,000,000, or 35 per cent, above the corresponding month in 1936, while imports were 8 per cent larger in value than a year ago,
President Anastasio Somoza called the leaders of all parties to the Presidential House today for a conference to discuss economic and political problems and specially the Honduras-Nicaraguan dispute.

The closIng session of the thirtieth annual National Tax Association Conference here today included addresses by Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the United States Treasury; Dr. Alzada Comstock, Professor of Economics at Mount Holyoke College, and Dr. Robert M. Haig of Columbia University.

Mrs. Alice Bartlett Stimson, a leading figure in women's civic and social clubs here and the widow of the Rev. Dr. Henry A; Stimson, founder and pastor emeritus of the Manhattan Congregational Church here, died on Wednesday of a cerebral hemorrhage and pneumonia at her home, 25 Claremont Avenue, after a brief illness. Her age was 83.

The Irish Free State gives a statutory right to annual vacations with full pay to a limited number of workers -under legislation passed early this year. Sean Lemass, Minister of Industry and Commerce, speaking at the annual luncheon of the, Irish Tourist Association here today, said he planned soon to introduce legislation extending this right to shop assistants, transport works and many others.

The Christian church-was described as the "most relevant fact today" in a world whose secular order offers no principle of cohesion by the Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay, president of the Princeton Theological Seminary, speaking last night before delegates to the centennial of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, meeting at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

National Aviation Corporation Liquidating value on Sept. 30, $13.82 a share after providing for normal income taxes on unrealized appreciation of securities held, and based on market value of listed securities in portfolio and estimated value of securities not having an active market.
Mrs. Mary Heathfield, playwright, died on Wednesday at her home, 22 East Thirty-sixth Street, at the age of 63. Mrs. Heathfield became ill last February.

The two-months' controversy between Governor Quinn and the turfman-publisher, Walter E. O'Hara, brought from J. Howard McGrath, United States Attorney, an announcement today that a special grand jury would convene next week to investigate alleged violations of the'Federal Corrupt Practices Act in connection with the battle.

Chinese defenders, having made good their retreat north of Shanghai, were constructing today a new strong line of defense. The main object of the Japanese, to break the morale of the enemy, was thus disappointed. A "suicide battalion" of Chinese held out in Chapei in front of the United States marines and the Japanese threatened to take severe action. [Page 1.]

Surrogate William J. Sheils of Westchester County, in commenting today on the action of the Court of Appeals yesterday in rejecting his claim to election to a full term as surrogate, said he would "rest the case" with the county electorate next Tuesday.
Abraham Kaplan, Tammany campaign manager, charged yesterday that "the most stupendous barrage of propaganda in behalf of any Mayoralty candidate" was being issued in behalf of Mayor La Guardia.
Syracuse's workout was limited to a one-hour signal drill today due to an all-day rain that turned Hendricks Field into a quagmire.
Effective on Nov. 15, short-sale margins on the New York Stock Exchange are to be $5 a share or 30 per cent of the market value, whichever is 'greater, according to a rule adopted yesterday.
The weekly statement of the Bank of Canada, issued today, showed reduced note circulation and increased Dominion and Provincialshort-term securities holdings. The statement follows:
Elmer Ellsworth Wentworth, teacher of English for many years, died here yesterday in his seventy-eighth year.

At a wildly enthusiastic rally of the American Labor party in Madison Square Garden last night, Mayor La Guardia appealed for the election of a Board of Estimate and City Council that would support his policies and credited Samuel Seabury with having revealed conditions in the city government that elected him four years ago and would re-elect him this year.

Staging a dummy defensive and offensive drill, the Yale eleven today finished its heavy work for Saturday's big battle with Dartmouth in the Bowl. The scrubs, drilled by Line Coach Gerry Ford and Backfield Coach Bill Renner, put on their- version of the Indians' attack during the first half hour when the varsity squad was divided,

Atrim-looking, middle-aged president of one of the country's large food corporations stood before seventy-five football-wise old Blues at the Cornell Club last night and made the heretical statement that it wasn't the introduction of the forward pass' that made the big change in the game of today from what it was when he was wearing cleats.
Rain today failed to halt the preparations of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor for their five-week tour across the United States to study American labor conditions.

Japanese troops composing the northern flank of the forces advancing on Taiyuan, Shansi's capital, along the Shihchiachuang Railway continued their drive westward today and occupied a district approximately ten miles north of Hsimenhou Pass, where the Chinese disputed the Japanese attack.

The Cuban Supreme Court tonight ordered the prosecution of Colonel Celestino Baizan, Governor of Havana Province, on a charge of attempted intimidation of the Provincial Council and fixed bond at $5,000.
Henri de Man, former Minister of Finance and a Socialist, today accepted the invitation of King Leopold to form a Cabinet, to succeed the government of Paul van Zeeland, who resigned this week.

Albert Lewis, who, as noted here on Wednesday, will be wandering back from Hollywood next month to offer "Salvage" by Martin Berkeley, plans to divide his time between the two coasts, offering a play or two here each year, then going west to film them.
More than 150 Barnard College students and their escorts will attend the Halloween Hop, the annual dance sponsored by the Athletic Association, to be held at Barnard Hall on the campus tonight.

The visiting army jumping teams that will compete in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden next week got into action at Squadron A Armory yesterday, where the mounts were sent through their paces.
Municipal ownership will be a big issue in next Tuesday's election in two widely separated Pennsylvania industrial centers, Reading and Pittsburgh.
Inaustrial activity in the Pittsburgh district, after allowance for ordinary seasonal changes, again receded last week. On the other hand, the seasonally adjusted trade index advanced somewhat.

Moving to bolster their revenues to take care of increased operating costs, directors of the Association of American Railroads met here today to consider the amount and extent of increased charges for the transportation of freight which the association will ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve.

Establishment of a "floor" on men's wear Spring fabrics brought a more settled tone to the wool goods market this week, and indications are business in men's wear "will begin to pick up shortly," the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday, adding that clothing manufacturers who had been delaying placing of contracts were expected to send in commitments in the next ten days.
New York University's football squad went through an intensive three-hour workout yesterday at Ohio Field in final preparation for the contest with Colgate at the Yankee - Stadium tomorrow.

Seven members of the Ozanam Guild, an organization of Catholic workers in the Emergency Relief Bureau, repudiated yesterday the action of their chairman, Frank J. Farrell, in endorsing the TammanyMahoney ticket.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and its associated companies, a $475,000,000 utility system operating almost'. completely within the State of.Illinois, resigned yesterday from membership in the Edison Electric Institute, according to an announcement by James Simpson, of the. company.
Mr. and Mrs. Russell G. D'Oench have left Searing Farm, their place in Albertson, L. I., and are at the Pierre before leaving on Nov. 15 to pass part of the Winter in Maryland.
The University Club, winners of the Class A title a year ago, gained a 5-to-O triumph as the Metropolitan League squash racquets interclub matches started last night.

The marriage of Miss Gabriele Martha Auguste Humbert, daughter of Mrs. Gabriele Humbert of Kiel, Germany, to Thomas Henry Parker of Hamilton, Bermuda, took place this evening at Vassar College, where the bride has been a member of the faculty since 1931.

Army worked out today on a muddy field as the coaches emphasized individual assignments and handling of the wet ball. With all of his first two teams present, Coach Gar Davidson had his first opportunity in a long time to look over all his players at practice.

The regular Williams quarterback, Tim King, who has been out with an injury since the Columbia game in New York, was back in the lineup today just as his reserve, Pete Seay, was forced to drop out with a minor ailment.
The consolidation of the Rainier Pulp and Paper Company, Grays Harbor Pulp and Paper Company and the Olympic Forest Products Company into a new organization to be known as Rayonier, Inc.,

Whitelys Patsy captured the 15-inch allage bitch stake, final trial of the New Jersey Beagle Club today. The weather was miserable, but contrary to general belief rabbits were plentiful and the work of the hounds was exceptional.
Miss Lillie Van Saun Berry of this place has completed plans for her marriage on Nov. 26 to Charles Jackson Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Smith, also of Short Hills.

Movements of livestock with Chicago markets today, reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 13,000, including 3,000 directs. The market was 5-15c higher than Wednesday's average. but part of the early advance was lost.

Robert A. Mahlstedt, 45 years old, of 22 Locust Avenue, New Rochelle, was sentenced here today by Justice of the Peace Wesley M. Messersmith to six months in the Westchester County penitentiary and was fined $50 for violating parole in a worthless check case by passing another $7 invalid check.

Elie Delville has been made secretary of the office of the Guaranty Trust Company in Brussels, Belgium.. Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company has been elected a director of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company.
Building activities on Manhattan Island in the nine months ended on Sept. 30 represented an outlay of $103,279,700, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

There is a definite relationship between build and the mortality -rate among women,. according to-a report presented yesterday by Dr. Louis I. Dublin; statistician and third vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, at the annual meeting of the Association of Life Insurance Medical Directors of America at the 'Hotel Pennsylvania.
Those who expected Japan to accept the invitation to attend the Nine-Power Conference at Brussels-and they were few-based the belief on this reasoning:
Chick Meehan of the Jaspers wants nothing to do with cats from now on whether they be Persians, Angoras, Cheshire, wild or just plain toms.
William Litchfield McKee, retired banker, died this afternoon of a kidney complaint at his home here in his sixtieth year. Mr. McKee had been retired since 1933.

Miss Hannah Jane Ewin, who had been for forty years superintendent of the Free Hospital for Women in Brookline, Mass., before her retirement in 1929, died yesterday of pneumonia at Pinehurst, N. C., where she had her Winter residence, according to word received here yesterday. She was 77 years old.

Release yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange of the tabulated results of its survey of the market in five leading stocks revealed that, from Sept. 7 to 25, inclusive, 22.7 per cent of all roundlot sales were for short account.

Scoring once in every period, the Barnard School for Boys football team gained undisputed possession of first place in the M. A. A. P. S. competition today by downing Woodmere Academy, 27-0. The victory was the third in as many league starts for Barnard.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and t Mrs. James Morgan Hutton of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Hutton, Robert Clermont Livingston Timpson of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Timpson of London, England, and formerly of Barrytown, N. Y. Mrs. Hutton and her daughter are at present at the St. Regis in New York.
Today's major events will be the recital of the soprano, Julia Peters, this evening at Carnegie Hall, and the concert of the Canadian Choir at the Town Hall tonight.

Jewelry and a fur piece with an estimated total value of $25,000 were stolen yesterday afternoon from the fifth-floor apartment of Charles A. Berns, treasurer of a liquor importing concern, at 15 West Fifty-third Street, adjoining the rear of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The DeBasil Ballet Russe introduced into its repertoire a work which had not previously been seen here when it presented David Lichine's choreographic version of "The Gods Go A-Begging" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

Diana Wilson, English actress, died today of pneumonia. She was 40 years old. She appeared in America after the World War with Isadora Duncan. One of her last engagements here was in the British version of "Anything Goes."

The Brooklyn College football team held its last heavy practice yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's game with Hofstra College at the Kingsmen's new athletic field at Bedford Avenue and Avenue H. Coach Lou Oshins sent his charges through a long session with an eye to perfecting the punting, passing and blocking assignments.

A dividend of $1.50 a share was declared yesterday on the common stock of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. The dividend, payable on Dec. 24 to stock of record of Dec. 17, is the same as paid in the preceding quarter, and brings to $4 a share the payments ordered this year. Dividends in 1936 were $1.50 a share, the first paid since February. 1932.
Mrs. Clara Pell Townsend, member of an old New York family, died on Wednesday at her home, 50 East Fifty-eighth Street, after a long illness. She was in her eightythird year.
Mr. and Mrs. F. A. Sherman of Hamilton, Ont., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Anna Sherman, to J. Hilton Leech, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Leech of Bridgeport.

Miss Harriet Cramp Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clothier Jones of Valley View, Ardmore, Pa., was married this afternoon to Robert Butcher Parker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Butcher Parker of Haverford.

Grace Moore, opera singer, was preparing today to take possession soon of her new home at Zoar Parish, Newton, Conn., a 200-year-old farmhouse which she purchased quite unexpectedly yesterday afternoon.
William N. Campbell has been elected a director of the Union Mutual Life Insurance Company, Portland, Me. He is president and treasurer of Goodall Worsted Company.

The will of Felix M. Warburg. financier and philanthropist, who died Oct. 20 at the age of 66, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court here, revealed that Mr. Warburg, in making his final will in 1935, omitted part of the charitable bequests he had planned in earlier wills, because of the large amounts already given to philanthropic, educational and civic causes.

The New York A. C. opened play in Group II of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association interclub matches last night by defeating the City A. C., 3 to 2, at the Winged Foot courts, losing the first and fifth matches.

When Yale goes into action against Darmouth tomorrow in a game which is attracting nationwide attention, the thousands in the stands will miss something when time is called and Yale's combat troops are ministered to from the sidelines.

Henry L. Stimson, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, and five former presidents of the association joined yesterday in urging the defeat of Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, who is running for re-election.

In reducing front 55 per cent to 40 per cent the maximum requirement of "margins" to be maintained against stock purchases, the Federal Reserve Board retraces the steps taken by it when, in October, 1934, that requirement was fixed at 45 per cent, and especially when, in February and May of 1936, it was further advanced to 55.
Eighteenth century paintings will be shown in rooms designed' by Isabella Barclay, Inc.; Bello, Inc.; Mimi Durant and Evelyn Rosenfeld, from Nov. 10 to Dec. 4, at the Decorators' Picture Gallery.
The birth of sextuplets in the far north of India on the border of Afghanistan, was announced today by Major Gene`al E. D. Giles.
William N. Campbell has been elected a director of the Union Mutual Life Insurance Company, Portland, Me. He is president and treasurer of Goodall Worsted Company.

The will of Felix M. Warburg. financier and philanthropist, who died Oct. 20 at the age of 66, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court here, revealed that Mr. Warburg, in making his final will in 1935, omitted part of the charitable bequests he had planned in earlier wills, because of the large amounts already given to philanthropic, educational and civic causes.

The New York A. C. opened play in Group II of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association interclub matches last night by defeating the City A. C., 3 to 2, at the Winged Foot courts, losing the first and fifth matches.

When Yale goes into action against Darmouth tomorrow in a game which is attracting nationwide attention, the thousands in the stands will miss something when time is called and Yale's combat troops are ministered to from the sidelines.

D. A. Macdonald, Chief Justice of the Court of King's Bench, died here today after a long illness. He was 79 years old. Lawyer, jurist and farmer, Daniel Alexander Macdonald became Chief Justice of the Court of King's Bench forty-four years after being admitted to the bar in 1883.
Eight new skyliners have been ordered by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., to accommodate the steady growth in travel over the company's air lines, Jack Frye, president, announced yesterday.

Dr. Charles Fama of the medical board of the'New York City employes retirement system charged yesterday that Tammany Hall was trying to inject a fictitious religious issue into the Mayoralty campaign, "having no arguments whatsoever against Mayor La Guardia's administration."
The Civil Service Commission is trying to ascertain, at President Roosevelt's request, what increase in government costs would result from a five-day work week for all Federal employes.
Municipal Court Justice Keyes Winter signed an order yesterday fining Miss Lucille Pugh, an attorney, $250 and sentencing her to ten days in the workhouse for contempt of court.

Plans for an apartment house on the West Side were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by A. A. Silberberg of the five five-story American basement dwellings at 7 to 15 West Eightyseventh Street, 167 feet west of Central Park West.

A Superior Court judge found Philip C. Provandie, 65-year-old deposed head of the Windham County Temporary Home for Children, guilty of indecent assault charges today and sentenced him to one year in the county jail at Brooklyn, near here.

The United States liner Manhattan, arriving this morning from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, has among her passengers Kerstin Thorborg, Swedish contralto of the Metropolitan Opera Company; Erica Morini, Austrian violinist;

An interesting question concerning New Deal labor laws was put before the Supreme Court today when the Santa Cruz Packing Company of California asked if it must submit to Labor Board jurisdiction in a dispute where unions declared its product "hot cargo," and where only 39 per cent of this product moved across State lines.

Dr. Charles Seymour, inducted early this month as the fifteenth president of Yale University, received today from Princeton University the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at a special convocation in the faculty room of Nassau Hall. One hundred and fifty Princeton faculty members and trustees attended the ceremonies.

An agreement to abolish further strikes, unless all peaceful means of a solution have been exhausted was signed late last night between the United States and British oil companies operating in Mexico and the oil unions as part of President Lazaro Cardenas's campaign to halt strikes until the end of the year in order to prevent the loss of government revenues.

Studies of industrial accidents -are revealing a gradually changing attitude on the part of employers toward the human machine, the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons was told today by Dr. M. N. Newquist of Chicago.

Completing heavy work in preparation for tomorrow's game at home with Providence College, Coach Benny Friedman sent the i City College football squad through a two-hour drill in the mud of Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.
In preparation for the Christmas season, during which the bulk of its business is done, the luggage industry is preparing to launch extensive campaigns next month to continue through the holidays.

Closer cooperation among older persons and the youth of communities to get broader and sounder views of problems, and a - wider range of interests for persons who restrict themselves to their own isolated- circles were advocated yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Mrs. Charlotte Whitaker Pennypacker, widow of Isaac R. Pennypacker, historian and chairman of the Valley Forge Park Commission, died today at her home in Ardmore after a long illness. She was 85.
Domei, Japan's national news agency, reported today from Seoul, Korea, that Soviet and Manchukuo border guards had clashed at Suiruho, northwest of Posiet Bay.
Retailers plan an early drive on the development of holiday toy and gift business, and the departments handling this merchandise are being put into shape earlier than in recent years.

We had word just now from Tom Garvin up in Madison County, and for a man who likes bird shooting he offers a strange suggestion. We've hunted with Tom, and cracked several birds over his fine setter Jolly, and we know a desire for a full game bag never influenced his sportsmanship.

A resolution appealing to the electorate to vote in the city election against all candidates connected with, endorsed by or sympathetic to the Communist party was signed yesterday by four clergymen after a meeting called by the Clergymen's Conference on Communism, in the Hotel Commodore.
Mayor La Guardia, as well as Police Commissioner Valentine will tour the city on election day to observe conditions in the various polling places, it was announced yesterday.

Harvard's football squad, seeking speed and precision, practiced in the rain today in its final hard workout for the Princeton game Saturday. The squad will leave tomorrow morning for Princeton, arriving in time for signal and kicking practice in Palmer Stadium.

A complaint that the Social Security Board had failed to cooperate with the Newark Police Department in an attempt to apprehend an alleged slayer was made today in a letter sent by Police Chief John F. Harris to J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, the National Socialist party's official philosopher, delivered a bitter counter-attack tonight against President Roosevelt's recent criticism of totalitarian States and American criticism of the Third Reich generally.

The Grand Vizier of Morocco ordered native authorities today to prohibit political meetings in mosques to avert outbreaks such as the clash yesterday at Port Lyautey, in which four persons were killed and nine wounded.

At an American Labor party rally of 18,000 at the Garden Mayor La Guardia pleaded for the election of a Board of Estimate and a City Council that would support him. He, Thomas E. Dewey and others on the ticket were wildly greeted. [Page 1]

A six-point program calling for elimination of unfair trade practices was submitted to the Cotton Thread Institute, Inc., at its annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday by Josef Pollack of Max Pollack Co., president of the institute, and the group authorized him to appoint a committee to draft rules for submission to the membership and later to the Federal Trade Commission.

A party of Indians who had watched Govind P. Nair, 32-year-old airman, make a perilously shaky start from Croydon Airfield on a double crossing of the Atlantic today had barely reached their homes when news came that he had crashed and was killed at Rouen, France.

Mrs. Isaac Altfeld, leader in Jewish activities in Cleveland, died yesterday at the age of 74. She founded the Jewish Center Sisterhood in 1905 and was its president for twenty-two years. She also founded the Ladies Auxiliaries of Mount Sinai Hospital and the Orthodox Home for the Aged.

A three-day protest strike of all Belgrade shops began today directed against department stores, disrupting the capital's trade. Shopkeepers demand that the stores be abolished entirely, particularly those belonging to the Czechoslovak shoe manufacturer Bata.
Mrs. Charlotte Whitaker Pennypacker, widow of Isaac R. Pennypacker, historian and chairman of the Valley Forge Park Commission, died today at her home in Ardmore after a long illness. She was 85.
Domei, Japan's national news agency, reported today from Seoul, Korea, that Soviet and Manchukuo border guards had clashed at Suiruho, northwest of Posiet Bay.
Retailers plan an early drive on the development of holiday toy and gift business, and the departments handling this merchandise are being put into shape earlier than in recent years.

We had word just now from Tom Garvin up in Madison County, and for a man who likes bird shooting he offers a strange suggestion. We've hunted with Tom, and cracked several birds over his fine setter Jolly, and we know a desire for a full game bag never influenced his sportsmanship.

A resolution appealing to the electorate to vote in the city election against all candidates connected with, endorsed by or sympathetic to the Communist party was signed yesterday by four clergymen after a meeting called by the Clergymen's Conference on Communism, in the Hotel Commodore.
Mayor La Guardia, as well as Police Commissioner Valentine will tour the city on election day to observe conditions in the various polling places, it was announced yesterday.

Harvard's football squad, seeking speed and precision, practiced in the rain today in its final hard workout for the Princeton game Saturday. The squad will leave tomorrow morning for Princeton, arriving in time for signal and kicking practice in Palmer Stadium.
Foreign military experts-like physicians watching a rare operation in a surgical amphitheatre-studied the battle of Shanghai today from lofty observation posts.
Prices of cotton remained almost stationary on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and ended the day within 1 point either way of the previous final quotations.

New bond financing this week, although restricted to two major classifications, amounted to $18,489,000, as compared with only $9,150,000 last week. During this week last year a total of $49,465,900 in new bonds were placed on the market.
Dr. G. Bromley Oxnam, president of De Pauw University, warned 3,000 school teachers, at the annual State convention today, that "capitalist democracy must solve certain problems."
The will of Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, was filed for probate yesterday. Mr. Mills left the bulk of his estate in trust for his widow, Mrs. Dorothy Randolph Mills.

John Milton Allen, paper company executive and World War hero, died Thursday night in Oak Sanitarium, Pewaukee, Wis., it was announced here last night. Mr. Allen, a native of Grand Rapids, Mich., was 41 years old and lived at 6 Quaker Centre, Scarsdale, N. Y.

The Ford Motor Company, Harry H. Bennett, personnel director, and nine others were sued today by nine officials and members of the United Automobile Workers of America for a total of $1,000,000 damages alleged to have been suffered in a fight outside the Ford Rouge plant May 26.

Mrs. Mary Moore Shackleton, wife of Horace E. Shackleton, 2 Inness Place, died last night in New York following an operation. She was born in Ithaca, N. Y. For the last fifteen years she had lived here. Mrs. Shackleton was graduated from Cornell University in 1920.

A capitalization of $350,525,120 for the reorganized New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, compared to a capitalization of $454,932,870 proposed in the debtor's plan for reorganization, has been urged upon the Interstate Commerce Commission in modifications to the debtor's plan filed with the commission by the Mutual Savings Bank Group Committee, it was learned today.

Meeting of tne American Mathematical Society, Harkness. Academic Theatre, Columbia University, 10 A. M. and 2 P. M. "The Application of Tensor Analysis to Problems of Electrical Engineering," Professor D. J. Struik.

The Carter Macy Tea and Coffee Company has acquired control of a blockfront in lower Manhattan through its purchase of the fivestory building on a lot 19.8 by 54.9 feet at 75 Front Street from the Bank of New York and Trust Company, as trustee, and the adjoining property at 71-3 Front Street from the ,Seamen's Bank for Savings. The deals were arranged by Hanford Henderson, Inc., brokers.

Stanley Wilson, an English artist (his work slenderly known over here), is holding, at the Kennedy Galleries, 785 Fifth Avenue, a oneman show of prints in several mediums and of water-colors done during the World War, in which he served as a British infantry commander.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, replied yesterday to the charge of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, of a link between his union and Soviet Russia.

The Roman Catholic Bishops of Yugoslavia, after a five-day meeting in Zagreb, issued today a sharply worded declaration which really is a protest against the Government's intimation that the Vatican concordat would not go to the Senate for ratification and never would come into force. Nineteen Archbishops and Bishops attended.

Headed by Captain Fred A. Aherne, the four officers who make up the Irish Free -State team which will compete in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden next week, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan.

Chesacroft Barron, Chesapeake Bay dog owned by Anthony A. Bliss of Westbury, L. I., today was placed first in the non-winners' stake, the opening competition on the program of the Autumn retriever trials of the Brookhaven Games Protective Asssociation, which will be continued through Sunday. The victor was handled by Lionel Bond and gave -a first-class exhibition, both on land and in the water.

Admitting that the record was unsatisfactory and that the motor vehicle fatalities this year probably would reach a new high of 40,000, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Automotive Safety Foundation, nevertheless had much of an encouraging nature to report yesterday to representatives of organizations cooperating for traffic safety whose total membership exceeds 7,000,000 at the annual luncheon of the foundation at the Hotel Commodore.

The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today a petition by the nation's railroads to place in effect on the short notice of fifteen days, freight rate schedules which would provide about $25,000,000 of additional revenues on miscellaneous commodities not covered by the commission's decision a week ago granting the railroads increases approximating $47,500,000.

Miss Jean MacDonald Bannerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Parry E. Bannerman of Hempstead, was married here tonight in the Cathedral of the Incarnation to Richard Marchand Hesselman, son of Captain and Mrs. Leo W. Hesselman of this place.
French anti-aircraft batteries fired six warning shots today at a German airliner which officers said flew over a forbidden zone on the Franco-Spanish frontier near Hendave.

Miss Harriet Jane Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Lee of Mount Arlington, was married in St. Mark's Episcopal Church here tonight to Stanton James MacIntosh, son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. MacIntosh of Passaic.

The marriage of Miss Susan Van Why Chamberlin, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Chamberlin of Ridgewood, N. J., and John D. Dolan Jr., son of John D. Dolan, U.S.A., Aviation Corps of Albrook Field, Panama Canal Zone, and the late Mrs. Dolan, took place this afternoon in Christ Presbyterian Church in this village. The Rev.

Miss Marie Edith Trommel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Trommel of this city, was married tonight in Blanchard Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church here to John James McIlveen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert H. McIlveen also of Passaic.

Charging that a "fantastic plot hatched by fanatics and picked up by Tammany Hall" had grown out of the granting of a police permit for a Nazi parade in Yorkville today, Mayor La Guardia asked his supporters to stay away from the demonstration.

A few days ago Joseph Curran, general organizer of the National Maritime Union, boasted in Washington that the union was going "to get the-scalp--and get it soon" of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Caroline Partridge McCabe of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Selden Partridge of Phelps, N. Y., to John F. Plummer of Ardsley-onHudson, which took place last Saturday in the Irvington (N. Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr.

The freshman first honor prize, awarded annually to the. Princeton sophomore who led his class scholastically in the freshman year, was conferred tonight on William Shand Jr. of Lancaster, Pa., at the Fall meeting of the Princeton Graduate Council.

Colonel Alvin Henry Graff, veteran of the Spanish-American War, Mexican border campaign and the World War, and formerly secretary of the Board of Education in Jersey City and personnel manager of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey there, died last night of a heart attack at his home here. He would have been 81 years old on Nov. 23.

Walter H. Ellis, formerly head of the Newark Chamber of Commerce and identified for many years with the automobile trade in Newark, retiring nine years ago, died this morning at his home here. He suffered a stroke three days ago.

In the Byzantine Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church Miss Ruth Mary Ruxton and Roy Dikeman Chapin Jr. were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent. The chapel was decorated in white, with the altar banked in cybotium ferns and lilies, and tall vases of white chrysanthemums in the chancel.

Nino Martini, Metropolitan Opera tenor, sang tonight at the opening of the eighth annual series of concerts under the auspices of Mrs. Julian Olney. His program included works by Puccini, Pergolesi, Scarlatti, Bizet, Tipton, Buzzi-Peccia and Bridge. "Sin Tu Amor," by Miguel Sandoval, who accompanied at the piano, concluded the program.
Clinton H. Crane was re-elected president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound when that organization held its Fall meeting at the Yale Club last night.

Alexander Pompez, a former operator of a Harlem policy game and a fugitive from Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's investigation since Jan. 15, is returning from Mexico City, the prosecutor announced yesterday.

Insurance to protect persons in' their old age and to provide funds for their dependents after death has been a common practice in this country, but the idea of providing similar protection for buildings by payments of premiums to cover depreciation and obsolescence is a comparatively recent development here.

The New York County grand jury, as its last act for the October term, handed up to General essions Judge Koenig yesterday a first-degree grand larceny indictment against H. Russell Ryder, 41 years old, t ex-convict' former "Broadway playboy," in the alleged theft of $19,00 i from'three investors in his so-called vent "group stock trading account."
Duquesne revealed power near the University of Richmond's goal line for three periods of their football party tonight, chalking up a 24-to-0 triumph before 5.000 spectators.

A series of broadcasts in which leading industrial executives will present industry's part in raising the American living standard above that of any other country, will begin next Saturday at 7:30 P. M.

A number of Japan's most. prominent citizens today prepared to leave San Francisco on their "goodwill" tour-around the globe to explain to various countries the Japanese side in the Sino-Japanese controversy.

South Carolina offset The Citadel's superior rushing power by seizing advantage of the breaks today to score a 21-to-6 victory before 8,000 spectators. The Gamecocks struck on the fifth play of the game for a touchdown. Gene Robinson, halfback,

Miss Sarann Eisner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Raymond Eisner of 791 Park Avenue and Red Bank, N. J., was married to Jerome Ludwig Burnham, son of Mrs. Hermine Burnham of 1,016 Fifth Avenue, yesterday at the Plaza by the Rev. Dr. Solomon Foster.

Sermons on the local political situation will be delivered in some of the churches tomorrow and in a few of the pulpits candidates in Tuesday's election will be heard. In the Catholic Churches the Feast of Christ the King will be observed.

" Plain people" of Pennsylvania who have not changed a religious custom since they. settled here in 1712 won a year-long fight today to keep their children away from "the wordly temptations" of a $112,000 PWA school building.

Organized labor will continue during the next four years to get the same "square deal" that it has received from the city administration during his first term, Mayor La Guardia declared last night in a campaign address delivered to 3.000 trade unionists in the Hippodrome at a rally held under the auspices of the American Federation of Labor Non-Partisan Committee for his re-election.

Miss Margaret Luer St. John, daughter of Mrs. Gamaliel C. St. John of Greenwich, was married to Elbridge Cleghorn Gale of Boston and Gloucester, Mass., in St. Bede's Chapel, Rosemary Hall, Greenwich, this afternoon.

A reign of terror in the labor union movement during the next four years was forecast last night by Harold W. Hastings in the event of the election of Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent for the office of District Attorney.

In a complaint filed with the National Labor Relations Board, the Committee for Industrial Organization charged the Aluminum Company of America today with "intimidation and coercion of employes" in the formation of an independent union at its local plant.

The French Foreign Legion and Senegalese troops established military control in the streets of Morocco's chief cities tonight to crush what officials said was a Nationalist plot to overthrow the French protectorate and set up an independent Arab kingdom.

Two naturalized American citizens of Spanish birth have been in jail here for more than one year on charges of sympathizing with the enemy and Theodore Monroe Fisher, the American vice consul, has been unable yet to obtain their release because island authorities refuse to recognize their American naturalization papers.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, a net income of $3,861,979 after all charges, including retirement reserve and dividends applicable to company before unearned cumulative preferred dividends of certain subsidiaries.

A compromise has been reached in the dispute between Viscount Lord Rothermere, British newspaper owner, and Ford Bond, American radio announcer, over outdoor dancing in the moonlight at an Elbow Beach hotel where both are living.
Representatives of the principal Mexican provincial newspapers met here today to protest the government's closing of the right wing newspaper the Informador in Guadalajara in the State of Jalisco.

In a speech in the First Manhattan Assembly District last night, Mayor La Guardia announced that he had taken measures to prevent intimidation and lawlessness at the polls next Tuesday, and told his hearers not to be afraid to vote the way they wanted to vote.

The first New York gourd festival opened yesterday in the Gardens of the Nations in Rockefeller Center with fifty gourd growers from all parts of the country exhibiting several thousand specimens. The display will be open to the public from 10 A. M. until 6 P. M. today and tomorrow.
Senator Wagner is "getting on." In his speech of Thursday night he propounded the curious theory that the election of the Fusion ticket would be an advantage to "reactionary Republican leadership."

A bid for the labor vote was made in a statement today by State Senator Lester H. CIee, Republican Gubernatorial nominee, before he departed for Camden, where he addressed a large party rally tonight.
Pennsylvania and the Navy, both striving to regain the victory highway, meet in their twenty-second football game on Franklin Field tomorrow before a crowd that will probably pass the 65,000 mark.

ONE-ACT PLAYS OF THE SEA, a revival of four short plays by Eugene O'Neill. Directed by William Challee; scenery and costumes by Perry Watkins. Produced by the Federal Theatre Project at the Lafayette Theatre.
Mrs. Elizabeth Macon Tilley and James Gordon Bohannan of Petersburg, Va., were married here this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner L. Boothe. Only a few friends were present.

" The Road Back," an American film based on Erich Maria Remarque's book, and "Sabotage," a Gaumont-British film based on a novel by Joseph Conrad, have been prohibited from exhibition in Brazil. "Sabotage" was banned, it was stated, because it upsets public order.

The International Longshoremen's Association accepted terms of a new wage contract submitted by ship operators in the coastwise trade at a meeting last night at St. Veronica's Hall, 272 West Tenth Street.
The Providence Star Tribune, published by Walter E. O'Hara, race track head, today apologized in print to Judge Charles A. Walsh for an article which the judge said was not a "statement of fact."
Funeral services will be held tomorrow for Brother Hamilton De Graw, last male member of the Shaker Colony near here. Brother Hamilton died yesterday at the age of 84 after a three-week illness.

Expressing his belief in the social objectives of the New Deal, George Backer, American Labor party candidate for Congress from the Seventeenth district, warned yesterday that Republican opposition in Congress would "break down our present policy of government."

Dr. Charles H. Townsend, director of the New York Aquarium and for thirty five years collector, exhibitor and sometimes trained nurse of some of the strangest creatures of the sea, will retire next Monday, on the anniversary of. his appointment in 1902.

At the opening of the Autumn session of Parliament today, Sudeten German Nazi] Deputies made a political demonstration. After one of them had protested the TeplitzSchoenau incidents last Sunday, in which they assert several of them were beaten by police, they marched out of the Chamber in a body.

A large sound truck with placards announcing unauthorized Communist endorsement of Mayor La Guardia and other political candidates was picked up by the police at 220th Street and White Plains Avenue, the Bronx, at 5:50 P. M. yesterday.

Cleveland police tonight captured Frank Bird, desperado, who made an armed break with two other members of the Bird gang and a fourth prisoner from the county jail on Sept. 23. Seized with the fugitive was his wife.

The Murphy Protective Committee for the 5 per cent accured debentures of the Kreugar Toll Company announced yesterday that it would distribute to holders of its certificates of deposit on Nov. 15, $95 for each $1,000 nominal amount of debentures deposited.

Mikhail A. Chernoff was removed as Commissar of Agriculture of the Soviet Union today by the Central Executive Committee. R. I. Eikhe was named his successor. No reason was given for the dismissal of Mr. Chernoff.

Russia refused to budge more than an inch in the subcommittee of the Non-Intervention Committee on Spain today, but instead of finding herself ostracized by the other powers she was saved at the last minute by a sudden twist of tactics on the part of Germany.
Dr. Preston P. Satterwhite will leave Preston Hall, his home in Great Neck, today for Louisville, Ky., where he will be for about ten days before returning to 960 Fifth Avenue for the Winter.

The sum of $25,000 to establish a Felix M. Warburg memorial fund for' social service work among underprivileged children in Palestine wads voted today by Hadassah, :the women's Zionist organization in Ainerica, at its twenty-third annual convention in the Hotel ChelSea here.

Although the salt-water fraternity has now dwindled down to the hardy few, and the surf rod is casting off the boat rod dynasty, thepresent lull is simply a brief period of inactivity for the angler who plans to follow the big fish south.
A new rate schedule, embodying reductions of more than $1,500,000 in the next six months, was filed today with the Public Utility Commission by the Philadelphia Electric Company.

Stung into action by what The Times described as "the over-supply of tortuous falsehood" broadcast from foreign stations in many tongues, the British Government has decided to introduce a world-wide service of "straight news" in a large number of languages.

Mayor La Guardia received 1,810 votes to Jeremiah T. Mahoney's 420 in a straw poll conducted by the New York University. Commerce Bulletin, undergraduate semi-weekly publication of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East.

Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. issued 203 additional warrants yesterday to be served by the police in Manhattan, and a Kings County grand jury in Brooklyn returned nineteen indictments for the same offense.

These Government informed the League of Nations in a note published today that, since its last communication on Oct. 13, the "Japanese have continued to bomb indiscriminately Chinese towns in the interior and the civilian population."

Thomas R. McMillen, senior of Decatur, Ill., and a veteran varsity oarsman, today annexed Princeton University's single sculling championship by sweeping to a four-length victory over John F. Kraemer, a classmate of New York, in the final of the Coaches Cup regatta on Lake Carnegie.

Marcelle Edwards Manville, fourth wife of Thomas Franklin Manville Jr., obtained a divorce today at a private trial on grounds of mental cruelty. A property settlement was placed in the record and sealed.

Governor Blanton H. Winship today appointed Enrique Ortega to head Puerto Rico's tourist activities. An engineer, Mr. Ortega has been assistant commissioner of the Interior Department. He has spent much of his time in Washington working for island improvements.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, who will supervise construction of the new Appellate Division Court House in Park Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets, made public yesterday a description of the new building.

BAGGI, NELLIE (Oct. 19). Estate, more than $10,000. To Charles and Georgia Tamm, 13 Summers Pl., West New Brighton, life estates in residue; Johanna Ferguson, same address, $240 annuity, 18 varying bequests. John J. Birby, 300 Central Park West, executor.
An ominous forecast of the ultimate fate of Japan's military ambitions in China comes from the Japanese War Office.

An invitation from the Belgian Government to participate in the forthcoming Nine-power treaty conference at Brussels, received by the German Government last night, was officialIy declined this morning.
Arturo Toscanini has decided to direct the British Broadcasting Corporation Symphony Orchestra tomorrow night, officials of the broadcasting company announced today.

State Controller Morris S. Tremaine appealed in a State-wide broadcast tonight for election of Democratic candidates for delegates at large to the 1938 State Constitutional Convention as "best qualified by experience and broad human sympathies."

Immediately after the Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate had voted yesterday to adopt the proposed city budget at the total of $589,985,046 to which they increased it, Mayor La Guardia promised that he would take all the excess charges out of the budget in January.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, Fusion candidate for District Attorney of New York County, Invaded last night the territory of two Tammany men who were this week the objects of his attacks-Albert Marinelli, leader of the East half of the Second Assembly District, and Assistant Attorney General Charles A. Schneider, leader of the Eighth Assembly Districtand promised enthusiastic rallies that he would drive crime out of the city.

Demonstrating its power in the first three minutes of the game, the Poly Prep eleven downed its borough rival, Brooklyn Prep, 18-0, before 1,000 spectators at Boys High field yesterday. It was the sixteenth meeting between the teams in a series which began in 1909.
Henry W. Lowe of New York City denied before the Board of Tax Appeals today that he took out a $2,500,000 insurance policy with a firm in Nassau, Bahamas, to evade income taxes.
Mrs. Henry W. Peabody of Beverly, Mass., and Orlando, Fla., has been appointed "Ambassador of Friendship" to the celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the Women's Christian Medical College,

Bonds moved forward over a broad front and in more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. All major groups participated in the upswing, with selected issues in the various groups displaying a buoyant tone as prices rose 1 to 5 points.

The re-establishment, of fear in a great section of the country. the business and financial community, by the Roosevelt Administration after its "amazing success" in "emotional uplift" in the early days of its regime, was scored here today by Wallace B. Donham, dean of the Harvard School of Business Administration, in an address at the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Homestead.

Miss Therese Murray, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Murray of Brooklyn, entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's. Her guests were the Misses Esms O'Brien, Betty McDonnell, Hope Baldwin, Rosamond Murray and Nancy Van Vleck.

Panic reigned in the western district of the International Settlement from 8 o'clock last night until early today after fifteen Japanese shells fell inside the British defense sector, killing three British soldiers and five Chinese civilians and wounding nearly forty Britons and Chinese.
Randle Boyd's beaver troubles are getting deeper and deeper, and so is the water that flooded a major portion of his farm and destroyed his Summer crops.

EARNEST HOOTON of Harvard can tell you more about your ancestry than you can learn froma whole :grove of family trees. He begins his slang-strewn survey of man's first sixty million years right,up in the. trees, with all our ancestors living among the high green branches, and comes zooming down to' the present. As an anthropologist Dr. Hooton writes crisply and lucidly for laymen.
The Zeppelin Company today ordered a helium-purifying plant built here, to be ready when the new Zeppelin, No. 130, takes the air next Spring for her voyage to Lakehurst. N. J.
Mrs. Carol Newberry Brooks, daughter of Truman H. Newberry of Detroit, former Secretary of the Navy, is residing at a hotel here.

The spread in foreign countries of rumors that the dollar would be devalued further was responsible yesterday for a general advance of the principal foreign exchanges in terms of the United States currency.

In an Indian Summer setting, Fordham went through its last workout at the Duke University Stadium today while some twelve miles away North Carolina staged its final practice at Chapel Hill, where these two unbeaten teams will clash tonorrow.

Miss Zita Stevens Shawell of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William J. Shawell, was married to John Alwin Dittmer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Dittmer, also of Elizabeth, here today.

The public in this vicinity seems at the moment to be divided into three groups or classes: first, those who understand the method by which P. R. ballots are counted, and can explain it; second, those who understand it but can't explain it; third, those who can neither understand nor explain it.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is now more than thirty years since I first suggested, in a letter to your journal, that snow might be quickly and economically removed by the use of the sewers.

Henry Armstrong clinched his claim to the world featherweight championship last night by stopping Petey Sarron, courageous battier from Birmingham, Ala., in the sixth round of their scheduled' fifteen-round battle at Madison Square Garden.
Dr. William Jeffries Chewning, who served during the World War as a first lieutenant in the Medical Corps, died last night in Walter Reed Hospital. His age was 60.
South Side High and West Side High of Newark played to a scoreless tie at the schools' stadium .tonight. Both teams fought evenly through the game.

Dr. John E. Greiwe, heart specialist and lecturer, died last night in a hospital here at the age of 72. He had practiced medicine in Cincinnati for forty-five years and lectured before medical groups in Canada, Germany, England and Spain.

The first seizure in the East of sufanilamid, the misuse of which has been blamed for sixty deaths in the United States, has been made' here on libels filed by Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, it was revealed yesterday.

Several bishops will participate in the fourth triennial-luncheon to be held today in the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the Missions' Committee of the Women's Auxiliary to the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church. More than a thousand guests are expected.

Dr. Halvdan Koht, the Norwegian Foreign Minister, was a guest of President Roosevelt today 'at luncheon. Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Minister, and Mrs. de Morgenstierne were with Dr. Koht, as was George T. Summerlin, chief of protocol for the State Department.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, making his first campaign address for Jeremiah T. Maboney, last night rebuked both sides in the Mayorelty campaign for having indulged in "an unusual degree of misrepresentation and abuse.

More than 200 colonists attended the Autumn Moon dinner dance tonight in the Tangerine Room at Greenbrier Casino. There with guests were Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Ingalls Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bohnsack, Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Magee, Mr. and Mrs. K. E. Vogel, Mr. and Mrs. George H. Lange, Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Hussey, Mr. and Mrs. William E. Emmett and Mr. and Mrs. Laurence McKinney.
Thirty-one heroes in the United States and Canada, ten of whom gave their lives in rescue efforts, were honored today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.
Miss Frances Willing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Willing of East Falls, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea given by her parents at the House of the Colonial Dames.
Princeton and Harvard-pick up the thread of their old football tradition tomorrow, and one of the largest crowds of the season will be in Palmer Stadium for the kick-off at 2 o'clock.
Cotton-mill activity increased last week, when- a marked decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index has spurted to 123.2 from 113.3. For the week ended Oct. 24, 1936, the index stood at 130.5.

One of the most comprehensive studies of the problems of merchandising electrical appliances ever to be made has been. undertaken by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday.

The text of Governor Lehman's address at the Democratic rally at the Academy of Music, in Brooklyn, last night follows: Several weeks ago I announced that I would vote for Judge Mahoney, Controller Taylor and Mr. Schneider.
The mythical crown of "champion of champions" dangles at the finish line of the $15,000 added Washington Handicap tomorrow before War Admiral, ruler of the 3-year-olds, and Seabiscuit. handicap king.

A hand-loomed Argentine flag, which will be flown in Philadelphia on Argentina's two national holidays, was presented to the city today as a gift of Buenos Aires. The presentation, made in Independence Hall, completed an exchange of national flags between the two cities as a gesture of neighborliness and good-will.

Hearings on a proposed reciprocal trade treaty with Czechoslovakia were concluded a today and government officials announced that actual negotiations with the Prague Government probably would begin within two weeks.

President Roosevelt declined to commit himself in any way today on the possibility of a revision of the capital-gains and corporate undistributed-profits taxes, replying to questions with a general dissertation on the importance of raising the income and purchasing power of 30,000,000 to 40,000,000 Americans who, he said, have almost nothing.

Several residential properties in Brooklyn underwent changes of ownership in realty deals reported yesterday. The Ridgeway Park Corporation sold the five-story apartment house at 659 Bay Ridge Avenue to a client of Hy D. Agar, Inc.
Johnny Goodman posted sub-par practice rounds of 70 and 68 today and was made a top-heavy favorite to retain the Mexican amateur golf championship in the tournament which gets under way, tomorrow.
Lehman Corporation c a p i t a stock, $1 par value, will be admitted today to the New York Stock Exchange list and the old no-par value capital stock will be suspended from dealings.
The preliminary work on the agenda of the Nine-Power Conference received a rude shock today when Germany refused to join in the deliberations on the Sino-Japanese dispute scheduled to begin Nov. 3.

The Appellate Division in a series of unanimous rulings disbarred yesterday Robert Morgan McGauley, a former assistant district attorney, and four other lawyers. It suspended two others for one year each for unethical conduct.

The claim to have isolated virulent germs in malignant growths in animals and to have subsequently infected the bodies of healthy animals injected with the virus from these growths was made tonight before the Vienna Medical Society by Professor Gerlach, director of the Federal Institute for Combating Contagious Diseases in Animals.

The decision of the Association of American Railroads yesterday to ask for another increase in freight rates came promptly on the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission raising rates in accordance with a petition filed on the expiration of the emergency surcharges at the end of last year.

The Calvert Distillers Corporation contemplates no reductions in prevailing prices for its whiskies, W. W. Wachtel, vice president, announced here yesterday. Mr. Wachtel's announcement followed action by the National Distillers Products Corporation on Thursday in reducing prices 20 per cent on its "Mount Vernon" and "Old Overholt" bottled-in-bond whisky brands.

Only the Department of Justice has the authority to appear in court to dispute a person's right to citizenship in the United States, Federal Judge John W. Clancy ruled yesterday, dismissing an action brought by Major Julius Hochfielder, Brooklyn attorney, to cancel the citizenship of Fritz Kuhn, head of the German American Bund, an alleged Nazi organization.
Rabbi Kalman Solomon of Congregation Temple Isaac, Brooklyn, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 374 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, at the age of 78.

The Merchants and Miners Transportation Company tonight announced a curtailment of steamship service between this city and three East Coast ports, due to "mounting costs of operation, unsettled labor conditions and decline in patronage."

The government last night issued a decree prohibiting the exportation of wheat and flour until further notice. At the same time Brig. Gen. Basilio B.
