Pertine, Minister of War, ordered all the army's baking equipment concentrated in this city and instructions were issued to the national penitentiary to be prepared to work its bakery at full capacity to supply bread to the public.
Tulsa University took to the air in the final period tonight to defeat George Washington University by a single point, 14 to 13, in an intersectional football game before'10,000 fans.

The Treasury obtained an average rate of 0.226 per cent on its second offering of the new shortterm bills maturing about March 15, Wayne C. Taylor, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, announced tonight.

General Public Service Postpones Payments Voted on Sept. 2 In a letter to preferred stockholders of the General Publio Service Corporation, D. K. Laidlaw, president, announces the postponement of preferred dividends declared on Sept. 2, owing to impairment of capital under Delaware laws. The letter says:

The Surry Players, who are Summer-time down East folks, will be putting on "As You Like It" this evening at the Ritz Theatre. Among the group's members are Katherine Emery, Shepperd Strudwick, Anne Revere, Frederic Tozere, Alan Handley, Hayden Rorke and Staat Cotsworth, and the production is the one which was tried out during the warmer months at Surry, Me.

Four men, former employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, were paroled in the custody of their attorney in Night Court last night following their arrest on charges of disorderly conduct while picketing in front of the Plymouth Theatre, 236 West Forty-fifth Street, Manhattan.

Early this evening as Jews were returning from prayers at the Wailing Wall in the old city of Jerusalem six shots were fired at a group of Jews, killing Aaron Alkabat, 32year-old Moroccan Jew and seriously wounding two others.

Aroused by a 22 per cent increase in traffic fatalities in New Jersey for the first nine months of 1937, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee urged in a statement today that local judges suspend drivers' licenses rather than impose fines where injuries result from traffic violations.

Bruce Crane, noted American landscape artist, died early today of a heart attack at his home, 6 Studio Arcade, here. Mr. Crane, one of the oldest active artists in the country, worked until the day of his death.

Reports of the President's press conference yesterday quote him as saying that it is more important to raise the purchasing power of "the lower onethird of the American people" than to revise the undistributed profits tax.

The wreath that Isador Gennett, visiting veteran from the Bronx, New York, laid yesterday on the monument to the German war dead on Unter den Linden in the name of Morris Krumholtz Post 18 of the Jewish War Veterans Association, American Legion Post 1169 and Post 32 of the Disabled American War Veterans of the World War is still there tonight.

Princeton University's powerful 150-pound football team preserved its undefeated status today on Fitzpatrick Field, turning back Villanova, 12-0, for its third consecutive triumph. Today's victory was the Tigers' second of the season in the Eastern Intercollegiate Lightweight League..
Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday ordered the receivers of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company to discontinue service on its New Rochelle-Port Chester branch at midnight tomorrow.

Yale and Dartmouth meet tomorrow in the only football game-of the day the country over, involving two unbeaten and untied teams of major standing, and the prospect is that the biggest crowd to gather in the Bowl since 1929 will see them play.

The British Broadcasting Corporation's television station at Alexandra Park here tonight transmitted the first "telephotogram" to a ship at sea--a visual message of greeting to the master of the liner Britannic, Captain A. T. Brown, and the ship's company.

Determined to cut short its losing streak and dispel a road jinx of seven years' standing, Manhattan's football team was pronounced fit tonight by Coach Chick Meehan for its annual meeting with the Georgetown University eleven at Griffith Stadium tomorrow.

To Sport Editor of The New York Times: During the last two years football gambling has increased by leaps and bounds. Such a forward stride by organized- gamblers bodes no good for the future of the game.

Reviewing the reasons which prompted the imposition- of the twenty-one-day. credit rule for liquor retailers, Henry Bruckman, Commissioner of the State Liquor Authority, refused yesterday the.request of a delegation of restaurant and bar owners for an. immediate modification of the rule. Mr.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the Unifed States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 7,000, including 2,000 directs. The market was fully steady with Thursday's average: top, $9.50: bulk, good and choice,
A light practice yesterday concluded Brooklyn College's preparation for the game with Hofstra College at the new Brooklyn College athletic field, Bedford Avenue and Avenue H, today.
There are encouraging signs that the Administration has at last become seriously convinced of the need of a prompt balancing of the Federal budget. It would be little short

Miss Mary Terry Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Strong Harrison of Cedarhurst, was married this afternoon in Trinity Church here to John Griswold Livingston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Griswold Livingston of Lawrence.

The American composer must have the encouragement and incentive of an American public interested in his works if he is expected to create. This was the stand taken by Roy Harris, American composer, participating in a composers' forum which was a feature of the federation day meeting of the New York Federation of Music Clubs, held yesterday morning at the Great Northern Hotel.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is for the most part marking time. Price reductions on standard worsted goods at the first of the week of 12 to 15 cents a yard on the average have had little apparent effect upon the wool goods buyers as yet.

Reports in steel circles here are that the changes made this week among officials of the United States Steel Corporation presage a radical change among subsidiaries of the corporation such as was effected when the Carnegie Steel Company and the Illinois Steel Company were merged into the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, with headquarters here.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The crew of the Panama Pacific liner Virginia, which is scheduled to sail at noon today for the Panama Canal and Pacific Coast, supported the claims of eight electricians for overtime wages by refusing yesterday afternoon to. sign on for the trip.

Julia Peters, a New York soprano who has been heard here at intervals during the last decade, gave a recital at Carnegie Hall last night. At this latest appearance Miss Peters evidenced considerable growth in her art since she sang here previously, for she had developed greater dramatic intensity in the interim and also had acquired deeper vision as interpreter.

Dr. William Metcalfe Stone, a physician in Flushing for thirtyseven years, died last night in the Columbia Medical Center of a complication of diseases. - Dr. Stone, who was 66 years old and lived at 136-36 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, became ill last July and was removed to the-hospital a month ago.

To refund the last of the tax-free bonds issued at the time of the war, Charles Dunning, Finance Minister, announced tonight that subscriptions would be opened on Wednesday on a new $100,000,000 loan. The $122,799,800 of 5 1/2 per cent victory bonds is redeemable on Dec. 1.

Predicting a continuance next year of the decline in publicly financed construction work, Thomas S. Holden, vice president of the W. Dodge Corporation, estimates that privately financed building and engineering work in 1938 will reach approximately the same volume as this year.

Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, said today that the State's election Tuesday would show as great a percentage of Democratic majorities as in the Presidential election last year, when the Democrats carried the State.

One-sided triumphs marked the opening of play in the Metropolitan League Class C squash tennis interclub matches last night. The Crescent A. C., Harvard and Yale clubs all scored 5-to-O victories,' while the other winner, the Princeton Club turned back the City A. C., 4 to 1.

A large number of American refugees from China who have arrived in Japan will sail for the United States in the next two days, according to a report to the State Department today from the United State Consulate General in Yokohama.
Stocks, gained. 1 to 4 points in heavier. trading; turnover, 2,803,740 shares. Bonds generally higher, with rails strong; United States Government bonds higher; transactions, $10,226,850.

Retail trade did not do particularly well here last week and department store sales volume again fell under last year's figures by 2 to 3 per cent, according, to retail executives. Weather conditions curbed the expansion of the apparel demand, and home furnishings failed to make more than a fair showing.

Trading in round lots by members for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 2 rose to 22.70 per cent of the total volume from 21.75 per cent in the week ended on Sept. 25, the Securities and Exchange Sa Commission reported today.

More than 34,000,000 social security numbers, including 4,000,000 representing applications for old age benefits received since July 1, had been assigned by Sept. 30, the Social Security Board announced today in its quarterly summary of progress.

Recognizing that the human factor is perhaps the most important one in the mounting rate of highway accidents, the National Automobile Show featured "Safety Day" at the Grand Central Palace yesterday.

The Canadian Choir of Brantford, Ont., directed by Frederic Lord, gave its first local concert last night at the Town Hall. The group, composed of some fifty mixed voices, began with a brace of works by the early contrapuntalists Sweelinck, Lasso and Mundy;
Chemical substances which have ended sterility in men and women were reported here today at the closing sessions of the annual Clinical Congress of the American College of Surgeons.

Although an enrolled Republican, Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, widow of the banker, announced today that she favored the election of William J. Sheils, the Democratic candidate for Surrogate of Westchester County.

Mayor La Guardia will present plaques to commanders of winning precincts in the interprecinct traffic safety competition of the Police Department at exercises this afternoon in connection with the department's annual motorized safety parade.

Final preparations for the outstanding professional football game between the undefeated' Chicago Bears and the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds tomorrow will be concluded today at the scene of the battle.

Mrs. Addie Ottenheim Straus, widow of Max Straus, president of the Baltic American Line, died yesterday at her home, 230 Central Park West, at the age of 70. Mrs. Straus had been ailing for several years.

Quarterback Frank Reagan, 180pound triple threat man, personally conducted the University of Pennsylvania's freshman eleven to a thrilling 7-6 triumph over a hitherto undefeated Princeton cub team today on University Field.

Lawrence Marks, 49-year-old exconvict, was found guilty of firstdegree murder yesterday by a blueribbon jury in County Court, Brooklyn, for the slaying of 8-year-old Paula Magagna, whose nude body was found in the cellar of her home at 349 Stockholm Street, Brooklyn, on July 31.

In a ceremony performed by the fathers of the bride and bridegroom this evening, Miss Esther Wasmund, daughter of the Rev. Henry C. Wasmund and Mrs. Wasmund, was married to William H. Trebert, son of the Rev. William Trebert of Rochester and Mrs. Trebert, in Trinity Lutheran Church here.

AMHERST VS, MASS. STATE-Maybe they, A have overlooked psychology as a potent force in football scrimmages. How about tiring some biology? Biology is the study of living things--plants and animals. If this isn't, a plant, one vital vote for Amherst.

Three Yale undergraduates received severe injuries early this morning when an automobile in which they were traveling along Beach Street in West Haven ran into a telephone pole, shattering the pole and demolishing the automobile.
The Mayor and hundreds of citizens of Nimes tonight welcomed William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, to the home of his ancestors.

New York University will meet Colgate's Red Raiders today at the Yankee Stadium in what may well turn out to be one of the most exciting games in the East. The contest is scheduled to start at 2:30 P. M.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $6,638,942, to be represented by three States and fifty-two municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $18,786,136 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $24,453,871.

Queens Village detectives announced last night that after questioning Mrs. Elizabeth Eaton Guggenheim, noted horsewoman, who divorced Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim on Tuesday in Reno, about a report that she and John Fry Jr., horse trainer, had been held up, robbed and beaten they had learned that there was no truth in the report.

City College's eleven returns to its home field, the Lewisohn Stadium, after an absence of three weeks this afternoon, when it clashes with the strong Providence College forces in the sixth game of their series. The kick-off is set for 2:30.

Eastchester High continued its victorious gridiron march by defeating Scarsdale High, 6-0, today. The result kept Eastchester's record intact, with five victories, no defeats, no ties and no score for any opponent thus far this season.

The Ford Motor Company announced tonight that it would reopen its assembly plant in Kansas City "as soon as it receives assurances from officials that men who want to work can do so without interference."

A plot containing 10,000 square feet on the south side of Lacombe Avenue, 175 feet east of Effingham Avenue, the Bronx, has been mold by Castle Hill Estate, Inc., through Edward B. Shanahan, sales manager, to a builder who intends to erect three one-family dwellings.

Houghton Mifflin have ordered a second large printing of "Men, Women and Tenors," the -autobiography of Mme. Frances Alda, former Metropolitan Opera star. Mme. Alda is scheduled to talk at THE NEw YORE TIMES Book Fair on Nov. 9.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reversed yesterday the conviction of Isadore Rauch of 94-45 166th Street, Jamaica, Queens, and dismissed the indictment charging second-degree manslaughter.

Rich deposits of lead, copper, iron and coal situated in and around Penarroya, forty miles northwest of Cordoba. is the prize for which the Rebels and Loyalists have struggled for the last three months.
United States Senator A. Harry Moore closed his South Jersey campaign here tonight with a speech in defense of his labor record at a rally of 4,000 Democrats at the 114th Infantry Armory.

The United Automobile Workers of America, affiliate of the C. I. O., which has won recognition from all the big manufacturers of motor cars except Henry Ford, has the Board of Commerce, the business leaders and more conservative elements of the middle class in this city in a state of jitters tonight with its drive to seize control of the municipal government on Tuesday.

A net profit of $4,857,560 for the first nine months of this year was reported yesterday by the United States Gypsum Company and subsidiaries after deducting depreciation, expenses and taxes, including Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

BRETTAUER, BLANCHE (July 24, 1936). Gross assets, $287,298: net, $279,503. To Dr. Joseph Brettauer, husband. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $262,357. Sullivan Cromwell, attorneys, 48 Wall St. CORLISS, CHARLES A. (Feb. 9, 1936). Gross assets, $2,380,523; net, $2,090,431.
The Catholic Youth Association of the Muenster Diocese, one of the Reich's strongest Catholic districts, has been suppressed by the secret political police.

An increase in freight and passenger rates, estimated to yield $508,000,000 annually and including a 15 per cent rise in general freight rates, will be asked of the. Interstate Commerce Commission at once by the nation's railroads.

Twenty unions, some affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and others with the Committee for Industrial Organization, petitioned the Court of Errors and Appeals today for a determination of the legality of closed-shop agreements.

Retail trade showed improvement over the previous week, but unfavorable weather conditions in some areas held the gain over.1936 to 5 to 15 per cent this week, according to the trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia tonight won his second of three matches in the world pocket billiard championship by defeatin Joe Diehl of Rockford, Ill., 125 to 74, in twenty-one innings.

Mr. and Mrs. Payson McL. Merrill of this city and Syossett, L., I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Merrill's daughter, Miss Elinor Ladd, to William Ladd Storey, son of Mrs. Richard Cutts Storey of New York and Boston, and the late Mr. Storey.

Hans Christian Jacobaeus, lung specialist and Professor of Medicine at the Stockholm Medical Institute, died here today at the age of 58. Dr. Jacobaeus originated a method of cauterization of pleural adhesions.

The directors of the Chrysler Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $3 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 13 to stock of record of Nov. 12, compared to $3.50 a share paid on Sept. 10, making total distributions voted this year $10 a share.

Yale vs. Dartmouth at New Haven, Harvard vs. Princeton at Princeton, Columbia vs. Cornell at Ithaca, Notre Dame vs. Minnesota at Minneapolis, Fordham vs. North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Georgia Tech vs. Vanderbilt at Atlanta, Stanford vs. Oregon State at Palo Alto-merely a few of the choice plums on gridirons from coast to coast today.

Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said today that "the restoration of long-term confidence in the profit prospect is a first requisite to a renewed flow of capital and the establishment of security market conditions permissive of the anticipated flow is a second."

Four Concerns, pleading guilty to charges of unlawfully receiving rebates on interstate commerce shipments, were fined by Judge Phillip Forman in the United State District Court here today. ourt here today.

The celebration of the fifteenth anniversary of the march on Rome ended today with an imposing military ceremony at the Unknown Soldier's Tomb this morning, during which Premier Mussolini distributed medals to families of Italian Legionnaires who distinguished themselves in the fighting in Spain and were killed there, and the inauguration this afternoon of Aprilia, the fourth city built in the reclaimed Pontine marshes.

Prices of wheat were on the down grade today, largely in sympathy with foreign markets, and closing trades on the Board of Trade here were at net losses of 1/2 to 7/8 cent a bushel, the latter on the May, which dropped to 3/4 cent a bushel under the December.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, instituted today an investigation of the lawfulness of trucking rates in the Middle Atlantic States. Pending motor-carrier rate cases in this area were consolidated by the commission's order, and all motor carriers in the district that are subject to the Motor Carrier Act were made parties to the proceeding.

E. M. Asher, associate producer at Universal Studios, died today at the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital here after a stroke of paralysis. His age was 49. He had been active in the movies for seventeen years. He was formerly a salesman for Sol Lesser Enterprises.

Seymour Knox's Aurora polo team, Which will compete in the. Argentine open championship,. today deheated a pick-up quartet, led by Roberto Cavanagh, 8 to 6, in a practice match at the Hurlingham Club.

The Yale junior varsity eleven today won its annual game with the Dartmouth reserves, 7-6, Don Henry taking the ball 4 yards across for a touchdown for the Blue in five plays from the kickoff, after Halfback Chuck Wooster lad on three occasions dashed 20 yards. Bob Hopgood kicked the goal for what proved the winning point.

Groton School's football team remained undefeated, untied and unscored on this season by crushing English High, 34--0, today. V. McClelland made the first touchdown on a line buck and G. McClelland ran 20 yards for the second.
The dairy farmers union milk strike spread to a nineteenth county today as violence broke out anew in scattered up-State areas. The union claims a membership of 9,000 of the State's 135,000 dairymen.

Stockholders of the Anchor Cap Corporation were advised in letters sent to them yesterday by I. R. Stewart, president, that a special meeting had been called for Nov. 18 to act upon a contract for the acquisition of the Hocking Glass Company and to authorize changes in the capitalization of their company necessary to effect the merger.

News of the death in Genoa, Italy, of Herbert Bryant Turner, an early candid camera exponent who made a hobby of photographs of European royalty, has reached here. Mr. Turner, formerly a resident of Cambridge and Gloucester, died Wednesday.

Miss Katherine Schoonmaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Schoonmaker of this city, was married this afternoon to Frederick Burdett Town, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Edward Town of South Orange, in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, South Orange, by the rector, the Rev. F. Randall Williams, assisted by the Rev. Edward Johnson of the First Unitarian Church, Orange.

The New York of the HamburgAmerican Line will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports, bringing Mrs. Michael MacWhite, wife of the Irish Free State Minister to the United States; Victor Neumann. Robert Luethge, Wilhelm Rodde, Edmund Tuerholzer, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Weisel, Mrs. Hans Strack, Georg Thiergartner, Raymond J. Connell, Mr. and Mrs. F. X. Monville, Wilhelm Braun, J. Wayne Tomb and Mr. and Mrs. Philip Schmitz.

John Sloan, etcher and artist, predicted today another "chamber of horrors" in murals done by union painters for the 1939 New York World's Fair. "It will be the worst aggregation of wall paintings ever assembled," the 65-year-old artist said as he closed his rambling Summer home.

As its answer to a strike called in midafternoon, the Davega-City Radio Stores, Inc., telegraphed more than 800 employes in its thirty-one stores throughout the metropolitan area last night that, effective Monday, the company would institute a -13 1/2 per cent pay increase, two weeks' vacation with pay and a holiday schedule with pay.
Chief Justice William H. Waste said tonight that the State Supreme Court would announce its decision tomorrow on the habeas corpus

Women sufferers from neurosis are nearly three times-more numerous than men, according to a report based on a study of life -insurance policy holders presented yesterday to the final session of the fortyeighth-annual meeting of the Association of Life Insurance Medical Directors of America.

ALPERS--Entered into rest, Ferdinand Alpers, beloved husband of Auguste Alpers and father of Edith, in his sixty-third year. Masonic Services Sunday evening, 8 o'clock, at funeral chapel. 188th St., Corner Webster Ave., Bronx. Funeral private.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court unanimously ruled yesterday that the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico must answer a suit brought by Louis Gallopin, a Swiss citizen, to collect his pro rata share of funds received by the committee for distribution to bondholders.

The marriage of Miss Abbie Louise English, daughter of Mrs. Richard W. A. English of this city and the late Dr. English, to George Clark Jelliffe, son of Mrs. Maltby D. Jelliffe, also of Jersey City, and the late Mr. Jelliffe, took place here today in the Old Bergen Church.
Rutgers University prepared today to greet more than 1,000 members of the alumni and hundreds of other guests at the annual Homecoming Day exercises tomorrow.

Inability to find an available leading man of the proper caliber has caused Grand National to revise its schedule for Anna Sten's return to the American screen and it now appears probable that Dr. Eugene Frenke's "Don't Lead With Your Heart" will supersede the Victor Schertzinger musical, "Love Me Again."

The stubborn refusal of all official sources to confirm Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's own assertion that he has resigned his post as Reich Minister of Economics and that his resignation has become effective is being interpreted as an indication that some sort of warfare is going on behind the Reich economic facade.

Preliminary gifts of more than $263,000 have been received in the United Hospital Campaign to raise a minimum of $3,171,000 in behalf of ninety-two voluntary hospitals of the city and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, it was reported yesterday by John W. Davis, general chairman of the campaign.
On the very stage where was first disclosed to the world on Oct. 29, 1787, that masterpiece of masterpieces, Mozart's "Don Giovanni," tonight was celebrated its 150th birthday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va.--Warnings against the mounting cost of radio talent, the practice of both advertisers and agencies in bidding against each other for air shows that "click" and emphasis on the necessity of improving space buying, have been among the chief topics of discussion between members of the Association of National Advertisers and their agency representatives in their closed sessions here.
Mrs. Hannah Leerburger, former president of the Sisterhood of Central Synagogue, died on Wednesday in her home at 1,239 Madison Avenue after a lone illness.

A group of 100 interest-paying realty bond issues, on the basis of payments made or declared from June through November, shows an average return on principal of 4.08 per cent for the 1937 period, as compared with 3.18 per cent for 1936 and 2.67 for 1935, according to a study by Eli T. Watson Co., Inc.

The persistent report mentioned in these dispatches yesterday that the Reichstag will soon be called to hear and ratify some decision of Chancellor Hitler is today coupled with a rumor that the Fuehrer is preparing a speech of proclamation in which two specific demands will be made and some sort of program outlined for their realization.

The alleged monopoly of electrical construction work by Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers was depicted yesterday as costing the city thousands of dollars in connection with school projects where low-bidding nonunion electrical contractors have been barred in favor of union shops.

The United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries, excluding the Philadelphia Gas Works Company, reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 net. income of $27,064,920 available for common stocks of utility subsidiaries after prefered dividends, compared with $26,049,050 for the preceding twelve months.

A total of 3,818 properties had been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation at the end of last month, it was announced today, and the number of sales reported in September, 593, was the largest for any month since it started operations.

The stock markets here were quietly firm today and most sections went ahead. Gilt-edge issues were well supported, while foreign bonds showed little change. International shares rose sharply in the afternoon following more optimistic reports from Wall Street.

Dr. Nelson Millard Chitterling, Bloomfield dental surgeon, died today at his home here after a brief illness. He was born in the section of Bloomfield now Glen Ridge sixty-seven years ago, the son of Joseph Smith Chitterling and Mary E. Hardcastle Chitterling.

Manhattan Alterations Hester St. 122; to 6-story tenement and stores; Citizens Savings Bank. mortgagee in possession, 58 Bowery, owner; R. Teichman, architect; cost $10,000. 15th St, 401-59 W; to 6-story bakery; National Biscuit Co, premises, owner; O. H. Spin. architect; cost $3.500.

Elihu R. Lyman, president of the Massachusetts Gear and Tool Company here, died tonight at his home, 57 Elm Street, at the age of 53. Born in Belchertown, the son of the late Rev. Payson W. Lyman of Fall River and Caroline E. Root, he was graduated from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in 1902.

R. P. Hill of Oklahoma City, Demooratio Representative from the Fifth Oklahoma District, died in a hospital today after suffering a heart attack. He was 63 years old. Mr. Hill had been a member of the House Judiciary Committee.

Rutgers will start the same team against Lehigh tomorrow that faced Princeton last Saturday, Coach Tasker announced today on the eve of the thirty-fourth renewal of the series dating back to 1882. A snappy signal drill and defense against passes constituted the final tune-up of the Scarlet.

Teachers, by taking a more active part in the life of the community, could aid in raising the educational level of this country, those attending the ninety-second annual meeting of the New York State Teachers Association were told yesterday.

Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Oct. 23 totaled 773,353 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 36,591 cars, or 4.5 per cent Fewer than in the preceding week;

Frank Van Rensselaer Reynolds, descendant of one of the oldest families here, died at the Greenwich Hospital this morning after a ten-day illness at the age of 66. He had been suffering for some time from a heart ailment.

The thirteen-story apartment house on the northeast corner of Riverside, Drive and Ninetieth Street was bid in yesterday at auction for $750,000 by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the plaintiff in an action against the Regnum East Estate Corporation, defendant, to recover on a judgment of $1,091,200.

Although a peace meeting between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization committees is scheduled for next Thursday, another rift in the relationships of the two organizations developed today.

Trade practice agreements without price fixing were urged for the leather--tanning industry by Dr. A. P. Haake, managing director of the National Association of Furniture- Manufacturers, in an address- today before the Tanners' Council of America, meeting at the Palmer House.

Dr: Wilfrid Greif, former first vice president and a director of the American I. G. Chemical Corporation- and one-time chairman of the executive committee of the Board of Trade" for German-American Commerce, died last Thursday at Baden Baden.

The first live quetzals ever shipped out of their Central American habitat arrived yesterday on the United Fruit liner Platano and were escorted to the Bronx Zoo with the care and tenderness befitting such valuable acquisitions.

Today's Town Hall recitals are those of Carol Moorland, pianist, in the afternoon, and of Richard Tauber, tenor, in the evening. Ignatz Waghalter, German conductor, has been appointed conductor of the orchestra of the Academy of Allied Arts.

The last one-day tournament on the schedule of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association took place today over the Knickerbocker golf course, and. resulted in a triple tie for low gross honors among Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont who posted 43, 45--88;

A field of thirteen has been named overnight for the $5,000 added Scarsdale Handicap, closing-day feature today at Empire where the regular racing season on the Jockey Club tracks will come to an end. Entered are Thorson and Busy K., who finished within a nose of each other-in the Yorktown last Saturday.

One of prep school football's outstanding traditional games, bringing together the Hill School and Lawrenceville,. heads today's extensive program of schoolboy gridiron activity. The thirty-second chapter in their old and colorful series is to take place at Lawrenceville, N. J., this afternoon.

A group representing the New York Stock Exchange and brokerage houses conferred today with William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in a move to bring about a mutual understanding and arranged
Supreme Court Justice Rosenman refused yesterday to order the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., to produce its books and accounts for inspection.

The recent series of personal and political attacks on the Prime Minister of Belgium reached a crisis on Monday in the resignation of the Cabinet and the designation a few days later of Henri de Man, Socialist Minister of Finance, to form a new Cabinet.
Stephen Hero, in Strathmore House, 404 Riverside Drive: Howard C. Mercer, in 55 W 55th St; Michael Ross. Thomas J. McShane, in 41 Central Park W; Potter, Hamilton Co, Inc, broker.

Miss Lida Bergen Plant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Plant of this place, and Harry A. Lore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lore of Millburn, N. J., were married in the Methodist Episcopal Church here tonight.

In an amended report to the Securities and Exchange 'Commission for the fiscal year 1935,' the Standard Oil Company of Kansas told of a resolution granting a bonus to all employes equal, to Federal income taxes upon their salaries. Under this resolution, C. B. Wrightsman, president, received a cash bonus of $7,476.
Charles R. Bettes, retired engineer, died yesterday at his home, 1,179 Beach Ninth Street, Far Rockaway, Queens, after a short illness. He was 74 years old.

Members of the Flying Caravan of five women who will make a 17,000-mile tour of South America by air for the People's Mandate to End War and urge ratification of the treaties signed at the Inter-American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires received a hearty send-off today from Sumner Welles as Acting Secretary of State.

Fair and warmer weather after three days of cold rain were promised tonight for Cornell's twenty-fifth game with Columbia tomorrow on Schoellkopf Field. The Big Red squad drilled under fair skies late today.

A new method of accrediting secondary schools in which the educational process rather than the material facilities of the institutions forms the basis for evaluation was -outlined yesterday to a group of educators in conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Base data which may be expected to throw light on many labor and social problems will be among the by-products of the National Unemployment Census, according to John D. Biggers, administrator, who made public today a copy of the information and instruction pamphlet to be furnished to postmasters soon in connection with the census to be undertaken on Nov. 16.

AMERICAN football and its cousin soccer having taken root abroad, many countries have issued stamps honoring these sports. A few of the sets are deemed to be of the punt-pass-andprayer variety; they fill no existing postal need, and are passed on to collectors.

While the Dionne quintuplets were playing happily at their home in Callander today, scientists here were presenting, for the benefit of children everywhere, a detailed picture of their health, minds and bodies, the most complete bne of its kind since the children were porn three years and five months ago.

WHEN the voters of Greater New York go to the polls on Tuesday, it is a pretty safe odds-on bet that a sizable percentage of them will do so with a fresh reminiscence of one of the most surprising pieces of political persuading that has ever been put to the public.

Miss Jane Kaufman, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Kaufman of 623 Park Avenue, has completed the junior committee, of which she is chairman, for the dinner dance, floor show and fashion parade to be held on Nov. 12 at the Lombardy for the benefit of the Manhattanville Nursery Association.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Langley Pierpont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harlan Trimble Pierpont, to William Waldo Grose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Grose of Great Neck, L. I., was announced today. Miss Pierpont is a member of the Junior League.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Beulah Ter Bush, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Ter Bush of this city, to Terry Stewart Hinkle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Terry Hinkle of New York.

Dr. Alexander C. Flick, State historian, will be among the speakers at the annual luncheon of the United States Daughters of 1812, New York branch, Thursday, at the Hotel McAlpin, at which Mrs. Bennett A. Wilson of Buffalo, State president, will preside.

New Yorkers who want to go to Reno were advised yesterday by the Right Rev. Thomas Jenkins, Bishop of Nevada, to "bring your wives with you." The Bishop spoke at a luncheon of the Protestant Episcopal Missions Committee of the New York Diocese Women's Auxiliary at the Hotel Astor.

Reports that an effort will be made by furniture buyers to drive down quotations on new lines were current in the wholesale market here yesterday as buyers and exhibitors left for the midseason furniture market opening at Chicago tomorrow.

PARENTHOOD: Fritz B. Talbot, Emeritus Professor of Pediatrics at the Harvard Medical School, issued a warning last week before a group of physicians, parents and psychologists. "If you want to breed normal children," he said, "you'd better not have too much brains.
Judge Charles S. Bell took under advisement today a motion for a directed verdict of acquittal in the case of Anna Marie Hahn, accused of the poison slaying of 78-year-old Jacob Wagner.

The decision of Myron C. Taylor not to accept re-election as chairman of the board of directors of the United States Steel Corporation at the annual meeting of stockholders on April 4, 1938, confirmed to the directors at their meeting on Tuesday, foreshadows the early consummation of his program to modernize and reorganize the corporation.

Harold W. Hastings, Demooratic candidate for District Attorney, who debated with Thomas E. Dewey yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the League for Political Education at the Hotel Astor and remained behind for a question period, while his Republican opponent left for another appointment, assailed Mr. Dewey last night as "an arrant coward and fourflusher."

The unbeaten Chicago Bears, riding along on a five-game winning streak and heading toward the Western Divisional championship of the National Football League, will encounter the New York Giants, the Eastern leaders, at the Polo Grounds today, starting at 2:30 P. M. A crowd of 40.000 is expected to witness this professional gridiron classic.

Byron Nelson, Reading (Pa.) pro, and Eugenio Dunezat of the home forces, fired rounds of 70, three under par, to tie for the lead in the first eighteen holes of the Argentine open golf championship over the Sanandres course today.

Representative Coffee, Nebraska Democrat, said today that there was "no justification" for compulsory control of domestic production of farm commodities figuring in imports. For crops of which the United States produces an exportable surplus, he declared in a radio address, he favored.
ASSURED by a friendly Congress that it will have on hand on June 30, 1940, its full authorized assortment of 2.
Before a Home-coming Day crowd of 4,000 the Shippensburg Teachers today defeated Bloomsburg Teachers, 20 to 0. In the second period Shippensburg drove sixty yards for a touchdown, Sweeney going over.

ADIKES--Oct. 30, 1937, Thomas, in his eighty-second year, beloved husband of Catherine and loving father of Mrs. Fred Kirtland, Mrs. Alice A. Stricker, Catherine, John, Henry K., Laurence, Walter and Philip. Funeral on Tuesday, Nov. 2, from his home, 41-64 Main St., Flushing, at 9:30 A. M.; thence to St. Michael's Church, at 10 A. M. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery.

In the face of an assertion by the State Board of Mediation that their strike represented a violation of a binding contract, members of 'Local 76B of the Upholsterers Union resumed yesterday a sit-down strike in the Long Island City warehouse of the Ludwig Baumann furniture company.

The ninety-fourth anniversary of the founding of B'nai B'rith and its mother lodge, New York Lodge No. 1, was celebrated last week at the Hotel Astor, with more than 1,000 persons in attendance. The event included addresses by the guests of honor, Dr. Stephen S.

In an attempt to clear up "a gross injustice to the Health Department, which has done fine work in the past and has been used too often as a political football," Dr. Louis I. Harris, former Health Commissioner, issued a statement yesterday condemning Mayor La Guardia's nineteenth lesson on municipal government, delivered last Monday, and toss also the Mayor's radio interview with Health Commissioner John L. Rice on Thursday.

MR. KROLL has written an interesting, indeed an amazing, book about a share-cropper's family, tied to the earth by toil, and of their constant wanderings to find better landowners for whom to work in the West Tennessee lowlands.

At Swampscott, Mass., in 1919, blond 5-year-old Alice Alexander was producing plays in the backyard of her father's country place Today, at 23, Miss Alexander sits in the darkened auditorium of the Little Theatre in Forty-fourth Street, watching rehearsals of "Right This Way," a musical which is scheduled for Broadway next month under her direction, and produced with her own money.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Oscar E. Kupferman of 152 East Ninety-fourth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Kupferman, to Robert V. Mansfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Mansfield of 1,016 Fifth Avenue.

Virginians will name a new Governor Tuesday, but no one is excited about the outcome. Leaders of the dominant Democratic Party say they have organized well to assure an overwhelming vote for James H. Price, and to make possible a big attendance at the next State Convention.

Now that the planting of trees and shrubs and especially of big trees is being done more extensively than ever in the Fall, the owners of new places, and those reconstructing old gardens, find interesting information this season in the result of a long series of experiments conducted by one of the country's, leading tree care organizations.
The Book Manufacturers Institute will install and operate a complete mechanical plant at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair so that those who like books may also see how one is made.
"TESTAMENT OF CALIBAN" (or as it might be, "From Heimdal to Mary Baker Eddy") is the autobiography of a celebrated Swedish-American sculptor.

At a cost that varies from 50 cents to 80 cents a month more than 1,200,000 employes of firms and members of families have made it possible for themselves to receive the best of hospital care when they need it. The plan has been endorsed by the American Hospital Association and the American College of Surgeons.
War Admiral, Samuel D. Riddle's little brown colt, scampered to his seventh straight triumph today in the $19,100 Washington Handicap and became the leading money winner of the year.

Backed by the Vargas government and the military forces, the Brazilian National Defense, a new civilian organization designed to rally all elements. of the nation against communism, met today to lay the foundation for a fight on all fronts against the"Red peril."

The survival of private educational institutions depends upon their ability to justify their right to existence, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, declared in his annual report to the trustees. "Wealth alone," he said, "will not save them."
THE portrait of General Franco, leader of the Spanish Rebels, has been placed on a 10-centimo dark brown stamp released by Spanish Morocco, which the Insurgents control.

Mongolia's claim as the only place in the world where dinosaur eggs have been found still holds good here. A batch of "rock eggs," found last year by a road crew blasting out a highway to Waterton Park, 100 miles southwest of here, have turned out to be just that.
Denied in the first half by a spirited Iowa State line, Missouri struck in the third and fourth quarters to hand the Cyclones a 12-0 homecoming. defeat before a crowd of 11,000 today.

A PROGRAM of traffic and safety reforms, which includes some drastic changes, has been submitted to the Common Council of Detroit by the State Highway Department. Some of the major recommendations are:
Mayor La Guardia's office acted yesterday to curb Democratic officeholders supporting Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor from campaigning for Mr. La Guardia under the guise of spurious Communist signs.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Yaffe of 895 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Eleanor Yaffe, to Laurence Covitz, nephew of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Winegarden of Flint, Mich., with whom he has made his home for many years.

Members of the Sacred Heart Alumnae Associations of Manhattanville, Maplehurst, 1 East Ninetyfirst Street, and Noroton, Conn., will hold their annual luncheon and bridge on Wednesday in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

The newly formed London International Theatre Club, which aims to encourage young playwrights, actors and designers, hopes to keep the Duke of York's Theatre open every Sunday night during the Winter.

Agreements affecting eleven milk plants with an output of 200,000 quarts daily were announced as signed tonight at the Dairy Farmers Union headquarters. However, union officials said that the strike would continue with redoubled vigor until all plants were signed up.

When many citizens were asking this week what the New Deal might do to relieve the business and stock market recessions, it was regarded as significant that a number of business and financial leaders, among them W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the Business Advisory Council, called on President Roosevelt at Hyde Park.

Despite the vexatious problems confronting real estate at the present time, such as high taxes, overassessments, rising costs of materials and labor, uncertainty regarding government competition and pending adjustments of the Mortgage Moratorium Act, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, told the members of the Westchester Clearing House Association recently in White Plains that there are some agreeable compensations.
THE center of interest in the exhibition field shifted sharply to museums last week, with a number of unusual attractions in New York and outof-town institutions.
Apparently beaten as they left the field for the half, Boston University's players rallied to score two touchdowns for a 14-to-12 victory over Washington University today.

The first book ever printed in what is now the United States will be exhibited at the Book Fair. It is designated on the title page "The Whole Booke of Psalmes" and is dated in Cambridge, 1640. Only eleven copies are known to be in existence.

Egypt is now suffering the first growingpains since her recent birth as an independent nation. To describe the present state of affairs here as a "political struggle" would be a gross misrepresentation. It is rather a struggle of personalities.

Cultivation of "consumer goodwill" was urged upon members of the apartment house group in the management division of. the Real Estate Board of New York at their meeting last week by Clement E. Merowit. He cited the tax situation as an instance of the value of this "good-will" attitude.

Miss Margaret Watts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Thomas Watts Jr. of this city, was married to John Overton Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Brosius Henderson of Washington, and Trivium, Bedford County, Va., here this afternoon in the Langhorne Chapel of the Virginia Episcopal School by the Rev. Dr. Carleton Barnwell, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

Capper Publications, Inc., of Topeka, Kan., of which United States Senator Arthur Capper is president, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the issuance of 4 per cent, six-month, first-mortgage Series 2 bonds; 41 per cent, one-year,

Members of Mexico's oil unions were in open mutiny today against the government after breaking the newly written anti-strike compact with the foreign petroleum companies operating in Mexico by paralyzing the key pipe line from the east coast to the capital.

As the ruins of Chapel smoulder into dust and ashes and the cold of North China's Winter- chills the blood of Japanese armies, the flag of the Rising Sun is planted above new conquests and flies now above a territory apparently almost swept clean of major Chinese resistance.

Miss Amparo Iturbi, Spanish pianist, and Ossy Renardy, 16-yearold Hungarian violinist, will be the artists on the opening program this week of the Friday morning musicales of the Criterion Society, to be held at the Hotel Plaza.
ONE of the most hopeful trends in the field of motor legislation is the tendency of the country's lawmakers to steer away from new experiments in regulating use of the automobile.

Pope Pius returned to the Vatican today from his Summer residence, Castel Gandolfo, where he. spent six months recuperating from the serious illness that threatened his life at the close of last year and early this year.
A Harvard football team that struck with almost brutal fury came roaring back into a place in the sun today. The long drought in Crimson major game victories is over, and, at Princeton's expense too.

THE American Music Alliance is celebrating its seventh anniversary in the course of the next fortnight, when musical events will be presented every evening. The festival opens tomorrow night at the Alliance auditorium, at 114 West Fifty-fourth Street, with a Beethoven program including the Septet, the Sonata in A, Op. 12, No. 2, and the clarinet trio in D flat, Op. 11, No. 4.

Pleading for a changing attitude which would permit women schola??s to lead a "full life," Dr. Cecelia Payne Gaposchkin of Harvard Observatory said today that the psychological effects of sex prejudice were more difficult for the woman scientist to combat than lack of opportunities.

The Panthers of Pitt, minus two of their big stars, rumbled to a 25-to14 triumph today in their twentyfourth annual "back-yard" tussle with Carnegie Tech. The valiant Tartans, however, had their share of glory, crossing the hitherto unpassed Pitt goal line twice.

Richard K. Buechler of 57 East Eighty-eighth Street has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Marian Louise Buechler. to Harold S. Cohn, son of Arthur L. Cohn, also of this city, and the late Mrs. Hattie J. Cohn.

The Hazel-Atlas Glass Company and its subsidiaries reported yes terday for the year ended on Oct 2 a net profit of $3,230,244 after de preciation, Federal income taxes loss on property retired and other charges, but before surtax on undistributed profits.

Mrs. Hildegard Huebener, wife of Dr. Theodore Huebener, assistant director of foreign languages in the New York City school system, died yesterday at Hunts Point Hospital, the Bronx, after a short illness. Also surviving are four children, Albert, Theodore Jr., Bertholz and Hildegard, and her mother, Mrs. Louise von Belling.
Alabama Poly vs. Tennessee at Birmingham. Amherst vs. Trinity at Amherst. Baylor vs. Texas at Waco. California vs. Washington at Berkeley. Centenary vs. Texas Christian at Shreveport.

More than 200 persons attended the funeral services yesterday in the chapel of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, for Mrs. Alice Bartlett Stimson, club leader, who died on Wednesday at her home, 25 Claremont Avenue, at the age of 83.

Miss Helen Merion Burke, caugnter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Burke of East Orange, was married to Lloyd Elton Castell, son of Mrs. William Castell, this afternoon in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stafford Blake.

AS in the Zoroastrian cosmogony, there are two powerful warring influences in Holly wood-the commercial, or children of darkness, and the artistic; or children of light-and it is in the thin ranks of the latter that Leo McCarey has always unashamedly aligned himself.

A method for settling jurisdictional disputes which is hailed by some authorities as "a great forward step" in solving some of the problems of builders and ,union workers in the New York.district is now in effect.
Mayor La Guardia told an enthusiastic audience of about 14,000 persons in Madison Square Garden last night that he had smashed the "rotten" Tammany machine once and he was going to do it again.

By order of his government, the Italian Ambassador to France, Vittorio Cerruti, has informed the Quai d'Orsay that he will leave Paris tomorrow for an indefinite period and that during his absence the Embassy will be in charge of- the Counselor, Renato Prunas.

Like other little girls who have to stay home and study their lessons while their mother and father go traveling, the future Queen of England and her 7-year-old sister have been left behind while the King and Queen are enjoying shooting at Sandringham.

An important step toward further knowledge of ultramicroscopic life' has been made by Netherlands chemist, Dr. L. W. Janssen, who has succeeded in tifying the chemical compound held responsible for hoof and mouth disease. He said it was a phosphoric protein.

A reception and tea will be given on Thursday afternoon at Huntington House of Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, for William Fleming, pianist, whose New York debut recital on the night of Dec. 3 at Carnegie Hall will be a benefit for Huntington House.

As the initial step in a program to discover the attitude of the consumer toward advertising and advertised products, the Advertising Women of New York will hold on Wednesday evening the first in a series of forums planned in cooperation with leaders of women's clubs.

El Salvador, joining other Latin-American governments, will use a special set of airmail stamps in celebration of the 150th anniversary:of the American Constitution. The issue will consist of 630,000 stamps of various values.

Dick Riffle's touchdown climaxing the Lions' 38- yard drive in the third quarter, gave Albright a 6-0 victory over Bucknell today before 8,000 fans. It was the fourth triumph for Coach Dietz's warriors, who are undefeated and have not had their goal line crossed, this season.

JULES VERNES of radio were quick to foresee wide uses of television cameras in warfare when the tele-eyes were first introduced. They envisaged aviators, screened by clouds, suspending a radio "eye" down toward the earth to spy on the enemy and telecast the scene to headquarters just as the microphone picks up sound.

The decline in the refunding of bonds prior to maturity which set in early this year was continued in the month ending today. The total of bonds called for payment dropped not only below that of September but was less than half the amount redeemed in October, 1936.

With the Narragansett race track at Pawtucket closed by Rhode Island troops, the struggle between the Racing Association's managing director, Walter E. O'Hara, and Governor Robert Emmet Quinn has now become a war of libel suits.
Alabama's Crimson tide, visioning a fifth Rose Bowl bid, swept over Kentucky, 41-to-0, this afternoon in a homecoming day game. A crowd of 13,000 watched the contest.
With the resignation of Paul van Zeeland from the Premiership on the eve of the nine-power conference at Brussels, Belgium has at least temporarily lost the services of a promising young leader.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with great interest the exchange of letters in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 26 about conditions of employment in present-day Germany, a subject of much controversy.
Villanova blasted the University of Detroit from the ranks of the nation's undefeated and untied football teams by sweeping to a 7-to 0 triumph over the Titans in a fierce battle today.
Unbeaten Baylor, relying on its aerial machine, defeated Texas Christian University,.6-O, today, in as thrilling an offensive football show as the southwest conference ever produced.

Chrysanthemums will be featured in a brilliant, Fall display at the thirtieth annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, opening Thursday evening, for four days, at the American Museum of Natural. History.

An exhibition of sketches and pottery made by children living in rural mountain areas of the South will be on display at a meeting of the New York Branch of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance to be held Friday afternoon in Room A at the Metropolitan Museum of Fine Art.

TO the foreign critics who fear that Hollywood motion pictures are imposing the manners of an alien civilization on their movie-going compatriots, it would seem a paradox to complain that American films are not sufficiently American.

A luncheon and fashion show under the auspices of the Rosemarian Association, the alumnae society of Rosemary Hall in Greenwich, Conn., one of the oldest schools for girls in the East, will take place Nov. 8 at Sherry's.

The city's newest and finest motorized equipment, followed by colorful floats and other vehicles of social, civic and business organizations, took part yesterday afternoon in Mayor La Guardia's annual safety parade.
THIS is a book of crimes Specifically, it is a book of insurance frauds. But to classify it thus gives a quite inadequate impression of its variety.

Josephine Roche merely changed battlefronts today when she left the government service for her own Colorado coal business. "Wherever you are, you can make the same fight for people." explained the only woman who ever has served as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury. "And I may be back. I can't prophesy."
Voters are confronted with the largest off-year ballot ever submitted in Suffolk County. This fact and the record registration indicate a heavy vote on Tuesday despite a lack of issues.

With 5,000,000 applications for social security account numbers received as of Sept. 30, and with about 3,000,000 account numbers issued to employes covered by New York State's Unemployment Insurance Law, the State of New York, as of Sept. 15, had credited to its account in the Unemployment Trust Fund $73,163,174.
Nonfraternity men are setting the pace in Franklin and Marshall College's scholastic ranks, according to averages of the second semester of the 1936-37 term announced by Dean Richard W. Bomberger.

CONSTRUCTION of the longawaited Union Passenger Terminal in Los Angeles is under way and by the latter part of 1938 trains of the Santa Fe, Union Pacific and Southern Pacific are expected to be using the $10,000,000 structure.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Martin of this community, who will observe the fifty-fifth anniversary of their marriage on Monday, will be entertained at a dinner tomorrow at the home of Mrs. Lazelle Whitmore of Paterson.

The Fordham University Glee Club looks forward to a series of eight concerts this year, ending in the traditional Town Hall concert in March. Besides the Town Hall recital, the outstanding event of the Glee Club's itinerary will be a concert on Nov. 22 at the Philadelphia

Those first five years of the infant's life when almost anything can happen-and does-are indeed the hardest, the most significant for his future and, therefore, most troublesome to parents lacking any training in "the practical art of child management," statements made yesterday by experts in the upbringing of the pre-school child agreed.

MORE than 5,600 pedestrians literally "walked to death" and more than65,000 suffered injury-many crippled for life--by failure to observe the rudimentary principles of highway safety, the Keystone Automobile Club finds in a survey of pedestrian accidents in Pennsylvania covering a period of eight years and eight months.
EVELOPMENTS in Cuba have brought the island republic's recently issued "Association of American Writers and Artists" stamps squarely into the spotlight in a way that is unique in philately's history.

"Men are attracted to Women with deep voices," declared Mrs. Allys Dwyer Vergara, Associate Professor of Speech at the College of New Rochelle, outlining a nation-wide broadcast on speech culture, which she will give on Nov. 8.
WITH war and its alarms overshadowing Europe and Asia, the eyes of the tourist are turning more and more toward South America.
In a story-book finish to a thrillpacked final quarter, Yale struck through the air with ten seconds left to play to tie Dartmouth, 9-9, in the Bowl this Indian Summer day.

A man who set out from his native village of Manosa in Sirmur State with his two sons more than two months ago on a "crawling pilgrimage" to Hardwar, 300 miles distant, has arrived in the sacred city.

A drop in export orders which has materialized in the midst of an active season and at a time when volume normally would be approaching its annual peak, mystified exporters of manufactured goods here this week.
British, French and Italian admirals conferred today aboard the British battleship Barham in Bizerta Harbor on methods of applying the Nyon accord for combating "piracy" in the Mediterranean.

Mrs. Paul I. Zimmerman, who was librarian with the Enoch Pratt library here before she moved West some years ago, died yesterday while on a vacation tour in Montana. She was descended from an old Maryland family.

The Hedgerow Theatre at Moylan-Rose Valley will open its Winter season Thursday, playing three performances weekly, on Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights. The six-daya-week schedule will be resumed April 21.

ANY woman, accustomed to having hats go out of style before she has quite got used to them, knows why automobiles have their own style show every year. She can afford an indulgent smile in the direction of the automobile industry, for she is used to lightning changes in design.

Edwin Maxwell Loye of Bronxville and Gardner A. Dailey of San Francisco are the winners of the two first awards in the tenth annual small-house competition for which cash prizes of $2,300 are given by House Beautiful Magazine.

The Yale 150-pound team today defeated the Rutgers lightweights, 13-0, in their annual game, practically again assuring the Elis the intercollegiate 150-pound championship. For two years the Yale lightweight eleven, coached by Ken Loeffier, has not lost a game.

A te perfect place kick by Leo Todd was the margin by which Moravian College defeated Susquehanna University today, 7 to 6. Moravian scored in the second period when two consecutive first downs placed the ball on the Crusaders' 3-yard line.
Plans for liquidating the Nansen Refugee Office by the end of 1938 in accordance with League Assembly resolutions were made at a session of the office's governing body just concluded here.

Lieut. Col. Edgar Fremont Haines, Medical Corps, U.S.A., and Mrs. Haines gave a dance last night at the Governors Island Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Meredith Haines, and simultaneously to announce her engagement to Donald Frederick Taylor of New York.

One of New York's best known charities, the Community of St. Johnland, will be the beneficiary of the performance on Saturday night of Mozart's comic opera, "Cosi Fan Tutte," by the Salzburg Opera Guild at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

More than 500 persons attended yesterday a memorial service for Samuel Gappel, 34-year-old treasurer of Local 442 of the Painters and Decorators Union, who was slain last Oct. 2 as he was entering his house at 292 Delancey Street.

Miss Eva Le Gallienne, actress, has dissolved her new repertory company in Westport, Conn., it was disclosed yesterday. Arthur S. Friend, her attorney, said that "practical difficulties" forced the abandonment of-the project, which had been largely financed by Mrs. Edward Bok of Philadelphia.
NEW COMMAND: The United States Army during the World War did its utmost to keep down venereal diseases among its men.

In planting the cactus garden slopes and ground levels will, together with the varying heights of the plants chosen, add interest. For a desert garden a top layer of white sand will prove effective. To secure a satisfactory effect everything must be in scale.

Fordham was hotter than theweather today-and it was 80 degrees at the Town Hall-as the unbeaten Rams hammered North Carolina from the ranks of the undefeated, 14 to 0, before a capacity and disconsolate crowd of 24,000 in the Kenan Memorial Stadium.

The trapshooters of the New York Athletic Club opened their Winter season at Travers Island yesterday. Fifty-five gunners came to the firing line, with three in a tie for the High-Over-All Cup, at 99 out of 100 targets.
Six seniors who have distinguished themselves during their college careers have been tapped by Khoda, secret honorary society established at Stevens Institute of Technology in 1909.

ONE of the biggest problems confronting engineers has been that of finding a way to prevent the transfer of road noises and vibrations into the body. As a result of a long period of testing, Buick has developed for 1938 a new system of body mounting, called "silent zone" mounting.

IN recent years the world has become increasingly familiar with the word "planning." Used first in its new meaning by the writers of books on economics, it is now heard with ever greater frequency from the lips of statesmen and government officials. Secretary Wallace talks constantly of agricultural planning. The President has advocated planning for many aspects of our economic life.

A pageant entitled "Kosciuszko's Dream" and based on episodes in the life of General Thaddeus Kosciuszko, Polish patriot and American Revolutionary war hero, will feature the fifth annual Night in Poland Ball which will be held on Jan. 28 in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE value of a supercharger on an automobile engine is illustrated in the motor specifications of the 1938 Graham line. The Special, which has an unsupercharged engine, develops ninety horsepower. The supercharger, with exactly the same engine, 116 horsepower.

The undergraduate managers of Princeton University's athletic teams will give a formal ball in the university gymnasium next Friday evening in honor of the Dartmouth students attending the PrincetonDartmouth football game on Saturday, Walter W. Johnson, '38, of Pelham Manor, N. Y., president of the Managers Club, announced today.

Fighting back a supposedly mighty Minnesota team which had figured to sweep it right off the gridiron, Notre Dame today rose to the heights to defeat the Golden Gophers in one of the major surprises of the season by the narrow margin of 7 to 6.

The engagement was announced today of Miss Olive Bowman, daughter of Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University, and Mrs. Bowman, to Dr. Walter Henry Gerwig Jr., son of Mr. and Walter Henry Gerwig of Parkersberg, W. Va.
Dr. and Mrs. John Miller of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Miller, to Rector Thomson Davol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Davol Jr. of Stamford.

In the forty-eight-hour interval that remains before the mob scene at the polls, the forty women candidates awaiting the verdict of the electorate in New York State are not sitting passively, biting their nails and debating their chances.

Employment in the manufacturing industries of the country is being seriously affected by the surplus profits tax, according to the results of a poll of a representative cross-section of manufacturing in this country announced yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.
A powerful Baldwin-Wallace football team of Berea, Ohio, invaded Pratt Field for the first time today to give a convincing display of speed, power and passing to swamp Springfield College, 30-to 6.

In the national election on Nov. 3, 1936, Maine and Yermont were the only two States in the Union which failed to give a majority to Franklin D. Roosevelt. In the following dispatcshes sentiment toward the President in those States a year afterward is sounded.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The annual football game between the University of Delaware and Pennsylvania Military College next Saturday evening is the highlight on the coming week's social calendar in the resort.
One of the liveliest and certainly one of the most highly personalMayoralty campaigns of recent years will reach its climax when New York City's voters go to the polls next Tuesday morning.

Miss Olive May Van Divort, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Edgar Van Divort of this place, was married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Congregational Church to Robert Edward Fendrich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Fendrich, also of Nutley, by the pastor, the Rev. Robert Falconer.

Discarding conventional education methods in the belief that the teacher's basic interest should be in boys and girls rather than in the subject matter to be taught, the School of Education at Syracuse University has introduced a unified program in professional education to a group of eighty-eight juniors this Fall.
Panzer College of East Orange, N. J., conquered Lowell Textile today, 19 to 0. The visitors had too many aerial guns for the local team and after an' even first period, their attack began to click.

Gains in Christmas trade of at least 5 per cent over a year ago are likely, but the real test of the retail trade situation will come in the first quarter of 1938, according to the consensus of retail merchandising executives last week.

The marriage of Miss Caroline Hoopes Smedley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace W. Smedley of Ardmore, to James Metcalf Joslin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Joslin of Winchester, Mass., took place here this afternoon in the Haverford Friends Meeting House.

Two more famous tones in Old Paris have sounded their last in the symphony of this vibrant city, for Foyot's, one of its most renowned restaurants, is closing its doors and the Moulin Rouge is to be pulled down.
Jay C. Flippen has been re-elected Abbot of the Friars Club, it was announced yesterday. Others elected were Bobby Clark, dean; Maurice H. Rose, treasurer, and Lester L. Hammel, secretary.

S. A., last week was a week of "Missions," supporting in the fervency of the prevailing spirit their continued relevancy.

If ever an object lesson was needed in the wisdom of avoiding foreign entanglements it is being proved just now by France and her relations with other countries. She has treaties with Russia, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Rumania, but all of them are in reality liabilities rather than assets.

The Dearborn Morgan School here, formerly a fashionable school for girls, is among twenty-four properties to be sold at auction Nov. 13 in the high school auditorium. The sale has been ordered by Leonard G. the Brown, receiver of the old Orange National Bank.

Twenty-five young women of society will serve as manikins at the annual fashion show and tea for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club, which will take place on Nov. 18 in the Iridium Room, Lounge and Oak Room of the St. Regis.

Mrs. Kathryn Lawes, wife of Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing prison, died in Ossining Hospital shortly before 11 o'clock tonight of injuries received some time during the day near the Westchester end of Bear Mountain Bridge.
The campaign for re-election to the City Council by Mayor Charles Stanton and Councilman Julius R. Hoesterey Jr. has resulted in one of the most bitter municipal contests known in-Rochester.

Shadows of terrible destruction and disaster are gathering thickly over Nantao as the Japanese forces plan their attack on that important part of Greater Shanghai. Half of the 600,000 inhabitants already have fled.

The plan of promoting millinery as Christmas gifts will be pushed aggressively this year by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, it was announced yesterday in the annual report of the commission, of which Max Meyer is chairman.

WITH the Macgregor Arctic Expedition settled down for the Winter at the foot of one of Greenland's mountains, 600 miles from the North Pole, all-wave listeners in this area now have a good opportunity to eavesdrop on reports from the Arctic camp.

The marriage of Miss Helen Saathoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Saathoff of this place, to Ralph Hopwood Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. David D. Davis of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., took place today in the First Presbyterian Church, here. The Rev. George A. Edrmison, the pastor, performed the ceremoney.

The St. John's Prep eleven toppled the St. Francis Prep team from the ranks of the unbeaten yesterday with a 20-to-0 decision at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn. Red Frane, Ed Dunham and quarterback English crossed the St. Francis goal line.

Gallagher is the chairman.

The president's program of Princeton University, evolved by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds for the future development of the university as a "national institution," has received $1,389,000 in contributions since its inception in the early Fall of 1935, according to figures released today by the offices of the program's executive committee.

Miss Margaret Elizabeth Burns of Woodbridge, daughter of Mrs. Arthur G. Burns of New Brunswick, was married to Runyon G. Ernst, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Ernst of Perth Amboy, in the First Presbyterian Church here tonight.
