It became known here today that the British Government had set Tuesday's meeting of the Non-Intervention Committee as the time limit for its final effort to settle the question of withdrawing "volunteers" and reestablishing control on Spain.

Led by Big Bill Tranavitch, who scored four touchdowns and as many extra points from placement to tally 28 points, the Rutgers football team crushed Lehigh, 34 to 0, on Neilson Field today before a homecoming day crowd of 9,000. Art Perry, Tranavitch's running mate at halfback, scored the other Rutgers six-pointer.
The long-delayed Japanese attack along the Tatung-Taiyuan highway began yesterday morning when Japanese troops engaged The left and right flanks of the Chinese troops defending Sinhsien.

The undefeated Holy Cross Crusaders were forced to a pair of mighty goal-line stands to fight off the unbeaten Temple University eleven and gain a scoreless tie in a rugged football battle fought through a stiff gale before a capacity crowd of 22,000 spectators today.

Interest in the election Tuesday in Rockland County centers in contests for the Assembly and for control of the Board of Supervisors. Indifference which marked the early stages of the campaign has given way to spirited rivalry at recent rallies.

If the action of the United States Supreme Court last Monday means that there is no further recourse through the courts for the Scottsboro case Negroes, who were accused of attacking two white women, and that the only hope of relief now is through Executive action by the State of Alabama; it is not unreasonable to believe such action possible.

Miss Marion Tompkins Wilsdon of Townley Street, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Arthur J. Wilsdon of Waterbury, has chosen next Saturday afternoon as the date for her marriage to Gerald Hazen Loomis, son of Frank W. Loomis of Hartford.

Doddario, fleet halfback, intercepted a Trinity forward pass today to give the Wesleyan eleven a 7-to-6 decision. As a result Wesleyan now has twenty-five victories to its credit in the series started in 1885. Trinity has taken fourteen games.
The most comprehensive collection of rings ever made by one person will be sold in London Nov. 9 to 12. There are nearly 2,000 of them, and they belonged to the late M. Guilhou of Paris.

The New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra opened the annual Princeton concert series here tonight in McCarter Theatre before a capacity audience. The orchestra, under the direction of John Barbirolli, played a program devoted to the works of Berlioz, Beethoven Purcell, Balakireff and Wagner.

An innovation at the Book Fair this year will be an exhibit entitled "Behind the Scenes of a Publishing Office," showing what a publisher does from the moment he begins to wonder if he ought to publish a given manuscript.

Coach Larry Kelley's Peddie School football team tasted its first defeat of the season today, bowing to Brown Prep of Philadelphia by a score of 18-0. All of the touchdowns were made in the last half.
Senator Copeland, chairman of the Commerce Committee, took preliminary steps today toward an investigation of what he said were "Communistic influences" at work on American ships.

ALL those who are acquainted with at least some of Mr. Bromfield's earlier novels, such as "The Green Bay Tree," "Possession" and "The Farm," will realize, once they come in contact with his newest fiction, that here is no ordinary novel, but rather a tour de force.
THERE is no doubt that the year 1937-1938 is going to make its mark in the history of modern car design in Great Britain.
IN reply to many inquiries about Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's book on peace, H. C. Kinsey Co. announce that it will be published on Jan. 3, 1938, under the title of "This Troubled World."

With a unanimous general resolution giving verbal satisfaction to all factions, the Radical-Socialist party congress closed its session at Lille today. Its program, nevertheless, is impossible to misconstrue.

Eighteen clubs and associations at Marymount College here began their Autumn activities last week. The plans and purposes of each group were outlined- to the freshmen by the committee on student activities, comprising the Misses Margie Steinbugler, June Shader and Catherine Manton.

A. Gordon Murdock, former Indianapolis pump manufacturer and son of a utility executive, died last night of a heart attack while attending a motion-picture show here with his wife, Mrs. Frances kMullins Murdock. His age was 41. They Were visiting Mrs. Murdock's ;nother, Mrs. Frank Mullins of East Orange, and planned to sail soon for their residence at Innsbruck, Austria.

Miss Winifred Earl Lefferts, caugnter of Mrs. Oscar Leffert Lefferts, formerly of Brooklyn, was married here this afternoon at the Summer home of her mother to Carleton Macy of New York and Hewlett, L. I. The Very Rev. Allen Evans, dean of the Philadelphia Theological Seminary, performed the ceremony in the presence of the families and intimate friends.

THE penguins have now definitely become household words. They are at least as well known today as the birds from which they take their name, and we shall be surprised if they are not given an entry in the next edition of the Concise Oxford Dictionary.

American colleges and universities face serious problems in possible loss of financial support through new policies in government, Dr. Neil Carothers, noted economist and dean of the school of business administration, told 300 Rutgers University alumni at the annual. home-coming day dinner. here tonight.

IT was a bear market in the movies this month, too. MetroGoldwyn-Mayer could have been sold short all the way. Paramount was logy and the Warners required clever in-and-out trading--in odd lots mostly. Universal experienced a technical reaction:

A military court today sentenced Dimitri Gitscheff, former Cabinet Minister and leader of the Peasants party, to one year in prison for violating the law dissolving political parties. He had issued a manifesto urging Bulgarians to defend the Constitution and their political rights.

Despite a marked decrease in the number of applicants for scholarships and loans more than $105,000 will again -be available this year to Williams College undergraduates in need of financial assistance.

The first luncheon and musical in a series of. similar events planned for the Winter by members of the Little Mothers Aid Association will take place on Thursday in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Anson Purcell, 32 years old, assistant director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been selected as, the successor of David Saperstein, director of the division, who resigned recently to resume the private practice of law on Dec. 1 in New York.

A "Gold and Silver Fashion Show, "-so titled because Mrs. Cameron McRae Winslow, chairman of the luncheon to be held in conjunction with the show, has invited her friends to bring their old gold and silver to the luncheon and thereby permit the sponsoring group, the Hospital Occupational Committee of the New York City Visiting Committee, to purchase supplies for the Bellevue Hospital workroom-will be held at the Weylin on Nov. 16.

The State Department has under consideration the advisability of moving the United States Embassy in Spain from Valencia to Barcelona, acting Secretary of State Welles said today, in view of reports that the Spanish Government may move its capital to Barcelona.

More lives are saved each year by New York's hospitals than the American Expeditionary Force lost in men killed in action during the World War, John W. Davis, United Hospital Campaign chairman, declared in an announcement issued last night.
STRIPPED of unrelated issues, the electric-power question which
Eight embryo American diplomats have completed a two-year term as language officers attached to the American Embassy at Tokyo and have been assigned to consular posts in the field.

THE National Automobile Show is a window into the youthful, exuberant and insatiably curious soul of Mr. American Average Man. On the faces of the thousands who now daily mill through the exhibits of Grand Central Palace, the Waldorf-Astoria and-the Ford and Chrysler Buildings, there can be read the same intense absorption that is found on the faces of boys watching a toy train careen through a paper mache tunnel.

Michigan's scrappy Wolverines applied a spot of tarnish to Bob Zuppke's silver jubilee celebration today, coming from behind with a quick third-period scoring thrust to defeat Illinois, 7-to 6, before 30,000 spectators in Memorial Stadium.

Brawler Slays Bystander Feorge Bertie, 35 years old, of 235 East 103d Street, a Negro, died last night in Harlem Hospital shortly after he had been shot in the stmoach at Fifth Avenue and 117th Street, according to the police.

A bleak picture of America's young people living in "a sick society," which has yet concretely to consider their manifold perplexities and problems, is limned in a report to the American Youth Commission of the American Coundil on Education made public yesterday under the title "How Fare American Youth?"
IN reviewing the new German poetry it must be confessed that, on the whole, the timesare not favorable to pure lyric art.

The engagement of Miss Helen A. Turrell, daughter of John C. Turrell of 10 Gracie Square, and the late Mrs. Turrell, to Richard M. Denne, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Denne, also of this city, has been announced by her father.

New York City voters, at the polls next Tuesday, will elect a City Council by proportional representation. Each will write the figure 1 before the candidate he wants most to elect, the figure 2 before his second choice, and so on as far as he cares to continue.

A substitute back, Otis Rogers, grabbed the third period kick-off and ran 90 yards for the touchdown which started Oklahoma off toward its 19-to-0 victory over Kansas State in a Big Six football game today.

THAT man Nagurski, he's still playing football They say he is better than ever. In which case he must be a couple of years ahead of Jim Thorpe's best form of olden days. When stout Steve Owen of the Giants was warned that Nagurski was better than ever, he dismissed it briefly and coldly with the remark:

The Rev. Gerald L. K. Smith, who has spent the last year building up a Committee of One Million to war on Communism, Fascism and other "alien philosophies," set forth yesterday his hope that the 1940 Presidential election would not confront the nation with a "quandary" similar to that which faces the voters in Tuesday's municipal election here.
Oregon State College and stanford University battled on a slippery field to a scoreless tie today in their Pacific Coast Conference game before 10,000 fans.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert T. Concord of Bloomfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yvonne Aimee Concord, to Richard S. Merrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Merrick of Kennett Square, Fa.

Worcester Tech defeated Rhode Island today in their annual game, 12 to 2. It was the first victory for the Engineers over the Rams since 1933. Gustavson went over from the 6yard mark in the second after several threats by Tech.

An experimental course to give students as much information as possible about their personalities has been introduced at Barnard College by Professor Harry Hol-, lingworth of the psychology department. This "mental adjust-. ments" course is especially designed for students who are not majoring in psychology and is the only course of this kind for un-. dergraduates.

The Eclectic Society, Phi Nu Theta, a local fraternity at Wesleyan University, the oldest of the four-year student societies on the campus, founded in 1837. will celebrate its centennial Friday and Saturday.

Fifty-nine undergraduate students at City College are enrolled for honors work in fourteen subjects this semester, according to an announcement by Dr. Morton Gottschall, dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Science.

The entire police force of the city, about 19,000 men, will be mobilized to safeguard the balloting and count of the votes on Tuesday. All leaves, days off and special assignments have been canceled from 8 o'clock tomorrow night until 8 o'clock Wednesday morning.

Mrs.Peggy Chandler of Dallas, Texas, twice champion of Mexico, scored an 83 from the men's tees on the rain-soaked Chapultepec course to win the qualifying medal in this country's title golf tourney today. Par for the links from the women's tees is 74.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday that applications for the position of principal in Junior High School 37, the Bronx, Junior High Schools 149 and 196, Brooklyn, are now being considered.

AUTOMOBILE SHOW time always brings forth the perennial query: "What about business for next year?" Far be it from me to don the robes of the ancient soothsayer, draw out my crystal and reel off the fortunes that may be in store for all of us in this industry during the next twelve months.

Sir Landon Ronald, for twenty-seven years the principal of the Guildhall School of Music and a famous music master, announced his retirement yesterday. He is 64 years old and at the time of his appointment was the youngest principal ever named by the City of London.

Afternoon--J. Donald Adams, chairman; Carl Carmer, Pearl S. Buck, Lotte Lehmann. Evening--"America at Home and Abroad": Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman; Stephen Bonsal, Sir Willmott Lewis, Eugene Lyons, Linton Wells.

Special Notice The deputy chiefs of the 12th Division are placed under the three-platoon tengroup system, effective at 12:01 A. M. Nov. 1. 1937. The three-platoon ten-group system is installed in the 3d and 36th Battalions, effective at 12:01 A. M. Nov. 1, 1937.
WITH "Le Vraies Richesses" (Grasset, 220 pp., 15 fr.) Jean Giono once more celebrates in imaginative prose life essential, which springs from the earth, blossoms forth in meadow flowers,

In a dizzy, thrilling football game crammed with contradictions, Biff Jones's. Nebraska Cornhuskers slashed out a lone touchdown on the first scrimmage play of the game to defeat the potent Hoosiers of Indiana, 7 to 0, and continue in the list of the nation's unbeaten elevens.

Employes of the Knapp Company, 141 East Twenty-fifth Street, were startled shortly before 9 o'clock yesterday morning when a group of tight-lipped firemen rushed through the loft to a window overlooking Twenty-sixth Street.

Preparations for the twentieth anniversary of the bolshevist revolution were officially launched today with the publication of the official slogans that, emblazoned in white on flaming red banners, will flutter over the streets of every town and village in the whole Soviet land Nov. 7.

Ever since the Aztecs first raised dahlias in their gardens in Central America, dahlia growers have been multiplying. Dahlia interest has had its curves up and down since the flower was sent to Spain from Mexico, where it was discovered, as "the first American cultivated garden flower." Right now dahlia interest is on one of its up-curves.

The movies are to become an integral part of classwork at Byrn Mawr College this year as an innovation introduced by the Department of English. The specific course for which a series of film programs has been planned is freshman composition, in which the reading of drama is stressed during the first semester.

Miss Matilda Anne Belcher, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Nathan Belcher of this city, was married to Morris Righton Swicegood, son of Mrs. Stephen Preston Swicegood of Savannah, Ga., this afternoon at the home of her parents.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Campbell of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Agnes Ann Campbell, to Ralph Meyerhoff, son of Charles Meyerhoff, also of this city.
Construction of a Memorial Field House, dedicated to Knute Rockne will be started at Notre Dame University Friday according to an announcement by the president, the Rev. John F. O'Hara.

A landslide for Mayor La Guardia and his running mates on the Republican - Labor-Fusion-Progressive tickets was predicted yesterday by William M. Chadbourne, chairman of the Fusion Campaign Committee, and Alex Rose, campaign director of the American Labor party.

Even before they learn the fortunes of women candidates in the municipal election organized women have set out to discover why their number is proportionately so low and to investigate ways and means of increasing it before another year's ballots are cast.

Delegates from 145 Junior Leagues in all parts of the United States, Hawaii, Mexico and Canada are arriving here to take part in the Welfare Conference of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America to be held here Monday to Friday inclusive.

Miss Helen Keller, famous teacher of the blind, is among the distinguished alumnae of Radcliffe College for whom rooms have been named in the new dormitory, Ella Lyman Cabot Hall, which will be formally opened today at Cambridge, Mass. Miss Keller was graduated in the class of 1904.

THE high cost of meat, the fact that choice grades of beef are scarce, and the further fact that some dealers have recently been accused of selling medium grades at top-grade prices have brought the municipal authorities to the rescue of the New York housewife,

After a twenty years California courts closed their doors finally and emphatically today to Thomas J. Mooney. The State Supreme Court, in a five-to-one decision, rejected his plea for a writ of habeas corpus.

Sixteenth annual communion mass and breakfast of Court Jeanne D'Arc, No. 500, Catholic Daughters of America, Church of the Incarnation, 8 A. M. Breakfast at the Paris-Bruxelles, 161 East Fifty-fourth Street. Speakers: Rev. Patrick J. Temple, Rev. Joseph Stanford, Rev. James J. Rowan, Rev. Cornelius Hance, Dr. Walter Kennedy, Margaret A. Tynan.

TWO operas and three concerts make up the subscription series this season at the Juilliard School of Music. The operas to be produced are Beryl Rubinstein's "The Sleeping Beauty," with book by John Erekine, which will be given its premiere, and Mozart's "The Abduction From the Seraglio."

Major provisions of the proposed new charter for Westchester County were outlined here today by public officials as follows: 1. Every four years a County Executive would be elected at large. He would receive $20,000 annually and perform administrative work now in the hands of the Board of Supervisors. The board would be continued chiefly as a legislative body. Subject to ratification by the Supervisors,

Guards in the Ohio Penitentiary were merely amused today when James Mason chanted "I want out of here" from a perch on the 150-foot high prison water tower. Mason broke from a marching line of convicts at breakfast time and climbed to the tower's catwalk where, four weeks ago, he paced back and forth demanding release.

Mrs. Malcolm McLeod of Pittsburgh has spent the last eight years in collecting and supplying books free to hospitals, prisons, orphanages and remote sections, not only in this country but throughout the world.
IT was in 1839--not yet a century ago--that Louis Jacques Daguerre published his method of producing light-etched images on plates of silver, and thereby ushered in the age of photography.

After sixteen years of ownership of 421 acres of land near Towson, bought for the eventual removal of Goucher College from this city, the trustees of the college have appointed an advisory board of architects with power to act for, and with the approval of the trustees in matters relating to design and construction of the institution on this new site.

The military Cabinet of General Ernesto Montagne, which was formed in October, 1936, as a result of an electoral crisis, resigned last night, and a new Cabinet, also headed by General Montagne, was sworn in today.

The last chapter in the history of German Jewry is now being written, for the Jews in Germany are condemned to extinction, Dr. Joachim Prinz of Berlin told some 2,500 delegates to the twenty-third annual convention of Hadassah here today.

New materials have made their appearance in the midseason models. Besides angora wool, with its fine hairy surface and mossy woolen, with its glossy pile, both of which still are seen, there are many new kinds of jersey.

The Committee for Industrial Organization will test its vote-getting power in Akron and Canton Mayoral eleotions Tuesday. In Akron the United Rubber Workers hope to elect Municipal Judge G. L. Patterson over Mayor Lee D. Schroy, who is completing his first two-year term.

The National Socialist Publishers and Booksellers Association issued another general appeal at Weimar today to the publishers of the world for the establishment of an international censorship agreement.

Tom Parry of Detroit, who came here last Spring to direct a C. I. O. strike and stayed to serve most of a six-months jail sentence, was released today and went home. "That unlawful assembly law is the most vicious ever put on the statute's of a democratic country," Parry declared as he left jail.

ANOTHER National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, beginning on Wednesday and running ahead a week and a day-longer than it has ever run before, because of the increasing crowds it attracts-reminds us that though our streets and highways are all built for motors the horse is still with us.
A blue-clad horde from Duke University overpowered a big but outclassed Washington and Lee football team, 43 to O, in a Southern Conference game before 5,000 spectators today.

THE picturesque little town of Brixham, perched high above the sea atop,the Devonshire cliff, in England, is preserving for posterity the Berry Head House, where nearly a hundred years ago the Rev. Henry Francis Lyte, Vicar of Brixham, wrote the greatly loved hymn "Abide With Me."

THE annual influx of deer hunters to the Northern Michigan woods this season, Nov. 15 to 30, inclusive, is expected to break all records. In 1935, it is estimated that 39,637 bucks were shot in Michigan during the two-week hunting period.
Tendentious headline and Chinese propaganda among the Amerioan masses are two of the causes of America's anti-Japanism, according to Viscount Hidemaro Konoe, the Japanese Premier's brother.

At the most important gathering of the Pilsudski Legionnaires since Marshal Joseph Pilsudski's death two and a half years ago, his successor, Marshal Edward SmiglyRyiz,' assured them today that he remained faithful to the Legion's ideals and that no pact had been made with the Nationalist Right.

Many additional subscribers have been reported for the card party to be held next Friday afternoon at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn under the auspices of the Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Museum.

It was the pleasant duty of the Town Hall management to inform last night's box-office applicants that every available seat and standing space was sold out. The occasion was the week's second recital of the tenor, Richard Tauber.

Power plays prevailed for Connecticut State today in defeating Middlebury, 20 to 7, in the first football meeting of the two institutions. A Boehm-to-Guarnaccia pass brought Middlebury's tally, while plunges by Posner, Scarchuk and Schwolsky resulted in Nutmeg scores.

SAID to produce 10 per cent more power and to offer 12 per cent more gasoline mileage, two new motors have been developed for its 1938 cars by the Nash Motor Division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation. The motors,

The Pepperell Manufacturing Company has issued new prices for publication on its entire line of sheets and pillow cases, bringing these goods to the lowest levels of the year. Reductions in net prices range from 3.57 to 6.3 per cent.
A passing attac that couldn't be stopped carried the University, of Maryland to a 13-7 intersectional football victory over Florida today. A crowd of 10,000 Homecoming Day fans saw the game.

Tomorrow night the United. States Government will launch a unique educational effort. Under the sponsorship of the Office of Education, the "Brave New World" series of broadcasts, to be presented on successive Monday nights over the Columbia Broadcasting System, will attempt to create among its listeners in the United States a fuller appreciation of the peoples of Central and South America.
STARTING from the interior of this year's cars one finds that ordinary noises are kept to a polite conversational level by the headlining, the carpeting and the upholstery on the cushions.

One of the most ambitious attempts to use radio for education will begin over a doast-to-coast hook-up tomorrow night, with the presentation of the first of a series of twenty-six half-hour programs called "Brave New World," dramatizing the history and culture of Latin America.

Pacifist strategy in Spain and China and other phases of the peace movement here and abroad will be discussed at a student conference convening Saturday at Vassar College under direction of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, the American Friends Service Committee, the War Resisters League and the Fellowship of Reconciliation.

The Princeton freshman seconds scored four times in the first three periods to defeat Blair at football, 24 to 0. today. Shortly after the first period opened, Princeton completed several passes to take the ball to the Blair 2-yard line, from where Stebbins plunged over the goal line.
An early scoring drive gave the Hempstead High School eleven victory over Chaminade, 13-7, before 4,500 spectators today. Hempstead thus remained undefeated and united in five starts this season.

City Detective Bob Eleazer gave a first-hand account today of the weird play in the South CarolinaCitadel football game at Orange-burg yesterday, in which a spectator stepped on the field and tackled a Carolina runner.

FROM an apprenticeship at the famous University Press of Cambridge, Mass., William Dana Orcutt rose to be its head and left it to become the typographic adviser of the Plimpton Press. In a lifetime devoted to making better and more beautiful books he studied the finest examples in libraries here and abroad.

BOYS who live in United States Territories and in foreign lands as students or sons of American business men and consular officials have the same opportunity to participate in Scouting as do boys in continental United States. As a matter of fact,
Prices of cotton on the Cotton Exchange here softened somewhat yesterday under moderately increased foreign and domestic liquidation and a week-end increase in Southern hedge-selling.
Amsterdam's population turned out this morning when about half of The Netherlands air force appeared above the city to execute the most extensive manoeuvres in the history of the country.

The promotion of 124 students enrolled as commissioned cadet officers in the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps was announced yesterday by Colonel Oliver Prescott Robinson, chairman of the Department of Military Science and Tactics.

Vermont defeated Norwich, 18 to 6, today in a game that was closer than the score indicates. The losers were deep in enemy territory half of the game, and twice they were stopped a yard from the' goal.

Members of the Club Las Tres Americas gave a dance last night in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton to celebrate the birthday of Simon Bolivar, the South American liberator. The Consul Generals at New York representing the South American and Central American republics attended the celebration.

Howard Welch of Cornell University, I. C. A. A. A. A. two-mile champion and Ivy League one-mile titleholder, ran off with the individual victory in the five-mile crosscountry meet among Dartmouth, Cornell, Yale and Columbia at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Welch,

Demolition of the two brownstone front buildings at 18 and 20 West Forty-eighth Street in the Radio City section will mark the passing of a residential landmark that belonged to the "Old New York" era.

On behalf of the City Fusion party,Samuel Seabury urged voters of the Bronx last night to vote for Isidore Nagler under the emblem of the Progressive party or the American Labor party. Mr. Seabury spoke over Station WOR.

The most intensive off-year political campaign in the history of Nassau County drew to a close tonight with leaders of both the Democratic and Republican organizations expressing confidence of victory at the polls on Tuesday.

A wreath placed Thursday on the German war dead memorial by Isador Gennett in the name of a Bronx post of the Jewish War Veterans Association was missing this evening when the memorial gates were closed.

The Bril ish Government today sought freedom for a twentieth-century "Soarlet Pimpernel," Captain Edwin C. Lance, formerly an honorary attache of the British Embassy in Madrid, who has been held in a Valencia jail for three weeks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Guiterman's discussion of the Constitution and the Supreme Court in his letter to THE TIMES on Oct. 24 is one of the very few pro-court statements I have read that deals with the subject calmly and judiciously.

FIRE--the ruthless besieger which burns nearly 40,000,000 acres of forests in this country each year-is being attacked directly from the air in tests by the Forest Service of the United States Department of Agriculture.

John E. Lager, an authority on orchids, died today at his home, 74 Boulevard, after a short illness at the age of 76. He was a member of the firm of Lager Hurrell. Mr. Lager maintained extensive greenhouses at 426 Morris Avenue; devoted almost exclusively to the culture of orchids.

The marriage of Miss Anna Neilson Bearman, daughter of Mrs. William Greenwood Bearman of First Cliff, Scituate, and the late Mr. Bearman, to Joseph Keen Rulon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson Birdsall Rulon of Philadelphia, took place here at noon today in St. Stephen's Church.

The revival of whipping as a mode of punishment in a Virginia judicial circuit has caused a sensation. Comment has come from various sections of the State, and the greater part of it holds that whipping is a step backward and is penologically and sociologically indefensible.

Dr. Paul Ganz, Professor of the History of Art at the University of Basle, Switzerland, and leading authority on the work of Hans Holbein the Younger, arrived in New York last week to lecture on the work of the sixteenth century artist and see examples of his work in public and private art collections in this country.

Diplomats outside the diplomatic service is what most of the nine girl students in the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, administered by Tufts College and Harvard University, expect to be when they complete their courses in this graduate school.

The Southern Methodist University Mustangs came out of the Southwest Conference cellar today with a 13-to-2 victory over the University of Texas. Southern Methodist scored in the third period when Bryan, Texas back, fumbled on the 4-yard line and Ranspot, end, recovered.
The average price of 200 issues of real estate mortgage bonds on properties in a number of Eastern cities has receded to the level reached April and May, 1935, according to Amott-Baker Co., Inc.

Many members of North and South Shore society who will keep their country homes open until after election day have made reservations for luncheon at the Turf and Field Club and will have guests in their boxes on Tuesday at the last race meeting of the season of the United Hunts Racing Association at Belmont Park.

The new Queens College of the City of New York will be one founded in the American tradition and American ideals, training its students to serve the community, speakers predicted last night at a testimonial dinner to Dr. Paul Klapper, its first president, at the Hotel Astor. Governor Herbert H. Lehman said:
California's Golden Bears paraded through here today on their steady march to the Rose Bowl, pausing long enough to defeat the University of California at Los Angels, 27 to 14.
West Virginia University put ten wellnigh perfect blockers and a speedy backfield into play on virtually all occasions today to overwhelm Western Maryland College. 64--0.
THE defense of the Alcazar of Toledo brought its unfor gettable epic quality into the horror of modern warfare and the desperate tragedy of the civil war in Spain.

The Misses Adele A. and Dorothy G. Parks have bought for oceupaney the three-story dwelling at 577 Fourth Street, Brooklyn, from the United States Trust Company of New York and A. N. Gitterman, co-executors of the Charles S. Lyons estate.
Full occupancy arid a sharp increase in income have resulted from the renovation a few weeks ago of the two old tenements at 231-33 East Fourth Street, near Avenue B, on the lower East Side.

BARLOW--Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand H., announce birth of a son, Oct. 22, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital. BROWN--Mr. and Mrs. John A. Brown announce the birth of a daughter, Jo Anne, Wednesday morning, Oct. 27, at Doctors Hospital.
Bids on 270 bombing planes were opened at the Navy Department today and it was indicated that the cost of the equipment in question would be in excess of $20,000,000.

One of the greatest disasters in the history of the Near East occurred over the week-end when torrential rains and cloudbursts caused unprecedented floods near this city. By some miracle Damascus itself was not damaged.

INCREASINGLY, it would seem, Americans are becoming conscious of their origins. I do not mean, merely, that we have been treated to an inordinate number of Civil War novels--or, to a lesser degree, novels of the Revolution and the pioneer West. Historical fiction is always and everywhere popular.

Miss Louise M. Peterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George G. Peterson of this place, was married here this afternoon to William Edward Callaghan of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, in the People's Church by the Rev. Charles Edward Souter, who was assisted by the Rev. George W. Parsons.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Edward N. Roeser of 319 West 101st Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Eleanor Roeser. to Dr. Jed Hotchkiss Irvine, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Irvine of Charlottesville, Va.

China's "lost battalion" escaped its besieged warehouse citadel early today. 'running a machine-gun gauntlet to sanctuary in Shanghai's International Settlement. At the height of fighting that sprayed shells over foreign-owned areas of central Shanghai, 377 Chinese dashed down a twenty-yard opening to safety.
Looking back over the diplomatic history of the last year, the present complacency and confidence of European dictatorship become wholly comprehensible.

Public schools of New York State are to be judged for the first time mainly upon their outcomes in human adjustment, in the forthcoming report of the two-year Regents inquiry into the character and cost of public education, Dr. Luther Gulick, the director, revealed in an interview yesterday.

The First Division polo team triumphed over the Squadron C quartet, 7 to 5, yesterday at Fort Hamilton in a game played for the joint benefit of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, the Army Relief Society and the Soldiers and Sailors Club'of New York.

Miss Laura Coldwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tompkins Coldwell of Alplaus, near here, was married to Martin B. Keenahan of Batavia, Java, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Keenahan of New York, today in the Alplaus Union Methodist Church, by the Rev. Fred Clarke of Albany, former pastor of the church.

After more than a year devoted to working out a model statute aimed at prohibiting sales of merchandise below cost, the National Grocery Conference Committee, composed of representatives from the manufacturing, wholesaling and retailing divisions of the industry,
Michele Russo, who was called "Spadaro, the fisherman of Capri" and was one of Europe's most photographed characters, died tonight of bronchial pneumonia on the Island of Capri.

The engagement of Miss Ellen Wells Hooper, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William T. Hooper of this place, to Paul Rutherford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford, also of West Hartford, formerly of Baltimore, has been announced by her parents.

Mayor La Guardia had a preview yesterday morning of the first of three streamlined ferryboats under construction for use by the city on the South Ferry to Staten Island run. Boarding the Gold Star Mother on the waters of the Upper Bay between Governors and Bedloes Islands while the builders were giving her a preliminary run, the Mayor pronounced her "beautiful."

Within the space of three minutes--the last three--so many things happened yesterday at the Yankee Stadium that the crowd of 25,000 persons watching the N. Y. U.-Colgate football battle found it difficult to follow the proceedings.
Drexel won a hard-fought game over Ursinus College today by a score of 6 to 0, in an Eastern Collegiate Conference game. Glenn Williams, sophome fullback, scored the Dragons' touchdown.

commander T. Craven, heading the United States delegation to the InterAmerican Radio Conference, which opens here on Nov. 1, arrived this morning. He is accompanied by technical advisers. Canadian and Mexican delegations also reached Havana today.

The wedding of Miss Dorothy Josephine Spawn, daughter of Theodore Spawn of Newark, and Sherwood Hoskins Mundy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Mundy of Metuchen, took place this morning in St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Metuchen. The rector, the Rev. Harold W.
