In spite of the defeat of major phases of his program for change in the Federal judiciary system, President Roosevelt has steadily adhered to a policy of appointing "younger blood" to the bench.

THE legitimate theatre has come to life in the second city in a notable manner. Customers are eager and plentiful; box offices are prospering; touring productions are competing for bookings. The omens for the season of 1937-38 are thus far completely favorable, and a shortage of theatres in operation seems to be the chief problem.

Unexpectedly timed to take place just before the reconvening of Congress in special session, the twentysixth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America will get under way on next Wednesday and continue through Sunday at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va. Members of the association hold that the meeting presents a propitious opportunity for constructive criticism of troublesome features of the laws and regulations governing the investment business.

The biggest news in Spain these days is the weather -rain and mud from the Pyrenees down to the Strait of Gibraltar. There is no fighting of any importance anywhere and, what is more significant, despite all previous beliefs and reports no important Rebel concentrations either on the Madrid or the Aragon front have been spotted yet.
It was revealed that the garrison on Quemoy Island off Amoy consisted of a portion of the 157th Division and suffered a number of casualties when the island was captured by the Japanese.

The general policy of the Bureau of Internal Revenue for the allowance of stock dividends as credits in' calculating corporate earnings subject to the undistributed-profits tax is assuring to corporations only in those cases in which there is no doubt about the taxability to the shareholders of the stock distributed. (I. T. 3,037.)
READING about an unexpected inheritance of nearly $5,000,000 is not the same as getting it, but there is a fascination in the fiction.
The directors of the management division, Real Estate Board of New York, have elected George W. Martin to be vice chairman of the board. Jeremiah K. Cronin,

Miss Frances Bosler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Bosler of Media, was married this afternoon to William H. Metzgar of Endicott, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence L. Metzgar, also of Media.. The ceremony took place in the First Presbyterian Church of Media.

Platrolman Michael Ryan, 28 years old, was shot and killed early this morning at his home,. 1,350 Purdy Avenue, the Bronx. Detectives of the Bronx Homicide Squad, who investigated, said that he had been wounded three times, apparently with bullets from his own service revolver.

Philadelphia was selected for the and site of the 1938 tri-State conference of the National Association of Credit Men at the close of a two-day session here today attended by Due about 500 delegates from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvaina.

EVEN though it is dangerous to make predictions as to the fu ture, it seems to me that I can safely make an optimistic one for the 1938 automobile year. My belief is that during this new year, the automobile industry as a whole will enjoy gratifyingly substantial sales increases.

German Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath in guarded language protested today before the German Chamber of Law in Munich against the designation of Japan as the aggressor in the Far Eastern conflict.
The opinion held by some sections of the American public that only military force or economic coercion can restore order in the Far East is causing considerable concern in Administration circles.
The University of Arkansas dr Razorbacks recovered all of their passing magic today to defeat Texas A. and M. College, 26 to 13, before 8,000 home-coming-day fans.
WHEN you see a house trailer hightailing down the line do you fancy its occupants are living a rather sketchy existence? Some of them are. Most of them are not.

On April 26, as the Confederate Memorial Day parade wended its way through the main streets of Atlanta, a straggling company brought up the rear. Behind the military bands and drum corps and the automobiles conveying the few enfeebled old soldiers, the Ku Klux Klan was marching again.
Irvington High School's eleven remained in the unbeaten ranks by gaining a 15-to-6 victory over the Kearny High squad today before a record crowd of more than 10,000.

The Social Security Board said today that of $252,439,339.45 of public assistance grants to States from Feb. 1, 1936, through Oct. 26, 1937, the aged received $218,780,088.74, the blind $7,538,416.89 and dependent children $26,120,833.82.
THE handsomely prepared portfolio issued last Monday by Knight Publishers, Inc., constitutes an event of considerable importance in the realm of color reproduction. This portfolio,

THAT veteran of the pen, Mr. StephenBonsal, has a great story to tell, and he knows how to tell it. About the vivacity of a great journalist there is a fascination that. whether literature or not, holds the attention.

After a year's experimentation with the broadcasting of college lectures and other features, Harvard University has adopted the radio as a regular part of its educational machinery, and during the coming Winter will prepare an international transmission every Tuesday night.

IT seems that Deems Taylor, who holds forth regularly in print and on the air, still has his secrets. One that was is the completion by Mr. Taylor of his third opera. Its name, its libretto, its form-these still are shrouded in mystery. Is it, as one has heard, based on a Basque theme?

When the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, holds its monthly meeting on Thursday, it will vote formally upon admitting to membership thirty-four prominent men approved by the executive committee. The group is one of the largest and most representative named for membership in some time.
European countries will receive large orders for arms and ammunition from the Nicaraguan Government because of the failure of American manufacturers to supply Nicaragua's demands immediately.

A forward pass in the last ten seconds of play gave Yale the touchdown that enabled it to tie Dartmouth in a thrill-packed game seen by 72,000 fans. This meeting of unbeaten teams was the feature attraction on Eastern gridirons. In another big game,

Washington State and University of Southern California battled through a thick fog to a scoreless tie in their Pacific Coast Conference football game today. The first half was played in fog so dense the 8,000 spectators were unable to see the play most of the time.

DESPITE the much-heralded efforts of the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce to simplify the Air Regulations, a preview of the new rules intended to take effect tomorrow indicates they may be far more complicated and a far greater deterrent ot the popularization of flying than even before.
ANOVEL type of bridge tournament during the past month in various parts of Westchester County ended Monday and Tuesday nights in a 28-pair final session.

The attempts of mankind to record information fittingly will be exhibited at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, from the lost remote existing evidence down to last month. Three separate exhibits supplement one another in this respect.

Henry R. Luce, president of Time, Inc., will be the principal speaker before Group Nine of the Ohio Bankers Association at its annual meeting in Cleveland on Nov. 10. Edward Jeuther Jr. is with Elliot Wolfe, members of the New York Security Dealers Association.

Belligerency, in international law, is a state of armed hostility which has been legally recognized. If, for example, Britain should admit the existence of belligerency in the Spanish civil war, she would confer equal wartime rights on both Loyalists and Insurgents.
The navy is arranging for mass flights of patrol craft, probably within the next four months, to Hawaii and the Panama Canal Zone, officials disclosed today.

Colby went down to-defeat, 13 to 0, today before the University of Maine, due primarily to some beautiful forward passes hurled by Franny Smith of the Orono forces. Colby was never a real threat after the first five minutes of play.

Hamilton College, with a powerful running attack, handed a scrappy Swarthmore College eleven a 20-to13 setback today. A final period aerial attack by Swarthmore netted the Quakers their second touchdown but failed to save them from their third defeat of the season.

The undefeated Choate School football team swamped the Loomis School eleven by the score of 38 to 0 today. Francis Lee made the first touchdown in the opening session. Tom Fuller tallied once after Charlie Spreyer had carried the ball over twice. Dick Davis also registered two markers.

Miss Constance Willard Huntington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Huntington of this city, and Charles Farrand Taplin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Farrand Taplin of Cleveland, were married -this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church by the Rev. Raymond Cunningham, rector, and Bishop D. Trumbull Huntington of China, the bride's uncle.

The Serb Opposition parties intended to hold a meeting tonight at Kragujevac, but political opponents, mainly of the governmental party, interfered. The resulting clash was marked by the firing of revolvers, after which the police intervened. One policeman was seriously wounded.

Germany's most crucial problem, how to feed herself, seems to be solved by the largest potato crop in the Reich's history, and perhaps in any country's history. The crop now being harvested will total 52,500,000 tons, exceeding last year's by 6,500,000 tons and the 1935 crop by 11,000,000 tons, or about 25 per cent.

Joseph J. O'Donohue, head of the real estate firm of his name at 303 Fifth Avenue and president of Evergreen Cemetery, died yesterday afternoon in St. Vincent's Hospital after a week's illness at the age of 75. He was a son of the late Joseph J. O'Donohue, City Chamberlain, Park Commissioner and a Tammany leader who was a president of the Monmouth County Horse Show Association.
THE great port of London, from Tower Bridge past the Pool and Gallion's Reach, all the way to Tilbury, is displaying more bustle than at any time since it attained its supremacy a century ago.
Workmen sanded the Arena of Nimes's old Roman amphitheatre today in preparation for a "bloodless" bullfight honoring William C. Bullitt, American Ambassador to France.
One of London's few remaining grand houses, Londonderry House, was the scene of the "eve of the session" reception held by Lady Londonderry before the State opening of Parliament.

Dividend payments in the final quarter of this year will run about 20 per cent higher than in the last three months of 1936 and the total of payments this year by public corporations will be about $4,750,000,000, Dr. Joseph J. Klein, attorney,

A registration of Erie County voters, which nears a record, shows the deep interest taken in next Tuesday's poll, which will wind up a spirited campaign. Leading in interest in the many contests is the four-way fight for the Mayoralty of Buffalo.

Railroads of the nation called attention to their financial plight this week when 200 leading executives, meeting in Chicago, asked for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates and certain increases in passenger rates which would yield them altogether $508,000,000 a year.

TALK over the back fences these days concerns the shake-ups in production personnel in several of the major institutions. There are. rumors and more tangible evidence which indicates that many of the boys will be driving through different studio gates each morning by the time the Santa Anita season opens.
A thrill-packed last-half raily by an aroused Syracuse University eleven brought it a 19-13 victory over Penn State today before 12,000 wildly cheering-fans in Archbold Stadium.

AHITHERTO unknown "Rumanian Rhapsody" by Franz Liszt was discovered recently in Vienna among the manuscripts in the archives of the Friends of Music by Dr. Octavian Beu, Rumanian diplomat and musicologist.

Good Saturday crowds were augmented yesterday at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace in the late afternoon by a considerable backwash from the football games of New York University and City College.

A bridge party will be given on Thursday at the McAlpin under the auspices of the St. Mark's Ladies Emergency Society, of which Mrs. William Graf is president. Proceeds will be used to augment the organization's general fund, from which contributions are made to charitable institutions during emergencies.

In line with its determination to utilize the drama as a force in education, Barnswallows, Wellesley dramatic organization, launched the year's experimental program with the presentation of two acts from comparable comedies of manners in Alumnae Hall tonight.

Peter V. Cacchione, Communist candidate for City Council, "Appeal to New York Labor"WMCA, 10:15 to 10:30 A. M. Oreste Ferrara, former Cuban Ambassador to the United States, on behalf of Mayor La GuardiaWOV, 10:45 to 11 A. M.

Arthur S. Taylor, representative of the International Committee of Young Men's Christian Associations in Italy and senior secretary of the Y. M. C. A. in Italy since 1923, died on Friday in Turin, Italy, after an operation, according to word received here yesterday. He was 54 years old.

Bowdoin swamped Bates, 19-7, today to gain its second leg on its third straight State championship. Outclassing Bates in every department, Bowdoin continuously shook loose its speedy backs for long gains, Karsokas, Soule, Legate and Melindy all shining.

Scoring a touchdown midway in the final period, Virginia's eleven won from the College of William and Mary today, 6 to 0. Starting in midfield, the Cavaliers marched to the Indians' 4-yard mark, where Male passed to Gillette across the goal line for the touchdown.
With the Supreme Court back at work and Congress about to meet in special session, debate has been revived on the subject of so-called "judiciary supremacy" in this country.

Turkeys are being fattened for the Thanksgiving marketS under schoolboy supervision at the Horace Mann School for Boys in Riverdale this Fall. And rabbits, pheasants and wild turkeys feed contentedly in pupil-constructed pens, as part of a practical extracurricular project devised by John Dallavo, dormitory supervisor.

Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel today, dipping early in sympathy with corn only to rally sharply later on reports of damaging frost in Argentina and strength in Winnipeg and Buenos Aires.
The vaule in the New York State Education. Department does not contains gold or silver. But its contents are closely guarded, and are of incalculable value to the State.

Because college freshmen need to become aware that study technique must be developed a,1/2 time goes on, a series of three lectures is being given at Smith College this Fall. The lectures have been planned to point out to the 563 freshmen what is expected of them, and how they may meet academic requirements.

The announcement this week by James Delinage Ross, newly appointed administrator of the Bonneville project, that President Roosevelt had agreed to a power formula providing for the amortization of the government's $51,000,000 investment at Bonneville over a forty-year period, with 31/2 per cent allowance for interest, was regarded here as a significant step in the Administration's plans for an integrated Federal power system.

THE United States mints at Philadelphia, San Francisco and Denver coined 379,387,569 one-cent pieces in 1936 for the small-change uses of the nation, according to the Bureau of the Mint. By far the largest number-more than 300,000,000-came from Philadelphia.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Moran of 1,355 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, who Were married on Oct. 31, 1887, in the Church of the Nativity, Madison Street, Brooklyn, will celebrate their golden wedding anniversary today at their home with special religious services and an informal reception.

Livestock prices have been slipping downward during the past fortnight. Of the several factors which may contribute to this condition that given greatest weight is the drop in wholesale meat prices, behind which are the butcher shop strikes in the East and general consumer resistance to high retail prices.

The central fact of the failure of the American Federation of Labor and Committee for Industrial Organization committees to conclude peace terms here this week was the refusal of the federation to agree to issue industrial-union charters in the mass-production industries.

Scoring in every period, the Amherst eleven today vanquished Massachusetts State by 41 to 6. Amherst tallied in the opening minutes, Pattengill going across. The losers scored a moment later as a 35-yard pass, Towle to Putnam,

Albert R. Knight, former executive of an oil company, was convicted tonight in the Delaware County Court on three indictments charging arson, in connection with a fire in his home in Lansdowne on May 28.

Upsets marked the racing at Empire City yesterday, where Esposa took the $7,500 Scarsdale Handicap at 10 to 1 and Miyako was first in the $3,875 Autumn Day Stakes at 7 to 1, features on the closing day of the Jockey Club racing season.

To the Radio Editor: What about the harassing noises created by those at the dials? I refer, of course, to those inconsiderate radio owners who have yet to learn that the volume knob turns left as well as right.

Supporters of both United States Senator A. Harry Moore and State Senator Lester H. Clee yesterday claimed victory in the hotly contested New Jersey Gubernatorial contest that will be settled on Tuesday by the New Jersey electorate.

Virtually every phase of the American college system was criticized by Dr. Hamilton Holt, president of Rollins College, last week in an address before education students at New York University's Washington Square College at Washington Square East.

A LOSS to theatre," announced The Midland Daily Telegraph (England) the other day, going on to say that it. was too bad that Helen Jerome was no longer among the living; indeed, "a tragic circumstance that she should not have lived :to see this masterly piece of adaptation for the stage ('Pride and Prejudice') actually poduced."

Mortgages valued at one billion dollars have been accepted for insurance by the FHA since its inception three years ago, announces Administrator Stewart McDonald. Virtually 99 per cent of this insured mortgage business has been done since April, 1935, he pointed out.

WHILE broadcasting will be the main topic under discussion at the Inter-American Radio Conference opening tomorrow at Havana, short and ultrashort waves will also be subjects for deliberation, according to Commander T. A. M. Craven, member of the Federal Communications Commission, who heads the United States delegation.

THERE is an old expression, "hind sight is better than foresight," so it is easier as Nov 2 approaches to appraise the achievements of broadcasting on its seventeenth anniversary than to answer the question, "When will television be in the home?"

A dramatic battle of words with no blows barred was staged yesterday by the League for Political Education before 1,000 persons at a luncheon in the ballroom of the Hotel Astor, with Thomas E. Dewey and Harold W. Hastings, opposing candidates for the District Attorneyship of New York County, and Mayor La Guardia as the antagonists.

Thomas Adikes, who with his brother owned the largest hay, grain and feed business in Queens during the period when horses were important, died at his home, 41-64 Main Street, Flushing, Saturday morning. He was 81 years old. Thomas Adikes was born in Jamaica, the son of Henry and Mary Adikes.

Leslie MacMitchell, sensational 17year-old George Washington High senior, raced into the limelight for the second successive Saturday when he topped the field yesterday in the running of the Manhattan P. S. A. L. cross-country championship over the Van Cortlandt Park course. Titles In the four other boroughs also were decided.

AUTOBIOGRAPHY as a subject for a book, the pubfishers seem to say on the jacket of this one, has never been tackled before. It is safe to assume that it never will be again and that its untouched solitude has not been causeless. Reasons in plenty will occur upon even cursory thought.

IN "Pity the Tyrant" Hans Otto Storm has produced a compelling, puzzling and pro vocative book. Here is displayed a new talent for prose that is so distinctive that I do not hesitate to say "Watch this man" He can write.

The combined assets of the fourteen Federal savings and loan associations in the Philadelphia dintrict increased approximately 80 per cent during the year ending Oct. 1, according to officials of these organizations.

Frederick A. Sharp, who will take office Monday as executive director of the White Plains Hospital, completed a survey of the institution this week and reported that it was 68.8 per cent occupied during the last six months, with some wards occupied almost 99 er cent.

Germany will soon be able to supply all her own needs in gasoline and fuel oil, according to Professor Friedrich Bergius. Present calculations indicate only 3 to 4 per cent of Germany's annual coal output will be needed to fill her gasoline requirements.

The engagement of Miss Rosamond Moore, daughter of Mrs. John F. Moore of this city and the late Mr. Moore, to James F. Carew, son of Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. John F Carew of New York, was announced by her mother at a tea today at the Moore home at 58 Montgomery Place.
Governor Lehman's self-respect would not permit him to lend his good name to the effort which has been made to raise the "Red" scare in the municipal election.
Mayor La Guardia with Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine went on the radio last night to defend the Police Department against charges of demoralization, inefficiency and coddling of strikers.

Behind all the ballyhoo about Detroit's nonpartisan form of government heard in this most bitterly contested Mayoralty fight in a generation, lies the basic fact that there is fear among the conservative elements that if labor wins in this campaign, it will write its own ticket for behavior in future industrial struggles.

A hard-charging C. C. N. Y. line made its own breaks through savage defensive play to score a wellearned 8-to-6 victory over a favored Providence College eleven before 4,000 spectators at Lewisohu Stadlum yesterday.

Clarkson Tech won its second game of the season by defeating Hartwick, 14 to 0. After an exchange of punts, Clarkson carried the ball down to the l-yard line. Hartwick held for three downs but on the fourth Connelly smashed through tackle to score.

A five day bazaar, beginning today, will be held under the auspices of the women's organization of the Free Synagogue at the Synagogue House, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street. Various booths and divertisements will be conducted daily and special entertainment for children has been arranged for Tuesday afternoon.

After being stalled for half the game, the Brooklyn College football team opened up a powerful running attack to pound out a 32-0 victory over the Nassau-Hofstra eleven before an overflow crowd of 5,000 at the Kingsmen's new campus athletic field yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Jones of this town have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Ward Jones, to Paul Baker Sheatsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Weidner Sheatsley of Mountain Lakes.
Coming from behind to erase a two-touchdown deficit in an inspiring exhibition of second-half power, a courageous Manhattan football team downed Georgetown, 20 to 12, at Griffith Stadium today.

Borough President Harvey of Queens hit back at the Republican-Fusion followers who booed him out 6f the Madison Square Garden rally of their party last night as soon as he got back to his bailiwick. He struck back by labeling them "Communists."
An inexperienced foreigner reading Jap anese newspapers this morning might come to the conclusion that if China is enemy number one Britain is enemy number two.

The annual Town Hall Endowment Series of concerts will be inaugurated on Nov. 10 with the appearance of LotteLehmann, soprano, in her first New York recital of the season. As in the past, the endowment series will have a large patronage of members of society.

Whenever the stock market falls the thousands of speculators, big and little, who have lost money, the investors who have been made to feel poorer and the business men and politicians who have been frightened look around for a scapegoat. Inevitably the first one that comes to mind is the "bear."

Newly elected and retiring officers of the Middle Atlantic Division of the Association of Bank Women will be honored at a dinner to be given by members in the metropolitan area on Friday evening at the Hotel Chatham.
Another giant corporation of the semi-State, semiprivate enterprise type that Japan favors for the exploitation of her new economic dominions,
Dr. and Mrs. John Parliman Cole of Scarsdale have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Elizabeth Cole, to John Shattuck Wait, son of Bertrand Hinman Wait of New Rochelle.

The first in a series of Tuesday morning lectures by Eleanor Markell on "Literary Personalities of Europe and America," will take place Nov. 9 in the French Room of the Plaza. The subject will be "New Novels of Distinction by Writers Internationally Recognized in Other Fields."

Miss Dorothea M. Doyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Doyle of 1,406 Avenue P, Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to Walter V. Brady, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick H. Brady of Jersey City, in St. Brendan's Church, Avenue O and East Twelth Street, Brooklyn.
Miss Polly Herndon Werth, daughter of Major and Mrs. James R. Werth of Alexandria, Va., was married to Cary Jacquelin Randolph this afternoon in historic Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria.
A dinner dance will be held at Chanticler in Millburn Monday night to aid the Newark Exchange for Woman's Work. Mrs. Henry Young Jr., who is treasurer of the organization, is general chairman.

Sinking Province, China's vast westernmost territory, is not being communized by Soviet Russia, Moscow having abandoned all Intentions to promote the communization of China, it was asserted in an interview by Chen Li-fu, potent Kuomintang leader and newly appointed Minister of Mass Training and Propaganda under the Military Affairs Commission.

The cordial relations between Chile and Bolivia, which have been growing for the last six months, will be intensified still further with the announced departure in a few. days of a Chilean mission to Bolivia.

Fourteen classes training church school workers for leadership in religious education have been introduced in the metropolitan area this year by the Columbia University Extension and the Department of Religious Education of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, it was announced yesterday by Dr. James C. Egbert, extension director.

Negotiations are under way to obtain a social activities building for the first coeducational, and thus far homeless, "house plan," at the Commerce Center of City College, which this Fall has achieved a membership of 700 students and 40 faculty members.

Members of the Northern Valley Branch of the Metropolitan Opera House Guild will meet this afternoon at Next Day Hill, home of Mrs. Dwight Whitney Morrow in Englewood, N. J. Mrs. Morrow will be assisted in receiving by Mrs. Denison Dean Dana, chairman of the organization.
The Yorkville Dinner Dances, which for many years have been among the most popular entertainments of the Winter here, will be resumed this season at the RitzCarlton.
WHY men long to go back to the polar North Again and again after they have once been there is incomprehensible to most people. It must be so cold, they say, or you must be frightfully bored.

AFTER the dawn had diluted cold darkness into wintry daylight at the lower end of Panther Gorge in the Adirondacks on Sunday,. Oct. 31, 1875, sixty-two years ago today, a little party of surveyors and guides began to stir in their snow-powdered blankets.
President Roosevelt has commended the prayer for peace to be offered by the faculty members and students of more than seventy-five Catholic colleges tomorrow, the Feast of Christ the King.

WHEN the Paris Opera threw wide its doors for the new season recently its opening night opera was the novelty "L'Aiglon," a work based on Rostand's drama, in the setting of which Arthur Honegger and Jacques Ibert collaborated.

A site on the Yale Farms property in Greenwich, Conn., located on Old Bedford Road and Pierson Drive, has been purchased by Mr. and Mrs. John B. Gates of New York City. A stream runs through the meadow portion of the property.

The Yale freshmen today defeated Mercersburg Academy, 20 to 0, in a scoring streak in the. second period in which Fullback Jim Reily, a former Kent School player, crossed twice on line plunges and tossed a neat pass to John Reid, who scampered 20 yards for the third.
Allegheny defeated the W. and J. eleven today in the first game between the schools since 1908. The score was 14--12. The victors tallied twice in the second quarter.
Robert H. McKay of 104-28 191st Street, Hollis, L. I., was awarded the first prize of $50 in the thirteenth annual design competition among Pratt Institute students of architecture.

Mountain Ridge, backed into favoritism after his stable-mate, Tiger, had been scratched, won the Jockey Club Stakes for 2-year-olds at Churchill Downs today. The free-running son of Royal Minstrel covered the mile on a fast track in the reasonably good time of 1:383-5. He won for his owner,

Mr. and Mrs. John Hampton Barnes of West Acres, Devon, gave a dance tonight for their debutante granddaughter, Miss Emily H. Todd, daughter of Captain Forde A. Todd, commandant of midshipmen at Annapolis, and Mrs. Todd, the former Miss Sylvia L. Barnes.

Assignment To take effect 8 A. M., Nov. 1: LIEUTENANT -- Josepn S. Christie. Emergency Service Division. Assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Joseph F. Quirk from 83d Precinct to office of the Chief Clerk, assigned to clerical duty, for 5 days, from 8 A. M. Nov. 1.

Santa Clara trampled a willing but inexperienced Marquette eleven from Milwaukee at Soldier Field today and maintained its place among the nation's undefeated and untied elevens by winning, 38 to 0, before 40,000 spectators.

THE Bureau of Public Roads of the United States Department of Agriculture is, perhaps, one of the least publicized divisions of that vast department. Much has been written and is to be written of programs for crop control, for soil conservation,

Army had a stubborn football opponent in Virginia Military Institute today, but finally won, 20-7. A capacity crowd of 27,000 witnessed the game under perfect weather conditions in Michie Stadium. There were 14,000 Boy Scouts from the Eastern section of the ountry, who came as guests of the army athletic aurthorities in attendance.

The Rutgers and Lehigh freshman football teams played a 0-0 tie on Neilson Field this morning before 1,000 spectators. Neither team demonstrated any sustained offensive power and most of the play was in midfield.

NATHAN STRAUS grew up under the handicap of being the son of a man distinguished in business, philanthropy and public life. The name he bears was perhaps as well and familiarly known as any in New York City a generation and less ago.
Great Britain and France are keeping watchful eyes not only upon Spain's Balearic Islands but also upon other possible Italian or German naval bases in the Western Mediterranean.
Charley Gelbert, Detroit utility infielder and scout for Hen Bream's Gettysburg College eleven, met his "Waterloo" as a scout today

Heavy patrols of French troops were stationed on the frontier between Algeria and Morocco tonight, virtually closing the border to all but foreigners to prevent the spread of Arab Nationalist agitation.

The first benefit performance of "Amphitryon 38," starring Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt at the Shubert Theatre, will be held on Dec. 6 in behalf of the George Junior Republio. Chauncey Stillman, a member of the board of trustees, is general chairman.

Dedication of the new $400,000 library under construction at the Coliege of New Rochelle to the memory of its founder, the late Rev. Mother Irene Gill, marked the central theme of the twenty-ninth annual Founder's Day exercises today, in which more than 1,500 students, faculty and alumnae participated.
Big Ernie Lain, sophomore, tossed two touchdown passes today to give Rice Institute a 19-7 triumph over previously undefeated Auburn. The victory was the second of the season for Rice.

A 161-pound sophomore halfback from Philadelphia, Jack Padley, pushed Western Reserve off the peak of football fame today as Dayton University won, 18 to 6, to end the unbeaten Cleveland university's streak at twentyeight games.

The marriage of Miss Juliette Rogers, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. W. Milton Rogers of New York, to Carl J. Kreitler, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kreitler of Maplewood, took place today in the home of the bride's uncle-and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. William Minder of South Orange.

Phillips Andover Academy, with Hal Tine staging some spectacular runs, defeated the Bowdoin freshmen, 13-0, today. Many fumbles marred the first quarter, but in the second the Academy attack clicked, with Kausel plunging over after a march featured by a Harrison to Seymour pass.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 28: COMMANDER Pamperin, L. S., Fourth Naval District, to command the Antares. LIEUTENANTS Henderson, H. H., to duty at Submarine Escape Training Tank, Pearl Harbor, T. H.

Either H. G. Wells has never heard of Mr. Throttlebottom or he has taken him too seriously. The distinguished Englishman in a lecture at Philadelphia on American institutions saw us without any national binding cement.
AS announced in the news columns last Sunday, the Frick Collection has just acquired from Wildenstein's another work by Francois Boucher.
The government has completed arrangements for construction of a modern broad-gauge railway in Northeastern Rumania between Salva and Viseu, replacing the antiquated wartime' narrow gauge line.

THE Reading Symphony Orchestra, which celebrates its twenty-fifth anniversary this year, plans to make its current season an outstanding one in the history of serious music in the Pennsylvania community. The orchestra, under Hans Kindler, who enters his seventh year with the organization, will be augmented to ninety musicians, and guest artists will appear at every concert.
ONE cannot go in for furs half heartedly this Winter-they must be thought about in a big way. Rather than use skimpy ones it is much better to use none at all, which is equally good style.

The stock market moved narrowly during the two-hour trading period yesterday and closed steady. Leading stocks fluctuated with a range from fractions to 2 1/2 points in the dullest trading of the month. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 713,910 shares, compared with 1,565,000 the Saturday before.

Samuel Ullmann, a member of the firm of Case Co., Inc., lace importers, of 220 West Fortieth Street, died on Thursday at the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-sixth Street and Park Avenue, after an illness of several months. He was 66 years old and lived at 200 West Ninetieth Street.

Officers and members of the operating committee of the Automotive Safety Foundation, sponsored by the Automobile Manufacturers Association, were re-elected unanimously at a meeting of the trustees of the foundation, it was disclosed yesterday.
NEXT Friday Ida M. Tarbell will celebrate her eightieth birthday. Memories are many at fourscore years, but this tall, thin, delicatelooking woman prefers to look forward rather than toward the past.

THOSE of us who have had a part in the planning of the second National New York Times Book Fair and have been involved in the infinite detail of creating a large complex exhibit of this kind are disconcerted by this remark made occasionally by our friends:

Countess Laszlo Szechenyi gave a dinner at the Breakers tonight; F. Razier Jelke, who returned to Eagle's Nest with guests for the week-end, also was a dinner host, and Perry Belmont entertained another dinner group at his home, Elm Cottage.

A tiger, very much alive, but caged, rode through New York's streets last week in a truck bearing the sign: "Keep the Tammany Tiger Caged." It expressed the issue emphasized in the city campaign by Mayor La Guardia and his Republican-Fusion-Labor-Progressive supporters.

Miss Katherine Leach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Howland Leach, was married here tonight at the home of her parents to Dr. Robert Emmett Mullarky of Seattle, son of Mrs. Patrick Henry Mullarky of Lewiston, Idaho, and the late Mr. Mullarky. The Rev. John H.

Lafayette remained in the select ranks of undefeated, untied and unscored-upon teams by repulsing the attack of a doughty Franklin and Marshall eleven in Fisher Stadium today while pushing across two touchdowns to triumph, 14--0.

Public officials of Westchester County and its eighteen towns and four cities will be elected Tuesday, but overshadowing in importance the elevation of individuals to public office, in the opinion of political observers, are referendums to be held on two major administrative changes.

The engagement of Miss Janet Evelyn Ullman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Ullman of 101 West Fifty-fifth Street, to Eugene Mentzel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Mentzel, also of this city, has been announced by her parents.
Every effort is being made in diplomatic circles here to verify the report that Japan has offered peace terms to China. There seems little doubt that some sort of negotiations have been started.

Among the many entertainments planned for younger members of society who will be at home from schools and colleges for the Winter holidays is the first Dolphin Dance for this season, which will take place on Dec. 20 in the ballroom of the Pierre. A second dance will be held during the Easter season.

THE man who on Jan. 1 takes over the task of guiding the destinies of metropolitan New York will assume a burden that is generally rated second only to that of the President. The new Mayor, whoever he may be, must be ready to deal with the problems and the needs of seven and a half million people.
Mrs. John T. H. Mitchell and her daughter, Miss Ann Mitchell, gave a luncheon today at The Castle, their country home here, for Mrs. Arthur Wooley-Hart of London.
With a touchdown by Goodrich and a field goal and extra point by Byrnes in the third quarter, St. Lawrence downed Northeastern 10--0 today.

Henry L. Doherty, New York financier who began an extensive resort development program In the Miami section of Florida six years ago, has extended his holdings in that State by the acquisition of four well-known Palm Beach properties.

The net operating income of the Class I railways in September was $59,304,948, a decrease of 15.4 per cent from September, 1936, the Association of American Railroads reported yesterday. Statements for October issued yesterday follow:

The marriage of Miss Patricia Wineberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wineberg of Evanston, Ill., to Warner F. De Foe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. De Foe of Scarsdale, N. Y., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The first tool in the propagandist's kit for fooling the public is listed as "the name-calling device" by the newly organized Institute for Propaganda Analysis, Inc., which enumerates seven such devices in its second monthly letter issued yesterday.

TREE FELLING has become a sport in Australia. More than 100,000 people paid to see the "wood-chopa" in Sydney recently, and former lumbermen like Marshall Winkle, the, new Australian champion, are making $5,000 a year by touring from show to show.

The Hornell Board of Education unanimously upheld today dismissal of the high school principal, Edward W. Cooke, on charges of incompetence and inefficiency. A. M. Seaman, board president, said the decision officially removed Mr. Cooke, retroactive to Aug. 17,

IN 1643 there was printed in London a little book by John White called "First Century of Scandalous, Malignant Priests." It was, briefly, as its subtitle explained. "A Narration of the Causes for which the Pariiament hath Ordered the Sequestration of the Benefices of severall Ministers."

Chinese are voicing warm expressions of gratitude to the United Atates as a result of the action of the American Embassy in turning over to the Chinese Red Cross large shipments of drugs which arrived here by plane from San Francisco.

Socially and economically, the outlook for agriculture as a career is better than at any time in recent years, Governor Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday at the dedication exercises of the new $245,000 dormitory and dining hell of the State Institute of Applied Agriculture at Farmingdale, L. I.
A late first-period end-around play on which Mike Latvis ran 20 yards to score standing up, gave Williams a 6-to-0 victory overUnion before 3,500 spectators on Weston Field today.

Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington correspondent of The Times of London, replied sharply yesterday to the assertion of Quincy How, editor of the publishing concern of Simon Schuster, that "England expects every American to do his duty."
A group of recent Harvard graduates is out to enlist 15,000,000 Americans of military age as the nucleus of a standing "police army" to enforce international peace and supplant the League of Nations.

When some paroled criminal, negligently watched, is caught plying his old trade, hasty persons are sure that the parole system has "broken down." In The Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology Mr. Huff, general superintendent of District of Columbia prisons and formerly parole executive of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, writes on the "Custodial Aspects of Federal Parole."

Northwestern pushed Wisconsin from the ranks of the undefeated in Big Ten football competition today with a 14-to-6 victory before a crowd of 30,000 in a game that dragged because of unseasonably warm weather.
Ralph Greenleaf, defending champion, today defeated the former national champion, George Kelly of Philadelphia, 125 to minus 6, in eleven innings in the world pocket billiard tournament.

The Boerse remained listless today, quotations moving only fractionally. Among the heavy industrials Hoesch gained 1 1/4 points, but other stocks were virtually unchanged. Hapag lost 1 1/2 points and Nord Deutscher Lloyd was off fractionally.

Miss Barbara Cary, daughter of Commander Robert W. Cary, U. S. N., and Mrs. Cary, 'has chosen Miss Patricia Guiler, daughter of Commander R. P. Guiler, U. S. N. (retired), and Mrs. Guiler of Washington, as her only .attendant at her marriage on Thursday to Lewis Pembroke Brown of Hartford, Conn.

An evening of roller-skating, indoor games and carnival divertissements has been arranged for the night of Nov. 12, when the Carnival on Wheels will be given at the Mecca Temple Casino, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the Vocational Service for Juniors.

IT is always comforting to know, when starting to read a murder story, that the person who is to be eliminated is one whose passing will not be regretted. The title of this book tells no more than the literal truth. When P. L. Brandon,

Pointing out that slum prevention is as important. as slum clearance in any large-scale, long-range housing program. for the New York metropolitan area, Irwin S. Chanin, architect and builder, warns that future slums can be avoided only through planned residential development.

A mail order house for supplying the German population in foreign countries has been founded here under governmental auspices. Named the Homeland Service Corporation, it will issue a catalogue presenting a great variety of German goods.

The executive committee of the National Maritime Union charged yesterday that an organized "whispering campaign" had been started on the waterfront, directed against several of the union officials, with a view to disrupting negotiations between the union and ship lines for new wage contracts.

Miss Lucy Hutchinson heads a group of young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons who are aiding in the plans for the annual dinner and dance for the benefit of the Alice Hall Ali Memorial Fund of the Prosperity Shop Nov. 19 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

Delegates from fifty-five clubs will attend the conference of the seventh and eighth districts of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs Thursday at the Newark Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. Mark O. Kimberling, Superintendent of State Police; Miss Clarette Sehon,

ELECTION bulletins from the Press-Radio Bureau will be broadcast by the majority of New York stations on Tuesday night at frequent intervals or during the regular periods listed in the programs for news items.
More houses taken, more lines captured, more trenches creeping around the last Rebel positions at White Hill-such is the picture of the Usera sector that a correspondent got today.

Groucho and Chico Marx, movie comedians, were convicted in Federal Court today of infringing on a copyright in a radio broadcast-a verdict which Groucho said in tragic tones, as the jury retired, "might mean a jail jolt for us."

"Stormfield," imposing, Connecticut estate with an Italian villa, many outbuildings and 209 acres of land, at Redding Ridge, has been -sold by Mrs. Mary Mallett to Mrs. Doreen Danks of New York. Ladd Nichols acted as brokers. The property was reported held at $150,000.

A committee of coat manufacturers and wholesalers has been formed to seek restoration of the former discount terms on woolens, most of which are now bought on a net basis, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

Amid a din of whistles blowing and torpedoes exploding, Matthew H. Bruen, aged 71, oldest engineer on the Putnam division of the New York Central Railroad, drove his engine into the roundhouse here tonight, completing fifty-five years of service as fireman and engineer, and retired from the service.

Upsala College defeated Shenandoah College at Ashland Stadium today, 27--0, for its second victory. Vito Miele crossed the visitors' goal line in the first and third periods, the second being followed by an automatic safety four plays later.

Senator Carter Glass of Virginia received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Hamilton College today. In a brief speech of thanks for the honor he expressed the wish, although he is a Jeffersonian Democrat that there were many Alexander Hamiltons in Washington. He added:

The executive board of the Deutsch-Amerikanischer Buerger Bund des Staates New York, the German-American Citizens League of the State of New York, adopted a resolution at a meeting yesterday at 401 Broadway attacking Mayor La Guardia as "un- and anti-Amerlcan" and endorsing Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor.

Better is a dinner of herbs where love is than a stalled ox and hatred therewith. LET something be said for kind ness in a play. It is one of the positive virtues. It turns up in this left-hand corner of the page in connection with "As You Like It," which the Surry Players .are now reviving, for "As You Like it" Is one of the kiNdest plays in our language.
The performance of "Aida" on Dec. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House has been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Aid Society's Foster Home Department and the Jones Children's Center.

Period furniture, Mortlake and Brussels Renaissance tapestries, paintings, Rodin and Remington bronzes, Oriental rugs and other appointments for interiors will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

James G. Graham, secretary and confidential adviser to Governor Benjamin B. Odell Jr. when the latter was a power in Republican party councils, died in St. Luke's Hospital here tonight after an illness of several months. He was 72 years old. Mr. Graham was born in Shawangunk, Ulster County, Dec. 21, 1864. He was admitted to the bar in 1885.

PINEJHURST, N. C.--Golf, as usual, will be the chief preoccupation at this mid-South resort during November. The month will be crowded with sports activity, the trend indicating an earlier and busier season than in former years. Cottage residents and hotel guests are arriving each day for the late and lasting "Indian Summer" weather now prevalent.

The cities of South Spain commemorated the war-fallen yesterday, the fourth anniversary of the Falange, Fascist party, with massed parades. It is estimated that 70,000 of the Fascist militia poured into Seville alone from surrounding villages.

Miss Mary Jane Kevan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Kevan of this city, was married to Hilles Ryan Pickens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hilles R. Pickens of Montreal, in the Church of the Ascension here. The Rev. Melford L. Brown officiated. A.reception was held at the Gramatan, Bronxville. Miss Catherine Clark Kevan was her sister's maid of honor.

The selective policy of admissions introduced in the Columbia Law School ten years ago with the object of training fewer but better lawyers has resulted in an increased number of well-qualified applicants representative of a wider geographical area, Professor Albert C. Jacobs, chairman of the Committee on Selection of Students, declared in a report to Dean Young B. Smith, made public yesterday.

IF there were a Chamber of Commerce in Surry, Me., it would do something handsome for the troupe which opened last night in "As You Like It" at the Ritz Theatre. But there isn't any Chamber of Commerce in Surry.

The International Mercantile Marine Company'won its dispute with striking seamen on the Panama Pacific liner Virginia yesterday when the workers signed for service in the face of a company threat to tie up the vessel and cancel the sailing.

London's famous policemen are the admiration of all visitors, but it is the postmen who win the praise of resident Americans. Although the Postmaster General every year reports a thumping surplus to Parliament (which is not merely a bookkeeping claim), money is used to keep the postmen delivering letters until 9 or 10 o'clock-after the maid has gone and it's time to think of putting out the cat.

Asserting that the Third Avenue Railway Company was insolvent, three of its bondholders, with total holdings of only $8,500, petitioned Federal Court yesterday for reorganization of the trolley system under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Michael Heumann, proprietor of the Lexington Hotel here, died in the hotel today of pneumonia at the age of 86. He had owned several hotels and dance halls in New 'York, including the Terrace Gardens in East Fifty-eighth Street; the National Garden on the Bowery and the Harlem Casino at 124th Street and Seventh Avenue.

The marriage of Miss Anne Ridgely Andrews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Newman Andrews of Somerset, Va., and Aiken, S. C., to John Sharpless McIntyre, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McIntyre of Cleveland and Hobby Horse Farm, Hollins, Va., took place this afternoon in Christ Church, Christiana Hundred, which was built by the bride's great-grandfather,

THE disruptions in artistic life caused by the encroachment of political creed are almost tragically exemplified in the career of Dr. Heinz Uger, Germanborn conductor, who is visiting this country for the first time. Professionally occupied since his youth in the musical activity of his native land, he has been since 1933 (the date dispenses with further comment) a resident of London.

A series of four lectures, entitled the "First Five Years of Life," will be held during November and December at Town Hall under the auspices of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association. Proceeds will be devoted to the educational work at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

The Public Service Commission will make every, effort to prevent a permanent discontinuance of service on the New Rochelle-Port Chester branch of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, even if Unable to block cessation of service at midnight tonight, Chairman Milo R. Maltbie said yesterday.

All markets in France will be closed tomorrow in observance of All Saints' Day. On Tuesday, general election day in the United States, all markets and banks will be closed in New York and in most other States, although the Chicago Board of Trade will be open, as will the Chicago livestock market, the grain futures and livestock markets in Kansas City, and some of the Pacific Coast securities markets.

THE collection of paintings and photographs of Palestinian scenes and types, brought to this country by Joshua Shaked and exhibited in connection with the twentieth anniversary celebration of the Jewish Center, was taken to Atlantic City last week for the Hadasseh convention.

EVERY year in the last five years a strange sight greets the foreign visitor to Budapest during the first days of June. A host of stalls, tents, pavilions springs up overnight on the pavement and huge posters announce that the "Days of the Book" are on.

A thorough knowledge of the cycle of changes which take place in both residential and business neighborhoods is necessary if one wishes to understand the economic forces which affect land values, states Wallace W. True, assistant chief appraiser of the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

The Curtis High football team bowed to the strong Union-Endicott squad of Endicott, N. Y., 7--O, at Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S. I., yesterday. A crowd of 5,000, composed almost entirely of Curtis root- C ers, saw the rugged up-State team push over a touchdown in the last three minutes of triumph and remain undefeated.

Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt will return Tuesday from Newport, and Mrs. Vanderbilt from Hot Springs, Va. William H. Sudduth 2d and his bride have returned from Honolulu and are at their new home at 6 Sniffen Court. Mrs. Sudduth is the former Miss Muriel Selden of Greenwich. Conn.
The Hobart College eleven invaded the University of Rochester football domain today to hand the locals a 19-to-0 defeat, their fifth straight of the campaign, before a crowd of nearly 6,000.
Hungarian newspapers report that the Regent, Admiral Nicolas Horthy, will go to Berlin next week to take part in a hunting party in connection with the opening of the hunting exposition.

Plans for the extension in 1938 of the home ownership program initiated this year by the National Lumber Manufacturers Association will be the principal subject for consideration at a meeting of the board of directors of the association in New Orleans Nov. 10, 11 and 12.

Miss Jean Van-Horne, daughter of Mrs. Byron Barret Van Horne of this place, was married today to Malcolm Johns Baber of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. William. Davis Baber of Pottsville, Pa. The ceremony was performed at the First Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Carl Hopkins Elmore, the pastor.

Rivalry over the "empty honor" of being classed as titular leader of the Republican party is th real basis of the present differences between former President Hoover and Alfred M. Landon, according to Charles Michelson, Director of Publicity of the Democratic National Committee.

TRADE reports became even spottier in the week. While some sections were as much as 15 per cent ahead of last year, important areas held only even or slipped under 1936 sales figures. The heavy industry districts particularly seemed to lose ground.

The Wagnerian Festival Singers will give a concert Tuesday night at the College of New Rochelle for the benefit of the library building fund, it was announced today. Miss Marjorie Kelly is chairman of the concert committee.
WORKING in reverse, probably because the temptation to start with the set including "Sea Drift" was too much, Columbia follows the second Delius Society album with Volume I.

Patrick J. Swan, for thirty-five years superintendent of Mount St. Mary Cemetery, Flushing, died yesterday at his home, 46-63 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing. Mr. Swan was born in Ireland seventy-six- years ago and came to the United States in 1887.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Louise Silverman of Harrison, N. Y., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry Silverman, to Jason David Radding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Radding of Larchmont, N. Y.

One hundred and ten book publishers will be represented in exhibits at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair. In preparation for the public opening next Friday morning, they are now putting the finishing touches on a panorama of current books and what lies behind them, to be spread over the two top floors of the International Building in Rockefeller Center.

The paste pot and a pair of shears are required accessories at Colby Junior College, New London, N. H., in a course in "Contemporary American Problems" in which students make their own textbooks. The instructor's lectures, a reading list, the student's personal judgments and a scrapbook of illustrative clippings from newspapers and periodicals are the basis for the work.

The next few A days are likely to prove very ominous for European peace. Once more the most competent observers anxlously are asking themselves when er it will be possible, after all, uphold the policy of non-intervention in Spain.

Johnny Goodman of Omaha, United States amateur champion, opened his defense of the amateur golf championship, of Mexico today by routing Morris Norton of Wichita Falls, Texas, 6 and 5, in a firstround match. Goodman,

The football teams of Berkshire and Kent battled to a scoreless tie on Alumni Field today. The game, played in a high wind, saw many fumbles made by both sides. Immediately after the Berkshire kickoff a Kent fumble gave the ball to the visitors.
The British freighter Jean Weems was sunk sixteen miles off the Catalan coast by a Rebel plane, according to a communique from the Ministry of National Defense tonight.
A new two-story store building, the latest addition to the growing shopping facilities on Madison Avenue, has been completed at the northeast corner of Forty-eighth Street.

In the forefront of interest on the Vassar campus is the annual canvass conducted by the Students' Association for funds for philanthropic purposes, the only appeal made to the college community during the year for such contributions.

Plans for building a student scholarship fund are among the subjects to be considered by the New Jersey State Federation of Music Clubs at the Autumn conference Saturday in the Presbyterian Church in Haddon Heights.

A revolutionary program of elementary school teacher training which accents the "well-rounded personality" more than the three R's is undertaking to prepare eighty girl students at New York University's School of Education for their future profession by intensive application of progressive education principles.

A crowd of 6,500 saw the Port Chester and Greenwich (Conn.) high school elevens renew their ancient rivalry at John W. Ryan Stadium today. Port Chester, defend ing Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association champion, won, 7 to 6, Kettler's conversion of an extra point on a plunge through tackle being the deciding factor.

AMES-SHANSKE--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Shanske announce the marriage of their daughter, Florence, to Sidney Ames, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mde Ames of Brooklyn, taking place Oct. 31. COPSTEIN-SPECTORSKY-Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Spectorsky take pleasure in announcing the marriage of their daughter, Miriam Lenore, to Mr. Seymour A. Copstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Copstein, at Hinsdale, Mass., Oct. 27, 1937.
Professor Hurst R. Anderson of the Allegheny College Speech Department outlined plans today for a speakers' bureau to serve district clubs and organizations free of charge.

The second annual edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair will open to the public at 11 o'clock next Friday morning. This year the two top floors of the International Building in Rockefeller Center, on Fifth Avenue just opposite St. Patrick's

Miss Hazel F. Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Silas E. Moore of this city, became the bride of Harold E. Crane Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. H. E. Crane of Atlantic City, in St. Johns Episcopal Church here this afternoon.

"I 'M sorry anybody brought it up." Speaking is not a ticket broker of October business, but Arthur Hopkins, squire of the arcate den adjacent to the balcony of the Plymouth Theatre. Specifically, of the fact that the onrushing December will mark the completion of his twenty-fifth year as a producer, discoverer of stars and chronicler of things theatrical.

Harvesting of one of the largest walnut crops in years is being completed in the Pacific Northwest. The combined yield in Oregon and Washington is estimated at 4,000 tons, almost a fifth greater than a year ago.

Amid a strongly mixed reception of boos and heils, the GermanAmerican Bund, numbering 800 uniformed members, paraded through Yorkville yesterday afternoon under the watchful eye of 1,300 patrolmen, who were stationed along the line of march and also on the rooftops of buildings to prevent possible disorder.
FASTER steering, easier handling and more effortless control will distinguish the new automobiles for 1938, as a result of important mechanical changes to be introduced at the automobile show here.

At his Friday press conference in Hyde Park the President remarked that newspaper accent on government relief was being concentrated these days in the business sector. He looked vainly in such dispatches, said Mr. Roosevelt, for stress on the depleted purchasing power of the low-income groups and the necessity of increasing this by augmenting the national income.

Mrs. Ira Haupt will give a reception Thursday at her Tower apartment in the Waldorf-Astoria for the 100 men and women who-have been conducting an informal drive for 1,000 new contributions to Irvington House, sanitorium for child heart cripples.

In Madison Square Garden next Wednesday morning the National Horse Show Association will inaugurate its fifty-second annual exhibition, which will continue through the following Wednesday, Nov. 10. With the exception of Sunday, when there will be only an evening performance, afternoon and evening sessions are slated daily.
Rescuers early today freed Manuel Camacho, 19 years old, of Lowell, from a sandbank in which he had been buried up to his neck for twelve hours. Almost unconscious at the end,
SO far as I am aware, no new appeal has recently been issued in America by the committee which has for so many years been attempting to establish a national theatre in England.

Dick Dawe's accurate placement kick after the first Muhlenberg touchdown proved to be Muhlenberg's margin of victory in the Cardinal and Grey's 13--12 triumph over the Gettysburg Bullets on Memorial Field today before a home coming day crowd of 5,000.

Leaders of other patriotic societies will be guests of the Manhattan chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution at its annual regent's day reception and tea on Friday at the Essex House Colonnades.
IT is by now no secret that by producing Michel Fokine's "Coq d'Or," the DeBasil Ballet Russe has made itself eligible for some special kind of distinguished service medal. It is, indeed,

Miss Louise Shoemaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Shoemaker, was married to William Alexander Brunson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mason C. Brunson of Florence, S. C., this evening in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Thomas Sparkman, the rector.

To the Drama Editor: In answer to "An American Actor," I take this liberty of pointing out how misinformed he is in stating "the few American actors who are in London are faced with rigidly enforced restrictions as to the limit of their engagement."

In an address at the Fall luncheon of the American Association of University Women yesterday Dean Margaret Morris of Pembroke College, Brown University, said the A. A. U. W. mobilized college women into an organization which energized the individual and strengthened the leadership of the group.
Four architects have been named as a jury to select sixty architects qualified for municipal appointment during the coming year, under a plan approved by Mayor La Guardia.
John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, announced yesterday that final arrangements to insure an honest and orderly election had been completed.

William H. Donner, retired steel manufacturer, who founded the International Cancer Research Foundation in 1932 with a gift of $2,000,000, has presented to the University of Pennslyvania $200,000 to enable the University Hospital to establish a new radiological and X-ray department for the study of malignant diseases.

Despite a thrilling last-period comeback, the Hill School had to be content with a 13-all tie today in the thirty-second ganie of its traditional rivalry with Lawrenceville as both teams remained undefeated for the current campaign.

Activity in the New York wholesale market held up well last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. Sports coats, underwear and home furnishings accounted for the bulk of orders received. The report continued:

A youthful hold-up man who attempted to rob the Albert Hosiery store at 609 Madison Avenue at 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon was captured by a patrolman when one of two girl employes of the store defied his order to "stick 'em up" and ran screaming into the crowded street.

J. Edward Breuer, auctioneer, predicts that the year 1938 will be the best for real estate on Long Island since 1928. Recent acreage deals for home development indicate, he says, that builders are preparing for large volume construction next year.

Mayor La Guardia will dedicate a new 1,000-watt transmitter of the municipal radio Station WNYC, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn tomorrow at ceremonies which will begin at 1:30 P. M. at the foot of Greenpoint Avenue and the East River.
Marion E. Martin of Bangor, Me., assistant to Republican Chairman John D. M. Hamilton, holds her job through a mistake, she says. She was reading one night in 1930 when the phone rang.

JULES ECKERT GOODMAN first experienced the flushes and fevers born of collaboration when, an undergraduate of Columbia, he became inflamed with a desire to interrupt "Joan of Arc" with exits and entrances and battlements. Fierce in his quest, he invaded the chamber of a whitemaned, white-mustached man in lower Fifth Avenue to ask if he would be outraged over such a plot.

Pennsylvania's underdog football team came through with a surprise triumph over the Navy eleven today. Registering two touchdowns in the second period, the Red and Blue built up just enough of an advantage- to offset a Navy third-period score and walked off -the field on the long end of a 14-to-7 count.

Two major considerations before the welfare conference to be held by the Association of Junior Leagues of America opening tomorrow in Milwaukee are the movements to raise standards of household employment to make it more attractive to workers, and to increase the layman's responsibility in public social work.

Commenting on the auction sales now being conducted to dispose of the real estate holdings of closed national banks in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, Joseph P. Day, auctioneer, said yesterday that they are producing many beneficial results.

The only eclipse of the moon in 1937 will occur on Nov. 18 and perhaps will be entirely visible here, according to the monthly sky calendar issued by the Hayden Planetarium of the Anierican Museum of Natural History.

The twin shadow of economic recession and international tension brooded over Parliament this week at the start of the new session, which will continue with only slight interruptions until the end of next July.

Elimination of existing intergovernmental exemptions from taxation, under which interest on the securities of Federal, State and local governments is relieved of taxes and governmental employes are exempted from income taxes, was advocated last week by Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

Mrs. Rose Cahan will speak on "Parent and Child Relations" at the first of a series of five lectures to be held tomorrow morning at the Jewish Seminary of America, under the sponsorship of Ivriah, the women's division of the Jewish Education Association. Mrs. Gabriel Hamburger, chairman, will preside.

A TOP the Kittatinny Ridge in Eastern Pennsylvania, near the little town of Drehersville, nature lovers and ornithologists are gathering these days. For the Fall flights are on, and there, at Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, they are met to observe and thrill to the passing of the birds of prey.

Mayor La Guardia will officiate at 3 P. M. tomorrow at the laying of a cornerstone to mark the completion of the foundation of the Bronx anchorage of the BronxWhitestone Bridge, it was announced yesterday by Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority.

The Exeter and Hebron Academy elevens battled to a scoreless tie today, although both had several opportunities to tally. In the second period Hebron got to the 7-yard line, where Johns failed at a field goal, and in the last period was well on the way to a touchdown when a forward went wrong and Exeter, recovered. and Exeter, recovered.

A preview performance of "Four Cents a Word" will be held at the Windsor Theatre on Nov. 20 for the benefit of the Metropolitan Junior Achievement, Inc., 16 East Fortyeighth Street, and will be followed by supper and dancing at the Restaurant Larue.

Voters of the city will go to the polls on Tuesday to select the city administration for the next four years, bringing to a close one of the most bitter local campaigns in recent history. It is predicted that as many as 2,300,000 citizens will exercise their franchise.

One of the world's celebrated collections of air-mail stamps and covers, assembled by Roger Steffan, a vice president of the National City Bank, was sold for approximately $75,300 yesterday and Friday at an auction conducted by Walter S. Scott for Nicolas Sanabria at 17 East Forty-second Street.

Miss Cynthia Brewster Wattles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Prime Wattles of Washington, formerly of Wynnewood, was married at noon today to Lieutenant Neale Roland Curtin, U.S.N., son of Mrs. T. A. Solberg of Annapolis and of the late Lieut. Comdr. Roland I. Curtin, U.S.N.

The combination of week-end holiday and mild weather helped yesterday to increase attendance at the 1938 General Motors Show in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Should the weather remain mild today, company officials expect the largest turnout since the show opened Wednesday.

The New York Aggies scored their fourth straight victory today by defeating the Wagner eleven, 43 to 14. before a large home crowd. Kaplan led the victors in scoring with five touchdowns, having runs of 45 and 35 yards.

He cites the fact that Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson, in deciding a recent tax case tried before him in White Plains, said.

Alfred University's eleven remained unbeaten as it conquered Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today, 13--0. Two long marches in the middle of the first and second periods were capped by Johnson and Glynn crossing the line.

The undefeated Dickinson College football team won its fifth game of the season by trouncing American University,' 41-0, on Biddle Field today before 2,500 spectators in the first meeting between the two elevens.

The defeat of the swimmers of James Monroe, Manhattan-BronxRichmond champions of the Public School Athletic League, was the high light of the fifth series of dual meets for the triborough senior high team title, conducted in the 25-yard pool of De Witt Clinton yesterday.
A 72-yard scoring dash by Eddie Berlinski, a backfield replacement, gave North Carolina State a 12-7 victory over a baffled Boston College team today before a crowd of 12,000.

The Department of Commerce issued some figures the other day that capture the interest of hibernating yachtsmen whose craft are now hauled out for the Winter and who have plenty of time ashore before the 1938 overhauling.

Dr. John Randolph Haynes, surgeon and civic leader, an early advocate of the initiative, referendum and recall provisions for city charters, died here today at the age of 84. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage a month ago. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, he moved to Los Angeles in 1887 and began his medical practice.

The treaties made between the nations of Americas are not regarded as scraps of paper, and that attitude has had great effect on the rest of the world, President Roosevelt said today in talking with the flying squadron of the People's Mandate for Peace.

Miss Cynthia Brewster Wattles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Prime Wattles of Washington, formerly of Wynnewood, was married at noon today to Lieutenant Neale Roland Curtin, U.S.N., son of Mrs. T. A. Solberg of Annapolis and of the late Lieut. Comdr. Roland I. Curtin, U.S.N.

Purdue's Boilermakers displayed a running attack for the first time this season and vanquished Iowa, 13 to 0, today to pull out of a tie for the Big Ten Conference cellar before a Dads' Day crowd of 20,000.
William MacRossie of Ladd Nichols, Greenwich, Conn., has been elected a member of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, a division of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

BOOKINGS for Christmas journeys to the "old country" are reported by all big steamship lines. Ships to Scottish, Irish and English ports, to Poland, Germany and Scandinavia, schedule sailings in good time to reach their destinations before the Yuletide.

Arthur Kaufmann, retired architect and business man, of 37 East Sixty-fourth Street, died Friday night in San Francisco of pneumonia, following illness of several weeks. He was a member of the Harmony Club and the North Shore and Sunningdale Country Clubs.

Frederick Sterling, one of the American Commissioners to the Paris Exposition, and Mrs. Sterling have been occupying the house in the Square du Bois de Boulogne that belonged to the late Mrs. Charles B. Alexander of New York.

An immediate reduction of approximately 20 per cent in the wholesale prices of Old Schenley and Monticello bottled-in-bond whiskies was announced yesterday by the Schenley Products Company. The James E. Pepper bonded Kentucky rye was reduced approximately 17 per cent.

Brown defeated Tufts, 19 to 0, today as. Coach D. O. (Tuss) McLaughry got his first opportunity of the season to use all of his reserves. The Bruins scored in the first, third and fourth periods, and capitalized on three of the four scoring opportunities presented.

In the presence of a large gallery of enthusiasts, including many members of New York and Long Island society, Pons Junior of Wingan won the amateur stake at the annual Autumn retriever trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association, which will be concluded tomorrow.
Attention was called to the unfavorable trade balance between Panama and Japan by The Panama American in a campaign for a boycott of Japanese goods here.

The Coast Guard cutter Champlain was speeding to the assistance of the British freighter Lord Byron last night after the vessel dropped her propeller and asked for aid about eighty-five miles east of New York.

For the first time since late in June, 1936, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity is below the estimated "normal" line. Declining for the tenth consecutive week,the index stands at 97.9 for the week ended on Oct. 23 and compares with 100.2 for the preceding week and 101.2 for the corresponding week last year.

Miss Helen Tufts Crocker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Harrower of the Hilltop, Fitchburg, and Edgar Steuart Davis, son of Edmonds Steuart Davis of Southampton, L. I., were married at noon today in Christ Church. The Rev.

Carol Moorland, a young pianist from New Orleans who received her musical education abroad, made her local debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Miss Moorland took her first lessons on the instrument from Lucie Cafferet in Paris.
Nelson J. Edge 2d of this place has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Adele Edge, to J. Randolph Jones of New York and Richmond, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chesnut E. Jones of Richmond.

The trustees of the American Medical Associaton played host today to members of the National Association of Science Writers in a special conference, at which representatives of organized medicine in America, medical columnists and science reporters exchanged views on ways and means to keep the public informed of progress in medical science.

Mrs. Harold H. Hackett, who heads the executive committee of the-Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, is chairman of the group in charge of the arrangements for a large card party in behalf of that organization Wednesday afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria.

A conference to celebrate inauguration of a national program for slum clearance will be held in New York on Nov. 12 and 13 under the sponsorship of the National Public Housing Conference and sixty other organizations, including the housing authorities of Buffalo, Syracuse, Schenectady, Yonkers and New York City.

Professor Percival J. Parrott was appointed today director of the State Agricultural Station here to succeed Dr. Ulysses P. Hedrick, resigned. Professor Parrott, vice director at the station since 1929, will assume his new position on Jan. 15.

Miss Lucile Forman, daughter of Mrs. Harry B. Spaulding, was married to Chauncey J. Hamlin Jr. of this city this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church, by the Right Rev. Cameron J. Davis, Bishop of Western New York.

THE annual pageant of thoroughbreds put on by the National Horse Show Association will start an eight-day run at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, and thousands of horse lovers are converging on New York for this annual classic of the show ring.

AMPHITRYON 38-Tomorrow evening at the Shubert Theatre. Being S. N. Behrman's adaptation of the Jean Giraudoux adaptation of the legend of the descent of Jupiter to woo a mortal lady of unquestioned virtue. Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne have the leading roles, with other players including Richard Whorf, Barry Thomson, Sydney Greenstreet, Edith King, George Meader and Alan Hewitt.

Industrial activity was curtailed further, wholesale buying was hesitant and retail trade made a fair showing in most districts last week, but there were outstanding exceptions to each of these trends in some areas.

The marriage of Miss Natalie Gillet Adenaw, daughter of Mrs. William Effingham Lawrence Hunter of Flushing, Queens, and Litchfield, Conn., and of the late Arthur Paul Frederick Adenaw, to John Brantley Mulford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Brantley Mulford of Philadelphia and Penrith Farm, Lodi, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in St. George's Church, Flushing.

Sir Herbert Eustace Maxwell, seventh Baronet of Monreith, Scottish educator, historian and novelist, died today at the age of 92.
