He was a Lord of the Treasury from 1886 to 1892, chairman of the Royal Commission on Tuberculosis in 1897-98 and chairman of the National Library of Scotland from 1928 to 1935.
Glue-fingered pass receivers and a trio of nimble-footed quarterbacks gave Tennessee's Volunteers an overwhelming 32-to-0 victory over the University of Georgia today before 15,000 spectators.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Walton High School Exhibition Hall, 196th Street and Reservoir, Avenue, the Bronx-20 easel paintings, 39 graphic prints, 7 pieces sculpture, 15 textiles of design.

AN outstanding feature of the 1938 edition of the united States Stamp Catalpgue, which was released last week, is the inclusion, for the first time, of the embossed revenue stamped paper which Great Britain forced upon the American Colonies by Acts of Parliament from 1755 onward to represent payment of taxes on almanacs, newspapers and commodities.

Bright children possess a finely developed sense of humor, and are above the average in personality, cheerfulness and good looks, according to a study made public yesterday by Professor Leta S. Hollingworth, educational psychologist at Teachers College, Columbia University.

Paced by Ralph Kelly, who scored three touchdowns, the Indiana State teachers of Pennsylvania today chalked up a 25-to-0 victory over the Mansfield Teachers before a homecoming-day crowd of 3,000 Kelly scored in the second, third and fourth periods on runs of 80, 60 and 5 yards.

IT is fifty years since "Corno di Bassetto" struck up his lively and sonorous tune in, the columns of T. P. O'Connor's newspaper The Star of London. (Who but Bernard Shaw would have invented the pseudonym?) Long before he wrote of drama Shaw acted as music critic. This was in 1888,
To Fergus Reid of Norfolk was given the Algernon Sydney Sullivan award by Sweet Briar College at the annual Founders' Day exercises yesterday morning.

When Great Britain dispatched the Hood, the world's strongest warship, to the Balearic Islands on Wednesday the strategic position of that archipelago in the Spanish and Mediterranean crisis was further emphasized.
A dead leaf fluttered down upon the general's cap and the band played "The Caissons Go Rolling Along" as the last truck rolled past the reviewing stand at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Credit conditions in thirteen of the twenty-one markets covered in its quarterly survey of Latin-America showed an improvement during the third quarter of the year, the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men reported yesterday.

H. Lamson Scovill died today of a heart ailment at his home here at the age of 56. Mr. Scovill was president of the Oiljak Manufacturing Company of Montclair and a director of the Scovill Manufacturing Company of Waterbury, Conn., a business founded by his grandfather, James Mitchell Lamson Scovill. He was a resident here thirty years.

RIGHT now, in a place some distance from New York, a symphony orchestra is in a turmoil because the conductor, after testing each member of the orchestra by having him play unidentified, behind a screen, has requested the retirement of ten players and their replacement with new men, most if not all of whom are younger than those invited to leave the organization.
Resuming play for the have chess championship of the world, Kel Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and a mi Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris contested the eleventh game of the series tonight.

Crusades against crime require the constant backing of the religious forces in the community, Rabbi Louis I. Newman declared yesterday in his sermon at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eightythird Street. The enthusiasm engendered during a campaign period is not sufficient to defeat criminal elements within society, he warned.

New York City will embark on Tuesday on a major political change in the form of election of a City Council by proportional representation voting. The new City Council will supplant the present Board of Aldermen, and as it gets into operation after the first of the new year it is expected to become the focus of attention not alone in New York but throughout the nation.

President Roosevelt, staying at Hyde Park last week, was host to a variety of callers. W. Averell Harriman, president of the Union Pacific and head of the President's Business Advisory Council, was on the list.

Mayor La Guardia's campaign managers predicted a landslide that would elect the whole Fusion ticket. One estimate for him was a 750,000 plurality, a record for a Mayoralty election. Impartial observers put his probable margin at a minimum of 200,000. Jeremiah T. Mahoney's manager forecast victory by 350,000 to 400,000.

The British cruiser York arrived here from Bermuda today in the first of. a number of measures to prevent disturbances after the publication of the report of the Colonial Office commission that inquired into the rioting of last June and July.

Yotaro Sugimura, Japanese Ambassador to France, last night attended an exhibition by the Jujitsu Club of France. He was received by Professor Frederick Joliot, president of the club, and his wife, Mme. Irene Joliot-Curie, former member of the Cabinet, who is also a member and instructor in the club.

A forum will be held at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, on the night of Nov. 8 under the auspices of the league's religious education committee. The Rev. Dr.

The Women's City Club today announced a Winter series of forums on "Woman Power and a Modern World." At opening sessions next Thursday the president, Dr. Ella D. Kilgus, and Mrs. Dorothy Fuldheim of Cleveland, news commentator and traveler, will speak.

Any, election is enough to set one to thinking. maybe a bit wistfully, about democracy. The struggle for freedom is like a youthful courtship, full of fire and poetry. Young Lochinvar comes out of the West, swings Universal Suffrage neatly into the saddle, leans over to tighten the Bill of Rights, and with the Australian Ballot in his teeth gallops across the moors and into the Esk River.

Ohio State's high-powered gridiron machine coughed and sputtered for one period today, but found the proper carburetor adjustment and rolled to a 39-to-O triumph over Chicago's game little band of Maroons.

Opera made its 1937 bow to music lovers of Chicago tonight in all its traditional glamour. Society occupied all the box seats. "Aida" was the opera. A cast of Chicago favorites headed by Elisabeth Rethberg in the title role opened the season, which will continue for seven weeks

President Manuel Azana has signed a decree transferring the government from Valencia to Barcelona. The first paragraph states that the seat of the government is located in Barcelona from the date of the publication of the decree.

Munchi Singh, an Indian untouchable under sentence to be hanged November 19, received commutation to life imprisonment by Governor Ridley today. Singh was sentenced to hang April 22 by former Judge R. C. P. Thomas for killing Harjindar Singh, a fellow-laborer, with a machete.
The Yamashita Line has announced the inauguration of a new South American-Pacific Coast service. It will begin with the motor ship Yamazato Maru sailing from Buenos Aires Dec. 26.

The freshman class of the College of William and Mary will hold its election on Monday afternoon in the Phi Beta Kappa Memorial Hall. At a recent meeting a change was made when the freshmen, opposed to the custom of holding elections at the beginning of the year, asked for more time to become acquainted with nominees, and drew up rules governing the election.

Joseph Curran, general organizer of the National Maritime Union, made public yesterday a survey showing that more than' twenty American seamen have been killed while fighting with Loyalist forces in Spain and about 100 wounded.

THE House of Lords had its recurrent day of glory last week when the two thrones at the head of the chamber were undraped and the King and Queen attended for the opening of Parliament. The peers rose to their sumptuous surroundings.

Listed bonds worked irregularly higher in quiet trading yesterday in the short session on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest centered on local traction issues, strength among which stood out as the group feature of the day. The trading pace slowed down to a turnover of $4,179,050, compared with $7,721,175 on. the preceding Saturday.

One of the characteristic features of the home-building activities in many sections of Queens Borough this year has been the sale of several large farm tracts and their immediate development into residential communities with mediumpriced houses.

PROFESSOR BROOKS may not have intended the moral of this well-poised study of union labor in the United States to be that members of labor unions behave about as employers would behave in similar situations, but that is about the gist of it.

ILYA ILF and Eugene Petrov toured 10,000 miles of America two years ago. They went to football games, visited Sing Sing, talked to Henry Ford, kibitzed while J. P. Morgan answered questions for a Senate committee,

Dartmouth students are apparently reading more books, as the circulation figures of the Baker Memorial Library showed a year's increase of 40.000. During the past year the library has added 16,496 volumes, bringing the total to 434,695.

Officers of the Ladies' Adoration Society, of which Mrs. Frank A. Otis is president, have arranged a bridge tournament and tea for the afternoon of Nov. 9 in the Gold Room of Sherry's to raise funds for the philanthropic enterprises of the Convent of Marie Reparatrix at 14 East Twenty-ninth Street.

NORMAL production and sales during the closing months will mark 1937 as the peak year in the motor truck business. Factory sales for the first nine months totaled 764,176 units, or 12.1 per cent above 1929, the last previous high for that period.

Coq Bruyere, an aged gray gelding owned by John Strawbridge, surprised a fashionable crowd of 8,000 as he galloped home an easy winner of the New Jersey Hunt Cup, which featured the closing day of the Essex fox hounds meeting.

IN this book Mr. Arthur Hopkins, the theatrical producer, has carried out a novel idea, that of writing an autobiography in a series of letters addressed to a friendless boy, suffering in a hospital from an incurable disease.

MOZABRT'S comic opera, "Cosi Fan Tutte," will be the opening attraction of the Salzburg Opera Guild at its first appearance here Saturday evening. This opera will head a repertoire of five works to be given during a week's engagement at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

The Pompton Lakes High eleven vanquished a fighting Bogota team today by 20 to 7 for its twenty-third consecutive victory. Bogota tallied early in the second quarter on passes from John Finneli to Bud Kenny.
A merchant marine officers' pension fund on a contributory basis was'formally established yesterday at a meeting of shipowners and officers' representatives.

The advantages of gardening with bulbs indoors have been mentioned before in this column. So many flower lovers, however, fail to profit.by this very simple, easy and inexpensive method of providing blooms during the Winter and early Spring months that it may well be emphasized again.

England and Wales are out in front in the battle for international soccer honors this season. Following the Englishmen's brilliant 5-1 victory over Ireland eight days ago, Wales thrilled a crowd of 45,000 at Ninian Park today by defeating Scotland, 2-1.

The performance of "Barchester Towers," a dramatization of Anthony Trollope's novel of the same name, with Ina Claire in the leading role, the night of Dec. 2 at the Martin Beck Theatre will aid the work of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women.

TOM HARRISSON is a young English biologist and explorer who, at the age of 22 led the Oxford expedition to the New Hebrides. His work with the expedition was ornithology, but becoming fascinated with native life he remained behind when the other members of the expedition returned to England.

Study off campus has an important place today in the curriculum at New Jersey College for Women in line with modern educational thought, a sharp contrast to college life a generation ago when students never left the campus for either laboratory work or lectures.

LAST in the long list of Italy's major music festivals of the Summer and Fall, the newly christened "Sagra Musicale dell'Umbria," which has just concluded its rich fortnight of activities in Perugia and Assisi, is by no means the least noteworthy.

Warning business either to adjust its own problems or accept the "strait-jacket of government regulation," the newly elected Senator John E. Miller of Arkansas, coauthor of the Miller-Tydings Act, declared here today that a definite trend was developing to take the government "out of Washington and to put it back in the laps of the people."

Ways in which Manhattan Camp Fire Girls may carry out the national conservation project, adopted at the recent conference in Dallas, Texas, will be discussed at a tea to be held Saturday at the National Poetry Center, in Rockefeller Plaza. Mrs. Francis B. Thurber Jr., head of the local council, will preside.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, campaigning last night in Queens, renewed his charge that Mayor La Guardia has communistic leanings and support and pledged himself to a broad program of public improvements for the city.
President Bird of Occidental College will speak at the founders' day convocation Friday at Lafayette College marking the culmination of the Decade of Progress drive for $500,000.
Organizations soliciting funds for relief work in Spain have reported to the State Department that they have raised $548,765.25 in the period from May 1 to Sept. 30, it was announced today.

Dr. Paul Dyer Merica, director of research of the International Nickel Company and vice president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, has won the 1938 John Fritz Gold Medal for "important contributions to the development of alloys for industrial uses," it was announced yesterday.

The estate known as Dunroamin on Nobscusset Road in Dennis, Cape Cod, Mass., has been sold by its former owners, Jane Sewell and Adelle Rawson to Alice Salinger. The property comprises a recently modernized Cape Cod home of eight rooms and two acres of lawn, gardens and orchard.
THREE one-man shows by artists all of whom, in greater degree or less, have become identified with the contemporary social theme opened in New York last week.

Columbia's hopes for a football renaissance after the Brown disaster tonight lie buried far below Cayuga's waters. In the twenty-fifth game of the Columbia-Cornell series-a series that began in 1889-the big Red team routed the Lions, 14-0, on Schoellkopf Field today in the presence of approximately 12,000 spectators.

Recent surveys indicate that in the judgment fo- 9,500 representative citizens, religion in the United States is losing ground and moral standards are getting worse, according to a statement issued yesterday by Charles V. Vickrey, secretary of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery.

Another example of Renaissance sculpture has come to this country from England to join the collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts as a gift from Mrs. Edsel Ford. It is a bronze statuette representing Judith, the heroine of the Old Testament, at the moment when she appears before the tent after she killed Holofernes.
Fifteen afternoon lectures on landscape architecture, intended for persons interested in ornamental gardening, will be given during the next six months at Nevis, Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 27, aggregated $9,088,000,000, or 12 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and about the same as the total for the corresponding week of last year..
J. L. Garvin, returning after an absence of some months to write his weekly review on international affairs in The Observer, has found "a spectacle of confusion worse confounded and wider spread."
In the following list are. shown all candidates for offices within New York City, for the Assembly and constitutional convention upState and for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals.

Charges by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, that property owners in Manhattan had been overtaxed $33,000,000 in 1937 were denied yesterday by William Stanley Miller, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments.
The Greenfield and Cosmopolitan clubs remained the only undefeated teams in the interclub rivalry of the Women's New York Field Hockey Association after matches played at Prospect Park yesterday.

The recent completion of the West Side Highway from Seventy-second Street northward providing quick motor traffic from mid-Manhattan to the George Washington Bridge is hailed by many builders and developers in the Bergen County areas of New Jersey as a distinct boon in making those suburban lo calities more attractive as residential centers.

Several entertainments were given here last night after the YaleDartmouth football game in New Haven. Keith Morgan entertained at a supper party in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis after the game for Mr. and Mrs. Truman Talley.
Two persons were injured yesterday when part of a fence erected at the north end of the Municipal Building on Centre Street, where repairs are in progress, was blown down by a gust of wind.

Two forward steps toward the realization of Colby College's plan to build a new campus on Mayflower Hill were taken yesterday and today as a result of the efforts of the men and women graduates of Colby.
WHAT is perhaps France's most famous prayer book has attracted more than a million visitors to the public library of Chalons-sur-Marne, where it has been on exhibit since 1885.

Alexander Pompez, once powerful Harlem policy banker'who was reduced to the role of a "servant" as Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer built the numbers game. into a $100,000,000-a-year racket, signifled his readiness yesterday to tell what he knows, information expected to include the identity of one or more persons "higherup" than Schultz.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 3,000 head, including 2,500 direct; shippers took none; estimated holdover, 1,000. Compared -week ago, prices mostly 50-65 cents a hundredweight lower; spots off 75 cents.

COHN-BUECHLER--Mr. Richard K. Buechler of 57 East 88th St. announces the engagement of his sister. Mariam Louise, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max J. Buechler of Bridgeport, Conn., to Mr. Harold S. Cohn of this city, son of Arthur L. Cohn and the late Hattie J. Cohn. The marriage will take place early in December.
The University of Buffalo football team scored its fourth victory in five starts today, defeating Defiance, to 7 The Bulls have scored two touchdowns in every game this season.

The early tulips, both single and double, offer countless opportunities for Spring garden pictures which even the warmly advocated Darwin Tulips cannot equal. The early tulips have larger flowers. Their colors are particularly pure. Their effect, when well placed, is indescribably gay.

THIS posthumous collection includes very nearly all of Miss Teasdale's work as put forth in several volumes between 1907 and 1933, only a few scattered pieces being excluded in accordance with wishes expressed by the poet shortly before her death.

Most valuable of all canine competitions in the United States is the $1,000 Big Four New England Novice Cocker Stake, which will be decided at the sixteenth annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders' Club of New England, to be held in Horticultural Hall, Boston, Friday and Saturday, Nov. 19 and 20.

The marriage of Miss Elinor Gunn of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Newton Gunn, to James W. O'Connor, also of New York, took place yesterday in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Charles J. Canivan, pastor of St. Dominic's Church, Oyster Bay, L. I.

Scotland Yard tonight hunted a "human cat" who twice Invaded London's most fashionable apartment and flashed a light in the sleeping face of 13-year-old Patricia Mountbatten, cousin of King George VI and sometimes called England's richest little girl.
Duncan Sandys, Conservative member of Parliament and son-in-law of Winston Churchill, today announced he would ask Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons Monday:

WHEN walls are plain and furniture ornamentation is minimized the floor becomes of extra importance. In the season's rugs and carpets new weaves are appearing, including the nubby and twisted pile and embossed or carved surfaces.

Four men were killed today when their automobile struck the rear end of a parked truck near Crossman's Corners. The victims were Stanley Costick, Bernard Mazur, Z Tyfczynski and Mathew Solesky, all of Syracuse.
Snipers renewed Palestine terrorism today by firing on constables guarding American stone quarries outside Jerusalem and cutting telephone wires. No casualties were reported.

The Labor party, which, although of negligible strength in the House of Commons, controls fifteen of twenty-eight London boroughs and several large provincial cities, is making a strong bid in the municipal elections tomorrow throughout England and Wales.

Frank Gillmore, president of the Actors Equity Association, today will assume the duties of a specially created office as executive director of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America for a period of five years.

The Brooklyn police were puzzled last night over an attack on Mrs. Bessie Feldman. 76 years old, of 8,460 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn. Mrs. Feldman was struck on the head by a man in the self-service elevator in the apartment house in which she lives. She was taken to the Harbor Hospital in a serious condition.

The Rev. James M. Gillis, editor of The Catholic World, predicted persecution of all Christian sects in this country in the near future, similar to that "now prevalent in Russia, Germany and Loyalist Spain." He said that while the attack may not be a bloody one, it will threaten the livelihood and social position of every one who professes Christianity.
THAT was a thrilling stand-off Dartmouth and Yale put on in the big Bowl but the stunning crash was at Princeton, W. J. Visitors from Harvard hadn't seen anything like it in fourteen years.

Mrs. Lydia B. Froment, who was president of the Baptist Home for the Aged for ten years until her retirement last Spring, died yesterday of a heart attack at her residence, 149 East Seventy-third Street, after an illness of three weeks. She was born in this city eighty years ago, a daughter of the late James McKibbin.

Dividends amounting to $304,634,647 were declared by 888 companies in October, against $363,170,461 by 1,311 companies in September, and $242,696,453 by 849 in October, 1936. Last month's payments were the largest for any October since 1930, when 1,159 corporations disbursed $310,112,902.
Reported by the American News Company, BloomingdaZe's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Gorham of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Gibson Gorham of 400 East Fifty-ninth Street, New York, to Donald Quinn Austin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbert J. Austin of Cleveland.

The New York Yankees scored their first American League victory of the season today by toppling the Boston Shamrocks, 13-7, before 3,000 fans. Although outrushed and outpassed, the Yankees ran up a 13-0 lead with tallies in the first and fourth quarters.

Though abhorring a "life of liberal idealism in the conservative camp," John Haynes Holmes confessed yesterday morning to members of the Community Church, worshiping in Town Hall, that he had suddenly found himself "lined up with the conservatives" on several issues, thus being exposed to the charge that "I myself am unwittingly becoming a conservative."
Two thousand persons gathered at Campion Jesuit Academy here today for the dedication of the new library housing 30,000 volumes as a memorial to Joyce Kilmer, the poet.

The demand of the student body of National Farm School, numbering 225 boys from various sections of the United Staes, that their dean, Cletus L. Goodling, resign, was placed before the board of directors of the school at a special meeting here tonight.

Cardinal Hayes praised the "glorifled and noble work" that the priests and parish of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, City Island, have accomplished during the last fifty years in his message at the golden jubilee mass yesterday morning. More than 500 attended the services and heard the Cardinal read a message from Cardinal Pacell of Rome in which Pope Pius XI awarded the parish his apostolic benediction.

A total of 820 newspapers throughout the country out of 980 which replied -to- questionnaires sent to 1,950 papers are accepting comic strip advertising in black and white, according to the-results of a survey being conducted by the Standard Rate and Data Service of this city.

Germany, Russia and Mexico promise to be the only countries not represented by sizable delegations at next year's Eucharistic Congress in Budapest. The Hungarian authorities have asked that applications for accommodations for the world gathering of Catholicism be made by next Friday.

The stock market here recovered its equilibrium this week. Minor fluctuations in the exchange rate for the franc were ascribed principally to small speculators who operate day by day. The exchange-equalization fund, however, so adjusted its operations as to discourage them.

The greatest challenge since the days of Mohammed is being met by Christianity in Europe today, said Professor Howard Chandler Robbins of the General Theological Seminary in his sermon yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Dec. 30-Jan. 1. Sno Birds of Lake Placld, seventeenth annual college week invitation tournament. Jan. 9, Bear Mountain Sports Association, interstate ski jump; 9, Lebanon O. C. and D. O. C., dual meet (first half), at Dartmouth; 16, Norway Ski Club, Fishkill, N. Y., annual meet; 23, Salisbury O. C.,
Fresh from their South American triumphs, Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, the English duo-pianists, were in top form at their recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt watched a series of bloodless bullfights today in the old Roman amphitheatre where Christians were thrown to the lions nineteen centuries ago.

Operations of the Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 resulted in aconsolidated net profit of $2,858,375, James Simpson, chairman, will report tomorrow to stockholders.

Professor Abdel R. Wentz of Gettysburg Seminary drew a parallel between the Reformation and the American Revolution in a sermon yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway at Ninety-third Street.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States; Lady Wright, Dick Merrill, Lord and Lady Ashburton, Sir Kenneth Lee, Lady Kemp and Captain and Mrs. D. C. Hanrahan are due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
Purchasing in the local wholesale markets last week favored sports coats, holiday merchandise of every sort and men's and boys' apparel.

This week's Bank of England reserve ratio of 28.6 per cent, although far under the year's high of 42 last January, 43 last year and the average of approximately 45 for several years previously, is not, under the present circumstances, regarded as unduly low. Last August it touched 16.6, which was the lowest since January, 1926, but since then a steady rise to the present level has occurred.

Frank Glazer, pianist, gave his second New York recital after an interval of a season last night in Town Hall. Mr. Glazer played a program which afforded him ample opportunity for a display of talent.

A. J. Du Pont, in 40 5th Ave; Mrs. Austin Dana, in 45 Gramercy Park; Rufus Beresford Ivor, in 18 E 58th St; Louis C Curttenden, in 321 E 54th St; Marion B. Stahl, in 825 5th Ave; Oscar E. Carlson, in 145 E 45th St; George C. Arnold, in W 67th St; A. About Arenson, in 310 W 75th St; William A. White Sons, brokers.

Jewelry valued by the owner at $3,000 to $5,000 vanished some time Saturday from the top drawer of a mahogany dresser in the residence of Myron I. Granger, stock broker, at 885 Park Avenue, near Seventyeighth Street.
The British Government does not plan to permit 6,000 Ethiopian refugees who fled to Kenya to remain permanently.

Once in a while you come across a man who is so completely convinced of the great need for conservation of wildlife that he is willing to make it his life work. Such a man is Jay (Ding) Darling, former chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey and now president of the General Wildlife Federation.

District Attorney William C Dodge, campaigning last night on the radio for the election of Harold W. Hastings as his successor, declared that no one in the Hastings camp was perturbed over what Lepke and Gurrah, two missing racketeers, might tell if they return.

Tomorrow's election will give the voter more chance to use common sense and discrimination than any other election ever held in this city. The new charter assumes that he has those qualities and wants to use them. In the new method of choosing members of a new legislative body, the City Council, the charter strikes directly at machine control and unthinking voting.

A Federal Communications Commission ruling that prohibits interstation radio transmission by any other method than wire where wire is available was attacked yesterday by Mayor F. H. La Guardia at the dedication of city station WNYC's new $177,000 transmitter in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on the grounds that it prevented the formation of a contemplated "cultural network" of non-commercial radio stations.
The 171st anniversary of the dedication of St. Paul's Chapel, Trinity parish, at Broadway between Fulton and Vesey Streets, was celebrated with special services yesterday.

The big imponderable in Tuesday's election here, in which the C. I. O. is seeking to take over control of the city administration, is the question of which side is to fall heir to the New Deal Democratic strength that a year ago gave Franklin D. Roosevelt a plurality of more than 200,000 over Alfred M. Landon.

The Presence of a third candidate in the mayoralty race was emphasized for the first time yesterday afternoon when the candidate, Emil F. Teichert, wound up his campaign at a rally attended by nearly 200 persons at- Pythian Temple, 135 West Seventieth Street. Mr. Teichert is the nominee of the Industrial Government party, local branch of the Socialist Labor party.

A crowd of 3,000 shivering persons watched today as 28-year-old Joseph Rospante of 1,971 Coleman Street, Brooklyn, won the Fall model airplane meet of the Metropolitan Model League at the Seversky field here. Most of the small gasoline engine models- were damaged landing in the 25-mile-an-hour wind.
Complete agreement has been reached, according to the newspaper Asahi, for the inclusion of Italy in the German-Japanese anti-Communist pact.

The general index of wholesale prices in France on Oct. 23 stood at 614, compared with 620 on Oct. 16 and 619 on Oct. 9. The gold index price of raw materials stood at 48.6 on Oct. 23, against 49.2 on both Oct. 16 and Oct. 9.

The "piety of the poor" was described as "any nation's best asset" by the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, in his sermon yesterday morning. He warned that great wealth more and more was becoming "the enemy of the true gospel."

Philadelphia will be the scene of the national figure skating championship in 1938. The Quaker City was awarded the fixture by the executive committee of the United States Figure Skating Association at a meeting held at the New York Bar Association Buildingyesterday.

The Daily Telegraph's Jerusalem correspondent reported today that French authorities had ordered the Mufti of Jerusalem and other members of the Arab High Committee to leave Syria and Lebanon by Saturday. It is expected the Mufti and the other leaders will go to Baghdad.

The Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, told his congregation yesterday morning that he was "shocked at times by the sins of so many of the well-to-do who can pay their bills but do not."

Gurden Edvards, who has been for the last fifteen years public relations director of the American Bankers Association, has been appointed director of a new research council formed by the association to coordinate and expand its research activities, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harold Stonier, executi??e manager of the association.

Colonel C. S. Ridley, Governor of the Canal Zone, sailed on the liner Ancon today, bound for Washington, to present budget estimates for the canal. Mrs. Ridley, who is accompanying the Governor, is president of the Canal Zone Red Cross and will confer at Red Cross headquarters in Washington.

The lawyers committee backing the candidacy of Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy for re-election charged yesterday that "a small coterie of vindictive bar members is attempting by outrageous vilification to loose Justice Levy's hold on the respect and affection of the voters in Manhattan and the Bronx."
The United States Brewers Association, convening in Pittsburgh, was obsessed by the nightmare that prohibition was once

A special appeal to their congregations for signatures for the initiative petition that is being sponsored by the New England Anti-Gambling Association, seeking repeal of the law permitting pari-mutuel betting in Massachusetts, was made from the pulpit in most of the Protestant churches in Greater Boston today.

The effectiveness of Administrator Brehon B. Somervell's effort to rid the WPA rolls in this city of shirkers and incompetents was reflected yesterday in an analysis of the causes of WPA "separations" during the year ended Sept. 30.
With supporters of Mayor La Guardia confident of his victory by a large plurality, the belief grew that he would sweep his city-wide ticket into office.

The voters of the city will encounter proportional representation at first hand for the first time tomorrow when they step out of voting machine- booths into old-style polling booths to cast their vote by paper ballot for the members of the new City Council.

Only sixteen communities in New York State will vote this year on local option, The A. B. C. News, official publication of the New York State Liquor Authority, discloses in its current issue. Last year forty-one communities voted on local option, ten going dry, and in 1935 eighty communities voted, thirty-six going dry.

Godwin Terrace (13-3404), e s, 200 ft n of Kemberley Pl, 100x125; Sadle Raidman to Barry Realties, Inc. 80 William St; mtg $156,750. 205th St (12-3312), n s, 287 ft w of Mosholu Parkway, 26x134: Vincent Gallo to Giuseppe Gennaro, 1,167 2d Ave. Gunther Ave. 4,322 (17-5051): Stuard Hirschman to Cameron A. Cooper, 4,414 Edson Ave.

The Commerz - und - Privat - Bank Aktiengesellschaft (Germany) has made alternative offers of settlement to holders residing outside of Germany of the certificates of partitipation in its ten-year 51/2 per cent note, due today, it was announced yesterday.

A record attendance of 200 representatives from fifty-nine clubs in the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association gathered today at the Hanover Inn to discuss means for furthering the development of skiing this year.

The Rayner-Consolidated Decalcomania Corporation, a merger of the Rayner-Consolidated Decalcomania Corporation of Chicago and the Rayner-Consolidated Decalcomania Corporation of Brooklyn, has leased about 110,000 square feet of manufacturing space in the Modern Industrial Building, formerly the Edward Langer Printing Company plant, at 184-10 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, L. I.

The campaign in Westchester County will close tomorrow with special rallies in favor of endorsement of the proposed county charter, which is being opposed in lastminute undercover tactics by voters in the northern part of the county, who fear their towns would lose their identity under the new form of government. Most of the county newspapers have come out in favor of the charter.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, headed by John Barbirolli, added two rarely performed works to its program at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon--Saint-Saens's "Le Rouet d'Omphale" and Delius's "A Dance Rhapsody,"

The first days of Indian Summer have scattered the Fall colony all over the countryside on picnics, carriage drives and on horseback. Among the New Yorkers carriage driving or horseback riding today were Mr. and Mrs. Alex Dommerich, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Harms, Mr. and Mrs. Clyde L. Davis, Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Rogers, Mrs. Huntington Hartford, Mrs. George Ingalls and Miss Elizabeth S. Bowlend.
Dr. Elie Faure, art historian, died yesterday at the age of 64. Originally a physician, he devoted most of his career to literature.

As the site for a three-story factory, a tract comprising 35,700 square feet in Orange, N. J., has been bought by E. Bilhuber Inc., pharmaceutical manufacturers, from the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad and the Spottiswoode-Cusack Company. The site fronts 269 feet on Crane Street and runs back to the Orange Station of the Lackawanna.
A. Newbold Morris, candidate for City Council PresidencyWMCA, 1:15 to 1:30 P. M. Anthony Di Giovanna, candidate for City Council-WOV, 2:25 to 2:30 P. M.

Struck by an automobile this evening as he was crossing Jericho Turnpike near Central Avenue, Michael Banaguro, 53 years old, of New York Avenue, Brooklyn, died of a fractured skull fifteen minutes later. The car was driven by Miss Mildred Katz, 22, of 291 Hempstead Turnpike, Elmont.

The nature of the Kingship of Christ is as much misunderstood today as it was centuries ago when Jesus lived on earth, according to the Rev. Charles O'Connor Sloane, who preached yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral on the Feast of Christ the King.
With the exception of Thursday and again today, when the bears covered, the week's stock market developed along reactionary lines.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair-Corporation, made public yesterday plans for a $750,000 gas building and animated exhibit for the exposition. A feature of the structure will be a wide circular "Court of Flame" in which a large jet of gas will be kept burning like a torch.
The international situation in Europe cannot be made clear unless one knows exactly the extent and trend of Italo-German collaboration usually described as the Rome-Berlin axis.

Violent attacks against Czechoslovakia in the German press, especially those contained in the Voelkischer Beobachter, were answered today in an article occupying the entire front page of the Prager Presse. The newspaper gives instances of cases far more serious in their injustices to minorities of which Germany takes no account..

The appointment of Francois D'Elescu as director of the intramural wrestling program at New York University was announced yesterday by Professor Francis P. Wall, director of intramural athletics. D'Elescu was formerly sports coach at Temple University and coach of wrestling at the University of Pennsylvania.
The Rev. Charles William Gordon, better known to millions of readers as Ralph Connor, author of "The Sky Pilot" and other prewar best sellers, died here today at the age of 77.
Mike (Twin) Sullivan, once considered one of the world's ranking welterweight pugilists, died at his home tonight. His age was 59.

The American Federation of Labor Non-Partisan Committee for the Re-election of Mayor La Guardia issued last night a statement signed by more than 200 union leaders supporting the Mayor and informing Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee, that "your candidacy is uniformly regarded with repugnance by the workingmen and women of New York."

Robert L. Corby, an authority on the chemistry of baking, who was formerly vice president of the Fleischmann Company, died at his home here yesterday morning of pneumonia after a brief illness. was born fifty-four years ago at Ithaca, N. Y.

G. D. Kelly, chairman of the Australian Woolgrowers Council reviewing the wool market, points out that at the end of the first month of selling this season the average price is more than 13d a pound, the opening sale having fallen to a little more than 14d but still representing a good return.

Party leaders estimate that approximately 2,300,000 persons will cast their votes in tomorrow's Mayoralty election in New York City. The estimates are based on the usual fall-off from the registration, which was 2,484,000. A smaller number are expected to vote for Councilmen.
Mr. and Mrs. William P. Gilmour of 116 East Sixty-eighth Street will give a tea dance on Nov. 26 at Sherry's to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Nancy Gilmour.

Extradition of General Encarnacion Arita of Honduras on charges of assassination has been refused by Judge Manuel Castro Ramirez Jr., who held - that the crimes attributed to General Arita were of a political character.

An average of 58 per cent of the ownerOccupied homes in twenty-one selected cities are mortgaged, according to a financial survey of urban housing, conducted by the Department of Commerce, the results of which were made public today.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

The second Beethoven orchestral program in a series of five being offered on alternate Sundays under the auspices of the Federal Music Project was given last night at the Federal Theatre of Music by the Federal Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, National Director of the Project.

Premier Benito Mussolini today dedicated Guidonia, a new community devoted to experimental aviation, fifteen miles from Rome. Mussolini said there was a close bond between the inauguration of the air city and the agricultural community reclaimed from the Pontine marshes as "vigilance in protection of the skies of the Fatherland is indispensable if the farmer is to be unmolested as he works to make the soil of Italy ever more fertile."

After a study of the Federal Government's plan to establish maximum hours and minimum wages a committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York has reached the conclusion that the proposal "is wrong in theory and foredoomed to failure."
The Paterson Panthers created a new American Professional Football Association scoring record today in defeating the Brooklyn Bushwicks, 41-0, at Hinchliffe Stadium before 4,500 persons.

A seaman who survived the sinking of the British freighter Jean Weems declared today that an Italian-made seaplane machinegunned the British vessel and then sank it with bombs. The 2,349-ton freighter, bound from Marseille to Barcelona with a cargo of wheat and condensed milk, was sunk in the Mediterannean yesterday sixteen miles off the northeast Spanish coast. The crew of twenty-six was saved.

A smoky fire that started in the rooms of the Cathedral Club on the first floor of a four-story- brick building at 85 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, caused injuries early yesterday to four persons, including a fireman.

It was Madrid's turn today to pay homage to the International Brigade and enthusiastic audiences packed three theatres to witness ceremonies at which General Jose Miaja, government Commander-in-Chief on the Madrid front, presided.
To the gastronomic delight of 400 guests, Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Reilly projected their fifteenth annual "Beefsteak Sweepstakes" at the Hotel Warwick last night.
Four flying deputies of the People's Mandate to End War arrived here today on their 17,000-mile peace tour of the Americas.

Karl Eilers was awakened early this morning by splashing sounds coming from the large lily and goldfish pond on his estate. Looking out a window, he saw one of his huskiest farm horses threshing among the lily pads, a victim of Halloween pranksters.

The recovery of security prices in the United States is viewed here as a natural consequence of a recent exaggerated selling movement after an equally exaggerated boom in the Spring. This means that the recovery was largely a technical readjustment after the boom and the subsequent selling and that the upswing had no relation to the actual trend in the trade cycle.
The Financial News's index of twenty fixedinterest stocks, based on 1928 as 100, on Oct. 28 stood at 127.4, compared with 127 a week ago, 126.6 a month ago and 138.5 a year ago.

More than 800 manufacturers, retailers and buyers attended the second annual Merchandising Industries Dinner given at the Hotel Astor last night in honor of John Block, veteran resident buyer, for the benefit of the Los Angeles Sanatorium. Major Benjamin H.
A 43-yard touchdown gallop by Substitute Halfback Stascavage decided a stubbornly fought game today, giving St. Thomas of Scranton a 7-0 triumph over St. Vincent's Bearcats before 5,000 fans.

Another season--The Lunts'--is to be ushered in tonight at the Shubert Theatre, whither the Theatre Guild brings what is called the Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne production of Jean Giraudoux's comedy, "Amphitryon 38," as adapted by S. N. Behrman.

Leopold Rosenblum, voted by Yale seniors of the Eighteen Eighties and Eighteen Nineties, under his nickname, Shorty Moses, as the most popular campus character, died last week at the residence of his sister in Los Angeles, according to an announcement made here today by his nephew, Julius Widder.
The Workers Alliance, charged by Jeremiah T. Mahoney with being communistic, announced yesterday its support of Joseph D. McGoldrick, Fusion nominee for Controller. In a statement,

A dinner for alumnae to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of Dr. William Allan Neilson's presidency at Smith College will be given Nov. 16 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Smith College Club of New York.
The exhibits of 110 book publishers at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair of 1937, opening Friday in Rockefeller Center, will present several novel ideas.

The Greater Texas and Pan American Exposition, which inherited most of its plant from last year's Texas Centennial, attracted a crowd officials estimated at 44,625 today as it drew to a midnight close. Attendance since the opening June 12 was reported as 2,384,830.

The Fort Jay and Fort Totten football teams played a scoreless tie at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, before 3,000 spectators yesterday. Fort Jay made nine first downs against three for Fort Totten. Fort Jay maintains the lead in the first division series and has not been defeated this year.

The Maritime Commission today made public rules for the application and regulation of persons entitled to practice before it and announced that after Jan. 1 it would maintain a permanent register of such practitfoners.

Since August the greatest improvement in Germany has been in consumers' goods, particularly textiles and metal wares, whereas the heavy industries have been relatively stagnant in the last two months.

Cotton prices fluctuated narrowly last week, and at the end they were about cent a pound above their recent extreme low levels. On the New York Cotton Exchange, prices for active future deliveries closed at net losses of 8 to 14 points for the week.

Alfred D. Crimi of: 1,975 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx, submitted the winning design in the competition for decorating the chancel of Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventythird Street and Broadway,'it was announced yesterday by the National Society of Mural Painters.

The 1937 nominating committee of the Metropolitan Golf Association, of which Jess W. Sweetser of the Siwanoy Country Club is chairman, will present a list of nine candidates for election to the various offices for 1938 at the organization's forty-first annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore on the night of Dec. 16.

Charles E. A. McCarthy of 70 Pine Street, New York City, applied yesterday to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to serve as vice president of the Alabama Great Southern Railroad and of the Cincinnati, New Orleans Texas Pacific Railway Company.

Valencia, for the first time in months, today was treated to a bullfight-which ended in a riot with half the spectators in the ring. The audience was heavily sprinkled with soldiers. Efforts of youthful toreros to dispatch six bulls were greeted with loud whistles--Spanish equivalent of Bronx cheers.

Collective bargaining rather than legislation is the better way of obtaining security for American labor, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. today told 400 delegates to the convention of the New England Association of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers at the Hotel Statler.

The government has been urged by the press to abolish the Exchange Control Commission here, which, it is declared, is a chief obstacle in the way of the normal development of trade between Chile and the United States, a subject that is being closely studied with a view to drawing up a commercial treaty.
Invitations have been issued by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ryan of 733 Jersey Avenue for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Alice J. Ryan, to Charles P. Lutkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Lutkin.

With fifteen named for the featured Baltimore Autumn Handicap, the Fall meeting at historic Pimlico will begin tomorrow with prospects that include the probable appearances of Menow, War Admiral and Seabiscuit.

An apartment property in Harlem accommodating forty families changed hands when the Merchants Salvage Corporation sold to the 272 Realty Corporation the five-story building at 118-120 East 120th Street. There are three and fourroom suites in the house, which occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet, between Park and Lexington Avenues.
Wing Commander Aubrey R. M. Rickards, called by the Arab chiefs "The Flying Lawrence," was killed with two other Royal Air Force officers in a plane crash at Khor Charim Saturday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Julius Sands of 233 West Seventy-seventh Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Sands, to Edward Roger Wiener, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin N. Wiener of the Bronx.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L., Wertz of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Marion Wertz, to Howard Brooks Bosworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Bosworth of Providence, R. I. The announcement was made at a dinner given at the Wertz home tonight.

Members of the Canadian team, which will compete in the National Horse Show, opening at Madison Square Garden Wednesday, arrived yesterday from Toronto and went to the Waldorf-Astoria, where they met officers of the United States, Belgian, Irish Free State and Netherlands groups.

The Rumanian press has adopted a hostile attitude toward Premier Mussolini's demands for a treaty revision. The Adeverul says: "Mussolini addresses a new threat to Rumania in order to encourage intransigence in Hungary just as if there were reasonable hopes that Hungarian leaders, during negotiations now progressing, would finally drop their revisionist propaganda."

Chris Cagle's All Stars defeated Fort Hamilton eleven, 15 to 13, before 5,500 persons at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation yesterday. The winners tallied their touchdowns in the second and third periods on forward passes thrown by Cagle. A safety in the second period gave the Stars their margin of victory.
A fourth $10 bill of the $50,000 Charles S. Ross ransom turned up today, five weeks after the abduction of the retired greeting-card manufacturer.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, in a morning sermon before the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall yesterday, urged his congregation to take a stand tomorrow for at least four more years for the consecration of democracy, efficiency and leadership over affairs of New York City by the re-election of Mayor La Guardia.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,348,036,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest- bearing discount bills. The list follows:

Despite the unsettlement and, at times, acute weakness in securities markets last month, the volume of new security offerings in October was the largest in the last three months. Compared with other years, however, the flotations in October were the smallest for that month since 1934.

Before a cheering crowd of nearly 7,000 persons here today, Senator A. Harry Moore, Democratic candidate for Governor, delivered a spirited defense of Mayor Frank Hague, State Democratic leader, and predicted that "we'll win by the greatest majority ever given the Democratic ticket in New Jersey."

LETTERS OF MADAME DE SEVIGNE, edited by Richard Aldington. (Dutton, $5). PRELUDE TO PARNASSUS, by James Cleugh. (Paisley, $2.50.) Scenes from the life of Pushkin. THE MARCH OF A NATION, by Harold G. Cardozo. (McBride, $2.75.) A correspondent with the Spanish Rebels.

The best foreign demand for American corn in several years developed last week, and the trade estimated that 3,000,000 bushels or more had been sold, the first important business since 1932, when clearances in the calendar year aggregated 7,880,000 bushels.

The annual election eve dance in aid of the House of Calvary, cancer hospital on Featherbed Lane, the Bronx, will take place this evening at Ben Riley's Arrowhead Inn. Miss Alice M. Witzel heads the arrangements committee, and Miss Helen McDonald is vice chairman.

Official announcement will be made tomorrow of the establishment in New York City of a central office for Eastern intercollegiate athletics with Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of ahtletics at Princeton University, as executive director.

While Kwangtung Province is having a respite from Japanese airplane and naval attacks, there is increased tension in Fukien Province because of recent Japanese activities, such as the occupation of Quemoy Island, where the Chinese report the Japanese landed additional forces,

President Roosevelt spent a quiet Sunday at home today at his mother's house here. In the morning, Mr. Roosevelt did not go to church, but he presided at a meeting of the vestry of St. James' Episcopal Church of which he is senior warden. James Roosevelt, the President's son and secretary, together with his wife came up for the day.

The condition of Floyd O. Hale, president of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company, who collapsed during the finish of yesterday's YaleDartmouth football game at Yale Bowl, was said tonight to be improved at New Haven Hospital.

Almost without exception, football's pace-setters stayed out in front Saturday on a day of exciting competition and huge crowds that saw Harvard and Pennsylvania score notable victories in the East and Notre Dame gain vastly in stature at the expense of Minnesota.

A plan for reorganization of the Cornwall Patterson Company offered by the Leach Manufacturing Company of Providence, R. I., was declared accepted yesterday by John Keogh, referee in bankruptcy, at a special meeting when 80 per cent of the creditors voted their approval.
Russell Clifford Durant, son of W. C. Durant, organizer of the General Motors Company, died of a heart attack 'yesterday at his Beverly Hills home at the age of 46.

The report of the Nationas, Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 shows that consolidated net income after 'all expenses and charges was $8,696,755, against $6,742,744 in the preceding twelve months.
Bill Tranavitch, Rutgers' highgeared halfback, regained the top of the Eastern individual football scoring list by virtue of his latest one-man touchdown parade.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Bray of this city have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Lois Kneeland Bray, to Albert Robeson McAllister Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McAllister of Bridgeton, N. J. The wedding will take place on Nov. 27.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson, elected as a Republican but now supporting the Democratic ticket, announced today that if the Republicans won the city-county election next Tuesday he would resign his office and return to private life.

The flood gates of the Autumn exhibitions season are let loose this year with the coming of November. Between forty and fifty exhibitions are on the calendar for the current week, with nearly every art medium drawn upon.

Concerned over "the misunderstandings concerning the Duke of Windsor's exile from Britain" the Cabinet is now debating whether to issue a "now it can be told" story of the abdication, The Daily Express will say tomorrow.
Twelve Federal agencies awarded 119 supply contracts valued at about $6,097,766 under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Oct. 28, the Department of Labor has announced.

Representatives of railroads operating in Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Arkansas, Missouri and Kansas will meet here tomorrow primarily to discuss national legislation affecting railroads. R. V. Fletcher, Washington, vice president and general counsel of the Association of American Railroads, will preside.

George Tatarescu, Rumanian prime Minister, left today for istanbul en route to Bucharest. According to a communique issued last night, M. Tatarescu's conversations with Prime Minister Jelal Bayer and Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras on the international situation again has showed the importance of a Balkan pact in the maintenance of peace.
The Pittsburgh Pirates handed the Philadelphia Eagles a touchdown early in their football game today, then went on to triumph over. their across-the-State rivals, 16 to 7.

The slower rate of business activity this Autumn has undoubtedly been exaggerated by the action of the securities markets, according to Banking, official publication of the American Bankers Association.

The conversion office for German foreign debts has announced an optional offer of exchange to holders of matured bonds of the following issues a like amount of bonds of an unmatured series of each issue: City of Frankfort-on-Main 7s, matured Oct. 1, 1937; city of Duisburg-Hamborn 7s, matured Nov. 1,

Swerving to avoid striking another car, William Noonan of 73 Third Street, East Rockaway, L. I., drove his car tonight onto the third rail of the Long Island Railroad tracks it Jamaica and Rockaway Turnpikes here. Noonan and a passenger escaped uninjured but an instant later the car burst into flames and was destroyed.

Polished performances by several powers, including Groton and Choate in the prep school ranks, were outstanding in scholastic football over the week-end as comparatively few surprises were recorded. And of those unexpected results, hardly any was startling.
The completion of the ninety-first year of service of the Society for Seamen's Children will be celebrated with a tea on Thursday at the Charles H. Marshall Cottage, 657 Castleton Avenue, S. I.
Paramount is to make another contribution to the insane cycle. "Vacation From Love," by Patterson McNutt and Harlan Ware, has been purchased for Fred MacMurray to follow "Men With Wings."

Miss Kathryn Ann Benson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Benson of this city and Kenilworth, has become engaged to Richard D. Culver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Culver of Westhampton, L. I., her parents announced today.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will visit Harper Brothers this Wednesday to receive from Cass Canfield, president of the concern, the first copy of her book "This Is My Story" which will be published Nov. 15. Later in the week, Mrs. Roosevelt will leave for a lecture tour of the Middle West.

Reorganization Petitions THIRD AVENUE RAILWAY CO., 130th St. and 3d Ave.--Involuntary proceeding under Sections 77a and 77b of the Bankruptcy Law filed by bondholders with aggregate holdings of $8,500. The petition states that the liabilities amount to $58,099,896, including a funded debt of $45,067,000, and estimates the value of the assets at $25,466,386.

Marjorie Ross, trading as Clear-Skin Institute of 375 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, will drop the word "Institute" from her trade name and discontinue certain claims for her preparation known as "Clear Skin" under a stipulation entered into with the Federal Trade Commission, the commission said today.
An intergovernmental conference to repress terrorism will open in the League of Nations Palace tomorrow under the presidency of Count Henry Carton de Wiart of Belgium.

The Very Rev. Canon Hugh Richard Lawrie Sheppard, probably the most prominent pacifist in Britain as well as active social worker, died of a heart attack here early this morning at the age of 57. Dressed in his pajamas, he was found slumped over a desk in his room at Amen Corner, near St. Paul's Cathedral, and apparently had been writing a letter when stricken.

One hundred and ten applications have been received at the office of the Dramatists Guild for the five fellowships of $1,000 each which John Golden has established for promising playwrights, Luise Sillcox, executive secretary of the guild, said yesterday.
Miss Marjorie Lee Judd, daughter of Mrs. Mortimer N. Judd of this city, will be married to Paul Allan Luchini, son of Joseph S. G. Luchini of Boston, on Nov. 8 in St.

Glodagh McTybe of the Cloisters, owned by Edwin M. Berolzheimer of New York City, won first place today in the open All-Age Stake at the Fall field trials of the Irish Setter Club of America. Elias C. Vail of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., handled the winner.

The marriage of Miss Frances Louise Bruno, daughter of Mrs. Lucien V. Bruno of this place and the late Mr. Bruno, architectural sculptor, to George Joseph Vogel, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Vogel of Fair Lawn and Lake Wallkill, took place here this afternoon in the Dutch Reformed Church.

A victory for the black forces, conducted by Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, was recorded at Rotterdam recently in the seventh game of his world chess championship match with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the titleholder.

The Metropolitan Opera Committee for Philadelphia will meet on Nov. 9 to discuss plans for the season, which will open at the Academy of Music on Nov. 30. Followed by performances on Dec. 14 and 21, Jan. 11 and 25, Feb. 15 and March 8 and 15.

Gari Shelton will give a piano recital tonight at 8:30 in Town Hall. Julius Katchen, 11-year-old New Jersey pianist, who made his debut recently with the Philadelphia Orchestra, will be heard for the first time in New York on the night of Nov. 22 at a special benefit concert for the orchestra pension fund of the Philharmonic-Symphony Socity. Bidu Sayao,
The 168 persons who will be charged with the duty of re-examining the Constitution of the State of New York in convention next April will be elected tomorrow.

The present development and the future of trailer coaches will be discussed by J. L. Brown, vice president in charge of sales for the Covered Wagon Company at the luncheon meeting on Wednesday of the local chapter of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Bedford.
Members of the Society of Virginia Women will give a bridge party Friday afternoon in the Jansen suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of their various charitable interests in Virginia.

Contributions and subscriptions totaling $63,292 have been received to date by the National AntiSyphilis Committee in its $500,000 campaign for the continuation and expansion of the national educational program of the American Social Hygiene Association, with which the committee is affiliated.
Mayor La Guardia made only one political appearance yesterday and spent the evening resting in his home after a strenuous week of campaigning.

The death mask of Henry George, celebrated American economist of the nineteenth century, was presented to Princeton University this afternoon by Mrs. Anna George De Mille, George's daughter, at the memorial meeting in the university library that marked to the hour the fortieth anniversary of the economist's funeral.

Philip Morris Co, Ltd, Inc, four floor in 119-21 5th Ave, northwest corner of 19th St, for American executive offices and showrooms; Lewis H. May Co, broker. Eugenics Publishing Co, additional floor in 317 E 34th St; American Dance Association, Inc. in 121 E 18th St; Harry Veldran in 160 5th Ave; Schiff Werring Co, linings, in 235 4th Ave; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson. Inc, brokers.

Accused of having registered illegally, Gaetano Imperato, 57 years old, a peddler, of 318 East Eleventh Street, and Jack Lieberman, 31, a bartender, of 158 Ridge Street, were held without bail for a hearing this morning after pleading not guilty yesterday before Magistrate Anthony F. Burke in the Essex Market Court.

Among the favorable factors which contributed to the satisfactory tone of the Stock Exchange here this week in spite of the market's inactivity was the hope that the Non-Intervention Committee would reach an agreement Viewed in retrospect,

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Everett Lake Crawford of Shanarock Farm, Port Chester, N. Y., and Aiken, S. C., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Gregory Crawford, to Robert Carpenter Marston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Jean Marston of Colorado Springs, Col., formerly of this city.

A worry-worn mother of seven children killed five of them and herself last night, after explaining in a note she had not enough shotgun shells to take all their lives. The woman. Mrs. G. R. McAninch, 35, set down her plans for the shooting in a note that lay beside an open Bible she apparently had been reading.
Ed Walsh Jr., son of "Big Ed" Walsh and, like his father, a former Chicago White Sox pitcher, died today at his parents' home after a long illness.

William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company said in a radio address tonight that, contrary to popular opinion, industrial employment of persons of 45 years or older had been on the increase for thirty years.

The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, whose proposal a year ago for a "moratorium" on sermons provoked widespread debate, explained in the Yearbook of Trinity, issued yesterday, that the last thing he had in mind was the abolition of the sermon.

With Princeton's Republican Mayor, Dr. Charles R. Erdman Jr., unopposed for re-election to a second term of two years, voters here are turning their attention to the spirited contest between two brothers who are seeking the same office in the election on Tuesday.

Pledging the "patience and cooperation" of the United Automobile Workers of America with the efforts of industrialists to adjust themselves to new principles of unionism, Homer Martin president of the U. A. W. A., asserted today, however, that labor would resist attempts by mass production employers to blame industrial unionism for what have been viewed in some quarters as new depression tendencies.
The Federal Trade Commission-renewed today, two weeks before the special session of Congress, recommendations for tightening of the antitrust laws. Its recommendations,

Upsets riddled the Mexican amateur golf championship lists today as Johnny Goodman, United States titleholder from Omaha, became the only favorite to survive two rdunds of play which carried the tournament into the semi-finals.

Precedent suggests strongly that the current business recession is of an intermediate character, the National City Bank says in its monthly letter issued today. The slackening in trade will run itself out in due course, the bank indicates, and it suggests that a leveling-out, at least, is perhaps nearer than the markets now appear to believe.
Renewing their drive at Shanghai, the Japanese yesterday forced their way across Soochow creek, west of the International Settlement, following an intense artillery bombardment.

Lowell Thomas, radio commentator, has bought the French estate, a 2,100acre property in the towns of Pawling and Dover, Dutchess County, which was developed by the late Fred F. French, builder and real estate operator.

The New York Maritime Council is seeking the cooperation of marine unions of three other countries in fighting anti-labor practices of certain Scandinavian steamship companies, it was announced yesterday.

More alert and superior in virtually every department of the game, the Washington Redskins handily blanked the Brooklyn Dodgers, 21 to 0, yesterday before a crowd of 22,500 fans, the largest turnout at Ebbets Field this Fall.
The induction this afternoon of Rabbi William Margolisg as the leader of the United Jewish Community of Ottawa was the highlight of the year's activity in Jewish religious circles in the capital.

AS YOU LIKE IT, the Shakespearean play in two acts. Staged by Samuel Rosen; costumes designed by Lucinda Ballard and Scott Wilson; dances arranged by May Gadd; revived by the Surry Players under the sponsorship of Dwight Deere Wiman. At the Ritz Theatre.

Canada probably will have 141 gold mills in operation before the year ends. There now are 128 mills in operation, and thirteen are under construction. In addition to these, twenty-three properties are equipped with idle mills.

An event known as the Mgr. John M. Hilpert Memorial card party and dance will be held on Wednesday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, by the United Mission Circles and Medical Missions Units.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 51 per cent of capacity, down 5 points in ? week and 33 points in eight weeks, from the week before Labor Day.

Senator Arthur Capper said tonight in a radio address that the Republican party should throw its weight into Congressional elections next year and not stage "a struggle for control of the party machinery" in a mid-term convention.
The annual Halloween dinner dance was held last night in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier. The room was decorated with masses of Autumn foliage, cornstalks and lighted pumpkins.
The Labor Bureau's general index of manufacturing employment in September, given out last week, compares with preceding months and years as follows, with the average of 1923-25 as 100:

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Merriam Chadbourne gave a small tea yesterday at their home, 40 East Sixtysecond Street, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Ghadbourne, to Allen Hurlburt Minor, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Crannell Minor, also of this city, and of Howarden, New Canaan, Conn.
The two-man debating team representing Oxford and Cambridge Universities lost two debates today with two separate teams from John Marshall College of Law, Jersey City.
The Radical Socialist party, leading unit of the People's Front government, today urged the convocation of a world conference to satisfy Germany's demands for raw materials.

Only Henry Picard, the Hershey (Pa.) pro, held his own for the United States forces today as a local shotmaker, Alberto Serra, took the lead at the halfway mark of the Argentine open golf championship with a 36-hole total of 144.
New Yorkers, released by Sunday from offices and shops, thronged yesterday to the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace, and displayed a marked interest in the numerous safety exhibits.

BABCOCK-Suddenly, Maud, beloved wife of John R. Babcock, at 25 East 86th St., New York City, Sunday, Oct. 31, 1937. Services private, Runyon Funeral Home, Plainfield, N. J., Tuesday, Nov. 2, 1937, 2:30 P. M. Interment Plainfield, N. J. Please omit flowers.
William - Montgomery Brown, selfstyled heretic and Communist who vainly sought reinstatement as an Episcopal Church Bishop after being unfrocked in 1925, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage.
A comparative newcomer and the defending champion were tied today for first place in the round-robin world's pocket billiard championship tournament at the end of-the first week of action.

Mgr. Stephen P. Connelly, pastor of St. Peter's Church here, was invested this afternoon with the robes of his new office as Papal Chamberlain, as 1,500 persons attended ceremonies in celebration of the Feast of Christ the King.

Continuing the high tariff policy inaugurated at the beginning of this year, President Lazaro Cardenas sent to Congress tonight an administration bill to raise the tariff on textiles from 2 to 5 per cent depending on the quality of the goods.
After three players had been dismissed from the team for breaking training rules, La Salle was beaten by Niagara University at McCarthy Stadium today, 20 to 0.

Mrs. Isobel Strong, stepdaughter of Robert Louis Stevenson, announced today that she was ready to turn over all the relics of the author which she possesses to the proposed shrine to be created in and around the house where he worked at Monterey before making his last voyage to the South Seas.

Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization in America, called upon the executive of the World Zionist Organizations tonight to strive to bring about a continued complete British mandate over an undivided Palestine.

Lore than 2,000 residents of the lower East Side witnessed yesterday afternoon a cornerstone laying ceremony which signalized the start of construction of the new quarters of the Ninth Street Day Nursery and Orphan Home, at 393 East Eighth Street, near Avenue D.

Amsel's Hans Brinker, owned and handled by Earle N. Cutler of Morristown, N. J., captured the Dachshund Club of America open all-age dog stake today, then went on to take a special contest to decide the outstanding-entry of the trials.

In addition to the prize annually awarded by the Drama Critics Circle to what it considers the best new American play of the season, the Circle henceforth will honor "the best new foreign play to be presented in English each season on the New York stage."

Francis L. Whitmarsh, chairman of the foods division in the United Hospital Campaign, announced last night the appointment of twelve associate members of the division, which has a quota of $65,000 in the drive.
A skyscraper now rising in downtown Miami is designed to withstand a wind velocity of 200 miles an hour, said to be far greater than recorded in any storm.

The "wavering" League of Nations can best be bolstered and saved by a League of Churches, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver said in his sermon yesterday morning on "Methodism and Church Unity" at the John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 44 John Street.

The mystery surrounding the Greek steamer Vena, which brought arms and munitions to the Estonian port of Baltic Port instead of carrying the Cargo to Bordeaux for the Valencia government, remains unsolved.

Balioting that was instituted on Sept. 23 to determine the union affiliation of seamen on 750 vessels in Atlantic and Gulf ports will be pushed rapidly to completion, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Regional Director of the National Labor Relations Board, which is supervising the elections.

Religious forces must combine to counteract pernicious propaganda, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Election of a City Council that will support Mayor La Guardia was urged last night by Chase Mellen Jr., former chairman of the New York Republican County Committee, in a speech over radio station WOR. Mr. Mellen, who is endorsed for Councilman by the Citizens Nonpartisan Committee, of which Samuel Seabury is chairman, presented a four-point platform as follows:

Germany's wholesale price index on Oct. 20 stood at 105.9, unchanged from a week before. In the first nine months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Canisius College scored its fourth victory of the season today, upsetting its favored rival, St. Bonaventure, by 14-0 in the final Western New York Little Three contest of the season before a crowd of 25,000 in Roesch Memorial Stadium.

A brilliant 62-yard return of a punt for a touchdown in the opening period helped the Chicago Cardinals gain a 13 to 7 victory over the Cleveland Rams in a National Football League game before 9,923 fans at Wrigley Field today.

Small circulars urging Roman Catholics to vote for Jeremiah T. Mahoney, "god-fearing" man, were distributed to members of many Roman Catholic congregations in Brooklyn and Manhattan yesterday as they left their churches after services.

At the conclusion of grand work in the covers of the Hollins and Lawrance Estates and in the waters of Great South Bay, the awards were announced late this afternoon in the open all-age stake, the final and most important competition of the three-day retriever trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association.

Financial sentiment has undergone a moderate though steady improvement in the last week. Wall Street again has been the dominating influence, but the international situation, still far from encouraging, played only a Moderate part in the quiet recovery.

Registrations of securities issues for $3,012,100,000 became effective in the first nine months of the year, compared with registrations of $3,574,000,000 in the same period of last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. This was a decline of $561,900,000.

A potential public that exceeds anything the most successful "best seller" of fiction could hope for awaits a pamphlet just published by the Women's Bureau at Washington, titled "Women in the Economy of the United States of America."

Closing his series of five Sunday evening radio broadcasts, Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey declared last night that every racket his office had broken had previously been reported to the office of the District Attorney and been ignored or dropped after an unsuccessful trial.

Here are notes on books published since July 1 that this reviewer enjoyed especially. The order of listing is haphazard. Charles Winslow Zitott's "WinsielZ Scott" (Macmillan). A full-dress study of the full-dress American soldier who had enormous political ambitions. Ranks with the best of our military biographies, such as Henderson's "Stonewall Jackson" and Freeman's "Robert E. Lee." Uncommonly good, though necessarily slow, reading.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three week:

The death late last night of Mrs. Lewis E. Lawes, wife of the warden of Sing Sing prison, was attributed today by Dr. Amos O. Squire, Medical Examiner of Westchester County, to shock and loss of blood from an accidental fall on a pathway descending from the Westchester approach of the Bear Mountain Bridge.

The last of the volunteer fire companies on Staten Island passed out of existence last night after more than forty years of service to the South Shore districts and was replaced by regular units from the City Fire Department.
