The Dionne quintuplets, by their antics at play, reduced two hundred scientists and educators to a state of doting affection today.

Anthony J. Billingham, a correspondent of TEE NEW YORK TIMES in China who was wounded Aug. 23 in Shanghai when an aerial bomb hit a department store, said yesterday on his return to New York for treatment of his injuries that the end of the undeclared ChineseJapanese war was not in sight.

Joseph Stalin has stepped personally into the present Soviet economic situation in a frank effort to restore morale in the coal and steel industries, the failure of which to fulfill their plans disarranges the production schedules of nearly every other industry.

Round table luncheon of the Smith College Club, 34 East Fiftieth Street, 12:30 P. M. "Can Japan Dominate the Pacific?" Nathaniel Peffer. Rally of the lawyers' division of the Nonpartisan Committee for the Reelection of City Court Justices Vincent S. Lippe, Henry S. Schimmel, Frank A. Carlin at the Transportation Building, 225 Broadway, 2 P. M.

Elizabeth St, 119-21, 50x94; Abbot Low Moffat to Emigrant Bank, consideration $3,000, foreclosure. 35th St, 113 E, 12.6x98.9: William T. Crocker. to Eleanor Farrington Crocker, his wife, 113 E 35th St; mtg $10,000 ($12). 68th St, 111 W. 20.6x100.5: Jack Lavinstein to Ralph Edwards Co, Inc. 152 W 42d St; mtg $24,000 (deed dated last Dec. 11). Amsterdam Av, 52, 25x100; Joyce Bushel to Central Savings Bank, consideration $1,000, foreclosure.

During the last two years the WPA Federal Art Project in this area has produced 6,271 easel paintings, 160 murals, 1,179 examples of graphic arts, and accomplished much else in the art field, according to a report for the period by Mrs. Audrey McMahon, assistant to the national director and director of the project in the New York region.

A 20-yard field goal by Jack Manders, the place-kicking automaton of the Chicago Bears, nullified a magnificent 42-yard shot by Ward Cuff as the New York Giants and the unbeaten Midwesterners battled yesterday to a 3-3 tie over the scarred Polo Grounds turf.

Dr. Bernard Sachs, the eminent neurologist, lately president of the New York Academy of Medicine, in an artide in Recreation advises that (barring well-known physical limitations) men and women over 50 should "continue doing those things which they have been accustomed to do"-and "add a few trick."
There is at Majorca an Italian and German aviation personnel comprising at least 500 men, including Bruno Mussolini, son of the italian Premier.
The alertness of two former N. Y. U. backs enabled the White Plains Bears to defeat the Mount Vernon Cardinals, 6 to 0, in an American Football Association contest at Memorial Stadium today.

The first financial report of the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund of Barnard College shows that out of a total of $226,500 in gifts, $82,500 was contributed by 1,180 women, $34,000 by 124 men and $100,000 by one foundation.
The Rev. Dr. Melancthon Jacobus, dean emeritus and actingpresident of the Hartford Theological Seminary, died tonight at his home here after a short illness. His age was 81.
Professor Arthur Lehman Goodhart, formerly of. Yale University, has just been elected Chairman of the Law Faculty of Oxford University, it was announced today.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, last night charged two unions had forced attendance at labor rallies for Mayor La Guardia by threatening a fine of $1 for all members who failed to appear. Mr. Mahoney made the charge at rallies in Brooklyn.
Official and private opinion on world business conditions continue to hold to the conviction that no major depression is impending.

The suspension by speculators of their operas tions in stocks on Wednesday was only an overt indication of the new crisis over Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, and even at the end of the week the whole affair remains unknown to the mass of the public.

Accused of killing her husband, a policeman, after what detectives called a quarrel over his failure to put the family automobile in the garage, Mrs. Patricia Ryan, 20 years old, mother of two children, was held without bail yesterday in Bronx Homicide Court.

Survival after death was discussed by two members of the Episcopal clergy in their sermons yesterday morning. The Rev. Dr. Roelif' H. Brooks, rector of St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, suggested that the Christian church had too little stressed the theme of joy and faith in the life after death.

New diplomatic manoeuvres loomed tonight in both the Anglo-French and the Italo-German camps at the start of another week of the unending "quarrel without a crisis" in the Spanish Non-Intervention Committee.

Imports of gold received at New York in October amounted to $39,598,700, the smallest amount for any month since July, 1936, when only $8,799,100 came in. The total compared with $67,237,300 received in September and $182,284,800 in October, 1936.

The army is preparing to create a recruiting agency which could be relied upon, in the event of war, to enlist at least 500,000 volunteers during the first sixty days of hostilities. The agency is intended to supply man power for the swift expansion of military units to combat strength while the contemplated universal draft is being put into operation.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the editorial "The Rate Increase" you state: "The assertion of these principles by a government commission will not be merely welcomed by the railroad owners; it must help to restore the confidence of the entire business community."

The Labor Department has disclosed that building activity in September was below the level of the previous month, but slightly higher than in the corresponding month of last year. The report was based upon figures received from 1,521 cities with population in excess of 2,500.
With tentative settlements reported already made with many independent dealers, the dairy farmers' union concentrated its milk strike efforts against the larger operators today.

An electric utility construction "deficit" of $2,600,000,000 accumulated in the last five years was blamed today by the Committee of Utility Executives on the Administration's "fixed punitive policy toward the industry," which the statement said "has so frightened capital that it has proved impossible to finance most of the needed construction."
Fordham University will open today a new placement bureau to "manufacture and service" trained personnel for industry and the professions.

An outbreak which police insisted had no link to labor difficulties but was due to personal ill-feeling caused injuries to three longshoremen'at about 8 A. M. yesterday at the foot of West Thirty-fourth Street. One man is expected to die.

Stocks rallied sharply and closed higher on the week for the first time since the end of September; turnover, 11,190,090 shares. United States Government and other bonds higher; transactions, $49,016,175.

Lard futures declined last week to new low levels for the season on the Board of Trade here, largely in sympathy with the general trend in commodities and securities. Fairly general liquidation was under way, but there was some recovery from the low point, due to the relative strength in cottonseed oil.
The Green Bay Packers remained in the fight for the Western division title in the National Football League by nosing out the Detroit Lions, 14 to 13, before a crowd of 25,000 today.
The marriage on Oct. 23 at Santa Barbara of Mrs. Gertrude Young and Eric Lindquist, both well known in Southern California society, was revealed here today.

The results achieved by foreign missions were lauded by Presbyterian pastors, whose sermons yesterday morning were in part inspired by the celebration during the past week of the centennial of Presbyterian foreign missions.

The church that is to win America to Jesus Christ must be a bigger and better church than any of the existing churches, the Rev. Dr. William Adams Brown, professor emeritus of the Union Theological Seminary, declared at yesterday morning's services in the James Memorial Chapel of the seminary, Claremont Avenue between 120th and 122d Streets.
Turned down finally and decisively by the California Supreme Court, Thomas J. Mooney conferred today in San Quentin prison with his attorney on an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.
The Swiss Government inaugurated a "scientific fortress" today atop the world-famed Jungfrau, Europe's highest Weather Bureau. The Jungfrau rises 13,672 feet above sea level.

Sailing dinghy racing of the Winter season was started today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, but started was just about all. A wind, that puffed up at times to over thirty miles an hour and shook across the top of the compass for six points, swept the harbor.

An "overwhelming victory" for Mayor La Guardia, Thomas Dewey, Stanley Isaacs and Joseph Clark Baldwin in next Tuesday's election in New York City was predicted by Representative Hamilton Fish in a statement issued today. He also defended Mayor La Guardia against charges of communistic sympathies.

Adherence to the Socialist party soon will cease to be a hindrance to appointment to certain government posts. Under existing regulations the government is authorized to dismiss civil servants and officers belonging to organizations that can be considered hostile to the present administration.

Mrs. Peggy Chandler of Dallas, Texas, former champion and current favorite, led the way into the semifinals of the women's division of the Mexican amateur golf tournament today with a 6 and 5 secondround victory over Mrs. R. E. Winger of Dallas.

The Bay Parkways conquered the Rutherford (N. J.) Packers, 9--, before a crowd of 4,500 at Erasmus Field in Brooklyn yesterday. Dick Russo kicked a 30-yard field goal in the second quarter and Charley Siegel went off tackle from the 5-yard line for a touchdown in the third period.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in October was the second largest for a month this year and was the most active for an October since 1930. The heaviest day's trading since July 21, 1933, occurred on Tuesday, Oct. 19,
Judge Francis Joseph Heney died here late today at his home after an illness of several weeks. He was 78 years old.

The engagement of Miss Catherine I. McKay, daughter of Mrs. John V. McKay of this place and the late Mr. McKay, to Douglas Johnston Miller Jr., son of Village Trustee Miller and Mrs. Miller, has been announced by her mother.

In his recent budget message the President estimated that the deficit in the current fiscal year would come to $695,000,000; but he pointed out that, instead of being financed by the banks it would be financed by $1,075,000,000 of special Government bonds sold to the Government's own Old-Age Reserve Account and its Unemployment Trust Fund, while the debt in the hands of the public, he estimated, would be reduced by. $380,000,000.

Francisco Galan, one of three famous brothers of revolutionary Spain, who with Colonel Prada was leading the .Asturian miners in a desperate but unsuccessful resistance, managed to escape to Loyalist Spain, it was learned today.
The DeBasil Ballet Russe closed its engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House with two performances yesterday before crowded houses.
Dr. Lamar Voorhees, a practicing physician of this town, died suddenly tonight in his home at the age of 48. He was discovered by his wife, lying in the bedroom of his young son.

Discussing reports of opposition from the United States Army and Navy to the approval of a new treaty with Panama, already approved by the National Assembly here, the Panama American takes issue with the Estrella de Panama.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 88.1, which compares with 89.3 a week ago, 89.5 two weeks ago, 89.8 three weeks ago and 90.7 four weeks ago.

Thomas E. Ray, district manager here for Swift Co. since 1931, will retire today after thirty-six years of service. He will be succeeded by C. E. Mitchell, district manager of the New England territory since 1932.

The prize winners in the international essay competition sponsored by the New History Society were announced last night at a meeting at the Caravan Hall, 110 East Fiftyninth Street. Mirza Ahmad Sohrab, director of the society, said that 3,208 persons had submitted essays on the topic, "How Can the People of the World Achieve Universal Disarmament?"

One more effort to get Japan to join the Nine-Power Conference probably will be made within a few days after the conference convenes Wednesday, it was indicated tonight as Belgian officials continued to work on the conference agenda.

Too much money has glutted the coffers and grayed the hair of borough officials. So fast is the unwanted cash pouring in that a plagued Mayor and council acted today to stem the flood of tax payments.

Under the influence of continued rumors abroad about an impending further advance in the price of gold here, foreign exchanges were strong yesterday in terms of the dollar and the London gold price went to a premium of more than 9 cents an ounce over the New York shipping parity.
Cuba's sixteenth Congress opened its fourth session today as lawmakers resumed work after a recess of six weeks.

CARPLES, EUGENE (Oct. 22). Estate, more than $10,000. To Carrie C. Jefferds, 158 Merriman St., Rochester, $2,500; Slema Carples, sister, 243 West End Ave., life estate in residue; Arthur L. Carples, brother, 300 W. 108th St., $2,000. Charles Carples, nephew, Janet Carples, niece, 135 North Tremont St., Hartford, Conn., $1,000 and remainders in residue. Corn Exchange Bank Trust Co., 13 William St., executor.

Captain William T. Davidson, who retired a year ago after fifty years at sea, died last night at his home here after an illness of a week. He was 69 years old. Captain Davidson, who had been melancholy since his retirement, suffered a heart attack in Philadelphia to which he succumbed.

The Philippine Commonwealth may spend 25,000,000 pesos ($12,500,000) for military purposes next year. Official copies of the detailed budget were delayed two days by the printers, but authoritative sources disclosed an increase in the military outlay.

Miss Louise Branch, chairman of the executive board of Dance International 1900-37, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for members of the committee and others interested in the exhibition to be opened at the center on Nov. 29.

Lady Wright of Durley House, Burbage, Wiltshire, England, accompanied by Miss Kathleen Maynard of Birmingham, arrived on the Queen Mary and is at the Weylin. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mitchell have left their place in Southampton and are at 1 Sutton Place South for the season.

The story of how a 12-year-old boy's illness, necessitating an expensive operation, finally persuaded eight Tennessee war veterans to unseal their lips and give for the first time an authentic account of their attempt to kidnap the Kaiser, was told here yesterday by T. H. Alexander, twenty-five years a reporter and columnist on The Nashville Tennesseean.

A Chinese spokesman declared today that Chinese units had driven Japanese forces back south of Soochow Creek despite a relentless Japanese artillery and aerial bombardment in an attempt to encircle Shanghai.

Despite threats of boycott, trains of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were filled to capacity today by commuters who were "abandoned" through discontinuance last midnight of service on the New Rochelle-Port Chester division of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad. Extra cars failed to provide seats for all passengers.

Cecil L. Bartholomew and his wife, Lillian, lost their fight today to regain custody of their son, Freddie, child screen star, after he had denied he loved them. Counsel for Miss Myllicent Bartholomew, the aunt who adopted the boy, asked if he was happy with her.

State Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, campaign manager for Senator Lester H. Clee, Republican candidate for Governor, withdrew tonight a request for an escort of State troopers tomorrow when he and several other Senators plan to tour Hudson County polling places to seek evidence of illegal voting.

Spanish Insurgent military dispatches from Salamanca said today the Government was concentrating troops and equipment in the Madrid sector for a general offensive to break the year-old siege of the city.
